https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/14/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Housing Crisis Is Worsening
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/14/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Housing Crisis Is Worsening
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/14/busin.body_text: **********, low- and moderate-income people seeking to rent or purchase shelter will find a housing industry in crisis and unable to meet their needs. **********The problems of the housing industry that result from high inflation, and even higher interest rates, are intensified by a generally unacknowledged but widely held attitude that capital going into housing could be put to better use. A joke by a former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development that the housing industry was invented to take crap shooting out of the streets and back alleys reflects the uncertainties of the industry. **********Recent predictions that annual housing starts will soon fall below one million units indicate that production of housing is being reduced even though need for shelter has not been met for many people. Most families are unable to afford new housing if they are first-time buyers, or to find rental housing. At the same time, interest rates and falling prices of existing housing have reduced the profitable liquidity of the family residence on which many have relied for the last few years. **********Little low- and moderate- or middle-income rental housing has been built in recent years without Federal assistance, and high costs and budget cuts have reduced the number of units being built with Federal funds. Although public housing for low- and moderate-income people continues to be built, there is also continuing abandonment of large numbers of low-income units in urban areas. **********Thus the middle class and the poor cannot find suitable housing because of the high cost of home ownership and rentals and because of a shortage of units. **********Despite growing shelter problems for the middle class and the poor and depression in the housing industry, the Federal response continues to be ad hoc, with no determination of a basic policy for meeting the needs of the 80's. Stated national policy is still limited to that of the basic housing statutes that articulate the right of every American to ''decent, safe and sanitary housing.'' On that fragile policy base, various housing programs, some as old as public housing and the Federal Housing Administration, and some as new as Section VIII rental assistance, have been authorized and reauthorized. **********In 1977, the Carter Administration enunciated a policy that the Federal Government would use Federal housing programs to promote stability in the housing industry. But that policy died at the next budget cycle when it became clear that the cost of assisted housing at stable unit levels would result in budget figures unacceptable to the President. For the rest of the Carter Administration, as with those before and after, housing policy had to be sought in budget and administrative decisions made for the myriad housing programs. **********Even an early effort by H.U.D. in the Carter years to codify the rambling and often contradictory housing statutes of the department was defeated by the absence of an executive and legislative consensus on the validity of existing programs. And for four straight years Congress voted less money for authorized Federal housing programs than was requested in the Carter budgets (and housing was one of the few areas in which Congress reduced President Reagan's budget). **********Such absence of consensus about national housing programs and policy is not new.  Federal housing programs, like Topsy, just grew, largely as a result of bad compromises of good program proposals or of brainstorms or idiosyncrasies of individual legislators or civil servants. **********A few weeks ago, another Federal commission was established to advise the President on national housing policy. It will join similar groups of the last decade in succumbing to pressures of budget cycles and problems of runaway costs of existing programs in deciding on its recommendations. **********Therefore, in addition to such a Presidential commission, there is need for a disinterested institution, such as a foundation, to conduct an intensive and extensive study of the present housing scene; its relationship to a troubled economy; the proper role of the Federal Government in providing housing, with particular attention to fiscal policy; the responsibilities of different levels of government, and the role of the private sector. **********That housing programs of the past have worked is proved by the housing programs for the elderly and the venerable F.H.A., but there is room for imagination and development of new approaches. **********There must be enunciation of a reasonable and comprehensive national housing policy before the shortage of housing in the United States spawns squatter movements such as those in Europe. We are not at that point (except, perhaps, for Philadelphia), but there are indications that we could reach it. We have the time and resources to develop a national housing policy not tied solely to budget issues. **********If we develop such a policy, we could be certain of finding ways to insure decent shelter for our citizens into the 21st century, and at the same time we would end the dice game that the housing industry has become. ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Leonard Silk is on vacation. Patricia R. Harris served as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and then as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare during the Carter Administration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/23/busin.body_text: **********The national debt passed the $1 trillion mark today, Treasury Department officials confirmed, but the acknowledgement came with little fanfare. ''It's not an issue for celebration,'' a spokesman said. **********Details on the exact debt total reached today will not be known for a day or so. It had stood at $999.39 billion on Tuesday, the latest day for which an exact figure was available. **********By one measure of what a $1 trillion figure means, it is about $4,700 for every American man, woman and child. By another, if someone were to count it out, a dollar every second, he would be 31,668 years old by the time he finished. **********The debt reached $1 billion in 1916 during World War I and climbed to $278 billion at the end of World War II.  Interest payments on the debt should approach $100 billion for the year beginning Oct. 1, the third-highest category in the Federal budget, after the Departments of Health and Human Services and of Defense.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/world.main_headline: URUGUAY HITS SNAGS IN PLANNING 1984 ELECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/world.print_headline: URUGUAY HITS SNAGS IN PLANNING 1984 ELECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/world.body_text: **********Early problems have arisen in Uruguay's effort to restore representative government, with military leaders and politicians accusing each other of obstructing discussions. **********Gen. Gregorio Alvarez, the former army commander who took over the presidency on Sept. 1, was appointed by the country's leading officers to try to arrange free and open general elections before his term expires in March 1985. **********Consultations began immediately with the country's two traditional political groups, the Colorado and Blanco Parties, on setting up talks to restore political freedoms suspended when the military took over in 1973. **********The talks have stalled, with politicians saying that the military has not clearly defined its program and the military countering that disagreements in the parties have prevented them from agreeing on representatives for the discussions. **********Government sources concede that details of the program have not been published but say these can emerge only after discussions with the parties. They say the basic intention of the talks is to elaborate a party statute that will define the rules for political activity, draw up a new constitutuion to be approved in a national referendum and hold general elections at the end of 1984. The Military Proposal **********Politicians said the military proposed that a commission formed by three high-ranking military officers and six members from each of the parties be established to draw up the party statute. They said the military stipulated that the representatives in clude three members from each party who supported Governm ent-proposed constitutional changes that were defeated in a referendum last November. **********The Government's surprise defeat in the vote on the new constitution, which would have given the military a permanent place in government, precipitated the move toward elections. **********The Colorado Party immediately proposed six names, but the Blanco Party sought further clarification from the military on whether certain names would be acceptable, politicians said. There has been no reply. **********President Alvarez, noted for his planning ability and his independence from any power group, has been maneuvering quietly to build support in the army, according to politicians. **********''Many Uruguayans feel that General Alvarez would like to stand as a candidate in the 1984 elections and that he will not tackle the political situation until he has solved the country's economic problems and made sure of military support,'' one political source said. Parties Are Suspicious **********The traditional parties are suspicious of military intentions, and politicians say the climate of repression has hardened since General Alvarez's takeover. They say politicians are being harassed and cite the closure of the Blanco Party's weekly magazine, Democracia, as a bad omen. The Government last month ordered the magazine to suspend publication for four weeks, saying it had incited disturbances and printed state ments by proscribed politicians. **********One obstacle in negotiations could be the military's insistence that the National Security Council, comprising the President, commanders of the three armed forces and the Ministers of the Interior, Defense and Foreign Affairs, be given sufficient powers to safeguard national security. **********The Government recently lifted a ban that had kept several hundred thousand people from voting, holding Government office or engaging in political activity. Among prominent politicians still proscribed are Jorge Batlle Ibanez, who could emerge as the Colorado leader, all members of the leftist Broad Front Movement, which is considered the third political force in the county, and several leaders of the Blanco Party. **********There is little difference between the two traditional parties and both have moderate leftist and rightist factions. Neither party has ever won free elections by more than a narrow majority, and when in power they have had to have the backing of the Broad Front Movement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/09/busin.body_text: **********From across the Atlantic comes news that Wilkens, the largest independent agency in West Germany, and Eurocom, the largest agency holding company in France, have joined forces to form a European agency network through a financial holding company called Satel G.m.b.H. in Hamburg, Germany. **********Wilkens will control 60 percent and Eurcom 40 percent. **********While the holding company holds shares of these agencies as capital, they will continue to operate independently, even in competition. **********One of the next steps will be to develop Satel agencies in the United States and Asia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/27/world.body_text: **********The federal Government today rejected an attempt by predominantly French-speaking Quebec to veto a proposed new constitution, raising the prospect of a new court battle over the plan, which has the support of Canada's nine predominantly Englishspeaking provinces. **********Quebec's Premier, Rene Levesque, announced last night that his cabinet had approved a decree vetoing a constitutional accord reached three weeks ago but rejected by Quebec as a threat to its legal prerogatives. He sent Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau a letter asking him to hold up action on the constitution resolution in the House of Commons as long as Quebec opposed it. **********In response to the legal manuever by Quebec, Mr. Trudeau sought to bring the resolution to a final vote tonight or tomorrow. But the two opposition groups in the House, the Progressive Conservatives and the New Democrats, sought to delay the vote to allow time for changes to appease Quebec, the only holdout, as well as for other changes. **********Quebec's action is based on the contention that the Canadian federation represents a pact between two founding peoples, the French and the English, and needs the consent of both for change. Last September the Supreme Court held that any federal action for a new constitution required provincial consensus but not necessarily unanimity. Quebec is expected to ask the court to rule that there can be no consensus that leaves out one of the founding peoples. **********The resolution opposed by Quebec will ask Britain to transform the British North America Act of 1867 into a purely Canadian constitution with the addition of a bill of rights and an amending procedure. The bill of rights contains guarantees to the English-speaking minority in Quebec and the French-speaking minority elsewhere of education in their own language, and one of Quebec's objections concerns the restrictions this would place on its legislative powers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/busin.main_headline: KEY ZAPATA STRATEGY: SHIFTING OF ASSETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/busin.print_headline: KEY ZAPATA STRATEGY: SHIFTING OF ASSETS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/busin.body_text: **********Back in 1952 George Bush, now Vice President of the United States, and J. Hugh Liedtke, now chairman of the Pennzoil Company, were sitting around their offices in the west Texas oil town of Midland, wondering what to name their fledgling drilling business. **********They wanted something that would attract attention, something exotic, something that began with A or Z so it would be easy to find in the phone book. Marlon Brando and Anthony Quinn had just made a hit movie called ''Viva Zapata!'' **********So Zapata it became, and the company has been attracting attention ever since. By 1966, when both Mr. Bush and Mr. Liedtke had sold their interests, the Zapata Corporation had become one of the world's biggest offshore drilling contractors. **********Last month the Occidental Petroleum Corporation offered to buy Zapata for $745 million in stock, but this time the company did not change hands. Armand Hammer, Occidental's chairman, withdrew the bid after Zapata rejected it as ''grossly inadequate.'' Strong Defensive Position **********Dr. Hammer said he had no intention of attempting a hostile takeover. One reason, analysts suggest, may have been that Zapata, profitable and in a position to line up sizable credit lines, is well equipped to put up a vigorous fight. **********That has not always been the case. In the years after the company's founders left, Zapata enthusiastically branched out into shipping, construction, dredging and mining. By the late 1970's, it found itself saddled with a string of weak operations, return on investment as low as 1 percent and a debt that had soared to $652 million, almost three times the value of the company's equity. **********Zapata's turnaround began in 1979, following the forced departure of its chairman, William H. Flynn. The new chairman, B. John Mackin, set out to return the company to its base in the oil business by getting rid of unrelated operations. **********The ''touchstone of our strategy,'' Mr. Mackin said the other day as the morning sun shone through the slanting glass windows of his office atop Pennzoil Place in downtown Houston, is simply to ''redeploy our assets to more profitable areas.'' Phase One: Divestitures **********The divestitures, described by Mr. Mackin as phase one of the company's restructuring, have included the sale of Zapata's tuna fishing business for $12 million and four oil tankers for $90 million. **********The company has also signed a letter of intent to sell its coal holdings in Pennsylvania and eastern Kentucky to subsidiaries of W.R. Grace & Company, the Hanna Mining Company and an affiliate of the Liberty Capital Group. The proposed purchase price has not been disclosed, but figures of more than $100 million have been mentioned. **********Phase two, Mr. Mackin said, will be the acquisition of new businesses to reduce the cyclical nature of Zapata's earnings. His immediate concern is that the current brisk pace of oil rig construction will mean an oversupply of rigs that will lead to a slump in the drilling business by the end of next year. **********''We haven't gotten to the point of determining what we're interested in and where we're going to go to find it,'' Mr. Mackin said. A management team is now working to set new objectives. Careful Choices Stressed **********The resulting strategy, Mr. Mackin conceded, may look like a move down the same diversification path that got the company into trouble during the late 1960's and early 1970's. But he argues that the problem then was not expansion into new businesses but the nature of the businesses selected. **********''I don't think there's anything we've done that could be used as a basis for the contention that conglomeration is bad,'' the Zapata chairman said. ''We're talking about a particular mix.'' **********For now, four activities, all related to oil and natural gas, are the core of Zapata's operations. These activities are offshore drilling, marine support services for offshore drilling, dredging and, finally, oil and gas exploration and production. Only two activities unrelated to energy remain: a fish-processing operation on the Gulf and Pacific coasts and a herring and sardine cannery in Maine that is up for sale. **********With its divestiture program nearly complete, the company's debt has been reduced to about $400 million while the value of its equity has increased to almost the same figure. With 19 mobile rigs scattered around the world, Zapata is the fifth-largest offshore drilling contractor in the world. Its large-vessel marine supply fleet ranks as No.4. Progress in New Sector **********The company has only recently moved into exploration and production. ''We're not a factor in that business yet,'' Mr. Mackin said, ''but we're quite satisfied with our progress in that direction.'' **********The corporate restructuring and the biggest oil-drilling boom in American history have had a dramatic impact on Zapata's bottom line.  The company's net income in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1980, was $43.6 million, or $2.19 a share, up 103 percent from a year earlier.  That gain came on a 21 percent increase in revenues, to a total of $637 million. The return on equity rose to 18 percent after having averaged 7.6 percent for the previous five years. **********Results for the fiscal year 1981, which ended two weeks ago, will not be announced until next month, but Mr. Mackin said the report could be expected to show another ''significant'' gain. **********''We're reaching the point in the evolution of our operation where we have our immediate objectives almost behind us,'' Mr. Mackin said. ''I think we have re-established credibility in the marketplace.'' Praise From Analysts **********Others agree. ''They've gotten their finances into shape, and they have good management,'' said one Wall Street analyst who asked not to be identified. **********George Faspar, an analyst who follows Zapata for Robert W. Baird & Company of Milwaukee, recently reported that Zapata had made ''extraordinary progress,'' that it was ''well positioned to see offshore and rig marine service revenues advance dramatically in the next two years'' and that its earnings momentum should continue in the fiscal year 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/06/world.main_headline: Yugoslav Province Chief Quits Over Ethnic Riots
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/06/world.print_headline: Yugoslav Province Chief Quits Over Ethnic Riots
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/06/world.body_text: **********Mahmut Bakali, the Communist Party leader in riot-troubled Kosovo Province, resigned today after a report accused the province's leaders of responsibility for separatist riots last month by ethnic Albanians. **********The Yugoslav press agency, Tanyug, said Mr. Bakali submitted his resignation during a session of the provincial party committee in Pristina, the capital. **********About 77 percent of the 1.6 million people are ethnic Albanians. **********A 70-page official report on the rioting, which began March 11 and ended April 3, leaving nine dead and 200 injured, charged that ''a hostile group'' was plotting to induce Kosovo to break away from Yugoslavia and merge with neighboring Albania. **********Ali Sukrija, a member of the Kosovo party's 19-member Presidium, told the session that ''hostile activity,'' such as distributing leaflets and attempts to stage new demonstrations, was still under way. **********He said that security organs had uncovered ''domestic enemies'' who were linked with emigre Albanian groups, supported by ''various foreign intelligence services.'' **********''Their aim is the overthrowing of Socialist Yugoslavia, secession of Kosovo and other parts of Yugoslavia where Albanians live and their attachment to Albania,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/14/busin.main_headline: U.S. CALLS STEEL EXPORTS BY FIVE NATIONS 'UNFAIR'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/14/busin.print_headline: U.S. CALLS STEEL EXPORTS BY FIVE NATIONS 'UNFAIR'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/14/busin.body_text: **********The Commerce Department today accused France, Belgium, South Africa, Rumania and Brazil of ''unfair competition'' in selling steel in the United States and filed complaints that could lead to sharply higher tariffs on steel imported from those countries. **********The accusation was the opening shot of what could be a major new trade conflict. European Common Market officials have said the United States is engaged on a ''dangerous course'' that could lead to European retaliation against imports of American food, machinery and other products. **********(In a meeting with United States officials in Geneva today, delegates from the Common Market rejected the allegations of dumping, according to a Reuters report.) Products Involved **********In announcing the action, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said the products named in the complaints were ''so important as to put world producers on notice that the United States is serious about enforcing its trade laws.'' **********The products are carbon steel plate, used in bridges and heavy machinery, and hot rolled sheet, used in cars, which altogether account for about 25 percent of domestic steel output. **********Today's action represented the first time that the United States Government had initiated a trade case to enforce internationally agreed upon prohibitions against exporting at ''unfairly'' low prices. **********The two-year-old prohibitions relate to ''dumping,'' or the sale of steel in foreign markets below the cost of production, and to the subsidizing of exports through low-cost credits, tax remissions and other aids from government treasuries. **********In the past, steel companies in the United States have had to bring such cases themselves and take their chances that Government adjudicatory bodies would agree, and then provide relief in the form of higher duties. These countervailing levies make domestically produced steel more competitive. The change authorizing the Government to initiate cases was written into the 1979 Trade Act. **********Mr. Baldrige said on Nov. 5 that the Government was preparing the actions, but that no action would be taken until the foreign governments were informed. The United States officially informed the Europeans of the action earlier today in Geneva. **********At a meeting of New York security analysts last Monday, David M.  Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, announced that his company intended to go ahead with its own complaints. Lionel H. Ulmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for international trade administration, said today that, if the industry went ahead with its complaints, ''then that means the end'' of the trigger price mechanism. **********The mechanism was introduced in 1978 as a means of controlling imports of unfairly priced steel. But a sharp growth in imports this year has led to industry complaints that the mechanism was not working well. **********Importers say the reason for the growth has been the sharply higher value of the dollar, which has made foreign steel more competitive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/13/busin.main_headline: STOCK BUYBACK SEEN AT LANE BRYANT INC.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; STOCK BUYBACK SEEN AT LANE BRYANT INC.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/13/busin.body_text: **********Lane Bryant Inc., which has been threatened by a Canadian takeover for more than a year, is close to removing the threat by buying back almost 20 percent of its stock from the companies that had sought to acquire it, sources said yesterday. . **********On Tuesday, sources said, Lane Bryant obtained a $21 million bank loan to purchase about 900,000 of its shares from the Hatleigh Corporation, Toronto, and Mico Enterprises Ltd. of Montreal. The negotiations among the companies, under way for several weeks, are said to be nearly completed. **********The reported price of the shares is estimated by analysts at slightly more than $22 each. Hatleigh, the investment arm of the North Canadian Oils Corporation, and Mico, a unit of Edper Equities, which is owned by the Bronfman interests in Canada, bought the shares at about $18 each. As of Jan. 1, Hatleigh owned 697,300 shares of Lane Bryant and Mico owned about 206,300 shares. **********Lane Bryant, the nation's largest retailer of extra-size and maternity apparel, has 4.5 million common shares outstanding.  Lane Bryant's stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 17 5/8, up 3/8.  Arthur Malsin, chairman of Lane Bryant, declined comment in New York on the reported negotiations, while James F. Kay, chief executive of Hatleigh in Toronto, would not return telephone calls. **********Last March, Lane Bryant sued Mr. Kay, Hatleigh, North Canadian Oils, Raphael Malsin, a former Lane chariman, and his wife, Elaine, in Federal District Court, charging that they had engaged in a conspiracy to acquire control of the company. The litigation is still pending.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/27/world.main_headline: MITTERRAND PLANS TO ASSURE ARABS FRANCE WILL CONTINUE ARMS SALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/27/world.print_headline: MITTERRAND PLANS TO ASSURE ARABS FRANCE WILL CONTINUE ARMS SALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/27/world.body_text: **********President Francois Mitterrand plans to send special envoys to Arab countries to assure them about France's Middle East policy, Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson said today. **********He said the Socialist leaders also planned to honor existing arms sales and other export contracts, although they would not sell additional arms to countries deemed to be ''fascist or racist.'' **********The Foreign Minister made clear in a radio interview that these decisions were intended to keep Mr. Mitterrand's generally pro-Israeli stance, in contrast to former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing's pro-Arab leanings, from harming the arms-for-oil trade with the Arabs. **********''No doubt, foreigners have a vested interest in saying that our contracts will not be respected, thus inciting the Arabs to buy elsewhere,'' Mr. Cheysson said. ''But the Arabs will not be fooled.  They have just signed a major contract with Aerospatiale for the launching of telecommunications satellites.'' **********The $135 million contract was signed yesterday in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, between the French aerospace concern and the Arab Telecommunications Satellite Organization. **********Mr. Cheysson said an effort had already been made to assure King Khalid of Saudi Arabia through a message delivered by the President's brother, Gen. Jacques Mitterrand, who heads Aeros@patiale. **********The Foreign Minister's remarks, a day after President Mitterrand announced that he would visit Israel, were apparently designed to show that the Socialists would not interfere with the lucrative arms contracts they criticized before coming to power. **********These include plans by Avions Marcel Dassault to sell 60 Mirage F-1 fighter bombers to Iraq; a $3 billion contract to build up Saudi Arabia's Navy; orders for missile-carrying patrol boats from Iran, Libya and Argentina as well as other orders for tanks, guns and missiles from the Middle East and Latin America. **********France has not sold arms to Israel since General de Gaulle's day, and the Israelis are no longer thought to be interested in buying from a country that has shown itself an unreliable supplier. **********Arms exports are a major prop for the economy, helping pay for increasingly expensive imports of oil and other raw materials and employing 250,000 people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; STOCKS THAT DON'T PAY DIVIDENDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/busin.body_text: **********T OM BROWN INC., an oil drilling and exploration company, won top honors last year in the portfolio of the Rowe Price New Horizons Fund, a mutual fund that invests in small growth companies. It soared 338 percent in price. The fund's other leading performers, climbing anywhere from 216 percent to 181 percent, were Tandy Corporation, Cray Research, Quotron Systems and Avantek Inc. **********None pays a cash dividend.  The worst performer for New Horizons in 1980 was Four-Phase Systems, a maker of distributed data processing systems, whose stock sank 43 percent in response to a sharp decline in profits. In January, three of the four biggest percentage losers on the New York Stock Exchange were Advanced Micro-Devices, Spectra Physics and Cray Research, with losses ranging between 31 percent and 26 percent. **********None of them pays a cash dividend, either. (The fourth big loser on the Big Board in January was the GCA Corporation, which pays only a token cash dividend.) **********Whatever happened to the orthodox market theory that earnings, and the dividends that derive from them, are basic determinants for investing? And who are these companies - not the staggering Chryslers forced into cutting dividends, but those preferring not to reward shareholders with quarterly distributions of cash? **********As a rule, the companies are young and small, and are involved in some form of high technology or energy, the two hottest sectors of the market in the last several years. What they offer investors is the chance - although not always the reality -of huge capital gains, in terms of both higher stock prices and, often, stock dividends. **********''We don't go looking for nondividend-paying companies at New Horizons,'' explains Carter O. Hoffman, chairman of the investment policy committee that advises the Rowe Price funds. ''But in most cases, these companies are growing so fast that they need to retain 100 percent of their earnings. In the early stage of such a company's life cycle, it's best to plow back profits.'' **********The concept, then, is to sacrifice the regular quarterly cash payment on the altar of more, and higher-priced stock.  ''A stock that pays stock dividends and no cash dividends usually denotes a faster-growing company,'' said Peter Schaeffer, a broker with Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. **********''I tell people to forget about yield if they are looking for capital appreciation,'' added Samuel Braude, a research vice president at Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden. ''If they're looking for yield, they should forget about growth and stick to money market funds, bonds or some other fixed-income instrument.'' **********Mr. Braude is something of a disciple for the nondividend-paying stock. He monitors a list of 30 smallish over-the-counter issues and, during 1979 and 1980, 16 of them more than doubled in price. Fourteen of them, bearing such esoteric names as Computer Consoles Inc., DigiLog Systems Inc., Kratos Inc. and the Sigmaform Corporation, have yet to declare their first cash dividend. **********The risks in these young, unproven companies are, of course, high.  Prime Computer, for example, dropped 6 7/8 last week just on word that its profits were under pressure. And if the market generally runs into an air pocket in 1981, utilities and other stocks paying hefty cash dividends may take on added allure. **********Still, nondividend-payers have become the Big Board's star performers in recent years. Shares of Hecla Mining - dividends halted in 1970, with only a small payout starting in October 1980 - soared nearly 800 percent in 1979. In 1980, Prime Computer grabbed the brass ring with a 272 percent price gain. **********''My sophisticated customers never ask me if a stock pays a cash dividend,'' says Mr. Schaeffer of Bache. ''They'd much rather have stock dividends than cash dividends.'' **********Some of the market's best performing companies, in fact, have been generous with stock splits or stock dividends without paying out a penny to shareowners. **********Teledyne, a conglomerate that has paid stock dividends annually since 1967, recently declared a 3-for-2 stock distribution.  Management consistently has held to the principle of putting money to work internally and in acquisitions, rather than doling out cash dividends. Meanwhile, between early 1975 and early 1981, the value of its stock multiplied more than 38 times. **********The Intel Corporation, a leader in the manufacture of semiconductors, microprocessors and microcomputers, also has treated its shareholders handsomely by declaring stock dividends rather than cash payments. During the 1970's, its shares rose more than 36 times in value. **********According to Vickers Associates Inc., Intel now ranks as the favorite over-the-counter holding of institutional investors.  Typically, the price of a security rises when a stock dividend or split is announced. On the other side of the coin, the price often falls after the split or dividend takes effect and some holders take profits. **********''Hot new issues,'' Wall Street's designation of sought-after stocks making their initial public offerings, generally pay no cash dividends. In time, however, they often declare stock splits. NBI Inc., which went public in December 1979, is a word-processing systems company that recently announced a 3-for-1 split. **********On the other hand, some analysts contend that when a glamour company consistently raises its cash dividend it betokens a sign of maturity. International Business Machines offers the classic example. In 1967 and 1968, the cash dividend of this kingpin of computer companies produced a yield of less than 1 percent. Currently, the stock yields better than 5 percent. But its dynamic phase of price appreciation occurred when the cash dividend return was minimal. **********Meanwhile, Uncle Sam has contributed to the appeal of nondividendpaying stocks by cutting the capital gains tax payable on large profits on the high-flying stocks. ''The 1978 tax cut bill made profits easier to take,'' states Standard & Poor's. ''The top capital gains rate is now 28 percent; it had been 49.125 percent.'' **********And, notes Mr. Hoffman of Rowe Price, ''there is some hope that the top rate may be reduced to 20 or 21 percent.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/24/world.print_headline: 2 LEADERS OF SPANISH REVOLT; Jaime Milans del Bosch
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/24/world.body_text: **********Lieut. Gen. Jaime Milans del Bosch, who declared a military revolt yesterday in Valencia as supporters seized Parliament in Madrid, is known as a prominent follower of Franco ... 65 years old ... In military since 1934, two years before Franco uprising ... Critic of Spanish democracy as too weak to contain terrorism ... Passed over after Franco's death in 1975 although in line for promotion to army chief of staff ... Sent to command eastern military region of Valencia ... Rumored to have been involved in 1980 conspiracy to capture Prime Minister and his Cabinet ... Reportedly received telephone call yesterday from leader of attack on Parliament: ''Uneventful, my general, all is in hand.'' Antonio Tejero Molina **********Lieut. Col. Antonio Tejero Molina, the Spanish Civil Guard officer who led the takeover of Parliament yesterday, was making his second attempt since November 1978 to seize power ... Angered by continued terrorism and the granting of autonomy to Spanish regions ... Got no further in first attempt than strategy session with four officers, three of whom reported to authorities his plan to hold Government ministers hostage until King Juan Carlos agreed to name right-wing regime ... Arrested and tried with remaining officer on sedition charges ... Sentenced in May 1980 to prison term but because of arrest was released and returned to duty ... 49 years old and unmarried ... Known as a nationalist who believes post-Franco governments have been too weak ... Has repeatedly proclaimed loyalty to the King but has denounced Parliament, which he faced yesterday with drawn pistol.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/09/busin.body_text: **********The Bankers Trust Company, the nation's eighth-largest bank, lowered its prime lending rate yesterday to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent, where it had stood since May 22. **********The action makes the 20 percent prime universal among the nation's major banks except for the Girard Bank, a leading commercial bank in Philadelphia, which raised its prime rate last Friday from 20 percent to 21 percent. The high so far this year for the prime, 20 1/2 percent, was set on May 22; the year's low was 17 percent, set in late March. A year ago the prime rate was at 12 1/2 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/04/world.main_headline: THAI PREMIER PROMISES LENIENCY FOR REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/04/world.print_headline: THAI PREMIER PROMISES LENIENCY FOR REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/04/world.body_text: **********With a two-day coup attempt crushed, Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda pledged today to give ''a fair judgment'' to the rebels. He called on them and all the Thai people to ''forget what happened'' and to get on with serving the nation. **********The statement was issued from the military base 130 miles to the northeast where the Prime Minister had taken refuge with the royal family when the uprising began early Wednesday. There were no casualties until this morning, when the rebellion collapsed as thousands of troops loyal to the Prime Minister swept into the capital, encountering little resistance. **********Two deaths were reported as a result of an exchange of fire at the royal palace, where, the Government said, rebel soldiers began the incident by shooting at Government troops. Four rebels were wounded, one fatally, and a civilian was reportedly shot to death accidentally. **********Two other rebels were slightly wounded later in the morning as they tried to run a roadblock. Leader May Have Fled to Burma **********The leader of the rebellion, 59-year-old Gen. Sant Chitpatima, was reported by military sources to have fled by helicopter to neighboring Burma. (Diplomatic sources said, according to United Press International, that the general would probably ask Washington for asylum since his wife and one of his sons were believed to be in the United States.) **********The rebel leader's top aides either gave up or were captured, and it was generally expected that they would be treated with leniency in the tradition that has developed in Thailand in the 15 coups since constitutional democracy was established in 1932. There has been no planned violence in a Bangkok revolt since 1951 when a vessel in the harbor was bombed, and the latest uprising was said to have been marked by the greatest use of force since then. **********To many, the outcome of the uprising seemed clear when King Phumiphol Aduldet and Queen Sirikit left the capital with General Prem, who is army commander as well as Prime Minister, and went to the army base at Nakhon Ratchasima. King is Revered by the People **********While the King has little constitutional power, he is revered by the Thai people and his approval is necessary for a Prime Minister.  His approval of General Prem was generally considered clear from his presence with the Prime Minister, and the rebel leader sought unsuccessfully yesterday to gain an audience to plead his case. **********Reports from Nakhon Ratchasima said the two sides began trying to negotiate a settlement soon thereafter to avoid any use of force, but General Sant, the leader of the Revolutionary Council that announced a takeover of power Wednesday morning, was said to have refused to yield. One of the apparent reasons for his revolt was that General Prem had blocked him from being promoted to army commander. **********About 5:30 A.M., General Prem ordered his troops to begin moving.  Some were reportedly flown to Bangkok's civilian airport, which was controlled by loyal air force officers from the adjoining military airfield. King's Bodyguard Moves In **********Meanwhile, the 21st Infantry, known as the King's Bodyguard, moved in from its base 50 miles to the south, and military units that had been in the capital throughout the uprising but had taken no active part were ordered to help. **********Key installations were quickly occupied. A delay of more than an hour, however, developed at army headquarters, where 300 rebel soldiers refused to give up. Finally, with Government soldiers standing and waiting, the rebels emerged to the cheers of thousands of Thais who had gathered to watch, climbed into trucks and returned to their barracks unescorted. ---- 'Special Panel' Will be Set Up **********BANGKOK, Thailand, April 3 (UPI) -Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda said today that there would be no reprisals against rank-and-file rebel troops but that a ''special committee'' would try the officers. **********''We will treat these people as fellow countrymen,'' General Prem said in an interview from his headquarters at Nakhon Ratchasima.  ''Most of them will not receive harsh treatment.'' **********Earlier, as the rebel support was vanishing and General Prem's forces were moving into Bangkok, Gen. Sant Chitpatima was quoted as having said before flying off: **********''Why should we fight each other? Why should we kill each other? We are all Thais together.'' It was generally agreed that if his uprising had succeeded there would have been few policy changes. He was General Prem's closest adviser and shared his strong pro-Western and other views.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/04/busin.body_text: **********The books were closed yesterday on an unusually controversial technology failure when the Reliance Electric Company announced that it was abandoning efforts to develop energy-saving motor controls based on a device invented in 1979 by its parent, the Exxon Corporation. **********In March, Exxon announced that its original design had proven uneconomical and that Reliance was working on an alternative approach. ''The results since then have not been encouraging,'' Reliance said yesterday in its brief announcement of a decision reached last week to terminate the program. **********Exxon had originally described its motor control technology as a conservation breakthrough and had cited it as justification for its $1.2 billion takeover of Reliance. Exxon said that it needed the manufacturing and technological expertise of the Cleveland-based company, one of the nation's largest motor control producers, to quickly bring its technology to market. Takeover Criticized **********Critics of the takeover accused Exxon of exaggerating the value of its invention to justify investing its oil profits outside the energy field. The March announcement was assailed as proof that the arguments for the takeover were a ruse. Exxon responded by saying that the discovery of problems by Reliance employees who took over control of the project confirmed Exxon's belief that it needed outside expertise. **********When it introduced its motor control technology at a New York press conference, Exxon said it could reduce a motor's energy consumption by up to 50 percent. **********However, numerous other companies were already in the market with energy-saving motor controllers. Exxon was never able to match the combination of reliability, low manufacturing costs and simplicity that would allow it to compete with its new design. **********One of the competitors was Reliance's own Electric Drives division, which has been operated separately from the rest of Reliance since the takeover because of a Federal Trade Commission antitrust complaint. ''Business has been very good,'' said Byron Lutman, the division's general manager of field operations and marketing. **********One of the questions left unanswered by yesterday's announcement was whether the complaint would be dropped or modified to allow the drives division to be reintegrated with the rest of Reliance. **********The whole episode was summed up from Wall Street's perspective by one analyst as ''an intriguing aside.'' Exxon earns more each day than it had spent on the device over the past decade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/world.main_headline: POPE TO SEND OUT AIDES IN BID TO END ATOMIC ARMS RACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/world.print_headline: POPE TO SEND OUT AIDES IN BID TO END ATOMIC ARMS RACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II is sending delegations to the United States, the Soviet Union, France, Britain and the United Nations this week to discuss how to end the nuclear arms race, the Vatican announced yesterday in Rome. **********A communique said the delegations, composed mainly of scientists from the Pontifical Academy of Sciences, would outline the ''terrifying prospects'' of the use of nuclear arms, as presented in a study by the academy. **********One delegation is to meet with President Reagan in Washington tomorrow, and another will confer Tuesday in Moscow with Leonid I.  Brezhnev, the Soviet leader. The dates of the meetings in Paris and London and at the United Nations were not immediately known. **********4 Americans to Meet Reagan **********In Washington, David R. Gergen, the White House communications director, said the meeting with Mr. Reagan would take place tomorrow afternoon. **********The Rev. Blase J. Cupich, a spokesman for the Vatican's mission, said the delegation would include Victor F. Weisskopf, a physicist of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; David Baltimore, an M.I.T. molecular biologist; Marshall W. Nirenberg, a biochemist of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., and Dr. Howard H.  Hiatt, dean of the Harvard School of Public Health. With them will be the Papal Nuncio, Archbishop Pio Laghi. **********Father Cupich said the four, except Dr. Hiatt, were members of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences. Dr. Hiatt is an expert on the medical consequences of nuclear war. **********The Pontifical Academy of Sciences is one of several academies advising the Pope in various fields of knowledge. It was established in 1607. **********According a member of the academy who spoke on condition that his name not be used, the Pope asked the nuclear powers to receive his delegates, but China and India refused. The academy member said he had learned that India denied that it was a nuclear power. **********The delegation that is scheduled to meet with Mr. Brezhnev will consist of three academy members - Christian de Duve, a Belgian biochemist; G.B. Marini Bettolo of Italy, a chemist, and Dr. Jerome Lejeune of France, a pediatrician. They will be accompanied by Dr.  Yevgeny I. Chazov, a Soviet Deputy Minister of Health, who has represented the Soviet Union at a number of international forums on ending the nuclear arms race. There are no Soviet members of the Pontifical Academy. **********The papal delegations will present the results of a study by the Pontifical Academy on ''the prospects connected with the use of nuclear arms with particular attention on the disastrous effects of an atomic war.'' **********The Vatican said the Pope had announced the missions in messages to President Reagan and Mr. Brezhnev on the eve of the talks in Geneva on limiting nuclear missiles in Europe. **********The Pope, who has been expressing alarm about the nuclear arms buildup, warned in his messages of the ''specter of a nuclear conflict.'' **********The Vatican said the academy's study on the use of nuclear arms ''examines the forecasts of total destruction that would become a distressing reality if such a type of armament were used.'' **********It said the Pope called on scientists to contribute to ''a more mature reflection of humanity,'' emphasizing ''the total absence of an alternative to the hypothesis of a nuclear war other than the reduction, today, and the elimination, tomorrow, of all nuclear armaments.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/jobs/.body_text: **********T HE nation's outlook on job availability is highly unpredictable and will remain so for some time, most experts believe, because of the Reagan Administration's rewriting of the nation's budget and tax policies, continued high interest rates and an economy that has been unsettled for several years. **********Authorities on the American work force say that predicting trends is always difficult but that economic forces currently operating make predictions more difficult than usual. Most economists foresee continuing low levels of growth and even those work experts who hold more optimistic views call for no major gains in employment or reductions in unemployment. Typical of them is Robert Eisner, a professor of economics at Northwestern University, who said, ''Employment will hold fairly steady, and unem-ployment wil l increase somewhat,'' but it is ''very hard to predict.'' He is among those who believe the automobile industry, co nstruction and housing will continue to be hurt in 1982, in large pa rt because of high interest rates. **********On the other hand, Ronald Utt, associate chief economist with the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, said he is ''still optimistic about 1982.'' He said his organization had expected a recovery to be in its early stages, following passage of the President's economic programs. Mr. Utt predicted that ''once fears and skittishness and caution that characterize the financial markets'' ended, interest rates would drop significantly and recovery would begin. The rates improvement could begin before the end of the year, he said. Still, Mr. Utt sees employment in 1982 only holding steady, not advancing, and said he saw no indications that unemployment would come down in 1982. **********A more bearish point is represented by David A. Smith, an economist at the National Center on Economic Alternatives in Washington, who said: ''There can be little question that in the short run unemployment will continue to go up. Capital investment is down and an enormous credit crunch is likely to continue, at least through the second quarter of next year.'' He would be ''very surprised,'' h esaid, ''if, b y the middle of next spring, we do not have unemploymentrates of clos e to 10 percent.'' **********The United States labor force currently stands at about 106.7 million, with 98.9 million Americans listed as employed and 7.8 million, 7.2 percent, counted as unemployed. Unemployment is expected to run greater than 7 percent, perhaps more, throughout 1982.  According to the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, this is the highest rate, except for the 1975-76 recession, since the Great Depression. **********The job picture is spotty. For years cities like Oklahoma City, Tulsa, Rochester, Minn.; Wichita Falls, Tex.; Austin, Tex.; Lincoln, Neb.; Stamford, Conn.; Minneapolis, Gainesville, Fla.; Richmond, Va., and Lexington, Ky., have enjoyed unemployment rates of less than 5 percent, some close to 3 percent. Other communities, however, losing jobs and not attracting new development, have in recent years suffered rates between 10 and 15 percent. These include Buffalo, N.Y.; Anderson and Muncie in Indiana; Lewiston, Me.; Kankakee, Ill.; Johnstown and Altoona, in Pennsylvania, and Detroit, Muskegon, Battle Creek, Saginaw and Flint, all Michigan. Philadelphia, typical of old, large manufacturing cities lost 140,000 jobs in the 1970's. Some coal-producing areas in western Kentucky and the lower Middle West traditionally have unemployment rates higher than 20 percent. And in some center areas of old cities in the Northeast and Middle West, rates can approach 50 percent. **********Longstanding public-service jobs are being curtailed. A full 300,000 jobs under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act have been eliminated, and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. predicts that budget and tax programs already approved will cost the economy a million jobs.  In addition, the Administration is proposing even more budget cuts that, at least in the immediate future, seem likely to cost more jobs. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. says that under the most optimistic Reagan Administration forecasts, unemployment will not return to the 1979 level of 5.8 percent until 1985. **********The Administration, however, contends that its economic programs will, in the long run, add jobs, as many as 13 million more by 1986.  Mr. Reagan maintains this would be three million more than would have been added under policies of his predecessor, Jimmy Carter. **********Meanwhile, curious trends are operating in the nation's work force, and analysts are often unable to say what they will mean. Old industries - automobiles, steel, rubber, coal - are experiencing large, apparently irreversible job losses. Employment at the McDonald Corporation, the fast-food company, with 350,000 workers, is greater than that at United States Steel, for decades a bastion of the economy, with 142,000 workers. Many of the McDonald's jobs are part-time, and are filled with teen-agers. Nevertheless, people as disparate as Lane Kirkland, A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, and Felix G.  Rohatyn, the New York financial expert, use the McDonald's-U.S. Steel figures as an example of where the nation's economy seems to be heading, with manufacturing employment, a major part of the economy for more than a century, continuing to shrink, and service employment increasing. The employment numbers point, they say, to the need for policies to spur reinvigoration of manufacturing industries. **********Thousands of jobs have been lost in the United States maritime industries, Mr. Kirkland has said. Tens of thousands of jobs have disappeared in such areas as the garment, clothing and textile industries as manufacturers look for cheaper labor rates and other reduced costs that can be achieved abroad. Significant plant closings also have occurred in the auto, auto parts and steel industries; many mining jobs have moved from the East to the West, which now turns out 35 percent of the nation's coal. **********Service employment, which has been essentially immune to recessionary pressures, will continue to grow through the next few years. But even in this sector, according to Diane N. Westcott, an economist at the U.S. L abor Department's Bure au of Labor Statistics, jobs increased in 1980 and the first half of 1981 at a considerably slower pace than in the years immediately pre vious. **********If President Reagan is able to expand the nation's military forces, and as he increases defense outlays, then the largest spur to employment in 1982 and the following years may be the defense program, according to Woodrow Ginsburg, research economist at the Center for Community Change in Washington, which specializes in employment problems of low-income people. He said this could stimulate the economy in areas around military bases and in the defense industries. Economists often argue, however, that defense spending creates fewer jobs than are generated by spending in the private sector. According to a study by the International Association of Machinists, $1 billion spent in industry for the military creates 45,000 jobs, while $1 billion spent in the civilian industry creates 59,000 jobs. The machinists' union, despite large numbers of its members who work on military projects, favors a decrease in arms spending. ''Spending money on either military industry or on military personnel increases the country's unemployment,'' the study says. **********Mr. Ginsburg said he saw no evidence that employers were rushing to take advan tage of accelerated tax write-offs passed by the Reagan Administratio n. Such actions take three or four years or more to takeeffect, he sa id, and companies so far have not been encouraged enoughby the econom y to begin vastly increased capital spending. **********Mr. Utt, the Chamber of commerce economist, explained that ''We live in a country in which, if you want to erect a factory you just don't go out and erect a factory. It used to take six months (to gain approval from localities and states). Now it could take three years.'' **********Harley Shaiken, a labor and technology specialist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, contends that even if the Reagan Administration policies work they could mean employment problems. ''The real question that is not being addressed,'' he said, ''is, will they create as many jobs as they destroy.'' **********If companies are spurred to expand because of revised tax policies, Mr. Shaiken believes, major efforts will center on using the most advanced technology, often based on computer systems, to improve productivity and in turn reduce work forces. Thus, Mr.  Shaiken argues, ''to the extent the policies do work, they will not be job-creating policies but productivity-increasing policies.'' **********Such a view is sometimes disputed, at least in part, by other economic experts, who say that new technology that increases productivity often results in expanded economic growth and thus, at times, increased employment. **********Joblessness is not a factor in such fields of continuing high demand as computer science, most engineering fields, robotics and other electronics specialties, tool and die-making, nursing and secretarial work. One other promising area of the job picture appears to be in part-time employment, although such work generally is at low pay. Today, nearly 25 percent of the work force are parttimers, four-fifths of them working such schedules voluntarily.  ''A lot of industries thrive on part-time work,'' said George Stamas, a work specialist with the Bureau of Labor Statistics. He cited as examples the fast-food and grocery industries and some sectors of manufacturing.   ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Reports on the job outlook in various regions of the nation begin on Page 70.
