https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.main_headline: HARD CHOICE GIVEN REAGAN ON BUDGET
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.print_headline: HARD CHOICE GIVEN REAGAN ON BUDGET
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan is being told that he must accept either higher budget deficits over the next three years or ask Congress to adopt tax increases that would raise billions of dollars in that period, White House spokesmen said today. **********But they said that Mr. Reagan was clinging to his hope of making further spending cuts to balance the budget by 1984.  Mr. Reagan was presented with the new fiscal dilemma at a review process that started yesterday and continued today at a luncheon meeting of the President and his main political and economic advisers. Congress and Recession Factors **********The review was made necessary by two factors. One is stiffening Congressional resistance, even among Republicans, to further deep cuts in Government spending that Mr. Reagan still favors as the main tool for achieving his goal of a balanced budget by 1984. **********The other factor is the economy's slide into what the Administration officials call ''a mild recession'' despite assurances given Mr. Reagan by White House economists that 1981 would be a year of economic growth. **********The review raised, for the first time in Mr. Reagan's term, the possibility of a retreat on key elements of his plan to balance the budget through spending cuts and reduce taxes at the same time. A White House aide said today that Mr. Reagan himself was in a quandary about which way to turn to combat an economic squeeze that none of his advisers foresaw. **********A number of White House aides insisted today there was no anger at the forecasters for failing to predict the economic slump that appears to be driving the budget deficit beyond the $43 billion level sought by Mr. Reagan for the 1982 fiscal year. But the aides acknowledged that the Reagan Administration was at an economic crossroads. **********''The first thing you do is try to get the President to make some decisions about what he wants to do,'' an adviser said. ''Right now he wants to try to live up to what he said on Sept. 24.'' On that date, Mr. Reagan told a national television audience that he wanted $13 billion in supplementary spending cuts in 1982, in addition to the $37 billion spending reduction approved earlier in the year. To help hold the deficit down, Mr. Reagan said he would also support a modest $3 billion increase in taxes. **********But now Mr. Reagan's situation is complicated by what one fiscal policy official described as an intense dispute over the size of that tax increase between the Administration's main economic thinkers - Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan and David A. Stockman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget. **********Mr. Stockman is said to want to shrink the deficit by imposing a much larger tax increase that would produce $60 billion in new revenues in the next three years. But, White House and budget officials said, Mr. Regan believes this would be a betrayal of the President's supply-side economic theory that holds that deep tax cuts will stimulate business growth sufficiently to produce an overall increase in tax revenues. **********David R. Gergen, the senior White House spokesman, said today that the President was leaning toward Mr. Regan's view. It is in keeping with the President's Sept. 24 policy statement that spending reductions have to be the main tool in bringing about a balanced budget. **********But that is where Mr. Reagan's economic theory runs into Congressional opposition. Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the majority leader, has already informed the White House that Senate Republicans will support only about half the $13 billion in supplementary budget cuts requested on Sept. 24. Also, Senate Republicans are talking of $60 billion in tax increases over three years - an amount close to the Stockman figure - rather than the $22 billion tax increase that the White House is willing to support over the same period if it is called ''revenue enhancement'' rather than a tax rise. **********At today's White House luncheon, a participant reported, Mr.  Reagan received more bad news from Capitol Hill. Of the 13 appropriations bills now before Congress, Mr. Reagan was told, the eight largest are running above his original March budget figures and do not even take into account the additional trims he asked for on Sept. 24. Prelude to Baker Meeting **********Today's meeting included the President's first-string economic advisers - Mr. Regan, Mr. Stockman and Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. But it was a prelude, aides acknowledged, to the week's most crucial session. That will probably come on Thursday, when Senator Baker and other Republican Congressional leaders come to the White House to hear what adjustments Mr. Reagan is willing to make in his Sept. 24 proposal. **********Before that time, a White House aide said, Mr. Reagan must decide ''whether we push for the budget cuts or buy into the various tax proposals that are floating around.'' **********Mr. Gergen said today that it was possible Mr. Reagan might choose to fight for his Sept. 24 plan, even though White House advisers privately acknowledged this would mean an open break with vital Congressional allies in the President's own party. **********Senator Baker, seeking to find a compromise that would satisfy Congress and save face for the White House, today proposed creation of a trust fund to finance military spending. It would, like the highway trust fund used to construct the interstate system, earmark certain tax revenues for defense. This would ease the competition between military and social programs for a shrinking pool of tax dollars. **********''We're searching for a way to get them out of competition with each other,'' Senator Baker said, adding that he did not know how such a trust would be supplied with money. But, he added, he had abandoned his earlier proposal for a national sales tax to finance a defense trust fund. 'Take It Away With the Other' **********Mr. Gergen said today that Mr. Reagan was reluctant to approve any tax increase after having won Congressional approval to reduce income taxes by 25 percent over three years. The President's view is ''that he does@n't want to give money back with one hand and take it away with the other,'' Mr. Gergen added. **********Some Administration officials, speaking with the guarantee of anonymity, acknowledge that Mr. Reagan now appears to be a victim of the success he had in ramming that tax cut through Congress. He acted then on the basis of what one official called ''totally unrealistic'' economic forecasts. They indicated that economic growth would be such that, even with tax cuts, there would still be enough Government revenue to fund essential social and defense spending. **********Now, with revenues diminished by both the Reagan tax cut and the recession, the official concluded, Mr. Reagan must choose between spending reductions that could touch off Congressional rebellion or tax increases that violated his own philosophy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/busin.main_headline: ANALYSTS SEE END OF RATE DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; ANALYSTS SEE END OF RATE DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/busin.body_text: **********The optimism over interest rates in the credit markets appears to have evaporated, with many analysts now believing that the move toward lower rates has come to an end. **********Analysts say that short-term rates, which have fallen more than two percentage points in the last month, may not dro p much further, if at all, be cause the Federal Reserve is not likely to pump money into the bank ing system at the rapid rate of the last three months. **********Long-term interest rates have increased to record levels, they add, and weak investor demand for bonds in the face of the Treasury's mounting borrowing needs points to higher yields in the future. **********''The markets are facing up to t he fact tha t the Treasury needs to raise about $70 billion of new cash over the next six months,'' said William Griggs, senior vice president at the J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company. **********''With that kind of financing, high yields are a necessity,'' he said. ''The markets have to sell each issue quickly because another one will be coming next week.'' Last Week's Attitude **********Just a week ago the credit markets were in a state of near-euphoria as short-term rates were declining and some analysts were predicting that the beleaguered bond market might attract some long-dormant investors. The Treasury's huge borrowing needs were worrisome, but even the most pessimistic analysts conceded that lower short-term rates could spill over into the long-term securities of the bond market. **********The market's performance, however, was vastly different from the rosy projections. Three-month and six-month Treasury bills, for example, ended last week at rates of 14.32 percent and 14.7 percent respectively, up from 14.2 percent and 14.13 percent at last Monday's auctions. One-year bill rates also rose to 14.53 percent late Friday from 13.91 percent on Monday. **********The market for long-term bonds was even weaker than the bill market as the 13 7/8 percent Treasury issue due in 2011 ended the week at 92 1/4 to yield 15.05 percent, down about 5 1/2 points, or $50.50 per $1,000 bond for the week. Twenty-year Treasury bonds also dropped in price, with the 13 3/8 percent issue due in 2001 closing at 87 3/8 to yield 15.42 percent, compared with its Monday price of 93 10/32 and a yield of 14.4 percent. Treasury Plans Sales **********The Treasury gets started on its heavy fourth-quarter borrowing this week with the sale of $4.5 billion each of three-month and sixmonth bills today, followed by $1.75 billion of 20-year bonds on Wednesday and $5 billion of one-year bills on Thursday. These financings will raise about $3.4 billion of the estimated $34 billion of new cash the Treasury needs in the next three months. **********''With psychology still bleak and institutional investors quite willing -and outright comfortable - to sit on the sidelines,'' analysts at Merrill Lynch & Company said in its Weekly Credit Market Bulletin, ''further upward yield pressure - especially in the longterm markets - would appear highly likely.'' **********The bleak outlook for the bond markets was especially pronounced last week when the bellwether 13 7/8 percent Treasury bond dropped almost 5 1/2 points, or $50.50 per $1,000 bond. That decline was especially ominous, analysts said, because it occurred while shortterm interest rates were declining. **********Earlier this year, many salesmen and traders predicted that a drop in short-term interest rates could be the catalyst for a bond market rally. Consequently when short-term rates began declining in early September, there was speculative buying of long-term bonds as some dealers and traders anticipated a shift of investor money into the bond market. The speculative demand for bonds was also fueled by lower overnight financing costs, which fell to 13 1/2 percent and 14 percent last week from 17 percent early in the month. Analysis of Fed's Action **********That speculative buying evaporated Friday after the Federal Reserve drained reserves from the banking system by temporarily selling securities. Traders quickly interpreted the Fed's move to mean that short-term rates would not continue to decline as they did earlier in the month. Three-month Treasury bills fell from 15.61 percent on Sept. 4 to 14.11 percent early Friday. **********The Fed's move to drain reserves was particularly significant, analysts said, because it came after three months when the Fed was increasing the supply of nonborrowed reserves in the banking system at an annual rate of more than 20 percent. **********The growth in reserves is one reason why many economists expect the growth of the nation's money supply to increase in coming months, along with economic activity in general. **********A Chemical Bank economist, Richard Scott-Ram, estimates that economic growth in the fourth quarter should be strong enough to keep short-term credit demands and interest rates high ''with upward pressure before year-end.'' The economy continues to show suprising resilience, he said, and is not lapsing into a recession. Of course, other economists contend that a recession is imminent and will soon lead to lower interest rates. Gloomy Prospect Seen **********At Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, Frank Mastrapasqua, an economist, said deteriorating business conditions were spreading beyond the housing and automobile sectors and were pointing toward a general recession. ''While the budget deficit is today's domin ant issue for the fixedincome markets, recession and lower shor t-term interest rates should be tomorrow's,'' he said. **********Forecasts similar to Mr. Mastrapaszua's have been circulating all year, though so far the burden of high interest rates has not been great enough to cause a recession or a financial calamity. **********Some analysts say that the burden of high interest rates is in their longevity, not just their high level, but they acknowledge that nobody really knows how much pain high rates cause. A recession or credit crunch could still materialize, many analysts say, but probably only at interest rates higher than the current levels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM COMMENTS ON POLAND AND MIDEAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM COMMENTS ON POLAND AND MIDEAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from texts of television interviews yesterday with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation'' and with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' as recorded by The New York Times: **********Following are excerpts from television interviews yesterday with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation'' and with Secretary of Defense Caspar W.  Weinberger on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' as recorded by The New York Times: **********Haig on Poland **********Q. Secretary Haig, a number of reports tell us that the Soviet Union has supplied technical assistance, advice, some supplies, all kinds of help and encouragement in the martial law imposed inside Poland. Are they not in a sense involved, are they not an involved party in the martial law in Poland? **********A. I think as the President said in his statement this week, there's no question about Soviet cooperation and support for the activities going on in Poland today. **********And just as the Polish authorities must be held be responsible for the excesses of the situation, so too must the Soviet Union.  Q. Does that mean, Mr. Secretary, that if there are any sanctions imposed against Poland, they should similarly be imposed against the country that is supporting it and pressing it on - the Soviet Union? **********A. Now, with respect to actions that will be taken in the future, either with regards to the Polish Government or the Soviet Union, I would prefer to let events speak for themselves. Significance of Events **********I think our policy thus far, and the President's policy in particular, has been one to avoid excesses and perhaps preoccupation with contemporary muscle tone, and be influenced by the historic significance of the events with which we are dealing. **********These are very important events and the situation is, in the President's words, grave. Now what is very important is that we Americans keep the historic significance of the events before us, and not the contemporary give-and-take of the situation. And that we apply all of the leverage available to us - in some respects it is limited, but it is not insignificant - to effect moderation, negotiation and, hopefully, conciliation among the peoples and the parties in Poland. **********Q. Mr. Secretary, do you think there's any hope that some of what Solidarity has achieved in Poland can be saved? And what do you think the United States and its allies can do to preserve some of the reforms made in Poland? 18 Months of Toleration **********A. Well, I think, in the first instance, we cannot accept a doomsday theory that all is lost and is inevitably lost. After all, there's been 18 months of toleration in dialectic form. And thus far, until this recent crisis, the Soviet Union and the party in Poland has accepted historic change in the normal way of doing business. **********And we must hope that those same constraints that have operated in the past will continue to influence the outcome of the situation in Poland - and do all we can to be sure that these pressures continue. **********Q. You said that the United States must apply all leverage available to us in this situation - what leverage do we really have at this time? **********A. Well, without labeling particular levers, which sometimes is self-defeating and lessens the impact when they're applied, they involve political, economic and, of course, security-related assets. **********Q. By security-related assets, you sound like you might be hinting at some kind of military leverage that we might apply against the Soviet - Solidarity Actions Cited **********A. Well, I think it's important that at a time like this that no public official describe in detail either what we will or what we will not do as events unfold. **********Q. You talked about how the Soviet Union and the Communist Party inside Poland had shown considerable accommodation to the new freedoms in Poland. That implies - perhaps I'm misunderstanding you - but it implies to me just a little bit that you feel that Solidarity overstepped itself perhaps when it called for a referendum to overthrow the Government. **********A. I think it's important that we not give too much weight to the contemporary excuse for the crackdown in Poland as being the consequence of excess exuberance or radicalism within the Solidarity movement. **********Clearly, from the outset, the Soviet Union has been insisting on a crackdown, and urging the Polish Government to crack down. Up until this point, they've been able to blunt those pressures. The Triggering Mechanism **********Now, the fact that this call for a referendum occurred very, very recently belies the fact that it was, in fact, the triggering mechanism. The plans put in place in Poland that were implemented last Saturday had been in preparation for an extended period. **********Q. Do you have some sort of a feeling what it is that the Polish Government, under Prime Minister or General Jaruzelski, wants out of all this? What kind of a Poland it wants? **********A. Well, I think his actions will determine the answer to that question, but I hope they will reflect a consciousness on the Prime Minister's part that a rejuvenation, if you will, or a reform has been under way leading towards greater liberties and that those improvements must be preserved. **********They have, after all, assured us -the Polish Government has - that that is their intention. Thus far, their actions belie the credibility of that. **********Q. So do you have any feeling how far back they may roll things?  Originally, they said they would hold to the agreements of August 1980; now you seem to imply that they're going to roll things back even further than that. Actions Under Way **********A. Well, one can only look to the actions that are under way today: repression, violence, imprisonment without due cause, termination of the right of the Polish people to travel, suppression of the free press - to the degree there ever was one, but certainly those of a more independent character. **********Q. Is this - you talked about putting it in perspective - is this another Hungary, another Czechoslovakia, another in the series that we've seen of Soviet slapdowns of movements of this kind? **********A. Well, I think it's important for the American people to recognize this is not a Hungary or Czechoslovakia, it is something far more profound in historic terms. **********We've witnessed for 18 months a loosening up of political reins of suppression in Poland. The previous incidents were more, I think, associated with economic deprivation, food shortages or repression per se. This represent a profound challenge to the Marxist-Leninist system of traditional control. A Threat to Soviet **********And for that reason, it is all the more dangerous. It does constitute a vital threat to the interests of the Soviet Union. And for all these reasons, we should not draw historic parallels in a precise sense. **********Q. Mr. Secretary, do you have any information on what has happened to the leadership of Solidarity, particularly Lech Walesa himself, that you could pass on to us? You sound like you have some kind of knowledge about the possibility that he might be surfaced or something. **********A. Well, it is our understanding, from a host of related intelligence reports, that Mr. Walesa is in confinement outside the outskirts of Warsaw, under Government control. We also have had some reports that he continues to remain the independent figure that he has proven to be thus far. **********Q. Then he's not cooperating with the military regime?  A. We've seen no signs of cooperation. We would hope that the Polish authorities would permit Mr. Walesa to bring his experience and wisdom to bear in this situation. Catholic Church Cited **********Q. The third force that's generally mentioned inside Poland is the Roman Catholic Church, Archbiship Jozef Glemp. Do you see any signs that they are in any position - are things close enough to equilibrium so that the third party could do some good here? Pushed on, of course, by the Pope who is a Pole himself. **********A. Well, this is an anguishing problem for the Pope, of course, with its great emphasis on the moral values and the humanitarian aspects of this tragedy. But the church in Poland plays an extremely important role. And thus far, I think it has been an extremely constructive role. **********In the days ahead, we would hope that their influence on the situation would continue to be one which urged conciliation and negotiation and compromise and not the total crushing of the Solidarity movement. **********Haig on Middle East **********Q. As you're well aware, Prime Minister Begin and the Israeli Government have issued, this morning, some rather strong statements.  They have canceled the so-called strategic relationship with the United States, and they're indicating they can get along without our help. I'm wondering if you have any reaction to the possibility that now Israel may go ahead and annex the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, and refuse to surrender the Sinai? And if that happens, what is our response going to be? **********A. You know, Israel has been, is today and will remain a close friend of the United States. President Reagan recognizes - perhaps far more than any President in recent history - the vital importance of our obligations to the people of Israel and our guarantees to the survival of that state. Nothing has changed. **********Now, it's always the case that differences occur, even among very good friends. And this is just such a difference. The task of American diplomacy in the days ahead is to work to resolve these issues, not to exacerbate them. Cordiality and Interrelationship **********And I would hope that the rhetoric and the demeanor of both Governments would recognize the overall imperative of our continuing cordiality and interrelationship. **********I anticipate that Israel will live religiously by the obligations of the Camp David accords; will return the Sinai on schedule; will continue, as it has in recent months, to participate as an active and cooperative member of the autonomy process. **********I'm very optimistic that today's storm clouds will pass, as they have.  Q. Are you equally confident, Mr. Secretary, that the Israelis will refrain from moving against the Palestinian positions in southern Lebanons, reigniting the conflict there? **********A. Well, I think it's important that Americans recognize that Palestinian locations overlooking the northern borders of Israel have been a constant irritation over an extended period. And the recently established cease-fire or cessation of hostilities has been a welcome relief in a pattern of historic trouble and danger for Israel. I have been very conscious of great incentives in Israel to take military action and to remove that danger, from their subjective point of view. Restraint Is Urged **********But it is also important, at this time in the peace process, that restraint be exercised by Israel, by the P.L.O., by the parties in Lebanon, and by Syria. And I'm very happy that, thus far, that restraint has manifested itself. **********Q. Let me ask you what happened to make everything so smooth and soft and sweet since the day when you first heard about the Israeli announcement and said, we regret this very surprising announcement which we first read about today; it is not consistent with Resolution 242 of the U.N. which is fundamental resolution underlying the peace process. And Secretary Weinberger called it provocative and destabilizing. Now, all of a sudden, it's part of our friendship with Israel, or what? **********A. No. My remarks with respect to our historic relationship with Israel should in no way be interpreted as a whitewash of the concern and disapproval that we felt and expressed on this recent annexation action. **********On the other hand, one must keep clearly in mind that the longstanding policies of this country represent not only the vital interests of Israel, but of the United States as well. And it is our task now - having spoken, having joined in a resolution of condemnation at the United Nations, having held in suspension the recent M.O.U., or Memorandum of Understanding, on Israeli-American strategic cooperation - the time has come now for the leadership in both countries to get to work to repair the damage. Historic Precedences **********Q. Do you have any feeling at all that this happened, that this was designed to happen, at a time when the United States Government was so deeply preoccupied with Poland; that Mr. Begin pulled this out of his hospital room and thrust it on the floor of the Knesset in such a hurry while we were totally preoccupied with Poland? **********A. Well, I'm not going to label tactics or motives in this particular case. There are perhaps historic precedences. But I think it is important to recognize that the fact of the actions did constitute a threat to the peace process. Therefore we had an obligation the President felt very strongly not to create an atmosphere in which blank checks are available for the leadership in Israel; that they have mutual obligations as well. **********Weinberger on Middle East **********Q. What about the Begin statement this morning, the rather rough, quite rough attack on the United States. What did you make of that?  A. Well, we're obviously disappointed on that kind of a reaction.  We have a feeling that it is essential that there be an understanding that the unilateral pre-emptive types of actions which surprised us and surprised the world are matters which shouldn't be allowed to pass lightly, particularly when they interfere with the peacemaking process that the President is so devoted to and has made such substantial progress in achieving. And, so we're very disappointed to hear a statement of that kind this morning. **********Q. What about there's an open break - verbal break - between the U.S. and Israel. Does that - how does that affect the chances of peace in the Middle East, would you say? **********A. Well, I think that we have to differentiate between an open break with Israel and with the people of Israel. I think - I think the basic commitment - the basic alliance of the United States and Israel is a strong one, a permanent one and I think what this represents is just what the Ambassador said - a temporary, very rough period. But it is essential to have a close working relationship with Israel just as it's essential to have a close working relationship with the moderate Arab governments in the Mideast if we are to bring peace to that troubled region. And that's what the President is most anxious to do and actually we he's succeeded in doing a couple of times just last year when he was able to have Saudi Arabia persuade Syria not to take action that would have precipitated all kinds of problems. A Banana Republic **********Q. Well, Mr. Secretary, the statement from Israel said we were treating Israel like a banana republic, like a vassal state. We had no right to punish Israel. Were we trying to punish Israel? **********A. No, I don't think there's any point in trying to go into and match this kind of vitriol. I think that's - that's not going to serve any purpose whatever. What we're trying to make it clear that actions like this kind as we tried to make it clear earlier with the pre-emptive bombing of the reactor in Iraq are actions that necessarily have to carry some cost with them. They aren't actions that are conducive to the peace or securing a peace in a very volatile region. **********Q. Mr. Secretary, for 14 years now we've been allowing Resolution 242 of the U.N. to frame the peace process.Now it seems 13 years later we can't even agree on what it means. Could you say precisely what it is in Resolution 242 that has been violated by the Israeli action? The Spirit of 242 **********A. Well, I think what's been violated by in - by the Israeli action is, first of all, the spirit of 242 which calls for all of the countries in that region to live at peace with one another and to settle all differences and all disputes by negotiation and arbitration and its equivalent as opposed to unilateral action. And that, I think, is what is considered to be violated by a statement that, all of a sudden out of the blue, Israel announces that they are now assuming what amounts to full sovereignty over a region whose future was under negotiation and discussion. The Camp David peace talks was based on these two resolutions. And I think it's vital that it as well as the resolution be observed as the only real method of trying to get peace in a region that has been torn by violence and dissent for hundreds of years. **********Q. Well, if it's only the spirit of 242 that's violated, has not the Syrians not just violated the spirit but repealed it by saying over and over again since 1948 recently and emphatically in the last few days that they will never, under any circumstances, negotiate with Israel? Chart for Settling Disputes **********A. I don't think that you can say the wrong on one side condones or justifies the wrong on the other. The Resolution 242 with the backing of world opinion that it had and still has is a resolution that charts a course for settling disputes of this kind. And my own feeling is that if it's observed on both sides, it can be carried out and there can be a reasoned settlment, a reasoned arrangement by which the disputed claims are settled and then that settlement put into effect. And that's what the resolution contemplates, it's what world opinion at the time it was drawn clearly wants, it's what we want and you can get into all kinds of legalisms as to whether the precise wording is violated or not. I happen to think it is. But there are others who say it's just the spirit that's violated. **********Q. Mr. Secretary, one of the reasons given by the Administration for this particular response is that the strategic agreement required consultation - the United States before such news. In The Boston Globe this weekend, speaking of the agreement, you said its only purpose has the object of deterring aggression and resisting aggression by the Soviets from outside the region into the region.  Its sole purpose is to defend the Middle East from the Soviets. That being so, two points, are we not cutting off our nose to spite our face, second, are the Israelis obliged to consult with us within the framework of this agreement dealing with the Soviet Union to do something strictly within the region. Peace to the Region **********A. No, the Israelis are not obliged to consult with us and the agreement is as I described it. On the other hand, the making of an agreement of that kind implies a certain understanding with respect to the kinds of actions that each partner to that agreement will take with respect to the - to the interest of the others. And it was certainly apparent, I'm sure, to everyone in Mr. Begin's Government that this kind of action, which as we see it violates either the letter or the spirit or both - I think both of the U.N. resolutions, would be something that would be very harmful to our interest in trying to bring peace to the region. While there wasn't any technical requirement that they consult with us, certainly our longstanding relationship with Israel over the years would have made that a very much more desirable course to pursue. Now, Mr. Begin, I think, has said very frankly that the reason he didn't was that he knew that we would say no. Well, we have no right to say yes or no. But we were not consulted any more than we had the faintest idea that they were going to bomb the Iraqi reactor so quickly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/29/busin.body_text: **********The Commodity Exchange Inc., the largest commodity exchange in New York, yesterday adopted the two-man, salaried top executive structure that is now common on most of the nation's securities exchanges. **********However, the Comex, which trades gold, silver, copper and financial instrument futures, did something differently. **********It retained the chairmanship for a member of the exchange and called the two senior paid officers executive vice chairman and president. **********Named to the presidency was Allan J. Brody, a 29-year-old lawyer.  Lee H. Berendt, 38, who had been president, received the newly created title of executive vice chairman. **********''We're in a critical time for all futures markets, with volume slightly declining,'' Mr. Brody said in a telephone interview. ''We are not doing as well as a year ago, but we were doing so spectacularly then that we're certainly not doing badly.'' **********Mr. Brody began as an associate with the firm of Baer Marks & Upham in 1977. He joined the Comex as vice president and counsel in July 1980. **********Mr. Berendt came to the exchange in 1971 as assistant to the executive director and became executive director himself two years later. He held the president's title since 1974. **********''I think that new products are important to the Comex,'' Mr. Brody said. ''Everybody has to make a decision whether to expand or not, and in my view, we've got to do things to expand behond precious metals.'' Leonard Sloane

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/28/busin.main_headline: DAVIS GAINS IN BID TO TAKE OVER FOX
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/28/busin.print_headline: DAVIS GAINS IN BID TO TAKE OVER FOX
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/28/busin.body_text: **********Directors of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, reacting favorably to a nearly $700 million takeover bid from Marvin Davis, the Denver oilman, authorized its management yesterday to meet further with Mr. Davis, to negotiate a formal merger agreement and to give him a look at the company's books. **********In a brief statement issued after a company board meeting in Los Angeles yesterday, Fox said that its board of directors had authorized ''negotiation of a formal merger agreement'' with Mr.  Davis. **********Speculation persisted, however, that a rival bidder for Fox may yet emerge, but no indications of another offer appeared.  Herbert J. Siegel, chairman of Chris-Craft Industries, owner of nearly 23 percent of Fox stock, said, ''No one has contacted me looking to outbid Mr. Davis.'' Specifically, he said that neither the General Electric Company nor the American Express Company, widely thought to be interested in Fox, had approached him about his key block in the huge film company. **********Stock Trading Is Moderate **********After reaching a high of $62 on the New York Stock Exchange, Fox closed yesterday at $61.50, up 37 1/2 cents, in only moderate dealings. Wall Street professionals said that extremely heavy trading - which has not developed all week - would be a sign that a powerful new bidder was laying the groundwork to battle Mr. Davis for Fox. **********In a move viewed by analysts as positive, despite the tentativeness of its announcement, Fox's decision to give Mr. Davis a look at its books was well in advance of the March 3 deadline imposed on the oilman under an agreement he has with Chris-Craft. **********Under the agreement, Chris-Craft is supporting Mr. Davis's offer to pay Fox stockholders $60 a share for all of Fox's outstanding shares. In the event of a higher offer for Fox stock from a competing company, Chris-Craft would give Mr. Davis 48 hours to match the bid. **********The Chris-Craft agreement also gives Mr. Davis until April 7 to sign a definitive agreement with Fox and until June 30 to get the approval of Fox's shareholders. Board to Meet March 27 **********Fox scheduled another board meeting for March 27 to discuss the offer further, again in advance of the April 7 deadline that ChrisCraft has given to Mr. Davis to reach agreement. Fox's annual stockholder meeting is scheduled for April 23 but the company said it might delay the meeting so that the Davis offer, requiring approval of two-thirds of its shares, might be considered. **********The Davis offer does not include Fox's television properties, which would be given to stockholders through a distribution of shares in United Television Inc., a Fox subsidiary that some analysts estimate might be worth around $10 a share. **********Thus, together with the $60 a share to be paid by Mr. Davis, Fox's sale could bring investors some $800 milion.  Earlier, in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Davis had notified Fox's directors in a letter, ''I have no plans to change the manner of Fox's operations, its corporate structure, the locale of its corporate headquarters or the composition of its management.'' **********He said he would also honor current employment agreements, pay executives at least as much as they receive now and provide for ''meaningful incentive compensation'' to key employees. His inspection of the records, he said, would take no longer than three weeks. **********In a separate development, Fox said that its directors had increased the quarterly dividend to 45 cents a share, from 37 1/2 cents, payable March 25 to holders of record on March 10.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/world.main_headline: VALIDITY OF MARCOS'S '73 CONSTITUTION IS CHALLENGED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/world.print_headline: VALIDITY OF MARCOS'S '73 CONSTITUTION IS CHALLENGED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/world.body_text: **********The validity of the 1973 Philippine Constitution under which the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos has ruled was challenged today by 130 of the 311 members of the body that drafted it. **********The challenge came a week before the nation is to hold a national plebiscite on proposed amendments that would provide for a strong president with a six-year term and no bar against re-election. Mr.  Marcos has announced that he intends to end his transitional status as President-Prime Minister and run for the new post of chief of state. **********Former President Diosdado Macapagal, an opponent of Mr. Marcos and chairman of the convention that drafted the 1973 charter, said in a telephone interview that the body had ''resumed'' its sessions and adopted a declaration that the Constitution had been improperly ratified and therefore had no legal force. **********There was no immediate reaction from the President to the challenge, but the legality of the move by the charter group was questioned in a statement quoted by the Information Ministry. Reconvening Called a 'Nuisance' **********That statement was made by Antonio Tupaz, the Minister of State for Local Affairs, who was a member of the convention, before the challenge occurred. Mr. Tupaz said that even if it was assumed that the move was legal, ''the reconvening of the convention bids to be a mere nuisance.'' He said that 61 of the nation's 110 districts were not represented. **********Mr. Macapagal said that the meeting had been called at the request of 130 of the convention's original total of 311 delegates and had been held at the suburban home of the body's vice president. He contended that since some 50 delegates had accepted positions in the Marcos Government and therefore could no longer be considered members of the charter-drafting body, the quorum required for reconvening was only 109. **********With the declaration adopted today, the Macapagal group sought to place into question the proposed amendments to be voted on next Tuesday. **********Mr. Macapagal said in the interview that the legal theory behind the challenge was that with the lifting of martial law last January, the 1935 Constitution was again in force and the Seventh Congress, suspended by Mr. Marcos, was restored to power. **********The charter convention, whose members were elected freely in 1970, opened in 1971 with a mandate to frame a new constitution replacing the 1935 charter adopted under American tutelage. Its work was overtaken by Mr. Marcos's imposition of martial law in 1972. Draft Charter Submitted to Marcos **********At its last session on Nov. 30, 1972, with some of its members in jail and others underground, the body was recessed by its president, Mr. Macapagal, who subsequently submitted a draft constitution to President Marcos. **********Mr. Marcos initially called a plebiscite to approve the draft but changed course and submitted it instead to ratification by informally organized citizens' assemblies. When opponents of the Government questioned this this manner of ratification before the Supreme Court, the Chief Justice, Roberto Concepcion, said in a decision that a majority of the court found that the procedure followed had not been valid but that ''there is no judicial obstacle to it being in force and effect.'' **********A subsequent referendum during the years of martial law produced affirmative responses to questions about the Constitution's validity, and the high court, now under another chief justice, ruled that the ratification had been valid. **********Armed with the 1973 charter, President Marcos formed a new Government and assumed the position of President-Prime Minister for an indefinite period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/17/busin.main_headline: DECONTROL OF A.T. & T. IS VOTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/17/busin.print_headline: DECONTROL OF A.T. & T. IS VOTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/17/busin.body_text: **********The Senate Commerce Committee today passed, by a 16-to-1 vote, a landmark bill to lift regulations from much of the telephone industry and allow the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to enter new and growing fields of information processing and distribution, although it restricts Bell from beaming classified advertising to homes or establishing its own electronic newspapers. **********Senator Bob Packwood, an Oregon Republican who is chairman of the committee and a strong proponent of the bill, hailed the passage as a ''momentous occasion'' and the culmination of four years of work by the committee. **********The American Newspaper Publishers Association had threatened to fight the bill if it did not contain the advertising protections.  Although the Senate Judiciary Committee has indicated it will propose amendments to the bill, its chance for passage late this year or early in 1982 are good, according to the committee. On the House side, Representative Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, chairman of the telecommunications subcommittee, has said he expects to introduce a bill by October. **********Vote Called 'Welcome' **********Pickard Wagner, a spokesman here for A.T.& T., said: ''The vote by the Senate Commerce Committee on this legislation is welcome. This moves us closer to the time when legislative uncertainties that now surroumd us can be finally resolved.'' **********Essentially, the Senate bill provides a clearer legal foundation for a deregulation plan already devised by the Federal Communications Commission, which wants to put it into effect early next year. The F.C.C. plan, however, has been threatened with substantial delays through court challenges, prompting Senator Packwood and other proponents of the new policies to obtain legislation that removes most doubt about the legality of the commission's decision. **********Senator Packwood and others who have provided the bipartisan support for the bill say it will unleash new forces of competition among the suppliers of communications services and manufacturers of equipment, get innovative ideas to the market more quickly and strengthen the nation's ability to compete worldwide in communications. **********In achieving the sizable vote, which enhances the bill's chances for favorable floor action, the committee bowed to several industries that feared the invasion of their domains by the huge phone company, and erected protective walls around the cable television business, newspaper publishers and providers of electronic fire and burglary systems. **********Bell is prevented from entering the cable television and alarm businesses, and publishers will benefit from provisions approved today that keep A.T.&T. from originating information services of the kind that newspapers and broadcasters might offer. 'Electronic Yellow Pages' **********Bell, through a special subsidiary for that purpose alone, may offer ''electronic Yellow Pages,'' including basic information about companies and industries - but not advertising. Also, while the phone company may store data for newspapers or other businesses, it may not be the originator of wide-ranging information. **********Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat, was the lone opponent of the bill today. He said he was firmly convinced that the restructuring of Bell by the bill was inadequate to prevent monopolistic abuses by A.T.& T. **********Addressing the committee at one point he said: ''You can heap all the self-praise on yourselves, and talk about how much you worked to get this bill but the fact remains, this is an A.T.& T. bill, Jack.'' **********He said that the fact that the newspapers, the cable industry and others were running for shelter showed that most people were unconvinced that the bill had adequate protection from monopolistic abuses. **********Senator Hollings proposed several amendments that he thought would help to contain Bell but all of them failed. He lost by a narrow 8-to-9 margin an effort to require that a certain amount of the stock in the Bell unregulated affiliate be made available to non-Bell stockholders - to otain some ''independent'' scrutiny of the affiliate's actions. **********''You let some outsiders buy stock, and get some of those Wall Street investment firms involved, and get the S.E.C. - not the F.C.C. - involved in watching those fellas,'' said Senator Hollings. ''That kind of scrutiny is worth more than Senators or the F.C.C.  watching.'' Other Amendments **********Even so, the committee added a provision for oversight hearings every six months to watch the progress of the new communications structure. **********In other amendments, the committee freed two Bell affiliates, Cincinnati Bell Inc. and Southern New England Telephone Company, from the requirement to set up separate subsidiaries for unregulated business because A.T.& T. has minority ownership of them. **********The committee, responding to fears among rural and small-town constituents that deregulation would lead to dramatic increases in phone rates for them, enacted a provision limiting rural rates to no more than ''110 percent of the national average.'' **********In another provision that was added to the bill just last night, the committee said that in communities where there is competition between cable systems and television broadcasting stations there will be no regulation of household rates. It also requires the F.C.C. to set limits on franchise fees that cities may levy against local cable operators. Thomas E. Wheeler, president of the National Cable Television Association, said the trade group ''enthusiastically supports'' the legislation. **********Mr. Wirth, whose House subcommittee is at work on its version of the bill, sent a note of congratulations today to Senator Packwood.  He promised a report by the end of August on his committee's extensive hearings on the state of competition in communications and urged a closer look at the concerns of telephone service ''users and consumers.'' **********Some very substantial users, such as the Ford Motor Company, Citicorp and the Bank of America, have raised concerns that Bell may dominate the services that they need and wipe out competition, according to Senator Hollings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/03/busin.main_headline: GENERAL MOTORS REPORTS '80 LOSS OF $763 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/03/busin.print_headline: GENERAL MOTORS REPORTS '80 LOSS OF $763 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/03/busin.body_text: **********Although it managed to earn $62 million in the fourth quarter, the General Motors Corporation, for decades one of the most profitable giants in American industry, yesterday reported a 1980 loss of $763 million. It was G.M.'s first full-year loss since 1921. **********The fourth-quarter profit, equal to 21 cents a share, was a sharp turnaround for G.M. from its third-quarter loss of $567 million, experienced as the American auto industry hit the low point in a sales slump that will result in an estimated 1980 loss of $4.06 billion for the Big Three American auto makers - G.M., Ford and Chrysler. **********The Chrysler Corporation's bid for $400 million in additional Federal loan guarantees advanced yesterday as the United Automobile Workers ratified wage concessions equal to a 13 percent pay cut.  (Page D4.) **********Acceptance of Imports **********The rapid and sustained decline of the American auto industry is the result of two years when sales of domestic cars shrank as imports of the smaller, fuel-efficient cars not available from American manufacturers won wide acceptance from American car buyers. **********For 1980 the domestic car makers reported sales of only about 6.6 million cars, making it the worst sales year since 1961. Imports captured 26.5 percent of the market. **********At the same time the domestic car makers are being forced to spend billions of dollars to retool plants to produce **********The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 15.10 points as the price of stock favorites eroded further. Gold fell to 10-month lows, hitting $482 in New York. Pages D1 and D14. smaller cars. The combination of huge investment and dwindling sales has created a financial squeeze that has brought Chrysler close to bankruptcy and has created a serious financial problem for Ford. **********With the auto industry's decline, G.M., the nation's largest auto maker, was replaced in 1979 by the Exxon Corporation as the American company reporting the largest annual sales and earnings. Exxon earned $4.29 billion in 1979 compared with G.M.'s $2.89 billion. This year Exxon earned $5.66 billion. **********Despite the grim problems, General Motors sells 45.9 percent of all cars bought in the United States, and many analysts believe that within a decade its market share will exceed 60 percent, partly at the expense of Ford and Chrysler. It is the only one of the Big Three to show a profit in any 1980 quarter. **********G.M.'s fourth-quarter earnings were down sharply from the $426 million, or $1.46 a share, earned in the fourth quarter of 1979.  Sales in the 1980 fourth quarter, however, amounted to $16.2 billion, up from $16.1 billion a year earlier. **********Arvid Jouppi, an analyst with John Muir & Company in Detroit, said he had expected G.M. to do better in the quarter, earning about 30 cents a share. **********Although Mr. Jouppi was optimistic that G.M. would pull out of its decline, he and other analysts observed that the company was in its worst earnings situation since it lost $38.7 million in 1921, a recession year when G.M. was only beginning to transform itself into a modern corporation from a collection of poorly coordinated companies. Projection for Ford **********Mr. Jouppi predicted that the Ford Motor Company, the nation's second-largest auto maker, would have a loss of about $1.6 billion for 1980, including $400 million in the fourth quarter. Chrysler has estimated its losses at $1.7 billion for last year, including an estimated $200 million fourth-quarter loss. Ford is expected to announce its fourth-quarter figures next week and Chrysler later in the month. **********G.M.'s 1980 sales, at $57.7 billion worldwide, were down 13 percent from the $66.3 billion in revenues for 1979. In earnings, the auto maker's 1979 figure of $2.89 billion represented a sharp drop from $3.5 billion in 1978, its record. **********Roger B. Smith, G.M.'s new chairman, and F. James McDonald, president, said in a joint announcement that G.M. had resorted to drastic measures to conserve cash to help finance its retooling program. **********''Employment was cut; the corporation's contribution to employee's savings stock purchase programs was reduced and the merit increase program was suspended for salaried employees; and there was no bonus for 1980 for any member of G.M. management.'' **********They said that G.M. would continue its product program in which $40 billion will be invested worldwide from 1980 to 1984.  Harvey Heinbach, an auto analyst for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, said in an interview that the cost cutting started earlier this year had helped the company become profitable in the fourth quarter.
