https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/22/busin.main_headline: Business Forum; BUSINESS IS ASKING FOR TROUBLE AGAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/22/busin.print_headline: Business Forum; BUSINESS IS ASKING FOR TROUBLE AGAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/22/busin.body_text: **********O NCE each generation, American business has an opportunity to exert public leadership rather than defend itself against the public. It has that opportunity now. Will it use it? If the past is any guide, the answer is probably ''no.'' **********American business had such an opportunity in the early and mid-1880's, with the advent of mass-production techniques and the modern diversified corporation. But the inability of businessmen to respond to their public responsibilities fueled the Populist and Progressivist activism of the early decades of this century and led to the first wave of Government regulation -antitrust legislation, the establishment of the Federal Trade Commission, laws governing hours and working conditions and health standards for medicines and meat. **********Business had a second opportunity during the 1920's, after earning a measure of public trust from its War Industries Board effort. Its failure then to respond to the postwar demands of labor, investors and consumers foreshadowed New Deal programs to protect these groups - legislation establishing a framework for labor-management relations, regulations governing the securities and banking industries and laws further protecting consumers from unsafe foods, drugs and cosmetics. **********A third opportunity arose in the 1950's and early 1960's when Government fiscal and monetary policies appeared to insure steady economic growth. But the failure of American business once again to seize the initiative in anticipation of a new set of emerging public concerns about the environment, health, consumer safety, equal opportunity and political corruption, set the stage for a third wave of regulation, beginning in 1965. This wave was manifested in 35 separate regulatory programs covering everything from unsafe toys and flammable fabrics to mines and chemicals. **********There are remarkable parallels among all three periods. Each successive wave was marked by a further extension of Government control over business - of the 28 independent regulatory agencies founded between 1887 and 1980, all but seven were established during one of these periods. **********Each wave was immediately preceded by dramatic accounts in the popular press of public dangers attendant upon business activity, ranging from Upton Sinclair's revelations of unsanitary conditions in the meat-packing industry at the turn of the century, to Ralph Nader's exposes on dangerous cars, drugs and food additives. **********And in each period, these dramatic events and revelations spurred middle-income citizens into political action, but for only about a decade. **********The immediate cause of the decline was an international crisis of some sort, culminating in the buildup of military armaments, economic mobilizations, or ''revitalizations,'' and the outbreak of global hostilities. Middle-income groups, whose economic survival was suddenly at stake, quickly forsook their antibusiness activities and joined in an unstable coalition with business. **********I have simplified this, of course. But I think it is fair to discern an almost predictable waxing and waning of antibusiness political activity whose momentum has been maintained in large part by the business community's own defensiveness or indifference to public concerns. **********These waves notwithstanding, public opinion toward business has been remarkably stable over time. In survey after survey, a majority of the public has continued to support Government regulation. In a recent Roper poll, 80 percent of the respondents felt that Government must insure that business clean up its air and water pollution, provide safe products and services, advertise honestly and provide safe working conditions. These results are not substantially different from those of similar polls undertaken over the last 30 years. **********This underlying public distrust of business manifests itself in a variety of ways. Even when there is not political support for increased regulation, as now, the public vents its latent distrust by bringing lawsuits and by forsaking American-made products. **********For example, approximately 15,000 asbestos cases are now pending in courts around the country, with additional suits being filed at the rate of about 200 per month. Claims against just one company, Johns-Manville, doubled last year, to 5,082 suits involving 9,300 plaintiffs. Injuries resulting from the use of Firestone 500 steelbelted radials have given rise to $214 million in personal damage awards. The list goes on: toxic shock from tampons, cancer from benzene and vinyl chloride, birth defects from endrin. **********A T the same time that more citizens are seeking legal redress, the courts are extending the limits of liability and are looking more favorably upon punitive damage awards, in which victims are not only compensated for the damages they endure but are also awarded an amount designed to punish the company for having inflicted the injury. The Minnesota Supreme Court recently affirmed a $1.8 million award - $1 million of it punitive - against a textile manufacturer for producing cotton pajamas that caught fire and badly burned a young child. **********The public also expresses its discontent with business by deserting American-made products of poor quality. Since the early 1970's, consumers have been flocking to Japanese and European producers of automobiles, calculators, cameras, machine tools, watches, tires and stereos. **********Business executives are not fortune tellers, and in many instances it is extremely difficult, if not impossible, to foresee potential dangers or injuries resulting from the use of certain products. But in reviewing these cases, one is struck by the abundance of earlywarning signals. The first cases of asbestos-related injuries, for example, were reported over 50 years ago. In almost every case of unsafe autos or tires, the companies involved received accident reports long before there were many injuries. **********All too often, American businesses have taken the short-term view, placing immediate profits above potential problems that may be years away. **********The lesson is clear. American business can no longer afford to wait for the next wave of regulation. America has grown more litigious and American manufacturers have become more vulnerable to foreign competition. **********If there should be a fourth wave of regulation it is likely to be far more onerous than any before.  Predictions are hazardous, but I can already perceive targets of stricter regulations: disposal of nuclear wastes; the freedom of corporations to close or relocate their factories; wheeling and dealing with small margins in commodity futures; the proliferation of mammoth, unfriendly corporate takeovers; the growing incidence of insider trading; toxic substances in the work place, and shoddy workmanship in consumer products. **********The irony is that unless American business actively seeks to anticipate and respond to emerging public concerns in advance of the next wave, business already will have been seriously eroded by the time it breaks.   ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Robert B. Reich, formerly director of policy planning at the Federal Trade Commission, teaches business and public policy at the John F.  Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. The above is adapted from a speech to the American Petroleum Institute.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/03/busin.main_headline: JAPAN TO CURB AUTO SHIPMENTS TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/03/busin.print_headline: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS; JAPAN TO CURB AUTO SHIPMENTS TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Japan agreed to cut back auto exports to the United States by almost 8 percent in a move to head off protectionist action by Congress. Japan's auto makers reacted with fury to the accord between governments but said they would obey the restrictions. Legislation in Congress would cut the imports by as much as 20 percent a year. **********Mitsubishi will be allowed to set up its own dealer network in the United States, its partner Chrysler, agreed. The accord releases Mitsubishi from a 10-year-old obligation that confined its marketing to Chrysler dealers. **********General Motors reported a 23 percent gain in first-quarter profit.  Ford and Chrysler posted losses. Chrysler, with a deficit of $298 million, said profitability would return in the fourth quarter.  Ford's loss was $439 million, more than analysts had expected. Ford increased prices by an average 2.1 percent and Chrysler by an average 2.6 percent. In West Germany, Volkswagen said earnings fell 51.9 percent last year. **********Interest rates headed higher. The prime rate at major banks was increased to 18 percent from 17 1/2 percent. The money supply increased by $4.2 billion, and the Federal Reserve was expected to intensify its squeeze on credit. Bond prices plunged and stocks fell. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 995.59, down 24 points on the week. **********Leading indicators of the economy rose 1.4 percent in March, after declining for three consecutive months. The Commerce Department, citing some distortions, said the figure might not presage economic strength. **********Factory orders increased 1.3 percent in March while manufacturers' inventories rose eight-tenths of 1 percent. **********Farm prices fell four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the fourth consecutive monthly drop, the Agriculture Department said. **********The trade deficit narrowed to $451.4 million in March, from $3.15 billion in February, mainly because of a sharp drop in imported oil. **********Texas International Airlines' bid to immediately take over Continental Airlines was rejected by the Civil Aeronautics Board. An employee group is also seeking control. **********LTV plans to spin off Wilson Foods, the nation's fourth-largest meat packer through distribution of stock to LTV shareholders. **********Consolidated Gold Fields acquired 7 percent of Newmont Mining for $108.2 million. Consolidated plans to buy at least 25 percent of Newmont. **********Eastman Kodak's first quarter earnings rose 29 percent from the same period a year ago. Some other results: U.S. Steel, up 115 percent; Dart & Kraft, down 4.6 percent; Texaco, up 9.6 percent; Phillips Petroleum, down 4.8 percent; Xerox, up 7.5 percent; Pepsico, up 13.2 percent, and Eastern Airlines, up 17.1 percent. Pan Am reported a loss of 114.5 million and UAL Inc. a deficit of $21.3 million. **********The Dillon family agreed last week to sell control of Dillon, Read & Company, the elite Wall Street investment banking house.  The purchaser is the Bechtel family of San Francisco, which operates one of the world's largest engineering companies. C. Douglas Dillon, 71, former Treasury Secretary, and his family hold the controlling shares in Dillon Read. Terms weren't disclosed. **********The 103-year-old private investment banking house, which has been slow to diversify, will now have an infusion of capital and access to Bechtel's worldwide connections in the oil industry and the Middle East.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/15/busin.body_text: **********The latest development in the advertising feud between Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola has No.2 agreeing to change some of its practices for the sake of more accurate claims. **********The move was the result of an investigation concluded last month by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus that was begun following a complaint by No.1, Coke. **********Pepsi, it seems, has been doing taste tests in shopping malls that came up with such results as 60 percent favoring Pepsi, 38 percent preferring Coke and 2 percent undecided. However, in a more scientific national sample by Pepsi, the score was 51.8 percent for Pepsi, and 41.3 percent for Coke. **********The N.A.D. felt it was misleading for Pepsi (through Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn) to state ''In tests like these . . .'' when the mall tests were ''not conducted under the same controlled conditions as the national test.'' **********Of the total of 12 matters settled in November, half were concluded when the claims were substantiated. The rest, like Pepsi's, ended when the advertising stopped using the questioned ads or changed the claim. **********In that second group were Becker & Becker for their Eltron Electric Shavers ads by Albert Behar Advertising; Bonne Bell for its Ten-O-Six Lotion ads by Leber Katz Partners; the Clorox Company for Soft Scrub Cleanser ads by Foote, Cone & Belding/Honig; Montgomery Ward with a sale ad done in-house, and a SSC&B Noxell ad for Noxzema Skin Cream.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.main_headline: DIGITAL RESOURCES DRIVEN BY SUCCESS INTO MAJOR CHANGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.print_headline: DIGITAL RESOURCES DRIVEN BY SUCCESS INTO MAJOR CHANGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.body_text: **********When Gary Kildall inspects his company's production floor and shipping dock, he walks through a kitchen, out to a patio where the company cat is sunning itself and into a former carriage house. **********There, Digital Research Inc. stockpiles its product - magnetic disks that contain software that International Business Machines has selected to operate its new personal computer. **********From headquarters in a yellow Victorian house in this quiet seaside village 125 miles south of San Francisco, Digital Research and its president, Mr. Kildall, function in a casual manner that belies the concern's leading position in the fast-paced microcomputer industry. Changing Structure **********But now, to cope with increased competition and larger contracts, such as that with I.B.M., Digital Research must change. It is formalizing its management structure, accepting venture-capital financing, altering its pricing policies and even planning to expand into a 16,000-square-foot modern office building, with a view of the ocean, of course. **********All this business, quite frankly, is more than Mr. Kildall cares to deal with. ''Basically I am a gadget-oriented person,'' the jeansclad Mr. Kildall said. ''I like to work with dials and knobs.  I'm not a very competitive person. I'm forced into it.'' **********Pacific Grove, a picturesque town near the artists colony of Carmel and a two-hour drive from California's Silicon Valley, seems an unlikely place for a computer concern. But there, in a small cottage near Monterey Bay, Mr. Kildall invented in the early 1970's what is now Digital Research's main product, an operating system. Computer Traffic Policeman **********Acting like a traffic policeman, an operating system is a type of software that directs a personal computer's activities. For example, if a user wants access to certain information, the operating system tells the computer how to retrieve it. **********In 1975 Mr. Kildall licensed what has become the leading operating system for microcomputers. It is called CP/ M, for Control Program for Microcomputers. The operating system was selected by the Xerox Corporation for its Xerox 820 office system and by I.B.M. as an option for its personal computer, set for delivery in October. **********Despite his preference for the laboratory over the board room, Mr.  Kildall, who holds a Ph.D. in computer science, has built his company to 50 employees in six years. For the year ended Aug. 31, the privately held concern had sales of about $6 million, and Mr.  Kildall expects $10 million in revenues this fiscal year. **********''They're doing terrific; they must be smiling from ear to ear with the I.B.M. contract,'' said Ulric Weil, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company.  Optimistic About Sales **********''Within five years, I think sales will be $100 million,'' said Dorothy McEwan, Mr. Kildall's wife and high school sweetheart of 19 years ago. She has handled the financial and marketing aspects of the business since the two started Digital Research in a 10-foot-by-13-foot playroom at their first Pacific Grove home, a cottage a few blocks from the ocean. **********But the expansion has become too much for Mrs. McEwan to supervise.  ''The company grew so rapidly that we had gone from small-time to a big-time operation, and we had to have professional managers,'' she said. **********After having venture capit alists knocking at his door for three years, Mr. Ki ldall recognized earlier this year that he should let them come in.  Mr. Kildall said he did not need their money, but wanted their expertise so he would not need to ''take chances'' with business deci sions. **********Last month, giving up only a small share of ownership, he brought in four: T.A. Associates of Boston, Hambrecht & Quist of San Francisco, Venrock Associates of New York and Page Mills Partners of Palo Alto. Changed Licensing Methods **********Under their counsel, Digital Research changed the structure of its sales agreements. In the past, the concern licensed its CP/M software to microcomputer makers for a one-time fee of $50,000. The simple arrangement was a bargain for manufacturers, said David Crockett, senior vice president of Dataquest Inc., a Cupertino, Calif., market research concern. **********Since Sept. 1, Digital Research has required graduated payment based on the number of computers sold by the manufacturer. Details of the contract with I.B.M. were not available. **********The simple arrangement bought CP/M market penetration, however.  About 300 computer makers use CP/ M, which means that Mr. Kildall's operating system is driving some 250,000 microcomputers, according to Digital Research. These computers range in price from $1,000 for home systems to $30,000 for small-business systems. **********At least 300 companies supply more than 1,000 software packages based on CP/M. Apple Computer Inc., the No.1 maker of personal computers, uses its own proprietary system, but users can purchase a plug-in peripheral card to adapt their Apple computers to CP/ M, thus making more applications software, especially business packages, available to them. Competition from Bell **********CP/M's strongest competition may come from Unix, an operating system developed by Bell Laboratories for 16-bit microprocessors.  ''Unix is competition at the higher end,'' said Mr. Weil of Morgan Stanley. **********Unix will likely be used most by universities and by the Bell System, Dataquest's Mr. Crockett said, while CP/ M ''will own the rest of the world.'' **********Previously, CP/M was used in the slower, eight-bit computers. Now, Digital Research has developed CP/ M-86, ordered by I.B.M., for 16-bit machines. **********Digital Research plans to branch into programming languages for computers. Just last week it purchased for an undisclosed amount Compiler Systems Inc., a small southern California concern that develops languages. **********''The company has a lot of potential,'' the soft-spoken Mr. Kildall said. ''I want to let the potential loose.'' He also said that he expected having a larger team would allow him to spend more time where he most likes to be -at a computer terminal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/27/busin.body_text: **********Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. announced yesterday an agreement with the American Express Company to offer a cash management type of account under which clients will receive an American Express gold card. **********The investment firm said that investors would be able to draw on the assets in their cash management type of account with the American Express card, but the card will not have a separate line of credit as American Express gold cards issued by banks have. **********Jim Settel, senior vice president of Bache, said in a statement that the cash management type of account was expected to be available by early 1982 and was modeled on a service offered by Merrill Lynch & Company. **********Under the Merrill Lynch service, an investor must put up an initial balance of $20,000 for an enhanced margin account that enables investors to buy and sell securities, borrow money, write checks or charge items to a Visa debit card. Cash balances are invested in a money market mutual fund. When a check is written or an item charged to the card, the amount is covered from the assets in the account. **********Donald Franz Jr., an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said the new account was ''an incentive to keep money at a brokerage house rather than at a bank.'' **********He added that American Express would pick up additional card holders and should be able to reduce its costs of financing payments to merchants because it would receive speedy payment from Bache. **********Mr. Settel said that many details of the Bache service still had to be worked out, including the amount of the initial investment. He noted that the service was aimed at affluent investors. **********Since American Express announced its agreement to acquire Shearson Loeb Rhoades, many on Wall Street had expected that Shearson would utilize the American Express card in a cash management account.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/busin.main_headline: U.S. Air Fare Ceiling Abroad to Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/busin.print_headline: U.S. Air Fare Ceiling Abroad to Rise
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/busin.body_text: **********Because of higher fuel prices, the Civil Aeronautics Board said today that it would raise airline fare ceilings June 1 for United States carriers flying on foreign routes. **********The increases in the so-called standard fare levels would range from 3.5 percent to 11 percent, depending on the region and whether the increase would be in effect two or four months. **********The standard fare, which is the base from which the ceilings are determined using a set formula, is adjusted periodically to reflect changes in fuel costs. **********The actual standard fare levels differ from one market to another.  Here are the increases: For two months: Atlantic, 6 percent; Latin America, 3.5 percent; Pacific 4.2 percent.  For four months: Atlantic, 11 percent; Latin America, 10.2 percent; Pacific 9.4 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/busin.body_text: **********1. Reginald H. Jones is a well-known employer, and Reginald I.  Jones is a not-so-well-known unemployer. Name their affiliations. 2. They're both chairmen - one of the Rockwell International Corporation and one of the Atlantic Richfield Company. **********What do they have in common? 3. One Regan has ultimate control of the Coast Guard, although most people think of him in terms of money. Another Regan wears only one hat, definitely money oriented. Who is which? 4. Identify Joseph Reed, John S. Reed, another John S. Reed and ''John Reed.'' 5. American Airlines and Braniff have a name in common. What is it? ANSWERS: 1. The first retired recently as chairman of the General Electric Company; the second runs the Reagan Administration's Task Force on Personnel Relations, charged with reducing the Federal work force. 2. The same name: Robert Anderson. 3. Donald T. Regan, as Secretary of the Treasury, also heads the Coast Guard. Edward V. Regan is New York State Comptroller. 4. Joseph is United States Ambassador to the Kingdom of Morocco and before that was a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank and special assistant to David Rockefeller. One John S. is senior executive vice president of Citicorp and the other is chairman and chief executive officer of Santa Fe Industries Inc.''John Reed'' is Warren Beatty's starring role in ''Reds,'' voted best film of 1981 by the New York Film Critics Circle. 5. Casey. Albert V. flies American and John J. is a Braniff man.  They are chairmen of their respective lines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.main_headline: HEAD OF CELEANSE UNIT OUTLINES HIS STRATEGY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; HEAD OF CELEANSE UNIT OUTLINES HIS STRATEGY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.body_text: **********C. Eugene Anderson, the newly named president of the Celanese International Corporation, the unit of Celanese Corporation that oversees its far-flung international operations, said yesterday, ''Working with our domestic companies, our people here in New York and with the various foreign subsidiaries and affiliates, we plan to develop an overall strategy for these businesses that should carry us well into the future.'' **********The dapper Mr. Anderson, who is 42, was formerly chief operating officer of Albright & Wilson Ltd., a London-based chemical company owned by Tenneco. **********Although his accent is now decidedly British, it still has the echoes of the American Southland. Educated at the University of Texas, he spent his early years as a Tenneco process engineer in New Orleans. **********Celanese International has units -some jointly owned - in Belgium, South Korea, Venezuela and other foreign countries. They make everything from cigarette filter material to acetate filament to cellophane.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/world.main_headline: U.S. AIDE OPTIMISTIC ON WEAPONS TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/world.print_headline: U.S. AIDE OPTIMISTIC ON WEAPONS TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/world.body_text: **********Paul H. Nitze, the chief United States arms negotiator, said today that there were ''prospects for reaching a fair, equitable and verifiable'' agreement with the Soviet Union in the talks that will open here Monday on the reduction of nuclear missiles in Europe. **********The two nations have ''every reason to be sincere in their efforts to reach agreement on the reduction of nuclear weapons,'' Mr. Nitze said on his arrival for the first formal Soviet-American arms negotiations since the Reagan Administration took office. **********Mr. Nitze, answering reporters' questions after reading a prepared statement at the airport, said he would be both ''reasonable and tough'' in the talks. **********A Meeting With Schmidt **********He said he would go to Hamburg tomorrow to meet with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who discussed the missile negotiations with Leonid I. Brezhnev this week during the Soviet leader's visit to West Germany. **********''If we can get rid of the longer- and intermediate-range weapons, it would be a great success,'' Mr. Nitze said, when asked if the talks would cover the entire range of nuclear arms in Europe. **********President Reagan said last week that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would forgo the planned deployment of 572 American-made Pershing-2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe in exchange for the dismantling by the Soviet Union of its SS-4, SS-5 and SS-20 missiles. **********Mr. Brezhnev countered by proposing a freeze by both sides on medium-range missiles along with some unspecified reductions by the Soviet Union of its weapons of this type in Europe as a ''good-will gesture.'' **********In Washington, however, the State Department said that the Brezhnev proposal was merely the revival of an old Soviet moratorium offer than contained nothing ''significantly new.'' 'Blueprint for a New Era' **********Mr. Nitze said today that the accord for which he saw ''prospects'' could be the ''blueprint for a new era of East-West relations.'' But he warned against ''unrealistic expectations.'' **********''These negotiations promise to be complex and delicate,'' he said, ''with many preliminary issues to be solved. We should not set deadlines for progress, but neither should we tolerate unnecessary delays.'' **********Mr. Nitze's Soviet counterpart, Yuli A. Kvitsinsky, is due to arrive here Saturday from Moscow, according to Soviet officials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/world.main_headline: Around the World; Honduran Battle Kills Policeman and Leftist
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/world.print_headline: Around the World; Honduran Battle Kills Policeman and Leftist
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/world.body_text: **********A Honduran policeman and a suspected leftist guerrilla were killed today in a gun battle, two days before the country votes in its first general election in 10 years. **********The police said they raided a house in a residential suburb of the capital where 10 guerrillas were completing plans to sabotage the voting Sunday. Two of the guerrillas and three policemen were seriously wounded. **********The police said they found dynamite, machine guns, rifles, ammunition and grenades inside the house as well as military communications equipment. **********The suspects, Hondurans, Nicaraguans and Salvadorans, were captured after an hourlong battle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/12/world.main_headline: CHINA SAYS THE VIETAMESE MUST BE DRIVEN OUT OF CAMBODIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/12/world.print_headline: CHINA SAYS THE VIETAMESE MUST BE DRIVEN OUT OF CAMBODIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/12/world.body_text: **********China said today that Vietnam's refusal to attend next week's United Nations conference on Cambodia supported Peking's view that Hanoi's 200,000 troops in Cambodia must be driven out by force. **********In a Government commentary distributed today by the official New China News Agency, Vietnam was portrayed as a proxy for Soviet expansion in Southeast Asia. **********It said the charge by Vietnam that its troops must remain in Cambodia because of a continuing threat from China was designed to divert world attention from Hanoi's aims of establishing an Indochina federation and was thus comparable to Hitler's accusations of threats from the Soviet Communists that camouflaged his aggressive intent before World War II. **********While other nations, including the United States, were describing next week's conference as an opportunity for Vietnam to end its estrangement from the world community through cooperation on Cambodia, China has held to the view that Hanoi understands only force and responds only to pressure. **********The commentary said that only by ''forcing Vietnam to withdraw its troops'' can a neutral and independent Cambodia be achieved.  ''Mere concessions will yield no stability, but instability; stability can be gained only by fighting for it,'' it said. ''Like other developing countries, China has a pressing need for a peaceful international environment, especially stability and peace in Southeast Asia, for her modernization program.'' **********The article charged that Hanoi's and Moscow's long-range goals of expansion prevented either from agreeing to any accommodations for tranquillity in Southeast Asia. **********It said Vietnam was actively resettling Vietnamese in Cambodia for long-term control. It also said that Hanoi maintained 50,000 to 60,000 troops in Laos in addition to 10,000 advisers who control that nation and that it had designs for incorporating 16 provinces of Thailand into its federation. **********''The Soviet Union is providing Vietnam with $6 million of aid per day in exchange for the use of naval and air bases in Vietnam's Cam Ranh Bay and Da Nang and Kampuchea's Kompong Som,'' it said, using the Cambodians' name for their country. ''From these bases warships and aircraft of the Soviet fleet operate in the South China Sea, the Western Pacific and the Gulf of Siam and encroach on the territorial air and waters of the Philippines.'' ---- Vietnam Calls Talks One-Sided **********BANGKOK, Thailand, July 11 (Reuters) - Vietnam said today that the United Nations conference on Cambodia starting on Monday is one-sided and doomed to failure. **********''At this conference, certain countries will propose a solution to the Cambodian problem with a cease-fire by all contesting parties,'' the official daily Nhan Dan said in a commentary. **********''The authors of this plan want to prevent the Cambodian people and their armed forces from sweeping away Pol Pot's remnants and are trying to use the U.N. to interfere more deeply in the internal affairs of independent and sovereign Cambodia,'' it said. The Cambodian regime of Mr. Pol Pot was ousted by Vietnamese troops in 1978 and guerrillas supporting him are fighting the Vietnamese. ---- Cambodia Denounces Conference **********BANGKOK, July 11 (AP) - The Phnom Penh Government today denounced the United Nations conference on Cambodia as ''illegal and arbitrary.'' **********The official news agency S.P.K., monitored here, said, ''It is an abuse of the United Nations to involve itself in the internal affairs of Cambodia, to perpetuate the clique of Pol Pot and to serve the interests of Peking expansionists in Southeast Asia.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/busin.main_headline: REAGAN'S BUDGET PROPOSALS INCLUDE DEEP CUT IN SYNTHETIC FUEL PROJECTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/busin.print_headline: REAGAN'S BUDGET PROPOSALS INCLUDE DEEP CUT IN SYNTHETIC FUEL PROJECTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration proposes to make major cuts in the Government's ambitious synthetic fuels program by eliminating five large projects.  It would also slash its financial support for the new Synthetic Fuels Corporation by about a third, or $5.3 billion, according to an unpublished document drafted by the Office of Management and Budget. The proposal also envisions that the main emphasis of the development corporation be shifted and that private sponsors be required to supply 40 percent, rather than 25 percent, of the cost of plants to be built with the help of the corporation. 'In short, Government would aid demonstration of synfuels capability but not subsidize building significant capacity,' said the working paper, though to have been written by the budget director, David A. Stockman. It said the Government would thus save $9.1 billion through the 1985 fiscal year.  It would also reduce possible disruptions in the credit markets, since the Government loan guarantees would not be so large as first planned. Word of the proposals has already brought criticism from Capitol Hill and prompted expressions of dismay from other supporters of synthetic fuels projects.  McClure Opposes 'Axiang' Project James A. McClure, the Idaho Republican who heads the Senate Energy Committee, said in a conversation last night that, when he heard that synthetic fuels were to be 'axed out,' he quickly asked that the proposals be reconsidered. 'I'm trying to find out what the signal is,' he said. 'You still can't read very well' how firmly the Administration is committed to the proposals. **********As outlined in the paper by the Office of Management and Budget, however, money would be effectively withdrawn from five demonstration projects that were to have been financed by the Department of Energy: two plants in West Virginia and Kentucky to produce liquid fuels from coal; two plants in Ohio and Illinois to convert coal into high-energy gas, and one plant in Memphis, to convert coal into medium-energy gas. A sixth project would be killed by carrying out President Carter's earlier budget request to deny funds to a Tennessee Valley Authority coal gasification project.  The Administration also says it want to Final design work is under way for all these plants.  For three of them, some site preparation work has begun. **********A sixth project would be killed by carying out President Carter's earlier budget request to deny funds to a Tennessee Valley Authority coal gasification project.  The administration also says it wants to transfer all major synthetic fuels construcition projects from the Energy Department to the Government corporation, and insists that those selected by the corporation for loan or other guarantees contain a minimum of 40 percent private capital.  Industry analysts said this requirement could effectively kill some projects. **********The basic rationale is to support a limited number (five to eight) a first-of-a-kind operating plants to demonstrate technical, economic and environmental problems and cost; to rely primarily on the private sector, and to minimize the net empenditure of Federal funds, the budget office's paper states. **********One of those opposing the cuts is Robert I. Hanfling, a Washington consultant who until recently was active in developing synthetic fuels as an official at the Department of Energy. **********These are strategic, long-term projects important to the national security, Mr. Hanfling said.  Is the obfective for the corporation not to spend any money, or is the corporation to be a means to an end for the United States to reduce its dependence on imported oil, reduce inflation and keep the economy whole?  Other Points in Policy **********Sources said that the Administration's proposed energy policy also included these points: **********The issuing of special oil bonds marketed to the public to finance a sharp increase to 200,000 to 230,000 barrels a day in the rate at which oil is pumped into the nation's strateghic petroleum, reserve.  Those oil-backed securities would be sold as long-term investments to produce capital gains and might not need to pay interest. **********The cutting of funds for solar energy research by 22 percent in the current fiscal year and 60 percent next year, and eliminating the Solar Energy and Energy Conservation Bank. **********The withdrawal this year of all Federal support for alcohol fuels, which should compete in energy markets without the benefits of taxpayer subsidies. **********The Synthetic Fuels Corporation was established last summer as the catalyst in developing a synthetic fuels industry that could produce the equivalent of 500,000 barrels of oil a day by 1987 and two million barrels daily by 1992, at a total cost of $25 billion. **********The projects to be selected were to be those whose technology had been largely proved and which were ready for commercial use.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/22/world.main_headline: Chun Promises an Amnesty Timed to His Inauguration
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/22/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Chun Promises an Amnesty Timed to His Inauguration
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/22/world.body_text: **********President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea has promised a large-scale amnesty in conjunction with his March 3 inauguration for a seven-year term, but it will apparently not include leading opposition figures, Seoul newspapers reported today. **********They said former President Yun Po Sun had told Mr. Chun at a meeting yesterday that he hoped the Government would free a large number of prisoners. **********In response, Mr. Chun was quoted as saying that the Government plans ''to grant a large-scale amnesty'' but that ''left-wing elements will be excluded.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/17/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM RADIO AND TELEVISION BROADCASTS BY POLAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/17/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM RADIO AND TELEVISION BROADCASTS BY POLAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/17/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service here: **********On Censorship 9:10 P.M. Tuesday **********(3:10 P.M. Tuesday, E.S.T.) The Ministry of Communications informs of the following curtailment of services: **********In the postal sector, the acceptance of domestic parcels is suspended, with the exception of drugs, means and objects essential for the saving of life and health and parcels of food and clothing.  Parcels should be unsealed, making it possible for the contents to be examined. Domestic postal packets containing books, press and printed matter destined for abroad are suspended. Food parcels from abroad will be handled according to the previous procedure. **********Censorship of telecommunications correspondence and control of telephone conversations is introduced and will consist of the censorship, retention and confiscation in whole or in part of telecommunications correspondence, telegram, telex; the cutting off of telephone conversations and telex and telegraph links if their content threatens the interests of state defense or security; the obliteration in telecommunications dispatches and correspondence of information whose content may threaten the security or defense of the state. **********In the sector of amateur radio and radio communications, a ban is introduced on setting up and using amateur and experimental radio transmitters and transmitter-receivers. Licenses to possess, set up and use individual and club and experimental radio stations, issued before 13 December 1981, lose their validity, including those for radiotelephones in the possession of private persons. **********Military Statement 7 P.M. Wednesday **********(1 P.M. Wednesday, E.S.T.) Forces hostile to the socialist state, taking advantage of society's disorientation and the psychological shock caused by the introduction of a state of martial law, are trying to proclaim that this means the shattering of the road of democratization and renewal. In view of this, the Military Council of National Salvation makes the following declaration: The Council's aim is not to restore the methods of ruling and the forms of social life of before August 1980. This was clearly formulated in the speech by the chairman of the Council, Army Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, on 13 December and in the military proclamation of the Military Council of National Salvation. There cannot and will not be any departure from that principle. There is no turning back from the fundamental premises of the process of democratization initiated last year. **********Discredited, incompetent, corrupt people, people who do not understand the new situation, have no right of return to the country's political state. **********The creation of the Military Council of National Salvation and the harsh limitations emerging from the state of martial law regulations were and are essential because the process of renewal was disrupted by forces hostile to socialism and the stability of the Polish state. Those forces tried to use the correct and essential process of profound democratization to weaken and overthrow the system, to carry out a coup d'etat of an antistate, counterrevolutionary character. **********An attempt to put these aims into effect would mean a fratricidal civil war. There is ample proof that in recent weeks specific measures were taken aimed in this direction. **********The Military Council of National Salvation states that, immediately after creating conditions guaranteeing order and law-abidance in the state, reforms will be started and continued with full energy, as with activities aimed at a still more profound reconstruction of structures and mechanisms of social and political life, which do not correspond to contemporary needs. **********There is no other way for Poland. This should be understood by everyone. The painful shock was essential in order to remove the threat to the state and its economy. **********The Military Council of National Salvation already in its first undertakings has shown that it is determined to act for a radical improvement of the country's life. The people responsible for taking Poland into crisis have been isolated. The purge of the apparatus of authority of people who are dishonest, incompetent or who cannot cope with the current tasks has been speeded up. A relentless struggle has been announced against manifestations of unbridled criminality and speculation. There is continuation of the activity aimed at introducing the economic reform, which particularly requires order and efficient functioning of structures. In the next few days, information will be published concerning further measures taken in this direction. **********The Military Council of National Salvation has no aims other than those it proclaimed on the day it was set up. The only supreme goal is the good of the whole nation. The council is acting, therefore, in the name of saving the basic content of socialist renewal and will do everything for that content to be brought into effect as quickly as possible. **********The Military Council of National Salvation is determined to continue the line of agreement with every social force that bases itself on the supreme interests of the socialist Polish state.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/busin.body_text: **********THE United States appears to be on the brink of winning the war it began in the 1970's for control of its energy destiny. The evidence is everywhere : Supplies are abundant, prices have flattened, a sharp decline in oi l imports has helped put OPEC in disarray, the crisisconceiv ed Department of Energy is scheduled to be dismantled and analysts of every stripe are busy trying to figure out why their pessimistic p rojections of the past eight years were so off. **********America, Energy Secretary James B. Edwards observed recently, has made major progress toward ''ending the siege mentality that we have all lived with since the 1973 oil crisis.'' **********To be sure, the United States has never lacked for energy resources. Its immense coal supplies alone are sufficient to fuel the world's biggest economy for hundreds of years. Yet, the country's recent ability to match its resources with its requirements, particularly with respect to petroleum, have been remarkable indeed. **********The issue now is not when will the United States run out of oil, nor how to restrict consumption. Rather concern centers on how long the current ''glut'' of oil will last - only to the mid-1980's or into the last decade of this century? **********Despite the considerable gains in energy conservation, vulnerability has not been eliminated. The economy is still very dependent on some 6 million barrels of imported oil a day. And the biggest question facing strategists is whether there will be further major supply interruptions such as arose from the 1973 Arab-Israeli war and the 1979 Iran-Iraq conflict and what to do in such an event.  These concerns were highlighted again last week with the renewed Middle East tension caused by the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt. **********This and other factors, such as the possibility that Saudi Arabia is likely to cut production if and when it wins price uniformity within OPEC, raises questions in the minds of some about the durability of today's comfortable situation. **********As to future conservation efforts, the Government's basic strategy appears to be to let energy prices continue to rise, thus inducing continued conservation. At the same time, sharp-penciled corporate strategists will continue to use less energy in their plants and factories and build them to use it more efficiently. **********For the consumer, analysts anticipate yet substantial improvement in conservation. They say that although the limits have been nearly reached in homeowners turning down their thermostats and putting on sweaters, there is still much potential for greater efficiency in furnaces, air conditioners and other home appliances, and in automobiles. **********''It is no longer a supply-limited world we're looking at,'' Donald A. Gunness, an economist for the Standard Oil Company of California, said. ''We're now looking at a demand-limited environment where oil is being pushed back into the ground, so to speak, by consumers.'' **********Such a forecast, not unlike those of some other major oil companies, would have been nearly unthinkable as recently as 1979 when prices doubled in the wake of the Iranian revolution. As recent as last year, the specter of gasoline lines loomed once again as fighting flared between Iran and Iraq, once leading producers within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********Rising prices, it is becoming increasingly evident, are doing a job that exhortation, production controls, appeals to patriotism and plain gloom-mongering failed to do in curbing co nsu mption. **********The reversal, in fact, is so great that at a conference last week sponsored by the Americans for Energy Independence, Philip K.  Verleger Jr. of Booz, Allen & Hamilton, a panelist, predicted that the Senate Energy Committee room in which the conference was held would be used in coming years to discuss ways to protect investments being made in alternate fuels. **********''The current oil surplus could last five, 10 years, and perhaps longer,'' Mr. Verleger said.  Economists now generally concede that they woefully underestimated the effect that the sharp price increases of the 1970's would have on the nation's demand for oil. **********In November 1974, the Federal Energy Administration's ''Project Independence'' report contained a table with five projections of total United States energy demand for 1985. They ranged from 102.9 quadrillion B.T.U.'s, or quads in energy parlance, to 124.9 quads, compared with the 72.8 quads the United States actually consumed in 1974. By 1980, the nation's usage had climbed to only 76.2 quads. **********At the time, it was assumed that there was a lock-step relationship between energy use and the gross national product, a belief that now looks pathetically naive, for the number of B.T.U.' s per dollar of G.N.P. fell last year to 51,500, from 58,300 in 1974. **********What's more, according to Roger W. Sant, president of Applied Energy Services Inc., of Arlington, Va., a new company that is going into the business of installing energy-efficient equipment for its clients, this decline in the energy-G.N.P. ratio now ''seems to be picking up, not slowing down.'' **********''Most of the doomsayers just underestimated the individual response to prices,'' Mr. Sant said. ''I would not be surprised by a further halving of the ratio over the next 20 to 30 years.'' **********WHAT helped fool economists was that after the first surge in oil prices in 1973-74, energy habits in the United States changed very little. Oil was still so cheap that after the initial shock of the Arab embargo wore off, big cars made a strong comeback and the first generation of more fuel-efficient cars was virtually unsaleable. **********Then followed nearly five years in which world oil prices, though rising nominally, actually declined slightly after adjusting for inflation. But in 1979, panic buying in the spot market allowed OPEC to raise prices far more than the disappearance of Iran as a major exporter would have otherwise caused. This time consumers got the message. **********''Prices doubled again and they really began to bite,'' William W.  Lewis, then an Assistant Secretary of Energy, noted. ''Everybody began to try to make adjustments.'' **********Only this year, however, have the effects of price-induced conservation, combined with world economic sluggishness and such legislative measures as automobile gas-mileage standards, caused an almost complete turnaround in the way many specialists are thinking about the energy future. **********Conservation, meaning a more efficient use of energy and not just doing without, is now seen to pay big dividends. Economies can grow even as they reduce energy use. The world now seems to have plenty of natural gas as well as coal and probably more oil than had previously been recognized. **********In addition, OPEC, which the Government in 1974 said might have difficulty maintaining a price of $7 a barrel, may have finally overshot the limit with current prices of $32 to $40. **********''The OPEC price is now so far out of the competitive range,'' Mr.  Sant said, that ''if I were in OPEC's shoes, I'd think I'd pretty well blown it.'' **********United States imports, for example, averaged only about 5.7 million barrels a day last month, down from 8 million in September 1979, and imports so far this year are 21 percent below 1980 levels if purchases for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve are excluded. **********Such reductions, emulated to a lesser extent by other Western countries and Japan, has major implications. Between the third quarter of 1978, when the price of oil was around $12 a barrel, and the end of this century, world demand for OPEC oil is now estimated by Standard of California to be 137 billion barrels less than if prices had not risen. **********Much of today's brighter energy picture, however, reflects relatively stagnant business conditions and the fact that very high interest rates - not normally an accompaniment of recession - have prompted oil companies to reduce their swollen inventories, which are costly to finance. **********It is estimated that during the past six months, world oil inventories have fallen at a rate of about two million barrels a day partly in response to interest charges of $6 to $8 a year for each barrel that must be stored. This drawdown is continuing at a time whe n companies are usually rebuilding their s tocks for the winter. **********William B. Nobles Jr., deputy manager of planning for the Exxon Corporation, says that while the notion of a long-term oil glut is ''a hot topic'' in his office, he sees only a ''temporary surplus'' that is more likely to shrink than grow. **********This is despite Exxon's assumption of a real global economic growth of only 3 percent a year for the rest of the century, compared with the 5 percent growth common before 1973. **********Another cautious analyst is Hans H. Landsberg of Resources for the Future, a Washington think tank. Although he says that recent developments represent ''more than a pause'' between crises and that great potential for improved efficiency still exists, especially in transportation, there is lots to worry about. **********Little progress has been made, he notes, in getting industry to switch to coal; nuclear power is not fulfilling earlier expectations for it, and the politics of natural gas - the only fuel still under Federal price control -makes full pricing of it uncertain. **********To soften the shock of the other big threat to the nation's new energy environment, another Arab boycott, the Government is stockpiling oil. Early this month the United States put the 200 millionth bar rel of crude into its strategic reserve - an amount thatwould replace imports for about five weeks. This cushion is valuable,but analysts caution that the nation remains dependent on overseas sources for m ore than one-third of its oil and has commitments to share with al lies in a crisis. **********Analysts also point to other reasons to avoid complacency, such as big increases in the developing world's energy demand and the prospect that slow economic growth in the industrial countries will probably retard investment in increased energy efficiency. **********When the history books are written, however, it now seems likely they will describe the 1980's as a period of major adaptation, a time when oil and other cheap energy sources ceased to be regarded as social entitlements and as commodities somewhow immune from the laws of economics. **********Craufurd D. Goodwin, James B. Duke Professor of Economics at Duke University, noted in a recent Brookings Institution survey of United States energy policy since the Truman years that free-market mechanisms ''had been abandoned so completely'' that when the energy crisis struck in the early 1970's, they could not be easily revived. **********But now market-pricing of energy, begun in the Carter Administration and accelerated under President Reagan, is largely a fact of life and the American energy transition is well under way.  Further increases in efficiency may be somewhat harder to obtain, but, except perhaps in heating buildings, there remains a vast potential for improvement. **********The key, however, is to continue to allow the newly embraced price regulator to work its magic, most economists say. Mr. Nobels, the Exxon planner, told his Capitol Hill audience last week that he had already cut his own heating oil use by 50 percent, but added: ''If the price of oil goes back down I'm going to take my sweater off and put the thermostat back up.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/busin.main_headline: Commodities; A Strong Comeback For Silver
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/busin.print_headline: Commodities; A Strong Comeback For Silver
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/busin.body_text: **********WHATEVER fundamental or technical factors may have provoked the remarkable rebound in silver prices this month, they have sent the metal soaring from a two-year low of $8.52 an ounce last July 31 to $9.60 at last Friday's spot (cash) quote in New York. **********The advance since July 31 has been particularly impressive because many of the silver bulls of past years had become disenchanted with the metal since it broke $10 late last June. Last week alone, the believers holding silver futures saw them rise 56 cents. **********Each one-cent move in silver represents $50 per contract of 5,000 ounces. On New York's Commodity Exchange, the biggest metals futures market, the minimum initial margin calls for $1,500 in cash. However, most brokers require somewhat more money. **********But among the most relieved winners in silver this month have not been those in the futures market, which has still to recover from the boom and bust in the metal in early 1980, when its price soared to a record of $50 an ounce on Jan. 21, and plunged to $10 just two months later. Rather, they are the owners of bags of silver-content coins and bars who held on. **********''Many holders of coins and bars couldn't or wouldn't sell after the 1980 crash because there were relatively few interested buyers,'' Ira Handler, trading manager at the Mocatta Metals Corporation, one of the world's largest metals houses, said in an interview last Friday. ''Refiners were swamped with all the silverware the public had unloaded during the winter of 1979-80, and it wasn't until the end of last year when the nation's handful of refiners saw daylight.'' **********Now, Mr. Handler noted, the growing demand silver has reached such proportions that the owners of bags of coins can obtain a premium that can be tax-free if they switch their holdings into bars and wafers. Silver bars are cast, while wafers are stamped out of strips of metal. Most refiners produce .999 or .9999 fine bars and lighter weight wafers. **********The bagged coins Mr. Handler spoke of are those of the 90 percent silver dimes, quarters and half dollars minted before 1964, silver dollars issued before that date and the 40-percent silver Kennedy halves minted between 1964 and 1969. **********''Many of the bagged coins have been culled for items of numismatic value and the coins are mostly worn,'' Mr. Handler said. ''But the trade's rule of thumb reckons that a 55-pound bag of 90-percent coins should contain 712 ounces of silver; the same size bag of 40-percent coins, 295 ounces, and the silver dollars, 760 ounces. All bagged coins traded have a face value, as currency, of $1,000 each.'' **********Mr. Handler, whose house does not deal with the public, said that the demand for silver by refiners that produce bars and wafers reflected in turn the strong retail market for their products recently. Whether this factor explains the sudden rebound in silver prices generally could not be determined at this time, he said. In any case, Mocatta quoted the following prices for bagged coins and their premiums per ounce over the New York spot market after last Friday's close: **********For a bag of 90-percent coins, the price was $8,829 and the premium was $2.80 over spot. A bag of the 40-percent silver-clad coins fetched $2,906 and a premium of 25 cents an ounce, and the silver dollars sold for $12,046 a bag and had a premium over cash metal of $6.25 an ounce in the market. **********Meanwhile, 100-ounce silver bars closed at $10.20 an ounce, for a premium of 60 cents, while the standard 1,000-ounce bar used in the global silver trade was quoted at $9.70, a premium of only 10 cents an ounce. As for the spot price in New York, it rose to $9.60 an ounce at Friday's close, up 57 cents on the week. The percentage rise in the spot market last week was fully reflected in the premiums. **********One major reason for the popularity of the small silver bars and wafers, which carry prices that vary according to size, fineness and the name of the refiner, was offered by Humayun Saeed, a vice president of E.F. Hutton & Company and manager of its Dubai branch in the United Arab Emirates. **********''Interest rates and inflation rates certainly govern precious metals prices worldwide,'' Mr. Saeed said. ''But in Dubai, which is the precious metals market for the Mideast and large areas of Asia and Africa, the market is often influenced by other factors as well.  A leading factor to us is how much silver is arriving from India, a very important source of the metal. This flow depends on world prices. When silver fell below $10, the flow dried up.'' **********Asked about the possible impact of resumed sales of silver from the United States Treasury, Mr. Saeed said: ''The Treasury has 139.5 million ounces left and Congress has authorized the sale of 105 million of it over the next three years. Well, these auctions should help raise the prices, just as the former sales of gold by the Treasury and International Monetary Fund raised that metal's price in past years.'' **********Why?  ''Such sales enable big buyers to acquire metal economically and easily. Suppose the Treasury auctions a million ounces of silver at a time. That, at today's prices, is $10 million, a piddling sum in the Dubai market. Where else can one buy so much silver at one time?  Even if one has to pay a premium at such sales, it is still more economical than having to make many deals. As soon as word spreads that one is buying heavily the price would become dearer and dearer.'' **********Paul Sarnoff, research director at Rudolf Wolff Commodity Brokers Inc., and a steadfast silver bull, agreed, adding: ''In the 1960's, our Government supplied the silver users with almost 2 billion ounces of metal at an average price of $1.69 an ounce. The photographic and electronics industries got a great bargain as a result. The question today in the market is where will the country get silver after the rest of the metal is sold. After all, we only produce about half the silver we use each year from mines and scrap. The rest must be imported for both industry and defense needs.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/25/world.print_headline: 45 LIBYA INCIDENTS REPORTED BY NAVY; News conference excerpts, page A10.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/25/world.body_text: **********The commander of the Sixth Fleet said today that American fighters intercepted Libyan aircraft on 45 occasions during manuevers last week, but had not fired on them until two Libyan SU-22's fired at two Navy F-14's. **********The commander of the fleet, Vice Adm. William H. Rowden, also said at a news conference aboard the U.S.S. Nimitz, that the air battle Wednesday that resulted in the shooting down of the two Libyan airplanes took place slightly outside a ''designated'' area where the United States had said manuevers were taking place, but still well within international waters. The Nimitz is anchored about seven miles from here in the Bay of Naples below Mount Vesuvius. **********The United States has said the two Soviet-built SU-22 fighters were shot down by F-14 Tomcats from the Nimitz over an area of the Gulf of Sidra that is claimed by Libya but is considered by the United States to be international waters. Libya conceded yesterday that its planes fired first in the incident, but still contends that eight American jets attacked its planes, and that one American jet was shot down. **********Comdr. Henry M. Kleemann, commanding officer of the squadron that brought down the Libyan jets and pilot of the first of two F-14's to engage them, said the two SU-22's were approaching head on and he was beginning a turn when he saw one of the Libyan jets fire a missile from about 1,000 feet away. **********''I decided we had been fired upon and they were likely to do it again,'' said the pilot, who had flown in the Vietnam War. He illustrated his account of the battle with wooden models of F-14's and a chart showing the spiraling maneuvers by which he turned to attack one of the Libyan planes from the rear so that its jet exhaust would attract his Sidewinder heat-seeking missile. **********''There was no chance that I was not going to pull the trigger'' Commander Kleemann said. ''It did go through my mind that it would cause a ruckus.'' His superior officers said he had acted according to procedures laid down for American airmen under fire and had not needed prior approval of his action. **********Sixth Fleet commanders said all their aircraft had returned to the Nimitz. They were not willing, however, to pinpoint the exact position where the Libyan planes were brought down. **********Admiral Rowden, while describing the maneuvers as routine and ''low risk'' made clear that they were intended to counter Libya's eightyear-old claim to sovereignty over the Gulf of Sidra, saying the exercises were designed ''as a demonstration of our ability to employ freedom of navigation in international waters.'' News Conference on Carrier **********Reporters were taken aboard the Nimitz, a 1,092-foot-long nuclearpowered carrier, after it anchored today in the Bay of Naples. The holding of a news conference was regarded as a departure from the Sixth Fleet's normally more reticent information policy. The pilots involved in the air battle on Aug. 19 were present, along with other officers, but their superiors frequently cut short impromptu comments. **********Admiral Rowden said shipping and aircraft in the Gulf of Sidra area had been alerted on Aug. 12th and 14th that the exercises, involving missiles fired at remote-controlled drones, would take place in a ''designated area whose coordinates were published in notices to airmen and navigators.'' **********Some Libyan aircraft flying toward this area were apparently intercepted by American aircraft far closer to the Libyan coast than has hitherto been disclosed. Last week, the Defense Department said that numerous Libyan aircraft had been intercepted, but until today it had never given an exact figure. **********''About the closest we came in any instances would have been 25 miles to their coast,'' said Rear Adm. James E. Service, commander of the Sixth Fleet's battle force, who commanded last week's exercise from the Nimitz. Previous accounts of the dogfight by American officials have concentrated on the downing of the two Soviet-made planes, which, the Pentagon has said, occurred about 60 miles from the Libyan coast, and within the designated area. Outside 'Designated' Area **********Admiral Service and Admiral Rowden insisted today that all the interceptions took place over international waters and within international airspace. Asked, however, whether the two Libyan planes were brought down within the ''designated'' area of the maneuvers, Admiral Rowden replied: ''We do not think so. We think it took place slightly to the south.'' **********This would place the incident well within what the United States contends are international waters and airspace, and also within the area claimed by Libya. Only six Libyan aircraft penetrated the designated area, the Sixth Fleet commanders said, but, apart from the two SU-22's, withdrew without opening fire when intercepted. **********''Designation'' of an area in notices to mariners and airmen was, the naval officers said, only an advisory procedure. The purpose of American air patrols outside the designated area was to prevent other vessels or aircraft from straying into it. **********Admiral Rowden said Libya had radioed a protest about the maneuvers to the Nimitz on Aug. 19th after the SU-22's were shot down. The protest, he asserted, did not refer to the dogfight. **********Speaking of the reaction among the 6,000 men on the Nimitz to the air battles, the admiral said there was ''no great jubilation'' but ''an extreme degree'' of professional pride.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/27/busin.body_text: **********Moody's Investors Service Inc., a major bond rating service, said it had lowered its rating on the F.W. Woolworth Company's senior debt to Baa from A. Moody's ratings range from AAA, considered the highest quality, to C, considered the highest risk. Baa is at the low end of what is considered investment grade. **********Moody's said the adjustment was the result of continued weak operating results by the retailer, especially by its Woolco division.  In the second quarter, Woolworth had net income of $15 million, or 49 cents a share, but the quarter included two one-time credits totaling $29 million. For the first six months of 1981, earnings were $9 million, or 26 cents a share, compared with $27 million, or 85 cents a share, in the corresponding 1980 period, which also included a $20 million one-time tax refund.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/17/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Bell System Brightening Ad Pages
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/17/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Bell System Brightening Ad Pages
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/17/busin.body_text: **********BY next year, if you're living in the right town, your fingers will find much more colorful scenery as they journey through the Yellow Pages. **********That's because the Bell System, having tested the concept, is now set to include four-color advertising amid the traditional black-onyellow fields of yore. **********''It's a new dimension in a proven medium,'' said S. Ross Brown, division manager, financial and market planning of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********And it is not only a proven medium, as he said, it's also booming.  Edward Hancharik, director of directory marketing, noted that the Bell System Yellow Pages, which had $678 million in revenues in 1970, went over $1 billion in 1975 and by last year had more than doubled to $2.1 billion. **********The idea of the color is to allow both national and local advertisers to give their regular listings more impact. Every business gets one free listing in the Yellow Pages and in the regular white pages, so the A.T.& T. crowd must come up with clever ideas to induce more spending. **********Possible ideas suggested by Mr. Brown were a two-page spread from Budget Rent A Car - a map of the area showing Budget locations, or local auditoriums or stadiums that would use the pages to print seating diagrams. **********To help with the latest effort, A.T.& T., after considering 10 companies, has signed up with Media Networks Inc., a subsidiary of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, to sell and to print the color advertising. **********That, of course, is right up Media Network's alley. For the last 13 years it has been doing the same thing for some of the nation's top magazine publishers - bringing together groups of four advertisers interested in advertising in the same market in the same select group of magazines; printing up ''signatures,'' and delivering them to the various magazines' printing plants. **********''The goal of color is to make Yellow Pages work better,'' said Peter O. Price, president of Media Network, which had revenues of $50 million in 1980. It has a sales force of 125 working from 30 offices. **********The color ads in phone directories, which will all be published together and will not carry individual advertiser's listings, will probably use cross-references pointing the users to the listings and the listings to the color ads. **********Since the directories are reprinted annually, ads will have to be created to last a year. The advertising rates will be based on a $20 cost per thousand and paying by the month - traditional for Yellow Pages - will be acceptable. **********A.T.& T. is starting with five markets this year and hopes to be in 40 or 50 by 1983. Denver will be first with its directory due out in October, followed by Atlanta in December, Chicago and Boston in January, and Manhattan - the core of the Big Apple - next March.  Total circulation will be about 5.7 million. **********The huge communications company began testing the concept two and a half years ago by going to ad agencies and asking them for four-color ads to be run for free. Some 24 pages were run in 7,500 copies of the Yellow Pages in Queens and Syracuse. Flags on the covers said, ''See color page section.'' **********Three months after distribution, W.R. Simmons, the research company, checked around and found that, among those consumers who got the color ads, some 17 percent could remember the advertisers without prompting and 35 percent said they had read the color pages within the last three months. **********Tests in 10 other markets came up with similar results.  The advantage to advertisers is that people who turn to them generally have made up their minds to buy. A.T.& T. distributed 165 million directories last year (both Yellow Pages and white), which probably account for 80 percent of those in the country, since the Bell System operates 80 percent of the telephones. Of Bell's approximately 2,500 directories, only 40 are all Yellow Pages. The rest are combinations.
