https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/02/busin.main_headline: Commodities; Sugar Bill Called Aid To Fructose
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/02/busin.print_headline: Commodities; Sugar Bill Called Aid To Fructose
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/02/busin.body_text: **********IN a bizarre turn of events, domestic beet and cane sugar producers are expected to attain a hard-fought legislative victory in Washington this week that will only help their chief competitors - the makers of corn-based sweeteners - gain an even greater share of the market. **********In fact, the corn sweetener industry has been euphoric over the campaign by the sugar cane and beet growers to raise Federal subsidies for their product, as well as increase the import levies on foreign sugar. **********''The corn-processing people I've talked to just can't believe their luck and will not until this Wednesday, when Senate and House conferees are expected to reconcile the subsidies legislation,'' said Nauman Barakat, sugar specialist in the commodity department of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, in an interview yesterday. **********''Given the record corn crop and resultant depressed prices, the 'victory' by the sucrose industry couldn't come at a better time'' for the makers of corn-based sweeteners, he added. **********By definition, what is commonly known as sugar is actually sucrose. The sucrose from cane and beets is indistinguishable. The sweetener that is produced from corn is fructose and is referred to in the trade as H.F.C.S. -high fructose corn sweetener. This fructose comes in varying strengths. Currently, 55 percent fructose is popular, gradually replacing the ''first generation'' 42 percent strength.  The remainder is dextrose. **********Because the high fructose corn sweetener comes in liquid form, it is eminently suited for use by soft drink makers, the leading consumer of all sweeteners in the nation, and by the canning, baking and other sectors of the food industry. **********Indeed, a special report on the sweetener industry by Paine Webber Jackson & Curtis noted that the goal of the corn processors was to raise their share of the domestic sweetener market to nearly 4 million tons, or 50 percent, of the total market in 1985 from roughly 2.7 million tons, or 30 percent, currently. Many in the trade hold that the impending higher sugar subsidies could bring this goal much nearer. **********What is expected to happen in Washington this Wednesday, Mr.  Barakat of Smith Barney said, is that the House of Representatives, which rejected a bill to raise the subsidy floor under domestic sugar prices to 19.6 cents a pound from 15 cents, will consider a Senate measure that set a subsidy floor of 18 cents. It is widely expected in the sugar trade that the final version will be a minimum price of 16.5 cents a pound. **********Initially, the White House was opposed to raising the sugar subsidy, despite the pleas of sugar producers that their costs were soaring and that they faced economic ruin. The Administration feared higher sugar prices would raise food prices generally and retard its battle against inflation. But President Reagan turned neutral in an effort to win the votes of Democratic members of Congress from sugar-producing states for his tax and budget bills last summer. **********''Assuming it is 16.5 cents,'' Mr. Barakat said, ''we then added 2.5 cents a pound for interest and storage-transport costs, and we get a basic market value of 19 cents. Add the refining costs, which vary from plant to plant, and we can expect a base price of between 21 and 25 cents a pound at the refiner's gate.'' **********By comparison, corn processors can produce 55 percent fructose at a cost of between 12 and 15 cents a pound, because they usually recover 40 to 50 percent of the highly complex and expensive manufacturing cost by selling corn byproducts such as oil and the residue mash as livestock feed or convert it into alcohol. **********Meanwhile, it is also expected that import fees on foreign sugar - 2.81 cents a pound - and duties - .0615 cent a pound - would be raised to further protect American sugar cane and beet growers. Last week, world raw (unrefined) sugar prices were quoted at about 12 cents a pound on the docks in New York. This is below the cost of production even in the poorest lands because it takes large amounts of energy to convert cane into sugar and transport it to world markets. **********''This is another mistake the domestic sugar people have made,'' Mr. Barakat said, adding: ''The poor cane-producing countries will sell as much as they can, even if it entails losses, because they desperately need hard currencies to pay for oil and other things. As for the wealthier sugar beet producing countries, notably France and West Germany, they too will unload as much as they can without regard to loss.'' **********Most farmers in Common Market countries receive high subsidies from their governments, which encourage the output of sugar beets and other farm products. In order to get rid of these burdensome surpluses, usually through exporting them, Common Market members often agree to sustain large losses, which the European Economic Community makes good with payments from its special funds. The E.E.C.'s beet sugar exports will account for about 30 percent of global sugar this year. **********''So the American sugar producers will therefore bolster their two major competitors, the foreign sugar exporters and the domestic corn sweetener industry,'' Mr. Barakat said. **********As for the fundamental global supply-demand situation, sugar market analysts expect total cane and beet output to climb by 6 mllion metric tons, to almost 93 million, in the statistical year that began last Sept. 1, from the previous season, while world consumption should rise about 3 million tons, to 92 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/24/busin.body_text: **********With a survival plan coming into place and the demand for tractors apparently rising, Massey-Ferguson is recalling workers who have been laid off for months at United States and Canadian factories. **********Peter Lowry, Massey's general corporate affairs manager, said today that the first 215 of the 600 production workers at the tractor factory in Des Moines, closed since last Aug. 1, would return to their jobs on Feb. 2 to resume production of four-wheel-drive tractors, the biggest model manufactured by Massey-Ferguson. **********Mr. Lowry said that some of the 1,150 production workers at Massey's Detroit factory, where two-wheel drive tractors are manufactured, would be recalled in March. The company has 5,000 United States employees, most of them white-collar workers. **********Mr. Lowry said that sales of farm tractors in North America had increased 26 percent in November and December for Massey and other manufacturers compared with the same period in 1979. 3,300 Recalled in Canada **********About 3,300 production employees in Canada have been recalled since last month to plants that make combines, other farm equipment and components for Massey plants outside Canada. An additional 2,500 production workers at plants in Toronto and Brantford, Ontario, are still laid off. **********The recalls coincide with the announcement last week of a plan to refinance $720 million (Canadian) of Massey-Ferguson's $2.4 billion in total debt, much of it short term. Under the plan, the company's banks have agreed in principle to swap payment of $280 million in interest due in coming months for 37 million common shares of new Massey stock, more than twice the 18.28 million shares outstanding. **********The remainder of the refinancing involves the issuing of additional shares of stock, giving the banks eventual control of about twothirds of the company's stock, and the injection of $200 million in new cash by outside investors now being sought by Massey-Ferguson. The national and Ontario governments are being asked to guarantee 75 percent of the $200 million (Canadian) investment in preferred stock. **********''While Massey-Ferguson is still a risk, it's certainly a better risk than two months ago,'' said David Schulman, an analyst with Geoffrion Leclerc Inc. of Montreal. He noted that Massey stock was currently trading on the Toronto Stock Exchange at $5.50 (Canadian) a share, up from $4.05 late last year. The Canadian dollar is worth about 84 cents in United States currency. **********The continuing search for the $200 million investment has turned up the names of Maurice F. Strong, who has held a number of high corporate and government posts, and the Campeau Corporation, an Ottawa real estate developer involved last year in a controversial and unsuccessful attempt to take over Royal Trustco, Canada's largest trust company. Giant Tractor Maker **********Mr. Strong has said that it would be a challenge to try to turn Massey around. W.J. Carroll, Campeau's executive vice president for finance, said Campeau discussed an investment in Massey but then decided not to pursue the matter. Massey is the world's largest tractor manufacturer. It ranks No. 3, after the International Harvester Company and Deere & Company, in farm equipment. **********The $720 million in debt to be refinanced is the most onerous part of Massey's total debt, analysts say, because most of it is short term at high interest rates. The servicing of this debt is expected to be a major part of the $100 million that Massey says it expects to lose in the fiscal quarter ending Jan. 31. The company lost $225.2 million in the 1980 fiscal year, ended Oct. 31, after earning $37 million in 1979. **********Massey's troubles stem from a wave of expansion that took place in the 1960's and 1970's and was financed largely with bank loans.  Though the management that took over in 1978 sold some plants and reduced worldwide employment to 42,000 from 69,000, the company was hit hard by the farm equipment slump last year that coincided with peak interest rates. **********In addition to the $280 million in forgiven interest payments and the $200 million private investment, the company's major lender, the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, will convert $100 million (Canadian) of Massey's debt into the company's convertible preferred shares and also will buy $50 million of those shares. **********In addition, British lenders have agreed to guarantee an issue of $90 million of convertible preferred shares.

Two other embassy employees face similar charges. **********The United States immediately filed a protest. **********A spokesman for the Managua Judiciary Processing Department said the marine, identified as Alejandro Mancheca, was arrested Thursday on complaints filed by two Nicaraguans. Warrants were issued for the arrest of Francisco Chapas and Richard Thompson. **********The complaints say that the marine robbed a woman of $230, and that he and the two others used their car to chase a man on the outskirts of Managua and beat him. The police said that the marine had been arrested at the scene but that the others had fled. ---- **********WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UPI) - Under Secretary of State Walter J.  Stoessel Jr. summoned the Nicaraguan Ambassador, Arturo Cruz, to the State Department today to protest the jailing of the marine and what he called ''the Nicaraguan Government's total disregard for international law,'' a spokesman, Joseph Reap, said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/29/busin.body_text: **********The House today overwhelmingly passed a compromise bill that sets guidelines for mergers and acquisitions to rescue financially troubled thrift institutions. The bill, approved by a vote of 371 to 46, now goes to the Senate, where its future is in doubt. **********Representative Fernand J. St Germain, a Rhode Island Democrat who is chairman of the House Banking Committee, appeased some opponents by pledging to dump the entire bill if the Senate tried to change it. The opponents had argued that the Senate might try to attach various amendments. **********The temporary legislation would expire Sept. 30, 1982, but all actions taken while the act is in effect would remain valid after that. **********The aim of the Administration-backed House bill is to give emergency assistance to failing mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations. **********It would let the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, when appointed receiver for a closed thrift institution with assets of more than $2 billion, sell the assets to a subsidary of an out-ofstate bank or holding company. But the transaction would be subject to state bank-branching laws in the state where the failed institution is situated. **********The bill also would establish priorities for which potential buyer to select. The first priority would go to institutions that a state allows to operate in the same area as the failed bank, the second to other institutions in the same state, the third to institutions in adjacent states and the fourth to all other instititions. **********The Independent Bankers Association and the Conference of State Bank Supervisors had criticized an earlier version of the bill but gave their last-minute endorsement after conferring privately with Mr. St Germain and other committee members.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/world.body_text: **********Within hours of becoming chairman of a key subcommittee, Senator Jesse Helms, a severe critic of President Carter's Latin American policies, held a hearing today on resuming military aid to El Salvador. **********The North Carolina Republican said the meeting of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs would be the first in a series of hearings ''to review all our policies toward Latin America.'' **********Congressional sources said Administration witnesses at the private meeting today, including State Department, Pentagon and Central Intelligence Agency officials, consulted the subcommittee about partly lifting the ban that President Carter imposed last month on military sales to El Salvador. **********Legislative aides said that subcommittee members at the meeting agreed to the leasing of six helicopters to El Salvador's armed forces. In addition to Mr. Helms, the participants - all Republicans -were Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum of Kansas, and Senator Larry Pressler of South Dakota. **********The suspension of $5 million in United States military aid to El Salvador followed the deaths of four American missionaries in the Central American nation, where more than 9,000 people were killed last year. **********A Presidential mission that visited El Salvador after the killings told Mr. Carter there was no evidence the Salvadoran military command was responsible. But the group said lower-level security forces might have been implicated. **********On the basis of this report and a Salvadoran Government pledge to investigate the murders, the President resumed $20 million in suspended economic aid, but did not resume the military aid. **********Two American labor union officials, Michael P. Hammer of Potomac, Md., and Mark David Pearlman of Seattle, were killed in El Salvador Saturday night. **********Jody Powell, the White House spokesman, said today that President Carter felt ''a sense of loss and outrage'' over latest the deaths.  He said that the American Government had ''no basis for knowing the identity of the murderers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/14/busin.main_headline: HONG KONG INVESTOR SHOWS NEW POWER OF LOCAL CHINESE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; HONG KONG INVESTOR SHOWS NEW POWER OF LOCAL CHINESE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/14/busin.body_text: **********When the chairmanship of Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. passed quietly into the hands of Li Ka Shing, a powerful developer, on Jan. 1, it was one more sign that local Chinese investors, many with official connections to the Chinese Communists, are challenging the British for control of Hong Kong's economy. **********''What you have here is a new visibility for Chinese money and Chinese control of publicly controlled companies in Hong Kong,'' said William R.A. Wyllie, the ousted British chairman of Hutchison Whampoa, a major trading and industrial conglomerate based here.  ''The real wealth in this colony has been in Chinese hands. But they've always kept a low profile until just recently.'' **********Mr. Li, the 52-year-old chairman of Cheung Kong Holdings Ltd., had acquired a controlling interest in the British holding company over the previous 15 months, but officially took charge this month. Cheung Kong has a market capitalization of about $2 billion and is projecting 1980 profits of about $200 million. **********The core of Cheung Kong's activities is property development, one of the most lucrative fields in the 400-square-mile British colony where commercial rents typically are twice those of midtown Manhattan. 'A One-Man Organization' **********''It is very much a one-man organization in the sense that one man controls it,'' said George C. Magnus, executive director of Cheung Kong. ''It is kept extremely small and moves extremely fast. Because we know which way we want to go, we don't have to waste time with committees and all that.'' **********Mr. Li, a native of southern China's Chiu Chow region, seems to epitomize the newly aggressive Chinese property and shipping executives who operate out of this British enclave. **********Although one of the richest and most powerful men in Hong Kong, Mr. Li has a passion for keeping out of the public eye. He has not granted a press interview since claiming the chairmanship of Hutchison Whampoa, saying only through an aide: ''All of what I should say I already have said.'' **********Associates say that Mr. Li was sent by his family to Hong Kong in 1940 to escape the Japanese invasion of China, and that he had originally hoped to become a scholar. But by 1950, he had opened a factory producing plastic flowers, toys and household items, and, in 1958, expanded into real estate. **********The purchase of a controlling stake in Hutchison Whampoa represented a major expansion of Mr. Li's influence. The company engages in general trading, quarrying, ship repair and a variety of other fields in Britain, Australia, Malaysia, Singapore and the Philippines. Expanding on Other Fronts **********Cheung Kong is also expanding on other fronts. Mr. Li is using his considerable profits to diversify from residential and commercialproperty development into two major cement plant deals. And several other companies, including the most powerful British holding company in the colony, Jardine Matheson and Company, have reportedly been considered by Mr. Li as possible takeover targets. **********His success is partially attributable to business connections that allow him to bridge the gulf between established British companies and a China bent on acquiring modern technology and management skills. **********Mr. Li sits on the board of directors of the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank, which recently purchased a controlling interest in the Marine Midland Bank in New York State, and derives much of his support from the Hongkong bank. When he staged his first assault on Hutchison Whampoa in October 1979, for example, he was able to purchase a 22 percent block of the company's stock from the bank on favorable terms. **********At the same time, Mr. Li is one of a handful of Hong Kong Chinese named to the China International Trust and Investment Corporation, an agency of the Chinese Government established in July 1979 to encourage foreign investment. **********Although Mr. Li denies that he is acting as an agent for Peking, the so-called China connection is evident in many of his major deals.  Links to Chinese Government **********Together with the Kiu Kwong Investment Company, a Chinesecontrolled company, Mr. Li formed Yee Pang Realty Ltd., which plans to build several 30-story apartment blocks here as part of a $60 million redevelopment project. **********He was also instrumental in setting up what has been described as China's largest outside investment since 1949, a $200 million cement plant for Hong Kong that is to be completed in 1982. Kaiser Cement of California will own 40 percent of the new company, to be called China Cement (Hong Kong), with the remainder owned by a consortium led by Cheung Kong. The Kiu Yip Investment Corporation, another Chinesecontrolled concern, will have a 20 percent stake in the consortium. **********Business associates and competitors alike say that a dominant factor in Mr. Li's success is his own personal business acumen. Mr.  Magnus calls him ''the most amazing businessman I've ever met,'' with a thirst for hard work, a fast mind for figures and a near photographic memory. Even Mr. Wyllie, who was displaced by Mr. Li, calls the Cheung Kong chairman ''a brilliant operator and entrepreneur.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/08/busin.body_text: **********With the new model year barely under way, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would offer rebates of $400 to $700 to increase sales of its small cars. **********The Ford rebate tended to mute the effect of its recently announced 4.8 percent average increase in the prices of its 1982 models, although some of the models to which the rebates apply had not been increased in price. Ford reported a 24.1 percent increase in auto sales in September over 1980. **********Ford's action, following purchase incentives offered by Chrysler and General Motors, was seen by analysts as yet another indication that sales of the just-introduced 1982 models are soft. **********Range of Prices **********Ford said it would offer rebates ranging from $400 to $700 on its subcompact Ford Escort and Mercury Lynx cars, their sporty derivatives, the EXP and LN7 and the compact Mustang and Capri. The prices for the basic versions of these models range from $5,518 to $8,308. **********The company said the program would run from Oct. 8 through Nov. 22 and would affect cars ordered or delivered during the rebate period.  Earlier, the Chrysler Corporation said that it would undersell both Ford and the General Motors Corporation on its Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon and ''K''-car models by holding 1982 prices at 1981 levels. Loan Discount Restored **********General Motors, which had announced a 5.8 percent price increase for most 1982 models, responded by restoring its loan discount program, which offers car loans at a 13.8 percent interest rate. That program is now scheduled to run through Nov. 11. The American Motors Corporation has cut the price of some of its Jeep and Renault models by 10 percent through Nov. 30. **********''There's no question it's early in the model year to do this,'' said Gordon MacKenzie, a Ford vice president. ''But the market is not as strong as we would like to see it, so we're attempting to help the people who need a new car but don't have the down payment or who can't handle the high interest rates.'' **********Auto industry analysts said the early application of rebates was an acknowledgement that consumers are resisting the higher price tags on 1982 models. Market Termed 'Abysmal' **********''It's fairly clear that the market is abysmal,'' said Harvey Heinbach, an analyst with Merrill Lynch. He said the Ford and G.M.  price cuts and sales incentives would pose special problems for Chrysler, the weakest of the Big Three domestic car makers. **********''They held down those p rices figuring they could pick up some market share,'' Mr. Heinbach added. ''Now tha t the others have acted,they may not pick up any share at all, but th ey'll still be stuck with the lower prices.'' **********Analysts also said the Ford and Chrysler price actions make General Motors' small cars the most expensive of the comparable domestics by several hundred dollars. ''The fact that they put the 13.8 percent back on for the 'X' and 'J' cars is a clue to the way they're reading the market,'' said David Healy of Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''I wouldn't be surprised to see them do rebates or a contest if their share starts to slip.'' Waiting for More Cuts **********General Motors has been the most reluctant of the auto companies to give price concessions, arguing that each rebate program conditions more prospective buyers to wait until a further concession is offered. **********In a recent interview, Howard Kehrl, G.M. vice chairman, said, ''We don't want people to think we have a continuous sale, that's not healthy.'' **********Ford's statement said that its rebates would save buyers more than would be gained by G.M.'s interest rate subsidy. It said the 13.8 percent rate on a typical ''J'' car would result in a saving of about $360 during the course of a 45-month loan. It is offering a $400 rebate on the Escort. **********However, the company said its dealers were expected to participate in the rebates, which some dealers had refused to do. The dealer participation is intended to range from $125 of a $400 rebate to $275 of a $700 rebate. **********In past rebate programs, some dealers have said they reduce the size of the discount from the list price offered to customers by the amount of their participation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/world.main_headline: NAMIBIA REBELS IN ANGOLA TRAIN 10,000 CHIDREN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/world.print_headline: NAMIBIA REBELS IN ANGOLA TRAIN 10,000 CHIDREN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/world.body_text: **********At a bend in the road, 40 boys and girls in blue shorts and red-peaked caps stand solemnly, holding handlettered placards in English reading, ''Reagan is a racist war monger but victory is certain,'' and ''Swapo condemns USA collaboration with South Africa and its puppets.'' **********On a signal from a tall girl with a drum, the group sings songs praising the guerrilla fighters of the South-West Africa People's Organization, or Swapo, promising quick and certain freedom for South-West Africa, also known as Namibia. **********This is the rehearsed introduction for visitors to a camp for 10,000 children on a former coffee plantation 200 miles southeast of Luanda, Angola's capital. Its residents have fled from the war in South-West Africa, and they are being trained to return as guerrillas. **********The camp's deputy director and principal of schools, Nangulu Mbumba, wears a khaki uniform and insists that none of the children have been summoned here from South-West Africa by the guerrilla organization. ''They are coming out because they are being forced,'' he said, ''not because we are calling them out.'' Unsmiling Robots **********Once inside, they become unsmiling robots, although those under 5 years of age giggle and wobble like children anywhere. Their older brothers and sisters snap to attention whenever visitors pass. They line roads rigidly, standing stock still alongside their tents. **********This green glade under tall palm trees is officially called the Namibia Health and Education Center. It may be the most singlemindedly political camp supported by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. No firm figure for costs is available, but a reasonable estimate is $2 million a year. **********The guerrilla organization is the United Nations' partner in the project. A United Nations official who asked that his name not be used explained: ''As long as there is no military activity, this is legitimate. We know of no guns here nor of any direct military training. This is a humanitarian venture for refugee children forced to leave their homes.'' **********Virtually none of the children here see their parents until they leave, at about 18, although there are two large camps of perhaps 25,000 women on nearby tracts. **********Sam Nujoma, president of the South-West African People's Organization, turns up as reporters arrive. He is neatly dressed in pressed suntans and trim goatee. Mr. Nujoma said, ''These kids here have left the country because the racist South African regime has introduced compulsory military training.'' South Africa has controlled the territory since soon after World War I. **********About 1,000 of the youngsters, still grim-faced, gather at the edge of a soccer field to hear Mr. Nujoma. Clenched Fists and Chants **********''They are ready to go to the front and fight against the racist South African troops and their puppets to insure the final victory,'' he says. **********The children shake clenched fists. Mr. Nujoma leads them in chanting: ''Victory will be! The struggle continues!'' The visitors are shown classrooms of corrugated iron, far sturdier than the thin tents used for sleeping. Mathematics and the teaching of English is demonstrated. ''Social studies'' is also on the curriculum but, according to Mr. Mbumba, this is where ''political education'' begins, and the reporters are not invited. **********In a field kitchen, a short girl with a large pole stirs a big pot of brown beans. Boiled into a porridge, this will be one of the two daily meals for those over five. Younger children get three meals. **********A group of neat cement-block buildings make a hospital. Two doctors, a Swedish woman and an East German man, run the tidy clinic, although the water they must boil is drawn ink-black from a nearby river. **********As the visitors leave, a contingent is brought from the adult women's camp. They are a chorus and imitate the breaking of chains.  They sing: ''We are determined that Namibia must be free.  Marxism-Leninism is our ideology, founded on scientific socialism.''

His victory in the June by-election is considered virtually certain. The main speculation centers on whether he will move to become a national political figure. ---- **********CALCUTTA, India, May 11 (Reuters) - More than 700 members of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party were arrested today in West Bengal during demonstrations against the Marxist state government, the police said.  The demonstrators were protesting what their party called indiscriminate arrests of party workers. The Marxists have accused Mrs. Gandhi's party of trying to seize power in the state.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/08/busin.main_headline: High Court Ends Stay in Oil Price Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/08/busin.print_headline: High Court Ends Stay in Oil Price Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/08/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Government moved a step closer today toward resolving the complex legal problems that have beset last January's termination of price controls on crude oil. **********The Supreme Court cleared the way for the Department of Energy to issue a final list of ''entitlements,'' pay-ments that oil refiners owe one another for price-controlled oil used during the four weeks before President Reagan lifted the controls. **********The Court, without explanation, lifted a stay it had granted three months ago to the Mobil Oil Corporation, which owes other refiners some $50 million under the entitlements program and has sued the Department of Energy on the ground that the program has been mismanaged. Stay Was Granted Sept. 3 **********The Supreme Court stay, granted to Mobil on Sept. 3 by Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr., had blocked the Energy Department from making the final calculations necessary to close its books on oil price controls. **********Today's action leaves the department free, in effect, to send out final bills under the entitlements program. But the department issued a statement today saying that it would not take any immediate action because challenges to other aspects of oil decontrol, which do not involve Mobil, remain unresolved. **********As a result, Mobil will continue to have the use of its $50 million for an indefinite period. Its own suit against the department is pending in the United States District Court in Albany. Mobil said today that ''we intend to pursue vigorously'' the substantive issues in that lawsuit, which were unaffected by the Supreme Court's action. **********The entitlement program was instituted in 1974 to give all refiners equal access to lower-cost, price-controlled crude oil. While price controls were in effect, there was more demand for controlled oil than could be met. An entitlement was, in effect, a license to refine price-controlled crude oil, with one entitlement needed for every barrel refined. Depended on Monthly Reports **********Refiners that, during a given month, used proportionately more price-controlled oil than the national average had to purchase entitlements from refiners who had used more expensive oil. The program depended for accuracy on monthly reports provided by the refiners to the Energy Department and Mobil has charged that lax management permitted some refiners to understate their use of pricecontrolled oil to the detriment of other refiners, such as Mobil, that filed accurate reports. **********At the same time that it lifted the stay today, the Court declined to hear Mobil's legal challenge to a ruling by the Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals, a special Federal court with jurisdiction over energy price controls. That court, in August, had refused to block the final entitlements list. The case was Mobil Oil v. Department of Energy, No. 81-499. **********Other Court action today included the following: Union Liability **********The Court agreed to decide whether a union that fails to process a grievance for a member who has been wrongfully discharged by an employer can be required to compensate the member for a portion of the wages lost. The Federal appeals courts are split over whether the employer in such a situation bears the sole liability for back pay, or whether a portion of the liability can be passed to the union when it is shown that intervention by the union would have averted some of the damage to the employee. **********The case, Bowen v. U.S. Postal Service, No. 81-525, is an appeal by a postal worker who was improperly dismissed in 1976. His union, the American Postal Workers Union, turned down his request for help, and a United States District Court in Virginia ordered the union to pay $30,000 of the $53,000 in back pay to which the worker was found entitled. **********However, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit overturned the damages assessed against the union, a ruling that left the worker able to collect less than half the back pay to which he was entitled. Asbestos Liability **********The Court declined to involve itself, at least at this stage, in the thousands of product liability lawsuits now pending against companies that manufactured and used asbestos during the decades before that substance's disease-causing properties became known. **********Most of the companies were covered by insurance during all or part of the time that their employees were exposed to asbestosis. The legal issue the Court declined to decide today involved how the liability should be assessed between the companies and their insurers, and among the various insurance companies that provided coverage at different times. **********The United States Courts of Appeals for the Fifth and Sixth Circuits, in the cases before the Supreme Court today, ruled that the ''event'' that gives rise to an insurance company's obligation to pay a claim is not the instant when the asbestos-related disease manifests itself, but rather the long period of exposure, years or decades, before any symptoms appear. The appeals courts held that all insurance companies that had provided coverage during the exposure period were liable in proportion to the number of years their policies were in force. **********Several insurance companies - the Insurance Company of North America, the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company and the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company - appealed those rulings, asking the Justices to decide that insurance liability only starts with the appearance of disease.  The lead case was INA v. Forty-Eight Insulations, No.  81-198. **********Product liability is traditionally an area of state rather than Federal law, in which the Supreme Court is typically reluctant to intervene. However, so many asbestos-related lawsuits are pending in courts around the country that the Justices will have numerous opportunities to become involved. The United States Court of Appeals here recently decided a similar case, taking a somewhat different approach to the question of apportioning liability among insurance companies. **********Asbestos produces several serious respiratory diseases, including lung cancer, asbestosis and mesothelioma, a cancer of the lining of the chest cavity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/25/busin.main_headline: New York Times March 1 1981 143 Lines P:810301; HOW SAUDI ARABIA MIXES WELFARE AND FREE ENTERPRISE; RIYADH, Saudi Arabia
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/25/busin.print_headline: New York Times March 1 1981 143 Lines P:810301; HOW SAUDI ARABIA MIXES WELFARE AND FREE ENTERPRISE; RIYADH, Saudi Arabia
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/25/busin.body_text: **********SAUDI ARABIA's economy is an odd hybrid, a melange of social welfare programs grafted onto a system dominated by free enterprise.  On one level, Saudi Arabia takes care of its own, But on another, the policy, which also includes severe economic discrimination against foreigners, leaves some Saudis fabulously wealthy, others moderately well-to-do and unskilled guest workers almost universally poor. **********In the sandy outskirts of this capital city, for example, high-walled compounds containing luxurious, often marble-clad villas, have sprung up. Downtown, Saudi families remain crammed into 20-year-old apartments above the city's shops. Tents and sheds dot the city's vast undeveloped blocks. **********The Saudi officials contend that their goal is to provide equality of opportunity, not equality of income or wealth. "When you're dealing with industry, you don't have a humanitarian a spect, you have to see the merits," said Fouad al-Farsi, Deputy M inister of Industry. "Since everybody qualifies, this is an o bjective policy." One reason for the disparities in wealth is the lack of a tax s ystem. In Saudi Arabia, there is no property tax to prevent the a ccumulation of vast estates and no income tax to slice sections off e ven enormous incomes. **********At least in part, the Saudi view of the economy stems from the Kingdom's strong religious ties. "It is God who blesses people with luck, brains or opportunity or it is he who blinds them to it," said Abdullah Alireza, Deputy Foreign Minister for Economic Affairs. **********For less talented Saudis, the Government pours tens of billions of riyals into subsidy programs so that the cost of basics will be brought to a level every Saudi can afford. A pound of sugar in a supermarket costs only 40 cents but a bottle of unsubsidized Perrier can run to several dollars. Electric power is one-twentieth the cost in the United States. **********Both Saudi and Western officials here argue that the plethora of Government programs and overall national prosperity have prevented the hardship conditions that produced revolution in countries like Iran. **********"Life is much better in Saudi Arabia than it was 10 years ago and better by far than 20 years ago," said one Western diplomat. "People are grateful to the Government and there aren't at present signs of dangerous dissatisfaction." **********Some of these benefits, such as food and telephone subsidies, also aid foreigners. Other benefits offered to Saudis, such as an apartment in the modern 20-story towers on the outskirts of Jidda and other cities or a job in a Government agency, are completely denied to non-Saudis. **********Foreigners have also been excluded from the principal avenue by which individual Saudis have acquired wealth - ownership of real estate. A Saudi can petition the Government for land and in most cases eventually be given without payment a plot worth hundreds of thousands of dollars. Foreigners are not permitted to own real estate. **********Until recently, real estate prices throughout the Kingdom were increasing at a torrid pace, providing instant windfalls for thousands of speculating Saudis. One Saudi, who pours coffee for the Interior Minister, lives in a half-million dollar house here because of real estate profits. **********said another, Abdul Sahin Saftah, a 32-year-old middle-level Government official who studied at Oklahoma State University, "It happens like a dream. One moment your're rich. **********To build, the Saudi Real Estate Development Fund will lend up to $100,000 for 25 years without interest with a 25 percent discount for early payment. Newly married Saudis receive a $5,000 Government dowry. **********Other Government programs abound. Free, unlimited education, including generous living allowances, is available to Saudis and 21,000 of them are now studying abroad, mostly at Government expense. **********A Saudi with an industrial project can apply for an interest-free loan to the development fund, which has already lent more than 500 enterprises an average of $4 million. In addition, for enterprises in which Saudis hold a substantial interest, the Government will provide leased land at nominal rentals, an exemption from customs duties for supplies, and a 10-year tax holiday. **********For development in industries favored by the Government, such as agriculture, the subsidies are even more generous. The Government will pay the entire air freight bills for bringing in cows, for example. **********Beyond real estate, entrepreneurial Saudis have made fortunes from their own businesses, particularly where foreign competition is restricted as in Government contracts, and, thanks again to Government regulations, from acting as local agent or partner for a foreign concern. Retail businesses must be Saudi-owned. **********Mindful of the talk of corruption and extravagance in Government spending, tighten the way money is spent and shift the economy from construction, which benefits relatively few Saudis, to more basic industry. Althought national income is running about $15,000 per person, household income has been only about a third, a fraction the rulers hope to increase. **********The ranks of the successful Saudis consist of both the longstanding leading families of Jidda where wealth is still concentrated and a group of newcomers to the ranks of the affluent, more widely dispersed in the kingdom. **********"Wealth is filtering down very nicely," said Abdulaziz Sulaiman, the scion of the man who was the Kingdom's first finance minister, as he sat in his elegant compound in Jidda. Mr. Sulaiman also noted that much of the poverty among Saudis is in rural areas, as a result of traditions and less developed Government services. **********For nonentrepreneurial Saudis, salaries at first glance do not seem high. A typical Government clerical worker, for example, would receive about $1,000 a month, substantially less than his American counterpart. But the absence of taxes, generous Government programs and the opportunities for private business profits change the calculations. The emphasis on hiring Saudis means that they are likely to be paid more and promoted faster than foreign counterparts. **********"We will have to pay a qualified Saudi more because he could get a better position with the Government," said Nabil Issa, general manager of AV Enterprises. **********The result is a good life for even the middle class. Servants - always foreign and often diminutive, dark Yemenis - are omnipresent.  Shiny new American cars, often with the factory sticker still in the window, clog the streets. Jet travel is widely enjoyed, particularly within the Kingdom as a result of generous subsidies. A dazzling array of goods are now available in this capital city. Electronics stores, which often feature video cassette players, are everywhere.  New luxury stores, like Hermes of Paris, open daily. **********The Saudi concern about the well-being of foreigners is far less evident. Guest workers who lose their jobs or misbehave are usually deported immediately. Those from the third world are paid little and live on less, since most send money back home. The more benevolent employers provide housing; otherwise the worker must fend for himself in the tumultuous housing markets. **********Abdul Kder, for example, is a 23-year-mold native of Eritrea, the embattled slice of the Horn of Africa. He came to Saudi Arabia looking for work and today drives for a transport company. He earns $469 a month and pays $156 a month in rent for a single room. **********But says Mr. Kder, "food is cheap."

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/busin.print_headline: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS; A DIM YEAR FOR AUTOS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/busin.body_text: **********Auto sales dropped 22.5 percent below last year's levels for mid-December, making 1981 a candidate for the Big Three's worst sales year in two decades. Huge layoffs in the industry prompted the United Autoworkers to schedule a meeting with General Motors and Ford in early January to consider renegotiating current labor contracts for wage concessions. **********Prices rose just 0.5 percent in November, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, promising that for the first time since 1978, this year's inflation rate may not top 10 percent. Orders for new durable goods increased 1.1 percent, after three consecutive months of declines, said the Commerce Department. **********Christmas retail sales rose, according to major stores around the nation, but the unexpectedly high volume reported in some cities was offset by widespread price discounts and promotions. **********Money market funds reported a net decrease of $1.4 billion in assets in the week ended Dec. 23, the first drop in 30 weeks. **********Unfairly low prices of steel imported from Belgium, Brazil, Rumania, and France may be damaging domestic steelmakers, said the International Trade Commission in a unanimous preliminary finding.  The domestic steel industry, plagued by declining orders and production, has been seeking Government help against imports. **********Economic sanctions against the Warsaw Government were announced by President Reagan, including suspending civil-aviation and fishing privileges, in addition to food shipments which had already been blocked. Western bankers are reportedly going to reject Poland's bid for $350 million to help meet a $500 million interest payment due on the country's debt to foreign bankers. The International Monetary Fund is still evaluating Poland's bid to join, which could give the nearly-bankrupt nation access to about $5 billion in fresh credit. **********Unsettled international conditions, particularly in Poland and Israel, cast a pall over the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average eased 2.38 during the week, to close Thursday at 873.38.  Meanwhile, the S.E.C. authorized trading in options on U.S. Treasury securities on three exchanges. Public trading in options on any form of fixed-income obligation has never been authorized before. **********Libya cut crude oil prices by up to $1.20 a barrel in an attempt to make its $37 a barrel high-grade oil more competitive on world markets. By contrast, Mexico raised gasoline prices 115 percent to stem subsidies to the state oil monopoly and discourage Americans from crossing the borders to fill up. **********Both Mobil and U.S. Steel were bitten by a Federal appeals court ruling on their competing bids for Marathon Oil. Mobil would be violating antitrust laws by acquiring Marathan and U.S. Steel would hold two illegal options, the court said. Nonetheless, U.S. Steel may be able to make a tender offer in a couple of weeks. **********Competitors of A.T.&T. pledged up to $2 million to lobby for a telecommunications bill that would set rules for A.T.&T.'s entry into unregulated businesses, such as equipment sales and computer-tocomputer data transmission.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/world.main_headline: SOME GUNFIRE ERUPTS IN LEBANON BUT THE CEASE-FIRE SEEMS TO BE HOLDING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/world.print_headline: SOME GUNFIRE ERUPTS IN LEBANON BUT THE CEASE-FIRE SEEMS TO BE HOLDING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/world.body_text: **********Despite occasional gunshots and a brief exchange of shelling late tonight at Zahle between Syrian forces and Christian militia units, a cease-fire ordered yesterday by President Elias Sarkis appeared to be holding. **********This morning, the International Committee of the Red Cross sent 11 ambulances and vans to Zahle, 30 miles east of Beirut, and evacuated about 20 people wounded in artillery duels by Syrians and Christians in the last week. **********Defense Minister Joseph Skaf, who is from Zahle, said that nearly 4,000 other wounded residents were being treated in clinics set up in wine cellars. Some of the wounded were being tended by French physicians who traveled to Zahle with the Red Cross convoy. Red Cross officials said that if the cease-fire held more evacuations might be carried out tomorrow. **********There was growing concern here tonight among Lebanese officials and Western diplomats over the durability of the cease-fire, the 18th since the crisis erupted a week ago. Syrians Bolster Artillery **********The officials noted that the Syrians, who were sent here five years ago by the Arab League to enforce a truce in the 1975-76 civil war, were reinforcing artillery positions around Zahle. ''The next 48 hours are going to be extremely critical,'' said a Western diplomat. **********Part of the general apprehension stemmed from the delay of President Sarkis and his Government to work out security arrangements to end the hostilities. **********President Sarkis talked today with Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan and then communicated with Syrian leaders in Damascus.  Apprehension over the cease-fire heightened tonight after reports that Israeli helicopter gunships had buzzed Palestinian positions south of Beirut, over Damur and down to the southern port of Sidon. **********The Syrians stress determination to get the Christian militiamen out of Zahle, a predominantly Christian town on the Beirut-Damascus highway. **********They charge that the Christians are turning Zahle into a strategic post connecting northern Lebanese areas controlled by Christians to parts of southern Lebanon held by other Christian forces. Syrians Want Control of Hills **********The Syrians insist on control of the hills over Zahle, a market town in a grape and vegetable area. They also say they want the Arab League force, made up of 22,000 Syrians, to command units of the Lebanese Army that might be sent to Zahle. The Syrians are insisting that the Arab force be in control of the Beirut-Damascus highway. **********There is growing perception among Western and Arab analysts that the Christians want the situation to become worse so United Nations peaekeeping troops could be brought in to replace the Syrians. **********The analysts feel that Syria, which spends $1 million a day to keep its soldiers in Lebanon, is unlikely to abandon that role.  The Syrians say they consider Bekaa Valley, east of Beirut, vital to their front with Israel. If Zahle is lost, according to the Syrians, the Christian militiamen would have an uninterrupted supply line from northern Lebanon to the Israeli border.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/busin.body_text: **********Interco Inc., a major maker of footwear, apparel and furniture, reported yesterday that net income for the fiscal fourth quarter was up 15.3 percent, to $38.5 million, or $2.36 a share, from $33.4 million, or $2.24 a share, for the comparable quarter the year before. **********Sales for the quarter were $630 million, up 23.8 percent from sales of $509 million for the similar quarter last year.  William L. Edwards, the chairman and chief executive, noted that the increases were registered despite softness in general retail operations, particularly in women's specialty stores. **********Income for the fiscal year was $124 million, up 16.2 percent from $106.7 million. Sales totaled $2.37 billion, up 18.5 percent from sales of $2 billion last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/world.main_headline: UNION LEADER ADVISES LOCALS; Walesa Acts After Talks Founder in Strike-Bound Southern City Over Ouster of Officials
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/world.print_headline: WORKERS IN POLAND ALERTED FOR SIT-INS IF ANY FORCE IS USED; UNION LEADER ADVISES LOCALS; Walesa Acts After Talks Founder in Strike-Bound Southern City Over Ouster of Officials
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/world.body_text: **********Poland's labor troubles took a turn for the worse today when the talks between the Government and strike leaders broke down in the southern province of Bielsko-Biala. The independent Solidarity trade union told its chapters to be ready to act if force were used to break the strike. **********Bielsko-Biala, close to the Czechoslovak border, is the only region where strikes continued after a weekend agreement between the Government and the union's national leadership. But the labor scene is tense in other areas where negotiations are under way. **********Spokesmen for the Bielsko-Biala local said they were unsure why a Government negotiating team that began talks yesterday had returned to Warsaw. The union spokesmen said it may have been because Prime Minister Jozef Pinkowski had refused to accept the resignation of the provincial Governor and his deputies. Union Demanded Aides' Dismissal **********The strikers demanded the dismissal of the officials, whom they accused of corruption, as the condition for ending their protest, now in its ninth day. **********In a speech made public yesterday, Stanislaw Kania, the Communist Party leader, lashed out against what he called political strikes, and it was thought that the Government could lose face before the public and Poland's allies if it bought labor peace by acceding to the union demands to dismiss provincial leaders. **********Lech Walesa, the national labor leader, who joined the Bielsko-Biala talks yesterday, sent messages to locals throughout the country, informing them of the impasse. The strike in Bielsko-Biala will continue, he said. **********"If a forceful attack is made on Bielsko and communications are broken," he told the locals, "Solidarity sit-ins should be organized. Only passive resistance should be used." **********The call for sit-ins by the union's 10 million members was construed as a warning to the Government not to rely on force. It also reflected the tensions in Bielsko-Biala, a textile manufacturing center of 125,00 people, south of Katowice. A twin city, it was formed in 1950 by the merger of the towns of Bielsko and Biala, on opposite sides of the Biala River, a tributary of the Vistula. **********A Bielsko-Biala union official, reached by telephone, said there was no sign of security forces massing or any other indication that a siege was being contemplated. **********Mr. Walesa also cautioned the union locals not to undertake any actions on the basis of telephoned instructions without his personal authorization. **********His appeal was followed by one from Zbigniew Bujak, the leader of the Warsaw union local, to factories and businesses in the capital, urging them to dis-seminate information about the situation and to prepare for sit-ins. **********The strike in Bielsko-Biala has stopped virtually all industrial production in the area, affecting 120 factories including an auto plant that makes the Polish Fiat. **********The labor controversy has been complicated by new government regulations on strike pay. They allow workers to get more than 50 percent of their back salaries only if they make up for lost production. They do not allow compensation for strikes that go beyond the union's statutory reasons. The union leaders in Bielsko-Biala said they rejected the rules. **********The provincial governor, Jozef Gabudek, and his three deputies offered their resignations yesterday. The three figured, along with others, in a 150-page report containing the union's accusations. **********Czeslaw Kotela, the Deputy Minister of Adminstration, Local Economy and Environmental Protection, who led the government negotiators in BielskoBiala, told the strikers that accusations of corruption would be investigated but that the Prime Minister wanted the matter examined "in conditions of law and order," not when emotions ran high. **********Other government teams were meeting with union leaders in Jelenia Gora, where the dismissal of local officials has also been demanded, and in Rzeszow, where farmers are pressing for their own independent union. The radio said today that the condition of hunger strikers in a church in Swidnica, fasting to support the farmers, was deteriorating and that three had been taken to the hospital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/busin.main_headline: FIRST PENN TO SETTLE BANK SUITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/busin.print_headline: FIRST PENN TO SETTLE BANK SUITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/busin.body_text: **********The First Pennsylvania Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $11.2 million in settlement of various shareholder suits, including 17 class actions, that were brought in opposition to terms of a rescue plan for a financially troubled banking subsidiary. **********First Penn, the largest banking corporation in Philadelphia and the 23d largest in the country, said it had agreed also to pay a maximum of $325,000 for the cost of administering the settlement **********In a separate development, the corporation announced that the Securities and Exchange Commission had opened a private investigation into its finances. **********In addition, George Butler, First Penn's chairman, said that he expected fourth-quarter operating losses of $46 million.  The suits were brought against the corporation, its subsidiary, the First Pennsylvania Bank, certain present and former officers and directors and the corporation's outside accountants and underwriters. Among the plaintiffs were individuals who had purchased First Penn shares from 1974 to early 1980. Some suits were filed following the announcement last April of a $1.5 billion rescue operation led by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Other suits involved stockholder class actions filed in 1976. **********Under the F.D.I.C. rescue plan, designed to keep the $9 billion banking organization from possible failure, aid was also provided by a group of 26 banks. Interest Rates Created Problem **********First Penn's losses arose from the sharp upsurge of interest rates last spring that left it with a huge portfolio of low-paying securities. **********A company spokesman, Bruce Crawley, said that the corporation did not admit any guilt in connection with the suits. He said the settlement was an effort ''to remove an element of uncertainty in the affairs of the corporation, save the expense of prolonged litigation and free management from the distraction and time required by a protracted defense.'' **********Mr. Crawley said that the S.E.C. investigation would look into First Pennsylvania's disclosures from January 1976 to the present; the corporation's record-keeping; its internal accounting controls, and possible trading in the corporation's common stock by ''persons in possession of material, nonpublic information.'' **********Mr. Butler said that First Penn had dismissed 270 employees and eliminated 75 positions through attrition since last October, saving the company $5.7 million annually in salaries. But he noted that a $31.5 million additional loan loss provision, $2.5 million in severance expenses, a $1.9 million real estate writedown and the settlement costs would add up to a $46 million fourth-quarter net loss. Special Meeting **********Following earlier postponement of First Penn's annual meeting, shareholders learned details of the rescue plan and how it would affect them at a special meeting last April. **********They were told that it would dilute the present ownership by more than half and prohibit payment of dividends for the next five years without specific approval of the F.D.I.C. Although steadied by the rescue operation, the banking organization continued to report losses last year. **********The suits against First Penn alleged violations of the Federal securities laws, including deficient public disclosures regarding the corporation's financial condition. As part of the settlement of one of the suits, the corporation agreed to revamp its board, as well as certain committees and procedures. **********First Penn said that the entire amount of the settlement will be charged against the corporation's fourth-quarter operating results.  The settlement is subject to approval by the United States District Court in Philadelphia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/15/world.main_headline: KEY STEP TO ACCORD IN HOSTAGE IMPASSE IS TAKEN IN TEHERAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/15/world.print_headline: KEY STEP TO ACCORD IN HOSTAGE IMPASSE IS TAKEN IN TEHERAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/15/world.body_text: **********The United States said today that the vote in the Iranian Parliament endorsing arbitration of claims over the hostage issue was ''apparently a step in the right direction'' toward ending the crisis, but cautioned that final agreement had not been reached. **********With time running out for the Carter Administration, there was a sense of anticipation in Washington that the next 24 to 48 hours would tell whether the 52 Americans would be freed before Ronald Reagan is sworn in as President on Tuesday. **********Officials were clearly more hopeful than at any other time in the 14 1/2-month-old crisis. But having endured so many disappointments in the past, they refused to predict a breakthrough in advance of definite word from Teheran that the Iranians had accepted the American proposals. The Americans have offered to return 73 percent of Iran's $9.5 billion in frozen assets in return for the release of the hostages, leaving a disputed $2.2 billion for eventual arbitration. **********Christopher Stays in Algiers **********Deputy Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher, the chief American negotiator, remained in Algiers, awaiting a message from Algerian intermediaries in Teheran on the Iranian decision. **********The public comments by Iranian authorities, as well as the action by the Parliament after a worrisome delay yesterday in approving the arbitration clause, were seen by Mr. Christopher and other officials as encouraging developments. **********''Our initial reaction to the Majlis resolution is to regard it as apparently a step in the right direction,'' John H. Trattner, the State Department spokesman, said after consulting by phone with Mr.  Christopher, ''if, as seems to be the case, the Iranian negotiating team feels that action is essential to their negotiating effort.'' The Majlis is the Iranian Parliament. **********Mr. Trattner said Mr. Christopher hoped that the Parliament's action would ''enable Iran to address the important differences that remain'' over resolving the crisis. **********American officials said they expected that the Iranians would inform the Algerians soon, perhaps as early as tomorrow morning, of their final decision. **********From the questions asked by Iran in recent days, some American officials have come to the conclusion that Iran is now ready to drop many of its previous demands and to accept the American proposals, sent two weeks ago, as the best that can be achieved. **********But this is only a hope, officials said, and the history of these negotiations has not supported optimistic predictions.  If the Iranians send an unconditional acceptance message, it would set in motion procedures in this country, Algeria and Iran that could produce the release of the hostages and the transfer of several billion dollars in Iranian assets by Sunday, officials said. **********But they added that if the Iranians introduce new proposals or otherwise alter the American plan, it could delay an agreement. Originally Asked for $24 Billion **********Iran insisted last month that before the hostages could be freed it had to be paid, in cash or guarantees, $14 billion to cover its frozen assets. It also asked for guarantees of $10 billion for the return of the property of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi. **********American officials now hope that Iran agrees with the American contention that only $9.5 billion in assets was frozen and that Iran can count on receiving only $7.3 billion of that total initially. It is also hoped that Iran will agree that it can seek return of the Shah's property only through the courts. Paul O'Dwyer, a New York lawyer who represents the Iranian Government, filed a suit in Federal Court in New York yesterday against members of the family of the Shah, seeking $36 million in what the suit said were assets belonging to Iran. **********But until Iran notifies the United States of its formal position, Mr. Christopher chooses to say that ''important differences'' remain.  The United States denied as ''totally untrue'' a Teheran radio commentary that said the United States had already deposited 70 percent of Iran's assets in an Algerian bank, pending conclusion of the deal. Officials said the radio had apparently picked up a report in the Sunday issue of The New York Times that said that the United States was willing to return more than 70 percent of the frozen assets in return for the hostage release. Hostages Would Go to Germany **********The mechanics of the actual exchange call on Algeria to take possession of some $5.5 billion in frozen assets from the United States and to release it to Iran as soon as the American hostages have been delivered to American custody, tentatively set for Ramstein Air Base in West Germany. **********''I'd like to state one principle in all this, which I think is obvious,'' Mr. Trattner said. ''The principle of simultaneity is going to be very important. There is not going to be any movement, any performance by either side on the basic exchange we are talking about until each side is absolutely certain of the other's performance.'' **********The Carter Administration is hoping that all the details can be agreed to before Mr. Reagan takes office. Officials said they were confident that Mr. Reagan would carry out any obligations agreed to by the Carter Administration.
