https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/07/busin.print_headline: NCC AND SIMPLICITY END MERGER TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/07/busin.body_text: **********NCC Energy Ltd. of London and the Simplicity Pattern Company, the nation's largest producer of sewing patterns, announced jointly yesterday that they had agreed to terminate plans for an earlier announced $85 million merger because of ''current circumstances.'' **********The two companies did not elaborate. **********However, the Bayswater Realty and Capital Corporation, a company headed by Carl C. Icahn, a New York financier, made an advertised offer earlier this week to buy 2.5 million Simplicity common shares at $11.50 a share. **********Mr. Icahn, the chairman and principal shareholder of Bayswater, already owns 1.8 million shares, or about 13 percent, of Simplicity's shares outstanding. He had opposed the Simplicity-NCC combination as not being in the best interest of the shareholders. **********E. Magnus Oppenheim, managing partner of E. Magnus Oppenheim & Company, investment counselors, said yesterday that it was likely that ''Simplicity's management may be able soon to recommend newer merger opportunities to its shareholders.'' **********The merger agreement, announced in early September, called for each outstanding share of NCC, which has oil, gas and mineral interests, to be converted to 0.252 share of Simplicity common for a total of about 8.2 million shares. **********The assets of the new holding company formed by the merger would have been about $250 million.  In their joint announcement yesterday, however, the two companies said they would continue an agreement calling for Simplicity shareholders to vote on a new board that would comprise five Simplicity nominees, four selected by NCC and one mutually agreedupon nominee. **********Simplicity sells its line of patterns through about 20,000 outlets in the United States and has about one-third of its total volume in foreign countries. The company's stock closed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at 9 5/8, down 1/2. PU COMPNEWS FOLOS

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/31/world.main_headline: SALVADOR OPPOSITION PLANS DIPLOMATIC DRIVE FOR NEW SUPPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/31/world.print_headline: SALVADOR OPPOSITION PLANS DIPLOMATIC DRIVE FOR NEW SUPPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/31/world.body_text: **********Cheered by their recognition as a ''representative political force'' by France and Mexico, El Salvador's guerrilla-led opposition groups are now planning a diplomatic offensive to rally support for their cause among other Western and third-world countries. **********An opposition spokesman said members of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, an alliance of leftist guerrilla and non-Marxist political groups, would travel to selected countries in Latin America, Western Europe and Africa as well as lobby among delegates attending the coming session of the United Nations General Assembly. **********''We're not looking for expressions of support from Nicaragua or Cuba or the Soviet Union,'' the spokesman said. ''We want to demonstrate that the Salvadoran conflict is not an East-West issue, despite what Washington claims. We want to show that a lot of nonsocialist countries sympathize with our cause.'' **********Opposition representatives traveled to Panama immediately after the French-Mexican declaration of support Friday and will soon visit Ecuador, Peru, Guyana and Brazil. Other representatives plan to meet with government officials in Austria, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Algeria, Zimbabwe, Kenya, Tanzania and Zambia. 'Protective Umbrella' **********''We hope that the Franco-Mexican statement will act as a sort of protective umbrella beneath which other countries can safely speak out,'' the opposition spokesman said. ''That's the importance of getting support from two countries that are so crucial to the United States.'' **********The opposition's immediate objective, according to its leaders, is to create international pressure on the Reagan Administration to recognize that a negotiated settlement of the Salvadoran conflict is the only alternative to more strife. To date, Washington has backed the Salvadoran military-civilian junta in its refusal to deal with the opposition and its rejection of outside mediation. **********''Unless there are negotiations, the war will go on,'' said Salvador Samayoa, a leader of one of five guerrilla groups that make up the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. ''The past few months have demonstrated that, even with enormous U.S. support, the Salvadoran armed forces have been unable to defeat us. On the contrary, we grow stronger by the day.'' **********The guerrillas withdrew to mountain strongholds after their unsuccessful ''final offensive'' in January. But they stepped up their attacks again in mid-July, concentrating on sabotaging energy supplies, railroads and bridges in a strategy that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. described last Friday as ''straight terrorism.'' U.S. Increases Aid to Junta **********The United States, which now has 46 military advisers in El Salvador, has gradually increased its weapons shipments to the country and has thrown its weight behind the junta's plan to hold elections for a constitutional assembly there in March. **********The opposition, which includes Social Democrats and dissident Christian Democrats as well as Marxists of various tendencies, says that no free elections can take place without prior negotiations and that it would boycott elections held under the junta's plan. **********The French-Mexican declaration echoed this position, asserting that ''a new internal order'' must be established and the military ''restructured'' before ''authentically free'' elections could be held. **********According to diplomatic sources, the initiative for a joint declaration came from Mexico in mid-June, although the original idea was that it should be followed immediately by a request for a United Nations Security Council debate on El Salvador. Disagreement Over Declaration **********But, when detailed negotiations began after a visit to Mexico City early this month by Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France, the two Governments reportedly found themselves in disagreement over the text of the declaration, with Mexico willing to recognize ''a state of belligerancy'' in El Salvador and France holding out for some reference in the statement to elections. **********Ten days ago, Guillermo Manuel Ungo, the president of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, flew to Paris for talks with French officials in the hope of persuading them to accept language that more closely reflected the opposition's views. **********According to opposition sources, the French Government argued for several days against the formula of recognizing the opposition alliance as a ''representative political force'' on the ground that such a move might establish a dangerous precedent in international law. But, after Mr. Ungo and his team reportedly threatened to leave Paris in protest, France accepted language that had been worked out with Mexico. **********''Mexico's position was that it would accept nothing that was not also acceptable to us,'' an opposition leader said, ''and it said that we could decide what was best for us.'' **********One result of the difficult negotiations preceding the French-Mexican declaration, however, is that a meeting of the United Nations Security Council on El Salvador seems unlikely to be called, at least for several weeks. **********''There are risks in having a Council debate,'' a key opposition leader said. ''The United States may pressure the Council to approve a resolution that we could not accept, so that would be a defeat.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.body_text: **********The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had approved a $6.98 million construction project to expand its trading floor capacity by 35 percent. **********The plan will appropriate what is now the visitors' gallery. A new facility will let visitors observe activity on the floor by closedcircuit television on a large screen, an Amex spokesman said.  The new trading space will contain room for four large trading posts and 140 new booths for member firms. Work is expected to begin this month and to be completed by the end of next year. **********The building plan was the result of a study by an 18-member committee appointed almost a year ago after the exchange and state officials abandoned attempts to find a home for the Amex in the new Battery Park City development. The committee had considered sites elsewhere in New York City, development of the property adjacent to the exchange and expansion within its building, which is at 86 Trinity Place. Suit Against Federal Agency **********The Amex also confirmed that it sued the Commodities Future Trading Commission Friday in Federal District Court in Manhattan in an effort to block the commission's pilot program for trading options on contracts for future delivery of certain commodities. The program, which is the first phase of a broader program to allow trading of options on the commodities themselves, is limited to seven exchanges that trade the futures contracts that will be covered by the options. **********A futures contract is an agreement to deliver or receive a certain commodity - an agricultural product, metal or even a financial instrument such as a Treasury bond - at a specific price and place at some future time. An option on a futures contract would give the purchaser the right to buy or refuse to buy a futures contract at a later date. **********The Amex, which currently trades stock opti ons, contends that the commission's program will give those exchange s involved an unfair head start in the new, potentially lucrative commodities options market. **********Amex hopes to trade gold and silver options and options on certain financial instruments such as United States Treasury bills, bonds and notes. Last Thursday, the exchange's board authorized creation of a new market for gold bullion coins. Pressure to Expand Facilities **********These new businesses, booming stock option trading and continued strong activity on the stock exchange are behind the Amex's need to expand its facilities. At one time the exchange threatened to move to New Jersey to obtain more space. That led to the unsuccessful negotiations for state aid that would have helped the exchange build a new headquarters in Battery City Park. **********This year is expected to be the third in a row in which more than one billion shares will be traded on the exchange. Stock option trading has grown from an average of 4,000 contracts a day in 1975, when it was introduced, to 126,000 contracts a day this year, an exchange spokesman said. **********The suit against the Commodities Futures Trading Commission is given little chance of success by outside analysts. But it is expected to draw attention in Congress to the Amex's concerns. Both the House and Senate agricultural committees must approve the agency's plan before it can go into effect. **********The plan limits the participating exchanges to just one option each. For example, the Commodity Exchange in New York, which currently trades both gold and silver futures, would have to select one or the other for option trading. The Exchange's Perspective **********From the Amex point of view, that is too much. ''If you look back at the history of competitive trading in futures, it has been fairly clear that the exchange that starts first develops liquidity and a dominant position,'' said Nathan Most, the executive in charge of new product development at the Amex. **********A lawyer on the commission's staff declined to comment on the lawsuit. Commodity lawyers said the key question might be whether the commission could reasonably conclude that it would be easier to oversee option trading on the futures exchanges, which it already regulates. If so, the commission's plan might be seen as a justifiable first step to a broader option trading program.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/12/busin.body_text: **********Following is a partial transcription of remarks by President Reagan to a group of supporters in the East Room of the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News: I came to pay tribute to you - the new superstars of American grass-roots politics. You represent a cross section of Americans from all backgrounds, different regions across this country. In fact you remind me very much of that one special-interest group that I mentioned on Inauguration Day, the one special-interest group that has been neglected and needs help - that is, we, the people. **********Now before you start feeling too good, let me warn you, you're not going to get out of here scot-free. We need your help with another vital bipartisan piece of legislation. **********We absolutely must have, across the board, a three-year, 25 percent rate reduction for every American taxpayer, and we're not going to settle for less. **********Now there are those who are insisting that we settle for less.  They demand proof in advance that what we propose will work, and they refuse to accept the record of history which clearly demonstrates that tax-rate reductions do work. I think we can prove that what they've been doing in the last few decades hasn't worked and never will. And I don't think it automatically follows that those who brought about the present economic mess are simply, by virtue of having done that, the best qualified to clean it up. The Central Question **********They never answer one question that I keep asking, and you probably heard me ask it: Why is it inflationary if the people keep their own money and spend it the way they want to, and it's not inflationary if the Government takes it and spends it the way it wants to? **********So we're asked to believe that their proposal is more compassionate to the working people. But their proposal won't even match the built-in tax increase that they themselves are responsible for. As a matter of fact, let's be honest about it, our 25 percent, across-theboard tax cut actually is not that much of a tax cut at all. It is simply removing the imposition over the next three years, by way of inflation which moves people up in brackets and built-in tax increases, of the tax increase that will be imposed on the people without that across-the-board reduction. And theirs doesn't match that. The people over the next three years will get a tax increase once this is adopted. **********Now it's that simple. Our opponents want more money from your family budget so they can spend it on the Federal budget and make it remain high. Maybe it's time that you and millions like you remind them of a few simple facts: It's your money, not theirs. You earned it, they didn't. You have every right to keep a bigger share than you've been allowed to keep for a great many years now. And when they insist we can't reduce taxes and spending and balance the budget too, one six-word answer will do: Yes we can, and yes we will.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/30/world.main_headline: News Analysis; REAGAN PUTTING HIS STAMP ON U.S. POLICIES: AT HOME AND ABROAD, A CHANGE OF COURSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/30/world.print_headline: News Analysis; REAGAN PUTTING HIS STAMP ON U.S. POLICIES: AT HOME AND ABROAD, A CHANGE OF COURSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/30/world.body_text: **********In accents as well as actions, in his denunciation of Soviet behavior around the world as well as his demands for budget austerity at home, President Reagan has begun to signal a break from the more moderate style and substance of the Carter era. **********''This Administration did not come here to be a caretaker government and just hope we would go along the same way and maybe do a little better,'' he said firmly at his first Presidential news conference. ''The time has come where there has to be a change of direction.'' **********On foreign affairs, he broke with his predecessor by charging that Soviet leaders, past and present, reserved the right ''to commit any crime, to lie, to cheat'' in their drive to promote world revolution. And on domestic matters, he declared flatly that President Carter's effort to control wages and prices had been such a failure that he was abolishing the Council on Wage and Price Stability. **********To Republicans as well as Democrats in Congress who have balked at his plan for a three-year program for cutting individual income taxes, he asserted he was not shrinking from his commitment. And to those who have warned that some social programs are so essential and sacrosanct that it is politically unwise to cut them, Mr. Reagan said ''no one is exempt'' from potential budget cuts. Some Slips of the Tongue **********Yet in spite of the toughness of his message, it was delivered in the amiable style that became Mr. Reagan's hallmark in the Presidential campaign, punctuated with occasional slips of the tongue. Mediterranean, he said at one point, when he meant Caribbean. **********And if the President sounded sharp on some issues, he was carefully restrained or vague on others. He would have to talk more with his advisers, he said, before deciding what to do about draft registration, the grain embargo against Moscow, and milk price supports. **********On Iran, he sought not to let the nation's passions over the treatment of the 52 American hostages carry the country into vengeful reprisals. ''I'm not thinking of revenge,'' he said. ''What good would revenge do? And what form would it take? I don't think revenge is worthy of us.'' **********Moreover, some actions he and his Cabinet have taken in their first nine days are less of a break with the Carter Administration's policies than an extension or an adaptation of them. **********Mr. Reagan's immediate decontrol of domestic crude oil prices is an acceleration of policies that Mr. Carter began. His freeze on hiring for the Federal Government is an extension of a Carter program. The plans of Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis to head a special interagency board to aid the beleaguered automobile industry is patterned after the panel led by former Transportation Secretary Neil E. Goldschmidt. Campaign Pledges Stand **********In other areas, Mr. Reagan insisted that he is sticking by campaign pledges to abolish the Departments of Education and Energy set up by Mr. Carter, but indicated that the move would be made more slowly and carefully than his most ardent partisans had hoped. And he sidestepped a final news conference questioner who wanted to know why some loyal conservatives were being ignored in his sub-Cabinet appointments in favor of more moderate nominees. **********On his most fundamental shift from the Carter approach, cuts in the 1981 and 1982 budgets, Mr. Reagan had only hints today. ''They probably are going to be bigger than anyone has ever attempted,'' he said. ''The clear message I received in the election campaign is that we must gain control of this inflationary monster.'' **********That kind of talk, his aides acknowledge, is intended to marshal public support for the legislative battle over his economic program.  The President intends to do more drumbeating for his program in an economic report to the nation next week and in an address to Congress planned for mid-February. **********In the meantime, he and his Cabinet spokesman have sought to project a new image in tone as well as substance. At his news conference yesterday, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  accused the Soviet Union of contributing to international terrorism.  Earlier he had sent a sharp message to the Soviet Foreign Minister warning against Soviet intervention in Poland. **********At the Department of Education, Secretary T.H. Bell talks of cutting back loans and grants to college students. At the Department of Health and Human Services, Secretary Richard S. Schweiker disagreed sharply with his predecessor by declaring that his department would not promote sex education and that he did not believe that contraceptives should be prescribed by doctors treating poor, unmarried teen-agers under Federal programs. **********As Mr. Reagan observed in another context, after the Republican victory in the elections last fall, ''We wouldn't want to go back to having just a different cast of characters with the same show going on.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/17/world.main_headline: U.S. BACKS SALVADORAN JUNTA AND STILLS COUP RUMORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/17/world.print_headline: U.S. BACKS SALVADORAN JUNTA AND STILLS COUP RUMORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/17/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration, three weeks after dismissing Robert E. White as Ambassador to El Salvador, is largely following the same course of action here as the Carter Administration while deliberating what its final policy should be, **********Since the arrival a little over a week ago of Frederic L. Chapin as charge d'affaires, rumors of an imminent coup in this Central American country have stopped and the position of Jose Napoleon Duarte, the Christian Democratic President of the ruling civilianmilitary junta, has been strengthened. **********According to Western and Salvadoran officials, Mr. Chapin has made it clear to officials here that the Reagan Administration, like the Carter Administration, supports the junta. **********In a show of support, Mr. Chapin attended a government ceremony here today at which the first of more than 150,000 land titles were given to peasants in an agricultural redistribution program that has been fiercely opposed by wealthy landowners living in self-exile in Miami and by some right-wing elements within the military. **********Defense Chief Backs Junta **********The program, which this year alone is receiving $23 million in United States grants and credits, had been thrown into some doubt by the removal of Mr. White and the Reagan Administration's focus on El Salvador in a major policy review it is conducting. **********The Administration's policy initiatives to date, however, have been directed more at pressing Marxist nations to cut off the supply of weapons to the guerrillas. The Administration is also tussling with the question of future American military aid to the junta while completing delivery of weapons and helicopters under the Carter Administration's last-minute emergency grant of $5 million. **********In an interview, Col. Jose Guillermo Garcia, the Minister of Defense and the most powerful military leader, supported the junta and its policies. **********''We think that the Government we have now is very recommendable,'' he said. ''We are not thinking of any moves to change it.  ''The military's commitment to the large landowners is a thing of the past. Agricultural reforms broke the support for the left, and it was carried out by soldiers.'' **********But while American policy has remained constant, the style has distinctly changed. Mr. Chapin, who is to represent the Administration until an ambassador is selected, has been dutifully making the rounds of senior officials but has declined, in contrast to the outspoken Mr. White, to make public statements. **********Mr. Chapin's behavior is in keeping with the Administration's advocacy of quiet diplomacy on human rights. More than 10,000 people were killed last year, many of them by right-wing squads presumed to be associated with elements of the police and the armed forces. American Military Advisers **********The Government is also fighting leftist guerrillas, and Mr.  Chapin, a career diplomat whose last job was in the Pentagon dealing with military assistance to Latin America, arrives when military aid to El Salvador is higher than ever before. **********There are 25 American military men in El Salvador, seven of them stationed here as attaches and coordinators of military aid.  According to American officials, 13 of the military men are here temporarily to train helicopter pilots and five are here temporarily to help coordinate and plan Salvadoran military efforts to protect the present harvest of coffee, cotton and sugar, the mainstays of the country's economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/11/world.main_headline: THIRD WORLD NATIONS ASSAIL U.S. POSITION IN LAW OF SEA TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/11/world.print_headline: THIRD WORLD NATIONS ASSAIL U.S. POSITION IN LAW OF SEA TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/11/world.body_text: **********Representatives of third world nations today accused the United States of displaying a ''cavalier attitude'' toward eight years of negotiations on a treaty to regulate the use of the oceans and said they were unwilling to reopen negotiations on issues already agreed upon in a draft treaty. **********A statement read by Inam ul-Haque of Pakistan on behalf of an organization representing most of the world's developing countries said there ''should not be any reopening of issues already negotiated'' if the new United States Administration rejects the ''work of over 150 nations, including its own predecessor Government's, for almost a decade.'' **********It said the American position threatened to ''destroy the principle of good-faith negotiations.'' The Reagan Administration has said it will not engage in substantive negotiations at this session of the Law of the Sea Conference because it has not finished a review of the draft treaty, completed before President Reagan took office. **********A Hint That U.S. May Be Left Out **********After delivering the statement, Mr. Inam, a representative of the Group of 77, a loose alliance of most of the world's developing countries, told reporters that adoption of the proposed treaty without the United States was ''not an unthinkable prospect.'' **********Nevertheless, he said that the ''door was not being closed'' on United States participation. Although the Group of 77 will not enter into formal contact with the United States delegation, he said, informal exchanges between individual delegations are ''going on all the time.'' **********The third world representatives also said, ''Great powers cannot afford anymore the luxury of pursuing national interests which adversely affect the developing countries and still hope to be accepted as world leaders.'' **********Expressing dismay over Washington's delay and its questioning of agreements already tentatively approved, the statement by the developing countries said ''this cavalier attitude of the United States'' should not be permitted to disrupt the conference program.  The program calls for the resolution of the outstanding issues so that the treaty can be put into final form. Malone Seeks Accommodation **********The third world statement said the implication of statements made by American representatives was that Washington would not accept the treaty if the ''conference is not prepared to negotiate on its terms.'' **********James L. Malone, the head of the American delegation, made it clear in a statement last week that he would attempt to determine to what extent United States ''concerns'' with the draft treaty might be accommodated. **********Without making specific proposals or requests, the American representative said the Administration was particularly concerned about the provisions for international control over the mining of mineral-rich nodules on the ocean floor and limitations that would be imposed on American companies trying to exploit these riches. **********The statement by the developing countries told of strong disappointment because there was ''no indication'' in Mr. Malone's statement that the United States was ''committed'' to conclusion of the treaty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/busin.body_text: **********The General Public Utilities Corporation, facing possible bankruptcy because of the Three Mile Island accident, won permission yesterday to increase substantially rates charged by its two Pennsylvania subsidiaries. **********Analysts said the increase, which would generate additional annual revenues of $106.7 million, could give the utility more time to solve its financial problems, although the amount was less than G.P.U. had requested. 'Needs Money to Survive' **********''The company needs this money to survive,'' a spokesman for the Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission said. The commission unanimously voted to approve the rate increases, the first the two subsidiaries have received since 1978. **********The total was $36.8 million less than the company had sought.  The rate increases, much higher than recommended on technical grounds by the commission advisory staff, were intended by the commission to maintain the solvency of a utility that has been teetering on the edge of bankruptcy. **********G.P.U.'s costs have raced ahead of revenues since the company's Three Mile Island reactor malfunctioned in a nuclear ''event'' two years ago, leading to one of the worst civilian nuclear accidents in history. G.P.U. has been forced to pay huge amounts to clean up Three Mile Island and has not been able to recover these costs through rate increases. Allotments to Subsidiaries **********The commission granted G.P.U.'s Metropolitan Edison Company unit, which operates Three Mile Island, an annual rate increase of $51.8 million, $24.7 million less than requested. It also allowed the Pennsylvania Electric Company unit a rate increase of $54.9 million, $12.1 million less than asked. The increases will go into effect when a final order is issued next week, probably on Thursday. **********The shortfall in the Met Ed request was by far the more important, G.P.U. officials said, because the company's bankers have said they would not extend credit to Met Ed if the full rate increase requested was not granted. Met Ed has a $23 million state tax bill due April 15, and has said it lacks the money to pay it. **********G.P.U.'s creditors are to meet April 10 to decide whether to lend the company money to pay the taxes. An attorney for the banking consortium, Gerald Gornish, said the lenders would consider the commission's decision, but he declined to predict what effect it would have on the utility's credit. **********Analysts said, however, that the fact the increase was considerably larger than the $9 million originally recommended by the commission's staff might be a positive factor from the banks' viewpoint. First Base Rise Since 1978 **********The rate increase is the first rise in base rates the Pennsylvania commission has granted the G.P.U. units since 1978, although it has permitted the utilities to pass on higher costs for replacement power to consumers. **********For its part, G.P.U. declined to rule out bankruptcy for either the whole company or one of its three subsidiaries. In addition to its Pennsylvania units, G.P.U. also owns the Jersey Central Power and Light Company, which also relied on the Three Mile Island station for electricity. **********The company spokesman said that the company was dependent on its revolving credit agreement, and noted that even with the increases, the Pennsylvania subsidiaries would continue to operate under conditions of ''severe austerity.'' **********No operating utility in the United States has ever gone bankrupt, and several management studies commissioned by G.P.U. have indicated that bankruptcy would not solve the problem of supplying power to G.P.U.'s current customers, or of cleaning up the damaged reactor. **********The Pennsylvania commission previously ruled that the cleanup costs could not be recovered through rate increases. Since the company cannot afford to foot the bill, however, G.P.U. and nuclear industry proponents are scrambling to come up with a plan that would somehow distribute these costs among the nuclear users in general, the Federal Government and Pennsylvania taxpayers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/20/busin.body_text: **********See Jean Cacharel drive his Rolls-Royce through Paris. See Donna Karan walk across Central Park. See Steve Davis (for Christian Dior sportswear) stroll past the Guggenheim. **********Perhaps under the belief that designers even get to work more stylishly than most folks, Bloomingdale's is running a series of television commercials this week and next showing eight designers on the way to their studios in New York, Paris and Dublin. The $250,000 campaign, a joint venture by the department store, the designers and the International Wool Secretariat, is the first major entry by television into designer-fashion advertising. **********On their way to work, the designers discuss their fall collections, design philosophy and approach to colors and fabrics.  The occasional dress is shown, but the sell is exceedingly soft.  ''We're not selling specific clothes, but concepts,'' explained Gordon Cooke, senior vice president of sales promotions at Bloomingdale's, but the ultimate design is to draw customers to the sales racks. **********The commercials, which will appear 15 times apiece on CBS, NBC and ABC, were conceived by Bloomingdale's and placed by Grey Advertising.

It said the bomb was planted between the museum and a filling station in predominantly Arab East Jerusalem.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; RATES SINK WITH MONEY SUPPLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates declined as much as 3/4 point yesterday, an extraordinary one-day move fueled by the unexpectedly large $2.8 billion decline in the money supply and hopes that short-term rates would decline further in the near future. **********In line with the trend, rates on three-and six-month Treasury bills auctioned yesterday fell.  Prices were also increased by the release of buying demand that had built up during the slow trading days of the holiday season, when many investors and speculators were absent from the marketplace. **********''There were a lot of buyers just lined up waiting for the new year,'' one Treasury securities dealer said. In the bond market, for example, 12 3/4 percent Treasury bonds due 2010 opened 1 3/4 point higher than late Friday and then rose another point to close at about 108 7/8 to yield 11.72 percent. Volatility remains a byword on the market, as shown by the bond issue, which was offered as high as 110 1/4 at one time. **********Drop in M-1B **********The sharp rise in prices and drop in yields began at the opening and gathered steam when the Federal Reserve announced a $2.8 billion decline in the basic money supply, M-1B. The decline in the money supply, which leaves the level of M-1B within the Fed's target area for 1981, encouraged traders to expect lower short-term rates soon.  As the money supply declines, banks need to hold fewer dollars on deposit at the Federal Reserve, so they borrow less in the Federal funds market. **********In the Treasury bill market, new three-and six-month issues were auctioned at rates well below the previous week. Late in the day the Treasury announced that new three-month bills averaged 13.60 percent compared with 13.91 percent last week while six-month bills averaged 13.18 compared with 13.41 percent. After adding 25 hundredths of a percentage point to the six-month bill, banks and thrift institutions may pay as much as 13.43 percent for new six-month money market savings certificates. **********Among outstanding Treasury bill issues, rates dropped as low as 13.35 percent for three months and 12.75 percent for six months before prices retreated and rates rose during the afternoon. **********According to many dealers, the buying demand for notes and bonds was mostly among securities firms that expect to earn profits when bonds bought now are sold at higher prices in the future. **********''I would not call it tremendous institutional buying,'' said Howard Blum Jr., an executive vice president at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. He added, however, that the move to lower rates has been great enough that many more corporations will now be willing to sell bonds, which in turn will attract more institutional buying. 'Risk-Averters' **********''The big investors are essentially risk averters,'' Mr. Blum said, ''so they will commit their funds to longer-term issues only gradually'' while assessing the chances that inflation and interest rates will decline for more than just a few months or calendar quarters. **********In the Treasury note sector, the 15 1/8 percent notes due in two years were offered at 104 22/32, up more than a point, to yield 12.36 percent, and the new 12 3/8 percent notes due in seven years were offered at 100 28/32 to yield 12.14 percent. **********In advance of today's Treasury auction of $1.5 billion of new 20-year, one-month bonds, dealers estimated the average yield at 11 3/4 percent to 12 percent. **********Prices also rose sharply in the tax-exempt market, dealers said.  While yields for Treasury issues decline for longer maturities, the opposite is true in the tax-exempt market. One dealer estimated that high-grade state bonds might yield around 7 percent for 1982-84 maturities, compared with 7.75 percent for bonds due in 10 years and 9 percent for bonds due in 20 years. ''Those yields are 40 and 50 basis points less than Friday,'' commented Alex Marcinkiewcz, a trader at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, who added that ''there are so few bonds around that it is hard to estimate yields.'' **********Because of the higher yields for longer maturities, Maryland announced that when it sells $149 million of bonds Feb. 4 it will ask underwriters to bid for bonds due from one through 10 years as well as one through 15 years. **********In the corporate market, underwriters led by Salomon Brothers said that American Express Credit Corporation's $100 million of Aa-rated notes due 1991 will be offered at par with a 12 7/8 percent coupon. **********Following are results of Monday's auction of new three-and sixmonth Treasury bills:

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/17/world.print_headline: U.S. 7TH ARMY: READY TO FIGHT; Military Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/17/world.body_text: **********The United States Seventh Army, a basic element in NATO's defense of Western Europe, is enjoying a new confidence based on a flow of new weapons, more money for long deferred projects and a perceptible rise in motivation and discipline. **********Balancing these positive factors are serious problems over the location of important units and suppliers, obsolescence of most of the Army's wheeled vehicles and appalling conditions at most bases and their barracks. **********These conditions are so serious that a staff officer predicted that nearly half the commissioned and noncommissioned officers scheduled for assignment to the Seventh Army this summer would be ''no shows.'' This means that they will choose to retire rather than accept the shoddy billets and primitive working conditions. **********The Seventh Army is not the perfect fighting machine its leaders would like it to be. But it is a better armed, more cohesive force than its detractors allege and is superior to the turbulent, drugridden force of five years ago. New Equipment Over Next 6 Years **********These conclusions are the result of a week's visit to armored, infantry, artillery and supply units of the Seventh Army and talks with soldiers, noncommissioned officers and junior and senior officers in field and staff posts. **********One cause for confidence is that over the next six years, the Seventh Army will receive more than 300 items of new equipment. These will range from protective clothing for nuclear, biological and chemical warfare to the M-1 tank and a family of antitank and antiaircraft missiles. **********Other items, such as the improved TOW vehicle and the M-60A3 tank, are already reaching units. Others, like the Tacfire and Tacfinder team, are on the way. **********Tacfire and Tacfinder are expected to strengthen the artillery, which, officers said, is deficient in numbers of guns and surface-tosurface missiles. Tacfinder, based on radar, picks up enemy mortar and gunfire. Tacfire instantly computes the range, battery and type of round to answer the incoming fire. **********The Seventh Army's trucks and jeeps are wearing out. At one motor pool there were two two-and-a-half-ton trucks with more than 100,000 miles on their odometers. Others had gone 75,000 miles. Jeeps and trucks are afflicted with rust, and as they age the time needed for maintenance increases. 'Well-Trained Combat Army' **********Gen. Frederick C. Kroessen, the Seventh Army commander, believes that he has a ''well-trained combat army'' that can defend the borders of Western Europe but that he must rely on reinforcement and resupply because there is ''no capacity in the European theater to sustain a battle.'' **********Officers and enlisted men believe that the existing deficiencies in some weapons will be met by a Defense Department acutely aware of the Seventh Army's needs. They are less sure that the Army will be repositioned to more tactically realistic sites and that working and living conditions will be improved. **********The most striking instance of the need for repositioning is the location of the Eighth Infantry Division of V Corps.  The Eighth is is the largest division in the Army, with 4 brigades, more than 21,000 soldiers, 490 tanks and nearly 900 armored personnel carriers. A 'Worrisome' Situation **********But the bulk of this division is stationed west of the Rhine River, in areas around Wiesbaden, Mainz and Mannheim. The estimate, perhaps optimistic, is that the division's covering force would take 12 hours to reach its war station near the Fulda Gap, in eastern Hesse state, the main force would need 25 to 27 hours and the artillery would take 20 hours. **********If the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has a week's warning of a possible Soviet invasion, these times would suffice. Most intelligence specialists believe that the alliance will have that much warning, but there is no guarantee. **********The present situation, which one divisional commander called ''worrisome,'' could be improved if what the Army calls its Master Restationing Plan is carried out. **********Relocation of the division's brigades is linked to a cure for the serious morale problem arising from the working and living conditions of the troops. These conditions are bad throughout the Seventh Army and the cost of correcting them would be astronomical. 'Generally Appalling' Conditions **********One estimate is that $2 billion would be required to complete the restationing program. General Kroessen recently reported to Congress that conditions in Army base and housing areas are ''generally appalling.'' The large military complexes, he emphasized, are urban facilities that are old and obsolete. **********Members of Congress interested in military affairs respond that NATO countries, specifically West Germany, should help pay for new construction. The West German Army and Air Force are housed in modern buildings superior to those available to the Seventh Army. **********The Second Battalion of the 75th Artillery Regiment is based at Fliegerhorst, a World War II Luftwaffe base near Hanau. In most American prisons, such working and living conditions would probably lead to riots. **********The battalion has only one maintenance shed, which has just two pits for vehicle repair. Water seeps through the ceiling. The lighting is poor, the working conditions cramped. **********The barracks are even worse, although they appeared to be average for the Seventh Army. Six men occupy a room intended for four. The lighting fixtures frequently fail and, because of the need to save energy, only one light is used. In the winter the cold is so intense in most rooms that soldiers take their sleeping bags and head for the warmth of the boiler room. **********The barracks' foundations are crumbling. Water seeps into the cellar, toilets back up. Water drips from the ceilings and runs down the walls. **********With the soldiers living in these conditions. a visitor felt it remarkable that they retained their interest, even enthusiasm, for their profession.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/31/busin.body_text: **********The Xerox Corporation reported a 7.5 percent rise in earnings for the second quarter on a 10.1 percent increase in revenues.  The company said that its earnings in the first half were reduced substantially by currency exchange rates but that the decline was offset by a lower effective tax rate overseas. **********But the copier company said the strong dollar was likely to have a more adverse impact in the second half of the year. In response to the report, Xerox stock dropped by 1 1/8 points, to 48 3/8. **********Xerox said it earned $183.8 million, or $2.18 a share, in the quarter, compared with $170.9, or $2.02 a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose to $2.24 billion from $2.04 billion. The company also said that the number of new copiers and duplicators installed rose faster than in any second quarter. **********Sanford J. Garrett, an analyst with Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, said Xerox had ''what I consider a good quarter,'' given that currency weakened earnings by 22 cents a share. But he said that the company's statements on the effect of currency would cause analysts to lower earnings estimates for the year as a whole. **********Xerox also announced that it was re-introducing its 3300 copier, a model it had initially marketed in late 1979 and then withdrew in 1980 because of defective parts and poor quality and reliability.  The new version of the small-to-medium-sized copier will sell for $6,800, compared with $7,700 for the original version.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/06/busin.main_headline: TREASURY BONDS SOLD AT 12.68%; (000 ommitted in dollar figures)
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/06/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; TREASURY BONDS SOLD AT 12.68%; (000 ommitted in dollar figures)
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/06/busin.body_text: **********Average Price................................100.47 Average Yield...............................12.68% Low Price....................................100.26 High Yield..................................12.70% High Price...................................100.81 Low Yield....................................12.63% Accepted at low.........................84% Total Applied for................$5,251,000 Accepted.........................$2,250,000 N.Y. applied for.................$4,616,833 N.Y. accepted....................$1,993,760 Noncompetitive......................238,000 The 29 3/4-year bonds mature Nov. 15,2010 By MICHAEL QUINT **********New 30-year Treasury bonds were sold yesterday at an average yield of 12.68 percent, a return that analysts said was high enough to attract good buying interest from speculators and dealers although not from investors. **********''Wall Street likes the bond market,'' said one Government securities specialist, who added that institutional investors seemed to be reluctant buyers of the $2.5 billion of 13 percent notes due in 1990 sold Wednesday and the $2.25 billion of 12 3/4 percent bonds due in 2010 sold yesterday. ''The big buyers seem to be fully invested, having spent their money during the December rally.'' **********Another institutional salesman explained that, when the yield of the 12 3/4 percent bonds briefly touched 13 percent Dec. 11, his more astute clients began buying modest amounts of bonds. ''Back then, the high financing costs discouraged speculative purchases, but now I see speculators returning to the market'' as they anticipate higher bond prices and lower long-term interest rates. **********Reasons for Reluctance **********Peter Kordell, president and an economist at the commodities firm of Kordell & Company, cited two reasons why investors were reluctant to buy bonds now. First, he said, ''they have yet to be convinced that Congress will go along with the spending cuts the President wants.'' **********Second, he said, ''there are doubts about whether the supply-side policies will work - I think the tax cuts could merely increase consumer spending without leading to the increased investment'' that is needed for economic growth without higher inflation. **********Despite his doubts, Mr. Kordell expects long-term interest rates to decline in the future, though saying that ''this is not a time to commit all your money to the bond market.'' He concluded that, ''if long-term interest rates don't come down as the President announces and implements his budget plans, then they will come down as the economy weakens.'' **********Prices of new Treasury note and bond issues declined on the day, but closed above their lowest levels. The new 13 1/4 percent notes due in September 1984 closed at 100, up from the average price of 99 22/32 set Tuesday, when the Treasury sold $3.75 billion of the new notes. The 13 percent notes due in 1990 closed at 100 11/32 to yield 12.92 percent, down from an average price of 100 1/2 at Wednesday's auction. **********After yesterday's auction, the outstanding 12 3/4 percent Treasury bonds closed at 101 1/4 to yield 12.58 percent. The 12.68 percent average yield at the auction was less than the 12.81 percent average on similar bonds sold last November. Rate Hopes Damped **********In the money markets, hopes that the Fed might be encouraging lower interest rates were damped yesterday, analysts said. When overnight loans in the Federal funds market were at 16 3/4 percent, the Fed acted shortly before noon to drain credit from the banking system temporarily by arranging four-day sales of securities. That action tends to put upward pressure on the funds rate. **********Analysts said they expected the Fed to drain credit from the banking system this week, adding that the latest action showed the Fed was not trying to supply the additional funds to the banking system that would be needed to cause a lower Federal funds rate. **********In the week ended Feb. 4, the Federal funds rate averaged 17.19 percent, down from 18.12 percent the previous week and well below the record 20.06 percent set in the first week of 1981. **********Following are results of the Treasury's auction yesterday of 12 3/4 percent bonds due in 2010:

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/30/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini said at a news conference today that Italy's governing parties had agreed to reconsider participation in the Soviet pipeline deal and possibly cut off negotiations. **********Mr. Spadolini said a ''pause for reflection'' might be needed. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/26/busin.body_text: **********Federal bank regulators decided today to lift by Aug. 1 the interest rate ceiling on 30-month ''small-saver'' certificates of deposit offered by banks and savings and loan associations and to study a proposal to double interest rates on passbook savings, now a maximum 5 1/2 percent. **********The regulators, members of the Depository Institutions Deregulation Committee, charged by Congress with the responsibility for phasing out interest rate ceilings, also decided at their meeting today to speed up by one year the original six-year schedule set for eliminating ceilings on all savings deposits. This means the ceiling will come off by Aug. 1, 1985. **********The ceiling on the 30-month certificate is now 12 percent at savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks and 11 3/4 percent at commercial banks. Beginning Aug. 1, the rate on these certificates will be pegged to the rate on 30-month Treasury securities, now about 14 1/2 percent. If the Treasury rate remained at that level, then the rate for the 30-month certificates would rise about 2 1/2 percentage points next Aug. 1. **********Timetable Described **********The new five-year timetable was described by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, a member of the D.I.D.C., as firm but not irreversible. He noted that, if interest rates should come down more rapidly than expected, the scheduled phase-out of ceilings could be accelerated even more. **********On the other hand he said that, if ''something untoward'' should happen and it becomes apparent that some financial institutions are being hurt by the schedule, it could be modified. **********He said the committee's actions were being put into legal language and would shortly be inserted in The Federal Register.  Under the complex schedule agreed to today by the Treasury Secretary and by the chairmen of the Federal Reserve Board, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the National Credit Union Administration, ceilings on all deposits of four years' maturity or more will also be eliminated on Aug. 1. Most of these deposits now have maximum ceilings of about 12 percent. **********Ceilings on deposits of between 30 months and four years would be eliminated on a staggered schedule, with some changes being made each Aug. 1 through Aug. 1, 1985, when the last of the ceilings would be dropped on savings deposits of 30 months or more in duration. **********Irvine H. Sprague, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, proposed to double the current interest rate on passbook savings, the form of account held by most small savers. These accounts, which have no required deposit length, now have a ceiling of 5 1/4 percent at commercial banks and 5 1/2 percent at savings institutions. **********Mr. Sprague argued that the small savers had long been discriminated against and were in effect subsidizing the higher interest rates offered on larger deposits. **********But Richard T. Pratt, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, contended that such action taken now, when most thrift institutions are feeling severe earnings pressure, would be ''extremely detrimental.'' **********The Home Loan Bank Board regulates savings and loan associations.  Mr. Sprague's agency regulates mutual savings banks and some smaller commercial banks. The savings associations and savings banks are collectively known as thrifts. **********Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, whose institution regulates most of the large commercial banks, suggested that the panel should put the Sprague proposal up for ''informal comment'' and at this time should come down neither for nor against it. **********The committee, which was holding an open meeting in the Treasury's gilded Cash Room under the so-called Sunshine Law, then agreed to this compromise. **********Treasury Secretary Regan, who is chairman of the panel, proposed the accelerated phase-out of the interest rate ceilings and his proposal was accepted by all members except Mr. Pratt, who abstained. **********The savings and loan industry has been chary of deregulalting too swiftly for fear that many of its members would fail financially if forced by competitive pressures to pay higher rates on savings. Many of the thrift units are locked into long-term mortgage portfolios that earn them less than 10 percent interest annually. **********The industry's income comes mainly from interest rates on home mortgages. Yields on most of these mortgages are less than 10 percent and are lower than the cost of deposits. Mr. Pratt reported that 70 percent of the 4,700 savings and loan associations were now suffering losses. **********Other industry specialists have forecast that the industry will lose more than $5 billion this year.  Congress in the current tax bill has been examining ways to help the industry. Both the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee have approved a 12-month tax-exempt savings certificate that would let single taxpayers exclude from their income up to $1,000 a year and would let married couples exclude up to $2,000 a year. The savings certificate would pay 70 percent of the interest on a 12-month Treasury bill, thus lowering the cost to the thrifts while increasing net income to many middle-income investors. **********But in earlier testimony today before a House Banking subcommittee, Mr. Volcker was highly critical of the idea. He said it was ''not a sound approach'' because it would merely ''rejigger existing savings'' and be more costly for the savings associations. **********The thrift industry has been waging an intense lobbying campaign to get the proposal carried.  Today's meeting of the regulators turned down a proposal by Mr.  Pratt of the Home Loan Bank Board to restore the quarter-percentagepoint differential for thrift institutions on another popular savings instrument, the six-month money market certificate. **********When these certificates were introduced in June 1978, the ceilings were set equal to the six-month Treasury bill rate plus a quarter of a percentage point for thrifts. **********But a later action eliminated this differential when the Treasury bill rate exceeded 9 percent, as it has in recent months.  Mr. Pratt argued that restoration of the differential was necessary to improve the competitive position of the thrifts, who he said were now losing the money-market certificate business to commercial banks. **********But other members of the panel voted against the idea, with Treasury Secretary Regan observing, ''Wouldn't we be creating more problems than we intend to solve'' and Mr. Volcker noting, ''It is not clear that this would have any positive impact on the earnings of the thrifts.'' **********The main item on the agenda was the five-year timetable for removing the interest-rate controls from the bank and thrift deposits. **********Mr. Regan said it was essential to get a firm schedule for deregulation on the books now to give the financial institutions a chance to ''know where they stand and get on with their forward planning.'' **********The former chairman of the Wall Street house of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith said, ''I'm a firm believer in deregulation and forward planning.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/03/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and the Premiers of Canada's 10 provinces tried today in private to resolve their differences on a new constitution after publicly setting out what seemed to be irreconcilable positions. **********At the opening of a televised conference on the problem there was much of the bickering and recrimination that have characterized past attempts to settle the question. **********By the time the public session ended at lunchtime, little middle ground had been created. **********Hanging over the heads of the Premiers was Mr. Trudeau's threat to proceed with his proposals if there is is no agreement this week. He would ask Parliament to approve a resolution asking Britain to add a bill of rights to the British North America Act of 1867, then transfer the document to Canada. **********Any compromises were saved for the afternoon private discussion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/31/world.main_headline: France Moves to Insure Limitations on Wiretaps
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/31/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; France Moves to Insure Limitations on Wiretaps
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/31/world.body_text: **********The French Government announced today that it was taking steps to insure that official wiretaps would be used only in cases involving national security or in certain cases involving professional criminals. **********Interior Minister Gaston Defferre said in a communique that a commission of lawyers, magistrates and police officials would be set up to make sure that the rules on phone tapping were strictly applied. **********Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing denied several times in his seven-year term that politicians, journalists and trade unionists had had their phones tapped by the Government. In 1975, the Socialist leader Francois Mitterrand, who is now President, suggested that the Government had gone back on a 1974 pledge by Mr.  Giscard d'Estaing to end such operations, which had been widespread in the past.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/25/world.print_headline: ...BUT FOR U.S., IT POSES NEW PROBLEMS; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/25/world.body_text: **********Although the Reagan Administration has responded with interest to Leonid I. Brezhnev's suggestion of a summit meeting, the Soviet leader's move has raised complications for the Administration's initial strategy of trying to rally support for a harder line toward Moscow. **********American experts on the Soviet Union and West European ambasadors acknowledge that Mr. Brezhnev has a long-term interest in detente, both for reasons of vital trade with the West and because of his personal commitment to the effort to improve relations. **********But specialists here also credit the aging Soviet leader with a clever gambit aimed at playing upon divisions between Washington and the West Europeans, especially Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, for whom the maintenance of cordial relations with Moscow is a central policy objective. **********Some experienced officials suspect that the Soviet suggestions of a top-level meeting, coupled with proposals on arms control, may also play upon the fears of American liberals that the initial flurry of anti-Soviet charges from President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., was ill-considered and might jeopardize prospects for arms control. **********'A Very Useful Line for Brezhnev' **********''It's a very useful line for Brezhnev to play,'' commented one high Administration official. ''It fits in with the constant desire the Soviets have to split us off from the Europeans. It would have been much simpler for us if he had taken the same hard line as Ustinov.'' **********Two days before Mr. Brezhnev spoke to the Soviet Communist Party Congress, Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov accused the Reagan Administration of trying to revive the cold war with its tough language and its plans to step up military spending. **********The article written by Marshal Ustinov was the kind of traditional Soviet polemic that played neatly into the hands of the Reagan Administration as a chorus of charges emanated from Washington about Soviet and Cuban involvement in arms shipments to leftist guerrillas in El Salvador. **********''Now, you've got the hard and soft pitch from Moscow,'' said one specialist on Soviet affairs. ''First Ustinov, the tough guy, and now Brezhnev, the statesman. That will encourage people like Schmidt to play the detente game.'' U.S. Pushed Into 2-Track Approach **********The two-track approach from Moscow has pushed the Reagan Administration into a two-track approach of its own -pursuing the hard line on El Salvador and making friendly comments about the idea of a summit meeting. **********Secretary Haig said yesterday that he might have found ''new and remarkable innovations'' in Mr. Brezhnev's summit suggestion and arms proposals, but he was also quick to emphasize that ''we are in no hurry'' to arrange an early meeting between Mr. Brezhnev and President Reagan. **********From the outset, the President and his Cabinet advisers on foreign policy have felt it wise to let the Russians know that they felt no irresistible domestic political pressure for a top-level meeting or arms negotiations, but wanted first to take steps to restore what Mr. Reagan, when he was a candidate, called ''the margin of safety'' in the American military arsenal. **********Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger remarked early in the Administration that it would be ''a good six months'' before Washington would be ready for full-fledged negotiations with the Kremlin on limitation of strategic arms. So far, there is no reason to suspect that Mr. Brezhnev's initiative has substantially altered that timetable. Broad Strategy Still Undeveloped **********In part, some officials concede privately, this is because the new Administration is not yet well enough organized to have devised a broad and well-formulated diplomatic strategy for dealing with the Soviet Union beyond initial charges over El Salvador and the general demand, voiced by Secretary Haig, that Moscow should agree to a ''code of conduct'' for global behavior if it wishes to pursue detente with the Reagan Administration. **********The diplomatic shorthand is that a summit meeting must be ''well prepared'' and that means, as both officials and European diplomats comment, stalling long enough to consult with top-ranking French, West German and British leaders who are now beginning a series of visits here, and then to attempt lower-level contacts with Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/06/world.body_text: **********The General Accounting Office said today that the United States lacked the weapons and the communications to carry out the basic nuclear strategy formulated by the Carter Administration and adopted by the Reagan Administration. **********In an unusually gloomy report, Congress was urged to require the Secretary of Defense to prepare and submit a plan to overcome those weaknesses when the new military budget is presented in January. **********The Defense Department, however, said that it wanted to avoid such a commitment even though it agreed with much of the assessment in the yearlong study. The department said that it would report what progress had been made when the budget is submitted in January. **********The assessment by the G.A.O., which does many analyses and investigations for Congress, contended that ''the large, sustained Soviet program to enhance its strategic nuclear capabilities has, by many measures, succeeded in altering the strategic nuclear balance.''  Advantages for Soviet Reported **********''Soviet forces have significant advantages that are not offset by United States forces,'' the report said.  The report appeared to be more pessimistic than the views expressed by many conservatives, including members of the Reagan Administration who deal with military issues, and far different from the assessment of the Carter Administration and many other Democrats, who have contended that the United States and the Soviet Union were essentially equal in strategic nuclear weapons. **********To meet the change in the balance, the report said, ''the United States gradually shifted its deterrence strategy through the 1970's,'' culminating in Presidential Directive 59, which was disclosed a year ago by Harold Brown, then Secretary of Defense. **********It established what is known as a countervailing strategy of ''flexible, controlled use of strategic weapons against all appropriate targets for any level of conflict.'' **********The previous strategy would have had the United States respond to a Soviet attack by firing a large part of its nuclear arsenal to assure widespread destruction throughout the Soviet Union. What U.S. Is Said to Need **********The Congressional agency asserted that the weapons of the United States on hand and those planned ''will not provide all the capabilities needed to fully carry out the strategy.'' Improvements in the ''communications network must be given a high priority if the United States is to implement countervailing strategy,'' the report said. **********To carry out the current nuclear strategy, the United States needs a communications system that provides reliable warning of a Soviet nuclear attack, channels through which leaders can control an appropriate response and reliable channels for two-way communication as the nuclear battle is fought. **********The Congressional investigation found, however, that ''a surprise nuclear attack could, in the worst case, destroy the ground-based and airborne command and control network'' with the single exception of an airplane kept aloft by the Strategic Air Command. **********The report said that radar stations, command centers and aircraft on the ground would be vulnerable to missiles fired from submarines close to American shores. Radio transmissions could be jammed or sabotaged. Satellites could be attacked by Soviet missiles with nuclear or conventional warheads. **********Beyond that, the report said, the current triad of intercontinental ballistics missiles, bombers and missiles launched from submarines was ''not designed to carry out the strategy that has evolved through the 1970's.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/world.body_text: **********The United States Ambassador to Algeria, Ulric St. Clair Haynes Jr., said here tonight that the agreement with Iran was ''a dangerous precedent'' but stressed that it was ''worthwhile'' because the 52 American hostages had been freed. **********The Ambassador, who took part in the protracted negotiations through the Algerian intermediaries, expressed concern that the agreement might set off a new round of hostage-taking and cause a variety of legal problems. **********''I'm terribly afraid that the whole hostage business could set a dangerous precedent,'' Mr. Haynes told a group of foreign journalists at his residence, where the American negotiators stayed during the delicate process. **********The Ambassador spoke at length about the negotiations - not the substance of the talks, which he said would come from Washington, but the ''atmospherics.'' He also recalled his emotional meeting with the Americans as they arrived here last night from their 444 days of captivity in Iran. **********''We were overwhelmed with happiness when we saw Bruce Laingen and the two girls with their arms linked at the top of the stairs,'' he said. ''That moment, we knew it was worthwhile.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/03/busin.print_headline: TRW to End A Switch Line
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/03/busin.body_text: **********TRW Inc. said that it had decided to discontinue its digital telephone switch business and had established a reserve to cover future losses on inventories, disposition of surplus equipment, severance pay and other expenses. **********The company, a manufacturer of products for the electronics, automotive, spacecraft and propulsion, industrial and energy markets, estimated that the reserve would reduce 1981 after-tax earnings by about $30 million. **********''The digital switch line has experienced substantial losses for some time,'' said Ruben Mettler, chairman and chief executive. He added that current economic conditions had aggravated the situation and further depressed demand. In addition, long-term overcapacity exists in the industry, he said. **********Mr. Mettler said at a meeting of securities analysts here that the decision to discontinue the product had come after more than a year of waiting for the market to improve. **********TRW stock fell 1 5/8 on the news, closing at 53 3/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.
