https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/14/busin.main_headline: HOUSE VOTES CURB ON FOREIGN BIDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/14/busin.print_headline: HOUSE VOTES CURB ON FOREIGN BIDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/14/busin.body_text: **********The House today approved by voice vote a measure that would make it more difficult for foreigners to finance acquisition of American companies. **********The action represented a response by Congress to a wave of attempted takeovers, chiefly but not exclusively from Canada, in recent months. Funds for these acquisitions, American critics say, were generated in most cases by 100 percent borrowed money. **********The bill applies domestic borrowing ceilings, known as margin requirements, to foreign investors who purchase more than 5 percent of an American company's stock. **********A similar measure has cleared a Senate securities subcommittee and is expected to be approved soon by the Senate Banking Committee.  Senate aides said that passage by that chamber seemed likely. Margin Now at 50% **********The Administration has not supported the legislation, but is not expected to oppose it actively. Administration officials say they are reluctant to take any steps that would impede the free flow of investment in this country. **********The present margin requirement is 50 percent, which means, for example, that for every $1 million borrowed from banks or brokers to buy securities, American investors have to put up $500,000 in collateral. **********Should the legislation clear the Senate and be signed by the President, foreign investors for the first time would have to meet the same conditions. **********To help in enforcement, an important provision of both the House and Senate bills gives stockholders in a company that may be a target for acquisition the right to bring legal action against a foreign purchaser if it is believed there has been a contravention of the margin requirement. S.E.C. Has Role Now **********Unless Congress specifically authorizes private right of action, only the Securities and Exchange Commission may now intervene in securities matters. The commission has said that lawyers, who may be quicker to respond to contraventions, could be a help to the agency in monitoring compliance. **********The House sponsors of the legislation, Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, who is chairman of the Subcommittee on Telecommunications, Consumer Protection and Finance, and James M.  Collins, Republican of Texas, said the exemption of foreigners from the margin requirements had put American companies at a disadvantage in resisting foreign bids. **********Senator Alphonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, the chief sponsor in the Senate, said the measure would make the rules equal for all investors. **********The bill was introduced last summer following the much-publicized effort of Canada's Seagram Company to acquire Conoco, Inc., at a time when the Canadian authorities were moving to consolidate that country's control over its energy industry. The Seagram move was thwarted by a bid from Du Pont for Conoco.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation, a leading producer of lumber, plywood and other forest products, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it plans to increase its stake in the National Gypsum Company of Dallas, a major producer of building materials, to more than 15 percent. **********Louisiana-Pacific, based in Portland, Ore., told the S.E.C. that it now holds 1,077,000, or 6.8 percent, of National Gypsum common shares. **********In a statement, National Gypsum, the nation's second-largest producer of gypsum products, said that it ''has emphasized to Louisiana-Pacific that National Gypsum is not for sale.'' The company also said that it believes that additional purchase of its shares by Louisiana-Pacific would not be in the interest of the company or its shareholders and would raise serious antitrust questions. **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Louisiana Pacific closed at 23 7/8, down 1/8. National Gypsum closed at 28 5/8, up 1 3/8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/17/busin.main_headline: Which Way Now for The French Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/17/busin.print_headline: Which Way Now for The French Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/17/busin.body_text: **********PARIS W ITH characteristic impulsiveness, the French business community and financial markets greeted Francois Mitterrand's election last Sunday as next President of France as a dire setback for the French economy. But the outburst of Gallic gloom seems premature and, in the event, may prove unwarranted. **********Last week, the Bourse collapsed, the franc was sold, and French savers rushed into gold. Suddenly a huge question mark was seen over what had been considered one of Europe's strongest and most promising economies with a heavy investment in the high technology industries of the future. ''The optimism over France in the 1980's has evaporated,'' said J. Paul Horne, Paris-based European analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. **********Yet whatever the pledges and promises Mr. Mitterrand and his associates have made on their way to the Elysee, they may find, when they take office, that their freedom of action is severely constrained. It is hemmed in by the balance of political forces, by the realities of the French economy, by their own cautious temperament and, not least, by the conservative instincts of the French people. **********In ending 23 years of right-wing Gaullist rule, Mr. Mitterrand has certainly opened a new chapter in his country's history, but whether that chapter will mark a fundamental revamping of French industry and finance remains uncertain. **********Taken at face value, Mr. Mitterrand's economic program implies a radical departure not just from the policies President Valery Giscard d'Estaing has followed, but also from those that nearly all Western industrial countries have embraced as they struggled to rebuild their prosperity in the stagflation of the 1980's. **********Elsewhere governments are fighting inflation, moderating government's claims on the economy, and trying to save imported oil.  By contrast, the French Socialists say they will move in exactly the opposite direction with a plan for solving the country's economic difficulties that relies on a mixture of old-fashioned Keynesian pump-priming, Marxist dogma and wholesale nationalization. **********Just as France broke with recent political trends in the West last Sunday by voting Left instead of Right, it is now proposing to experiment with an alternative ''social democratic'' answer to the world economic predicament, in place of the ''monetarist'' prescriptions being tried elsewhere. As Michel Rocard, the Socialist Party's second-in-command said on Sunday night, ''Francois Mitterrand's victory is a sign of hope not just for France but for millions in other countries suffering from unjust economic policies.'' **********Demand is to be stimulated immediately by raising the minimum wage, increasing family allowances and creating 220,000 new public sector jobs. **********At the same time, the new Government is committed to increasing dramatically its control over the economy through a nationalization plan far more extensive than that put in place by the Popular Front in 1936. Its measures, if carried out, would bring another million workers onto the state payroll and make it master of companies with sales exceeding $50 billion. **********As the plan has it, France's remaining private banks and insurance companies, including the holding companies of banks like Suez, Parisbas and Banque Rothschild are to be taken over, to give the Government complete control over the financial sector and enable it to direct the supply of credit. **********The list of industrial companies to be nationalized includes two subsidaries of foreign groups, the Roussel Uclaf pharmaceutical company controlled by Hoechst of West Germany and ITT-France, whose importance has been reduced now that it has quit the telephone sector; CII-Honeywell Bull, the computer maker 47 percent-owned by Honeywell; Dassault, maker of the Mirage fighter; Rhone-Poulenc, the troubled chemical and textile company; USINOR and SACILOR, two virtually bankrupt steelmakers; and five of the companies spearheading France's drive in advanced industries - St.-Gobain-Pont-a-Mousson, Matra, Compagnie Generale d'Electricite and Thomson-Brandt, all heavily engaged in advanced electronics and computers, and part of Creusot-Loire, which builds nuclear power stations. **********The Socialists also have vowed to increase the Government's holding in the two state-controlled oil companies, Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles and Elf-Acquitaine, take a stake in Peugeot-Citroen, the automobile maker, and give local authorities control over private water utilities. **********The object of these nationalizations, according to Michel Charzat, the Socialist Party Secretary, is ''not so much dogma but to create a piloting instrument.'' The groups would be restructured into more coherent units with only one or two companies in each sector.  Management would supposedly be free of political control. **********The Socialists also promise a new tax on private capital to reduce the inequalities of wealth, which are probably more glaring in France than in any other European country. And in a bid for the country's ''green'' vote, a useful 4 percent of the electorate, Mr. Mitterrand has promised to re-examine France's ambitious nuclear power program, which was intended to halve the country's oil import requirements by the end of the decade. **********Markets panicked last week because they assumed all this might really happen. Money fled the country on fears that a jacked up minimum wage will produce a general wage explosion, pushing up inflation and forcing devaluation of the franc later this year and tighter exchange controls. **********The Bourse, or stock exchange, collapsed because investors feared the Socialists will used their tighter grip over industry to halt the painful process of restructuring begun under President Giscard d'Estaing to preserve jobs. Competitiveness will slip, it is feared, and eventually the Government will be forced to retreat into protectionism. **********Yet much of the panic is certainly premature. Mr. Mitterrand does not yet have the votes in Parliament to even get his budget adopted, much less nationalize French companies or change tax rates. This is why he plans new Parliamentary elections for June. **********The Socialists may pick up some extra seats then, particularly from the Communists who did relatively badly in the Presidential race, but there is no prospect of their winning an overall majority. Crucial for the future of the party's economic reforms will be who they pick as allies in what is bound to be a coalition government. **********The President-elect has already said he will not bring Communists into the French Government. But even if he relies on them for Parliamentary support, the Communists are bound to press him to implement the whole economic program in return. On the other hand, if the Socialists ally with the small centrist parties that once supported President Giscard d'Estaing, they will be asked to water down their economic plans considerably. **********A third possibility is that the Giscardians and their neo-Gaullist allies will retain control of the Parliament. In this case, France is probably heading for a constitutional crisis as its elected President clashes openly with its elected Parliament. This may damage investor confidence, but while the political sparks fly, the Mitterrand program will remain in the freezer. **********Another reason why last week's panic may prove overdone lies in the personality of Mr. Mitterrand and those around him.  The new President is essentially a cautious man, a man of deals and compromises who won his spurs in the kaleidoscopic political climate of the Fourth Republic, when Governments changed like traffic lights and everything was negotiable. **********His closest associates include Jacques Delors, an experienced civil servant who has worked in the French Central Bank, and Claude Cheysoson, a member of the Common Market Executive Commission in Brussels. Both are expected to get high appointments in his first Government. Neither is a radical, and both know that the party's economic manifesto threatens to make its rule harder rather than easier. **********Nor would nationalization, with ''full and fair'' compensation, come cheap. Last week, for instance, the stock market valued St.  Gobain alone at just under $1 billion. **********Indeed, the history of the Socialists' economic program - as well as the curiously calm attitude taken by businessmen and bankers whose enterprises are actually the targets for nationalization - suggest that blueprint may never be fully implemented. **********The program and the nationalization list are the same as those agreed to in 1972 when the Socialists made an alliance with the Communists, a pact that came unstuck at the 1978 Parliamentary elections. Resurrecting it for the Presidential elections, Mr.  Mitterrand clearly hoped to again attract Communist support. He was also morally obliged to run on it after defeating an attempt to oust him as party leader last year by Mr. Rocard and a group of Young Turks who consider the nationalization plan outdated. **********Throughout the campaign the President-elect played down the more radical aspects and on several occasions qualified the nationalization plan by saying it would happen only ''when the economic conditions are right.'' **********Many Socialists say openly that the nationalization plan has become outdated. After all, they argue, the face of French industry has changed a lot since 1972, given the seven years of restructuring and reshaping by President Giscard d'Estaing to prepare it for the more difficult world markets of the 1980's and 1990's. Then, France had not made its big push into high-technology industries. Now, it has. **********During the election campaign, private bankers and industrialists, taking their cue from Mr. Mitterrand, seemed careful to avoid inflaming political passions by openly attacking the Socialist's nationalization proposals. **********The presidents of the industrial companies on the target list have been conspicuously silent. In the banking sector, Jean-Maxi me Leveque, president of the privately owned Credit Commercial de France, has been running a one-man advertising campaign against the nationalization plan, which he calls ''an irreparable error.'' But significantly, the Rothschild family and top management at the big privately owned investment banks, like Suez and Parisbas, have been invisible and inaudible. **********Privately, some of these executives argue that the Presidentelect's commitment to nationalization is uncertain and that anything said in public would make it harder for him to compromise. **********As a practical matter, few would object to nationalizing France's staggering steel industry, which the Government has already bought several times over with grants and loans. Likewise, there would little opposition to the Government taking over deeply troubled Rhone-Poulenc. And in banking, many say privately that the Left may need at least one sacrificial lamb. The favorite candidate is either Suez or Paribas. Buying either one would also give the Government some big shareholdings in other target companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/04/world.main_headline: FUTURE OF INDEPENDENT BELIZE IS FULL OF QUESTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/04/world.print_headline: FUTURE OF INDEPENDENT BELIZE IS FULL OF QUESTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/04/world.body_text: **********For over 30 years, the tiny British colony of Belize slowly gathered the recognized attributes of nationhood, including its own government, army, flag, currency and national anthem. **********Amid the toasts that followed its independence on Sept. 21, a lingering doubt floated among the foreign delegations who had travelled here for the occasion: Belize had become an independent state, but was it viable as a nation? **********The question was perhaps not original. Over the past quarter century, dozens of colonies in Africa, Asia and the Caribbean have become independent and then struggled for survival. **********But, in the case of Belize, concern has been sharpened by the fact that the new nation is part of Central America and Belize's failure to stand on its own could become a new factor of instability. **********One immediate problem is that neigboring Guatemala claims Belize as part of its own territory. And, with a population of 6.5 million compared to Belize's 145,000 inhabitants and an army infinitely superior to the 700-member Belize Defense Force, Guatemala could swallow up the new nation. **********Britain has agreed to protect Belize ''for an appropriate period,'' but, facing an annual cost of $50 million, the British have also indicated that they cannot do so indefinitely. And, in the absence of a settlement with Guatemala, Britain hopes that some force drawn from Commonwealth nations, headed perhaps by Canada, will take over its responsibility. **********The Reagan Administration, on the other hand, fears that without British troops patrolling the jungles near Belize's border with Guatemala, this country could become a conduit for illegal arms shipments from Cuba to leftist guerrillas elsewhere in Central America. Washington has therefore offered military training and weapons credits to improve Belize's security apparatus. Its Own Democratic Tradition **********Politically, however, Central America's revolutionary fever seems unlikely to prove contagious here. Belize not only has a predominately black, English-speaking population strongly identified with the Caribbean and with few links to Central America, but it has also established its own democratic tradition in its 17 years as a self-governing colony. **********Further, the principal opposit ion to Prime Minister George Price's People's United Party, which has long dominat ed domestic politics, comes from the more conservative United Democ ratic Party, while neither leftist nor militant black nationalis t groups have much o f a following. **********In contrast to most of Central America, social conditions are relatively good. Belize City, where 30 percent of Belizeans reside, suffers from a severe housing shortage that forces many people to live in dilapidated wooden shacks. But most children - half the population is under 15 years of age - attend school, 90 percent of adults are literate and health standards are considered adequate. **********The question marks about Belize's future, however, revolve around the country's economic viability. Prime Minister Price believes that independence will open the way for the country's ''economic liberation'' and he looks forward to a significant amount of foreign aid. But many foreign analysts argue that it will be difficult for Belize to generate its own wealth. Few Resources and No Industry **********Belize shares the economic profile of many former colonies: its principal natural resource, timber, was depleted by two centuries of exploitation and minimal reforestation by British companies, while its sugar industry, which accounts for 70 percent of foreign exchange earnings, is controlled by Britain's Tate and Lyle Ltd. **********A sparsely-populated territory about the size of Massachusetts, only about 15 percent of Belize's cultivable land is being farmed.  While sugar, citrus and timber are exported, one-third of the country's total imports consist of food. **********With a miniscule domestic consumer market, Belize has virtually no industry. Belize is trying to woo United States companies to establish assembly plants here, but competition is stiff from other small countries of the region and, so far, only a small textile operation has opened here. Employment opportunities in Belize City therefore remain scarse. **********One symptom is that tens of thousands of Belizeans have migrated to the United States in search of better-paid jobs. ''Anyone with any skills can earn five times as much in the states,'' said the manager of one large company. ''There is a brain drain and a skills drain that leaves Belize without its most talented.'' Considerable Tourist Potential **********As with much of the Caribbean basin, Belize does have considerable tourist potential, above all in the tiny deserted keys that run beside the world's second largest barrier reef, a mere 15 miles offshore. Last year tourism brought in only $9 million. **********But Prime Minister Price has shown little interest in major foreign-financed tourist development, arguing that it would turn Belize into a nation of ''tray-carriers'' and would, on balance, bring more cultural problems than economic benefits. **********The country is anticipating an economic boom in the coming two or three years, but this will be the result of increased foreign aid and low-interest credits from governments and international organizations to which Belize now has access, rather than because of increased production. ''It will be artificial in the sense that it will expand the country's infrastructure but won't really strengthen the economy,'' one foreign economist noted. **********The one variable that could dramatically change Belize's economic outlook as a nation is oil. At present, the country imports all its oil, yet Guatemala to the west and Mexico to the north have both discovered important oil fields and local geologists are confident that this territory forms part of the same hydrocarbon basin. So far, though, all exploratory wells have been dry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/world.main_headline: 2.5 Million Registered To Vote Today in Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/world.print_headline: 2.5 Million Registered To Vote Today in Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/world.body_text: **********About 2,490,000 Israelis will be eligible to vote in tomorrow's parliamentary elections. **********Most polling places will be open from 7 A.M. to 10 P.M. (1 A.M. to 4 P.M. New York time). **********Because paper ballots are used and must be counted by hand, official results are expected to come in slowly. Voters select a slate that is allotted seats in Parliament according to the number of votes it wins. The head of the slate with the most seats is asked by the President to form a cabinet. **********Early predictions will be available from the Israeli television, which plans to conduct an exit poll, and private pollsters, who intend to make forecasts on the basis of returns from sample precincts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/07/busin.body_text: **********May 6: Dome Petroleum made a bid for 14 million shares of Conoco at $65 a share, reserving the right to purchase as many as 22 million shares. Conoco shares closed up 6 5/8 points on the day, at 56 1/2.  Despite an unfavorable recommendation by Conoco's directors, 54.8 million shares were ultimately tendered.  May 29: Seagram approached Conoco privately and made an offer for 35 percent of Conoco. Conoco shares closed at 51 5/8, down 2.  June 1: Conoco announced an agreement to sell Dome Petroleum 52.9 percent of its holding in Hudson Bay Oil and Gas in exchange for 22 million shares of Conoco stock that Dome had acquired through its tender offer plus $245 million in cash. Conoco shares rose to 53.  June 17: Conoco turned down two more offers by Seagram, following the exchange with Dome Petroleum: to buy 28.6 million shares directly for $2 billion, or $70 a share; or to purchase 15.9 million shares at $75 apiece and 9.6 million shares on the open market for an estimated $1.7 billion.  June 18: Seagram began purchases of Conoco stock on the open market totaling 143,000 shares, for an estimated $7.7 million. Conoco shares closed at 54 1/4, up 1.  June 25: The boards of Conoco and Cities Service agreed to a merger.  That afternoon, however, negotiations were terminated because Seagram made an unsolicited $2.56 billion tender offer for 35 million shares of Conoco, a 40.7 percent stake, at $73 a share, with the option to acquire further shares. **********Trading in Conoco was suspended; when it resumed on June 26, the stock closed at 65 1/4, up 3 1/4 from June 24.  Week of June 25: Conoco sought other partners that it considered more compatible and subsequently began talks with Texaco for a cash merger.  June 30: Conoco's board of directors voted unanimously to oppose the Seagram offer, calling it ''inadequate.'' Conoco also filed a $1 billion suit against Seagram and its American subsidiaries to block the tender offer, alleging interference by Seagram with Conoco's merger discussions with Cities Service.  July 3: Seagram filed a countersuit against Conoco.  July 6: Du Pont agreed to acquire 100 percent of Conoco's stock for $7.3 billion in Du Pont common stock and cash. Under the terms of the merger, Du Pont would buy 40 percent of Conoco's 86 million outstanding shares for $87.50 each in cash and would exchange 1.6 shares of Du Pont for each remaining Conoco share. Conoco's shares closed at 77, up 7 3/8 from its close on July 2, the previous trading day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/05/world.main_headline: TERRORISTS IN SPAIN KILL GENERAL AND THREE POLICEMEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/05/world.print_headline: TERRORISTS IN SPAIN KILL GENERAL AND THREE POLICEMEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/05/world.body_text: **********Gunmen killed a 62-year-old general in a fashionable Madrid neighborhood today and in Barcelona two Civil Guards were slain while having breakfast in a bar. **********In the Madrid incident, a policemen was killed and two terrorists were wounded, as were four bystanders caught in a wild gun battle.  One terrorist was caught after neighborhood residents led the police to a garage where he had hidden. Two others fled. **********King Juan Carlos, just back from a short sailing holiday, visited the chapels where the bodies of the slain general, Andres Gonzalez de Suso, and the policemen were lying. Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo drove from Madrid airport to the chapels on his return from a visit to Portugal. He declared that the Government and the military were prepared for ''a long struggle against terrorism.'' Timing of Trial Debated **********While Mr. Calvo Sotelo has displayed firmness and decisiveness in his two difficult months as Prime Minister, a debate is unfolding in his Government on the timing of the court-martial that will judge the alleged authors of the unsuccessful coup in February, among them three senior generals. **********The matter has been complicated by the unauthorized disclosure to the press of the pretrial testimony of Lieut. Col. Antonio Tejero Molina, who invaded Parliament on Feb. 23 and held its members hostage for 18 hours. The colonel has attempted to implicate the King and senior officers in the plot. **********The publication of the ''Tejero papers,'' as the testimony is being called, lends force to defense lawyers' charges that the accused officers are being tried in the press and has begun to blur real responsibilities in the unsuccessful coup. Even before this affair, the prospect of a full-dress court-martial was troubling the Government, which is fearful of further arousing the military. **********The 28-year-old terrorist captured today was identified by the police as a member of the First of October Antifascist Resistance Organizations. The group also appeared responsible for the slayings in Barcelona. 5 Jailed Terrorists Escape **********Since the allegedly far-left organization came to public attention at the time of Francisco Franco's death in 1975, there have been persistent reports that is has been infiltrated by extreme rightists in the police, who have been portrayed as manipulating it at crucial moments to disrupt Spain's transition to democracy. **********Decimated by arrests and several killings of its leaders by the police, the group got a new lease on life when five of its members tunneled out of a prison in Zamora in December 1979. One of these fugitives apparently was involved in the Barcelona killings today. **********Gen. Gonzalez de Suso, who did not have a bodyguard, was the first head of the press office in the newly created Defense Ministry from 1977 to 1980. He was the fifth military officer killed since the unsuccessful coup.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/28/busin.body_text: **********Wage increases reached in major collective bargaining moderated in the first quarter and worker productivity improved substantially, the Labor Department reported today. But Government and business experts warned that the improvement might be short-lived. **********If both these trends were to continue, they would be likely to relieve inflationary pressures, but experts from the Labor Department and the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service said that wages were likely to rise in the second quarter and productivity to decline. **********Major collective bargaining settlements in the first three months of 1981 produced average wage increases of 9 percent in the first year of the new contracts compared with average first-year increases of 9.5 percent in 1980 settlements, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. **********However, the settlements covered relatively few workers and no major pattern-setting contracts, and the first-quarter results should not be regarded as a portent of future wage trends, Government officials cautioned. **********The officials said that wage contracts coming in the second quarter had been substantially higher. Some construction industry contracts signed recently have been in the 12 to 15 percent range for firstyear increases in wages and benefits, they added. **********In another report, the Labor Department said that the nation's productivity, which is defined as the output per hour of all workers, increased by a seasonally adjusted 3.9 percent in the private business sector in the first quarter compared with last year's fourth quarter. The increase in productivity, often considered a key factor in reducing inflation, was the biggest since the third quarter of 1977, when it rose 5.1 percent, the bureau said. **********However, unit labor costs to business were again up sharply as hourly compensation, which includes Social Security and benefit payments by employers as well as wages, again outstripped the increase in productivity by a wide margin. Unit labor costs were up by 7.4 percent in the quarter, the bureau reported. **********Sharp rises in productivity are customary when the nation's economy grows after a recession, as it did in the first quarter. The increase in the first quarter was on top of a low base: productivity had declined by 1.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1980. **********In the manufacturing sector, the productivity increase was at an annual rate of 1.6 percent, after jumping 11.4 percent in 1980's last quarter. **********Labor economists traditionally look at collective bargaining in three-year cycles. This year is regarded as the least active and significant of the cycle because there are few major contract expirations. The major contracts that are being renegotiated in 1981, in coal, railroads and the Postal Service, historically have not set patterns for wage negotiations that follow them. Teamster Pact Seen as Crucial **********Next year a new cycle begins with the negotiation of the master freight agreement between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking industry. That settlement has been generally regarded as crucial in setting wage patterns for much of the rest of the economy. **********Richard W. Rahn, chief economist for the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, commented that, although the first-quarter collective bargaining results were relatively meaningless in terms of what was likely to happen for the rest of the year, ''if people really begin to find inflation going down, we will start getting harder-nosed bargaining from businessmen.'' **********The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that collective bargaining settlements in the first quarter provided wage increases averaging 7.7 percent over the life of the contract - as opposed to the first year of the contract. In 1980, the average increase for the life of the contract was 7.1 percent. **********The Consumer Price Index rose by 9.6 percent in the first quarter as prices continued to outpace wages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM A SOVIET BOOLKET ON NUCLEAR WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM A SOVIET BOOLKET ON NUCLEAR WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from ''The Threat to Europe,'' a booklet written in the form of questions and answers, that was issued today in English by the Soviet Committee for European Security and Cooperation: **********Q. Can a nuclear war be considered winnable?  A. Western political and military writers contend that Soviet military doctrine is based exclusively on the belief that a world nuclear war can be won. But that is a simplistic and distorted view of our approach. In fact, the Soviet Union holds that nuclear war would be a universal disaster and that it would most probably mean the end of civilization. It may lead to the destruction of all humankind. There may be no victor in such a war, and it can solve no political problems. **********Soviet people are not thinking in terms of winning a nuclear war but of averting such a war by all means. They take into account the changing relevance of armed forces as an instrument of politics.  Here is how Leonid Brezhnev put it: ''By and large, it is probably safe to say that people are gradually coming to understand that none of the problems in the world can be solved from positions of strength, by any sabre-rattling.'' (Speech in Alma-Ata, 29 August 1980.) **********'Limited Nuclear War' **********The same applies to the idea of a ''limited nuclear war'' in Europe or elsewhere as conceived in U.S. Presidential Directive 59 of 25 July 1980. One might discourse on ''limited nuclear war'' in theory only, but on the practical plane it is nothing less than unrealistic. **********Q. In the West one hears now and then that Soviet military doctrine is of an aggressively offensive nature, considers a first strike possible and includes plans for a sudden, blitzkrieg-style invasion of Western Europe. Is this true? **********A. That is another popular theme in Western military and political propaganda. They use a very simple ruse to adduce that Soviet doctrine is aggressively offensive. They do so by quoting from works of Soviet military theorists devoted not to doctrine or military policy but to particular aspects of combat, such as tactics in the battlefield. These quotes are passed off as Soviet doctrine, though that is a deliberately incorrect and specious approach. It gives not the slightest idea of Soviet doctrine, which is defensive but, of course, necessarily envisages the training of soldiers for various actions in the field of battle. Defensive Military Doctrine **********Soviet military doctrine is of a purely defensive nature. ''We never had and never will have any strategic doctrine other than a defensive one,'' says the declaration of the Warsaw Treaty states of 15 May 1980. It does not admit of either a first or pre-emptive strike or of any ''lightning'' invasion of Western Europe. In so doing it follows definite political, ethical and military principles. There is no aggressive element in Soviet military doctrine because the Soviet Union has no political, economic, social or military aims in Europe or anywhere else that it intends to secure by armed force. **********Q. Why then do Soviet theoretical works on military strategy of, say, the early 60's refer to offensive action, to building up a military advantage? Doesn't this prove that Soviet military strategy reposes on these principles even today? **********A. No, it proves no such thing. Soviet military strategy is neither immutable nor everlasting. It changes with the changing world. The same happens in the United States, where the strategy of flexible response and thereupon that of realistic deterrence replaced a doctrine of massive retaliation. Soviet theoretical works of the early 60's reflected the views of their time. And it was a time when the United States commanded a considerable nuclear-missile advantage, when it threatened the Soviet Union with massive nuclear strikes and declared that a nuclear war against the U.S.S.R. was winnable. Emergence of Detente **********The equilibrium of strategic forces that shaped up between the U.S.S.R. and the U.S.A. compelled the latter to accept detente, which made considerable headway in the 70's and slackened the war danger. Technological advances and growth of nuclear weapons stockpiles had made nuclear war altogether senseless. Soviet military doctrine, which has always reposed on the principle of retaliatory, that is, defensive, action, says nothing at all in the new conditions of the 70's and early 80's of nuclear war being winnable and, more, lays the accent still more emphatically than before on preventing it, on maintaining the military equilibrium and on lowering the level of military confrontation by means of military detente. **********Q. It is said that the numerical strength of the Soviet armed forces is far greater than the country needs for defense. Is that true? **********A. The strength of the Soviet armed forces is not greater than needed for defense. It matches the defensive needs. To see this you must consider at least two pertinent factors: the regional strength balances and the g@eostrategic factor. Special Soviet Situation **********The Soviet Union's strategic situation compels it, for purposes of defense, to insure not only a general equilibrium of strength between it and the U.S.A., and between the Warsaw Treaty countries and NATO, but also a regional equilibrium in separate theaters, each with its own military specifics. To begin with, the strength of the armed forces of the Soviet Union and its allies must match the area of the territory they defend, the overall length of frontiers and the nature of the potential dangers. No other country in the world has anything even remotely equal or similar to these factors. The armies of the Warsaw Treaty countries have a territory of 23,500,000 square kilometers to defend, out of which 22,500,000 square kilometers are Soviet territory. This is more than the area of the United States, Europe and China combined. The NATO armies have only 2 million square kilometers, or one-eleventh of that area, to defend. **********Faced in the West by the NATO bloc, which includes three nuclear powers, the Soviet Union is simultaneously exposed to danger in the east from two American Pacific nuclear fleets and from China, with its growing nuclear potential and the world's most numerous army.  Furthermore, the deployment of U.S. Naval nuclear forces in the northern sector of the Indian Ocean within reach of southern regions of the Soviet Union combines with the string of U.S. military bases stretching from the Mediterranean across the Middle East to Pakistan and countries in Southeast Asia. In effect, the Soviet Union is compelled to reckon with the likelihood of a blockade being put up around it. This is being made increasingly apparent, among other things, by the growing political and military cooperation between the United States and China. An American Advantage **********Further, it ought to be borne in mind that by virtue of its favorable geographical situation, the United States can insure the defense of its own national frontiers by a minimal force. The Soviet Union, on the other hand, is compelled to guarantee proper balance and dependable defense by distributing its forces along the entire length of its borders and, moreover, insuring a rough equilibrium in the world ocean where it is exposed to growing dangers from the U.S.  nuclear Navy. **********Q. Isn't the military balance steadily tipping in favor of the Soviet Union? This can't help creating alarm in the West.  A. During the first roughly 20 years after the war, the United States had a strategic nuclear advantage over the U.S.S.R. At the turn of the 70's, the defensive efforts of the Soviet Union ended this superiority. Since then, there has been military-strategic equilibrium. **********This is acknowledged by the Soviet Union and by Western statesmen as well.  Q. Why do these statesmen say today that the Soviet Union is militarily ahead, and that Soviet-American parity no longer exists?  A. Because the U.S. Administration does not want parity. It wants the world to identify parity with U.S. military superiority. By definition, the achievement of military equilibrium by the Soviet Union means the U.S.A. has dropped behind and the pillars of peace are undermined. Spokesmen of the Reagan Administration claim that peace hinges on U.S. military superiority. Caspar W. Weinberger, for example, said on 20 May 1981 that to preserve peace the United States must have the kind of lead that it had in the 50's and 60's. **********This view is the very opposite to the opinion of the Soviet Union and many West European governments. They hold that in the present circumstances peace and international stability depend not on the superiority of either of the sides but precisely on military equilibrium. And since this viewpoint is widespread across the world, and notably among the West European public, advocates of military superiority are at pains to distort the obtaining state of affairs by irresponsible pronouncements equating parity to Soviet military superiority, and thus justifying their arms buildup. **********Q. Though that is what the Soviet Union maintains, it is continuously, developing new types of weapons. Its deeds don't match its words: it says it wants the arms race stopped. But isn't the U.S.S.R. taking an active part in it? **********A. You must look below the surface of things. The Soviet Union does not initiate new weapons. It develops them in response to the appearance of such weapons in the United States. Here are the facts to prove it: Strategic Weapons Milestones U.S.  U.S.S.R.  Atom bomb 1945 1949 Intercontinental strategic bomber 1948 1954-55 Nuclear-powered submarine 1960 1968 MRV missile (operational) 1964 1973 **********By the beginning of the 70's the United States had initiated 23 out of the 25 existing major weapons systems. And since then the number of U.S. ''initiatives'' has increased. The latest one is the decision to manufacture neutron bombs. **********Remember, too, that the Soviet Union has invariably offered to mutually renounce development every time the prospect of new still more dagngerous types of weapons appeared. At the dawn of the nuclear era the Soviet Union proposed that nuclear arms should be outlawed and their development stopped. For many years, it has been campaigning for a complete halt to nuclear tests. That would have stopped or at least greatly restricted the development of new types of nuclear weapons. The Soviet Union offered the United States to mutually renounce multiple warheads (if this proposal had been acccepted, there would have been no SS-20 missile). The proposal not to adopt cruise missiles came from the Soviet Union as well. The Soviet Union proposed that no one in the world should manufacture neutron weapons. But all these proposals were turned down by the United States in its continuous pursuit of elusive military superiority.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/07/busin.print_headline: CITICORP PLANS A BANK IN DELAWARE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/07/busin.body_text: **********Citicorp, the nation's biggest banking organization and one of the largest employers in New York City, announced yesterday that it had taken steps to establish a bank in Delaware where the tax rate averages 3 percent compared with a 26 percent rate for big New York banks. **********It is expected that much of the future growth in Citicorp's banking business would be channeled through the proposed Delaware subsidiary.  Currently, Citicorp employs 17,000 people in the New York metropolitan area. Although it is not expected that the establishment of a subsidiary in Delaware would reduce this number, analysts contend that it could seriously reduce any growth in Citicorp jobs in the New York region. **********The move by Citicorp is in line with similar actions taken earlier this year by the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the second-largest bank in New York, and by J.P. Morgan & Company, the fifth-largest. Tax-Reduction Motive Cited **********Citicorp's decision to establish a Delaware office was seen by some analysts as part of a strategy to apply pressure on Governor Hugh Carey, the New York State Legislature and New York City to reduce state and city taxes imposed on banks. The 26 percent tax rate comprises both state and city taxes. **********Citicorp indicated that it would shift its interest-free checking deposits, on which it makes some of its greatest profits, from Citibank in New York to Citibank Delaware. According to the New York Clearing House Association, such deposits at Citibank averaged $5.1 billion a day during the financial week that ended July 29. **********The interest-free deposits would be used to finance loans that were transferred to the Delaware subsidiary. If the average rate of interest on such loans were, say, 22 percent, the profit, before taxes and other expenses, would amount to about $1 billion of income a year. Moved Operations to South Dakota **********The strategy is similar to one used last year when Citicorp threatened to pull its large credit-card processing business, which has employed as many as 2,000 people on Long Island, out of New York. **********Citicorp had warned that if New York State failed to eliminate its ceilings on the amount of interest banks may charge on consumer loans, the bank would move its credit-card operations to South Dakota. Although the ceilings were removed last November, Citicorp established a subsidiary in Sioux Falls anyway, explaining that the bank had made a commitment to the South Dakota state government. **********In yesterday's terse announcement, Citicorp said it would invest $50 million in the proposed bank, which initially would employ more than 110 people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/15/busin.body_text: **********The pace of corporate mergers quickened in the first quarter of 1981, rising to 599, or 46 percent ahead of the 411 in the same quarter a year earlier, W.T. Grimm & Company, a Chicago-based merger specialist said yesterday. **********Reflecting several billion-dollar acquisitions under way in the quarter, total dollar volume rose to a record $17.5 billion, more than double the $7.2 billion in the first quarter of 1980, Grimm said. **********The company called the number of mergers the highest quarterly count since the third quarter of 1977, although only 25 of the total involved combinations of $100 million or more. **********Some of the largest mergers completed or pending as of March 3l are: Standard Oil Company of California's proposed acquisition of Amax Inc. for $3.9 billion; the proposed acquisition by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) of the Kennecott Corporation for $2 billion; the Penn Central Corporation's offer of $700 million for G.K.  Technologies Inc., and the purchase by the General Foods Corporation of Oscar Mayer & Company for $465 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/01/world.main_headline: SYRIAN VEHICLES MOVE MORE ANTIAIRCRAFT MISSILES INTO EASTERN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/01/world.print_headline: SYRIAN VEHICLES MOVE MORE ANTIAIRCRAFT MISSILES INTO EASTERN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/01/world.body_text: **********More Syrian vehicles carrying what appeared to be antiaircraft missiles could be seen moving into eastern Lebanon today, and Syrian planes patrolled the skies to guard against further Israeli attacks. **********Six Soviet-made SAM-6's were reported to have been transported into the Bekaa Valley east of here yesterday after Israeli planes shot down two Syrian helicopters on Tuesday. Six more missiles were seen moving into eastern Lebanon today by a reporter during a visit to the valley. **********Later, the missiles were reported to be deployed near Riyaq, five miles east of Zahle, the Lebanese Christian town that Syrian forces have besieged since the beginning of the month. **********The two Syrian helicopters were downed near Riyaq in attacks that Israel described as a warning that it would not tolerate any Syrian attempt to ''conquer Lebanon and liquidate the Christians.'' **********Reports from Tel Aviv, however, quoted Prime Minister Menachem Begin as saying, in an apparent attempt to calm the situation, that he did not expect the friction with Syria to lead to war. **********''We don't want one,'' he said in an interview, ''and the Syrians have good reason not to rush into one.'' Apparently in a further move to ease tensions, he said Israel had no authoritative confirmation of reports that the Syrians had deployed SAM-6's in Lebanon. He persisted in this statement even after being reminded that his military spokesman had reported otherwise. **********Supporting the Israeli military spokesman was a statement from the State Department in Washington. It said American intelligence reports indicated that the Syrians had moved an unspecified number of SAM-6's into eastern Lebanon. **********In other developments, a spokesman for the alliance of Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese leftists said that the group's forces in southern Lebanon heavily shelled 17 settlements in northern israel today. Palestinian officials described the shelling as a response to repeated Israeli air raids this week over suspected guerrilla encampments. **********An Israeli army spokesman said eight persons were slightly wounded in today's shelling. He said it was the fourth day of shelling and the first to produce any casualties. **********Meanwhile, Lebanon's President, Elias Sarkis, sent a 200-man unit of the regular Lebanese Army to join 500 Lebanese soldiers serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon. The purpose was to try to extend Lebanese Government influence in the area. **********According to the Damascus radio, President Assad received assurances today from King Khalid of Saudi Arabia, Kuwaiti leaders and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, that they would fully support Syria in the event of a war with Israel. **********Here in Beirut, an undeclared cease-fire between the Syrians and Christians appeared to be holding. ---- U.S. Checks Israeli Arms Use Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, April 30 - The State Department said today it was ''looking into the question'' whether Israel had violated agreements with the United States by using American-built aircraft in its recent raids against targets in Lebanon. **********The department made this known in response to reporters' questions.  Under a 1952 mutual security agreement with Israel, the Israelis agreed to use American-supplied weapons for ''legitimate self-defense.'' Similar requirements are written into the Arms Export Control Act of 1968.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/world.main_headline: REAGAN SON TO QUIT JOB IN CONTROVERSY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/world.print_headline: REAGAN SON TO QUIT JOB IN CONTROVERSY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/world.body_text: **********President Reagan's son Michael said today that he would resign from his job with a military contractor, just after the White House defended his use of his father's name in seeking Air Force contracts on behalf of the concern. **********There were conflicting accounts today of who first brought up the President's name.  The White House, defending Michael Reagan, said he had mentioned his relationship to the President only after others had brought it up. But an Air Force officer and a civilian employee of the Department of Defense said today that Michael Reagan had first brought up the President's name, in a telephone call and a letter seeking business at the military installation that maintains Air Force One. **********Advice From Counsel **********Michael Reagan, who is 35 years old, is a vice president of Dana Ingalls Profile Inc. of Burbank, Calif., which manufactures missile and aircraft components. He is also a senior vice president of the Southern Pacific Title Company of Santa Ana. **********A White House spokesman said Michael Reagan had done nothing ''illegal or improper,'' but this afternoon the President asked the White House counsel, Fred Fielding, to advise his son and other family members to help them avoid ''even the appearance of impropriety.'' A White House announcement termed this ''a precautionary step'' taken in response to the son's request. **********Asked today whether he was going to quit his job at the Burbank concern, the President's son replied, ''I'm going to have to.'' This was so, he said, according to a tape recording of an interview made by CBS News, because the company would find it impossible to get Government work. He said the step was necessary not because of anything the company might have done, but because of the actions of the news media in reporting his activities. **********The younger Mr. Reagan referred to The Oklahoma City Times, which first disclosed the matter, as Pravda, which is the name of the Communist Party newspaper in the Soviet Union. He asserted, ''It's a stupid, stupid story.'' **********He said the news media were making it impossible for him to find work, which he needed. He added, ''I have got to make a house payment, a car payment, raise a child.'' **********He insisted, as he had previously, that he had mentioned his father in his letters only after two or three conversations in which others had mentioned the President first. **********Michael Reagan said that he spoke to the President yesterday and that he intended in the future to follow his father's advice to him, which he said was, ''Don't write any letters.'' **********The White House press office said tonight that there would be no comment on Michael Reagan's statements, which he made in apparent anger to a large group of reporters on the lawn in front of his house in the Sherman Oaks section of Los Angeles. **********The controversy arose when the Oklahoma newspaper found that the younger Mr. Reagan had written to Tinker Air Force Base near Oklahoma City, which, among other things, services Air Force One and other Presidential jets, asking that Dana Ingalls Profile be put on the list of businesses qualified to submit competitive bids. It later turned out that similar letters had been sent to at least five other bases. **********''I know that, with my father's leadership at the White House, this countries (sic) Armed Services are going to be rebuilt and strengthened,'' he wrote. ''We at Dana Ingalls Profile want to be involved in that process.'' Reagan Aide Explains Reference **********Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, said today that Michael Reagan had mentioned the President only because the purchasing official, Roy Sadler, had commented on the Reagan relationship in an earlier phone conversation. ''The use of the President's name in his correspondence was a reference in that letter to a conversation that he had had with the individual he was writing,'' Mr. Speakes said. **********But Mr. Sadler said in an interview today that neither he nor anyone in his office had spoken with Michael Reagan. They were ''startled,'' he said, to get a business letter invoking the President's name, and wondered how many other military bases were being so solicited. **********The President's son had earlier phoned the Air Force officer in charge of a purchasing division at Tinker Air Force Base, which buys $2 billion worth of airplane parts a year by competitive bid. In that telephone call, too, it was Mr. Reagan who first mentioned his relationship to the President, according to the officer, Col. Tom Nash. **********The colonel said Michael Reagan had called him on March 23 to find out how the Ingalls firm could get on the bid list. Colonel Nash quoted Mr. Reagan as saying, ''We need a stronger national defense.  Maybe Dad can help.'' No 'Problems' for President **********At first, Colonel Nash said, he was puzzled by the remark. He said in an interview that it was not until a few days later, when Mr.  Reagan mailed him a carbon copy of the letter to Mr. Sadler, that he realized that ''Dad'' was the President. **********Mr. Speakes said today that the President did not have ''any problems with the way Michael is doing business.'' He said Michael Reagan's associates, without prompting from him, habitually raise the kinship issue. The President, Mr. Speakes said, ''is hopeful that Michael can do business as a private citizen without the family name constantly being raised.'' **********Mr. Speakes said that Michael Reagan called his father yesterday ''because he was being hounded by members of the press corps.'' The letter to Tinker Air Force Base came to light yesterday, after The Oklahoma City Times secured it under the Freedom of Information Act. **********Mr. Speakes said he did not know if the President thought it was wrong for his relatives to seek Government business, but he added, ''The President feels Michael should have the opportunity to do business as a private citizen without the problems of his being related to the President of the United States interfering.'' Carter Guidelines Dropped **********Mr. Speakes added that guidelines proscribing Government dealings by members of the First Family - instituted by President Carter to curb his brother, Billy - were no longer in effect. Those guidelines read, ''While it could be argued that members of the President's family have the same right as any other citizens to have the Government engage in discretionary dealings with them, this is a right that is best relinquished during the President's incumbency.'' **********J. Jackson Walter, the head of the Office of Government Ethics, a Federal agency, said that Michael Reagan's actions were not illegal but represented ''a dubious kind of behavior.'' He added, ''Would this letter have been sent but for the parent situation?'' **********Harold Palmer, vice president and general manager of Dana Ingalls Inc., said Michael Reagan had joined the company as marketing vice president last December. His job is to sell its aircraft and machinery components. Following Mr. Reagan's letter, according to Air Force officials, the company was put on Tinker Air Force Base's computerized list of approved suppliers in a routine way. **********Mr. Palmer said Mr. Reagan wrote to at least five military installations that buy airplane parts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/19/world.main_headline: PEKING SAYS ARMS FOR TAIWAN PERIL U.S.-CHINA TIE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/19/world.print_headline: PEKING SAYS ARMS FOR TAIWAN PERIL U.S.-CHINA TIE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/19/world.body_text: **********The New China News Agency, in an assessment of the visit by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., said today that China and the United States had ''identical or similar views'' on global strategic matters and had made progress in improving their realtions. But it said the issue of arms sales to Taiwan remained a stumbling block. **********Stressing that China wanted to see relations with the United States develop on the basis of an identity of strategic interests, the agency added: **********''However, if the United States merely pays attention to the pressure of some pro-Taiwan forces and ignores the national feelings of the Chinese people, Chinese-United States relations cannot even be preserved as they are today, to say nothing of any further development.'' **********The news agency said Americans who thought China would ''swallow the bitter pill of United States arms sales to Taiwan'' to get American support against the Soviet Union had made a ''wrong calculation betraying their ignorance of history.'' **********Alluding to President Reagan's comments in a news conference upholding present legislation on relations with Taiwan, the agency said: **********''Before and just after Secretary of State Alexander Haig's visit to China, Americans in the United States Government and in the opposition still advocated clinging to the Taiwan Relations Act and continuing arms sales to the island. This cannot but cast a shadow on the developing Chinese-United States relations.'' **********In another development, a Chinese official who took part in 1969 border talks with the Russians accused Moscow of reneging on an agreement to negotiate boundary disputes. The official, Li Huichuan, who is an adviser to the Foreign Ministry, said Soviet intransigence over the issue was ''not only malicious but also dangerous, reeking of expansionism and gunpowder.'' **********The agreement to open negotiations on boundary disputes, which followed a series of border clashes, was reached in September 1969 between the Chinese Prime Minister, Zhou Enlai, and the Soviet Prime Minister, Aleksei N. Kosygin. The border talks began the following month and dragged on for several years before becoming inactive. **********Mr. Li, who was a deputy chief of the original Chinese negotiating team, made his points in an article to be published July 1 in Research on International Problems, a quarterly journal. The article appeared Wednesday in The People's Daily, the party newspaper. **********The article reviews the border talks beginning in 1964, when, it said, the Chinese renounced any claim to czarist annexations under 19th-century treaties. Despite this concession, Mr. Li said, the Soviet Union insisted on keeping territory it had gained since those treaties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/busin.body_text: **********Some call it a three-ring circus; others describe it as three pits. Both refer to trading in new futures contracts for bank certificates of deposit now under way on the New York Futures Exchange, the Chicago Board of Trade and the International Monetary Market. **********The inability of bankers, securities dealers and investors to predict interest rates in recent years has created a ready market for financial futures, making it one of the fastest growing areas of the securities business. **********High and volatile interest rates have caused more borrowers and lenders to use financial futures, of which contracts on certificates of deposit are the latest entry, to protect themselves from adverse changes of interest rates. Indeed, the rosy outlook for financial futures has attracted competitors to the market. **********Choices Available **********The 90-day Treasury bill contracts offered by the International Monetary Market of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange is among the dominant futures available. Others include the Chicago Board of Trade's Treasury bond futures and Government National Mortgage Association pass-through certificates. **********So far, the dominance of these contracts has not been challenged.  But the rapid growth has attracted competition from the New York Futures Exchange, a subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange that started business about a year ago, and the Commodity Exchange Inc., known as Comex. The big success at Comex, which does not trade in C.D. futures, has been its gold contract, which is by far the most active of its type. **********At the New York Futures Exchange, officials are optimistic that they will be successful with the new C.D. futures, which in less than two months have emerged as the exchange's most active contract. Contracts in C.D.'s **********The new C.D. contracts are a promise to buy or sell, at a specific price at some specificed future time, a $1 million, three-month certificate of deposit issued by one of a select group of large American banks. In trading before the delivery date, contract prices drop if interest rates rise, but if rates fall, the contract prices rise. In case of losses, the buyer or seller of a contract must either deposit additional margin with his broker, or make an offsetting transaction to wipe out the position. **********A simple hedge using C.D's. might involve a securities dealer who wanted to buy $10 million of C.D.'s from a bank, but wanted to reduce the risk of loss should interest rates rise before he could resell the certificates. By selling 10 C.D. contracts on an exchange, the dealer could offset losses on the C.D.'s purchased from the bank with profits on the C.D. futures contracts. **********Officials at all three exchanges have high hopes for the C.D.  contracts because, they claim, it fills a special need that is not satisfied by a futures contract in 90-day Treasury bills. **********Treasury bill rates are often a poor guide to changes in shortterm domestic interest rates, they say, because of huge purchases or sales by foreign central banks. Source of Funds **********Certificates of deposit, which are issued by large banks to raise money for loans they make, are a more accurate measure of domestic credit conditions, it is claimed. **********After languishing in the files of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for years, the C.D. contracts emerged in rapid succession this summer. The New York Futures Exchange started trading July 9, followed by the International Monetary Market of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on July 22, and the Chicago Board of Trade on July 29. **********While the Chicago exchanges dominate Treasury bill and bond futures partly because they were first to offer the product, analysts say that the New York Futures Exchange, although it offered the first C.D. contract, offers no such advantage. The other exchanges were quick to follow, and they still have a larger pool of active, experienced traders than does the New York Futures Exchange. Liquidity Credited **********''Chicago will remain the leader in financial futures because we have the people who are willing to risk their money to make highly liquid and efficient markets,'' said Leo Melamed, special counsel to the Chicago Merchantile Exchange. **********No exchange has emerged as a winner yet, but many analysts predict that the C.D. contract will survive at only two of the exchanges.  Richard Sandor, president of Conti Commodities and sometimes called ''the father of financial futures,'' predicted that ''one exchange will dominate the contract, with another in a secondary role.'' The experience with gold and other commodities, he said, has shown that three exchanges with the same product cannot endure. **********Officials at all three exchanges agreed that, so far, there is no clear loser in the competition for a C.D. contract. Commercial Market Essential **********John Blin, director of marketing at the New York Futures Exchange, explained that ''the two surviving exchanges with C.D.'s will be those that successfully attract the commercial users of C.D.'s - the dealers and ultimately the banks.'' A futures market that relies too much on arbitrage against similar futures contracts, and upon traders trading with traders ''is not a long-term proposition,'' he added. **********Securities dealers have so far been the biggest users of the markets, but have not shown a clear favorite among the exchanges.  ''It looks like the dealers are rotating their orders, testing and probing each exchange,'' said Mike Kijanka, director of marketing at the International Monetary Market. **********What about the banks, which are supposed to be natural users of the market because the contracts for certificates of deposit match the C.D.'s they issue? ''So far, the talk-to-ticket ratio is quite high,'' commented Richard MacWilliams, senior vice-president at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. ''There are lots of people studying the market,'' he said, but few have integrated C.D. futures into their asset and liability management decisions. Risk in Some Indicators **********The success or failure of the exchanges will be influenced by technical variations in their contracts that are important to traders and arbitrageurs. Some analysts warn that daily trading volumes and open interest data are not reliable indicators of the success of the exchanges, since those numbers can be inflated by meaningless transactions. **********In fact, at the Chicago exchanges, the published figures for estimated daily volume have exceeded the actual trading volume by as much as 40 percent, although on some days, the published volume estimates are less than the actual volume reported a day later by the clearing corporation. At the New York Futures Exchange, an on-line computer system eliminates the need for estimating volume, according to Mr. Blin. **********According to analysts familiar with the three C.D. contracts, the version offered by the New York Futures Exchange has extra appeal because it includes delivery in nearby months, and not just one month every quarter as do contracts of the Chicago exchanges. The International Monetary Market has a natural advantage, they say, because it calls for delivery in the second half of the month, while the Board of Trade and the New York Futures Exchange are both competing with contracts that specify delivery in the first half of the month.
