https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/02/busin.body_text: **********straightforward, efficient and built to survive. He is also a man who has said more than once that free enterprise should be used to defend free enterprise. In other words, if a jet fighter is reliable, efficient and meets the needs of the market, it will sell. It doesn't need a handout from Uncle Sam. **********To prove it, Mr. Jones is spending $300 million of Northrop's money on a new plane, the F-5G Tigershark, the latest of the company's supersonic fighters in the immensely successful F-5 family. (The 3,500th family member was delivered last week, to Thailand.) And he is challenging a longtime industry pattern that normally calls for getting advance orders and government money to assist in the enormously expensive process of designing, building and testing new planes. **********Mr. Jones has no advance orders. In fact, he didn't even build a prototype. ''We didn't need it. We designed it right the first time,'' the 61-year-old executive said. ''When you're using your own money, you usually do what's right.'' **********As Mr. Jones tells it, the plane, to be ready for delivery in July 1983, will fit so well into the arsenals of Northrop's 28 nation clients that it will be as natural as adding a microwave oven to a modern kitchen. **********Nothing comes without a price, however, and at Northrop the price of going its own way with the F-5G has been a 77.1 percent drop in second-quarter earnings and a 37.9 percent decline in the first half. For this year and next, analysts are predicting earnings at about the same level as 1980's $86.1 million. **********But Mr. Jones is betting short-term appearances against long-term gains. ''All defense business is long term,'' said Mr. Jones. ''Five years is very close in. If a customer intends to have a meaningful force, then 10 years is a relatively short time.'' **********Northrop is, in short, something of an anomaly in the defense and aerospace industry, where government nurturing is standard and erratic performance has been the norm. Like everyone else in the defense industries, it looks forward to a mid-decade surge in business promoted by the Reagan Administration. But there the common thread is snapped. **********Northrop shuns the usual cost-plus contracts, in which the government underwrites the cost of overruns. Instead, it offers its customers a fixed price good for a number of years. The idea is to spread estimated costs over the projected sales life of the aircraft, taking the risk that the company might never break even. **********That way, Northrop may have small profit margins at the outset, when production wrinkles are being worked out, but it can predict its long-run profitability. **********Then too, except for its fighter planes, Northrop tends to concentrate its business on specific components rather than whole systems. So, unless the MX program is canceled or cutback drastically, Northrop can expect to see the completion of the $235 million contract it has with the United State Air Force to develop the MX guidance system. **********Northrop tends to spread risk by becoming involved in many projects. It has a $4.6 million contract for gyroscopes for the F-16, for example, a $112 million United States Air Force contract for radar jamming equipment, a $36.2 million contract for MX gyroscopes and a $14.7 million contract from the United States Army for an electro-optical system for the Hawk missile. **********Mr. Jones likes to keep his eye on control and quality, so Northrop has avoided government-owned plants, which its competitors widely use. He prefers to own his own facilities, where equipment can be designed to meet Northrop's needs. ''How do you improve plant and equipment if you don't own it?'' Mr. Jones asked. **********Undaunted by the evaporation of government support for research for export aircraft, Northrop is paying for its own, betting on its own technology to cut waste and its own programs to eliminate red tape.  The F-5's, whose only effective competition in world markets is the Soviet MIG, are totally export-oriented, although, because of their simplicity, the United States Air Force and Navy have bought a few for use in training. **********Only about one-quarter the size of Rockwell International, less than one-half the size of McDonnell Douglas or Lockheed, Northrop has been by far the best performer of the lot. Its stock has climbed from $10 to $53 since 1975. **********The fact is, Northrop can probably afford to take a chance with the Tigershark, the $7 million version of its lightweight, nononsense jets, even though its investment will strain its $115 million annual cash flow. (Its nearest domestic competitor is General Dynamics's F-16, with similar performance but a $12 million price tag.) **********With the $200 million capital expansion program for Northrop's portion of the F-18 and other programs, Northrop's investments will exceed $500 million in the next few years, not by any means a shocking amount. **********Mr. Jones, although he controls only about 260,059 of Northrop's 14.4 million shares, has operated the company as if it were his own for more than two decades. **********Thomas O. Paine, a former head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and a General Electric executive, came in as president in 1976, after Northrop was rocked by a questionable payments scandal. But Mr. Paine, while forming with Mr. Jones a twoman executive committee, concentrates on the nonaircraft portion of the business, which have their headquarters in Chicago, Kansas City, Hawthorne and Ventura. **********While heads rolled at other companies tainted by scandal, Mr.  Jones remains in the driver's seat at Northrop. For that remarkable feat, he has to thank his inspired salesmanship, Northrop's continued prosperity under his hand, and, as a special board committee noted, the ''absence of an apparent successor.'' **********At the beginning of the F-5 program, Mr. Jones personally convinced heads of state in Saudi Arabia, Singapore and Iran - he was a friend of the late Shah - to buy his planes. He jetted around the world arranging meetings and sales, and he built a sales network that is unexcelled in the industry for its ingenuity. **********Not only would Northrop service the planes, but the company would help finance them, help build the airstrips, train the pilots and help out with nonmilitary problems. When Switzerland signed a contract for 72 F-5's in 1976, Northrop promised to find new business for its client so that Switzerland could afford its $150 million aircraft tab. **********Under what became known as the ''Swiss offset program,'' Northrop became a promoter of Swiss products, even convincing the Pentagon to help out. It delivered $150 million worth of business, three years before deadline, and won a second round, 65 percent going to third countries, the remainder to the United States. **********Last month, Switzerland came back for an additional 38 planes valued at more than $300 million. As with the previous sale, Northrop has promised to promote Swiss business products throughout the world - this time $140 million worth of nondefense business ranging from interior design and wine presses to X-ray equipment. **********Northrop's marketing program gradually leads customers through Northrop's alphabet of F-5 fighters, beginning with the simplist available and graduating to the higher end of the model line. **********Even the high end is marked by a noticeable simplicity. While competitors built birds, Northrop built gnats -small, easily maneuverable, easily maintained, fast-flying and reasonably priced defensive weapons -that could swamp an attacker, hit and run. ''We have used our advanced technology to simplify,'' said Mr. Jones. **********The F-5 was designed primarily for American allies after it became apparent in 1956 that planes given by the United States to countries like Brazil and Turkey were too sophisticated, required too many parts and skilled mechanics. Northrop set out to develop a simple plane, one that would counteract the threat of the Soviet-built MIG-15. **********The F-5G, now up against the MIG-23, is the newest in the tradition. And, according to Northrop, it is the simplest and most reliable yet. It has a General Electric engine with 14,300 parts, 7,700 fewer than its predecessor, the single pilot F-5E and the twopilot F-5F, but offers 60 percent more engine thrust. **********And the engine is designed so that it can be broken down into six units for easy maintenance. Manpower requirements for maintenance have been reduced by 52 percent and the cost of operation and maintenance by 63 percent. Even though the plane will weigh more than the F-5E, it will take off in 28 percent less distance and climb 48 percent faster. Flying at a maximum speed of up to 1,300 miles an hour at 36,000 feet, the F-5G is 22 percent faster than the F-5E, while consuming 53 percent less fuel. **********''We have tried to look at the whole picture, the real needs of the customer,'' C. Robert Gates vice president international and the F-5G program manager, said. ''Perhaps the best feature is that we can promise our customers that the F-5G's average operational ready rate will be 80 percent. That means there will be more of them in the air, not on the ground for repair. The planes on the ground are the same as having no planes at all.'' **********''Numbers is the name of the game,'' Mr. Jones said. ''The number of planes you can afford. The number of planes in the air.'' Diversification into less cyclical businesses than aerospace might have been tempting to some, but Mr. Jones believes in keeping Northrop on a tried and true course. **********The result has been selective business expansion in areas where Northrop's reputation for advanced technology and reliability can pay off. Northrop's Wilcox Electric Inc., for example, is recognized as a leading supplier of navigational equipment with customers in more than 100 countries. The company's Precision Products division is a leader in gyroscopes. And, Northrop is the leader in the production of electronic countermeasure instrumentation, which are Soviet missile detection devices. **********''A company has to have a character,'' said Mr. Jones, who acknowledges the company is a lot like him in many ways. ''I like to think we're bold in concept and conservative in details.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/16/world.main_headline: NEW BRITISH PARTY IN ELECTION DEBUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/16/world.print_headline: NEW BRITISH PARTY IN ELECTION DEBUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/16/world.body_text: **********''We were not willing to go on being the fig leaves for policies we believed to be detrimental,'' said Roy Jenkins, his voice rising with unaccustomed passion. ''So we have set out to create a great shift - a geological flux - in British politics. With your help we can imprint the name of Warrington on the history of our country.'' **********For the urbane and reflective Mr. Jenkins, a Home Secretary and a Chancellor of the Exchequer in Labor Governments, later president of the European Economic Community, it was a crucial moment in a most unfamiliar setting -the final rally of a furious by-election campaign in this gritty industrial borough between Liverpool and Manchester. The election, which takes place tomorrow, is perhaps the most important of its kind in Britain since the war, for it marks the electoral debut of the new Social Democratic Party. **********Mr. Jenkins and three other former Cabinet Ministers - Shirley Williams, Dr. David Owen and William Rodgers -broke away from the Labor Party earlier this year. They have signed up 55,000 members for their new party at $17 a year each. Now, in alliance with the Liberal Party, a small centrist group, and with Roy Jenkins as their standard-bearer, they are trying to capture the Labor stronghold of Warrington to give weight to their argument that both of the big parties are too extreme for the average British voter. **********''I am making no predictions,'' the candidate told 700 supporters in shabby old Parr Hall last night. ''I came here with no illusions.  But win or lose, we shall achieve a major impact.'' Jenkins Is Expected to Lose **********Mr. Jenkins is almost certain to lose. The latest poll, completed last weekend by Market and Opinion Research International, gave him only 33 percent of the vote, with 56 percent going to Douglas Hoyle, the Labor candidate, and 10 percent to Stanley Sorrell, the nominee of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party. Even allowing for greater zeal on the part of the Social Democrats, and therefore a higher turnout of their supporters than of traditional Conservative and Labor voters, Mr. Jenkins seems unlikely to get more than 35 percent of the total. **********But that would be a considerable accomplishment, in the view of political commentators here, for a party contesting its first election on decidedly unfavorable ground. Sir Thomas Williams, whose appointment as a judge created the parliamentary vacancy that will be filled tomorrow, won the seat from Labor in May 1979 with a majority of 10,274, one of the largest of that general election. The Liberals received only 9 percent of the vote. **********''Roy Jenkins has given us a good campaign,'' said a barman at the Rose and Crown pub, ''but Warrington's a Labor town, isn't it? You can tell by looking around.'' **********The constituency, which has 44,000 voters, is a collection of brick row houses dating from the Victorian era, of newer public housing developments and of factories plopped down in the midst of them - wire mills, soap plants, breweries, a distillery. It is almost entirely working-class, with only a few suburban tracts around the edges. Conflicting Views of Party **********Lord Harris, one of the Social Democrats' top organizers and publicists, said in an interview that 30 percent of the vote or more would demonstrate that the party was taken seriously even in the Labor heartland, would help it regain the momentum it generated when it was formed but has since lost, and would augur well for the alliance's chances in the next by-election at Croydon, in the suburbs south of London, sometime this fall. The electoral organization, he said, ''will have been blooded without being bloodied.'' **********''They've not taken off,'' Mr. Hoyle said in rebuttal, ''and if they can't win by-elections like this one, they'll never run the country. They should have done better with such a famous man.'' **********Mr. Hoyle, a grandfather whose neat mustache, cheerful manner and pin-stripe suits belie his reputation as a fierce left-winger, has described Mr. Jenkins as ''a traitor.'' But apart from that, he has all but ignored the Social Democrats, refusing Mr. Jenkins's demands that he say whether he is supporting Tony Benn, the left's leading ideologue, in his campaign to unseat Denis Healey as the deputy leader of the Labor Party. **********Even so, Mr. Hoyle's past associations with Mr. Benn appear to have cost him some votes. Social Democratic and Liberal campaigners have distributed handbills quoting the Laborite's statement of support for The Morning Star, the Communist Party newspaper; his assertion that ''the highlight'' of his visit to Moscow some years ago was laying a wreath at Lenin's tomb, and his description of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother as a ''hanger-on.'' Had his party been able to mount a media campaign, which is not permitted in by-elections, Mr. Jenkins might have driven the point home more sharply. Unemployment Has Doubled **********As it is, most of his support seems to be coming from Conservatives upset about unemployment, which has doubled in Warrington from 6 percent to 12.8 percent in less than a year. **********Mr. Sorrell, a London bus driver, has fought back bravely, attempting to capitalize on law-and-order sentiment aroused by the riots in Liverpool, Manchester and other nearby cities, but to no avail. He is in danger of forfeiting his electoral deposit by failing to poll 12.5 percent of the vote, which would be a humiliation for Mrs. Thatcher.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/10/world.print_headline: FOR BOLIVIA, CHAOS RULES; News Analy sis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/10/world.body_text: **********Many Bolivians say they would laugh at their revolving governments if their poverty did not make them cry.  Boliva got its third Government in little more than a year Sept. 4 when the ruling junta, which less than two weeks before had declared its three members to be co-presidents, made one of them, Gen. Celso Torrelio, the army commander, the single President. **********The junta acted under pressure from a group of young hard-line colonels allied with Gen. Luis Garcia Meza, who was forced to step down as President a month ago by another group of officers who charged that he was corrupt. **********General Torrelio is considered an honest man, but whether he will be a figurehead or will forge his own administration is unclear. **********Economy Is Foundering **********Bolivia, one of the most impoverished countries in South America, has averaged more than one government a year since independence in 1825, and chagrined Bolivians say this latest bout of instability is particularly inopportune. When decisive action has been needed to deal with a foundering economy, the Government has been largely paralyzed. **********''Politics here are surrealistic,'' a European diplomat said.  Officials concede that the Government is virtually bankrupt.  Bankers and economists report that it bounced $12 million to $15 million in checks on United States banks before closing down all exchange operations in August for one month. **********The Finance Ministry now reports that it has since built up $96 million in reserves, against $268 million in short-term obligations and an unclear amount of long-term payments due this year out of a total foreign debt of $3.7 billion. Credit Is Restricted **********Most international banks have restricted their lines of credit to the country. The junta has pledged it will not devalue the peso, though the country continues to run balance of payments deficits and black-market dollars have been in demand at up to one-third above the official price. **********The lack of dollars has cut imports and forced a drop in production at a time when the economy was not expected to grow in any case.  Unemployment, poorly measured, is clearly rising, and inflation is running around 30 percent. Wages have been frozen for the last year. **********The tragedy is that Bolivia has only 5.5 million people in a land the size of Texas and California combined, is rich in unexploited minerals and farms only 2 percent of its arable land, according to agricultural and mineral experts. **********Almost 80 percent of the country's gross national product is produced by the state, much of it through the state mining company, Comibol, the Finance Ministry said. But the state enterprises have been historically inefficient. Gen. Abel Martinez Mendez, general manager of Comibol, said 13 of its 14 production companies were losing money. Cocaine Trade Thrives **********In the meantime, the illicit cocaine trade is thriving with the aidof senior mil itary officials, and one result is that the country is denied the in ternational economic help it needs. The United States withdrew its Ambassador last year and, with many other countries, hasreduced aid. **********Even the Government acknowledges its shaky position. ''The polity is unstable, capricious and chaotic,'' Adolfo Linares Arraya, Minister of Planning and Coordination, said.  ''The predominance of crisis situations has made the future unforeseeable.'' **********The junta of three service chiefs, former allies of General Garcia Meza, came to power after a rebellion in August by a group of officers who said they wanted to end corruption. The rebels fell short of taking over the Government, although they did force the resignation of General Garcia Meza. The junta members - General Torrelio, Gen. Waldo Bernal of the air force and Adm. Oscar Pammo - were unable to attract much loyalty from within their services. **********They could not be faulted for want of trying, however. They issued a flurry of economic and administrative decrees, such as one limiting public spending, but their actions were met with widespread cynicism in the military. Army Chief Exiled **********General Torrelio, 48 years old, was little known before General Garcia Meza appointed him Interior Minister earlier this year and then, in June, made him Commander in Chief of the army after sending the existing chief into exile for plotting against him. **********General Torrelio had reportedly been opposing efforts to make him President, preferring instead to remain head of the army.  General Bernal, who had been the de facto head of the junta, said that General Torrelio's appointment as Presi dent was the result of aconsensus within the armed forces. No formal meeting of senior officers took place, however, and some said t he choice was more a putsch by the hard-line colonels, with others who hoped to stabilize the Government behind a single President who at least has an image of honesty acquiescing. **********The reformists, whose center of support is Santa Cruz, 350 miles east of here, are led by Gen. Lucio Anez. The former commander, Gen.  Alberto Natusch, retired to his farm after he inexplicably called off the August rebellion. **********Overlooked in the recent political maneuvering has been the country's civilian political leaders, most of whom are spread around South America in exile. Neither General Torrelio or any of the other military leaders have proposed elections any time soon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/26/world.main_headline: SAUDIS ARE SAID TO REJECT SHARING AWACS CONTROL WITH U.S. INTO 90'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/26/world.print_headline: SAUDIS ARE SAID TO REJECT SHARING AWACS CONTROL WITH U.S. INTO 90'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/26/world.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia has told the United States that it cannot not agree to joint control of Awacs planes into the 1990's, although it is willing to permit United States training personnel to fly on all missions for three or four years once the planes are delivered in 1985 and 1986, authoritative sources said today. **********The sources said the Saudis therefore seemed unlikely to accept a complex compromise that would assign some American personnel to all crews that monitor and manipulate radar surveillance and combatcontrol consoles on the Boeing E-3A Airborne Warning and Control System planes. Reagan Criticizes Senators **********Such crew assignments had been suggested as a means of allaying the misgivings of some members of Congress about the sale of the planes to the Saudis. President Reagan today strongly criticized senators who oppose or are leaning against approval of the $8.5 billion sale of Awacs and other air combat equipment to the Saudis. **********''They are literally doing away with our ability to continue to try to bring peace to the Middle East,'' Mr. Reagan said of the senators.  As he left the White House for a weekend at Camp David, Mr. Reagan told reporters, ''We're trying to find out if there is anything that can persuade these people, without in any way presuming on the good will of the Saudi Arabians, anything that can persuade some of these people to see common sense on this.'' **********The President's remarks reflected disappointment at the assessment given to him earlier in the week by Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the Senate Republican leader. Senate sources said Senator Baker had told the White House that there was little, if any, chance that the Senate would agree to the Saudi arms sale unless some changes were made in it. **********At meetings yesterday at the White House and in the offices of Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, a complicated formula was discussed at length, according to sources familiar with the discussions. A Continuing U.S. Presence **********There was a suggestion that the Saudi Government permit some, per haps two o r three, United States Air Force personnel to fly as part of the 1 3-member ''mission crew'' that handles the complex electronic ge ar in the cabin of an Awacs plane. The four-member flight crew t hat flies the plane, and is subordinate to the mission crew commande r, would c onsist entirely of Saudis. **********This continuing American presence on the aircraft would presumably ease the fears of some senators who believe that the Awacs planes could pose a threat to Israel. **********Another feature of the proposal discussed yesterday, the sources said, was a plan to equip the Saudi Awacs planes with militarily sensitive communications and ''electronic counter-countermeasure'' gear being developed for United States Awacs to resist enemy ''jamming,'' or electronic deception measures. **********Senator Glenn, who said last week that he opposed the outright sale of Awacs to any nation, had also complained that ''it made no sense'' to deliver what he called a ''downgraded'' Awacs to the Saudis because it would not be able to communicate effectively with United States naval aircraft in an emergency in the Persian Gulf. **********If Saudi Awacs continued to be operated by joint crews, fear among senators that secret technology might be compromised would presumably be reduced. **********Another feature of the proposal discussed yesterday reportedly called for a review of the arrangement by both Governments five years after the planes are delivered, or about 1991. If the Saudis then wanted to terminate the joint-crew arrangement, the United States would reportedly have to buy back the Awacs. **********The Saudi Government, represented at these discussions by Prince Bandar bin Sultan, an air force officer who is looking after Saudi interests in the Awacs debate, reportedly said it could not accept important features of the proposal. **********The Saudis did not feel that their sovereignty and political position in the Arab world would permit them to ''agree in writing to a guarantee'' of shared control of the Awacs past 1989, the authoritative sources said. A 'Training Label' **********Some United States uniformed Air Force training personnel will be assigned to Saudi Arabia, along with civilian contract maintenance personnel, to continue the training that Saudi Awacs personnel will receive in the United States and on an Awacs simulator, which is part of the arms package. The Saudis told Mr. Glenn and the White House that they could agree to having Americans fly on their Awacs until about 1989 if they had a ''training label,'' the sources said. **********The Saudis reportedly wanted to make a public statement indicating that they could not accept the proposal as outlined yesterday but were urged to remain silent by the White House. **********Some proponents of the sale, both in the executive branch and in the Senate, were opposed to a compromise anyway, believing that the best course would be to try to guide the unmodified proposal through Congress. A senior Senate staff member said he regarded that plan as ''riding your horse over the cliff.'' **********The Senate Armed Services Committee heard secret testimony in closed session today on aspects of the sale from the Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, Adm. Bobby R. Inman. Later the committee chairman, Senator John Tower of Texas, said, ''The arrangement as it currently stands is a good arrangement.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/04/busin.body_text: **********Libya has summoned oil companies that buy its oil to a meeting tomorrow in Tripoli with Maj. Abdul Salam Jalloud, a former prime minister now considered to be second in power to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. **********Some major United States and foreign oil companies, which have rebelled at Libya's high prices by cutting their purchases, are expected to respond with their own tough talk. **********''The purpose, I think, is to launch some veiled threats by reminding the companies that we could go from the current glut to a shortage situation very quickly,'' said a top official of a major foreign oil company. ''They will point out the shoe could be on the other foot very, very soon.'' **********Meeting's Intent Unclear **********Other oil industry officials recalled that in the past they have responded to urgent Libyan meetings in Tripoli, only to discover that the leaders of that North African country had nothing of consequence to discuss. ''I wouldn't venture a guess what will be discussed,'' said the president of a major United States oil company. **********The companies, which say they are losing between $3 and $6 on every barrel of Libyan oil they refine, indicate they will take an equally tough stance. Already, they have slashed purchases of Libyan oil to such an extent that Libya's overall production has fallen to an estimated 800,000 barrels to 900,000 barrels a day, less than half the normal level. **********Prices charged by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries range from Saudi Arabia's $32 a barrel to the $40 a barrel charged by Libya and the other high-priced African producers, Nigeria and Algeria. The oil companies complain that they earn only $37 to $37.50 a barrel for their petroleum products. Increasing Aggressiveness **********Libya's aggressiveness on oil prices comes as the Reagan Administration is taking a more aggressive stance toward that country, partly because Washington believes Libya to be a major supporter of international terrorism. Already, the State Depatment has asked American dependents of oil company personnel to leave Libya, and policy planners have gone so far as to consider the option of ordering the companies to leave Libya as a means of pressuring Col. Qaddafi, the Libyan leader. **********''Whether a cutting off of purchases of the oil is going to be a useful tool is something we continue to look at,'' said Robert Flaten, the State Department's Director of North African Affairs.  ''We don't close any option.'' **********Libya ranks as the third-largest oil exporter to the United States, behind Saudi Arabia and Nigeria. For the first four months of 1981, its daily exports to this country averaged 473,000 barrels a day, a figure that has probably since plunged to less than 450,000 barrels daily. In the first four months of 1980, Libyan exports to the United States averaged 630,000 barrels a day. Sign of Turmoil **********Libya's surprise meeting summons is indicative of the current turmoil in world oil markets, as Saudi Arabia has deliberately flooded the world market with cheaper oil to force high-priced producers, such as Libya, to lower their prices. The Saudis have been motivated by a desire to first stabilize prices and then implement a pricing formula to make future increases more predictable. **********Saudi Arabia is also known to be concerned that the price of oil has risen so rapidly that oil consumers will switch to alternative fuels well before the kingdom's major reserves have been depleted. **********Last week, the four African members of the 13-member OPEC cartel called for a special meeting to try to resolve Saudi Arabia's dispute with the other members. Presumably, the purpose of such a meeting would be to convince the kingdom to agree to cut its output and raise prices in return for agreements from other OPEC members to slash prices and decrease the size of surcharges for differences in quality among various grades of crude. **********Although Iraq has also come out in favor of the OPEC meeting, going so far as to say it could take place as early as Saturday, oil analysts were far from convinced OPEC would convene soon. Such a meeting could take place, they said, only if Saudi Arabia wanted it.  So far, the kingdom has said nothing. Dominance Seen Unlikely **********Analysts also suggested that Libya was unlikely to take the lead in reducing prices to bring OPEC together, and generally discounted the possibility that the meeting was called for that purpose.  Compared to more populous oil-producing countries with larger development needs, Libya can better weather low levels of oil production. **********''Nigeria has been much more hard-pressed than Libya,'' said Gary Ross of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. He and other analysts said they believe that Nigeria would logically be the first African producer to compromise with Saudi Arabia. **********In a separate development, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, a trade publication, yesterday reported that Mexico had responded to the soft oil market by cutting its price by $1.90 a barrel. The publication based its report on company sources, and noted that the Mexican Government has not yet officially confirmed the move. If true, the move would make the average export price of Mexican crude $30.70 a barrel, restoring all but 10 cents of a $4 price cut declared by Mexico in June, and later reduced to a $2 cut.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/13/world.main_headline: AUSTRIA ANGERED BY STAND OF P.L.O.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/13/world.print_headline: AUSTRIA ANGERED BY STAND OF P.L.O.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/13/world.body_text: **********A spokesman for Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria said today that Austria might suspend its contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization or even close the P.L.O.'s office in Vienna because of the organization's outbursts of joy at the slaying of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt. **********Chancellor Kreisky said in a radio interview over the weekend that the jubilant reaction by leaders of the P.L.O. might have consequences for Austria's ties with the organization. In the interview, which was recorded Friday evening, Mr. Kreisky said it was ''incomprehensible that anyone could praise a murder, that anyone could by happy over a murder.'' **********Mr. Kreisky said that he and Yasir Arafat, the head of the P.L.O., had ''unbridgeable differences'' in their assessments of the assassination, and he suggested that he considered ''personal consequences'' as a result of Mr. Arafat's expression of joy at the death. **********Mr. Kreisky, who has often angered Israel and upset Western leaders with his open contacts with the P.L.O., reiterated his belief that the Palestinian question is at the ''core of the Mideast problem.'' 'A Cruel Fact' **********Mr. Sadat's assassination, he said, ''is a cruel fact, which I most deeply condemn.'' He said the Palestinian question was a ''hard, cruel political fact which I recognize.'' **********A spokesman for the Chancellor, Wolfgang Petritsch, in a telephone interview, interpreted Mr. Kreisky's remarks today by saying: ''We are in written diplomatic contact with the P.L.O. This could mean reconsidering how the contacts would be continued.'' **********He also said, however, that the remarks could mean Austria would reconsider whether to let the P.L.O. keep a representative in Vienna. The group's office in Vienna represents the organization at several United Nations agencies and with the Austrian Government. In August, however, Vienna asked the P.L.O. to remove its representative, Ghazi Hussain, and the post has been vacant since. **********Mr. Petritsch said Mr. Kreisky's remarks could be interpreted to mean that Austria would tell the P.L.O. ''it has no interest at the moment in seeing that post re-occupied.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/19/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission's approval 10 days ago of a plan to allow hundreds of new low-power television stations has touched off an angry reaction from commercial and public broadcasting interests, possibly derailing the project. **********The commission has responded to the complaints by extending the deadline for applications for the new stations to Feb. 17.  The F.C.C. promised last year to promote the concept of low-power television, giving minorities and others greater access to television and furthering competition. The concept has not been formally approved, but the commission wants to let the new stations on the air on an interim basis. Low-power stations would broadcast with a weaker signal than regular stations and thus cover only a neighborhood, not a whole region. **********Established television stations are wary of new competition from low-power stations, despite their modest size. The present stations fear that many operators would tie the new stations together by satellite and create new networks - a strategy the F.C.C. supports.  Some large businesses (such as the Allstate insurance branch of Sears, Roebuck & Company) are seeking hundreds of the proposed ministations. F.C.C.'s Original Action **********As a way to get low-power stations on the air quickly, the commission voted Jan. 8 to cut off the first wave of applications, effective last Friday. The F.C.C. said the applicants could then go ahead and put as many as 15 stations each on the air, even though the concept has not been formally approved. **********The National Association of Broadcasters, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the ABC network and established stations immediately sent angry letters to the commission demanding an extension of the deadline so that current broadcasters could also apply for some of the new stations. After the complaints poured in, last Thursday the extension was announced. **********The effect of the extension is to let broadcasters or other opponents block new stations besides applying for their own, according to commission staff members. The process could keep many proposed stations off the air indefinitely. While new stations that are unopposed could have gone on the air quickly, the filing of competing applications starts a process that could tie them up while each applicant's bid is studied. **********Erwin G. Krasnow, general counsel of the N.A.B., wrote a letter dated the same day as the Jan. 8 vote, saying the commission should extend its deadline because it had not let present broadcasters know that they were qualified to apply for new stations themselves. Threat of a Court Test **********''N.A.B. therefore requests a 60-day postponement of the Jan. 16 cut-off date - which involved hundreds of frequencies that otherwise will become immune from potential competing applications by now eligible radio and television broadcasters,'' Mr. Krasnow said in his letter to the commission. **********The Corporation for Public Broadcasting threatened to go to court.  It asked that the commission instead go through the exhaustive process of compiling a table of frequency assignments for cities such as was done when television was originally authorized more than three decades ago. **********The F.C.C.'s lawyers, noting the specter of litigation, advised the commissioners to extend the deadline one month as a compromise.  All of them except Robert E. Lee voted for it in an informal poll. **********Possible casualties of the new extension could include Community Television Inc., a proposed network of low-power stations across the South. It would have become the first TV network owned by blacks. **********Andrew Schwartzman, director of the Media Access Project in Washington, said the low-power applicants would fight any attempts to tie up their plans with red tape. ---- Turner's 25 Applications **********ATLANTA, Jan. 18 (AP) - Turner Television Stations, a subsidiary of the Turner Broadcasting System, has filed applications with the Federal Communications Commission for the right to operate 25 lowpower television stations in 15 states and the District of Columbia. **********Ted Turner, chairman, said, ''The establishment of a network of low-power stations in cities across the country will provide an additional source of alternative programming for millions of television viewers.'' **********The company said material for its proposed low-power network would consist of advertising-supported information and public affairs programming on a full-time basis. It would originate at Turner's broadcast facilities in Atlanta and elsewhere. **********Distribution of programming to the proposed stations would be via satellite and conventional routing, the company said.  The states in which Turner stations have been requested are Arizona, California, Connecticut, Florida, Illinois, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island and Texas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/29/busin.body_text: **********M. Gerald O'Neil, who turns 59 today, has been president and chief executive officer of the General Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's fifth-largest tire manufacturer, since 1960. His forthcoming assumption of the chairmanship from his 65-year-old brother, Thomas F., may have seemed anticlimactic to him, and he reflected that attitude in a telephone interview from his Akron headquaters. **********''I've been chief executive officer for a number of years and I'm not getting any more authority,'' he said about the realignment. ''My brother built RKO up, and he's run that for years and years.'' **********The General Tire chief executive referred to RKO General Inc., a New York-based subsidiary at which his brother will continue as chairman and chief executive officer. A third brother, John, is chairman of the finance committee of General Tire, which was founded by their father, William, in 1915. **********Referring to Thomas O'Neil's current activities, Gerald O'Neil said, ''We've got problems with RKO and it's imperative that he stay there until the problems are straightened out.'' RKO is contesting in court a challenge that threatens to cost the company its license to operate three broadcast stations, including WOR-TV in New York. **********As for the tire business, Mr. O'Neil -alluding to the General Tire report early this week that profits for the fiscal year ended Nov. 30 were almost halved, to $40.8 million - observed: ''We haven't had the price increases we should have because of conditions in the automobile industry. When auto sales come back, we'll be pretty good. I'm more optimistic about the future of the tire industry that I have been in the past. The past has not been too good.'' **********Mr. O'Neil joined the corporation in 1947 and spent some time at its Venezuelan subsidiary. From 1951 until taking his current post, he was executive assistant to the president. **********According to Mr. O'Neil, a new president and chief operating officer will be appointed, but not until after the annual meeting on March 26, when he will become chairman. ''We're in pretty good shape and we have no intention of naming anybody right now,'' he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Even if the second flight of the space shuttle Columbia this week is as successful as the first, concern over how soon the new spaceships could assume the burden of carrying most satellites into orbit is forcing potential commercial, scientific and military users to make or consider alternate plans. **********The result is that the old-fashioned launching rockets, the Deltas, Atlas-Centaurs and Titans, are being pulled back from the brink of extinction. Or- **********Countdown preparations for the Wednesday launch of the space shuttle continued trouble-free. Page D15. ders are expected to extend production at least to the middle of the decade for Deltas, produced by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation; for Atlas-Centaurs, produced by the General Dynamics Corporation, and for Titans, which are made by the Martin Marietta Corporation. **********Contrary to the optimistic predictions in the 1970's, Government and industry officials say the re-usable shuttles may never entirely put the one-shot expendable rockets out of the launching business. **********The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, under pressure from the communications satellite industry in particular, is refurbishing and modifying a second launching pad here to handle the heavy demand for future flights by upgraded Delta rockets. Many communications satellite customers continue to ''double book,'' putting down deposits on shuttle reservations and on the Deltas, too. The agency has commitments for nearly 30 Delta flights through 1985. 'Mixed-Fleet' Concept Studied **********The United States Air Force, which maintains five to seven Titan 3D rockets in readiness for its communications and surveillance missions, does not plan to begin its transition to shuttle operations until 1985. There is a feeling among Air Force planners that, even then, it would be unwise to be dependent solely on the shuttle. **********The concept of a ''mixed fleet'' is now being studied by the Air Force under the leadership of Brig. Gen. John H. Storrie, who heads the new Directorate of Space at the Defense Department. A mixed fleet would presumably include shuttles - two of the four planned vehicles are to be available to the Air Force - the Titan 3D's that are now the military workhorses and perhaps some new expendable rockets. **********The planned five-day mission of the Columbia, scheduled to be launched here Wednesday morning, will thus be followed with great interest by its future users, commercial and military. NASA plans a conference in December to brief shuttle customers on the vehicle's performance and scheduling. **********Joseph B. Mahon, NASA's director of expendable launch vehicles, said in an interview, ''In the next few months more people will have to make decisions on whether to count on the shuttle or fall back on the expendables.'' **********Uncertainties about the shuttle stem from the space agency's budget crunch and questions concerning the frequency of flights. Budget reductions ordered by the Reagan Administration could force NASA to defer or even cancel production of the fourth shuttle, now scheduled for delivery in 1985. Fewer Shuttle Missions Planned **********Even with a fleet of four vehicles, the shuttles cannot yet be counted on to handle the volume of traffic that was once envisaged.  Engineers are unable to give a realistic estimate of the time that will be required for ground maintenance between flights, but they no longer speak of a two-week turnaround capability. The original schedule of 48 shuttle missions between now and late 1985 has been reduced to 32 and may be reduced further. **********Most of NASA's customers, both domestic and international communications carriers, would prefer to have their satellites deposited in orbit by the shuttle because the price is right. Mr.  Mahon said that costs for launching a satellite with a Delta rocket run about $25 million; the same size satellite, about 2,750 pounds, would cost about $12 million to launch from the shuttle. **********Customers double-booked on the shuttle and Delta must make a choice 30 to 33 months before they want the launching. If they choose the Delta rocket, NASA would then place the production order with McDonnell Douglas and the customer would begin making quarterly payments. Under the arrangement, NASA is reimbursed for all launching costs, including the rocket itself, but is barred from making any profit. **********After the first shuttle flight, last April, eight customers that had to make a choice went for the shuttle six to two. The two that chose the Delta rocket, Satellite Business Systems and the RCA Corporation, wanted the assurance of an early launching because of their own economic commitments. RCA, for example, needed to deploy a replacement for its Satcom satellite that failed last year. Atlas-Centaur Launchings **********Mr. Mahon said that double-booking was not permitted for the larger satellites requiring the Atlas-Centaur rocket, but at least 10 flights are expected between now and 1985. Both the United States Navy and Intelsat, the international satellite communications organization, have placed orders. An Atlas-Centaur launching costs about $55 million, or about twice what it would cost to send a comparable 5,000-pound satellite aloft in the shuttle. **********Shuttle charges for the first three years amount to introductory offers. What the real costs are for shuttle launchings and what those charges will be eventually will depend, in large measure, on the frequency of shuttle flights and a minimizing of ground maintenance. **********Mr. Mahon said that Intelsat and other customers were ''taking a hard look'' at the European Space Agency's Ariane rockets as a possible alternative to the shuttle, or even to Delta and Atlas-Centaur rockets. The fourth test launching of Ariane is scheduled for Dec. 18 at Kourou, French Guiana. **********Once the Arianes, which are conventional, three-stage expendable rockets, are cleared for regular operations after the next flight, they will be boosting two Delta-size satellites on one rocket or one Atlas Centaur-size satellite. Intelsat has already booked a couple of Ariane launchings. The Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, L.I., is the Ariane marketing agent in the United States and is negotiating with several potential customers. **********Both European and American space officials say they believe that there will be more than enough business, probably from the communiciations industry alone. The Texas real-estate investors who created Space Services Inc. of Houston apparently think that there is room in the launching business for private entrepreneurs. But their expendable rocket, called Percheron, exploded in its first test last summer. They say they will try again in about a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/world.main_headline: SALVADOR FARM PROGRAM IS DESCRIBED AS ENDURING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/world.print_headline: SALVADOR FARM PROGRAM IS DESCRIBED AS ENDURING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/06/world.body_text: **********El Salvador's land redistribution program is described by American advisers helping to carry it out as one of the most extensive ever attempted in Latin America. **********Those involved also say it is too far advanced to be reversed despite attempts to undermine it by both business interests and elements of the left that would prefer a collective approach. **********Pressure from impoverished farm laborers for land ownership has been a major source of political violence in El Salvador, where close to 40 percent of the five million inhabitants lived under a virtually feudal agricultural system dominated by 300 large landowners. **********With the political and economic support of the United States and international bankers, the military-civilian junta expropriated the large sugar, cotton and coffee plantations last March and turned the land over to 60,000 farm families who had been cultivating it. In April, 150,000 more families assumed ownership of 500,000 acres of sharecropped property on 7,500 medium-sized holdings. **********Most of Land Distributed **********Now these 210,000 families, totaling some 1.2 million people, legally own the land they till and no longer pay rent to their former landlords. Under the program, 90 percent of the expropriated property has been turned over to two-thirds of the country's landless peasants. Specialists say the it is proportionally the most extensive land redistribution program in Latin America. **********''We've changed their title from feudal serf to freeman,'' asserted Bob Dougherty, executive director of the American Institute for Free Labor Development, an arm of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. that has been advising El Salvador on agrarian matters since the mid-1960's. **********''This is a revolutionary approach, not only in terms of the numbers involved but in the way it's being done. More than a million people are now individual private capitalists in a way whose only parallel is the Homestead Act in the eary days of our own country.'' **********The large estates are being kept intact, he said, and farmed cooperatively, with the former laborers now owning as much as 17 acres apiece. However, legislation giving them title to the property remains to be completed. **********Compensation to the former landholders, in the form of cash and government bonds, also remains to be carried through. Under the March and April decrees, the new peasant landowners are to make annual payments over 30 years that would equal the amount the Government is to pay the former owners. **********The delay in completing these arrangements has added fuel to the opposition, the one-time landlords and their families who have lost claim to large inheritances, as well as left-wing agitators who are taking advantage of the legal loopholes to try to prevent the transfer of land from going forward. **********But Americans who are helping carry out the program believe the process is irreversible.  ''There is no way to reverse this short of all-out civil war,'' said Roy L. Prosterman, a University of Washington law professor who has worked on such projects in a dozen developing countries and who spent about four months in El Salvador last year. Although he thinks a civil war can be avoided, he acknowledges it remains a possibility.  'Reform Can't Be Stopped' **********As an adviser to the Free Labor Insitute, Dr. Prosterman worked closely with Michael P. Hammer and Mark D. Pearlman, his one-time law student, who were killed by terrorists in San Salvador Saturday night. The two employees of the institute were advising Jose Rodolfo Viera, director of El Salvador's Institute for Agrarian Transformation, who was also killed in the attack. **********''It is obvious that the people who killed them want to kill land reform,'' Dr. Prosterman said in an interview. ''But this reform can't be stopped by assassin's bullets.'' **********Rupert Scofield, an assistant to Mr. Hammer, who had worked for the Free Labor Institute for 17 years, mostly in Central and South America, said he had flown to El Salvador Saturday to consult with Mr. Viera about reports that the latter was to be dismissed as head of the agrarian project. Mr. Viera also directed the Savadoran Communal Union, a peasant farmer group organized in 1966 with the help of the Free Labor Institute. **********''It's unquestionably a blow,'' Mr. Scofield said of Mr. Viera's death and those of his two colleagues. ''But whether it's mortal or not, we don't know. Our preference is to keep pushing, using all our influence to keep the project going.'' Farm Workers' Support Cited **********He and others remain somewhat optimistic, citing the enthusiastic support of the farm workers and the continued high crop yields since the land transfers last spring. **********''The left has been exhorting the campesinos to burn their own crops so as to paralyze and destroy the economy,'' he said. ''But the farmers aren't going along because they're benefiting. They now have a stake in the Government and the economy.'' **********''Now they are not working just for a wage, but for a share of the profits,'' he said. ''And they've suddenly built up an enormous equity. **********''Even those who at first found the reform distasteful are going along. No one is saying they're going to turn it around.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/world.print_headline: U.S. FAVORS NEW PROPOSAL FOR THE INDEPENDENCE OF NAMIBIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/world.body_text: **********Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States was prepared to discuss a modification of the United Nations plan for South-West African independence that might be acceptable to South Africa and to black African states. **********The officials discussed this possibility as the White House, seeking to demonstrate that foreign policy business was going on as usual despite the wounding of President Reagan, announced formally that Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State-designate for African Affairs, would lead a mission to southern Africa next month. **********The Administration wants to ask the various parties to consider adoption of a ''Zimbabwe formula,'' in which the future laws of the country would be worked out before an election took place. The current United Nations plan for South-West Africa's independence says elections would be held first to set up a constituent assembly that would in turn draft the laws. **********Seeking to make it clear that President Reagan's hospitalization had not halted international contacts, there were these other developments: **********- Vice President Bush and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  met separately and together with Prime Minister Andreas A.M. van Agt of the Netherlands, who arrived yesterday. **********- Plans for Mr. Haig to leave Friday night for an eight-day trip to the Middle East and Europe went ahead as scheduled, and there was a possibility that Mr. Haig might add West Germany and France to his itinerary. He is due to visit Egypt, Israel, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Spain and Britain, and aides traveling with him will visit Iraq. In a meeting with White House aides this morning in the hospital, Mr.  Reagan reiterated his wish for Mr. Haig to make the trip. **********- The State Department announced that Foreign Minister Ilter Turkmen of Turkey would meet with Mr. Haig and other officials on Thursday. **********- Messages went out around the world yesterday and today informing governments of Mr. Reagan's having been wounded and of the doctors' reports that his prognosis was excellent. **********The mission by Mr. Crocker, expected to start in two weeks or so, is viewed by Administration officials as one of the most important of the Administration. **********This is because Mr. Reagan, in his comments before and after the election, had given the impression that he might drastically revise American policy toward that area in favor of South Africa. The trip is meant to reverse that perception in Africa, officials said. **********As issued by the White House, the statement was also meant to signal that although this Administration would have its own policy toward southern Africa, the effort of the preceding Administration to bring about an international settlement removing South-West Africa from South African control would be continued in consultation with black-led African nations and white-dominated South Africa. **********Referring to South Africa's policy of racial separation, it said ''there can be no question of American support for apartheid, which is repugnant to our multiracial and democratic society.'' **********But it said ''we intend to make our views plainly known'' to the South Africans ''not in a spirit of confrontation but of constructive help.'' **********On the deadlocked negotiations for an independent South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, it said, ''We seek a peaceful solution of the Namibian problem leading to a genuinely independent and democratic Namibia, recognized by the international community.'' **********Administration officials said that in the long policy review of southern Africa that has just been concluded, there was a consensus to discuss with the Africans the possibility of a significant shift in the independence plan. This also would be discussed with the four countries, West Germany, Britain, France and Canada, that had been working with the United States as the ''contact group'' in United Nations-sponsored negotiations on the issue. **********Until now, the United Nations plan has called for United Nationssponsored elections in South-West Africa for a constituent assembly.  The South Africans and their supporters in South-West Africa, the Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, have been reluctant to accept that approach in the fear that the main guerrilla group, the South-West African People's Organization, led by Sam Nujomo, would prevail and be able to dictate the country's future. **********The American approach is said to incorporate aspects of the solution that led finally to international acceptance of a government of Zimbabwe, the former Rhodesia. Under this approach, the British held a conference during which a legal framework was set up before elections. **********The Reagan Administration is considering proposing that the constitution be drawn up ahead of time in Geneva or some other neutral site.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher tonight ordered a police investigation into allegations of financial irregularities involving an automobile plant in Northern Ireland established by John DeLorean, an American entrepreneur. **********The plant outside Belfast produces a sports car. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/12/busin.body_text: **********Anheuser-Busch Inc., the nation's largest brewer, says it is increasing its wholesale beer prices, effective Jan. 26, as a result of higher production costs. **********The move announced Friday is expected to raise the retail price of a six-pack of beer by 15 to 20 cents.  At least one St. Louis-area distributor has already notified retailers that it would pass on price increases of at least 40 cents a case as early as this week. **********Last April, Anheuser-Busch increased the wholesale price of packaged beer by 32 cents, to $7.87 a case.  Anheuser-Busch, which has its headquarters in St. Louis, brews Budweiser, Busch, Michelob, Natural Light and Michelob Light beers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/10/busin.main_headline: F.T.C. Forces Sale Of Kennecott Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/10/busin.print_headline: F.T.C. Forces Sale Of Kennecott Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/10/busin.body_text: **********The Kennecott Corporation has agreed to sell a division that makes industrial air pollution-control equipment after the Federal Trade Commission alleged antitrust violations, the F.T.C. announced today. **********The F.T.C. said that Kennecott's $110 million acquisition of Dorr-Oliver Inc. from the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in January violated antitrust law because both companies make fabric air-filter bags, which are used in air pollution-control systems that filter matter from gas streams for environmental or safety reasons. **********The Government agency said that the purchase reduced competition between the two manufacturers and made it more difficult for other companies to enter the market. **********In Stamford, Conn., a Kennecott spokesman, Peter Roach, declined to comment other than to note that the dispute centered on ''rather small parts'' of the two companies. **********Under the agreement, Kennecott must divest its Filter Media division in a way that preserves its assets as a viable competitor.  Until the divestiture, which must take place within nine months of a final order, Kennecott cannot do anything to reduce the value of the division. **********Kennecott also agreed to run the National Filter Media Corporation, the Dorr-Oliver unit that produces the filter bags, under separate management. In addition, the agreement requires that for 10 years Kennecott must obtain F.T.C. approval before it buys assets in any company that makes fabric air-filter bags. **********Kennecott, the nation's largest producer of copper and second largest in gold, was acquired last week by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) in a $1.76 billion merger that had the approval of the F.T.C. **********Dorr-Oliver is primarily engaged in the manufacture and sale of environmental systems equipment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/01/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: In ''Tax Cuts: First, Business Wants Fast Depreciation'' (Feb. 1), Edward Cowan brings to light the current list of strategies open to Congress and President Reagan for providing relief from both business and personal income taxes. The solutions seem to focus on first, increased capital cost recovery (by way of faster depreciation schedules) and second, preferences for interest and dividend income (by larger exemptions for these items). **********President Reagan's stated goal, according to the above article, includes ''re-invigoration of investment as a step toward more efficient production and a less inflationary economy.'' **********If the goal is increased investment, a more sensible approach might be to provide tax schedules for investment income which are independent of other income; that is, have investment income taxed without regard to earned income. At present, personal service income is taxed at a maximum rate of 50 percent; non-earned income is taxed up to 70 percent (except long-term capital gains, which are reduced by 60 percent first, thus being taxed at a 28 percent maximum). Since personal service income is considered in computing a taxpayer's marginal rate, investment income can be taxed at inflated rates even if it is small in amount. **********By providing independent rate schedules this income, which might include all ''passive income'' (including interest income, dividends, partnership income, and even capital gains), will be favored and investment encouraged. **********To counter Treasury comments that such incentive might merely reward the wealthy without stimulating further investment, ''post-1981'' investment could be earmarked for the special treatment (just as ''post-1975'' interest expense was identified when Congress, in the Tax Reform Act of 1976, severely limited the investment-related interest that could be deducted by individuals). **********Of course the marginal rates for such investment income could be set (possibly, annually) according to its anticipated effect on Treasury revenue.  PETER J. CONNORS New York, N.Y., Feb. 3, 1981
