https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/09/busin.body_text: **********The Occidental Petroleum Corporation is offering $754 million in stock for the Zapata Corporation, a major oil services company, Zapata disclosed in Houston yesterday. **********Wall Street sources close to both companies said they had heard that Zapata told Occidental it was ''not for sale.'' Others close to the situation, however, insisted that such talk was just part of the bargaining process. **********Asked if the proposal was friendly, Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental, said in a telephone interview: ''Yes, absolutely. I would not be a party to an unfriendly merger with anybody.'' **********Wall Street professionals, sensing further developments, bid up the price of Zapata stock by 3 3/4 points, to 31 5/8 in heavy trading.  The offer, which Zapata described as unsolicited, is understood to have been arranged by David H. Murdock, a multimillionaire West Coast businessman and a director of Zapata. He is a close friend of Dr. Hammer's. Iowa Beef Deal Recalled **********Mr. Murdock is Zapata's largest stockholder. He had nearly 2 million shares when his holding was last reported in February. He was also instrumental in arranging for Occidental to buy Iowa Beef Processors in June for $800 million in stock. **********Mr. Murdock, who has holdings in a number of corporations, had owned 19 percent of Iowa Beef and thus became a significant stockholder in Occidental. He would become an even larger Occidental stockholder if the Zapata deal is completed, because it would involve a transfer of Occidental shares. **********Zapata said the offer called for its shareholders to get 0.6904 Occidental common share plus 0.1804 share of a new $100 Occidental preferred issue for each Zapata share. Based on Friday's market close, the offer was valued at about $36 per Zapata share, or a total of $763 million. Based on yesterday's close, it was valued at $35.56 a share, or $754 million. The value changes daily with the price of Occidental's stock. **********Without commenting on the proposal, B. John Mackin, Zapata's 64-year-old chairman, said it would be ''taken under consideration.'' In a separate statement issued later by Occidental, Dr. Hammer said he had met last Satur day with Mr. Mackin and other Zapata executives and had made a written proposal. Offer Open for 45 Days **********The Occidental statement went on to say that the offer was open for 45 days and might be withdrawn after that. It added that, if the merger went through, Zapata would keep its headquarters in Houston and would continue under its present management as an independent company.  People fami liar with the talks said that, much in the manner of theIowa Beef dea l, Mr. Murdock brought Dr. Hammer and Mr. Mackin together and that the two met in his office near Los Angeles. **********Although Mr. Murdock is known as an astute investor who rarely embarks on a venture without elaborate study, Zapata's executives were said to have gone only ''as a matter of courtesy.'' There were signs that the Zapata officers knew what to expect. Just the day before, they had retained the Wall Street firm of Lazard Freres for advice. Mr. Mackin is understood to have told Dr. Hammer that his directors would ''evaluate the offer and take a position,'' but he added: ''Zapata is not for sale. It's not looking to sell.'' **********Commenting on the rationale for the Iowa Beef venture, Value Line, the investment survey, noted last July that Occidental had $117 million in unused investment tax credits at the end of 1980 and that it pays no Federal income tax because it consistently loses money in the United States. Thus, the advisory service said, post-acquisition income would be ''enhanced substantially'' by applying these credits to Iowa Beef's profits. Tax Credits Increasing **********Dr. Hammer said yesterday: ''The same will hold for Zapata if we do it. Our investment tax credits are increasing substantially because we're investing more money in coal mines and chemicals.'' **********He added, however, that the main reason his company wanted Zapata was Occidental's ''very ambitious'' offshore oil expansion program in which he said it would spend some $2 billion in the next five years. **********He said Occidental would need Zapata's offshore drilling rigs - especially its five semisubmersible ones. He said he was also interested in Zapata's oil operations in the Gulf of Mexico and its coal holdings, which he described as ''not large'' but interesting. **********Zapata was founded in 1954 by George Bush, now Vice President of the United States, and the Liedtke brothers - J. Hugh Liedtke, now chairman of the Pennzoil Company, and William Liedtke, chairman of the Pogo Producing Company, a former Pennzoil subsidiary. **********Mr. Bush sold his Zapata interest in 1966 when he was preparing to run for the House of Representatives. The founders, looking for a catchy name with an international flavor, are thought to have taken the name Zapata from a contemporary movie, ''Viva Zapata,'' starring Marlon Brando and Anthony Quinn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/30/world.print_headline: A-BOMB RACE IN THE OFFING?; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/30/world.body_text: **********The simmering suspicions dividing India and Pakistan are again becoming inflamed, this time raising the prospect of the first nuclear arms race between countries that are not superpowers. **********It is almost exactly seven years since India demonstrated its nuclear muscle with an underground blast in the Rajasthan Desert.  Now, as evidence mounts that Pakistan is striving to build an atomic weapon, voices are being raised here calling for quick and open pursuit of the nuclear option. Over the last few weeks there has been a steady stream of articles by military strategists and technicians, some of them close to the Government, urging a nuclear arms program for India to counter Pakistan's presumed atomic ambitions. **********Assertions that India is preparing an underground test site, allegations based on United States intelligence reports, have drawn only perfunctory official denials. As in Pakistan, the flexing of nuclear muscle is domestically popular though internationally embarrassing. **********A Western diplomat who has been closely monitoring the nuclear politics of the subcontinent said he believed that the tunneling near the site of the 1974 blast was still part of contingency planning and that no final decision had yet been made here whether to set off another device. 'We Have to Be Prepared' **********The diplomat said it was widely assumed that the Indians had produced several devices at the time of the first test. He added that he thought that the underground site was being prepared so that an explosion could be set off on short notice if the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi decided to shift from the previous policy of publicly forswearing a buildup of atomic arms. **********''We have to be prepared for any situation,'' Mrs. Gandhi said this week as she warned of heightened tensions. ''The major danger is that without anybody wanting it, there may suddenly be war.'' **********The suddenly intensifying tensions are somewhat surprising, since the underlying reasons have been apparent for years. Almost since the partition that created their two countries, Indians and Pakistanis have been ready to think the worst of each other. That India had nuclear ability and that Pakistan was actively seeking it has been known for several years. With the history of conflicts, with Kashmir remaining an unresolved and potentially incendiary issue, India and Pakistan have often regarded each other as belligerents waiting for the right moment to strike. **********It was this reasoning that led a group of political scientists and nuclear monitors in the United States to conclude that the greatest risk of nuclear confrontation in the world was in this region and not in the Washington-Moscow standoff. And yet, until this spring, the Indians showed remarkably little alarm at the reports of Pakistan's development of atomic arms, a program that Westerners describe as being some two years away from the testing stage. U.S. Seeks to Arm Pakistan **********What seems to have stirred Indian anxieties much more than Pakistan's nuclear effort is the eagerness of the Reagan Administration to arm Pakistan as a bulwark against any Soviet penetration in and around the Persian Gulf. **********With the Administration moving in Congress to change existing legislation so that United States military aid may go to Pakistan despite Islamabad's nuclear activities, the Indians are concerned. **********High officials in the Indian Foreign Ministry refuse to accept the proposed Pakistani-American arms agreement as a mirror image of India's own $1.9 billion arms deal with the Soviet Union. Instead, they take the view that the military Government in Pakistan, once afforded protection by the United States and gaining tolerance and legitimacy for its nuclear program, could easily turn to militarist adventures. **********It is also an undenied fact that despite the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and the threat it represents to Pakistan's western border, Islamabad still deploys seven-eighths of its forces toward India. Calculated Ambiguity **********In reflecting the general apprehension here, Mrs. Gandhi summarized the situation with calculated ambiguity. ''There is no question of trying to compete with Pakistan in an arms race,'' she said. ''We have never complained about Pakistan being armed. Our only worry is that such arms supply is creating a situation where everybody is drifting towards a war.'' **********The day before she made these comments, K. Subrahmanyam, the director of the Indian Institute for Defense Studies and Analysis, a Government-financed organization, publicly called on the country to shed all pretenses and openly amass a nuclear arsenal. **********''The time to act is not after Pakistan conducts the test,'' Mr.  Subrahmanyam, a former Defense Ministry official, wrote in The Times of India. ''That would give Pakistan an undue advantage. The time to get ready for the appropriate response is now.'' **********He also wrote: ''If we make the bomb, the United States will realize that they cannot ignore a nation of seven hundred million with nuclear weapons just as Nixon said about China in 1971. It will enable us to deal with China on an equal basis. We shall be able to sustain our cordial relations with the Soviet Union too.'' **********In the newspaper article and in several others that have appeared recently, the implication was clear that India should drop its selfconscious hesitation and call its bomb a bomb. Since the 1974 test India has clung to its insistence that what occurred in the desert was ''a peaceful nuclear explosion,'' which many contend is just as lethal as an atomic bomb. Since then India has avowed that it has produced no weapons and has no weapons delivery system. **********Now articles such as Mr. Subrahmanyam's, which is widely regarded as knowingly prophetic, are recommending an undisguised atomic arms program as the best way to deter Pakistan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/10/busin.body_text: **********Ramada Inns Inc., which has had major cost overruns at its casino-hotel project here, announced refinancing steps today that it asserted would cost the company money now but improve chances for future profits. **********Richard Snell, who took over as chairman when M. William Isbell resigned on Aug. 19, also said from the company's headquarters in Phoenix, Ariz., that Ramada Inns will report a 1981 loss of $26 million, or nearly $1 a share, and suspend its 3-cent quarterly dividend for the current quarter. **********Mr. Snell said the company's long-term financial health should be improved by efforts to ''strengthen its balance sheet and streamline its operations.'' **********''We've identified all the key problems facing the company,'' said a spokesman, Robert M. Renneisen, ''and it's a question of taking all the bitter medicine in one lump. It makes sacrifices this year and puts things back into a rational structure for the future.'' **********Mr. Snell announced an additional $50 million in financing for the company's proposed 524-room Tropicana casino-hotel, where costs have increased to $330 million from $139 million when the project was approved two years ago. The hotel is more than six months behind schedule and is expected to open in late fall. **********The company said the new loans would bring Ramada Inns' borrowing for the project to about $200 million. Mr. Snell said the company would absorb the Tropicana's $23 million in pre-opening expenses this year instead of over three years, saving it about $7 million annually. **********Some gambling industry experts have questioned whether the Tropicana can show a profit with a 48,000-square-foot casino, threefourths the size of those at Resorts International Hotel Casino and Bally's Park Place. **********But Mr. Renneisen said the $7 million saving would help the company ret ur n a profit in its first full year of operation.  Ramada Inns also plans to sell its utility stocks, worth about $45 million, at a $33 million loss. But Mr. Snell said the action would help the comp any in the long term through cash-flow benefits. **********Mr. Snell also said Ramada Inns would no longer market its computer subsidiary, International Micor Systems Inc., which had provided computerized hotel reservation service to other hotel chains. **********Mr. Snell said, however, the subsidiary would honor all contracts to other hotels and would continue to provide service for Ramada Inns' hotels worldwide. **********Ramada Inns has skipped quarterly dividends only once before, between September 1975 and September 1976, company officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM; READER COMMENT; ROUNDTABLE REPLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/busin.body_text: **********''T HE Business Roundtable issues this statement out of a strong conviction that the future of this nation depends upon the existence of strong and responsive business enterprises and that, in turn, the long-term viability of the business sector is linked to its responsibility to the society of which it is a part.'' **********That's how we began the Roundtable's recent paper on Corporate Responsibility, contrary to what Paul MacAvoy stated in ''The Business Lobby's Wrong Business'' (Dec. 20). **********His article took our statement to task in ways that suggest an almost deliberate misunderstanding of our position. Let me try to summarize what we said so it can be judged on its merits, for we believe it was a clear statement of where we came from and where we mean to go. **********The 16 chief executive officers of major companies who participated in developing the paper agreed that the corporate community must deal effectively with the issues in the public debate about the role of the corporation in society. This must be done by either explaining the corporate role satisfactorily or by meeting new expectations - or both. Failure to do so might mean no corporations as we now know them. **********We recognized that corporations have a responsibility, first of all, to make available to the public quality goods and services at fair prices, thereby earning a profit that attracts investment to continue and enhance the enterprise, provide jobs and build the economy. And we said that all sides must recognize the fundamental importance of profits and their contribution to the long-term viability of the enterprise: ''If the bottom line is a minus, there is no plus for society.'' **********Perhaps Samuel Gompers, father of the American labor movement, put it better when he said, ''The worst crime against the working people is a company that fails to make a profit.'' **********As shareholders make the corporation possible by providing funds for corporate birth, growth and development, we said that the interest of shareholders must be considered in all important corporate activities. **********But the character of shareholders has changed. At one time most of them were long-term, personally involved individual investors. Now large numbers of them are grouped in institutions as unidentified short-term buyers most interested in maximum near-term gain. Such interest must be balanced with a long-term perspective. The simple theory that management can get along by considering only the shareholder has been left behind in old economic dissertations. **********Chief executive officers who have been out there facing reality know that corporations are surrounded by a complicated pattern of economic, social, ethical, and political ideas and expectations. They know that they have to be concerned not only about shareholders but about such constituent groups as customers, employees, communities, suppliers and society at large. And they believe a corporation best serves its shareholders by carefully balancing the legitimate interests of all constituents. **********R EGINALD H. JONES, former chairman of the General Electric Company, put it well: ''Public policy and social issues are no longer adjuncts to business planning and management. They are in the mainstream of it. The concern must be pervasive in companies today, from boardroom to factory floor.'' **********Carefully weighing the effects of decisions and balancing different constituent interests must be an integral part of the corporation's decision-making and management process. A corporation's economic responsibility is by no means incompatible with other corporate responsibilities. **********The specifics of how a corporation addresses these responsibilities will vary from one company to another. Each corporation has an individual character, related to its products, markets, facilities, manufacturing processes and other aspects of its business. Some theorists may long for a total operational strategy or even a statute to dictate corporate responsibility, but only the naive or contentious would seek to fashion such a document. **********It is true that business enterprises are not designed to be either political or cultural institutions, but the business community will be well-served by habit of mind that stays alert to social currents.  That fundamental point carried through to the conclusion of our statement: ''A corporation's responsibilities include how the whole business is conducted every day. It must be a thoughtful institution which rises above the bottom line to consider the impact of its action on all, from shareholders to the society at large. Its business activities must make social sense just as its social activities must make business sense.'' **********We think that's good business.   ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Andrew C. Sigler is chief executive officer of the Champion International Corporation and chairman of the Business Roundtable Task Force on Corporate Responsibility.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/02/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 9.22 points, to 967.66, its seventh loss in eight trading sessions, as rising short-term interest rates deflated investor enthusiasm for stocks. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 49.1 million shares from Wednesday's 41.6 million. Conoco, a takeover candidate, rose 3 1/8 points as 1.4 million shares changed hands. (Page D1.) Prices declined and interest rates rose in all credit markets as dealers tried to trim inventory. (D7.) **********The dollar continued its surge against major foreign currencies.  Gold and silver prices fell sharply in New York after appearing to stabilize earlier in European trading. Gold closed here at $415.50 a troy ounce, down $8.50 from Tuesday. (D11.) **********The New York Cotton Exchange imposed emergency regulations on cotton futures trading because the amount of cotton in warehouses was not large enough to satisfy the unusually large number of open contracts held by traders. (D11.) Cocoa and coffee prices rose their daily limit, as the International Coffee Organization agreed on new limits on exports. (D11.) Grain and soybean futures soared on the news that a heat wave was threatening the Soviet Union's winter-sown wheat crop. (D11.) Companies **********The Justice Department rested its antitrust case against A.T.&T.  The Government took 61 days to present testimony. The Reagan Administration may drop the effort to break up the phone company. If not, A.T.&T.'s rebuttal, scheduled to begin in August, is expected to last four or five months. (D1.) **********British Petroleum suspended liftings of Libyan crude oil, saying that it was overpriced, and Exxon notified Libya that it would cut back oil purchases there. Similar cutbacks and suspensions are expected in Nigeria and Algeria unless they bow to pressure from the oil companies to cut their prices. (D6.) **********General Portland rejected Canada Cement Lafarge's unsolicited takeover bid of $45 a share, or a total of $315 million, calling it too low. It also cited antitrust issues. (D4.) **********Alan J. Hirschfield emerged the winner at 20th Century Fox after Dennis C. Stanfill resigned as chairman after failing to win the backing of Marvin Davis, the company's new owner, for his plans to discharge Harris Katleman, head of the studio's television operation. (D4.) **********Wheelabrator-Frye named Robert Page to head Kellogg Rust, the holding company it has set up to run its Rust Engineering subsidiary and the much larger M.W. Kellogg Company, an engineering and construction company it acquired when it purchased Pullman Inc. early this year. (D2.) The Economy **********Spending for new construction dropped 4.7 percent in May to an annual rate of $237.3 billion, the fourth straight monthly decline, the Commerce Department reported. Economists said the decline reflected high interest rates and the generally soft economy. (D2.) **********TV stations must sell ''reasonable amounts of time'' to candidates for Federal office, the Supreme Court ruled. The decision said that the F.C.C. had the right to override the networks' judgment of whether a candidate's campaign was eligible for the time. (A1.) **********The United Auto Workers formally rejoined the A.F.L.-C.I.O., 13 years after philosophical and policy differences led the U.A.W. to withdraw from the nation's largest labor group. The addition of 1.2 million U.A.W. members to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. will bring its total membership to almost 15 million. (A14.) **********Kurt Waldheim attacked overreliance on monetary policy in the fight against inflation at a United Nation's meeting in Geneva. Such a policy causes high interest rates that destabilize financial policies in other nations, he said, echoing criticism that the French and West Germans have leveled at the Reagan Administration. (D9.) Today's Columns **********Monogram Industries' earnings per share are looking good in spite of hard times because the mini-conglomerate has bought back about 60 percent of its shares since 1973. Market Place. (D8.) **********New devices can leave prerecorded messages - voice telegrams - on a businessman's telephone line. Major office-of-the-future companies are gearing up to sell them. Technology. (D2.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/13/world.print_headline: Around the World; Danish Cabinet Falls; Election Set for Dec. 8
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/13/world.body_text: **********Denmark's minority Social Democratic Government was toppled today as Parliament voted down an economic program that Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen had termed vital to revive the nation's stagnant economy. Mr. Jorgensen thereupon announced that special elections would be held Dec. 8. **********The defeat for Mr. Jorgensen, Prime Minister since 1975 except for a year in the late 1970's, came on a motion to carry out a compromise worked out in May with the three small parties - the Center Democrats, Social Liberals and the Christian Party - that have voted to keep him in power. **********At issue was how to channel interest revenues from pension and insurance funds into Denmark's industry and agriculture. **********The six Center Democrats in the 179-seat Parliament abandoned the Government on its plan to order public and private pension plans to reinvest about $425 million now in high-interest but unproductive government bonds. **********Mr. Jorgensen wanted the funds put in so-called ''active investments'' in the hard-hit agricultural and building sectors, helping his plan to create 50,000 new jobs a year. By the end of 1981, 250,000 Danes - 9 percent of the work force - are expected to be unemployed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/27/busin.body_text: **********Harvard University announced today that it would vote in favor of an International Business Machine's stockholder resolution to restrict the company's ability to sell or service computers for the South African Government. **********Harvard's vote in favor of the stockholder resolution, which I.B.M. management opposes, will be cast tomorrow in Kansas City at the company's annual meeting. **********Harvard's most recent financial report, dated June 30, 1980, indicated holdings of 1.04 million shares of I.B.M. stock worth approximately $61 million. **********Lawrence F. Stevens, the administrative assistant to Harvard's general counsel, said activities of I.B.M. in South Africa were ''exemplary'' and added that the resolution, if passed, would require no change in current company policy. **********I.B.M. management has opposed the resolution, contending it would expand the United States Government's restriction of sales to South Africa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/01/busin.body_text: **********ROGER B. SMITH, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, has an extra $500,000 a day to spend on new cars now, thanks to the Federal Government, which two weeks ago decided not to require air bags or other passive restraints on 1983 model cars. **********That's not a whole lot of money for a company that is spending a little under $1 million an hour around the clock on new plants and products. By now, more than 10 months since the inauguration of Ronald Reagan, General Motors, like thousands of other American manufacturers, had hoped to realize far greater savings from the Administration's promises to purge many of the Federal regulations of business. Deregulation to date has done little to pull the giant automobile company out of its severest slump in decades. The auto makers continue to report dismal results. In the third quarter, G.M.  posted a loss of $468 million, Ford $334.5 million and Chrysler $149.3 million. **********General Motors, for its part, is getting impatient. The savings from deregulation may come, Mr. Smith said, once they work their way through the bureaucratic pipeline and, in some instances, Congress.  For the moment, though, he takes satisfaction in the realization that, if G.M. hasn't felt much of the impact of deregulation, at least it need no longer fear adoption of new regulations. ''If nothing else,'' he said, ''our hearts are lighter.'' **********General Motors' experience with deregulation is a test not only of the Administration's promises but of its economic theories as well.  By easing the Federal grip on industry, the Administration has promised that industry could turn the resulting savings to investment in better plants and improvements in productivity. **********Not surprisingly, many of the Administration's critics contend that the deregulation that is good for General Motors is bad social policy for the country. Executives at G.M. dwell on the added costs, but environmental and safety advocates argue that the auto companies showed scant concern for clean air and safety before laws were passed and regulations written. **********Deregulation may also be bad for the economy: Certain kinds of deregulation simply shift costs from one sector to another. Prof.  William Nordhaus, a former member of the Council of Economic Advisers, has calculated that ending the passive restraint requirement will cost the country $4.5 billion during the life of the automobiles made in the 1982 through 1985 model years in medical costs, insurance costs and lost wages because of automobile deaths and injuries. **********The automobile industry was virtually free of regulation at the Federal level until the mid-1960's, when it was required to march to rules set by dozens of agencies. Today, regulators in Washington set standards for emissions, safety and mileage that affect the size, shape and performance of new automobiles as much as designers at G.M.'s Technical Center in Warren, Mich. Occupational safety inspectors prowl through factories while equal op-portunity officials have a say in who gets hired and promoted. Until earlier this year, lawyers at the Federal Trade Commission were contemplating a suit aimed at splitting the company into pieces. **********But last April, the Reagan Administration said it would assist the ailing auto industry by reducing the burden of regulation, rather than grant tax concessions and impose formal quotas on Japanese car imports, as the auto makers had requested. **********Vice President Bush, who heads the Administration's deregulatory effort, predicted that the proposed changes would save the industry $1.3 billion in capital costs and consumers more than $9 billion over five years. **********G .M. executives have calculated that complying with government regulations costs $2.2 billion annually, and that does not include the cost of the devices installed on cars to meet emissions and safety standards. Looked at another way, regulations required the efforts of the equivalent of 26,000 full-time G.M. employees, according to the company. **********''When you are making $10 billion a year that $2 billion is one thing,'' Mr. Smith said in an interview in his office on the tightly guarded 14th floor of the corporation's headquarters building. ''But when you are losing $700 million a year as we did in 1980, you look at it and say 'that's the difference between losing money and making money.' '' **********Asked if the Administration's program has had much impact on G.M.  as yet, Mr. Smith replied, ''unfortunately not.'' Although some of the 34 regulations on the April ''hit list'' have been rescinded, most have been minor. **********''The ones I think are important, the bumpers, the E.P.A., the ones that have the big money in them, we haven't seen any of those,'' Mr.  Smith said. G.M. estimates that meeting emissions standards adds $725 to the price of a new car while safety standards add $400. **********Nevertheless, the Administration has made deregulation a key part of its ''supply-side'' approach to the economy. And business has been accommodated in other ways. **********Since the advent of the Reagan Administration, Mr. Smith said there has been a change of attitude at agencies like the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission that in times past tended to view corporate actions with skepticism. He said G.M.  executives who deal with Federal regulators report ''they finally listened to what we were trying to say without that look of suspicion on their face.'' **********One exception, he said, is the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which has been pressing a race and sex discrimination case against the company since 1974. ''I have not seen as much change at E.E.O.C. as in other places. Maybe it's just taking longer to get that one turned around,'' he said. Other G.M. executives, arguing that the company has a good record on advancement of minorities and women, say the commission has not offered any ''rational'' plans to settle the case. **********Although he can't quantify the benefits, Mr. Smith said G.M. was being aided by deregulation efforts at the Interstate Commerce Commission, which is encouraging competition in shipping, and the freeing of price controls on oil, which tend to drive consumers toward newer, more fuel-efficient cars. **********The single largest achievement of the Reagan approach to regulation, Mr. Smith said, is not so much getting rid of the existing regulations but preventing the new ones from going into effect. Shortly after assuming office, the new Administration froze dozens of new regulatory initiatives advanced in the waning days of the Carter Administration. One would have ordered car makers to include crash-worthiness ratings, based on tests conducted at 35 miles an hour, on window price stickers. **********Part of the problem in deregulation, Administration officials concede, is the bureaucratic process needed to rescind rules. In the April declaration, the Environmental Protection Agency said it would relax by mid-September three regulations dealing with heavy truck emissions and emissions tests. It did so, but the proposed revisions are stalled in the Office of Management and Budget, which has been ordered by President Reagan to review all regulatory actions. ''There was a hang-up on one point involving testing,'' conceded an O.M.B.  spokesman, Edwin L. Dale Jr.. He said the dispute had been resolved and that the new rules would be published ''shortly.'' **********A proposal to lower the bumper crash-worthiness standard from 5 miles an hour to 2.5 miles an hour has similarly met with obstacles as the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration considers nine alternative propoposals. G.M. has said the 2.5-mile standard would save consumers $100 a car in fuel savings and lower purchase price.  Opponents of the change argue that car repair costs would increase. **********And Administration efforts to assist the auto industry by easing air pollution standards are stumbling over the fact that the current standards were set by Congress. Although some members of Congress have said action on the Clean Air Act is unlikely this year, a spokesman for Vice President Bush said an effort is being made to cobble together a compromise bill for action before Congress adjourns on Dec. 18. **********Mr. Smith, who favors a roll back of the standards to the 1980 levels, fears the changes may come too late to help the company through the current crunch because of the industry's long lead times. Even if the standards were revised tomorrow, he said, the effect would not be really felt until the 1983 model year. G.M. has said the stiffer 1981 standards have added $300 to the price of a car, and said the price of cars would be reduced by this amount if the standards were relaxed. **********As a result of its poor financial performance, auto industry analysts say, G.M. is being forced to reduce the number of new model cars it will bring out. Mr. Smith says the Administration needs to move more quickly if it really plans to assist the automobile industry with deregulation. **********''We're trying to be patient because we understand the necessity of rule-making procedures,'' Mr. Smith said. ''But we're getting tired of treading in the deep water and we would like a little bit of help on some of this. It just seems to be taking longer than we think it should.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/24/world.print_headline: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: TROOPS EVICT STRIKERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/24/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish here by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency End of Steel Strike 10 P.M. Wednesday, (4 P.M. Wednesday E.S.T.) **********Today the forces of order of the civic militia together with soldiers of the Polish People's Army restored order and calm in the Katowice steelworks. Some 2,000 employees from some departments, kept in the foundry for many days by terrorists from the former Solidarity works committee, have left for home. **********Many metalurgists earlier managed to flee the works. No one was hurt during the action by the forces of order. Most of the provocateurs and organizers of the work boycott in the Katowice steelworks have been apprehended. **********The search for some of them is still in progress in the works. The investigation continues. Appeal to Strikers 2 P.M. Wednesday, (8 A.M. Wednesday E.S.T.) **********In the past 24 hours, functionaries of the forces of order have detained 357 persons who did not observe the curfew. These persons must appear before the misdemeanor courts. Speculation gangs have also been unearthed. In one of them in Tychy, goods worth 600,000 zlotys were amassed. **********The anxiety and concern of all those who desire peace and stabilization is being aroused by the situation in the Ziemonwit and Piast collieries and in the Katowice steel mill. At the Ziemowit colliery, 1,026 miners have already come to the surface but around 1,000 miners are being detained below by a group of vigilantes numbering over 100, who are applying psychological terror on the miners. **********We remind you that the work force of this colliery numbers around 10,000 persons. The miners detained below are cut off from accurate information and are being threatened with drastic punishments which they will allegedly sustain after leaving the mine. The situation is similar at the Piast mine. **********The situation in these enterprises is referred to in today's appeal by the Provincial Committee of the Polish United Workers Party in Katowice to party members, miners of the Katowice Province. We read in the appeal that enormous efforts are still being made so that all the miners of the Ziemowit and Piast collieries can spend the approaching holiday with their relatives. However, these endeavors are not having an effect because of the group of adventurers who are playing with human life in a carefree manner. **********In the appeal, words are also addressed to the families of the Ziemowit and Piast miners. We know that you are anxious about the fate, health and life of your husbands and sons. Let us help them make a decision. **********We are all waiting for this decision to be made, together with the miners' families. Meeting With Intellectuals 7:30 P.M. Wednesday, (1:30 P.M. Wednesday E.S.T.) **********We have just received news that the premier, Army Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, today met a group of 59 representatives of the country's scientific quarters, higher educational establishments and scientific and research institutes. **********The meeting of distinguished scientists and intellectuals was attended by Prof. Dr. Hieronin Kubiak, Politburo member and Polish United Workers Party Central Committee secretary, Mieczyslaw Rakowski and deputy chairman of the Council of Ministers, head of the Science Higher Education and Technology Department, Mieczyslaw Kazimierczuk. **********On behalf of the Military Council of National Salvation and the Government, Army Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski discussed the country's sociopolitical and economic situation under conditions of martial law. The main objective of actions taken so far is to draw Poland away from this dramatic twist of history and to overcome the socioeconomic crisis threatening the socialist state's foundations. **********Today this calls for sacrifices - sacrifices made with the future of the country in mind - for its development is linked indissolubly with the process of socialist renewal. **********General Jaruzelski urged those attending the meeting to assist in the active role of Polish scientists, intellectuals and creators in working for the salvation of the homeland, for consolidation of the state, and for building a bridge of social and patriotic agreement. **********In a long and open debate many eminent professors focused attention on the duties and targets of academic and scientific quarters in conditions of martial law. **********Views of the world of science and current national issues particularly the urgent need to rebuild trust, calm and scientific and teaching work in Polish universities, were relayed to the premier. Demands of Miners 4:06 A.M. Wednesday, (10:06 P.M. Tuesday E.S.T.) **********From the regional press review: In Silesia flashpoints continue to exist. In yesterday's Trybuna Roboinicza I came across a report entitled ''A Drama of Division and Perplexity'' and above this title was the title ''We Sincerely Hope for a Shared Christmas - A Family Affair in All Miners Homes.'' The report was prepared by journalists Jerzy Bielonski, Ryszard Zula, Jerzy Nismiec, and Andrzej Wozniak.  Here is the full text of the material from Trybuna Roboinicza: **********From the Ziemowit mine. A hopeless protest is continuing a drama of division and perplexity is being played out. It is a disagreement that is not needed today. The painful waiting of those at the surface to see what will happen is continuing. They know that life in the country is very onerous but that it is returning to normal. They want at all costs to convince their nearest and dearest of this. They value efforts to make Christmas peaceful. However the resistance of those who treat every telephone call and every appeal by a mother or wife as a lie or provocation is continuing. Sometimes even a mother's voice is treated with suspicion. **********When we visited the Ziemowit mine on the ninth day of martial law we learned that the mine was operational. But that there was no extraction. On the surface life went on as normal. Miners came in for the second shift. Those who were making sure that the mine was safe, although it was not extracting, came out freely. **********We did not notice in the vicinity of the mine or on the roads leading to it any patrol, a feature which is after all so characteristic of the streets of our towns today. Let us repeat there was not a single patrol - not an Army one, not one from the militia, nor a workers' one. Private cars entered the parking lots. **********During the course of the protest which is going on, 874 miners have already come up. Yesterday at 7 A.M. there were still 1,147 miners down in the pit out of a workforce of over (number indistinct). The people concerned with mining supervision the army officers who come through to this place all say the same, 'We are very concerned. We are doing everything and we will do everything so that these dramatic days come to an end as soon as possible. We warmly hope that Christmas will be a shared family affair in all our miners' homes. **********From the Piast mine. Since Dec. 4 in the Piast mine in Tychy a protest by part of the work force has been going on. Yesterday, at 4 P.M., 1,726 miners of the Piast mine where the work force numbers 8,300, were still down under at level 50. Among those who are ocupying the level are workers of the mining work enterprise from Myslowice. **********The protest broke out last Monday and (number indistinct) miners joined in on the first shift. Work still went on according to the normal rhythm: 7,800 tons of coal were extracted. However, following the end of the first shift, a portion of the work force then at work - about 300 persons - refused to come to the surface later the workers of further extraction shifts joined them. **********The protesters are calling for the freeing of all internees, including the deputy chairman of the plant union commission of Solidarity in the Piast mine, Eugeniusz Szelongowski, and the head of the Solidarity group of the State Mining Council at Piast, Stanislaw Dziwac: the repeal of martial law and a guarantee to all participants in this protest of security. **********Between Dec. 15 and up to 4 P.M. yesterday 24 of the protesters left occupied level 50. These remaining below are staying in the site of the main pumping plant in the air shaft, at the passenger stations and the shaft bottoms. **********Systematic telephonic communication with them is being maintained.  However, of 160 telephones which are normally in action at this level, only 7 are fully efficient. The remainder have been damaged or switched off by the protesters. **********Representatives of the directorate and officers of the Polish Army have on many occasions made contact with the protesters. However, no arguments get through to those who are occupying the bottom of the pit. **********Three priests from the Tychy parish went down. They spent several hourse at level 50, leaving it after 7 P.M. Saturday.  The priests did not obtain the permission of the protesters to go down again yesterday, on Monday, nor was similar permission given to several wives who also wanted to see (word indistinct) husbands. The protesters personally define who has the right of direct contact with them and when. Yesterday, for instance, when it was necessary to examine the condition of part of the occupied workings, in accordance with mining regulations -an inspector of the mining office was there - the protestors personally defined who was to be the inspector and they made his coming down dependent on his not being accompanied - as is customary in mining - by a team of helpers bearing the instruments essential for taking measurements. Increased Soviet Supplies 7 A.M. Wednesday, (1 A.M. Wednesday E.S.T.) **********Just a few days ago, a Polish-Soviet agreement was concluded concerning additional deliveries of food items, clothing for children, and the speeding up of Soviet deliveries of oil and gasoline; and already today we have received a report on the almost complete implementation by the Soviet Union of the deliveries offered to our country. **********At the transloading rail stations on the Polish border, 20,000 tons of rice, 200 tons of raisins and over 2,000 tons of mandarin oranges have already arrived. Also, confectionary cans of grape juice, prepared foods for children and toys have been delivered. Children's clothing, as well as half a million pairs of children's shoes, have already been sent from the Soviet Union to Poland. Reopening of Schools 7 P.M. Wednesday, (1 P.M. Wednesday E.S.T.) **********Schools will reopen on 4 January under conditions of martial law.  Maria Mazurowa, director of the General Education Department in the Ministry of Education and Training, told a Trybuna Ludu journalist that in addition to the restrictions connected with the situation in the country, there will be difficulties in transporting children to schools and a shortage of heating fuel - in other words, all the inconveniences of winter. Hence, good work organization, careful consideration by principals of all decisions and discipline among educational workers are of particular importance. We have learned that schools will be using the curriculum which has been in force to date. Lecture plans will also not be altered. However, in exceptional cases, a school principal has the right to reduce curriculum content and the right, even the duty to introduce changes in weekly schedules should conditions require them. Schools will remain on a 5-day week. Recreational activities will be organized on Saturdays.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/26/world.main_headline: CRISIS IN POLAND PART OF U.S. PLOT, PRAVDA CHARGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/26/world.print_headline: CRISIS IN POLAND PART OF U.S. PLOT, PRAVDA CHARGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/26/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union today published the most comprehensive charges to date that events in Poland over the last 17 months were part of a long and intricate campaign by the United States to wrest Poland from the Communist camp. **********Western diplomats asserted that the 3,600-word Pravda article by Vladimir Bolshakov was less remarkable for the substance of its claims than for what it revealed about the Kremlin's insecurity and suspicion. **********Mr. Bolshakov described virtually every Polish emigre organization, thousands of Polish-Americans who returned to retire in Poland, all the supplies and donations sent to Solidarity and virtually every contact between the labor union and the West as part of a web spun by the United States Central Intelligence Agency ''to undermine the socialist statehood and to create conditions for a counterrevolutionary coup.'' **********(Asked to comment on the Pravda article, Mark D. Weinberg, the assistant White House press secretary, said in Washington: ''Charges similar to these have been made in the past. There was no truth to them then and there is no truth to them now.'') **********Martial Law Not Discussed **********Under the headline ''On the Interference of the Special Services of the U.S.A. in the Affairs of the P.P.R.,'' Mr. Bolshakov said the C.I.A. declared a ''full-scale secret war'' against Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia in the early 1950's under the code name Redsox-Redcap. After revolts in Hungary and Czechoslovakia were put down by Soviet forces, the C.I.A. made Poland its prime target, he said. **********The article did not discuss Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's declaration of martial law on Dec. 13 and referred only in passing to ''a number of miscalculations of the leadership in economic and social policy.'' Rather, Mr. Bolshakov's focus was almost entirely on what he described as the ''old plans of imperialism for the restoration of capitalism in Poland, for wresting the country out of the socialist community, above all from the Warsaw treaty organization.'' **********The intent of the article, whose length suggested high-level approval, was apparently to provide authoritative and detailed support for the claim that Poland faced the threat of a coup by C.I.A.-backed foes of Communism among Solidarity's leaders. **********The immediate purpose of such a claim was evidently to justify martial law in Poland, but the underlying theme of a plot against the Warsaw Pact suggested that the article could also be used to justify Soviet intervention if it comes. **********''The White House did not conceal that the events in Poland were a subject not only of political but also of strategic interest for the U.S.A.,'' Mr. Bolshakov wrote. An Attack on the System **********He said a special panel set up under Vice President Bush to follow events in Poland had received a special directive to explore ways of aiding ''Polish counterrevolutionaries.'' **********The article concluded, ''Those who are hatching such aggressive plans and conducting a new crusade against Poland under Dulles' banner of 'rolling back Communism' should be reminded that the socialist community has repulsed lovers of such ventures more than once.'' **********Mr. Bolshakov composed a picture of a concerted attack on Poland's Communist system, manipulated and financed by the C.I.A. and other Western intelligence services and using ''well-organized units'' of many thousands in Poland and 400 centers outside. **********Mr. Bolshakov said the C.I.A.'s campaign to create a ''controlled crisis'' in Poland led to the establishment of an organization of East European emigres in 1975 that helped found and finance the dissident Polish organization KOR. **********The committees of independent trade unions set up by KOR in Gdansk and Katowice became the nucleus of Solidarity, the article said. Radio Stations Cited **********Throughout this period, Mr. Bolshakov said, KOR acted in concert with other dissident groups backed and financed by Western intelligence services, and the activities of ''that whole antisocialist rabble'' were directed by the American radio stations Radio Liberty, Radio Free Europe and the Voice of America. The Voice, Mr. Bolshakov said, broadcast instructions in cipher to the Polish underground. **********Mr. Bolshakov described with disapproval the Polish Government's practice of letting Polish-Americans visit and settle in Poland, a policy unthinkable in the Soviet Union, which regards all its own emigres with suspicion. **********''Ten thousand American citizens were resident in Poland in November 1981, among them quite a lot of people who were openly hostile to socialism or agents of the U.S. intelligence services,'' he said. **********Mr. Bolshakov said that by the time Solidarity was formed in August 1980, the ''antisocialist'' forces had a network able to take control of it quickly. **********He continued: ''From the very beginning, the U.S. Administration oriented itself to the counterrevolutionary top leaders of 'Solidarity.' This was done evidently in the belief that the seizure of power in Poland by the 'Solidarity' leaders is a matter of the near future.'' **********Pravda went on to enumerate what it called Solidarity's foreign sources of support and funds, including the A.F.L.-C.I.O., linking most organizations with the C.I.A. The 400 centers of support abroad secretly sent several million dollars to Poland, the paper said. U.S. Denies Charges Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 - When asked for comment on the Pravda assertion of United States manipulation of Solidarity, Mark D.  Weinberg, assistant White House press secretary, said tonight: **********''Charges similar to these have been made in the past. There was no truth to them then and there is no truth to them now.'' As to the Pravda assertion of a Central Intelligence Agency program code-named Redsox-Redcap, a C.I.A. spokesman, Dale Peterson, said, ''We never comment on Soviet propaganda no matter how ridiculous.'' **********When asked whether, as Pravda asserted, a panel under Vice President Bush had been set up to aid Polish counterrevolutionaries, Mr. Bush's spokesman, Peter Teeley, said: ''No. That's ridiculous.'' **********Mr. Teeley said that Pravda apparently was referring to a special situation group, led by Mr. Bush, that reviews information coming out of Poland and presents its evaluations of it to President Reagan. **********Regarding the charge against the Voice of America, the service's director of programs, Frank E. Scott, said, ''We never have broadcast coded messages in any language, and we certainly are not broadcasting coded messages to Poland in Polish.'' **********A State Department official who spoke only on condition that he not be identified said that the Pravda article contained ''an immense array of falsehoods, hogwash and absolute junk.'' **********He said that the article appeared to retell history as the Soviet Union wished it had occurred, rather than as it actually happened.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/12/world.main_headline: 3 Killed and 14 Are Wounded In 3 Incidents in Guatemala
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/12/world.print_headline: 3 Killed and 14 Are Wounded In 3 Incidents in Guatemala
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/12/world.body_text: **********Gunmen driving past the United States Embassy killed a Guatemalan policeman and bombings and a gun fight left two others dead and 14 wounded, the authorities reported today. The securit y force spokesmen said that assailants firing automatic weapons from several vehicles sped past the embassy last night and killed the 23 -year-old national policeman guarding the building. **********No group claimed responsibility for the attack. **********A land mine exploded this morning on a highway 67 miles west of the capital, killing a 9-year-old girl and injuring 14 others aboard a vehicle taking them to a vacation resort, the police reported. They said the victims were Government workers and their families. **********The military spokesmen said a bomb exploded later in the day outside an army barracks in northern Guatemala City and in a brief exchange of gunfire that followed a young man believed to be a passerby was killed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/world.main_headline: Athens to Let Constantine Stay for Just a Few Hours
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Athens to Let Constantine Stay for Just a Few Hours
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/world.body_text: **********In a last-minute bid to avert political violence and a revival of the traditional schism between monarchists and republicans, the Government today persuaded King Constantine to stay here for only a few hours on Thursday. **********The former sovereign, who will be returning for the first time in 14 years for the burial of Frederika, the Queen Mother, had originally been granted permission for a visit of two days. **********The decision was taken, according to a Government minister, after it became apparent that a confrontation was likely.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/14/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation, historically the domestic automobile company most committed to producing its own components, is looking increasingly to outside suppliers as a means of lowering its labor costs, according to the company's chairman, Roger B. Smith. **********''It's a matter of being competitive in the marketplace,'' Mr.  Smith said, after predicting that the practice, known as ''outsourcing,'' would become more common throughout the American automobile industry. He said that as a result of the General Motors effort, some of its plants might close. **********In a meeting on Monday with a group of reporters and editors at The New York Times, Mr. Smith touched on a broad range of topics affecting General Motors and the auto industry, but saved his strongest remarks for labor issues. **********Critical of Wage Rates **********Mr. Smith said that American auto workers had ''priced themselves out of the market.'' In addition to spurring manufacturers to buy more components from nonunion suppliers and overseas automobile companies, he said, labor was encouraging the replacement of people with automated equipment because of its high wage rates. **********''Every time the cost of labor goes up $1 an hour, 1,000 more robots become economical,'' he said.  Since becoming chairman of the company, Mr. Smith has tried to modify the labor contract negotiated by his predecessors in September 1979. The United Automobile Workers union, however, has refused to reopen the agreement, which extends until September 1982. G.M. and the Ford Motor Company have said that their labor costs of about $20 an hour put them at a severe disadvantage with their Japanese competitors, whose labor costs are about $12 an hour. **********Mr. Smith's emphasis on controlling labor costs appeared to be part of the public buildup leading to the 1982 labor negotiations, in which it is generally expected that G.M. will be the target company for the union. **********Mr. Smith said he believed that an agreement would be reached without a strike, noting that union leaders understood the industry's difficulties and the threat to jobs posed by decisions to produce more components outside the auto companies. But, he added, union leaders were trapped by the skepticism of their rank-and-file members. 'They've Overreached' **********''There's got to be a realization on the part of the union that they've overreached,'' Mr. Smith said. ''They've stampeded this herd of buffalo by telling them they are underpaid. Now they've got to tell them they are overpaid in relation to the competition.'' **********He said that General Motors was prepared to offer profit-sharing in return for reduced labor costs, but balked at job guarantees, a demand that the union's president, Douglas A. Fraser, has said would figure prominently in the talks next summer. **********''What good is a job guarantee when the result is uneconomical? Mr. Smith asked. ''What happens if the company goes broke? It doesn't do any good to give a false sense of security.'' **********Mr. Smith declined to predict how well the 1982 models would sell, breaking with a long industry tradition of issuing optimistic sales forecasts. ''You tell me what interest rates are going to do and I'll tell you about the automobile market,'' he said. **********Most other auto industry leaders have been forecasting car sales of about 10.5 million in 1982, compared with about 9 million this year, although they have generally said that interest rates would have to decline for the 1982 prediction to be reached. **********When the new ''A''-body intermediate-size models, the ''F''-body sports models and new small pickup trucks are introduced later this year and early next year, the company will be about two-thirds through its ''downsizing'' program, Mr. Smith said. The program is intended to increase fuel efficiency. Still to be redesigned, he added, are the company's larger cars and its vans. Fuel Economy Stressed **********Although some auto makers, notably Chrysler, will stop making larger cars entirely, Mr. Smith said that G.M. would continue to make cars in all sizes. ''People don't want small cars,'' he said, ''they want fuel-efficient cars. So we say, you can have any size car you want and it will be fuel-efficient.'' **********Conceding that he disagreed with some of G.M.'s own marketing experts, Mr. Smith said he believed that Americans who formerly purchased large cars were not likely to shift their allegiance to compacts. Instead, he said, he believed that such consumers would simply repair their present cars until they are attracted back into the showrooms by a new generation of more fuel-efficient large autos. **********Commenting on the Reagan Administration's economic program and its effect on the automobile industry, Mr. Smith said that while he generally favored the Administration's course, there had been little impact so far. ''We could get substantial benefits from the Reagan tax program in later years, but it won't help much this year,'' he said. Similarly, he observed that the impact of the Administration's deregulation efforts was largely in proposals not yet enacted, rather than in existing regulations revoked. May Buy foreign Steel **********In addition to looking overseas for components produced at low wage rates, Mr. Smith said that General Motors was considering the purchase of foreign steel. Virtually all of the company's steel is now bought from American mills, but Mr. Smith said: ''We're looking hard at outsourcing. You've got to in this environment.'' **********Increasingly sophisticated automated manufacturing equipment and computer control of car operations will be the major technological innovations of this decade, Mr. Smith said. In cooperation with machine tool companies and on its own, G.M. has been concentrating on developing a generation of industrial robots that can recognize different parts, no matter how assembled, and install them accurately despite changes in the pace or alignment of items on the assembly line. ''I'm trying to get them out of the labs and into the plants,'' he said. **********Computer control of engine and transmission operations is reaching the point, he added, that cars equipped with a computer-controlled automatic transmission may soon get better mileage than those with standard shifts, the traditional mileage leaders. **********''We now can understand and control the engine as never before,'' Mr. Smith said. But, he added, he expected improvements in automobiles to be a series of adjustments rather than a technological breakthrough. ''One of the best things about automobiles,'' he said, ''is that each has about 15,000 parts. There's always got to be a way to put them together cheaper, better and faster.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/18/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of a statement made June 12 by Sigvard Eklund of Sweden, head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, to the agency's Board of Governors in Vienna: **********I have received the following report from the Department of Safeguards: The task of the agency in the implementation of safeguards is to verify that no safeguarded nuclear material is diverted from peaceful purposes. In a research reactor of the Osiris type this means, in the first place, to insure that fuel elements supplied from abroad are checked on arrival and that from that moment on continuity of knowledge is maintained on their location and integrity. The primary measures used for this purpose are item accounting, identification and containment and surveillance. The design of the facility and of the fuel elements is such that they provide assurance that the diversion of fuel elements would be detected with very high probability.1 **********Production of Plutonium **********The second possibility of diversion in a facility of the Osiris type is based on the undeclared production of plutonium. As the fuel elements consist of highly enriched uranium, only very small quantities of plutonium can be produced in them. Larger quantities, perhaps up to the order of one significant quantity2 per year, could only be produced if the core of the reactor were surrounded by a blanket of fertile elements made of natural or depleted uranium. The size and location of this blanket would be such that ordinary visual inspection would reveal its presence. The production of plutonium in fertile elements located underneath the reactor is practically impossible since the core is placed on a thick concrete slab, which in turn is lined with a heavy steel plate. These provide shielding to permit maintenance work on control element drives located in a vault below the reactor to be carried out. The Conclusion **********The existence or otherwise of undeclared underground installations has no influence on the detection capability of the I.A.E.A.'s inspectorate at reactors of the Osiris type. In such a transparent pool reactor, the absence of fuel elements or the presence of undeclared fertile elements for plutonium production would be easily detected. **********In conclusion, in a reactor of this type, diversion of fuel elements or of undeclared plutonium produced at low rates cannot be technically excluded but would be detected with very high probability. **********It should, of course, be borne in mind that it is not the task of the agency to search facilities or installations which do not contain safeguarded material. **********May I end by saying that the presence of a large number of technicians from the country which has delivered the reactor could also be expected to provide some assurance.  ---- Explanation of technical terms: 1-''Very high probability'' means, in this case, a full guarantee, since the main inspection activity is counting about 60 fuel elements, which are individual objects of considerable size.  Additionally, measurements are made that prove that the elements are not dummies.  2-''Significant quantity'' is an amount of special fissionable material sufficent for manufacturing - after processing losses -a single nuclear explosive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/13/busin.body_text: **********The Sun Company said that its Sun Gas Liquids Inc. marketing subsidiary had reached a definitive agreement to sell its retail assets to Synergy Group Inc. for an undisclosed amount. **********Synergy Group, which is engaged in propane distribution, leisure and energy-related consumer products and material handling equipment, will acquire all retail facilities and merchandise in 80 branch outlets in nine Southern and Middle Western states, but Sun said that the sale did not include its wholesale liquefied petroleum gas business. **********Sun said that the sale, which will close by the end of the year after a Government-required waiting period, is part of its continuing assets redeployment strategy, which will channel more capital into energy exploration and production.

Lefever, the Administration's nominee to become Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, used a mailing list paid for by the Nestle Corporation to distribute an article favoring the sale of infant formula to poor nations, it was disclosed today. **********Richard Edelman, an executive of the public relations concern representing Nestle, made the disclosure in an interview.  Mr. Lefever, the president of the Washington-based Ethics and Public Policy Center, refused to comment on Mr. Edelman's disclosure. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/27/busin.body_text: **********A device for controlling machines by voice and musical sounds has been invented by Theodore Lasar, a New York electronics engineer. **********He has a working model. **********Patent 4,275,266, granted this week, explains that the idea is to enable persons who can create musical notes by humming, singing, whistling or playing an instrument to command machines. A memory and microprocessor produce control signals. **********Other uses suggested by the patent are telephone dialing, opening doors and turning on lights for the disabled and letting automobile drivers regulate their radios and headlamps. **********Mr. Lasar is proprietor of the Electric Eye Products Company, which makes electric eyes that report people as they enter doors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/03/busin.body_text: **********An engineer employed by the Army has, in his spare time, devised an approved method of creating large honey bee colonies with two queen bees, which are isolated to prevent one from killing the other. Otis R. Pannell of Alexandria, Va., has been awarded patent 4,241,467 for a hive arrangement with four chambers, between which only the honey bees can pass. **********Each spring, the queens lay their eggs, from which honey bees are hatched after 21 days. The honey bees, which live only six weeks, produce honey by flying to various blooming plants and depositing what they collect in their honeycombs. The isolation of the queens keeps them from fighting, and assures that at least one will be left to perpetuate the colonies. **********Mr. Pannell has hives in his yard, and plans more tests before any commercialization.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/11/busin.body_text: **********The lackluster pace of retail sales in October and expectations of sharply lower third-quarter earnings for the nation's big chain stores are leading to some unusually pessimistic forecasts for the coming Christmas season. **********Major retailers posted their weakest sales gains of the year last month, and some chains, including Montgomery Ward & Company and the F.W. Woolworth Company, reported declines. This disappointing performance spurred many industry analysts to reduce their already low third-quarter profit forecasts for retailers. **********Retail earnings for the three months ended Oct. 31 will trickle out later this week, and analysts are predicting declines of as much as 60 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. **********Most Important Period **********But it is the Christmas season and its strategic influence on the fourth quarter, the most important period of the year for retailers, that is of the most concern to industry analysts. **********''It looks like it will be a decent Christmas season but nothing to write home about,'' said Terence J. McEvoy, vice president and analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. He added that the small October sales gain was the result of a substantial cutback in consumer buying that ''reflects a less than inspiring national economy.'' **********Industry executives are also apprehensive about the Christmas season. ''The recent sales numbers show some deceleration in sales compared to the spring season,'' said Howard Goldfeder, chairman and chief executive officer of Federated Department Stores Inc., which owns Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, as well as other leading stores. 'It Could Be Weaker' **********''I know of little reason why that should not continue, although Christmas occupies a special niche in the heart of the American consumer,'' he said. ''But I doubt that the season's business will be better than it is currently and it could be weaker.'' **********Fabian Linden, director of consumer research and an economist for the Conference Board, a business research group, is also pessimistic. ''At this moment, the Christmas shopping season doesn't look especially promising,'' he said. ''The fact that unemployment is up means that sooner or later there will be a decline in disposable income.'' **********''Although there's an avalanche of opinion for a rough recession, I think it might be much too early for so dreary a prognosis,'' he added. ''It's hard to think of a big bust without a preceding boom.''  Associated's Chief Optimistic **********William P. Arnold, chairman and chief executive officer of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, is a bit more optimistic. He expects ''a very strong Christmas, although I was somewhat depressed by the consumer's reaction of the last three weeks.'' He attributed the slowing sales pace to widespread consumer interest in the taxexempt savings certificates offered by banks. **********Mr. Arnold, whose company is oriented toward higher-income consumers and operates Lord & Taylor, Joseph Horne's in Pittsburgh, J.W. Robinson in Los Angeles and others, expects that President Reagan's tax cut and ''more disposable income on the part of our customers mean that we'll have a good season; if people don't spend money for cars, homes or go on expensive vacations, then they will have it for us.'' **********One retail analyst, Jeffrey M. Feiner of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, expects sales during the holiday season to increase by less than the 8 percent rise registered last Christmas. **********''We believe that the continued generally difficult economy, high interest rates, the sluggish employment trend and the declining consumer confidence levels are all likely to result in continued sluggish sales for most retailers,'' he said. **********Edward Johnson, director of the Johnson Redbook Service, a division of Prescott, Ball & Turben, said that a number of company thirdquarter earnings have been reduced ''mainly due to lower than expected sales increases, high interest rates and lower gross margins due to higher promotional sales.'' **********He added that earnings estimates for all of 1981 ''could prove too high if the current slowdown in consumer expenditures accelerates and results in a disappointing Christmas season.'' Big Woolworth Drop Forecast **********As for the third-quarter results soon to be announced, Robert J.  Simonson, an analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, expects the biggest year-to-year decline, 62 percent, to be reported by Woolworth. He attributes the drop to ''sharply higher interest costs and a negative swing in foreign currency adjustments, together with profit declines in all major geographic areas, the United States, primarily at Woolco and Kinney Shoes, Britain, West Germany and Canada.'' **********He estimated that Woolworth would report third-quarter results of 30 cents a share against 79 cents the year before.  The Allied Stores Corporation, Carter Hawley Hale Stores and the Dayton-Hudson Corporation will be reporting quarterly earnings blunted by pressure from a sales slowdown and sharply higher interest costs, according to Mr. Simonson. Allied is expected to have quarterly earnings of 67 cents a share, down 14 percent from last year's 78 cents a share. Carter Hawley is expected to have 27 percent lower earnings in the quarter, 27 cents a share against 37 cents, he said, while Dayton-Hudson's earnings will be up 8 percent, to an estimated $1.35 a share from $1.25 in the 1980 period. **********The K mart Corporation, the second-biggest retailer after Sears, Roebuck & Company, will have virtually no gain in third-quarter earnings, reporting an estimated 25 cents a share, the same as last year, according to Mr. Johnson of Johnson Redbook. Mr. McEvoy of Dean Witter concurs in the estimate. Rise Expected for J.C. Penney **********But the J.C. Penney Company is expected to have a 19 percent rise or even higher gains in its quarter's earnings. Mr. Simonson expects Penney to report $1 a share against 84 cents in the 1980 period but Mr. McEvoy estimates its earnings may be as high as $1.05 a share.  ''Although Penney's sales have slowed noticeably since August,'' Mr.  Simonson said, ''a strong improvement in gross margin and a decline in LIFO charges should produce a double-digit profit increase from the year-earlier depressed level.'' LIFO refers to the ''last in, first out'' method of valuing inventories. **********The only major retailer that has announced its third-quarter results, Sears, said on Oct. 22 that it had a 4.7 percent decline, to 40 cents a share from 42 cents a year ago, because of rising interest rates that affected its credit business and adverse underwriting results in its Allstate Insurance Group. **********But Sears added that the total net income of its merchandising group rose sharply in the quarter, to $43.4 million from $30 million. Sears moved away from the rest of the big retailers in its reporting period by shifting this year to a calendar year rather than remaining with a fiscal year that began on Feb. 1. **********Exceptions to the dour estimates for retail third-quarter earnings included some of the specialty retailers, such as Best Products, a catalogue showroom chain expected to be up 68 percent; Wal-Mart Stores, a discounter, expected to rise 34 percent, and Longs Drug Stores, with an increase of 14 percent forecast.
