https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/29/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Yields of New Bills Advance; 6-Month Rate Set at 12.45%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/29/busin.body_text: **********Rates continued to climb at yesterday's Treasury auction of threeand six-month bills. The average yield on three-month bills jumped to 11.690 percent from 11.037 a week ago, while the rate on the companion six-month bills advanced to 12.45 percent from 11.84 percent. **********As a result, banks and thrift institutions may offer a maximum rate of 12.698 percent on their new six-month savings certificates, effective today. The top rate on these instruments last week was 12.088 percent. **********The maximum allowable rate payable to savers is set at a quarter percentage point above the average yield at the weekly sales of Treasury six-month bills. **********Meanwhile, short-term rates and prices of long-term Treasury coupon issues meandered in a narrow range in extremely light trading, finally closing on an upward bias. **********Several dealers said that they closed last week's three-month Treasury bills at a rate of 11.25 percent, which would be a rise of 15 basis points. (A hundred basis points equals a full percentage point.) The companion six-month bills were closed out at 12.30 on average, a rise of 20 basis points. **********Some of the longer Treasury coupon maturities were up by a quarter point, or $2.50 for each $1,000 of face value, if they were changed at all. The tax-exempt and corporate bond markets continued to mark time until the holiday season ends. Institutions Absent **********Dealers attributed the slow session mainly to the absence of institutional buyers, who are not expected to return to the credit markets until the new year. Much of the business that took place was among Government securities dealers squaring their books for year-end accounting purposes. **********Also absent was the usual late flurry of trading that attends the Federal Reserve's release of the weekly figures on the nation's basic money supply. Several dealers said that the declines in the narrow and broader-based computations were largely offset by the upward revisions in the previous week's numbers. 'A Standoff' **********''Today's money supply figures represent a standoff,'' observed Edward E. Yardeni, vice president and chief economist at E.F. Hutton & Company. ''The net decline in the figures was too small to really move the market either way.'' **********There can be no significant rise in bond prices and a concomitant fall in yields until the key short-term rates move downward, Mr.  Yardeni emphasized, ''and we are still waiting for this to happen.'' **********At midday, the Federal Reserve moved, in effect, to temporarily inject funds into the banking system through three-day repurchase agreements. The Federal funds rate, the sensitive overnight interbank lending rate, was at 12.75 percent at the time. It remained at that level for the rest of the day. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auctions of three- and six-month Treasury bills: (000 omitted in dollar figures) 3-Mo. Bills 6-Mo. Bills Average Price 97.045 93.707 Discounted Rate 11.690% 12.448% Coupon Yield 12.21% 13.47% Low Price 97.032 93.687 Discounted Rate 11.742% 12.487% Coupon Yield 12.27% 13.51% High Price 97.080 93.762 Discounted Rate 11.552% 12.339% Coupon Yield 12.06% 13.34% Accepted at low 28% 66% Total applied for $10,456,005 $8,585,170 Accepted $4,905,755 $4,900,460 N.Y. applied for $8,468,585 $7,114,240 N.Y. accepted $4,028,985 $4,060,240 Noncompetitive $741,670 $482,195 **********Both these issues are dated Dec. 31. The three-month bills mature April 1, 1982, and the six-month bills, July 1, 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/03/busin.body_text: **********Depite some reservations within the oil industry, Canadian business leaders hailed yesterday's energy pricing agreement between the federal Government and the major oilproducing province of Alberta and expressed hope that it would stimulate the faltering economy. **********The 16-month dispute put a damper on the nation's oil industry.  Major energy projects were postponed and uncertainty about the course of Canadian energy policy helped to depress the Canadian dollar. **********C. William Daniel, president and chief executive officer of Shell Canada, echoing the view of other businessmen interviewed, called the agreement between the federal and provincial governments ''the best news the Canadians have heard in years.'' He said that settlement of the dispute over oil pricing would give the economy a strong boost. **********Forrest Rogers, economic advisor to the Toronto Dominion Bank, said the agreement ''should be helpful in a broad variety of ways,'' a major advantage being the impact on federal revenues. In this regard, Finance Minister Allan MacEachen, who is expected to present a budget this autumn, said in Ottawa that the agreement reduced the need for increased personal income taxes. **********Under the agreement between the federal Government and the Province of Alberta, which accounts for more than 90 percent of Canadian oil production, the federal share of revenues from oil and gas is to be increased to 29 percent from 10 percent. Alberta's share would drop to 34 percent from 45 percent, and the industry share would drop to 37 percent from 45 percent. Praise Not Unanimous **********Despite the initial euphoria, however, an undercurrent of dissatisfaction became evident as analysts studied the agreement's effects upon the oil industry. **********Ian R. Smyth, executive director of the Canadian Petroleum Association in Calgary, Alberta's capital, said that a preliminary study of the complex agreement showed that ''well over 90 percent of the energy price increase will go to Government. Where do we get the cash flow for development?'' **********Mr. Smyth, whose group represents mostly the big, integrated oil and gas companies, said it was ''obvious that the two governments have satisfied their financial objectives. Now let's see what's left over to the producer.'' **********The agreement, signed in Ottawa by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Alberta's premier, Peter Lougheed, will provide an estimated $54.3 billion (in Canadian currency) in revenues for Ottawa, $64.3 billion for Alberta and $94.2 billion for the oil industry between now and the end of 1986, when the agreement expires. It became effective immediately. **********Alex Squires, energy analyst for Pitfield Mackay Ross Ltd., a Toronto investment firm, said that a provision in the agreement for a two-tier price structure would have widely different revenue effects on companies that were current producers and those that discovered oil in the future. **********In a system comparable to that in the United States before oil deregulation, the price of currently produced ''old oil'' - that is, oil discovered before last Jan.1 - will rise to 75 percent of the world price by mid-1986, while the price of ''new oil'' - from new fields, oil sands and the Arctic frontier - will rise to the world price. The current before-tax domestic price of Ca nadian crude oil is about $17.76 for a 42-gallon barrel, a bit mo re than half the weighted average international price of $34.1 3 a barrel. **********Yesterday, the oil and gas index on the Toronto Stock Exchange rose 140 points - almost 3 percent - to 4,937.5 in anticipation of the Trudeau-Lougheed announcement, which was made shortly after the market closed. The index fell 9 points today. **********Mr. Squires said that the 75 percent figure, which would affect mostly the major integrated companies that were largely foreign controlled, ''seems inadequate. It will likely result in a decline in cash flow from old oil.'' However, the newer companies, and the established concerns that find oil in future, stand to benefit from the full world price. **********Two Alberta oil sands plants, the A lsands consortium led by Shell Canada of Tor onto and the Cold Creek project, led by Imperial Oil Ltd. of Toron to, have been stalled by the 16-month dispute. **********The projects, each valued at about $12 billion, are now likely to go ahead, Mr. Squires said, and the world price for their production will benefit the companies in the consortiums. He noted, however, that the projects would not be completed until the late 1980's. **********Speaking of the agreement's effect on the economy as a whole, Mr.  Rogers, of the Toronto Dominion Bank, said the agreement ''will improve the general business and political atmosphere, which has been soured by the dispute. Strength for Dollar **********He expressed hope that the Canadian dollar will continue to strengthen. It closed on the foreign exchange market today at 83.58 cents in United States currency, up from 83.13 cents yesterday and a 50-year low of 80.43 cents on Aug. 4. **********Roy A. Phillips, president of the Canadian Manufacturers' Association, cautioned that ''this agreement will be meaningful only if the energy industry is provided with adequate returns. Otherwise there will not be enough exploration, development and production in Canada to reduce, or even maintain at current levels, our dependency on imports.'' **********One company with no reservations about the agreement was Suncor Inc., a Toronto subsidiary of the Sun Company, of Radnor, Pa. Last autumn, Ottawa withdrew Suncor's right to charge the world price for oil from its Alberta oil sands plant, but that price method was estored as part of yesterday's agreement. **********Ross Hennigar, president and chief executive officer, said the decision ''will move the plant from a marginal operation to one with a strong future.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/19/busin.body_text: **********Lags in reporting changes in how small businesses are coping with high interest rates have some analysts worried that official Government employment statistics may be overstated. **********No one, apparently, can estimate small businesses' ability to create new jobs. **********A variety of studies lead Gregory Kipnis, chief economist at ACLI International, a commodity service firm, to conclude that businesses with less than 100 employees have accounted for between 70 and 80 percent of total employment growth in the past decade. That figure was embraced by Treasury Secretary Donald Regan in a televised press interview last weekend. **********In spite of its seemingly important economic role, small business remains outside the Bureau of Labor Statistics sample that is used for estimating total non-farm employment. As a consequence, the B.L.S. adjusts its employment figures to account for changes in small business formations. **********Currently, Mr. Kipnis estimates the B.L.S. adds nearly 130,000 jobs to its employment numbers each month to account for small business expansion. ''Over the life of the business cycle, the adjustment is probably accurate,'' Mr. Kipnis said. ''However, during cyclical downturns, especially ones which affect small business, the fine tuning could distort the true picture.'' **********Mr. Kipnis added that during the 1970's, downturns in the nonfarm employment index lagged changes in the Commerce Department's new business formation index, one of the best sources of data on the small business sector, by about a year. However, since mid-1979 the gap between the two indexes has been widening. And, with new business formations declining each month since December, Mr. Kipnis estimates the B.L.S. may have overstated nonfarm employment by as many as 500,000 jobs through April.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.main_headline: RESURGENCE OF SWEATSHOPS REPORTED IN NEW YORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.print_headline: RESURGENCE OF SWEATSHOPS REPORTED IN NEW YORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.body_text: **********violations (page D11) By SANDRA SALMANS **********Concealed behind painted-over storefronts and crowded into shuttered lofts and cellars, sweatshops are reappearing in garment manufacturing in the New York area, Government investigators and union officials say. **********According to these investigators, the sweatshops are spreading from Chinatown, where they took root long ago, to Washington Heights, Inwood and the South Bronx, and extending into Queens, Brooklyn and even Staten Island. Sweatshops have also been found in northern New Jersey and parts of Westchester. **********''It's exploding,'' said Herbert Rickman, special assistant to Mayor Koch.  While sweatshop conditions vary, there is a grim sameness to the basic appearance: rows of women bent over sewing machines, separated by narrow aisles often made impassable by dress racks and piles of piece goods. Fire exits and windows, too, are often blocked or even padlocked, reducing emergency escapes to a rickety freight elevator and unlit stairs. For 30 employees, there may be only a handful of time cards - with stamped times that bear little resemblance to the actual hours worked. **********Even the most reputable garment factories tend to be crowded and cluttered by modern standards. Sweatshops, however, may fail to comply with minimum wage and hour laws, child labor regulations and fire and safety codes laws. 50,000 Workers Estimated **********Precisely how many sweatshops and sweatshop workers there are in New York is impossible to determine. In a report to be released today, State Senator Franz Leichter, who represents an upper Manhattan district where many sweatshops have recently sprung up, estimates that some 50,000 people are employed in as many as 3,000 sweatshops in the apparel trade. Ten years ago, according to Senator Leichter, there were only 200 sweatshops in the city, half of them in Chinatown. The industry's official estimate of total employment in New York is less than 200,000, but no one dismisses the sweatshop figure as improbably high. **********The resurgence comes nearly 70 years after the fire at the Triangle Shirtwaist factory, where 146 garment workers died. The notorious episode is invariably invoked by government officials in discussing the situation today. **********Increasingly, the workers are illegal aliens - from Hong Kong, South Korea, the Dominican Republic, Haiti or Latin America. Lacking work permits and sufficient knowledge of English, they are easy targets for exploitation. The flow of immigrants from these areas is generally cited as a main factor in the revival of sweatshops, which were believed to have declined sharply in the city following reformist legislation and union activity in the 1930's and 40's. **********As Herman Starobin, research director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, noted, ''There's a growing garment-producing operation in the midst of a completely different culture.'' **********Government, union and industry officials cite several reasons for the growth of the sweatshops: **********- Budgetary cutbacks have compelled government departments to reduce the number of inspectors and deploy them in top-priority sectors, which do not include garment manufacturing. **********- The large inflow of immigrants, both legal and illegal, has created a sizable and trained pool of workers who are easily exploited. **********- Indifferent or ineffectual officials in government and the I.L.G.W.U., the main union responsible for organizing garment factories in the New York area, are cited by some garment manufacturers as contributing to the problem. Many Chinatown factories are unionized but are often found in violation of city building and fire codes. **********- The contracting system, in which apparel companies parcel out the production of garments to small, highly competitive contractors and subcontractors, is said to encourage the companies to put a squeeze on wages while obviating any sense of responsibility. **********In theory, a number of government departments are responsible for policing the apparel trade and imposing criminal and civil penalties. But, apart from some much-publicized periodic raids - the most recent of which occurred some 18 months ago in Chinatown - inspection and policing have been sharply curtailed as a result of budgetary cutbacks, officials say. When inspections are carried out, they are often handicapped by a lack of interpreters, especially in questioning new immigrants from South Korea or South Vietnam. Number of Inspectors Cut **********For the five boroughs, the buildings department has only 69 inspectors to examine construction, issue violations and pursue recalcitrant owners. The fire department has only 150 inspectors, down by 100 from several years ago. Instead of annual inspections, ''we might hit between 10 and 15 percent of the buildings each year,'' said Paul Kotch, the department's inspector-general. Payoffs of inspectors by contractors, Mr. Kotch acknowledged, were an additional problem. **********While the city's authority covers only building and fire codes, the United States Labor Department is supposed to inspect for machine safety, minimum-wage and overtime payments, and the employment of minors. But since the Chinatown raids in 1979, the department has turned its attention to higher-priority industries. **********''We don't normally make inspections unless we get complaints,'' said Nicholas DiArchangel, deputy regional administrator in New York for the Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration. He added: ''Very few complaints come from sweatshops. They don't speak English, and they're afraid.'' **********While garment manufacturing is admittedly not a high-risk trade, OSHA inspectors are supposed to insure that sewing machines have needle guards to protect seamstresses' hands. But in sweatshops, where workers tend to be paid by piecework and productivity is the foremost concern, the workers themselves resist using guards, saying the guards slow them down, Mr. DiArchangel said. **********''If I tried to enforce it, I'd be doing someone out of a livelihood,'' he added. ''Do you get punctures - which can become infected - or do you feed your children? It's that basic.'' **********Paying for piecework, the norm in garment sweatshops, is not illegal as long as workers receive at least the minimum wage of $3.35 an hour. ''But in most cases, people can't possibly make the number of pieces to come anywhere near the minimum wage,'' said Frank Mercurio, regional director of the Labor Department's Employment Standards Administration. **********Mr. Mercurio's department has found sweatshops where workers were averaging $1.50 an hour for a 50-hour week. To show a 40-hour week on their records, inspectors say, employers often punch time cards in and out dutifully as workers remain at their machines, not collecting overtime for extra hours. **********To raise their income, inspectors say, garment workers increasingly take work home. The practice, largely banned by state and Federal law, removes workers from public scrutiny and makes law enforcement difficult. **********It is widely agreed that sweatshop workers are easy to exploit because many are recent immigrants, lacking adequate English, fearful of government and accustomed to substandard wages and working conditions. If they are here illegally, they are even more vulnerable to abuse by employers. **********''Undocumented workers are afraid,'' Mr. Starobin said. ''That fear allows employers not to pay Social Security or withholding tax, and to fight efforts to unionize. If the workers protest, he threatens to tell the Department of Immigration about them. Legally, they're unpersons. The less documentation they have, the more serious the violations are apt to be.'' Union Cited as Part of Problem **********Some manufacturers suggest that the I.L.G.W.U., as a result of ineffectual leadership, is partly to blame for the resurgence of sweatshops. **********''Why blame someone who gives work to people?'' said Myron Norris, owner of Givenchy for Little Tantrums, which makes children's apparel under license from the designer. The company uses a contractor in Chinatown. ''Why not blame the Mayor, or the union for not enforcing the contract?'' **********Union officials insist that they are working harder than ever to organize garment workers, including illegal aliens. Of the 110,000 I.L.G.W.U. members in the New York area, as many as 30 percent are estimated to be illegal immigrants. **********The Seventh Avenue manufacturers are the guilty ones, says Frederick Siems, I.L.G.W.U. executive vice president. ''The name of the game is price,'' he said. ''Sweatshop operators bid on garments, and the one who is most desperate gets the work. These manufacturers know what's happening.'' **********In the view of Mr. Siems and others, contracting, the traditional method of garment manufacturing, is fundamental to the perpetuation of the sweatshop. Typically, apparel manufacturers send their cut or piece goods to contractors to be sewn; the contractors, in turn, may subcontract the work. **********The system encourages fly-by-night operators who, in a seasonal industry, manufacture for a few months, pocket their profits and close. ''It isn't difficult to find a loft where you can put 30 or 60 machines, and you're in business,'' Mr. Mercurio said. ''It's a fastbuck operation. It's just like a pusher - the police kick him off one corner, but in a week he resurfaces on another.'' 'We Can't Police Him' **********Contracting also removes the manufacturer from direct responsibility for the treatment of workers. ''When we give a contractor an order, we can't police him,'' said Mr. Norris of Little Tantrums. Mr. Norris has a representative visit his Chinatown contractor daily to inspect the garments' quality but not wages or working conditions. ''If they're breaking the law,'' he said of his contractors, ''the city should close them down.'' **********Government representatives also charge that the truckers, who convey piece goods from the manufacturer to the contractors, help support sweatshops by charging excessively high rates for shipping the goods. And it is virtually impossible for contractors to switch to another trucking concern because of the influence of organized crime, according to Senator Leichter. **********To clamp down on sweatshops, Senator Leichter this week is offering legislation that would compel contractors to register with the state. Under the measure, the state would be able to confiscate goods found in sweatshops - a practice that would adversely affect manufacturers who own the goods. **********''The manufacturers may become our policemen,'' said James Quillin, Labor Commissioner of California, where a similar law is scheduled to go into effect this July. **********Most New York manufacturers oppose the measure. ''All the laws that we need are already on the books,'' said Kurt Barnard, executive director of the Federation of Apparel Manufacturers. ''They should be enforced.'' **********Other measures cited as means of stopping sweatshops include making it a crime knowingly to employ illegal aliens, and granting amnesty - and legalization of their status - to illegal immigrants already working here. **********The outlook for any legislation is uncertain, however. A similar bill proposed by Senator Leichter failed to pass last year, and laws concerning immigrants require Federal action. **********Some manufacturers and government representatives tend to be blase about the need for such laws. As one manufacturer noted, ''Why should we object to employing people in sweatshops here when we're willing to import garments from sweatshops in Hong Kong and other countries?'' **********But Mr. DiArchangel rejects that. ''Legal or not,'' he said of the workers, ''they're here and they're working and we should be protecting them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/busin.body_text: **********A CRYPTOGRAPHIC system that keeps unauthorized persons from entering offices, plants and hotels was patented this week by a staff mathematician for the International Business Machines Corporation. **********Roy L. Adler of the I.B.M. Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., was granted patent 4,255,811 for the encryption method, which is employed in I.B.M.'s widely used Controlled Access System. **********The lock is operated by a plastic card that contains a strip of magnetic material. The pattern of magnetized spots in the strip serves as a ''key.'' The magnetic code on each card contains two numbers. One is the number of the card and the other is called a password. An automatic card reader at a door transmits the numbers to a small computer, which deciphers and adds them together. If the total equals a fixed number stored in the computer, the door opens. **********According to an I.B.M. spokesman, a much smaller computer is needed than would be required if each card contained the name or identifying number of the person to whom it was issued.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/world.main_headline: Around the World; Unemployment Rate Rises To 11.1% in Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/world.print_headline: Around the World; Unemployment Rate Rises To 11.1% in Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/world.body_text: **********British unemployment rose to a 50-year high of 2,680,977 in June, or 11.1 percent of the work force, the government announced today. The figure was double the jobless total when Conservative Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took office in May 1979. **********Employment Secretary James Prior said a figure of three million jobless was possible by the end of the year. Mrs. Thatcher would not confirm the forecast, but told the House of Commons that the June figures were ''deplorable.'' She went on, ''Inevitably, unemployment will rise during the coming months.'' **********Mrs. Thatcher said the Department of Employment figures showed a slowdown in the underlying unemployment rate, but drew jeers from Labor Party member when she said much of the problem was caused by teen-agers leaving school at a time when few people were reaching retirement age. **********''It is necessary to get rid of over-manning if industry is to be competitive,'' she said in Parliament. ''The irony is that it does give rise to unemployment in the early stages. Nevertheless it has to be done if we are to have any hope of expanding business in the long term.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/busin.main_headline: HE MAKES SURE THE SHOW IS ON
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/busin.print_headline: HE MAKES SURE THE SHOW IS ON
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/busin.body_text: **********''I 'M the longest act on Broadway,'' Robert A. Boyar said somewhat immodestly the other day, ''in my 33d year as an insurance broker to the bright lights and to the stars.'' Since 1948, in fact, Mr. Boyar, who is 56, has made the slogan ''the show must go on'' a reality - more so than any producer, director, writer or even a star - as he busily arranges insurance (for all risks) for half the shows on Broadway, some productions elsewhere, plus a certain number of actors and actresses as well. **********In his small offices at 217 Broadway in lower Manhattan, Mr. Boyar wheels and deals with the top names in show business, mostly by phone, although ''sometimes I make house calls.'' It is often a 7 A.M. to 10 P.M. day for him -somewhat less for his wife Margery, his administrative aide, and his staff of 12. **********Mr. Boyar, who maintains that no other broker specializes to the extent he does in theatrical insurance, handled about $5 million in premiums last year, on which his agency received commissions of about 10 percent. He shares no risks with the underwriters, usually in his case the Chubb insurance group. **********His clients have included Liza Minnelli, Tom Conti, Henry Fonda, Rex Harrison, Bob Fosse, Sandy Duncan and Claudette Colbert, among others. Top shows he has known include ''Grease,'' ''Gemini,'' ''Peter Pan,'' ''Death Trap,'' ''Dancin','' ''Sophisticated Ladies'' and ''The Little Foxes.'' For Foxes, Mr. Boyar arranged coverage by Lloyd's of London, which will be shelling out about $200,000 to the producers because Elizabeth Taylor missed eight performances recently. **********Basically Mr. Boyar insures against business interruption, the sort of things that happened when Henry Fonda had a heart attack in the middle of the run of ''Darrow,'' Bette Davis's nerves overcame her during rehearsals for ''Miss Moffat,'' George C. Scott contracted the flu during ''Sly Fox'' and had to drop out and Gertrude Lawrence died while starring in ''The King and I.'' All were covered by theatrical insurance. Mr. Boyar said Zero Mostel was not insured when he died unexpectedly after one preview performance of ''The Merchant.'') **********Since cost of policies can sometimes deter prospects, Mr. Boyar often recommends a one- or two-performance deductible. This discourages the tempermental star from goofing off for a couple of days. **********In the last years, Mr. Boyar has gone beyond simple business interruption, designing a new, all-risk policy for theatrical productions with Chubb. This policy covers property and scenery against theft and damage, as well as the personal possessions of actors and production staffs and wardrobe. (The policy includes the extra-expense coverage that guards against business interruption.) **********''Scenery for a musical, any musical is elaborate, all custommade,'' he said. ''You can't just go back to the store and repurchase it. And the electronic control boards, which most shows rent today, are worth in excess of $100,000 alone.'' **********To illustrate his all-risks theme, Mr. Boyar referred to the recent revival of ''Brigadoon'' in Washington, where it was at the National Theater prior to its New York run. Cracks developed in the theater's walls, and the producers wanted to know if their policy covered structural damages including alterations. The answer was no. The cracks proved not to be dangerous and the show did go on, but Mr.  Boyar's new all-risk policy takes care of this. **********''For the first nine years of my career, I was associated with another broker,'' Mr. Boyar said. ''But I soon found out that I could best work alone in this very specialized, very personalized aspect of the insurance business.'' **********''Actually there are just three or four cities in North America, where my type of insurance is a practicality - is in real demand - and they are New York, Los Angeles, Toronto and, sometimes, Chicago,'' he said. ''And we can go anywhere,'' explaining that ''Turn to the Right'' a show at the Westwood Playhouse in Los Angeles, was recently insured by him, as were West Coast productions of ''Camelot.'' He also insures the St. Nicholas Theater in Chicago on a regular basis. **********While Chubb is his major partner in the game, it is Lloyd's of London, he said, that comes into play when other carriers balk.  ''This is usually the case with actors or actresses who have a history of illness or other problems,'' he said. **********The payoff can come in handy indeed. The Elizabeth Taylor policy for $2 million - a record for a single actor or actress in a play - cost her producers a premium of $105,000 for seven months, well covered by the $200,000 award. (''It was a very fair settlement,'' said a spokesman for Foxes producer Zev Bufman.) When Liza Minnelli developed the flu on Broadway several years ago, her producers got $270,000 on a premium of $10,000. **********The ANTA, Eugene O'Neill and the Theater De Lys are all insured by Mr. Boyar for all risks, he said, adding that he had also represented cable television and film productions as well. **********''M Y business is in the performing arts, but 90 percent of it is in the theater,'' he said. ''We do go after business, but for the most part the producers come to us.'' **********Although the $2 million figure on Miss Taylor is the highest sum insured for any individual stage actor or actress, larger sums are written for shows and various performances, particularly musicals, and they are usually notated on a per-performance-lost basis, around $25,000 a performance for ''The Little Foxes.'' Other coverage has been $800,000 for theatrical property and $350,000 in extra expenses for ''Peter Pan,'' $900,000 and $350,000, respectively, for ''Camelot'' and $860,000 and $300,000 for ''My Fair Lady.'' **********What do premiums cost? Mr. Boyar calculates that a premium for a conventional drama might run between $4,000 and $10,000 a year, and for something like the fast-moving ''Dancin' '' about $800 a week.  Coverage for stars can be as little as $2,500, but Rex Harrison's premium in the upcoming revival of ''My Fair Lady'' will be $100,000 a year. **********Mr. Boyar's father was the late Ben A. Boyar, theatrical manager for Max Gordon, who produced many famous Broadway shows in the 20's, 30's and 40's. When Ben Boyar turned to his son, who loved the wandering theatrical life, too, and advised him to go into a legitimate business, Robert Boyar chose theatrical insurance. **********''Very early on we offered financial protection for shows' loss and damage as they traveled from point to point in the country,'' Mr.  Boyar said. ''We then developed our business-interruption policy and then our all-risk policy, and they work like a charm.'' **********A favorite story of Mr. Boyar's concerns a road show leaving Los Angeles, when suddenly the truck in which sets and drops were being moved caught fire. ''They were totally destroyed, but a $160,000 claim was paid. This meant that show was indeed able to go on.  Without the insurance, the troupe would not have been able to make it back to New York.'' **********Perhaps the most unusual theater insurance story Mr. Boyar has to tell is that of Algernon, a trained theater mouse who was scheduled to open last fall in a Broadway musical. He was asked to quote on providing coverage on an understudy mouse since the theater company felt it wouldn't have time in which to train more than two mice. **********Taking matters seriously, Mr. Boyar went straight to his broker at Lloyd's, got the quote and went back to the producers with a $12,500 per performance lost policy. After guffaws from both sides of the Atlantic, the producers decided to simply train more mice as understudies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/busin.main_headline: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2.9 BILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/busin.print_headline: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2.9 BILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve announced yesterday afternoon that the nation's basic money supply dropped by $2.9 billion in the week ended June 3.  The decline was larger than analysts had expected and set off a sharp drop in interest rates. **********''I think we are very near a point where the Fed can relax its policy and let short-term interest rates drop by perhaps a few percentage points over the next two weeks,'' said Al Gross, an economist at Refco Partners, which trades in Government securities. **********He said that ''the Fed's willingness to keep rates very high for an extended period - about six weeks now - means that the economy should continue to weaken, and slow money growth will continue as the public's demand for money continues weak.'' **********Treasury bill rates fell more than three-eighths of a percentage point in late trading, with three- and six-month issues quoted at 14.12 percent and 13.62 percent, respectively. Long-term bond yields also fell. The bellwether 13 7/8 percent Treasury issue due in 2011 was offered at 109 15/32 to yield 12.62 percent, up more than 1 1/2 points, or $15 per bond, in less than an hour. M-1B at $424.6 Billion **********The closely watched M-1B measure of money supply, consisting of currency plus interest- and noninterest-bearing demand deposits at banks and savings institutions, declined $2.9 billion in the week, to $424.6 billion. Combined with a drop during May of $1.8 billion, the basic M-1B measure has declined at an annual rate of 8.2 percent over the latest reporting month, although it has grown at an annual rate of 6.8 percent over the latest statistical quarter. The Federal Reserve's maximum 1981 growth target for this key measure of money is 8.5 percent. **********The drop in money supply during May and early June came after rapid growth during April, when M-1B expanded by $6.6 billion, to an average of $429.5 billion. That rapid growth had caused the Fed to make bank reserves scarcer and pushed up interest rates so that three-month Treasury bills traded with rates as high as 17 percent in the first half of May. **********Securities traders reasoned that the money supply decline in recent weeks hastened the day when the Fed will encourage, or at least allow, interest rates to decline. An extended period of slow money supply growth means that banks need fewer reserves on deposit and therefore do not have as much need to borrow at high interest rates to obtain the reserves necessary to satisfy Fed requirements. **********According to monetary policy makers, the Fed is paying closer attention to M-1B after subtracting deposits that have been shifted from savings accounts. By that measure, money supply growth has been slower than the total M-1B number would indicate. **********The latest Fed data for May show that M-1B included about $9 billion of money once held in savings accounts, so that the adjusted level for M-1B was only $418.7 billion for May. That level is $500 million less than the $419.2 billion that would be consistent with the Fed's 5 1/2 percent annual growth rate target for the Marchthrough-June period. **********Fed officials are on record as saying they will pay closer attention to growth of M-2, a broader money supply measure. M-2, consisting of M-1B plus some short-term bank borrowings in the domestic and Eurodollar markets, money market mutual funds and savings deposits, averaged $1,741.7 billion in May, below the $1,746.9 billion level that would be consistent with the Fed's March-June growth target of 10 1/2 percent. **********Despite the Fed's stated intention of emphasizing M-2, many analysts have doubts about such a policy. Charles Lieberman, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, asked: ''Why should they emphasize a monetary aggregate over which they have little control?'' **********Along with many other analysts, Mr. Lieberman said that growth of money market mututal funds, which the Fed said totaled $118.4 billion on June 3, was ''largely outside the control of the Fed.'' In fact, analysts explain that when the Fed tries to reduce money supply growth by making bank reserves scarcer, the resulting high interest rates actually tend to increase growth of the money market funds. **********Other data published weekly by the Fed showed that the central bank was continuing to prevent expansion of banks' reserves. Reserves are the building blocks for future money supply growth, so slow or negative reserve growth now is another reason for expecting modest money growth in the future. **********Nonborrowed reserves declined $693 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $37.76 billion, and have contracted at an annual rate of 5.5 percent over the latest quarter. The Fed kept reserves scarce enough so that banks and others were forced to borrow an average of $2.2 billion at the discount window in the week to Wednesday. **********While slow growth and declines in monetary aggregates seem to point toward lower rates soon, Fed data showed that business credit demands continued robust. That worries some analysts, who say that a significant rate decline is not likely as long as credit demands are strong. **********Fed data showed that business loans extended by banks rose $1.17 billion in the week ended June 3, while nonfinancial companies raised an additional $1.29 billion of credit in the commercial paper market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/17/busin.body_text: **********Poland indicated it cannot meet a pledge to pay $500 million by year-end in overdue interest owed to foreign banks. American bankers said Poland has asked a number of lending institutions for an additional $350 million so that the past-due interest payment could be met. But bankers around the world indicated no further loans would be made until the $500 million is paid. (Page A1.) **********The Polish economy needs at least $12 billion in Western aid next year, just to keep its economic crisis from getting worse, according to a strongly pessimistic report issued by one of France's three big state-owned banks. A permanent cure, the report found, is likely to require far greater assistance from the West. (D14.) **********Japan and China signed a $1.38 billion agreement covering Japanese financial aid to major Chinese industrial projects. (D1.) **********The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act is an export disincentive, says Bill Brock, the United States trade representative. Testifying before a House commerce subcommittee, he declared that it was ''urgent and necessary'' to make changes in the law. (D13.) **********Worsening trade conflicts could have ''poisonous effects'' on United States relations with Europe and on Atlantic security, said Robert D. Hormats, a State Department economics official. (D9.) The Economy **********Industrial production fell 2.1 percent in November, the Government reported, as the 1981 recession widened. The monthly decline in industrial production, which accounts for about a third of the economy's output, was the largest since the 1980 recession. The new figures indicated that the decline in the gross national product this quarter could be as much as 7 percent. (D1.) **********Housing starts rose a slight eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, the first gain since July for the depressed industry, the Government reported. But permits for future building dropped again. (D8.) **********Natural gas prices are rising much faster than had been contemplated under the partial decontrol law of 1978, mainly because producers are adapting their operations to gain maximum revenue.  Their moves to reclassify gas in higher-priced categories, as defined by the legislation, may cost consumers $4 billion next year. (D1.) Companies **********Ford will sell up to 5,000 propane-powered cars next year to take advantage of propane's lower cost. This will be the first time a major American auto maker has offered a propane-powered car. (D1.) **********Levi Strauss will sell its clothes to J.C. Penney, marking the first time the line will be carried by a mass merchandiser. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.main_headline: BONN ALSO IN AUTO PACT WITH JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.print_headline: BONN ALSO IN AUTO PACT WITH JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.body_text: **********Japan and West Germany have reached an agreement to limit the growth of Japanese automobile exports to Germany to 10 percent annually. The accord was announced here today by the Bonn Government at the beginning of talks between Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan. **********Mr. Suzuki is on a 13-day tour of six Western European countries, the focus of which is expected to be the growing economic friction generated by Japan's mounting exports, particularly to the Common Market. **********According to a German spokesman, Kurt Becker, the auto import agreement was reached by Bonn's Economics Minister, Count Otto Lambsdorff, who is in Tokyo this week seeking a relaxation of Japan's import restrictions and assurances of Japanese export restraint. Move to Defuse Tensions **********The agreement is apparently an attempt to deflect some of the trade tensions during the Schmidt-Suzuki talks. Mr. Suzuki has repeatedly expressed his intention to concentrate on wider political issues, leaving trade policy to his Minister for Trade, Rokusuke Tanaka, who visits Europe next week. **********West German leaders have sought to gain Japanese concessions to stem a wave of strong protectionist feeling in Europe that they fear could lead to a wider trade dispute. **********The Europeans were clearly upset by agreements, reached last month between Japan and the United States and Japan and Canada, to limit Japanese car exports to those countries. The Tokyo-Washington agreement, for example, will bring exports of Japanese cars to the United States down to 1.68 million units a year from 1.82 million last year, and limit the growth in these exports to the growth in the American market over the next two years. **********Europeans fear that those agreements may deflect shipments of Japanese autos to Europe, where a severe economic recession has already led to widespread unemployment and shorter working hours in key sectors like the auto industry. Rise in Sales to Germany **********Several countries, including France, Britain and Italy, have limits on Japanese auto imports, but countries with open borders, like West Germany and Belgium, have been hit hard. Imports of Japanese cars to Germany jumped to 250,000 last year, lifting Japan's share of the German market to 10.4 percent from 5.6 percent in 1979. **********Mr. Suzuki will also visit Rome, Brussels, the Hague, London and Paris for talks with Government and Common Market officials.  Economic issues ranging from the thorny question of trade to the extent of damage that high American interest rates are causing the economies of Europe and Japan will head the list of topics Mr. Suzuki will discuss. **********Though less troubled by automobile imports, countries like Britain and the Netherlands are feeling the effect of mounting imports of Japanese electronic equipment and machine tools, and Italy has complained of increased shipments of motorcycles, steel and machinery.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/world.main_headline: A SOWETO WOMAN REGAINS HER POLITICAL VOICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/world.print_headline: A SOWETO WOMAN REGAINS HER POLITICAL VOICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/24/world.body_text: **********Albertina Sisulu has just recovered her voice. Her problem was not medical but political, in the form of what are known in South Africa as banning orders. **********Banning orders make it a crime for their recipients to speak at any kind of gathering - usually even of three persons - or ever to be quoted in print. **********Mrs. Sisulu's banning orders lasted for 17 years, and were coupled with severe restrictions on her movements, even within this black township outside Johannesburg. Now she would like to tell her husband and the youngest of her three sons that she is able to speak out again on political issues, but they are in jail. **********Her husband is Walter Sisulu, a former secretary general of the outlawed African National Congress, who has been serving a life sentence on Robben Island, off Cape Town, since 1964. The two were married 37 years ago. Mrs. Sisulu, a nurse at a government clinic here, calculates that she and her husband, who will be 70 years old next year, have had a total of perhaps four or five years of normal family life. No Chance for Home Life **********Even before his last arrest, when he was not in jail or in hiding, her husband was usually on trial or under various forms of restrictions that interfered with his home life as well as his political activities. **********Her youngest son, Zwelakhe, has been detained for more than two months under the Terrorism Act, which relieves the authorities of any responsibility to draw up charges against him, allow him access to a lawyer or a relative, or even to disclose where he is being held. **********Mrs. Sisulu and her daughter-in-law, Zodwa, with whom she lives, have been making regular deliveries of clothing for Zwelakhe to the local headquarters of the security police. The fact that these were accepted was a kind of encouragement, until the other day when all the clothes were returned to her home without explanation. **********Five months before his arrest, Zwelakhe Sisulu, who is 31 years old, received a severe banning order that forced him to give up his job as a news editor on a black newspaper as well as his position as the outspoken leader of a union of black journalists called the Media Workers Association of South Africa. The paper for which he worked was then banned too. Awkward Situation Created **********South African law makes it a crime for two banned persons to meet or speak. This was awkward since mother and son were living in the same building, a small four-room brick bungalow that Walter Sisulu first occupied in 1940. **********Despite their banning orders, Mrs. Sisulu and her son went on meeting and speaking. ''I said, 'Nonsense,' '' she recalled, '' 'they must come and arrest us.' '' Instead, a security policeman showed up one day with an officially stamped authorization permitting mother and son to speak. ''We didn't apply for it,'' she said, laughing. **********She last visited Robben Island in January, but she is fairly confident that her husband must know by now about the lifting of her ban. She wrote him, but she cannot be sure that the letter went through uncensored.  As for Zwelakhe, she thinks there is little or no chance that he knows what is happening outside his prison, wherever it is. **********''We know he is going to be inside for a long time,'' she said.  ''We only wish they would tell us where he is.'' 1956 Protest Commemorated **********Despite the risk of provoking a new ban, it was only a week after the expiration of her old one that Mrs. Sisulu made her first political speech in nearly two decades. The occasion was a meeting at a local church to mark the 25th anniversary of a mass protest of black women against the requirement, then being introduced, that they carry passbooks when they were in areas deemed to be ''white.'' **********Mrs. Sisulu had been a leader of the protest that was being commemorated. ''It felt so good to be among people and to speak to the people,'' she said. ''I spoke about the role of women. I said their work is to fight side-by-side with their men until freedom is won.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/15/world.main_headline: BRITAIN ANNOUNCES TOUGHER MEASURES TO COMBAT RIOTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/15/world.print_headline: BRITAIN ANNOUNCES TOUGHER MEASURES TO COMBAT RIOTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/15/world.body_text: **********In a toughening counteroffensive against rioters, the British Government has decided to permit the country's traditionally unarmed police to use plastic bullets, armored vehicles and water cannon to quell disorders. **********At the same time, the Home Ministry was considering the use of army camps as detention centers for those convicted of crimes stemming from the 12 days of riots. Several hundred of the thousands of people arrested are expected to be sentenced within the next few weeks, adding a new burden to an already overcrowded prison system. **********The new measures were announced late last night by Edward Gardner, a Conservative member of Parliament, after he and other Conservative legislators had met with William Whitelaw, the Home Secretary. **********Need for Aggressive Action **********Mr. Gardner quoted Mr. Whitelaw as having told the group that there ought to be aggressive action to remove people from the streets and that the police ought to move forward offensively. **********The Home Secretary's decisions on weapons and on the use of army camps - and the way that the decisions were disclosed - aggravated the debate between the Government and its Labor Party critics over what the riots signified and what tactics should be used in dealing with them. **********The disorders and the tensions that gripped more than a dozen cities appeared to be easing. There were incidents reported last night in Nottingham, Liverpool, Huddersfield and Aldershot, with the most severe outbreak of violence occurring in Leicester, where the police reported that 15 people were arrested after a group of about 100 youths began throwing stones at policemen. Brickbats To and Fro **********The hurling of ideological brickbats by defenders and critics of the Government's policies was, however, intensifying. Michael Foot, the Labor Party leader, responded to Mr. Whitelaw's decisions by warning against the introduction of panic laws. Another Labor M.P., Clive Soley, deplored the announcement of the new measures through a partisan political group. Mr. Soley also repeated what has become the opposition's prevailing view on the riots when he declared, ''Nobody is going to condone looting and rioting, but we have to understand there are deeper causes which cannot be dealt with simply by a heavy handed clampdown.'' **********Essentially, it is the view of the opposition that the riots reflect social discontent and frustration that have grown as unemployment has increased and as spending on social programs has shrunk in accordance with the Government's anti-inflationary policies. The position of the Government defenders is that the disorders are largely the result of a growing indiscipline of the family and the community. **********In Parliament this afternoon, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher reported that the top law officers in the Cabinet were conducting an urgent review of laws and procedures affecting riot control. She said that plastic bullets would be made available to police in the current emergency. Mrs. Thatcher said that other details would be formally outlined in what she described as a major speech that the Home Secretary would make on Thursday when debate on the riots is scheduled in the House of Commons. **********Meanwhile, representatives of the 43 police commands in England and Wales are to meet here tomorrow to discuss antiriot tactics and possible new equipment and strategy. Until now, the police have been unobtrusive and have avoided confrontations and sweeps that might incite further violence. At the moment, police officials are considering the use of so-called ''snatch squads'' whose members, both in uniform and in plain clothes, rush into mobs to arrest suspects. Talks in Belfast **********According to press reports, a delegation of top British police officials was to leave tomorrow for Belfast for discussions with riot control experts in the Royal Ulster Constabulary, which for 12 years has sought to cope with fire bombs and rampaging youths. The visiting police officials will reportedly be shown the group's antiriot arsenal and be briefed on its tactics. **********Among the weapons being considered for use are water cannon, which project high pressure sprays to dispel crowds. Such equipment, which has been used effectively in France, was tested in Ulster but was found ineffective for conditions there. Plastic bullets, which like tear gas can now be employed at the discretion of police commanders, are nonlethal ammunition used in many parts of the world to scatter mobs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/world.main_headline: FROM NEW DELHI TO IOWA, INDIGNATION AND PRAYERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/world.print_headline: FROM NEW DELHI TO IOWA, INDIGNATION AND PRAYERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/world.body_text: **********Around the world, political and religious leaders and ordinary people continued yesterday to pray for a speedy recovery for Pope John Paul II and express concern about the attempt on his life. **********In Bonn, the West German Parliament paused for a moment of silence on behalf of the Pope. In Moscow, Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, said he was ''profoundly indignant'' over the assassination attempt. In New Delhi, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said she was ''too shocked for words.'' **********In a message to the Pope from Beirut, Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said he deplored ''this abominable, criminal attempt on your precious life.'' **********Bulent Ulusu, the Turkish Prime Minister, said he condemned ''this terrible act with all my heart,'' but made no comment about Mehmet Ali Agca, the 23-year-old Turk being held as a suspect by the police in Rome. Sadat Calls Suspect an Infidel **********President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt called Mr. Agca an infidel ''who could not possibly belong to Islam.'' Early yesterday afternoon in Manhattan, diplomats from dozens of countries gathered to pray for the Pope in a special mass at the Roman Catholic chapel that serves the United Nations. In the evening, a dozen Harlem ministers held a candlelight service in the open-air pavilion at the Harlem State Office Building at 125th Street and Seventh Avenue. **********Across the nation, churches were crowded with people responding to the attack in Rome, and in many schools children were making get-well cards for the Pope. **********Nearly the entire congregration turned out at St. Patrick's Church in the tiny Iowa farm town of Cumming, which John Paul visited when he was in the United States in 1979. 'A More Personal Feeling' **********''The Pope, to these people, isn't just somebody they've seen on TV,'' said the Rev. John Richter, who celebrated the mass for the Pope in the 113-year-old white frame church. **********''He's somebody you've met,'' Father Richter continued. ''It gives you a more personal feeling.'' John Connor, who farms just across the street from the Cumming church, said of the service: ''There were lots of special words.  He's more than just our Holy Father. He walked with us and visited with us.'' **********In Poland, the Pope's native country, hundreds of thousands filed into churches to pray not only for John Paul, but for the Polish primate, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, who is 79 years old and gravely ill. Theaters Close in Poland **********The crowd at St. John's Cathedral in Warsaw's old section overflowed into the cobbled streets for a block on both sides of the entrance. Many worshipers wept. Those outside the church knelt in the street. **********All the cinemas, theaters, nightclubs and cabarets in Poland were closed. State radio and television had subdued programming and gave extensive coverage to the details of the assassination attempt. **********At the United Nations service at the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church on East 47th Street, Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said: ''We were all deeply moved by this tragedy. At the United Nations it is our duty to do all we can to combat this kind of violence.'' **********Asked what could be done, Mr. Waldheim said, ''Pray for a speedy recovery.'' 'The Turks Are Doubly Shocked' **********Sitting in the last pew was Altemur Kilic, deputy representative of Turkey at the United Nations. ''The Turks are doubly shocked,'' he said. ''We don't consider the man who shot the Holy Father a Turk.  He is a demented lunatic. Yes, he is a citizen but we don't consider him a Turk.'' **********Communists and capitalists, Buddhists and Jews, ambassadors and maintenance workers, came from the nearby United Nations building to fill the church. **********Many privately expressed dismay and anger at the prevalence of such violence in their countries. But Archbishop Giovanni Cheli, the personal representative of the Pope at the United Nations, told the congregation that the shooting was another ''episode in the old battle between hate and love'' and that to show hatred for the man who shot the Pope would be unfaithul to the Pope's teachings. **********''Let us lift our hearts in praise of God that the Pope continues with us in this struggle of love over evil,'' Archbishop Cheli said. Visit of Pope Paul VI Recalled **********A few in the audience said they remembered when Pope Paul VI came to this church in 1965 to proclaim the United Nations ''the last hope of peace.'' Virtually all remembered warmly the visit of Pope John Paul II to the United Nations, in 1979, as an uplifitng experience that ''reminded us all of why we were here,'' as one in the audience put it. **********During the mass, members of the congregation shook hands with their neighbors and said, ''Peace be with you.'' Afterward, they lingered outside talking of their concern for the Pope.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/19/busin.print_headline: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS; Ted Turner
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/19/busin.body_text: **********Ted Turner, the colorful owner of The Atlanta Braves and Cable News Network, received a setback last week. His Turner Broadcasting System announced withdrawal of a proposal to publicly offer a million new common shares. The company declined to say why it was withdrawing the offer, the proceeds of which would have gone toward retiring company debt. One reason might have been a recent appearance by Mr.  Turner on the ''Phil Donahue Show'' in which he talked about the company - an action that could be construed by the Securities and Exchange Commission as promoting the offering. **********The money supply jumped sharply in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve said. The measure known as M1-B rose $4.8 billion, following a revised increase of $3.3 billion in the previous week.  More credit tightening was forecast. **********Auto sales fell 11.9 percent in the April 1-10 selling period from the comparable period a year ago, the domestic makers reported.  Chrysler posted a 32.8 percent gain and Ford a 4.8 percent rise, but General Motors pulled the industry showing down with a drop of 22.9 percent. **********Retail sales rose by one-tenth of 1 percent in March, the Commerce Department said. It was the 10th monthly increase but much smaller than February's revised gain of 1.6 percent. **********Industrial output gained four-tenths of 1 percent in March, offsetting a like drop in February, the Federal Reserve said. March's rise was attributed to a partial recovery in auto assemblies. **********Housing starts increased 5.8 percent in March, recovering a bit from February's decline of 27 percent. Personal income in March rose by eight-tenths of 1 percent from February. **********A.T.&T. net rose 11.1 percent in the first quarter. General Telephone's nearly doubled. Other corporate results: Philip Morris, up 22.4 percent; United Technologies, up 16.4 percent; Honeywell, up 16.5 percent; Allied Chemical, up 23.5 percent; CBS, up 6.9 percent; Union Pacific, up 23.9 percent; RCA, down 47 percent; Polaroid, down 45 percent; Texas Instruments, down 32 percent; Alcoa down 29 percent. **********American Motors said it lost $52.7 million in the first quarter on sales decline of 24.2 percent. Trans World posted a deficit of $57.5 million. **********BankAmerica operating profits fell 19 percent in the first quarter. Other results from financial institutions: Chase, down 16.6 percent; Manufacturer's Hanover, up 6 percent; Bankers Trust, up 8 percent; Wells Fargo, up 27 percent, and Continental Illinois, up 30 percent. Merrill Lynch said profits rose 31 percent. **********Braniff International's accounting firm reported conditions that would prevent the airline from being able to continue as a going concern. The accountant, Deloitte Haskins & Sells, made the statement in the annual report of the financially troubled carrier. **********Warner Lambert plans to sell an optical subsidiary and a line of disposable hospital dressings, as well as phasing out its American Chicle plant in Long Island City. The moves resulted in a one-time charge of $134.3 million against first-quarter earnings and the company reported an overall loss of $97.5 million. **********Gould will sell its industrial group of 23 plants to the Reading Company for some $380 million. The group being sold makes auto parts and other materials. **********UA-Columbia Cablevision received a bid of $85 a share for up to 725,000 shares from United Artists Theater Circuit. The bid tops a joint offer of $75 a share from Dow Jones and Knight-Ridder. **********Westinghouse settled the last of 17 suits filed against it by electric utilities. The suits arose when Westinghouse canceled contracts for the supply uranium after prices of the fuel rose sharply.
