https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/busin.body_text: **********Grey Advertising, which in the past has produced some extremely dramatic and poignant TV public service messages, has pulled a switch on its latest effort in behalf of the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission, which is committed to doing something about the 36 million product-related injuries and 30,000 deaths that annually cost the American people $9.5 billion. Grey is going to try humor. **********The TV spots are directed at the two major causes of accidents, carelessness and faulty products, and will soon be shipped to the networks and about 690 commercial TV stations. They will be expected to run them free as a public service. But the agency is working under a $400,000 annual contract. **********Yesterday at the agency John Marder, executive vice president and James Graham and Dennis Schmidt, vice presidents, noted the need for good product production values since each public service spot must compete with all the others that flood stations and networks looking for free time. **********Mr. Marder seemed very anxious to make the point that Grey is a lot more than just a packaged goods agency and that it has proved itself over the years as a shop that can also sell ideas and issues. In the last 10 years, he said, Grey has had 10 Government assignements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/11/busin.snippet: WASHINGTON W HEN President Carter sends his final military budget to Congress this week, it will call for spending almost $200 billion in fiscal 1982, up 14.5 percent from the previous year, and will project further increases that will result in s...
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/11/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON W HEN President Carter sends his final military budget to Congress this week, it will call for spending almost $200 billion in fiscal 1982, up 14.5 percent from the previous year, and will project further increases that will result in spending more than $1 trillion in the next five years. **********Then the Republicans, taking office on Jan. 20, will cheerfully promise to add more to those totals. And the Congress, which voted $6 billion more than President Carter asked for last year, is already charged up to do its part in expanding the defense budget. The question, then, is not whether, but by how much, the budget will swell. **********The consequences for the taxpayer and the economy in general will be mixed at best, but for businesses large and small, the prospective increases mean a surge in sales. **********About $55 billion of the Carter budget, up from $45 billion this year, will be allotted to procurement. President-elect Ronald Reagan's nominee to be Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, said during his confirmation hearing last week that shipbuilding would be increased, which is likely to mean more income for the likes of Litton Industries, the Newport News Shipbuilding subsidiary of Tenneco, and Electric Boat of General Dynamics. **********The expanding hardware sales could also mean more F-14 Tomcat fighters from Grumman on Long Island, more Blackhawk helicopters from United Technologies' Sikorsky operations in Connecticut, and more XM-1 Abrams tanks from Chrysler in Ohio. The Republicans have said they want a new long-range bomber to replace the aging B-52's and the B-1 that Mr. Carter killed early in his Presidency. That could mean lucrative contracts for Boeing or the North American division of Rockwell, both on the West Coast. **********There is much more, however, than big benefits to a few large companies. Less glamorous items covered in the budget under ''operations and maintenance'' may be going up faster than hardware.  More than $60 billion will be requested for more fuel for planes, trucks and ships plus everything from grease to paint to bullets to socks and boots - good news for hundreds of smaller, local companies scattered across the landscape. **********Then too, Mr. Weinberger and other Republicans have suggested pay increases to induce men and women to stay in the Armed Forces, as well as restoring the G.I. Bill of Educational Benefits. That could mean more spending by military personnel in communities near bases from Norfolk to San Diego, from Mountain Home, Idaho, to El Paso, Tex. - and more students and income for increasingly hard-pressed universities. **********I N all of the outcry for more spending, most people simply talk of overall increases, like the 14.5 percent rise indicated by the final Carter budget. Only a few have held up hands of caution. **********Some point out that, since Vietnam, the United States has lacked a cohesive military strategy to govern the expenditure of military funds. Instead, Americans have argued over the draft, the state of military readiness, and the basing of the mobile missile called ''MX.'' That, say the critics, leads to spending money without knowing precisely why it is being spent. **********''This frantic game of bidding up percentage points is a deeply flawed analysis of needs,'' said Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie last winter, when he was chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.  ''In fact, it is no analysis at all. We must begin to solve our military problems by asking the right questions - questions about the ends we want to achieve and the means required to achieve them,'' he continued. ''Beware of the practitioner of statecraft who designs his policies on a calculator.'' **********''More funds will provide a better defense only if the money is spent for the right things,'' added Senator Gary Hart, Democrat of Colorado, who has won a widening reputation as a thoughtful critic of the nation's defense policies. **********A few organizations, such as the Center for Defense Information led by retired Rear Adm. Gene R. LaRocque, or the Boston Study Group, an informal association of scholars, have argued that the expenditures aren't necessary and detract from pressing social or economic needs. **********Moreover, Mr. Reagan and his close advisers have still not convincingly shown that they can jack up military spending, cut taxes, and balance the national budget within the relatively short space of four years - and get inflation under control. **********But those objections seem to have been brushed aside. The advocates of a great leap upward in military spending point to more than a decade of expansion of Soviet military power. They point out that that the Soviet Union was modernizing its military forces while the United States was spending billions of dollars to conduct the Vietnam war. The net result: the Soviet Union has plenty of weapons to show for its expenditures; the United States tons of arms in the jungles of Indochina. **********Then too, they argue that defense spending, as a part of the gross national product, has room to grow. For the 15 years of peace and war from 1956 through 1970, for example, national defense consumed an average of 8.3 percent of G.N.P. Since then, it has declined steadily each year, to 5.2 percent in both 1979 and 1980. The prospect today is for a sustained growth toward 6 percent. **********The reasons that defense costs so much, however, are more complicated than that. They range from the fundamental way that Americans have chosen to defend themselves, to a variety of domestic political motives, weaknesses in the nation's industrial structure, and military waste. Beyond those factors are the failure of allies to pick up a proportionate share of the financial burden, and general economic elements such as inflation.Fundamental Posture **********U NITED STATES ARMED FORCES cost more than they otherwise might because Americans have chosen to defend themselves as far from their own shores as possible. In each of World War I, World War II, the Korean War and the war in Vietnam, American forces moved farther away, across the Atlantic and Pacific oceans that Americans have always perceived as two great moats protecting the country. Only the nuclear deterrent remains based primarily within the United States. **********It's an expensive approach. To airlift and supply a lightly-armed combat force of only 625 men to Egypt in the recent ''bright star'' exercise of the new rapid deployment force cost $25 million for less than two weeks - about $40,000 a man. In contrast, the Soviet Union since World War II has sent forces to Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Afghanistan, all of which are, literally, a truck ride away. **********Moreover, Americans have elected to spend treasure rather than blood in defense, relying increasingly on advanced - and expensive - technology. An F-15 fighter from McDonell Douglas is priced at $17 million a copy; each of Chrysler's new XM-1 tanks costs $1 million; the Aegis cruisers under construction by Litton's Ingalls subsidiary will cost close to $1 billion apiece. Perhaps most stunning, one round, meaning one piece of ammunition, for a standard antitank gun costs $5,000. One shot of an air-to-air missile can cost more than most men will earn in a lifetime. **********Then too, there has been palpable evidence of ''gold-plating'' to get the last 10 percent of performance out of a weapon, regardless of cost. Maintenance of high-performance planes, tanks and ships also costs more. **********By contrast, the Soviet Union makes more, simpler and cheaper weapons but maintains a military force twice the size of that of the United States, with a willingness to suffer much higher casualties. **********Intelligence gathering is also costly for the United States because the Soviet Union and other potential adversaries are closed societies. That means relying on expensive satellites for photographs and sensors, on an elaborate network of electronic listening devices, on a variety of high-priced reconnaissance planes and ships. **********The Soviet Union, again by contrast, can learn most of what it wants to know about the West by subscribing to an abundance of military, industrial and other specialized journals and to the general press.Political Impetus **********E XPENDITURES for military forces, whether well conceived or not, have become a banner to display national determination. ''The military budget is no longer a component of foreign policy - it is its very symbol,'' as Robert J. Bresler, a political scientist at Penn State, has said. Thus, Secretary Muskie has had plenty of company among both Democrats and Republicans in calling for strategy before spending. But so far that appears to have fallen on deaf ears. **********Then too, according to Secretary of Defense Harold Brown, perhaps $5 billion a year could be cut from the military budget if Congressmen voted for the national interests rather than the economic interests of their districts. **********A classic example was the $112.6 million voted last year for six A-7 attack planes for the Air National Guard that the Pentagon didn't ask for and tried to kill after the House put them into the bill. But the delegation from Texas, where the planes are built by Vought, insisted and got its way. In comparison, the 60 Fairchild Republic A-10 aircraft requested and received for the active Air Force were budgeted at just $452.6 million. **********In another case, the Defense Department wanted to close Fort Dix in New Jersey and to consolidate its functions elsewhere to save money.  But officials in New Jersey and New York were successful in blocking the closure. Mr. Reagan is no stranger to that game. California, the state of which he was once Governor, is by far the largest recipient of military dollars, receiving $12.3 billion in 1979. **********All over the country, then, defense contractors are rubbing their hands in the expectation of a bonanza. Their lobbyists here can be expected to begin a full court press as soon as the new administration takes office - all in the interest of what's best for the XYZ gunmaker, and its community.Industrial Weaknesses **********P ICK up any newspaper or news magazine these days and the chances are good it will contain a report on a military cost overrun, a delay in deliveries, a case of faulty workmanship. **********Recently, for instance, General Dynamics's Electric Boat Company in Groton, Conn., was publicly flogged because of delays in delivering its first Trident ballistic missile submarine. A subcontractor had failed to deliver steel that fit specifications, inadequately trained workers did poor welding, and technicians installed pipes and valves improperly. Also, Chrysler reported that it has fallen behind in delivering the new XM-1 tank because the subcontractor failed to deliver engines on time. **********Much of the high and rising cost of weapons in military equipment is rooted in the same industrial weaknesses that cause high and rising costs in civilian products: outdated manufacturing facilities, low productivity, inadequate quality control, and poor workmanship. **********But peculiar to the defense industry is the practice of using the same contractor both to design and produce a weapon. That leads, according to Congressional investigators, to designers rendering optimistic reports on developmental progress so that a production contract will result. **********Jacques S. Gansler, a former senior official in the Defense Department, contends in a new book, ''The Defense Industry,'' that the nation's economic system has failed to foster an efficient defense industry. He suggests that $3 billion a year could be saved by revitalizing that industry. **********Defense industrialists complain that Government overregulation hinders them even more than civilian industry and thus drives up the cost of arms. A fear of mistakes in research and development has fostered layer on layer of review boards that slow down the process and raise costs. **********The procurement policies of the Government, many of which are set by Congress, are a particular target of criticism. Stretching out orders over several years - ostensibly to keep down the military budget - only precludes economies of scale and causes higher per unit costs. Defense contractors further complain that repeated changes in design, mandated by the military, drive up prices. **********In addition, the practice of single-year budgets, defense contractors say, makes it difficult for them to operate efficiently.  In a recent year-end report, Karl G. Harr, president of the Aerospace Industries Association, asserted that 10 to 30 percent could be saved through contracts that covered several years. **********Edward Hidalgo, the Secretary of the Navy, has vigorously argued that the costly adversarial relationship between the Government and industry must end. ''Either Government and business devise and execute an appropriate plan for cooperative coexistence or they will find themselves increasingly divided and conquered,'' he said.Military Waste **********''T HE Pentagon,'' says a Congressional student of the Defense Department, ''is the world's largest nonprofit organization.'' He and others contend that Pentagon officials, from top to middle management, have little incentive to save money. If they do, Congress will only take it back and cut their budgets the next year, and their personal careers will suffer. **********If an officer saves money on one weapon or program, there is practically no way that his service can use that money elsewhere for more ammunition, extra equipment, or an additional training exercise. So the drive is to get as much as possible for each category of spending. **********That puts the military services into intense competition with each other. Inter-service rivalry has been curbed in recent years by the increasingly centralized budget-making process and the Pentagon under the watchful eye of the Office of Management and Budget in the White House. But it is still there. **********In a bureaucracy as large as the military establishment - covering 3 million uniformed and civilian people - waste seems inevitable. An estimated $3 billion a year is spent just on moving people from one station to another. **********Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said in an interview last summer that he had struggled for nearly four years against inefficiency and waste in his department and thought maybe he had saved $1.5 billion in his best year. But he was clearly dissatisfied with his inability to overcome bureaucratic resistance. ''One man's waste,'' he sighed, ''is another man's job.'' **********The cost of the volunteer army has been coming under increasing scrutiny, without much evidence that a draft army would be much cheaper. Secretary Brown says that it costs the United States $15,000 a year on an average for each soldier while West Germany, with its drafted army, pays $14,000. But General Edward C. Meyer, the Army Chief of Staff, has contended that the nation must pay more if it is to make the volunteer army work. It is he who has urged a return to G.I. Bill of Educational Benefits and a substantial pay increase for senior sergeants and specialists to keep them in the service.Thrifty Allies **********T HE failure of Western Europe and Japan to carry a proportionate share of the Western world's defense burden is a clear source of irritation in the United States. As a rough guide, while the United States has been spending its 5 percent and more of G.N.P. on defense, the 13 allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization spend an average of 3.5 percent. Britain alone, at 4.8 percent, approaches the United States. Japan spends slightly less than 1 percent. **********The Carter Administration succeeded in extracting a pledge from the NATO allies that each would increase military spending 3 percent a year, after the effects of inflation (compared with the 4.5 percent real growth implied in the expected Carter budget). But few have done so. **********''No American Government, and still less the American people or the American Congress,'' Defense Secretary Brown has warned, ''are going to accept a situation in which some other country feels that it's our job to defend them and they needn't bother to defend themselves.'' **********The slow pace of standardizing weapons and equipment to reduce duplication is also a thorn. Professor Bresler wrote: ''Alliance leaders collectively wring their hands about growing Soviet might, yet none of them is prepared to lose a dollar or a franc or a deutschemark in defense contracts, or take the political cost of closing factories or laying workers off in order to improve the Alliance's efficiency.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/30/busin.body_text: **********Continental Air Lines said today its acquisition by Texas International Airlines would create a weak, debt-ridden carrier and would reduce air service, especially in the South Pacific areas now serviced by Continental. **********But Texas International, which holds 48.5 percent of Continental's stock, said the airlines could be profitable under common management with no significant loss of service. **********The arguments were made before the Civil Aeronautics Board, which must decide by the end of August whether to approve the acquisition.  An administrative law judge on the C.A.B. staff recommended on July 17 that the acquisition be approved. **********A Continental attorney, Lee Hydeman, said that the judge supported the acquisition even though Texas International must go borrow money to finance the takeover. ''It will create a debt-ridden carrier so severely strapped as to have to take drastic measures to survive,'' he said. **********Continental has proposed an employee stock ownership plan as an alternative to a takeover by Texas International.  A Texas International attorney, John Barnum, said that the two airlines would be operated separately for some time if the acquisition is approved.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/02/world.main_headline: SOCIALIST TEST: TAXING RICHES OF THE FRENCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/02/world.print_headline: SOCIALIST TEST: TAXING RICHES OF THE FRENCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/02/world.body_text: **********''The opposition should at least be consistent,'' Budget Minister Laurent Fabius said, looking haggard after spending a hard week in the National Assembly over the Government's proposed wealth tax. ''First they attack us for making it too harsh. When we amend it, they say it is ineffectual.'' **********The wealth tax, which began last week as one of the big symbolic spearheads of the Socialist battle to create a more egalitarian economic system, has come out the size of a penknife. **********President Francois Mitterrand, whose twin passions for the arts and for Socialism had never up to this point conflicted, decided Thursday night to eliminate paintings, sculpture and antiquities from the list of things that will be considered taxable wealth under the new law. At the same time, it was indicated that stocks of wine and forest holdings would also be exempt. **********''Bravo, la France!'' the 94-year-old Marc Chagall telegraphed Mr.  Mitterrand at Elysee Palace. Painters, art collectors, gallery owners and auctioneers, who had been predicting that Paris - after the expected clandestine flight of canvases and statues - would rapidly achieve the artistic standing of Pinsk, expressed great relief. Tax on Sales of Art **********Instead of taxing the possession of art objects, the law will put a tax of up to 6 percent upon sales. In a booming art market this is unlikely to have much impact. Less clear was the impact of an amendment requiring that the wealth tax be exacted, retroactively to the passage of the law, when an art object is exported. The amendment was offered not by the Socialists but by former Prime Minister Michel Debre, a strongly nationalist member of the opposition. **********The wealth tax originally aimed at levying between one-half of 1 percent and 1.5 percent on personal holdings valued at more than $600,000 and on business holdings above $1 million. The law now has so many restrictions that it is expected to bring in only $1 billion a year, or less than 1 percent of Government revenues. **********For the Government, the shrinking of its wealth tax is, if not precisely a defeat, a reminder of the difficulties it faces in working out its program, and a source of some additional ones -mainly involving the cohesion of its own followers. **********In the National Assembly, the Socialist deputies loyally passed the Government proposals and warded off amendments that the Government opposed. A number of them had misgivings, however, notably Mr. Fabius himself, who, until last week, had argued strongly within the Cabinet against any further reduction of the tax. 'An Empty Sack' **********The Communists, who are minority partners in the Government and are expected to support it in the Assembly, came the closest they have been so far to opposing it. One Communist deputy called the law ''a sieve,'' and another said it was ''an empty sack.'' For the first time in the life of the current Assembly, Socialists found themselves -in partnership with the opposition - voting down Communist amendments seeking to strengthen the law. **********The difficulties over the wealth tax are essentially a struggle between two contradictory portions of the French Socialist soul.  The Socialists harbor simultaneous impulses to wield ideology for the sake of changing France, and pragmatism for the sake of gauging what France will accept. The wealth tax, while not unpopular in theory - even among businessmen it does not stand high on the worry list - became so when it began to touch particular concrete things that signify France to different groups of the French. It can be wine to some, grandfather's bit of oak forest to others, and art to still others - including the President. **********In recent weeks the friction between ideology and pragmatism, between the exercise of prudence and the wielding of power, has become more pronounced. Like any friction, it produces heat. Personnel Changes **********The wealth tax aside, the main source of heat is now a number of personnel changes that the Government has made. A high official in the Budget Ministry and another in the Labor Ministry were replaced.  They are both highly respected - so much so that even newspapers that support the Government have lamented their removal, suggesting that the only reason they were ousted is that they served under the previous Government. **********To which Government ministers have retorted that this is normal practice in a democratic system when the government changes, and that if France is not used to it, this is only because the same party had been in power for nearly a quarter of a century. **********Over the last few days the Government has encountered the most serious protest so far against its personnel shifts. This was the resignation of virtually the entire top echelon of France's major scientific research body, the National Center for Scientific Research. **********The Minister of Research and Technology, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, had requested that the center's director replace the head of the sociology department with a Marxist-oriented sociologist. The director general, Jacques Ducuing, resigned Thursday.  On Friday, Charles Thibault, president of the center, and five of the six scientists on the governing council resigned. Their protest was not over the identity of the new appointee but over the fact that the normal procedure, under which the center proposes its candidates to the Minister, had been flouted. **********''Even in the United States, which is supposed to be a model democracy, you have a spoils system,'' Mr. Chevenement said. It seems likely, judging by early comments here, that the more pragmatic members of the Government will find fault, if not with Mr.  Chevenement's argument, at least with his way of carrying it out.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/15/busin.body_text: **********The United States Postal Service's controversial nine-digit ZIP code, which has run into strong Congressional opposition, received another jolt today when the Office of Management and Budget ordered the service to justify its plan with a costbenefit analysis. **********While the budget office made the request for the regulatory impact analysis, it was understood that Congress and not the Reagan Administration would use the material provided to decide whether to allow the Postal Service to go through with its plan. **********Legislation has been introduced in both houses of Congress to prevent the new ZIP code from becoming effective June 1, as planned by the Postal Service. **********The letter was sent Friday by James C. Miller 3d, executive director of the White House task force on regulatory relief, to Postmaster General William Bolger. The Postal Service, which said it received the letter today, had no comment on it. **********Last February, Representative Glenn English, Democrat of Oklahoma, and Senator David F. Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, both sent letters to the budget office requesting an evaluation of the regulatory impact of the proposed ZIP code, whose use would be voluntary. **********The Postal Service contends that the code would improve efficiency and hold down costs.  Today's actions received mixed reviews in Congress. One House staff member said the budget office letter failed because it did not pin down the Postal Service to a deadline for doing the analysis. **********''The letter is very soft,'' said the House staff member, ''and we're not going to let them get away with being soft on this.'' He said the Postal Service should have been told to stop its plans until it complied with the request of a cost-benefit analysis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/24/world.main_headline: FORMER HOSTAGE SAYS SOME OF THE 52 WOULD NOT VIEW TAPES OF TAKEOVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/24/world.print_headline: FORMER HOSTAGE SAYS SOME OF THE 52 WOULD NOT VIEW TAPES OF TAKEOVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/24/world.body_text: **********Bruce W. German, one of the freed hostages, said today that some of his colleagues were having more problems than others in adjusting. ''They showed us videotapes of the embassy takeover,'' he said, ''and some of the group simply would not look at them.'' **********Mr. German, from Rockville, Md., was the budget officer at the United States Embassy in Teheran. He described what it was like to be in the embassy on Sunday, Nov. 4, 1979, when the Iranian militants broke in. **********''I was working in the basement of one of the buildings in the compound,'' he said. ''Sunday is just another working day in the Islamic world. We could hear the crowd yelling and cheering. Then someone came in and told us we'd better move upstairs to a safer location. We barricaded ourselves in but it didn't make any difference. We had to let them in or they would have torn the whole place down. That first day was the closest I've ever come to total terror.'' **********Asked if he considered resisting or escaping, Mr. German replied, ''When there is a gun being cocked in your ear, you don't have many options.'' Would Return 'in a B-52' **********Mr. German, 44 years old, said he believed that the hostage crisis could make life difficult for other diplomats. ''There is just no way you can make an embassy safe from half a million angry people,'' he said. Mr. German added that he would never take a foreign post where new security measures, now being planned, were not in effect. As for Iran, he said he would return there - ''only in a B-52.'' **********''We had our moments of despair,'' he said. He insisted at first that there was ''very little bitterness'' among the former hostages.  Then he stopped and added in a subdued voice, ''I'd rather not get into that.'' **********Mr. German said that for him the captivity grew worse after the unsuccessful rescue attempt last April. ''We had good food at first,'' he said. ''We had the Ambassador's cook.'' After the aborted mission the hostages were dispersed. ''We were spread over the whole country,'' he said, ''from the cities to the smallest village.'' **********He said the hostages heard about the rescue attempt soon after it was over. ''We were against it,'' he said. ''We heard that Secretary Vance had resigned over it and we applauded that. After all, it came six months into it -what was the sense?'' Learned About Iran-Iraq War **********The hostages eventually learned about the Iraqi-Iranian war, although their captors at first denied that it was taking place, Mr.  German said. ''In September, when they imposed the blackout, they told us it was for a celebration,'' he said. ''We just hoped it was the Iraqis who were celebrating.'' **********Wearing the new Air Force parka he received on the flight from Algiers to West Germany on Wednesday morning, Mr. German grinned broadly and said, ''I'm thankful I'm still intact -physically and mentally.'' **********He gave further indication that the front shown by the hostages was not that solid. Asked repeatedly, ''How do you all feel?'' he became irritated. ''Look,'' he said, ''there were 52 of us. There are 52 different stories.'' He paused and added, ''Everyone was so isolated.'' **********Of the Iranian militants, he said: ''We were sympathetic to their cause at first - we thought their motives were sound. But they weren't students. They may have been students once. We all were. They were terrorists, pure and simple.'' **********Mr. German said that the stay in Wiesbaden had been beneficial.  ''This halfway stop was one of the best things that could have happened to us,'' Mr. German said. **********But he added, ''I just want to become an American again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/26/busin.main_headline: S.E.C. CHIEF PLANS INSIDER TRADE CURB
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/26/busin.print_headline: S.E.C. CHIEF PLANS INSIDER TRADE CURB
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/26/busin.body_text: **********Instances of insider trading appear to be on the rise, a problem that has not escaped the attention of John S.R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Restraining such abuses, he says, will be a top priority during his term in office. **********Mr. Shad, who did not elaborate on how the commission would deal with this problem, said that the agency's enforcement division would ''have some dramatic news that relates to the insider trading area'' this week. ''We're going to come down with hobnail boots to give some shocking examples to inhibit the activity.'' **********The commission chairman, in a meeting with a group of reporters and editors at The New York Times, touched on a broad range of topics affecting the economy and the securities industry, but he saved his strongest remarks for the problem of controlling insider trading abuses. **********Charges of insider trading - trading in stock on the basis of information not available to the public - have received widespread publicity in the last few weeks. The trading of stock options in Sante Fe International before the recent announcement that the Kuwaiti Government wanted to buy the oil drilling company has been under scrutiny. And a partner with the New York law firm of Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz was discharged in September after admitting that he had traded in stocks of several of the firm's client companies. Insider Trades Limited **********Despite these two instances, Mr. Shad cautioned against undermining investor confidence by exaggerating the amount of insider activity in the stock market. **********''It's definitely a major problem, and it requires a major assault by the S.E.C., the Bar and the industry - and that's what I'm trying to support,'' Mr. Shad said. ''But to suggest that the billions of dollars of securities that change hand daily in America are on insider trading is irrational - it's only a tiny fraction of 1 percent of the volume of trading.'' **********''I think it's wrong to suggest that the public is playing a game for which the dice is loaded against them,'' he said. ''To say that insider trading is the rule rather than the exception, that it's a common act, is just not true.'' **********Mr. Shad said he ''constantly'' has heard reports of poor morale in the enforcement division since the departure of Stanley Sporkin, who as head of the unit in the 1970's vigorously pursued hundreds of cases involving questionable payments by American corporations. **********But he said that the commission already has enough work that cannot be pursued and to suggest that the division has problems because it will no longer be able to investigate foreign bribes is unwarranted.  ''The problem is that we lack the resources,'' he said. Extent of S.E.C. Authority **********Mr. Shad emphasized that he supported the vigorous enforcement of the securities laws, but ''the question I'm raising is should they also be engaged in writing the law? Do we need to extend the authority of the S.E.C. to marginal questions?'' **********''In times past, within the enforcement division - and probably even today, there are people who want to move the cutting edge of the law -that are really going for greater authority in the commission, and I think that that should be a secondary issue.'' **********During his time in office, Mr. Shad said he would like the commission to focus on ''improving the capital formation process,'' which is investment in plant and equipment financed by profits, securities offerings and debt issues. **********Mr. Shad's ideas about capital formation by public corporations contrast sharply in some areas with the philosophy of his precedessor, Harold M. Williams. **********Mr. Williams, while encouraging the capital formation process, also raised questions during his tenure about whether corporate takeovers diverted credit and capital from more productive and innovative uses. **********In contrast, Mr. Shad said the trend toward mergers and the creation of financial service conglomerates is ''a natural extension of evolutionary developments in the securities industry, It's not bad. There are advantages of size, and I think the public will benefit and won't be hurt by these major mergers.'' Supports Disclosure Streamlining **********Before his appointment as commission chairman, Mr. Shad spent almost all of his working life on Wall Street, rising to vice chairman of the E.F. Hutton Group Inc., as a specialist in mergers and acquisitions. **********Although the commission has limited jurisdiction over mergers, it does review the adequacy of disclosure statements filed with the agency in connection with acquisitions. Mr. Shad promised to simplify that process by reducing excessive registration, reporting and other regulatory burdens on the industry. ''The problem we have all the time in the commission is, what is the value of more disclosure? To what extent is more and more disclosure actually less significant to the public?'' he said. **********Mr. Shad, speaking about the national securities market that Congress mandated in 1975, said that the commission wanted the securities industry to develop a rule dealing with the potential problems of ''internalization,'' or execution of a customer order by a brokerage firm ''in house'' rather than on a stock exchange floor. **********The ability of larger brokerage firms to internalize orders has been viewed by exchanges as a competitive threat that could diminish orders on exchange floors. **********The commission has said that it was concerned about internalization, but it indicated the issue should not delay establishment of a national securities market. **********''The industry would like us to come up with a rule, and we said, we want you to come up with a rule, you're going to have to live with this,'' Mr. Shad said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/world.body_text: **********Fourteen people were killed in the last week in clashes between Government soldiers and ''counterrevolutionary'' groups in northern Nicaragua, the Interior Ministry announced yesterday. The Ministry said no Government soldiers had been killed. **********Nicaragua says that bands of troops still loyal to the ousted Government of Anastasio Somoza Debayle are operating in the country.The number of reported clashes has increased in recent months. The Government has accused Honduras of allowing the rebels to use territory along its border with Nicaragua as a staging area for attacks. Honduras denies the Nicaraguan charg e. **********PUERTO CORTES, Honduras, Oct. 10 (AP) - Three days of joint United States-Honduran Navy exercises ended yesterday without incident and ''in keeping with our plans,'' said Capt. Julio Raudales Soto, a Honduran spokesman at the Puerto Cortes navy base. Nicaragua had charged that the maneuvers represented ''a threat to peace in Central America and a danger to Nicaragua.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/20/busin.body_text: **********The economic summit conference has been an annual event since 1975. Following are summaries of the six previous meetings.  Rambouillet, France, 1975 - The conferees rejected a return to fixed exchange rates while agreeing on the need for monetary stability and for international economic cooperation. **********Dorado Beach, Puerto Rico, 1976 -The nations agreed the greatest danger was overly rapid, inflationary growth. However, unemployment, ignored at the meeting, later soared. **********London, 1977 - The industrialized nations committed themselves to a 5 percent growth rate for the year, butWest Germany and Japan failed to meet goals for rapid growth. While the American economy spurted ahead, promises for a comprehensive energy program were not fulfilled. **********Bonn, 1978 - The conference ended with a modest set of pledges to maintain slow-growth policies. The United States had to promise to reduce oil imports in order to win concessions from Tokyo and Bonn.  But oil consumption and imports continued to swell. **********Tokyo, 1979 - Energy dominated the meeting. The United States again vowed to cut petroleum imports as part of an agreement to put ceilings on oil purchases through 1985. **********Venice, 1980 - The economic talks again centered on energy, with the nations agreeing to develop alternate energy sources and cut deeply into oil imports. A world surplus of oil developed during the next year because of higher prices and slow growth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/world.main_headline: BLACK AFRICANS ASK PARLEY WITH ARABS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/world.print_headline: BLACK AFRICANS ASK PARLEY WITH ARABS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/world.body_text: **********Foreign ministers from the 50 members of the Organization of African Unity overwhelmingly approved a resolution today calling for a summit meeting of Arabs and black Africans to sort out their grievances. **********But several hours later, Chedli Ayari, head of the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa, said that he saw no immediate prospect for such a meeting. Instead, Dr. Ayari said, efforts are being made to revive the so-called Standing Commission consisting of members from the O.A.U. and the Arab League to discuss problems relating to the Arab-African situation. **********Black African leaders are voicing increasing concern that relations between their nations and the Arab world have deteriorated to a point where major political steps need to be taken to avert a crisis. **********At the heart of this ''crisis'' is a belief by many black African nations, particularly poorer ones such as Uganda, Kenya, Ghana and Zambia, that the oil-producing countries of the Arab world have long promised major infusions of financial aid as well as significant concessions in oil prices, but that these Arab nations simply have not come through adequately in meeting their pledges. Egyptian Presence Is Obstacle **********The Standing Commission has long been moribund. Moves to set up a working session for the unit have been stymied by the fact that Egypt is a member of the commission, and many Arab nations, opposed to the Egyptian-Israeli Peace Treaty, have refused to attend any meeting where Egyptian representatives would be present. **********Peter Onu, Assistant Secretary General of the African organization, insisted today that since Egypt was a legitimate member, it ''must be allowed to participate'' in the working sessions of the Standing Commission. Egypt was suspended from the Arab League in 1979 after it signed the peace treaty with Israel. **********However, the black African countries have pointed to their consistent support of the general Arab position concerning Middle East issues. Tonight they reached agreement on a new resolution, proposed by Egypt, that condemned the recent raid by Israel on a nuclear reactor in Iraq. The 1,200-word Egyptian resolution, calling the Israeli attack ''a flagrant violation'' of the United Nations Charter and international law, urges that the Israelis be ordered to allow international inspectors at its own nuclear reactor site. **********Whatever Egypt's isolation in the Arab world, it is apparent that President Anwar el-Sadat retains considerable popularity among African leaders. Many of these view Egypt as presenting a counter to a perceived adventurism of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Egypt Active in Black Africa **********Moreover, Egypt has long had an active foreign policy in black Africa, and it has sent teachers, technicians, physicians and military advisers to several black African countries. **********Several leaders of black African nations attending the O.A.U summit session said that Arab nations, especially the oil-producing countries, have not sufficiently helped poor black African countries that severed their relations with Israel at the urging of the Arab world. **********Some of these countries, like Uganda and Kenya, used to have major programs of technical assistance set up by the Israelis, particularly in agriculture and engineering. The black African leaders complain that although their countries provide the Arab world with often vocal support on the Palestine issue, by pursuing highprice policies the oil-producing Arabs have damaged the economies of the poor Africans. **********African leaders here assert that the volume of aid given by Arabs to black Africa - about $1 billion a year, according to Dr. Ayari - is simply not enough to overcome the fuel bills that they are increasingly being required to pay. Kenya, for example, is reported to spend nearly 75 percent of its budget on oil imports, or more than $800 million a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/01/busin.body_text: **********New orders for manufactured goods rose 1.3 percent in March, with modest increases coming in automotive equipment, construction materials and various kinds of machinery, the Commerce Department reported today. **********Most major durable-goods categories were relatively stable, with losses reported for household goods and primary metals. Orders for nonmilitary planes and parts made up about $1.8 billion of the $2.1 billion increase. The seasonally adjusted value of total factory orders was $164.9 billion. **********The Commerce Department also reported that factory inventories rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in March after a 1.1 percent jump in February. About half of the new increase was accounted for within the petroleum industry. Previous reports had indicated that oil supplies were building as prices rose and Americans cut back energy use. **********''Inventories are saying that the economy may be turning a bit softer,'' but the rise in new orders indicates some underlying strength, said Ago Ambre, a Commerce Department analyst. **********The Commerce Department report did not adjust for the effect of price increases on the value of factory orders or inventories.  Inventories of finished goods rose 2.5 percent in March, a much bigger increase than those recorded for stockpiles of raw materials and work in process. **********Mr. Ambre said that was an indication that the buildup was not planned for meeting future demand. Instead, he continued, it is a sign that goods ''are not moving out the door as fast as business would like.'' **********A private economist, David Ernst, a vice president with Evans Economics in Washington, saw less to worry about in the inventory increase, noting that most industries' stockpiles were still relatively lean. **********''If inventories got to a fairly unmanageable state, it could mean cutbacks in production and employment,'' Mr. Ernst said, but he added that his firm did not expect that. **********Most private and government economists are forecasting little or no growth in the next few months following a first quarter in which economic strength proved stronger than many had predicted. **********Mr. Ambre said March gains in orders for several categories of heavy machinery indicated that that part of big industry ''is likely to remain strong.'' **********The new report also revised February's orders record from a negative five-tenths of 1 percent to a positive four-tenths of 1 percent, so the figure has now risen for nine of the last 10 months - including a decline of less than one-tenth of 1 percent in January. **********Durable goods orders, heavily influenced by the aircraft, rose 2.9 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $84.6 billion in March, the report said. The Commerce Department had said in an advance report last week that durable goods appeared to have risen only 1.3 percent last month. **********Nondurable goods industries, such as those producing food, clothing, gasoline and other relatively short-lived items, declined three-tenths of 1 percent to $80.3 billion, the new report said. **********New orders for nondefense capital goods rose 15.8 percent, to $23.8 billion, after falling 16 percent in February. That category is sometimes considered a harbinger of future industrial investment, but it also apparently was heavily affected by the aircraft orders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/20/busin.body_text: **********IN 1979, Great Basins Petroleum decided to either sell out or liquidate to realize values in the company's Canadian oil and gas properties that were not reflected in the share price. **********Thereupon began a saga that saw the shares soar and then slide. At present, the company expects to realize more cash on assets sold than the price for which the shares are selling, 11 3/4 at yesterday's close on the American Stock Exchange. **********Evidently, from Wall Street's point of view, it's back to basics.  When the plan to sell or liquidate was announced, the shares were selling at under 10 a share, or just a bit below current levels. **********The plan did focus attention on the shares, and they began to rise smartly. Soon a rumor arose that a major oil and gas company would be making a bid for Great Basins. People on Wall Street believed the rumor and, guessing that the takeover price would be $25 to $30 a share, pushed the stock price to 24 1/4. **********However, when the Phillips Petroleum Company made a bid in March 1980, the United States-based company offered $18 a share in cash.  Great Basins promptly fell to 15 5/8, reflecting the disappointing price. The discount from that price had to do with the time cost of financing the purchase of shares on margin pending the consummation of the takeover deal and the uncertainties that such bids entail. **********In October, a major uncertainty materialized when the Canadian Government announced a new policy toward foreign takeovers. The Government's professed goal is to increase Canadian ownership of Canadian energy companies to 50 percent by the end of the decade, up from an average of 30 percent ownership held by Canadians today. **********The new policy makes Canadian acquisitions by United States companies difficult if not impossible in most cases. Great Basins shares promptly plummeted to 11 as investors speculated that Phillips might withdraw. It did the next month. **********Discouraged over the prospects of a merger, Great Basins then announced that the company would liqui-date. Thereafter, the shares rallied to trade as high as 15, but they have since drifted lower. **********Great Basins has already agreed to sell its oil and gas interests north of the border to Canadian-controlled United Canso Oil and Gas Ltd. for $154 million (Canadian) adjusted for repayment of debt, or $128.6 million (United States). This equals $12 a share. Great Basins has 10.7 million shares outstanding. **********Great Basins sold one small United States oil and gas property, and the remaining Canadian oil and gas properties are to be disposed of contingent upon stockholder approval, which is expected. These properties are to produce enough to retire the remaining Great Basins long-term debt. **********It may be that investors are overlooking the fact that Great Basins will have $12 a share in cash after all debt is liquidated. Anyway, one way of looking at this prospect, says Christopher Stavro, an analyst for Evans & Company who specializes in buying shares of companies that are being bought out or are liquidating, is that at yesterday's closing price, the investor would acquire the rest of the company free. **********The remaining assets are not spectacular, but they do amount to something. They include a 17.6 percent working interest in the Ladner Creek Gold Mine in British Columbia, currently being managed by Carolin Mines. Some believe that the Great Basins interest in that mine might eventually be worth a great deal more than $5 a share. On the other hand, Mr. Stavro believes the mine interest would bring $2.50 a share in liquidation. **********Great Basins also has 17 million tons of coal reserves in the Taggart and Harlan coal seams in Virginia that are said to be worth 25 cents to 50 cents a ton. At the midpoint, 37 cents a ton, the coal would be worth 60 cents a Great Basins share, Mr.Stavro said. **********Mr. Stavro's clients own approximately 10,000 shares of Great Basins stock, and he has placed a substantial number of shares with institutions. **********Clearly, the remaining assets are worth somewhat more than the price for which the shares are now selling. Mr. Stavro believes there is total value ranging from $15.50 to $18 a share, a substantial premium over the cash the company is to receive on the sale of its oil and gas interests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/busin.body_text: **********A senate staff study of who owns America's 100 leading corporations has found a high degree of concentration, rooted in overlapping institutional stock holding and interlocking directorates. **********The study found that the top levels of ownership in almost all major corporations are held or controlled by as few as 15 financial institutions, including major banks and insurance companies. **********The report echoes the findings of most previous studies of corporate concentration, including private and government analyses of ownership and interlocking directorates as well as of market penetration.  Over the past 35 years, the data from these studies indicate that ownership or control of the common stock of America's corporations has become increasingly concentrated. **********The new, computer-aided Senate study, relying on 1980 Securities and Exchange Commission data, provides no analysis of the economic or social consequences of concentration. **********Some critics of such reports argue that the high concentration of ownership and interlocking directorates have relatively little economic impact. **********The study, prepared for the Senate Committee on Government Affairs by E. Winslow Turner, an outside consultant, studied 100 of the nation's largest companies in 17 areas of finance and industry, including banking, insurance, automotives, steel, energy, transportation and retailing. Mr. Turner is a former antitrust attorney with the Justice Department. **********J.P. Morgan & Company, New York's fourth-largest bank, is effectively the first - or second-largest stockholder, through holdings it manages for others, in 25 of the companies studied in the report, including International Business Machines, Bank of America, Eastern Airlines, Citicorp, Sears, Mobil, General Motors, General Electric and Westinghouse. **********The aggregate holdings of pension funds and large financial institutions like Morgan place "them in a special position to exert control or influence over the management of their portfolio companies," the Senate study concluded. **********Citicorp was found to have the most interlocking directorates: 49 direct interlocks with the other companies and 887 indirect interlocks. **********A direct interlock occurs when two corporations have a common director, while an indirect interlock takes place when directors of two corporations meet as directors of a third corporation.  Interocking directorates among direct competitors are forbidden by Federal Law.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/29/busin.main_headline: HUDSON'S BAY SET TO BUY AMOCO UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/29/busin.print_headline: HUDSON'S BAY SET TO BUY AMOCO UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/29/busin.body_text: **********The Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company of Calgary said it has agreed to buy a controlling interest in the Cyprus Anvil Mining Corporation of Vancouver for $212.4 million (Canadian) from the Amoco Minerals Company, a unit of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana). **********The Canadian dollar is worth about 81.6 cents in United States currency.  The agreement was seen as yet another example of how Canadian Government policies are encouraging the takeover by Canadian companies of foreign-owned concerns in Canada, **********The Calgary company said it would pay $44.25 for each of 4.8 million Cyprus Anvil shares in the 63 percent control block held by Amoco Minerals and later would make a similar offer for the remaining publicly owned shares. At the offering price, the indicated value of the purchase would be $127.4 million. **********Major Ore Producer **********Cyprus Anvil's lead, silver and zinc mine at Faro in the Yukon Territory produces about 24 percent of Canada's lead and 10 percent of its zinc, ''marking it as one of Canada's major producers,'' according to John Jennings, mining analyst at Nesbitt Thomson Bongard Inc., a Toronto investment firm. **********While Canada's national energy program favors Canadian control of companies by giving them exploration incentives in frontier areas denied to foreign-controlled concerns, it does not affect mining companies. The circumstances behind the sale of the Cyprus Anvil interest are not related to the energy policy. **********Amoco Minerals acquired Cyprus Anvil Mining as part of its 1979 purchase of the Cyprus Mines Corporation of Los Angeles. As required by Canada's Foreign Investment Review Act, it sought permission for the control change from the Foreign Investment Review Agency but was refused. Denial Prompted Sale **********With the after-the-fact permission to control Cyprus Anvil thus denied, Amoco Minerals placed the holdings on sale last May 27 through Dominion Securities, a Toronto investment house. **********The review agency began operations in 1974 with the mandate to screen foreign ventures and changes of control on the broad basis of ''significant benefit to Canada.'' It then makes recommendations to the Cabinet. **********An agency spokesman in Ottawa said today that ''in 99.9 percent of cases'' it does not give reasons for denial of applications, and did not do so in the case of Amoco's Cyprus Anvil petition. He added that the criteria for judging applications before the agency included the degree of Canadian participation and equity, the effect of the proposal on economic activity, productivity and competition within the industry and compatibility with national and provincial economic and industrial policies. **********Last night's announcements said that since 1976 Hudson's Bay Oil and Cyprus Anvil had been involved in several joint explorations in a program that led to a significant lead, silver and zinc discovery at Cirque in northeastern British Columbia. **********Mr. Jennings said that the two companies ''have a good working relationship'' and that Hudson's Bay ''has the cash on hand'' for the takeover. **********Cyprus Anvil had a loss for the first six months of 1981 of $6.9 million in contrast to a profit in the first half of 1980 of $12.0 million, or $1.56 a share. Revenue declined to $56.7 million from $92.5 million. The company cited lower concentrate production and significantly lower lead and silver prices.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/29/busin.body_text: **********A perception that interest rates will stay high longer than anticipated, deepening the current world economic slump and compounding debt repayment problems, is casting a pall over a meeting here of world bankers. **********International bankers and government financial officials attending the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund said the realization that economic adjustment now would be even more difficult than previously imagined had added to a sense of despondency and uncertainty that had been brewing for some time. In addition, the sense of that difficulty, they said, was contributing to the turbulence in world stock markets. **********'Deeper Recession' Foreseen **********Boyer de la Giroday, a leading monetary official of the European Common Market, said, ''High interest rates are not good for the world economy, but what can we do about them?'' **********''For us in Europe,'' he added, ''the meaning is clear - we'll have a deeper recession.'' The Europeans, he said, had been counting on decelerating interest rates and a pickup in American economic activity, which he said would now be deferred, as a spur to their own growth. **********''The atmosphere is absolutely awful,'' said Claudio Segre, a Paris investment banker and a former high official in the Common Market bureaucracy. He added that American budget deficits were now ''suddenly seen as a threat to the whole process of more gradual economic adjustment.'' **********Paul N. Goldschmidt, London-based director of the Wall Street investment house of Goldman, Sachs, said that the persistence of high interest rates, which was squeezing world liquidity, had increased the risks of a ''financial accident'' - meaning a major bankruptcy. Little Criticism of Reagan **********Although the economic situation in the United States was viewed as the key to the world economic outlook, since the United States still accounts for about a quarter of the world's total output, bankers and government officials from industrial countries expressed little criticism of President Reagan's economic policies. **********Hans Matthofer, West German Finance Minister, said that the general air of uncertainty about what was going to happen had in fact brought the industrial countries closer in trying to harmonize their policies. **********While West German officials earlier this year had been particularly critical of high American interest rates, Mr. Matthofer took special pains today, at a breakfast meeting with reporters, to observe that ''I have found myself in particular agreement'' with Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan on the direction of American policies. **********Pierre Werner, the Prime Minister and Treasury Minister of Luxembourg, said that he expected pressures to mount within the United States to revise interest-rate policie s, and he forecast lowerrates within the next month. **********Representatives from the third world saw high rates combined with American efforts to restrain lending activities of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as seriously wea kening their financial pos ition. In addition, the economic stagnation in the industrial co untries has reduced the trade of the developing countries. **********While these countries are calling for increased aid, a leading Japanese banker, Kyonosuke Ibe, chairman of the Sumitomo Bank, summed up the position of the industrial countries in these terms: ''No one is capable of extending a great amount of help to these countries. We have to clean our own house first.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/20/world.main_headline: IRAN AIDE CONDEMNS U.S. BANKS IN DELAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/20/world.print_headline: IRAN AIDE CONDEMNS U.S. BANKS IN DELAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/20/world.body_text: **********Iran's chief hostage negotiator said early today that American banks had filed an unexpected appendix to the hostage agreement reached with the United States that he described as ''an underhanded maneuver for delaying the final solution of the problem.'' **********The official Pars press agency later quoted Behzad Nabavi, the negotiator, as saying Text of Pars broadcast, page A7. that Iran would take more severe action if the United States did not meet a new deadline for transferring frozen Iranian assets in exchange for the hostages. **********He said the deadline would be announced after he had discussed with Algerian intermediaries what he earlier called "underhanded maneuvers" and delays by American banks. (The threat was made before the United States and Iran on the dispute over assets.) **********If the transfer was not begun, ''we will take more severe action,'' Mr. Nabavi said. He did not elaborate. 'Subterfuge' Is Condemned In his earlier remarks, Mr. Navabi said that Algerian intermediaries had given Iran a document drawn up by American banks aimed at forcing Iran to drop claims to certain of its assets. **********Pars quoted Mr. Nabavi as having said: ''The Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran severely condemned this subterfuge by the U.S. banks.'' **********His remarks suggested that a serious new complication had arisen in addition to a problem over a missing signature that delayed departure of the 52 American hostages after they had been told they were going home. **********That delay evidently resulted, according to diplomatic sources, because the Iranians forgot to sign a document to open an escrow account with the Bank of England. The Bank of England is to act as a neutral depository for funds to be transferred to Iran in return for release of the hostages. **********''Until 12 midnight Teheran time, no news had been received of this transfer,'' Mr. Nabavi added, according to Pars.  Mr. Nabavi said that Algeria had relayed an 11-page appendix from American banks. **********''They have meant to make it binding on Iran to drop any further claims beyond the approximately $8 billion which are to be escrowed in the British central bank,'' Pars quoted Mr. Nabavi as saying. **********''The U.S. banks claimed that the said amount was the whole of the assets credited to Iran,'' Mr. Nabavi added. **********''The declaration which had been signed by Iran and the U.S.  Government earlier in the day did not stipulate any such appendix and producing this appendix had been done against the clear and unequivocal text of the declaration,'' Pars quoted him further. **********The sudden addition of the appendix from the banks, he said, ''even with the utmost optimism could only be viewed as an underhanded maneuver for delaying the final solution of the problem, especially after the U.S. President had issued an order for releasing Iran's assets in the U.S. banks.'' **********In his interview later, Mr. Nabavi said: ''We are waiting for American banks to transfer deposits of Iran to the Bank of England.  If any delay takes place on this matter, the American banks will be responsible for it. They are not even obeying the agreements signed by the President of the United States. **********''We have asked the Algerian delegation for a meeting in which we will give our latest opinions and give a new deadline for American banks to transfer deposits to the Bank of England,'' Mr. Nabavi said. ''If this does not take place, obviously we will take more severe action.'' **********Until the new problem developed over the appendix, the hostages were all set to go after examination by a team of Algerian doctors who told them the good news, diplomatic sources said. Algerian Planes Await Hostages **********Two red and white Algerian Boeing 727 airliners waited for the hostages on the tarmac at Teheran's Mehrabad Airport, blacked out because of the war with Iraq. They were fueled up and ready to fly the Americans out of the country. **********One of the planes was loaded with the hostages' baggage, including many gifts they received from home on two Christmas Days, airport officials said. **********The airliners, and a smaller executive jet that brought the Algerian doctors here last week, were parked half a mile from the airport terminal tonight, surrounded by a milling crowd including Algerian diplomats, Iranian policemen and armed Islamic Revolutionary Guards. **********A spokesman for Mr. Nabavi denied reports that the Americans had been taken to the airport but declined to say whether they had been moved from their places of captivity. **********An airport official said tonight that the Algerian planes had clearance to fly west over the Iranian city of Tabriz and across Turkey. They had permission to land in Ankara and Istanbul but would do so only if they required fuel, the official said. **********Mr. Nabavi scheduled a news conference yesterday for about 6:30 A.M. New York time to announce that the hostages were in the air, according to diplomats here. **********But as a result of the bank difficulty, Mr. Nabavi put off the news conference several times, eventually starting it at 5.30 P.M., or 9 A.M. New York time. **********He told reporters that the hostages were still in Iran because their medical examination had taken longer than expected. **********Mr. Nabavi said at the early news conference that Iran would have put the hostages on trial as spies rather than negotiate with an administration headed by Ronald Reagan. **********''Our aim was to free the hostages during Carter's time or try them,'' he said. ''We had decided to hand them over to the courts if America did not accept the conditions of our Majlis (parliament). **********''We had no interest in continuing negotiations with somebody who called the Iranians 'barbarians,''' he added, refererring to a remark a few weeks ago by President-elect Ronald Reagan. **********He also said Iran would have no future relations with the ''world predator Government of America,'' either politically or economically.  ''It was not because of the occupation of the nest of spies that our relations with America worsened,'' he said. ''It was because of our revolution that relations became hostile.'' **********By ''nest of spies,'' he meant the United States Embassy, seized by Iranian militants on Nov. 4, 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/02/world.main_headline: EAST GERMANY EASING CONTROLS ON CHURCHES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/02/world.print_headline: EAST GERMANY EASING CONTROLS ON CHURCHES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/02/world.body_text: **********Communist East Germany, in a move away from trying to isolate the country's Christian believers, has embarked on an ambitious program of building new churches, restoring old religious buildings and honoring historic church leaders. **********Recently Martin Luther, the Protestant reformer, made his appearance on the East German stage in a new play, demanding that a monument be erected for him here. The public roared and applauded. To everyone's surprise Erich Honecker, the Communist Party leader, had announced shortly before that he would personally oversee preparations for observance of the 500th anniversary in 1983 of Luther's birth. **********Earlier this summer, East Germans witnessed the ceremonies for a new Protestant church and community center at Eisenhuttenstadt, a Communist-built industrial center, where religious services had been barred for nearly 30 years. At Potsdam last month, the war-damaged St. Nicholas Church was reconsecrated in the presence of Communist officials, Western diplomats and church leaders from East and West. **********''Our churches are experiencing a real construction boom,'' Klaus Gysi, the East German Secretary of State for Church Affairs, recently told a group of Western visitors. He said 21 churches and community centers were going up in new towns and housing developments, while about 30 historic landmarks throughout the country were undergoing renovation. **********The most notable of these structures is the cathedral built by Kaiser Wilhelm in the heart of East Berlin, a huge neo-Baroque edifice whose copper-plated dome overshadows the Parliament building across the street. **********''Every time I look out, I see the golden cross,'' said Herbert Fechner, a party official in Parliament. He and his colleagues can also watch worshippers and sightseers at all hours of the day entering a small side church, the baptismal chapel, that was the first part of the cathedral to be reopened this year. **********Church leaders have welcomed the Communists' new approach and the larger scope granted them, but they have also warned of continuing conflicts. **********''We have accepted our role as a church in a socialist country, but we will not become a socialist church,'' said the Rev. Rolf-Dieter Gunther, a spokesman for the Protestant clergy. He added that the church would abide by its independent role as a spiritual force. **********Most observers believe that the change in the official attitude reflects a desire to integrate the country's practicing Christians into East German society instead of letting them build up an opposition to the state. Originally the Communists in East Germany ignored or fought the churches, regarding them as superfluous or dangerous. **********Other officials said the new moves were aimed at winning over clergymen and believers for the East's anti-Western drive, in an attempt to influence West Germany through the close links that exist between the churches in the two Germanys. **********The Protestant Church, which with eight million members in a population of 17 million is the strongest religious group, has long opposed military indoctrination, especially the paramilitary training for boys and girls at the state-run primary and secondary schools. **********The Roman Catholic Church here, a relatively small group with 1.2 million members, has in general restricted itself to pastoral care, refraining from political involvement. But it too has profited from the new program, having just inaugurated a modern church and community center at the town of Neubrandenburg, north of Berlin. **********The new Protestant church at Eisenhuttenstadt, a city formerly known as Stalinstadt and founded in the early 1950's as a symbol of Communism, is seen as marking the most significant shift in official thinking. ''There is recognition that we are needed that makes us confident,'' said the Rev. Heinz Breuer, pastor of the new church.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.main_headline: ROTHSCHILDS AIM TO BUILD U.S. PRESENCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.print_headline: ROTHSCHILDS AIM TO BUILD U.S. PRESENCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.body_text: **********The British and French Rothschilds have joined banking forces in a move intended to build a stronger presence in the United States market, and an important part of their strategy is to attract the business of rich Americans. **********''We're franchising the Rothschild name,'' said Evelyn de Rothschild, 49-year-old chairman of N.M. Rothschild & Sons Ltd., the London merchant bank. His colleague is Baron Guy de Rothschild, 72, the retired chairman of Banque Rothschild of Paris. **********Both Baron Guy and Evelyn will be conducting presentations across the United States in an attempt to persuade wealthy Americans to let the Rothschilds manage their money. The large Jewish community in the United States is expected to be a major target. ''The Rothschild name must carry some weight in certain parts of the American community,'' Evelyn de Rothschild said in an interview yesterday. **********The New Court Securities Corporation is at the heart of the American strategy. New Court, formed in 1967, was owned primarily by the British and French Rothschilds, but minority interests were held by the Dutch merchant banking firm of Pierson, Heldring & Pierson and by members of New Court's management. Until the new strategy was adopted, New Court was managed independently of the Rothschilds. **********Now that has been changed. Baron Guy and Evelyn Rothschild, through their Swiss affiliate, Rothschild Bank A.G. of Zurich, have bought out the minority interests, and have named themselves vice chairmen. A Family Loyalist **********John P. Birkelund, chairman and chief executive officer, and Charles L. Lea Jr., managing director, have resigned. In addition, New Court Securities will be renamed to reflect its affiliation with the Rothschilds, according to Mr. de Rothschild. **********''They wanted a family loyalist to run this business,'' said Gilbert de Botton, who has been named president and chief executive officer of the American company. Mr. de Botton is that ''family loyalist.'' He had been director general of Rothschild Bank of Zurich, which was also started in 1968 and now has ''well over $2 billion'' in managed funds. **********To do business with the Zurich bank, clients need a minimum investment of $1 million. Asked whether the same minimum would apply in the United States, Mr. de Botton replied, ''I wouldn't want to discourage people by saying that.'' **********Among the services being considered is the establishment in the United States of a money market mutal fund managed by the Rothschilds. Real Estate Plans **********The reorganization, however, is more than a unit to attract the business of wealthy Americans. The Rothschilds see it as a vehicle through which they will channel their entire group's investments in the United States. **********They are especially eager to use the New York firm as a means of identifying and purchasing real estate in the United States for their global clientele. They have hired John D. McGurk, a real estate expert who had been with the Prudential Insurance Company, to head their real estate activities here. **********The New York company will be responsible for all the Rothschild group's investments in the United States. ''We're trying to build up an American team of experts,'' Mr. de Rothschild said. **********He added that the company would seek to expand the merger-andacquisition and venture capital businesses that were established by the firm's previous management. Mr. de Rothschild also said New Court currently managed about $1 billion in pension funds, and he said he would like to broaden that business as well. **********''The opportuities never cease to exist in America,'' Mr. de Rothschild said.
