https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/29/world.body_text: **********The Polish Government averted a strike in the city of Radom today. At the same time, it agreed to negotiate with Solidarity, the independent trade union movement, on demands for extensive television coverage of the union's first national congress next month. **********The one-hour strike in Radom was called off after a Government delegation met a deadline set by Solidarity and began talks on local grievances arising from the suppression of a workers' revolt there five years ago. **********But a 10-day-old printers' strike continued in the city of Olsztyn in defiance of Solidarity leaders.  The major development was an agreement that Solidarity and the Government would hold open talks in Warsaw tomorrow on the question of how the congress, starting next week, would be reported in the news media. The union issued a new warning that it would ban Polish television from the congress if the coverage was not adequate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/25/world.main_headline: BONN IS NOW HELD UNLIKELY TO SELL ARMS TO SAUDI ARABIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/25/world.print_headline: BONN IS NOW HELD UNLIKELY TO SELL ARMS TO SAUDI ARABIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/25/world.body_text: **********BONN. Sept. 24 - The West German Government has effectively dropped consideration of a Saudi Arabian order for advanced weapon systems, including the Leopard 2 tank, an authoritative source said today. **********The source, who requested anonymity, said the deal had insufficient backing in both the parties of the West German Government coalition, the Social Democrats and the Free Democrats. **********The Government, he said, is facing a battle over the deployment of new middle-range nuclear missiles in West Germany and feels that it would be squandering its strength to attempt to deal with a second major issue involving arms, international security and emotional public debate. **********''It has been obvious for a while that the momentum is not there, ''the source said. ''Now the problem is explaining it to the Saudis.'' **********In a debate that had some parallels with the discussion in the United States over the sale of radar planes to Saudi Arabia, a number of West German officials and businessmen have said that to deny the Saudi request would have disastrous effects on relations between the two countries. Opponents Cite Prestige Aspect **********Opponents to the deal said the request involved more prestige than actual military considerations and that excellent relations in the past had not been based on arms sales. Many West Germans felt that the weapons might be used against Israel and against survivors of the Nazis' persecution of the Jews. **********The exact Saudi requirements were never made public, but West German Government sources said they included hundreds of Leopard 2 tanks, Gepard antiaircraft vehicles and Marder armored vehicles. **********The advanced Leopard tanks are considered difficult to master even by the most experienced tank crews. The Gepards would have provided the Saudis with mobile antiaircraft protection. **********Chancellor Helmut Schmidt was in favor of the deal, but opposition within Parliament was such that he was forced to tell the Saudis during a visit to Riyadh in April that it was ''not feasible'' for Bonn to modify its ban on arms sales to Middle Eastern countries. Stricter Rules Expected **********At that time, Mr. Schmidt said there would be a review of arms sales policy. An associate of the Chancellor, talking with a reporter on the Chancellor's plane returning from Saudi Arabia, said: ''The deal is not foreclosed. It is in an intermediate phase.'' **********The authoritative source who reported that the Government would no longer press for the sale said the guidelines growing out of the current review were likely to be stricter than those now in effect.  The present rules bar arms sales to countries in ''crisis zones.'' **********The decision means, he said, that West Germany will have to be particularly restrictive in its actions to continue to appear evenhanded. It is possible, he continued, that either Britain or France, which have sold weapons to Saudi Arabia in the past, will be able to step in. **********One of the reasons for the Saudis' interest in West German weapons was said to be a desire to avoid dependence on the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/12/world.main_headline: SCHMIDT OPENS PARLEY IN EAST GERMANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/12/world.print_headline: SCHMIDT OPENS PARLEY IN EAST GERMANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/12/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Erich Honecker, the East German Communist Party leader, met in a hunting lodge near here today for the first fullscale talks between leaders of their countries in more than a decade. **********The conversations, involving five meetings over three days, are expected to produce little in the way of concrete developments. West German officials hoped, however, that the talks would improve relations, and both leaders have investments in the effect of the talks on domestic public opinion. **********Mr. Schmidt and Mr. Honecker seemed intent on providing a positive ambiance when the Chancellor's plane arrived at Schonefeld just outside East Berlin. Mr. Honecker, normally a dour man, grinned for photographers, and Mr. Schmidt joked, telling reporters to ''hurry up, we won't get any prettier.'' **********Later, as the two men posed for pictures at the Hubertusstock hunting lodge, north of Berlin, the Chancellor said, ''You can't force us to move closer together. We're no loving couple.'' Schmidt Tries to Allay Fears **********After the first round of talks, an official accompanying the Chancellor said that they were proceeding ''in a very relaxed fashion.'' The official said the Chancellor considered the talks as serving the cause of peace in Europe. **********The emphasis on the word Europe - it was used three times in a short press briefing tonight - seemed to indicate that Mr. Schmidt was concerned that his European allies might be worried about what the two German leaders could be discussing in private. **********Mr. Schmidt and Mr. Honecker have met briefly twice before, at the signing of the Helsinki accords in 1975 and in 1980 at the funeral of Marshal Tito, but the discussions here were the first official encounters between leaders of the two Germanys since 1970. **********The Chancellor and the East German party chief, who is also Chairman of the Council of State, scheduled meetings last year, but they were postponed, first because of the worsened international climate after the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, and then when tensions developed in Poland over the Solidarity trade union movement. **********Now the visit brings Mr. Schmidt the advantage of appearing to have continually sought an East-West dialogue. Barriers to Travel a Topic **********For Mr. Honecker, the visit strengthens his position at home. But he was also likely to use the occasion, with the aid of live television coverage to West Germany, to continue his Government's portrayal of the United States as the main cause of world tension. **********The East German spokesman, Wolfgang Meyer, gave a hint of this in a television interview tonight when he said ''that the question of securing peace is at the center of the talks, which have great political importance.'' **********Mr. Schmidt's main interest, aside from the effect on internal West German politics, was regarded as attempting to reduce some of the barriers the East Germans have erected to slow the pace of visits by West Germans. **********Mr. Schmidt could not expect to soften the stringent East German controls governing travel by citizens here, but he was likely to argue for some reductions in the monetary exchange requirements affecting West Germans that were instituted last year. **********The key point of economic interest for Mr. Honecker is in gaining continuation of interest-free West German credit arrangements of up to $400 million a year. The agreement runs out at the end of December and there have been reports that the West German central bank would not finance the credit, used for the purchase of West German goods. **********Before leaving West Germany, Mr. Schmidt said he doubted that agreements of any kind could be signed during his visit here.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/26/world.body_text: **********A leading opponent of the Sandinist revolutionary Government in Nicaragua, Alfonso Robelo Callejas, said today that the Sandinist Party is seeking to push Nicaragua ''toward a Communist, totalitarian regimen'' but urged the United States to continue sending financial aid to private groups in his country. **********Mr. Robelo, who last year quit the ruling junta formed after the dictator Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle was ousted, spoke in Caracas after attending a symposium sponsored by Christian Democrats here. **********''There is still a struggle in Nicaragua between forces that want a democracy and those trying to turn the country toward a Communist, totalitarian regime,'' Mr. Robelo, a businessman, said. ''The United States Government should continue trying to aid the Nicaraguan people, and should be creative in looking for channels parallel to the Sandinist Government, such as cooperatives and other privatesector groups.'' Control of Press Denounced **********Mr. Robelo, who was jailed by the Somoza regime for his political activities, also denounced the Sandinist Government's control of the press and what he called its oppressive attitude toward any political opponents. **********He also said that about 5,000 Cubans had been sent to Nicaragua. He said that some 1,200 of these were teachers, 250 doctors and 300 to 400 specialized construction workers. The remainder, he said, work with the Sandinist army and security forces and in communications and agrarian reform. **********''The main goal of the Sandinist Front is the consolidation of its military power,'' he said. ''They're playing with the same kind of system that Somoza had: power through arms. We can see this very clearly when a country of 2.5 million has an army of 40,000 and a militia of about 100,000 persons.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/01/busin.main_headline: U.S. TAX LOSSES ON SAVER NOTES COULD BE HIGH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/01/busin.print_headline: U.S. TAX LOSSES ON SAVER NOTES COULD BE HIGH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/01/busin.body_text: **********The new, eagerly promoted tax-exempt savings certificates go on sale today amid predictions that they will attract far more funds than originally expected. This would mean a substantially higher tax loss to the Government than it initially believed. **********Commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations are competing vigorously in offering the new tax-exempt certificates, which come in denominations as low as $500. Many banks are adding staff or extending their hours, and heavy advertising campaigns are common. Credit unions also are offering the certificates. **********Each person who buys the one-year certificates, sometimes referred to as ''all-savers certificates,'' may exempt up to $1,000 of the interest from Federal income taxes. Married couples filing joint tax returns may exempt up to $2,000. **********Viewed as Tax Shelter **********''Many people see this as a tax shelter for the little guy, so there should be a lot of interest,'' said Oscar S. Pollock, a partner at Ingalls & Snyder, a brokerage firm. ''The revenue losses in the budget have been drastically underestimated.'' **********Although Government officials originally felt that $65 billion or $70 billion might go into the tax-exempt certificates, costing the Treasury about $3 billion in forgone tax revenues, many analysts now say that investors could put in $200 billion or more, which would mean $10 billion of forgone tax revenues. **********The certificates are authorized by the 1981 tax law, though they were added by Congress, not proposed by the Reagan Administration. It is generally agreed that the tax-exempt certificates will help savings institutions but will not succeed in drawing substantial new sums into the housing market, which was one goal of the program.  This is because savings institutions might invest the new funds in short-term money market instruments rather than long-term home mortgages. A Matter of Timing **********Initially the savings certificates will offer a yield of 12.61 percent, or $126.10 for every $1,000. Although savings institutions say they expect an influx of customers today, the first day's response may be slowed by the fact that if savers wait until tomorrow they can tell whether the certificates will offer a higher yield if not bought until next week. **********The certificates are mainly expected to draw money out of investments where income is taxable, such as certificates of deposit, money market funds, stocks and bonds. The new certificates may be bought at any time during the next 15 months. ''I think there will be a real surge,'' said Timothy J. Howard, vice president and senior financial economist at the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco. ''For anyone in a marginal tax bracket of about 35 percent or higher, the certificates offer a greater after-tax return than money market funds, six-month money-market certificates and 30-month certificates of deposit.'' **********The new certificates have received a strong lift from wide advertising by banks and other financial institutions competing to attract new money. For them, the interest they pay on the certificates will be appreciably less costly than the rates on many of the other deposits they already hold. **********The rates on the certificates are set at 70 percent of the yield on new one-year Treasury bills at the most recent monthly auction. The interest rate on a certificate will remain constant for the one-year term of the certificate, but every month the rate available on newly issued certif icates will change. **********Certificates that go on sale today will offer the 12.61 percent yield. That rate will be for certificates sold only this week, and it remains uncertain whether the new rate next week will be higher or lower. Treasury Auction Awaited **********The rate on certificates sold for the four weeks beginning Monday will be based on this afternoon's Treasury auction of one-year bills. The rate beginning Monday will be higher than the one available this week if the discount rate on one-year bills auctioned this afternoon exceeds 15.056 percent, which would amount to a yield of 18.06 percent. (The yield on a security is higher than its rate of interest, since the yield includes interest payments that are reinvested at the same rate for the entire period.) **********Financial a nalysts said yesterday that they thought the new rate would probabl y be lower, since one-year bills were trading in the market yester day afternoon at a rate of about 14.66 percent. If oneyear bills were issued at a discount rate of 14.66, the new certificates would yield about 12.21 percent. **********If the rates for next month are to be lower, investors will still have a day or two to buy certificates at the 12.61 percent yield.  Whether higher yields will be available in later months depends entirely on the future course of interest rates, a matter of considerable debate among professional economists and financial experts. Outlook for Interest Rates **********Some economists, including those advising the Reagan Administration, expect interest rates to fall in the coming months.  Others, however, predict that rates will go higher sometime within the 15-month period during which the certificates will be available. **********Sanford I. Weill, chairman of Shearson/American Express Inc., said he planned to buy certificates at the 12.61 yield. ''I believe that the President's program is going to work and that rates are going to come down,'' he said. **********''Rates are at historically high levels now,'' noted Timothy J.  Howard, senior financial economist at the Wells Fargo Bank. ''If you can live with the present rate for investment purposes, buying now would not be a bad idea. But if you feel that one-year Treasury bills are going to go above 15 percent, you might want to hold off.'' **********At least one bank, Citibank, plans to tell its customers that if the new rate beginning Monday turns out to be higher than 12.61 percent, their money will be placed at the higher rate, even if the bank gets it before Monday. **********Although interest from the new certificates (up to $1,000 or $2,000) is exempt from Federal income tax, investors should also consider whether the interest is subject to state or local tax. That varies from state to state. In New York and Connecticut, for example, the certificates will not be subject to a state tax, while in New Jersey they will be. Various Buying Patterns **********Financial advisers point out that people who do not have $8,000 or $16,000 to invest in certificates all at once could buy less than that amount or could plan to buy smaller certificates throughout the 15-month period. And they say that people who are not prepared to tie up their money for a whole year or whose top tax bracket is not 30 percent or higher should not buy the certificates at all. **********''The penalties for early withdrawal are horrendous,'' said Sheldon Chaiken, director of the financial services group at Paine Webber Jackson & Curtis, a brokerage firm. ''You forfeit the tax exemption and have to pay a penalty of three months' interest as well.'' **********Despite such penalties, the certificates are expected to attract hundreds of billions of dollars. Earlier this year, when the tax bill was considered in Congress, Federal analysts estimated that $65 billion to $70 billion would be invested in the certificates, at a cost to the Treasury of about $3 billion in forgone tax revenues. **********Many economists now predict that $200 billion or more could flow into the certificates, which could cost the Treasury more than $10 billion in forgone revenues. Data Resources Inc., the economic research firm has concluded, for example, that $237 billion will be placed in the certificates. Its figure is representative of other projections as well. 'An Unusual Situation' **********Of course, no one knows for sure how many people will buy certificates. ''I'm not even sure that an econometric model will be very worthwhile, since this is such an unusual situation'' said Alfred P. Johnson, chief economist for the Investment Company Institute, a trade group for the mutual fund industry. **********There are several reasons for the hi gher es timates. For one thing, the rates on the certificates will be somewha t higher than originallyanticipated. When Congress granted the tax ex emption, it was widely assumed that the certificates would pay 70 pe rcent of the coupon rate on one-year Treasury bills. Instead, Fed eral regulators set the return on the certificates equal to 70 percen t of the total yield, a somewhat higher figure. **********Another reason for the higher estimates now is that the tax exemption on the certificates appears to have captured the imagination of the American public. While most experts advise that people in tax brackets below 30 percent can earn higher after-tax returns in other kinds of investments, many people in lower tax brackets may purchase certificates anyway. Government revenue estimators did not count on such purchases. Big Marketi ng Push **********Finally, enthusiasm has been fanned by heavy marketing and advertising efforts. Even institutions such as brokerage firms and mutual funds that are expected to lose money to the certificates are preparing to help customers buy the certificates. Paine Webber, E.F.  Hutton, Shearson and Merrill Lynch are among the Wall Street firms planning to help interested customers move their money into the new certificates if the customer seems ready to do it. The Fidelity Management and Research Company, which manages a family of mutual funds, plans a similar service. How actively the firms market this service will depend partly on whether they are permitted to accept finders' fees from the banks. **********Even without all this help, banks and other financial institutions anticipate heavy demand for the certificates.  Despite the prospect of heavy traffic, financial experts expect relatively little disruption in the financial markets. Money fund managers, for example, expect to be able to handle withdrawals out of their normal cash flow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/03/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Ways to Select A Money Fund
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/03/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Ways to Select A Money Fund
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/03/busin.body_text: **********MONEY market funds confuse many investors who find it difficult to choose among them. The selection process is usually a question of picking a fund for the highest yield. But at a time when the funds are growing almost too fast to keep up with new business, many investors simply settle for one with an open telephone line. **********Denis Jamison, a vice president of the $700 million Lexington Management Corporation and the Englewood, N.J., management company's money fund specialist, believes it essential that the investor look beyond high yields and ready accessibility in picking a fund. **********Before he went to Lexington, he managed the Value Line Cash Fund and produced the highest yield for a money fund in 1980. **********In selecting a fund, Mr. Jamison said, the investor should examine the fund's holdings and should be comfortable with its portfolio. He added, as an example, that some timid investors were more comfortable with money funds that invest in United States Government securities only. But the investor should realize that this timidity would cost a substantial yield, he stressed. **********''A number of money funds investing in commercial paper and Eurodollar deposits currently offer 17 1/2 percent to 18 percent yields compared with 16 percent to 16 1/2 percent for funds buying only U.S. Governments,'' he added. ''In my opinion, the difference in risk is minimal.'' He argued that most fund managers were highly professional - fully capable of evaluating the creditworthiness of the securities they buy. **********In Mr. Jamison's view, the key risk is in illiquid money funds - those with unusually long average maturities. On one or two occasions, when interest rates have spurted, funds holding securities with maturities in excess of 60 days have suffered. Under those circumstances, he said, the dollar value of the money fund can be jeopardized. That is, prices of securities outstanding drop until their yields equal those offered by new securities of similar quality. **********Investors have not lost money even so. Mr. Jamison noted that when a Chicago-based fund called Institutional Liquid Assets was caught in such a bind some time ago investors began withdrawing funds heavily, but its managers shored it up with their own capital. The result was that those redeeming shares were paid at face amounts. **********Mr. Jamison believes that money fund managers have learned an important lesson from that near disaster and that the risk of similar episodes has been minimized. He said that the maturity of money funds generally now averaged less than 30 days and this suggested to him that the money funds were liquid enough to meet any and all redemptions - even if interest rates rose suddenly. **********On the other hand, when interest rates plunge, those money funds with relatively long maturities can, for a time, provide higher yields than short-maturity money funds - until existing holdings become due. But, Mr. Jamison said, a sudden drop in interest rates ''creates no risk'' to funds with short maturities even though their yields drop faster. This is because wholesale redemptions, should they develop, can be met with funds produced as the short-term securities mature, he added. **********Mr. Jamison spoke of another jarring event -fluctuating yields.  These result from an accounting practice called ''marking to market,'' he said. That is, each day the fund's manager prices certain securities - those in the portfolio maturing in 60 days or more - at current market values. In a period of fluctuating interest rates, the holder of shares in such money funds finds that yields fluctuate, too, and widely. **********On the other hand, some sophisticated purchasers of money fund shares are now switching into funds that mark to market during periods of falling interest rates. In such periods, the prices of the securities in the mark-to-market funds will rise and produce capital gains. While these gains are unrealized, the mark-to-market funds credit them immediately to shareholder accounts and this adds to yields. By contrast, funds carrying their portfolios at cost do not write up the value of holdings in such periods and therefore have no extras to credit. **********Anyone who is distressed by the fluctuations in yields in such money funds may prefer money funds that carry all securities at cost less amortization, Mr. Jamison said. **********Mr. Jamison offered some general words of advice. ''First,'' he said, ''examine the money fund's yield over an extended period of time - preferably for a year or more. How consistent has it been in comparison with other funds?'' Short-term and long-term performances of most money market funds are listed in ''William E. Donoghue's Complete Money Market Guide,'' published by Harper & Row. **********''Second,'' Mr. Jamison added, ''note the fees the manager charges; the range is 30 to 50 basis points.'' (A basis point is one onehundredth of a percentage point.) ''If the manager charges a high fee and gives extra services, well and good; but make sure the high-fee manager doesn't buy speculative securities to keep up with the other money funds.'' **********''Third,'' he concluded, ''examine the services the fund offers.  Can the investor move to another fund quickly when the investment climate dictates a move? Most important, can you get someone in authority on the telephone and get sound advice when you need guidance?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/world.body_text: **********President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France said tonight that jewels given him by Jean-Bedel Bokassa, the former leader of the Central African Republic, had been sold and the money given to charities in the African nation. **********Mr. Giscard d'Estaing said the jewels could hardly be described as diamonds. **********''They were not big stones,'' he said, ''only something that could be used as a decoration or as jewelery.'' **********Mr. Giscard d'Estaing, who was speaking in the first television interview of his campaign for re-election, went into greater detail on the subject of the diamonds than on any previous occasion. **********The French weekly Le Canard Enchaine broke the story of the diamonds in October 1979 when it published documents purporting to prove that Mr. Giscard d'Estaing had received diamonds from Mr.  Bokassa, who proclaimed himself Emperor Bokassa I and who was deposed in September 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/19/busin.body_text: **********A heterodyne detection system that enhances faraway images, such as those transmitted by television or radar, was patented this week by researchers for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology at its Lincoln, Mass., laboratory. **********Richard J. Becherer and Wilfrid B.  Veldkamp were granted patent 4,305,666. **********The images are made clearer by superimposing reference patterns from known sources. Thus, if a picture of a distant helicopter landing strip is not clear, it can be enhanced with the aid of a previously recorded view. The invention is thought to have primarily military applications, but it may also be useful in chemical analysis with the aid of an optical instrument called a spectroscope.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/23/busin.body_text: **********The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation said it will sign a cross-licensing technology agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation, probably in Tokyo next month. **********An agreement was recently reached after a year of talks. **********The proposed five-year agreement would allow both sides to use each other's patents on electronic switching systems, computers and terminal equipment free of charge, Nippon said. **********The agreement would also call for I.B.M. to provide Nippon with the right to have other manufacturers produce equipment using I.B.M.  patents because Nippon Telegraph has no manufacturing division. **********Industry sources said I.B.M. had been interested in advanced Nippon telephone and telecommunications technology, but that has not become part of the agreement. **********Nippon also said it was negotiating with the Western Electric Corporation of the United States on renewing a technology exchange agreement that expired in May. **********Under strong United States pressure, Nippon last January allowed foreign companies to bid in its procurements for telecommunications equipment and to participate in the research and development of new equipment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/20/busin.body_text: **********Ontario Hydro, Ontario's big provincially owned electric utility, said yesterday that it had received permission from the Canadian Government to sharply increase its electric power exports to utilities in the United States over the next decade. **********Potential customers for the increased power exports were not identified, by Ontario Hydro currently exports to several Middle West states and has load-sharing agreements with several East Coast utilities. **********Under the new guidelines, Canada's National Energy Board said the utility could supply up to 20 billion kilowatt-hours in any consecutive 12-month period from July 1 this year to Dec. 31, 1983, and as many as 25 billion kilowatt-hours in any later 12-month period through June 30, 1991. **********The utility is currently permitted to export no more than 15 billion kilowatt-hours a year.  Other provincial utilities, including Quebec Hydro, also plan to increase power exports to the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/09/world.body_text: **********The issue of racism is again creating serious strains within the Commonwealth, that fragile but enduring association of countries that once made up the British Empire. **********The new crisis, which is considered one of the most serious of the last decade, has arisen over a tour of New Zealand by the Springbok rugby team, South Africa's national squad. South Africa was expelled from the Commonwealth in 1961 because of its policy of apartheid, or separation of the races. **********Rebuffed in its demand that the tour be canceled, the Commonwealth has retaliated by shifting a meeting of its finance ministers next month from Auckland, the largest city in New Zealand, to the Bahamas. **********Robert D. Muldoon, New Zealand's Prime Minister, says the dispute threatens the future of the Commonwealth, which is one of the few world organizations promoting frequent, informal contacts between the industrialized North and the developing South. The issue is sure to be passionately debated when Commonwealth heads of government meet in Melbourne, Australia, in October. Two Matches Canceled **********The New Zealand matches are part of a world tour by the Springbok team that will include games in the United States in September.  Mayor Koch, who had approved plans for the Springboks to play a game on Randalls Island next month, reversed himself yesterday and ordered the game canceled. **********Demonstrations, some of them surprisingly violent for the usually placid island nation in the South Pacific, have accompanied the Springbok stops in New Zealand. The second of 16 matches, which was to have been played in Hamilton, was called off when 300 people opposed to apartheid occupied the field and could not be moved.  Another contest, scheduled for Aug. 19, was canceled well in advance. **********Retired members of the police force have been recalled to duty and special constables have been appointed in an effort to maintain peace in the streets and on the playing fields. More than 4,000 of the country's 5,000 policemen are involved in coping with the situation. **********The dispute illustrates the deep divisions within the Commonwealth, which is united only by a shared history and a common language.  For the black and brown nations that form a large majority of the Commonwealth's 44 members, the isolation of South Africa is the central political goal, almost a crusade, especially now that Zimbabwe, formerly Rhodesia, does not have a white regime. For several members of what is euphemistically called the Old Commonwealth, meaning the predominantly white nations, the abuses of human rights and democratic traditions in many black member countries are of equal significance. An Agreement on a Boycott **********In 1977 the Commonwealth countries agreed at a conference in Scotland to a voluntary athletic boycott of South Africa. In a document known as the Gleneagles Agreement, they said it was ''the urgent duty of each government vigorously to combat the evil of apartheid by withholding any form of support for, and taking every practical step to discourage, sporting contacts with South Africa.'' New Zealand signed the agreement, but only after insisting that it would not undertake to dictate to athletes in New Zealand. **********From the beginning, Mr. Muldoon has insisted that he did not approve of the tour and said he would like to ''get shot of it.'' The Prime Minister made four attempts to persuade the New Zealand Rugby Union to call off the tour, urging it at various times ''to reconsider,'' to ''think again'' and to ''weigh the consequences.'' But the Government never formally called upon the union to cancel the tour, and it decided, in keeping with its standing policy, not to refuse visas to the Springboks, as other Commonwealth nations have done. **********Mr. Muldoon said, ''To take from our sportsmen and our sporting bodies the right to make their own final decision on whom they would play against, or with whom they would play, would be to take from them a freedom which they have always had and which is just one of many freedoms which the citizens of a civilized country should enjoy.'' Criticism for Muldoon **********Sir Shridath Ramphal of Guyana, the Commonwealth's Secretary General, concedes that the Gleneagles Agreement does not require New Zealand to deny visas to the South Africans. But he argues that its decision to grant the visas imposed on Mr. Muldoon a duty to fulfill his obligations under the agreement by other means. **********''Gleneagles left it to each government to find and employ its own means of discouragement, and it held out the assurance of success,'' Sir Shridath wrote in an article in The Times of London. ''The question is not one of interpretation, it is one of performance, and it is one on which many Commonwealth countries are less than satisfied.'' **********Mr. Muldoon, the conservative leader of perhaps the most conservative major Commonwealth nation, is loath to be dictated to by New Commonwealth leaders, some of whom he has called ''gangsters.'' He attacked Sir Shridath this week, asserting that the Guyanese leader was so committed to the views of black nations that ''no argument of principle will override that allegiance.'' He accused the Secretary General of ''hypocritical platitudes and downright mis-statements.'' **********His opponents in New Zealand accuse the Prime Minister of acting as he has done for domestic political reasons rather than on principle.  They note, for example, that New Zealand refused entry to a group of Rhodesian golfers in 1976 and a group from Taiwan in 1977.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/27/world.main_headline: INFLATION MAKES ARGENTINES GAMBLERS IN RISKY GAME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/27/world.print_headline: INFLATION MAKES ARGENTINES GAMBLERS IN RISKY GAME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/27/world.body_text: **********People the world over are trying to cope with inflation. And then there are Argentines.  In the last 30 years many countries have risen and fallen in the inflation ranks, but Argentina has remained near the top. The rate of increase in consumer prices peaked at nearly 450 percent in 1976.  Last year, it was under 90 percent, and some Government officials crowed success. But this year many economists expect the rate to shoot back up. **********Inflation has contributed to a cost of living that the State Department ranks second only to Japan's. The daily newspaper costs 60 cents. A cup of coffee in an ordinary coffee shop costs $1. Rents for a two-bedroom apartment in areas equivalent to Manhattan's Upper East and West Sides begin at $2,000 a month. **********The causes are lost in mounds of statistics and competing economic theories. The effects are found in jammed stores and crowded psychiatrists' offices, in a national cynicism and - sometimes - individual sadness that has helped replace the country's reputation for gaiety. Fast Money and Hard Luck **********''For 10 years we have have been told things will get better,'' said Alberto Piro as he arranged the fruits and vegetables in his small shop. ''Now we are just waiting for better times.'' **********In the meantime, Argentines have turned to ingenuity, creating a country of speculators and moonlighters, of fast money and hard luck.  Playing the interest rates has become a national pastime.Thirtyday savings certificates - and no one commits his money for longer - pay interest at an annual rate of about 100 percent. **********People punching pocket calculators stand outside bank windows daily, studying the day's posted rates. In the last year more than 40 small banks and financial houses have collapsed in the wheeling and dealing. While rumors that a place is about to fold lead most people to start a run on the institution, the more daring increase their deposits, hoping to reap higher rates and be saved by Government guarantees on deposits. **********But then consumers pay even more for mortgages, automobile loans and the like. Interest is usually indexed to inflation, so buying on credit is an adventure into the unknown on payments. A Scheme With a Flaw **********Interest rates are so high that American bankers here are courted by Argentines wanting loans of several million dollars, which they convert to pesos and deposit in local banks, often earning enough interest in a month to pay back the loan and make a handsome profit. **********The scheme works so long as the interest rate outstrips devaluations. In the last two months, however, the Government has devalued the peso 40 percent. Some instant millionaires have become instant paupers, although most anticipated the devaluation and created a run on foreign reserves by switching into dollars, marks, yen and gold. **********The speculation has helped create a large class of nouveaux riches who have turned this city's stately old neighborhood of Barrio Norte into canyons of high-rises and choking auto fumes. **********The wealthy, new and old, hedge in the Argentine tradition of sending money to Zurich and buying land - or at least apartments - in Punta del Este, Miami and New York as well as here. 'Horror' Story About Maids **********But there are also losers, even among the rich. One matronly dowager who was approached in a food market complained bitterly.  Before, she had two live-in maids. Now she has only one maid come twice a week. ''A horror,'' she said. **********Picking among the onions and apples at Mr. Piro's shop, Mary Rollinson, an American who lives here, said, ''Many people here are putting on a show of living well even though they are on the verge of bankruptcy and cannot pay the rent.'' **********The Economics Ministry says real income has risen over the last several years. Certainly many Argentines from bankers to plumbers have done well. Many have salaries indexed to the inflation rate, and many people who set their own fees, such as doctors and carpenters, charge almost at will. Having a baby, for example, costs $5,000 in private medical and hospital fees. **********It is this new middle class that hedges in the panoply of imported appliances such as juicers and color televisions that have been flooding stores. The military Government has been dropping import tariffs in the hope that the competition of cheaper and better imported goods would cut prices on domestic goods. **********Factory workers, who have benefitted from erratic past protectionist policies, are thus less fortunate this time around.  Their companies are strapped by the competition and the interest rates on loans. Some have closed, and even the military fears workers' reaction. **********In February, the Institute of Economic Investigation of the University of Buenos Aires surveyed 300 major factories in the capital area and found that it takes workers longer to earn the price of such basic items as bread and milk than it did a year ago. Wine was one of the few items to be cheaper in terms of working time. **********Argentina, nonetheless, is a primarily middle-class country that still enjoys the highest standard of living in Latin America.  Unskilled laborers in the survey earned up to $8,700 a year, while skilled workers earned $4,000 to $15,000 and their plant supervisors earned up to $28,000. The Retired Suffer the Most **********This middle class gambles, too. Some laid-off factory workers have reportedly bought cement and wood, held them, then sold them after the price rose, which is usually within a month. **********The majority, however, appear to do as Mr. Piro does. His Falcon is 11 years old, and he has put off buying the color television and new refrigerator he would like. **********The retired suffer the most. Two weeks ago, the military Government decreed a quarterly increase of 16 percent for all pensioners. Buenos Aires municipal taxes will rise 150 percent this year. The Economics Ministry has ordered an increase of over 15 percent in all utility charges over the next three months. **********But storekeepers cannot so easily multiply their prices. ''You cannot raise your prices too much,'' Jose Maria Llama, a butcher, said. ''People get scared and do not buy.'' **********The pressures have contributed to what many psychiatrists and psychologists say is an explosion in recent years in the number of people who seek their help. **********''You do not learn to live with the inflation,'' the owner of a fabric shop said. ''You learn how to adapt to live with the constant economic anxiety.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/05/busin.body_text: **********The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had begun construction of a coal mine in the Powder River Basin near Gillette, Wyo., marking the oil company's first venture in the coal mining business. **********The start of construction was cleared on Tuesday by the issuance of the last of more than 24 Federal and state authorizations, it said.  Production at the 5,815-acre site, called the Rojo Caballos Mine, is scheduled to begin in January 1983.  The mine is designed to produce 6 million tons a year at the outset, and could be expanded to 15 million tons a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.body_text: **********Many large corporations plan to increase their philanthropy next year, but corporate executives say that business cannot replace the billions of dollars that will be cut from the Federal budget for education, social welfare and the arts, according to a survey and interviews with business leaders. **********President Reagan has been urging businesses to give more money as the Federal Government reduces its own role. He has told company and foundation officials at the White House that the private sector can offer alternatives to solving social problems that are more creative, more efficient and less expensive than those provided by the Government. He has also set up a Presidential study group headed by William Verity, chairman of Armco Steel, to promote private initiatives. **********Sixty percent of the 400 corporations that responded to a survey taken this fall by the Conference Board, a business research organization, said they planned to increase their philanthropy next year. Two-thirds of the companies that anticipate increasing donations are among the nation's 1,300 largest industrial concerns, a group that historically has provided the major share of corporate giving. Six percent said they would reduce contributions and the rest anticipated no change. Reagan's View Is Disputed **********At the same time, however, 63 percent of those who responded to the survey said they did not agree with the Reagan Administration's perception of the ability of the business community to replace Government-financed programs. **********''There is no corporate monolith and companies, like cereal boxes, come in different sizes,'' said Anne Klepper, senior research associate at the Conference Board. She added that the responses clearly indicated that business could not fill the gap and that expectations were unreal. Corporations, she said, direct their philanthropic programs to areas where they have business operations, whereas the Government's focus is national. **********The upward trend in corporate contributions by large and mediumsized companies, as well as individual giving, is also showing up in the response to the 2,100 fund-raising campaigns currently being conducted across the country by United Way, according to William Aramony, president of United Way of America. Last year, $1.5 billion was raised. **********These developments were welcomed by Brian O'Connell, president of the Independent Sector, a Washington-based coalition of foundations, nonprofit organizations and corporations committed to pilanthropy.  But he cautioned against excessive optimism that resources from the private sector could compensate for the huge cutbacks in Government support for the country's 300,000 nonprofit groups. These include universities, community associations helping the poor and disabled, and a broad spectrum of cultural organizations. **********''Even with this growth, we should not give the impression to nonprofit organizations and to the people they serve that the gap will be filled,'' he said. **********He said that the current estimate of direct losses to the nonprofit organizations was $20 billion over the next three years.  Corporations represent a growing but relatively small share of philanthropy. Corporate giving last year totaled $2.7 billion.  Foundations provided $2.4 billion. The major share of philanthropy, as usual, came from individual donors who last year contributed $39.9 billion, most of it for religious organizations. **********Many corporate executives in interviews said they expected to see companies increase their contributions, but underscored that the response of the business sector would depend on the country's economic situation. **********''It is not realistic in these days of lagging productivity, cost inflation and earnings pressure to expect that shareholders generally would accept large increases in corporate contributions,'' said Walter A. Fallon, chairman of the Eastman Kodak Corporation. The company said it expected to make a ''moderate'' increase in giving. **********For the next year or two, nonprofit organizations are likely to have to retrench, merge or go out of business, said Alex J. Plinio, vice president of corporate contributions at the Prudential Insurance Company. Budget Cut a Small Factor **********The planned increases in corporate giving were attributed only in small part to the budget reductions or the President's appeals to business leaders. The Conference Board survey showed that only 15 companies said they were expanding giving in response to the budget situation. **********The rate of increases planned by a number of the larger contributors would barely outpace inflation.  Exxon, the country's top corporate contributor, expects its donations to rise to more than $50 million in 1982, up from $45 million this year, said Richard F. Neblett, contributions coordinator. **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its affiliates in the Bell System expect contributions this year to be about $45 million and to approach $50 million in 1982, according to Robert Thill, secretary of contributions. He said the rise reflected increased recognition of the nonprofit groups' substantial needs that ''are coming home to us more forcefully only in the last few years,'' adding that the reduction in Government support had increased significantly the demands for corporate aid. **********William A. Orme, secretary of the General Electric Foundation, agreed, and calculated that requests for grants were arriving at a rate of one every 26 seconds and posing problems for executives who wanted to deal responsibly with them and not ''merely shuffle papers.'' Contributions next year were expected to go up to $19.5 million, a 50 percent rise. **********Atlantic Richfield, another major donor, has raised contributions to more than $34 million, the major share channeled through its company foundation. Among others, United States Steel, Westinghouse Electric, International Business Machines and Standard Oil (Indiana) plan to increase grants substantially. **********The response to the United Way campaigns from business and individuals is running particularly strong in the West, Southwest and Northeast, according to campaign officials. They said that cities with high unemployment rates were watched anxiously but that Detroit was expected to exceed its $42 million goal and that Cleveland was ahead of last year's record. **********The impact of the Federal budget cuts was an underlying theme at the 1981 National Conference on Philanthropy held recently in Minneapolis by the Independent Sector. **********John H. Filer, chairman of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, counseled nonprofit organizations against believing that the Reagan Administration was ''dumping'' all social problems on the private sector and making it a scapegoat for future social disarray. The Federal Government wants a partnership with the private sector, he maintained. **********But the optimism expressed by some conference participants about the future for nonprofit groups appeared troubling to others.  ''What I sense lacking is a sense of urgency,'' said Eleanor P.  Petersen, president of Chicago's Donor's Forum, adding, ''Sure, organizations are in trouble but it is really people who are in trouble, the disadvantaged, children, women and minorities. The pain out there is terrible and it is not getting through to them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/busin.body_text: **********Portugal's Government clamped down today on spending in an effort to contain its budget deficit. **********The new budget will limit spending in nonessential areas, streamline the governmental structure and try to improve productivity in all departments by 3 percent. Some taxes are going up. **********Despite these austerity measures, the Government expects the budget deficit to widen to $2.9 billion in 1982 from this year's projected deficit of $2.6 billion. **********But Alipio Dias, the budget secretary, said in an interview that the 1982 deficit, after adjustment for inflation, would actually be smaller.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/04/busin.body_text: **********Frank Dell'Aglio, whose involvement proved the kiss of death to two ad agencies, faces up to five years in prison after pleading guilty to a Federal grand jury information that had charged him with wire fraud. **********The case was heard last Thursday by Federal District Judge Lawrence A. Whipple in Newark and concerned the purchase of Riedl Associates by Everest Industries, which Mr. Dell'Aglio headed. **********In 1978, Riedl went bankrupt, as did Meltzer, Aron & Lemen on the West Coast, which was previously owned by Everest. **********In pleading guilty, Mr. Dell'Aglio admitted that Everest was set up as a dummy corporation and was used to drain Riedl's assets.  Everest became generally known in June 1978, when Adolph J. Toigo, the 72-year-old adman who had presided over the demise of Lennen & Newell, announced the existence of the Adolph Toigo Group, which was owned by Everest and was made up of the Reidl and Meltzer agencies. **********Mr. Dell'Aglio is scheduled to be sentenced March 10.

The nation's leading producer of containers and packaging products said its revenues for the three months ended Sept. 30 were $1.24 billion, down slightly from last year's third-quarter revenues of $1.25 billion. ''The current recessionary environment, soft demand and margin pressure in certain of our businesses continue to impact overall results,'' said William S. Woodside, chairman and chief executive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/world.print_headline: WORLD NUCLEAR SAFEGUARDS WEAK, U.S. REGULATORY AGENCY CONCLUDES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/world.body_text: **********The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded that the international system of safeguards intended to prevent the diversion of nuclear materials to atomic weapons ''would not detect a diversion in at least some types of facilities.'' **********The commission also declared that it could no longer be ''confident'' that members of the International Atomic Energy Agency, the Vienna-based organization that monitors the peaceful uses of nuclear material, ''would be notified of a diversion in timely fashion.'' **********The conclusions are contained in a brief letter, dated Nov. 27, from Nunzio J. Palladino, chairman of the commission, to the chairmen of several Congressional committees. The letter, unanimously approved by the panel, also states that the commission is ''reviewing our responsibilities'' under the Atomic Energy Act ''for the licensing of nuclear exports.'' **********While the international agency's monitoring has increasingly come under attack by legislators and other critics, the letter from the five-member, independent regulatory commission is the first official Government assertion that the safeguards system is ineffective for some nuclear installations. U.S. Expresses Concern **********The commission did not specify which types of installations posed monitoring problems, but one commission official said that some members of the panel were particularly concerned about atomic reactors that are continuously loaded as well as facilities that engage in the fabrication, enrichment or reprocessing of uranium and nuclear fuel. **********The continuously loading reactor, which uses natural uranimum as fuel, was developed by Canada and has been sold to nations such as India and Pakistan. The State Department and the International Atomic Energy Agency recently expressed private concern about the ability to monitor such reactors. **********The United States makes reactors that are periodically loaded and, therefore, easier to monitor.  One commission official said that the letter to Congressional committees was prompted by the panel's growing concern about the adequacy of safeguards ''accross the board,'' but particularly in a number of nuclear installations abroad. **********The commission's review of its responsibilities could have serious ramifications for the export of nuclear technology, which at present is licensed by the commission. **********While the commission requires that the safeguards of the International Atomic Energy Agency be applied to recipients of the exports, it has not routinely debated whether the monitoring system is adequate or likely to prevent the diversion of American-supplied nuclear material or technology from civilian to military purposes. **********Should the commission decide that the system is unreliable, it might decide to reject or delay nuclear exports. Such action could deal a severe blow to the Reagan Administration's goal of restoring the United States as a ''reliable supplier'' of nuclear materials and technology. **********In a joint letter to the commission that was sent today, three Democrats -Representatives John D. Dingell of Michigan and Richard L. Ottinger of New York and Senator Gary Hart of Colorado - said that the commission's assessment raises ''the gravest questions'' about the effectiveness of the safeguards system. All three serve on Congressional committees with oversight responsibility for nuclear energy or the commission. Examples Are Requested **********The letter asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to provide their committees with specific examples of weaknesses in the safeguards system, and requested the commission's view on whether Congress should provide it with specific legal authority to consider the effectiveness of the monitoring system. **********''Nothing But a Facade'' **********''If internationl safeguards are indeed inadequate,'' the letter from the Democrats said, ''then the nuclear nonproliferation regime relied on by the United States and other countries is nothing but a facade which legitimizes trade in nuclear technology and materials while placing the world in increasingly greater danger from the undetected misuse of nuclear material.'' **********Senator Charles Percy, Republican of Illinois and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said today that he was ''very concerned'' about the N.R.C. letter, adding that the agency's assessment was ''yet another reason why the committee was holding a hearing on this subject on Wednesday.'' **********''The issue before us is what to do about this,'' Senator Percy said The commission's letter was trigered in part by a recent report to the panel by a former staff member and international inspector highlighting what he described as deficiencies in the safeguards system. The report was drafted by Emanuel R. Morgan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/05/busin.body_text: **********Energy stocks finally showed some strength yesterday, but the rest of the market finished virtually on an even keel as investors remained sensitive to interest-rate changes and other concerns.  Japanese issues that have constituted one of the market's strongest sectors were hit by profit-taking. **********These divergent movements in stock groups typified the conflicting signals given off by the market. Continued uncertainty over the fate of the Administration's tax-cut program was an additional factor dampening any rally attempt. **********The Dow Jones industrial average declined by 2.97 points, to 986.74, wiping out Wednesday's gain of 2.23 points. Advancing issues edged ahead of declines by 785 to 751. Trading volume contracted to 48.9 million shares from the previous session's 54.7 million. Rate Rise a Concern **********A major source of investor concern was the increase in short-term rates in the money market. In addition, several New York City banks raised their charges for broker loans by a point, to 20 1/2 percent.  This caused some conjecture that the prime lending rate - recently cut by half a point, to 20 percent - possibly might be increased. A higher broker loan rate sometimes precedes an increase in the prime rate. **********Another reason for caution in the equity market was the possibility, analysts said, that the Federal Reserve might report an increase in the money supply this afternoon, following two weeks of decline. Any substantial increase could set off new fears of credittightening moves by the Fed. **********And while investors continued to fret over high interest rates, the commodity market was flashing different signals. Prices for metals and other basic commodities have been falling all year - one indication of lower expectations for inflation. **********Underscoring the improvement in energy shares, no less than four oil stocks posted gains on the active list. They were Cities Service, Atlantic Richfield, Union Oil of California and Standard Oil (Indiana). Japanese Stocks Drop **********Matsushita Electric Industries, a dynamic performer in May, fell 3 1/4, to 74 3/4. The Japanese company forecast earlier this week that 1981 earnings will run about $4.60 a share, compared with $4.50 last year. Also moving lower were such recent favorites as the Sony Corporation and Honda Motor. **********Measurex jumped 3 points, to 25 1/8. This gain was attributed to the company's announcement that orders for its quarter ended May 31 totaled a record for this period. **********Conflicting signals were apparent elsewhere. The Value Line Investment Survey has rated United States Steel as a stock likely to outperform the general market over the next 12 months. Yesterday, Big Steel fell 1 3/8, to 31 5/8. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the Knogo Corporation, which makes electronic detector systems, fell 1 7/8, to 14. The company reported a loss for its latest quarter. The Amex market value index gained 0.53, to 369.37. The Nasdaq composite index advanced 0.79, to 219.68.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/18/world.main_headline: IN PARTS OF AFRICA, ANCESTRAL SPIRITS GUIDE THE LIVING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/18/world.print_headline: IN PARTS OF AFRICA, ANCESTRAL SPIRITS GUIDE THE LIVING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/18/world.body_text: **********In the language of the people who live there, the village's name is said to mean ''a place of death.'' Recently it lived up to its reputation. **********One afternoon, a bolt of lightning struck the school at Biego in western Kenya, crackled around the classroom and killed 11 children.  It was, villagers recounted, the sixth time in their memory that lightning had struck the school. That, they said, could be no coincidence. And their response to the disaster said much about that part of Africa that lies beyond the modernity introduced by recent history. **********For an explanation of the inexplicable, the villagers fell back on what seemed most natural to them: the supernatural. Or, rather, the folly of others who had ignored the requisite magic to deal with it. **********''Our ancestors who lived here died of an unknown epidemic,'' said John Nyamara, a teacher at the school. ''But there was no sacrifice made.'' Now, he said, it is too late for the ancestral spirits to accept sacrifice, so the spirits' curse that brought the first, anonymous epidemic lives on, manifest in bolts of lightning and the village's name. Beliefs Deeply Felt **********His explanation raised few eyebrows here, for beliefs that are sometimes ridiculed in Western societies are woven deep in the fabric of life in some parts of Africa. **********Curses are still put on people in Africa, students of these traditions say, and spirit doctors still lift the maledictions. There is said to be a world where spirits are as quick as the living and where the past does not disappear with death, but lives on through the ghosts of ancestors who mold the fortunes of the earthly. **********In Zambia, for instance, there is a man who, for a fee, will prepare potions and make imprecations to these spirits and then blow up the inner tube of a bicycle tire. Simultaneously, he tells the client who has ordered this magic to hurt an adversary that the enemy's stomach will grow and swell. Then, the foe must seek a healer to raise the curse and deflate the stomach, or die. **********In Zimbabwe recently, the police were called to investigate a string of murders of white farmers. Their inquiries led to a woman who said that a spirit had come to live in her and had ordered the killings. A Fabled Spirit **********The inspiration, she said, was that of Nehanda, a fabled spirit on whose orders young men went to kill the white invaders of the colonial 1890's. Nehanda is sometimes credited with starting the black nationalist war of liberation that, nearly a century later, brought an end to white rule in what used to be called Rhodesia. **********In many parts of Africa, Kenya among them, witchcraft is illegal, and nowhere is it officially encouraged in all its forms. The Kenyan authorities have undertaken vigorous campaigns against it.  But laws enacted in distant capitals sometimes hold little sway among those confronted daily with the threat of arbitrary natural disasters in need of explanation -droughts, or floods, or famines, or bolts of lightning. **********The courts of some countries, including Zimbabwe, will on occasion accept a plea that the defendant acted out of a belief in the spirit world. **********In the first few months of this year, 80 Zimbabweans were charged, in separate cases, with murder. All of them said that they were not murderers, but killers of witches who had performed necessary tasks to rid their communities of evil by doing away with the possessed, often brutally. Their sentences were generally from 3 to 13 years. Old and New Coexist **********Witchcraft is as old as man's own sense of horror. But in Africa it has blended with the new so that it coexists with Christianity and the advance of modern politics. **********According to a recent study, ''The Struggle for Zimbabwe,'' by David Martin and Phyllis Johnson, guerrillas fighting white rule in Zimbabwe were given inspiration by a frail old woman in whom Nehanda's spirit was said to reside. **********Zimbabwe's Health Minister, Herbert Ushewokunze, insists that traditional and modern medicine should coexist since they complement each other: where one fails, the other succeeds, as is said to have happened for a man called News Horufu. **********According to accounts of the case, News Horufu lived in a village north of Salisbury, the capital of Zimbabwe, and was prone to fits of extreme violence. His parents chained him to a tree for 10 years.  Occasionally, when calm descended on him, they would unchain him and take him to a hospital, but he could not be cured. Spirit Doctors Take Case **********Then his case came to the attention of Zimbabwe's traditional healers. The spirit doctors took him under their care. After a few weeks, according to the accounts, News Horufu was healed and was not chained to the tree again. **********The case illustrates one of the categories into which those called witch doctors by Westerners can be divided. News Horufu was reportedly cured by a traditional healer whose adeptness was said to lie in treating psychosomatic and other psychiatric maladies through the language and rituals of longstanding tradition. **********Other traditional healers say that they act as conduits of communication between the stricken on earth and the spirits of ancestors who, according to Dr. Ushewokunze and others, channel the inspiration of a life source that animists hold to be the ultimate power. **********These healers are said to communicate with the spirits in trances that, in Zimbabwe, are invoked with closed eyes.  The spirit is then said to speak through the healers. Believers feel that spirits may be appeased in advance by sacrifices, such as rituals to insure that rains come and crops grow. If they are not appeased, as the villagers of Biego believe, there is disaster. Spirits, too, may reside in animals, which then become holy, according to believers. **********Still a third category of African traditional healers are herbalists, whose potions and remedies may be more acceptable to some - and cheaper - than modern medicines. The act of taking the remedies, Western doctors say, may be as much a cure as the remedy itself - a phenomenon not confined to Africa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/06/busin.body_text: **********About 10,000 workers at General Electric Company's giant Appliance Park here have been recalled from two-week furloughs, but 900 G.E. employees with the least seniority face indefinite layoffs beginning Nov. 9. **********The 10,000 workers were laid off for two weeks as G.E. sought to reduce its inventory of unsold major appliances such as ranges, refrigerators and washers. **********Another 5,000 workers had been laid off for one week and returned to work Sept. 28. **********In addition to the indefinite layoffs pending Nov. 9 for 900 worke rs, anot her 13,000 employees face temporary layoffs during November and December at Appliance Park, Kentucky's largest private employer. **********About 1,750 range workers will be laid off Nov. 30-Dec. 22, about 5,600 workers in the refrigerator division will be laid off Dec.  7-22, about 4,400 people who make washers, dryers and dishwashers will be laid off Dec. 13-22 and 1,700 people who make air-conditioners will be laid off Dec. 21 and 22. **********G.E. has attributed the layoffs to persistent high interest rates which affect sales of major appliances and the slumping home building industry, Appliance Park's biggest customer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.body_text: **********Oman has lowered the price of its crude oil shipped to Japan between October and December by $1.50 a barrel, to $34, Government officials said today. **********The International Trade and Industry Ministry said Oman, not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, was the first Middle East producer to lower its crude price to $34 a barrel apart from Saudi Arabia, which is sticking to $32. **********Japan imports 50,000 barrels a day of crude from Oman. **********A ministry spokesman said three Japanese trading houses and an oil refinery were likely to stop imports of Iranian crude tomorrow when their contracts expired following a pricing dispute with the National Iranian Oil Company. **********The four companies are seeking a cut in the price of Iranian light crude from $37 to about $32 a barrel, he said.  They had been importing a total of 82,000 barrels a day under present contracts, although shipments have been suspended since last month because of stalled negotiations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/busin.body_text: **********The Student Loan Marketing Association, Sallie Mae, will begin borrowing under its own name this year as it phases out its dependence on the Federal Financing Bank, the Treasury announced yesterday. **********Edward Fox, president of the association, said the agency would probably issue up to $500 million of discount notes this year. **********The agency was organized in 1972 to create a secondary market for federally guaranteed student loans.  By September 1982, when Sallie Mae plans to stop borrowing from the Treasury, it expects to attract lenders on the strength of its own balance sheet and operating history, Mr. Fox said. He acknowledged that the association had a relatively small capital base, about $50 million compared with $3.5 billion of assets, but added that, in recent years, it had operated at a profit with a return on equity of 15 to 20 percent. **********Sallie Mae issues after September 1982 will not be federally guaranteed, Mr. Fox noted, but the association has a line of credit with the Treasury.

Those rates reflect commitments made earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/21/busin.main_headline: U.S. OIL EXECUTIVES IN LIBYA DISCOUNT RETALIATION THREAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/21/busin.print_headline: U.S. OIL EXECUTIVES IN LIBYA DISCOUNT RETALIATION THREAT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Representatives of American oil companies operating in Libya said yesterday that they had received assurances from top Libyan leaders that Libya would not retaliate against United States oil interests for the downing of two Libyan planes by American Navy fighters. Some company officials criticized the United States Government for the action. **********Most industry officials discounted the possibility that Tripoli would retaliate by nationalizing United States companies or by conducting an embargo on oil sales to this country. However, they said they were concerned about the safety of American personnel and their families. **********Indeed, growing worries over the safety of the approximately 1,500 United States citizens working and living in Libya, mostly for oil companies, seemed to have replaced an initial apparent lack of concern that companies expressed immediately after news that two United States Navy fighters had shot down two Libyan fighters on Wednesday. Evacuation by Exxon **********Exxon became the first company to evacuate dependents of its employees, a step the five other American companies operating in Libya are also considering. Mobil has prepared what it called ''a readiness plan.'' Both companies declined to provide details, as did others that are also considering evacuations. **********A number of companies even declined to give the specific number of employees and dependents they have in Libya, partly on the theory that the information could prove sensitive if the situation should worsen. Typically, most companies have considerably fewer than 100 United States citizens each. However, numerous American oilfield service companies, such as Halliburton, also employ Americans in Libya. **********In general, however, oil industry experts in the United States and Libya suggested that, so far, the Libyan position had been moderate, especially when compared with what some view as aggressiveness on the part of the United States. American Action Criticized **********''This was a blunder, a very foolish big-stick move on the part of the United States,'' declared a high official of an American oil company speaking by telephone from Tripoli. ''But we were given assurances that the chances of retaliation are very, very slim.'' **********The official said the assurances were made in a meeting with top officials of Libya's ministries for heavy industry and oil. He further reported that the Americans living in Libya remained ''calm,'' oilfield operations had not been impaired and Libyan citizens had not conducted any large demonstrations. ''It's business as usual,'' he said. **********''The authorities have handled this in a very low-key way,'' the oil executive continued. ''The community is very calm. There is no cause for concern.'' He even joked that the Libyans had not yet called in the ''rent-a-crowds'' that are often assembled for protests against the United States. **********The American-based oil companies operating in Libya are Conoco, Marathon, Amerada Hess, Occidental Petroleum, Exxon and Mobil. In addition, Italian, French and German companies produce oil there.  The American companies produce crude oil in Libya themselves, in joint ventures with the state-owned oil company, and purchase crude oil from the state company for export. Their investments include oil well equipment, pipelines, export terminals and some refining operations for the 70,000-barrel-a-day Libyan market. Nationalization Discounted **********Most American companies dismissed the possibility of nationalization, but several well-placed European oil executives suggested there was at least an even chance that Tripoli would make such a move. Lending support to this speculation was a threat yesterday in Abu Dhabi by Mohammed al-Qamoudi, head of the Libyan Brotherhood Bureau, to use the ''oil weapon.'' **********Nationalization of oil properties has been a tactic of Tripoli since it seized British Petroleum's Libyan operations in 1971. In 1974, Libya became the first country to nationalize foreign properties for specifically political reasons when it took over the operations of Standard Oil of California, Texaco, Royal Dutch/Shell and Atlantic Richfield to protest a meeting of the Western oilconsuming nations to formulate a common strategy to deal with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********Oil analysts said that Libyan nationalizations were considerably more punitive than most nations. Tripoli, in a continuing wave of nationalizations, has ignored the value of oil in the ground and the future revenues of companies as factors in determining compensation.  It has only considered the depreciated value of the actual hardware used to produce oil, an amount that industry analysts say is almost neglibile. Production Figures Guarded **********Most companies are reluctant to disclose how much oil they have been producing in Libya, because they have been drastically reducing both their own production as well as the amount they buy from the Libyan Government. Although these reductions are an acknowledged tool to force Tripoli to cut its price of $40 a barrel, the highest among the 13 nations in OPEC, companies shrink from highlighting the issue because of fears that it would it will embarrass their host country. **********But the companies made it clear that, at least for the present, they could do without Libya's oil. Output has dropped to 600,000 barrels daily, a third of capacity. This clearly reduces the effectiveness of an embargo against the United States, which gets less than 5 percent of its oil from Libya. **********Nevertheless, analysts are convinced that Libya could sustain a long embargo. G. Henry M. Schuler, who has worked as both an American diplomat and a company representative in Libya, said that the Libyans had $10 billion invested in gold and hard currency reserves, large overseas holdings and credit with some of the world's biggest banks.  And they have a much smaller population than such hard-pressed oilproducing nations as Nigeria. **********''We'd cry uncle before they did,'' Mr. Schuler said. The other arguments that the Libyans will probably weigh in deciding how to punish the United States, he said, are the example of the precipitous decline in Iran's petroleum production after that country ejected foreign companies, and the fact the continued presence of American citizens on Libyan soil increases Tripoli's leverage.
