https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/09/busin.body_text: **********The 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries opens its regular biannual ministerial conference Wednesday, and several sources said the main item on the agenda would be how to deal with the world oil oversupply. **********The oversupply has depressed prices and caused difficulties for some of the member nations trying to sell their oil at the official prices set by the group at the meeting in Geneva in October. **********That meeting unified oil prices at $34 a barrel for light Arabian marker crude and allowed a maximum differential of $4-a-barrel more for higher quality oil. **********''Differentials is one subject to discuss seriously because the differentials set at Geneva did not reflect real market conditions,'' said Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, whose country is the largest producer in the organization. Price Cuts Offered **********Sheik Yamani, who was chairman of the oil group's long-term strategy committee meeting today, said some members had been offering unannounced price reductions and would have to cut their prices further because of market conditions. **********Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, said that ''OPEC would have to revise the set of differentials agreed upon in Geneva'' because they were too high. **********He said he would propose that the maximum differential be reduced to $3.50 a barrel, for a top price of $37.50 a barrel.  Industry sources said Nigeria had been unable to market its highquality low-sulfur crude at the oil group's set price and had sold its production of 1.2 million to 1.3 million barrels a day at $36.50 instead of $38 a barrel. **********Libya and Algeria, which produce similar quality crudes, have complained that Nigeria's selling price is making it difficult for them to sell their oil. Libya, in turn, has been reported to have offered its customers a $1.25-a-barrel discount. Nigeria's Position **********Nigeria, saying that market conditions do not justify the higher price, has asked for a reduction of the differentials, hoping to reduce the price of the top-quality light crude from $38 a barrel, to $36.50 a barrel. **********Saudi Arabia and several other member nations were reportedly calling for a 50-cent reduction in the maximum price for a barrel of oil. Libya and Algeria were expected to oppose this demand. **********Industry analysts said that there had also been some undercutting at the lower end of the group's price scale. Kuwait, for example, has been charging only $32.50 for its heavy crude, the analysts said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/19/busin.body_text: **********Stocks edged higher yesterday, despite another half-point increase in the prime rate to 20 percent by major banks - the sort of news that often depresses the market. Growing conjecture on Wall Street that interest rates are near their peak served as a prop to prices. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, however, showed a token decline of 0.18, to 985.77, after climbing 12.88 points Friday. Meanwhile, the transportation average moved ahead, reflecting continued strength in airline and railroad issues. The Dow utility average, which is sensitive to interest rate developments, scored its ninth consecutive advance. **********Most other popular indicators displayed small gains, and market breadth continued to improve, as advances outpaced declines by a 4-to-3 margin. Moderate Volume **********Trading held to its recent moderate rate. The volume of 42.5 million shares compared with the previous session's 45.5 million. **********Bond prices extended their recent gains, and yields declined.  Analysts said this trend also helped stock prices, inasmuch as the yield gap between the two sectors is at a record. **********''We would expect the stock market to respond positively if there is a further near-term bond market rally,'' Robert Farrell of Merrill Lynch advised clients yesterday morning. ''However, a twist could develop if the stock market began to perceive that the reasons for any extended bond market strength was a weakening of economic activity. It might then start to worry about the outlook for corporate profits and have that excuse for another phase of decline.'' **********Health-care issues, one of the market's best performing groups in recent years, moved higher. Strength also appeared in defense issues and some energy-related stocks. **********J.P. Morgan, corporate parent of the bank that initiated the prime rate increase to 20 percent, moved ahead 1 3/8, to 55 3/4.  Dean Witter Reynolds tumbled 3 7/8, to 32. It had climbed 3 7/8 points Friday amid rumors of a possible takeover bid from a large insurance company. After the close of Friday's trading, however, officials said that Dean Witter Reynolds ''is not engaged in negotiations with any potential acquirers.'' Last year, the company's shares sold as low as 8 1/2. **********Shearson Loeb Rhoades, with an acquisition by the American Express Company pending, rose 3 1/8, to 54 1/2. Meanwhile, American Express gained 1 1/2, to 45. Health-Care Gains **********In the health-care sector, the Hospital Corporation of America rose 1 7/8, to 46 7/8. Last Wednesday, when the stock was selling at 43, David H. Talbot of Drexel Burnham Lambert maintained his ''buy'' rating on the issue. ''The proposed acquisition of Hospital Affiliates International, a division of INA Corporation, puts Hospital Corporation meaningfully into the psychiatric care business and escalates its diversification process,'' he noted. **********The analyst estimated earnings of the Hospital Corporation at $2.25 a share this year and $3 in 1982, compared with last year's profits of $1.73 a share. **********Elsewhere in the group, Humana jumped 3 points, to 41 5/8.  A feature in the energy sector was Artra Group Inc., climbing 2 1/2 points, to 29 1/8, after gaining 2 5/8 points Friday. Dutch Boy Inc.  changed its name to Artra at the end of last year to reflect a redeployment of assets. Last week, the company reported higher quarterly profits and yesterday it announced a minor oil and gas discovery. **********Fieldcrest Mills rose 1 point, to 33 1/2, after agreeing to a merger with the Amoskeag Company. In over-the-counter trading, Amoskeag climbed 2 points, to 33 bid. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq composite average gained 0.43, to 216.94. **********The American Stock Exchange's market value index, after closing Friday at a record high, fell 2.06, to 368.84. Recent gains in this index reflected a brisk price recovery in Canadian oil and gas stocks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/01/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; NEW FUNDS FOR HOME IMPROVEMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/01/busin.body_text: **********W HERE does a growing family turn when it outgrows its home? Usually it buys a bigger home, but these days, with interest rates at twice their levels of just a couple of years ago, such a move is often impossible. The alternative? A smaller loan to add a room or two to the existing home. **********Home improvement loans could soon become much easier to obtain because the Government is getting into the business. Last month the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation - Freddie Mac - began a oneyear pilot program not unlike its mortgage program. It has set aside $200 million to purchase home-improvement loans from participating lending institutions, thereby freeing the lenders to extend more loans. **********The $200 million is a minuscule amount, but Freddie Mac expects that if the pilot project proves itself this year, it will then initiate a full-scale program involving billions of dollars.  Meanwhile, another Government-sponsored corporation, the Federal National Mortgage Association -Fannie Mae - has developed a similar multibillion-dollar program of its own. If approved by the Reagan Administration, it could get under way by late summer. **********Home improvement loans under the Freddie Mac pilot program offer borrowers some important advantages over the usual loan. Terms are exceptionally liberal, with fixed periods of five, 10, 15 or 20 years. The owner of a condominium can receive a maximum loan of $15,000, a single-family structure qualifies for up to $30,000, while a two-to-four family structure is eligible for a loan up to $60,000.  In all cases, the residence must be owner-occupied. **********Without the program, many lending institutions might agree to lend only $5,000, or make the funds available for a maximum of five years. Furthermore, the interest rate is certain to be more favorable than what the borrower would have paid had he been compelled to refinance his first mortgage or take out a second one. Generally, said Donald E. Miller, the Freddie Mac program's director of underwriting, the rate for a home improvement loan might be 1 to 2 percentage points higher than that for a first mortgage. **********The program under study at Fannie Mae differs in some important respects from Freddie Mac's. For one thing, it would accept home improvement loans with adjustable interest rates as well as fixed rates. For a fixed-rate loan, Fannie Mae would grant a minimum term of three years, and a maximum term of only five years. In the case of an adjustable-rate loan, however, it would set a maximum 15-year term for amounts below $15,000, and a maximum 30-year term for loans of $15,000 or more. **********As adjustable-rate loans are still effectively prohibited by about 30 states, however, Freddie Mac's terms would seem to be more attractive to the borrower than Fannie Mae's. On the other hand, the proposed Fannie Mae program does not require that two-to-four unit dwellings be owner-occupied. It should be cautioned, however, that the latter program has yet to win official approval, and could emerge significantly changed. **********The potential size of the demand for the two programs could be immense. According to Freddie Mac, about $42 billion was spent on home repairs and improvements in 1979, and such expenditures are expected to grow to $75 billion by 1984. **********''There are many families who are forced into buying a new home simply because they have outgrown their old one,'' declared John Dalton, a Freddie Mac director. ''With funds more readily available for home improvement, we can expect a certain easing of the pressure for new units.'' **********The program, it is hoped, will also help restore deterioriating inner cities and conserve energy by financing fuel-efficient measures, including solar-energy systems. **********Money for housing-related loans of all kinds has been squeezed by the tight credit conditions of recent years. But where the Government had previously stepped in to ease the situation in the mortgage market through Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, only now is it beginning to take a similarly active role in home improvement financing. **********Basically, both Government-sponsored corporations buy mortgages from banks and other lenders, providing them with the funds to make additional mortgages. This ''secondary market'' for mortgages has helped prevent any real shortage of mortgage money, although it has been available at record rates of interest. Until now, however, no such secondary market has existed for home improvement loans. **********Under the new program, banks and other financial institutions can sell 80 percent of their home-improvement loans to Freddie Mac and re-invest the recouped funds. The lenders thus improve their portfolios' yields and, through continual turnover, avoid being stuck with long-term loans at below-market rates. **********The main difference for the borrower will be the greater availability of home-improvement financing during periods of tight money. In most cases, individual borrowers will be unaware that their loans have been sold, and they will continue making payments to their local bank. **********In the long term, Mr. Miller said, the program may lead to a decline in interest rates as more funds become available and the cost of money to lending institutions is reduced. If the program succeeds, he added, even lending institutions that aren't in it may adopt its terms in order to compete. **********Another possible consequence of the program is that others besides Freddie Mac will follow its initiative in buying home improvement loans, leading to a private-sector secondary market in home-improvement loans similar to that in home mortgages. Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae have together developed uniform, nationwide documentation, such as notes and deeds of trust. The hope is that the standardization of documents will facilitate more interstate purchases of home improvement loans by financial institutions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/busin.body_text: **********Although high interest rates and slumping demand have resulted in sharp price declines for major commodities during the past 12 months, oil prices have bucked those trends. **********While the composite price for a barrel of oil to refiners has shown steady declines since April, the $33.57-a-barrel price quoted by the Department of Energy as the September figure is 16 percent above levels of a year earlier. **********The bulk of the increase occurred between September 1980 and March 1981, when prices rose more than 29 percent, to $37.48 a barrel.  Since then, oil prices have fallen more than 10 percent. **********The Energy Department collects data for its monthly cost report from about 180 refiners across the country. Lamar Gowland, an economist with the department's Energy Information Administration, said refiners are asked to submit the cost and volume of oil purchased from domestic and foreign producers. Department economists then formulate a composite price. **********''Normally, refiners handle about 400 million barrels of oil a month,'' Mr. Gowland said. ''About 100 million of that is foreign, the rest domestic. However, the weaker demand and high interest rates have clearly had an effect on volume this year. Right now, I'd say refiners are handling between 320 and 330 million barrels a month,'' he said. **********Since late January, when prices of domestically produced oil were decontrolled, the gap between foreign and domestically produced crude has narrowed dramatically. **********''In February, the first month after decontrol, there was a spread of almost $3 per barrel between foreign and domestic oil,'' Mr.  Gowland said. ''In September, our preliminary price data show that the difference is $1.33.'' In September, domestic crude cost refiners $33.10, and imported oil, $34.43.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/19/busin.body_text: **********Some people like to think of the Robert Bosch company as a West German auto parts manufacturer with hobbies.  Although Bosch diversified into products like home appliances and radio equipment as early as the 1920's, its reputation still rests largely on its sophisticated auto ignitions, fuel injection and lighting systems. **********But now Bosch plans a major investment in telecommunications, using as a channel the operations of the faltering AEG-Telefunken group.  Executives at Bosch headquarters outside this south German city hope the new venture will grow into one of its most profitable. **********''This is the entrance ticket to a market we think has an enormous future,'' said Kurt Losten, the Bosch board member for sales and international activities. ''We already have much of the know-how. We now will have the possibility to develop very interesting comprehensive systems.'' The Symbolism of Bosch **********The new development is being watched closely in Europe. The telecommunications sector is widely expected to see tremendous expansion in the 1980's. In addition, the family-owned Bosch is viewed as something of a pillar of fiscal and managerial stability in a German industrial world where recession, strained finances and spreading pessimism are bringing a record harvest of bankruptcies among weak companies, and shockingly shrunken profits even among the traditionally strong. **********In recent weeks, Bosch has entered into a complex series of deals that will give it, by 1983, a controlling share of Telefonbau und Normalzeit, the telephone systems manufacturer now 41 percent owned by AEG-Telefunken, and strong minority interests in AEG's telecommunications division and Olympia office machine subsidiary. **********It will share these interests with Mannesmann, a steel company that is also branching out into electronics, and with several banks and an insurance company to establish a large new German telecommunications group. 'Saving' a Profitable Company **********The idea is to bring Bosch's capital and expertise in things like radio and television equipment, power antennas and wide-band communications equipment to the AEG division that is among its most profitable, but that could be dragged down by the overall weakness of the parent. AEG has paid no dividends since 1973, and expects a loss this year of $300 million. **********AEG's telecommunications division makes transmission systems and radio equipment, manages all AEG's space activities and is moving into optical fiber cables. **********Bosch executives see a market developing in the 1980's for products like data banks and new forms of communications and telephone systems. Gains in these sectors, they reason, will offset any slowdown in the automobile or housing markets, where Bosch is now most vulnerable. Others Express More Caution **********But despite Bosch's successes elsewhere, some analysts of the new venture judge it cautiously. **********Most agree that the industry is headed for stirring growth. But they also predict fierce competition, citing, in West Germany alone, Siemens, the country's largest electrical company, which has a strong and profitable telecommunications division, and Standard Elektrik Lorenz, the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's West German subsidiary. **********''In the weight of the financial investment and in the framework of our corporate policy, this decision is comparable to Bosch's development in the 1920's,'' Mr. Losten said. **********Analysts tend to agree, but they add that it may also be Bosch's biggest risk since that time. In the words of one bank's analyst, who asked not be named because of business relations: ''It's certainly one of their biggest opportunities in a long while. But it is also, no doubt, one of their major risks.'' Recession Begins to Bite **********A continuing slump in Europe's auto industry and a serious housing crisis are already taking a toll on Bosch. Net income slipped last year, the most recent period for which figures are available, to $64.7 million from $82.5 million in 1979, although revenues rose to $4.26 billion from $3.92 billion. **********Bosch's ability to invest so much capital - the venture is expected to cost the company at least $225 million - is very much a result of the way the company is run. **********When Robert Bosch, the founder, died in 1942 at the age of 81, he left instructions for a system of ownership that keeps 90 percent of the company's assets, but no voting rights, in the hands of a philanthropic foundation, and leaves policy making to Bosch management. That meant, for example, that only a quarter of last year's earnings were paid out as a dividend, while the rest flowed into Bosch's reserves. Founder's Strong Pesonality **********Mr. Bosch is described as having been an exceptionally dedicated, remarkably independent man with strong personal convictions, who once dared give a job to the former mayor of Leipzig after the official had been cast out of office for opposing Hitler. **********Mr. Bosch has had only two successors. The current chairman, Hans L. Merkle, who will be 69 in January and shows no sign of stepping down, is described as a man who only reluctantly talks to reporters.  Press officials at Bosch distribute instead a policy speech Mr.  Merkle made nearly 10 years ago. In principle, they proudly note, little has changed. **********Bosch is no newcomer to diversification. In the 1920's, Mr. Bosch tried his company's hand at products like power tools, expanding later into home appliances, heating systems and camera and movie equipment. In 1929 he entered a venture called Fernseh, an early experimenter in television. **********There have been slips. Two ventures in the postwar years, one in office machinery and another in housing, fell flat when Bosch misjudged the market. Broad Geographical Spread **********But diversification has not been Bosch's only source of growth; geographical spread has been another. **********Bosch went to Japan to seek customers for automobile magneto starters in 1911. Last year, Bosch sold $22 million worth of products in Japan, including power tools, appliances and packaging machines.  Bosch also supplied the auto industry with fuel injection systems built at a Bosch plant and under license. **********Bosch re-entered North America, which had accounted for 70 percent of sales before expropriations of plants and trade names during the two world wars, in a big way in the 1970's. Among other activities, Bosch began producing fuel injection systems in South Carolina, paid $62.9 million for a 9.3 percent share of the Borg-Warner Corporation and acquired a 25 percent share of American Microsystems Inc., a components maker. **********The company has also expanded its auto parts business and moved into power tools. Last year, sales in the United States totaled $300 million. Bosch expects to invest $40 million in the United States over the next five years, expanding revenues to $500 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/13/busin.main_headline: G.M., SUZUKI AND ISUZU AGREE TO 'MINI-CAR' DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/13/busin.print_headline: G.M., SUZUKI AND ISUZU AGREE TO 'MINI-CAR' DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/13/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation will cooperate with Isuzu Motors Ltd. and the Suzuki Motor Company in the production and marketing of new ''mini-cars,'' smaller than the Chevrolet Chevette, leaders of the three corporations announced today at a news conference here. **********John F. Waters Jr. a vice president of General Motors in charge of its overseas group, joined Toshi Okamo@to, president of Isuzu Motors, and Osamu Suzuki, Suzuki Motors president, in announcing the agreement. **********The companies hope to gain an edge in the increasingly competive market for small, fuel-efficient cars with an engine displacement of 1,000 cubic centimeters and under. The agreement provides for each of the three companies to acquire shares in the other companies and to offer mutual technological and marketing assistance. **********Isuzu Started Talks **********Mr. Okamoto initiated the negotiations with Suzuki, and broached the proposal to G.M. when its chairman, Roger B. Smith, visited Tokyo last month. The final details were decided after Mr. Suzuki and Mr.  Okamoto visited the General Motors corporate offices in Detroit recently, Mr. Okamoto said. **********In a statement released today, Mr. Smith said, ''As a leading producer of vehicles smaller than any G.M. manufactures, Suzuki offers products and production capacity which can be of interest in many parts of G.M.'s worldwide marketing network, and G.M. has technology in many fields which is of interest to Suzuki.'' **********The mini-car is Suzuki's field of expertise. It also produces minitrucks, motorcycles, marine outboard motors and generator sets.  Auto makers expect worldwide demand for mini-cars to grow rapidly as oil prices continue to climb and consumers seek gas-saving vehicles for use in town or for short-distance commuting. Smaller Than Chevette **********In Japan, the mini-car designation is given to cars that are less than 126 inches long and 55.1 inches wide and have an engine displacement under 550 cubic centimeters. By contrast, the Chevette is 161.9 inches long and 61.8 inches wide and has a 1,600-cubic-centimeter engine. **********Analysts here predict that G.M. will use the engineering technology of the two companies to produce engines for its planned ''S''-car models, a tiny car that G.M. plans to build in Spain. Production of the ''S'' cars has been delayed because of cost and engineering difficulties in developing the smaller-size engines, analysts say. **********General Motors will acquire a 5 percent equity of 14 million shares in Suzuki, a major manufacturer of mini-cars and motorcycles for the Japanese domestic market. General Motors already owns a 34.2 percent share in Isuzu Motors, Japan's third-largest truck manufacturer. Stock Agreement **********Isuzu Motors will purchase 10 million shares of stock in Suzuki Motors, acquiring a 4 percent equity in that company. Suzuki Motors will also purchase 10 million shares of stock in Isuzu Motors. **********The agreement also provides an option by which G.M. and Suzuki may make mutual supply and resale arrangements for both vehicles and components, an option that Mr. Waters today termed ''a clear possibility.'' **********Executives of Suzuki and Isuzu also said they looked forward to technological and marketing gains from the agreement to cooperate.  Isuzu, which, like G.M., does not now manufacture mini-cars or trucks, can learn from Suzuki's mini-car manufacturing technology and profit by sharing its extensive domestic marketing network, Mr.  Okamoto said. Sales Gain for Suzuki **********The popularity of Suzuki's highly fuel efficient 1,000-cubiccentimeter Alto mini-car model helped push Suzuki to No.4 in sales among Japan's domestic car makers over the past two years. **********In turn, Suzuki can gain assistance from G.M. and Isuzu in its bid to develop an ''internationally acceptable'' economy car designed for the international - primarily American - market, Mr. Suzuki said. With technological assistance from General Motors in the fields of safety and emission standards, Suzuki can meet the demands of the United States market. In addition, the terms of the agreement provide for G.M. to resell Suzuki's current and future products through its overseas sales network. Isuzu and Suzuki will also cooperate in product development, production and sale. **********G.M. did not say when the vehicle supply and distribution arrangements with Suzuki would take effect, nor did it say where or when a mini-car supplied by Suzuki would be sold. **********Last May, Isuzu reached agreement with Yanase & Company, Japan's leading distributor of imported autos, to market General Motors' ''J'' cars and Isuzu's domestic car models.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.main_headline: Most Interest Rates Off Slightly; Fed Funds Rise Slows Buying
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Most Interest Rates Off Slightly; Fed Funds Rise Slows Buying
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates declined in early trading yesterday, but uncertainty about their future direction was so great that much of the decline was erased before trading ended. **********''The idea that interest rates will trend lower is entrenched enough so that there is a small undercurrent of buyers,'' one government securities dealer said. He quickly added, however, that the temporary gains early yesterday were the result of speculative purchases and not broad-based institutional buying. **********Traders and speculators said they were more willing to buy yesterday because financing costs - measured by overnight repurchase agreements with Treasury securities as collateral -dropped to 16 1/4 percent from over 18 percent earlier this week and over 20 percent last Friday. **********Their enthusiasm waned, however, when the rate on overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market climbed to an unexpected 22 percent during the afternoon. After opening at 17 3/4 percent, the funds rate had earlier dropped to 16 percent, a move that some traders took as a sign that the long-awaited decline in the funds rate was under way. The rates for Federal funds and repurchase agreements are not identical, but usually a change in the funds rate leads traders to expect similar adjustments in other short-term instruments, including repurchase agreements. Erratic on Wednesday **********Other analysts noted that daily fluctuations in the funds rate are a poor indicator of future rates, especially on a Wednesday, when the funds rate is erratic because it is the last day of the bank statement week. **********The future course of the Federal funds rate, which lately has been guiding all segments of the credit markets, will be determined by money supply growth, analysts explain. If money supply growth is slow and within the Fed's target, as it has been during May, then the Fed will be able to supply reserves more liberally to the banking system and the funds rate will fall. If money supply growth is rapid, then the Fed will make reserves scarcer, and the funds rate could rise, or stay at the current level. **********Forecasts of future money supply growth vary widely. Willaim N.  Griggs, an economist at J. Henry Schroder Bank and Trust Company, says that ''the risks are clearly on the side of actual M-1B and M-2 growth being near the high end rather than the low end of the Fed's annual range by December 1981.'' **********Robert Ried, an economist at McCarthy, Ried, Crisanti & Maffei Inc., has a similar forecast and concludes that ''Federal Reserve officials are in trouble. Consequently, so are the fixed income markets.'' He said that money market rates might drop to the midteens in the third quarter before rising to the high teens or low twenties by year-end. **********One of those expecting slower money supply growth and lower interest rates is Allen Sinai, an economist with Data Resources Inc., who estimates that the Federal funds rate could be 13 1/2-14 percent by August, with long-term bond yields declining two percentage points or more by then. To support his projections, he cites ''the reversed momentum for the economy, decelerating inflation, the emerging slow pace of monetary growth, a strong dollar, and diminishing credit demands.'' **********Despite the disappointment due to the afternoon increase in the funds rate, short-term interst rates remain well below the levels of late last week, and many traders continue to expect declines in the near future. Large negotiable bank certificates of deposit due in one and three months, for example, were bid early yesterday at about 17 1/2 percent and 16 1/2 percent, down a percentage point from last Friday. Treasury Announces Note Sale **********The Treasury announced plans yesterday to sell $4.25 billion of new two-year notes on June 18 and $3.25 billion of four-year notes on June 23. The financings will raise about $2.34 billion of new cash for the Treasury. **********In advance of those auctions, the outstanding 15 5/8 percent notes due in two years were offered at 102 6/32 to yield 14.3 percent and the 13 3/8 percent notes due in March 1985 were offered at 98 11/32 to yield 13.93 percent. **********In the long-term bond market, prices closed slightly higher, with the bellwether 13 7/8 percent Treasury issue due 2011 offered at 107 7/8 to yield 12.82 percent. The new Aaa-rated Shell Oil 14 1/4 percent debentures due 2011 were offered at 100 1/4, up from 100 originally. **********Elsewhere in the corporate market, underwriters led by Morgan Stanley said General Motors Acceptance Corporation's AAA-rated, 14 5/8 percent notes due 1989 will go on sale today at 99.65 to yield 14.7 percent. **********In the tax-exempt market, underwriters led by Merrill Lynch reoffered Maryland's Aaa-rated notes with yields ranging from 8 percent in 1984 to 9.2 percent in 1993, with no public reoffering of bonds due 1994-96. As expected, the issue carried higher yields than like-rated North Carolina bonds offered earlier in the week to yield from 7.5 percent in 1982 to 8.7 percent in 1991 and 9.6 percent in 1999.
