https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A WARY LAB SUPPLIER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/16/busin.body_text: **********Benjamin Fisher, the 65-year-old chairman of the Fisher Scientific Company, wants his corporation, a leader in the laboratory supply industry, to remain an independent entity. But recent events - such as the purchase of 8.9 percent of Fisher stock by Tyco Laboratories and the sale of 10 percent of the company's stock by Mr. Fisher's brother James - have caused Mr. Fisher to become somewhat concerned about his company's future. **********''I would really like to be independent, but sometimes you don't really go through life doing what you'd like to do,'' Mr. Fisher said in a telephone interview from his Pittsburgh headquarters. ''If anybody makes a legitimate offer, we have a responsibility to examine that offer and make a judgment in the light of it.'' **********Last April, after engaging the First Boston Corporation to provide guidance, Mr. Fisher and his colleagues on the board rejected a takeover bid from the Whittaker Corporation. Since then James Fisher, who had resigned as an officer of the company two years earlier, and his wife have sold their shareholdings. And last month Tyco, with its 8.9 percent of Fisher, told the Securities and Exchange Commission in a filing that it planned to acquire ''a significant stock position.'' The Fisher family now owns about 19 percent of the company's stock. **********The standard answer given by Benjamin Fisher when asked about the Tyco purchase is that ''we welcome shareholders at any time - it's a free world.'' But in the course of conversation, the intensity of his feeling emerged when he added: ''It's like finding a shark in your swimming pool. That's a whole new element. I'm not very happy.'' **********Mr. Fisher joined the company, which had been founded by his father, Chester, in 1902, in 1938. He became executive vice president in 1961, president and chief executive officer four years later and chairman in 1975. **********''I really sort of retired six years ago,'' Mr. Fisher said.  ''Instead of being in my house on Cape Cod a lot of the time, I'm here. And when I'm at Cape Cod, I'm on the phone a lot of the time.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/22/world.main_headline: U.S. OFICIALS INVESTIGATING POSSIBLITY OF FRAUD IN IMMIGRATION OF KHOMEIMI IRANIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/22/world.print_headline: U.S. OFICIALS INVESTIGATING POSSIBLITY OF FRAUD IN IMMIGRATION OF KHOMEIMI IRANIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/22/world.body_text: **********Federal officials are reviewing immigration records for hundreds of Iranians on the suspicion that many got immigration benefits, including status as permanent residents of the United States, through fraud or bribery. **********The investigation focuses on the period after the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran, which led President Carter to impose severe restrictions on the issuance of visas and permanent resident alien identification cards, commonly known as green cards, to Iranians. **********Officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said last week that Federal agents were reviewing the records and interviewing Iranians to find out how hundreds had obtained visas and green cards despite the restrictions. **********Although the United States and Iran have no formal diplomatic relations, Iranians streaming out of the Middle East through Europe continue to seek a haven here. They include supporters of the late Shah, opponents of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and members of many religious and ethnic minority groups. **********Grand Jury Investigation **********The officials said that a grand jury, to be convened here this summer, would focus on two tactics tried by many Iranians: the use of counterfeit documents to show a close family relationship to citizens or permanent residents of the United States, and the incorporation of American businesses purporting to be subsidiaries of Iranian companies. **********Both tactics enabled Iranians to get green cards, which give foreigners many of the rights of citizens. After living in this country for five years, permanent resident aliens are eligible to become naturalized citizens. **********Federal agents have been scrutinizing the activities of Shams Javid, a 47-year-old Iranian-American whom they described as a target of the investigation. In a two-hour interview at a restaurant near his home in Falls Church, Va., Mr. Javid said that Federal agents ''were constantly there at my house'' and had interrogated many Iranians whom he had advised on immigration matters. **********Mr. Javid is not a lawyer, but said he had helped Iranians fill out immigration forms. When asked how many of his countrymen had entered the United States with his assistance, he smiled and said, ''God knows - thousands.'' Became Citizen in 1970 **********Mr. Javid said that he came to the United States in 1963, became a citizen in 1970 and worked at Iran's Embassy here as a purchasing officer in 1973 and 1974. **********In the last year, he said, he offered his services as an immigration consultant from the Falls Church office of the Sunshine Company of America Inc. The company's articles of incorporation, on file with the Virginia State Corporation Commission, show that it was formed in December 1979 as a subsidiary of an Iranian company to engage in the export-import business. **********It became virtually impossible for such companies to trade with Iran after President Carter, on April 7, 1980, announced a break in diplomatic relations with Teheran and prohibited exports from the United States to Iran. **********Several immigration lawyers said that their Iranian clients had been interviewed by immigration officers who wanted to know about Mr. Javid and his activities. **********With the help of a grand jury, Federal agents also plan to investigate whether immigration service employees helped Iranians in their efforts to get benefits for themselves and their relatives. Indirect Payments Suspected **********Sources close to the investigation said the investigators believed that some Iranians had paid immigration service employees indirectly, through intermediaries who ''laundered'' the money. **********The investigation to date has concentrated on the Washington district office of the immigration service, which serves the District of Columbia and Virginia, but it may be extended to other offices. **********Investigators said that to obtain green cards, some Iranians had submitted counterfeit birth certificates and marriage certificates to establish that they were related to citizens or permanent resident aliens. In some cases, the officials said, the documents were not birth or marriage records, but copies of pages from law books written in Persian. **********Immigration examiners are supposed to obtain translations of documents written in a foreign language, but even so, Government lawyers said, it might be difficult to prove criminal intent rather than negligence by immigration service employees in such cases. Fraud Said to Continue **********Law-enforcement officials said that the fraud was apparently continuing, but that the immigration service had put into effect controls to prevent the issuance of green cards to ineligible applicants. So far, no employees have been dismissed or reassigned. **********The investigation of Iranian immigration cases overlaps, but is separate from, the work of a Federal grand jury that has been investigating charges of immigration fraud for the last 18 months.  According to reports published in February 1980, the charges involved Mario T. Noto, a former Deputy Commissioner of Immigration, and Maron J. Sheehi, an immigration inspector who retired last month. **********Mr. Javid said he had known Mr. Sheehi since his younger brother Samad Javid bought a home from Mr. Sheehi in 1978. Property records show that the house was sold for $69,500 in what appears to be a routine transaction. **********Property records also show that last month Mr. Sheehi sold an adjacent lot for $20,000 to a Virginia company called the Firm Corporation, which was formed last March by four Iranians who had been military officers under the Shah. **********One of the four Iranians said that he and his colleagues had applied for asylum and that Mr. Sheehi had not had anything to do with their immigration cases. **********Mr. Sheehi said that he would not answer any questions on the subject because they related to matters pending before the grand jury.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.body_text: **********A pep rally was broadcast last night over satellite to 75 cities to excite the company's 5,000 dealers about the product. An all-out advertising blitz, costing close to $20 million, will begin March 16 to exhort consumers to ''bring the magic home.'' **********With all this orchestrated hoopla, the RCA Corporation on March 22 plans to introduce its long-awaited videodisk system.  ''This is the most significant consumer electronics product since color television,'' declared Herbert S. Schlosser, executive vice president. At least RCA, which brought out color television in 1954, is hoping it will be. **********RCA's videodisk system will be the second to reach the market. It is a stripped-down Chevrolet while the competing system is a soupedup Cadillac. Yet a third system is expected to enter the fray later this year. **********The videodisk can be thought of as a phonograph system that plays pictures as well as sound. The RCA disk player costs $500 and attaches to any television set. The disks, which sell for $15 to $28 and play for up to an hour per side, allow viewers to watch movies or other programs on their television sets. Gives Viewer Greater Control **********The videodisk is the latest of several expanding technologies - cable television and video cassette recorders among them - that are giving viewers more control over what they watch on their television sets. **********More than merely an additional form of entertainment, however, the videodisk promises to become a way of teaching courses, demonstrating and advertising products and cataloguing information. An encylcopedia stored on a disk, for example, could show moving pictures and sounds of its subject, in addition to photographs and text. **********RCA says the videodisk will reach 30 to 50 percent of American homes by 1990 and become an industry with annual sales of $7 billion. By the end of this year, it hopes to sell 200,000 players and two million disks. Three Systems Are Incompatible **********The risks, however, are as great as the potential market. Some industry analysts think consumers will be too confused by the three incompatible systems - none of them will be able to play disks made for the other two - or will prefer the video cassette recorder, which, while more expensive than the disk player, can tape programs off the air as well as play prerecorded material. **********''RCA seems to think of this thing as a toaster,'' said Anthony M.  Hoffman, an entertainment industry analyst and vice president of A.G. Becker Inc. ''It isn't. This isn't a mass consumer item.'' **********A more technologically sophisticated system, marketed by Magnavox and U.S. Pioneer, has been available for two years but distribution has been spotty, publicity limited and sales small. Most consumers still do not know what a videodisk is. RCA's advertising barrage should change that. And the marketing battle will begin in earnest. **********RCA's advertising campaign is expected to easily sell out its immediately available players and result in the sales of competing systems. Indeed, some analysts suggest that RCA may educate the public about videodisks only to have its competitors win the market. **********But RCA is confident. ''I don't think there will be a dogfight at all,'' said Roy H. Pollack, executive vice president. Development Cost $150 Million **********For RCA, which has spent more than 15 years and $150 million developing the videodisk system, the project is of crucial importance. **********The company has been beset by management shake-ups - the most recent being the sudden announcement a month ago that its chairman, Edgar H. Griffiths, would resign in July - and the company is now attempting to consolidate its diversified operations into a few lines of business. The videodisk is a morale booster and a return to the company's traditional stronghold of consumer electronics. **********RCA's product has fewer features than the two competing systems. It is designed to have a low price - $500 -and attract the average consumer, not the gadget-minded. **********''Our program is aimed, with a rifle, at the consumer,'' Mr.  Pollack said.  The Magnavox-U.S. Pioneer product, which was developed by MCA Inc.  and the Dutch company N.V. Philips, boasts several features, such as the ability to find and display any single frame and to go forward and backward in slow motion. But the players sell for $750 to $800, while most of the disks sell for about $25. **********The third product, expected to be introduced later this year, will seek the low price of the RCA system with many of the special features offered by the other system. Japanese Competition **********It was developed by the Victor Company of Japan (JVC) and will be marketed by JVC; its parent company, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, which sells under the names Panasonic and Quasar, and by the General Electric Company. **********In principle, the videodisk system works like a phonograph in that signals are picked off a rotating disk. But since many more signals must be picked up to convey a picture in addition to sound, the traditional phonograph needle wiggling in a groove cannot work. The videodisks spin at 450 to 1,800 revolutions a minute compared with only 33.3 for a phonograph. **********RCA's system uses a stylus that moves in grooves so narrow that 38 of them can fit into a single groove on an audio record.  The JVC system uses a stylus that glides along the disk without grooves. The Philips-MCA system uses a laser to read the information on the spinning disk without touching the disk at all. **********So far, it is estimated that perhaps 25,000 of the laser players have been sold in two years, as many as RCA plans to have on its dealers' shelves next month. Product Introduced Gradually **********Magnavox introduced the product in a few cities at a time starting in late 1978 and did not achieve national distribution until last November. **********Disks were in short supply and many proved defective. The disks contained a half hour of programming per side, meaning a feature film required two disks. **********''The effort has been pathetic,'' said James Magid, an analyst with L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.  RCA says it is determined to do better. It will start the product nationwide and has lined up allies that, with RCA, account for nearly 60 percent of color television sales in the United States. They include the Zenith Radio Corporation; three Japanese companies, Toshiba, Hitachi and Sanyo, as well as Sears, Montgomery Ward, J.C.  Penney and Radio Shack. The Columbia Broadcasting System will eventually make its own disks. If the RCA system becomes the industry standard, these allies, in effect, will wind up competing with RCA. **********RCA also has developed a disk catalogue of 100 titles and says it will introduce 50 more by August. The catalogue is heavily tilted toward feature movies - from ''The Absent-Minded Professor'' to ''The Godfather'' - with some sports, television shows, music, culture and educational material. **********Finally, RCA will advertise far more heavily. Its commercials will tempt consumers with the prospect of John Travolta dancing in their living rooms and the Godfather coming to dinner. RCA Ads Will Help Others **********The laser forces, meanwhile, which advertise their product as ''gourmet video,'' have taken steps to improve marketing and disk production. They now have disks that can play an hour on each side, but at the expense of some features. RCA's advertising is expected to help this product also. **********John C. Messerschmitt, vice president of North American Philips, said that the RCA promotion is ''the greatest thing that can happen to LaserVision. As soon as people understand what the videodisk is, then we get them.'' **********With a combination of advanced features and a low price, the JVC system could be a powerful contender, especially since Matsushita is the largest consumer electronics company in the world. But with the product's introduction less than a year away, the group has not signed up any programs to put on its disks and some analysts wonder how serious the consortium is. Video Cassette Sales Rise **********Meanwhile, video cassette recorders, which have been sold since 1975, seemed suddenly to catch on last year, when sales rose 69 percent, to 800,000 units, from sales in 1979. **********The tape players range from $600 to more than $1,000 and prerecorded tapes cost $45 to $80, more than twice as much as disks.  But consumers can rent tapes and can tape their own programs to cut costs. **********Ultimately, the fate of the various competitors and of the budding industry in general, is likely to depend on whether the videodisk can offer a service not provided by movies, cable television and other entertainment media. That depends on the development of programs specifically for the disk. **********''Feature films will be the locomotive that gets the industry started and pulls it along,'' said Mr. Schlosser of RCA. ''But Hollywood comes out with only 15 to 20 hits a year. That's not enough to sustain a disk industry.'' **********One big area will be musical disks in which the performer can be seen as well as heard. By 1982, all systems on the market will be able to play stereo. The disks could also provide programming for a small audience spread across the country, much as magazines now do. A Giant Storage System **********Perhaps the biggest potential lies, however, in taking advantage of two features that the optical, or laser, system has - the ability to find and display a single frame. **********With 54,000 individual frames on one side, the disk becomes a giant file for storing photographs and text as well as moving pictures.  Soon disks will also be used to store computer data. **********Moreover, the disk players can be programmed by a computer to play the frames in any order desired. For example, a computerized disk program used for teaching can quiz the viewer and keep score, and automatically repeat certain segments if a question is answered incorrectly. The General Motors Corporation uses the disks to train mechanics and salesmen and for customer presentations in its showroom.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/world.main_headline: HIJACKERS OF TURKISH JET OVERPOWERED IN BULGARIA AND 91 HOSTAGES FREED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/world.print_headline: HIJACKERS OF TURKISH JET OVERPOWERED IN BULGARIA AND 91 HOSTAGES FREED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/world.body_text: **********Turkey, saying that it had shown that terrorism must be ''confronted decisively,'' announced today that four terrorists who yesterday hijacked a Turkish airliner to Bulgaria had been captured and all of the hostages freed. **********It was reported that a total of 91 passengers and crew members were aboard the plane when it was recaptured. Five of the passengers were American executives of Citibank. **********The Turkish state radio said tonight that the hijackers, who have been identified as ''leftist extremists,'' were seized after a struggle during which five of the passengers were wounded and one terrorist seriously hurt. Later it was reported that two of the five injured passengers were in serious condition with wounds suffered during the recapture of the aircraft. **********There were varying accounts of the capture of the hijackers, but there seemed to be general agreement that some of the terrorists were overpowered by passengers and crew members who attacked them aboard the plane, while others were detained by Bulgarian security forces on the ground. **********Turkish authorities identified two of the four terrorists as members of the Dev Sol, or Revolutionary Left. Black Sea Resort **********The rescue operation occurred in the Bulgarian Black Sea resort of Burgas. The hijackers had said that if their demands were not met, they would kill the five Citibank officials, then blow up the plane with the rest of the passengers. They were asking for the release of 47 prisoners in Turkey and $500,000. **********''Our Government has given an example by showing that terror must be confronted decisively,'' the Turkish Prime Minister, Adm. Bulend Ulusu, said tonight, expressing satisfaction over ''the happy conclusion of the hijacking.'' **********The Prime Minister's office expressed appreciation for ''the close and efficient cooperation'' shown by the Bulgarian authorities during the hijacking incident. The Turkish head of state, Gen. Kenan Evren, the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister sent telegrams of thanks to their Bulgarian counterparts. **********It was the fourth Turkish airliner hijacked to Bulgaria since 1969. All of the incidents ended without fatalities. Once the Bulgarians returned a hijacker to Turkey because he was found to be insane and on the two other occasions, the hostages were freed and the hijackers were given political asylum in Bulgaria. Hijackers Lured Off Plane **********According to Bulgarian news agency reports received here, Bulgarian security officials lured two of the hijackers off the aircraft with the promise to let them hold a news conference and detained them immediately. **********The agency said that at the same time inside the plane, the passengers overpowered one of the hijackers and seized his gun. He tried to escape by jumping out of the rear door but was captured by the Bulgarian security services. The other hijacker reportedly began firing indiscriminately, wounding several passengers. He was seriously injured himself in the struggle. **********The entire operation took 45 minutes, the Bulgarian news agency said.  Another version was given tonight by Turkish state radio correspondents who were also present. Plan to Capture Terrorists **********According to this version, the Turkish crew of the hijacked DC-9 worked out a secret plan with the passengers for the capture of the terrorists. As part of this plan, the pilot moved the plane up from its isolated position and parked near the air terminal at 2:20 P.M.  Later the pilot moved the plane again and came to an abrupt halt, throwing the hijackers off balance. The passengers then attacked their captors. Two tried to escape but were seized when they got out of the plane. In the scuffle that ensued, one of the hijackers was seriously wounded and five passengers - two Turks, two Japanese and an Iranian - were injured. The wounded passengers were taken at once to a Bulgarian hospital for treatment. **********A special Turkish aircraft was sent to Burgas late this afternoon and they were flown back to Istanbul tonight.  The Turkish airliner took off from Istanbul's Yesilkoy Airport at 7 A.M. yesterday on a domestic flight to Ankara. Shortly afterward, gunmen forced the pilot to change his course and fly to Burgas. There were 110 passengers, mostly Turkish citizens, and 8 crew members aboard the aircraft.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/busin.body_text: **********The growth in the British money supply slowed in December, the Bank of England announced today. **********The bank said money supply grew about five-tenths of 1 percent, compared with rises of 2 percent in each of the previous two months.  As a result, it is estimated that the annual rate of growth since last February has fallen from 24.25 percent to 22.5 percent.  Nevertheless, this is still far above Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's target range of 7 to 11 percent a year.  The announcement came on the day that Alan Walters, the Englishborn economist from Johns Hopkins University, arrived in London to assume a two-year post as Mrs. Thatcher's chief economic adviser. He is a committed monetarist.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/04/busin.main_headline: Careers; Dual Major: Leverage in Job Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/04/busin.print_headline: Careers; Dual Major: Leverage in Job Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/04/busin.body_text: **********TAKING double majors in college is the look of the future, according to many educators. The impetus for this trend has come from the students themselves rather than from college administrations. **********''It might not loom large yet, but the taking of double majors has been increasing,'' J. Paul Hunter, dean of the College of Arts and Science at the University of Rochester, said last week. It is a trend he hopes to encourage, he added. **********''I think it is a good trend - a trend of the future,'' said Angel G. Jordan, dean of the Carnegie Institute of Technology at Carnegie Mellon University. **********Engineering students, he added, have more difficulty with double majors than liberal arts students because of crowded schedules that allow few electives. But they are combining such majors as chemical engineering with English, economics or other subjects that can help an engineer. **********Career problems await a typical liberal arts major who focuses on history, classics, English or languages. Looking ahead, he or she realizes that upon graduation the best job opportunities will go to students with majors in such areas as engineering, physics, chemistry, geology and computer science. **********A study by Fox-Morris Associates, personnel consultants, finds that a typical liberal arts graduate earns $14,530 a year in the first job, compared with $19,400 for a computer science major and more than $21,000 for an engineer. **********What to do? A graduate degree in law or business administration is a possibility. But many liberal arts graduates cannot afford to go on to a professional school immediately or they want a breather, so they work a while before studying for an advanced degree. **********Taking a double major in two disparate subjects enables the student to knock at more than one door to the job market. **********Some music majors, knowing the difficulty of finding good jobs in their field, are also majoring in mathematics and computer science because computer jobs abound. **********Economics majors might add a language major, making them extra useful to a multinational company.  Some majors reinforce each other. English students, for instance, can also take majors in geology, physics or biology. Such double majors could lead to a job as a technical writer or editor. **********At the University of Rochester, Dean Hunter estimated that 21 to 23 percent of the students in the College of Arts and Science chose double majors in the last four years, compared with 13 percent in 1972 and 7 percent in 1970. He said 142 of the 654 students who received degrees last spring had double majors, compared with 137 of 664 in the class of 1978 and only 48 of 651 in 1970. Among the double-major combinations were microbiology and philosophy, physics and religion and nursing and art. **********At Pennsylvania State University, John J. Romano, associate dean of the College of Liberal Arts, said double majors had held fairly steady during the last five years at about 8 percent of the graduating class. **********''They really took off about five years ago,'' he said yesterday.  ''When I talk to the freshman class, I try to push the taking of multiple majors.'' One unusual double major, he said, was East Asian studies and mineral economics. **********On some campuses, especially at major liberal arts colleges, taking a double major is almost impossible because so wide a spectrum of basic courses is required. **********Why do some colleges discourage double majors? They take more faculty advising time, and perhaps academic conservatism is a factor. Instead, many liberal arts colleges stress an interdisciplinary approach or use of a strong minor. **********Sometimes a student working for a double major has to take extra courses, especially if one of the fields is a science. The requirements for a major in biology, for example, may include both general and organic chemistry, physics and mathematics, as well as biology courses. **********Two majors with less demanding requirements - English and economics, say - would probably be less rigorous.  Nevin Murtha, a 20-year-old junior in the Newark College of Arts and Sciences at Rutgers University, is working on a double major in geology and history. He approached this program from an unusual perspective. **********After taking a high school course in geology, Mr. Murtha decided to study that subject in college and eventually earn a master's degree in geology. In his freshman year he happened to take American history and liked that, too. ''I did well in it,'' Mr. Murtha said last week. ''I had a knack, and I even thought of switching my major.'' But he remembered that geology offers better job opportunities. **********''Jobs for teachers in the history field are very tight, so I stuck with geology,'' he said. ''I don't know about the trend, but I do know a fair number of people who are doing double majors.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; What Reagan Will Propose
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; What Reagan Will Propose
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.body_text: **********PRESIDENT REAGAN will lay out his economic plan for stopping inflation and revitalizing the American economy tonight. The American people, according to the White House press secretary, James S. Brady, will be told they have ''no choice'' but to support ''our plan.'' **********The White House has mounted the biggest public relations campaign in memory to sell an economic program - replete with briefing sessions for influential legislators, businessmen and news media representatives, television appearances by Cabinet officers and economic aides and masses of data to augment the President's own message. **********Indeed, so huge is the publicity blitz that Mr. Brady has begun to worry about overkill. ''We don't want to turn this into a MEGO - My Eyes Glaze Over,'' he said. **********But boredom would appear to be the last thing the Administration has to worry about. Virtually everyone is opposed to some specific aspects of the President's program - including the leaders of organized labor; dairy farmers; the medical profession; urban mayors; blacks; people on welfare; champions of the arts, the humanities, the sciences and social sciences; environmentalists; the Pentagon; the poor and the near-poor who are afraid of losing their food stamps or jobs or unemployment compensation, and the rich and near-rich who have been hoping for bigger and prompter tax cuts on their earned or unearned income. **********The plan has four major elements, much of which has already leaked: **********- Reductions in Federal spending. President Reagan will propose budget cuts of $13.5 billion in the current fiscal year, chops as high as $53 billion in the fiscal year 1982, about $80 billion in the fiscal 1983 and an average of $130 billion in the fiscal years 1984 through 1986. These cuts are even larger than Mr. Reagan proposed during the election campaign. Some observers attribute the depth of the proposed cuts to the zealotry of David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget. Others believe that the President wanted to confront the nation with the biggest possible shopping list of budget cuts, which could be used for bargaining with Congress. The huge proposed spending cuts will also enable the President to look more fiscally responsible as he moves slowly toward a balanced budget. **********- Cuts in business and personal income taxes. The President has been trimming his tax-cut proposals to avoid worsening future budget deficits. He will delay the start of the first year's installment of three annual 10 percent tax cuts until July 1 and shave proposed tax cuts for upper-income taxpayers. But he has apparently decided to make depreciation write-offs for business investment more generous, substituting a modified version of the 10-5-3 plan for the Senate Finance Committee plan that would have shortened the ''useful lives'' of plant and equipment by about 40 percent. Under the new Reagan plan, in which write-offs would be phased in over five years retroactive to Jan. 1, 1981, plants, warehouses and other nonresidential buildings could be written off in 10 years and residential properties in 15 to 18 years; new machinery could be written off in five years and vehicles in three years. The President seems to have bought the arguments of those who wanted the tax-cut package weighted more heavily toward productivity-increasing investments. **********- Deregulation and regulatory reform. The President has already started down this path with the decontrol of oil and gasoline prices ahead of former President Jimmy Carter's schedule. The jump in gasoline prices, despite reports of gluts in supply, has exceeded the Administration's expectations and may, paradoxically, help build support for his anti-inflation budget cuts. Some of the effort to cut regulation will take the form of chopping funds and personnel of the regulatory agencies. **********- Stabilization of the country's monetary system. The cutting edge of the Administration's anti-inflation program still appears to be the monetary restraints administered by the Federal Reserve. High interest rates seem likely to persist despite widespread howls of anguish. **********Reaganomics is emerging as a blend of supply-side radicalism and demand-side conservatism; the danger is that the economy will garner neither the dynamic expansion promised by the supply-siders nor the anti-inflationary impact promised by the old-line conservatives, budget balancers and monetarists. **********Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, says that ''the standard Keynesian model will not get the results on economic growth or bringing down the rate of inflation that we are showing'' by using ''a supply-side model.'' **********Whether the public, business, the stock market or the economics fraternity will accept the new supply-side model or reject it remains to be seen. Certainly, the big battles over the ultimate shape of President Reagan's anti-inflation and revitalization program lie ahead, in Congress and in the nation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/27/busin.print_headline: EARNINGS; FIRESTONE POSTS NET OF $27 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/27/busin.body_text: **********The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, buoyed by strong gains from its tire operations in North America, reported yesterday that it had net income of $27 million in the second quarter of the fiscal year 1981, in contrast to a loss of $52 million in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales fell 10.5 percent, the company said. **********The Akron-based company said that its North American operations reported a pretax operating profit of $17 million in the latest quarter, in contrast to a loss of $3 million in the second quarter in 1980. The company said that actions taken in 1980 to eliminate excess production capacity and cut overhead caused the improvement in North America, despite a 25 percent decline in unit shipments. **********Firestone, the nation's second-largest tire producer after the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said that its net income in the three months ended April 30 amounted to 46 cents a share, in contrast to a deficit in the second quarter last year. Sales slipped to $1.1 billion from $1.23 billion. **********The net in the 1980 period, Firestone said, was after an extraordinary credit of $1.7 million from a tax-loss carry-forward, while the latest quarter included a nonoperating after-tax gain of $12 million from the repurchase of debt and a loss of $14 million after tax from foreign-currency fluctuations. **********Analysts indicated that increased demand for Firestone's tires and other products, greater use of manufacturing capacity, a stringent cost-cutting program, and the absence of the costs of closing nine plants in the fiscal year 1980 pointed to much improved earnings for the company in the fiscal year 1981. **********Operating profits from international tire operations, the company said, slipped 45.5 percent, to $12 million, from $22 million, because of significantly higher losses associated with the effect of exchange-rate fluctuations on inventory valuations. **********----

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/busin.body_text: **********The Jeep Corporation introduced a small, four-wheel-drive truck in a bid to meet stiffening competition from Japan. Officials of the company said the new Jeep Scrambler, priced at $7,288, would be aimed at a market now dominated by Datsuns, Toyotas and small Japanese-made trucks sold under the Ford Motor and General Motors names. The Scrambler will have a fourcylinder engine and four-speed manual transmission.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.main_headline: U.N. DISPUTE LOOMS ON INFANT FORMULA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.print_headline: U.N. DISPUTE LOOMS ON INFANT FORMULA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.body_text: **********A dispute over the sale of artificial milk to third-world countries is likely to break out next week when the United States casts what may be the sole vote against a code outlawing the promotion of infant formula. **********Reagan Administration officials confirmed today that the White House had directly ordered the ''no'' vote, overriding the Departments of State and Health and Human Services. The two departments had recommended an abstention, officials said, to narrow the gap between the United States and the 156 other nations at the United Nations' World Health Assembly. **********The leading American makers of powdered milk, Abbott Laboratories, the American Home Products Corporation and the Bristol-Myers Company, have waged a campaign for the ''no'' vote. Administration aides agreed with the manufacturers that there was no persuasive evidence of a connection between the promotion of powdered milk and a drop in breast-feeding and that the code infringes on free speech and restrains trade. In addition, Administration officials oppose any precedent for economic regulation by United Nations agencies. **********Order Said to Came From Meese **********According to one aide, the telegram instructing the United States delegation to vote ''no'' was signed by Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan. **********The World Health Assembly includes all members of the World Health Organization, which opened its annual meeting in Geneva on May 4 and is scheduled to vote on May 21. The importance of the issue was underlined by the presence of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India, who addressed the gathering on its third day. **********The triumph of the formula industry could prove to be selfdefeating. The United States position may so outrage third-world nations that they will translate the code's recommendations into legislation. This, however, would have only a limited effect on the American companies. They sell about $500 million in powdered milk at home and $150 million abroad. But the Nestle Company of Switzerland alone accounts for about $500 million of the $1 billion in thirdworld sales. **********Aggressive promotion of powdered milk in the third world has come under fire from church and social activist groups for several years.  Their campaign has been joined and enlarged by the World Health Organization and by the United Nations Children's Fund. Acute Problem in Third World **********These groups contend that marketing of the synthetic discourages breast-feeding, which many doctors believe is both phsyiologically and psychologically far more healthy. The problem is said to be acute in Africa, Asia and Latin America, where the powder is often mixed with polluted water or left standing without refrigeration until it sours. **********Although there are no recent large-scale studies linking formulafeeding in the third world to infant disease and mortality, several samplings do indicate that breast-fed babies from the same background do have a higher rate of survival. **********Feelings have risen so high that activist groups have organized a world boycott of Nestle, the biggest formula producer in a $2 billion world market. **********The Geneva code recommends protective practices and does not have the force of a law or a treaty. But the companies contend that nations voting for it will be morally obligated to pass legislation that carries out the proposals. An All-Embracing Code **********The code, moreover, is all-embracing and would apply to wealthy industrial nations with literate populations and uncontaminated water supplies as well as to poor countries. This aspect, defended by W.H.O. and by Unicef as a reflection of the need to promote breastfeeding everywhere, makes the document more vulnerable to the industry's attack. **********The code would outlaw ''advertising or other form of promotion to the general public''; prohibit the distribution of free samples to pregnant women and health-care workers, except for testing; prohibit premiums to promote sales; bar salesmen from getting in touch with mothers; outlaw commissions on sales, and prohibit product labels that idealize infant formula. **********Most of the major producers, under the pressure of the critics, have drawn up their own codes and say they subscribe to them. These documents, however, are limited to marketing practices in the third world and do not extend to developed nations. They vary considerably. The American codes are the broadest, generally prohibiting promotion through the mass media. **********A spokesman for Bristol-Myers, Harry Levine, said that his company would continue to adhere to its own code, regardless of the vote in Geneva. ''Nothing we are doing is stopping breast-feeding,'' he said. **********In Washington, Douglas A. Johnson, chairman of the Infant Formula Action Committee, a leading crusader against powdered milk, said that an American vote against the code ''would isolate the U.S. from its allies to protect an industry that has been highly criticized for the past decade and a half.'' He added that ''the Administration is associating itself with that industry for political and ideological reasons rather than protecting the lives of infants.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/19/busin.main_headline: MORE WORKERS GET TAX BREAK AS THEY SAVE FOR RETIREMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/19/busin.print_headline: MORE WORKERS GET TAX BREAK AS THEY SAVE FOR RETIREMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/19/busin.body_text: **********Saving for retirement will be more attractive financially for many individuals under the new tax law. The rules are so beneficial, tax experts say, that virtually everyone with any kind of wage or salary income should be thinking of establishing a tax-exempt retirement account, even though the new provisions do not take effect until Jan. 1. ''Here you've got the simplest, safest tax shelter you could have,'' Herbert Paul, associate national tax director for Touche Ross & Company, said in an interview recently. ''This is a gift that everybody ought to take advantage of.'' **********In a sweeping expansion of the eligibility requirements for retirement savings accounts, the new tax law permits people who are already covered by qualified pension plans to establish Individual Retirement Accounts as well. A Significant Change **********''Letting everyone have a retirement account is probably the most significant change in the law,'' said William M. Tartikoff, assistant counsel for the Investment Company Institute, a trade association for the mutual fund industry. **********The theory behind an Individual Retirement Account is simple.  People are allowed to exclude a portion of their earned income from income taxes if the money is put into a specially designated investment account. Earnings on this account are allowed to accumulate tax-free. Individuals do not pay taxes on any of these funds until they are withdrawn, generally after retirement, at which time the withdrawals are subject to income taxes but presumably at a lower rate. **********This tax-deferred buildup to help pay for retirement is in sharp contrast to the Social Security program, which individuals support with after-tax dollars. Some observers who welcome the new greater incentive for personal savings say that it could become a basis for shrinking the Social Security program sometime in the future. **********''The Government's basic thrust is to say that people are going to have to save for themselves, to provide for their own retirement,'' Howard Stein, chairman of the Dreyfus Corporation, a money management company, said in a discussion of the new law. **********Even if a person expects to have to pay a tax rate after retirement as high as the rate paid now, tax specialists say it probably still makes sense to establish an Individual Retirement Account. That is because money in an I.R.A., as such accounts are commonly called, will compound faster than it would if taxes took a bite out of each dollar invested and each dollar earned on the investment. According to calculations by Touche Ross, an individual who put $2,000 a year into an I.R.A. each year for 20 years, earning 12 percent on the funds invested, would accumulate $160,000. Over 40 years, the sum would jump to $1.7 million. After assuming 40 years of inflation, of course, this would be worth somewhat less than it is today. **********''Even if you are only putting in small amounts now, over time, because of compounding, the sums become astronomical,'' Mr. Paul commented. At 12 percent, the sum doubles every six years. **********Despite its general appeal, an Individual Retirement Account may create something of a dilemma for workers who save in a company plan where the employer matches their contributions, perhaps putting up $1 for every $2 put up by the employee. Funds saved by employees that are matched by a company are taxable and may not count as I.R.A.  contributions, warned Deborah Marx Fishman, a partner at Kwasha Lipton, an employee-benefits consulting firm. An Individual's Decision **********''For the average employee, who does not have enough money both to establish an I.R.A. and to continue in the company savings plan, the choice of which is better is not clear-cut,'' she said. ''The tax deduction for an I.R.A. is only a temporary thing, while the company match is an outright gift, and the funds can be withdrawn sooner and without penalty.'' **********The new rules governing retirement accounts are simple. Anyone with income from wages or salaries may take up to $2,000 of that income each year and put it into a specially designated retirement account. An individual with earnings from investments - but no compensation income - would not qualify for the special tax provisions for Individual Retirement Accounts. **********The new law allows people to put as much as 100 percent of their earned income into an I.R.A., with a limit of $2,000. This means that, beginning next year, someone who earns only $2,000 and does not need that money for living expenses could put all of the $2,000 into an I.R.A. (The new tax-exempt savings certificates, which will permit individuals to exclude up to $1,000 a person in interest from the certificates beginning Oct. 1, have no connection with the I.R.A.  program and generally would not be a wise investment vehicle for an I.R.A.) Liberalization of Rules **********Previous rules governing retirement accounts kept people covered by qualified company pension plans from establishing I.R.A.'s, unless they also had sources of earned income outside their company wages.  Those who did set up an I.R.A. could put no more than 15 percent of their earned income into it, up to a limit of $1,500 a person. Now even a self-employed person with a retirement program known as a Keogh Plan can put $2,000 into an I.R.A. on top of the $15,000 he can put into the Keogh Plan. And he can deduct all $17,000 from taxable income. **********The new tax law, like the old, permits an individual with a spouse who does not hold a job to set up an additional account for the nonworking spouse, and it raises the amounts. Under the new law, the two accounts together may total as much as $2,250, and the money may be divided almost any way between the two accounts. The only restrictions are that at least $250 must be put into the account of the nonworking spouse and that neither account may receive more than $2,000 in one year. **********While these accounts - and the tax exemption - look attractive, the individual should think hard about whether he is prepared to lock away the money until at least age 59 1/2, for there is a penalty for withdrawing money before then. Not only would the saver have to pay income taxes on any money withdrawn but he also would have to pay a penalty equal to 10 percent of the sums taken out early. Leeway on Withdrawals **********''If you're making only $10,000 a year, you may have better things to do with your money than put it aside,'' John W. Hamm, a tax partner at Arthur Young & Company, suggested. **********A person with enough funds may choose not to withdraw money at 59 1/2, allowing it to continue to compound tax-free. However, withdrawals must begin by the time the individual turns 70 1/2. Money withdrawn after that point may be withdrawn all at once or gradually. If it is taken out gradually, it must be withdrawn at least as fast as a schedule that would reduce the account to zero by the time the person is expected to die. Most banks and other institutions that are custodians for such retirement accounts have actuarial tables that can be used to determine a person's life expectancy. **********Deciding where to place I.R.A. dollars can be a challenge - something like choosing from a long Chinese restaurant menu. There are relatively few constraints on how the money may be invested, but the usual tax considerations go by the wayside. An individual may set up an I.R.A. for a year's income any time until he files his income tax return for that year, meaning it can be established as late as April 15 for the previous year. Buying Insurance Barred **********The only legal prohibition is that the funds may not be used to buy life insurance. (Because money already accumulates in insurance accounts tax-free and may also escape taxation when a person dies, Congress did not want to permit yet another layer of tax deferral through an I.R.A.) The new I.R.A. rules also penalize investments in collectibles - such as diamonds, rare stamps or antiques - in such a way that collectibles are effectively prohibited. **********''A good rule of thumb is to look for the safest investment with the highest return,'' Mr. Paul recommended. ''Going for the highest yield is really the name of the game.'' **********The bulk of the money in I.R.A.'s now is in various kinds of bank deposits. But with the anticipated expansion of I.R.A.'s, brokers and mutual funds are expected to make a greater pitch for the money.  Most of these institutions have programs with simple registration forms to fill out, for creating an I.R.A. **********''We'll have a system for people to take money already in our mutual funds and move it into an I.R.A.,'' Mr. Stein of Dreyfus said. ''Why shouldn't people move money to gain the tax exemption?'' A Company Savings Plan **********Another option under the new tax law may be to place the money in a company-sponsored retirement or savings program. Then the company, rather than the individual, is responsible for investing the money.  The funds must be designated as ''qualified voluntary employee contributions'' -the equivalent of an I.R.A. account -so that the employee may deduct them from his income for tax purposes. And they may not be dollars that the employer matches as part of a company savings plan. **********The individual who decides he has made a wrong investment for his I.R.A. has some flexibility in moving the funds around. Active changes, where the individual takes his money back and places it elsewhere (known as a rollover) may be made once each year. But if an employee retains the same bank or broker or fund manager who is serving as a trustee and simply shifts the I.R.A. money from one investment to another - say from stocks to bonds - then the move does not count as a rollover. **********Investment advisers expect this to be a strong selling point for mutual funds and brokerage firms, since an individual could transfer money from a money market fund to stocks to bonds and back, all without officially touching the money. **********The individual who does move his funds from one trustee to another has up to 60 days from the time he receives the money to establish a new I.R.A. account without its being deemed a withdrawal. And there is no legal bar against splitting the I.R.A. money among several types of accounts. The New Tax Law Fifth article of a series on how it affects investment planning.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/10/busin.body_text: **********The Ogden Corporation said that it had agreed to acquire the Buffalo Forge Company for $32.75 a share, or about $70 million, in 10-year Ogden promissory notes. **********The offer appears to rescue Buffalo Forge, a manufacturer of heavy industrial equipment, from an unwelcome, $25-a-share takeover bid from the Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation. **********Ogden said it had purchased 425,000 Buffalo treasury shares, or 16.6 percent of the company, for its 9 percent note and that it also had a year's option to buy 143,400 additional treasury shares, which would then increase its stake in the company to 21 percent. **********Both companies, without naming Ampco, said that if anyone bids $29 or more for at least 40 percent of Buffalo Forge, Buffalo Forge would be free to bid $32.75 in cash for a maximum of 500,000 shares and that Buffalo Forge has the right to ask Ogden to buy them, also for cash, if the merger between them collapses. **********Ampco had no immediate comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/world.main_headline: Soviet Rights Activist Gets A Five-Year Prison Term
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Soviet Rights Activist Gets A Five-Year Prison Term
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/03/world.body_text: **********Tatyana Osipova, a 32-year-old human rights activist, was convicted today of anti-Soviet agitation and sentenced to five years' imprisonment to be followed by five years of exile within the Soviet Union. **********Miss Osipova, who pleaded not guilty, could have received up to seven years in prison in addition to the internal exile. **********The charge stemmed from her participation in the unofficial Moscow group that monitors human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki agreements. **********The organizer of the group, Yuri F. Orlov, is in a Soviet prison camp in the Ural mountains despite international appeals for his release. ---- **********Jeri Laber, executive director of the New York-based Helsinki Watch Committee, said in a statement yesterday that the committee members were ''shocked and grieved'' at the sentencing of Miss Osipova and urged Moscow to ''reconsider the harsh punishment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/19/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; POLISH AUTHORITIES OUTLINE PLANS FOR TIES WITH UNION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/19/world.body_text: **********The Polish Government published a working paper last night on its relations with the independent trade union movement Solidarity. **********The document, which lists issues that the Government seeks to discuss with Solidarity, acknowledged the union's right to reply on national television and radio. **********It said Solidarity could have weekly programs to broadcast decisions of the union either nationally or locally.  Many of the issues listed for discussion were aimed at jointly solving Poland's economic crisis and preparing the nation for further hardships, such as a wage freeze and the relocation of workers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Unsold goods held by United States businesses rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in October as sales dropped sharply and the recession took hold, the Government reported today. **********October's rise in the seasonally adjusted value of business inventories, the 10th consecutive monthly increase, was accompanied by a 2.3 percent drop in sales, the second decrease in three months, a Commerce Department report said. **********That raised the inventory-to-sales ratio, which business officials try to keep low, from September's 1.44 to 1.48, the highest it has been since the 1.52 mark at the height of last year's recession. The ratio reflects the number of months it would take to sell off current stockpiles of products and materials at October's sales pace. **********''Businesses are already taking steps to bring inventories back in line with sales,'' Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said in a statement released by the department. Production Cutbacks Seen **********However, he added, ''production cutbacks are likely to carry on into early 1982, with attendant further increases in unemployment until business improves.'' **********Economists consider rising inventories, when accompanied by falling sales, a strong indication of recession since producers are likely to cut production and lay off workers rather than keep turning out products they are having trouble selling. **********Other economic indicators, such as unemployment, industrial production and retail sales, have also been worsening this fall.  The unemployment rate had already risen to 8.4 percent in November, the highest since the 1974 recession. Administration officials say it could rise as high as 9 percent, and some private economists say it could go even higher if the recession lingers very long into next year. Car Sales Off 9.7% **********Lagging car sales, a severe problem for much of the year, helped contribute to the overall October sales decline, dropping 9.7 percent, the Commerce Departmernt report said. **********However, auto dealers' inventories rose only one-tenth of 1 percent for the month, an indication that the industry has already cut back production substantially and probably will not suffer a much bigger inventory buildup. **********The report put total inventories held by United States manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers at $513 billion in October, with sales at $345.4 billion. Both figures were adjusted for normal seasonal variations in inventories and sales. **********Inventories of durable goods, items such as autos and heavy appliances that are expected to last three years or more, rose 1.1 percent in October compared with seven-tenths of 1 percent for nondurables, another indication that current economic weakness is concentrated in housing, autos and other durable-goods industries dependent on those two giants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/13/busin.body_text: **********John Bickford, president of the sales group for the Westmoreland Coal Company, recalled the marathon sessions during which he and officials of the Israeli Electric Company sat blearyeyed trying to agree on a 30-year contract to deliver steam coal to the utility. **********''It was pretty tough,'' he said, with both sides seeking the best terms possible. But after numerous trips to Haifa, Mr. Bickford came back late last year with what is believed to be the first major longterm export contract for steam coal landed by an American coal company. **********The agreement, under which Westmoreland expects to deliver a minimum of 15.7 million metric tons of steam coal, used mostly to produce electricity, over 30 years, is viewed as a key part of the company's strategy to cope with a slowdown in its traditional markets. **********Others Looking for Exports **********Westmoreland's hopes for the export market are shared by many domestic coal companies. In fact, the Pittston Company, the Island Creek Coal Company and Armco were all battling for the contract with Israeli Electric, which is switching from oil to coal. **********''We need the security to be able to pay for our investment, as opposed to wondering every year that we might not have a market,'' said Pemberton Hutchinson, Westmoreland's president, in an interview. **********A decline in demand from overseas steel mills for metallurgical coal and reduced shipments of steam coal to domestic utilities sharply reduced Westmoreland's earnings last year. And in this year's first quarter, the company was in the red for the first time since 1961. **********''Westmoreland is struggling,'' Jack Kawa, a coal analyst for Wheat First Securities, a brokerage firm in Richmond, said. He estimated that Westmoreland would lose about $8 million to $10 million in the present quarter even if the coal strike is settled this month. **********Thus long-term contracts such as the one concluded with Israeli Electric, he added, become particularly important. The provisions to recover rapidly rising costs increase the company's ability to keep up with inflation and lessen its vulnerability to losses from lower prices on short-term contracts when the coal market is soft. Development Costs Increase **********In the past, Mr. Hutchinson noted, the company has had short-term export contracts that had to be renegotiated every year. The risk of developing new coal mines in the 1970's, when the cost was about $20 per ton a year, was not as great as now, with the price at $50 to $70 per ton a year. **********''If you have a one-year contract,'' Mr. Hutchinson observed, ''the banks are not going to lend you $100 million. If you have a long-term contract it will certainly help.'' **********Now some of those risks are haunting Westmoreland. Because the market for coal has not expanded as rapidly as the industry had expected, excess capacity has developed. **********Westmoreland, for example, has put into mothballs its Triangle Mine Complex in Eccles, W. Va., on which it had spent $21 million.  The phase-out of steel-making capacity and the severe drop in demand for steel last year have depressed the demand for metallurgical coal, used by steel companies to make coke. **********In addition, a venture in Montana on which the company has spent $80 million to develop surface mines for steam coal has also been scaled back. Originally planned for a capacity of 10 million tons a year, the mines have been producing at a rate of 5 million tons. Conservation a Factor **********Major utilities in this Western region have decided to put off expansion of power-generating plants because of reduced demand, resulting from consumer conservation. This has left Westmoreland with excess capacity. In addition the company has closed other mines to bring production more into line with demand. **********Lower coal prices and reduced shipments have cut the income of this medium-sized coal company, ranking 13th in production, from a high of $48.2 million, or $7.07 a share, in 1976, to $340,000, or 5 cents a share, last year. It reported a loss of $4.8 million for the first quarter of this year. **********Last year it sold 16 million tons of coal - 66 percent of which was steam coal - for $448 million, but lost money on its coal operations. It was able to turn in a modest profit from the recovery of deferred income taxes and the sale of a subsidiary, Virginia Birmingham Bolt Inc., which makes bolts used in mines. Five Died in Explosion **********Also Last Nov. 7 an explosion at its Ferrell Mine killed five miners, an accident that led the Virginia Department of Mines to fine Westmoreland $255,450 for violations; five of the mine supervisors were fined a total of $63,500. **********Westmoreland cannot sustain many more quarters with such sizable losses, said Mr. Kawa, the analyst.  One of the few bright spots for the company, therefore, was the surge in steam coal exports and the long-term contract with the Israelis. **********Westmoreland was eager to find long-term export business to provide a market for some of its excess capacity and lessen the risk of developing new mines. **********The company's effort focused on countries where it felt it might have an advantage over its competitors. ''You can't shotgun shoot the whole world market,'' Mr. Hutchinson said. A Key Advantage **********Westmoreland offers a major advantage in the battle for export markets: It is an independent coal company, **********This is important to customers concerned about an involvement with coal companies that are subsidiaries of oil companies. Two such companies are the Consolidation Coal Company, a subsidiary of Conoco, and the Island Creek Coal Company, a subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Company. **********Some executives involved in talks with delegations from overseas utilties noted that there was concern about a possible conflict of interest, in which a company might hold back on the development of coal if its oil sales started to decline. **********Even with such an advantage, Westmoreland faces a serious hurdle: port congestion. It is an important point, since Westmoreland insisted in its bargaining that it would not be responsible for demurrage costs incurred for loading delays. **********The company stressed, however, that it had joined with Armco, Ashland Coal and Utah International to develop a coal export terminal at Newport News, Va., the nation's largest coal port. **********Mr. Hutchinson said that the company was seeking diversified customers, particularly in export markets, which promise more rapid growth. **********The company is meeting with delegations from South Korea and Japan to discuss long-term agreements for steam coal.  Most European countries, which have been largely responsible for the surge in exports of American steam coal, have adopted a waitand-see attitude. **********They are willing to negotiate short one- to three-year contracts to see whether the port congestion will ease and what the long-range effects of the coal strike will be.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/10/busin.main_headline: CHRYSLER TANK UNIT STIRS BUYER INTEREST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/10/busin.print_headline: CHRYSLER TANK UNIT STIRS BUYER INTEREST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/10/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation said today that several companies had ''expressed an interest'' in buying Chrysler Defense Inc., the subsidiary that makes tanks for the Army. **********Chrysler said, in a terse announcement, that it had provided information about the subsidiary to the unnamed companies and that representatives of the potential buyers had toured the tank plants in Lima, Ohio, and Warren, Mich. Both plants are owned by the Army and operated by Chrysler. **********Chrysler said it had not decided to sell the subsidiary and had not begun negotiations with any of the interested parties.  Chrysler executives have said for some time that selling Chrysler Defense as well as the company's profitable auto assembly operation in Mexico were last-ditch possibilities if Chrysler ran seriously short of cash. The company still has not used $300 million of the $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees that were approved by Congress. The company's chairman, Lee A. Iacocca, has pledged not to turn to Washington again for aid. Sales Incentives Cited **********Chrysler officials have maintained that the company's sales incentives have assured enough production to get it through the fourth quarter. Nevertheless, they have acknowledged that the unexpected weakness of automobile sales is endangering its plans for financial recovery. **********Talking to reporters last week, Chrysler's chief financial officer, Robert S. Miller, said the company needed its share of a 9.5 million industry sales level to be profitable. ''If the market keeps dropping for another six months, you can all go write stories at General Motors,'' he said. The auto industry's sales this year are expected to total somewhere between 8.6 million and 8.8 million vehicles. M1 Tank Has Its Critics **********Although the tank subsidiary provides the parent company with an estimated annual profit of about $60 million, the M-1 tank it produces has been criticized for its price tag - $2.7 million each - and reliability problems. Army officials have said they are considering adding a competitive supplier for the M-1 tank but add that no decision has been made. **********In a recent interview with Ward's Auto World, Chrysler's vice chairman, Gerald Greenwald, said the company had $250 million in cash at the end of the third quarter, but he conceded that the current quarter would be a drain on its resources. **********Commenting on what Chrysler might do if it found itself in a cash pinch, Mr. Greenwald said: ''We've learned to build a set of contingency plans, and they go from pleasant to unpleasant. But they all have Chrysler here to stay, and we'll invoke some of them as necessary.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.main_headline: SATISFACTION VOICED BY U.S. ON NATO ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.print_headline: SATISFACTION VOICED BY U.S. ON NATO ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.body_text: **********Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he was ''very satisfied'' with the recognition by the European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that they might be required to ''facilitate'' United States deployments in areas outside Europe. **********He said he had no doubt that if there should be an invasion of Middle Eastern oilfields, presumably by the Soviet Union, ''countries whose vital interests'' were affected would want to provide ''facilities to assist in repelling the invaders.'' **********A statement issued after the two-day meeting of NATO defense ministers here, while promising ''all the resources needed'' to strengthen military forces, stopped short of assuring the United States of the use of ports and of transit and overflight rights that would be required to move forces rapidly from the United States to the Persian Gulf or other areas. **********Agreement on Increasing Outlays **********Another reason for American satisfaction, Mr. Weinberger said, is that the defense ministers confirmed their willingness to continue raising military expenditures by 3 percent a year in real terms. **********This formula was agreed on in May 1977, but some members of the alliance, notably the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and Portugal, have gone above the 3 percent mark in the last two years. Others, including Denmark and Canada, have lagged. Canada, regarded by European members as a country rich in resources, spent only 1.7 percent of its gross national product on defense in 1979. **********Although a Soviet threat to the oil resources of the Persian Gulf has been recognized for more than a year, American officials believe that this was the first defense meeting at which European members had faced the related questions of what they could do to assist American deployment in Southwest Asia and what they would have to do if that deployment cut into the reinforcements earmarked for Europe. **********''There was no disagreement,'' Mr. Weinberger said. ''NATO is very concerned.'' The alliance's first step in the event of a threat to the oilfields would be to consult on the nature of the threat ''in order to deter aggression and to respond to requests from other nations for help in resisting threats to their security or independence,'' the statement said. Statement Falls Short of U.S. Aims **********The defense ministers, it continued, recognized that common objectives identified in their consultations ''may require members of the alliance to facilitate out-of-area deployments in support of the vital interests of all.'' **********This statement falls well short of what the United States seeks, military sources said. Greece, Italy and West Germany are wary about granting port facilities or overflight rights for troops or equipment of the rapid deployment force moving to Southwest Asia. Mr.  Weinberger, who flew to Lisbon this afternoon, is expected to sound the Portuguese Government about its attitude to these issues. **********An important issue for NATO's European members is the impact on defense planning in the case of American intervention in Southwest Asia or elsewhere. This, the statement noted, ''could involve possible changes in the availability of combat and support forces currently committed to NATO'' as reinforcements. The communique said that Europe, in that case, should also maintain and strengthen its ability to deter aggression. **********Whether this is probable is remote. Military sources stress that the thin crust of allied forces in West Germany cannot be appreciably strengthened in current economic conditions. **********However, the defense ministers agreed that military planning should provide for changes in the availability of forces assigned to NATO because of national operations outside the alliance's boundaries in support of the allies' vital interests.
