https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/05/busin.main_headline: COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY PERVADES LIF E IN JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/05/busin.print_headline: COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY PERVADES LIF E IN JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/05/busin.body_text: **********At every turn here, one confronts overwhelming evidence that Japan, more than any other nation, has embraced advanced electronic and computer technology as a way to improve industrial productivity, save energy and, in theory, make day-to-day life more convenient, enriching and entertaining. **********The influence of such technology is apparent in hundreds of small ways. In the Asahi Shimbun building, home of the leading Japanese newspaper, venetian blinds rise and fall at the whim of an energyconscious computer. In the Hotel Okura, a visitor does not have to request a wake-up call because a soft beep can be ordered for any time by punching a few buttons on an electronic bedside console. **********''I've lived here for four years, so I should be inured to it, but I'm still struck every time I walk through Akihabara,'' said Eric W.  Hayden, chief economist for the Bank of America's Asia division. He was referring to the bustling district of semiconductor shops that form a veritable electronics flea market. ''This is where these people really excel - in electronics,'' he added. **********To expand its success in electronics, Japan hopes to do what it has not yet done: come up with new basic technology on its own, rather than just embellish the computer technology developed by other nations, the United States in particular. **********The market-oriented Japanese approach to electronic research has led Japan's trading partners to accuse it of being a free rider in the technological area. Japan now seems committed to changing this image. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry announced in recent months that it would spend more than $300 million over the next decade on these major research projects: **********- Development of a supercomputer that would be more than 60 times faster than the best now available. **********- Basic work on a ''fifth-generation'' computer that could follow oral commands as well as solve problems nobody told it to tackle - a capacity known as ''artificial intelligence.'' **********- Development of new, sophisticated semiconductor devices.  The prospect of Japan's forging ahead in computer manufacturing, a sector where the United States still claims supremacy, is worrying American executives and Government officials. They see the possibility of a challenge to the industry's giant, the International Business Machines Corporation. **********''There is a feeling that, in 10 years or so, the best computers in the world may well be made by Fujitsu and Hitachi,'' Franklin J.  Vargo, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce, said during a recent interview in his Washington office. ''If that happens, it will give Japan enormous leverage in the United States in terms of foreign and defense policy because we, as a society, are so dependent on computers, and that dependency will only increase.'' **********Japan's reliance on electronics and computers is easy to see in its factories, where impressive gains in productivity have been achieved, mainly because of the nation's ability to introduce electronic techniques in industries that were once mechanical. This has reduced labor costs and has increased efficiency. 'Robots Making Robots' **********Perhaps the most striking example of this trend is the handful of so-called manless factories that are springing up in Japan. In Nagoya, for instance, the Yamazaki Machinery Works has opened a plant in which computer-controlled machine tools produce more machine tools exactly like themselves. Some people describe the process as ''robots making robots.'' **********The plant, which will begin full operation in October, already runs 24 hours a day, with five workers in each of the first two shifts and no workers in the third shift. The main task of the human laborers is to check for wear on the 18 machines. Company officials told a delegation of Americans -members of Congress, business executives and academic leaders - who visited the plant last week that a conventional factory would need 70 machines and a work force of 200 to match the production of this automated setup. **********The evidence of observation and the success of Japanese electronic products in international markets suggest that Japan is a leader in making the transition toward an electronic-based, fully computerized society - what some people call the ''second industrial revolution.'' Jean-Jacque s Servan-Schreiber, the French writer, asserts in his new book, ''T he World Challenge,'' that ''Japan stands as a model to the world.'' **********An ambitious vision of Japan's future is offered in a report issued in June by an advisory group to the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. This stud y, which has not yet b een published in English, predicts that the pace of computeriz ation will continue without letup, changing industrial practices and people's everyday routines more than ever. The report represent s a consensus of views of top business and governmental officials. Felt Virtually Everywhere **********A hint of things to come can also be seen on the office wall of the trade ministry's electronics policy division. Smiling cartoon characters in a black-and-white mural inhabit a community where the computer's presence is felt virtually everywhere - in homes, offices and other places. **********In the mural, physicians in hospitals have only to push a button to flash a patient's entire medical history onto a video screen.  Computer-controlled vehicles have replaced buses and taxis. Seagoing robots roam the ocean, gauging underwater currents and spotting schools of fish. **********Gesturing toward the mural, Kiyoshi Hosomizo, a department chief in the electronics policy division, says that ''these are examples of the future computer-oriented society.'' **********Although such a future is years away, the plan has moved beyond the drawing board. For example, 160 families near Osaka are already linked together by a network of computer terminals, cameras and microphones in a Government-sponsored experiment. The system allows two-way communication and includes a wide variety of entertainment and educational offerings, such as English lessons for individuals. **********''The experiment is going very well,'' said Haruo Katsuyama, the trade ministry official overseeing the project. ''The people like it because of all the information they can get.'' **********According to a booklet describing the experiment, the data in greatest demand are these: men want golfing lessons, women want cooking tips and children want cartoon fairy tales. Poor in Natural Resources **********Japan has moved so rapidly to increase the use of electronics and computers in its economy because it is poor in natural resources. The country has to import nearly all of the oil it consumes, for example. Reacting to the two oil price shocks of the 1970's, Japan began to develop an industrial system that relies on its highly skilled, energetic work force rather than on scarce resources. **********Beyond the pressure of necessity, however, Japan's impressive push into the electronic age also owes much to the business-oriented society that prevails in this nation of 118 million people.  Structural differences in the Japanese system, many observers say, has given it a big edge over other countries. **********In Japan, for example, much of the stock of big corporations is typically owned by banks and other financial institutions, far more so than in the United States. The banks are often major lenders to the same corporations whose stock they own. **********Being beholden to knowledgable owners and creditors, who are less concerned about quarterly profit gains than long-range financial health, makes it easier for Japanese corporate executives to invest in computer-controlled production equipment even if short-term earnings suffer as a result. **********In addition, antitrust laws in Japan are less stringent than in the United States, permitting a measure of consultation between companies and cooperative effort in some areas that would be illegal in America. Lifetime Employment **********Most large Japanese companies maintain a system of lifetime employment for their workers, and unions are delineated not by the workers' trade but by the company that employs them. All this helps explain why Japanese workers have been so receptive to the introduction of computers - they have no fear of losing their jobs. A machinist whose job has become obsolete, for instance, may become a specialist in programming the very robot that displaced him on the shop floor. **********Consequently, there are more robots in Japanese factories than in all other countries combined, it is generally believed. The Japan Industrial Robot Association says about 70,000 robots are operating in Japan. Other estimates vary because there is no clear-cut definition of just what qualifies as a robot. Narrower definitions put the Japanese robot population at roughly 7,500. **********The apparent ease with which Japan has moved toward a more efficient economy based on electronics is in marked contrast to the slowe r progre ss of other nations, including the United States. To some analysts , the Japanese success implies flaws in America's business and economic policies. **********''We have an antiquated financial system, antiquated antitrust laws, an antiquated labor system and an antiquated management approach,'' Prof. William G. Ouchi of the University of California at Los Angeles said the other day during an inte rview in Tokyo. He recently began a three-year study, financed b y several American companies, comparing the electronics industri es of Japan and the United States. **********''You don't find out your weaknesses until you have a competitor,'' Mr. Ouchi added. ''And Japan is that competitor.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/world.main_headline: SCHOOL CLASSES FOUND UNRELATED TO SCORES IN WORLD-AFFAIRS TEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/world.print_headline: SCHOOL CLASSES FOUND UNRELATED TO SCORES IN WORLD-AFFAIRS TEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/world.body_text: **********A survey of American college students that was made public yesterday shows that those who study foreign languages or take courses on international affairs are no more likely to have a grasp of world issues than other students. **********Misconceptions about population, energy, religion and nutrition were common even among the students scoring the highest on a test in the survey, and there were few indications that the curriculums of many schools provide the knowledge that many students lack. **********The project was sponsored by the Council on Learning, a nonprofit research group, and the Educational Testing Service, which prepared the multiple-choice test of 101 questions that was taken by a scientifically selected sample of 3,000 students across the country.  The project was paid for with $500,000 in grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities and the Department of Education and $130,000 from the Exxon Education Foundation. **********On the average, seniors answered 50.5 percent of the questions correctly, freshmen answered 41.9 percent correctly and the students at two-year community colleges scored 40.5 percent. Fewer than 10 percent of the seniors scored above 67 percent, and no one answered more than 84 questions correctly. Education Majors Scored Lowest **********About 30 percent knew the trend of world population growth, fewer than 25 percent understood the pattern of fossil fuel consumption and about 15 percent knew the purpose of recently completed international trade negotiations. **********History majors consistently scored the highest and education majors the lowest. In general, students who had taken courses related to global issues were not more knowledgeable than those who had not.  Reading newspapers and magazines was a far more important factor in being informed. **********''Efforts to enhance the campus experience outside of the traditional domestic concentration will require comprehensive reviews of the total curriculum and the learning experience of each academic institution,'' a panel of prominent citizens stated. ''To merely add international appendages to predominently domestic concerns does not reflect a world in which these issues have long existed.'' **********''The lack of association between knowledge and course study is disappointing,'' commented the report of the survey, ''College Students' Knowledge and Beliefs: A Survey of Global Understanding,'' which is being published by Change Magazine Press. No Tie to Language Study Found **********This finding was apparently one of the reasons that the panel urged an overhaul of curriculums rather than the addition of more courses in an approach that seems not to be working. **********The absence of a relationship between proficiency in a foreign language and knowledge of world affairs was called ''the most surprising result of this analysis of correlations.'' **********Nearly 90 percent of the students had studied a foreign language, but only a third felt they could order a meal and only one in 12 could understand a native speaker. **********Many students mistakenly said that the Helsinki accords of 1975 established a court for human rights complaints and did not know that one of the major accomplishments of the accords was the recognition of human rights as a legitimate subject of East-West discussion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/24/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; A.M.C.: $1.6 Billion For New Vehicles
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/24/busin.body_text: **********The American Motors Corporation said today that it will spend $1.6 billion to develop new, fuel-efficient vehicles that will strengthen its ability to compete with Japanese imports. **********A.M.C.'s chairman, Gerald C. Meyers, announced the program - which the company called the largest capital investment program in its history - in response to Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige who earlier this week asked domestic auto makers to explain what they are doing to solve the auto industry's financial problems. **********''We believe that U.S. auto manufacturers have a clear responsibility to do everything they can to restore the health of the industry,'' Mr. Meyers said. ''American Motors Corporation has taken vigorous, imaginative and timely steps to solve its own problems without Government assistance.'' **********In addition to the capital investment program, A.M.C. said that, as part of a ''15-point self-help program to meet the challenge of Japanese imports,'' it has cut its corporate salaried work force by about 13 percent, stopped paying dividends to its stockholders and entered into a partnership with the French auto maker Renault - which now owns about 46 percent of American Motors. The auto maker also said it had frozen merit pay increase for salaried employees and since January has trimmed its car prices 10 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/03/busin.body_text: **********Three more United States refiners raised their wholesale gasoline prices yesterday amid indications that Saudi Arabia, America's largest foreign oil supplier, may cut production by 500,000 barrels a day to remove some slack from the global oil market. **********Declining world oil demand has almost negated the impact of the five-month-old Iraq-Iran war and resumed exports from both oil states could create a world oil glut by summer, analysts say. **********The Mobil Corporation, the nation's No.2 refiner, lifted its wholesale gasoline prices by 1 to 1.5 cents a gallon and the Atlantic Richfield Company, ranked seventh, raised its gasoline by 1 to 2 cents - depending on region. **********The Sun Company, the No.10 refiner, raised its gasoline by a penny a gallon in New England and upstate New York last Saturday but lowered it by 1 cent in Florida. **********Meanwhile, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly reported yesterday that Saudi Arabia, the largest producer in the Organization of Petroleum Exaporting Countries, was ''beginning to hint it may make small 'token' oil production cuts going into the second quarter. **********''The reduction might be around 500,000 barrels a day off Aramco's current 10 million barrel a day output,'' the journal said.  The United States imports 1.3 million barrels a day from Saudi Arabia, or 24 percent of its crude imports.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/22/world.body_text: **********An American-trained battalion of the Salvadoran Army landed in Honduras last week and then crossed the border back into El Salvador to attack this village. **********According to some of the soldiers among the group of several hundred brought here, they landed in Honduras on Friday in an effort to surround the guerrillas in Los Filos. They said they had walked for almost a full day before engaging in combat with the guerrilla forces that occupied the village. Supported by mortars and heavy artillery, the soldiers said, they fought for nearly two days before they chased the guerrillas off of the mountain on which the village sits. **********The soldiers said there were no United States military advisers with them.  An officer said that the casualties on both sides had been ''very light.'' Villagers in Honduras said that the area had been bombed for several days before the soldiers arrived. Today, helicopters flew overhead and the echo of automatic rifle fire echoed off the gorges below the clouds that draped the mountain ridges. Established as a Neutral Area **********In 1969, after a brief war between Honduras and El Salvador, the Organization of American States established the area around Los Filos as one of several neutral zones thatneither country's armed forces were allowed to enter. **********Asked about the soldiers being in a demilitarized zone, a senior officer here said that because a peace treaty had been signed last year between Honduras and El Salvador it was no longer an important issue. The O.A.S. has not taken any actions that would make it legal for either country's armed forces to be in the area. **********Today, anything that moved in the gorges below Los Filos was subject to being shot at. As they climbed up to the camp, four journalists waving a large white flag with red letters spelling out ''Press'' were pinned down in a cornfield by automatic weapons fire for several minutes. **********When it was finally explained that the four were journalists, smiling soldiers escorted them to their camp, making a final steep ascent through a tunnel of trees. **********An unsmiling senior officer, wearing a camouflage hat, a knife attached to his uniform at the chest and with a plastic covered topographical map in his pocket, agreed to talk with the reporters but declined to give his name and said that he could not speak officially. 'Landed in Our Country' **********Asked if the battalion had landed in Honduras, he said, ''According to us, we landed in our country.'' But on the Honduran side of the border, a shirtless village boy, encouraged by his parents, led a reporter along a narrow, rutted path to a cornfield down the mountain from the Honduran village of Valladolid, near where the Salvadoran soldiers said they had landed.  The young villager told how he had watched as the helicopters hovered just above the cornstalks and the soldiers jumped out. He pointed in the directions they ran. Other villagers who said they were Hondurans also reported the landing. **********One Honduran army sergeant in the area said that the Salvadorans landed with permission from his Government. Others said that if the landing was not with the knowledge of the Hondurans, the soldiers would have started shooting, thinking that another war had begun. **********In Los Filos, exhausted soldiers, many with green camouflage grease smeared on their faces and green bandannas covering the top of their heads, sprawled in uncomfortable positions against mud brick walls, M-16 automatic rifles across their chests. **********At the highest point of the village, with sweeping vistas of mountain ranges in Honduras and in El Salvador, soldiers and officers congregated around a mud hut hidden by bamboo trees and tropical foliage. The dirt was littered with pages of a child's school notebook, smashed ceramic pots of red beans, and the feathers and severed heads of ducks and chickens that had been slaughtered to feed the soldiers. **********The villagers in Los Filos had supported the leftists and the surrounding area was controlled militarily by the guerrilla forces of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. From here, the guerriillas had launched frequent attacks on Arcapao and put pressure on Chalatenango, a major city which the Front has been trying to seize. **********The steep hillsides below Los Filos were abandoned, except for scrawny cattle grazing unattended in cornfields.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/19/busin.body_text: **********STANDARD BRANDS is yanking all its food advertising, with total billings of $17 million, out of four major agencies and assigning them all to MCA Advertising. **********The losers are Doyle Dane Bernbach and Wells Rich Greene, which went on Standard Brands' agency roster three years ago with products reassigned from Ted Bates & Company; D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, which had the Royal Desserts line, and Lee King & Partners, Chicago, which had the Curtiss candy division. **********MCA Advertising is a New York-based division of the Marketing Corporation of America; its other units include a successful newspaper couponing distribution system, a sales promotion arm, a market research division and a management consultancy. **********Standard Brands management got to know MCA management when the latter was doing a study of the former's organizational structure and recommending a new approach - from brand to category groupings, much like General Foods uses. **********Advertising people with long memories may recall that during an interview last January, Arthur S. Pearson, who had recently become Standard Brands' first corporate vice president for advertising and marketing, had a few things to say about changing agencies. Having voiced disapproval of some of the methods of agency evaluation, he remarked: ''I think agencies and clients know themselves when it's time for a change. And I hope I can help to bring longer client relationships.'' **********Some months later Standard Brands and Nabisco announced merger plans that will end up with the Nabisco chairman, Robert M.  Schaeberle, as the chief. Nabisco may list six agencies in the Standard Directory of Advertisers, but only two, the William Esty Company and McCann-Erickson, have most of the business. **********Standard Brands, on the other hand, lists 13 agencies with assignments scattered all over the place.  Nabisco spent an estimated $72.8 million for advertising in 1979.  This year Standard Brands said it was lifting its advertising from $30 million to more than $50 million. **********One agency executive close to the Standard Brand scene said that what it all came down to was that the executives of MCA (James R.  McManus, chairman, and William D. Dunlap Jr., president) promised Standard Brand personal, top management involvement with the advertising, which is easy to promise if the client makes the account big enough. **********The assignment to MCA Advertising is for Fleischmann's Margarine, Spread and Egg Beaters, which had been at W.R.G.; Blue Bonnet Margarine and Spread, which had been at Doyle Dane; Royal Gelatin and Desserts, which were at D'Arcy, and Baby Ruth, Butterfinger and Reggie bars, which had been at Lee King. **********Wells, Rich also had the products of the American Distilled Spirits Company, which, Mr. Pearson said, will be assigned to one of Standard Brands' liquor agencies. **********The company's other agencies are Benton & Bowles, with Planters Peanuts; the J. Walter Thompson Company, with Fleischmann's Yeast, and Sacks & Rosen; Waring & LaRosa, and Mathieu, Gerfen & Bresner, which handle the Beverage Group. **********MCA Advertising came into being three and a half years ago with the Lorillard cigarette business that had been at William Graham. By last December, MCA was billing some $75 million, which led Mr. McManus, the chairman, to say, ''We are the second-fastest growing agency after Backer & Spielvogel.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/09/busin.body_text: **********The economic decline that began in January 1980 bottomed out just seven months later, making it the shortest recession on record, according to the National Bureau of Economic Research. **********The nonprofit research group's Business Cycle Dating Committee, composed of seven academic economists, is widely considered the most authoritative voice on the existence, timing and duration of recessions. Its business-cycle chronology dates back to 1854, and since 1961 its business-cycle evaluations have been adopted as official by the Department of Commerce. **********''The depth and breadth of the contraction in early 1980 clearly marked it as a recession in spite of its unusual brevity,'' the bureau said yesterday. Some economists had been reluctant to call the downturn a recession because a recession is normallly defined as two consecutive quarters of decline in the measure of total goods and services produced, known as the gross national product. In 1980, real G.N.P., the statistic that adjusts those overall output figures to eliminate the impact of inflation, declined only in the second quarter. **********The committee fixed last July as the trough of the decline at a meeting in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday at which it reviewed trends in key economic statistics. Some of these indicators, such as the G.N.P., retail sales and total civilian employment, reached their nadir in May or June. But most, including total industrial production, nonfarm employment, personal income and overall unemployment, did not indicate an end to the recession until July. Not 'Mechanical' **********On a quarterly basis, the economy reached a peak in the first quarter of 1980 and hit its trough in the third quarter, the committee said. **********''It is not a mechanical formula,'' said Martin Feldstein, a Harvard professor who is president of the National Bureau and a member of the committee. ''We try to decide what is important and what may be explained by an anomaly.'' **********The decision that the trough came in July reflected not only broad statistics, but also figures showing that most industrial groups reached their production trough that month, he said. **********The decision came 13 months after the committee announced that the nation was in a recession that had begun in January 1980. The sevenmonth peak-to-trough movement was one month shorter than the previous record, set by the recession that lasted from August 1918 to March 1919. **********''There is really no trend to be seen from this,'' Mr. Feldstein said. The business-cycle information is primarily of interest to those who want to follow the performance of particular activities or markets, such as housing starts or interest rates, against the background of the business cycles. **********The recession was the nation's seventh since World War II. While it was shorter than the average of just under one year, it was marked by a 9.6 percent G.N.P. decline in the second quarter, the steepest on record. **********The economists who closed the books on the recession at yesterday's meeting were: Mr. Feldstein and Benjamin Freidman, both from Harvard University; Robert Gordon, Northwestern University; Robert Hall, Stanford University; Geoffrey Moore, director of the Center for International Business Cycle Research at Rutgers University, and Victor Zarnowitz, University of Chicago. The seventh committee member, Prof. William Branson of Princeton University, was unable to attend.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/17/world.main_headline: 2 SALVADORAN LEFTIST GROUPS SEEK ROLE AT U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/17/world.print_headline: 2 SALVADORAN LEFTIST GROUPS SEEK ROLE AT U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/17/world.body_text: **********A clandestine guerrilla radio station said today that two anti-Government leftist groups wanted to be represented at the United Nations General Assembly. **********The broadcast by Radio Venceremos said Guillermo Ungo, head of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, would lead a delegation of Salvadoran leftists to the United Nations. But it did not say who would go with him or when they would leave. **********The broadcast said the delegation would represent Mr. Ungo's group and a coalition of guerrilla organizations, the Faribundo Marti National Liberation Front. **********At a rally yesterday, President Jose Napoleon Duarte asked the leftist groups to lay down their arms and show that they were ''representative political forces'' by forming political parties and taking part in elections scheduled for next year. **********He was apparently speaking of a statement by Mexico and France on Aug. 28 that recognized leftists in El Salvador as ''representative political forces.'' **********Elections are scheduled for March for an assembly to name an interim President and Vice President. Presidential elections are planned in 1983. Duarte to Visit U.S. **********A presidential spokesman confirmed reports that Mr. Duarte would go to the United States next week but gave no details except to say that he would visit New York. State Department sources in Washington said he was expected to meet with high Administration officials. **********The United States is supporting the junta with economic and military aid and favors elections, rather than negotiations with the leftists, as a route to peace in El Salvador. **********Maj. Robert D'Abuisson, a rightist who has been underground in San Salvador for months, announced plans today to form a political party ''despite obstacles imposed by the Government's official party.'' **********Major D'Abuisson has often been accused of directing extreme rightwing groups, but he denies the accusations and says, ''What I am is a true anti-Communist.'' He made the announcement through a spokesman. **********Others who say they will form parties for the March elections are the Productive Alliance, a business group, and the new Democratic Action, a group headed by Rene Fortin Magana, a lawyer who has a revolutionary background but says he opposes violence. **********Others preparing to take part include Mr. Duarte's Christian Democrat Party, the Popular Orientation Party and the National Conciliation Party. The latter was the Government party when a military coup ousted the military regime of Gen. Carlos Humberto Romero in October 1979. **********The Salvadoran Human Rights Commission estimates that more than 32,000 Salvadorans have been killed in political violence since then, when the civilian-mili tary junta was formed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/06/world.print_headline: WALESA HOLDS TALKS WITH POLISH ARCHBISHOP
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/06/world.body_text: **********Lech Walesa, leader of the Solidarity union movement, met today with the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, apparently to discuss deteriorating relations between the independent union and the Government. **********The union's news service, which announced the meeting, did not disclose the nature of the talks. Church sources who asked not to be identified said the discussions lasted two-and-a-half hours, but they gave no details. **********Archbishop Glemp has said he is always ready to mediate between the two sides for the sake of social calm and avoiding confrontation.  Solidarity threatened on Friday to call a nationwide strike if Poland's Communist leaders asked Parliament to invoke emergency powers that would curtail union action. Talks Have Broken Down **********On Nov. 4 the Communist Party leader and Prime Minister, Gen.  Wojciech Jaruzelski, met with Mr. Walesa and Archbishop Glemp to discuss forming a front for national accord and cooperation. But since then all negotiations between the union and the Government have broken down. **********The situation worsened on Wednesday when the authorities ordered policemen and troops to evict cadets who were on strike at a firemen's training academy in Warsaw. **********The leader of the country's organization of private farmers, Jan Kulaj, proposed today that his union and Solidarity merge with the independent student union into one movement. Divisive Tactics Charged **********A statement by the three-million-member Peasants' Solidarity, signed by Mr. Kulaj, said the movement would consolidate farmers, workers and students against Government attempts to set the three groups at odds. **********It said his union supported the stand taken on Thursday by the presidium of the industrial Solidarity union, which claims 13 million members, warning of a general strike over Communist terms for a front of national accord. **********''Like the presidium, we disagree with the tactic of taking Polish citizens by surprise with Government decisions in which they were not consulted, with inconclusive talks, unrealized or broken off agreements, stimulating the atmosphere of discontent in order to bring about confrontation and annul Government pledges,'' Mr. Kulaj said in the statement. ''We are against giving the Government extraordinary measures for overpowering the nation.''

The unit is called the MCA Marketing Group, and its managing director is Morgan V. Hunter, who resigned last November from the Scott Paper Company. **********He was president and chief operating officer, having resigned the same titles at R.J. Reynolds Tobacco in 1979 to go to Scott. **********The new unit that the 51-year-old Mr. Hunter will be running starting July 1, will be composed of the Marketing Consulting Division, the MCA Development Agency, MCA Research and MCA Advertising, a fast-growing, full-service agency in New York. **********The announcement was made by James R. McManus, chairman of M.C.A., who had started at Procter & Gamble with Mr. Hunter. As chairman of the MCA Advertising agency, Mr. McManus will report to Mr. Hunter, but Mr. Hunter will be reporting to him as chairman of M.C.A. **********Mr. Hunter, an infantry soldier in Korea, had also worked as a senior vice president in charge of worldwide consumer businesses for American Cyanamid, having gone there after 18 years at P.& G., where his last post was as head of its coffee division and head of its Folger Coffee Company. **********What had Mr. Hunter been doing since leaving Scott? Mr. McManus was asked.  ''Finding tax shelters for the $1 million settlement,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/29/world.main_headline: POLES IN TORONTO START A PRO-SOLIDARITY PAPER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/29/world.print_headline: POLES IN TORONTO START A PRO-SOLIDARITY PAPER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/29/world.body_text: **********A small group of Polish-Canadians has begun a publishing venture to support the Solidarity labor movement in Poland and possibly give themselves new careers in Canada. **********Led by Alexander Pruszynski, who came to Canada nine years ago, the group publishes a new weekly newspaper here, Slowo, or The Word. The paper includes four pages of locally written news in Polish plus a complete 16-page reprint of the Solidarity newspaper that is published in Warsaw and smuggled out of the country to supporters abroad. **********''There is a real hunger here for news about what's happening back home,'' sadi Mr. Pruszynski, a 47-year-old businessman.  Slowo's main circulation targets are the Polish populations in Chicago, Detroit, Pittsburgh, Buffalo, New York, Winnipeg and Toronto, which is estimated to have 60,000 Polish residents. Close to Breaking Even **********Mr. Pruszynski says his offset paper prints about 4,500 copies a week and sells about 2,500, which is close to the break-even point.  He said that sales at $1 a copy are growing and that 40 percent of the readers are in the United States. The paper, the newest of several Polish publications in Canada, recently gained valuable support through Canadian Government advertising. **********Solidarity's newspaper is printed each Wednesday morning in Warsaw, he said, and is usually received here within 10 days. Mr. Pruszynski declined to say how he gets the issues, which are sometimes confiscated by Polish authorities. But he said he was working with Solidarity representatives to speed the paper's delivery to the West. **********Besides the 16-page Solidarity reprint, a recent issue of Slowo included articles on the problems of small businesses in Poland, a report on the beating of prisoners at the Wronki Prison near Poznan last April, excerpts from opposition political pamphlets in Poland, a sermon on the war dead by a Polish-Canadian priest, a feature on a Polish horse show in Vancouver, an analysis of some of Solidarity's political problems and a letter critical of an earlier article. The writers are usually young, politically active Polish-Canadian freelancers and sometimes include Mr. Pruszynski's mother. Was Freelance Writer in Poland **********In an interview here, Mr. Pruszynski, who is the son of a journalist and who was a freelance writer and part-time translator for foreign correspondents in Poland, said he had always wanted to work in journalism but had been forced by economic necessity into sales and cost analysis, most recently with the city government of Edmonton, Alberta. **********He said he planned some changes in the new paper, such as gradually increasing the amount of copy written in Canada and perhaps varying the content from Poland by including a greater variety of reports from local Solidarity publications. **********''We might end up with something like a Polish Reader's Digest,'' he said. ''After all, we don't want to be too serious all the time.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/22/world.main_headline: GANDHI REGIME ENDS COMMUNISTS' RULE OF A STATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/22/world.print_headline: GANDHI REGIME ENDS COMMUNISTS' RULE OF A STATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/22/world.body_text: **********In a move underscoring the friction between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and India's Marxist parties, the central Government today suspended and took over from the Communistdominated legislature in the state of Kerala. **********Under the Indian Constitution such a dismissal of state governments, known as President's rule, is permitted when the Prime Minister advises the President that a local political crisis has become so chaotic that the normal operation of government is paralyzed. **********Mrs. Gandhi is currently out of the country, in Cancun, Mexico for the meeting of rich and poor nations, but she has been kept aware of the recent defections that robbed the Marxist coalition in Kerala of its majority. This afternoon, after a meeting of her Cabinet, President Sanjiva Reddy signed the proclamation that effectively turned over the administration of Kerala to the ministries of the federal Government. **********Mechanism Used Previously **********Soon after her return to power, Mrs. Gandhi used the same mechanism to turn out state governments in seven states that had been led by loyalists of the Janata coalition that she defeated and destroyed in national parliamentary elections in January 1980. Subsequently elections were ordered in these states and in each case Mrs. Gandhi's supporters won clear majorities. **********However, in the three states where Marxist governments held sway - Kerala, West Bengal and the small state of Tripura - Mrs. Gandhi's party has until now shied away from direct confrontation, even though the Prime Minister has often shown contempt for the factionalized Communists. Her son, Rajiv Gandhi, who is taking on increasing organizational responsibilities for her party, has spoken of the need to impede efforts at unity by the divided Communists and has described at least one of the factions as representing a potentially competitive party with effective grass-roots mobilization. **********There has been no firm evidence to suggest that the defections from the Marxist coalition were engineered by Mrs. Gandhi's followers, who are relatively weak in Kerala, a state that has often been called the political laboratory of India. **********On the other hand, it is clear that Mrs. Gandhi's close advisers moved quickly to take advantage of the political void that developed. In the past her party has used the period of President's rule to build up effective election machines, or entice opposition politicians to defect. Complex Three-Way Relations **********While these maneuverings have great importance for the future of Kerala, a tropical area on the Arabian Sea, the major significance involves the complex relations between Mrs. Gandhi, the Indian Communist parties and Moscow. **********Basically, Mrs. Gandhi has great contempt for the more orthodox and pro-Soviet of the two major Communist parties. This group, the Communist Party of India, had publicly recanted for having been the single opposition group to have supported Mrs. Gandhi's suspension of democratic rule in 1975. Her scorn for the other, larger Communist party, the Communist Party of India-Marxist, which governs in West Bengal and Tripura, is only slightly less apparent. Still, these parties support her Government's foreign policies, and all three have claims on the Soviet Union. **********From time to time, aides close to Mrs. Gandhi tell Western diplomats she is annoyed that Moscow appears to be encouraging unity among the two Communist groups. One Western diplomat says that while Mrs. Gandhi may well be bothered by professions of international solidarity she must be aware that Soviet obligations to her Government far outweigh Soviet duties to the Communist parties. The diplomat suggested that one motive for the leaked reports of her annoyance is a strong desire by Mrs. Gandhi to assert nonalignment. **********It was this interest, for example, that led Mrs. Gandhi to give short shrift to the celebrations of the 10th anniversary of the Indian-Soviet friendship treaty. While the occasion was marked in Moscow by special editions of Pravda and long statements by Leonid I. Brezhnev and all major Politburo members, here there was only an eight-paragraph comment from Mrs. Gandhi. The Prime Minister also spurned Soviet invitations to go to Moscow.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/14/busin.body_text: **********Just as stock options and financial futures developed into the hot investments of the 1970's, the nation's financial exchanges hope to make a new product, commodity options, the trading star of the 1980's. **********Some exchanges have applied to Federal regulators for permission to trade these options. Others are either developing proposals or studying the possibility. Gold and silver, coffee and sugar, Treasury securities and other financial instruments - the exchanges are interested in all of them. **********''The people we've worked with feel the potential is huge, that options on financial instruments could eventually dwarf options on stocks,'' said Thomas N. Rzepski, senior vice president at the Chicago Board Options Exchange. **********An option simply gives its buyer the right to purchase some amount of an item at a fixed price within a certain period, even if the price of the item itself increases. The commodity options proposals being developed involve options on commodity futures contracts as well as options on physical commodities. A futures contract commits an investor to purchase or sell a fixed amount of a commodity at a set price within a certain period. But the investor may be forced to pay more money to meet margin calls if the price of the commodity contract fluctuates sharply. Options eliminate that risk. **********Futures and options are somewhat exotic types of financial instruments used by major corporations and wealthy individuals, but are not recommended to smaller investors. **********Like futures contracts, options can be used by businesses to insure a constant price for the goods they plan to use in the future, and are favored by speculators for their substantial leverage. But the cost for an option is a single relatively small fee, known as the premium, paid at the front end, rather than the unforseeable margin calls on futures contracts. **********Stock options have boomed in the seven years they have been traded on exchanges, with 96.7 million contracts traded last year. But efforts to create exchange-traded commodity options stalled in 1979 when members of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission failed to agree on rules for trading. There had been efforts to put commodity options on exchanges after scandals in over-the-counter commodity options led the commission to ban their sales by all but a few dealers. **********Now investment industry executives have new hope that commodity options are about to take off. For one thing, the complexion of the commission is expected to change when the Reagan administration fills three slots on the five-member commission, two open now and one opening in April. Industry participants say that could break the logjam at the commission that has blocked approval of options trading. **********In the meantime, however, the Securities and Exchange Commission has asserted its own jurisdiction over what it calls options on financial instruments. The S.E.C. seems to be moving actively toward approving one proposal, by the Chicago Board Options Exchange, to trade options on mortgage securities guaranteed by the Government (Government National Mortgage Association certificates, known as Ginnie Maes). The commission is also moving, though more slowly, on the exchange's second proposal, for options on Treasury bills. **********Among the staunchest advocates of the proposal is the mortgage banking industry, whose spokesmen say options may provide more funds for the housing market. **********A Federal Reserve study on exchange-traded options agreed, noting that the instruments would probably ''to a degree facilitate the process of forming and investing in home mortgage pools.'' **********''Everyone seems to be in general agreement that a product like the Ginnie Mae options is desirable,'' said Douglas Scarff, director of the S.E.C.'s Division of Market Regulation. Jurisdictional Questions **********The apparent readiness of the S.E.C. to approve a new kind of option - stock options are already traded on several exchanges - raises ticklish jurisdictional questions. Some maintain that the Congressional charter of the futures commission specifically gives it responsibility for all options other than stock options. Others say that all options on securities should come under the S.E.C., and that only options on more traditional commodities belong to the commodity agency. But whatever the arguments, they have not stopped the rush by exchanges to develop their own options proposals: **********- The Chicago Board of Trade plans to apply to the futures commission to trade options on futures contracts in Treasury bonds and Ginnie Mae's. In December, the board voted to create a separate division to trade options, with 150 new memberships to be sold at no more than $30,000 each. **********- The American Stock Exchange board voted last Thursday to apply to the S.E.C. for options on 13-week Treasury bills and 30-year Treasury bonds. **********- The New York Stock Exchange board voted last Wednesday to consider developing options on Ginnie Maes, Treasury securities, foreign currencies, gold, silver and a stock index. ''We have been delayed on stock options because some people think we have an unfair advantage because we trade stocks,'' John J. Phelan Jr., president of the exchange, said. **********- The New York Futures Exchange, a subsidiary of the Big Board, plans to apply for options on futures contracts, probably on Treasury bills and bonds. **********- The Philadelphia Stock Exchange, which already trades stock options, is planning to apply to the S.E.C. for options on five foreign currencies. It is expected to file shortly. **********- The Commodity Exchange in New York is still hoping for clearance from the futures commission on silver and copper options, for which it applied in 1975, and on gold options, for which it filed in 1976. New York Board Studies Platinum **********The Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the New York Mercantile Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange all said they were not working on options applications now but would if other applications began to be approved. **********Such a panoply of new options, if all approved, could be somewhat confusing to investors. Potentially more disconcerting, however, is the possible confusion over the difference between the options on commodity futures contracts and the options on the commodities themselves. Someday, for example, there could be an option on Ginnie Maes and a separate option on a futures contract on Ginnie Maes. **********Industry experts say that the direct commodity options might be conceptually easier to follow, but that there would be relatively little economic difference between the two. ''The biggest differences may be in the rules imposed by the S.E.C. and the C.F.T.C.,'' one observer said. ''The broker may aim for the less regulated market, which may or may not help the investor depending on the nature of the rules.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/02/world.main_headline: 8 INDIAN UNIONS JOIN TO FIGHT BAN ON STRIKES IN KEY SECTORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/02/world.print_headline: 8 INDIAN UNIONS JOIN TO FIGHT BAN ON STRIKES IN KEY SECTORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/02/world.body_text: **********A group of labor unions have decided to join forces to fight the Indian Government's decision to ban strikes in essential services, a move they feel poses a threat to union activity. **********Eight major unions owing allegiance to different political parties, ranging from far left to extreme right, have formed a committee jointly to fight a bill in Parliament that would bar strikes in such essential services as railways, post offices, petroleum refineries and defense industries. **********The legislation, which will be debated in the next few weeks, empowers the Government to bar strikes for six months, with a provision to extend the ban for an additional six months. It prescribes summary trial for anyone inciting or participating in an illegal strike, and imprisonment and fines for those found guilty.  The legislation is intended to replace an ordinance containing similar provisions that was signed by President Sanjiva Reddy on July 27. **********Although the unions have planned joint opposition within Parliament and big rallies outside, they concede that they cannot block the bill because Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party has a decisive majority. Further, a major union, the Indian National Trade Union Congress, is affiliated with her party and is supporting the legislation. Move to 'Shatter' Unions Seen **********''The ban on strikes is intended to shatter the trade union movement in India,'' said P. Ramamurti, secretary of the Center of Indian Trade Unions, which is affiliated with the Marxist Communist Party of India. The party controls two state governments, those of West Bengal and Kerala, and both vehemently oppose the bill. **********Leaders of the central Government have justified the bill on the ground that opposition political parties were misusing the unions to obstruct production and distribution in an effort to undermine the Government. **********In the campaign against the bill, the All-India Trade Union Congress, which is affiliated with the pro-Moscow Communist Party, the Bharatiya Mazdoor Sangh, a union affiliated with the right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party, and the Hind Mazdoor Sangh, a Socialist grouping, have joined hands along with several smaller union organizations. **********On the opening day of Parliament, Aug. 17, several thousand workers belonging to these unions held a rally outside to denounce the bill. Mr. Ramamurti said that a larger rally was being planned for November to mark the beginning of countrywide agitation against the ''black law.'' **********However, he acknowledged that he felt ''helpless'' in the face of the strong support Mrs. Gandhi has gained from her party and the lukewarm attitude of the general public. Many Workers Called Indifferent **********Subramania Swamy, a leader of the opposition Janata Party and president of the Life Insurance Corporation union, which has over 20,000 members, said that a large number of the workers themselves were indifferent to the call for agitation against the bill. **********''The trade union leaders have abused the strike weapon so often that most workers actually welcome the ban,'' he said. ''Trade union leaders resort to the strike call as a first resort instead of using it as a last resort,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/15/busin.main_headline: DEMOCRATS CONFRONTING THEIR OWN TAX DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/15/busin.print_headline: DEMOCRATS CONFRONTING THEIR OWN TAX DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/15/busin.body_text: **********Representative Ed Jenkins, a Democrat from a district of small farms and businesses in north Georgia, says he hopes the Ways and Means Committee ''can stick with across-theboard'' cuts in personal income tax rates. **********Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Democrat from a district of suburbs and small businesses on the south shore of Long Island, wants to find another way to cut taxes, perhaps by widening existing income brackets. **********Mr. Downey, Mr. Jenkins and three other Ways and Means Democrats will meet for the first time tomorrow as a task force appointed by the committee chairman, Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, to advise the Democrats how best to shape this part of a tax-relief bill. Stresses Among Democrats **********The difference in approach between Mr. Jenkins, a conservative, and Mr. Downey, a liberal, is typical of the stresses that already have sundered House Democrats. Leaders of the conservative wing have pledged to support President Reagan's bill to cut personal tax rates by 25 percent over 33 months, starting with a 5 percent cut Oct.1.  There would also be cuts of 10 percent on July 1, 1982, and July 1, 1983. **********Mr. Rostenkowski and the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., have drawn a line at a two-stage, 15-percent reduction in rates, plus a grab-bag of other provisions that already have been incorporated in large part into the Reagan bill. For the mainstream Democrats, the challenge is to write a bill that is different from the President's, responsible and politically palatable to most Democrats and perhaps a few Republicans. **********A showdown on the House floor is more than a month away. The Ways and Means Committee will begin drafting business tax-relief provisions on Tuesday. Mr. Rostenkowski has left individual tax relief for last because it is politically the most explosive part of the package. Democrats' Morale Is Low **********Morale among the Democrats is not high. A liberal, asked to appraise the chances of beating the President on the House floor, replied ''dismal.'' When Mr. Jenkins was asked if abandoning uniform, across-the-board rate cuts would make it harder to win, he replied, ''I think it's going to be hard to win anyway.'' **********Another Southern Democrat who is loyal to the leadership said the White House ''has locked it up'' by writing into its bill relief from the so-called windfall profits tax on crude oil and from the estate tax, the bane of farmers, ranchers and small-business owners. Those two lures won a number of Southern Democrats to the Administration's cause, the loyal Southerner said, particularly several Texans. **********Mr. Jenkins says Mr. Reagan is popular in his district but he also asserts that the many low-income workers there would like a Democratic-style tax bill. Administration Says Bill Is Fair **********The Administration contends that its bill is fair because it would allocate tax relief in proportion to current tax burdens. For example, under current law, persons in the $20,000-to-$30,000 annual income range would pay an estimated 20.7 percent of 1984 taxes, according to the Treasury, and would get 21.3 of the President's total tax cut. **********''We are asking how can we distribute this in a more equitable way,'' counters Representative James M. Shannon of Massachusetts, a liberal Democrat on Ways and Means. **********Mr. Shannon and others contend that a tilt to taxpayers below $50,000 would be just because they ''are people who have suffered the greatest increase in burden,'' but the Democrats also acknowledge that they have an eye on political consequences. **********''We Democrats want to make sure that our people, people who make moderate incomes, get the tax relief they need,'' Speaker O'Neill said on June 2. Reduction in Brackets **********In searching for a ''Democratic'' tax-cutting formula, the Democrats are looking at a variety of ideas. Representative Wyche Fowler Jr., a moderate from the suburbs of Atlanta, has asked the staff of the Joint Tax Committee to design tax tables with only five or seven brackets, compared to sixteen now. The lowest bracket would start at a higher tax rate than the 14 percent now in effect, but also would start at a higher level of income. **********Another idea is to offer more generous relief from the ''marriage penalty'' than the maximum $3,000 deduction proposed by the President; the Democrats are considering $4,000. With a $4,000 maximum deduction for couples, based on 10 percent of the lower-earning spouse's income, one Democratic formula being considered would give an average 1982 tax cut of $1,059 to taxpayers with total income of $30,000 to $50,000, compared to $789 in the Reagan measure. **********Put differently, the Democrats would give these taxpayers 32.2 percent of the total tax saving against 30 percent in the Administration bill. These calculations were done for the Democrats by the Joint Committee staff. Wanting to Be Different **********These are not profound differences.  The reasons for the items that the Democrats list add up to one thing - a felt need to be different. Right now, say the Democrats, the similarities between their position and Mr. Reagan's are greater than the differences, largely because each has adopted part of the other's position. The Democrats, for example, now favor dropping the current 70 percent maximum tax rate on investment income to 50 percent, a proposal the Reagan White House liked but avoided as politically risky for Republicans. **********The most readily grasped difference is that Mr. Reagan would mandate now a third cut in rates, in 1983.  Some Democrats say privately that the Republican Senate ultimately will force the Democratic House to accept a 1983 rate cut. Others, like Mr. Fowler of Georgia, speculate that the President will ultimately settle for two years on the grounds of fiscal conservatism.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/20/busin.main_headline: FOUNDATION SELLING ASSETS WORTH OVER $1 BILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/20/busin.print_headline: FOUNDATION SELLING ASSETS WORTH OVER $1 BILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/20/busin.body_text: **********The MacArthur Foundation of Chicago, one of the country's wealthiest foundations, is selling its considerable assets in insurance companies and real estate. Its aim is to comply with Federal laws limiting the tax-free business ownership that is permitted private foundations. **********According to experts in the investment banking community, the sale may realize $1 billion to $2 billion for the MacArthur Foundation and would consolidate its position as a financial leader in the philanthropic field, possibly second only to the Ford Foundation, which lists its assets at $2.7 billion. **********''The divestiture, which is necessitated by the Tax Reform Act of 1969, will enable us to substantially increase our grant programs,'' Gaylord Freeman, chairman of the MacArthur Foundation's finance committee, said yesterday. The act limits a foundation's ownership of a business property to a 20 percent holding. **********The John D.  and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation is the sole owner of the Bankers Life and Casualty Company, which has more than 80 subsidiaries and properties. These properties include the Gulf and Western Building, the Lincoln Towers residential complex and 15 other office buildings in Manhattan, 85,000 acres of prime real estate in Florida and shopping centers or other commercial holdings in Dallas, Los Angeles, New Orleans, Chicago and other cities. **********The Foundation has acquired a reputation for innovative grantmaking that included rescuing Harper's magazine by paying $4.1 million for it when it was on the verge of closing because of its financial problems. The foundation also devoted $6.5 million to discover and support exceptionally talented scientists and artists by providing them with no-strings prizes ranging up to $60,000 a year. Keeping Headquarters Site **********Although the foundation would sell virtually all of its real estate, it would retain its headquarters, the Marquette Building in Chicago. **********''We believe this may be the largest transaction involving a privately owned company,'' said Larry Michel, a managing director of Warburg Paribas Becker Inc. He and Donald A. Petrie, a partner of Lazard Freres & Company, represent the two concerns handling the undertaking. **********They placed advertisements yesterday in newspapers in the United States and abroad, saying they were exclusive agents for the divestiture of Bankers Life. This company was described as one of the largest writers of accident, health and life insurance policies and sole owner of a large portfolio of commercial and residential properties. **********The agents are looking for a single purchaser, and there will be no public sale of the MacArthur holdings. They declined to discuss the undertaking, but offerings of this dimension are usually arranged to attract a relatively small number of potential buyers who already are known to the major banking houses. Only those capable of such a purchase receive a brochure giving details of the properties. **********Life insurance companies are in a regulated industry, adding an element of ethical standing to be satisfied.  The properties offered include the Colonnades Beach Hotel in West Palm Beach, Fla., where the late John D. MacArthur lived until he died three years ago at the age of 80. He occupied a modest threeroom apartment and conducted his business from a table in the hotel's coffee shop because he disliked opulent offices. Getting Started in Chicago **********Mr. MacArthur, a self-made multimillionaire, started his business career in Chicago by selling low-cost insurance policies, making enough money to buy the nearly bankrupt Bankers Life for $2,500 in 1935. Within five years he had built its assets to $1 million. In 1978 the company's assets were estimated at a little over $1 billion. **********Along the way, Mr. MacArthur acquired vast land holdings in Florida's Palm Beach area that included three golf courses, one of them the former P.G.A. National Golf Club in Palm Beach Gardens that he designed. He also acquired prime office buildings in New York including the 44-story Gulf and Western tower at Columbus Circle, opened in 1970, and the Lincoln Tower residential property with 3,850 apartment units as well as an office building at 410 Park Avenue and other commercial properties. He also bought but disposed of myriad other holdings that included banks and utilities, paper and pulp plants, a tug and barge fleet, an oil-drilling company and a distillery. Foundation Specified in Will **********When Mr. MacArthur died in 1978, he left the bulk of his estate for establishment of the foundation, leaving its program to be shaped by his widow and son, J. Roderick MacArthur, and a few business associates. They, in turn, expanded its board, bringing in a number of prominent scientists. John E. Corbally, a former president of the University of Illinois, became its president. **********The MacArthur Foundation listed its assets at $840 million in 1979. This put it in third place behind the Ford Foundation and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation (which had assets just above $1 billion at the end of last year). Directors of the MacArthur Foundation said privately, however, that the full extent of its holdings had not been fixed and that the assets would exceed $1 billion. How the 1969 Law Evolved **********Its sale of properties is the largest divestiture since the 1969 Tax Reform Act was passed, according to John A. Edie, a lawyer for the Council on Foundations in Washington, which represents 950 foundations of all sizes. **********The regulations regarding the business holdings of private foundations evolved after Congressional committees examined the practices of the country's foundations. The committees turned up some instances of financial misconduct, providing fuel for critics demanding tighter control. Some people argued that limiting ownership would help curb conflict-of-interest abuses. It was decided that it would be prudent to make foundations diversify their holdings to assure their grant-making ability. **********The new rules limited ownership to 20 percent of a business enterprise and gave foundations five years to dispose of the excess.  The MacArthur Foundation, because it was established in 1978, has until Dec. 1, 1983, to dispose of its properties or face penalties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/28/busin.body_text: **********The Army said today that it had asked 61 companies, including the major auto makers and suppliers, to suggest a replacement for its most-famous vehicle, the jeep. **********Michael J. Scharra, contract specialist at the Army Tank-Automotive Command in Warren, Mich., said that the new vehicle must be diesel-powered, have an automatic transmission, carry a 2,500-pound payload and cruise up to 300 miles without refueling. **********''It will be a replacement for the jeep and several other military vehicles, including the half-ton truck and one-and-a-quarter-ton Gamma Goat,'' said Douglas E. Philips, senior project engineer. ''We want one vehicle to do the jobs that several have been doing, to cut down our supply problems.'' **********The jeep replacement would be called the High Mobility Multipurpose Wheeled Vehicle and is expected to cost between $20,000 and $27,000.  The total number required was not disclosed, although the Army's inventory of jeeps alone exceeds 15,000, a source said. **********The deadline for industry proposals was April 27, Mr. Scharra said. Three companies will be asked to deliver 11 prototypes for testing before one of the companies will be awarded a contract, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/22/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: In Jan R. Van Meter's article, ''A Message for the Medium'' (Oct.  25), he offered some free advice on how to deal with special interest groups who threaten boycotts because they do not like television programs that companies sponsor. **********Unfortunately, Mr. Van Meter devalues his advice by basing it on stereotypes about television. **********He argues that commercial television is ''debasing our culture,'' ''enfeebling the minds of our children'' and is ''completely unresponsive to our desires'' and that ''neither the networks nor the advertisers have confronted the problem of quality in programming or of responsibility for program content.'' **********While all programs may not suit all tastes, such categorical denunciation is absurd in light of such shows as ''Roots,'' ''Project Peacock,'' ''60 Minutes'' and many, many others. **********Furthermore, we at NBC are concerned about quality and programming responsibility every day. That's true from our program executives, to our broadcast standards department, which reviews some 3,800 hours of entertainment programming and some 50,000 proposed commercials each year. **********We also recently sponsored a three-day conference on ''Television and Social Changes in the 80's'' that brought together our key executives and leaders of 35 major religious, ethnic, racial and professional groups. **********We believe understanding realities like these - not the stereotypes Mr. Van Meter offers - must form the basis for sound policy decisions about television.Robert J. Cornet Vice President Editorial Services Corporate Communications National Broadcasting Company New York, Nov. 19, 1981

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/13/busin.main_headline: ENERGY COMPANIES RANK HIGH ON LIST OF BLACK-OWNED BUSINESSES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/13/busin.print_headline: ENERGY COMPANIES RANK HIGH ON LIST OF BLACK-OWNED BUSINESSES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/13/busin.body_text: **********Energy-related companies dominated the list of the top 100 blackowned businesses in revenues, while car dealerships, usually the largest category on the list, lost ranking as a result of the general slump in the auto industry, according to Black Enterprise magazine's ninth annual survey of the top 100 black businesses. **********The survey, published in the June issue and based on revenues, shows five energy companies, with combined annual sales of $255.4 million, placed in the top 10. Wallace & Wallace Enterprises, a petrochemical company, had the most dramatic growth, jumping from 10th to the No.2 spot with sales of $81.9 million in 1980, up 216 percent from 1979. **********Black-owned auto dealerships, which reached a peak at 37 in 1977, lost two more places on the list this year and dropped to 30. While five new dealerships made the list, seven did not reach the cutoff point of $5.2 million in revenues, and three of those seven closed within the year. Auto dealerships still make up the list's largest single category. **********Combined Sales Up 23.3% **********The combined revenues of the top 100 companies rose 23.3 percent, to $1.5 billion, almost equivalent to the 1980 sales of AMF Inc., listed 225th on the Fortune 500 list. **********Earl G. Graves, publisher of Black Enterprise magazine, said the performance of black-owned businesses reflected the ups and downs of the general economy, and added that the main problem minority businesses would face during the next year would be similiar to that of many other companies - access to credit. **********Mr. Graves said that, in addition, minority-owned enterprises needed Washington's continued support in encouraging the general business community to contract with them. He said he was confident that President Reagan would ''carry the day'' and keep intact the Federal programs intended to foster the development of minority-owned businesses. **********Mr. Graves said that if Federal assistance, such as the bidding program on some Government contracts held exclusively for minorityowned businesses, did not survive ''it would raise havoc'' with the balance sheets of about 10 percent of the companies listed in the survey. The energy companies, in particular, benefited from the Federal bidding program. Motown at Top of List **********Motown Industries, an entertainment company, retained its No.1 spot with $91.7 million in revenues. In addition to Wallace & Wallace, the four other energy-related concerns in the top 10 were the Vanguard Oil and Service Company, with revenues of $50.5 million; Smith Pipe and Supply Inc., with revenues of $48 million; the Grimes Oil Company, with revenues of $40 million, and the Chioke International Corporation, with revenues of $35 million. **********Despite the glut of petroleum products that has slowed the sales of the major oil companies, Richard Carroll, operations manager for Grimes Oil, said he expected Grimes's sales to increase in the next year. The heating oil distributor services a large black population, Mr. Carroll said, but its source of revenue is widely distributed among the general population and includes major commercial contracts. **********The sales of the 13 manufacturing companies, which make up the second-largest group on the list, rose 31.6 percent, to $209 million in aggregate sales. M & M Products of Atlanta, a producer of hair care products for the black consumer, led the manufacturing list in terms of growth with a 184 percent jump, to $27 million. Listing of Banks **********Included in the June issue of Black Enterprise was an overview of banks, savings and loan associations, and insurance companies that are owned and controlled by blacks. Assets of the savings and loan associations rose 13.5 percent, to $949 million, while the assets of insurance companies increased 3.4 percent, to $699 million. The assets of black-owned commercial banks edged up by 6.6 percent, to $1.26 billion. **********Mr. Graves said the top 100 companies and the black-owned financial institutions employed an estimated 25,000 blacks, or about three-tenths of 1 percent of the total number of working blacks. **********Companies on the list were based in 20 states and the District of Columbia, with 15 in New York, 11 in Illinois, 11 in California, 10 in Michigan, six in Ohio, five in Georgia and five in Maryland.
