https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/busin.body_text: **********In the first transfer of ownership of an Atlantic City casino-hotel, Dallas-based Inns of the Americas Inc. has taken over the controlling interest in the struggling Brighton Hotel and Casino under a previously announced agreement. **********The company and two businessmen from Binghamton, N.Y., paid about $30 million for a 78 percent interest in the Greate Bay Hotel Corporation, which in turn owns 73 percent interest in the casinohotel and a country club and condominium development in nearby Somers Point. **********The 504-room Brighton, which was built for about $70 million, opened last August as the fourth of seven legal casinos here. The casino-hotel reported a loss of $15.4 million for 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/08/world.main_headline: IRAQIS PAUSE OUTSIDE IRANIAN CITY TO AWAIT RESULT OF INDIAN PARLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/08/world.print_headline: IRAQIS PAUSE OUTSIDE IRANIAN CITY TO AWAIT RESULT OF INDIAN PARLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/08/world.body_text: **********uf814BASRA, Iraq, Feb. 7 (Reuters) - Iraqi forces have moved to within a mile of the besieged southwest Iranian city of Susangird, but it was unclear whether they would soon move to capture the city. **********Arab diplomatic sources close to the Iraqis said Baghdad would leave any major new strategy decisions until after it saw the outcome of a meeting of the nations professing nonalignment that opens Monday in New Delhi. **********The Iraqi military command said in a communique issued in Baghdad today that 183 Iranians had been killed in a battle near Susangird.  It said an Iranian infantry force that tried to approach Iraqi positions near Susangird had been decisively repulsed. **********Iraqi armor and artillery pushed to their present positions outside Susangird after repulsing an Iranian counterattack in a major tank battle south of the town last month. Iraqis May Move Later **********The Arab sources said the seizure of Susangird was likely to be Iraq's next move, should the New Delhi meeting produce no result on the conflict and Baghdad want to put new pressure on the Iranians to come to the negotiating table. **********Iraqi commanders said, however, that they did not have Susangird surrounded and that the Iranians could still use the road between Susangird and Ahwaz, capital of Iran's province of Khuzistan. **********The only big Iranian town to have fallen to the Iraqis is the cargo port of Khurramshahr on the disputed Shatt al Arab waterway. The refining complex of Abadan is still being held by Iran despite a siege of more than two months. ---- India Takes Role of Mediator **********NEW DELHI, Feb. 7 (Reuters) - India led a strong diplomatic effort today to overcome political differences that threaten to disrupt next week's conference of foreign ministers from the countries that profess to be nonaligned, conference sources said. **********The disputes in the nonaligned movement, particularly concerning the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, the Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia, the Persian Gulf war and Egypt's peace treaty with Israel, have slowed a preparatory meeting of officials to fix an agenda and draft a declaration for the conference. **********Foreign Minister Saadun Hamadi of Iraq said on his arrival here that his Government would be happy to receive a nonaligned mission to mediate in its war with Iran. He added, however, that the composition of the mission should be agreed upon by both sides.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/10/busin.body_text: **********The Ronson Corporation said today that it had sold its British subsidiary, Ronson Products, as part of a program of concentrating its resources on its more profitable operations. **********A Ronson spokesman said the subsidiary was sold to Cavwain Ltd. for about $6.1 million. He said the money would be used to pay off most of a $10.7 million debt Ronson owes Barclays Bank for loans and mortgages. Ronson had a net loss of $5.5 million in 1980.  The British unit alone lost $3.6 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/03/busin.body_text: **********The stock of the Santa Fe International Cor poration, one of the world's largest oil drilling companies, did n ot trade yesterday afterthe company asked that trading be suspended o n the New York Stock Exchange pending an announcement to be made o n Monday. **********The company, whose profits nearly quadrupled in 1980 compared with 1979, has long been regarded as a prime takeover candidate by oil industry analysts. In 1981's first six months, earnings rose 51 percent. **********The stock of the company was up 2 1/2 on Thursday, to 24 3/4, a level that some analysts said made it very attractive for a takeover move. 'They're Cheap' **********One analyst estimated that at the current level the price of the stock was about one-third of the company's cash flow. ''They're cheap, they're awfully cheap,'' he said. **********Santa Fe International, which had sales of $1.2 billion last year, is one of four oil drilling companies that analysts have been considering as takeover candidates. **********The others are Global Marine Inc., Reading & Bates and the Zapata Corporation. Last month, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation withdrew its offer of $760 million to acquire Zapata after the Zapata management rejected the offer. Perils of Unfriendly Bid **********One analyst, who has followed oil drilling companies, said that, while the companies were attractive takeover candidates, they ceased being so if the takeover was unfriendly. In such a case, one noted, the management team can pull out, leaving a shell that is worth very little. **********Santa Fe, which is based in Alhambra, Calif., acquired C F Braun & Company last year for $309 million. Braun, which specializes in the planning, engineering and construction of process and power plants, has greatly increased its order backlog and has complemented some of Santa Fe's operations. Santa Fe's drilling operations have also grown rapidly and the company is in the midst of a two-year, $442 million expansion program.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration's newly designated Assistant Attorney General for antitrust told the Senate today that he would be unlikely to oppose mergers between companies in different industries unless it could be shown that such combinations would diminish competition for a single product. **********Prof. William F. Baxter gave this testimony at at a 90-minute confirmation hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee at which not one Democratic senator appeared. **********Mr. Baxter told the committee that he had no objection to mergers of companies in different sectors of the energy market - oil and coal, for example, unless the merger would reduce actual or potential competition. **********Similarly, he said the Justice Department's antitrust division would not oppose recent proposed acquisitions of three minerals companies unless evidence emerged that an oil company might otherwise have entered the minerals field as a competitor. **********Might Prove Desirable **********Mr. Baxter testified that such mergers might, in fact, prove desirable. Mining companies have not done well lately, he said, and need the ''large infusions of cash'' oil partners can provide to finance new technology. **********The reference was to the proposal by Standard Oil of California to buy Amax for $4 billion, the agreement by Standard Oil (Ohio) to purchase Kennecott for $1.77 billion and the attempt by Joseph E.  Seagram to buy the St. Joe Minerals Corporation with $2 billion it made selling oil assets last year. **********Mr. Baxter seemed certain to be confirmed by the Senate after the committee votes on him Tuesday.  The nominee, 51 years old and a native of New York City, has taught law at Stanford University for most of the past 25 years and has been, he testified, a consultant to ''a very, very long list of companies.'' Accordingly, he said, he had disqualified himself from all cases involving Levi Strauss & Company and from certain issues involving Visa credit cards, Western Electric employees, a joint venture between two aircraft companies, McDonnell Douglas and Northrop, and a controversy over software between Data General and Fairchild Industries. **********Mr. Baxter said his ''several hours'' as a consultant to Western Electric did not disqualify him, in his opinion, from supervising the Government's antitrust case against Western Electric's parent, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, a case in which the Government seeks to break up A.T &T. No senator disputed him. **********If confirmed, Mr. Baxter would have final authority to settle the A.T.& T. case for the Government. Both the Attorney General and the Deputy Attorney General have disqualified themselves because of business with the Bell System as private lawyers. Tenacious Questioning **********Much of the questioning of Mr. Baxter was done by a freshman Republican from Pennsylvania, Arlen Specter, a former prosecutor who pursued the witness with quiet tenacity. Mr. Specter invited Mr.  Baxter to criticize the Reagan Administration's decontrol of oil prices last month on the ground that oil companies had more money coming in than they could reinvest in oil exploration. Mr. Baxter demurred. **********Mr. Baxter said oil companies could not be criticized for failing to reinvest all of their revenues in exploration because makers of drilling rigs and oilfield equipment cannot keep up with orders. On that ground, Mr. Specter asked whether Congress should postpone deregulation of natural gas. **********Mr. Baxter said he was reluctant to discuss policy outside the antitrust sphere, then did so: ''Free market prices are probably the most important conservation devices we can find.'' **********As for acquisitions, the company's belief that it would increase profits ''is sufficient reason for me to leave it alone'' if there is no evidence of anticompetitive results in a single product market, he said. He added, however, that understanding the buying company's motives entered into determining the effect on competition. **********Mr. Baxter said that he saw nothing wrong with long-term agreements between sellers and customers if they promoted efficiency and did not diminish competition. This is a much-disputed, complex area of antitrust law. **********Mr. Baxter said that had he been sitting on the Supreme Court in 1977, he would have held with the majority in the Illinois Brick case that the right to sue suspected price fixers for treble damages should be confined to direct purchasers. **********As for abolishing the antitrust function of the Federal Trade Commission, Mr. Baxter said that was for Congress to decide but he knew of no ''sound reason'' for having two agencies with antitrust responsibility. ''With only a little effort, I can imagine life going on without the antitrust enforcement function of the F.T.C.,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/14/world.main_headline: CLERIC SWORN IN AS IRAN'S PRESIDENT AMID CRIES OF 'DEATH TO AMERICA!'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/14/world.print_headline: CLERIC SWORN IN AS IRAN'S PRESIDENT AMID CRIES OF 'DEATH TO AMERICA!'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/14/world.body_text: **********Amid cries of ''Death to America!'' Iran's first clergyman-President took the oath of office before Parliament today and vowed to stamp out ''deviation, liberalism and American-influenced leftists.'' **********The Teheran radio said that leading figures of the Government, judiciary and the armed forces attended the ceremony in which the new President, 42-year-old Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, was sworn in by the Chief Justice, Ayatollah Abdulkarim Musavi Ardebeli. **********The Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, and the Prime Minister, Ayatollah Mohammed Riza Mahdavi-Kani, both hailed the inauguration as a victory for the clergy and for Islam, and the Speaker called on the new President to put into effect policies to check the wave of anti-Government assassinations that began more than three months ago. **********President Khamenei said in his inaugural address that he took pride in the fact that assassins had slain a President, Prime Minister, Chief Justice, Members of Parliament and other political and religious figures. Oath Is Recited **********''This shows,'' he said, ''that in our society the sense of mission and commitment is not narrowed to only one segment of the people.'' **********His right hand on the Koran, Hojatolislam Khamenei recited the oath of office: ''I swear as President in the name of God to be a custodian of the state religion, the system of Government of the Islamic republic and the constitutional law, to devote myself to the service of the people, the grandeur of my country, the promotion of religion and morality and the supporting of furtherance of justice.'' **********His inauguration completed the clergy's dominance of Iran's executive, legislative and judicial branches. Iran's two previous Presidents since the 1979 revolution were laymen. Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, who was elected in January 1980, was dismissed by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on June 22 this year. His fundamentalist successor, Mohammed Ali Rajai, was assassinated Aug. 30, only 37 days after being elected. **********Wearing the traditional black robe and black turban of a Moslem Shiite mullah, President Khamenei said his election victory on Oct.  2, when 95 percent of those participating supported him, was a vote of ''trust for the clergy, a vote for Islam, a vote for independence and a vote for stamping out deviation, liberalism and American-influenced leftists.'' 22 Executions Announced **********As the swearing-in ceremony was under way, the Government announced that 22 more leftist guerrillas had been executed in different cities on charges of armed revolt, anti-Government violence and armed robbery. **********This brought to at least 1,350 the number of leftists executed in Iran since the ouster of Mr. Bani-Sadr, most of them members of the leftist guerrilla organization People's Mujahedeen. In London, Amnesty International said its records showed a total of 1,800. The Mujahedeen have been blamed for bombings and assassinations that have claimed the lives of more than 100 leading political and clerical figures. **********In another development, Iran's official Pars press agency said some Iranian pilgrims were arrested in Saudi Arabia yesterday for staging a pro-Khomeini demonstration in Islam's holy city of Mecca.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/world.main_headline: POPE SEEKS SETTLEMENT IN POLAND WITHOUT VIOLENCE OR INTERVENTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/world.print_headline: POPE SEEKS SETTLEMENT IN POLAND WITHOUT VIOLENCE OR INTERVENTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/21/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II called on Poles today to resolve their country's problems without bloodshed and said that Poland has the right to decide its future without outside intervention. **********''The important and difficult questions must be resolved by dialogue and not by confrontation,'' the Polish-born Pope told a cheering crowd of 10,000 at his summer residence south of Rome. ''The experience of the past year has demonstrated that the Polish people are capable of resolving difficulties peacefully, without violence and without the spilling of blood.'' **********He continued: ''Already, too much blood has been spilled, during the last war, to talk or think about new bloodshed in Poland. I must underline that the nation, which has paid such a price for its independence, has the right to decide its affairs autonomously.'' **********At that point, the Polish pilgrims in the crowd applauded and started singing the Polish national anthem. The Pope joined in the singing, his baritone voice booming over the loudspeakers. **********''This right of self-determination is a principle of international order. It must be respected,'' the Pope said. He spoke in Polish and his comments we re translated into Italian by the Vatican radio. Pope Cites Bishops' Report **********The Pope read from a report of a meeting of Polish bishops last week that had stressed the importance of peaceful negotiations.  ''In the last few weeks, the tensions have grown to a point in which it is necessary to find a way to sit down at a negotiating table and find solutions that will have a national consensus,'' the Pope read. **********In a letter prepared for the clergy to read in Polish churches on Sunday, the bishops said that monopolization of the news media is ''inadmissible'' and said that all should have equal access to it.  One of the demands of Solidarity, Poland's independent trade union, is for uncensored access to the Government-run press and broadcasting outlets. **********The Soviet Union has called for a crackdown on Solidarity, and last week the union and the Polish Government attacked each other in a war of words. **********The Pope has repeatedly endorsed Solidarity and has met with its leader, Lech Walesa. On Sept. 6, the Pope compared Solidarity's struggles to the sacrifices made by his countrymen in World War II.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Alan M. Lovelace, acting administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, announced today that he will leave NASA on July 11 to join the General Dynamics Corporation as vice president for science and engineering. **********Mr. Lovelace has been acting head of NASA since Jan. 20, when Robert Frosch, appointed during the Carter Administration, resigned that post. **********Before that, Mr. Lovelace was deputy administrator. He has been with the agency since 1974. **********NASA's new chief, James M. Beggs, until recently was executive vice president for aerospace for General Dynamics, which is based in St. Louis. The Senate confirmed his nomination last week and he is to start work next Tuesday. **********President Reagan recently awarded Mr. Lovelace the Presidential Citizen's Medal for his role in the development of the space shuttle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/21/busin.body_text: **********The International Harvester Company, one of the nation's leading producers of farm equipment and trucks, announced yesterday that its loss for the second fiscal quarter, ended April 30, narrowed to $79.2 million, from $257.2 million in the similar quarter a year ago. **********Sales increased 91.4 percent, to $2.22 billion, from $1.16 billion. **********International Harvester has encountered serious financial problems because of losses in the fiscal year 1980 from a six-month strike and further losses in the fiscal year 1981 from weak demand in some product lines. **********In March, the company reached an agreement in principle with eight banks to replace $3.4 billion in short-term loans with a three-year revolving credit agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/world.body_text: **********Morocco held parliamentary elections today in the southern part of the former Spanish Sahara that it annexed in 1979. Morocco took over the area after Mauritania withdrew under a peace agreement with Algerian-backed guerrillas who have been fighting for the independence of the area since 1976. The inhabitants of the sparsely populated territory were due to elect three deputies to the Moroccan Parliament for the first time since they came under Moroccan rule.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/11/world.body_text: **********A United Nations report estimates that there were 9,250 political murders in El Salvador in the first six months of this year, more than the total estimated by the State Department for all of last year. **********The report, to the United Nations Human Rights Commission, concluded that there has been ''a consistent pattern of gross violations'' of human rights in El Salvador since the ruling junta took over in 1979. **********The study found more detailed information about abuses by the Government and its rightist supporters than by the armed leftist guerrillas. The report said, however, that it could not ''establish even approximately'' each side's share of the violence. **********The report also said that the executive and judicial branches of El Salvador's Government ''have adopted a very widespread attitude of passivity and inactivity'' toward the violations. **********Ernesto Rivas-Gallon, El Salvador's Ambassador to Washington, and Mauricio Rosales-Rivera, the head of El Salvador's United Nations mission, were unavailable for comment. Other Salvadoran officials in Washington and New York, reached by telephone, declined to answer questions about the report. An aide to Mr. Rivas-Gallon suggested the Ambassador might comment on the report later. **********The 35-page study based its estimate of deaths on reports by Government and private organizations, including Amnesty International and Legal Aid, an office run by the Archdiocese of San Salvador. **********The report was prepared by Jose Antonio Pastor Ridruejo, a Spanish human rights advocate who teaches law at the University of Madrid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/12/world.main_headline: SOME ARE SAD TO LEAVE LIBYA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/12/world.print_headline: SOME ARE SAD TO LEAVE LIBYA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/12/world.body_text: **********Several Americans in Libya said today that they did not feel threatened, and wanted to stay there despite a request by President Reagan that they leave. **********With businesses closed for the Moslem Sabbath, some Americans played soccer, while others listened to the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corporation for more information on the decision announced Thursday by the Reagan Administration. **********Four Americans reached by telephone in Tripoli said that they thought the United States Government and the American press had exaggerated their difficulties in Libya. There are 1,500 Americans in Libya, mostly oil company employees and their families. **********''I feel absolutely safe here, and I always have,'' said Barbara Devine, a 30-year-old junior high school teacher from Los Angeles.  She said she had been in Libya for four years. 'Our Lives Are Invested Here' **********She and two other American employees of the school run by the United States oil companies said 90 percent of the 70 American teachers wanted to stay. **********''We're teachers and our lives are invested here,'' she said.  Paul Baden, the 27-year-old assistant recreation director and a native of Roseville, Minn., said the school was decorated with green and red crepe paper for Christmas. ''Santa will fly in and see that it's safe,'' he said. **********The teachers and the wife of a United States oil company executive said the Americans here were anxious to hear from their home offices about whether they had to leave. 'The People Are All Very Calm' **********''The people are all very calm,'' said the woman, who asked that her name not be used to comply with company policy. ''We're just doing the things we normally do.'' **********The Americans admitted that they had an economic and personal interest in staying in Libya, where many United States citizens have high-paying jobs. But they stressed that they did not have a false sense of security. **********''I've been here 10 years and have many good Libyan friends,'' said Skender Brame, 46 years old, of Cleveland, recreation director at the school. ''I just don't think they would do what the Iranians did at the embassy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/05/world.main_headline: ISLAMIC MISSION TAKES PLAN FOR A TRUCE TO IRAN AND IRAQ
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/05/world.print_headline: ISLAMIC MISSION TAKES PLAN FOR A TRUCE TO IRAN AND IRAQ
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/05/world.body_text: **********An Islamic peace mission visited Iran and Iraq today for the second time this week and presented a detailed proposal for a cease-fire in the two countries' war and for negotiations for a settlement. **********Iran's Supreme Defense Council met immediately under the chairmanship of President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the Commander in Chief of Iran's armed forces, to consider the proposal. Mr. Bani-Sadr said later that its deliberations would continue. **********Arab diplomats here said that the proposal, the first detailed one to be presented to both sides in any mediation attempt thus far, called for disengagement of the opposing troops and deployment of a joint Islamic military force between them followed by negotiations.  The opposing troops are at various parts of a 300-mile front in Iran. **********The peace mission met with Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini before flying to Baghdad to present the same proposal to the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein. It then returned to Jidda, Saudi Arabia, to await the formal replies. **********Both Iranian and Iraqi leaders, meanwhile, continued to stress publicly that they would not back down from their conflicting positions. Despite these statements, Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization and a member of the Islamic mission, expressed some optimism about the chances for progress toward a cease-fire. He commented after conferring with President Bani-Sadr. Open Dispute in Iran **********Also on the mission are presidents or cabinet ministers of seven Islamic countries and the secretary general of the Islamic Conference Organization, which is based in Jidda. **********President Ahmed Sekou Toure of Guinea, the chairman of the mission, said in an interview with the Saudi press agency that Iraq and Iran had agreed in principle to a cease-fire but had each put forward conditions. He said that Iran insisted that the Iraqis withdraw first from territory seized in September and October and that Iraq demanded territorial guarantees before pulling back. **********On Monday, Gen. Valiollah Fallahi, Iran's military chief of staff and a supporter of President Bani-Sadr in his feud with the Islamic fundamentalists, suggested that a brief cease-fire could be accepted first to allow Iraq to withdraw. This statement apparently prompted a strong attack today by Ayatollah Mohammed Beheshti, the leader of the fundamentalist Islamic Republican Party, which dominates the Iranian Government and Parliament. He denounced such ideas as tantamount to treason, the Teheran radio reported. **********President Bani-Sadr, by contrast, was quoted as having told the Islamic mission that he hoped it would continue its efforts.   Italy Selling Ships to Iraq **********ROME, March 4 (Reuters) - The Italian Government has authorized the export to Iraq of 11 naval vessels and a floating dock worth a total of $1.8 billion, the state-owned shipbuilding company Fincantieri said today. The are four 2,500-ton frigates, six 600-ton corvettes and a support vessel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/world.main_headline: Parliamentary Elections Set for June 30 in Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/world.print_headline: Parliamentary Elections Set for June 30 in Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/world.body_text: **********After a month of political maneuvering and bargaining, Parliament voted unanimously today to set June 30 as the date for new elections. **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin is to remain in office at least until a new Government can be formed after the election of a new Parliament. **********June 30 was a compromise between the Begin Cabinet's preference for July 7 and an earlier date favored by the opposition Labor Party, which has been heavily favored over Mr. Begin's Likud bloc in public opinion polls. Labor had called for elections in April or May to take advantage of discontent with the Government. **********Mr. Begin and his Cabinet had not wanted elections before November, when they were originally scheduled. A series of defections and resignations, however, weakened the coalition and made a vote of no confidence inevitable if the Government tried to continue. **********The event that tipped the scale was the resignation last month of Finance Minister Yigael Hurwitz, who took his three members of the Rafi faction with him, in protest over a Cabinet decision to accept a plan for large midcontract raises for teachers. He said the decision would undermine his fight against inflation. **********The economy finally broke the Government's resilience, and the economy seemed likely to figure prominently in the election campaign.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.main_headline: BID FOR COLT IS OPPOSED BY HUNTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.print_headline: BID FOR COLT IS OPPOSED BY HUNTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.body_text: **********The Penn Central Corporation disclosed yesterday that the Hunt brothers of Texas and two former executives of a Penn Central subsidiary had joined forces to oppose its pending $1.4 billion purchase of Colt Industries. **********Stockholders in Penn Central, which has been rapidly diversifying into manufacturing and energy-related businesses, are scheduled to vote on the cash and stock deal Oct. 29. Colt makes diesel engines, pumps, machine tools and other industrial products in addition to its well-known firearms. **********Operating under the name Penn Central Stockholders Committee, the opponents of the acquisition own 2.1 million Penn Central preferred shares, according to papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Penn Central said this represente d 7.5 percent of Penn Central's shares eligible to vote. **********The committee's members include William Herbert Hunt, Nelson Bunker Hunt and Lamar Hunt as well as Howard L. Terry and Walter M. Mischer, according to the filing with the Federal agency. Mr. Terry, a Penn Central director, had been executive committee chairman of the Marathon Manufacturing Company, now a Penn Central subsidiary. Mr.  Mischer is a former Marathon director. Origin of Committee's Holding Penn Centra l said yesterday that most of the preferred stock in thehands of the committee was obtained by committee members when Penn Central acqui red Marathon. **********The committee's S.E.C. filing said that the committee was formed to investigate the venture and ''take such other action as may be deemed appropriate.'' It said that possible activities might include solicitation of proxies to defeat the plan and litigation against it. The filing also said that the committee might ask Penn Central to take ''corrective action,'' and seek to improve the offer from the standpoint of Penn Central stockholders. **********Telephone calls to Ivan Irwin Jr., of Dallas, attorney to the dissidents, were referred to the Hunt Energy Corporation, also of Dallas, where a secretary said that the only person authorized to comment was out of the office for the day. **********In a Mailgram sent last month to Richard Dicker, chairman of Penn Central, Nelson Bunker Hunt protested the purchase as ''extremely beneficial'' to Colt shareholders and ''very detrimental'' to Penn Central investors. William Herbert Hunt said in a letter to directors that the merger would depress Penn Central stock, ''wiping out'' the value to preferred stockholders of converting their shares into common stock. GK Technologies Stand Cited **********Mr. Dicker said in a prepared statement that Penn Central's directors, management and advisers had already considered the committee's views before going ahead with the deal. He termed it ''highly beneficial'' for shareholders. ''This same group,'' he said, ''opposed the acquisition of GK Technologies,'' which, he maintained, had been ''highly beneficial to Penn Central.'' **********Later, in a telephone interview, Mr. Dicker said he had received two phone calls last week from William Herbert Hunt. He said Mr. Hunt asked if he could attend a Penn Central board meeting about Colt and present his views. Mr. Dicker said he told Mr. Hunt he would study the matter and report back. He said Mr. Hunt called again several hours later and that he told Mr. Hunt that a stockholder's participation in the meeting would not be appropriate. **********Mr. Dicker said he told Mr. Hunt that the Oct. 29 stockholders' meeting was the proper forum for stockholder comment. He said he also proposed a meeting between Mr. Hunt and Penn Central officers and, ''perhaps directors'' and ''perhaps me.'' He said Mr. Hunt ''just listened'' and made no comments on the suggestion. **********Asked about the shareholder vote, he said, ''My expectation is that a majority of shareholders of Penn Central will approve the transaction.'' He noted that Penn Central's advisers, Lazard Freres and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, had said the terms were fair to Penn Central stockholders. **********Colt shares, which stood at $63 when merger talks were announced in late July, jumped $5.25, to $87.75, when both signed a definitive agreement last month. Yesterday, Colt slid $3, to $80. Penn Central rose 25 cents, to $35 a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/busin.body_text: **********Three members of President Reagan's auto industry task force told a Senate panel today that they opposed legislation to restrict Japanese auto imports. **********Secretary of Transportation Drew Lewis, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and the United States trade representative, Bill Brock, said they preferred negotiation of import limitations with the Japanese rather than legislated quotas. **********Mr. Lewis said there was a difference of opinion among the sixmember task force regarding import restraints but that in their recommendations to the President, ''we will be pushing in the area of voluntary restraints.'' **********The hearing involved a proposed bill that would limit Japanese auto imports to 1.6 million units a year. Senators from states that depend heavily on the auto industry for jobs have called for an even greater reduction of Japanese imports. **********Mr. Baldrige said that of the 2.6-million-unit decline in domestic auto sales from 1976 to 1980, only 400,000 sales could be attributed to ''import substitutions.''
