https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/world.main_headline: SUZUKI SAYS HE WILL PRESS REAGAN ON SHIP SINKING DURING U.S. VISIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/world.print_headline: SUZUKI SAYS HE WILL PRESS REAGAN ON SHIP SINKING DURING U.S. VISIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki told Parliament today that he would ask President Reagan about the collision between an American submarine and a Japanese freighter at their meeting in Washington next month. **********Mr. Suzuki described the accident last Thursday, which resulted in the sinking of the freighter and the deaths of two of its crew, as ''very regrettable and a big shock to me.'' **********The Japanese have said that the nuclear submarine, the George Washington, failed to pick up the 13 survivors of the collision and that the United States Navy did not report the incident promptly. The dispute over the collision comes at a time when the United States is trying hard to obtain an increased Japanese military commitment. **********The main topic at the Reagan-Suzuki meeting is expected here to be defense and American requests for Japan to assume a greater part of the burden of protecting itself. **********The United States, according to Ambassador Mike Mansfield, wants Japan to protect sea lanes close to home, to spend much more on antisubmarine and surveillance aircraft supplied by the United States and to increase military spending to substantially higher levels. Speech by Mansfield Noted **********''At the time of the accident, Ambassador Mike Mansfield was addressing a meeting, appealing to the audience on the importance of Japan's defense capability,'' said the mass-circulation newspaper Yomiuri. ''His appeal could have little effect when such an accident takes place in waters around Japan,'' it commented. **********''I am not convinced yet by the statement that the visibility was insufficient or that they lost sight of the ship,'' said Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ito in Parliament Monday, referring to a United States Navy account of the accident, which occurred some 110 miles south-southeast of Sasebo in western Japan **********The United States has apologized to Japan through Mr. Mansfield.  But there were no further explanations of what happened when the ballistic-missile submarine struck the 2,350-ton freighter. **********Mr. Ito said today that he expected the United States to provide an ''interim account'' of the accident following a United States Navy inquiry that started yesterday at Seventh Fleet headquarters in Yokosuka. **********Japanese survivors said that visibility at the time of the collision was close to 2,000 yards and that they had seen the submarine about 500 yards away on the surface after the crash. **********The United States Navy said that the submarine saw no survivors and no sign of a ship going down, that it called for an aircraft to check the area, and that it left the scene after the plane found nothing to report.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/21/busin.print_headline: EARNINGS; Du Pont Up 50.6%; Carbide Rises 29%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/21/busin.body_text: **********E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical producer, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter of 1981 increased 50.6 percent as sales rose 14.2 percent. **********The Wilmington, Del., concern said that earnings in the latest three months rose to $262 million, or $1.67 a share, from $174 million, or $1.10 a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales advanced to $3.93 billion from $3.44 billion. **********Du Pont, a major manufacturer of textile fibers and a variety of other specialty products, said that sales and earnings in the second quarter include the results of the New England Nuclear Corporation, which became a subsidiary in April. Prior-year results have been restated accordingly. **********''Second-quarter results showed a significant improvement over last year,'' said Edward G. Jefferson, Du Pont's chairman. ''This progress was especially encouraging since it was accomplished in an economic environment still affected by depressed activity in the domestic automotive and housing industries and weakness in some international markets.'' Union Carbide **********The Union Carbide Corporation, a diversified company in chemicals and plastics, industrial gases, metals and carbon products and consumer goods, announced that net income in its second quarter rose 29 percent, to $193.4 million, or $2.86 a share, from $149.9 million, or $2.25 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales advanced 12.7 percent, to $2.67 billion, from $2.37 billion. **********William S. Sneath, Carbide's chairman and chief executive officer, said that the second-quarter gain in net income resulted from a balanced product mix and strength in earnings from operations of most domestic businesses. **********Carbide said second-quarter earnings included an after-tax gain of $41.8 million due to foreign-currency translation and exchange. The currency gain does not include the effects of the currency-rate changes on inventories, the company said. These effects in 1981 substantially offset the reported currency gains, according to Carbide. Merck **********Merck & Company, one of the largest ethical drug concerns, said that its net income in the second quarter dipped 1.7 percent, to $108.5 million, or $1.46 a share, from $110.4 million, or $1.47 a share, in the second quarter of 1980. Sales rose by 10.3 percent, to $744.3 million, from $674.8 million. **********The Rahway, N.J., concern said that currency exchanges with the rising United States dollar and declining European and Latin American currencies created unfavorable balances totaling $17.5 million in the latest three months. About half of Merck's sales are overseas. SmithKline **********The SmithKline Corporation, a leading producer of pharmaceuticals based in Philadelphia, reported that net income in the second quarter rose 17.1 percent, to $80.3 million, or $1.21 a share, from $68.6 million, or $1.04 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 18.4 percent, to $478.1 million, from $403.7 million. **********''Excellent performances in our worldwide ethical pharmaceuticals business, resurgent sales in the animal health field and continued sharp increases in the volume of eye-care products were the major factors in our second-quarter growth,'' said Robert F. Dee, SmithKline's chairman and chief executive. Pfizer **********Pfizer Inc. reported that net income in the second quarter increased 4.5 percent, to $60 million, or 80 cents a share, from $57.4 million, or 78 cents a share, in the three months a year earlier. Sales increased 8.6 percent, to $797.8 million, from $734.5 million. **********Pfizer said that losses from discontinued operations associated with the phased withdrawal from the diagnostic imaging business reduced 1981 net income by $4.7 million, or 5 cents a share. G.D. Searle **********G. D. Searle & Company reported a loss of $3.2 million in the second quarter contrasted to earnings of $28.2 million, or 53 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. **********The latest quarter, Searle said, included a loss from discontinued operations of $32.5 million while the quarter a year earlier included a loss from discontinued operations of $10.8 million and an extraordinary tax credit of $13 million. American Cyanamid **********The American Cyanamid Company, a major producer of chemicals and pharmaceutical products based in Wayne, N.J., reported that net income in the second quarter advanced 29.4 percent, to $42.2 million, or 88 cents a share, from $32.6 million, or 68 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 7.5 percent, to $900 million, from $837 million. ---- Earnings tables, page D6.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/07/busin.body_text: **********Purchasing agents at many of the leading industrial companies in the United States believe that the economy is sliding deeper into recession but still has a long way to go before it hits bottom, according to the November survey of the National Association of Purchasing Management. **********''The downward turn in the economy reported in September, which continued lower in October, worsened in November,'' said the association's latest report, which was released yesterday. ''A recession,'' concluded the report, which surveyed purchasing agents at 225 major industrial concerns, ''is definitely upon us.'' **********The survey is regarded as an indication of future economic trends, since today's purchasing orders are a factor in determining the strength of tomorrow's economy. **********In Close Touch With Data **********The purchasing agents must be in close touch with their companies' production and sales figures before they can place orders for supplies. The association has been conducting the monthly survey of its members since the 1930's. **********Judging from the tapestry of gloom woven by purchasing agents questioned in the November poll, the recession will be more than just a mild downturn. **********The report said that ''there are some striking similarities between this period and the dismal performance of the economy in the second quarter of 1980, when real gross national product dropped by almost 10 percent.'' Purchasing agents, it added, found that all key economic indicators - new orders, capital expenditures, production and employment - continued to decline substantially in November. 'Orders Fell Off a Cliff' **********''The chemicals and container salesmen to whom I talk say that their orders fell off a cliff in November and are not showing any improvement in December,'' said Hank Batek, regional purchasing manager for the Nalco Chemical Company, a major producer of specialty chemical products based in Oak Brook, Ill. ''It has not bottomed out yet, not by a long shot.'' **********''Business has dropped like a stone in the last month,'' said Douglas D. Rossman, raw materials purchaser for the Federal-Mogul Corporation, a Southfield, Mich., manufacturer of bearings and other metal products. Its business is highly influenced by the fortunes of the automobile and construction industries. **********''We are cutting back our orders from the steel mills and brokers of nonferrous metals such as copper, tin and aluminum,'' added Mr.  Rossman, whose views were not included in the purchasing managers' survey. The only bright spot, he said, was that requests by suppliers for price increases in 1982 were much less than in the previous two years since no one could take their customers for granted any more. **********Only 25 percent of the purchasing managers in the association's survey said that the prices of the goods they were buying were up in November. That has happened just once before since the 1973-75 recession. Of those who did cite increased costs, many said that the official prices were being offset by considerable discounting. Prices of Rail Products Down **********William C. Meares, assistant vice president for purchasing at the Santa Fe Railroad, said he has not only seen price stabilization in railroad products, but some significant price deterioration. ''It's a buyer's market,'' added Mr. Meares, ''and we are tickled to death.'' **********The association's survey found that its members increased the rate at which they were cutting their inventories in November, an indication that companies were reaching into their warehouses instead of placing new orders. Any inventory accumulation that is taking place is largely a result of companies not being able to move the new products coming off the assembly line. **********''Everyone is very cautious,'' said Ralph P. Baker, vice president for purchasing at the Corning Glass Works. ''They want to see what kind of incoming orders they get for next year before they commit themselves to building up inventories. Right now orders are soft and if they stay that way we are going to hold down on our output so we don't build up excessive stocks.'' **********Donald O. Corvey, vice president for materials at the RCA Corporation, said orders for consumer products such as television sets and other electronic entertainment equipment had been ''sluggish.'' Although the fourth quarter is usually the biggest quarter of the year for RCA's consumer goods, this year's sales were trailing last year's, he added. Interest in Leasing Cited **********The global communications and satellite business has fared better, he said, but there was still a noticeable ''restraint'' in capital expenditures. Customers are much more interested in leasing equipment unless it is absolutely essential that they buy, he explained. **********That assessment was echoed in the association's survey. The number of purchasing managers saying that they were committing themselves to capital equipment orders ''six months in advance or longer'' fell to 64 percent -the lowest level since March 1973, just before the last major recession. Industry is trying to survive by ordering ''hand-to-mouth,'' the report said. **********Probably the most pessimistic aspect of the purchasing managers' report was the outlook on employment. In November, only 3 percent of the respondents said their employment was higher, down from 7 percent in October. This was the smallest number of managers to report higher employment since the end of World War II. **********''We have a hiring freeze on in our department,'' said Gary E.  Owens, purchasing agent for the Travelers Insurance Company in Hartford, ''and the same is true throughout most of the company. We are replacing people who leave, but there are no additions to the staff. We are definitely in a recession and we don't know when this thing is going to bottom out.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/07/busin.body_text: **********The nation's consumers increased their installment debt for the sixth consecutive month in January, buying $869 million more on credit than they paid off, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. **********The expansion in short-term debt was about half the $1.6 billion increase recorded in December, in line with many analysts' predictions that credit growth would slow early this year along with a slackening of the nation's economic growth. **********''The rate of expansion weakened for all categories of installment credit, with small declines registered for automobile and mobile home loans,'' the report said. The figures, which include creditcard, auto-loan and other short-term debt but not home mortgages, are adjusted for seasonal variations but not for inflation. **********The Federal Reserve said installment credit grew at an annual rate of 3 percent in January, compared with a 6 percent annual rate for December and 4 percent for the fourth quarter of 1980. Credit growth for all of last year, including the spring recession, was less than 1 percent. **********The report said consumers used $27.06 billion in short-term credit for January purchases, slightly less than December's $27.15 billion.  And they paid off slightly more of their old debt - $26.19 billion, up from $25.53 billion - thus accounting for the smaller rise in credit growth. **********In overall unadjusted figures, American consumers had $310.6 billion in outstanding installment debt in January, down one-tenth of 1 percent from $311 billion a year earlier, the report said. **********Borrowing for new auto loans was slightly higher in January at $7.24 billion, up from $7.23 billion in December, but consumers paid off old auto loans at a faster rate, decreasing the amount of autoloan debt outstanding. **********They also bought more with their retail store credit cards and oil company cards than in the previous month.  However, those new-borrowing increases were outweighed by a 6.6 percent drop in new purchases with bank credit cards and check credit, to $5.2 billion in January, from a seasonally adjusted $5.6 billion in December. **********Consumers paid off $7.3 billion on auto loans, up 5.3 percent from December liquidations of $6.9 billion, and also paid off oil-card and retail-store debt slightly faster. However, they paid off bank-card credit at a slower pace than in December, liquidating $5.1 billion in debt, down from December's $5.3 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/16/world.main_headline: Tass Points to Killings in Atlanta As Sign of Racist 'Terror' in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/16/world.print_headline: Tass Points to Killings in Atlanta As Sign of Racist 'Terror' in U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/16/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union charged yesterday that the killing of black children in Atlanta showed that the ''real terror'' of racist violence was rampant in America. **********''There is every indication that the senseless and cruel killings of children in Atlanta is of little concern both to the authorities of the state and to Washington,'' Tass, the official Soviet Government press agency, said. **********Instead of catching the killers, Tass asserted, Federal officials were preoccupied with fanning another ''anti-Soviet campaign by maliciously imputing to the Soviet Union an involvement in international terrorism.'' **********The Tass dispatch made no mention of President Reagan's approval Friday of $1.5 million to help pay the cost of investigation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/28/busin.body_text: **********The Exxon Corporation reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings dropped 1.1 percent from the comparable period a year earlier, but said profits for all of last year surged 31.8 percent, to a record $5.66 billion. **********The world's largest oil company also said that revenues for all of 1980 soared to $110.47 billion, up 30 percent from $84.97 billion in 1979 and believed to be the highest sales figure ever reported by an industrial company. **********Exxon's quarterly decline surprised many analysts, who generally expected somewhat better results.  ''I don't think we thought it was going to be as bad as what they're coming in with,'' said Merz K. Peters of Brown Brothers Harriman. ''It reflects some of the rough crosscurrents in the world today,'' added Joel Fischer of Drexell Burnham. **********In a separate announcement, the Marathon Oil Company said its earnings rose only 2 percent in the final three months of last year, although its profits for the full year were also sharply higher. Exxon **********The Exxon Corporation said net income for the fourth quarter totaled $1.35 billion, or $3.12 a share, on revenues of $29.85 billion. This compares with net earnings in the comparable 1979 period of $1.36 billion, or $3.10 a share, on revenues of $25.82 billion. **********For the full year, Exxon posted record earnings of $5.66 billion, or $13.0l a share, compared with 1979's $4.3 billion, or $9.74 a share. **********Exxon attributed the 1.1 percent decline in quarterly net income to lower operating earnings. ''Most significantly, foreign petroleum and natural gas earnings, which totaled $834 million in the fourth quarter of 1980, were down $224 million from the corresponding period of 1979, due to higher exploration costs as well as lower demand and margins on petroleum product sales,'' C.C. Garvin, Exxon chairman, said. Chemical Earnings Decline **********''Worldwide chemical earnings declined from $136 million in the strong 1979 quarter to $77 million in the latest quarter, reflecting worldwide recessionary effects on both demand and margins,'' his statement continued. In addition, Exxon's Reliance Electric subsidiary suffered a $36 million loss, mainly because of accounting adjustments. The retroactive application of a $2-a-barrel crude oil price increase by Saudi Arabia also hurt. **********Exxon's flat quarter came despite foreign exchange gains of $215 million, up sharply from the $2 million posted a year earlier.  For the full year, Mr. Garvin said, ''Earnings in the exploration and production segment of the United States petroleum and natural gas operations rose to $2.13 billion from $1.44 billion in 1979,'' mainly because of higher prices. **********The Exxon chairman also cited year-to-year annual gains in the refining and marketing segments of United States petroleum operations, and for foreign exploration, production, refining and marketing. Worldwide chemical earnings fell to $404 million in 1980 from $456 million in 1979. Marathon **********The Marathon Oil Company announced fourth-quarter earnings of $55.3 million, or 92 cents a share, up from the $54.3 million, or 90 cents a share, in the comparable 1979 period. Revenues increased 9 percent, to $2.42 billion from $2.22 billion. **********For the full year, Marathon reported earnings of $379 million, or $6.27 a share, compared with $323.2 million, or $5.34 a share, in 1979. The 1979 result included an extraordinary credit of $28 million, or 46 cents a share, realized in the first half. Revenues increased to $8.75 billion from $7.2 billion. **********Marathon said its income from United States exploration and production activities showed strong improvement in the quarter, and that this increase offset the worldwide impact of lower demand for refined products and higher exploration costs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/08/world.main_headline: POLISH UNION TO OPEN PUBLICITY OFFICE IN NEW YORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/08/world.print_headline: POLISH UNION TO OPEN PUBLICITY OFFICE IN NEW YORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/08/world.body_text: **********A representative of Solidarity, Poland's in dependent trade union movement, marched in the Labor Day parade in New York yesterday and said that in two weeks he would open in New York the first foreign office of Solidarity. **********Zygmunt Przetakiewicz, 35 years old, said that he would be the managing director of a press and information office that would supply news of the union movement to American news organizations. **********Mr. Przetakiewicz, who speaks good English, arrived in New York two weeks ago and has taken office space at 260 Park Avenue South, the building occupied by the United Federation of Teachers. **********''We will be opening officially at the end of September,'' Mr.  Przetakiewicz said. ''We want to bring some fresh information. It is our first office abroad.'' **********He said that the Polish Government was not aware of the plans for the new office and that he had arrived here on a tourist visa. Aid From Teachers' Group **********Albert Shanker, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, who marched alongside Mr. Przetakiewicz at the beginning of the parade, said: ''We found the space in our headquarters. We have people in press relations who will help him. We will give him whatever he needs.'' **********Mr. Przetakiewicz was initially helped by the president of the A.F.L-C.I.O., Lane Kirkland. Mr. Kirkland said during the parade yesterday: ''We've been in close touch with Solidarity all along.  We've raised $300,000 for them.'' Mr. Kirkland said that his office had introduced Mr. Przetakiewicz to Mr. Shanker. **********Mr. Przetakiewicz said that he planned to provide a twice-a-day news service to the American press by a telex link between his office in New York and the Solidarity press office in Warsaw. Spokesman Joined Union Early On **********Mr. Przetakiewicz, who joined Solidarity two days after its founding on Aug. 31, 1980, said he had been a journalist for two newspapers in Warsaw, Nieraleznosc and Informator Biezacy, before leaving for the United States. He said he would draw a salary from Solidarity for his work here and that his immediate superior would be Janusz Onyszkiewicz, the spokesman for Solidarity in Poland. **********Wearing a Solidarity button on his white shirt and a blue rimmed white hat with ''Solidarnosc'' - the Polish word for Solidarity - in bold letters, Mr. Przetakiewicz seemed impressed with the parade. **********''It's great. I've never seen it before,'' he said as a crowd of cheering metal sheet workers went by. ''This is full of happiness, people enjoy it. The last parade we had was for lack of food.'' **********He would not be drawn into commenting on President Reagan. ''I would not like to be involved in this kind of thing,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/30/world.main_headline: MURDERS BRING FEAR TO PROTESTANTS ON ULSTER BORDER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/30/world.print_headline: MURDERS BRING FEAR TO PROTESTANTS ON ULSTER BORDER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/30/world.body_text: **********Last Sunday afternoon, when they buried Sir Norman Stronge, a prominent retired politician whom Irish Republican Army terrorists said they had killed, the British Cabinet Minister responsible for Northern Ireland pointedly stayed away from the service in the little gray stone church here. **********The minister, Humphrey Atkins, would normally have been one of the chief mourners of Sir Norman, whose murder at the age of 86 has deeply shocked this tidy village on the border with the Irish Republic. But Sir Norman's family, incensed at what they see as the inadequacy of the security along the border, had told him that he was not welcome. **********The Stronge family's symbolic protest against the British Government reflects a growing sense of insecurity and fear among Protestants on this side of the 300-mile border, which is frequently crossed and recrossed by Irish Republican gunmen, who feel safest in the south. **********''You learn to live with the fear because it is part of your daily life,'' said a Protestant woman who was buying eggs and butter in the Tynan grocery store, just down the road from the 18th-century mansion in which Irish Republican Army gunmen killed Sir Norman, a former Speaker of the provincial legislature, and his son, James, last Wednesday night. 'Ruling Classes' Warned **********After the attack, in which the Stronge house was burned by firebombs, the Provisional I.R.A. issued a statement warning other members of what it called the ''Loyalist ruling classes'' that they were also in ''the firing line.'' **********The statement acknowledged that this was a ''departure'' for the terrorist organization, which had been concentrating its attacks on policemen, soldiers and others actively in the service of the Government, and it sent through the province shivers of anxiety that there might be a new wave of killings. **********''If the Government shows that it cannot protect law-abiding citizens, then there will be more and more of these murders,'' said Harold McCusker, who represents this area in the Parliament in London and who has had dozens of constituents killed in recent years. **********The murder of Sir Norman and his son was thought to have been retribution for an attack five days earlier on Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, the activist who gained international renown as a young member of Parliament in the early 1970's. Mrs. McAliskey and her husband, Michael, were shot in their home 15 miles north of here, presumably by members of a Protestant paramilitary group. Both were badly wounded and are still hospitalized in Belfast. Numerous Roads Cross Border **********The ease with which Sir Norman Stronge's killers escaped, despite a huge and immediate manhunt across the hills and meadows of his 900-acre estate and beyond, reflects a perennial problem that concerns the Governments in both Belfast and Dublin - the porousness of the long border. **********The border cuts across farms, villages and even pubs, and it is crossed by as many as 300 roads and lanes and paths that are wide enough to accommodate a carload of terrorists sneaking north or rushing back south. **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Government have lately been praising the police in the Irish Republic for being more and more cooperative in the cross-border fight against terrorism. ''We have no complaints at all on that score,'' said an official involved with the problem in London. **********But in the view of the people here, including Mr. McCusker, that sort of talk is largely designed to placate the Dublin Government, with which London is eagerly striving to have better relations. **********''I'm not saying that no progress has been made with the police in the Republic, but we must do more on our side,'' said Mr. McCusker, who said he ''fully sympathized'' with the Stronge family's desire not to have the British Government represented at the funeral. Protestant Families Nervous **********In most of Northern Ireland, Protestants are heavily in the majority, and in fact the province was created 60 years ago along lines drawn to make it so. But here along the border there are many areas where Roman Catholics predominate, and the surrounded Protestant families are often nervous. **********''Please don't mention my name,'' said a Protestant woman who lives in a small town southeast of here. ''We feel that we are targets enough as it is.'' **********I.R.A. sources in Belfast have traditionally said that Protestants who live in this area are safe from attack so long as they are not affiliated with the police, the militia or the Government. But last week's statement threatening the ''Loyalist ruling classes'' seemed to narrow that immunity. I.R.A. 'Cannot Drive Us Out' **********''They cannot drive us out, though,'' said a Protestant farmer whose brother, a part-time policeman, was shot dead two years ago.  ''It's our home, too, and we are staying.'' **********Many of the 11,200 British troops stationed in Northern Ireland are constantly along the border, especially in the stretch of it here where County Monaghan, in the Republic, meets County Armagh, in the North. It is startling to come suddenly across them on patrol - half a dozen young men in battle fatigues, who seem out of place as they stalk watchfully through what looks like peaceful green countryside, their automatic weapons at the ready. **********''We stop everyone who comes along here,'' said the sergeant commanding a patrol on a narrow and muddy back road half a mile from Sir Norman Stronge's house. ''And we watch everything that moves. But still, we could not prevent them from murdering that old man. You just can't be everywhere.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/30/world.main_headline: Around the World; U.S. and South Korea Resume Security Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/30/world.print_headline: Around the World; U.S. and South Korea Resume Security Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/30/world.body_text: **********The United States and South Korea today resumed regular consultations on security that were postponed by the Carter Administration after the military seized power in Seoul in December 1979. **********Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and the South Korean Defense Minister, Choo Young Bock, met in San Francisco for the first of two days of talks originally scheduled to have taken place more than a year ago. **********Pentagon officials said earlier this week that the United States would reaffirm its commitment to South Korea but would gently shelve a request from Seoul for more military aid. **********Relations between the two countries have improved markedly since President Reagan took office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/23/world.body_text: **********Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, warned today that a rash step in the Middle East could engulf the entire region in war. **********Speaking in Tbilisi, capital of Soviet Georgia, at celebrations marking the 60th anniversary of the Georgian Communist Party, Mr.  Brezhnev said that a proposal he made three months ago for an international conference on the Middle East still offered a ''good chance'' for stabilizing the situation. **********The speech did not offer a detailed discussion of the crisis between Israel and Syria over the emplacement of Syrian antiaircraft missiles in Lebanon. Western diplomats here interpreted Mr.  Brezhnev's remarks as an attempt to promote the conference he proposed in February at a Communist Party congress. **********Most of Mr. Brezhnev's speech focused on domestic Georgian issues.  His comments on international affairs largely avoided the sharp attacks on the United States that have marked some of his recent statements. **********In the speech Mr. Brezhnev again attacked the NATO decision to deploy new American nuclear missiles in Western Europe. ''If necessary, we shall find impressive means to safeguard our vital interests,'' he said without elaborating. **********Mr. Brezhnev said the Soviet Union was prepared to discuss the security of the Persian Gulf and Afghanistan, either separately or ''in connection with each other.'' He reiterated that Moscow was prepared to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan if ''outside interference'' there was terminated and he accused Pakistan of a ''stubborn refusal'' to come to terms with its Afghan neighbors. **********Mr. Brezhnev made no mention of Poland in his address, which was televised. But his speech coincided with a sharp new statement by the official press agency Tass accusing ''revisionist elements'' in Poland of seeking to give the Communist Party there a ''social democratic or other direction.'' ---- Haig Opposes a Conference Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, May 22 - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  today rebuffed Mr. Brezhnev's proposal for an international conference to discuss Lebanon, saying that the United States was interested instead ''in an international conference that would focus on the Soviet presence in Afghanistan.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/02/busin.body_text: **********Pork production during the rest of the year is expected to be 10 percent less than last year and, in response to the production decline, hog prices will be higher, the Agriculture Department said today in a report. **********Hog prices have rebounded to more than $50 per hundredweight, or 100 pounds, up from a winter average of $41, when prices were well below costs. **********Prices of fed cattle have increased less sharply. Choice steers sold at Omaha, Neb., are selling for about $70 per hundredweight, the department said. **********Beef output will be ''a little larger'' than last summer and fall as more beef is fed in feedlots, and marketings of grass-fed cattle rise seasonally in late summer, according to the department. It also said that broiler production will be up 10 percent compared to last summer when heat waves reduced output. This fall, production will be up about 5 percent. **********Corn and soybean crops for livestock feeding are expected to be much greater than a year ago when drought reduced yields. Larger crops would encourage livestock production, the department said. **********Higher livestock prices did nothing to change the department's estimate of 1981 farm income from last month's forecast. Experts predicted that income will fall within a range of $22 billion to $27 billion, which would be less than predicted earlier this year. In 1980, farm income was a depressed $22 billion, 29 percent less than 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; 102 New Products Introduced in March
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/busin.body_text: **********The New Product News published by Dancer Fitzgerald Sample reports that 102 new products were introduced in March, compared with 78 in February. **********The March figure was down 10 percent from the 114 products introduced in the similar month a year ago. For the first quarter this year, there were 265 new products, compared with 278 in the comparable period last year. **********Two standouts this month include a fingernail repair glue called Lady Fingers by Woodhill Permatex of Cleveland. Call it an emergency road kit for her if you like. The other is a new weapon for the war against insects called Mouse-O-Leum by Custom Tapes in Chicago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/world.main_headline: IRAN FREES ONE AMERICAN AND HAS HEARING FOR ANOTHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/world.print_headline: IRAN FREES ONE AMERICAN AND HAS HEARING FOR ANOTHER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/05/world.body_text: **********The State Department said today that one of three Americans being held prisoner in Iran was released last night and a hearing on another's case was held today. **********William J. Dyess, the department spokesman, said that Mohi Sobhani, an Iranian-born American citizen from Los Angeles who had been held since Sept. 6 on espionage charges, had telephoned his brother in Santa Barbara, Calif., to tell him of his release. **********A spokesman for Representative Henry A Waxman, Democrat of California, who has followed the case, said that Mr. Sobhani was still in Teheran with his Iranian wife and their four-year-old daughter. The spokesman said he understood that Mr. Sobhani's wife and her mother had petitioned Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini on Mr.  Sobhani's behalf and that a $900,000 bond had been posted by the family. **********In the other case, Mr. Dyess said that the Swiss Government, which represents the United States in Teheran, reported that a hearing had been held today in the case of Cynthia B. Dwyer of Amherst, N.Y., outside of Buffalo, who has been imprisoned since May 5. **********Reports from Switzerland have quoted Swiss officials as saying that a "trial" on espionage charges against Mrs. Dwyer had been conducted at Evin Prison in Teheran with Swiss diplomats present. Mr. Dyess, however, insisted on calling the event "a hearing" and said he was not aware of any specific charges against Mrs. Dwyer. Her husband says she went to Iran intending to work as a freelance journlist. She has been describes by her family as sympathetic to the goals of the Irania revolution. **********Mr. Dyess and reports from Bern and Teheran agreed that "a disposition" in Mrs. Dwyer's case was expected about Monday. State Department officials are privately hoping that Iran will alow Mrs.  Dwyer to return home. They were heartened by the report of Mr.  Sobhani's release. A Swiss diplomat in Teheran said that Mrs. Dwyer had appeared before a daylong session of a revolutionary court, according to Reuters. The diplomat, Wilhelm Shcmidt, said that she had "behaved admirably" in her defense and that she had appeared to be in good health but looked nervous. He said that the Swiss Embassy had supplied Mrs. Dwyer with an interpreter for her court appearance. **********Mr. Waxman's office said that Mr. Sobhani's brother in Santa Barbara and his sister, who lives in Los Angeles, had both spoken to Mr. Sobhani by phone. They understood that a trial was held on espionage charges last night and that after four witnesses were unable to substantiate the allegations, the court allowed him to go free. **********It was unclear whether he was acquitted, as Mr. Waxman's office asserted, or whether he was free on bail pending further inquires. **********Mr. Waxman said that Mr. Sobhani, a computer technician for Rockwell International, had not been given his American passport and it was not known when he and his family would be able to leave Iran. 3d American Is Afghan Born **********The third American being held in Iran is Zia Nassri, an Afghan-born American citizen. His wife, who lives in New York said in a phone conversation that Mr. Nassri, who she said was a travel agent, was active on behalf of Afghan refugees and had gone several times to Iran to help them. She said she learned that he was arrested last March in the Teheran Hilton and was being held on espionage charges. **********The Swiss diplomats were not allowed to see either Mr. Sobhani or Mr. Nassri, the State Department said. **********In a news conference last week, Secretary of State Alexander M.  Haig, Jr. called on Iran to free the three prisoners. He said the treatment of the prisoners would influence American policy toward Iran. **********The case of Mrs. Dwyer, the wife of an English professor at Buffalo State College, has attracted the most attention in this country. She left the United States for Iran on April 10, shortly before the United States banned travel to Iran. She has been accused in the Iranian press of having worked for the Central Intelligence Agency, a charged denied by her husband. **********In all three cases, the State Department has said that it does not comment on such charges but that its lack of comment should not be regarded as confirming or denying them. **********Four Britons are also beign detained in Iran, apparently without charges. ----------- Husband Says He Is Patient **********BUFFALO, Feb. 4 - John F. Dwyer said today that he remained patient over delvelopments in his wife's case. **********"In some ways, things haven't changed," said Professor Dwyer, who is chariman of the English Department at the University of Buffalo.  "There has been no decision." **********The professor said he spent a hectic day answering telephone calls from reporters after the State Department told him in a 6:30 A.M.  telephone call that Swiss diplomats had attended "some sort of proceeding" involving his wife and an Iranian revolutionary tribunal. **********He said he had planned to go to the college today but decided not to after hearing about developments in the case. **********"I have administrative duties," Mr. Dwyer said. "After this broke, I called and said I wouldn't be in. It would be too disruptive." **********The couple have three children, Ben, 14 years old, Dan, 12 and Susannah, 9, and Mr. Dwyer said of the long wait and the attention from the press: "I'm sure they have resigned themselves to it." **********He said he had received little news about his wife other than a confirmation from Swiss diplomats who visited her on Jan. 12 that she had received a shipment of warm clothes in December. "Other than that, her health is good, " he said. "I don't know much else."

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/29/busin.main_headline: LEAGUE OF CITIES ASSAILS CABLE TV DEREGULATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/29/busin.print_headline: LEAGUE OF CITIES ASSAILS CABLE TV DEREGULATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/29/busin.body_text: **********The National League of Cities, the nation's largest municipal association, threatened today to fight a comprehensive telecommunications deregulation bill because it would end the authority of cities to own cable systems or regulate local cable operators. **********The proposed provisions were labeled ''a meat ax for cutting local government out of any effective regulatory role in present or future local cable franchises'' by Mayor Ernest N. Morial of New Orleans, a spokesman for the league, which is based here. **********He termed the bill a ''blatant give-away'' to the cable industry and its approval by the Senate Commerce Committee ''a display of back-room politics and back-door decision-making.'' He said that he was especially angry that the cable amendments were added without a public hearing. **********The amendments, which would end the authority of cities to control cable television subscription rates and services, were added the night before the committee approved the bill on July 16. Floor action is expected this fall. **********A historic piece of legislation, the bill would lift many of the regulations covering the telephone industry and would permit the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to expand into many information services. **********The opposition of the league, which represents 980 cities, could upset a delicate balance of support for the bill engineered by Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, the committee chairman. **********A number of accommodations were made in the bill to assuage powerful groups. Newspapers were protected from competition by Bell in classified advertising and dissemination of information through electronic newspapers, and subsequently the American Newspaper Publishers Association endorsed the bill. Cable was protected by putting cable television off-limits to most telephone companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/13/world.main_headline: Around the World; Brazil's Chief Resumes Job After Heart Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/13/world.print_headline: Around the World; Brazil's Chief Resumes Job After Heart Attack
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/13/world.body_text: **********Joao Baptista Figueiredo reassumed the Presidency of Brazil today after 53 days spent out of office recuperating from a heart attack. **********The 63-year-old retired army general told a gathering of Cabinet ministers in the capital city of Brasilia that he was returning to the job with undiminished resolve to fulfill his goal of gradually restoring democracy to Brazil, a program known as abertura, the Portuguese word for opening. **********''I cannot say that my heart is stronger because my doctors would tell you the contrary,'' President Figueiredo said. ''But my spirit is just as determined to lead this Government and this nation together with all of you and to persist in the final objective of my Government, which is the return of democratic normality to my country.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/27/world.body_text: **********The United States, in a gesture to Poland, announced today that it was allowing the Poles to defer repayment of nearly $90 million in debts over the next four months. **********The assistance was described by officials here as ''a bridging arrangement'' in concert with other Western nations to help the Poles. The major non-Communist creditors of Poland met in Paris this week to discuss urgent short-term aid to help the Warsaw Government deal with its heavy foreign debts. **********Poland, which has been beset by economic difficulties and labor problems, owes Western countries $23 billion to $25 billion, with interest and debt payments due this year alone totaling almost $10 billion. **********The announcement by the State Department said: ''The United States has decided to join with Poland's other creditors in providing shortterm assistance by deferring $88 million in repayments of United States Government credits.'' Agricultural Products Involved **********These debts fell under the program run by the Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corporation, which facilitates the sale of American agricultural products to foreign countries. **********The nearly $90 million debt payments that are being deferred were due between March 1 and June 30 of this year and are installments on credits granted in 1979 and 1980, officials said. **********Poland has asked the United States for as much as $3 billion in long-term economic assistance and has asked other Western nations for similar help. But the United States has put off any decisions on long-term assistance, officials said. **********''We continue to consult with Poland's other Western creditors to determine what steps might be taken to deal with Poland's debt problem over the longer term,'' the State Department said. **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has said that a major factor in deciding whether and to what extent to help Poland would be the kind of economic changes and stabilization programs that the Warsaw Government undertakes. To Indicate West's Interest **********The effort to help Poland economically reflects Western determination to maintain links with Warsaw and to indicate the West's interest in Poland's future, officials said. **********The countries that participated in the Paris meeting included the United States, West Germany, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Italy, Japan, Norway, the Netherlands, Britain, Sweden and Switzerland. Another meeting is planned in April to discuss long-range economic problems in Poland. **********The Poles will still owe the United States about $160 million in the second half of this year in agricultural commodities repayments.  It has not been decided whether to defer those repayments. **********Poland has already paid some $90 million on debts owed the United States this year, officials said, in addition to the nearly $90 million that will be deferred for the first half of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/03/busin.main_headline: KEY DEMOCRATS DRAFT TWO-YEAR BILL TO CUT TAXES 5%, THEN 10%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/03/busin.print_headline: KEY DEMOCRATS DRAFT TWO-YEAR BILL TO CUT TAXES 5%, THEN 10%
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/03/busin.body_text: **********In a challenge to the Reagan Administration, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee began drawing up a new two-year tax relief bill today that the committee's chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, said he hoped ''all Democrats'' would support on the House floor. **********This statement by Mr. Rostenkowski, at the end of a two-hour, closed-door caucus of Ways and Means Democrats, indicated that the Democrats were preparing for a test of strength with the Administration on the House floor over the tax cuts. **********One Democratic member of the committee reported that there was an informal committee agreement on a first-year cut of 5 percent and a further 10 percent reduction in 1982. Reagan Backs Three-Year Bill **********President Reagan has insisted on a three-year bill with 10 percent annual cuts, although he said yesterday that he would accept a 5 percent cut in the first year. **********The idea of a 15 percent reduction over two years, reported by Representative Kent Hance of Texas, was the first public indication of how large an across-the-board cut Mr. Rostenskowski would support. Administration officials have repeatedly complained that the panel's chairman had not made a specific coun-terproposal. Mr.  Rostenkowski had an unannounced meeting this morning with 11 Southern Democrats who belong to the newly organized Conservative Democratic Forum. The meeting was intended to sound out the Southerners on what kind of tax bill the Ways and Means Committee had to produce to win their support on the floor of the House of Representatives. **********The forum, with its members appearing to hold the balance of power on the floor, met this afternoon. Afterward, its coordinator, Representative Charles W. Stenholm of Texas, said that the 34 members present were about evenly divided between favoring a two-year bill and the tax cut over three years that President Reagan has said is nonnegotiable. **********Negotiations between the White House and Mr. Rostenkowski over a compromise tax bill have foundered essentially on this issue of two years or three years. Mr. Rostenkowski and other Democratic House leaders met with the President yesterday and reported that they were still split on the number of years. **********The Democrats have argued that a three-year cut would be imprudent because of inflation and uncertainty about the Federal budget deficit. Republicans charge that the Democrats are trying to hang onto Federal revenues in an effort to reverse this year's budget cuts in the future. **********Mr. Reagan has backed away from his original proposal of three consecutive annual tax cuts of 10 percent to the extent that he has accepted the proposal of the Southern Democrats for a 5 percent cut in the first year, starting Oct. 1, and 10 percent in 1982 and again in 1983. No Further Action Planned **********Mr. Stenholm said his group would take no further action on taxes until the shape of a Ways and Means bill was clear. **********Representative Hance, a conservative Democrat, reported that there was informal agreement on the Ways and Means Committee on a 5 percent cut in tax rates, effective Oct. 1, and a 10 percent cut on July 1, 1982. He said that the committee Democrats were also in general agreement that extra tax relief for people with incomes of $20,000 to $50,000 - a tilt that Mr. Rostenkowski has insisted upon - would be delivered by a provision to soften the ''marriage penalty'' paid by some two-income couples, an increase in the standard deduction for taxpayers who do not itemize, and liberalization of tax deductions for retirement savings. **********That framework is similar to a bill drafted by Mr. Hance and adopted by the Conservative Democratic Forum, except that Mr. Hance's bill has an additional 10 percent cut in 1983. The Reagan Administration has indicated that it would go along with such a three-year bill. Committee Compromise Seen **********Some Democrats suggested that the bill-drafting process in the committee might produce a bipartisan compromise that a number of House Republicans, if not the President, would support. **********''I think we'll work out in committee what will be called a compromise,'' said Representative Wyche Fowler Jr., a Georgia Democrat on the committee. Aides to Representative Rostenkowski also hinted at the possibility of Republican support. **********Emerging early this evening from a two-hour meeting with committee Democrats, Mr. Rostenkowski, a Chicago Democrat, said ''progress was made with respect to where we should be going'' and that another such session would start at 2 P.M. tomorrow. Asked if the committee would go into a formal bill-drafting session next week, as has been anticipated, he replied, ''Ask me at 2 P.M. tomorrow,'' He apparently meant after the meeting tomorrow. **********''I hope we can fashion a program that can be enjoyed by all Democrats on the floor of the House,'' Mr. Rostenkowski said. In reply to a question, he added that ''we're talking of the possibility of a multiyear bill.'' Later, he acknowledged that he meant a two-year bill. **********In light of the failure of the Democratic leadership and President Reagan to come to terms on taxes at the White House meeting yesterday, the next move was thought to be Mr. Rostenkowski's. O'Neill Accused by Dole **********''The next move must be theirs,'' said Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, after a meeting of Congressional Republican leaders with Mr. Reagan. Mr. Dole accused the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, of being ''so out of touch that he doesn't want the American people to have tax cuts.'' **********Mr. O'Neill in turn called the Administration's three-year tax relief proposal ''a lemon from the beginning.'' He said that ''we Democrats want to make sure that our people, people who make moderate incomes, get the tax relief they need.'' **********An aide to the Speaker, clarifying a report of yesterday's White House meeting, said Mr. O'Neill told the President that ''he hoped'' Congress would pass a tax bill by Aug. 1 and that ''the House would do its part.'' A Republican at the meeting had reported that Mr.  O'Neill assured Mr. Reagan of passage by Aug. 1. **********One of the conservative Democrats who met with Mr. Rostenkowski for breakfast this morning, Representative John B. Breaux of Louisiana, said later that there was ''agreement on recommending a strong Democratic tax package.'' Mr. Breaux, a member of the Conservative Democratic Forum, said of the members, ''Most are hanging loose and are not committed.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/12/busin.print_headline: INVENTOR; TRYING AGAIN IN CONSUMER ELECTRONICS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/12/busin.body_text: **********LONDON The British, it is said, are great at designing a product but awful at exploiting it. In earlier eras, for example, much of the original work on the jet engine, the computer, radar and the early work on semiconductors was done in Britain. But the money on them was made elsewhere. **********Clive Sinclair seems living proof that the axiom holds true today.  In 1972, his Sinclair Radionics came out with the Executive, in a neck-and-neck race with Texas Instruments to market the world's first hand-held calculator. The Government poured millions into the venture. But it was swept away by a tide of cheaper, more sophisticated American and Japanese models. An economic artifact, the calculator now sits in the design gallery of New York's Museum of Modern Art. **********''The message has come through loud and clear that Sinclair is a good designer, but he is no good at running a business,'' said Richard Harwood, a financial analyst with the London-based brokerage firm Scott, Goff, Hancock & Company. **********That may be rather too hasty a judgment. Mr. Sinclair is back, as head of Sinclair Research, maker of a highly successful line of microcomputers -and now he has what he hopes will be truly a first.  It's pocket-sized television, a 6-by-4-by-1-inch black-and-white model that weighs only a few ounces. Again, he has Government support. And this time, Mr. Sinclair vows he is not going to repeat past mistakes. ''We aim to be first in the market - and stay in the market,'' he said. **********To get around production problems that have plagued other projects, Mr. Sinclair has contracted with Timex to produce both the minitelevisions and advanced microcomputers at the big watchmaker's Dundee, Scotland, plant. Marketing is expected to begin by the middle of next year. To avoid getting caught in the price trap again, he plans to sell the mini-televisions for just $100 or so. (An earlier model, announced in 1977, would have cost about $300.) Offices to direct promotion and sales (all mail order) have been opened in Boston, Munich and Paris. **********Mr. Sinclair, the son of a small London businessman who now works for him, quit school at the age of 17 to engage in several entrepreneurial fits and starts - running a small publishing company, making transistor radio kits and writing for a technical magazine. He set up Sinclair Radionics when he was 22, to assemble components for transistor radios and hi-fi's. **********Now 40, he firmly believes he will join the ranks of inventorsturned-entrepreneurs - like Edwin Land, inventor of the Polaroid instant camera -who prove capable of surviving in a world of high technology dominated by multinational companies with million-dollar research budgets. **********First, however, he must put behind him a track record that has won him a lot of critics.  Part of the problem is his own personality. Soon after introducing his hand-held calculator in 1972, for example, (the Executive cost the equivalent of $174 in 1972 and only performed five basic arithmetic functions) Mr. Sinclair began design work on his pet project, the pocket television, while at the same time throwing his small company behind the Black Watch, a digital wrist watch. **********''Clive gets ideas so fast that sometimes he does the last thing he thinks up before he finishes with the first,'' explained one electronics expert who has watched Mr. Sinclair's roller-coaster career. **********''Clive is not particularly prepared to listen to other people's ideas,'' added a former colleague, Christopher Curry, who has gone on his own to start the micro-computer company, Acorn. ''He is, in a word, irascible.'' **********Production of the Black Watch was held up for 18 important months because of problems with the supply of components. It finally began in 1975, but quietly died without a recouping of the initial investment. **********Sinclair Radionics had never become truly large - the company had sales of some $20 million in its best year - and by l976, Mr.  Sinclair was forced to seek outside financing in order to continue work on the pocket television. **********He turned first to the City, London's financial community, but he found no takers. So the National Enterprise Board, a Governmentfinanced organization designed to provide financing for high-risk ventures, bailed out the failing company. **********But Mr. Sinclair's highly individual style did not mix well with state capitalism. In 1979, Mr. Sinclair left, with a $22,000 ''golden handshake,'' his design team, and his ideas. The N.E.B. wrote off the venture as a $17 million loss. The financial community watched, with a note of self-congratulation. **********However, Mr. Sinclair promptly sold his house and his car (a collector's Rolls-Royce), set up Sinclair Research and began production of the ZX8O, an inexpensive, $199.95 microcomputer. He also managed to continue the Government connection with a $1 million grant from the state-controlled National Research and Development Corporation for development of the pocket television, in return for an undisclosed royalty. **********The lesson from the calculator battle did not go unheeded: ''We want to remain cheap enough to discourage Oriental competition,'' said Mr. Sinclair. ''There is, of course, always the problem in consumer electronics of being overtaken by cheaper products -we are making every effort to update our products.'' **********With that in mind, Sinclair recently announced the ZX81 (with four microchips compared with 22 in the earlier model) to go into production at Dundee this spring and be priced at retail for about $120. The newer model can also be hooked into a printer, for an additional $112. **********Mr. Sinclair is now producing 10,000 ZX80's a month, which puts him third in volume of personal computers, behind Apple and Tandy Radio Shack. **********His models, which rely on conventional television sets for their screens and cassette recorders to store the programs, are slower, have less memory, can handle far fewer commands and do less complex calculations than those of Apple and Tandy. That difference is, of course, reflected in price. A basic Apple model runs to more than $1,500. **********Mr. Sinclair is aiming at the novice who wants to learn his way around a computer rather than the small-business executive who wants storage and information processing capacity. **********''The Sinclair model has gadget appeal,'' said Gavin Embry, an electronics consultant. ''I have two, one to play with and one to take apart to see how it works.'' **********More than 50,000 ZX80's were sold in the first nine months of last year, more than half of them abroad, bringing the company $1.8 million in profits on $7 million in revenues. Mr. Sinclair says that he will soon be selling more units than either Apple or Tandy. **********And, typically, he has his eye on bigger things even than pocket television. ''We have already started a detailed design of an electric car,'' said Mr. Sinclair. ''Yes, I realize that General Motors is working on the same thing, but I'm not particularly nervous about that - and I'm sure that they are not very nervous about me, either. It's a case of mutual lack of nervousness.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/12/busin.body_text: **********Seagram Company Ltd.'s operating results set records for the threemonth and nine-month periods ended April 30, the company reported yesterday. Net income for the three months totaled $72.4 million, or $2.07 a share, up 37.9 percent from $52.5 million, or $1.49, in the 1980 quarter. For the nine months, net income was $1.4 billion, or $40.71 a share, due to extraordinary gains, against $113.3 million, or $3.23, in the like year-ago period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Chrysler Makes Payment on Loan
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation said it had made a $71 million payment due to its bankers as the first installment in a plan to retire $650 million in debt. **********Chrysler officials said the company's cash flow in recent weeks had been more than adequate to make the initial payment because of improvements in vehicle sales. **********Under terms of its latest restructuring, Chrysler agreed to retire its $650 million in debt at 30 cents on the dollar in four installments. The auto maker must make additional payments of $23.8 million on Sept. 10, $47.6 million on Dec. 31 and $47.6 million next March 12.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/11/world.main_headline: NO PLAN TO INTERVENE IN EL SALVADOR, REAGAN SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/11/world.print_headline: NO PLAN TO INTERVENE IN EL SALVADOR, REAGAN SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/11/world.body_text: **********President Reagan said today that his Administration had no plans to send troops to El Salvador, although he acknowledged that the effort by the United States-backed Government there to defeat leftist insurgents may have reached a stalemate. **********At a news conference today, Mr. Reagan also reaffirmed his view that there was a ''possibility'' that the use of tactical nuclear weapons in Western Europe would not lead to an all-out nuclear war.  His earlier statement had brought criticism from anti-nuclear and pacifist groups in Western Europe. He also expressed confidence in Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and denounced news reports depicting ''chaos and disarray'' in Administration foreign policy as a disservice to the nation. **********The President may have provided new fuel for the controversy by appearing to suggest today that he was ''optimistic'' that such battlefield nuclear weapons could be used in Europe without leading to full-scale nuclear war between the United States and the Soviet Union. **********Mr. Reagan, under close questioning about his views on nuclear arms, added that he had not been able to find out if the North Atlantic Treaty Organization had an optional battle plan calling for explosion of a nuclear device in a remote area of Europe as a ''warning shot'' to deter Soviet aggression. Reagan Criticizes News Accounts **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger have made conflicting statements about such a ''warning shot.'' While he did not clarify that issue, Mr. Reagan again criticized news accounts of disputes among his foreign policy advisers, saying ''the picture that has been given of chaos and disarray is a disservice to the country and to other countries and allies as well.'' **********''There is no animus, personal animus, and there is no bickering or back-stabbing going on,'' Mr. Reagan said when asked about the events of last week. ''We're a happy group.'' These included, in addition to the Haig-Weinberger dispute, a meeting at which the President ordered Mr. Haig and Richard V. Allen, the White House national security adviser, to end their policy disputes and personal feuding. **********''Well, I called them in, actually, to find out and to urge that they, with their staffs, just as I have with my own, insure that we're a little more careful,'' Mr. Reagan said, condemning ''loose talk'' of conflict that has ''been exaggerated out of all reality.'' He added, ''We are not in disarray with regard to foreign policy.'' 'Our Goal Is Peace' **********In his remarks on El Salvador, however, Mr. Reagan backed away from a reported effort by Mr. Haig to get the Pentagon to develop contingency plans for military action there. ''We have no plans for putting Americans in combat any place in the world and our goal is peace,'' Mr. Reagan said. **********Mr. Reagan sided with Mr. Haig in asserting that ''there may be something of a stalemate'' in El Salvador. That country's president, Jose Napoleon Duarte, yesterday protested this characterization of his Government's conflict with leftist guerrillas. He said Washington still hopes for a settlement based on free elections with all parties participating. **********On the issue of tactical nuclear weapons in Europe, Mr. Reagan first asserted that his initial comments on that issue on Oct. 6 had been misrepresented in ''second-hand'' accounts. He sought to avoid discussion of the issue by saying reporters should check the transcript of the Oct. 6 remarks. A few minutes later, a CBS News reporter produced a transcript of those remarks. At this point, Mr.  Reagan acknowledged that he had said it was possible that there could be a limited nuclear exchange in Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/25/world.print_headline: IN MOSCOW SUMMIT PLAN IS VIEWED AS HOPEFUL...; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/25/world.body_text: **********One of the Soviet leadership's biggest complaints about Jimmy Carter was that he did not understand the uses of secrecy. Diplomatic initiatives, the men in the Kremlin used to say, cannot begin in public; they must be carefully explored in private beforehand. **********Now, to the consternation and confusion of Kremlin-watchers here, Leonid I. Brezhnev has done just what he accused Mr. Carter of doing. Apparently without warning to Washington or other Western capitals, he appealed yesterday for ''an active dialogue, at all levels,'' with the United States, including a meeting with President Reagan. **********He did it, moreover, on a great state occasion, in the keynote report that a Soviet leader presents only once every five years to the congress of the Communist Party. The setting gave his words added weight. He coupled his appeal with a series of proposals - some new, some old, some refurbished - that he said would help to relax EastWest tensions. Treaty Renegotiation Offered **********The most important of these, couched in murky terms but apparently intended as a distinct concession, is renegotiation of the second treaty on limitation of strategic nuclear arms. **********Mr. Brezhnev gave his speech a conciliatory tone, with few echoes of the polemics that have issued from Washington and Moscow alike in the last few weeks. He chose, for example, to make no riposte to Mr.  Reagan's rather sharp attack on the morality of the Soviet leadership. **********Instead, he seemed to be trying to picture himself and his colleagues in the ruling Politburo as seasoned politicians -which they no doubt are, with an average age of 68 - who understand the need for patience, restraint and, ultimately, communication rather than confrontation with the other superpower. **********It is easy enough to dismiss Mr. Brezhnev's effort as propaganda, and some Western diplomats immediately did so, arguing that nothing meant anything until the Soviet Union showed that it was ready to pull out of Afghanistan. One of them said, ''Russians don't float serious ideas at the United Nations or at Communist Party congresses.'' An Exception to the Rule Seen **********But there is persuasive evidence that yesterday's speech was the exception to the rule, that Mr. Brezhnev was in earnest about dialogue, and that he had good political reasons for being so. **********In little more than a year, the ailing leader has seen the Afghanistan move and Western worries about possible Soviet military intervention in Poland bring his policy of detente - the centerpiece of his career, by which he has said he wants to be remembered - to the very edge of extinction. **********Even Western Europeans, who clung to detente long after it fell from favor in the United States, have been expressing doubts. One more misstep, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany is said to have told Mr. Brezhnev, and that would be it for detente. **********What the 74-year-old Soviet leader told the party congress was designed, in part, to repair his relations with Bonn and Paris.  Slight but potentially significant changes in policy on Afghanistan and on the deployment of nuclear weapons in Europe seemed tailor-made to catch the eye of politicians like Mr. Schmidt. Statement Welcomed by European **********As one Western European diplomat said, ''I suppose they think they can reopen a gap between us and the Americans, but it is still a very welcome statement from our viewpoint.'' **********The speech was also a response to domestic imperatives. This is the year, in the prediction of Nikita S. Khrushchev, when the standard of living in the Soviet Union would surpass that in the West. Nothing of the sort has happened; food supplies are worse than they were three years ago, and the range and quality of consumer goods have improved little. Public grumbling is discreet but audible. **********Rectifying the situation will be difficult at best, given the rigidity of the bureaucracy. But it would seem impossible if the Kremlin felt compelled to undertake yet another armaments program. It is in this context that the bellicosity of some statements in Washington has caused distress here and has made the achievement of a new nuclear arms limitation treaty seem even more important. **********''They won't go broke without a new SALT treaty,'' a Communist from the third world said today, ''but they won't be able to deliver what they feel they must deliver to the average Soviet citizen.'' **********Mr. Brezhnev himself, in commenting on the economic problems of the Soviet Union and its allies, said yesterday: ''Our countries are having to deal with their constructive tasks in more complicated conditions. The deterioration of the world economy and spiraling prices are making themselves felt. The slowing of the detente process and the arms race imposed by the imperialist powers are no small burden for us as well.'' A Moment of Unusual Candor **********It was a moment of candor. Mr. Brezhnev must also have been aware that many party members, including lower-level officials, have been anxious about the acrimony between Washington and Moscow since Mr.  Reagan took office. Even to Western friends, such people have begun to express worry that perhaps the two countries are drifting toward war. Things seem to them to be getting out of control. **********In a sense then, Mr. Brezhnev appears to have spoken from a position of strategic weakness and vulnerability. But he also spoke from a position of formidable military strength; he could have chosen the occasion for a display of bluster. **********It was the emphasis on dialogue that caught the attention of diplomats here and politicians in the West and prompted them to take the speech more seriously than they took, for example, Mr. Brezhnev's proposals on the Persian Gulf in a speech in New Delhi last year. **********The summit proposal may have been primarily a device to dramatize the broader idea. If that is what it was, it has already fulfilled its purpose.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/09/world.main_headline: U.N. PANEL SURVEYS ISRAELI ATOM SKILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/09/world.print_headline: U.N. PANEL SURVEYS ISRAELI ATOM SKILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/09/world.body_text: **********An international panel selected by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has concluded that Israel can make nuclear weapons ''within a very short time.'' But it says that a policy of ''deliberate ambiguity'' makes it impossible to determine whether Israel actually possesses bombs. **********The panel, named in response to a General Assembly resolution adopted in 1979, calculates that ''Israel may already have enough weapons-grade material for making several bombs comparable to the bomb dropped on Nagasaki'' in 1945. The panel estimates that Israel's Dimona reactor, which is not subject to international inspection, could have produced enough weapons-grade plutonium for 10 to 15 nuclear weapons. **********The panel urges Israel to renounce the making of bombs and to let the International Atomic Energy Agency inspect its nuclear plants.  These statements are in a draft report written May 12, before Israel bombed and wrecked an Iraqi nuclear reactor. The experts are now amending their document to take account of the attack. American Critical of Israel **********The panel consists of four political scientists - one each from the United States, the Soviet Union, India and Kenya - and a nuclear physicist from Lebanon. **********The American member, George Quester, chairman of Cornell's government department, has proposed that Israel be accused of practicing a ''double standard'' under which it demands assurance that its neighbors are not making bombs but refuses to give such assurance itself. Israel's official position has been that it will not be the first nation to introduce nuclear weapons into the Middle East. **********Mr. Quester's amendment asserts that the attack ''will be seen as Israeli hypocrisy if it is not followed now by a full Israeli acceptance of international safeguards.'' Dayan Made Similar Comment **********Those involved in writing the revised report predict, however, that Mr. Quester's language will be toned down.  The other panel members are Ashok Kapur, an Indian political scientist at the University of Waterloo in Canada; Mark A. Khrustalev of the Moscow State Institute of International Relations; Ali A.  Mazrui, a Kenyan who directs the Center for Afro-American and African Studies at the University of Michigan, and Assaad Saab, the Lebanese physicist. **********The final report is to be released next month. It will bear, one official said, both a ''blessing and a disavowal'' by Mr. Waldheim, who will say he is not equipped to judge the judges. **********The document's principal finding is not new. In June, former Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said that Israel could make a nuclear bomb ''in a short time'' but did not yet have one.
