https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/19/world.main_headline: MADRID TALKS ADJOURN WITH WRANGLING OVER POLAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/19/world.print_headline: MADRID TALKS ADJOURN WITH WRANGLING OVER POLAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/19/world.body_text: **********In its last session before adjourning for two months, the Madrid conference on detente and human rights today broke out in sharp exchanges over Poland. **********The United States and other Western nations called the imposition of martial law in Poland a violation of the 1975 Helsinki agreements that have been under review here for more than a year. **********''Poland has been a living demonstration for the world of the vitality of the process launched at Helsinki which is embodied at this meeting today,'' said Max M. Kampelman, the head of the American delegation. **********''Our regret at recent developments is, therefore, a profound one,'' Mr. Kampelman said. ''Arbitrary detentions; interference with the free flow of information, ideas and people; the wholesale repression of civil liberties; the imposition of military control at the workplace; the use of violence against Polish workers, and the attempt to stifle and possibly destroy Solidarity, the legitimate expression of the yearning of Polish working men and women for dignity - all these represent gross violations of the Final Act.'' Talks Are Deadlocked **********The American delegate warned that any reversal of the Polish people's progress ''toward a more open and just society'' would ''inevitably damage'' the one-year-old negotiations in Madrid to broaden the Helsinki agreements. **********Deadlocked in the talks, the 33 European nations, Canada and the United States agreed today to reconvene in Madrid on Feb. 9 for one more month of work. **********Other Western nations joined in the criticism of the military crackdown in Poland. ''France now issues an appeal that the Polish trade unionists be freed and that civil liberties be restored,'' said Guy de Commines, the French delegate, who expressed the hope that ''the democratic conquests of the last months'' would be preserved. **********Talking to reporters, John Wilberforce, the British delegate who had spoken in the negotiating session on behalf of the 10 nations of the European Common Market, suggested that if the Soviet Union intervened in Poland, it would threaten the structure of the Helsinki accords, which Moscow has regarded as ratifying the post-World War II balance of power in Europe. **********''I think that one can conceive of some circumstances in which this conference would not continue at all,'' Mr. Wilberforce said. More Sorrow Than Anger **********There was an more-in-sorrow-than-anger quality to Western criticisms of the actions taken in Poland by Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski, who is widely regarded as being under heavy Soviet pressure. **********Wlodzimierz Konarski, the Polish delegate, attempted to turn this sympathy to his country's advantage by appealing for economic aid from nations that today criticized Warsaw. **********''There is no need to say that what is going on in Poland now is first of all a painful experience for all of us - that means all Poles,'' he said. ''What Poland needs most at this very moment is neither good advice nor an international debate on its problems, but understanding and economic assistance.'' **********In the closed-door session, Leonid F. Ilyichev, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, repeated the Polish argument that the crackdown was an internal matter that should not be discussed at the Madrid talks. Mr. Ilyichev maintained that the Polish crisis had been ''fanned by the Western media.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday.  Although the consensus forecast is for lower interest rates in the next few weeks, dealers said yesterday's move to lower prices and higher yields was not too surprising since it followed a week when prices rose rapidly. **********''It was a classic pattern we've seen many times,'' one Government securities dealer said, in which the market rallies after the money supply numbers come out on Friday and then subsequently retreats. **********Other market participants observed that the decline in prices started in the morning when some investors and traders decided to sell notes and bonds to lock in profits from the rally of the last two weeks. **********Retail Sales a Disappointment **********The market continued to fall in light afternoon activity as some traders were disappointed at the strength of retail sales in September, which rose four-tenths of 1 percent rather than falling as expected. Even though most of the gain resulted from car sales, analysts said the stronger-than-expected number was another sign of the economy's resilience in the face of high interest rates. **********Analysts reason that, if the economy remains strong enough to avoid a recession, business credit demands and interest rates will be higher than they would be if there were a recession. **********News that several large banks reduced their prime rate to 18 percent had little effect in the credit markets, since changes in the prime rate usually lag behind changes in other short-term interest rates. Banks were paying about 15 percent for new three-month certificates of deposit yesterday, down from 17 3/4 percent in the first week of September and 17 percent in the week ended Sept. 16. Last Thursday, the three-month certificate was at about 15 1/2 percent. **********Among other short-term instruments, three- and six-month Treasury bill rates rose to 13.56 percent and 13.65 percent, respectively, or about three-eighths of a percentage point higher than the late Friday levels. **********Among actively traded long-term issues, the 16 percent Treasury notes due in two years were offered at 101 5/ 32 to yield 15.52 percent, and the 13 7/8 percent bonds due in 2011 were offered at 96 1/2 to yield 14.38 percent. Late Friday, the 30-year bond was offered at 98 1/2, compared with 95 1/8 last Tuesday and 91 7/8 on Tuesday, Sept. 29. **********In the tax-exempt market, underwriters announced tentative yields for a variety of issues with maturities ranging from 30 years to one month. Georgia Power Bonds Priced **********About $50 million of 30-year pollution control revenue bonds of the Georgia Power Company were tentatively priced by a First Boston Corporation group at par with a 14 percent coupon. Later this week, Georgia Power plans to sell $120 million of 30-year first mortgage bonds, an issue that is certain to carry a far higher interest rate than the tax-exempt bonds. Outstanding 30-year Baa-rated electric utility bonds have been trading with yields in the vicinity of 18 3/4 percent. **********Among other upcoming tax-exempt issues, a $120 million issue of coal terminal revenue bonds due in 1984 of the Peninsula Port Authority of Virginia was tentatively priced at par with a 10 1/4 percent coupon by a First Boston Corporation group. The three-year bonds are triple-A-rated with the backing of a letter of credit issued by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. Besides the bank letter of credit, the bonds are backed by agreements with the A.T. Massey Coal Company, a subsidiary of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation. **********In the short end of the tax-exempt market, underwriters led by Citibank announced tentative prices for a $400 million issue of Washington State's flexible-rate certificates of indebtedness.  Investors may buy notes with maturities ranging from one to 12 months, at yields ranging from 8.1 percent for one month to 9 percent for six months and 9 1/4 percent for eight through 12 months. **********For notes due in less than 12 months, the investor has the option at maturity of being repaid at par or rolling over the notes into a remaining maturity. Moody's Investors Service recently downgraded the state's bonds to A-1 from Aa, but it left the note rating unchanged at the highest MIG-1 level.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/04/world.main_headline: BLACK UNION ENDS STRIKE AT SOUTH AFRICAN AUTO PLANTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/04/world.print_headline: BLACK UNION ENDS STRIKE AT SOUTH AFRICAN AUTO PLANTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/04/world.body_text: **********One of the newest and most assertive black labor unions decided today to end a two-week strike against the two largest American companies in South Africa, Ford and General Motors. The union had called the strikes with the unusual aim of getting the two companies to put pressure on a third, Firestone, to take back some dismissed employees. **********The solidarity strike began when two black workers at Ford's factory here were suspended for refusing to fit Firestone tires on a new car. It ended after Ford and General Motors rejected a demand from the union, the Motor Assemblies and Components Workers Union, that they hire some of the 160 men who lost their jobs four months ago after a wildcat walkout at Firestone. **********Late this afternoon, at a mass meeting attended by about 2,500 strikers, it was decided to accept Firestone's latest offer and return to work at all three companies on Monday, even though the offer fell far short of the union's demands. **********Although the effectiveness of the sympathy strike tactic had obviously been slight, it demonstrated the characteristics of this union that make it different from most of the longer-established black unions. These are its refusal to play by the intricate rules of the South African system of labor relations and its insistence on its right to act on behalf of the entire black community. **********When the pensions issue arose, it caught both the union, which had no standing at all at Firestone when the dispute began, and the management off guard. What triggered it was a proposed change in the pension law, which would have made it impossible for workers to draw out any of their pension funds before retirement. **********Mistrusting the Government and not wanting to lose access to the money they had put into the funds, the black workers demanded that it be paid out to them immediately. Firestone obtained a promise from the Government to exempt its workers from the proposed law, but this also was not trusted. **********Finally, after agreeing to pay back the workers' pension contributions the company demanded that they return to work. The workers said they would wait until the cash was in their hands, so Firestone tried a tactic that has been commonplace in South Africa in the year and a half since full trade union rights were extended to blacks - mass dismissals. **********Firestone set a date on which it said it would start hiring. By the time the workers had their pension money and were ready to return in early February, 160 places had been filled. It was then that the Motor Assemblies and Components Workers Union came on the scene on behalf, it said, not of its members but of the community of which they were a part. **********The union asked Ford and General Motors to stop using Firestone tires. They refused, so black workers struck at all three plants.  Under the offer the union accepted today, Firestone will take back 21 older workers who, the union charged, were dismissed because of their age. Others will be taken back as vacancies occur, while those who the company says have bad work records will become a subject for negotiation with the union. **********The most far-reaching effect of the strike is to harden the division of organized labor here into separate black, mixed-race and white unions at just the time when non-racial unionism is becoming legal in South Africa. Fred Sauls, leader of a multiracial union that was spurned by the blacks at Firestone, deplored the division of the work force on what he called a ''racialistic basis.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/16/world.body_text: **********Nazli Ilicak, a top editorial writer for the right-wing Turkish daily newspaper Tercuman, was convicted of criticizing a court's rulings and was sentenced to nine months in prison, the newspaper reported today. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/01/busin.main_headline: SAVINGS UNITS, CONFUSED, WAIT FOR I.R.S. MOVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/01/busin.print_headline: SAVINGS UNITS, CONFUSED, WAIT FOR I.R.S. MOVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/01/busin.body_text: **********Banks and savings and loan associations across the country reacted in confusion yesterday to an Internal Revenue Service warning about their high-interest ''bonus'' programs aimed at lining up deposits for the new ''All Savers'' certificates. **********In a survey, many savings and loan associations said they were shelving the packages while they awaited a final I.R.S. ruling, expected this week. Other savings institutions and commercial banks said they were revising their pro- **********Chase Manhattan and First National of Chicago cut their prime rates half a point, to 20 percent. Page D1. grams in an attempt to meet what they believed were the IRS objections. **********The I.R.S. warning was that the tax-free status of the new ''All Savers'' certificates might be withdrawn for those sold in advance through the special high-interest programs. The agency said that the programs might distort the tax relief intended by Congress. Money Certificates Freed **********In another development, Federal regulators announced in Washington that holders of the popular six-month money market certificates, in denominations of $10,000 or more, could convert these funds into ''All Savers'' certificates after Oct. 1 without penalties for early withdrawals. (Page D19.) **********Most of the high interest rate packages, which the industry began to offer two weeks ago, promise customers interest rates now as as high as 40 percent on an annual basis until Oct. 1 on the condition that the money then be transferred to the one-year certificates. **********Some savings and loan associations had not required an automatic transfer into the new savings certificate. They said yesterday that they had dropped their advertising but would continue to sell the packages. **********Banks and savings and loans devised the ''All Savers'' repurchase programs to get a head start in the competition for the $250 billion that the new savings certificates are expected to attract when they become available Oct. 1. **********The higher the interest rate in the repurchase agreement for the weeks preceding Oct. 1, the higher the overall return would be on the final yield of the savings certificate if the two are treated as one package. **********The Chase Manhattan Bank, which was the first to suspend its tiein package on Sunday, said that on Wednesday it would begin to offer a similiar package that it believed would protect the consumer and get the approval of the I.R.S. **********Fred Hammer, executive vice president of Chase, said that the bank would offer its customers a repurchase agreement at a 15 percent interest rate, which is the market rate, instead of the 40 percent interest rate it had offered last week. The repurchase agreement, essentially a customer loan to the bank, will mature at the end of September and the customer can then decide to either withdraw the funds or deposit them in an ''All Savers'' certificate. **********''If the I.R.S. rules that we can offer the higher interest rate then we will rewrite the agreements,'' Mr. Hammer added. Sold at Varying Rates **********Repurchase agreements are regularly sold by banks at varying interest rates to raise money. These rates usually are in line with prevailing market rates, but never as high as the interest rates that have been offered in recent weeks in the competition to attract funds for the ''All Savers'' certificates. The repurchase agreements are generally sold in large denominations and have a longer maturity period. **********Ellen Murphy of the I.R.S. said that each package would have to be considered individually, but that the agency seemed to have the most problems with tie-in packages that required the customer to buy a savings certificate. She would not say for certain, however, that packages that did not require an automatic tie-in, such as the Chase plan, would be allowed. **********There was uncertainty yesterday as to what might happen to customers who had already signed up for one of the tie-in packages that have been offered nationwide. Most banks, however, expressed confidence that the repurchase accounts already signed up for would be permitted. The total invested so far nationwide is not known. **********The I.R.S. questions on the tie-in accounts seemed to be focused on whether they violate the intent of the new tax law. The statute stipulates that the savings certificates be issued after Sept. 30 and that the interest rate paid on the savings certificates be equal to 70 percent of the average investment yield on one-year Treasury bills. Increase Yield and Time **********Since the tie-in packages begin before Oct. 1 and for a short period of time offer higher annnual interest rates, they would increase both the yield and the effective time period of the savings certificate. **********The savings certificate program, which is part of the Reagan Administrations tax relief program, will permit individuals to earn up to $1,000 interest tax-free and married couples up to $2,000. Most tax experts believe that the certificates make the most sense for a person above the 30 percent tax bracket. **********'At this point you can't get a straight answer from anyone,'' said Raymond O'Brien, chairman of the Emigrant Savings Bank in New York .  ''The I.R.S. should have had the regulations out long before this.'' **********He added that although Emigrant would drop its advertising drive, it would continue to sell the repurchase agreements. ''We don't think the I.R.S. will have a problem with the packages that don't have a forced tie-in,'' he said. Dime to Discontinue Ads **********The Dime Savings Bank, which does not have an automatic tie-in, will also continue to sell the agreements but will discontinue its ads until the I.R.S. issues a ruling. **********''We pulled the ads and won't sell the packages again until after the I.R.S. makes its rulings,'' W. Barton Cummings, senior vice president of the Dry Dock Savings Bank, said. ''I seriously don't think that the I.R.S. can take the tax-exempt status away from the accounts that have already been opened.'' **********The Dollar Federal Savings and Loan Association and the Lincoln Savings Bank have also suspended their programs.  The American Savings and Loan Association in California plans to continue to offer its tie-in packges, which promise the depositor a 20 percent interest rate between now and Oct. l. If the account is not transferred to a savings certifcate the customer would only receive a 17 percent interest rate. **********''Until they come out with a ruling we are going to assume that the packages will be allowed,'' said Charles Dorsey of American Savings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/02/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Niagara Share's Foreign Focus
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/02/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Niagara Share's Foreign Focus
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/02/busin.body_text: **********THE Wing Lung Bank Ltd. and Sime Darby Holdings Ltd. are not exactly household names even to institutional investors, but these stocks are among the holdings of the Niagara Share Corporation. The Wing Lung Bank, as it turns out, is a major bank in Hong Kong, while Sime Darby Holdings operates plantations and conducts diversified trading activities in Malaysia. **********As for Niagara Share, it is a closed-end investment company listed on the New York Stock Exchange. Closed-end companies maintain a constant number of outstanding shares, in contrast to open-end investment companies - commonly known as mutual funds - that do not have a fixed number of shares. **********''Even some of our foreign stocks are unfamiliar to most foreign investors,'' said Robert J.A. Irwin, president of Niagara Share, in an interview. ''We are prepared to go outside the United States and Canada in search of investment opportunities. **********''These overseas investments aggregated almost $40 million, or 20 percent of our total assets of $189 million, at the end of 1980. Our portfolio includes companies in Mexico and South Africa, as well as in the Pacific Basin markets of Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore, Malaysia and Australia. We de-emphasized investment in European companies in 1977.'' **********Niagara Share, which began picking up foreign stocks in 1958, usually maintains a fully invested position in the market. The stated objective of its domestic and foreign securities portfolio is to invest in companies that, in the opinion of its management, have prospects of superior long-term appreciation. **********The stock of Niagara Share itself has displayed superior gains in recent years. It sold last November at a record price of 26, after trading as low as 9 5/8 in early 1979. Yesterday, the stock closed at 22 1/8, up 1/8. **********''Niagara Share's portfolio outperformed all the other diversified common stock funds we followed last year,'' the Value Line Investment Survey reported in a current appraisal of the closed-end fund industry. ''These good results were in large part due to the natural resource and electronics portions of the portfolio.'' **********Value Line offered these additional comments: ''Niagara Share uses interesting investment strategies. Though its holdings are scattered among about 20 industry classifications, the fund tends to bunch up much of its assets in certain areas. Right now, for example, resource stocks outweigh technology and general industry categories, and there are no holdings in retailing issues.'' **********In 1980, the net asset value per share at Niagara Share rose 42.5 percent. This compared with a gain of 31.6 percent for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. **********Several other closed-end funds, including the Madison Fund and General American Investors, have performed well relative to the broad market and to the rate of inflation. Typically, a fund with a good record tends to sell closer to its net asset value per share, while laggards in the group often sell at a discount on the Big Board. **********However, in periods of sharply depressed stock prices, some investors purchase shares of closed-end companies trading at substantial discounts, hoping that these diversified portfolios will benefit by a market rebound. **********Meanwhile, it must be emphasized that favorable past performance offers no guarantee of future results for a closed-end investment company. **********Nevertheless, Value Line stated that the ''internationalization of Niagara Share's portfolio will help its performance over the long pull, while the portfolio also will benefit from the heavy flow of Mideast oil money into foreign stock markets.'' **********For the next 12 months, the investment advisory service has rated Niagara Share as an average performer in terms of the overall market. **********Some of the fund's other foreign holdings at the end of the year included Genting Bhd. (the Malaysian equivalent of Inc.), a property developer and hotel operator in Malaysia; Sasol Ltd., a South African producer of synthetic fuels; Renison Ltd., a producer of high-grade tin in Australia, and G.T. Japan Small Companies Fund, an investment company based in Japan. **********But for all its interest in foreign securities, Niagara Share has not forsaken the domestic stock market. Its 10 largest holdings at the end of the year, in fact, are issues trading either on the Big Board, the American Stock Exchange or in the over-the-counter market. **********In order of market value, these holdings consisted of: Schlumberger, Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals, Superior Oil, the Norton Company, Great Lakes Chemical, the SmithKline Corporation, the American International Group, Flightsafety International, the Raychem Corporation and Smith International. **********Meanwhile, Mr. Irwin noted, the fund holds one distinction. It is the only Big Board-listed company that is based in Buffalo.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/world.main_headline: Indian Express Closes Its Bombay Edition
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Indian Express Closes Its Bombay Edition
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/world.body_text: **********The Indian Express, the country's largest English-language newspaper, announced today that it was closing its edition in Bombay and seven allied publications. It blamed political pressure and labor and financial troubles, **********The announcement by Saroj Goenka, a director of The Express, followed a campaign by the newspaper in which it accused A.R.  Antulay, chief minister of Maharashtra State, of corruption. **********The state's capital is Bombay. **********Mr. Antulay, a member of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party, has criticized articles in The Express about his money-raising activities for five ostensibly charitable trusts. **********In a statement announcing the closing of the newspaper, Mrs. Goenka said the company's stand on issues such as corruption in public life made it ''a direct target of the machinations of politicians.'' **********''Over the last month and a half, an active conspiracy of outsiders instigated workers to indulge in acts that have made it impossible for us to continue operations,'' she said. **********The newspaper is published in 10 Indian cities and has a total circulation of 675,000. The Bombay edition's circulation was about 160,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/21/busin.body_text: **********More homes are watching weekend television than ever before, according a study by the Television Bureau of Advertising. In the last five years, the study found, weekend viewing in every time period was up by at least 10 percent, with a 27 percent increase in Sunday morning viewing and 21 percent increase in Saturday afternoon. **********The study also found that men and working women watch more television on weekends - approximately four hours on the average Saturday or Sunday - than either group watches on weekdays.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/world.main_headline: FOR A LAOTIAN, FRUSTRATION AND ESCAPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/world.print_headline: FOR A LAOTIAN, FRUSTRATION AND ESCAPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/world.body_text: **********In June 1975, when the Laotian Communists were sweeping aside the coalition Government and taking over the country, a senior, nonpolitical official explained to an American friend why he would not join the mounting tide of people fleeing to Thailand across the Mekong River. **********Six years later, in this city, his tone as calm and as sad as it was then, the former official resumed that conversation, to explain why he was here, after swimming across the Mekong. He had spent the intervening years in rigorous and remote mountain camps, ostensibly to be reeducated for service to the new Laos, and five months in Vientiane realizing that his services were not wanted. **********Still not angry, still uncomplaining, the French-educated official, now 51 years old, consented to have his story told only if his name was withheld. He explained that he did not want his escape to be depicted and politically exploited as an act of opposition. **********Recalling the earlier conversation, the soft-spoken Laotian said he had stayed when many of his friends fled because he believed that Laos, under whatever government, would need the services of those who had been trained in the skills needed to develop a country without industry or roads that are passable throughout the year. He Expected to Be Mistrusted **********He said then that he knew he would have to pay a price for his decision. As a member of the ''wrong'' social class, married to a Frenchwoman, he expected to be mistrusted and to have to prove his good faith before being allowed to contribute fully to the development of Laos. **********But he said that as leader of a small movement of intellectuals who had fought against the corruption of the old regime and the excessive power of certain generals, he would betray his previous stand if he left with the onset of the Communist regime. **********A few weeks after the 1975 conversation, the official was summoned to attend a ''seminar,'' the Laotian euphemism for detention without charges or trial, and with no limit to the term of confinement, of people distrusted by the Communist Government. The equivalent designation in Vietnam, whose influence is dominant in Laos, is ''reeducation.'' **********With a change of clothes, he left for the ''seminar,'' to be held in Vientiane and to last a maximum of one month. But he was one of the first group chosen ''for further study'' in the mountains of Viengsay, in the northeastern border region with Vietnam. He pointed out to a Communist official that he had been about to enter hospital for a hemorrhoid operation but was reassured that he would be back within a week and that medical facilities in Viengsay were excellent.  'Not Punishment,' He Was Told **********Without taking leave of his wife and two sons, the former official was flown to the Plain of Jars, taken by helicopter to Viengsay and by truck for 60 miles farther north to an old prison-camp site in the forest. **********Together with about 600 other former civil servants, soldiers and policemen, he began a routine that combined all the work required to sustain life among inhospitable and primitive surroundings with basic political education. **********''They told us this was not punishment,'' the former official said. ''They said they themselves were always working on their political education. They wanted to make Communists of us.'' **********''I tried to do what I could to understand their politics,'' he continued. ''I knew that if I wanted to be allowed to work in their society, I would have to understand this.'' 'A New Patriotism' **********The former official described the Communist supervisors and instructors in sympathetic terms, as people who believed in what they were saying and in the justice of what they were doing. He said they shared the hardships and deprivations of their prisoners' lives and committed no brutalities. **********Political instruction was rudimentary, with barely educated peasants teaching men of advanced education what the former official described as ''a new patriotism, in which the Communist Party demanded that all Laotians voluntarily accept its authority over all aspects of their lives.'' He said the party was depicted as infallible, and those who doubted it as swimming against the flow of history. **********Prisoners had to form cells of 10 men to discuss the political lessons, engage in criticism of themselves and each other, and write again and again the story of their lives in the light of the new teaching. ''My hope was that eventually this Marxism-Leninism would take on a specific Laotian form and in this adaptation would make it possible for all of us to construct our country,'' the official explained. **********His wife, a pediatrician, remained in Vientiane, awaiting his return and hoping, by working at a hospital and teaching at the medical faculty, to speed his liberation. In 1978, when France broke relations with Laos, the Laotian authorities made it evident that they wanted her to leave. She rejoined their sons at school in France. Long Stretches Without News **********Her letters and packages reached him only occasionally, and there were long stretches when the couple were without news of each other.  Last January, the former official was told that he was being ''reassigned to Vientiane.'' At a farewell lunch, the political commissar told him he would be put to work in the capital, at a lesser job and with lower pay than in the past. He arrived, eager to go to work and assuming that he was now considered ''reeducated'' and acceptable to the authorities. **********His wife was allowed to visit him for two weeks.  ''I think I disappointed her badly,'' he said. ''She thought that she would find me like a victim of Hitler's concentration camps, bitter and above all eager to leave my country. Instead, I told her I was waiting to be put to work and asked her to apply for a job that would bring her back to Laos.'' **********The former official's most bitter disappointment came in his last months in Laos, when he was free in Vientiane, with nothing to do but occasionally translate for friends in ministries and bring his tennis game up to its old form. 'We Had Been Forgotten' **********He learned that the five and a half years of imprisonment that he believed had been a preparation for being useful to Laos had been mere imprisonment. No one in Vientiane knew what his capacities were, and no one intended to employ his skills. **********''For five and a half years, I saw an image of a Laos that was poor, lacking everything, but led by people who would finally lead the Laotian people to a prosperous and honorable future,'' he said sadly but without bitterness. **********''I was wrong. We had been forgotten, and in Vientiane I found no creative enthusiasm, nor any of the new solidarity we had heard about in the camp. Then I thought of the sadness of my wife and children.'' **********Last month, six years to the month after his decision not to join the exodus, the former official slid down the bank to the riverside and swam to Thailand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/busin.main_headline: Creamer Dickson Offers Women's Clubs Report
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Creamer Dickson Offers Women's Clubs Report
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/01/busin.body_text: **********Since 1945 Creamer Dickson Basford, or its predecesor public relations firms, has found the women's clubs of the nation an ideal outlet for ''business-sponsored materials.'' **********The clubs, the agency feels, are a ''microcosm of the maturity market.'' **********So C.D.B. did a survey of 1,000 of the members and on the basis of their responses has compiled a Report on Members of Women's Clubs that is available at the Creamer Inc. subsidiary at 1633 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10019. **********''The typical respondent,'' C.D.B. said, ''is a mature upscale consumer who is financially comfortable and often employed.'' It reports that 45 percent of the members are between 40 and 59 years of age and 30 percent between 50 and 59. Of the total 43 percent are employed. Over half (58 percent) are from homes with an average annual income of $20,000.

The rig, which will be capable of drilling in water up to 3,000 feet deep, will be completed by 1983, the statement added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/19/busin.body_text: **********The nation's brewers entered the busy summer season under a full head of steam. Patrick A. King, a research analyst at the United States Brewers Association, says withdrawals from brewers to wholesalers through May reached an estimated 71.3 million barrels, up 2.1 percent from a year ago. **********Still, Mr. King does not expect June and July figures to show much improvement from last year. **********''The early summer months were really big ones for brewers last year,'' he said. ''June deliveries in 1980 were 16.6 million barrels, up nearly 7 percent from a year earlier, and in July they were 17.1 million, 13 percent better than a year before. I don't anticipate deliveries will reach those levels again this year.'' **********According to Emmanuel Goldman, who follows the industry for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, Anheuser Busch, the nation's largest, and G.  Heilman Brewing, which produces a number of regional beers, have shown the fastest growth among domestic brewers so far this year. **********Imported beers, taking up less than 3 percent of the market, are also gaining, Mr. Goldman said. Through April, imports had increased 9 percent from a year earlier. And, in a trend begun last year, lower-priced brews from Canada and Mexico are outpacing more expensive European brands like Heineken and Kronenbourg. **********Thus far, the impact on sales of the five-week-old baseball strike has been difficult to assess. While Mr. King thinks the strike is bound to hurt, Joseph Finnigan, an spokesman for Anheuser-Busch, the company with the largest advertising and sales link to baseball, takes a different view. ''So far, the strike's impact on Busch has been zilch,'' he said. ''We're selling every drop we can produce.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/08/world.body_text: **********WASHINGTON AS the developing countries, aided by their relatively low wage scales, become increasingly competitive in traditional manufacturing industries, the developed nations are rushing to dominate the hightechnology sector, hoping to provide the jobs and exports they will need in the future. **********In the charge, the United States and its principal trading partners have had their share of clashes. A good example is the agreement between the United States and Japan, signed in the waning days of 1980, permitting sales of American telecommunications equipment to the mammoth Nippon Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********Although the new agreement may pave the way for joint AmericanJapanese research ventures that could help the participants move into the forefront of telecommunications development, it came only after three years of difficult, tense negotiation - an indication of the importance Japan places on protecting its advanced-technology industries. **********Government-owned Nippon Telephone, bestowed with the monopoly for providing telecommunications services to the Japanese, purchases $3.5 billion of equipment annually - ranging from utility poles to sophisticated switching apparatus. But in line with longstanding Japanese policy, the company gave all of its business only to Japanese suppliers. **********The situation was not unique. Post office and telephone monopolies exist in most countries of Western Europe and also operate under buynational purchasing policies. **********Thus, as in Japan, the governments of industrialized Europe both guarantee domestic companies demand for advanced technology products and provide much of the money for research and development through foreign exchange, fiscal and monetary policies and direct grants. **********In information processing, semiconductors, and microelectronics the story is much the same in most of the industrial coutries - active government intervention supports the expansion of domestic hightechology companies. **********The common theme behind these efforts is to develop advanced industries that will provide the jobs being lost in traditional manufacturing sectors that are facing stiff competition from developing nations. But the policy also stymies the efforts of American technology companies, which do not enjoy similar government support, to break into foreign markets. **********In addition to that disadvantage, spending by United States companies on research and development, a crucial sector for hightechnology industries, has lagged behind the principal competition. Although the United States research effort is still larger in absolute terms than in most other countries, spending has declined as a percentage of total output since 1961. **********In the same period, similar spending by West Germany increased by 80 percent. In Japan, the growth was 40 percent, while France's remained roughly constant and Britain's declined. **********According to a study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the United States accounted for 60 percent of the total expenditures on research and development in 1970 by all 24 members of the institution. By 1978, the percentage had fallen to 50 percent. **********''U.S. firms have fallen badly behind in the rate of productive investment and technological improvement, and are now falling behind in absolute levels as well,'' William V. Rapp, vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, said. **********This trend, coupled with the efforts of foreign governments to protect their technology industries, has meant that, over the last decade, the United States role as an exporter of manufactured goods had steadily shrunk. **********While the three leading competitors of the United States - West Germany, Japan and France - all increased their shares of manufactured exports during the decade, the United States share fell from 21.3 percent in 1970 to 17.4 percent in 1979. **********This has raised calls from United States manufacturers for broader Government emphasis on trade policy.  ''Domestically, it is essential to develop policies and programs which will enhance the competitive capabilities of export-oriented industries,'' Lawrence A. Fox, vice president for international affairs at the National Association of Manufacturers, said. **********In terms of trade policy, the United States' arguments are more with Japan than with Europe. The basic reason is that the United States still enjoys a healthy trade surplus with Europe, while it runs ever-mounting deficits with Japan. **********What has taken place in one high-technology sector, the manufacture of semiconductors, illustrates the problems between the two countries. **********Like telecommunications, semiconductors are favored by Japanese industrial policy, which means the Government helps fund research and development. **********Furthermore, the Japanese companies can carry a much higher debtto-capital ratio than United States banks consider sound, which means the actual cost of capital is reduced. Under the Japanese system of Government subsidies and low interest rates, it is cheaper to borrow from a bank than to raise capital from stockholders who expect to be rewarded with a stream of dividends. **********In the case of semiconductors, competition from the subsidised Japanese companies in the United States forced many small- and medium-size United States companies to cut prices, thus reducing profitability. The reduced profits shrank the capital available for development, making it harder for the American companies to compete. **********As a result, the Semiconductor Industry Association, which is made up of independent companies (such as Motorola, Intel, Fairchild and Advanced Micro Devices, but not the bigger companies like International Business Machines and Texas Instruments) sought advice about filing a petition with the Federal Government for import protection. **********The group approached Alan W. Wolff, a former deputy American trade negotiator and now with a Washington law firm that represents the association. He dissuaded the trade association on two counts: **********First, there seem to be reasonably good chances of getting tax credits for research as well as other investment incentives from the new Congress. **********Second, and perhaps more important, the Government is making progress on convincing the Japanese to open their market to American high-technology exports, including semiconductors, as the agreement on telecommunications exports shows.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/06/busin.body_text: **********As the financial markets keep sliding in the aftermath of the Reagan tax and budget-cutting victories, Congress and the Administration return to work this week with much to do, and little time to get it done. **********Wall Street and Washington analysts say that in order to prevent what could be just a temporary downturn from getting much worse, the executive and legislative branches need to come up with a coordinated stategy. The problem, these analysts say, is that while both branches seem aware that quick action is necessary, there is little agreement on what needs to be done. **********After a month off, Congress is likely to renew its push for a relaxation of the Fed's tough money policies which it thinks would ease burgeoning Federal deficits and stimulate economic growth. The Administration, on the other hand, currently seems to feel that additional budget cuts will convince the financial markets it means business. According to Lawrence Chimerine, chief economist at Chase Econometrics, both efforts are necessary - and even that may not be enough. **********Slower Credit Growth **********Detriot's rebate programs have lured consumers into auto showrooms this quarter, a development which should be reflected in higher consumer debt figures this week. Even so, analysts say high interest rates are causing people to postpone purchases, and save. Elizabeth Allison, an economist at Data Resources, says high interest rates are not the only deterrent to rising indebtedness. Recent declines in the stock market have led to a reduction in net worth, dampening the inclination to take on new debt. Outside of autos, that's bad news for durable goods manufacturers. Mrs. Allison currently expects sales of durable goods to grow at less than 1 percent in real terms in the third quarter, with a slight uptick in the fourth. As long as interest rates remain high, private credit demand should not be expected to pick up, Mrs. Allison says. After this quarter, when new installment debt is forecast to rise 12 percent, to $356 billion at an annual rate, the quarterly annualized rates of increase remain well below that figure. After inflation is accounted for, the rate of increase is likely to be only 1 or 2 percent through the end of 1982.  Clear Track for Railroads **********In most businesses, a slack economy and a protracted strike in an important client's industry often mean red ink. Such is not the case for the nation's major railroads. Nearly a year after deregulation, business is brisk. **********Richard Fischer, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, says two elements of last year's deregulation legislation have been particularly helpful.  Greater rate-setting flexibility and a cost recovery provision allow companies to recoup costs attributable to inflation on a quarterly basis. And the ability to set contract rates gives railroads the opportunity to woo types of traffic they had lost in the past for long-term hauling. With coal traffic fully recovered from the strike and a bumper crop forecast, the outlook for the rest of 1981 seems even brighter. **********Although forecasts of further weakness in the economy next year could harm profitability, Andras R. Petery of Morgan Stanley notes that accelerated depreciation schedules will prove beneficial. At the moment, Mr. Petery projects earnings for the 10 major railroads will reach $1.6 billion this year, up 19 percent from 1980 levels. Japanese Trade Revives **********A year ago, rising oil bills pushed Japan's current account into an $11 billion deficit. And, with opposition rising against further penetration in auto markets, additional deterioration seemed likely. **********That is not happening. During the past year, Japanese export strategy has shifted markedly, and led to an export boom that some analysts think might trigger a new wave of protectionist sentiment in foreign markets. High rates of interest in the U.S. have helped weaken the value of the yen again st the dollar, and Japan's central bank has done little to restore th e balance. With major industrial country markets reluctant to accept more of the country's products, its steel and auto producer s, among others, have redoubled efforts in d e veloping countries. In Western markets, the Japanese are now concen trating on selling sophisticated and expensive products that currentl y arouse less protectionist alarm. **********Roger Bird, director of the Wharton Econometrics forecasting model, says these shifts should translate into a current account swing of at least $12 billion this year, and projects a surplus of $2 billion to $3 billion in 1982. **********Kenneth N. Gilpin  [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ]

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/world.main_headline: France Ends Its Embargo On Armaments for Iran
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/world.print_headline: France Ends Its Embargo On Armaments for Iran
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/world.body_text: **********France has lifted a provisional arms embargo against Iran and will deliver three missile boats ordered by the Iranian Navy, a spokesman for Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy said today. **********The outgoing Government of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing imposed a temporary arms embargo against Iran, Argentina and Libya on May 13 until the new administration could take over. **********The embargo against Argentina was lifted yesterday. Arms deliveries to Libya remain frozen pending a review.During the Presidential election campaign, Francois Mitterrand pledged to halt arms sales to countries at war or to ''fascist'' or ''racist'' nations. But shortly after his election, officials said that contracts already signed would be honored. **********The three missile boats ordered by Teheran have been blocked in Cherbourg harbor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/04/busin.main_headline: CANADIANS ARE PURSUING FOREIGN OIL COMPANIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/04/busin.print_headline: CANADIANS ARE PURSUING FOREIGN OIL COMPANIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Foreign oil companies in Canada today find themselves increasingly the targets of a corporate big game hunt with billions of dollars at stake. **********The immediate cause is Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's new nationalistic energy policy, which uses discriminatory taxing and exploration grant guidelines to favor oil companies defined as Canadian-owned. The goal is to raise domestic ownership of Canada's petroleum industry to 50 percent by 1990 from 28 percent today. **********Government planners hope that many huge foreign energy companies, such as Exxon, Gulf, Texaco, Acquitaine, Chevron and British Petroleum, will sell all or part of their Canadian subsidiaries to Canadian companies, including Petro-Canada, the state oil company.  The federal Government is using Petro-Canada to gain its own substantial share of the oil business. **********''Despite all their denials,'' said one Canadian investment banker, ''we now regard all foreign oil companies as fair game.'' Hudson's Bay Control Shifts **********Just this week Dome Petroleum, an aggressive, acquisition-minded Canadian concern that began in 1950 as a resource investment arm for the endowment funds of Harvard, Princeton and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, won a wrestling match with the United States' Conoco Inc. for control of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company, Canada's No.2 natural gas producer. **********In February, Petro-Canada spent $1.4 billion to buy the Canadian subsidiary of Belgium's Petrofina S.A. In April, the St. Joe Minerals Corporation sold its Canadian oil and gas subsidiary, Candel Oil Ltd., to a Canadian company, Sulpetro Ltd., as part of its defense against a takeover by Canada's giant cash-rich distiller, Seagram's.  Union Oil of California has announced that it is selling its oil and gas holdings in Canada. **********In a possible repeat of the Dome-Conoco struggle, the Nu-West Group Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta, has purchased more than 6 percent of the stock of the Cities Service Company. Many analysts expect the Canadian company to increase its holdings in the parent American company and then offer to trade those shares for control of Cities Service's Canadian subsidiary. **********Cities Service, in a lawsuit filed against Nu-West in Tulsa, Okla., charges that the Canadian Government's energy policies have created an economic and political environment in which some Canadian companies can put pressure on American companies to sell their Canadian operations at less than market value. Lower earnings projections as a result of the new energy taxes have also depressed share prices here, making them even more attractive bargains. Hiram Walker Purchase **********In January, Hiram Walker-Consumers Home Ltd., a giant liquor, energy and utility company here, bought $600 million worth of United States oil and gas properties from the Davis Oil Company of Denver. **********There have been signs of growing Congressional concern over the mounting aggressiveness of Canadian energy companies. Both the Carter and Reagan Administrations warned Canadian officials that Canada's energy program, yet to be fully legislated, threatens to increase economic frictions between the two countries, both each other's largest trading partner. Under American law and the principle of reciprocity, restrictions can be imposed on foreign companies operating on Federal lands whose homeland restricts American companies operating there. **********Mr. Trudeau's energy policy, Canada's latest preoccupation with economic nationalism, is not without domestic opponents, many of whom are critical of increased energy taxes used to finance billion-dollar buyouts that change ownership papers but produce no more oil. **********''The notion that foreign ownership is bad ownership,'' said Rowland Frazee, chairman of the Royal Bank, Canada's largest, ''and that we can penalize it retroactively, as contained in the National Energy Program, is living dangerously, damaging Canada's reputation abroad and fomenting wasteful bickering at home. It must be changed.'' Financing Affected **********The energy plan, combined with other incidents of economic resource nationalism such as Saskatchewan's potash takeover and Quebec's threatened expropriation of General Dynamics' Asbestos Corporation, has hurt Canada's ability to raise foreign funds for investments, including billions needed for frontier oil exploration. **********According to Brian Gilmer, a corporate finance officer for A.E Ames & Company Ltd., a major investment house here, ''A lot of General Dynamics board members take these experiences back to their own companies. The bad reputation spreads - 'I got stomped in Canada, why bother?' -and you can bet it'll be a while before they come piling back into Canada.'' **********Overall American investment here is at a steady level or declining slightly. The Amoco Minerals Company, a unit of Standard Oil (Indiana), is offering its 63 percent slice of the Cyprus Anvil Mining Corporation for sale to Canadians while Amoco Canada Petroleum cut its exploration budget 56 percent. **********While recent takeover activity has aroused much attention, it has actually been under way for years, lowering foreign ownership of Canada's petroleum industry to 72 percent from a high of 80 percent.  In 1976, Petro-Canada bought Atlantic Richfield Canada for $320 million. In 1979, it bought Phillips Petroleum's Canadian operations, Pacific Petroleums Ltd. And in 1978-79, the Nova Corporation, formerly Alberta Gas Trunk Line, took over Husky Oil. Moving Into American Markets **********Most analysts see the energy takeovers as part of a larger swing of the North American economic pendulum toward the United States, a tempting market 10 times the size of Canada's. It is proving a powerful lure to Canadian investors, manufacturers, real estate operators, insurance companies, brewers, banks, cable television companies and energy corporations. **********The energy companies were especially spurred by the start of oil deregulation in the United States in 1979. Some Canadian companies like Bow Valley Industries Ltd. may not even use all their government incentives because American deals look better. **********''Businessmen are not all that ideological,'' Mr. Gilmer said. ''A $30 barrel of oil found in the United States just looks a lot better than an $11 barrel in Canada.'' **********Continuous federal-provincial bickering over energy prices has created considerable economic uncertainty in Canada while export restrictions and high export prices help create a natural gas surplus keeping many new gas finds shut in the ground for years. **********''In Texas,'' Mr. Gilmer said, ''a long shut-in is two weeks. I know one utility laid pipes right to the drill site. I couldn't even guess at the Canadian money that's flowed into Texas, the Rockies and Michigan.'' **********In fact, Mr. Gilmer's Canadian firm recently held an investment seminar on oil prospects in the United States for its institutional investor clients. The result was a string of Canadian oilmen enthusiastically addressing an attentive crowd of Canadian investors - in Houston.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/08/world.main_headline: SCHMIDT, IN PARLIAMENT, SILENT ON ATTACKS BY BEGIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/08/world.print_headline: SCHMIDT, IN PARLIAMENT, SILENT ON ATTACKS BY BEGIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/08/world.body_text: **********Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, in a report to Parliament today on his recent Middle East trip, declined to respond to personal attacks by Prime Minister Menachem Begin, and called on Israel and the Arabs to live together ''in a just and all-embracing peace.'' **********Mr. Schmidt said he had nothing to add to comments made earlier this week by a West German Government spokesman, who said Mr. Begin was making campaign speeches that were ''not to the point and insulting.'' **********The Chancellor, who has made every effort not to strain relations further, said he chose silence ''precisely because I am conscious of the moral and historical quality of German-Israeli relations.'' **********A German-Palestinian Parallel **********Mr. Begin began to attack Mr. Schmidt's role as a German officer in World War II after the Chancellor, in an interview on April 30, discussed the Palestine Liberation Organization, the Palestinians' right to self-determination and the Germans' moral duty to support that right. Mr. Schmidt said: **********''In the Palestinian conflict, one cannot simply assign all morality to one side and shrug away the other side. That's impossible. It is particularly impossible for a German living in a divided nation and claiming the right to self-determination for the German people. In that case, the Palestinians' claim to the right of selfdetermination must also be recognized. **********''Let me say one thing with regard to the P.L.O. If we in the West continue to treat the P.L.O. basically as terrorist and don't learn to differentiate among its factions - the P.L.O. is, after all, nothing but an umbrella group for a variety of organizations - that will be the surest way to drive it into the arms of Moscow.'' **********Israel lodged an official protest against Mr. Schmidt's statement, made on his return from a visit to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. ---- Electioneering Charged in Israel **********JERUSALEM, May 7 (Reuters) -Prime Minister Begin's attacks on Chancellor Schmidt and the Israeli leader's tough stance on Lebanon drew cheers today from his followers and charges of electioneering from opposition leaders. **********A poll in The Jerusalem Post showed that Mr. Begin's Likud Party had made a remarkable recovery and was running almost evenly with the opposition Labor Party, which had been expected to win the June 30 election easily. **********''The Prime Minister's performance in recent days shows that the old Mr. Begin is back and the polls prove that the voters like it,'' a Likud Party official said. **********A Labor official said his party supported Mr. Begin's demands that Syria remove its antiaircraft missiles from Lebanon and his criticism of Mr. Schmidt's advocacy of Palestinian rights. But he added, ''We believe Mr. Begin's strident tone is uncalled for and is aimed at Israeli voters.'' **********Likud Party officials rejected the charges of electioneering.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/25/world.main_headline: A TRIBUTE TO A SPRY BREZHNEV BRINGS AN EDGY SOVIET REPLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/25/world.print_headline: A TRIBUTE TO A SPRY BREZHNEV BRINGS AN EDGY SOVIET REPLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/25/world.body_text: **********The state of Leonid I. Brezhnev's health created a heated dispute today between Soviet and West German spokesmen.  In what seemed intended as a compliment, Kurt Becker of West Germany said at a news conference that Bonn leaders were ''impressed with the physical stability'' with which Mr. Brezhnev followed a long program on Monday without outward signs of fatigue. **********The Soviet spokesman, Leonid M. Zamyatin, responded sharply: ''I can assure you that his physical condition is good, and that he is fully capable of working. That was proven by the seven hours of talks he held yesterday with the leaders of West Germany.'' **********Mr. Zamyatin then listed the appointments set up for Mr. Brezhnev, who will be 75 next month, ''to illustrate that Mr. Becker's remarks were not correct.'' **********It was unclear whether Mr. Zamyatin had misunderstood Mr. Becker through an interpreter or sought to indicate that the Russians viewed any discussion of Mr. Brezhnev's health as unseemly. **********Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, who had a heart pacemaker implanted in his chest last month, seemed sprightly during the visit of the Soviet leader, who left a dinner on Monday immediately after delivering a short speech. **********Mr. Brezhnev's health has been the object of speculation in the West. There have been reports, never confirmed, that he has received a heart pacemaker, and there was much puzzling over his condition during his last visit here in 1978. Mr. Brezhnev then seemed bloated and puffy, descended the stairs of his plane on arrival leaning heavily on the arms of aides, and was often unable to rise from chairs without assistance. This time, he appears more at ease and to move with greater facility. **********His health was not the only problem of comprehension for the spokesmen. There were also disputes over the role of the United States' Polaris submarines in arms talks, and even confusion over the number of weeks in the year. **********After Mr. Zamyatin had said that the Polaris submarines, which he said were each armed with 12 missiles, partly offset Soviet mediumrange missiles, Mr. Becker observed that the Polaris submarines were already covered by agreements limiting strategic arms and that each carried 16, not 12, missiles. **********Confusion over the number of weeks in the year arose later, when Mr. Zamyatin discussed Western news reports that the Soviet Union was installing a SS-20 missile system a week. **********''You can be glad there are only 54 weeks in the year,'' he told reporters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/22/world.main_headline: BUCKLEY, OUTLINING REAGAN POLICY, CALLS ARMS SALES ABROAD 'VITAL' TOOL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/22/world.print_headline: BUCKLEY, OUTLINING REAGAN POLICY, CALLS ARMS SALES ABROAD 'VITAL' TOOL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/22/world.body_text: **********Under Secretary of State James L. Buckley declared today that sales of American weapons abroad ''complement and supplement our own defense efforts and serve as a vital and constructive instrument of American foreign policy.'' **********Speaking before the Aerospace Industries Association in Williamsburg, Va., Mr. Buckley presented a general framework for President Reagan's new policy on arms sales. Specific guidelines will be made public early next week, according to Administration officials. **********Mr. Buckley said today that while the Carter Administration considered arms sales ''inherently evil or morally reprehensible,'' the Reagan Administration would use weapons transfers as one way of ''facing up to the realities of Soviet aggrandizement.'' **********''Arms transfers can thus serve as an important adjunct to our own security,'' Mr. Buckley said, ''by helping deter acts of aggression, by enhancing the self-d@efense capabilities of nations with which we share close ties, and by facilitating access by American forces to military facilities abroad.'' Buckley Outlines Policy Goals **********According to Mr. Buckley, the goals of the policy include enhancing the ''state of preparedness of our friends and allies,'' revitalizing American alliances, fashioning ''more coherent'' policies and strategies that affect East-West relations and ''buttressing our own defense production capabilities.'' **********He denied that the new policy would herald a period of unrestrained arms sales abroad. But he added that the Administration would give the ''highest priority'' to requests for arms from ''members of our major alliances and from those nations with whom we have developed cooperative relations.'' **********In assessing other requests, the Administration will consider the military threat facing the recipient, how the weapons would serve to maintain stability in regions where there are tensions, and whether the arms could be absorbed by the recipient, Mr. Buckley said. **********''For this reason, we are prepared to encourage the efforts of American manufacturers to produce equipment which, in terms of cost, complexity and sophistication, is more appropriate to the needs of nonindustrial nations,'' he said. Carter Policy Is Rescinded **********This morning, in one of his first actions to put the new policy into effect, Mr. Buckley rescinded the Carter Administration's instructions to United States officials abroad not to assist American arms merchants. Mr. Buckley said American Government representatives abroad would instead be ''expected to provide the same courtesies and support'' to companies selling arms as to those marketing any other product. **********Mr. Buckley also disavowed the concept of one-sided restraint in arms sales. But he said that the Administration would ''continue to examine ways to secure multilateral restraint.'' **********The policy outlined by Mr. Buckley has been under review for more than two months and was recently approved by an interagency group led by the State Department. **********The new position essentially reverses the Carter Administration's six-point policy on arms sales issued May 19, 1977. In that policy statement, President Carter introduced broad measures to restrict overseas weapons sales, calling them an ''exceptional'' instrument of foreign policy to be used only when it could be ''clearly demonstrated that the arms transfer contributes to our national security.'' **********Despite the proclamation of the new policy, however, the Carter Administration did not completely restrain conventional arms exports. American sales abroad totaled $10.6 billion in 1976 and $10.3 billion in 1979, but arms deliveries rose from $4.8 billion to $5.7 billion in the same years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/11/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration today outlined a plan to step up substantially the pace at which the Government leases offshore oil and gas properties. **********Six additional sales would be made over the next five years, and procedures would be streamlined so that the time required to prepare a lease for bids would be cut to about 18 months from two or three years currently. **********''This action hastens the day when America's offshore oil reserves are better known and evaluated,'' Energy Secretary James B. Edwards told a news conference at which he appeared with Interior Secretary James G. Watt. ''We cannot know what domestic energy sources are available to us until we inventory the resources - and that means exploratory drilling in offshore areas.'' **********Only One California Basin **********At the same time, however, the Administration withdrew its February proposal to include in a lease sale late next month four basins off California that have been the object of concern by environmentalists. Only the Santa Maria Basin, which has an estimated oil-equivalent potential four times that of the other basins combined, would be put up for bids. **********A decision on whether leasing all or part of the lesser basins - Eel River, Point Arena, Bodega and Santa Cruz -is in the national interest is scheduled for late May or June, the Administration said. **********''It sounds like a temporary reprieve, but I'd rather have a pardon,'' said Representative Leon Panetta, a California Democrat whose district includes many miles of coastline. 42 Sales Now Planned **********The 42 proposed sales during 1982-86 compares with the current schedule of 36 for the five-year period ending in June 1985. **********The bulk of the increased activity will be off the shore of Alaska, where the sales are about doubled, to 16. There will be 10 sales in the Gulf of Mexico, five off California, six in the Atlantic and one reoffering each year of undesignated properties put up previously. **********The Alaskan sales also reflect the plan to speed up lease preparation, which includes Government evaluations of oil and gas potential. **********The Norton Basin, for example, is to be moved forward four months, to May 1982; the North Aleutian Basin six months, to April 1983; the Navarin Basin 12 months, to December 1983, and the Chukchi Sea (renamed the Barrow Arch) one month, to January 1985. **********The plan also calls for speeding up by one-third the pace of scheduling for second offerings in promising areas. Governor Brown's Protests **********The Interior Department attributed its decision to defer the sale of the four California leases to objections by Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., who also opposes leasing some of the tracts in the Santa Maria Basin. **********In all, the five basins off central and northern California total 1.3 million acres. They lie 3 to 27 miles offshore, in water that ranges in depth from 162 to 2,437 feet. **********Mr. Watt said that with about 4,000 offshore wells now producing oil and gas outside the three-mile limit, there have been only two spills of more than 1,000 barrels in United States waters since 1970. Both of these involved stored oil, not blowouts or other losses of well control. He added that neither the 1969 Santa Barbara spill nor the 1980 Mexican spill had caused significant long-term damage. **********''The Congress expected environmental protection to be achieved through sound planning and operating practices, not through closing of geographic areas to leasing and development,'' Mr. Watt said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/13/world.main_headline: SEOUL DISSIDENT BLAMED IN PART FOR HIS PLIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/13/world.print_headline: SEOUL DISSIDENT BLAMED IN PART FOR HIS PLIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/13/world.body_text: **********Kim Dae Jung, the jailed dissident leader, is regarded by his supporters as the wronged victim of judicial manipulations by the military rulers of South Korea. But some also say that he is partly responsible for his plight. **********One of them, former President Yun Po Sun, said in an interview that Mr. Kim made serious errors of political strategy last year in an overly hasty bid to become a candidate for President in elections this year. **********A major error, Mr. Yun declared, was Mr. Kim 's sudden decision in early 1980 to form his own party and to disso ciate himself from the New Democratic Party, which was then the main opposition group and has since been forcibly disbanded. According to this view, Mr. Kim's decision split the democratic forces in South Korea and made possiblea military takeover in May of last year by Ch un Doo Hwan, then a lieutenant general in the South Korean army. **********Mr. Kim, who was arrested on April 17, 1980, is serving a life sentence in prison on sedition charges. Church groups abroad and the United States and Japanese Governments are making low-key efforts to obtain his release. So far President Chun has declined to respond. 'In Too Much of a Hurry' **********''He was in too much of a hurry,'' said the 84-year-old Mr. Yun of the tactics of Mr. Kim, who was previously a presidential candidate in 1971. **********Mr. Kim did not maintain communications with Mr. Yun, the former President declared, and did not inform him in advance of his decision to abandon his informal, but close, ties with the New Democratic Party. **********Mr. Yun said that Mr. Kim might have felt that he had at the time no chance to become the presidential candidate of the party, whose leader, Kim Young Sam, also had presidential aspirations. But Mr. Yun said that Kim Dae Jung was ''much more popular in the country'' and that he would surely have emerged as the party's nominee. **********The former President gave his version of the events of last year over a two-hour dinner at his home in central Seoul. Mr. Yun is retired from active politics but served as an adviser to both Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam. The former President said he had wanted the two men to agree to a single opposition candidacy. Yun Quit Presidency After Coup **********Mr. Yun, President from 1960 to 1962, quit his office a year after a military takeover by a junta led by Park Chung Hee, who ruled South Korea until his assassination in 1979. **********Since the military seizure of power on May 17 last year, Mr. Yun h as maintaine d formal relations with President Chun and his army advisers. He has been criticized for this by dissidents here. **********The decision by Kim Dae Jung to split with the New Democratic Party was criticized in a separate interview by Park Kwon Hum, who was a supporter of Kim Young Sam in Parliament. ''He committed political suicide,'' Mr. Park said. **********Mr. Yun said that Kim Dae Jung had made his decision on the spur of the movement.  ''Kim Dae Jung came to see me one day, and we had a long talk,'' he said. ''Then the next day I heard that he had announced he was leaving the New Democratic Party. Message Brought by Son **********''The next day his second son brought around a note to say there was no point in us meeting for the time being as he had nothing further to say.'' **********Kim Young Sam said in an interview that he and Kim Dae Jung had ''always agreed that if we two split then the army would intervene.'' ''To this day I don't understand why Kim Dae Jung did that,'' Mr.  Kim said at his home. He declined to criticize his rival directly, however. **********Mr. Kim is in prison at Chongju, 60 miles from here. His wife, Lee Hi Ho, reportedly goes to the prison twice weekly but is allowed to see her husband for only 30 minutes once a month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/busin.print_headline: YOUR MONEY; OIL COMPANIES' STIFF CREDIT TEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/09/busin.body_text: **********WANT an oil company credit card? A few caveats are in order. Make sure you answer all questions on the application. Be careful about estimates of how much gas you expect to use. Take pains to see that your previous credit performance is up to par. And be accurate - a tough computer is watching and scoring you. **********Don't be disappointed if you are rejected. Oil companies generally turn down as many as 50 percent of all applications. Recently, rising fraud, theft of cards and delinquency have made the companies more careful about credit authorization. **********Most companies, such as Amoco, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), and the Shell Oil Company, use scoring systems to evaluate applicants' answers and may say no if the total falls below an acceptable level. **********Recently, Mary Derrington, head of the mathematics department at Mineola High School, in Mineola, L.I., was rejected by Amoco because she failed to clear the point-scoring minimum. Reason: Amoco, through a spokesman in Chicago, said it was because she had estimated that her 1971 Camero (having already traveled about 85,000 miles) used about $150 worth of gasoline a month. Amoco said that would amount to at least 100 gallons a month. ''Our computer said that $150 worth of gas a month was too much for a car of that age to consume,'' Amoco's spokesman said. **********Miss Derrington explained in an interview that she had included the cost of repairs and the buying of equipment such as tires in her estimate because she also uses credit cards to pay for such costs. **********She estimated that she generally drove about 20 miles a day from her home to her school and back. She argued that her estimate of her gas costs should not be the basis for rejection, but that the decision should be made on her credit rating and her history of paying her debts. **********Amoco said it had also turned down a Congressman who listed his bank account but not his salary.''The lady missed passing the scoring test by just one point,'' the company added. ''If she had estimated a lower figure, she might well have gotten her application approved.'' **********In a letter explaining why she was rejected, Amoco listed other reasons besides the estimate of gas purchases. It mentioned the age of her vehicle, her state of residence and the type of housing in relation to the number of dependents. (She's single, has no dependents and lives in an apartment.) On state of residence, Amoco said in the letter, ''Marketing considerations and/or the delinquency rate we have experienced prompt us to require a higher total score for approval in your state.'' **********Miss Derrington, however, is angry. ''Why should the age of my vehicle be considered a mark against me?'' she demands. ''If I promised to purchase a brand-new car, American-made, of course, would this remove the first blot from my family escutcheon? Why am I penalized for living in New York State? I care not for the delinquency of others. I concern myself with my personal record. And of what importance is my type of housing and the question regarding the number of dependents? Is it improper or second-rate if I rent an apartment as opposed to owning a home?'' **********She concludes: ''It would seem that my past record of so many years with my landlord and other credit card companies plus 19 years in the teaching profession should lend some credence to my status of acceptability.'' **********Oil companies in general tend to withhold information about their credit card business, saying that such information is competitive.  But it is clear that rising fraud in credit card use is making them all more cautious. Delinquencies are up as well. Shell, for example, says: ''We feel that there are 4,000 fraud attempts made every day at Shell stations. Each month, about 7,000 Shell credit cards or stolen or lost. All that makes the oil companies very sensitive about credit card use.'' **********Shell has 5.5 million to six million credit accounts, and, since many families have several cards in use on one account, it estimates it has about 10 million credit cards outstanding. **********Amoco says: ''We certainly find that bad debts are a substantial cost of doing business. As a result, our credit people are continually attempting to have the computer predict more accurately.'' **********Are the oil companies getting tougher on credit authorization? Both Amoco and Shell deny it. They tightened terms a year ago when credit controls were put into effect but have not toughened them since. **********In most cases, oil companies demand payment in 30 days and charge annual interest rates from 12 percent up, depending on state laws, on the unpaid balance. Revolving credit is allowed on purchases up to $300, with a minimum monthly payment of $25 if the account is more than $200. On purchases of more than $300, the difference must be paid in full at the time of billing. **********Exxon USA, which reports that it approves slightly more than 50 percent of its applications, says insufficient credit references are the biggest reason for rejections. The company has 6.5 million credit card accounts.
