https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/08/world.body_text: **********George Kouris, a Greek newspaper publisher who went into hiding three weeks ago after being sentenced to four years in prison for having accused President Constantine Caramanlis of corruption, appeared here this week seeking political asylum. **********Mr. Kouris is the publisher of Avriani, which was founded last March and has since reached a circulation of 60,000 daily and 130,000 on Sundays, according to the publisher. **********His brother Makis, who is co-publisher of Avriani, remains in Greece and is free pending appeal of a sentence of two years in prison arising from another article on alleged Government corruption. George Kouris, unlike his brother, was ordered jailed immediately, and he fled. **********He said here on Tuesday that he intended to put his case before political figures in several Western European countries and then go to the United States. He said Avriani continued to publish despite his absence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/28/busin.main_headline: AT THE CONTROLS OF PAN AM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/28/busin.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; AT THE CONTROLS OF PAN AM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/28/busin.body_text: **********''I was thinking about finding a more challenging job,'' said C.  Edward Acker, ''and I asked about being the captain of the Titanic.  But they said I was years too late. So I decided to take the job of Pan Am chairman.'' **********With that quip Charles Edward Acker, chairman of Air Florida, explained why he had accepted an offer from the board of the foundering Pan American World Airways to assume its chairmanship Sept. 1, replacing William T. Seawell. **********Considered by his colleagues as a feisty airline marketer who has never been afraid to take a run at his larger competitors, the 52-year-old Mr. Acker brings to the job long experience in finance and a devotee's knowledge of every aspect of the airline trade. His friends say that his favorite reading is his dog-eared Official Airline Guide of route schedules, which he constantly thumbs through in search of new cities to connect. 'Calls on All Your Skills' **********''Once you get hooked on the airline business it's worse than dope,'' Mr. Acker said in an interview. ''It's awful hard to get out. It's got everything you would want for excitement: a capitalintensive, labor-intensive, around-the-clock service business. It calls on all your skills as an executive.'' **********Mr. Acker has spent the last four years satisfying his airline addiction as chairman of Air Florida, which he converted from an obscure intrastate carrier into what many consider to be the most innovative and fastest-growing fleet in the nation. His techniques became the talk of the industry. But his aggressive, expansionary management style has brought him into conflict at times with more than a few competing airlines, not to mention the Federal Government. **********Mr. Acker stepped down as president of Braniff Airways in 1975 on the heels of a Federal investigation of Braniff officials for illegally distributing airline tickets worth about $1 million to travel agents in Latin America. Some of the proceeds were said to have been contributed to President Richard M. Nixon's 1972 election campaign. Mr. Acker and the company's chairman, Harding L. Lawrence, were among the Braniff officials who were named in a settlement with the Civil Aeronautics Board. The airline paid a $300,000 penalty. **********Born in Dallas on April 7, 1929, Mr. Acker received his B.A. in economics and psychology from Southern Methodist University in 1950.  He has been using his twin degree ever since. **********''The key to success in the airline business,'' said Mr. Acker, outling his operating philosophy, ''is determining what customers want in each different market and how best to give it to them. That's what we did at Air Florida. For the customers looking for value we offered a single, unrestricted fare that was the lowest on the market. For the businessman we offered frequency of flights to key cities. And we did it all in an uncomplicated fashion that everyone could understand - no 'Super-Savers,' no 45 days in advance, just one fare all the time.'' Joined Air Florida in 1977 **********Mr. Acker joined the foundering Air Florida in 1977 as chairman, bringing with him cash from a group of Dallas investors who were prepared to bet he could turn the airline around. He had worked in investment counseling and finance for a variety of Dallas companies between 1952 and 1965, before joining Braniff Airways where he eventually rose to president in 1970. After his departure, he worked as an executive of a financial holding company until joining Air Florida. **********For the small regional airline, Edward Acker proved to be the right man at the right time. In 1978, the airline industry was deregulated and Mr. Acker became known among his colleagues as the ''darling of deregulation.'' The unshackling of the airline business allowed Air Florida to break out of its Miami-Tampa pattern into lucrative routes to the Northeast United States and Europe, and it allowed Mr. Acker to let his entrepreneurial instincts run riot. He scrapped the carrier's gas-guzzling Boeing 707's for the more efficient 737's, cut every other cost corner he could find and began flying, with a Miami hub, routes that stretched from Texas to Amsterdam. **********''But his reach never exceeded his grasp,'' said Simeon R.  Trotter, an airlines analyst with Rauscher Pierce Refsnes, a Dallas brokerage firm. ''He was always able to combine ambitious growth with the financial controls to pull it off.'' 'Free Rides for a Kiss' **********His tenure at Air Florida will surely be remembered for such marketing innovations as ''Free Rides for a Kiss'' - a promotion that gave customers a free trip if they kissed an airline employee - that was introduced in the highly competitive Florida-Texas market.  Another lure was the orange juice and champagne elixer, called the ''Sunshine Sparkler'' that the airline served to morning passengers out of Miami. **********But most of all it was Mr. Acker's ''Sweet and Simple'' low-cost, unrestricted fares that made Air Florida competitive on some routes with Eastern and Pan Am. Planes were run profitably not only by keeping them nearly 100 percent full, but by scheduling aircraft that normally remained idle on weekends and holidays to run charters to Europe and the Caribbean. **********''We are all going to miss Ed Acker,'' said Robin Cohn, director of communications for Air Florida, which grew twentyfold under Mr.  Acker's direction. ''But to tell you the truth we are so busy around here no one has even had much time to talk about it.'' **********Mr. Acker took his colleagues and the airline industry by surprise, as much for signing on with Pan Am as by the way he announced it. He announced his acceptance of the post on Wednesday while addressing a group of Wall Street airline analysts gathered to hear about the future of Air Florida. He had been approached by an executive recruiter to replace William T. Seawell in the Pan Am top position. **********The shock having been absorbed, one of his first moves after signing on with Pan Am was to change his first-class reservation for the flight back to Miami from Eastern to Pan Am, ''in order to start meeting the people and sampling the service.'' He always flies first class because ''it's free'' and he because he cannott fit his 6-foot 4-inch frame comfortably into the seat-packed tourist cabin of his own airline. **********His second move was to order up a list of every nonproductive asset owned by Pan Am, a list of all the fees it has paid to its consultants and lawyers, and a description of all major jobs in the company. That, he said, is only ''5 percent'' of what he wants to know about Pan Am. **********Separated from his wife, Mr. Acker said he will use his Westport, Conn., vacation home as base for himself, two grown sons and a daughter, while he looks for something closer to Pan Am's Manhattan offices. He is also looking for a local court to exercise his passion for frontennis - an unusual game resembling racquetball that is played by four people in a three-walled court. **********''I picked it up down in Mexico,'' he said. ''Boy is it fast. I love the competition.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/28/busin.body_text: **********The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the nation's second-largest telephone company after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said that it would introduce a computerized data retrieval system to allow doctors to call up medical information on video terminals in their offices and hospitals. **********The system, being prepared with the help of the American Medical Association, represents G.T.E.'s first entry into electronic publishing since 1966, when it acquired a company that provides news and stock prices electronically. **********The new service, which would be transmitted by G.T.E.'s Telenet Communications subsidiary, will be available in mid-1982. It will initially offer drug information that is now published in printed form by the A.M.A.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/01/busin.body_text: **********THE Transamerica Corporation has an image problem. Mr. Average American, it seems, is hard-pressed to know what it is that Transamerica does. In the investment community, as one Wall Street analyst put it, ''There are only a handful of people who can even spell Transamerica.'' Ask someone what Transamerica is - all $4.4 billion of it - and you draw long hard stares. **********So one of the conglomerate's chief ambitions is to mold Transamerica into an instantly recognizable name, like General Motors or General Electric. And the man charged with tackling that task is James Harvey, who took over in January as Transamerica's chief executive officer, replacing John Beckett, the company's long-time guiding father who has retired from the post, while continuing as chairman for another two years. **********''Our goal is to build one of the great consumer names in the country, like General Electric,'' Mr. Harvey said. ''In the past the company simply hasn't been that well recognized.'' **********Out of an office high up in a striking 853-foot, pyramid-shaped building that ranks as the tallest structure in San Francisco, the 46-year-old Transamerica chief executive oversees an empire that embraces a group of insurance companies led by Occidental Insurance, a trailer and container transportation concern called Transamerica Interway, a machinery manufacturer, Budget Rent a Car, Transamerica Airlines (a charter airline that boasts that it flies to more airports than any other carrier), and United Artists, the film company that brought unenvied renown to itself (and to Transamerica) for its ''Heaven's Gate'' debacle and the resignation two weeks ago of Andy Albeck, its chief executive officer. **********Transamerica has endured a somewhat schizophrenic history. The company was started in 1928 by A.P. Giannini, the founder of the Bank of America, whose core philosophy was to serve the ''little fellows.'' Originally, Transamerica's purpose was to hold stock in Mr. Giannini's banking and nonbanking activities. **********In 1956, however, Congress essentially barred any company from owning controlling interests in both banking and nonbanking endeavors. As a result, the banking entities were spun off and Transamerica was left primarily with Occidental and a few other insurance companies. Starting in the 1960's, Transamerica began to diversify until it assumed its current huge form, and came slap up against its lack of image. **********''Part of the problem is that the name Transamerica doesn't carry over to all the companies,'' Mr. Harvey said. Hence, the appellations of four of them were modified over the last two years to include the parent's name - Transamerica Financial, for example, and Transamerica Interway. Others, most notably the big Occidental Insurance Company, which chips in more than a third of the conglomerate's revenues, are to be tinkered with in the near future. Omitted from the strategy is Budget, since Transamerica feels that the rental agency's name is well fixed in the public mind. In pursuit of implanting the Transamerica name on the tips of the public's tongue, Mr. Harvey reckons that the company has expended some $5 million in the last few years on paperwork and new signs and stationery. For instance, 500 offices of the Transamerica Financial subsidiary required new signs.  Transamerica has also standardized the colors for all of its subsidiaries to red, blue and beige. **********T HE conglomerate hopes to reap considerable recognition mileage out of the change of the Interway Company to Transamerica Interway. All new Interway containers are being painted with the revised name and old ones are repainted when hauled in for repair. About half the containers have been modified, and it's expected that in a few more years the entire fleet will bear the new name. **********''We expect a big impact from all those containers shooting up and down the highways with Transamerica painted on them,'' a Transamerica official says. **********Besides trumpeting its name far and wide, Transamerica is also scouting for ways to spend an enormous accumulation of cash over the next five years. It expects to generate excess cash on the order of $500 million to $1 billion in that five-year stretch, and it doesn't plan to just stuff it in the corporate mattress. **********''The existing companies are all well-positioned in their industries and are all profitable,'' said Frank Herringer, the senior vice president for corporate development and strategic planning, a new position at Transamerica. **********''The problem is, as I see it, that the companies are generally mature,'' he added. ''They're growing, but not extraordinarily rapidly, except for Interway. As a result, they are throwing off cash and not using it. That's okay if you have a couple of companies like that and a few cash-users. But we don't have the cash-users. So, over the next few years we'll be developing a lot of cash and the challenge that faces us is how to use that cash.'' **********Further acquisition is the most likely answer. At the moment, Transamerica is leery of straying into unrelated areas. It would like to buy another property and casualty insurance company. It would like to expand in the manufacturing of precision-engineered products. And it would like to build on United Artists, which has remained essentially a motion picture company while its competitors have been branching out. **********The kind of things United's rivals have been getting into include cable television and the sundry other new video technologies. But price is a problem there. ''We've been shown a number of cable companies and come to what should be a proper price for us to pay, or to even stretch to pay,'' Mr. Herringer said, ''and someone else comes along and pays 75 percent more.'' **********United Artists has been one of the Transamerica's more nettlesome offspring. Rumors abounded last year that the corporate parent had put it on the block. ''All a bunch of baloney,'' Mr. Harvey said.  Many Wall Street observers think that, regardless of its sentiments last year, Transamerica ought to unload the film company now. **********But Mr. Harvey professes to be firm about sticking with it. In December, he shuffled the management about, moving Andy Albeck, the president and chief executive, to chairman and chief executive, and naming Norman Auerbach as the president and chief operating officer.  Mr. Auerbach assumed Mr. Albeck's post after the latter's recent departure. Other executive shuffling has transpired, and still more is rumored to be in the works. Mr. Harvey has also insisted on tighter control of film costs. **********Recent troubles at United Artists date back to January 1978, when the five principal officers stomped out as a result of disgruntlement with Transamerica management. They founded a new company called Orion Pictures, which has steadily lured away much of United Artists' top talent. The most recent defection of note was Woody Allen. **********Mr. Harvey, however, plays down the impact of these developments, and even is sanguine about the prospects for ''Heaven's Gate'' when it is reincarnated as a two-hour film in April. ''Heaven's Gate,'' of course, is Michael Cimino's epic $36 million Western that was yanked from theaters last November after receiving caustic reviews. **********What does Mr. Harvey think about the reams of publicity generated by the movie? ''I hope it will be helpful for 'Heaven's Gate' when the edited version comes out,'' he said. **********Transamerica also believes it would make sense for it to explore buying a hotel chain, which would fit in with its Budget and Transamerica Airlines busi nesses. ''The question there is what is the long-term trend for the travel industry,'' says Mr. Herringer.  ''The big unknown is communications. What is the electronic communications industry going to do to the travel business in 1995?'' **********Budget and Transamerica Airlines executives may offer a glimpse of what that impact would be. They confer on a quarterly basis for planning purposes, at either the airline's headquarters in Oakland or at Budget quarters in Chicago. For the latest meeting, however, the companies opted to hold a teleconference meeting over the phone lines. And they loved it. **********Transamerica is not barren of additional short-term woes. ''What you've got is a lot of nicely-run subsidiaries but if you're going to be in the wrong businesses for 1981 they're in it,'' said Joseph Dowling, an analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''This is a company that has really been hit by the interest-rate problem, and I think they've done well not to be hurt further. They are a financial services company that is probably more exposed than any other financial services company. There's almost no good news for them until the economy improves.'' **********Last year, Transamerica reported a mild increase in earnings, to $245 million from $240.2 million. Revenues grew to $4.4 billion from $4 billion. United Artists suffered a decline, much of it due to a write-off of ''Heaven's Gate'' costs. Interway also suffered mightily from the recession, though it is viewed as a highly promising growth area for the future. For 1981, analysts are anticipating fairly flat results again for Transamerica. Mr. Harvey forecasts a moderate earnings gain. **********LONG-TERM prospects, however, appear quite advantageous.  Transamerica thinks that general population trends bode very much in the favor of a service company. During the 1980's, it points out, the postwar baby boom generation will fall within the 25-to-40-year-old age bracket, which represents big earning and big spending years for most individuals. At the same time, people are living longer and retiring earlier. They, too, will require a heavy supply of entertainment and financial services. **********As for the changing of Transamerica's guard, Mr. Beckett seems happy. ''I've felt very strongly for many years that 20 years in the saddle is long enough for anyone, and maybe too long,'' he said.  ''The new broom sweeps clean.'' He expects to spend less time in the office, and to ''write music, paint a little, play tennis and spend more time with my wife.'' He also will teach an effective management course at the graduate school of business at San Francisco State starting in September. **********Not all company watchers, however, are convinced that Mr. Beckett will switch from a brooding presence to an interested observer who will leave Mr. Harvey alone. ''That's not the way Jack is,'' says Mr. Dowling of Drexel Burnham. ''He's an activist. He built this company from scratch. It's like a mother-in-law: 'You may have married my son, but I don't like the way you treated him.' It's like other top management changes. You get the title now and three years later you get the job.'' **********Mr. Dowling, among others, foresees some differences between the two executives: ''In style, Harvey will probably be more of a private person than Beckett. In content, Beckett tried to stay in financial services, and I think Harvey might stray afield.'' **********One disappointment is that the company has still roused no more than a lackluster response from the Wall Street investment community. ''They're convinced that they run a better show than most of the other financial services companies, but Wall Street has not been reflecting it,'' said John E. O'Neil, an analyst at A.G. Becker. **********''I've worked my heart out for this company,'' Mr. Beckett said.''From a financial record, we have one of the great records. We increased earnings per share in 20 years by 1,400 percent. We've increased the dividend for 19 straight years. Of course, what I feel badly about is that while we've increased earnings per share by 1,400 percent in 20 years our price per share has gone up a little over two times. I only wish I could still be in the saddle while the sales ratio improves. I hope Jim will be able to do a better job of getting to the investors.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.print_headline: Business People; HECTIC DAYS FOR T.W.A.'S FARE EXPERT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.body_text: **********Neil M. Effman, the senior vice president of Trans World Airlines responsible for the carrier's pricing and marketing strategy, gestured at a full-page Air Florida advertisement that ran last week offering a one-way fare of $114 to Miami, Fort Lauderdale and West Palm Beach. That same day, he and his staff worked out T.W.A's response: It would meet Air Florida's lower fares for the high season between Nov. 16 and Jan. 31 to Miami and Fort Lauderdale but would keep its $135 fare to West Palm Beach. **********Over the weekend, however, Eastern Airlines, a big competitor in the New York-to-Florida market, instituted a fare of $124 to West Palm Beach. ''You can't be out there with the highest fare against a major carrier,'' Mr. Effman said in an interview in his 42d-floor ofice in a New York skyscraper. T.W.A. immediately decided to match Eastern's price. **********Mr. Effman observed that deregulation, which lets airlines cut fares and shift routes quickly, has changed his job radically and has increased the uncertainties. Previously there were few fare and route changes, and the pricing, marketing or scheduling departments could go about their business without much contact with each other. **********But when there can be several fare cuts and route shifts a week, Mr. Effman is constantly forced to come up with a quick response to a competitor's move. ''Now there's a lot of action, '' the 46-year-old executive said, ''and you have to integrate your fare decision with your marketing decision.'' **********Mr. Effman, a graduate of City College of New York, joined T.W.A in 1958 and has spent most of his career dealing with pricing and routes. He was placed in charge of long-range planning in 1978, and he became a senior vice president last year. **********Mr. Effman recalled that his parents had urged him to study accounting, which he hated. To satisfy their wishes, he signed up for an advanced accounting course and afterward took a wide range of subjects that interested him. Today he still believes that in college ''you should learn how to think, how to lay out a problem.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/20/busin.main_headline: PAN AM UNIT IS PROFITABLE, AND FOR SALE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/20/busin.print_headline: PAN AM UNIT IS PROFITABLE, AND FOR SALE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/20/busin.body_text: **********Bullets ricocheted around the Amman Intercontinental during Jordan's 1970 civil war. Revolutionaries smashed windows at the Teheran Intercontinental while the Shah's regime was being overthrown. Sheiks have been sauntering through the Riyadh Intercontinental since well before the 1970's oil boom. **********History and revenues have been flowing copiously through the farflung portals of the Intercontinental Hotels Corporation, which is the most profitable subsidiary of ailing Pan American World Airways.  It logged pretax earnings of $23.8 million on operating revenues of $136.7 million for this year's first half. **********A Pan Am spokesman, James A. Arey, said yesterday that negotiations were continuing between Pan Am and an unnamed suitor that has made an offer for Intercontinental, which runs 83 hotels in 48 countries and has more than tripled earnings between 1976 and 1980. He said Pan Am's board would soon meet to discuss the deal. **********At both Pan Am and Intercontinental, executives declined to comment on Wall Street analysts' estimates of the subsidiary's worth - ranging from $250 million to $500 million - and on reports that the offer for Intercontinental was from an expansion-prone British company, Grand Metropolitan Ltd., and that previous bidders included a corporation in Abu Dhabi. **********Intercontinental's performance in recent years and its position in the industry have drawn praise from analysts. ''In the past 10 or 12 years, competition has increased, but Intercontinental has done well in the face of it,'' said Daniel R. Lee, leisure industry analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert, who was formerly with Hilton International. ''They run good hotels, though their hotels are are probably a little older than the Hilton Internationals, in general.'' **********Louis A. Marckesano, senior analyst with Janney Montgomery Scott, said Intercontinental ''has been a nice source of earnings, but up until the last few years, it wasn't as profitable as some of the international chains, such as Hilton International,'' mainly ''because many Intercontinentals were in isolated regions.'' He said, however, that in recent years, Intercontinental's expansion ''has been not so much in underdeveloped areas,'' a strategy he considers positive. **********Nonetheless, Intercontinental produced less income last year and had a lower overall room-occupancy rate than its rival Hilton International, which is owned by the Trans World Corporation, parent company also of Trans World Airlines. Operates 30,400 Rooms **********Service World International, a hotel industry publication, calculated late last year that Intercontinental's total number of hotel rooms operated - the current figure is 30,400 - put it in 15th place among hotel companies with operations in more than one country. First place was held by Holiday Inns, with 303,578 rooms, and one of Intercontinental's chief rivals, Hilton International, was in 16th place with 29,485. **********A network was what Juan Trippe, then Pan Am's president, had in mind when Intercontinental Hotels was formed as a wholly owned Pan Am subsidiary in 1946. Mr. Trippe had been urged by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, according Intercontinental, to help promote tourism and trade to Latin America. Began in Brazil **********The organization began with a hostelry in Belem, Brazil, and grew to 14 hotels within a decade. In 1961, long before the Middle East oil boom of the 1970's, Intercontinental opened its first Middle East hotel - in Beirut - and it now operates nine in that region, with four more being built. **********In the 1960's, Intercontinental moved into Eastern Europe, beginning with a franchise hotel operation in Zagreb, Yugoslavia, and starting new operations in the Far East, Australia, Africa and elsewhere in Europe. **********During the 1970's, while Pan Am's fortunes fluctuated, Intercontinental expanded, including the 1972 founding of its Forum Hotels division to provide relatively inexpensive lodgings. Forum has five hostelries in operation and plans others. **********In addition, Intercontinental has been mapping expansion in the United States, where it already operates four hotels: New York's Barclay, San Francisco's Mark Hopkins and others in San Antonio and Hawaii. Others are others being built in Boston, Fort Lauderdale, Houston and New Orleans, and future growth is planned for Dallas, Los Angeles, San Diego, Chicago and Washington, D.C. **********Intercontinental's $41.6 million in pretax income on 1980 operating revenues of $273.5 million were 23.6 percent better than 1979's pretax earnings of $33.7 million on operating revenues of $259.8 million. **********By contrast, Hilton International in 1980 had pretax income of $65.8 million on total revenues of $628.3 million, up 18.7 percent from $55.5 million on 1979 revenues of $556.3 million. **********Hilton had an overall occupancy rate of 73 percent in 1980 in the 79 hostelries it operated with 28,800 rooms, while Intercontinental's occupancy rate was 69.1 percent for the year. One analyst said that the disparity in performances was partly because Intercontinental still has relatively more of its operations in third world countries that are relatively prone to instability. **********Most of Intercontinental's rooms are in the 76 of its hotels that it operates under lease, management or franchise agreements, rather than owns. It is the owner of only six - the hotels in New York, San Antonio, Vienna and Paris, and in Hanover and Wiesbaden, West Germany - and has a half interest in the London Intercontinental. **********Given that structure, the eventual buyer of Intercontinental ''will be getting mostly an earnings stream,'' one Wall Street analyst said this week. **********As Pan Am's red ink proliferated -it had a net loss of $218 million, the highest in its history, on revenues of $1.968 billion during this year's first six months - there was recurrent speculation that it would sell off all or part of its hotel subsidiary. **********MidEast Report, a New York-based newsletter, reported Aug. 1 that a $450 million offer for Intercontinental Hotels had been made by the Abu Dhabi Hotel Corporation, a subsidiary of the Government-owned Abu Dhabi Investment Authority.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/21/world.main_headline: BEIRUT THREATENS TO ASK FOR SANCTIONS ON ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/21/world.print_headline: BEIRUT THREATENS TO ASK FOR SANCTIONS ON ISRAEL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/21/world.body_text: **********Lebanon said today that it would seek sanctions against Israel unless the Israelis agree to halt their attacks. **********Ghassan Tueni, Beirut's chief delegate here, said at a news conference that he would ask the Security Council to ''condemn Israeli aggression'' and ''resort to sanctions'' if Israel continues its attacks by air, sea and land. **********Mr. Tueni did not specify the precise nature of the sanctions he might seek. The United Nations Charter provides for imposing embargoes on the shipment of commercial and military products to nations threatening peace. **********In private, Arab diplomats said they expected Lebanon to wait until noon tomorrow before pressing the Council to act. A key factor is believed to be the mission of Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East. He is attempting to gain Prime Minister Menachem Begin's assent to a cease-fire. Diplomats in all camps here believe that reports of Mr. Begin flatly turning down Mr.  Habib are too categorical. Arafat Meets U.N. Commander **********It is taken for granted at the United Nations that Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, will readily agree to halt his organization's shelling of Israeli towns. Mr.  Arafat met in Beirut today with Lieut. Gen. William Callaghan, the Irish commander of the United Nations peacekeeping forces in southern Lebanon. The P.L.O. chief is understood to have said, in effect, that his forces will stop firing if Israel will. **********If Mr. Habib fails to arrange a cease-fire, the United States will confront a difficult set of political choices in the Council. It could veto a cease-fire resolution linked to sanctions, but that would upset America's key friends in the Arab world - Egypt and Saudi Arabia. **********If Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American delegate, votes in favor of the resolution, she will anger Mr. Begin's Government and its supporters in the United States. Until recently, American support for sanctions against Israel was considered inconceivable. But a resolution carefully drafted to rebuke violence by all sides and to suggest the possibility of punishment for failure to abide by a cease-fire at a future date might gain American assent. American support would be even more likely if it appeared that Britain and France might back such a document, isolating the United States. **********American diplomats made no secret of their uneasiness over this problem, placing an even greater premium on Mr. Habib's mission. 'I Am Encouraged' **********Mr. Tueni, who saw Mrs. Kirkpatrick last night, said, ''I am encouraged by the attitude of Washington.'' Asked if he believed that the Reagan Administration had secretly encouraged Israel to bomb Beirut and other points in Lebanon, the Lebanese delegate said, ''I have heard that accusation but I doubt it.'' **********Mr. Tueni said Lebanon had no interest in resolutions or speeches but wanted action from the United Nations. He said he had suggested to the Council President, Ide Oumarou of Niger, that a resolution on the issue should have four elements: an immediate cease-fire with a mechanism to carry it out; condemnation of ''Israeli aggression and its policy of pre-emptive strikes''; a provision for '' sanctions contingent on non-compliance,'' and a report by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim on implementation of the resolution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/busin.body_text: **********The LTV Corporation said that it would install a $165 million continuous caster at its Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation Indiana Harbor Works in East Chicago, Ind. The company said the two-strand caster would be the first of its type in the Western Hemisphere. **********Two similar casters are being built in Japan.  LTV also announced plans to rebuild two coke oven batteries at J.& L.'s Campbell Works in Youngstown, Ohio. The caster and the coke oven projects are part of a $315 million capital expenditure program announced by LTV. **********Thomas Graham, J.& L. president and chief executive, said the batteries at the Youngstown plant are ''at the end of their life.'' He said the expenditure represented ''a recommitment to that existing capacity.'' **********J.& L., one of the nation's largest steel concerns, plans to make the expenditures in 1982-1985.  Mr. Graham said the caster had been designed by Jones & Laughlin engineers to save production costs and energy, and improve yield and quality. The caster is expected to be able to process 260,400 slab tons of steel a month and will be completed in 30 months. **********Shipments from the Indiana Harbor Works are expected to jump 12 percent on completion of the project, Mr. Graham said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.main_headline: U.S. STUDY SEES REPRISAL PERIL IN NEUTRON WEAPONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.print_headline: U.S. STUDY SEES REPRISAL PERIL IN NEUTRON WEAPONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.body_text: **********United States deployment of neutron warheads in Western Europe might ''increase Soviet propensities'' to use regular nuclear weapons in a war, according to a Government report made public today. **********The report stressed that neutron warheads, which are designed to kill people by radiation, avoiding widespread blast and fire damage, would in the end have only slight effect in limiting destructiveness of a nuclear war in Europe. **********The assessment was contained in a report on more than 90 weapons systems prepared by the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and other agencies and submitted to Congress by the Carter Administration. **********A heavily censored version of the statement was released by the House Foreign Affairs Committee.  It concluded that placing neutron warheads on missiles and artillery shells ''would have only slight impact on the course of ongoing arms control negotiations, efforts to stem nuclear proliferation, deterrence and stability in Europe, or the destructiveness of war should it occur.'' **********Fitting the warheads, known as enhanced-radiation weapons, to missiles and artillery shells might help deter nuclear war, the report said, but at the same time ''could increase Soviet propensities to initiate the use of nuclear weapons if they have decided to go to war.'' Carter Deferred Weapon in 1978 **********In 1978 President Jimmy Carter decided to defer the neutron warhead amid controversy in Western Europe. Recently, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger renewed the neutron debate when he said he favored deploying the warhead to restore ''some kind of balance'' along the North Atlantic Treaty Organization front. **********The report made public today said that the prospects of a United States decision to deploy neutron weapons had been incorrectly perceived by many as representing a change in doctrine that would make use of nuclear weapons more likely in a limited war. But it added that modernization of nuclear weapons deployed for a war in Europe and improvements in conventional weapons could diminish the risk of nuclear war by providing a more credible deterrent. **********The report said that the use of neutron warheads, instead of regular nuclear weapons, would be no less likely to provoke a Soviet retaliation with nuclear battlefield weapons, leading to the very damage that neutron weapons were meant to avoid. Chemical Warfare Problems **********The report said an American program to upgrade military protection against chemical warfare risked possible misunderstanding because such protection was needed for both defense and attack. But it said better protection for United States forces should have a positive, though modest, arms-control effect by lessening an enemy's incentive to use chemical weapons. **********By maintaining its own stockpile of chemical weapons, the report said, the United States contributed to a climate for negotiating a ban on them. But it said that full compliance with a ban on producing, stockpiling, acquiring and retaining chemical warfare agents and munitions, as sought by the United States, could take at least 10 years. **********Soviet efforts in research and development of chemical weapons, training and operational equipment have continued, the report went on. Referring to chemical warfare, it added: ''Soviet forces are the best prepared and equipped in the world to operate in a CW environment produced either by an enemy or themselves.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/19/world.print_headline: HELMUT SCHMIDT: LAST YEAR'S CRITIC, TODAY'S SUITOR; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/19/world.body_text: **********He has said it himself: Helmut Schmidt, a source of international envy and admiration a year ago, is a politician in trouble, a man urgently in need of friends. His threat on Sunday to resign over his party's problems with the **********NATO nuclear modernization program is not only an acknowledgment of difficulties in governing but a mortgage on his future. His most vital assets - his personality and his presence - are being put up as collateral after only eight months of a four-year term. **********As a result, the West German Chancellor, leader of the United States' most important ally, will be politically hobbled when he goes to Washington on Wednesday for talks with President Reagan. **********Mr. Schmidt has become a supplicant. A year ago, it was the Carter Administration that was unsuccessfully beseeching him to react more vigorously to the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. Now, with detente in tatters, West Germany's economy in recession and his own Social Democrats rebelling against him, Mr. Schmidt very much needs good relations with the United States. Statement of Good Intentions **********His remarks over the weekend, denouncing anti-American and pro-Soviet trends in his party while tying his fate to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's nuclear modernization program, can be viewed as a statement of good intentions to the Reagan Administration. **********In exchange, Mr. Schmidt would apparently like the trip to seem successful and his treatment by the United States to show he is held in respect. In addition, he would like the Americans to avoid loading him down with demands, particularly about defense, while he fights for the NATO plan to bring a new generation of medium-range nuclear weapons to Western Europe. **********With the Christian Democratic opposition waiting to call in Mr.  Schmidt's mortgage and the Social Democrats in danger of losing the Free Democrats as a coalition partner, the Chancellor will need considerable energy to convince the Reagan Administration that he is still a winner. His strongest argument is that the Social Democrats can best guarantee support for the NATO decision and that he can best fight the growing faction in the party opposed to the missile program. **********Although other factors are involved, Mr. Schmidt's troubles at home are significantly related to his attitude toward the United States. Critic of Carter Policies **********In the last years of the Carter Administration, particularly when it was demanding a more combative West German attitude toward the Soviet Union after the intervention in Afghanistan, Mr. Schmidt made clear that he felt American policies were confused, unpredictable and potentially dangerous. His palpable contempt tended to legitimize anti-American attitudes within the party that he must now combat to survive. **********The effort by some Social Democrats to portray the United States as the greatest threat to detente was accelerated in the first nine months of 1980. Former Chancellor Willy Brandt made a series of speeches in which he lumped the United States and the Soviet Union together as similar mammoths, both disagreable and more or less equally responsible for the tensions in the world. The party's deputy parliamentary leader, Herbert Wehner, described Soviet military power as defensive rather than offensive in character, calling the Soviet presence in Afghanistan a ''preventive'' measure. **********Although he was keeping his distance from Washington at the time, Mr. Schmidt warned at least once about what seemed to be a distorted view of reality. But the warnings were included in the customary party discourse about detente in a way that left the Social Democratic rank and file able to interpret the Chancellor's remarks as obligatory gestures to quiet the Americans. Such an interpretation seemed reasonable because Mr. Schmidt's friends often talked last summer about creating a broad European front that would permit the Chancellor's allies in the West and the East to block Soviet-American confrontations or steer clear of them. Polish Upheaval Alters Situation **********The situation changed radically in August, when the Polish upheaval began to undermine 10 years of calm and stability in central Europe.  The Social Democrats did not do as well as they expected in the West German elections last October. Although Mr. Schmidt was returned to office, he was privately blamed for running a campaign that was too personal and insufficiently ideological. **********Critics in the party accused him of reacting too pragmatically to the new threats in Eastern Europe. Detente, for the left wing of the party, had always been the key to its hopes for making West Germany independent of the United States and NATO. However, Mr. Schmidt was talking about the necessity of matching the Soviet missile arsenal. **********The debate about the missiles during the winter filled a spiritual vacuum in the party. The recession had eliminated new plans for social change and the Polish situation had suspended hopes for progress in relations with East Germany. The emotional issue that remained was disarmament, and the frustrations of the party's left wing were easily mobilized to fight new missiles on West German soil.  Schmidt Aides Lose Party Posts **********Feeding on the psychological conditions that were created during the year of contempt for the Carter Administration, the groups opposing the missiles gained considerable strength at the roots of party and initiated a movement at the Social Democrats' national convention last year to end support for the NATO plan. The movement gained enough strength to force two Cabinet-level officials out of their seats on a party regional council two weeks ago after they supported the Chancellor's position. **********Mr. Schmidt's aim in publicly warning of his own resignation is to cut the trend short while there is enough time for the more moderate members of the party, particularly in the trade unions, to organize a counteroffensive. **********If the threat works, Mr. Schmidt may be free to attack and isolate the party's left wing, and reverse his poor standing in public opinion polls. The surveys indicate that he is held in lower esteem than Mr. Brandt was when he resigned in 1974. **********Unless there is some immediate effect, however, Mr. Schmidt may find that he moved too soon. Without some evidence of his threat working, the issue may immobilize him and lead to a loss of confidence in him by the Free Democrats.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/26/world.main_headline: NEW POLISH MILITARY RULERS: AN OLD-BOY NETWORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/26/world.print_headline: NEW POLISH MILITARY RULERS: AN OLD-BOY NETWORK
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/26/world.body_text: **********United States military analysts say that the Polish military council ruling under martial law appears to be a cohesive group of accomplished professional officers. **********The analysts, who acknowledged that they were caught unawares when the 21-man council took over, said they found the council divided into two layers. At the top were 14 senior generals, most of them also in the Communist Party leadership; at the bottom were younger proteges and men with technical expertise. **********The analysts also emphasized that the council was made up of strong nationalists. ''All of these people are first of all Poles and second of all Communists,'' one analyst said. **********The ruling officers were said to have close ties with military colleagues in the Soviet Union and other Eastern European nations.  Several have served with the high command of the Warsaw Pact, the alliance led by the Soviet Union. **********The analysts cautioned, however, that there were still many gaps in their information on the council. They suggested that such a shortcoming could hamper United States policy decisions. Colonel Is Unidentified **********The analysts said they were still unable to identify Col. Tadeusz Makarewicz, a council member whose name had not been seen before and whose post was unknown. He was listed in the second layer of the council. **********The cohesion among the top layer, according to the analysts, arises from several factors. The officers are all about the same age, born in the early 1920's, and served in World War II, either as guerrillas or with Polish units that fought alongside the Russians. **********The analysts said the group did not include officers who had served with emigre Polish forces that fought in Western units during that war. Such officers have long since been eased out or purged, they said. **********The analysts said the officers in the council seemed to have known each other for nearly 40 years. With the exception of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the head of the council, the other army officers in the council are lieutenant generals, not major generals as reported earlier. Absence of Military Discord **********Although eight other lieutenant generals were not selected for the council, the analysts said that those named included all the generals who might have expected to be chosen. That suggests, they said, an absence of military dissidents outside the council. **********The analysts said that the council appeared to be made up of welleducated men. Some of their early and intermediate military education was in Polish command and general staff schools, they said, while the highest military education took place in war colleges in the Soviet Union. **********Lieut. Gen. Czeslaw Piotrowski, the former chief of engineers and current Minister of Mining and Power, was reported to have earned a doctor of philosphy degree in military science and a master of science degree in civil engineering. **********Among the younger members, Brig. Gen. Michal Janiszewski, who appears to be head of the council's secretariat, studied at the technical university in Gdansk, the Soviet Academy of Communications and the Polish Academy of General Staff. **********Since most members of the council have studied in the Soviet Union, the analysts said, they are believed to speak Russian. That means they can communicate directly with Russian military officers and leaders - a point that may prove important in the days ahead as the Soviet Union decides whether to send its forces into Poland. **********The military analysts said they believed that the majority of the members of the council were professional soldiers who would prefer to go back to their military duties if they set Poland's economy on its feet and stabilize the political situation. **********But they also speculated that the senior military officers might succumb to the temptation to remain in power, even though that has not been the pattern in Eastern Europe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/busin.main_headline: BANKRUPTCY PETITION IS FILED BY O.P.M.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/busin.print_headline: BANKRUPTCY PETITION IS FILED BY O.P.M.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/busin.body_text: **********O.P.M. Leasing Services Inc., which is under investigation because of reports that it put together questionable computer leasing arrangements, filed for reorganization yesterday under the Chapter 11 provisions of the Bankruptcy Act. **********The Manhattan-based company, one of the nation's largest computer leasing companies, listed liabilities of $504 million and assets of $446 million in its petition for court protection from creditors while it reorganizes its affairs. **********The bankruptcy petition was filed before Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lefland in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. **********The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan said Tuesday that it was ''investigating allegations related to O.P.M.'' This was prompted by industry reports questioning the concern's ability to honor leases on computer equipment that involve financing from major banks and Wall Street investment houses. **********According to O.P.M.'s petition, the details of which were supplied by its law firm, Anderson, Russell, Kill & Olick, the Securities and Exchange Commission has started an investigation into O.P.M.'s dealings with the Rockwell International Corporation, an O.P.M.  customer. The investigation by the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan is proceeding along similar lines, the petition stated. **********In recent days, several lending institutions have disclosed what appear to be ''discrepancies'' between the lease equipment schedules in their files involving O.P.M. equipment and the schedules found in O.P.M. files, according to the petition. **********In explaining why it was seeking court protection, O.P.M. said that its ''financial embarrassment'' arose from a severe problem of liquidity and changing economic conditions in the industry. It cited the introduction of the International Business Machines Corporation's 303X computer and, later, the 4300 computer, which O.P.M. said created major technological changes and ''greatly reduced costs,'' and caused older equipment to fall in value. **********Because of that, the petition said, ''a large number of the debtor's user lessees exercised early termination options in their leases. As a result, the debtor is now obligated to pay substantial sums of money to the user lessees.'' **********Philip Ryan, formerly an assistant United States Attorney and a former lawyer for the General Electric Credit Corporation, has been appointed executive vice president and director of O.P.M., the petition said. Mr. Ryan was in the process of naming an auditing concern for the company, to fill a void that has existed for several years, the petition said. 'To the Extent It Can' **********O.P.M. said in its brief that its intention was ''to investigate all allegations and to discharge its obligations to all creditors to the extent it can,'' given the Chapter 11 action and its assets. **********Under Chapter 11 provisions, an insolvent company seeks to obtain court protection against suits from creditors while it continues to operate and prepares a plan for reorganization and payment of debts.  The bankruptcy judge and major creditors must approve the proposed plan. **********According to industry sources, O.P.M., which has leased computers to some of the nation's biggest corporations, offered low lease rates to customers through leases that ran as long as eight years, in contrast with industry practice basing payments on leases of three to four years to account for the rapidly changing technology that limits a computer's useful life. **********The long-term leases, signed by major companies with impeccable credit ratings, helped O.P.M. obtain financing for the computers.  However, according to the reports, O.P.M. told customers they could terminate their leases in two to three years in the event their computers became obsolete and could not be re-marketed for the full monthly leasing rate. Allegedly Lacked Insurance **********O.P.M. reportedly told these customers that it would cover any financial loss caused by the remarketing of obsolete equipment, although it allegedly lacked insurance to cover this exposure. **********O.P.M. is controlled by Mordecai Weissman, its president, and Myron Goodman, who resigned as executive vice president last week. Each owns 50 percent of Cali Trading International Ltd., which, in turn, owns O.P.M. Neither Mr. Weissman nor Mr. Goodman nor their lawyers could be reached by telephone late yesterday for comment on the bankruptcy petition. **********It is unclear whether companies that have leased computers from O.P.M. or the investors in the leasing arrangements would be forced to absorb losses that might result from O.P.M.'s inability to honor its agreements. **********The bankruptcy petition must be approved by the court before O.P.M. can gain protection from creditors.  O.P.M. was requested several years ago to end its membership in the former Computer Lessors Association, a trade group since replaced by the Computer Dealers and Lessors Association, when O.P.M. refused to provide financial information.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/20/busin.body_text: **********Robert B. Holmes, 49, has been named president and chief executive officer of Aristar Inc., a consumer finance and insurance corporation. He succeeds E. Arnold Lewin, 64, who retired from the Coral Gables, Fla., company. **********Aristar, which operates largely in the Southeastern states, had earnings of more than $8 million in 1980 on revenues of $350 million. At the end of last year, its total assets amounted to $720 million. **********''I will be trying to expand the business into related financial services in the United States through internal growth and acquisition,'' Mr. Holmes said. ''For example, we'd look at other types of insurance, lending or tax services.'' **********Mr. Holmes began his career in 1954 at the New England Merchants National Bank and moved to Lazard Freres & Company 10 years later, where he became a general partner. He joined Ticor in 1977 as executive vice president and chief financial officer, becoming its president and chief operating officer about two years later. **********Mr. Lewin spent most of his career with the Household Finance Corporation. He joined Aristar approximately five years ago and later was promoted to president. **********According to Mr. Holmes, his company ''is obviously impacted by high interest rates.'' He added, ''But there are still a lot of expansion possibilities.'

Bluhdorn, chairman of G.&W., had told National that ''this purchase was for investment purposes only.'' The spokesman had no further comment. **********National Steel makes iron, steel and aluminum products. Gulf and Western is a diversified financial and industrial concern.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/world.main_headline: IN THE U.S., POLISH ACTION STIRS PROTEST AND PRAYER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/world.print_headline: IN THE U.S., POLISH ACTION STIRS PROTEST AND PRAYER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/world.body_text: **********With noisy demonstrations and silent prayers, with angry statements and fervent appeals for justice, tens of thousands of Polish-Americans across the nation voiced outrage and despair yesterday at Poland's declaration of martial law and the arrest of Solidarity union leaders. **********Across the New York metropolitan area and in Chicago, Philadelphia and other centers of Polish-American life, the outpouring was emotional but restrained and nonviolent as workers, scholars, writers, clergymen and diplomats spoke of fears and hopes for their beleaguered homeland. **********In homes, churches, meeting halls, cafes and streets swept by wintry winds, there were countless expressions of concern over possible civil war in Poland similar to the uprisings that wracked Hungary in 1956 and Czechoslovakia in 1968. **********And there were widespread fears that Soviet military intervention might bring rumbling tanks and bloodshed to the streets of Warsaw, Gdansk and other Polish cities in the days to come. Telephone Contacts Severed **********With a communications blackout severing telephone and other contacts with friends and relatives in Poland, there was also widespread concern over loved ones and acquaintances. **********But in nearly every gathering, there was a sense that the crackdown in Poland had not been an unexpected development, coming as it had after more than a year of mounting tensions and confrontation between the Warsaw Government and the militant labor movement, whose voice of dissent has grown powerful and strident. **********Indeed, some said they thought Warsaw's action had been virtually inevitable, particularly to avert Soviet intervention, after the union's call on Saturday for a national referendum on setting up a non-Communist government. It was most direct threat yet against the regime of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. **********Chants of ''Long Live Lech Walesa,'' ''Down With Communism'' and ''Freedom for Poland'' echoed off the facades of the Polish Consulate and the Soviet Mission to the United Nations in Manhattan yesterday as hundreds of flag-waving, placard-carrying Polish-Americans staged noisy but orderly demonstrations in the afternoon. Fear Voiced for Union Leaders **********''I'm afraid for the lives of thousands of Solidarity leaders in Poland and for the fate of millions,'' said Irena Lasota, a leader of a 1968 Polish student uprising, who helped organize yesterday's protest. **********As she spoke, more than 300 people -members of the Polish-American Congress, the Confederation for Independent Poland, the Association of Polish Veterans and other groups - marched in circles and shouted angry slogans in East 37th Street, just east of Madison Avenue, outside the baroque, four-story, white-stone Polish Consulate. **********The consulate doors remained locked during the two-hour protest, but now and then heavy draperies in the windows parted and men with cameras could be seen taking pictures of the demonstrators. Later, the crowd moved uptown to the Soviet Mission on 67th Street near Lexington Avenue and continued the demonstration. **********Though the demonstrators had not obtained permits for the protests, the police made no effort to intervene, and there were no arrests or incidents, though at one point the police tore down a bedsheet sign that had been scrawled with ''Solidarnosc'' in red letters and hung over the consulate door, blocking the entryway. In Brooklyn, People Await News **********In the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, a mostly Polish neighborhood, clusters of people gathered in coffee shops and cigarette stands and huddled beside radios, waiting for news from Warsaw. **********''The people in this neighborhood are talking of little else today and they are worried,'' said the Rev. Joseph Spilski of St.  Stanislaus Kostka Roman Catholic Church, most of whose 2,500 parishioners are of Polish descent. He said he could ''see their concern on their faces at mass this morning.'' **********''We prayed for Poland this morning,'' said the Rev. John Harchula, pastor of the Polish National Catholic Church of the Resurrection. ''It was very emotional. Many members of the congregation broke down. I'm very, very sorry that it came to this. I came back from Poland three months ago and could feel that the steam kettle was about to blow.'' **********Polish-Americans in New Jersey expressed shock over the weekend's developments and a sense of frustration at being unable to aid friends and relatives in Poland. ''We're stunned,'' said the Rev.  Adam Ziolkowki of St. John Kanty Roman Catholic Church in Clifton.  ''No one wants to overreact, but there is great concern and a feeling of helplessness.'' Differing Views of Solidarity **********There were also some conflicting views of Solidarity. ''They're trying to change things for the better for the people,'' said Henry Pastuszak, proprietor of Stanley's Restaurant in Passaic, referring to the union movement. **********But Chester Grabowski of Clifton, publisher of The Post-Eagle, a weekly Polish-American newspaper, said: ''The Solidarity boys are moving a little too fast. You can't change ideology overnight. Poland has had so many years of suffering. The people should be more practical and tactful and take a little piece at a time.'' **********John Cardinal Krol, the Archbishop of Philadelphia, who is of Polish descent and has been active in many programs to aid Poland, called the declaration of martial law ''drastic action'' and ''distressing but not surprising.'' **********He said the inference could be drawn that Poland's Communist Party feared it would lose any referendum on the establishment of a new government, and he added: ''It is our fervent prayer that the influence of moderates on both sides will prevail.'' Prayers Offered in Chicago **********In Chicago, home to 600,000 Polish-Americans, a greater concentration of ethnic Poles than in any city outside Warsaw, prayers were offered in churches for an end to strife in Poland.  Community leaders spoke of widespread fears for loved ones and in taverns and cafes on the northwest side, tense conversations in Polish and halting English focused on Poland and its patriots. **********''The Polish people are in trouble,'' said Jozef Jasiak, a gift shop owner. ''They don't like Communism. My son, my wife are in Cracow.'' An organization to which Mr. Jasiak belongs sent 3,000 packages to Poland this year, containing ''90 percent food - ham, bacon, sugar, coffee, everything.'' **********At the nearby Kasztelanka Restaurant, Leopold Holweger, who left Poland in 1965 to become an American citizen, said amid sips of coffee and clouds of cigarette smoke, ''It's a bad situation -how will the people stay organized? **********''There's only one way to fight Communism, and that's revolution,'' said his friend, Zbigniew Uchanski, a jeweler from Cracow. 'For Freedom, You Have to Fight' **********Mr. Holweger reluctantly agreed. ''There has to be blood on the street,'' he said. ''For freedom, you have to fight.'' ''We don't think the Polish Army will shoot Polish workers,'' said Mr. Uchanski, ''but Russian soldiers in Polish uniforms might do it.  Every Western country must help Poland.'' **********Many Polish-Americans said the Government's martial law declaration and its moves against Solidarity had been expected. ''I'm shocked and a little horrified,'' said Aloysius Mazewski, president of both the Polish National Alliance and the Polish-American Congress. ''I am very appalled, but I was expecting that something was bound to happen.'' **********Many people wanted to call their families and friends in Poland.  But with communictions cut off, ''we can only pray,'' said one Chicago Polish-American leader, Alderman Roman Pucinski, who is also president of the Illinois Division of the Polish-American Congress. **********Roman Koperskin, an editor of the Pomost Social Political Quarterly, said the turmoil in Poland had frightened Polish-Americans. ''Many were expecting relatives from Poland to visit them for Christmas,'' he said, ''but now the communications and transportation have been cut off. They don't know what will happen.'' Pomost is the Polish-American youth organization. Intellectuals' Attitudes Vary **********There were differing views from Polish intellectuals on possible reactions to the crackdown by the Polish Government.  Stanislas Baranczak, a visiting professor at Harvard and a founder of KOR, a dissident group that predated Solidarity, called the action a tactical blunder and said: ''The Polish people can't be suppressed in this way. This will only strengthen reaction against the Government.'' **********But Czeslaw Miros, Poland's 1980 Nobel Prize winner for literature who is also at Harvard as a visiting lecturer, said: ''People have shown a lot of restraint, wisdom and maturity until now. I wouldn't expect any drastic developments at the present moment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Further evidence of television's pervasive reach into American life comes from the A.C. Nielsen Company in estimates based on recently released 1980 census figures on housing. The data showed that more than 80 million American homes now have TV sets - a 2.7 percent increase from figures compiled as recently as last September, when Nielsen's latest annual survey was taken. **********The latest figures will be used in the May and July ''sweeps,'' Nielsen's broadest check of television viewership, surveys that are critical in determining the rates that stations charge advertisers.  Large and fast-growing markets command the highest ad fees, and owners of television stations in those areas tend to see their licenses appreciate sharply in value. **********The latest report showed no change in the ranking of the top 10 markets. The New York and the Los Angeles/ Palm Springs areas both registered declines in the number of homes with television. But they nevertheless remain far and away the nation's largest television markets. Of the top 10, Dallas-Fort Worth showed the largest rise; more than 9 percent. **********There was some shifting in the second tier of leading markets.  Houston, Miami-Fort Lauderdale, Indianapolis-Lafayette, Ind., and Tampa-St. Petersburg all recorded gains. Of those, the Tampa market showed the fastest growth, as households increased more than 17 percent, pushing the area up to 13th from 18th on the national list. **********In the booming Sun Belt, two Florida metropolitan areas, West Palm Beach-Fort Pierce and Fort Myers-Naples, where the numbers swelled 35 percent and 25 percent, respectively, expanded the most rapidly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/busin.body_text: **********The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation of Houston has signed a letter of intent with the Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation of Houston and the Algonquin Gas Transmission Company of Boston to become a partner with them in the New England states pipeline project. **********Each company plans to become a one-third partner in construction of the proposed $600 million natural gas pipeline, which would run about 350 miles from the Canadian border near St. Stephen, New Brunswick, to Algonquin's existing facilities near Burrillville, R.I. **********The companies will share equally in agreements with Pan-Alberta Gas Ltd. for 300 million cubic feet of Canadian natural gas a day.  The pipeline could be in operation in 1984, assuming timely receipt of all necessary Government approval.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/24/busin.body_text: **********Archie McCardell, chairman of the troubled International Harvester Company, predicted today that the company would suffer a ''substantial loss'' in the first quarter of 1982, following a loss of $635.7 million on continuing operations for the fiscal year 1981. **********In the fiscal year 1980, Harvester sank $374.8 million into the red.  Mr. McCardell made his prediction as the company was announcing the completion of a $4.2 billion financial restructuring plan, which Harvester officials said was the largest in American corporate history. **********The remarks on losses underscored the company's assertion that completion of the financing agreement -after months of negotiation - was only an inital step in pulling the company back from the brink of bankruptcy. 'Volatile Environment' **********''The environment is going to be much more volatile than in the past,'' Mr. McCardell asserted, explaining that demand for the company's heavy trucks, farm machinery and construction equipment could in the coming years be as much as 30 percent below the levels that existed in the late 1970's. Harvester said that its business plan for 1982 assumes that its markets will shrink 10 percent to 15 percent from this year's depressed levels. **********In the past, the company has been severely criticized for its rosy projections and for not trimming operations in anticipation of the worst. Harvester said today that it can adjust its operations to the worst economic assumptions. **********The company has announced plans to reopen its contract with the United Automobile Workers early next year. It is asking the union for concessions of $100 million a year in the form of more liberal work rules and fewer fringe benefits. **********Mr. McCardell said that Harvester would continue to divest itself of underperforming assets, estimating that the company still had ''several hundred millions of underutilized assets.'' He denied, however, that there were plans to sell the beleaguered construction equipment business, but he implied that certain products in that division might be phased out. **********Inventories are to be cut further and the holiday shutdown of some plants may be extended into February. Harvester estimated that its plants will operate at only 33 percent of capacity in the first quarter of the fiscal year 1982, which ends on Jan. 31. **********More components will be purchased from outside the company as old high-cost production facilities are phased out. Salaries of management and clerical employees will remain frozen, a move that saved the company $45 million in the fiscal year 1981. Capital expenditures will be reduced to ''the absolute minimum,'' according to Mr. McCardell. **********Mr. McCardell dismissed suggestions that he and Warren Hayford, the president, would find it easier to win concessions from the auto workers if they gave back bonuses of $1.8 million for Mr. McCardell and $900,000 for Mr. Hayford, given them last year by the board of directors. **********''We've spent a lot of time trying to undo this - trying to figure out a way that would make it as if it never happened,'' he said.  ''But we haven't found a way that we could do it without helping me.'' **********Mr. McCardell said that his bonus -actually a loan that was given in stages - all went to buy Harvester stock. He says that because of interest payments, taxes and paper losses on the stock's decline in the market, he had suffered losses of $500,000 in the value of the bonus. To undo the agreement would wipe out his losses, he maintained. **********Harvester said several covenants had been attached to the new financial agreement, which transforms the company's $3.5 billion in short-term debt into a term loan maturing in December 1983. The plan also calls for the sale of $750 million in receivables of Harvester's financing subsidiary. **********In addition, cash interest payments will be only at the rate of 11 percent for the credit subsidiary and not more than 16 percent for the parent company. Paper, convertible to equity, will be issued for the difference between the cash interest payments and prevailing markets rates during the two-year agreement. **********Included among covenants are restrictions on the payment of dividends on common and preferred stock. The fixed assets of the parent company and some receivables of the credit corporation will serve as collateral for the new term loans. **********Harvester gained 62 1/2 cents, to $8.25, on the New York Stock Exchange today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/busin.main_headline: ALASKANS SEE A DELAY IN GAS LINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/busin.print_headline: ALASKANS SEE A DELAY IN GAS LINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/busin.body_text: **********An increasing number of Alaskans are coming to the conclusion that construction of a natural gas pipeline from Prudhoe Bay to the Canadian border will not begin within the next year or two, mainly because of financial and political problems. **********Typical of those who expect building to be delayed is Gov. Jay Hammond, who said in a recent interview that he believed ''the gas line will be built -some day.'' **********A major financial problem is that there has not yet been any reaction to a borrowing presentation last month seeking $22.5 billion from a group of banks and insurance companies. **********Another hitch involves the three oil companies that own 95 percent of the natural gas in Prudhoe Bay: They are concerned about a Federal law that prohibits them from owning part of the gas pipeline that they are expected to help to finance. **********'Significant Amount of Gas' **********While there is growing pessimism about when the pipeline will be started, Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Alaska Republican, told members of the Fartherest North Press Club recently, ''the economics of Alaska gas are based on a very significant amount of gas for a long period of time.'' The Prudhoe gas reserves have been estimated at 26 trillion cubic feet. Total annual production in the United States is 20 trillion cubic feet. **********The Alaskan portion of the line, to be built by a consortium called the Northwest Alaskan Pipeline Company, is to follow the existing oil line south from Prudhoe Bay, then parallel the Alcan Highway southeast. Other groups are to bring the line south from the Canadian border to Edmonton, Alberta, where it will branch to a western leg ending near San Francisco and an eastern one to Chicago. **********The southern legs are to be built first, moving Canadian gas to the United States. Alaska gas would ultimately replace the Canadian supplies. **********There is not yet a firm estimate of what the gas will cost American consumers. Estimates have ranged from $10 to $15 for a thousand cubic feet. Gas currently exported by Canada costs less than $5 a thousand cubic feet. Deliveries Now Set for 1986-87 **********Planners in the companies that own the gas now talk of deliveries in 1986-87. A year ago, plans called for service to begin in 1985.  Two weeks ago Harold Moles, vice president of Northwest Alaskan Pipeline, said, ''We have not quite given up on November 1985, but 1986 looks more realistic.'' **********None of the delays that have pushed the start of construction back a year stem from the engineering concerns that afflicted the Trans Alaska Pipeline System in its planning stages a decade ago. Nothing like the TAPS line, which brings oil from Prudhoe Bay to the Alaskan port of Valdez, had ever been done. **********''Midyear will see the preliminary designs engineered and the costs well established,'' said Lieut. Gov. Terry Miller, who has been a nonvoting member of the project's design and engineering board. The state owns 12.5 percent of the gas as its royalty share. **********Engineers and survey crews working out of the gas pipeline's offices have the oil line's successful experiments to depend on as they reach crucial decision points, and can avoid TAPS' mistakes.  They are currently making extensive tests in permafrost on the line's behavior when buried in constantly frozen soil. The oil line was elevated on individually engineered supports in those areas, an immense expense. Political and Financial Problems **********The financing is one major unresolved issue.  A group of four banks and two insurance companies was asked on May 21 to set up $22.5 billion in financing, with 30 percent of the equity being provided by the oil companies that own the gas and 70 percent coming from the construction consortium. **********The banks involved were Chase Manhattan, Citicorp, Bank of America and Morgan Guaranty; the insurance companies were Prudential and Metropolitan Life. They have not yet responded to the proposal. **********Changes in Federal law that govern the pipeline are the other area of concern. Two of these are crucial, according to sources within the group that proposes to build the line. **********First, the Exxon Corporation, the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), which own the gas at Prudhoe Bay, have balked over the prohibition against their owning part of the line they are expected to help pay to build. When the Carter Administration wrote the law authorizing the pipeline, the Department of Justice antitrust division wanted the oil companies barred from ownership. **********The consortium of 11 gas distribution firms that owns Northwest Alaskan Pipeline as a partnership has agreed to have the oil companies own 30 percent of the project. Paying for Conditioning Plant **********The oil companies are also concerned about the provision that requires them to pay for the conditioning plant that cleans up the gas before it enters the pipeline system. **********As things stand now, this plant would be considered a part of the oilfield development. The companies are insisting that the plant be considered part of the pipeline, which would allow it to be paid for in part from gas transport fees. **********This costing arrangement is crucial to the oil companies. They will not participate under the current conditions, one source said.  The banks and insurance companies were told that the cost of the line would be $21 billion, that the conditioning plant would cost $6 billion and that a precommitted sum described as a completion assurance pool of $3 billion would be set up to meet cost overruns.  The oil companies have agreed to provide equity and debt of $9 billion to cover their share. **********With a debt-equity ratio of 75/25 percent, the oil companies must provide $2.25 billion equity and $6.75 billion in debt, while the consortium provides $5.25 billion in equity and $15.75 billion of debt. **********Lieutenant Governor Miller said that ''the state is fairly pleased'' with the financial proposals. He noted that the plan did not involve state participation in construction costs and that it sought to protect wellhead value, which is where the state's royalty is calculated, by insisting on having the conditioning plant treated as part of the line, not a field development cost. **********''We hope the Federal Government will grant the law changes that are needed,'' he said.
