https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/12/world.body_text: **********A senior American official arrived here today for the first high-level talks between the United States and Nicaragua's revolutionary Government since the Reagan Administration took office. **********The official, Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, met with the ruling junta as well as the critics of the regime in the church, press and private sector. **********Under the Reagan Administration, United States relations with Nicaragua have deteriorated. Washington has suspended economic aid, charging that Nicaragua has aided the Salvadoran guerrillas; Nicaraguan officials contend that the United States is trying to destabilize their Government. **********A key Nicaraguan military commander, Bayardo Arce Castano, said yesterday that Mr. Enders's visit was ''a magnificent opportunity'' to exchange views and improve relations. ''We hope for positive results and clarification by both sides of what our relations should be in the future,'' he said. **********Mr. Enders was expected to raise the issues of Nicaragua's role in Central America and its increased weapons arsenal.  Nicaragua is known to be concerned about training camps used by right-wing exiles in Florida and about the Senate's recent ratification of a treaty with Colombia in which the United States renounced any claim to three islands off the Nicaraguan coast.  Nicaragua claims sovereignty over the islands and believes the action implies recognition of Colombia's rights over them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/world.main_headline: VANCE ASSAILS POLICY ON CHINA ARMS SALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/world.print_headline: VANCE ASSAILS POLICY ON CHINA ARMS SALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/world.body_text: **********Cyrus R. Vance, the former Secretary of State, has sharply criticized the Reagan Administration's decision to sell arms to China as ''needlessly provocative.'' **********Mr. Vance, who was in Moscow just before the new policy was announced, said that the proposed arms deal has ''virtually removed any influence we have left over the Soviet Union.'' **********''We played the China card in no-trump,'' he said in an interview Monday, ''and there is not much left.'' **********Influence Diminished, He Says **********On reflection, he amended his judgement slightly. The new policy, he said, ''has substantially diminished,'' rather than wiped out, any influence Washington retains. **********President Carter's former Secretary of State spoke at the midtown Park Avenue offices of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, the law firm where he is a senior partner. Mr. Vance was in Moscow 10 days ago for a conference on disarmament. He saw several Soviet leaders, including Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. **********He said he had discussed with Mr. Gromyko the consequences of a pact to sell China weapons and the Foreign Minister had ''expressed his concern.'' 'Pushing These Arms on Them' **********Mr. Vance said he knew of no pressure from Peking for arms. ''It seems to me that we were pushing these arms on them rather than any felt need on their part to have lethal weapons,'' he said. **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. announced in Peking last week that the United States would for the first time offer to sell ''lethal weapons'' to China. **********Mr. Vance said this decision ''was neither sound nor well-timed.'' ''It was a very bad mistake,'' he said. ''It was needlessly provocative and smacked of bear-baiting rather than well-thought-outpolicy. It runs counter to the objective of diplomacy - influencing others in dealing with a subject you are concerned with.'' **********The former Secretary said he did not know how Moscow would respond, but he said that it would respond and in a manner the United States would not welcome. Mr. Vance was reluctant to say what effect the arrangement might have on potential Soviet moves in Poland. ''But what we say as a restraint is lessened,'' he said. **********In office, Mr. Vance said, he had used the same arguments against arming China to those urging weapons for Peking. He would not name the proponents. He Favors Aid for Pakistan **********The Administration's decision to sell arms to Pakistan also drew mixed reviews from Mr. Vance. The Carter Administration tried to arrange a similar pact after the Soviet Union intervened militarily in Afghanistan, but Pakistan's ruler, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, dismissed the offer as ''peanuts.'' **********''I was glad an agreement has been reached,'' Mr. Vance said. ''It is important that Pakistan be assisted.'' But he said the ratio of military aid, about $400 million a year, to economic assistance, about $100 million a year, was too heavily weighted on the side of arms. Mr. Vance also quarreled with the proposal to sell Pakistan sophisticated F-16 fighter-bombers that he said would be far more useful against India than against any attack by the Soviet Union. **********However, he said, ''India clearly brought this about by their decision to buy high-performance aircraft.'' New Delhi has been negotiating with Moscow to buy and manufacture MIG-23's from the Soviet Union.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/22/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; PRAGMATIC FRENCH PREMIER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/22/world.body_text: **********''Facts are stubborn,'' Pierre Mauroy told the Socialist Party congress assembled at Metz in 1979 to thrash out the leadership battle between Francois Mitterrand and his young challenger, Michel Rocard. **********Mr. Mauroy, who at the time was allied with Mr. Rocard, was trying to persuade his colleagues that Mr. Mitterrand and his left-wing supporters were freezing the party into dogmatic intransigence and were out of touch with the centrist feelings of the French electorate. **********Facts may be stubborn, but Mr. Mitterrand proved even more so. He won the fight and clung to his vision that the way to beat the Communists was to strangle them with love: to maintain the notion of a united left, that is, win over the Communist voters and eventually force the Communist leaders to break with him out of sheer selfpreservation. **********It is what happened, more or less. Mr. Mitterrand is President thanks, in part, to voters who abandoned their normal tendency to vote Communist and voted for him instead. At the same time, without ever quite announcing it, Mr. Mitterrand has given more and more support to his party's center; and today, an hour after his inauguration, he named Mr. Mauroy as his Prime Minister. 'Illusion of Revolution' **********It was a move intended to signal the intention to reform France, not to revolutionize it. ''To change society it is necessary to turn our back on the illusion of revolution,'' Mr. Mauroy told the dogmatists in Metz. **********Pierre Mauroy - the name is pronounced Mawr-WAH - is a big, generous-mannered man who radiates an air of bonhomie and tolerance that is not the normal demeanor of a French politician, whether of the left or right. Some have called him ''our German Socialist,'' and in many ways he has more in common with the pragmatic ways of a Helmut Schmidt than with the fitful Jacobin conscience of the French party. **********Mr. Mauroy is more professional politician than ideologue; his enthusiasms for the accommodation and gritty practice of politics, if they made him an antagonist to the left wing of his party, have made him suspect lately to the supporters of Mr. Rocard. Still, they get along with him - everyone seems to - and it is no bad quality in a politician to be just a little bit distrusted all around, so long as it is done equitably and in good humor. **********Mr. Mauroy, who is 52, has his fief in France's industrial and depressed northeast. He has been Mayor of Lille, as well as a deputy in the National Assembly, since 1973. The northeast is a closely fought battleground between the Socialists and the Communists. Mr.  Mauroy fought hard, did well and has good credentials to argue with those in the center and the right of the French spectrum who contend that the Socialists, once in power, will let the Communists lead them around by the nose. Helped Rebuild Socialist Party **********Mr. Mauroy, who is married and has a grown son, is the son of a schoolteacher and the grandson of a woodcutter. The oldest of seven children, he became a professor at a technical school and joined the Socialist Party. He caught the attention of Guy Mollet, then the head of the party, and went to work as his deputy. **********When the Socialist Party went into deep decline in the 1960's, at one point winning only 5 percent of the vote, Mr. Mauroy teamed up with Mr. Mitterrand to begin the long process of rebuilding the party. At the same time he established himself as the head of the Socialist federation of the northeast. **********A man with a taste for concrete things, he worked hard for his region; among other things, he succeeded in getting a local train service established. He needed help from the national Government and managed to get it from President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, despite their opposite political alignments. Of all the leading Socialists, in fact, he was the one with whom Mr. Giscard d'Estaing got along best. **********Mr. Mauroy's energy, affability and reputation as a moderate are qualities that Mr. Mitterrand clearly intends to draw on in the coming months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/busin.main_headline: BANKS CUT PRIME TO 20% REFLECTING LOWER COSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/busin.print_headline: BANKS CUT PRIME TO 20% REFLECTING LOWER COSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/busin.body_text: **********Businesses across the country received a bi t of relief from high interest rates yesterday as scores of banks l owered their prime lending rates half a percentage point, to 20 percent. The reduction reflected a sharp decline in what banks must pay for their own funds,giving them leeway for further reductions in the interest rates they charge their customers. **********Interest rates also declined in the credit markets yesterday for both long-term and short-term issues as the financial markets debated whether the Federal Reserve had eased monetary policy. (Page D12.) **********Many bankers were guardedly optimistic that interest rates would continue to decline. But after having guessed wrong often during the past year of high interest rates, they were reluctant to make any firm predictions. **********''The markets have been so volatile, it would be foolhardy to say unequivocally that this is it,'' said Irwin L. Kellner, senior vice president and chief economist of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. ''But I'm hopeful, and I'm forecasting that the decline has begun.'' **********''Obviously, we would like to think this is the beginning of a decline in interest rates, but it could be wishful thinking,'' said Edward L. Palmer, chairman of the executive committee of Citibank, which was the first to announce the reduction in the rate. **********''We see the next movement continuing to be down,'' said Frank V.  Cahouet, vice chairman of the Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles. ''But the speed of the decline will depend upon a lot of things, including further budget cuts, Wall Street attitudes and Federal Reserve policy.'' Cost of Funds Drops **********Yesterday's drop in the prime was the first widespread reduction in that key lending rate since May 20, when it also dropped to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent. The May decline, however, turned out to be a false start, and the next movement, on July 2, was a return to the 20 1/2 percent level. **********The move back to the 20 percent level was initiated on Aug. 31 by the Chase Manhattan Bank. Three other major banks followed Chase's lead over the last two weeks, and the re st of the nation's major banks acted y esterday. **********The decline in the prime was attributed to a sharp drop in the rates banks must pay for their own funds. Only a week ago, banks were paying about 18 percent for large, six-month certificates of deposit that are issued in denominations of $1 million or more. By yesterday, that rate had declined to around 16 3/4 percent. **********Interest rates that banks must pay for Federal funds, overnight money that banks trade among themselves, have also declined sharply.  The Federal funds rate ranged from 15 5/8 percent to 15 3/4 percent yesterday, down a full percentage point from the level of a week earlier and down from the 18 percent level that prevailed until the third week of August. **********Mr. Kellner of Manufacturers Hanover said yesterday that, by itself, the decline in these costs would justify a prime rate as low as 19 or 19 1/2 percent. But, he said, aside from the short-term profits that might be earned by keeping the prime above that level, the banks feared that lower rates would encourage more borrowing by businesses and that this would eventually drive rates still higher. **********Heavy demand for credit is one of the reasons that some bankers and economists are pessimistic that rates will decline much further, if at all. **********''In view of the demand for credit, which is moving along at a very brisk pace, I think it is likely we'll see a rise in the money supply, which will cause the Federal Reserve to tighten credit again,'' said Jay N. Woodworth, vice president and economist of the Bankers Trust Company. Heavy Borrowing Feared **********Mr. Woodworth also expressed fear that heavy borrowing by the Treasury in the last quarter of 1981 and the first quarter of 1982 will exert upward pressure on interest rates. He estimated that Treasury demands in these two quarters will be close to the $66 billion it borrowed in the comparable 1980-81 period. During that period, the prime reached a record 21 1/2 percent. **********By contrast, last year the prime dropped quickly from 20 percent in early April to 10 3/4 percent in late July. But then it rose again to the record 21 1/2 percent on Dec. 19. By April 1981, it had dropped to a low for the year of 17 percent before rising again. **********The prime is a nominal rate around which many other interest rates are established. Major companies can often borrow below the prime, at least on very short-term credits, but most businesses must pay somewhat more than the prime for their bank loans. **********Other banks that lowered their primes yesterday included Manufacturers Hanover, Chemical, Bankers Trust, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Continental Illinois National Bank and T rust Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/world.main_headline: UNION MILITANTS IN POLAND ATTACK LEADERS OVER GOVERNMENT ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/world.print_headline: UNION MILITANTS IN POLAND ATTACK LEADERS OVER GOVERNMENT ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/world.body_text: **********Solidarity leaders defended themselves today against bitter accusations from the union's rank and file that the leadership had exceeded its authority in compromising with the Goverment over the right of workers to run factories. **********More than two dozen of the 824 delegates at the union's national convention **********Output falls, shortages worsen and worker apathy spreads as Solidarity and the Government wrangle over Poland's problems. Page D1. in Gdansk rose to denounce the compromise, some in stinging terms.  ''This union was not created to make compro mises, but to smash the totalitarian system in our country,'' Jan Rul ewski, a leading militant from Bydgoszcz, said. **********'Don't Think I'm a Fool' **********The leaders argued back, saying that the agreement was not a bad one, that some delegates' speeches smacked of electioneering for union office and that what counted now, above all, was keeping Solidarity united. **********''Don't think I'm a fool,'' Lech Walesa, the union's leader, said, leaning toward the microphone and chopping the air with his right hand in combative style. **********''I have to ride the horses you've given me,'' he said, referring to the union's advisers who counseled him to accept the compromise. Union Cautioned on Politics **********Mr. Walesa also cautioned the union once again against seeking to seize political power.  ''Some ideas are to destroy the Sejm and Government, take their place and became as totalitarian as they are,'' he said. ''This we cannot do - we must protect ourselves from ourselves.'' The Sejm is Poland's Parliament. **********The compromise was embodied in legislation on workers' self-management that was passed by Parliament last week. It settled the sticky question of who appoints directors in factories and other enterprises, the workers or the state, by allowing both to propose candidates in all but strategic industries. Decision-Making Is Assailed **********At the first phase of its congress earlier this month, the delegates took the position that workers alone, through their elected councils, should have the right to make managerial appointments. They also called on Parliament to undertake a national referendum to insure that any legislation on self-management would reflect the genuine wishes of the workers. **********What upset some of the more radical chapter leaders was not just the compromise, but the way in which it was reached. Solidarity proposed the outline of the agreement to the Government after only four members of the union's ruling presidium approved it. Mr. Walesa was among the four.  Jacek Kuron, a leading dissident, was reportedly instrumental in convincing the union officials to accept the compromise. Despite the angry tone of today's speeches, which took a more personal turn than any during the session two weeks ago, union leaders and strategists were confidently predicting that the delegates would go along with the leadership and not repudiate the legislation. **********Even some of the critics seemed to accept this, arguing that they had been presented with an accomplished fact. Only half a dozen, including Mr. Rulewski, advocated trying to overturn the new law. **********''We have lost the battle but not the war,'' Maciej Sewerynski, a delegate from Warsaw, said. ''We've got to fight to change the law.'' It seemed likely that the leadership could heal the division over the issue without opening a major split in Solidarity, although the fracas could well help to erode some of the mystique of unchallenged authority that still surrounds Mr. Walesa. **********In March. Mr. Walesa and a small circle of other leaders called off a national strike. The move, criticized at the time as ''undemocratic,'' was recalled bitterly today by more than one delegate. **********With 49 speakers scheduled to talk and the debate taking up the entire second day of the second phase of the convention, it was shaping up as something of a test of Mr. Walesa's self-assertive style of leadership. But no one doubts that he will be re-elected by an overwhelming vote later in the session. Few Leaders Attack New Law **********One rea son that an open split seems unlikely is that very few of the leaders w ith national stature, except for Mr. Rulewski, took a strong stand against accepting the new law. Some who might have done so, such as A ndrzej Gwiazda of Gdansk or Karol Modzelewski of Wroclaw, supp orted the compromise but more in sorrow than in pleasure. **********Mr. Gwiazda said it was a ''deplorable political mistake'' for such an important decision to be taken by such a small group, but he did not attack the law itself. The leadership, he suggested, is rapidly losing touch with the grass roots. **********''I think our leaders use a different kind of language now,'' he said, ''It' s a language understood by the authorities, but not by the rank and file. There are no longer talking to the grass roots.'' **********Mr. Gwiazda, a member of the union's presidium, was out of town when the decision to offer the compromise was taken. In addition to Mr. Walesa, the only presidium members present were Mr. Rulewski, who voted against the compromis e, and Leszek Wado lowski and Andrzej Jedynak, who joined Mr. Walesa in supporting it. Fears of a Split in Union **********Mr. Modzelewski's speech concentrated on fears that the union might split over the issue and was losing its capacity to mount an effective protest. ''The conflict must not come into the union itself - this is what the authorities are counting on,'' he said. **********''We are in a political situation now,'' Mr. Modzelewski said. ''Do we have the driving force to fight for changes in the law? I believe we don't have it. For many members the credibility of the union has gone down.'' **********Mr. Walesa defended himself vigorously with the personal revelations that mark his speaking style. He was sick the day of the meeting, but he managed to get there, he said. Where were the others?

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/24/busin.main_headline: Metropolitan Life Plans TV and Cable Blitz
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/24/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Metropolitan Life Plans TV and Cable Blitz
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/24/busin.body_text: **********If you've got the money, you can reach the American people in a hurry. Whether you impress them or persuade them is another matter. **********Metropolitan Life Insurance can tell you all about it, the reach part, since it is about to start a weeklong advertising blitz on TV and cable and in newspapers that is expected to reach 97 percent of the country's adults eight times during the week of March 30. Young & Rubicam is the agency. **********The electronic communications will be used to alert viewers to the coming Sunday newspapers, 500 of which will carry inserts or spreads entitled ''Life Insurance ... Should you 'rent' it or 'own' it'' - an attempt to sell a new policy called Whole Life Plus. **********A lot of the network advertising will be used in roadblocking fashion, meaning that no matter which of the networks you tune into when they run you will hit the 30-second spot. Additionally 223 spots will run on seven cable networks during the week. **********The print effort will be an eight-page, third-of-a-page-size insert in Parade and Family Weekly and a spread in a number of largermarket Sunday supplements. The price tag for the one-week media explosion is $2.5 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/10/world.body_text: **********The People's National Movement, which has ruled this Caribbean island nation for 25 years, swept to victory today in voting for a new Parliament. **********''I think it is a mandate from the people for the new leadership'' of Prime Minister George Chambers, said the party general secretary, Alvan Quamina. **********Eric Williams, founder of the party and the only previous Prime Minister, died March 29. **********Initial results showed the ruling party would pick up five seats, giving it 28 seats in the 36-seat Parliament. The opposition conceded defeat. **********Basdeo Panday, leader of the United Labor Front, won his seat as did Energy Minister Errol Mahabir of the ruling party.  The two oppositon parties had accused the ruling party of corruption and economic mismanagement, but the voters apparently ignored the charge. **********Trinidad's politics traditionally is determined by race. Blacks, who live in urban areas, tend to vote for the People's National Movement. East Indians live in the central agricultural belt and vote for the United Labor Front.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/27/busin.print_headline: Financial Futures Spur Brokers' Net; Financial Futures Gain
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/27/busin.body_text: **********The rapid growth of financial futures has helped commodity brokerage firms to increase profits this year despite declines in such big-volume areas as soybean, corn, live cattle and gold futures, according to a survey released today by the Commodity News Service. **********The bottom line for commodity futures brokerage firms is overall trading volume, which has continued to increase because of sharp advances in interest rate and foreign currency futures, the news service said. **********During the first seven months of 1981, total futures volume on all domestic commodity exchanges was 56.1 million contracts, up 18.1 percent from the 47.5 million contracts traded in the same period of 1980. The increase in overall volume means more brokerage fees. **********Brokerage house executives say that the fees just cover the costs of trading, advice and execution but that the higher volume puts more money in brokerage house equity accounts, where profits come from investing equity capital in overnight financial markets. **********While high interest rates this year have added to the return on overnight investments, high borrowing costs and bearish markets have been major deflators of volume in commodity markets, according to Richard Jameson, vice president of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. **********''If the financial markets had not come about, the brokerage business would be down considerably,'' Mr. Jameson added.  Larry Molner, first vice president for commodities with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said: ''We're in the plus column for this fiscal year, but growth is down from last year. There has been a slowdown in speculative activity.'' **********While overall brokerage growth has slowed this year, brokerage officials note that 1979 and 1980 were boom years when volatile commodity prices and a ''draggy'' stock market put futures markets in the public spotlight as a highly leveraged investment arena.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/10/busin.body_text: **********SEVERAL years ago, when banks first started offering bill payment by telephone, the service was widely viewed as the first step in the inevitable and imminent transition to a totally electronic banking system. But pay-by-phone, as it is sometimes known, has failed to live up to expectations. **********''We expected a lot more growth, but it did not materialize,'' said Paul R. Messing, a vice president of the Greater New York Bank for Savings, which pioneered the service in the New York City area. **********''It has not caught fire,'' agreed Stephen Iovino, vice president in charge of electronic banking for the Chase Manhattan Bank, which also offers the service. **********The major reason, according to Mr. Iovino, is the difficulty that most people have in adjusting to a new form of banking and their fear of losing their financial privacy. ''The uninitiated customer perceives some loss of control,'' he said. ''But it is still the customer, not the bank, who has the responsibility for allocating resources. The bank, in effect, acts like a secretary.'' **********Altho ugh it may seem intimidating, the mech anics of telephone bill payment are simple. Customers dial a special bank telephone number, give their bank account number, their persona l identification number, the numerical code of the merchant an d the amount they wish to pay. **********Usually, consumers give this information to live bank operators who remain on duty long past normal banking hours. The information is then fed into the central bank computer, where the orders are pro cessed. In cases where the banks are fully automated and the customers hav e push-button phones that can ''talk'' directly to the bank computer , there is no human contact at all. **********Most banks have fairly extensive, but fixed, lists of merchants they will pay, including department stores, utilities, other banks, real estate companies and hospitals. But they will usually not make payments to individually owned busineses, such as medical and dental practices or landlords of single-family houses, or to merchants outside the immediate area. One attractive feature that is generally available permits banks to automatically pay regularly recurring bills, such as payments on mortgage or installment loans, without prompting by the customer each month. **********Pay-by-phone eliminates checks, stamps and envelopes. Consumers get no immediate paper receipt of the transaction, but instead receive monthly statements describing all the bills paid by telephone. For tax purposes, the statements, which list the names of the merchants and the amounts they were paid, are equivalent to canceled checks. **********Banks benefit from this arrangement because it reduces their timeconsuming and expensive paperwork costs. Instead of having to process many small individual payments to a given merchant, a bank can combine all the payments into one giant check. If the merchant is large enough, or if the merchant is also a customer of the bank, the funds are transferred electronically. **********More than 100 banks across the country offer the service, but it is available only at Chase and Greater New York in New York City.  Several Connecticut banks, including the Peoples Savings Bank and the Union Trust Company, offer the service. In New Jersey, it is available from the Howard Savings Bank in Newark. **********Although they expect that the advent of the 20-cent postage stamp will bring in some new business from consumers who believe they can save money by avoiding the mail when paying bills, bankers who offer the service are not predicting a major turnaround that would put the service into the black. **********''If you called 100 bankers, unless one of them was a liar, every one would tell you it's a money loser,'' said Ronald McCulloch, vice president for corporate planning at Union Trust, which has offered the service for several years. **********''In fact, I'm a little concerned about the 20-cent stamp,'' he added, noting that the more of this business the bank gets, the more money it loses. The major reason, he said, is the high cost in tracking payments made to merchants. ''They often say they didn't get a payment, so we must check and check and check. Usually they've misplaced the check, but it happens frequently enough to tie up one person full time.'' **********Despite the disappointing experience with pay-by-phone, major banks have not been discouraged from testing the waters for the next chapter in the saga of electronic banking - home video banking. The Bank of America, Citibank and Chase all have, or are planning, pilot projects to gauge customer reaction to services that let people perform banking transactions through computers and television sets in their homes. **********Meanwhile, for consumers who are not afraid of change, paying bills by telephone is probably a good deal. Costs of the service have not risen much in the last few years, and are certainly cheaper than using the mail for people who write many checks. **********At Chase, for example, the service is free for people who maintain an extra $1,500 in their accounts over and above the bank's standard minimum balance; otherwise it costs $1.50 a month. Greater New York charges 10 cents per telephone call, but allows people to pay as many bills as they wish on that one call. **********Without exception, bankers say that the vast majority of people who try the service become devoted converts. ''If we were ever to tell our customers that we were discontinuing it, I think they'd leave the bank,'' said Mr. Messing of Greater New York. ''It's the greatest thing in the world, if people would just try it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/06/world.print_headline: LATIN POLICY: A NEW PLAN; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/06/world.body_text: **********After months of often contradictory signals, Reagan Administration officials say they have settled on a four-part approach to dealing with what they see as the problems of Cuban and Soviet intervention in Nicaragua and elsewhere in Central America. **********They say they hope this tentative plan, which they say they will refine in coming weeks, will involve other Latin nations and reduce the necessity of a single-handed American military role. **********The general outline of the approach was made public Friday in Castries, St. Lucia, to the Organization of American States by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. It was amplified in private talks with diplomats and journalists. Warning Called 'a Solid Plus' **********On Mr. Haig's airplane returning to Washington Friday night, reporters were told that the Secretary believed his forceful warning about Nicaragua's becoming a potential Communist bastion in Central America had been ''a solid plus.'' The other Latin delegates were almost unanimous, the reporters were told, in wanting to do something to prevent what Mr. Haig called in his speech the transformation of Nicaragua into a ''platform of terror and war in the region.'' **********In a conversation today, a senior State Department official, who asked not to be named, said the next several weeks would be crucial.  The Administration hopes in that period to hold consultations with other Latin countries, with members of Congress and within the often divided executive branch so that a firm policy declaration can be made by President Reagan, perhaps by the time of his State of the Union address next month. The aim is to put an end to the seeming indecision that has marked the Administration's policy for most of the year. **********The four-point approach that is being worked on is described in this manner by Mr. Haig and others: The Administration hopes to keep open lines of communication with Nicaragua in the hope that the country's Sandinist leadership can be persuaded that its support for the guerrillas in El Salvador should stop and that its interests do not lie in throwing itself completely into the Cuban and Soviet camps. **********There is not much optimism within the State Department that the Sandinists, who see themselves as liberators in the area, will be turned from their course. Nevertheless, in deference to Mexico and other countries that still see some hope in Nicaragua, Washington will keep the door open. **********Mr. Haig is also in regular contact with Moscow. As to contacts with Cuba, the State Department would not comment on a report in a Madrid newspaper that Mr. Haig, while in Mexico 10 days ago, met with a high-ranking Cuban official. Collective Approach Sought **********Meanwhile, taking advantage of widespread concern in the hemisphere about what are seen as renewed Cuban subversive tactics, particularly in the militarization of Nicaragua, the Administration hopes to formulate some kind of collective approach to deal with the situation. **********There is no expectation of an initiative by the Organization of American States as such, but rather the bringing together of those nations most willing to act in unison to formulate common positions.  Mr. Haig talked about preventing the importing of heavy offensive weapons, such as Soviet-built fighter aircraft, into Nicaragua and the limiting of foreign military advisers. **********One possibility would be military cooperation between El Salvador, Honduras, Costa Rica and Guatemala, the countries perceived to be most threatened by Nicaragua, with aid and advice provided by the United States, Argentina and other major powers. More Aid Would Be Available **********While ruling out American combat involvement, the United States would make clear that it would be ready to supply increased military and economic assistance. The amounts of aid involved are small, relative to the large-scale American assistance for such areas as the Middle East. But the Administration has already doubled its military aid to Honduras, for instance, to $10 million for this fiscal year. **********Any significant increases in aid will require the full support of Congress, however, and this is questionable. So far, for example, Congress has seemed reluctant about, if not critical of, American support for El Salvador, because of that Government's seeming inability to keep its police in check. There is also strong criticism of Guatemala because of repressive policies there. **********Mr. Haig intends to make a major effort this week, before going on a trip to Europe, to persuade the House of Representatives to approve the new aid bill to make increased support in Latin America possible.  Caribbean Basin Plan Evolving **********Finally, to demonstrate that it is concerned with more than just security matters, the United States would make public a concrete plan for the Caribbean basin that has been worked on for most of the year, but which until Friday appeared to be devoid of much substance. **********Mr. Haig said President Reagan was preparing a three-part economic plan: legislation to allow Caribbean and Central American countries one-way free trade preferences into the American market; special incentives and other measures to spur private investment in private ventures in the region, and an increase in American financial aid to deal with acute liquidity crises in such countries as Costa Rica. It is not known whether Congress, in the current tight budget atmosphere, will be generous to the Caribbean countries. **********Much of the confusion surrounding American policy in the Caribbean has been caused by the seemingly erratic nature of Administration statements. **********At the start of the Administration, Mr. Haig opened a major campaign around the world to draw attention to what he said was Cuban, Vietnamese and Soviet support for the insurgents in El Salvador, who he charged were being supplied by way of Nicaragua. U.S. Involvement Opposed **********There was considerable speculation in this country that the campaign was a precursor for involvement of the Vietnam war type.  Since El Salvador's Government was regarded as having been responsible for, or at least having countenanced, the murder of four American Roman Catholic workers, as well as other assassinations, there was almost no public support for a deeper American involvement there. **********The White House, concerned earlier this year with gaining approval of the President's economic package, did not welcome a Salvador distraction and told Mr. Haig to put an end to his public campaign.  This irritated Mr. Haig, who felt that he was being muzzled; subsequently he said privately that his campaign had led Nicaragua to stop supplying arms to the Salvadoran rebels but that the flow had resumed after the United States stopped talking about the issue. **********Now he has been given permission again to make his concerns known, and he has seemed to pick up an ally in Edwin A. Meese 3d, the White House counselor, who has recently echoed Mr. Haig's words of concern. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, however, has been wary of the campaign and has said very little about the situation. Military Moves Hinted **********As part of this increased public campaign, Mr. Haig and Mr. Meese refused in recent weeks to rule out such American military moves as a naval blockade of Nicaragua or the mining of Nicaraguan harbors. **********But the presentation by Mr. Haig in St. Lucia was meant, in part, to assure the Latins that the United States wanted to avoid playing a unilateral military role. **********''I think if we 'heavy-hand' our position there, it is wrong,'' reporters on Mr. Haig's plane were told. ''It's wrong in the sense of American policy and it is wrong also from the standpoint of hemispheric unity and collective action.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/busin.main_headline: Market Place; New Options In Mergers
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/busin.print_headline: Market Place; New Options In Mergers
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/28/busin.body_text: **********CREDITHRIFT FINANCIAL has been living with uncertainty since Orion Capital made a merger proposal backed by holdings of 9.9 percent of Credithrift's shares in the spring of 1979. **********Though Credithrift's management discouraged the plan, the Orion Capital shares, taken with shares owned by the Wickes Companies (9.8 percent) and those owned by Petra Capital (just under 5 percent) accounted for nearly a quarter of capitalization. Management, by contrast, owned less than 2 percent of the shares. **********Credithrift acted to eliminate the uncertainty earlier this month in deciding to merge with American General, a casualty insurance company that has acquired the Wickes block of shares. **********Terms of the deal were greeted with dismay by both Orion and Petra. Credithrift's common shares are to be exchanged for $11.50 stated value of an American General junior preferred, which the companies announced would have a 10 percent annual dividend rate and would be convertible into American General shares at $4 8. American General closed Friday at 39. Credithrift closed at 10 1/2. **********In an unusual feature, the preferred can be redeemed at any time for cash equal to the $11.50 stated value. From Orion's and Petra's point of view, the price is low - discouragingly close to Credithrift's book value of roughly $11.60 a share. A recent acquisition of Dial Financial, which like Credithrift is a consumer finance company, brought a price nearer twice book value. **********The next step is for Credithrift shareholders to vote on the deal.  In doing so later this year they will, in effect, be concerned about the fairness of the exchange ratio. Carl Ferenbach, managing director of merger s and acquisitions for the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group, represented Credithrift in the negotiations with American General. **********He confirmed last Friday that Merrill Lynch as adviser to Credithrift will be giving an opinion to the shareholders that the merger terms are fair and reasonable. **********What has drawn the attention of some followers of the merger scene is another detail in connection with the negotiation of the merger.  Credithrift management agreed to give American General an option to buy 18 percent of Credithrift's common at $11.50 a share. **********The option, referred to by some investment bankers as a ''well poisoner,'' is designed to make it difficult for any other potential suitor to make a competing bid. For American General will have locked up more than a quarter of the shares if it exercises the option.  Obviously, any suitor owning a quarter of a company before a bidding war has a formidable advantage. **********Unlike the competition, which must pay a price reflecting a heated contest for all shares acquired, the option holder averages down the higher cost of additional shares with the low cost shares he starts with. In addition, the option holder doesn't have to buy as many shares as the competition to attain a majority position. **********If the option technique works, the holder's advantage is at the expense of shareholders who could expect to receive more for their holdings in an open bidding contest. **********If a bidding contest weren't likely, why would management use the option in the first place? That's the question troubled analysts ask.  Options of this nature are still relatively new in merger and acquisition practice. The device is aimed at clinching a deal with a favored merger partner, though the price may not be the best obtainable. **********The option was first employed by strategists for Pullman and its white knight, Wheelabrator-Frye. Had the plan worked, it clearly would have foreclosed a higher bid by the McDermott Corporation which had been seeking Pullman for more than a month. **********In that case, the outside strategists had Pullman offer Wheelabrator an option to buy Pullman's prized Kellogg engineering division in the event that the white knight bid failed. **********McDermott publicly disparaged the two options and raised its bid anyway. At that point, Wheelabrator chose not to rely on either of the two novel options and met McDermott dollar for dollar in the market place, eventually topping McDermott's highest bid. **********Thus, the first time out, the option technique had no significance as a clincher. But it did bring Wheelabrator management into a game it might never have played had the final price been even dimly foreseen. **********Wheelabrator eventually paid $52.50 a share in cash and stock - over $100 million more than its initial bid. Moreover, in making its winning bid, Wheelabrator had to ante up cash for 5.5 million shares, up from the 2 million shares for cash contemplated by its initial offer. **********Since that time, scores of deals have included sweetheart options for stock, but no court in a position to rule on their legality has done so. **********It is understood that some acquiring companies have shunned these options on grounds that they may be unfair to the shareholders of the acquired company. **********Mr. Ferenbach was asked how his firm could give a fairness opinion on the American General merger terms in view of the existence of the option. **********He said: ''I don't think the option impacts on fairness. The option is something many have offered to encourage potential buyers to enter into a transaction.'' **********One lawyer active in mergers and acquisitions said that no prominent law firm he knows of has given a formal opinion that these options are legal, valid and binding under state law.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/world.main_headline: Prolonged Rain in France Kills Livestock and Destroys Crops
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/world.print_headline: Prolonged Rain in France Kills Livestock and Destroys Crops
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/world.body_text: **********Eight days of heavy rain have caused flooding across France, killing thousands of farm animals and destroying millions of dollars worth of crops and agricultural equipment, officials said today. **********More rain was forecast for large parts of the nation Monday.  In Paris, the level of the Seine River was reported six feet above normal today. The rising water forced the evacuation of families living in houseboats along the Seine, and closed Paris's river-bank expressways. **********Around Bordeaux near the Atlantic coast, authorities said thousands of cattle, pigs, goats and chickens have drowned since the Garonne and the Lot rivers began flooding last week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/08/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration today threw its weight behind efforts to build a 4,800-mile pipeline to bring natural gas from Alaska to the lower 48 states, an enormous project that has bogged down because of problems in raising the money. **********Sponsors welcomed the decision as a major step toward building the line, which w ould be the biggest privately financed construction project in hi story, but further hurdles lie ahead. **********The White House endorsement came in an announcement that it would ask Congress this week to approve a package of waivers that are needed to line up financing for 75 percent of the project. The line is expected to cost as much as $40 billion, most of which would be spent to build the 731-mile leg of the pipeline running through Alaska to the Canadian border. **********The official statement did not list the specific items in the waiver package.  But according to a spokesman for the Northwest Alaskan Pipeline Company, formed to build the pipeline, it would include a fiercely debated provision under which gas consumers would start to help pay for the line before they received any gas. **********It would also guarantee the sponsors what has come to be called ''regulatory certainty,'' or assurance that once terms were settled for construction of the pipeline, the Government would not make changes that would increase costs. And the waiver package would allow the three oil companies that own the gas reserves in Alaska to purchase part ownership of the line. **********The companies are the Exxon Corporation, the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), which also produce virtually all the oil from Alaska's North Slope. The British Petroleum Company is majority shareholder in Sohio. **********The line from Prudhoe Bay, running through Canada, would tap a gas supply estimated at about 13 percent of total current United States reserves. Once the Administration's proposals reach Capitol Hill, each chamber has 60 days in which to approve them. **********Since the provisions were generally worked out with key Sena te Energy Committee members, approval by the Sen ate is considered likely. **********Some strong opposition, however, has been expressed in the House, including that of John D. Dingell, a Democrat from Michigan and head of its energy committee. **********A New York banker involved in preliminary fund-raising plans was noncommittal today when asked whether passage of all the waiver items would clear the way to successful financing, mostly by private banks. **********The banker said that thorough financing reviews remained to be conducted, as well as surveys of the eventual marketability of the gas.  Northwest Alaskan has said that if the waiver package was not provided in this session of Congress, the project would have to be shelved. The company has insisted, however, that with the waivers, it could proceed despite any eventual decontrol of gas prices that might make it difficult to market gas brought in through the pipeline. **********The current completion target for the pipeline is now the fall of 1986. Construction of the Canadian and ''Lower-48'' sections is already well advanced and in some areas nearly completed. If a decision was made not to build the Alaskan section, the Canadian and ''Lower 48'' sections would be used to transport Canadian natural gas. **********Other provisions understood to be part of the legislative package include granting Exxon, Atlantic Richfield and Sohio an ''assured minority equity position'' in the line that remained unspecified, but is expected to be at least 30 percent. **********The package, which is not subject to amendment by Congress, also provides for guarantees to Canada so that it can sell its own gas in this country even if the Alaskan section is not built, and permission for the sponsors to include a $6 billion gas-conditioning plant on the North Slope in calculations of its charges to consumers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/19/busin.body_text: **********Shareholders of the Rossmoor Corporation, the builder that pioneered the concept of the large retirement community and constructed seven Leisure World communities nationwide, have approved a motion to liquidate within 12 months, company officials said. **********A company official said that the move had been discussed in the corporation's last two annual reports and approval had been expected. **********An initial cash distribution in January 1982 of about $10 a share and a second distribution in June 1982 of about $4.25 a share are anticipated. **********The company said rising interest rates, dwindling supplies of large parcels of land near urban centers and a growing number of smaller retirement communities outside the Sun Belt had diminished the profit prospects from building such huge projects as Leisure World, even though the number of retired persons was at record levels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/busin.body_text: **********Three Japanese companies have won an order totaling approximately $72 million to construct a microwave communications system in Ibadan, Nigeria, the Marubeni Corporation said today. Marubeni, the Nippon Electric Company and Sumitomo Electric Industries will supply equipment and undertake all installation work for the system, which is expected to be completed in two years. The contract was placed by the Nigerian Communications Ministry under Nigeria's five-year development plan, which began last year, Marubeni added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/11/world.body_text: **********Foreign Minister Jose Pedro Perez Llorca said today on his return from talks in Washington that he had told United States leaders that they could no longer regard Spain as a mere tool to be used for American strategic needs. ''Spain must be seen as an active partner of interest in Europe,'' he said. **********The Foreign Minister conferred with President Reagan, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., and Secretary of Defense Caspar W.  Weinberger about continuing American use of four military bases in Spain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.main_headline: 7 Hostages Are Seized At Mexico University,; But 6 Are Later Freed
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.print_headline: 7 Hostages Are Seized At Mexico University,; But 6 Are Later Freed
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.body_text: **********Three armed preparatory students burst into the office of the rector of the University of Mexico today, took seven people hostage and later freed six of them, witnesses said. **********A team of university officials managed to talk the students into freeing all of the captives except Leopoldo Silva, personal secretary to the rector. **********University officials said the gunmen, who identified themselves as students at a preparatory school, wanted more money for laboratory equipment and other items for their school. **********University officials said the three first demanded an airplane to take them to the United States, but later asked to be granted asylum in an unspecified embassy. The university used aninteroffice communications system to negotiate with them. **********The students were said to be about 18 years old and armed with a rifle, a submachine gun and a pistol.  Campus police said the raiders had tried to capture the rector, Octavio Rivera, but he escaped through a back door.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/busin.main_headline: TAX CREDITS ARE CLAIMED FOR WIDE RANGE OF COSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/busin.print_headline: TAX CREDITS ARE CLAIMED FOR WIDE RANGE OF COSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Your TaxesA Guide to Preparing 1980 ReturnsNinth of 12 articles.- By DEBORAH RANKIN **********If you paid someone to look after your children last year so you could go to work, if you made a donation to an election-year political campaign, or if you installed storm windows in the family home you may be able to claim a tax credit that will substantially reduce the amount you owe to the Internal Revenue Service. And last year the credit for some types of renewable energy source expenditures was generously increased. **********One imaginative taxpayer last year even claimed the 10 percent investment tax credit, typically claimed for depreciable property such as machinery used in a business, for his extensive home library. The tax court sided with James Ginkel, an English professor at the Ellsworth Community College in Iowa Falls, Iowa, who had spent $1,811 on books used in his college courses, but said that only half the volume he had purchased had qualified for the credit. **********Tax credits, which are enumerated on the back of the long form 1040, are much more valuable than itemized deductions for people in lower tax brackets. A $100 charitable contribution is worth only $14 to someone in the lowest bracket of 14 percent, but worth $70 to someone in the highest bracket, 70 percent. A $100 credit, by contrast, reduces taxes by $100 regardless of a taxpayer's bracket. **********People who hire a baby-sitter or housekeeper to care for their children, even if the parents work only part time or are full-time students, may be able to claim a tax credit for part of the expense, depending on income. For one child, the credit is 20 percent of up to $2,000 in expenses, or a maximum of $400; for two or more children, it is 20 percent of up to $4,000 in expenses, or a maximum of $800. **********To claim the credit, one must maintain a home for a child under the age of 15, or for a dependent, regardless of age, who is mentally or physically incapable of caring for himself or herself. Generally, both spouses must have some earnings from a job or self-employment, unless one of them is disabled or a full-time student. **********For purposes of calculating the credit, a full-time student or disabled spouse is considered to have earned $166 a month if there is one qualifying child or disabled spouse to be cared for, or $333 a month if there are two or more qualifying dependents. Determining the Credit **********The amount of the credit is not determined by combined joint income, but is limited by the income of the lower-paid spouse, or the amount of child-care expenses, whichever is lower. **********Take the case of a couple who spend $2,500 on baby-sitters for their two children during the six months the wife attends college full time. The husband earns $20,000, but the credit is determined by the amount that the wife is considered to have earned: $1,998, or six times $333. The maximum credit they can claim is thus $399.60 (20 percent of $1,998). **********The cost of a housekeeper who also does laundry, cleaning and cooking is deductible. So is the cost of care provided outside the home, for example at a day camp or nursery school. And payments to a relative, such as a grandmother, also qualify for the credit as long as the relative is not also claimed as a dependent. **********The Tax Court has upheld the deductibility of child-care payments, even when a parent has mixed motives for incurring the costs. One case concerned a mother who withdrew her son from a disruptive public school and then took a full-time job after sending him to a boarding school. **********The court allowed her to write off part of the private school costs, even though it noted that she had sent him there not only because she wanted him to get a better education but also because she wanted to work. Energy-Saving Credits **********To encourage energy conservation, Congress several years ago enacted two separate credits for taxpayers who install energy-saving devices in their homes. **********The first credit, for expenditures on residential energy improvements such as storm windows and insulation, is 15 percent of the first $2,000 spent, up to a maximum credit of $300. **********The second, for expenditures on renewable energy source improvements such as solar heating systems, was increased last year to 40 percent of the first $10,000 spent, up to a maximum credit of $4,000. The previous ceiling was $2,200. **********Both credits are limited to improvements made to a principal residence that you own or rent; but the residential energy improvement credit is limited to installations in homes substantially completed before April 20, 1977, while the renewable energy source credit can be claimed for any residence. **********In addition to expenditures on storm doors and windows, the residential energy credit can be claimed for such items as caulking and weatherstripping, automatic set-back thermostats, and moreefficient furnace replacement burners. But dual-purpose home improvements that are primarily decorative in nature, such as fireplaces and wood-burning stoves, or carpeting and drapes, do not qualify. **********You can claim the maximum $300 credit on other qualifying homes you may buy, and the buyer of your old house can also claim a credit of up to $300 if qualifying improvements are made. In addition, the residential energy credit and the renewable energy source credit are calculated separately, so that expenditures for one type of credit do not reduce the other. **********Last year, the Crude Oil Windfall Profit Tax Act of 1980 clarified the confused treatment of joint ownership of energy items qualifying for the credit. Now it is clear, for example, that four owners of adjacent condominium units who each contribute $5,000 of the total $20,000 cost for installing a jointly owned solar heating system serving their units would each be entitled to a credit of $2,000 (40 percent of $5,000). Previously, there was some thought that they might be limited to pro-rating a single maximum credit of $4,000. Political Contributions **********People who made financial contributions in the general election campaign last year may qualify for the political contribution credit. It is half of the amount contributed during the year, up to a maximum credit of $100 for married persons filing jointly ($50 for single taxpayers). This is in addition to the $1 or $2 they may have designated on their tax return for the Presidential election campaign fund. **********To be deductible, political contributions must have been made in money, rather than in property or services. Contributions to newsletter funds established by elected officials or candidates for public office also qualify. **********But last year the I.R.S. ruled that donations to ''negative'' campaigns organized for the purpose of defeating certain candidates were not deductible, saying that the law only allows contributions to further a candidacy. Tax Credit for the Elderly **********People aged 65 or over who receive a small amount of Social Security or Railroad Retirement benefits, or people under that age who receive a small amount of income from a public retirement system, may be able to claim the tax credit for the elderly. **********The credit, which is determined on a sliding scale based on the amount of income and other benefits a person receives, can range up to $562.50 for a married couple filing jointly. Because the law in this area is complex, and taxpayers have made so many errors in calculating the credit, the I.R.S. will calculate it by mail as long as the necessary information is provided on the return. **********Low-income workers with families may be able to claim the earnedincome credit, a negative income tax that provides a refund or subsidy that can range up to $500. Qualifying workers who maintain a household for dependent children can receive this payment from the Government even if they owe no taxes. **********The credit, which is computed on a sliding scale and stops when income exceeds $10,000, is based on earned income. The I.R.S. will also calculate this credit free of cost if the necessary information is provided. **********If you worked for two or more employers last year who together paid you more than $25,900 in wages, too much Social Security tax may have been withheld from your wages. Check your W2 forms, and if the total withheld exceeded $1,587.67, you can claim the excess as a reduction of your income tax. ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Next: How to compute your tax.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/21/busin.main_headline: Mexico to Sell Crude Oil To U.S. for Its Stockpile
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/21/busin.print_headline: Mexico to Sell Crude Oil To U.S. for Its Stockpile
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Mexico signed a five-year contract to sell crude oil directly to the United States Energy Department for its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, officials said today. **********An announcement by the National Resources and Industrial Development Ministry said the contract guaranteed the Energy Department 200,000 barrels of oil a day, beginning Sept.1, or about 24 million barrels by the end of the year. **********From January 1982 to August 1986, the notice said, Petroleos Mexicanos, the state oil monopoly, would export 50,000 barrels a day. **********Mexican officials said the oil would be used to help fill the Strategic Petroleum Reserves, located in salt caverns in Texas and Louisiana, which now contain less than a third of a planned 750 million barrels. **********Mexico currently exports its petroleum, a 50-50 mixture of light Isthmus and heavy Maya crudes, for an average price of $31.25 a barrel. The ministry note said the export price would be renegotiable every three months. **********The contract - thought to be thefirst ever by the United States Government for direct purchase of petroleum from another government - caused speculation that the sale might be protested by suppliers of oil to American companies. Saudi Arabia especially had opposed the government-to-government contract for oil sales when Pemex announced earlier this month that it was negotiating with the Energy Department. **********Mexico exports about 1.25 million barrels of crude each day, compared to more than 1.42 million barrels six months ago. Like other oil exporters, it is suffering a weak market because of a drop in demand caused in part by high prices. Mexico is not a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/30/world.main_headline: FRENCH AIDE TO LEAVE TODAY FOR A VISIT TO LATIN AMERICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/30/world.print_headline: FRENCH AIDE TO LEAVE TODAY FOR A VISIT TO LATIN AMERICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/30/world.body_text: **********France's Foreign Minister will leave Paris tomorrow for a weeklong visit to Mexico and Central America that diplomats here have called the first demonstration of France's new interest in third-world nations outside of its own French-speaking sphere. **********France hopes to double its aid to developing nations in the next five years, according to reports in Paris, and the visit by Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson will make it easier to evaluate that region's economic needs and political problems. **********After two days in Mexico, Mr. Cheysson will visit Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Honduras. It will be the first time a French Foreign Minister has visited those Central American nations since their independence a century and a half ago. **********'Reaffirm France's Support' **********Nicaragua will be the most important stop in Central America, a Foreign Ministry official said, because it ''will permit Mr. Cheysson to reaffirm clearly France's support for the leaders in Managua and to underline France's belief that only democratic political solutions will permit Central America to emerge from the shadow of civil war such as that which followed the fall of the Somoza regime and the one presently under way in El Salvador.'' **********One purpose of the visit, another aide said, ''is to illustrate the heightened concern for the third world that is a keystone of the new French foreign policy.'' **********Relations with third-world nations are generally recognized here as an area in which French-American relations, apparently strengthed at the economic meeting in Ottawa by the meetings between President Reagan and President Francois Mitterrand of France, could most easily founder. **********Mr. Cheysson will meet with President Jose Lopez Portillo and Foreign Minister Jorge Castaneda of Mexico at the Cancun resort area.  Mr. Cheysson will not visit El Salvador, but aides said the situation in that country would be on his agenda at each stop.  Mr. Cheysson is expected carry messages to Mexican and Latin American leaders from Mr. Mitterrand, who held a special meeting at the Ottawa economic meeting with Ed Broadbent, a Canadian Member of Parliament who recently concluded a fact-finding mission in Central America and Cuba for the Socialist International. **********Mr. Broadbent is the leader of the New Democratic Party, which represents Canada in the Socialist International. Mr. Mitterrand, a Socialist, specifically requested the special meeting after Mr.  Broadbent was denied access to the Ottawa conference. Mr. Broadbent was said to have told told Mr. Mitterrand that negotiations were possible in El Salvador but that no mediation would be possible as long as United States military aid continues to flow to the Salvadoran Army. **********Foreign Ministry officials have declined to discuss French policy toward Central America except in general terms. Other diplomants in Paris insist that no specific policy exists. ''It is a very, very delicate issue right now,'' one diplomat said. ''They have got to walk a thin line between their committment to social justice and their desire for a working relationship with the United States.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.main_headline: Sales Rise Seen For U.S. Autos
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.print_headline: Sales Rise Seen For U.S. Autos
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.body_text: **********Domestic car and truck sales will hit 17.5 million by 1990, an increase of more than 50 percent over last year's 11.5 million, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Roger B. Smith, predicted today. **********In a speech at the Philadelphia Rotary Club, the G.M. chairman predicted worldwide retail sales of nearly 32 million cars and trucks in 1990, an increase of about 36 percent over sales of 23.5 million in 1980. **********A copy of Mr. Smith's remarks was released in Detroit. **********''We believe that the worst of the recession in auto sales is over,'' he said. ''We see a continuing and growing demand for a variety of personal transportation, not only here in this country, but around the world.'' **********Mr. Smith said the No.1 United States auto maker has planned a capital investment program of $40 billion in the period 1980-84.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/22/busin.body_text: **********In a move intended ultimately to position itself in the Pittsburgh consumer-banking market, the Chase Manhattan Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to invest $125 million in the troubled Equimark Corporation, that city's third-largest bank holding company. **********Chase, in return for its infusion of capital, would receive an option to buy all the stock of Equibank, which is owned by Equimark.  ''We're not buying up a bank here; it's a healthy mutual marriage of our interests,'' said Willard C. Butcher, Chase's chairman, in an interview yesterday. If Chase eventually were to acquire Equimark, it would give the New York bank a strong position throughout the greater Pittsburgh area and the Ohio Valley, he said. **********At the same time, Equimark reported a net operating loss for the second quarter of $33.26 million. In the second quarter of 1980, Equimark showed a $2.5 million profit. Blocked by Federal Law **********At present, however, Federal law prohibits banking companies from acquiring full-service banking subsidiaries outside their own state.  Thus, Chase could not exercise its option until Federal law was changed, if ever. In addition, the proposal is subject to approval by regulatory authorities and by Equimark's shareholders. **********If Chase were to exercise its option, it would pay $75 million for the shares, which is considerably below Equibank's book value of about $104 million. But it also is considerably above the recent market value of about $42 million. **********The bank's equity, however, is greater than that of its parent company, which means that Equimark has a negative net worth.  For years, Equimark and Equibank have experienced low profitability levels and low ratios of equity to total assets. Among the 81 banks in the nation with assets between $2 billion and $5 billion, Equimark last year ranked 80th in terms of return on assets, 78th in terms of return on equity, and 79th in terms of equity as a percentage of its total assets, according to the bank-stock company of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, which acted as adviser to Equimark in the transaction. Added Flexibility **********Chase's investment is intended to bolster Equibank's capital position to give it more flexibility in dealing with its problems.  The package will include a $75 million, five-year loan at 14 1/2 percent, secured by United States Government securities; a $25 million investment in newly issued nonvoting preferred shares of Equimark, and an additional $25 million investment in newly issued nonvoting preferred shares of Equibank. **********The preferred shares are to be redeemed in 15 years, with a sinking fund that gives the loan an average life of 10 1/2 years. The dividend rate begins at 7 percent and rises to 14 percent. **********''This is a great opportunity for us to be more aggressive in the market,'' said W.E. Bierer, Equimark's chairman and chief executive officer. ''We're really up on the thing, it couldn't be a better marriage.'' **********Gregory A. Root, vice president of Keefe, Bruyette, said the infusion of capital ''gives Equimark the flexibility it needs to restructure their assets.'' **********In its asset-liability structure, Equimark resembles a savings bank. Of its $2.8 billion in assets, at year-end it had $832 in United States Government securities and $489 million in mortgages.  Many of these investments were made when interest rates were far lower than they are today. Since then, Equimark's cost of funds has risen above the yield on these investments, creating a profit squeeze. **********With the added capital, Equimark will be able to sell some of these investments at a loss and reinvest the money in higher-yielding loans or securities. **********The second-quarter loss was attributed to $35 million in loan write-offs - $20 million at the holding company level, and $15 million at the bank. **********Equimark has total assets of $2.8 billion and is the 82d-largest banking company in the United States. Chase Manhattan, with assets of $78.3 billion, is third largest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/busin.main_headline: HIGHER FUEL COSTS LED JANUARY'S RISE IN PRODUCER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/busin.print_headline: HIGHER FUEL COSTS LED JANUARY'S RISE IN PRODUCER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/busin.body_text: **********The prices that producers charge retailers for finished goods rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, a significant acceleration from the pattern of last fall, the Labor Department reported today. **********The principal cause of the acceleration was rising prices for fuel oil and gasoline, which are expected to rise even more sharply in coming months because the figures released today did not include the effects of President Reagan's decontrol of domestic oil on Jan. 28. **********In December, the prices charged by producers of finished goods rose by five- **********The dollar surged in value in both Europe and the United States amid hectic buying. Page 29. tenths of 1 percent. The increase had been seven-tenths of 1 percent in each of the two preceding months. **********With the January increase, the Government's index of the prices of finished goods at the wholesale level was 10.8 percent higher than it was in January 1980. Leaving out energy, the index was up 8.9 percent from a year earlier. **********The news that prices for finished goods increased at a double-digit annual rate last month, the first time in four months that the annual rate had exceeded 10 percent, represented confirmation of economists' predictions that the inflation rate would accelerate in the first three months of 1981. Slowdown Is Expected **********''It's not a big surprise,'' said Leif Olsen, chief economist at Citibank. ''We and many other economists anticipated that inflation during this first quarter would probably run quite high.'' However, Mr. Olsen added: ''We expect the inflation rate to slow in the second quarter.'' **********Among the reasons for the added inflation are the sharp rises in raw material prices last summer and fall, the added strength of the economy in recent months and the surge in interest rates, which will show up mostly in the Consumer Price Index, which measures prices at the retail level. **********Helping to moderate last month's rise in the producer price index, however, were finished food prices, which showed no increase at all.  For the last three months, the prices of finished food, ready for sale to a retailer, have risen by less than the overall increase in the index. **********Last month, for example, prices of such finished food items as fresh fruits, eggs, processed poultry, pork and roasted coffee all fell by 2.5 percent or more. The only substantial increases in finished foods were posted by milled rice, fish and soft drinks. **********Still, Labor Department economists warned today that the effect of the cold weather in Florida had not yet appeared in the finished goods index. The prices of oranges, orange juice and other fruits and vegetables grown in Florida have already begun to rise. **********In addition to the index of finished-goods prices, which includes such items as automobiles, the Government keeps track of prices for crude goods, such as commodities and raw farm products, and intermediate goods, made up of items that are only partly processed. **********At the intermediate level - which includes items such as flour, steel and fabric - food prices rose by 1.2 percent last month, the same as the month before. But nonfood items rose by 1.3 percent last month and by 1.7 percent in December. **********Crude goods - such as wheat and raw cotton - fell by 1 percent last month, the second consecutive decline. Such changes can lead to smaller price increases at the finished-goods level and, ultimately, in the prices paid by consumers. **********In January, fuel oil prices increased by 5.7 percent and gasoline rose by 2.5 percent, both more than double the December increases.  Capital equipment prices continued to rise rapidly, up 1 percent last month. The index for finished consumer goods was up eighttenths of 1 percent in January, following a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in December. Prices rose faster than in December for passenger cars, textiles, home furnishings, appliances and prescription drugs. Prices fell for sterling silverware and tires and tubes.
