https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/busin.main_headline: A Chairman-Chief For New York Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A Chairman-Chief For New York Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/busin.body_text: **********At a board meeting of the New York Life Insurance Company yesterday, Donald K. Ross, 55 years old, was elected chairman and chief executive officer, effective May 20. He will succeed R. Manning Brown, who will step down at the mandatory retirement age of 65 after 30 years with the big New York-based insurer. Mr. Ross will be succeeded as president and chief administrative officer by Jacob R.  Underhill, 54. **********''Our business is pretty good, and we had an excellent year in individual life sales last year,'' Mr. Ross said yesterday.  ''Individual life is the biggest piece of what we do, but the prospects in the individual annuity and group pension areas are also very attractive. However, our net gains may not be as good as 1979 because the group business was not as good as in 1979.'' **********Mr. Ross joined New York Life in 1948 as a securities analyst and became a vice president 16 years later. He was promoted to executive vice president in 1974, appointed vice chairman in 1979 and named president last May. **********Mr. Underhill, a former newspaper reporter, magazine editor and assistant press secretary to Governor Rockefeller, spent five years as a New York State deputy superintendent of insurance before joining the corporation as vice president for corporate responsibilityy in 1972. He became a senior vice president in 1973, an executive vice president the following year and vice chairman in 1977. **********''I enjoy getting out and meeting our people in the field,'' Mr.  Ross said. ''There's no substitute for talking with your folks on the firing line where the rubber meets the road. We've got some hungry salesmen and they're awfully good. One of the jobs for the future is to build a little more depth and provide the folks to run the company in future years.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/22/busin.body_text: **********Citibank, the nation's second-largest commercial bank, raised its prime rate yesterday by one-half percentage point, joining other major banks that lifted theirs to 17 1/2 percent on Monday. **********The prime rate is what banks charge on loans to their most creditworthy corporate customers. **********Although the prime rate does not apply to consumer loans, it is considered an indicator of interest rates in general. **********All major banks are now quoting a prime rate of 17 1/2 percent, a level that took nearly two weeks to spread throughout the industry.  The consensus was slow to crystallize, analysts say, because of uncertainty about the future course of interest rates. **********Many bank economists have predicted a slowing of the nation's economy and a drop in interest rates between now and midyear. On Monday, however, the Government reported that economic growth in the first quarter was at a 6.5 percent annual rate, a much stronger pace than had been expected.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/19/world.main_headline: HAIG CITES 'HIT LIST' FOR SOVIET CONTROL OF CENTRAL AMERICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/19/world.print_headline: HAIG CITES 'HIT LIST' FOR SOVIET CONTROL OF CENTRAL AMERICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/19/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration made another attack on the Soviet Union today, with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. accusing it of being responsible for ''international terrorism,'' of having ''a hit list'' for domination of Central America, and of posing ''the most serious threat to world peace that we're facing.'' **********In the first public appearance before a Congressional committee since confirmation hearings in January, Mr. Haig Excerpts from testimony, page A10. was combative when liberal Democrats on the House Foreign Affairs Committee suggested he was overzealous in his concerns about Moscow. **********In answer to a question from Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, Mr. Haig said he agreed that it would be sterile to have ''a total preoccupation with the so-called Russians-are-coming syndrome,'' but he spent much of the hearing explaining why the Administration was so concerned about their behavior. **********Exchange With Representative **********In a lively exchange with Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of New York, Mr. Haig said attention ''is focused on the Soviet problem'' because ''of the dangerous trends which have resulted in the recent past from Soviet activity.'' **********''It does no good to pretend in our policies or our proclamations that that is not the most serious threat to world peace that we're facing today,'' he said. **********Ostensibly Mr. Haig appeared before the committee to defend the $6.87 billion security assistance program for the 1982 fiscal year, but his appearance was more akin to a news conference, with committee members asking questions. **********Mr. Haig made several other points in his testimony: **********- He indicated that the United States might have to supply some of the 2,500 troops for a peacekeeping force to be established in Sinai in April 1982 if other countries do not volunteer. The United States is obliged, under the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty, to take the lead in setting up an international force and some Pentagon officials favor an American presence as the first step toward a permanent land force in the Middle East. **********- Mr. Haig hinted that he favored repeal of a the 1976 law that bars covert aid to anti-Communist rebels in Angola. He said the legislation restricted Presidential authority. Experts on southern Africa have warned that such aid may upset efforts to bring about a peaceful settlement in South-West Africa. **********- He said he favored modification of legislation that bars aid to Pakistan because of a secret program to develop nuclear devices. He said the Administration wanted to avoid isolating countries like Pakistan so that they would not be driven ''toward the nuclear option.'' **********Several committee members expressed concern at the decision to provide Saudi Arabia with additional equipment for F-15 jets it has ordered. In response to a question from the ranking Republican on the committee, Representative William S. Broomfield of Michigan, Mr.  Haig put the Saudi decision in terms of a threat from the Soviet Union. Arab-Jewish Consensus Needed **********''It is fundamentally important to begin to develop a consensus of strategic concerns throughout the region among Arab and Jew and to be sure that the overriding danger of Soviet inroads is not overlooked,'' Mr. Haig said. **********In his opening statement, he said Israel played an important role ''in countering the more serious threats involving the Soviet Union.'' **********The ''most dangerous'' trend in the world, he said, ''is the growth of Soviet military power, which is now capable of supporting an imperial foreign policy.'' **********''Soviet adventurism in the Horn of Africa, in South Asia, in the Persian Gulf, and in South-West Africa appears to conform to a basic and ominous objective: to strike at countries on or near the vital resource lines of the Western world,'' Mr. Haig said in his statement. **********Asked about the concern over Soviet bloc aid to El Salvador, Mr.  Haig told the committee that the insurgency in El Salvador was only part of a ''four-phased operation'' in which the first part was ''the seizure of Nicaragua.'' **********''Next is El Salvador,'' he said, ''to be followed by Honduras and Guatemala.'' When asked by Representative Robert K. Dornan, Republican of California, whether this was ''a Caribbean domino theory,'' he replied: **********''I wouldn't call it necessarily a domino theory. I would call it a priority target list - a hit list, if you will - for the ultimate takeover of Central America.'' The 'Bottom Line' on Terrorism **********On terrorism, Mr. Haig amplified previous allegations that Moscow was responsible for much of the world's troubles.  ''When you get to the bottom line,'' he said, ''it is the Soviet Union which bears a major responsibility today for the proliferation and hemorrhaging, if you will, of international terrorism as we have come to know it.'' **********He said terrorrists ''maintain camps, training centers in the Soviet Union, in their Eastern European satellites, in Libya, where literally thousands of third world embryo-terrorists are running through a training course.'' **********''I think it's time that this issue be addressed publicly and be stated forthrightly no matter how much anguish it may give us,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/26/world.main_headline: BAKER SEES NO CHANGE IN AWACS TERMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/26/world.print_headline: BAKER SEES NO CHANGE IN AWACS TERMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/26/world.body_text: **********Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader of the Senate, said today that he did not envision any important change in the terms and conditions of the proposed sale of Awacs radar aircraft to Saudi Arabia. **********He said, however, that he believed it was still possible to prevent defeat for the proposed sale when the Senate votes on Wednesday.  The Tennessee Republican's remarks, made during a television appearance on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation,'' seemed to confirm statements by Administration officials that no effort was made to reopen or to renegotiate the terms of the $8.5 billion sale of the Airborne Warning and Control System planes and other air combat equipment when President Reagan met Friday in Cancun, Mexico, with Prince Fahd, the administrative head of the Saudi Arabian Government. **********Some Senators, including Republicans who have indicated they might consider switching from opposition to support of the sale, have said they would be influenced by any modification of the outright Saudi control and ownership of the Awacs aircraft that is an important element of the present proposal. **********No 'Bombshell' Foreseen **********With only three working days remaining before the Senate vote, scheduled for about 5 P.M. Wednesday, Mr. Baker said: ''I do not expect some major new announcement. I don't think there is going to be a bombshell of any sort.'' **********At another point Senator Baker was asked what new argument the President could present, and he answered, ''I don't think there are any new arguments.'' **********The House of Representatives has already voted to disapprove of the sale. If the Senate also votes to adopt a resolution of disapproval by the legal deadline next Saturday, the sale cannot take place unless the President chooses to exercise one of the two legal provisions that might permit him to waive the Congressional veto.  There is no evidence now that he plans to use either of those waiver provisions. **********Congress is empowered to veto such arms sales under Section 36b of the Military Export Controls Act, part of the basic Foreign Assistance Act. But the same law has a provision that allows a President to go ahead with an arms sale on his own if he ''states in his certification that an emergency exists, which requires such sale in the national security interests of the United States.'' **********A second law, Section 614 of the Foreign Assistance Act, also permits a President to approve up to $250 million of foreign aid despite Congressional opposition if he declares that it is needed in the interests of national security. Since the $8.5 billion sale is for cash, it would not be affected by the $250 million limit. President to See 7 Senators **********The President has invited seven Senators to the White House tomorrow and White House officials said he planned to see 11 more before Wednesday's vote. **********Senator Baker said during the televised interview that he expected some Senators who were now on record as opposing the Awacs sale to switch and support the President by Wednesday, but he would give no numbers. **********Of 50 Senators who originally sponsored a resolution of disapproval in early September, 47 are still publicly in favor of vetoing the sale, and three have switched to supporting the President in the last three weeks. Three Democratic Senators announced publicly last week that they would vote against the sale. **********Two more Senators have indicated they are almost certain to vote against the President. At least eight members are actually or nominally still uncommitted. **********The opponents of the sale say they do not believe that three or four switches will win for the White House because the opponents expect to pick up a share of the still undeclared votes. **********Walter F. Mondale, the former Vice President, said on the NBC News ''Meet the Press'' program that he believed ''it would be a wise move'' for President Reagan to withdraw the proposed sale before a Senate vote ''in order to avoid an embarrassment.'' **********Mr. Mondale said he had been opposed to the Awacs sale when he was Vice President and ''I'm opposed to it now.'' Former President Jimmy Carter and former Secretary of Defense Harold Brown have urged Congress to support the sale, while former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has expressed opposition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/19/busin.body_text: **********Although many economists who follow developments on the building front rely on a Commerce Department series for an accurate picture of work under way, an index of construction contract awards is valued as a leading indicator of what's in store for construction. The index is published by F.W. Dodge, a division of McGraw-Hill Inc. **********News of aggregate construction contract values for all residential, nonresidential and nonbuilding construction (highways, bridges and streets, for example) is compiled monthly by McGraw-Hill reporters across the country. Robert Murray, an economist at F.W.  Dodge, said that contract awards generally precede actual construction - which shows up in the Commerce Department numbers - by anywhere from one to four months. **********High interest rates severely hurt construction in 1980, and they threaten to do the same this year. Last year the Dodge Index declined nearly 13 percent from 1979 levels, the first annual drop since 1975. Total construction awards last year totaled more than $144 billion, down from $166 billion in 1979. After a sharp run-up during the first two months of the fourth quarter, interest rates have forced the index to retreat from its November levels. Contract activity in February, the most recent available monthly report, was 16 percent below the November peak. **********Construction contract awards showed their sharpest decline in the Middle West last year, where values were nearly 25 percent below 1979 levels. In spite of a 16 percent drop, the South remained the nation's dominant area for building in 1980, according to the McGraw-Hill figures, with more than $54 billion in construction contracts. The Northeast, with $25.6 billion, had the least impressive construction record in the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/13/busin.main_headline: TRUST HOUSES BIDS $130 MILLION TO BUY SAVOY HOTEL GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/13/busin.print_headline: TRUST HOUSES BIDS $130 MILLION TO BUY SAVOY HOTEL GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/13/busin.body_text: **********Trust Houses Forte Ltd., the international hotel and catering chain, made a $130 million bid today to acquire the Savoy Hotel group, which runs four of London's most luxurious hotels. **********The Savoy board, after consultations this afternoon, termed the surprise takeover bid ''utterly unacceptable,'' and vowed to fight it. **********Besides the Savoy Hotel, a grand, 90-year-old establishment overlooking the Thames, Savoy Hotel Ltd. also owns the Berkeley, Claridge's and the Connaught. All four charge nearly $200 a night for a double room, and project a mood of discreet opulence that has appealed for generations to a wealthy international clientele. **********The management of the Savoy group, which also includes the Lancaster Hotel in Paris and several restaurants, has successfully fought off takeover bids in the past, notably in 1971, when the prospective buyer was Trafalgar House Ltd., the property giant that owns Express Newspapers and Cunard Line. **********But Sir Charles Forte, who started with a milk bar on Regent Street at the age of 26 and now runs a $1 billion empire, is known as a shrewd master of corporate acquisition in the hotel and food service business. 'A Good Fight' Expected **********Analysts in London's financial district tonight were anticipating what one of them called ''a good fight'' between Sir Charles and the Savoy directors, who include Dame Bridget D'Oyly Carte, the 72-yearold granddaughter of Richard D'Oyly Carte, who built the Savoy Hotel (and also founded the Gilbert and Sullivan opera company) in the 19th century. **********At a news conference this afternoon, Sir Charles, who came to this country from Italy at the age of 5, and is now 72, said: ''There is a time for everything, and we think the time for a takeover bid is now.'' **********Tourism has slumped badly in Britain recently because of high prices, and the strength of the British pound has made it even worse for Americans and other foreigners. Luxury hotels have been particularly hard hit, and the Savoy group reported a loss in the first half of 1980 of $1.8 million, on total revenues of $30 million. **********''In the 91 years the company has been trading, it has more than once passed through difficult times, but the present conditions of trade, intensified by a worldwide recession, are as severe a handicap as any that have hitherto been encountered,'' the management told shareholders last fall, in reporting the loss. **********Earlier this year, it announced that it would sell a section of the Savoy Hotel, which contains about one-third of its 300 rooms, for conversion into offices and private apartments. Sir Charles, who is known in the business world for a sense of tradition and propriety that belies his success as an entrepreneur, was indignant at the Savoy's plan. **********''Can you imagine mutilating a fine old hotel that way?'' he asked last month. 'It's crazy.'' Improvements Planned **********If his company's bid for the Savoy group is successful, he said today, it would stop the losses within a year, and spend $30 million or more on improvements. **********''The name and individuality of Savoy's hotels will all be retained and the the standards of service with which those names have become associated will be preserved and enhanced,'' Trust Houses Forte said in a statement. **********The Kuwait Investment Office, a holding company that owns one-third of the Savoy's class A stock, promptly endorsed the Forte takeover bid. **********But the hotel company's voting structure is heavily weighted in favor of the class B shares, the majority of which are in the hands of Dame Bridget, Sir Hugh Wontner, the chairman, and other directors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/busin.main_headline: MONEY SUPPLY TO BE CURTAILED UNDER PROGRAM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/busin.print_headline: MONEY SUPPLY TO BE CURTAILED UNDER PROGRAM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/19/busin.body_text: **********In addition to tax reductions, spending cuts and deregulation of business, the White House is counting on a steady decline in the growth of the money supply as a major element of its new economic package. **********''A successful program to achieve stable and moderate growth patterns in the money supply will keep both inflation and interest rates down and restore vigor to our financial institutions and markets,'' President Reagan said in his televised address to the nation tonight. **********By 1986, according to a Government news release distributed today, the White House expects growth of money and credit to be half the level of 1980, thereby helping achieve the 4.2 percent inflation rate projected for that year. **********The focus on control of the money supply represents a sharp departure from economic programs of previous administrations.  ''It is a break with the notion of trying to hold interest rates down, which marked policies of the Carter Administration,'' commented Lacy H. Hunt, senior vice president and chief economist of the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia. Cooperation With Volcker **********The stage was set for close cooperation between Administration economic officials and the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A.  Volcker. **********The Federal Reserve is an independent agency, and Administration officials said they would do nothing to undermine its independence.  President Reagan emphasized in his speech, however, that ''we will consult regularly with the Federal Reserve Board on all aspects of our economic program and will vigorously pursue budget policies that will make their job easier in reducing monetary growth.'' **********The Federal Reserve used to try to control money growth by setting targets for interest rates.  Under procedures adopted in October 1979, however, the Federal Reserve now sets targets for growth of monetary reserves considered to be consistent with desired expansion of the money supply. Interest rates, meanwhile, are allowed to vary over a much wider range in response to market conditions. **********Reagan officials say they are hopeful of a ''stable and predictable'' monetary policy in the future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/23/world.body_text: **********The grounding of a Soviet submarine on the Swedish coast in late October cost Sweden $960,000 in surveillance and salvage operations, the defense staff said today. **********''These costs ought to be paid by the Soviet Union,'' the commander in chief, Gen. Lennart Ljung, said in a letter to the Government, a defense spokesman said. **********The amount included surveillance, inspection of the submarine's torpedoes and refloating of the craft during a storm, she said. **********''It is up to the Government to decide how much to charge the Soviets,'' the spokesman said. Civil costs were not included in the defense charges. **********During the 10-day confrontation before the aging submarine was allowed to sail out from the Karlskrona archipelago to the open seas, Soviet authorities agreed to pay salvage costs and certain other charges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.main_headline: IN INDIA, SIKHS RAISE A CRY FOR INDEPENDENT NATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.print_headline: IN INDIA, SIKHS RAISE A CRY FOR INDEPENDENT NATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.body_text: **********A 49-year-old former teacher sits cross-legged in the room he dares not leave for fear of arrest and explains passionately if seditiously how he advocates the creation of a Sikh nation to be wrenched violently from India. **********The movement represented by Balbhir Singh Sandhu is quixotic and relatively small, but it is growing quickly. Several hundred activists, most of them young, have fanned out through the villages of the heavily Sikh Punjab evangelizing for independence. In Delhi they go out on graffiti raids at night and leave behind the message, ''The Sikh are a nation.'' **********Mr. Sandhu has sought publicity for his cause by issuing passports in the name of Khalistan, the dreamed-of Sikh homeland that translates as the Country of the Pure. **********Amritsar is the holy city of the Sikhs, and nationalistically aroused Sikhs are leading demonstrations to ban the sale of cigarettes since the use of tobacco is forbidden to Sikhs. **********The Indian Government has responded to the Sikh nationalism with disdain. Asked about the Khalistan agitation, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said, ''It is in the United States and Canada,'' a reference to Sikhs living abroad who are supporting the movement. The Police Move Cautiously **********The police in the Punjab have arrested only a handful of the activists on charges of insulting the Constitution, clearly aware that the 512-year-old religion venerates its martyrs and that a crackdown could increase support for the activists. **********''If they seek to stop us by force, we will only grow that much faster,'' said Gajender Singh, a 30-year-old organizer for the Khalsa Dal, or Society of the Pure, a group that he said was being patterned after the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********Like Mr. Sandhu, who belongs to a different faction, Gajender Singh spends his days in the Sikh hostel attached to the Golden Temple, Sikhism's holiest shrine. It is from this sanctuary that they maintain contact with the 1,500 activists they say belong to their two groups. **********''We are maturing,'' said Gajender Singh. ''We have finished with the organizational stage and are now involved in propagation. Next will come direct action and then, finally, full-scale confrontation.  Like the P.L.O., we are seeking international recognition, and at home we are prepared to use terror, the political language of the 20th century.'' A Challenge to National Unity **********Though Indian authorities are showing restraint and treating such pronouncements as bluster, they are clearly aware that Sikh nationalism, even in incipient form, poses a challenge to national unity and the commitment to secular political development. **********The Punjab has a sensitive geography, adjoining Pakistan just south of Kashmir, the Indian state long sought by Pakistan.  There is widespread dissatisfaction among Sikhs who, though not ready to demand independence, say of themselves that they are an industrious and enterprising people who have contributed more to India than they have received. **********Activist Sikhs contend that the Sikhs were deceived at the time of partition. ''The British were willing to provide us with our homeland, but we were talked out of this by Nehru and Gandhi,'' said Mr. Sandhu, who calls himself the secretary general of the national council of Khalistan. ''The Hindus said that we would share with them in the Government, but they lied. What we are facing is Hindu imperialism, which threatens our integrity.'' Sikhs Do Not Cut Their Hair **********The Sikhs practice a monotheistic religion that arose as an attempt to synthesize Islam and Hinduism. A practicing male Sikh proclaims his identity by never cutting his hair, by wearing a dagger and an iron bracelet and by using the name Singh, which means lion. **********According to census statistics, Sikhs are among the better-off groups in India. Though forming less than 2 percent of the population, they account for more than 8 percent of the army and close to half the Olympic athletes. **********The Punjab has the richest farms and the highest per capita income. Sikh farmers produce the largest grain surpluses. They are a sizable and prominent minority in Delhi. They have a reputation for energy and enterprise, but it is sometimes rendered as pushiness and aggressiveness. Many Sikhs are active in politics; the important post of Home Minister is held by a Sikh, Zail Singh. **********Narendrajit Singh is the official spokesman for the Golden Temple and as such reflects the Sikh establishment. He disassociates himself from the activists but acknowledges that many of their grievances are valid. A List of Complaints **********''The Punjab is well off, but it is due to ourselves and our efforts and not the Government,'' he said.  Subsidies on fertilizers have been removed. Sikh farmers are discouraged from selling grain at world prices and are coerced into selling at lower Government prices. But worst of all, he said, the Government is withholding licenses from the Punjab, depriving talented Sikhs of opportunities to share in major industrial projects. **********Narendrajit Singh said he did not think that many Sikhs wanted to break with India.  ''Many of us like myself came over from Pakistan during partition and we know what it is like,'' he said. But he said most Sikhs feel they are thwarted rather than aided by the Government. **********For Gajender Singh, the ardent young nationalist, the material inequities are insignificant. Fighting for Their Identity **********''Even if we had industries and even if every member of the Indian Cabinet was a Sikh, we would still want independence because what we are fighting for is our cultural integrity,'' he said. **********Khushwant Singh, an editor and author who has written a two-volume history of his people, has said that a pervasive fear among the Sikhs is that they may be absorbed by the elasticity of Hinduism. This happened to another sect, the Jains. **********''The Indians say they have a secular state, but it is really a Hindu state and it advances Hindu imperialism,'' said Gajender Singh. ''They say that Sikhism is really a part of Hinduism. This is false.  This land was ruled by Sikhs and it will be ruled by Sikhs.'' **********He pointed to a map in his room that showed the Punjabi-speaking areas of India, which have as many Hindus as they have Sikhs, as the area of Khalistan. Sikhs Play the Kashmir Card **********Such assertions of cultural identity would be largely of anthropological interest if not for the presence of Pakistan and Kashmir, and this is a card that the activists are playing. **********''We have no problem with Pakistan,'' said Balbhir Singh Sandhu.  Gajender Singh said his group was trying to establish close contacts with Jamiat-e-Islami, an organization of Moslem fundamentalists in Kashmir who favor ties to Pakistan. **********''One day the people of Kashmir will turn to Pakistan and we will benefit,'' said Gajender Singh. ''One thing is certain: the next war with Pakistan will result in a Pakistani Kashmir and a sovereign Khalistan.'' **********It may be bluster, but it is troublesome bluster for an Indian Government that says it is trying to preserve a secular orientation.  The Government has been embarrassed by recent efforts by Sikhs to get associate status at the United Nations for Khalistan groups. Sikhs Seek Refugee Status **********In recent weeks, more than a thousand Sikhs went to Canada on visitor permits and tried to gain permanent entry by declaring themselves political refugees victimized by India because of their demands for an independent Khalistan. The Canadians have dismissed the claims, accusing unscrupulous Indian travel agents of concocting the ploy as a way around Canadian immigration laws. **********The Communist press here has written that the Khalistan issue is a creation of the American Central Intelligence Agency, which pro-Soviet papers say is working to strengthen Pakistan and weaken India. **********Gajender Singh and Balbhir Singh Sandhu deny that they have any links to the West, but Gajender Singh adds, ''We would be willing to accept help from any foreign country.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/25/busin.body_text: **********Eastern Airlines said it would cut to $29 its one-way fare on selected shuttle flights between New York, Boston and Washington for passengers between ages 2 and 21. **********Regular fares normally are $59 between New York and Washington, and $49 between New York and Boston. Eastern said the $29 fare would apply Monday through Friday on the 11 A.M., noon and 1 P.M. departures from all three cities, and also on the 8 P.M. and 9 P.M. flights Monday through Thursday. The fares will be in effect from March 26 to June 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/15/busin.body_text: **********The Natomas Company said the United States District Court in Los Angeles had granted a temporary order restraining the Magma Power Company, its chairman and directors from communicating with Magma shareholders on the merits of a $42-a-share tender offer by Natomas. **********A hearing on the issue was scheduled for next Monday. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/world.main_headline: Jew Who Hijacked a Plane Is Reported Missing in Soviet
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Jew Who Hijacked a Plane Is Reported Missing in Soviet
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/world.body_text: **********Iosif Mendelevich, who was involved in an attempt to hijack a Soviet plane 11 years ago, reportedly has disappeared from a Soviet labor camp, his sister said today. **********Mr. Mendelevich is the last Jewish member held in the Soviet Union of a group that tried to hijack a plane from Leningrad and escape to Israel. **********The others have emigrated. **********His sister, Rivka Drori, told reporters that friends in Moscow recently received a letter from the commander of Mr. Mendelevich's labor camp in the Urals saying Mr. Mendelevich had disappeared. The letter did not elaborate. **********Mrs. Drori said she feared that her brother, who has not been allowed visits from friends for several years, might be in a hospital or even have died.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/28/busin.body_text: **********Washington's largest single benefit program - Medicare - celebrates its 15th birthday this week. It's likely to be an unhappy one.  Inflation, a rapidly aging population and the need to cut costs in entitlement programs are likely to force sharp reductions in what has been viewed as a sacrosanct area of government spending. **********With nearly 30 million Americans currently enrolled, and many more scheduled to join the ranks of those over 65 during the 1980's, analysts at the Congressional Budget Office don't see how how the program can continue to fund itself unless cuts in benefits or payments to hospitals and physicians are enacted. **********Currently, House and Senate committees propose to lop more than $1 billion off spending estimates for 1982, much more than what Mr.  Reagan proposed. About half of those cuts are likely to go through this year. Further on, the reductions could be far more severe if the Administration's economic forecast doesn't pan out. Unless current laws are changed, the C.B.O. estimates that Medicare costs will double by 1986, to $80.5 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/11/busin.body_text: **********United States auto production last month tumbled 26 percent from November, 1980, to its lowest November level since 1970, Automotive News, an industry journal, said today. **********The month's production of 415,802 cars compared with 562,380 built in November 1980, the publication reported. **********The figure was the lowest November total since 372,561 in 1970, when production at the General Motors Corporation was slowed by a strike. **********The journal also said United States car makers plan to make 25.6 percent fewer cars next month than they did in December 1980, putting production for the year at about 6.3 million cars, down 1.6 percent from about 6.4 million last year. **********This week, United States car makers plan to build 101,265 cars, up 14.9 percent from 88,100 made last week but down 33.3 percent from 151,812 in the comparable 1980 week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/20/world.print_headline: SOVIET ACTIONS INSIDE POLAND BEING STUDIED; Military Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/20/world.body_text: **********The Polish crackdown against the independent trade union Solidarity may not be as successful as it is pictured in official pronouncements from Warsaw, according to analysts in Washington and at NATO headquarters in Brussels. **********One analyst said that the two Soviet armored divisions in Poland had left their barracks and been deployed in urban areas, suggesting that this reflected difficulties faced by the Polish martial-law regime. The analyst would not identify the destinations of the armored units, but sources at North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters said they believed that the tanks had been sent to the Gdansk and Warsaw regions. **********The Soviet divisions appear to be playing a backup role.  Intelligence sources say that the Soviet Union does not want to intervene but that Soviet political and military leaders hold that, if the Polish repression fails, intervention may be necessary to stifle a movement that could have the gravest effect on the rest of the Soviet bloc. **********Cloud Cover Hinders Information **********Intelligence gathering about Soviet movements has been impeded by the heavy cloud cover that has blanketed eastern Europe since Monday.  Analysts could not confirm persistent rumors that Soviet landing craft were being loaded with troops at Riga, Latvia, and at other ports on the Baltic Sea in preparation for a landing on Poland's northern coast. **********Pentagon sources, however, said that a sea landing would be an expensive and complicated form of intervention, considering that Soviet forces control major airfields in Poland and would probably have little difficulty in transporting troops and equipment by road or rail. **********American and NATO analysts said they were surprised by the criticism that United States intelligence had failed to anticipate the use of Polish forces rather than the Soviet Army against Solidarity. **********Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy, said Thursday that there had been ''a collective failure'' in intelligence gathering and assessment before the Polish Army moved. Mr. Perle asserted that American concern over the possibility of Soviet involvement resulted in insufficient concentration on the Polish Army's mission. **********Military analysts pointed out, however, that there was no reliable way of monitoring a Polish operation that they said they believed was the result of verbal orders issued by the high command. Army on a Medium Alert **********A NATO analyst said that the Polish Army had been on ''a medium alert for the last fortnight,'' that the forces had clearly been told their mission and that all that was necessary was ''a single word of command.'' **********Nor do Western analysts place much credence in a West German theory that the military takeover began last month when hundreds of small military units were deployed in the countryside to symbolize the Government's interest in equitable food distribution by local authorities. **********The military takeover, the analysts said, was a far wider operation, one that demanded extensive planning for the deployment of major units. **********The Polish high command's plans, they believe, were submitted to Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov, the Soviet officer who commands all Warsaw Pact forces, before he left the Polish capital on Dec. 15.  Marshal Kulikov, who was in Warsaw before the crackdown began, is reported to have returned to Moscow after having approved the Polish plans. **********The analysts said persistent reports that Soviet transport planes had been landing in Poland should be seen in the perspective of normal logistical arrangements for Soviet troops in the country.  Spare parts, replacements and some food are normally sent to the two armored divisions and the tactical air force stationed in Poland. **********NATO's position was described by one official there as ''watchful waiting.'' The communique issued at the end of the meeting of NATO foreign ministers Dec. 11 declared that the Polish people ''must be free to solve their problems without interference or pressure of any kind.'' **********NATO, one analyst said, is clearly not prepared to take any action now.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/17/world.main_headline: Around The World; Bulgarian Prime Minister Is Reported Replaced
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/17/world.print_headline: Around The World; Bulgarian Prime Minister Is Reported Replaced
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/17/world.body_text: **********Stanko Todorov was replaced today as Prime Minister of this Soviet Bloc nation, the state press agency B.T.A. said. **********Grisha Filipov, a Communist Party Politburo member and Secretary of the party Central Committee, was named to the post and asked to present a list of new ministers to Parliament, the Bulgarian agency said. **********The announcement came as a surprise to Western diplomats who said it might have been the latest move in longstanding efforts of the Government and the Communist Party leader, Todor Zhivkov, to limit the accumulation of power by other politicians. **********The change was expected to have no affect on the overall policies of Bulgaria, long guided by Mr. Zhivkov and a firmly pro-Moscow member of the Warsaw Pact. **********The Bulgarian press agency said Mr. Todorov, 60 years old, had been elected chairman of the country's newly elected Parliament. The change amounts to a demotion in Bulgaria's Communist hierarchy. **********B.T.A. also reported that Mr. Zhivkov had been re-elected Tuesday as President of the country's State Council.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/22/world.body_text: **********Around The World; London Police Charge 2 And Hold 28 Over Rioting **********LONDON, June 20 (AP) - Two persons were charged today and 28 were being held for questioning after last night's rioting by 450 youths in the south London suburb of Peckham. The rioters pelted the police with broken fence rails, broke windows and looted stores. **********Peckham is about two miles from Brixton, the mostly nonwhite neighborhood that was the scene of violent disturbances in April. ---- **********LONDON, June 21 (UPI) - One person died of smoke inhalation and at least 16 were injured today in London's third subway fire in nine days. Fire officials said the blaze, on the Northern Line near Oxford Circus in central London, trapped more than 100 passengers for 35 minutes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/25/world.print_headline: Around the World; Afghans Offer Terms For Talks on Rebellion
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/25/world.body_text: **********Afghanistan announced new terms today for negotiations to end the Moslem guerrilla rebellion that led to Soviet military intervention, the Kabul radio reported. **********For the first time, the Soviet-supported regime agreed to an active role for Secretary General Kurt Waldheim in eventual negotiations and dropped a condition that talks with Iran and Pakistan be held separately. **********It did not, however, meet the demands of Iran and Pakistan for Soviet troops to withdraw before talks and for recognition of the right of the Afghan people to choose their own government. The Afghan statement, which was monitored here, also reiterated a condition set May 14, 1980, that negotiations directly involve the Afghan Government headed by President Babrak Karmal. He was instaled when the Soviet Union intervened in December 1979. **********The announcement today coincided with the arrival in Pakistan of a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Nikolai P. Firyubin, for talks with Government leaders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/10/world.main_headline: SOUTH AFRICAN DISCLOSES BID TO 'BREAK' BLACK UNION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/10/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICAN DISCLOSES BID TO 'BREAK' BLACK UNION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/10/world.body_text: **********Only days after legislation was introduced in Parliament to legitimize further the status of black trade unions, South Africa's Minister of Police has acknowledged that a security officer circulated a memorandum on union-busting tactics among corporations in East London, where a militant black trade union has succeeded in organizing a mass membership. **********The minister, Louis Le Grange, who made the disclosure in Parliament, gave no indication in responding to a legislator's question that he saw any irregularity in the security police's efforts to shape the development of the black trade union movement.  His brief statement followed by only a few days the introduction of the latest installment in legislation changing the labor laws, a bill that was remarkable for South Africa in that it makes no reference to race in seeking to define the legal role of trade unions in the industrial system. **********But while the legislation was giving black unions legitimate status, the security police memorandum to employers in East London, an industrial port on the Indian Ocean, made a series of proposals designed ''to break the power'' of unions that are determined to be outspoken on political issues. The employers, for instance, were counseled to keep a register of unemployed people ''who could start work at very short notice'' in the event of a strike. **********New Status for Black Unions **********Until two years ago, black trade unions had no legal status, and employers were under no obligation to deal with them. Few of them, in fact, did. **********Now black unions can operate under the industrial conciliation system, which was originally designed for white workers who seldom threatened to strike since their privileges were defined on a racial basis and entrenched in the law. The new black unions have split on the question of whether that system can meet the needs of the mass of low-paid, unskilled or semiskilled black laborers who fill about 60 percent of all manufacturing jobs. **********Unions that have refused to register under the existing industrial conciliation system have been the ones most closely monitored by the security police. These include the African Food and Canning Workers Union in Cape Town, whose national organizer, Oscar Mpheta, is now the main figure in an elaborately-staged murder and terrorism trial here; the Motor Assemblies and Components Workers Union, a new group that has taken root at the Ford Motor Company in Port Elizabeth and spread from there to neighboring factories, and the South African Allied Workers Union of East London. Union Says It Is Succeeding **********The leaders of the East London union have been repeatedly arrested and detained without charge in the last year, but despite the arrests it says it has signed up a membership of 16,000 black workers in that time. About 2,000 of those have since been dismissed as a result of strikes and other confrontations with East London companies, only one of which has entered into a formal collective-bargaining agreement with the union. **********Others, including two American-owned companies, Johnson & Johnson and Hoover Appliances, have acknowledged that the union has won the allegiance of a majority of their black workers, and they have negotiated with its leaders on the question of formal recognition without reaching an agreement. The publication of the security police memorandum confirmed earlier reports that the companies have been under official pressure to withhold recognition. **********The memorandum declared that the leaders of various business organizations in East London had been attending meetings, presumably with representatives of the security police, ''where the aims of S.A.A.W.U. are explained to them as well as the necessity of uniform action by industry in East London against S.A.A.W.U.'' The S.A.A.W.U. is the South African Allied Workers Union. 'Do Not Have to Fear a Strike' **********The memorandum suggested that the lists of unemployed people in the area be kept at a ''central point'' so that ''firms with labor differences or problems can be informed about these lists and the number of unemployed persons looking for work and therefore do not have to fear a strike.'' **********The text of the memorandum was printed in The South African Labor Bulletin, a journal for social scientists and union activists, but it said the document was jointly drafted by the security police, the Ministry of Manpower Utilization and the Ministry of Cooperation and Development. The memorandum blames much of the ferment among black workers in recent years on ''white agitators,'' and asserts that workers were being ''indoctrinated.'' **********''One can expect that in the near future East London will be plagued by a wave of strikes,'' the memorandum warns. A police raid on the union's office, it says, revealed that it had potential organizers ''in practically every big business or industry in East London.'' One Solution Is Mentioned **********The memorandum concedes that black workers have real grievances, such as low wages and separation from their families under the South African migrant labor system. But when it speaks of ''long-term solutions'' for the problem of labor militancy, it mentions only the possibility of legislation to force black unions to limit their activities to specific industries. Such a law, the document suggests, would inhibit the growth of a labor movement capable of calling a general strike on a local or national basis. **********It also suggests that employers should seek to ''activate and motivate'' the Trade Union Congress of South Africa, a white-led movement that has been signing black workers in competition with the unions that are led by blacks. **********The memorandum is reported to have been circulated late last year.  Since then, companies in East London that have faced strikes by the South African Allied Workers Union have tended to discharge the strikers, hire unemployed workers and negotiate agreements with white-led unions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/27/busin.body_text: *********** Charles Schwab & Co. said that it had agreed to acquire the Baltimore and Laurel, Md., offices of Brokers Exchange Inc. for an undisclosed price. The move marks Schwab's first entry into Maryland, the company said. *********** Coca-Cola Co. said that the Government of China had signed an agreement to build and operate a second Coca-Cola bottling plant in China, to be in Canton. *********** Dial Corp., a financial holding company, said that it had agreed to purchase about $40 million of receivables from Suburban Finance Co. of Roseland, N.J. The price was not disclosed. *********** Gerber Children's Centers Inc., a subsidiary of Gerber Products Co., said that it had agreed to purchase 10 child care centers in northwestern Ohio. Terms and the identity of the seller were not disclosed. *********** Gulf and Western Industries said that it had increased its share of Cluett, Peabody & Co. to 7.87 percent of the common stock outstanding. *********** Quay-Perfex Inc. said that it had ended discussions with Suter Electrical Ltd., a British company, and its subsidiary, Prestcold Holding Ltd., concerning the possible acquistion of a 51 percent shareholding in Prestcold's Searle Manufacturing Ltd. *********** Midlantic Banks Inc. of West Orange, N.J., said that shareholders of Burlington County National Bank had approved the acquisition of Burlington by Midlantic. *********** N.C.R Corp. agreed to purchase a line of office work stations from Convergent Technologies Inc. Terms were not mentioned. *********** Selmer Co., a subsidiary of North American Philips Corp., and Ludwig Industries, a Chicago-based maker of drums and other percussion instruments, agreed in principle for Selmer to acquire the assets and business of Ludwig for an undisclosed sum. *********** Synalloy Corp. said that it had increased its stake in Kysor Industrial Corp. to 6.6 percent of the common shares outstanding. *********** Vulcan Industrial Packaging Ltd. said that it had completed the purchase of Plant Industries Inc.'s Canadian operations for $16.5 million in Canadian currency. *********** Western Union Corp. said that its principal subsidiary, Western Union Telegraph Co., had won regulatory approval to build its sixth domestic communications satellite. Cost of the new satellite will be about $28 million. *********** Zapata Corp. said that it had signed a construction contract for a drilling rig worth about $115 million to be built by Kawasaki Heavy Industries Ltd. for delivery in August 1983.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/22/busin.print_headline: READERS DISPUTE WHY WOMEN EARN LESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/22/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: **********Obviously, nothing short of a restructuring of the entire labor market will eliminate the disproportionate number of women in lower paid positions. Even then, I question whether the 40 percent gap can be eliminated. **********My cynicism is based on evidence which goes back a bit further than Professor Thurow's ''long time.'' To wit: In Leviticus 27;1-4, ''When the Lord spoke unto Moses, He said: '. . . thy valuation shall be for the male from 20 years old even until 60 years old . . . 50 shekels of silver . . . and if it be a female, then thy valuation shall be 30 shekels.''  MARILYN RUBIN, Associate Professor of Urban Affairs and Policy Analysis, New School for Social Research, New York, N.Y., March 10, 1981

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/busin.main_headline: G.M. and Ford Delay Steel Orders
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; G.M. and Ford Delay Steel Orders
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company have told steel producers to postpone deliveries to some auto plants through December, according to a trade publication. **********Executives of the Inland Steel Company, the Republic Steel Corporation and the McLouth Steel Corporation told the magazine American Metal Market that G.M.'s action apparently stems from the auto maker's decision to reduce production plans for its ''X''-body and ''J''-body cars by 70,000 vehicles. **********That would eliminate the need for about 100,000 tons of steel, industry sources said.  ''We have reported in recent weeks that some adjustments are being made in our assembly schedules to bring production in line with market demand,'' G.M. said in a statement. ''Such reductions reduce the amount of steel needed at General Motors.'' The auto maker would not confirm specific details of the report. **********A Ford executive, who asked not to be identified, told the publication that Ford will delay taking delivery of 25,000 tons of steel ordered for December to be used for January production. **********''We have an 89-day inventory on steel,'' he said. ''That's 29 days more of inventory than what we want. We usually have a 60-day inventory. If this trend continues, we won't be buying steel until sales go up.'' **********A source at Republic Steel told the New York-based publication that steel buying by domestic auto makers for November is down by at least 25 percent from the third-quarter average.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/busin.main_headline: HOW THE OIL GLUT IS CHANGING BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/busin.print_headline: HOW THE OIL GLUT IS CHANGING BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/busin.body_text: **********Oil glut! What once seemed as unlikely as $850 gold or an 18 percent Treasury bill is here. Suddenly, oil is so plentiful that prices are falling by amounts that impress even big-time corporate decisionmakers. **********Businesses across the country, which for a decade have seen nothing but oil stealing an ever larger bite of their operating dollar, are calculating what they can do to capitalize on the oil price drop. While most such adjustments are quick and modest, some companies are already puzzling over how to factor the newly favorable oil situation into longer range plans as well. **********To be sure, the dominant mood remains one of great caution. After all, world energy consumers have watched helplessly for years as the price of oil raced in breathtaking spurts from next to nothing to more than $40 a barrel while consumers endured periodic shortages that made some wonder if oil would ever be freely available again. **********''The surplus could be with us a while,'' said James E. McNabb, an economist for Conoco Inc., a major oil, natural gas and coal producer. ''But it should be viewed as a temporary phenomenon that could change overnight,'' he added. ''In the world of corporate planning we're learning not to overreact to immediate situations.'' **********At company after company, however, there is evidence that the glut and price break are being taken seriously enough to influence planning. **********Take the case of John B. Walters, manager of the Firestone Tire & Rubber Company's largest plant. Tomorrow morning in Des Moines, Mr.  Walters will sit down to study fresh Department of Energy figures dictating what he must pay for natural gas. He will probably conclude that the plant should switch in July to burning oil instead. The heavy No. 6 oil his plant is also equipped to use has tumbled in price recently, wiping out what was once a large advantage for gas. **********''We're fighting for our jobs out here,'' Mr. Walters declared, noting that in the past Firestone has often had to shift some production to Illinois, where gas is cheaper than in Iowa. **********''We have to look at the economics of it,'' Mr. Walters added. ''If oil is cheaper, we'll use it - and it certainly looks that way.'' The Consolidated Edison Company, which alone burns about 1 percent of the nation's oil, is looking at ''every cargo'' being offered these days in New York harbor, though it has not yet raised its purchases much because of the high cost of financing inventories and a lack of storage space. **********The Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railway Company is being offered diesel oil contracts for up to a year, something suppliers ''haven't been willing to do until very recently,'' a spokesman says. (Price, however, is still adjustable.) **********Airline entrepreneur Dan A. Colussy, who recently announced plans to create a new short-haul line on the East Coast, says he is tempted to buy his jet fuel in the spot market, though he will probably decide he can't take such a risk. **********As an indication of how things might change over the longer term, the Caterpillar Tractor Company says that if oil supplies remain ample, it might decide to design new plants to burn oil with natural gas as a backup, reversing current practice. **********For the first time in many years corporate strategists do not have to automatically assume that oil prices will be rising by at least the inflation rate and probably by much more. **********Already some serious students of energy are arguing that no price increase exceeding the inflation rate is likely during the next two years. They say price-induced conservation has now cut Western demand so greatly that it has caused some disarray within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********When OPEC failed at its meeting last month to come to an agreement on cutting production, and thus taking the edge off the glut, the price impact was quick to be felt. Most OPEC nations eliminated any surcharges over the official price still in effect and Ecuador actually cut its official price by $3.80 a barrel. **********Among nonmembers, Mexico dropped its price $4 a barrel to the $28-to-$34.50-a-barrel range. (While it later rescinded that cut, domestic political reasons were cited, not oil economics.) And Britain announced a $2-a-barrel cut, later deepened to $4.25, that brought its North Sea crude down to $35 a barrel, roughly in line with Saudi Arabia, the lowest-price OPEC member. The spot price, for oil not under long-term contract, has fallen below $32 a barrel for the first time since last August, after jumping above $42 in November after the Iran-Iraq war broke out. **********But though the profitability of many fuel-sensitive industries - airlines, utilities, metals and paper - is significantly enhanced by the current decline in oil prices, interviews with a score of business planners show them to be profoundly skeptical that a new era has arrived. Most companies still have far to go in adjusting to the price increases that have already occurred. **********American Airlines, for example, has recently decided to retire the last of its fuel-thirsty 707's by the end of August instead of in mid-September. Executives of the Santa Fe are making public speeches these days in which company research into the aerodynamics of locomotives and freight cars, to improve fuel efficiency, is a major theme. **********The reluctance of corporate planners to embrace the notion of stable oil prices indefinitely owes much to the severity of the jolts of the 1970's and the fact that while the narrow economics of oil may have changed for the better, the politics of the situation has not.  the Middle East, dominant supplier to America's allies in Europe and a major source for the United States itself, remains as unstable as ever. **********''The biggest effect of the oil surplus on us so far is that we're guessing this element of costs will go up at a lower rate than we were previously forecasting,'' said David K. Barnes, a senior vice president of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, who doubts that companies can yet safely shift their long-range view of energy prices and supplies. ''It's just a moderation of the cost - and not an opportunity for strategic change.'' **********Du Pont, which relies on oil and natural gas as a feedstock in 70 percent of its products, will continue to push its program to use more coal as a plant power source. **********Company officials also point out that despite almost daily headlines about sharp declines in OPEC and other oil prices, it takes time for these to flow through to individual businesses, many of which also use large amounts of increasingly expensive natural gas. **********And unlike oil, which in January was totally freed of United States price controls, a move that itself may have contributed to the current price decline by inducing more conservation, natural gas is to rise steadily by statute until at least 1985. **********The country's car and truck manufacturers, not surprisingly, appear the most optimistic about oil, though there is no intention to, say, revive the V-8 engine because of lower gasoline prices or the rebound in prices for big used cars in certain areas. **********The oil surplus, says a spokesman for the General Motors Corporation, ''might make us relax a little bit about the automobile sales picture. If the perception increases that there is an ample supply of gasoline, that we'd see as highly positive.'' **********According to Jacques R. Maroni, director of energy planning for the Ford Motor Company, there has never been a genuine fuel shortage for cars and there probably will not be for a century or more. **********He says the facts about oil have not changed, simply the perception of them. ''There was no shortage, there is no glut,'' Mr. Maroni asserted. Supplies, in other words, have moved from below ground in the oil fields to oil-company storage tanks. **********''What we now have is a gradual settling back down (of prices) so oil does not lose its markets,'' Mr. Maroni continued. During the next few years ''you're going to find a generously supplied oil market at a price which will not rise in real terms.'' In fact, because of the availability of alternative fuels he said there is ''no fuels he said there is ''no reason'' why the price of gasoline should ever rise above $2 a gallon after adjusting for future after adjusting for future inflation. **********OPEC, he declared, is just ''a trade association, a country club'' dominated by Saudi Arabia, which he thinks for political reasons may be forced to let real prices actually decline for an extended period. **********The Department of Energy, meanwhile, has made no change in the basic assumption it has used for the past two years that oil prices will show annual real price increases of about 3 percent during the 1980's and 1990's. **********But, according to Roger F. Naill, associate director for energy analysis, this may now not apply over the next two years or so.  What's happening now, he said, ''seems a natural reacin 1979. One should have expected to see a glut.'' Nonetheless, the Energy Information Administration, an arm of the Energy Department, did not. Its quarterly short-term forecast in February for 1981 gasoline prices -stickers so annual fuel costs can be computed - was $1.55 a gallon, far above today's price. A year earlier this forecast was much too low, 90 cents a gallon. **********Though American companies are not rushing to revise long-term plans, some are being forced to react quickly to lower oil prices right now. **********Perhaps the most threatened are natural gas pipelines, which are already losing business from people like Firestone's Mr. Walters and are in danger of losing lots more. **********''The oil jobbers have been able to come in and undercut the price,'' complained Kenneth W. Thompson, a vice president of the Interstate Natural Gas Association, a trade group. One constituent, he said, has lost seven industrial customers in recent weeks after they found cheap residual oil ''dumped'' by refiners to fire their plants instead. **********''When they've got a glut of No. 6 oil they have to get rid of it,'' Mr. Thompson said. ''The people they market it to are our marginal users. This is something we are very concerned about in terms of the future of our industry.'' **********In its apparent eagerness to keep Firestone on natural gas, Mr.  Walters said, his supplier, the Iowa Power & Light Company, has been getting a bit ''clever'' about pricing recently, he observed. **********Some planners say that synthetic fuels projects may also prove to be casualties of the current oil market.  ''I suspect there is some careful rethinking of projects just on the border,'' said Mr. McNabb of Conoco, whose own company scrubbed a proposed synthetic gas plant this spring. **********Just last week the new chairman of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, Edward E. Noble, told the chief sponsor of the Great Plains Coal Gasification project in North Dakota he had doubts both about the need for the gas and the price it would have to command. **********Although the oil surplus is an internatinal phenomenon, the main beneficiary of falling prices so far has been the United States. This is because oil is priced in dollars and for various reasons, including lower American oil imports and high interest rates, the dollar has been very strong against most other currencies. **********Thus, according to Mr. Maroni of Ford, Europeans think prices are still rising and therefore buying less gasoline.  ''Overseas,'' he declared, ''I detect quite a bit of price resistance,'' a fact that bodes well for continued oil surpluses and for American oil users.
