https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Cable Video Future Is Topic
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Cable Video Future Is Topic
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/busin.body_text: **********IN at least two locations in town yesterday people were talking in public about the future of cable video. At the Plaza, where the Association of National Advertisers Television Workshop began its two-day stay, the interest was in programming. At the New York Hilton, where the Advertising Research Foundation was finishing up its two-day conference, the stress was on audience measurement. **********And there was agreement at both that while the cable industry is still aborning it is time to act.  ''The possibilities are endless and the opportunities for the advertiser to become involved and help shape the programming of tomorrow exist today,'' said Michael Lepiner, president of Telecom Entertainment, a newly formed subsidiary of Benton & Bowles. A young man, Mr. Lepiner, probably is not aware of how in the early days of television critics decried the involvement of advertisers in programming. **********So he could say of the lack of current involvement: ''I believe many of you today would have preferred a more direct role creatively and economically in the program product which is your avenue to the public and one of the largest expenditures of your business.'' **********''In an industry which you singly support financially, it is ironic that you exercise so little creative and financial control of your destiny.'' **********Bristol-Myers, an advertiser with a keen interest in cable, was represented among the speakers by Robert Turner, its director of advertising services. He saw great promise for cable in the way regular television is moving toward greater audience selectivity - advertisers, for economic reasons, using programming to more closely define target groups. **********He said that even though for a long time to come cable would not offer sizable audiences, it would constitute a reasonable advertising buy since it offered a low-cost way to reach a well-defined audience with frequency. **********His company last week announced that it had signed an agreement with the USA Cable Network to present 10 hours a week of healthoriented original programming for 10 years starting next October. **********Over at the A.R.F. conference, Ronald B. Kaatz, a senior vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, reminded his audience that a cable measurement committee made up of people from both the advertising and cable industries was already at work evaluating proposals for cable audience-measuring methodology, probably the ''first time in the media research world that the buyers and sellers of a medium are consulting before a technique is developed as to just what it should look like.'' **********To those who think that cable will offer selectivity of audience much as specialty magazines and radio do, Mr. Kaatz said: ''Not so, if you regard cable as a new and distinct media form which will offer high viewer involvement and be in many ways close to direct mail, direct response and shopping newspapers than to television.  There must be acknowledgement of this before we design the calipers to measure cable.'' **********He warned of a new phenomenon, or at least the aggravation of a current one, with the increase in the number of channels to watch.  More flipping. In Canada, he reported, where there is 70 percent penetration by cable, there is a game popular among the young called zapping. The object is to see how long you can view the tube without sitting through a commercial. What's the record? **********The lead speaker at the A.N.A.-TV Workshop was A.B. Priemer, director of advertising services of S.C. Johnson and known throughout the business as Gus. He spoke about an economically important topic of wear-out, that is when TV commercials start to lose their effectiveness from too much viewing. His well-made point was that before such a thing as wear-out can be measured it must first be discovered how advertising works. **********''Wearing out means, or should mean, a decline in the working of a TV commercial,'' he said. ''We obviously can't measure the decline of this invisible, untelligible process.'' **********Mr. Priemer got off a number of keen observations, not the least of which was his comment on the value of high recall scores for advertising. ''Most of you would remember a commercial for a solarpowered nose-warmer,'' he said. ''You wouldn't buy one, but you wouldn't forget it either.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/busin.main_headline: INVESTOR INTEREST IN ST. JOE EASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/busin.print_headline: INVESTOR INTEREST IN ST. JOE EASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/14/busin.body_text: **********Despite some expectations of higher bids for the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, its shares fell 1 1/2 points, to 47 1/2, in heavy trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. **********''Everybody's bullish expectations that somebody else will enter the picture calmed down somewhat,'' a Wall Street investment banker said. ''They thought they'd get $55; now they may get something in the high 40's or low 50's.'' **********Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, a Canadian wine and liquor company, has offered to pay $45 a share, or some $2 billion, but Wall Street bankers expect St. Joe to resist the proposal. They say there is a strong possibility that Seagram will have to sweeten the price. **********In a related matter, Seagram said yesterday that it had amended a lawsuit filed Wednesday against St. Joe and Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York State. The original suit, now in abeyance by mutual agreement between Seagram and St. Joe, was designed to block a New York State takeover law giving Mr. Abrams the right to call a hearing in acquisition cases. **********The amendment charged St. Joe with ''false and misleading'' statements last Wednesday and Thursday that the $45 offer was ''grossly inadequate.'' Seagram contended that St. Joe had not conducted any study adequate enough to support such a statement, and that it had made the statement to mislead St. Joe investors. Large Mineral Holdings **********St. Joe, the nation's largest lead producer, also has vast oil and gas operations in the United States and in Canada and owns immense coal deposits in a joint venture with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. **********Stephen A. Royce, one Wall Street professional, remarked, ''The stock market is saying they'll come to a friendly deal, but at a higher price.'' **********''Somebody else may buy St. Joe,'' another said, ''although I don't believe they're talking to anyone else. Even so, St. Joe will ultimately be sold.'' **********By the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, more than 625,000 St. Joe shares had been traded. Professional traders already have purchased an estimated one million shares, worth almost $50 million, since the Seagram offer on Wednesday. The unwelcome offer is regarded by independent analysts as somewhat low -even though St. Joe shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange 48 hours before the bid at less than $28. The magic number, some Wall Street analysts say, may eventually top $50. **********One of the key factors in the bid is the Canadian Government. Since St. Joe has major Canadian oil and gas holdings, the Canadian Government -which is taking a harder line on foreign control of Canadian companies and Canadian energy resources - would look more favorably on Seagram, as a Canadian company, than on an American company that might attempt to rescue St. Joe. Alternative Plans **********Then again, if St. Joe can fight hard enough to fend off Seagram, there is always an outside chance that St. Joe could keep its stockholders contented by either going private or liquidating the company's assets and distributing the cash to stockholders. **********An even greater long shot, as viewed by some analysts, might be for St. Joe to support the formation of a consortium to buy the company.  Such a consortium might consist of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Newmont Mining Company, which already have strong financial ties to St. Joe, and a third partner, such as a Canadian oil company. **********A Wall Street analysis of the takeover concluded that the likelihood of another company coming forward to outbid Seagram seemed remote. Few oil companies would attempt it, one reasoned, because St. Joe's vast coal holdings would almost surely set off an antitrust investigation, creating delay, if nothing more. Many American oil companies, moreover, are getting out of Canada because of impending energy legislation restricting foreign ownership. **********Several analysts said that the most conservative approach seemed to be that St. Joe might ultimately change hands for a price as high as $51 or $52.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/05/busin.body_text: **********The Washington Post Company announced yesterday that it was discussing with prospective buyers the sale of its money-losing sports magazine, Inside Sports. **********The Post company's new president, Richard D. Simmons, said it had been concluded that the monthly magazine ''does not fit into the long-range strategic plans of the company.'' **********He did not elaborate, but Ellen Berland Sachar, vice president and media analyst with Goldman, Sachs, said the magazine evidently ''didn't have the kind of popularity, either with the readers or the advertisers, that they hoped it would have.'' **********Martin Cohen, the Post company's vice president for finance, said Inside Sports was continuing to lose money, although not as much as in 1980, when it was founded by Newsweek Inc., part of the Post company's magazine and book division. **********Inside Sports began regular publication in April 1980 and lost $12 million during the year, which was $4 million more than the Post company had projected. Mr. Cohen declined to give figures on losses so far this year. **********Mr. Cohen, who was reached at the company's New York offices, declined to say with whom it was holding the sales discussions, who might buy the magazine or what price it might fetch. Meanwhile, it is to continue appearing. **********Inside Sports' losses, analysts said, have been swelled by heavy promotion expenditures. For example, one newspaper advertisement that appeared on Tuesday was headlined ''Inside Sports . . . Growing Strong.'' **********''Our numbers sound like a much older, well-established magazine,'' the advertisement said in part. ''In 1980 Inside Sports earned over $12 million in total revenue. We now have 5 million readers per issue. And we're showing a 115 percent increase in new subscribers in 1981 alone. Plus 75 new advertisers. And more.'' **********Terry MacDonald, a senior vice president at the advertising agency Young & Rubicam, said: ''Sports Illustrated is clearly a better editorial product than Inside Sports, and it seems to me that Inside Sports has not found its editorial niche. The editorial content has been varying. In one issue the cover story was very gossipy, and in the next one it was more serious.'' Sports Illustrated is published by Time Inc. **********She suggested that Inside Sports' appeal to advertisers was limited because if they were going to advertise ''in a sports book, they would probably think of Sports Illustrated first.'' Influence of Simmons **********Commenting on the prospective sale, John S. Reidy, media analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert, said it seemed to be part of ''a program furthered under Richard Simmons, who took his post in September.'' He added, ''What they're really doing is deploying their assets in businesses that appear to be working.'' **********The Post company, which had been in the black, showed a net loss of $440,000 in this year's third quarter, compared with net income of $2,509,000 last year. The company reported revenues of $175,289,000 in the latest quarter, up from $152,510,000 in the 1980 period. The Post company's stock closed yesterday at 31 1/8, up 7/8, in trading on the American Stock Exchange. **********The loss, Mr. Reidy said, largely reflected investment to capitalize on the closing in August of the rival Washington Star, an afternoon newspaper. The Washington Post, a morning newspaper, has subsequently increased its daily circulation by more than 150,000. **********Mr. Reidy also said it was reasonable to assume that the Post company might be considering an afternoon tabloid newspaper, a project that was reportedly discussed and rejected within the Post company earlier this year. **********He noted that the Post company last month sold The Trenton Times, which it had owned since 1974. The paper had fought a losing circulation war with the rival Trentonian in recent years. Publishing sources said the price was between $10 million and $12 million. **********''So a couple of operations which don't look all that good are going bye-bye,'' Mr. Reidy continued, ''From an earnings and growth point of view, if you can't make them work, then you should get rid of them.'' **********He predicted that Inside Sports' eventual sale price would be no more than $10 million, adding, ''I would think it would be a lot less, maybe a few million maximum, and it could be even less than that.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/30/busin.main_headline: HELLO L.A.? MIAMI? HONG KONG? COME IN TO THE CONFERENCE ROOM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/30/busin.print_headline: HELLO L.A.? MIAMI? HONG KONG? COME IN TO THE CONFERENCE ROOM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/30/busin.body_text: **********T WO months before he was elected President, after shaking countless hands and meeting thousands of people face-to-face, Ronald Reagan addressed an estimated 50,000 campaign workers, with a ringing recruiting and morale-building speech. **********This time, it was all done without boarding yet another plane, crossing another time zone, or making a single whistle stop. His recorded message, traveling via satellite, was played before audiences at 86 Holiday Inns around the country. Like many corporate executives, Ronald Reagan had discovered teleconferencing. **********A neologism denoting a televised meeting, teleconferencing is changing the way a number of American corporations - including International Business Machines, Aetna Insurance, and Atlantic Richfield transact their business. Applications range from vast national hookups resembling a televised press conference to intimate, one-to-one conversations akin to a telephone call with pictures. **********As soaring air fares and hotel room rates cut sharply into corporate travel budgets and executives complain about time lost and discomfort endured in travel, many corporations are turning to electronics. That's fine with a growing number of businesses that cater to the demand, including the Memphis-based Holiday Inn chain and venturesome entrepreneurs. **********Though only now attracting widespread attention, this aspect of the electronic communications revolution has been developing since 1964, when the American Telephone and Telegraph Company demonstrated and heavily promoted its Picturephone service at the New York World's Fair. **********The device never caught on, largely because the user had to go to an A.T.& T. office, rather than operate out of his own office or a relatively accessible hotel location. (While Ma Bell maintains two conference rooms in New York as well as in other cities around the country - using far more sophisticated equipment than the old Picturephone - the problem of limited, fixed locations has continued to plague the operation.) **********But the potential was recognized even in the early days by the state of South Carolina, which saw in it a new use for its already established Education TeleVision system. Now 11 years old, South Carolina's teleconferencing network links more than 90 installations and 16 two-way sites via the We@star I and Satcom I communications satellites. System uses are rather mundane, but vital: training poll managers, volunteer firemen, nurses, and ambulance drivers. **********The psychological drawbacks are generally acknowledged. ''People miss the personal and social cueing of a face-to-face meeting,'' as Kent Nickerson of South Carolina's ETV explained. ''There's also the joy of being away from the routine to do something special.'' **********Or as a salesman for Atlantic Richfield, which is spending $20 million on an eight-location teleconferencing system, puts it, ''This is excellent for waving the flag, but I can't press the flesh.'' **********But cost-effectiveness, highlighted by the travel delays during the air controllers' strike, is providing a real boost to the stayat-home meeting. And, as Jody Brightman, consultant on teleconferencing at Atlantic Richfield, said, ''Most people after four or five minutes stop feeling unnatural and establish rapport.'' **********Indeed, companies that shunned the teleconference in an era when gasoline was cheap and communications satellites (a prerequisite for most teleconferences) scarce are now investing heavily in the necessary hardware. **********Los Angeles-based Atlantic Richfield, for one, with broadly scattered operations (two of its teleconferencing sites are to be in Alaska, one in Anchorage and one in remote Prudhoe Bay) expects to trim 23 percent from its travel costs when the system is fully operational, perhaps as early as next year. That's not to mention the savings on wear and tear of senior executives, for whom the romance of travel has faded. **********A S ambitious as such individual corporate systems sound, they are dwarfed by Satellite Business Systems of McLean, Va. S.B.S. was set up in 1975 by International Business Machines, Aetna Insurance, and Comsat, which by the end of this year will have poured $590 million into the venture. **********S.B.S. launched its own communications satellite last year (a second is due to go up this Thursday), and its three parent companies expect to use it for their own teleconferencing needs as well as offering its services to other businesses. **********S.B.S. systems won't come cheap. The company predicts an installation cost of $100,000 per room.  Given the costs involved, a number of organizations have capitalized either on existing equipment - television station WNET in New York is one example - or existing sites to offer others a relatively low-cost teleconference. **********Chief among the less expensive tier is the Holiday Inn chain, promoting a teleconference network linking more than 165 of its inns. Users, aside from President Reagan, have included Warner Brothers, which introduced a new Elton John record to distributors via the Inn system. Compared with an in-house system, prices are low. A standard $21,000 fee covers a group of 350 - equivalent to $60 a person, or substantially less than it would cost to transport and maintain someone attending a conventional meeting in a distant city. **********On a smaller scale, VideoNet, a company with offices on both coasts, sublets the Holiday Inn network to arrange teleconferences for other companies as well as ''teleseminars,'' usually on economic topics, for individual paying customers. VideoNet president Gary Badoud, who started the company in 1979, says he has booked 28 ''satellite events'' for this year, estimated to involve about 90,000 people. ''Within three to five years,'' he maintains, ''there are going to be 20 VideoNets doing this.'' **********One of the problems with the new medium is television itself. The late Marshall McLuhan was right; the medium is indeed the message, and once television intrudes on a meeting, it has a way of wheedling its way onto center stage and staying there. **********Recognizing this, S.B.S., according to a company spokeman, has determined ''to avoid anything that smacks of the broadcast studio's lighting and equipment.'' To this end, S.B.S. installations will have recessed cameras and lights, two large projection screens at opposite ends of the conference room, and a U-shaped table permitting participants to face screens and cameras. **********The conference leader controls camera views and close-ups, zooms and graphics. S.B.S. maintains that such gadgets are no more difficult to operate than a slide projector, but it is apparent that they enhance the power of the conference leader. It would be futile to interrupt without the assistance of a camera and microphone. **********Conferees should also keep in mind that often the television picture is not of the same caliber as the one viewers see at home.  Gus Morck, chief architect of the Atlantic Richfield system, notes that his system compresses television signals in order to shoehorn at least 30 video channels onto a single satellite transponder. In the resulting picture, rapid movement produces distortion. **********Then there is the secrecy problem. Not every executive wants to broadcast those confidential understandings and off-the-cuff remarks that pervade a face-to-face meeting. More seriously, there is the danger of giving a competitor easy access to secrets, strategies, and personal relationships as they are transmitted from one site to another. To combat this problem, both S.B.S. and Atlantic Richfield have developed encryption systems to scramble signals at the point of origin. S.B.S. claims its system is so secure that only a government would have the resources to crack it. **********Finally, there is that nagging question of what one loses when face-to-face meetings are replaced with electronics. Teleconferences can be ''beneficial for meetings within the company, where you already know the person and can pick up subtle cues such as body language that don't come over the phone,'' says Robert Alden of Strategic Planning Associates, a Washington-based business consulting firm. However, he adds, ''A lot of business decisions are based on instinct, on gut reactions'' and depend on nuances such as the firmness of a handshake. The teleconference that can convey the firmness of a handshake has yet to be invented.   ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Laurence Bergreen is the author of ''Look Now, Pay Later: The Rise of Network Broadcasting.'' A NEW VENTURE FORWNET **********One unexpected contender in the bustling new business of selling teleconference services is New York's public broadcasting station, WNET. **********It wasn't the entrepreneurial spirit, or a leading edge in technology that spurred them on. It was the threat of budget cuts.  WNET had the equipment in place, and underutilized personnel as well. What it needed badly was added income, so this year it went after it. **********One of its first customers was General Mills, the Minneapolis-based food processing concern, which paid an estimated $60,000 for the full teleconference treatment featuring satellite linkup to 18 sites around the country. (WNET stresses that the cost per person comes down as the number of sites increases. For example, an additional site for General Mills would have added but $600 to the tab.) **********At the General Mills teleconference in May, moderator Kathleen Campion, a WNET correspondent, broke the ice by introducing H.  Brewster Atwater Jr., the chairman of the board, who in turn yielded the spotlight to pollster Louis Harris, who described the findings of a new survey comparing men's and women's attitudes toward working.(The company had commissioned the survey as part of a public information effort known as the General Mills American Family Report.) Questions from hookups in Boston, Seattle, Salt Lake City and Denver were fielded by the ''stars.'' **********Sound booms, television cameras, kleig lights and, on some oncamera figures, makeup, contributed a distinctively theatrical aura to the occasion. In fact, business seemed to take a back seat to the media event. What color shirt shows best on television? How does one gracefully read a speech from a Teleprompter? Most importantly how does one communicate credibly with an unseen audience? Chief executives might begin by studying the technique of a current master of the small screen, Ronald Reagan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/18/busin.body_text: **********Timothy Mellon, a member of the Mellon banking family of Pittsburgh, has completed his acquisition of the Maine Central Railroad at an undisclosed price. Mr. Mellon, 38 years old, met today with railroad officials in Portland to confirm the purchase and his intention to retain current management, Bradley L. Peters, the railroad's vice president, said. Maine Central will be a subsidiary of Guilford Transportation Industries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/busin.main_headline: GULF, SMALLEST OF THE SEVEN OIL SISTERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/busin.print_headline: GULF, SMALLEST OF THE SEVEN OIL SISTERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/05/busin.body_text: **********FEW Companies have a historq as grand and glorious as that of the Gulf Oil Corporation. Born in the Spindletop gusher of 1901 and financed by the Mellon fortune, Gulf went on to successfully challenge the Rockefeller oil empire. In dizzying succession, it opened the world's first gasoline filling station, acquired oceans of oil beneath the deserts of the Middle East and the swamps of Venezuela, and firmly established itself as one of the leading producers, refiners and purveyors of black gold. **********Gulf is now the seventh-largest oil company in the world, the seventh-biggest company in America and a member of the planet's most exclusive business sorority - the Seven Sisters of international oil. On a warm summer evening, the orange light emanating from the crown of the company's headquarters tower in downtown Pittsburgh seems to suggest power, confidence and even a trace of deserved smugness. **********Appearances, however, can be deceiving. Over the last half decade, Gulf has been hammered by a political payoff scandal, a battery of lawsuits, the loss of most of its prized foreign oil, declines in domestic output, a ludicrously disadvantageous natural gas sales contract and a devastating change in energy policy by the Government in Canada, where Gulf has vast holdings. Perhaps most painful, however, has been the combination of sharply reduced consumer demand and an overabundance of refining capacity, an industrywide affliction that is stinging Gulf particularly. **********''Gulf is a company going through a shrinking phase,'' Sal Ilacqua, an analyst with L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg & Towbin, says.  ''Gulf has no real turn-ons,'' Robert LeVine of E.F. Hutton, adds. ''Everytime they straighten out their business, something happens and they get hurt,'' Constantine Fliakos of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, says.  The upshot is that Wall Street seems agreed that Gulf will not be able to match its 1980 earnings of $6.70 a share (excluding a 51-cent gain from the sale of stock in the company's Canadian unit). The price of Gulf stock has plunged by 35 percent in less than year, and some oil experts are beginning to ask an ominous question: Is Gulf - whose revenues last year totaled $28.8 billion - a company on the ropes? **********''I would reject that question out of hand - vociferously, vigorously, every way I could,'' snaps Jerry McAfee, the folksy, 64-year-old chairman of the board. Readily admitting Gulf has faced, and indeed still faces, big problems, Mr. McAfee contends that the worst is behind, and things are on the uptick. **********Gulf, like other oil companies, is representative of a fundamental paradox. Control of foreign oil has slipped away, production from United States oilfields is falling and the market for petroleum products is eroding. Yet, in the face of what would be a nightmare for almost any other business, things have seldom been rosier. The reason is a sixteenfold increase in the price of oil over the last decade. Sales, profits and assets have soared, as oil companies have directly benefited from the aggressive pricing of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. As is often true in architecture, less is more. **********''Adversity sometimes leads to strength,'' Mr. McAfee said, voicing a confidence that has characterized Gulf since its first president, James Guffey, dazzled turn-of-the-century Texas society with his big black hat, stovepipe trousers and loud waistcoats. **********The company, more geared to light, low-sulfur crude than any other major, is now spending $500 million to upgrade refineries to handle the heavier, more sulfurous crude oil increasingly prevalent these days. It acquired 700,000 exploratory acres last year, bringing its total inventory to more than 13 million. Through two acquisitions earlier this year it increased its coal producing capacity by 50 percent. And it has begun an ambitious program to sharpen its refining and marketing operations. **********In addition, Gulf is in excellent financial position with nearly $2 billion of cash on hand, a Triple-A credit rating, one of the lowest debt-to-equity positions in the industry and a $4 billion capital budget in 1981. Accordingly, the company argues that, after years of floundering, it is now firmly on the right track. **********''We are now paying the price for some wrong decisions taken 10 years ago,'' Mr. McAfee said, wincing as he recalled Gulf's failure, at a time when he was not in the head office, to establish a prominent exploration position in Alaska, America's richest petroleum province. ''We are now if the period of time lag between putting forth additional efforts and tasting the fruits of them.'' **********Perhaps. But analysts have criticized the company for a lack of crispness in corporate decision-making, citing what they call a start-and-stop development of its huge Mount Taylor uranium prospect in New Mexico. **********Further, Gulf's success hinges on the turn of events in the turbulent entrepreneurial arena of energy, where changes in consumer demand, catastrophes in far corners of the globe and decisions by governments can alter the landscape overnight. **********I N Gulf's case, worldwide oil production has plunged 80 percent over the past decade, even as assets have nearly doubled and profits have increased by 150 percent. This constricting character of the basic business is evident from the following facts: *********** Both Venezuela and Kuwait nationalized Gulf's holdings in December 1975. Largely because of these actions, Gulf has dropped to fifth position among worldwide crude producers, from second place in 1970. *********** The loss of ready oil has been accelerated further as OPEC countries have cut major oil companies' share of the world's oil, in order to market it themselves. Last year, Gulf lost more than 500,000 barrels a day of long-term crude purchases, primarily from Kuwait, Venezuela and Nigeria. *********** Domestic crude production has been on the decline. Last year it totaled 364,200 barrels a day, down from 425,500 in 1975 and 626,000 in 1970. *********** Gulf has cut daily worldwide refining capacity to 1.6 million barrels, from about two million five years ago. *********** Once reputed to be one of the world's pre-eminent oil traders, Gulf's trading and transportation division last year handled just 806,000 barrels of crude, nearly 50 percent below 1979. This marks a continuation of a trend that has seen a cut in the number of tankers Gulf owns, leases and charters to 53, from 75 in 1976, from 99 in 1970. **********Does all this mean Gulf is slipping into a different category from the Exxon Corporation, the Mobil Corporation, Texaco Inc. and others of the Seven Sisters? **********''We haven't been your typical sorority member,'' Mr. McAfee conceded. Gulf has the particular disadvantage of never having had access to Saudi Arabia's huge crude supplies -at $32 a barrel the cheapest crude oil available in the world. In what turned out to be the company's biggest mistake ever, 50 years ago, Gulf spurned an offer to enter the desert kingdom as one of its first petroleum producers. **********Today analysts are hard pressed to define Gulf in traditional industry terms. The company has deliberately retrenched into North America, but the its wealth and continuing foreign interests argue for continuing to classify it as an international. ''Gulf isn't really a major or a minor,'' Mr. Ilacqua, of L.F. Rothschild, said. **********What will it be? ''It is really a question of what senior management wants to do,'' Charles C. Cahn, of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, observed. **********More than other major oil companies, Gulf has traditionally preferred to grab the bulk of its profits from finding and producing oil. Just 10 years ago, the company had considerably more crude than it could refine and market itself, and was in the enviable position of peddling its surplus. **********But now, not only is worldwide production slashed, but also, analysts think, there is little likelihood that Gulf will be able to halt the steady decline in its United States reserves. **********''They just don't seem to be in the sweet spots,'' Mr. Levine of E.F. Hutton, said. Mr. Cahn characterized the company's exploration acreage as ''riskier'' and ''just not as exciting'' as that held by other major companies. **********Another often-cited trap is a 1964 natural gas sales contract under which Gulf must sell 24 percent of its gas for 19 to 22 cents a thousand cubic feet to the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, substantially below its average price of $1.71. **********Mr. McAfee points out that the contract ends in 1986, and early renegotiation is likely. ''It is in the interests of Texas Eastern to renegotiate now in order to have access to significant additional gas at the end of this contract,'' he said. **********Mr. McAfee acknowledges Gulf's problems, but is, typically, optimistic. ''Although flattening out the decline in domestic production is proving to be frustratingly difficult, it is a challenge we must overcome,'' he told analysts last December. In particular, Gulf feels there is considerable promise in the Overthrust Belt of the Rocky Mountains, the Gulf of Mexico and a bevy of other areas so secretive that Mr. McAfee does not discuss them. **********Domestically, then, the company is counting on loads of serendipity laced with the latest in geophysics and petroleum engineering and a tough bargaining postion. **********Worldwide, Gulf's problem is akin to trying to compete in the lemonade business if your biggest competitors can buy lemons for a dime when you have to pay 15 cents. Further, people are drinking less all the time and you have to slash prices to sell any at all. **********A money-losing proposition? Of course. Exxon, Mobil, Texaco and the Standard Oil Company of California -the four biggest oil companies in the United States - buy the bulk of their crude oil from Saudi Arabia at just $32 a barrel. Gulf gets the majority of its foreign crude from West Africa at $40 a barrel. And, given an inability to pass on these full costs in today's highly competitive environment, it loses $3.50 or more on each barrel of Nigerian oil it refines. **********Largely because of this, Gulf lost $197 million from United States refining and marketing operations in the first quarter, versus a profit of $142 million in the first quarter of 1980. **********Gulf's strategy for dealing with the squeeze is first to reduce the amount of oil its buys from Nigeria to the lowest level permitted under its contracts, and second, to press hard to convince Nigeria to lower its price. Oil experts seem to agree that African petroleum prices are on their way down. ''It's got to come down from where it is now,'' John H. Lichtblau of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said. **********Additionally, Gulf is cutting its refining capacity. Worldwide, capacity has fallen 20 percent in five years, and domesticly it has been cut 8 percent with the closing of two refineries last year. **********For future crude supplies, Gulf is counting on an extrapolation of some existing trends. By 1985, it expects its daily output from Nigeria, the company's biggest source of crude, to increase by 50 percent from last year's 112,000 barrels a day, and North Sea daily output is expected to double by 1984 from this year's 35,000 barrels. **********The big question mark in terms of exploration and production is Canada, where price controls hamper profit potential and - more important - a new energy policy is making it very difficult for American companies to operate, partly by giving Canadian-owned companies financial incentives to explore in treacherous frontier areas that are not available to American companies. Gulf, which has major interests in two of Canada's hottest frontier plays, Hibernia and the Beaufort Sea, acknowledges that it has looked into a variety of ways to increase Canadian ownership. **********M R. McAFEE noted that Gulf would be eligible for the frontier incentives if it ''farms out'' a majority portion of its ownership to Canadian-owned companies, in return for those Canadian companies picking up the check for drilling the well. Because of the big expense of drilling in difficult offshore areas, Gulf would have farmed out much of its acreage in any case, he says. **********''Canada is still a good pdace to do business,'' Mr. McAfee said.  ''We'll be there for a long time.'' In a decade, Mr. McAfee thinks that Gulf ''will not look significantly different than it does right now.'' The company's focus will still be on energy, principally United States exploration and production of oil and gas. **********Capital, Mr. McAfee says, is the company's major, almost unquenchable need, despite its current large pool of cash. Both Gulf and Gulf Canada will soon have to go to the debt market, he says, and the company is cutting back expenditures for projects with an uncertain payout - among others, most synthetic fuels projects. **********Does this mean Gulf is sacrificing its future for a comfortable present? ''It is a great temptation to put everything we've got into the immediate, short-term quick payoff items,'' Mr. McAfee said.  Nonetheless, Gulf continues to be heavily involved in the Rio Blanco shale oil project in western Colorado, in partnership with the Standard Oil Company (Indiana). **********Over the short term, analysts are watching closely to see if Gulf will pull back more - close another big refinery, for example, or abandon more markets. (Since 1970, Gulf has shut down 20,000 stations, 14,450 of them in the United States.) **********Then, there is the question of succession. Mr. McAfee is scheduled to retire Nov. 30, and while no one at the company will speculate on who will take over, a home-grown talent is conceded to be the likely choice. Top contenders certainly include James E. Lee, president, Harold H. Hammer, executive vice president, and Edward B. Walker, also an executive vice president. **********Intriguingly, Mr. McAfee said that Gulf is ''seriously considering'' buying a block of its own stock, something the company did in 1973 when it bought back $341 million worth. This would tend to bolster the stock price by increasing earnings per share, a key determinant of share prices. **********But such a move would also represent a deliberate shrinking back of the size of the company, almost an admission that shareholders might find a better way to spend the money than Gulf itself could. Such steps are unusual for large growing companies. Like emperors, most have developed a taste for growing ever larger.   GULF'SSAD CHAPTER **********PITTSBURGH Five years ago, Gulf directors, each with a lawyer by his side, huddled in Pittsburgh to deal with one of the biggest corporate scandals ever. At issue was Gulf's secret, and illegal, generosity to a host of powerful politiciansof both parties over a 15-year period. High-living capital lobbyists, a mysterious Gulf subsidiary in the Bahamas and suspicious gifts to the Nixon White House were all involved. The net result was the removal of chairman Bob Dorsey and three other top executives. **********''When you assume the law of the land is your enemy, you're in trouble,'' said Sister Jane Scully, president of Carlow College, who was brought on to Gulf's board to help clean up the company's act. **********Jerry McAfee, the man who replaced Mr. Dorsey as Gulf's chairman, has devoted a great deal of his tenure to closing the book on that chapter. ''I had to spend whatever time was required to get those things properly behind us,'' he said. Those who watch the company think he has done quite a job. **********''The prime purpose of McAfee was to change the image of the company from one guilty of a crime to a decent corporate citizen,'' Charles C. Cahn, analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, said. ''He has done a good job.'' **********Today, Mr. McAfee is able to boast that Gulf, as a corporation, makes no campaign contributions and does not even maintain a political action committee. Instead, he says, the company is contributing expertise, partly through his personal contacts with all three Energy Secretaries who have held the office. ''It is possible to participate effectively in the governmental process by making contributions of other things than money,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/08/busin.body_text: **********Selected metals, chemic als and paper products were higher in price in August, a ccording to a survey of 225 industrial company purchasing managers. However, the National Association of Purchasing Management's latest monthly survey indicated that aluminum , wheat, corn and fuel, including gasoline, generally declined in p rice. **********The trade group, which has been conducting the survey since the 1930's, said that its figures indicate that the economy ''is declining, but at a slightly lower rate than July.'' **********The group said that the managers sense ''that there is a tug of war in business moods'' - with optimism over the good news of budget and tax cuts competing with the gloom of high interest rates and lower profits. **********The metals that the managers said rose in price were copper, lead and steel.  Overall, the managers, who purchase raw materials and goods for their companies, said that the level of price increases had slackened. **********The survey stated that managers turned cautious last month and more and more bought materials on a shorter-term basis to keep inventories low. **********The report noted that inventories dropped again last August, although not so sharply as in July.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Noranda Mines Ltd. of Toronto has won the bidding war for Canada's largest forest products company, MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. of Vancouver, following the formal withdrawal of the British Columbia Resources Investment Corporation. **********Bruce Howe, president of B.C. Resources, said that directors had voted unanimously to sell their 4.2 million MacMillan Bloedel shares after the company's offer expired yesterday morning with only a marginal number of shares tendered. **********The concern had started the contest for MacMillan on March 10 by offering $46 a share for 6.2 million shares. **********The Noranda bid, raised once in response to a higher B.C. Resources offer, stands at $62 ($12 cash, $50 in shares), indicating that B.C.  Resources' shares in MacMillan are worth about $260 million (Canadian) under the offer, or $223 million at yesterday's market price. Mr. Howe said the company had not yet decided whether to tender the shares to Noranda or sell them on the open market. **********Under the bid, which expires April 21, Noranda seeks to raise its interest in MacMillan Bloedel from 8 percent, to 49 percent for a total of $626 million (Canadian). **********Noranda is already a major forest products operator, ranking second in Canada in terms of the sales of companies in which it is the controlling shareholder. In 1980, forest products contributed nearly $80 million to Noranda's $408 million net profit. **********If the Noranda offer is successful, about a third of the shares of Canadian forest products companies will have disappeared from the hands of the public in less than two months. In March, Olympia and York Investments Ltd. of Toronto succeeded in buying 91 percent of the stock of Abitibi-Price Inc. of Toronto, the world's largest forest products producer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/29/world.main_headline: SADAT'S DEATH TURNS SPOTLIGHT TO A SUDANESE WAR OF SORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/29/world.print_headline: SADAT'S DEATH TURNS SPOTLIGHT TO A SUDANESE WAR OF SORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/29/world.body_text: **********There is a war going on in this land where the hot, pale desert peopled by nomads provides an inhospitable and improbable theater of confrontation between East and West. **********It is not so much a shooting conflict as a battle involving propaganda, ancient trade routes and a surrogate army that wants the United States to support it against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader. **********Geneina lies on the indistinct border between the Sudan, a pro-Western bulwark protecting Egypt's southern flank, and Chad, a country that the Soviet-supported Colonel Qaddafi all but annexed 10 months ago. Nomads Know No Boundaries **********This region is known as Darfur, an area the size of France that was once a proud, independent sultanate run by a dynasty of rulers that lasted 560 years. From Geneina, caravans of pilgrims heading overland to Mecca make their way east. Men of the Tuareg stock of desert nomads roam the area, dressed in long white robes and white turbans.  With their camels and mules and trappings they recognize no international boundaries, lines that appear on the maps but not on the shifting sands and dry river beds they traverse. The town itself is one of flat-roofed houses, stretched resources and economic decay. **********Casualties Are Modest **********The war is ostensibly between the Sudan and Libya. Libyan aircraft bombed border villages near here 25 times between Sept. 10 and Oct.  13. It is a token of the low level of the fighting that, among the most severe casualties listed by the Sudan were 7 goats, 44 cows and 3 camels. **********The raids hit villages, including one called Kulbus, 75 miles north of here. The official Sudanese position is that the village is just one more of the small settlements that lie on the border. Other authoritative informants, however, say that Kulbus is the general headquarters of a Chadian insurgent group, numbering about 2,500 men led by Hissen Habre, Chad's former Defense Minister, who opposes the Libyan presence in his country. The raids, these informants maintain, were intended to destabilize the insurgent leader's rear base and turn the local Sudanese population against him and his mentor, President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan. **********Earlier this month, General Nimeiry, seeking to dramatize his plight, depicted this border confict as the forerunner of a Libyan invasion. He siad it was part of a wider assault on the West's allies in the Middle East at a time of vulnerability after the assassination of his ally, Anwar el-Sadat, in Egypt. **********Sudanese Army officers here say such an invasion is physically possible but unlikely at present. The terrain, they say, would be suitable for a push by Libya's Soviet-built T-54 tanks, but the supply lines would be overextended and the logistics difficult. For reporters who drove here from El Fasher, 220 miles to the east, the trip took 13 hours across deep sand, indistinct tracks, dry river beds and rocky mountain passes where locusts swarmed from thorn trees, water was scarce and fuel yet scarcer. How It Began **********The border conflict started last December when Libyan troops moved into Chad to support Goukouni Oueddei, the Prime Minister, against Mr. Habre, who fled to the Sudan. It remains a conflict involving allies of convenience rather than conviction. **********Colonel Qaddafi supported Mr. Habre in an earlier insurrection in Chad. Now Colonel Qaddafi is backing Mr. Goukouni, and Mr. Habre needs a new protector. Both the Sudan and Egypt require a means of harassing the Libyans in Chad, so the former friend of their enemy, has become their ally. **********Tony Brauman, a French volunteer doctor who has become a confidant of Mr. Habre in Kulbus, said the insurgents there were equipped with new Egyptian-supplied weapons, incuding antiaircraft guns and assault rifles of both Eastern and Western design. Egyptian military advisers have been seen in Kulbus, Mr. Brauman said. According to other informants, four Egyptian transport aircraft landed recently at El Fasher with fresh supplies. The insurgents led by Mr. Habre have penetrated 70 to 130 miles into Chad but do not hold any towns. **********Brig. Abbas Mohamed Abulaal, the Sudanese commander here, who describes his area of authority as ''the western frontier,'' said Libyan troops and Chadian Government forces held a town just across the border in Chad. Fighting to Negotiate **********Mr. Habre does not believe he can win a straight military victory unless Colonel Qaddafi withdraws his men. ''They know they cannot win a military victory,'' Mr. Brauman said. ''They want to keep up pressure and then be able to negotiate. If they do not fight, they have no negotiating position.'' **********Several recent developments have heartened Mr. Habre's men. The Reagan Administration's hostility toward Colonel Qaddafi, an authoritative Sudanese source said, has encouraged a belief that Washington will support them indirectly through Egypt. When the Libyan bombing raids ceased 10 days ago, the source said, Mr. Habre's men attributed that to the presence of United States Awacs aircraft monitoring the border area. In this remote zone, travellers have noted, the Awacs have taken on a special aura, as if they provided an impenetrable defense line. **********For its part, Libya is conducting a war on several fronts, apparently in pursuance of Colonel Qaddafi's campaign to establish a line of anti-American governments from his borders through the Sudan to Marxist Ethiopia, Somalia and Southern Yemen. Colonel Qaddafi already has an alliance with Ethiopia and Southern Yemen, which is worrying the Sudan, and Sudanese officials assert that he wants to bring down President Nimeiry to isolate Egypt and thus combat the peace treaty with Israel. Bombs in Cigarettes **********Libyan broadcasts are beamed into this area, urging the people to turn against President Nimeiry, and the bombing raids, Sudanese officials say, are intended in part to make the Sudanese leader look weak in the eyes of his compatriots. At the same time, Libya has reportedly sent sabotage and assassination squads into this region. **********Brigadier Abbas recently showed reporters an attache case packed with cartons of Rothmans cigarettes and Courreges toilet water packed with plastic explosives. The box of toilet water, Brigadier Abbas said, was rigged to explode when it was opened. The explosives in the cigarette packets were connected to timing devices. ''This was an attempt to kill me,'' Brigadier Abbas said. ''But our security services intercepted the briefcase and arrested the Libyan agents carrying it.'' **********The Libyan campaign perceived by the Sudan extends further. In the deserts north of here, there are caravan trails where for centuries nomads have crossed the ocher wastes on camels, trading among their kinfolk between Darfur and what is now Libya. These days, young Sudanese go to work in Libya and return laden with Japanese hi-fi equipment, blue jeans, perfumes and Italian shirts. ''We are closer to Libya than we are to our own port on the Red Sea,'' a Sudanese official said. ''Our trade has traditionally been with Libya.'' Fugitives Are a Problem **********The Governor of the Darfur region, Ahmed Ibrahim Derreig, said: ''This is the dangerous thing. The Libyans can exploit the economic situation and tell the people their point of view without our Government telling our point of view.'' Radio Tripoli's broadcasts reach Geneina. Those of Radio Omdurman, the official Sudanese radio, do not. **********Yet a further destabilizing factor is the presence of Chadian fugitives here. There are 8,000 registered refugees in Geneina, most of them from the ferocious Guran tribe, whose men traditionally carry a dagger in a scabbard on the upper arm concealed in a flowing robe.  The refugees eat from aid supplies when the local people do not, relief workers say, and their presence taxes the town's resources, which are barely able to meet the demands of its 60,000 people. **********Mr. Habre's insurgents, too, have incurred some disfavor among Sudanese. French medical personnel working in Kulbus said the insurgents had been confined to their barracks after 6 P.M. because they had gotten drunk and had brawls with the local people and there had been killings. Reason for Attention **********This small conflict with its minutiae would have been largely unnoticed by the outside world had it not been for the assassination of President Sadat and the sudden focusing of Western attention on the Sudan as Egypt's geographically closest ally. The Reagan Administration has agreed to try to accelerate deliveries of military hardware to the Sudan, apparently as a gesture of psychological support. President Nimeiry, whose army of 60,000 is poorly equipped, encouraged these attentions. **********Now, Sudanese officials contend, the prospect of American military involvement on a larger scale has produced its own hazards. ''We do not want to have another Vietnam in Africa,'' Governor Derreig said.  ''If the big powers come and the conflict becomes bigger, our people will suffer not only during the war but afterward.'' **********External involvement here has its anomalies. Egypt and the Sudan, Washington's allies, have become embroiled with Mr. Habre's forces as part of their campaign against Libya, a fierce opponent of the Camp David accords. At the same time, however, France has begun supporting the Chad Government of Mr. Goukouni in Ndjamena. The Reagan Administration is supporting a French initiative to create an African peacekeeping force to replace the Libyans in Chad, something Colonel Qaddafi is resisting because of what he terms Sudanese aggression. Washington, thus, seems to be indirectly involved on both sides of a conflict that shows little sign now of easing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/03/busin.body_text: **********United States auto makers plan to build 42 percent more cars this week than they did in the comparable week of 1980, but the number of workers on long-term layoff remains virtually unchanged from last week, according to industry reports released today. **********The industry journal Ward's Automotive Reports said that the five major domestic manufacturers scheduled production of 144,060 cars this week, up from 101,411 units during the 1980 week, but down 12 percent from the 164,388 cars made last week. **********Domestic truck production was scheduled to reach 35,445 units for the week, up 64 percent from the 21,587 trucks built during the same week last year, but down 11 percent from 39,823 units made last week, Ward's said. **********Meanwhile, the auto makers said they have 153,375 employees on long-term layoffs without a recall date, virtually unchanged from 153,400 last week. The number of temporary layoffs, however, rose to 14,325 from last week's 12,900 as the auto makers began closing plants for the annual model change-over. **********So far this year in the United States, car production stands at 3,667,625 units, up 5.8 percent from 3,467,910 units built by the same time in 1980There have been 946,055 trucks built, 15 percent more than the 824,746 trucks built a year ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/29/world.body_text: **********The Irish have been given a new picture of themselves by an American diplomat. He has called them a dull, dreary country that is ''small potatoes'' in world affairs. **********Robin Berrington, the United States Embassy's cultural affairs and press officer, made the critical statements in a private letter to a friend. But the letter ended up in the hands of The Irish Times because it was put in a packet of press releases about President Reagan instead of being mailed. **********In his letter, which was published today, Mr. Berrington said ''the high cost of goods, their unavailability, the dreary landscapes, the constant strikes and the long, dark and damp winters combine to gnaw away at one's enthusiasm for being here.'' **********He said Ireland was ''pretty small potatoes'' compared to other European countries and that the hottest issue seemed to be whether President Reagan's ancestors really came from Tipperary. **********''I submit that while Ireland is a great place to visit, living and working here is something else,'' he said. ''Don't forget Murphy's Law is Murphy's Law, not Schmidt's Law, Gonzalez' Law or Mastroianni's Law. What is amazing is that the Irish manage to muddle through with such good humor, pluck and inventiveness.'' **********Mr. Berrington, facing reassignment to Japan, was unavailable for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/28/busin.print_headline: Other Business; E.F. HUTTON'S REGAL REPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/28/busin.body_text: **********When E.F. Hutton talks, people listen. When E.F. Hutton poses, people are riveted to the page. The investment giant's latest offering is a slick collection of portrait photography, almost $400,000 in the making, that immortalizes in museum-quality black and white E.F. Hutton's executive elite and their photogenic clientele. **********The book, designed, it would seem, to look at home on the best of coffee tables, is ''The E.F. Hutton Group Inc. Annual Report 1980.'' ''An annual report is a fact of life. It has to happen every year,'' said Robin D. Davis, assistant vice president and art director, who designed this year's offering, down to the silver stock imported from West Germany, but is not among the portrayed. On the other hand, she said, ''This was E.F. Hutton's most successful year, and I felt it had to stand out from other years.'' **********It does. Seventy-four E.F. Hutton men and eight E.F. Hutton women each spent half a day or more posing - on regal staircases, in helicopters, with special customers. **********The printing was done by Rapoport, a New York company that has produced the works of Richard Avedon, Ansel Adams and Irving Penn.  The split personality is evident in the product's outside uses: Copies are serving as texts for a business course at New York University, and an art course at Cooper Hewitt. **********The photographer is Cheryl Rossum, a perfectionist who takes pictures for the likes of Northrop, Mobil and International Paper.  She spared no detail. ''She brought a makeup person,'' recalled Thomas P. Lynch, Hutton's chief financial officer (at a renovation site at 1 Broadway high over the Hudson river). ''I was a little queasy the first time because I was being made up by a man. The second time I was made up by a woman, which was a little more comfortable.'' **********Robert Fomon, Hutton chairman and chief executive officer (who did not wear makeup when posing for the cover shot), said the report ''was not written just for stockholders. It's aimed also at our present and future customers. One or two new clients can more than pay for the entire annual report.'' **********The response has been highly favorable over all, Mr. Lynch said.  ''Some said it looks too expensive,'' he conceded, and asked whether the money would have been better spent increasing the dividend. ''But we just did,'' he added, and ''this month the stock split five for four.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/05/busin.body_text: **********Time magazine is down. Newsweek is down. Reader's Digest is down.  TV Guide is down. The New Yorker is down. Woman's Day is down.  Business Week is down. Cosmopolitan is down. Sports Illustrated is down. Such is the direction of first-quarter advertising pages for some of America's best-known and sturdiest magazines. **********From 1976 through 1979, it seemed that magazines could do nothing wrong. Ad pages climbed nearly 50 percent. Revenues doubled.  Then things abruptly leveled off last year. Ad pages were essentially flat; revenues rose a modest 8 percent. And the trend has not changed so far this year. **********Blaming the Economy **********Most magazine publishers blame tight ad budgets resulting from the skittish economy for most of their problems, though other factors - including increasing competition from other media - also seem to be gnawing away at business. **********''It's the toughest year I can recall since 1975,'' observed David O'Brasky, advertising director of New York magazine. In 1975, both ad pages and ad revenues of the magazine industry dived for the first time since 1970. **********Not all publications, however, are suffering: Town & Country, Money magazine and Architectural Digest are all doing well, to name a few.  And New York magazine increased its ad pages 19 percent in the first quarter of 1981, though most of that improvement could be ascribed to gains from the insertion of Cue magazine into New York. **********But most of the big names are suffering unwelcome erosions. A Flat 1981 Is Expected **********In the view of Robert Coen, a magazine forecaster at McCann-Erickson, ad pages for the entire industry will once again be flat for all of 1981 and ad revenues will climb only 8 to 10 percent, solely because of rate increases. He expects pages in the first half of the year to tumble by a few percent and then, if the economy rebounds, rise by a similar amount in the second half, a reversal of last year's pattern. **********Newsstand sales have also been soft for a good many magazines this year, and publishers are tending to deliver little bonus circulation above their rate bases. **********''It's clear that the first quarter was weaker than expected, and the second quarter, as far as we know it, looks like a continuation of that,'' said Kent Rhodes, head of the Magazine Publishers Association. ''Our upward curve has been stopped and we're treading water for a while.'' Moving Back to TV **********As Joe Ostrow, director of communications services at the big Young & Rubicam advertising agency, observed: ''For a lot of diverse reasons, people have become less enamored of magazines. I think there were a lot of people dragged kicking and screaming into magazines when TV rates went through the roof. Because television rate increases have softened a bit, I think the people who really want to be in TV have gone back.'' **********Mr. Ostrow adds, ''I think the key thing, if magazines are to grow again, is the effort of the industry to sell magazines in a meaningful way. I think they lost an opportunity, three or four years ago when all these people were pushed into magazines, to really solidify their sales.'' **********Taking a particularly severe thrashing are the women's service books. Of the so-called Seven Sisters - Good Housekeeping, The Ladies' Home Journal, McCall's, Family Circle, Woman's Day, Redbook and Better Homes and Gardens - only Good Housekeeping ran ahead of last year in first-quarter ad pages. **********''The most dramatic reason for our being down is cigarettes,'' said Peter Bonanni, publisher of Woman's Day, which carried 19 percent fewer ad pages in the first quarter. Big packaged goods are off, he adds, as are regional and new-product ads. **********Family Circle, a property of The New York Times Company, managed to lose fewer pages, but it chose not to raise rates this spring (as Woman's Day did) in order to keep the orders coming in. Reynolds and Seagram's Shift **********Two nettlesome factors for the women's books and the news weeklies were decisions reached late last year by R.J. Reynolds, the nation's No.1 cigarette maker, and Seagram's, the big liquor concern, to realign their media mix. **********Reynolds moved a good chunk of its magazine ads into newspapers, billboards and regional magazines, while Seagram's pulled pages out of the news weeklies in particular and put them into regional publications, some new magazines such as Discover and Inside Sports, and newspapers and outdoor advertising. **********Over at Newsweek, which found itself some 70 ad pages short of last year in the first quarter, the magazine calculates it will lose a total of about 100 pages this year from R.J. Reynolds and Seagram's. **********Why, in all this gloom, is Good Housekeeping up? ''It's probably one of the first choices on schedules and so it's a little less vulnerable than some of the others,'' noted Mr. Coen of McCann-Erickson. **********At Time Inc., which has six established magazines, Time, Sports Illustrated, People, Money, Fortune and Life, and the new entry, Discover, only Money ran ahead in first-quarter ad pages, according to Publishers Information Bureau numbers. ''We kind of thought the first quarter would be not too terrific,'' says Kelso Sutton, group vice president in charge of the Time Inc. magazines. ''I'm not sitting over here slitting my wrists.'' Business Magazines Slip **********All three heavyweights of the business magazine field, Business Week, Fortune and Forbes, have also been lagging. Business Week, which led the entire magazine pack in ad pages last year, fell 9 percent in the first quarter. The softness, according to Orlin Davis, the ad director, was in travel, industrial materials, liquor and media. **********Even in these penny-pinching times, however, most of the slick women's fashion magazines are ahead. Hearst's Harper's Bazaar, for instance, posted a 23 percent rise in first-quarter ad pages. **********''Women are still buying the fashion categories - apparel, cosmetics,'' remarked Gilbert C. Maurer, president of Hearst Magazines. ''I think you can make a case that the up-scale, up-market magazines have been affected less than the middle-market magazines.  The ad staff at Harper's Bazaar wouldn't have any inkling that there's a recession.'' **********Few magazines have gone out of business this year, though a number of them are reportedly teetering and Triangle Publications' lavish Panorama magazine about the television industry will close with the June issue because of skimpy circulation. And fewer new magazines are planned by publishers. **********But, one magazine official noted, ''I think you could see some well-known magazines go down the tubes this year that are going to really surprise some people.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/02/busin.body_text: **********China's production of oil and natural gas declined in 1980, the official New China News Agency said yesterday.  Government sources in Japan, meanwhile, said China had raised its crude oil price by 85 cents a barrel, retroactive to Dec. 1. **********The New China News Agency said China produced 775.5 million 42-gallon barrels of oil and 480 billion cubic feet of natural gas in 1980, fulfilling Government targets. **********In 1979, China reported oil production of 778.1 million barrels, up 2 percent from 1978, and natural gas output of 507.4 billion cubic feet, up 5.7 percent. **********In Tokyo, sources at the Japanese Ministry of Trade and Industry said China had lifted its oil price to $33.98 a barrel following increases of between $2 and $5.50 a barrel announced earlier this month by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and by Mexico. **********The New China News Agency said earlier that China's leading oilfield at Daqing, which produces nearly half of the nation's oil, had met its 1980 target of 366.5 million barrels 10 days ahead of schedule and was expected to produce 377.5 million barrels for the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/13/world.body_text: **********The North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed today on the need to conclude the European security review conference in Madrid by Christmas, a senior United States diplomat said. **********Max Kempelman, chief American negotiator at the 35-member conference, said the NATO countries reaffirmed their will to reach a substantive, balanced outcome when the negotiations resume Oct. 27 after the summer recess. **********The talks adjourned in July with the key issues of military security in Europe and human rights unresolved.  ''We think it is important to end it by Christmas,'' Mr. Kempelman said. ''It would change the nature of the Helsinki process if it continues.'' **********Mr. Kempelman spoke after taking part in a meeting of NATO heads of delegation at Madrid to prepare for the resumption of the 11-month-old talks.

Conoco dropped 25 cents, to $54.50 a share, after adding 87.5 cents in the previous two sessions.
