https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/busin.body_text: **********For years the Chicago Mercantile Exchange has been overshadowed by the visibility and prestige of the Chicago Board of Trade, its more glamorous neighbor. **********The Merc, as it is known, gained little attention for its highly successful listed contracts in live hogs, pork bellies and lumber.  And hardly anyone cared enough even to snicker when the exchange tried and failed to establish futures markets in turkeys, potatoes and frozen eggs. **********But now this city's second futures exchange, bidding to become the premier trading house for financial instruments, has upset the competition with the success of its three-month-old certificate of deposit contract. **********And the Merc is preparing a spirited challenge to its rivals for dominance in the proposed Eurodollar contracts, which promise to become one of the hottest ever. Further clashes are likely also over the trading of stock index futures, if they are instituted, and over affiliations with foreign futures exchanges. **********The competition is fierce, and most analysts say it is too early to predict a winner. ''The game is changing very rapidly and either exchange may come up with a product that could build its volume,'' said Arthur Hahn, president of Rouse Woodstock, a commodities firm that trades on both exchanges. **********But many believe that the Merc's mix of short-term contracts and its international reputation put it in a good position to compete over the next few months. **********''I wouldn't underestimate the mutuality of interest that the Merc has already established around the world with its gold futures and currency contracts,'' said Patrick S. Collins, a vice president at the First Boston Corporation. ''You might have the Board of Trade going to foreign exchanges saying 'we're the greatest corn market in the world.' In Hong Kong that could produce a big yawn.'' **********Relations between the two exchanges have not always been so intensely competitive. In fact, they have coexisted for decades seeming perfectly content to divide the commodity contracts between their two floors. Crops, such as corn, soybeans and wheat, became the staple of the Board of Trade, while meat - hogs and cattle - was emphasized at the Merc. **********They stayed out of each other's way even in the early days of financial futures. The Merc got a head start by establishing in the early 1970's a division called the International Monetary Market to trade currencies. The Board of Trade later developed Treasury-bond contracts and silver futures contracts that propelled it ahead of the Merc. **********When interest rate futures came into vogue a few years later the two also stayed out of each other's way. The Board of Trade concentrated on long-term Treasury bonds, while the Merc focused on 90-day Treasury bills. Confrontation With C.D.'s **********But the stage was set for confrontation last summer when the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, after a two-year moratorium on new futures contracts, granted exchanges the right to trade threemonth certificates of deposit, **********Certificate of deposit futures contracts, traded in $1 million denominations, are popular among bankers. Banks issue certificates of deposit to raise lendable funds. Using the futures market helps protect them from wild swings in interest rates by locking up a fixed rate in advance. Speculators try to earn a profit in the market by correctly anticipating rate changes. **********Trading in certificates of deposit began early in July on the New York Futures Exchange, followed two weeks later by the Board of Trade and then by the Merc at the end of that month. The Merc, maintaining that as a general rule a given contract will be successful on only one exchange, is claiming victory over the early birds. **********''The last two or three weeks have indicated clearly that the liquidity is coming our way,'' said Leo Melamed, a special counsel to the Merc who masterminded that exchange's move into financial futures. ''Our C.D. contract has become acceptable to the majority of users and once that happens you need an act of God to change directions.'' **********Last week, according to Mercantile Exchange figures, more than 75 percent of the 43,700 certificate of deposit contracts that changed hands were traded on the Merc. The reason for the great imbalance, experts say, is that traders have been able to ''spread,'' or arbitrage, their trades against the 90-day Treasury bills, which are traded on the Merc also. **********Spreading is used almost solely by professional traders who watch closely the relative prices between different contracts. If, for example, the price gap between certificates of deposit and Treasury bills is unusually wide, a trader may sell certificates of deposit and buy Treasury bills. If he is correct, the gain on one contract will be greater than the loss on the other. **********''With a new contract the user's main concern is can he get out easily; that's the big question,'' Mr. Melamed said. ''We had the 90-day T-bill contract. So when you're in trouble and can't sell C.D.'s, you can sell T-bills and cover 80 percent of your exposure.  The Tbills provided us with an emergency exit.'' **********Because the Eurodollar contract would possess characteristics similar to those of the other short-term instruments that are trading successfully at the Merc, that exchange is predicting that it will handle most of the volume when the contract begins trading in December or early next year. Eurodollars are dollars held and circulated by overseas banks. Merc Restructuring Floor **********The Merc is so confident of success that it is rebuilding its exchange floor to accommodate increased futures trading. It will move the Treasury bill pit out of a corner and into the center of the room, near new Eurodollar and certificate of deposit pits. It has begun an aggressive program to educate its members in trading and arbitrage possibilities with Eurodollar contracts. **********In fact the Merc is already promoting itself as the world's largest futures exchange, based on the number of contracts listed. It has 13, the Board of Trade, five. But other yardsticks show that the distinction is still up for grabs. **********In the first six months of this year, the latest period for which comparable data are available, the volume at the Board of Trade in financial futures stood at 7.1 million contracts, compared with 6.4 million at the Merc. Volume for the Board of Trade's Treasury bond contract generally exceeds 60,000 contracts a day, making it the most successful financial futures contract ever. **********Full membership on the Board of Trade cost the last purchaser $235,000, $10,000 more than the latest price for a seat on the Merc.  But a partial membership, permitting the holder to trade financial futures only, last sold for $200,000 on the Merc, $40,000 more than the last transaction for similar privileges at the Board of Trade.  Last year total revenue for the Merc totaled $26.4 million, while the Board of Trade reported gross receipts of $29.6 million. 'Stop-the-Merc Movement' **********To meet these challenges, the Board of Trade and the struggling New York Futures Exchange (a subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange) have reached an affiliation agreement, pending approval by the membership, that many futures experts interpret as a ''stop-the-Merc movement.'' By pooling their listed contracts the two exchanges hope to come up with the arbitrage combinations that have worked so well for the Merc. **********''The competition has shifted from New York versus Chicago to Chicago versus Chicago. There is no competition in New York,'' Leslie Rosenthal, chairman of the Board of Trade, told his membership and the press last week, adding, ''If we didn't make this type of association the future would be settled for us.'' **********Nevertheless, the agreement has sown discord among the Board of Trade's members, some of whom believe that the New York exchange should be allowed to die. Responding to these complaints, the directors of the Board of Trade decided on Monday to appoint a panel to study the agreement and to submit the matter to a membership vote next month. **********To prevent the Merc from overtaking it, the Board of Trade is trying to increase its affiliations, making overtures to fledgling futures exchanges in London and Hong Kong. It hopes that the tie-in with the New York Futures Exchange, if it is sustained by the membership, will help it establish the dominant contract in futures on stock indexes, which would allow futures traders to buy or sell a basket of securities based on the New York Stock Exchange's proprietary average.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/world.main_headline: U.S. AND JAPANESE ARE URGED TO SHARE MORE RESPONSIBILITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/world.print_headline: U.S. AND JAPANESE ARE URGED TO SHARE MORE RESPONSIBILITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/world.body_text: **********The Japanese-American relationship has been mutually beneficial in recent years but should be readjusted if it is to function most effectively in future, Graham Allison, dean of Harvard's John F.  Kennedy School of Government, said yesterday. **********Citing the term ''productive partnership'' used by the late Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira as the goal, Mr. Allison said that the relationship had proved highly productive for the United States in economic, security and political terms. He cited the vast amount of trade between the two countries, Japan's provision of important bases for American military forces and its role as one of the United States's principal political allies. The partnership has advanced ''a variety of vital interests in both countries,'' he said. **********For the future, he said, a main problem will be agreement on the sharing of responsibilities. There sho uld be less ''unilateralism'' in American d ecision-making on matters of joint concern if the Japanese are to accept a larger role, and broader recognition by Japan of its increased responsibility in meeting common requirements,he said. **********The Harvard dean was one of several speakers at a meeting held by the Japan Society yesterday to open a series of programs marking its 75th year. At the session, held at Japan House, the society's headquarters at 333 East 47th St., dignitaries of the two countries extolled the role of the society in promoting understanding and friendly relations between the United States and Japan. Range of Programs Cited David Rockefeller, the organization's honor ary chairman, cited the wide range of its informational and cultural programs. ''Interest in Japan is bound to increase in years to come,' ' he said, and the Japan Society will play an important part in ''filling the need for accurate information.'' **********Nobuhiko Ushiba, former Japanese Ambassador to the United States, who with Mr. Rockefeller is co-chairman of the society's 75th anniversary committee, declared that the organization had been instrumental in ''restoring good relations between our two countries'' after World War II. ''The work of the Japan Society has always been highly respected and appreciated in Japan,'' he said. **********Prince Hitachi, second son of Emperor Hirohito, represented his father at the meeting. The Prince surprised many in the audience by speaking in slow but clear English, declaring that at the time of the society's founding in 1907, Japan was a ''mystery'' to the American people. The society, he said, ''has gone to great lengths to show that Japan is not really an enigma.'' Former Ambassador Presides **********Robert S. Ingersoll, former ambassador to Japan and Deputy Secretary of State, and chairman of the society, presided at the meeting. A message from Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki praising the society's ''great contribution to understanding'' was read. **********The Japan Society is a nonprofit, nonpartisan organization that operates throughout the United States, ''dedicated to enhancing the relationship between Japan and the United States.'' Its activities include meetings, seminars, conferences and exchange programs on political, economic and public affairs topics, art exhibitions, film screenings, concerts, educational programs including language classes, and lectures on Japanese life and culture.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/23/busin.main_headline: COSTLIER JAPANESE CARS LINKED TO EXPORT CURB
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/23/busin.print_headline: COSTLIER JAPANESE CARS LINKED TO EXPORT CURB
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/23/busin.body_text: **********The auto export restraints that the Japanese adopted earlier this year, at the urging of the Reagan Administration, apparently have resulted in higher prices for Japanese cars sold in the United States, a House trade subcommittee said today. **********The panel, reporting on the conclusions of a recent mission to Japan, warned that trade curbs are not the answer to the Japanese challenge in autos and high-technology industries. **********Such restraints ''will only further burden the U.S. economy, making it more sluggish and inefficient, and we will slip further and further into a 'British disease' economy,'' the report warned in an allusion to the industrial decline that has characterized Britain in recent years. **********Commenting on the auto situation, the legislators found that there have been ''substantial'' price increases for Japanese cars since the export limitations went into effect last April 1. Commerce Department figures show that actual import levels since April 1 have been running at about the same level as a year ago. Domestic industry sales, meanwhile, have fallen to their lowest level in two decades. Closed Markets Criticized **********The report was highly critical of Japan's reluctance to open its markets faster to American agricultural and industrial exports. **********''This is perhaps natural for an island nation of talented people who have practiced centuries of absolute isolationism, but in today's one-world economy, it is a style of operating that is bringing out the anger of all the rest of the world,'' the legislators warned. **********Although the report did not threaten Japan with specific trade retaliation, it did note that Japan, as a major exporter, ''may have more to lose than most countries from any restrictions on free trade mechanisms.'' **********But the report was also critical of American industry's response to the Japanese challenge. It cited one example from the auto industry.  The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has been conducting 35-mile-an-hour crash tests, although these standards are not yet required by law. Last year most Japanese cars failed the test while many American cars passed. This year the Honda three-door Civic passed the test. **********Rather than building from its strength in these test showings, the report said, Detroit has complained that they are not sanctioned by law. **********''Spokesmen for Japanese auto firms have told us that one of Japan's new goals in autos is to build the world's safest autos,'' the report said. ''By responding creatively to these government regulations, rather than hiring more lobbyists to overturn them, Japan is again likely to make a product the American public wants.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/06/busin.body_text: **********IN an effort to fight back against money market mutual funds, banks are suddenly offering a host of new products to the consumer. None of the new products quite match the liquidity of money market funds, where cash can usually be withdrawn at any time simply by writing a check. Like the money funds, however, some of the new instruments do pay higher interest rates and provide greater liquidity than traditional savings vehicles: passbook accounts or certificates of deposit. **********And some may be particularly intriguing if interest rates turn down, since they allow the investor to lock in an interest rate for a period of time, but still provide the freedom to pull funds out. **********Some banks are working to make the six-month certificate of deposit a more flexible investment. In a traditional C.D., the investor is penalized for withdrawing money before the certificate matures. But under Citibank's Easy Access C.D., for example, an investor can withdraw all but $3,000 of the investment, allowing reinvestment at higher interest rates if rates are rising. **********Several bank holding companies, including Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover and Continental Illinois are about to begin to issue seven-year notes at rates that fluctuate weekly with average commercial paper rates. The interest will be paid on a monthly basis. To redeem their funds, however, investors will have to sell the notes or wait until they mature. **********Another new alternative is a consumer version of an investment long available to wealthy investors: the repurchase agreement, or ''repo.'' For a minimum investment of $1,000, the consumer can earn a return at an annual rate of 15 percent for up to 12 weeks. **********That rate remains in effect for the life of the investment, even if interest rates head down. But if rates go up and there are better investments elsewhere, the money can be withdrawn any time after an initial period of about eight or 10 days - the details vary from bank to bank. The banks may also set new rates, but they would not affect repos already in existence. **********Only a few savings banks and savings associations in the New York area now offer such plans, and they all call them by different names. At the American Savings Bank (and its Franklin and Empire Savings Bank divisions), which has had the program the longest, it is called the Investment Certificate. The County Federal Savings and Loan Association of Rockville Centre, L.I., introduced such a plan, called the Investors Fund, in mid-May. At the West Side Savings and Loan Association, the program, which began last Wednesday, is called the Growth Fund. **********But, predicts John L. Reilly, senior vice president and secretary at the American Savings Bank, ''over the next few months, this plan is going to proliferate.'' **********The investment is actually in the form of a ''loan'' to the bank.  The bank puts up Government securities as collateral that it will repay the loan. The loan itself, however, is not guaranteed by the Government. **********The repo procedure is widely used by both bankers and brokerage firms. In a typical repo, an investor buys Government securities from a bank, with the promise that the bank will buy back the securities and also pay for the use of the money. Hundreds of millions of dollars of repos change hands daily. But until recently, the repo was unavailable to the small investor. Scattered banking institutions around the country have begun to offer these retail repos in recent months. **********Under American's plan, money must remain for at least eight days.  The maximum term is 84 days, or 12 weeks, and the 15 percent interest rate is guaranteed for that period. If an investor wants to withdraw funds before 84 days, they must be completely withdrawn, and there is a $3 service fee. However, if there is at least $1,000 remaining, a new Investment Certificate could be purchased. **********From time to time, the bank may change the rate available on new certificates, although that would not affect certificates already outstanding. The rate has been changed three times in the five months the certificates have been available. **********Details of similar programs vary from bank to bank. At County Federal, the minimum investment is also $1,000, but the full term runs 89 days rather than 84, and money must remain for 10 days rather than eight. There is no charge for withdrawing money after 10 days.  When the 89 days are up, the money is transferred automatically into either a daily passbook account or a NOW - negotiable order of withdrawal - account that must be set up when money is placed in the Investors Fund. An investor may also immediately withdraw the funds on the final day. **********At West Side Federal, the Growth Fund also calls for a $1,000 minimum investment and funds must stay at the bank for at least 10 days up to a maximum of 89 days. The savings and loan association also requires investors to open either a passbook account, with a $10 minimum deposit, or a NOW checking account, with a $500 minimum - the minimum deposit levels are scheduled to change on July 1. George Hottum, a vice president at West Side Federal, said that the Growth Fund was a limited offering and could be withdrawn at any time.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/jobs/.main_headline: THE MARKETPLACE IN FOUR MAJOR FIELDS ENGINEERING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/jobs/.print_headline: THE MARKETPLACE IN FOUR MAJOR FIELDS ENGINEERING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/jobs/.body_text: **********S OME say the inevitable downturn in the cyclical demand for engineers may begin soon. Others say there is no sign of it. However, by all accounts, the estimated 60,000 engineering graduates who entered the job market in the last year have benefited from a clear gap between supply and demand, and next year's crop is likely to do just as well. **********Just ask John Herb, who handles colleg e recruiting for the Pacific Gas & Electri c Company in San Francisco. ''From what I have seen,'' Mr. Herb said , ''your typical engineer with a 3.0 grade point averageand one summe r of work experience has at least three offers, and probably five or six. We had one guy in for an interview who had 17.'' **********Or Willard Greenwald, a 1980 graduate of the University of Vermont now employed as a mechanical engineer at Stanley Tools in South Shaftsbury, Vt. ''There were so many interviews on campus that I didn't even have to mail out resumes,'' he said. **********Or Robin Greenlief, a June graduate of Oregon State University now employed as a civil engineer in the power group at Bechtel Corporation in San Francisco. She is one of the rapidly growing group of women entering the profession. ''I had 10 interviews and 10 offers,'' she said. **********These experiences jibe with the results of a survey by the College Placement Council of Bethlehem, Pa., which found that engineering students, who made up about 7 percent of last year's graduates, received about 65 percent of the reported job offers. **********They also are borne out by the Endicott Report, an annual survey by Frank Endicott, the recently retired director of placement at Northwestern University, of hiring at large companies. Some 93 responding companies, which spent an average of $3.5 million on new engineers, said last December that they would hire 8,872 engineers, a increase in the per-company average of 14.4 percent from the previous year. A follow-up survey in May indicated that actual hiring was almost 5 percent greater than predicted. **********All this explains why George Thoms, manager of placement for Allied Chemical Company, the largest recruiter of engineers within the Allied Corporation, found competition for the graduates keener than ever. Allied interviewed more than 1,000 candidates at 75 colleges, Mr. Thoms said, for 72 technical positions. **********The strong demand translates into attractive starting salaries.  Most surveys show new engineers with Bachelor of Science degrees earn an average of between $22,000 and $23,000. Those with a Master of Science degree start at $25,000 or more. Civil engineers may be a little lower and specialties, such as electrical engineering, higher. **********The strong demand also enables new engineers to consider more than money in choosing prospective employers. ''I was looking at training programs,'' Mr. Greenwald said. ''I wanted one that would be fairly formal and give me the most practical knowledge about manufacturing.'' **********Still, some flexibility may be required. Thomas Krieger, a classmate of Mr. Greenwald's, wanted a job in the Burlington area, where the University of Vermont is situated. Eventually, he widened his search and, in May, took an offer to work in Allied's specialty chemicals division in Baton Rouge, La. ''There isn't much demand in northern New England because there is so little industry, but I see jobs galore advertised in the paper down here,'' he said. **********History indicates that the imbalance in supply and demand is bound to end. Some, like Robert N. Mills, manager of professional recruiting and university relations at the General Electric Company, believe it will persist throughout the decade. ''What is different from any time in the past 25 years is that we also have a high attrition rate now because the generation that was hired at the end of World War II is beginning to retire,'' he said. **********But others, like Harrison Shull, provost at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and chairman of the National Academy of Sciences' Commission on Human Resources, say the swing to oversupply could come in two or three years. **********''I've been watching freshman enrollments,'' he said. ''Last year's class was 110,000. If they finish at the same rate they have been during the past 10 years - more than 70 percent - we would see 75,000 of them entering the job market. Glut is too big a word for it, but there would be a modest surplus in supply.'' **********A softening of demand would not be felt evenly. Engineers in rapidly growing areas, such as computers and petroleum engineering, are likely to remain in short supply, as are those in unp opular niches, such as nuclear engineering, accordin g to most experts. **********Experts say that one healthy sign that the gap between supply and demand has narrowed would be a rise in the numbers of engineers going on for higher degrees to enhance their appeal to employers. As things stand, even well-known schools like the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute are having trouble attracting Ph.D. candidates. **********More advanced degree candidates and fewer job opportunities in industry might also replenish the ranks of teaching engineers. In recent years, industry has been offering engineers fresh out of undergraduate programs salaries 10 percent above those paid to junior faculty members with Ph.D. degrees. **********One large u nknown is whether the career-development opportunities of engineers entering the work force today will be limited simply because there are so many of them. The narrow passageway into management wi ll certainly not be easier to negotiate in a crowd. **********Few persons have adopted the long-range view of Brian Sedar, an architectural-engineering student who went on to get a master's degree in business administration at the University of Colorado before looking for work last summer. ''I ended up selling myself as an engineer because the recruiting was so much heavier,'' said Mr.  Sedar, now in Bechtel's petroleum group. ''But I want to get into management eventually and I expect the business degree to help.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/19/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; The Challenge Facing Reagan
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/19/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; The Challenge Facing Reagan
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/19/busin.body_text: **********THE biggest mistake President Reagan made at his news conference this week appears to have been his attack on House Speaker Thomas P.  O'Neill Jr., whom he accused of ''sheer demogoguery'' for criticizing his economic program as too generous to the wealthy and too hard on working people and the poor. ''I'm trying to find out something about his boyhood,'' the President said, ''because we didn't live on the wrong side of the railroad tracks, but we lived so close to them we could hear the whistle real loud.'' **********Mr. Reagan's attack on Mr. O'Neill appears to have backfired by rallying the Democrats not only to the support of their Congressional leader but also of a budget and tax package of their own design. The President hastened to try to patch things up, but the Democrats would have none of it. **********They apparently sensed that Mr. Reagan was highly sensitive to the charge that he had fashioned a program designed to serve the rich and sought to refute it by declaring, ''I grew up in poverty and got what education I got all by myself and so forth.'' **********Mr. O'Neill quickly turned this Presidential maneuver to his own advantage by remarking, ''I still live in the same neighborhood I did as a young boy,'' a pointed reference to the President's more recent affluent surroundings and friends. The Massachusetts Democrat does indeed live in the same old house in North Cambridge, near Porter Square, where he grew up - a working-class neighborhood. Mr. O'Neill followed up this left jab with a right cross for a hard-hitting combination. ''The issue,'' he said, ''is the programs he's been sending to the Congress. These are all geared to the wealthy of America.'' **********The President had sought to block that charge at his news conference by saying that ''we're going to do our utmost to keep the bottom rung of the ladder clear for those people that haven't yet started to climb.'' What those words were intended to convey was the now familiar supply-side message that tax cuts aimed at increasing incentives to save, invest and produce, and the deregulation of business would benefit the working poor more than Government programs or tax cuts aimed directly at them. **********But the conservative political faith, despite its current ascendancy, has a hard row to hoe in democratic societies if it is perceived as a special-interest doctrine designed to serve the interests only of the fortunate few at the top. **********The United States, along with Britain and some other Western countries, is in a conservative trend, stemming largely from the failures or exhaustion of liberal and socialist policies. **********This conservative trend, according to A. James Reichley, a former White House aide in the Ford Administration and now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, ''is reflected not only in the recent electoral successes of conservative parties in many of the industrial democracies, but also in the growing conservatism of leadership groups in many liberal and even socialist parties who seek solutions to pressing problems common to most democratic countries, such as economic inflation, the drying up of sources of cheap energy, social dissonance, personal alienation, rampaging hedonism, institutional corruption, and the renewed dangers of Soviet aggression.'' **********Indeed, in this country the conservative trend may be more brilliantly illuminated on the Democratic side than the Republican side in Congress. For instance, the Democrats have been at least as eager to give tax benefits to business to stimulate investment.  Whichever plan wins in Congress, as Alan Greenspan, the conservative economist, put it, ''To borrow a phrase from the Administration, we're rolling in jelly beans.'' **********But, in his new book, ''Conservatives in an Age of Change,'' Mr.  Reichley warns against premature euphoria or overreaching on the right. ''A decisive shift to conservatism will not occur, or at least will not last very long,'' he says, ''if conservatism is no more than a rationalization for organized greed, or a soapbox for belligerent nationalism.'' **********He declares that if conservatism's roots are in the essential tradition of Western civilization, and even in the fundamental nature of humanity, its contemporary expression will need to show ''a breadth and nobility'' reflecting such origins. ''To approach this standard,'' he says, ''conservatism will have to include a capacity for change as well as foundations for stability.'' **********Having been hit so hard so soon with the charge that it is nothing but a rationalization for greed and a soapbox for belligerent nationalism, the Reagan Administration may need to demonstrate that it does in fact have a capacity for change and a breadth and nobility that encompass the working people and the poor as well as the rich.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/31/world.main_headline: POLISH FOOD SHORTAGE SPURS NEW UNREST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/31/world.print_headline: POLISH FOOD SHORTAGE SPURS NEW UNREST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/31/world.body_text: **********Demonstrations and strike calls increased in Poland today as the independent labor organization attempted to channel popular anger against food shortages and meat-ration cuts. **********Solidarity's Warsaw local called a two-hour warning strike for next Wednesday and said that tomorrow a delegation of workers would present a petition to Parliament, which is debating the parlous economic situation. **********Transport workers here also called a three-hour strike for Wednesday, while locals in Gdansk and Czestochowa announced plans to stop work in August. **********This afternoon, thousands of women and children marched through the heart of the textile city of Lodz, culminating four days of protests there. **********The growing protests have punctured a faintly upbeat mood after the ruling Communist Party at its congress earlier this month introduced limited democratic procedures for selecting its leadership. Grim Union Poster on the Street **********A grim union poster that has just appeared on the streets shows a black skull with a crossed knife and fork under it.  ''The first result of the ninth party congress: a cut in food rations,'' the poster says, referring to the 20 percent reduction in meat allotments announced last week. **********The decision has given a common theme to the latest wave of unrest, though the initiative, whether here or in the provinces, rests with factory-level units of the union. **********''We must not allow spontaneous protests to be transformed into chaotic hunger disturbances,'' Wiadomosci, a Warsaw union bulletin, said, criticizing the union leadership for lack of guidance. **********Poles are aware that three times in the recent past - 1970, 1976 and just a year ago - economic difficulties led to worker rebellions.  As union locals announced their planned protests, including a women's march tomorrow in Szczecin and a rally in Wroclaw, Parliament met to consider the plight of the economy. **********Gen. Mieczyslaw Moczar, head of a committee that watches over the economy, painted a gloomy picture. Lack of Responsibility Seen **********Lamenting a ''decline in the sense of responsibility and a serious loosening of work discipline,'' he spoke of unfulfilled plans and the neglect of agriculture and said that one-fourth of the railway cars in Poland were beyond use. **********Deputies debated the Government's economic proposals, including plans to raise subsidized prices, which are well below what they would be in a free market. One deputy said the price increases should be introduced ''very carefully.'' **********''We've had bad experiences in 1970 and 1976 when the prices were changed,'' he recalled.  Economists have called for a stiff, one-shot rise in prices, which could be as much as 300 percent, to soak up an excess of money in circulation. But the latest protests have made the Government wary, and now politicians are talking about step-by-step increases. **********Zycie Warszawy, a Warsaw daily, said the food demonstrations suggested that ''the society's limit of resistance is approaching.'' ''Perhaps the chances for shock therapy were greater a few months ago,'' the paper said, alluding to the price debate. ''Now the fascination with renewal and the buoyant mood of society, which could have given support to strong measures, have given way to exhaustion, a sense of hopelessness and chaos.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/05/world.body_text: **********Leaders of the independent trade union approved plans today for a brief warning strike in four northern cities next week. It would be the first industrial protest since Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski instructed Parliament on April 10 to outlaw strikes for two months. **********The action was called to protest a delay by the authorities in punishing officials responsible for ordering the police to evict union members from the Bydgoszcz provincial assembly hall on March 19. Three unionists were beaten up when the police evicted a worker delegation from the hall and the union is annoyed because the authorities have not revealed the names of those responsible. **********Today the union's National Commission, meeting without Lech Walesa, the union leader, who is in Geneva, voted 22 to 13 with two abstentions to stage a two-hour warning strike on Thursday in Bydgoszcz, Wloclawek, Plock and Torun. **********After the strike vote, Mieczyslaw Rakowski, the Deputy Prime Minister in charge of union affairs, said on television that he was going to Bydgoszcz. **********Some prominent union members and the Roman Catholic Church expressed disapproval of the strike vote. A church spokesman said the decision flew in the face of church expectations that the union would respect a 30-day period of mourning for the nation's Primate, Cardinal Stefan Wyszynski, by refraining from industrial protest. **********Meanwhile, 26 people around Poland continued fasting to press for the release of so-called political prisoners, and inmates of a jail were refusing food to press for better conditions. Minister Affirms Ties to Bloc Special to the New York Times **********GENEVA, June 4 - Janusz Obodowski, the Polish Minister of Labor, told the annual assembly of the International Labor Organization today that he welcomed world interest in Polish developments. But he denounced attempts to use them to drive a wedge between Poland and its Soviet-bloc allies. **********Lech Walesa, the union leader, who is attending as Poland's worker delegate, told reporters that he had discussed a future visit to the United States with Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

Coen, senior vice president and popular pundit at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, who updated his 1981 forecast yesterday in the pleasant precincts of the Princeton Club. **********In December, Mr. Coen estimated a 10.8 percent increase in the nation's advertising spending this year. **********Now, though, he has revised the estimate to 11.9 percent, or to a total of more than $61 billion. **********He sees all of the media exceeding their 1980 revenues with the various performances as follows: magazines up 9 percent, to $3.4 billion; national ads in newspapers up 15 percent, to $2.7 billion; network TV up 10 percent, to $5.5 billion; spot TV 13 percent, to $3.7 billion; network radio up 12 percent, to $200 million; spot radio up 12 percent, to $865 million; ''other national advertising'' up 11 percent, to $17.2 billion, and total local advertising up 12.8 percent, to $27.4 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/busin.print_headline: YOUR MONEY; KEOGH BENEFITS FOR YOUNGSTERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/14/busin.body_text: **********Some years ago the idea was advanced that Keogh retirement plans could be used for teen-agers and college students, with some help from parents or grandparents. Little has been done with the idea, however, by banks and others who advertise Keogh plans and their tax advantages. **********And that is understandable. What young person with a newspaper route earning $500 a year thinks of putting 15 percent, or $75, into a Keogh plan if the money cannot be used, without penalty, until age 59 1/2? But that attitude does not take into consideration what parents or grandparents can do to help. In effect, they can put up the money for a youngster to salt away, tax-sheltered, in a Keogh plan. **********Keogh plans, named for Eugene J. Keogh, the former Congressman who sponsored the legislation, provide retirement plans for the selfemployed: for doctors, lawyers, salesmen, writers, artists, storeowners and others who work independently and are not covered by company pension plans. Keoghs can also be used by freelancers: consulting engineers, writers who sell articles, artists who sell paintings, even though many such persons hold regular jobs covered by corporate pension plans. **********Currently 15 percent of such freelance income can be put into a Keogh plan, up to a maximum $7,500 a year and thus be deducted from gross income on one's tax return. For the self-employed person whose earnings are low, the amount can nevertheless be as much as $750, provided at least that much is earned. For example, a person who earns only $1,000 can put up to $750 into a Keogh plan. The usual 15 percent ceiling does not apply. **********In addition to the obvious advantage of being deductible, the plan offers a second advantage: it accumulates dividends, interest and capital gains tax free. At age 59 1/2 a person can withdraw the money (and it must be withdrawn by age 70 1/2). At withdrawal the individual pays a tax figured by a complex formula. **********These days high school students can earn substantially more than pocket change from newspaper routes, cutting grass, painting houses, working as lifeguards, snow removal, tree pruning, baby-sitting. At college they often find even better-paying freelance jobs. **********If a youngster is earning money and eligible to set up a Keogh plan, nothing in the law bars parents or grandparents from reimbursing a child for money to be deposited in a Keogh account opened by the child. Florence Brady Donohue, a lawyer who specializes in women's tax problems in New York, said: ''It's a good idea for parents or grandparents to give children money for Keogh accounts.  The children might have to file income tax returns, however.'' **********In case of earned income, a child need not pay Federal income tax until he or she earns the $2,300 zero bracket amount plus the $1,000 personal exemption, or $3,300 total, during a year. In fact, the child with a Keogh could earn more without paying tax since the Keogh contribution cuts gross income. **********When someone is in a low bracket - as most youngsters are - the deductibility of Keogh contributions does not mean great tax savings, of course. In that case, the major benefit would be tax-free accumulation of dividends, interest and capital gains over many years. **********For example, suppose Donald Jr., a go-getter, earns $2,000 a year during high school. At college he earns more - $4,000 a year for four years. His parents decide they can afford to give him the equivalent each year of 15 percent for a Keogh plan - a total of $1,200 in high school years and $2,400 in college years, or $3,600 altogether. **********Let's assume that his Keogh plan grows to $5,000 by the time Donald Jr. takes a permanent job at age 22. Also assume that whatever plan handles the money - bank, mutual fund, broker - yields 9 percent a year thereafter. Compounded at 9 percent, money doubles in eight years. **********The accompanying chart shows roughly what could happen to Donald Jr.'s Keogh plan, without further contributions: He conceivably has a retirement fund of $160,000, which could be more or less depending on investment success. Inflation could take a toll, but the investments, if well chosen, might keep up. **********''It's a terrifc idea, and I cannot think of any drawback except for tantalization.'' John Klaus, head of the pension department at Prentice-Hall Inc., the financial and tax publishing company, said.  By ''tantalization,'' he meant that the young person might be tempted to withdraw money early, even though an early withdrawal entails a stiff penalty. **********''It certainly has not been thought of by many people,'' he said.  ''It offers no problems, and there's no doubt it would fly.'' He agreed that the $750 contribution for low-income freelancers made it even better. **********As another advantage, he said, with the Keogh plan steadily compounding, Donald Jr. might not feel he had to save as much money out of income when he starts working and marries. In addition, the Keogh plan is a partial substitute for life insurance; if the Keogh holder dies, the money goes to the spouse and children at advantageous tax rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/23/world.main_headline: IN INDIA, THERE'S A DEMONSTRATION FOR ANY OCCASION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/23/world.print_headline: IN INDIA, THERE'S A DEMONSTRATION FOR ANY OCCASION
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/23/world.body_text: **********Just as Eskimos have more than a hundred words for snow and Arabs have dozens of expressions for sand, so it is entirely fitting that people in India have many ways of saying demonstration. **********Every day in every city and large town groups of men and women march, chant, sit, fast or mill about to protest or support all sorts of things, ranging from public policies and salary scales to private utterances or religious behavior. **********From time to time the demonstrations flare into violence and are treated nationally as front-page news. But mostly they remain highly ritualized local events that barely impinge on the awareness of passers-by. **********The forms of the protests vary greatly. There is, for instance, the ''gherao,'' in which the target of the protest - often a college head or company manager - is blockaded in his office by a demonstrating throng. There is also that monument to Indian pragmatism, the ''relay hunger strikes,'' in which groups of protesters take turns skipping meals to dramatize their grievances. 36 Separate Demonstrations **********The high incidence and great diversity of protesting was reflected in a cursory survey of the Indian press over two recent days that turned up small reports of 36 separate demonstrations. **********A few of the headlines provided a sampler of the more common types of agitations: ''Black Flags at Two Places,'' ''Rasta Roko Stir by Bombay Party,'' ''West Uttar Pradesh Lawyers Stage Dharna,'' ''Black Day by Medical Students,'' ''Token Fast by Government Printing Staff'' and ''Clerks on Mass Casual Leave.'' The terms are explained in the glossary below. **********Often the demonstrations involve processions and in such cases they clearly take their inspiration from religious festivals and rites.  Others echo the campaigns of civil disobedience with which Mohandas K. Gandhi shook and broke the ties of the British Empire. All of them involve the use and movement of human bodies, something that India has in great abundance. **********Romesh Thapar, a journalist and a pillar of New Delhi's intellectual inner circle, remarked some months ago that this mobilizing of bodies for rallies and protests was the single Indian manifestation in a democratic system that he said was otherwise simply cloned from the British model. Mr. Thapar scorned what has been termed ''rent-a-crowd politics,'' but he acknowledged their impact on political and social life. ''Our throngs are as much a part of our political processes as polling and motivational research are in the United States,'' he said. Indian Terms Explained **********These are some of the more purely Indian types of demonstrations: Satyagraha - A term coined by Gandhi that literally means a protest by truth. It applies to almost any form of civil disobedience.  Rasta roko - This means ''block the road,'' and it is becoming increasingly popular, especially among groups of farmers who have thronged highways creating long traffic jams in order to dramatize their claims for higher prices for their crops. **********Morcha - This means procession and it can be anything from a straggly little outing to a real hike with a column of marchers several miles long. **********Pen down strike - In this protest workers come to the office but do nothing. A version of this was recently called by the All-India Station Masters Federation, which put up posters saying they would hold a ''control phone boycott.'' As explained by a stationmaster in Kerala this meant that the railroad employees were not going to answer the phones that report delays, reroutings and oncoming trains. **********Gherao - This is a Bengali word meaning surround, and it describes a tactic first introduced by Maoist activists in the 1960's. It involves assembling in such a way as to imprison people in their offices. **********Black flags - In this demonstration protesters show up with black flags that are supposed to show their disgust and shame the target of the protest. When Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain arrived here last week several small groups waved black flags for her. They were not anarchists. She did not seem to notice or mind. **********Black day - In this maneuver people come to work wearing a black armband, indicating that they are displeased with their employer or conditions of work. **********Mass casual leave - This is not a strike but it is hard to tell the difference. Basically, everybody suddenly stays home from work or school. There are no pickets or slogans. **********Dharna - This is a strike, with pickets and placards. There is also a subcategory known as ''sitting dharna,'' in which a prominent and highly respected man sits by himself in front of the alleged exploiter. If he is distinguished enough the lone sitter is thought to have the force of as many as 50,000 people and he can bring enormous moral pressure to bear on the strike target. **********Then there are the hunger strikes. A drawn-out fast is rare, though ''token'' strikes in which groups gather to skip lunch or dinner are quite common. And there is the ''relay hunger strike.'' For more than six months the Association of Unemployed Airplane Pilots maintained a vigil in a gaily colored tent it erected on a downtown street. **********The generally robust young men maintained around-the-clock shifts in the tent, vowing to keep missing alternate meals until someone gave them jobs flying light propeller craft. Perhaps they got their wish or they starved because, quite suddenly, they were gone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/17/world.main_headline: NO A HOT RIO DAY, ICY BEER AND MINIMAL SWIMSUITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/17/world.print_headline: NO A HOT RIO DAY, ICY BEER AND MINIMAL SWIMSUITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/17/world.body_text: **********News of jewel thefts at luxury hotels gave way the other day to an account of a truck hijacking that could be taken as a sure sign of summer. Four gunmen commandeered the rig and made off with its cargo, 11,000 quart bottles of beer. **********The hijackers knew their business. When the air in Rio wrinkles from the heat in January, February and March, the wavy image that most often registers on the retina is a sweating glass of lager. **********This month Cariocas, as the inhabitants of Rio are known, are being told by breweries that there will be a shortage. Some bars are already rationing to keep enough on hand to slake the thirst of steady customers. **********''Chopp,'' as draft beer is called in Portuguese, is a word uttered frequently at this time of year, often in a dry whisper. The quality of the product is unsurpassed; even German tourists brighten with admiration at the first swallow. **********Beer is sold at the more than 5,000 stand-up lunch counters in Rio, at cafes along the beachfront, in supermarkets and from the shacks that house mom-and-pop groceries in the chockablock hillside slums.  About the only place it cannot be found is Maracana, the soccer stadium that seats 200,000 fans, more than any other arena in the world. The authorities decided long ago that passions there are high enough. **********Shirtsleeves can pass for being overdressed in many parts of town.  More common attire is a bathing suit, and in Rio that can mean almost nothing at all, for the Brazilian bathing suit has been doing a gradual disappearing act for several years. **********You will see people in bathing suits on downtown streets, on buses, in restaurants and at home. Pregnant women are not reluctant to wear bikinis, though some suspend a discreet awning from the suit top. **********When the Christmas holidays arrive and temperatures regularly soar above 100 degrees, the matinal procession to the beach takes on the aspects of a tribal migration. People swarm there to escape the heat and the congestion of the city, whose five million people live in one of the world's densest urban concentrations. **********Swimming is an in-and-out affair. Not many Cariocas stray out as far as the breakers, perhaps wary of becoming one of the two or three drowning victims each sunny summer weekend. The more common pattern is to stand at water's edge in clutches, talking business, gossiping or doing something that, in Portuguese, is decorously called ''making charm'' and usually involves members of the opposite sex. **********Subsistence is provided by hardy barefoot vendors who somehow maintain their good nature while plying the beach and percussively singing out their offerings - cold drinks, hot dogs, coconuts, pineapples, sweets, biscuits, ice cream, shrimp cooked on a spit, meat pies, beach chairs, tanning lotions, kites, parasols and, of course, beer. **********The beach offers a lot of well-tanned and well-toned flesh to admire. More than half the population is 18 years old or younger, and many of the rest hold age at bay by working out on gymnastic equipment at the edge of the pavement along the waterfront. **********For all the warmth of summer in the Southern Hemisphere, murders, assaults and holdups have created a profound climate of fear, displacing the easygoing style that characterized Rio and replacing with deadly seriousness the romance that surrounded its fabled character, the ''malandro.'' **********A streetcorner type with no visible means of support, the malandro typified a Carioca capacity to get by with a lot of wits and little work. His method was the ''jeito,'' a word that roughly translates as ''knack'' and is necessary in almost every daily transaction. **********Jeito is usually practiced best by Brazilians, a notable exception being Ronald Biggs, long Britain's most wanted man as the last of the great train robbers of 1963. He was awaiting deportation in 1974 after being discovered as a fugitive from a London prison until he learned that his mistress, a nightclub dancer, was pregnant. He quickly acted on a law that forbids the expulsion of the father of a dependent Brazilian child, and he is still here, an honorary malandro. **********Jeito lives on in an institutionalized form in the person of the ''despachante.'' Though in English they would be called fixers, they are so much an established part of life that they are listed in the yellow pages. They know the back entrances to the bureaucracy that governs so many aspects of life. For a price they can speed the process of getting something officially authorized; for a higher price they can speed it even more. **********Speed does not characterize motion here, but rhythm does. The kettle drums, tambourines, whistles, rattles, graters, cowbells and other timpani of the highly organized samba schools are beating out their locomotive cadences every night in the slums as they prepare for the Carnival competition early in March. Watch a construction worker or an elevator operator or a passenger on an airplane fall to idle finger tapping and you will invariably hear the samba beat. **********Life is much harder for most Cariocas than the cheerful cadence of a samba would suggest. Class distinctions are strong and social mobility is slight. **********Look at the city from the 2,330-foot height at the base of the mountaintop statue of Christ the Redeemer and you will see that even the air is apportioned on a preferential basis. Over the slums and industrial suburbs of the north the atmosphere is jaundiced, choked with pollution and trapped by surrounding hills; to the south and west, where people with money live and work, the sky is cleansed by sea breezes. **********Carnival represents a chance to turn this system on its head, if only for four days. The poor dress like kings and queens and the streets are theirs. Then they return to their roles and their routines. **********With violence, inflation and headlong building patterns that are turning the city into a nest of characterless high-rises, much of the color and gracefulness of life that tempered those harsh divisions has vanished.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/05/busin.main_headline: REAGAN NAMES STANS TO OPIC BOARD
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/05/busin.print_headline: REAGAN NAMES STANS TO OPIC BOARD
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/05/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan today announced the nomination of Maurice H. Stans, a former Nixon Administration official who was convicted of election campaign violations during the Watergate years, to be a director of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. **********Mr. Stans, who was Secretary of Commerce during Mr. Nixon's first term, is believed to be the first person with a criminal record from the Watergate scandal to be named to a Federal post. His nomination must be confirmed by the Senate. Mr. Stans, 73 years old, is now a private consultant in Los Angeles. **********A White House statement said that Mr. Stans would succeed William M. Landau on the OPIC board. OPIC was created to help American businessmen invest in developing countries by offering assistance with insurance, loans and loan guarantees. Fund-Raising Record Set **********Mr. Stans, who also served as budget director under President Eisenhower, is best known for the role he played during President Nixon's 1972 re-election campaign. As finance chairman of the Committee for the Re-election of the President, Mr. Stans raised $62 million, a record in political fund-raising. The abuses later uncovered during the Watergate investigation led to an overhaul of Federal campaign laws, and limits were placed on the amount an individual could give to one campaign. **********Mr. Stans pleaded guilty on March 12, 1975, to three counts of violating the reporting sections of the Federal Election Campaign Act and two counts of accepting illegal campaign contributions. He was fined $5,000. **********According to testimony in the Watergate case, Mr. Stans authorized Hugh Sloan, the campaign treasurer, to pay G. Gordon Liddy $83,000.  Mr. Liddy used the money to finance a political intelligencegathering operation, including the break-in and bugging of Democratic Party headquarters at the Watergate complex in Washington. Acquitted in New York Trial **********Mr. Stans insisted that he knew nothing of Mr. Liddy's plan. He said he had simply notified Mr. Sloan that higher authorities had said Mr. Liddy was authorized to receive campaign funds. **********Mr. Stans was also a defendant in a New York trial in which he and John N. Mitchell, former Attorney General, were accused of conspiracy, obstruction of justice and perjury in connection with an investigation of Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier. After a long trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan, both Mr. Stans and Mr. Mitchell were acquitted. **********Mr. Stans later wrote ''The Terrors of Justice,'' a bitter memoir of the Watergate days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/world.main_headline: U.N. Agency Says Cambodia Still Faces Food Problems
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; U.N. Agency Says Cambodia Still Faces Food Problems
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/26/world.body_text: **********A United Nations agency here reported today that ''widespread starvation and serious malnutrition'' had been overcome in Cambodia but that it still faced food problems. **********The report, based on two visits to Cambodia, was issued here by the Food and Agriculture Organization.  United Nations agencies have channeled $470 million worth of aid to Cambodia since mid-1979, when widespread famine there captured world attention. The F.A.O. estimated that $235 million in aid for food and agriculture development would be needed this year. Less than a quarter of that amount has been pledged by the world body's member countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/busin.body_text: **********As Wall Street sorted through Monday's surprise announcement about the proposed acquisition of Salomon Brothers, the nation's largest privately owned investment banking firm, by the Phibro Corporation, a large commodity trading company, analysts said they were as impressed by the potential power of the combination as by the multimilliondollar payments that the Salomon partners are to receive. **********This latest Wall Street merger, analysts noted, could put additional pressure on brokerage firms and other financial companies in their competition with this new and well-capitalized firm - still to be named - that will have a seemingly unparalleled global reach both in commodities and in securities trading. **********''I have been doing mergers for 30 years, and this is one of the more rational mergers I have seen,'' said Felix Rohatyn, a partner at Lazard Freres & Company, who represented Phibro in the negotiations. **********In fact, Salomon partners say it was more the prospect of the combination than the financial considerations that finally convinced them to take a merger proposal seriously. **********What finally sold John H. Gutfreund, managing partner, on the idea, he said, was ''the overwhelming business fit - it so tickled me.'' Growing Pains **********Since Mr. Gutfreund assumed the post nearly three years ago, Salomon has been undergoing growing pains. Part of this process is visible in the steady stream of partners leaving the firm in the last few years. This week's disclosure that six more partners will leave the firm on Oct. 1 is a continuation of that process, Mr. Gutfreund said. **********Although he confirmed that this latest group included three people in corporate finance, Robert Bernhard, Norman Levy and Craig Stearns, the firm emphasized that it does not mean the new firm will move away from investment banking. Partners say that, on the contrary, Phibro was very interested in gaining a foothold in this area. **********The three other general partners who will take early retirement on Oct. 1 are Stanley Arkin, a securities trader; Michael Bloomberg, the former chief of the stock trading desk and the architect of the firm's new computerized trading system, and David Osborne, a partner in the firm's San Francisco office. James D. Wolfensohn, who has headed Salomon's investment banking efforts for the last several years, will also be stepping down as a general partner on Oct. 1, as previously announced. **********All of these partners, however, will share in the returns from the sale of their firm. Each of the 62 general partners will receive an immediate payment, tax-free, of his share of the firm's net worth. As of March 31, that amounted to about $233 million. Of course, the exact figure at the end of September, and the share that will go to the limited partners, is still undetermined. Phibro has said that it will replenish that capital with its own funds. **********Furthermore, each general partner will receive a share of $250 million of 9 percent debentures, convertible into Phibro stock at $27.78 a share, over five years. The first year, partners will be allowed to convert up to 35 percent of their debentures; the second year, an additional 25 percent, and 13 1/3 percent each year for the following three years. Partners would have to pay capital gains taxes on those debentures when they convert them, the firm said. **********The seven members of Salomon's executive committee have signed five-year employment contracts, while the other partners who are staying on have signed three-year contracts. **********Although Salomon employees will no longer be considered partners, the firm will establish a similar category of ''managing directors.'' And Mr. Gutfreund said that there would be new additions to that rank, besides the existing partners, on Oct. 1. **********Following is a list of the 62 general partners at Salomon Brothers who will profit from the merger with Phibro: Stanly J. Arkin, Robert A. Bernhard, Michael R. Bloomberg, Bruce V. Carp, Peter W. Certo, E. Craig Coats Jr., Stanley L. Cohen, J. Scott Crabtree, L. Eugene Crowley, Robert F. Dall, John M. Donovan, Jason M. Elsas Jr., Michael H. Epstein, Donald M. Feuerstein, Allan H.  Fine, Ronald M. Freeman, Tully M. Friedman, Raymond L. Golden, Peter A. Gordon, Peter M. Gottsegan. **********Richard L. Grand-Jean, Steven D. Grand-Jean, John H. Gutfreund, J.  Ira Harris, Jay F. Higgins, Gedale B. Horowitz, George P. Hutchinson, Henry Kaufman, Jay L. Lassner, Martin L. Leibowitz, Norman J. Levy, Kenneth Lipper, Joseph P. Lombard, J. Steven Manolis, Thomas J.  Marron, James L. Massey, William A. McIntosh, Charles S. McVeigh 3d, John W. Meriwether, Roger W. Miller, John J. O'Brien. **********John L. O'Grady, David H. Osborne, Robert P. Quinn, Lewis S.  Ranieri, Richard G. Rosenthal, Jon W. Rotenstreich, Robert S. Salomon Jr., Daniel I. Sargent, Jerome M. Scheckman, Richard J. Schmeelk, Stanley B. Shopkorn, Layton F. Smith, Craig B. Stearns, Thomas W.  Strauss, Ronald M. Stuart, Harold Tanner, William J. Tierney Jr., William J. Voute, William N. Wight, John E. Wiley, James D.  Wolfensohn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/03/busin.main_headline: NEWSWEEK HEAD TAKES CBS PUBLISHING POST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/03/busin.print_headline: NEWSWEEK HEAD TAKES CBS PUBLISHING POST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/03/busin.body_text: **********Peter A. Derow has resigned as chairman and president of Newsweek Inc. and will replace John S. Suhler as president of the CBS/Publishing group. **********The sudden move marked the second time in four years that Mr.  Derow, 41 years old, has left the presidency of Newsweek for a high executive position at CBS Inc. In 1978, the Washington Post Company, Newsweek's parent, was able to lure Mr. Derow back to Newsweek only six months after he left it to become a senior vice president at CBS. **********In Washington, Katharine Graham, chairman of the Washington Post Company, announced that Mark Edmiston, 38, an executive vice president and head of domestic business operations for Newsweek, would succeed Mr. Derow as president. Newsweek publishes the weekly news magazine, as well as a new monthly called Inside Sports, and operates video and book divisions. The post of chairman and Mr.  Derow's position on the board of directors of the Washington Post Company were not immediately filled. **********Record Profits in 1980 **********The CBS/Publishing group is one of nation's largest suppliers of educational and professional learning materials and publishes various magazines, including Women's Day and Field and Stream, trade books and paperbacks. Last year, it had operating profits of $42.4 million on sales of $541.9 million, both group records. **********Because both Newsweek and CBS/ Publishing have been performing relatively well while many publishing enterprises have been struggling, the changes touched off speculation about possible personality conflicts and corporate intrigue in both companies. **********Sources at CBS said that Mr. Derow had been offered the position of president of the Washington Post Company by Mrs. Graham but had turned it down. Mrs. Graham said that the position had been ''discussed'' but that a formal offer had not been made because Mr.  Derow had made it clear he wanted to stay in New York. **********''The key is that I want to work in New York and that I think CBS is on the cutting edge of a lot of important developments,'' Mr.  Derow said, declining to discuss whether he had been offered the Washington Post position. He said that his decision to return to Newsweek from CBS in 1978 had involved ''a different job under different management.'' He added that he has known and respected Thomas H. Wyman, CBS Inc.'s new president, for 12 years. **********Mr. Suhler, 38, said that his resignation after two years in his current position and eight with the publishing group was involuntary but not acrimonious. Asked about speculation by analysts that the switch was related to a general housecleaning of executives associated with James D. Backe, whom Mr. Wyman replaced just over a year ago, Mr. Suhler said, ''I think there is something to that.'' **********Sources at the company said that the attitudes of William S. Paley, CBS's chairman, were also a factor. Mr. Paley was said to be concerned that CBS might be overextending itself in attempting to develop too many new technologies at once. One of them is videotex - the transmission of text and graphic displays, such as tables or charts - to television screens, a project with which Mr. Suhler has been deeply involved. Through a spokesman, Mr. Paley said that he was enthusiastic about all of the company's efforts in new technology.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/14/busin.body_text: **********Deciding that they could no longer wait for the Synthetic Fuels Corporation to act on their request for $75 million in aid, the private backers of a California coal gasification project have committed themselves to completing the $300 million project without Federal money. **********The 100 megawatt demonstration facility will be the nation's first electric generating plant using coal gasification technology, according to Ed Williams, a spokesman for Texaco Inc., the sponsor whose gasification technology is being used. **********The facility, which will be situated at the Southern California Edison Company's Coolwater generating station in the Mojave Desert near Barstow, Calif., is designed to convert Utah coal into gas. The gas will then be burned in a General Electric turbine system to create enough electricity to meet the needs of 35,000 homes, according to Mr. Williams. **********The sponsors announced late last week that the Electric Power Research Institute, the nonprofit research arm of the electric utility industry, had increased its commitment for the project to $126 million from $50 million and that the other sponsors, including Texaco, the Bechtel Corporation, the General Electric Company and Southern California Edison, had agreed to raise their investments by lesser, unspecified amounts to prevent construction delays. Project Manager Comments **********''The Synfuels Corporation has been encouraging to us and we still hope that it will participate in the project, but any further delays would have cost escalation and uncertainty associated with them,'' said Thomas O'Shea, the project manager for the research organization. **********Construction was delayed six months as the sponsors worked to line up more private participants, evaluated the impact of the Reagan tax program passed last summer and hoped for positive news from the Federal agency. **********The new commitments brought the project back to its original financial strategy, announced in 1979, of relying on private financing. The sponsors said they are continuing to seek other private sources of money, including individual utilities and a Japanese consortium. **********The Federal corporation was created 18 months ago to stimulate synthetic fuel technology, but it was slow to organize and has yet to announce its first grant. **********''We probably would have had Energy Department support if it wasn't for the Synfuels Corporation,'' said Mr. O'Shea, noting that the project had been in line to receive a $25 million grant from the Energy Department. That grant was rescinded by President Reagan as part of the shift of responsibility for federal synthetic fuels programs to the corporation. **********The decision of the utilities' group to increase its contribution - already the largest it has ever made to a single project - cleared the way for site preparation to begin. The facility is now scheduled to start operating in June 1984.
