https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/14/world.main_headline: A VISIT TO A SALVADORAN VILLAGE AT WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/14/world.print_headline: A VISIT TO A SALVADORAN VILLAGE AT WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/14/world.body_text: **********Shredded strips of the blue and white Salvadoran flag flutter at the top of a 50-foot-high bamboo pole in front of the gutted shell of what was the village's municipal building. **********In the shallow of a crater formed by a bomb that blew down the walls of the telephone company office, three pine wreaths and a red floral spray mark the graves of four soldiers. **********At the end of a paved road high in the mountains, about 130 miles northeast of San Salvador, this village and strategic military outpost was held for nine days in August by Farabundo Marti guerrillas. They fled when the Government sent in reinforcements and began bombing. **********But the guerrillas still control about a third of Morazan, the region where Perquin is located, according to a longtime resident who travels frequently in the mountainous countryside. Prepared for Another Attack **********Soldiers guarding this outpost said they were fired on nightly by the guerrillas, and were prepared for another attack.  This morning some woodcutters were stopped by guerrillas and asked about Perquin's military defenses, according to Rafael Antonio Orellano, a lieutenant in charge of the 20 National Guard soldiers here. Thirty army rangers are also defending the village, which is less than 10 miles from the Honduran border. **********Asked about the military situation, Lieut. Francisco Mata Portillo said the guerrillas were coming close to the village ''late at night and early in the morning.'' **********''They come, they fire on us, we fire back and they leave again,'' he said as he sat shirtless on a cot in his jungle camouflage trousers. Army Says It's in Control **********Government and military officials have insisted that the army has had complete control of this area since August. But they have repeatedly denied requests by foreign correspondents to visit Perquin, saying they could not guarantee the safety of the reporters. **********Today three reporters were permitted to travel here along the 25-mile road from San Francisco, the region's capital. But the authorization came only after the reporters signed a letter saying the Government would not be responsible if anything happened to them. They were then given a ''safe conduct pass'' by the military commander in San Francisco. **********The pass strictly limited the journalists to traveling between San Francisco and Perquin. They were not allowed into the surrounding mountains, where the guerrillas have reportedly set up village governments and are engaged in small-scale farming. A priest said he no longer visited these villages to perform his pastoral duties because he would be accused by the army of ''fomenting Communism.'' **********The road from San Francisco to Perquin is patrolled by small groups of soldiers. The authorities have yet to repair eight trenches, up to three feet deep, that the guerrillas dug across the road to impede military vehicles. Throughout the country, soldiers are burning and clearing wide swathes along the sides of roads. But the journey here has large stretches where dense tall weeds are sprawling onto the blacktop, heightening the danger of a guerrilla attack. At one point a notice neatly painted on the surface declares that travelers are entering a Farabundo Marti ''Liberated Zone.'' Hills Are Stripped of Trees **********The forested hills above and below Perquin, however, have been denuded by the army in an attempt to make it more difficult for the guerrillas to attack the town. **********In August about 300 rebels attacked this village, which was defended by 20 National Guardsmen as well as members of Orden, a rural civil defense force, according to Lieutenant Mata. In addition to killing four soldiers, he said, the guerrillas took some soldiers prisoner. He did not say how many. **********A religious leader in San Francisco said today that the guerrillas offered to release the prisoners to the International Red Cross. In addition, he said, the Red Cross offered to try to arrange a 12-hour cease-fire. The Government did not permit the Red Cross to get involved, according to the man, who asked not to be identified. **********Radio Venceremos, the guerrilla station that reportedly operates from somewhere in the mountains near here, said in August that the insurgents had left Perquin because they did not want civilians killed and the town destroyed by bombing. Leftist leaders said the takeover of Perquin was a success because it showed that the guerrillas were stronger than the Government contended. Rebels Take Villagers Hostage **********Perquin's residents said today that the guerrillas did not kill any civilians when they attacked. However, the residents said the guerrillas took 18 men and women from the village with them when they left. **********Sitting in a tiny general store, a woman whose husband was among those captured said all 18 escaped and returned to the village. An older woman, a towel wrapped around her head, said her son, forced by the guerrillas to build fortifications, escaped when the bombing began. **********As the journalists were preparing to leave today, a woman approached and asked softly if they were Red Cross workers here to distribute food. **********There is no electricity, drinkable water and bus service here. Only a few trucks and cars risk the journey to the village to bring in supplies for civilians. Lieutenant Mata said military helicopters were flying in supplies for the soldiers. **********Everyone who wants to come here must first receive a pass from the commander in San Francisco, said a 25-year-old teacher who lives in Perquin. **********Asked about the military situation, a 19-year-old soldier who has been in the army for 10 months and receives $72 a month, answered, ''It's a mess.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/busin.main_headline: UNC SAYS COLUSSY IS ITS CHOICE IF AIRLINE MARGER IS SUCCESSFUL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; UNC SAYS COLUSSY IS ITS CHOICE IF AIRLINE MARGER IS SUCCESSFUL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/busin.body_text: **********Dan A. Colussy, who resigned last November as president of Pan American World Airways with his future plans unsettled, has found himself in the midst of a complex merger struggle. **********The 49-year-old executive would take over the reins of Western Airlines if UNC Resources should win out over Continental Air Lines and acquire the Los Angeles-based carrier, according to an announcement by UNC, a holding company based in Falls Church, Va., which has extensive uranium and coal interests. **********Mr. Colussy said in an interview yesterday that a UNC-Western deal ''would be an ideal lash-up.'' He observed that UNC was considering moving some of its uranium assets into gas and oil, which, if it acquired Western, would help the airline by providing ''independent sources of fuel.'' He pointed out that other major carriers had been moving to purchase independent fuel sources to mitigate huge increases in fuel costs. **********Mr. Colussy also said that, while UNC's operations were not ''prey to the business cycle'' like those of airlines, they did not necessarily benefit from upswings. A merger with Western, he added, would allow participation in any such upswings. **********The UNC announcement said that there had still been no response from the carrier to the merger proposal. UNC made its approach to Western in December, thereby challenging a Western-Continental merger agreement that had been approved by the two carriers' boards of directors, but has not yet been approved by their stockholders. **********The UNC offer was to pay 50 percent more than the average market price of Western stock over the last six months. Under the WesternContinental agreement, each Western share would be swapped for one share of the combined company while each Continental share would be exchanged for 1.65 shares of the new concern. **********Mr. Colussy said that a UNC-Western agreement would require no Government approval, as would the Western-Continental merger. He estimated that the UNC acquisition could be consummated in as little as 60 to 90 days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/05/busin.body_text: **********The Boeing Company, the country's leading manufacturer of commercial jets, announced yesterday that its net income in the first three months of 1981 edged up 3.1 percent, to $144.1 million, or $1.49 a share, from $139.8 million, or $1.45 a share, in the first quarter of 1980. Sales increased 12.6 percent, to $2.42 billion, from $2.15 billion. **********Boeing attributed the earnings gain to an increase in sales volume and a lower Federal income tax rate. The company added, however, that operating margins declined somewhat and that interest income was significantly lower. **********T.A. Wilson, Boeing's chairman, said that recent economic conditions, increased competition and rising fuel prices that have adversely affected traffic growth and profitability in certain segments of the airline industry continued to result in reduced orders for Boeing's 727 and 747 airplanes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/22/world.body_text: **********The World Council of Churches today announced that 46 groups in 17 countries would receive a $587,000 grant to ''combat racism.'' The South-West Africa People's Organization, a guerrilla group that is fighting to end South African rule in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, got the largest sum. **********The Namibian group, which was the target of a South African raid into Angola last month, is to receive $125,000 for ''administrative and legal defense costs in Namibia and administrative costs in four countries which border Namibia,'' a council statement said. **********The Namibian guerrillas have waged a 15-year war against South Africa to gain independence for the mineral-rich territory, which has been administered by South Africa since World War I under a League of Nations mandate that was terminated by the United Nations in 1966. **********The rest of the grants included $65,000 to the African National Congress, a major black group in South Africa; $27,000 to TransAfrica, a Washington-based group that promotes a ''progressive U.S. policy towards the nations of Africa and the Caribbean;'' and $4,000 to an Irish anti-apartheid movement that is ''currently focusing its activities to stop the 1981 rugby tour'' of South Africa's Springboks team. Apartheid is South Africa's policy of strict racial segregation. **********In all, $4.7 million has been allotted since the council initiated the program in 1970. The Namibian rebels alone have drawn $698,500.  The World Council is an ecumenical body with about 300 Protestant, Orthodox and other denominations representing about 400 million Christians worldwide. **********The antiracism program has stirred controversy among the council's members. Last month, the Salvation Army, in a dispute about support for guerrilla movements in southern Africa, became the first council affiliate to renounce its membership.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/busin.print_headline: HOW A TAX COMPROMISE MIGHT LOOK; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/busin.body_text: **********In informal discussions over the past week, Congressional tax experts have been outlining a tax-relief bill that they say would satisfy the seemingly conflicting requirements of the Reagan Administration and the House Democratic leadership. **********The bill, sources say, would combine uniform across-the-board cuts in tax rates, which is the Administration's chief requirement, with two other types of tax relief that would let the Democrats assert they had produced a bill weighted toward low-and middle-income taxpayers. That requirement could be satisfied by a small increase in the standard deduction, plus a partial abatement of the ''marriage penalty'' imposed by joint filing on many working couples. **********''If a compromise is going to be reached, that is the most plausible way to do it,'' said Representative James R. Jones, Democrat of Oklahoma, an influential member of the Ways and Means Committee. **********Such a package was discussed in talks last week between House Democrats, including Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, and senior Administration officials, including Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. Further negotiations are expected this week, after Congress returns from the long Memorial Day weekend. **********Although the main elements of a compromise package seem to be defined, one important issue remains unresolved. President Reagan has not retreated from his original proposal of rate cuts of 10 percent a year in each of three years. Although Mr. Rostenkowski has declared he wants a one-year bill, many Democrats, including aides to Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., have said they could accept a two-year bill. **********Thus, a third year looms as the crucial difference between a decisive Reagan victory and a significant White House concession.  In the Senate, controlled by the Republicans, it is an open secret that Chairman Bob Dole of the finance committee has no desire for a three-year tax cut. This has led to speculation that Mr. Dole and Mr. Rostenkowski, each in his first year as chairman and eager to show that tax bills are written in Congress, not the White House, might forge an entente of their own in favor of a two-year bill. **********But, said one congressional veteran, ''I don't see how Dole could control the Senate floor without the Administration behind him.'' If the White House and Mr. Rostenkowski come to terms, the bill that the heavily Democratic Ways and Means Committee is to start drafting next week would be assured of easy sailing on the House floor. But if a ''grand alliance'' cannot be forged in the next few days, there could be a pitched battle with the Republicans seeking the support of Southern Democrats for a substitute for the Ways and Means bill. **********How to deliver tax relief to business is much less controversial this year than tax relief for individuals. There is broad support for giving business faster writeoffs for the cost of vehicles, machines and buildings, although some important details are still at issue.  Deductions for depreciation reduce taxable income and taxes owed. **********Small business just may get modest relief in the corporate tax rate. There is a slim chance, say Congressional aides, that Congress also will shrink the portion of capital gains subject to tax, now 40 percent. How much room there is for these secondary types of tax relief will depend on how much revenue is earmarked for general relief for individuals and couples. **********The Administration has proposed $44 billion of cuts for individuals and $10 billion for business for the 1982 fiscal year, which starts next Oct. 1. But with the economy stronger than expected, sentiment is growing in Congress -and within the Administration - to shrink the revenue loss and the budget deficit in fiscal 1982. **********One way would be to make the personal tax cut effective Jan. 1, 1982, as proposed by Representative Kent Hance of Texas, a junior Democrat on Ways and Means who also has proposed holding down the first round of relief to 5 percent instead of 10. **********Mr. Rostenkowski and Mr. Jones have said that to win Democratic support a tax bill must be weighted toward the broad middle class of taxpayers with incomes of $20,000 to $50,000. ''If I, as a Democrat, can be accused of income redistribution, it's to this group,'' Mr.  Rostenkowski has said. **********Because taxpayers in this income bracket account for one-third of all taxpayers and half of all income tax paid, the benefits of a larger standard deduction and an abatement of the ''marriage penalty'' would accrue heavily in this range. **********The standard deduction now is $2,300 for single taxpayers and $3,400 for couples. The ''modest liberalization'' Mr. Rostenkowski has mentioned would probably be $100 for individuals and $200 for couples. Such increases in the deduction would reduce total taxes owed by $1.6 billion. Of that sum, $710 million, or 44.5 percent, would accrue to taxpayers in the $20,000-$50,000 range. Another $266 million, or 16.7 percent, would go to taxpayers with incomes of $15,000 to $20,000. **********A frequently mentioned formula for relieving the ''marriage penalty'' -the difference between what a couple pays filing jointly and what they would pay if unmarried and filing separately - is to permit a deduction of 10 percent of the lower-earning partner's income up to a limit of $30,000. **********The tax saving from such a maximum deduction of $3,000 would be heavily weighted in the middle ranges, the analysts say. They calculate that 48.1 percent of the benefits would go to couples with combined incomes of $20,000 to $50,000 and 19.5 percent would fall into the $15,000 to $20,000 bracket. **********In addition, Congress is likely to liberalize the allowed deductions from taxable income for money deposited in individual retirement accounts. A popular proposal is to broaden elegibility for such accounts to employees of companies with pension plans.  Originally, the accounts were created only for employees of companies without pension plans. **********How much revenue would be lost in this way is uncertain because it depends on how much money taxpayers will stash away in these accounts. Nevertheless, the analysts believe that these tax savings also will fall heavily in the middle-income ranges.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/19/world.main_headline: AT THE WAILING WALL, A REMEMBRANCE AND A WARNING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/19/world.print_headline: AT THE WAILING WALL, A REMEMBRANCE AND A WARNING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/19/world.body_text: **********In a somber mood of warning for the future, 5,000 survivors of the ghettos and the concentration camps of Hitler's Europe ended four days of remembrance and reunion tonight at Jerusalem's Wailing Wall, the holiest place in Judaism, where they passed the legacy of the Holocaust symbolically to their children. **********Gathered beside the great stones that formed the western wall of the Temple Mount in Herod's time, the survivors heard and echoed admonitions to keep alive the memory of the horror that took six million Jews to their deaths. They lit thousands of candles and watched six torches, one for each million, flare in the night as a nearly-full moon rose above the place where the Romans burned the Second Temple in A.D. 70. **********It was a powerful conjunction of symbols and emotions, and Prime Minister Menachem Begin caught the tone as he declared to the assembled throng in Yiddish: ''Mir zaynen do. We are here.'' **********''Where is the Emperor? Where is his might? Where is Rome?'' asked Mr. Begin. ''Jerusalem lives forever. We are here.'' First Worldwide Gathering **********An apprehension that the Holocaust would be forgotten, or that its evil would be tempered by the passing of the generation that lived through it, was a central force in bringing survivors together for the first worldwide gathering since their liberation from the Germans in 1945. **********Furthermore, as conversations with many of them revealed, they are now moved to record their experiences, to speak out, both by the approach of their own deaths and a renewed sense of fear at what they see as rising anti-Semitism. The most infuriating symptom, many said, is the synthetic history now being published by a few American and French polemicists who are trying to prove that the Holocaust never happened. **********Abraham H. Foxman, associate national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said in an interview that until recently it had been difficult to get survivors to talk about their experiences, to spread the word. ''For 30 years they kept silent,'' he noted. ''Ten years ago we couldn't get anybody to talk.  Revisionism was a catalyst. That's touched them so personally. It's an indignity to all they went through.'' **********Samuel Pisar, a lawyer, author and survivor, explained his feelings in a conversation. ''To me the Holocaust is no longer a lamentation. To me it's a warning. It's a warning to Jews and non-Jews alike, from people like myself who have lived through the collapse of the world, and who know that worlds do collapse.'' 'The End of Creation' **********''When I look back today to Auschwitz,'' he continued, ''I have the personal feeling that I have witnessed the end of creation. In the shadow of flaming gas chambers I've seen the premonition of the death rattle of the species that was about to enter the thermonuclear age.  I feel that what I lived there was a pilot project of the destruction of humanity. You know that the unthinkable is indeed possible. And evil times are returning. When uneasiness and fear come back, then it is the season for demagogues.'' **********In a farewell address to the gathering, Elie Wiesel, the author, also struck a note of warning. ''Have we, survivors, done our duty?  Something went wrong with our testimony; it was not received.  Otherwise things would have been different. Look, look at the world around us: suspicion again, violence everywhere, hatred everywhere, organized state-sponsored terror, racism, fascism, fanatcisim, anti-Semitism. **********''Had anyone told us, when we were liberated, that we shall be compelled in our lifetime to fight anti-Semitism once more; or worse, that we shall have to prove that our suffering was genuine, that our victims had perished indeed -we would have had no strength to lift our eyes from the ruins. If only we could tell the tale. we thought, the world would change. Well, we have told the tale, and the world remained the same.'' **********The worry was crystallized by two schoolteachers at the gathering, one a survivor of Auschwitz named Edith Singer, born in Czechoslovakia, now teaching in California, and a daughter of concentration camp survivors named Arlene Goldfarb, from New York City. Schoolchildren Do Not Know **********Mrs. Singer had a jolt when an 8-year-old boy in her class noticed the number tatooed on her arm. ''What is this number?'' he asked.  ''Your phone number?'' She wanted to slap his face, then realized that he simply did not know. **********Miss Goldfarb told her class why she was coming to this gathering, and afterward a 13-year-old girl came to her and asked, ''What's a concentration camp?'' **********It was to help keep the memory alive that the legacy, signed by all those present, was transferred tonight. ''We, the survivors, are growing older,'' said Benjamin Meed, an Israeli and co-chairman of the gathering. ''We may never again gather together as we have this week. The burden of preserving the legacy of the Holocaust is now to be passed on to our children and the people of Israel.'' **********The legacy was then read by six survivors in six languages - Hebrew, Yiddish, English, French, Ladino and Russian.  ''We take this oath!'' it began. ''We take it in the shadow of flames whose tongues scar the soul of our people. We vow in the name of dead parents and children. We vow, with our sadness hidden, our faith renewed. We vow, we shall never let the sacred memory of our perished six million be scorned or erased.'' **********And it concluded: ''Let our legacy endure as a stone of the temple wall. For here prayers and memories burn. They burn and burn and will not be consumed.'' **********To which the children, now young adults, replied in part: ''We accept the obligation of this legacy. We are the first generation born after the darkness.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/31/world.main_headline: EGYPT REPORTS PLOT TO KILL AIDES AT SADAT'S FUNERAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/31/world.print_headline: EGYPT REPORTS PLOT TO KILL AIDES AT SADAT'S FUNERAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/31/world.body_text: **********Investigators interrogating suspects in the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat say that the plotters planned to kill senior Government officials at Mr. Sadat's funeral, according to today's issue of the semi-official newspaper Al Ahram. **********Mr. Sadat was slain as he watched a military parade on Oct. 6. His funeral was held four days later at the same site and was attended by Egypt's top officials and by leaders from more than 80 nations.  Security was intense, and the funeral rite, from which ordinary Egyptians were barred, appeared to go smoothly. **********Al Ahram said today that the plotters had planned a bomb attack against Egyptian officials at the funeral because of ''a rare opportunity of having their targets assembled all in one place.'' **********The newspaper said a number of loosely aligned Moslem fundamentalist groups bent on deposing Mr. Sadat and his secular regime had planned to install as temporary leader Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, a blind mufti, whom the investigators accused of having provided a religious rationale for killing Mr. Sadat. Sheik Rahman is under arrest. 587 Reported Arrested **********Al Ahram reported that 587 people had been arrested so far in the investigation into Mr. Sadat's death. President Hosni Mubarak said the other day that he expected a full report soon and that it would be made public. No date has been set for issuing the report, although another newspaper said it would be made available next week. **********Sheik Rahman is not well known here, according to Egyptian officials queried today. The report in Al Ahram carried a picture of a man it identified as ''the ideologue of the terrorists.'' It showed a man over 40 with a frizzy beard. **********Many of the officials the plotters reportedly planned to kill at the funeral were in the reviewing stand at the military parade when Mr. Sadat was killed. **********Al Ahram said: ''It was found out that they had decided to repeat the attempt, planning to kill all the officials who took part in the late President's funeral, considering this as a chance for them because of the presence of all these officials in one place.'' Extraordinary Measures Taken **********The extraordinary security at Mr. Sadat's funeral included plainclothes policemen, uniformed guards, military units, Egyptian Secret Service officials and dozens, perhaps hundreds, of foreign security men accompanying the world leaders who briefly attended the service. **********The foreign dignitaries, who included former Presidents Richard M.  Nixon, Gerald R. Ford and Jimmy Carter, marched in a procession on the parade grounds and briefly greeted Mr. Sadat's widow, Jihan, before speeding away in their limousines. The Sadat family, Mr.  Mubarak and other top officials then walked across the field to the site of the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, where Mr. Sadat was temporarily interred after a half-hour service. **********According to Al Ahram, Sheik Rahman has confessed to issuing a fatwa, or religious decree, giving permission to the fundamentalist conspirators to carry out the plot. The newspaper said the decree ordered those chosen to carry out the attempt ''not to try to commit suicide after the incident because then 'they would die as infidels.' '' Instead, the account said, they should try to escape, and if gunned down by soldiers they would be 'martyrs.' **********The newspaper said Sheik Rahman had been chosen to be an interim leader while the fundamentalists seized control and carried out a ''Khomeini-type revolution'' to replace the Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/15/world.main_headline: Around the World; France Plans Expansion Of Its Nuclear Forces
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/15/world.print_headline: Around the World; France Plans Expansion Of Its Nuclear Forces
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/15/world.body_text: **********Defense Minister Charles Hernu announced today in Parliament that France would develop a new tactical missile system and build a seventh nuclear submarine. The program will increase military spending by 17.8 percent. **********Mr. Hernu said France, which left the military structure of the Atlantic alliance in 1966, would modernize its nuclear strike force to present a credible deterrent to a potential enemy. **********The new systems, approved this week at a meeting of the National Defense Council headed by President Francois Mitterrand, include a land-based mobile missile called Hades, which will eventually replace the aging Mirage IV bomber in the strategic strike force. Hades, which is due in service in 1992, will replace the existing Pluto system when it becomes outmoded, Mr. Hernu said. **********The daily Le Monde quoted a Socialist legislator with defense responsibilities as having said that two Hades missiles would be mounted on a wheeled vehicle, giving greater mobility than the Pluto, which is carried on a tracked launcher.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/12/busin.main_headline: A RECORD GRAIN CROP IN '81 FORECAST BY U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/12/busin.print_headline: A RECORD GRAIN CROP IN '81 FORECAST BY U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/12/busin.body_text: **********The Agriculture Department today forecast a record 1981 grain crop that could mean lower prices for consumers but higher farm subsidy payments for the Reagan Administration, which is struggling to hold down spending. **********In its August report, the department's Crop Reporting Board forecast a record corn crop exceeding 7.94 billion bushels and repeated last month's predictions of a record 2.75-billion-bushel wheat crop and a huge soybean crop of more than 2 billion bushels. **********For consumers, such an abundance of grain could mean a reduction in farm costs for feed that should encourage increased hog and poultry production. This might result in lower retail pork and poultry prices by the end of the year, in the view of analysts, and prevent any substantial rise in beef prices next winter. **********Large Subsidy Foreseen **********But lower grain prices for farmers would increase the number of price support loans on their 1981 crops, raising the Government's expenditures for handling and storing wheat and corn taken later as payment for the loans. **********Average farm prices for wheat are already below the Government's target of $3.81. Unless they unexpectedly rise above that before Nov.1, direct subsidy payments to wheat farmers would cost $300 million to $500 million, which would come out of Mr. Reagan's budget for the fiscal year 1982. **********The forecast of record wheat and corn crops was likely to add to Mr. Reagan's difficulties in trying to get Congress to reduce the costly farm price support and subsidy levels that its agriculture committees have written into the omnibus farm bill. The Senate is scheduled to take up the measure next week. **********By late this afternoon the Administration had failed to reach a firm compromise on these loan and subsidy levels with most of the farm state Republicans, who form a majority on the Senate Agriculture Committee. **********Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the committee, said he would offer amendments to cut almost $1.3 billion from the cost of the Senate committee's legislation if the Administration would support them. **********Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, said he would also attempt to amend the committee bill, to give the Agriculture Secretary the authority to set loan and subsidy payments at any level he chose. Senator Lugar said the committee's bill in its current form would result in commodity support costs next year that would exceed the Congressional budget limits by at least $1.5 billion. Small Soviet Crop Forecast **********The only encouraging news for farmers and the Reagan Administration in today's production forecasts was a new estimate of Soviet grain production, which the department's Foreign Agriculture Service forecast at 180 million metric tons. This would be one of the smallest Soviet crops in the past nine years and the third year in a row in which Soviet wheat and feed grain harvests had fallen far below that country's goals. The department's previous Russian grain forecast was 185 million tons. **********In 1979, when their grain production fell to 179.2 million tons, the Russians ordered more than 25 million tons of American wheat, corn and soybeans. **********With the American wheat harvest completed and the corn and soybean harvests about to begin, today's forecasts were considered much more accurate than last month's. The prediction of a 7.94-billion-bushel corn crop was 3 percent hi gher t han las t month's estimate. A yield of this magnitude would be19 percent larg er than last year's drought-reduced crop and slightly greater than th e 1979 record of 7.93 billion bushels. **********Earlier this week Conrad Leslie, a leading private forecaster, predicted that total corn production would reach 8.04 billion bushels and the soybean 2.04 billion bushels. **********The Crop Reporting Board today estimated soybean production at 2.09 billion bushels, up 15 percent from the 1980 crop of 1.81 billion bushels and close to the 1979 record of 2.26 billion. **********A 1981 wheat crop of more than 2.75 billion bushels would be 16 percent larger than last year's record crop of 2.37 billion bushels.  There was also good news for fanciers of peanuts and peanut butter: The board estimated that total peanut production would reach 3.86 billion pounds, 67 percent more than the drought-reduced 1980 crop of 2.31 billion pounds. **********The board forecast this year's cotton crop at 15.5 million bales, 39 percent larger than 1980's 11.1 million bales.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/23/world.main_headline: ENVOY SAYS IRAN FAVORS ALGERIA AND P.L.O. AS MEDIATORS IN WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/23/world.print_headline: ENVOY SAYS IRAN FAVORS ALGERIA AND P.L.O. AS MEDIATORS IN WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/23/world.body_text: **********Iran's Ambassador to Kuwait said today that his country was ready to accept Algeria and the Palestine Liberation Organization as mediators of its war with Iraq. **********The statement by Ambassador Ali Shams Ardakani, made in interviews with newspapers in Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, aroused interest because Iran's hostage crisis with the United States has just been resolved through Algerian intermediaries. Moreover, Iran had previously refused to consider moves to end the war while Iraqi troops remained on its soil. **********But there was no direct statement from Teheran, the Iranian capital, or any immediate comment from Iraq.  (Officials in Algiers were reported to have said earlier this week that Algeria would be willing to mediate the war but that Iran had given no indication it was ready for such a step.) Arafat Has Offered Services **********Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has repeatedly offered his group's services to Iran. It was not clear from Ambassador Ardakani's remarks whether any formal arrangements were being made. Mr. Ardakani's statements appeared in the English-language newspaper Arab Times in Kuwait and the Arabiclanguage Al Khaleej in the United Arab Emirates. **********In Teheran, meanwhile, a Cabinet minister reiterated that Iran would not participate in a conference of leaders of 38 Islamic nations opening Sunday in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, where another proposal for cease-fire mediation might be discussed. Executive Affairs Minister Behzad Nabavi said the reason remained the expected presence there of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. **********Ambassador Ardakani said Algerian and P.L.O. mediation should be based on the border treaty that Iran and Iraq signed in Algiers in 1975. The accord set the two countries' southern border midstream in the 120-mile Shatt al Arab waterway. Iraq Abrogated Treaty **********Iraq, demanding full sovereignty over the entire estuary that forms its only sea outlet to the Persian Gulf, abrogated the treaty five days before it opened widescale hostilities on Sept. 22, 1980. Iraqi infantry and armor quickly overran most of Iran's bank of the Shatt el Arab, seizing about one-third of the oil-producing province of Khuzistan. They also occupied smaller pieces of territory along the border to the north. **********War communiques during the day indicated that there was only sporadic fighting along the 300-mile front from Khuzistan to the Gilan region in the north. Continued fighting was reported in Iran's Kurdish areas farther north, with Iran saying its forces had dealt severe blows to the Kurds, who are fighting for autonomy with Iraqi help.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/19/busin.print_headline: YOUR MONEY; BARGAIN LOANS FROM G.M.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/19/busin.body_text: **********ALL the big auto makers have resorted to ploys to increase sagging car sales, and among the most imaginative is the one taken by the General Motors Corporation. **********Through its financing subsidiary, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the company is offering a bargain loan rate to consumers who buy a new G.M. car, light-duty truck or van. But the offer is about to expire, and the rock-bottom rate of 13.8 percent will only be available to consumers who take delivery of the vehicle by the end of next Wednesday. **********The reason for the offer, which was first made on July 28 and then extended on Aug. 31, was to perk up sluggish sales and help clear out the large inventory of unsold cars before the bulk of the 1982 models reach dealer showrooms. The offer is only for the purchase of new 1981 vehicles and 1982 ''J'' cars such as the Chevy Cavalier or Cadillac Cimarron. **********''We felt that a lot of people were not buying cars because of high interest rates,'' said John Andrews, a G.M.A.C. spokesman. **********According to General Motors, the offer will save consumers an average of $550 on the financing cost of a typical G.M. car, compared with unsubsidized financing available from other lenders such as banks. **********This assumes that people borrow an average of $7,593 and would otherwise pay a rate of 17 percent on a car loan lasting about 45 months. But the $550 is a nationwide figure, and the projected sav ings vary depending on the loan term and t he interest rate that prevail in a given area. **********Mr. Andrews said the savings range from a low of $300 in Connecticut to a high of $800 in California. In New York, the benefit of the rate cut is $725 while in New Jersey it is only $650, he added. **********But the subsidized rate is not available everywhere. The offer is not being made in Arkansas, which has a 10 percent usury ceiling, Mr. Andrews said. Nor is it available from the 5 percent or so of G.M.  dealers who objected to sharing part of the cost of the promotion with the company. (The offer requires dealers to forgo 70 percent of their participation in the finance charge, which typically works out to about $150 over the life of the loan.) In general, the auto maker's financing offer of 13.8 percent is a hard one for other lenders to beat. It is for a maximum term of 48 months, and w hile a down payment is required, the amount is flexible,depending on the creditworthiness of the buyer. **********''I can't imagine any bank that can do it for less than that, because they don't have to worry about inventory,'' said Susan Weeks of Citibank. The bank, the largest in New York, is charging 18 percent to customers who have checking or savings accounts there, and 20 percent to people without such ties. **********According to the Federal Reserve Board, which collects information on loan rates charged by commercial banks, the average rate on a 36-month new-car loan from a bank in August was 16.92 percent. A spotcheck of banks around the country indicates that rates do not seem to have varied much since then, making the G.M.A.C. offer as attractive as ever. **********For example, the Bank of America, the nation's biggest bank, charges between 18 percent and 19 percent, depending on the length of the loan. The Continental Illinois Bank in Chicago also has a sliding rate that ranges from 15.85 percent to 15.95 percent. The Amalgamated Bank, traditionally one of the lowest-cost sources of financing in the New York area, is charging 15.15 percent for loans to purchase new American-made cars. **********Even credit unions are hard-pressed to match the G.M.A.C. offer.  The Credit Union National Association, a trade group that represents more than 90 percent of all credit unions, does not collect information on rates charged by members on a nationwide basis. But Howard Cosgrove, a spokesman for the association, said he believed that ''a few months ago, the majority of credit unions were charging about 15 percent and are probably a little higher than that now.'' **********While a few credit unions, such as the National Capitol Federal Credit Union in Washington and the Newsweek Employees Federal Credit Union in New York, are charging as little as 12 percent on some loans, he said, the Pan Am Employees Credit Union in New York, which is charging 16 percent, ''is more typical.'' **********By all accounts, the offering has been a huge success. Mr. Andrews said that in August, G.M.A.C. wrote 215,000 loan contracts (of which about 172,000 took advantage of the offer). This was ''the highest for any single month in General Motors' history,'' he said, and compares with only 92,000 contracts written in August 1980. **********''It's clearly a great success for them,'' said Harvey E.  Heinbach, a vice president and research analyst with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. He noted that G.M.'s market share went from 60.5 percent in July, before the promotion started, to 64 percent in August, ''and that's a big swing.'' **********Initially, he said, ''dealers were screaming, but when they saw how many people came in the showroom they were thrilled to death.'' Of course, G.M. is not alone in offering sweeteners to prospective buyers. Chrysler is offering direct rebates to customers, while Ford is offering dealer incentives that presumably are passed along to purchasers. **********Despite the difference in the form of the sales gimmicks, ''the amount that is being gained is probably not that different from company to company,'' Mr. Heinbach said. Customers should go where they happen to get the best deal on a car, he advised.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/21/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices moved higher on expanded trading volume yesterday after retreating in six of the seven previous sessions. Energy, technology, brokerage, airline and defense issues ranked among the leaders. The Dow Jones industrial average finished at 851.88, up 4.75 points. At 3 P.M., the indicator was ahead nearly 9 points. **********Reports that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet Oct. 29 in Geneva in an effort to unify the price of OPEC oil - reportedly at $34 a barrel - provided the main spark for yesterday's rally. **********The rationale, as explained by Thomas H. Mack, an investment strategist for Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins Inc., is that in return for a unified price Saudi Arabia would agree to cut its oil production. Such a move, he noted, would tend to erase the worldwide glut that has weakened oil prices this year. **********Energy stocks gaining 1 point or more included Mobil, Standard Oil (Indiana), the Sun Company, Superior Oil and Getty Oil. In the oilequipment field, Hughes Tool rose 2 1/8, to 36 1/8. **********Turnover climbed sharply to 51.5 million shares from Monday's 41.6 million. Advancing issues outpaced declines by nearly 2 to 1.  E.F. Hutton & Company, a recurring Wall Street favorite as a rumored takeover target, jumped 4 3/8 points, to 46, while its call options also saored. Merrill Lynch and Paine Webber each showed point-plus advances. **********Investors are placing increasing emphasis on corporate earnings.  Digital Equipment, reporting a strong advance in quarterly profits, rose 3 points, to 97 3/8. **********Penn Central climbed 3 1/8, to 44, after gaining 2 points Monday.  The company reported last week that its quarter profits more than doubled from levels in the period a year earlier. And yesterday there were unconfirmed rumors on Wall Street that Esmark was interested in acquiring Penn Central if Penn Central's own $1.4 billion bid for Colt Industries failed. **********In the transportation sector, both Delta Air Lines and Union Pacific climbed more than 1 point apiece. Union Pacific forecast that its profits for the year would match or exceed 1980's record figure. **********McDonnell Douglas, awarded a $2.7 billion contract to supply Australia with fighter planes, advanced 1 5/8, to 30 1/4. The best gainer on the active list was the Mitel Corporation, climbing 2 5/8, to 30. **********On the American Stock Exchange, Dunes Hotels and Casinos dropped 3 3/4, to 21 1/8. It rose 4 3/8 points Monday after the company said it had a suitor. **********In over-the-counter trading, the Lane Company gained 1/2, to 40 bid, its best price within the last 12 months. Last week, on the strength of improved earnings, the stock jumped 4 1/4 points. The Nasdaq composite index advanced 1.46, to 191.23.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/world.main_headline: SALAVADOR REBELS SEE OPENING TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/world.print_headline: SALAVADOR REBELS SEE OPENING TO U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/21/world.body_text: **********Two leaders of the Salvadoran guerrillas' political organization have had their first meeting with Administration officials here and said afterward that a channel of communication between the rebels and the Reagan State Department had finally been opened. **********''We were at little bit surprised that a meeting took place at all,'' Ruben Zamora, a member of the political and diplomatic commisssion of the Democratic Revolutionary Front, said in an interview. ''The meeting was cordial. They listened and we listened.'' **********Mr. Zamora and Francisco Altschul, also representing the political arm of the guerrillas' Farabundo Marti Liberation Front, said they had met with Everett E. Briggs, Deputy Assistant Secrefairs; Ralph L. Braibanti, the El Salvador desk officer, and Joseph G. Sullivan of the Inter-American policy planning staff. **********The State Department has declined to comment on the participants or the nature of the meeting, which was held last Tuesday, except to say that it had taken place. Criticism of Duarte Muted **********Mr. Zamora, who reiterated in the interview the guerrillas' objections to a United States-backed plan for elections in El Salvador, nevertheless refrained from harsh criticism of Jose Napoleon Duarte, the Salvadoran junta President. **********''In speaking of Duarte, we must make the distinction between administration and rule,'' Mr. Zamora said. ''He is trying to administer a country ruled by the military.'' **********''He wanted to investigate Playon,'' Mr. Zamora said, referring to the discovery of an undetermined number of bodies on a lava field dump 15 miles from San Salvador. ''There was a meeting, and Garcia said to him quite clearly: this is a military matter. And that ly: this is a military matter. And that was the end of it.'' Col. Jose Guillermo Garcia, a member of the junta, is also El Salvador's Defense Minister. **********In testimony to the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on hemispheric affairs last Monday, Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of States for Inter-American Affairs, said that Mr. Zamora and Mr. Altschul, who live in Mexico, had come to discuss the Salvadoran election process. Mr. Zamora said that the talks had not been limited to that topic. Campaign 'Would Be Suicide' **********''We had proposed an open agenda,'' he said. ''If the State Department wanted to talk to us about elections that was fine,'' he said, '' but we made it clear we wouldn't have the meeting limited to that. The guerrilla organizations have said they will not take part in voting for a constituent assembly, planned for next March 28. **********''We cannot ask people to go into the streets and make campaigns,'' Mr. Zamora said. ''It would be suicide.'' ''We told them that we don't see how the March election will be anything near a free election,'' Mr. Zamora, a former Christian Democrat, said. ''We tried to explain to them why a comprehensive political solution was necessary. **********''In El Salvador there is a war. A lot of people are being killed.  If we want to achieve peace we have to address the problems that have caused this. We need a full rethinking of Salvadoran society.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/03/world.main_headline: U.S. ASSERTS SAUDIS NEED 'ASSISTANCE' ON AWACS INTO 90'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/03/world.print_headline: U.S. ASSERTS SAUDIS NEED 'ASSISTANCE' ON AWACS INTO 90'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/03/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met in New York today with Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, and a State Department spokesman said later that United States ''assistance'' would be necessary well into the 1990's for what was called ''the support'' of five Saudi Awacs aircraft. **********The statement was worded differently from one made by Mr. Haig yesterday in testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Haig told the committee that because of what he called a shortage of Saudi air crews and technicians, ''there will be an American presence in the aircraft and on the ground well into the 1990's.'' **********Department of Defense estimates of the time necessary to train crews for Airborne Warning and Control System aircraft are much less than the more than 10 years suggested by Mr.  Haig's testimony yesterday. Training Time Varies **********A published United States Air Force statement said that about 300 NATO airmen who began training in July at Tinker Air Force Base in Oklahoma to operate NATO Awacs were in programs that ''vary from 3 to 55 weeks, with an average time of about 4 months.'' **********Pentagon sources said that even with personnel from a nation such as Saudi Arabia ''it would take about two to three years'' to train senior noncommissioned officers who could operate and give in-flight servicing to the Awacs radar and on-board computer. These sources said it would not take that long to train the commissioned officers who act as ''controllers'' and man the surveillance and weaponscontrol consoles on an Awacs. **********The State Department press office said this afternoon that it was not able now to furnish any comment that might reconcile the very extended training periods suggested by Mr. Haig's testimony with those statements. A U.S. Training Presence **********Senate staff members opposed to the $8.5 billion sale of Awacs and other air combat equipment to the Saudis expressed a belief that the Administration statements about some American training presence on Saudi Awacs into the 1990's were meant to be a substitute for more formal joint United States-Saudi crews or joint command of the Awacs suggested by some members of Congress who are now leaning against the sale. **********Congress can block the sale if both houses vote to do so before the end of this month. Majorities in both houses appear to be leaning against the sale, even after President Reagan and Mr. Haig strongly urged yesterday that it be approved. **********A spokesman for Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, who is a leader of the group opposing the sale, said that all 50 senators who had agreed to co-sponsor a resolution of disapproval last month agreed to permit their names to remain on the resolution after President Reagan's news conference and Mr. Haig's testimony yesterday. **********Dean Fischer, the State Department spokesman, said after Mr.  Haig's meeting today with the Saudi Foreign Minister, ''The kingdom has requested maintenance and training assis tance, and the U.S. is willing to pr ovide such assistance, which will be necessary for the support of th e system well into the 1990's.'' Today's statement did not mention a n ''American presence'' on the Saudi aircraft in the 1990's. **********The Administration has always said that 400 to 480 United States civilian contractor experts would be necessary to service and maintain the Saudi Awacs when they begin to arrive in Saudi Arabia in 1985 and that, while the number would decrease considerably over the years, some such maintenance contractors would be necessary into the next century. But last April, and again in August, Administration officials said that the first two Saudi Awacs crews would be trained by the time the planes arrived in 1985 and that an American presence on the Awacs would ''fade away'' within a few years. Meeting Called Unsuccessful **********The original plan called for Saudi personnel to begin training for Awacs duties in the United States soon after the proposal cleared Congress and for substantial portions of the training to be completed before the Awacs were delivered. **********A number of people who were present at a two-and-a-half-hour closed meeting of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee yesterday in which Mr. Haig and other State Department officials tried to persuade members of the committee to support the arms sale said the meeting had not been successful or especially amicable. **********Some opponents of the sale, who appear to be a majority on the committee as of now, said they had been unable to determine whether or not any agreement to insure joint American control of the Awacs while in flight had been reached in a week of negotiations with the Saudi Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/04/busin.body_text: **********Stock market prices plunged again yesterday, apparently because of renewed concern over high interest rates.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which had managed slight gains on Tuesday and Wednesday, fell 17.22 points yesterday, to 867.01, its lowest level in almost 15 months. **********''The market apparently abandoned any hope for near-term relief from high interest rates because of Wall Street's expectations that the Federal Reserve will report a large rise'' in the basic money supply, said Thomas R. Brown, director of research at Butcher & Singer Inc., a brokerage house. **********The weekly Fed report, due to be released after the stock markets close today, is expected to show an increase of $1 billion to $2 billion in the basic money supply, Mr. Brown said. Such an increase would indicate that the Fed will not relax its current tight-money policy, which has resulted in high interest rates. **********Dow Lowest Since June 10, 1980 **********The Dow average of 30 major industrial companies was at its lowest point yesterday since June 10, 1980, when it finished at 863.99. In the nearly two weeks since Aug. 24, the blue-chip barometer has tumbled 53.56 points, mainly because of investors' apprehension over interest rates and a growing recognition that the Reagan Admini stration will not be able to balance th e budget by 1984, as thePresident had pledged. The decline included a 20.46-point drop on Aug. 24. **********Some of the market's weakness was also attributed by some analysts to concern over the growing budget deficit and to the sharp drop in long-term Government bond prices yesterday, a drop that pushed up yields. **********High interest rates and rising yields for fixed-income securities discourage investors from equities and attract funds to competing forms of investments, such as money market funds, which offer higher returns and less risk. Moreover, high interest rates increase business costs and reduce corporate profits, which also discourage stock purchasing. **********Alan C. Poole, vice president of Laidlaw, Adams & Peck Inc., said that investors apparently did not believe that the Reagan economic program was going to work and that as a result, ''This nation will have either severe inflation or a serious recession.'' **********Jack Baker, vice president for equities trading at the First Boston Corporation, said, ''When bond prices cracked yesterday afternoon, equities quickly followed.'' At 2 P.M., the Dow average was off only 5.52 points. **********The sell-off was broadly based, with declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering advances by more than a 4-to-1 ratio.  The worst performers were the blue-chip, transportation and energyrelated stocks. **********Turnover on the exchange rose to 41.7 million shares from 37.6 million shares on Wednesday.  Among the hard-hit blue-chip stocks yesterday, Allied Corporation lost 2 1/2, to 45 1/8; American Can 1 1/2, to 32 3/8; Merck 1 3/4, to 81 1/4; Owens-Illinois 1 1/8, to 27 3/8; Union Carbide 1 1/8, to 49 3/4; United Technologies 1 1/8, to 43 3/4, and International Business Machines, the volume leader, 1 1/8, to 54 5/8. Cities Service Down 3 7/8 **********The drop in energy-related issues reflected investors' belief that the current oil glut would continue and that oil company profits would drop. Among the bigger losers in this group, Cities Service, a reported takeover candidate, dropped 3 7/8, to 47 5/8; Superior Oil 2 1/2, to 34 3/4; Atlantic Richfield 2 1/8, to 45 3/4; Murphy Oil 2 1/4, to 31 3/4; Halliburton 2 1/8, to 58 1/8, and Standard Oil (Indiana) 1 7 /8, to 56 1/8. **********Reflecting the weakness in the transportation issues, the Dow Jones transportation average tumbled 9.90, to 363.11. In this group, Delta Air Lines fell 3 1/8, to 55 3/8; Burlington Northern 2, to 45 7/8; Canadian Pacific 1 1/8, to 39, and Southern Pacific 1 3/4, to 43 3/4. **********Itek was off 2 1/2, to 20 3/8, in active trading. On Wednesday, the issue fell 2 1/8 after the company said its profits from continuing operations for the third quarter would trail those of a year ago. **********Athough Litton Industries reported higher profits for the quarter ended July 31 and voted a 2 percent stock dividend, its stock lost 1 1/2, to 60 7/8. **********Another decline was in Reading & Bates, which slipped 3/4, to 35 5/8. The company yesterday declared a 3-for-2 stock split and raised its dividend. Gold Stocks Gain **********Higher bullion prices abroad moved the gold issues ahead for the second consecutive session. Homestake Mining gained 1 3/8, to 55 7/8; ASA 7/8, to 52 1/8, and Campbell Red Lake 7/8, to 18 1/8. **********Stock prices on the American Stock Exchange also dropped sharply, with the market-value index off 14, to 339.29, its lowest closing price since March 12, when it ended at 336.39. **********The biggest casualties on the Amex were energy issues, most of which were heavily traded. Among the losers were Delhi International Oil, which slumped 6 1/8, to 57 7/8; Gulf Canada 2 1/8, to 21 1/2; Imperial Oil Class A 1 7/8, to 28, and Petro-Lewis 1, to 17 1/2. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 3.40, to 191.99, its closing low for the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/13/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: What was not evident from y our article, ''Moribund Bonds'' (Aug.  30), is the t remendous cost to business. **********Industry capital improvements are postponed or abandoned. Industry clearly loses when highways dete riorate and bridges are closed to traffic. Similarly, private inves tment is deterred when water sewer system expansion cannot be fin anced. **********If the burden of these capital improvements is shifted to the private sector, due to state and local governments' inability to borrow, the interest costs will be higher and inefficiencies greater. Business leaders, and investors need to recognize how a ''moribund'' bond market in the public sector hurts them.  MARY JOHN MILLER Washington, D.C.  Sept. 4, 1981

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/07/busin.main_headline: ALLEGHENY'S ANGEL IS A HOMETOWN BOY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/07/busin.print_headline: ALLEGHENY'S ANGEL IS A HOMETOWN BOY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/07/busin.body_text: **********George W. Tippins, president and owner of the Tippins Machinery Company, and Richard P. Simmons, president of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, waited with suspense in the law offices of Buchanan, Ingersoll, Rodewald, Kyle & Buerger on the 57th floor of the United States Steel Building in downtown Pittsburgh. Flanked by a group of lawyers, both men were eager to close a deal for Mr. Tippins to buy Allegheny, the nation's largest stainless steel producer, from its parent, Allegheny Ludlum Industries. **********There was one hitch. Mr. Simmons, whose job it was to find a buyer, had earlier gone far afield and arranged a similar deal with a company headed by Clint W. Murchison Jr., the Texas financier. Now Mr. Simmons no longer wanted the Murchison deal. With much the same terms, he had lined up what he thought was a much better prospect: Mr. Tippins, who had made a fortune in the Pittsburgh area as a builder of steel rolling mills. **********The men were waiting to see whether Mr. Murchison would show up and lay claim to the company. To the relief of both, he didn't, and Mr.  Tippins drew a certified check out of his pocket toward purchase of 80 percent of the equity in the company. Mr. Simmons and some of his executive team picked up the remaining 20 percent. The total price was $195 million, of which $60 million was in cash and the rest in a note and preferred stock. **********Thus, the hometown boys combined to keep the outsiders from the business. As both saw it, the investor should not be tempted to milk the company to finance his interests elsewhere and the manager should have a free hand to continue to run the day-to-day business. ''To interfere with Simmons -that's the last thing I want,'' Mr. Tippins said. **********The closing was on Dec. 26. It may be too early to tell how the deal is working out, but to a large degree success depends on the willingness of both men to stay within their roles. The company, as a privately owned entity, is able to keep its profits and problems to itself. But there is every reason to believe that it is extremely well-positioned in the stainless steel industry and ready to benefit from the hometown synergism. **********Mr. Simmons has a good grasp of the business and has moved aggressively to phase out older equipment, said Charles A. Bradford, the steel analyst for Merrill Lynch. But he cautioned that a large share of flat rolled stainless steel is used by the auto industry to make catalytic converters. The auto makers, he said, are seeking cheaper and lighter alloys, and this could pose a problem for Allegheny Ludlum in the future. But another major Allegheny product, steel used in motors and generators, is a ''super business,'' Mr.  Bradford said, since this equipment is being upgraded or replaced in the drive for energy efficiency. **********B ECOMING a private company provides some advantages for running a capital-intensive business such as steel, Mr. Simmons said. One doesn't have to worry about satisfying the hunger of stockholders for dividends and the earnings performance demanded by Wall Street analysts. Also, he added, there is the worry that when one has built up a good business another company comes along and ''gobbles it up.'' **********Mr. Simmons, a man who pursues his goals tenaciously, according to former Allegheny executives, wants to spend $100 million in the next four years upgrading the equipment at the steel plants, expanding capacity and perhaps adding some specialty steels to the wide line that the company now makes. Mr. Simmons, who is 50 years old, has spent his career at Allegheny Ludlum except for stints at Republic Steel and Latrobe. He reports to Mr. Tippins by phone every week. **********The company was profitable under Allegheny Ludlum Industries, although its return on equity averaged about 7 percent, which was only half the return for the parent as a whole. But the company was not neglected by its parent, which spent $100 million in the last four years installing new melting capacity and a new continuous caster at plants in Natrona and Brackenridge, Pa. **********Allegheny Ludlum Industries (which has since changed its name to Allegheny International), said that it wanted to sell the company to avoid steel's vast capital needs and to cut loose from the industry's ride on the ups and downs of the business cycle. It also wanted cash for its diversification program - to help it acquire the 55.5 percent of the stock of Wilkinson Match that it didn't already own. **********For Mr. Tippins, 55, a man whose square-jawed face is framed by steel-rim glasses, the Allegheny deal represented the end of a long search to acquire a company. ''We came out of the woodwork and we had the money,'' he said in a recent interview at the Waldorf Astoria, where he was attending the annual get-together of the American Iron and Steel Institute. **********The new owner is no longer in the backwater of the Pittsburgh business world. The reputation of his Tippins Machinery Company, although it had built mills around the world, was confined mainly to steelmakers. It has its offices in a three-story red-brick former theater on the main street of Etna, six miles north of downtown Pittsburgh. **********Although obscure, it has been profitable. Mr. Tippins's search to buy a business was motivated by a desire to diversify his holdings and to get some major tax savings for his accumulated capital. Before finding Allegheny, he had hired a Wall Street business broker for $18,000 a year in an unsuccessful search for a company. ''I was shown a shoe business, a lumber business, a manufacturing business,'' he said. ''I can't relate to them.'' **********Thus when he heard that the Allegheny deal with the Murchison interests might fall through, he was interested. Mr. Simmons asked Mr. Tippins a few days before Christmas whether he would come to the closing ready to buy. He said yes. **********''It's a business I know something about,'' he said. ''Its a lot better to do this than to buy some lending company or a trucking company. My life has been set in this direction.'' **********Tippins Machinery was founded by his father, L.H. Tippins, in 1923. It remained largely a small family business confined to reconditioning used mining machinery. After the son graduated from Yale in 1946 with a degree in electrical engineering he shifted the business into reconditioning rolling equipment for smaller steel mills. He has since built his company from one of about five employees and annual sales of $2 million in the 1950's to one that employs 200 with sales expected to be about $70 million this year. It has built mills in South Africa, West Germany, Britain, Italy, Mexico, Canada and the United States. **********Now Mr. Tippins is busy getting ready for a major expansion. He is going after orders to renovate the large rolling mills for major steel producers. To rebuild these mills would cost about $300 million each, he estimated. His company is offering to bring the mills up to date under a patented process for about a fourth of that cost.  Several major steel makers have expressed interest, he said. **********Mr. Tippins's investment in Allegheny has at times put him in a difficult position with other steel companies, who now see him also as a potential competitor as well as builder of mills. **********He has had to tread carefully to show that his interest in Allegheny is one of investment only.  ''My wealth has been made in the steel industry,'' he said. ''I feel an obligation to put it back. This is a long-term investment.  This is not to come in and rob and steal and then walk away from it.'' **********It is also not to look over Mr. Simmons's shoulder at Allegheny.  ''I won't tell him how to run his business,'' he said, ''and he can't tell me how to build a rolling mill.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/15/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration's stringent monetarist strategy aimed at curbing inflation in the United States is causing serious difficulties for other countries and could lead to a breakdown of economic cooperation that would spell disaster, the Bank for International Settlements warns in its latest annual report. **********The annual statement by the bank, which is owned by the world's central banks, traditionally sets out in forthright language the bankers' views on the major economic problems of the day. The report was issued today in conjunction with the meeting of central bankers this week. **********The message this year is that the United States and other countries are relying too heavily on monetary policy in their fight against inflation. **********Ripple Effect of High Rates **********America's high interest rates are forcing other countries to defend their currencies by raising their own rates to damagingly high levels at a time of recession, the bank says. Such defense is needed because the high returns available on dollar holdings draw funds from other currencies. **********Business investment is suffering as a result, and with it, the West's chances of reducing unemployment through industrial development. Meanwhile, the developing world's economies are being crushed by the soaring cost of servicing its debt and by slack demand for its exports in the depressed economies of the West. **********The bank would like the United States and other industrial countries to take some of the upward pressure off interest rates by doing more to fight inflation by fiscal means: cutting budget deficits, loosening economic bottlenecks and persuading trade unions to limit wage demands by subscribing to voluntary incomes policies. Dangers of a Backlash **********The report conveys concern that because inflation has become ''a way of life'' in today's world, it will take a monetary squeeze of intolerable severity to halt inflation. Such a squeeze, in the bank's view, risks setting off a political backlash not just against tightmoney policies but against the Western world's commitment to making inflation-fighting its top economic priority. **********If the worldwide monetary squeeze continues, the bank fears a breakdown in international economic cooperation, as European countries rebel against the prolonged recession that the Reagan Administration's tight-money policy is seen as imposing on them. **********The bank pointedly recalls that habits of economic cooperation built up since World War II represent ''the most effective bulwark against a repetition of the kind of events witnessed in the 1930's, which ultimately resulted in the disintegration of the world economy.'' **********The report concludes ominously. ''The warning signs are written clearly on the wall,'' it says. ''The Western world is already paying a high price for having tolerated too high an inflation rate for too long. If, in the present decisive phase, confidence in the effectiveness of international cooperation were to be shaken, the price would be greater still.'' Reflects a Broad View **********Although the bank insists that Washington is not the only culprit, its thinly veiled attack on the Reagan Administration's monetarist approach to inflation-fighting echoes the increasingly strident complaints now coming from virtually all other Western countries except Britain. **********In recent weeks, European governments have told the United States that soaring American interest rates are spreading stagflation around the world, killing off hopes of an economic recovery in the West this year and raising the cost of oil and other imported raw materials that must be paid for in increasingly expensive dollars. **********Europe and the Bank for International Settlements want the United States instead to reduce inflation by cutting its budget deficit, stimulating competition and restraining pay claims, thus making room for a coordinated reduction in world interest rates that would revive the world economy. Demands Due at O.E.C.D. Meeting **********These demands will certainly be repeated by foreign and finance ministers at Tuesday's annual ministerial meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. But so far, the Reagan Administration has turned a deaf ear to such pleas, saying that world interest rates would come down as soon as American inflation subsided and not before. **********But some Western officials already fear that the O.E.C.D. meeting will provide the first signs of the kind of revolt against the West's inflation-fighting commitment that the bank fears. France's new Socialist Government, for example, has already started to stimulate the economy mildly, and several smaller European countries are starting to say that unemployment is a more serious problem than inflation. **********Besides being unduly deflationary, the bank says, a purely monetary assault on inflation is increasingly difficult to carry out, a point made frequently by Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. **********Bankers continually thwart efforts to control the growth of the money supply by devising new forms of credit. In the view of the bank, the Federal Reserve's new policy of concentrating on control of the monetary base has led to wild swings in interest rates and exchange rates without making the growth of the monetary aggregates noticeably more stable. **********While acknowledging that a restrictive monetary policy is essential if inflation is to be beaten, the bank wants it to be supplemented first and foremost by a general drive to reduce government deficits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/20/busin.main_headline: Forum; GETTING THE COAL ON THE ROAD
