https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/20/busin.body_text: **********I F the dredging of channels in a few United States ports is not begun in the next several years, American efforts to beat stagflation will be significantly hampered.  To say that this connection is not widely appreciated would be a vast understatement. But the connection is there, and unless we take account of it, we will suffer. **********The 1970's showed that sharply rising oil prices meant more inflation and less economic growth in the industrial countries. Oil prices are no longer rising steeply, in part because these countries have reacted to higher prices by reducing their oil consumption and increasing their use of alternative energy sources. **********The most important of these alternatives is coal. When the leaders of the seven main industrial countries met at the 1980 economic summit conference in Venice, they pledged their countries to double coal trade in the coming decade. Whether this pledge is fulfilled will do much to determine whether the present relative stability of oil prices continues, or fades away as the current recession wanes and unforeseen interruptions in oil supply occur. **********The obstacle to doubling coal trade is not lack of supply in the main exporting countries: The United States, Australia, Poland, and South Africa have sufficient reserves to increase enormously their production of coal for sale abroad. **********Nor is the obstacle any lag in demand: Conversion of oil-burning facilities to coal and creation of new coal burning facilities is proceeding so rapidly in Western Europe and Japan that demand for coal imports by these regions is expected to increase fourfold from 1979 to 1990. Despite present softness of the coal spot market in Europe, a very substantial long-term increase in demand remains likely. THE obstacl e to increased coal trade lies in artificial restraints in the coal e xporting nations: Unstable conditions in Poland, which have reduced its coal output; fear of interracial strife in the future and an equivocal government policy in the past, which have made importer s reluctant to rely unduly on South Africa; periodic labor difficu lties in Australia, reflected in last year's strike, andinadequate po rt facilities in the United States, which have provoked bitter compla ints from our trading partners. The problems in Poland, South Africa, and A ustralia are not susceptible to rapid resolution. So the Unite d States will remain a key residual supplier - the more so since mos t coal importers are anxious to diversify their sources of supply in order to reduce theirvulnerability to untoward events in other cou ntries. The United States role is so large as to make it unlikel y that world coal trade will be doubled unless restraints on that rol e created by inadequate ports are overcome. **********There is a good deal of misunderstanding about these restraints.  Three separate problems need to be distinguished from each other: *********** There are the short-term problems of adjustment that caused large numbers of European ships to wait long periods to load coal at United States East Coast ports last spring. These problems have been eased not only by the end of the Australian strike but also by innovative procedures that have made it possible to schedule waiting ships at our East Coast ports more efficiently and by increased coal exports from our Gulf Coast ports. *********** There is the medium-term problem of structural change: United States coal loading and storage port facilities were designed for lesser amounts than must now be moved, and were designed primarily for metallurgical coal, rather than the steam coal that is now in growing demand abroad. So these facilities must be expanded and modernized. The private companies that own the piers and the relevant port authorities are taking effective steps to these ends. *********** There is the longer-term problem of channel depths. Even if the improvements in coal loading and storage facilities described above are achieved, United States coal ports will remain inadequate, because European and Japanese coal importers want to shift some of their coal commerce from the present Panamax 60,000-ton ships to larger ships (100,000 tons and over), which can transport coal more economically. Present water depths in most world coal ports are too shallow to take these ships. Steps are being taken to remedy this condition in some European, Australian, and South African ports, but not in the United States. **********This United States lag is due to a legislative problem: The Administration has concluded that dredging should not and cannot, in present budgetary circumstances, be financed by the Federal Government. This means that a bill will have to be passed by the Congress defining how this function is to be transferred to the states and local authorities. And it has proved damnably difficult to get Congressional agreement on such a bill. Many coastal states are involved, and their immediate interests and financial capabilities differ. **********Until it is clear that a few United States coal ports will be dredged, some European and Japanese coal importers will be reluctant to sign long-term contracts to buy greatly increased amounts of American coal. In the absence of such contracts, some American companies will be reluctant to make the long-term investments needed to fulfill United States coal export potential. This will not only limit world coal trade but also hurt those Americans who make their living producing and transporting coal. **********The Administration is cutting red tape on dredging. Legislative action in the next 12 months is also needed, and is feasible. But this will require that two things occur: *********** That the Administration take the lead in seeking legislative consensus. *********** That public demand for port dredging be felt, making it easier for the members of Congress principally concerned to compromise.  Failing this, the great United States export coal boom that people talk about for the 1980's will turn out like the great United States domestic coal boom that people used to talk about for the 1970's - a dazzling vision that is only partially reflected in expanded sales of the hard black stuff that substitutes for oil. **********Without a United States coal export boom, the link between oil consumption and economic growth in the industrial world will not be broken - a link that condemns us to recurring inflation and low growth, whenever the balance between oil demand and supply tilts, as it may periodically, against the oil importing nations. **********There is an excellent chance of solving our coal port problem. But only if a lot more public attention is paid to it than is now the case.   ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Henry Owen, w ho was in charge of the White House coordination for President Car ter at the London, Bonn, Tokyo and Venice economic summit meetin gs, is with the Consultants International Group in Washington.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/03/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON THE Patent and Trademark Office has arranged for the transmission to its 37 depository libraries of information that should be advantageous to independent inventors. A contract was awarded this week to the ABA Corporation, Arlington, Va., to conduct a classification and search support information system. **********Users of the patent collections in 25 states will have direct access to computerized data. The 4.3 million United States patents are classified into more than 100,000 subclasses. The libraries can use computer terminals to learn the classification of any American patent. **********The service will begin early in 1982. The contract, which was awarded under the Small Business Act, provides for a $350,000 fee for the first year. The ABA Corporation, of which Donna M. Choma is president, designs computer-based information systems and office automation. **********Independent inventors do not have access to the staff patent attorneys and information files maintained by corporations. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/08/busin.body_text: **********The Canadian Government, which helped organize a worldwide uranium cartel in 1972, filed criminal charges against six Canadian companies today for allegedly restraining competition and trade in uranium within Canada. **********The Ministry of Justice made the charges in a Toronto court five weeks after receiving a secret report from the Ministry of Consumer and Corporate Affairs that found grounds for prosecution. Opposition parties, convinced that the Government itself had operated outside the law, have been demanding that the report be made public. Minister of Justice Jean Chretien had refused to disclose the findings before charges were filed and, presumably, the report will now be released. **********Government Concerns Cited **********Among the indicted companies are two Government-owned concerns, Eldorado Nuclear and Uranium Canada of Ottawa. The latter concern was formed in 1971 as an agent of the Government to purchase, stockpile and sell uranium. The other companies are Gulf Minerals Canada of Toronto, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Corporation, Denison Mines of Toronto, Rio Algom of Toronto, owned mostly by the Rio Tinto-Zinc Corporation of London, and Uranerz Exploration and Mining Ltd. of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, a wholly owned subsidiary of Uranerzbergbau of West Germany. **********The Government accused the companies of unlawfully conspiring to act with 21 persons and companies in Canada and abroad between 1970 and 1978 ''to prevent or lessen unduly competition in production, manufacture, purchase, sale and supply in Canada'' of uranium, uranium oxide and other uranium substances. **********Among the persons named but not indicted as conspirators were J.C.  Runnalls, former senior adviser on uranium and nuclear energy in the Ministry of Energy, Mines and Resources, who is now retired from Government service, and Gordon MacNabb, another high permanent official in the same ministry with the title of assistant deputy minister. Formation of Cartel **********The international uranium cartel was formed by Canada, Australia, France, South Africa and Rio Tinto after a ban by the United States on uranium imports in the late 1960's led to a sharp drop in uranium prices. The operations of the cartel led to Congressional investigations in the United States as well as suits by the United States Government and several electric power companies for price fixing. The unindicted conspirators include companies and individuals in the other countries which participated in the cartel. **********In testimony before a House committee in 1976. Gulf Oil asserted that it had been obliged to participate in the cartel if its subsidiary was to continue mining operations in Canada. There was also testimony to the effect that Gulf would be immune from indictment in Canada. In the United States, Gulf was charged with a misdemeanor after pressure from Canada led the Department of Justice to drop a felony charge. **********The Canadian Government appeared to be making a distinction between participation in the cartel's operations to control production and sales of uranium on international markets, and the operations and effects of the cartel on the domestic market. Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has declared that production control and sale on international markets were wholly within the Government's powers. **********One large Canadian company affected by a rise in uranium prices has been Hydro-Ontario, the provincially owned utility that buys large quantities of uranium for its nuclear power stations. Presumably, the federal charges for restraint of trade within Canada now open the door for a civil suit by Hydro-Ontario.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/busin.main_headline: BIG BROKERS BORROWING AT BELOW NORMAL RATES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/busin.print_headline: BIG BROKERS BORROWING AT BELOW NORMAL RATES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/busin.body_text: **********Several leading New York banks have quietly been lending at preferred rates to about a dozen securities firms to finance the margin accounts of their customers, according to commercial and investment bankers. **********The very concept of the so-called broker-loan rate is being challenged as a result of the changes in the pricing structure, bankers say. The move is also giving larger securities firms a further advantage over their smaller competitors, which are not eligible for the cut-rate loans. **********The interest rates that brokerage houses charge their customers to finance the purchase of securities on credit are tied to the brokerloan rate. Under the rules of the New York Stock Exchange, for example, brokerage firms are required to charge their customers at least one-half percentage point more than the broker-loan rate on their margin accounts. **********As a result of the new pricing procedures, the larger brokerage firms have been able to obtain broker loans from banks at discounts greater than a full percentage point below the posted rate. Morgan Largest Lender **********''It's questionable whether we'll continue to have anything that can be called a 'broker-loan' rate,'' says Earle N. Cutler 3d, vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the single biggest bank lender to securities firms. **********''We do get money from banks below the broker-loan rate from time to time,'' Joseph P. Matorella, a money manager at Kidder, Peabody & Company, said. **********He added that Kidder, Peabody was not a big borrower of broker loans but that, when it borrowed in recent weeks, it found that money was readily available below the posted rates. ''This was the first week that we took advantage of the lower rate from Chase,'' he added. The Chase Manhattan Bank is a leading lender to brokerage firms. **********Three other leading securities firms acknowledged privately this week that they had been obtaining broker loans below the posted rate, but they asked not to be quoted. **********Some of the major firms obtain their funds primarily from nonbank sources and borrow little from banks. Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest securities firm, raises most of its money in the commercial-paper market, where rates are usually lower than even the cut-rate bank loans. Discounts Not Passed On **********The situation is sensitive because brokerage firms are not passing the discounts on to their customers, who continue to pay interest rates scaled up from the posted broker-loan rate. These customers are charged anywhere from one-half percentage point to two and a half percentage points above the posted broker-loan rate. **********Income from such loans has been a major source of earnings for many brokerage firms. The total amount of margin-account lending by brokerage firms to their customers amounted to $14.7 billion at yearend, according to the Federal Reserve Bulletin. **********In 1980, for instance, Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, one of the nation's largest securities firms, earned $52 million before taxes on its margin accounts, compared with its net after-tax income of only $26.8 million. **********Among the commercial banks, only Morgan was willing to publicly acknowledge that it had been making broker loans below its posted rates. At least four other of the nation's ten largest banks privately confirmed that they had been engaging in such practices, however. **********For the last month and a half, Morgan has been testing a program under which it tailors its rate on broker loans to its overall relationship with the borrower, Mr. Cutler said. The program has gone well and will soon be introduced to all its customers, he added. **********Other banks are offering broker-loan discounts in a more haphazard way, depending on the amount of funds they have available on any particular day and the trend of interest rates. The loans are priced in relation to the rate on Federal funds, money that banks buy and sell among themselves. Recently, many broker loans have been made at only a quarter of a percentage point above the Federal funds rate. **********Yesterday, according to Mr. Matorella of Kidder, Peabody, the posted broker-loan rate ranged from 14 1/2 percent to 15 percent, while Federal funds were trading around 13 percent. In periods of rapidly declining interest rates, as at present, it becomes easier to get broker loans below the posted rate, he said. **********Aside from Morgan, other banks particularly active in the market include the Irving Trust Company, the Bankers Trust Company, the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Chemical Bank. **********The firms being offered the discounts are those that can borrow large amounts, according to the bankers. Bankers say it is not worthwhile lending smaller amounts at discounts because overhead on smaller loans reduces the net return to a rate lower than that obtainable in the Federal funds market. **********Each day banks formally post the basic rate they charge on broker loans. On Tuesday, several banks announced they had lowered their broker-loan rates to 16 percent from 16 1/2 percent. **********Yet, as a result of the ''tiering'' that has emerged, one securities firm said on Tuesday that it had obtained broker loans at rates as low as 15 percent. **********The tiering has resulted from growing competition, especially from foreign bank branches and agencies in New York and from banks outside New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Will History Repeat Itself?
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Will History Repeat Itself?
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/busin.body_text: **********COULD another Great Depression like that of the 1930's happen now?  Many economists think it was the worldwide liquidity crisis of 1931 that turned the recession of 1929-30 into the worst depression in history. **********What brought on the liquidity crisis of 1931? According to Maurice W. Lee, Boshamer Distinguished Professor of Economics at the University of North Carolina, these were the key factors: **********- An unmanageable amount of consumer installment debt. **********- A heavy burden of agricultural mortgage debt, dating back to the land boom caused by inflation during World War I. **********- A mountain of home mortgage debt resulting from the suburban land boom of the 1920's. **********- A huge pyramid of business debt built on a thin equity base. **********- A critical mass of international borrowing resting on a continuing flow of credit from the United States.  By the end of the 1920's, the American economy - indeed the world economy - was operating, Professor Lee says, like a huge chain letter: ''As long as the chain was not broken, as long as new infusions of credit kept the circular flow moving, the 'prosperity decade' could continue.'' **********But the stock market crash of 1929 caused American companies to pull back on their foreign loans. And the Smoot-Hawley tariff chopped United States imports, slashing foreign countries' earnings. As their economies foundered, they imposed trade barriers of their own, and United States exports also sank. **********The collapse of the Credit Anstalt in Austria threatened the German banks, which rushed to liquidate their holdings in London and Paris.  The whole international banking structure began to fall apart. **********How does the present situation compare to 1931? One brighter element stressed by Professor Lee is that consumers have been monitoring their use of credit more carefully. Measured against income, their debt burdens do not look critical, although they are high by historical standards. ''However,'' he says, ''the consumer's situation could become critical if unemployment rises or personal income declines.'' **********But the debt burden on nonfinancial corporations, he notes, has reached very high levels, just as corporate profits are sagging, and the failure rate among smaller businesses is rising sharply. Savings rates are low and lendable funds for long-term investment are short. **********The great amount of short-term debt waiting to be refinanced in the long-term market, he contends, sets a floor under long-term rates ''every bit as strong as the often-remarked forces that give us an embedded inflation rate.'' **********High mortgage rates have driven housing sales and new housing construction to its lowest level of the postwar period. And those high rates are jeopardizing the survival of many savings banks and other thrift institutions. **********Prof. Franco Modigliani of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a former president of the American Economic Association, said in a telephone interview this week: ''It is long past time when the Government should do something to rescue the thrift institutions. They were told to borrow short and lend long, and they got caught. Since the Government pushed them into it, the Government has some responsibility to get them out of it.'' **********Could another international monetary breakdown, like the one that followed the collapse of the Credit Anstalt in 1931, occur now?  Professor Modigliani says he is ''frankly worried - it's a very delicate situation.'' He feels that more government regulation of foreign lending by private banks is needed, and that central banks have not yet provided adequate assurances that, in a crisis, they could and would function as ''lenders of last resort'' to prevent an international banking breakdown. **********With the piling up of debts, domestically and internationally, the classic conditions for a serious systemic breakdown appear to exist.  In pressing hard for financial growth, decade after decade, the United States and the rest of the world seem once more to have created a huge ''chain letter'' -a process that could collapse, with devastating effects on output, income and employment, if the flow of credit were cut off. **********But to keep the chain letter growing, with credit mounting higher and higher, would add to the dangers of worse inflation and a still more serious collapse later. **********How to escape from this dilemma will be considered in another column. Perhaps the most hopeful aspect of the present situation, to reverse the dictum of the philosopher George Santayana, is that we do remember the crisis of 1931 and are not condemned by ignorance to repeat it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/07/world.body_text: **********AROUND THE WORLD; Salvador Prelate Assails 'Repression' of Junta **********SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 6 (UPI) - Msgr. Arturo Rivera Damas, the acting Archbishop of San Salvador, said today that the junta headed by President Jose Napoleon Duarte was imposing ''an almost massive level of repression in rural areas'' and said elections alone would not end the violence. **********He also accused Government forces of waging a campaign of ''selective'' violence against civilians in urban centers. He said that the level of violence in the country ''would make it appear that elections alone are not the desired solution for the simple reason that elections and war are different problems.'' ---- **********CASTRIES, St. Lucia, Dec. 6 (Reuters) - A resolution of support for the junta in El Salvador and its plans for elections in 1982 was formally submitted to the Organization of American States general assembly here last night. Assembly sources said the resolution appeared to have the support of at least 20 of the 27 member nations. They said the measure represented a reaction against the September declaration by France and Mexico charging the junta with using repressive force.

The agency said it sent patrol boats to the scene after receiving a distress call from the 5,923-ton Komsomolets Nakhodki, which was on its way to the Soviet Union from Muroran, north of Hakodate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/19/world.main_headline: Israeli Parliament Lifts Immunity Of Minister Accused in Scandal
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/19/world.print_headline: Israeli Parliament Lifts Immunity Of Minister Accused in Scandal
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/19/world.body_text: **********The Israeli Parliament today lifted the immunity of Religious Affairs Minister Aharon Abuhazira to permit the state to try him on charges of embezzlement. **********The minister is awaiting the judgment of the Jerusalem District Court in another case in which he was accused of receiving kickbacks from grants to religious institutions. **********Mr. Abuhazira suspended himself from office when he was indicted for bribery in the first case, but he retained his seat in Parliament as a member of the National Religious Party. **********The new case relates to his tenure as Mayor of Ramle before he joined Prime Minister Menachem Begin's coalition Government in 1977.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/11/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; NONCONFORMIST POLITICIAN: FRANCOIS MAURICE MITTERRANDws
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/11/world.body_text: **********For close to two generations Francois Mitterrand has pursued his zigzag and unpredictable way in French politics. In effect, he has had three political careers, and the first two were unremarkable and not very successful. **********His triumph today, in American terms, would be remotely as if Harold E. Stassen had returned to public life 10 years ago, become a Democrat, revitalized the party and won last November's Presidential election. Served in Many Cabinets **********Francois Mitterrand - his name is pronounced frahn-SWAH mee-terr-AHN - was one of the blur of people moving in and out of offices in the postwar Fourth Republic, whose governments rose and fell irregularly, but often. A member of various small centrist or centerleft groupings whose names not even the French remember, he was caught up in the political moves of the time: backing the Suez invasion of 1956, affirming that the only policy to be followed toward the Algerian nationalists was war and participating dutifully in the nonstop process of political intrigues and swaps that came to be called the Waltz of the Cabinets. **********When Gen. Charles de Gaulle was called back in 1958 to disband the Fourth Republic and set up the Fifth, Mr. Mitterrand stepped out of the shuffle. Unlike other political figures who hastened to join the general, he became one of his most persistent opponents, and in 1965 he participated in the first of three presidential campaigns as the candidate of the left. He did well, but lost, and for the next five years seemed ready to retire. **********Then, in 1971, after the Socialist Party had dropped to an abysmal 5 percent of the vote, a conference was held to decide its future.  Mr. Mitterrand turned up with a proposal for a united left that might some day wrench the Fifth Republic from what seemed to be the perpetual control of the right. The vision seemed precarious, and Mr. Mitterrand did not even belong to the party: nevertheless, there were no better ideas around, so he was made a party member and the party leader all at the same time. **********If he had lost to Valery Giscard d'Estaing today, as he did seven years ago, he would still have accomplished something remarkable.  From its lowest ebb in history, he built the Socialist Party up to the greatest strength it has known. The Communists dropped to 15 percent of the electorate in the first round of the elections two weeks ago, and the Socialists grew to 26 percent. **********The man who has done this remains, nonetheless, a puzzle to most of the French and a source of distrust to many of them. Part of both the puzzlement and the distrust is political. His enemies call him an opportunist or worse, while his admirers see a man of private and idiosyncratic loyalty to his own sense of the authentic. Antipolitical Qualities **********His demeanor is both cool and elusive; he cultivates, perhaps deliberately, antipolitical qualities. Not long ago he visited, for the third time in a few years, the same small town in the Limousin district of south central France. The local Socialist leader, who had received him each time, asked him to autograph a book. ''What is your name?'' Mr. Mitterrand inquired, reaching for a pen. **********It was not that he just forgot the name; it was that he obviously attached no importance to remembering it. In 1971, after he had become the Socialist leader, a party official came up to him. ''So, Francois, now we can use 'tu,' '' the official boomed out in broad Gascon tones. ''Comme vous voulez'' - ''As you wish'' - Mr.  Mitterrand replied, holding to the formal usage. **********Mr. Mitterrand has written several books of political and literary essays, and has a gift for observation and for perceptive phrases.  There is something of a literary quality to the public figure he presents to the French. In contrast to the brisk activism of Mr.  Giscard d'Estaing, the sense that each moment is the morning and can be taken up clean, Mr. Mitterrand is all late afternoon. Escaped From German Prison **********Francois Maurice Mitterrand was born on Oct. 26, 1916, at Jarnac in southwestern France. He was educated at the University of Paris and has degrees in law, letters and political science. He was wounded in World War II and taken prisoner by the Germans, but escaped and joined the underground. **********At the age of 64 and, if anything, an intellectual, he tramps about in a bargeman's cap, an overcoat and several scarves, suggesting an old countryman, slow, tempered and attached to the land. ''Inspector Maigret,'' one commentator called him. ''He doesn't so much travel about France as plow it,'' wrote another. He is the candidate of the left but, much as his old adversary de Gaulle used to do, and as Mr.  Giscard d'Estaing decidedly does not, he presents himself as France's roots. **********Clearly his mournful visage, his slow speech, his air of taking thought, suggest a kind of authenticity, a refusal of gimmickry, that he has employed to show up the more mechanical showmanship of Mr.  Giscard d'Estaing. Is it a gimmick itself? There are those, including some in his own party, who think so. **********Mr. Mitterrand does not reveal himself to many. He has close friends, a wife, the former Danielle Gouze, and two grown sons, with whom he spends time, whenever possible, at a modest country retreat in the Landes region of the southwest, where he tramps the pine woods by day and writes in the evenings. But there are not many French people, including those who voted for him, who are confident that they know what he is like. **********When they do, it is mainly as an intuition. ''There is a pessimism about Mitterrand that I feel each time he speaks on television,'' the novelist Marguerite Duras, who supports him, wrote recently. ''It is an essential pessimism that is common to us all. It is the end of lying.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/busin.main_headline: RISING TREND OF COMPUTER AGE: EMPLOYEES WHO WORK AT HOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/busin.print_headline: RISING TREND OF COMPUTER AGE: EMPLOYEES WHO WORK AT HOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/12/busin.body_text: **********Louise Priester used to key-punch insurance claims into a computer in the office of Blue Cross-Blue Shield of South Carolina. Now she does the same thing from a bedroom in her house in Columbia, S.C., using a terminal connected to the office's computer by telephone. **********Like Mrs. Priester, a small but growing number of workers are doing office work at home on small computers or terminals with typewriter keyboards. Corporations encourage the practice, to save commuting time for their employees and to recruit some workers, such as mothers of small children, who might not be able to hold conventional jobs. **********Working at home gives employees more flexibility in scheduling other activities.  ''I can get up when I want to and work when I want to,'' said Mrs.  Priester, adding that she can now take better care of her elderly mother. **********Companies and workers say the new system can transform relationships between co-workers, between employees and employers and between workers and their families. **********''What we're really talking about is returning production to the home, which is where it was before the Industrial Revolution,'' said Alvin Toffler, author of the book ''The Third Wave,'' in an interview. Although Mr. Toffler is dismissed by many as an unrealistic visionary, he has drawn attention to working at home with a phrase, ''the electronic cottage.'' **********People have always worked at home, of course. Nearly 2.6 million people, or 3.2 percent of the United States labor force, worked at home in 1975, according to the latest figures available from the Census Bureau. More than one-third of them were farmers, and many of the rest were in business for themselves. What electronics can do is extend that option to more people in a diversity of occupations, including employees of large corporations. **********Some see working at home as part of a trend in which telecommunications, growing more sophisticated, replaces transportation, growing more expensive because of rising energy costs. **********In an experiment in Knoxville, Tenn., people bank electronically without leaving home. Others elsewhere in the nation shop electronically from home. In Columbus, Ohio, people can use two-way cable television to vote at home. And business people, instead of traveling to other cities, can now hold meetings in which they see as well as hear colleagues across the nation. **********These new activities are called teleshopping and teleconferencing.  Working at home has been dubbed telecommuting.  So far, the number of full-time telecommuters is small. There are probably hundreds of them nationwide. They are confined to jobs that lend themselves to solitary effort: writers, typists and computer programmers. Thousands of others in various jobs, including corporate executives, do extra work at home on personal computers or terminals.  Programmers' Tasks **********The Control Data Corporation, the Minneapolis computer company, has 60 of its 48,000 United States employees, mostly computer programmers, working at home. The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in Chicago recently hired four persons to transcribe recorded dictation in their homes and transmit the text to office computers. **********Other concerns, including the Aetna Life and Casualty Companies, the North American Life Insurance Company and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, are studying similar programs. **********The FMC Corporation in Chicago, while requiring workers to come to the office during the day, has installed terminals in the homes of four programmers. They are on call at night to handle computer breakdowns. **********''They used to get a phone call, hop in their car, take 45 minutes getting to the office, 15 minutes solving the problem and 45 minutes driving home,'' said Robert A. Copella, FMC's manager of manufacturing systems. Now the programmers can solve the problem in their pajamas. **********Work at home is done on terminals, word processors or computers that cost several thousand dollars. The devices either print out data on paper or display it on a television screen. Role of Phone Varies **********In some cases, the terminal must be continuously linked by telephone with a central computer. In other cases, terminals and word processors have their own computing capacity. The worker uses the phone only to transmit the final work to the central computer. **********Home typists for Continental Illinois record dictation off the telephone. They type the text and edit it on computer screens. Then they dial a special number, put the telephone receiver in a cradle and transmit the completed text over the phone line to the bank's computer. **********Employees have mixed feelings about working at home. Although it gives them more freedom, it removes them from the social life of the office. Some think their fellow workers or supervisors mistrust those who work at home. **********''I still think there's a mentality around here that people who work at home are not working,'' said the vice president of a New York-based management consulting firm who works out of his home in Florida. His house contains a small computer, a word processor and a printer, allowing him to prepare reports. **********''I like to have uninterrupted periods to work alone,'' he said.  ''If I have to stop and go to a meeting for two hours, I lose more than two hours.'' Special Arrangement **********He concedes that he was able to work out such an arrangement only because of his stature in the firm, and he asked that his name not be used because the management did not want other employees to know about the setup. **********John Pistacchi of Control Data, who last year worked at his home in San Jose, Calif., found that his business associates hesitated to call him because they did not want to disturb him at home, even though they knew he was working there. **********Some people could not work at all except at home.  ''I have a small child and don't have to get a baby-sitter,'' said Terry Medlin of Columbia, S.C., one of Blue Cross-Blue Shield's four ''cottage keyers.'' **********Mrs. Medlin said, however, that working at home ''gets kind of lonesome some of the time.'' The hardest part, she said, is ''putting yourself on a schedule.'' **********Being with one's family can be an advantage, but it can also be a distraction. David A. Pimley, a Control Data employee in Sunnyvale, Calif, who worked at home last year, said his daughter continued to go to a neighbor's house after school, even if her father was at home. ''I was there to work, not to baby-sit,'' Mr. Pimley said. A Portable Terminal **********Vincent E. Giuliano, who works for Arthur D. Little Inc., the Cambridge, Mass., consulting concern, uses a portable terminal that allows him to work not only from his home but also from a cottage in New Hampshire or from a motel while on business trips. **********Working at home can give handicapped people a chance at employment they would not otherwise have.  Lift Inc., a nonprofit organization based in Northbrook, Ill., has trained about 30 handicapped workers who now write computer programs from their homes for companies such as the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the First National Bank of Chicago and Montgomery Ward & Company. **********Some of the handicapped workers operate the keyboard with sticks strapped to their hands. In a compromise between saving commuting time and retaining workers' contact with others, some companies have opened neighborhood offices and allowed employees to work at the one closest to home. Control Data will soon open such a center for 55 workers. **********The Southern New England Telephone Company tested a remote business center in 1978. The center, in Meriden, Conn., 15 miles from company headquarters in New Haven, was equipped with phones, facsimile machines and message-handling terminals. Feeling of Isolation **********Yet the four workers at the remote center felt isolated. Among other things, they had trouble obtaining files from the central office. **********''Being away from the home area was almost like the old cliche 'out of sight, out of mind,' '' said Anthony J. Francalangia, a planner who worked at the remote office. **********Work-at-home programs can save corporations the cost of expanding office space in expensive downtown areas and can allow them to recruit workers who otherwise would not be available. This is especially important for jobs where qualified workers are in short supply - secretaries and computer programmers, for instance. **********''The industry is starving for computer talent, so we make available a resource that is hidden from the market,'' said Leah L.  Tracy, branch manager of Heights Information Technology Service Inc.  This data processing consulting company, with offices in Tarrytown, N.Y., and Oakland, Calif., employs 180 persons who write programs, mainly at home. **********Yet many companies balk at the idea because having employees work at home raises problems. It requires new ways of making sure that an employee puts in a full day's work. **********''A lot of companies are really conservative about this,'' said Margrethe Olson, an assistant professor at the New York University Graduate School of Business Administration, who is studying work-athome programs. ''They want those employees in sight.'' Output Quotas Set **********Blue Cross-Blue Shield of South Carolina and Continental Illinois both require a certain minimum daily output from their clerical workers who stay at home. Other companies restrict work at home to salaried employees who are judged by output, not hours worked. **********Companies must also decide if they save money by having employees stay home.  Blue Cross-Blue Shield has found that its cottage keyers process claims less expensively than its office keyers. But that is because the cottage keyers get no fringe benefits and must pay for their own terminals, paper and phone bills - at a cost of $2,640 a year. **********Technological problems can arise. At Continental Illinois, occasional computer breakdowns prevent home typists from sending in their finished text. The taped dictation has to be sent back over the phone and transcribed in the bank. **********If working at home catches on, the long-term effects could be widespread, according to Mr. Toffler and Charles C. McClintock, a psychologist in the College of Human Ecology at Cornell University, who is studying the phenomenon. **********When work is done at home, they said, family members can share a job and can work for more than one company. Distance Unimportant **********Data can be transmitted long distance as well as locally, so there is little need for workers to be in the same city as their employer. **********When a person gets a new job, instead of moving, he or she may merely ''plug into a different line,'' Mr. Toffler said.  No one expects the office or factory to disappear. Too many jobs require face-to-face meetings. This may bar full work-at-home programs. **********''There are not that many types of white-collar or blue-collar jobs that can be done on a lonely basis,'' said Kenneth G. Bosomworth, president of International Resource and Development Inc., a consulting concern that studies office automation. ''What you end up with is a scenario in which only 1 or 2 percent of the work force can commute in this way.'' **********Jack M. Nilles, director of interdisciplinary programs at the University of Southern California, is more optimistic. He estimates that 15 percent of the urban work force may work at home by 1990. **********But Dr. Nilles, a proponent of telecommuting, finds it hard to practice what he preaches because meetings require him to come to campus at least four times a week. **********''If I could schedule the rest of the university better, I wouldn't have to,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/20/world.body_text: **********AROUND THE WORLD; Guatemala to Draft Peasants to Fight Rebels **********GUATEMALA, Nov. 19 (AP) - Hundreds of peasants will be drafted into the military reserve to fight a growing leftist guerrilla threat, the army chief of staff, Benedicto Lucas Garcia, said today. **********The army chief, brother of President Fernando Romeo Lucas Garcia, said the draft would be centered in Quiche Province, where he said peasants ''have asked to fight against subversion because of damages caused to their communities.'' **********The Government has about 3,000 reservists, part of its 18,000-member armed forces, against four Marxist groups that have 2,000 to 4,000 guerrillas in the western and central highlands. ---- **********GENEVA, Nov. 19 (Reuters) - The International Labor Organization called on the Guatemalan Government today to act to put an end to a wave of murders of trade union leaders. It said 30 had been slain in Guatemala in two years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.main_headline: A FIRM PAPACY FOR THE PEOPLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.print_headline: A FIRM PAPACY FOR THE PEOPLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.body_text: **********From the day that Karol Cardinal Wojtyla stepped confidently onto the balcony of St. Peter's Basilica as the newly elected Pope John Paul II, he has boldly challenged the church and the world. **********Striving to make Christianity a renewed force, he has taken his message from St. Peter's Square around the globe, traveling widely with little apparent regard for his personal safety. **********The ''Popemobile,'' an open vehicle such as the one he was riding in when he was shot yesterday, has become a symbol of his mobility.  Before his weekly audiences in the square, he stands in the vehicle as it winds through the crowds. The act is a byproduct of his instinctive showmanship and his irrepressible desire to bring the church to the people. **********Whether his efforts have been applauded or criticized, John Paul has made the world pay attention to the church. He is a subject of great contentiousness as a leader, but he has remained personally popular to all sides in disputes and has gained a reputation for bending decorum and playing to crowds. Took Nine Major Trips **********The Pope has undertaken nine major trips in his mission of evangelization, a concept that includes not only the preaching of the Gospel as an alternative to ideologies such as Marxism but also the advocacy of the rights of the poor and oppressed. Repeatedly he has warned Roman Catholics against using violence to erase injustice.  ''Violence,'' he said during his trip to Brazil, ''kills what it intends to create.'' **********Elected to the papacy on Oct. 16, 1978, he promised ''a ministry of love,'' and he has plunged into the world scene with a sense of fearless resolve and tireless devotion. **********On his trips, he has thrived on schedules that most of his aides find exhausting. Though an intensely private man, he has a knack for stirring crowds - wandering into their midst, donning the hats worn by local people, often speaking in the local language and reaching out to touch hands. **********Some of his aides have been nervous about this informality and the risks he takes, but the Pope has shown that he will exercise his right to conduct the papacy as he sees fit. His reign centers on a conviction that he must assert the authority of the office to restore stability to a church shaken by the reforms of the Second Vatican Council of the 1960's. Further, never shrinking from his role as an international leader, he believes he must aggressively confront secular creeds that compete with the church for the loyalties and affections of people. **********His courage has been formidable in the face of conflicts he has sparked in his attempt to create unity in Catholic belief and practice. He has warned Catholics against further experimentation in worship, insisted that the church's opposition to divorce and artificial birth control must be upheld and approved the censuring of the Rev. Hans Kung, a Swiss theologian who disagrees with the Vatican's teaching on papal infallibility. **********On his journeys, he has tried to impart to Catholics a sense of love and respect for the church even while he has sometimes scolded its clergy for getting too involved in politics and lectured Catholic families about the need to remain unwaveringly committed to the church's teachings on morality. He has been a father figure without apologies and a firm disciplinarian. Reaching Paris, for instance, he declared chidingly: ''France, eldest daughter of the church, are you faithful to the promises of your baptism?'' Yearning to Meet People **********More than any Pope in history, John Paul has a yearning to see his far-flung congregation in its various surroundings.  ''The journeys of the Pope to the different continents and countries of the world all have one characteristic in common,'' the Pope said in Ghana in May 1980. ''The visits are always too short.'' **********He has traveled to underdeveloped nations, where his own beliefs about the relations between church and state have been tested and have undergone some change. On his first venture in early 1979 to Mexico, he projected some ambiguity by warning priests to stay out of politics but responding with compassion and encouragement to lay people who are struggling for human rights. Dedicated to Human Rights **********By the time he visited Brazil in July of last year, he was still pronouncing a hard line between Marxism and Christianity but siding more with elements of the church that are striving to correct injustice. His dedication to human rights was expressed most dramatically when he pleaded for justice in the presence of President Ferdinand E. Marcos on a journey to the Philippines last February. **********In his speeches and sermons, the Pope has made it clear that his efforts are rooted in devotion to Christ. The key to his first encyclical, ''Redemptor Hominis,'' or ''Christ the Redeemer of Man,'' was that concern for human life springs from the love of Christ, a thought summed up in his reference to ''the relation between Christ's redemption and human dignity.'' **********With that conviction at the core of his mission, he has become a preacher of salvation and human rights to millions in distant parts of the earth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/15/busin.body_text: **********Antwerp,Belgium, May 14(Reuter)-Zaire has ended its exclusive diamond sales contract with De BEers Consolidated Mines Ltd's Central Selling Organization, a dealer, David Susskind, said today.  Mr.  Susskind told Reuter that Caddi and Giasol N.V. both based in Antwerp, and the International Diamond Company of London would market Zaire diamonds, worth $100 million a year, beginning the end of May.  Under the new deal,the participating companies will receive guarantee monthly diamond shipments, from Zaire, Mr. Susskind, managing director of Caddi, said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/world.main_headline: SEIZURE OF JORDSANIAN ENVOY SHOCKS EVEN BLASE BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/world.print_headline: SEIZURE OF JORDSANIAN ENVOY SHOCKS EVEN BLASE BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/11/world.body_text: **********The mysterious abduction here five days ago of the chargee d'affaires of Jordan has shaken Beirut, a city so inured to violence as to be blase, heightened tensions in the Arab world and provided a look at what seems to be a shadowy underground battle between rival Arab nations. **********A score of gunmen seized the Jordanian diplomat, Hisham alMohaisen, in a hail of automatic-weapon fire early Friday, killing three persons in the process. **********This morning, an anonymous caller to the right-wing Phalangist Party's radio station, Voice of Lebanon, declared that the diplomat had been slain. But telephone calls to the Voice of Lebanon have themselves been among the confusing elements over the last few days, and Mr. Mohaisen's fate still seems uncertain. **********It was widely assumed here that the abductors were operating on behalf of Syria. Relations between Damascus and Amman are particularly strained, with Syria supporting Iran in the Persian Gulf war while Jordan is backing Iraq. Syria also accuses Jordan of harboring Moslem Brotherhood terrorists attempting to overthrow President Hafez al-Assad. In November, the two countries massed tanks at their border. Saudi Arabia mediated to calm the crisis. **********The abduction occurred not far from roadblocks manned by Syrian soldiers of the Arab League's peacekeeping force. Jordan Accused Syria **********Jordanian officials immediately accused Damascus in the abduction and charged that it had been carried out by the Special Forces commanded by Riffat al-Assad, the President's brother. The Prime Minister of Jordan, Mudar Badran, charged that the Syrian peacekeeping forces had turned Lebanon into an arena of chaos. **********Syrian officials denied complicity in the abduction. The Government newspaper Tichrin called the accusations part of the ''Jordanian campaign of hatred against Syria.'' **********The anonymous caller to the Phalangist radio claimed to be a member of the Eagles of the Revolution, the underground branch of As Saiqa, the pro-Syrian Palestinian guerrilla faction, and took responsibility for seizure. **********The caller said that the diplomat was being held hostage pending the return of two Syrian Air Force pilots who defected to Jordan last year. The caller said the Jordanian faced death at 5 P.M. yesterday if the pilots had not been turned over. Conflicting Series of Calls **********Later telephone calls raised the number of pilots to five, then seven, some of them supposedly having defected to Iraq. The diplomat was said to be in poor health and suffering a nervous breakdown. Then he was said to be in a Palestinian camp, later in Syria and then back in Lebanon. Callers said he was being treated by a doctor and a psychiatrist. Yesterday, the Phalangist radio said it had received other calls but that it would not broadcast them. **********Yesterday afternoon, a spokesman for Eagles of the Revolution held a news conference at the offices of a pro-Syrian newspaper, Ash Sharq, to deny his group's involvement. **********The Lebanese Government, as usual, seemed unable to do much but deplore the situation. The police were pressed to look for a body.  There is no shortage of bodies here and several were soon found. But none was that of the missing diplomat.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.main_headline: BOGNER, PRODUCER OF SKI WEAR, PLODDING ALONG
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.print_headline: BOGNER, PRODUCER OF SKI WEAR, PLODDING ALONG
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.body_text: **********This used to be the time of year when people at Willy Bogner, the West German clothing manufacturer, eagerly looked for an early salmon run or other signs of a long, snowy winter. Bogner had made its fortune by revolutionizing ski clothing. It took skiers out of their fluffy sweaters and baggy knickers and put them into sleek wedge-shaped pants and trim anoraks. **********But now, with West Germany under a cloud of recession, with the sportswear market flooded with competitors and with Bogner in the middle of a fickle fashion market, the company's executives are more likely to be looking hopefully for shifts in the business climate. **********Although Bogner remains a synomym for skiwear from Chamonix to St.  Moritz and from Squaw Valley to Sapporo, the company has not been spared by the recession, said Willy Bogner, son of the company's founder and its top executive. An Olympic skier like his father, the younger Willy skied for West Germany at Squaw Valley in 1960 and at Innsbruck in 1964. In his spare time Mr. Bogner, tanned and still boyish-looking at 39, shoots ski films. He did ski chases for three James Bond movies. The Outlook for Sales **********This year's sales, Mr. Bogner said, are expected to rise between 7 and 10 percent, to about 175 million marks, the equivalent of $75 million. But after allowing for inflation, he conceded, that means a real drop of roughly 5 percent. The volume has steadily climbed - from 123 million marks in 1978 to 145 million marks in 1979 to 160 million marks in 1980. **********The company publishes no figures on earnings, but Mr. Bogner said its healthy profit margin of about 7 percent, enjoyed in years past, was down considerably. **********To counter the slide, Bogner plans to invest in a new type of retailing network, so-called Bogner Houses, which sell exclusively Bogner products. Three of these already exist in Munich, Cologne and Hamburg, and more are planned in other Western European cities and New York. **********Unlike numerous competitors, who were swept away by new trends and inexpensive imports, Bogner moved early into high fashion, established itself overseas and entered the high-priced market for better-made clothes. Such decisions helped bring it annual growth rates of 20 to 30 percent during the 1970's. A Formula for Success **********''I think there were two things - the move to activewear and our decision to trade up,'' said Mr. Bogner, in explaining the company's success of recent years. ''But when you're successful you have many imitators: the big concerns, the department stores.'' **********Bogner markets its products primarily through specialty sporting goods stores and women's and men's apparel shops. In Europe it avoids chain stores and department stores, and in the United States it selects only a few of the best. **********Bogner's success bucked the trend in West Germany's apparel industry, where high manufacturing costs, new fashion trends from overseas and low-priced imports from Asia wiped out 130,000 of 400,000 jobs in the last 10 years. **********Innovation had been a source of Bogner's success ever since Willy Bogner, the company's founder, brought back skis, ski clothing and ski accessories from Scandinavia, where he worked in the early 1930's. He was an Olympic skier at Garmisch-Parten Kirchen in 1936.  On the slopes, he tested products his wife designed. Designs Tha t Caught On **********Mrs. Bogner created the basic wedge-shaped pants (called ''Bogners'' by some American skiers) and the light anorak, the hooded jacket that was to revolutionize ski apparel. In the 1950's light stretch materials, enabling a nearly skin-tight but elastic fit, sleeker forms and less wind resistance, led to further refinements. **********Later, to bridge the slow summer months, Mrs. Bogner began designing the collection of women's wear. Originally inspired by rustic Bavarian fashions, it evolved into a high-fashion collection her son cha ra cterizes as ''uncomplicated, very practical clothing.'' **********But the real spurt of growth, annual sales jumps of 20 and 30 percent, came in the 1960's and 1970's as Europeans and Americans discovered sports dress for everyday use and the market for what the apparel industry came to call activewear ballooned. **********Women's wear now accounts for about 65 percent of Bogner's total sales. Sports apparel, including clothing for skiing, tennis and hiking, accounts for 20 percent and men's wear 15 percent. **********Bogner began selling skiwear in the United States after World War II. By 1973, with sales vigorous and the West German mark strengthening, the company set up Bogner of America, a subsidiary. It is headed by Mr. Bogner's younger brother, Michael. Building Markets Abroad **********Bogner's first overseas plant was built in Newport, Vt. Later one was constructed on the Mediterranean island of Malta. **********About 85 percent of Bogner's production is absorbed by the West German market, while exports account for 15 percent. Four-fifths of the exports go to Western European countries, with the United States getting most of the rest. (Items sold in America are largely made there.) Some shipments go to South Africa and Australia. **********Bogner feels that most of its future growth will come from abroad, and Japan is a prime prospect. For the Japanese market, companies in Japan now make goods there under license from Bogner. Its ski collection is sold in Japan, and there are plans to add women's and men's wear. **********Coupled with its move into nonsports attire, Bogner also decided to trade up by producing expensive, high-quality apparel with concentration on details and quality. Bogner left the rest of the market to inexpensive Far Eastern imports. The company felt it could not compete against these because of West Germany's relatively high cost of labor and materials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/17/world.main_headline: JAPAN REPLACES FOREIGN MINISTER IN RIFT OVER U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/17/world.print_headline: JAPAN REPLACES FOREIGN MINISTER IN RIFT OVER U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/17/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki appointed Sunao Sonoda to take over as Foreign Minister today after Masayoshi Ito resigned unexpectedly in a dispute over the degree of Japanese military cooperation with the United States. **********Mr. Ito's resignation followed reported criticism by the Prime Minister of the way the Foreign Ministry had handled issuance of a communique summing up Mr. Suzuki's talks with President Reagan a week ago. **********Because of timing of the release, the Japanese press reported the communique's passages stressing an American-Japanese ''alliance, '' which was taken here to have a military meaning. The first press reports did not contain Mr. Suzuki's subsequent interpretation at a news briefing saying that Japan could do little to increase defense spending. **********Military Activity Restricted **********The Japanese say their Constitution requires that military activities be strictly self-defensive. Before going to the United States, Mr. Suzuki said that there was not yet a consensus in Japan that would permit the sort of enhanced military efforts the United States seemed to be seeking. **********(In Washington, the State Department described the change as a domestic matter that would not affect relations between Japan and the United States.) **********Mr. Suzuki has been attacked by the press for his handling of the crisis, and the Asahi newspaper says in an editorial in tomorrow's issue: ''This Prime Minister's lack of leadership is now clear.'' **********Mr. Ito, in a brief statement, said he was leaving the Government ''to take responsibility for the way the communique was announced and related confusion after Prime Minister Suzuki returned from Washington.'' **********A last-minute effort was made by Mr. Suzuki today to dissuade Mr.  Ito from resigning when the Prime Minister sent Kiichi Miyazawa, the chief Cabinet secretary, to the Foreign Ministry to patch over the rift. The move failed. **********The new Foreign Minister, Mr. Sonoda, 67 years old, previously served as Health and Welfare Minister in the Suzuki Cabinet. He was Foreign Minister from 1977 to 1979 and is highly regarded by American officials. **********The dispute over the communique stemmed from the fact that advance copies were given to Japanese reporters in Washington to meet late edition deadlines in Japan, but not allowing time for the Prime Minister to brief the press on his interpretation of the communique. **********As a result, Japanese morning papers on May 9, the day after a second Reagan-Suzuki meeting, emphasized literal aspects of the communique, including a new stress on ''alliance'' between the United States and Japan, which was read as having a military meaning. **********The press did not immediatey carry Mr. Suzuki's account of the meeting, in which the Prime Minister emphasized that Japan could do little to increase its defense spending. **********The resulting confusion over the meaning of the Suzuki-Reagan talks went on all this week. On Tuesday, Mr. Suzuki told two former Prime Ministers, Takeo Miki and Takeo Fukuda, of his displeasure with the Foreign Ministry for the way the communique was handled. Criticism From Foreign Ministry **********Foreign Ministry officials privately ridiculed the Prime Minister for a lack of experience in foreign affairs and for having criticized a communique that he had read beforehand. Mr. Suzuki countered with attacks in the Cabinet that were publicized against Mr. Ito's wishes. **********The disputed passages in the communique referred to ''the alliance between Japan and the United States ... built upon their shared values of democracy'' and also called for ''an appropriate division of (defense) roles between Japan and the United States.'' **********The Japanese press and opposition groups charged that Mr. Suzuki had reneged on his promises not to agree to raise defense spending in response to United States pressures, and right-wing members of Mr.  Suzuki's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, who favor rearmament, quietly rejoiced over the confusion. **********According to the Prime Minister's aides, Japanese public opinion lost sight of what Mr. Suzuki said he told Mr. Reagan at their second meeting on May 8. According to the aides at a Washington briefing, Mr. Suzuki listed four reasons why Japan could not raise defense spending much from $11 billion in the fiscal 1981 budget running from April 1. **********The reasons were: Public opinion does not favor a sizable rise in the defense budget; the Government plans an overall squeeze on the national budget; the Government has other priorities in spending as well; an increase in arms spending would alarm Japan's Asian neighbors. **********The communique, however, states: ''Japan, on its own initiative and in accordance with its Constitution and basic defense policy, will seek to make ever greater efforts for improving its defense capabilities in Japanese territories and in its surrounding sea and air space.'' **********Western diplomats said that Mr. Suzuki had read the communique before he signed it and that there was no explanation of how he hoped that the Japanese press would interpret the communique in a sense different from the one it implied. ---- U.S. Calls It an Internal matter Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, May 16 - The State Department today called the resignation of Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ito a purely domestic matter that would not affect relations between the two nations. **********''It's purely a Japanese internal affair, and does not affect U.S.-Japan relations,'' a statement said in response to question from Japanese reporters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/16/world.main_headline: FOR SALVADOR PEASANTS, FRUITS OF CHANGE SEEM GOOD
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/16/world.print_headline: FOR SALVADOR PEASANTS, FRUITS OF CHANGE SEEM GOOD
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/16/world.body_text: **********When Government soldiers came a year ago and claimed the plantation here on behalf of the peasants, one of the first things the peasants did was to vote out the administrators. **********If was not that they particularly disliked the former owner, or even some of his administrators. For them, it was a new start.  ''Now we are all equals,'' said Mateos de Jesus Vega, the elected vice president of the assembly formed by the peasants, ''and if there is a problem, we can solve it ourselves.'' **********Los Lagartos, 30 miles west of San Salvador, is one of the 282 cooperatives formed by the Government last year in a land redistribution program designed to undercut the power of right-wing landowners and win the hearts and minds of the peasants away from leftist guerrillas. All farms over 1,250 acres were expropriated and turned over to the peasants who worked them. Cooperatives Called a Success **********A year later, the cooperatives are being termed a success. More than 260,000 people - 10 to 15 percent of the rural population - live and work on the farms. The harvests just completed were about as big as those last year under the former owners, according to Western and Salvadoran experts. **********At Los Lagartos, where peasants say the harvest was actually up, the reasons appear elementary.  ''We are more conscientious in our work,'' said Jose Luis Oriana, a 27-year-old farm worker. ''We know who we are working for.'' Los Lagartos is a typical plantation village. Its 3,000 people live in dirt huts surrounded by dirt yards filled with tropical shade trees and unkept bougainvilleas. **********The main dirt road leads to a cluster of wooden buildings in a small dirt square. One building houses the farm offices and another is the town hall, where once every two weeks an old Mexican movie is shown. Church's Doors Are Closed **********A plain plaster church also sits on the square, but its doors are usually closed. There is no priest; one comes from nearby towns on special occasions. **********Across the road, under the shade of a sprawling amate tree, a man sells slices of watermelon to children wearing wide-brimmed hats to block the burning sun. **********The village sits in the middle of an 8,000-acre farm. Almost every man and woman, and many of the children, work either in the fields, where coffee, sugar, corn and beans are grown, or in the sheds as carpenters, bricklayers, mechanics and general laborers. **********The system under the former owner was virtually feudal. The owner paid the men the minimum agricultural wage of $2.08 a day and the women $1.86. Today, the women earn the men's former pay and the men have been given a raise to $2.40 a day. **********As before, medical care primary education is free, as are tortillas and beans, the basic diet, three times a day. The food is cooked communally in huge vats and wood-burning ovens in the plantation kitchen. Profits to Be Reinvested **********The biggest change is that the 506 adults who are members of the cooperative each own an equal piece of the farm. They expect to make a profit this year, but have decided to reinvest the money. **********''We are just beginning,'' said Jose Roberto Calderon, a young general laborer. ''We still lack a lot.'' Some of the profits will go for new housing, small prefabricated homes that the Government will help build and that will introduce many of the peasants to indoor plumbing. The village now has electricity but no running water. **********The cooperative is fortunate in being able to afford the housing.  The former owner was more generous than many; he took with him only the furniture in his home, known as the ''Great House,'' leaving behind the farm equipment. Many cooperatives are having to use their profits to buy equipment. **********Future profits will also go toward paying the Government for the land. The Government has still not set a price or paid the former owner, one reason being that the 250-acre plot he will be able keep for himself has yet to be designated. The Government has promised to pay owners for the confiscated land in Government bonds of up to 30 years. Guardsmen Are Replaced **********Leaders at many cooperatives were assassinated last year, allegedly by members of the security forces loyal to the former landlords. Los Lagartos did not have that problem. Nonetheless, the two National Guardsmen who were stationed here for many years have been transferred and six new ones brought in. The two, according to one of the new guardsmen, received a salary from the former owner in addition to their Guard salary. **********Most major decisions at the cooperative are made by a general assembly of the members. Administrators and the heads of work committees are elected, and are mostly peasants who can read and write. That narrows the field considerably since only about one-third of the rural population is literate. **********Complaints that early administrators were inefficient and were giving their friends easy jobs led to some being replaced, though there are still complaints. **********Officials from the Government's Institute for Agrarian Transformation are working closely with the cooperatives in a threeyear transition program. The institute also provides agrarian experts as well as training. The ''Great House'' is used for classes.  Insecticides Needed Urgently **********But what peasants say they need most are legal and financial experts. A shortage of financing because of the deficit in the country's balance of payments is slowing fertilizing and feeding.  There is barely enough work for some cooperative members. **********Perhaps worse, coffee rust, a plant disease, is spreading and could destroy crops if enough insecticides are not bought and sprayed soon.  The Reagan Administration is considering providing credit for such imports as part of an emergency economic aid package. In the meantime, the Government, which has already received $57 million in direct and indirect aid for the agrarian program, is scraping to find more funds. **********About 30 of the country's cooperatives have been cut off at one time or another by Marxist guerrillas. Los Lagartos is not in a guerrilla-infested area, and at the moment it does not appear they would be well received. Many of the peasants said they resent the guerrilla tactics of cutting roads, blowing up power lines and burning buses, trains and warehouses. **********''They are destroying our occupations,'' said Mr. Oriana.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/26/busin.main_headline: THE HIGH COST OF KIDNEY CARE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/26/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; THE HIGH COST OF KIDNEY CARE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/26/busin.body_text: **********Statistically, the number of Americans suffering from serious kidney diseases may not loom large, but certainly for them - and also the nation -their survival is becoming a serious economic problem, and possibly a moral one. **********The annual cost of kidney-disease benefits now exceeds $1 billion, up from about $900 million a year ago. In the next few years, the costs can be expected to reach $2 billion to $3 billion annually. **********What is known as the ''dialysis population'' in this country is now about 62,000, compared with about 16,000 five years ago. It rose last year by about 7,000 people, despite the fact that 2,000 had kidney transplants, which took them off dialysis for as much as five years. But only about half of kidney transplants are successful. **********Medical authorities say the dialysis population could rise to at least 90,000 by the end of the 1980's, with costs reaching $4 billion to $5 billion annually. **********The main treatment for kidney failure, or drastic impairment of the organ that is vital for cleansing the blood of waste, is hemodialysis, or an artificial kidney machine. Beyond that, a kidney transplant, though not feasible in all cases, may bring at least a temporary cure. **********For the patient, there is now almost complete protection on the major costs of such treatment. In 1973, the Social Security Act was amended to extend Medicare benefits for the first time to persons under 65, specifically to anyone suffering kidney failure. Medicare now pays 80 percent of the costs of hospitalization and treatment, and 100 percent of kidney transplant costs. **********Dr. Jeffrey Brensilver, attending nephrologist at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan, and an assistant professor at Columbia University, said a national program of benefits is necessary because kidney diseases are prevalent everywhere - in small and large communities. He noted that ghetto populations, which he said are more prone to high blood pressure and stress that cause many kidney diseases, need particular help on costs. **********New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and most other states take care of the additional 20 percent of treatment costs. In addition, Blue Cross and other private health insurance provide some benefits - perhaps three or four months of outpatient treatment. **********But, with rising costs of the benefits program, attributed mainly to the greater number of kidney-disease patients who survive because of the increasingly advanced technology available to them, anxiety is growing over the possibility that a budget-conscious Reagan Administration might reduce benefits. If, doctors assert, the present program is cut back - there has been no proposal, but the worry persists - it will imply that those who can't handle the costs simply won't survive. **********''We have to consider that we have nearly 60,000 people walking around who wouldn't be here if it were not for the program,'' said Dr. Belding H. Scribner, professor of medicine and head of the division of nephrology at the University of Washington. The program under Medicare has been regarded as a model for similar programs involving high-cost medical technology, Dr. Scribner said, and future development of heart transplants and artificial hearts will also raise problems of financing. **********Added Dr. Michael Michelis, chief of the kidney hypertension unit at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan: ''I find it encouraging that one-third of our unit's 50 patients have been returned to full-time jobs. This is a program that works.'' **********In dialysis - from the Greek for ''dissolve'' - the patient's blood is circulated through a machine containing artificial membranes and solutions that cleanse the blood of impurities before it is returned to the patient's body. **********Treatment, usually taking four hours, two or three times a week, costs about $130 to $150 at hospitals, clinics or special dialysis centers. Average annual cost per patient: $25,000 a year, plus in some cases treatment for complications that can involve the lungs, heart, or other organs. **********Home treatment, with the aid of a spouse or relative, or with a visiting nurse or paramedic, is less - perhaps $18,000 a year with a dialysis machine costing $5,000 or more. **********The kidney-disease patient's primary guide to help is the physician. But there are other groups offering assistance such as the National Kidney Foundation in Manhattan and the National Association of Patients on Hemodialysis and Transplantation, based in Great Neck, L.I. **********Margaret F. Diener, executive director of the patient group for the foundation, said there are now about 1,000 dialysis units in this country, mostly in major cities, and there are units also in about 50 foreign countries, primarily in Western Europe. **********There are now two main paths open for holding down dialysis costs for individuals: the encouragement of more home treatment through educational and special training programs and the development of simpler and more effective dialysis equipment. **********Dr. Michelis of Lenox Hill noted that while the effectiveness of treatment is improving steadily, costs, other than those for labor and materials, have not risen substantially. With an increase of home care, now accounting for about 10 percent of patients, he said, individual costs could be cut. **********Concerning progress in reducing the costs of dialysis machines, particularly with smaller ''suitcase'' models, Dr. Robert Stephen of the University of Utah in Salt Lake City, said a number of prototypes had been developed but that commercial production is still years away and in their current state of development, the new models would cost three times what a current one costs. **********Dr. Stephen, associate director of the division of artificial organs at the university, is a close associate of Dr. Willem Kolff, who in 1945 perfected the first successful artificial kidney. **********Technically, Dr. Stephen said, it is now possible to produce the portable, more efficient machine if costs could be brought down. The machines ''would then be less expensive and less complicated,'' Dr.  Stephen observed, ''and would also allow patients to go on one- or two-hour daily sessions that we feel would be better for them than the present four-hour treatments.'' He estimated per-treatment costs at $50.
