https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/01/world.main_headline: AMID THE ANARCHY OF BEIRUT, 8 DIE IN SHELLING ON A BEACH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/01/world.print_headline: AMID THE ANARCHY OF BEIRUT, 8 DIE IN SHELLING ON A BEACH
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/01/world.body_text: **********The beaches were jammed this afternoon, as they always are here on Sunday, when the Lebanese try to enjoy the sun and the Mediterranean, two of the few gifts they have left. **********Then the rockets hit. Within seconds, the beach front in West Beirut emptied in pandemonium, people fleeing into the streets in their bathing suits. Cars careered the wrong way on one-way streets, horns blaring. Gunfire crackled as the gunmen of half a dozen factions fired pistols and Kalashnikov rifles in the air. **********In the emergency room of the American University hospital, where the casualties from the beach were taken, a doctor said this evening that 8 people had died and that about 60 were wounded. Chronic Chaos in Beirut **********It was perhaps the worst incident in a violent weekend here as constant shelling echoed across the so-called Green Line, which divides Beirut into a Christian east and a predominantly Moslem west. **********In the chronic chaos here, statistics are uncertain, but officials said that about 15 people were killed overnight and 18 during the day, and that more than 100 were wounded. **********As usual, nobody could say for sure who started the shelling, and each side blamed the other. But, in a way, it simply does not matter anymore. Victims of Anarchic War **********Beirut is settling into a permanent state of anarchic war. The victims are not the defenders of various causes in their tailored fatigue uniforms, who are hunkered down in heavily sandbagged shelters, but the old woman buying eggs, the auto repairman, the young couple on the beach and the children growing up with nothing else. **********In the Moslem districts along Corniche Mazraa, few people have been able to sleep for the last two nights because of the artillery fire.  Across town, the Christian neighborhood of Achrafayieh is nearly deserted, with its residents having fled into the mountains and its clean streets, lined with French colonial architecture, eerily silent. Shells in Yacht Club Harbor **********Up the coast, near the Maronite Catholic port of Junieh, where a huge statue of Jesus dominates a hilltop, several shells crashed into the harbor of the Kaslik Yacht Club among the bobbing white powerboats. One man was injured. **********The fighting comes in fits and starts. It has stepped up in the last few days, since the departure from the Middle East of President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, who is seeking a way out of the standoff between Israel and Syria over the SAM-6 antiaircraft missiles Syria has stationed in the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon. **********''It won't last long,'' a doctor at the American University hospital said last night, referring to the intensified violence, ''because Habib will be coming back soon.'' **********But Mr. Habib's mission is only the latest round in a continuous crisis here. The crisis is rooted in a centuries-old feud that tore this country into warring factions half a dozen years ago. **********After the overnight artillery fire the morning was clear and quiet. Diners enjoying a late lunch of Lebanese mezza at the lamb house overlooking the Mediterranean suddenly saw two shells crash into the sea. **********Across the street, under a Ferris wheel, the clientele of the open-air Mediterranean restaurant vanished, leaving upturned chairs and half-eaten broiled fish. Beach Road Is Unusual Target **********The Corniche, the beach road running along Ras Beirut, or Beirut Neck, is one of the few pleasures left to the average people in West Beirut. Each Sunday it is crowded with cars and picnickers perched over the traffic islands, and its broad sidewalk is choked with strollers and vendors selling fruit drinks, shoes, pitchers, glassware and plastic toy monsters. **********The area is normally not fired upon.  But about 4 this afternoon, wounded people said, five rockets slammed into Long Beach, a broad strip of sand lying just down the hill from a Syrian roadblock and antiaircraft positions. **********Although much of the shoreline is cut up by private beach clubs, this is a ''free beach,'' where there is no required membership or admission. The sand was covered with people, many of whom had been cooped up in hallway or basement shelters for the last two days. **********Barefoot people ran screaming up the road. The taxicabs disappeared, and people tried to grab the few private cars on the road. Families near their autos piled in and raced off. Business District Is Deserted **********At least one shell fell near the Hamra business district, sending people scurrying. Leftist militiamen piled into their trucks and cars and drove wildly, firing into the air. **********In the ramshackle row of corrugated iron stalls along the Corniche that form a makeshift bazaar, the steel gates clanged down. Within minutes the area was deserted, with Palestinian commandos setting up roadblocks and ambulances wailing toward the beach. **********Firing stepped up along the Green Line as darkness fell. From the Muir Tower, a half-finished skyscraper towering over the vegetable market, Syrian troops fired at the Christian part of town. **********The Christian artillery had been sounding most of the day, too.  Shortly after dark gunmen from one of west Beirut's leftist factions brandished their Kalashnikov rifles in a Mobil service station in Ras Beirut and made off with two ambulances parked there. A Packed Emergency Room **********At the American University hospital the wounded from the beach were brought in on stretchers. Several leftist militiamen in uniform were also carried in, their ammunition belts stripped off and given to their friends before they underwent treatment. **********At least 30 people were brought in within half an hour, and three ambulances were backed up by the emergency room door, but the staff seemed calm. **********''We're used to this sort of thing,'' a nurse said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; ENERGY AIDE AT COOPERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/26/busin.body_text: **********W. Bowman Cutter, 38 years old, an official of the Carter Administration and a major architect of the legislation that created the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, will become a partner of Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, on Feb. 1. He will be based in its Washington office as national energy partner and serve as chairman of its alternative energy development task force. **********''If we're going to have adequate supplies of liquid fuels, we'll have to get a good part of it through synthetics and develop the managerial structures for evaluation,'' Mr. Cutter said. ''For the longer range, I'll be taking a more focused look across the whole energy field to see what opportunities there are for the firm.'' **********Mr. Cutter's efforts in connection with the passage of the Energy Security Act came in the course of his work as executive associate director for budget at the Office of Management and Budget. Before going into Government service when former President Carter was inauguarated, he was assistant to the chief executive officer of the Washington Post Company for a year and a half. He had also been executive director of the Cable Television Center and special assistant to the president of Northwest Industries. **********Mr. Cutter - who is an economist, not an accountant - called his move to Coopers ''a continuation of a fascination with the energy field.'' He added: ''I've always thought of accounting firms as the best available repositories of financial knowledge. They are naturals from which to develop further kinds of expertise about organizations.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/busin.main_headline: NO CUTS HERE: THE LIFE ON THE TAB
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/busin.print_headline: NO CUTS HERE: THE LIFE ON THE TAB
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/busin.body_text: **********The place: a restaurant, 21 Club, Lutece or the Palm. The sound: the tinkling of silver and china, the hum of conversation. The food: excellent, royal squab grille, croustade of chicken livers or broiled fresh mushrooms on toast. A bottle of wine perhaps. Then the coffee, and the cup refilled without request. **********The check is laid upon the table in a most discreet fashion, and the payment, usually by credit card, sometimes by cash, follows.  Finally, the most important part of all - the light blue customer's copy from the American Express receipt is placed in pocket, purse or billfold. For the ultimate purchaser of the meal is not the businessman or businesswoman who signed for the meal, but the host's employer and ultimately, in large part, the American taxpayer. **********The meal is a product of that important American institution, the expense account.  Each year, individuals and corporations deduct billions of dollars from their revenues for meals, drinks, hotel rooms, entertainment and travel, thus reducing their taxable income. The Internal Revenue Service and the Treasury Department say it's impossible to calculate the amount of money involved, but Sidney Rutberg, author of ''The Joy of Expense Account Living,'' put the fig-ure at $54 billion annually. A sizable but much smaller estimate by a Library of Congress study put deductible spending for meals alone at $3.2 billion in 1976. **********It is one pocket of the economy that is unlikely to be touched by the Reagan Administration's budget writers. ''That's not the way the wind is blowing,'' said a Treasury Department official. **********The expense account is a businessman's perquisite that the businessman is rarely forced to defend. That's because one man's perk is another man's profit. Major businesses - restaurants, hotels, banking and credit card companies, theaters, professional sports, convention operators, airlines, car rental agencies and limousine services - often depend for a lion's share of their business on the expense account. **********Yet critics of the expense account say that it is responsible for higher prices in restaurants, hotels and airline travel, and that it often means that business decisions are not made on the basis of the quality of a product, but on the basis of personal or social obligations established by the expense account. They also say that the expense account system can lead to corruption. **********Philip M. Stern, author of ''The Great American Treasury Raid'' and ''The Rape of the Taxpayer,'' both studies of American tax policies, said, ''The expense account creates a two-class society, those who can utilize expense accounts, generally the middle and upper classes, and those who cannot, the working class and the poor.'' **********The Treasury Department, which in 1978 told of a taxpayer who had legitimatly deducted every meal for two years with the exception of one day, said that, with inflation, making extensive entertainment and travel privileges available to executives instead of salary was an attractive prospect for both employers and employees. Moreover, it appears that people with access to expense accounts will increasingly resort to them, sometimes in illegal ways, to increase income, Treasury officers believe. **********According to the New York State Restaurant Association, about 25 percent of the meals bought in all of New York City are expense account meals, and those in the restaurant industy say the figure rises to perhaps 50 percent in such business districts of Manhattan, Boston, Chicago, Houston, San Francisco and Los Angeles. **********New York food authorities believe, however, that in the restaurants widely regarded as the city's finest - 21 Club, the Four Seasons, the Palm, Lutece, La Grenouille and Christ Cella - perhaps 70 to 90 percent of lunches and dinners are placed on expense accounts. **********''Midtown is credit cards, and a large percentage of credit cards are business lunches,'' said Thomas Haas, publisher of Nation's Restaurant News. **********These restaurants are places where patrons can easily pay $50 to $100 for two for lunch and perhaps $135 to $160 for dinner. Some call the expense account lunch - or dinner, or, increasingly, breakfast - the Government's largest food program. **********Last year, 17.1 million visitors came to New York City, according to the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, with a vast number on business trips, although the exact number is not known. The American Hotel and Motel Association says about 65 percent of the nation's hotel and motel guests - an estimated 1.4 million hotel and motel rooms are occupied every night with yearly lodging costs estimated at $25.9 billion - are businessmen, government employees or convention goers, people who could legitimately claim deductions on their room rates. In New York, such hotels as the Waldorf-Astoria, the Pierre, the Grand Hyatt and the Hilton are favorite dwellings for visiting businessmen. **********The American Express Company, the nation's leading travel and entertainment card company, with 11.9 million subscribers, says a majority of the use of its cards is for business expenses. The Air Transport Association says that one-half of the 300 million passengers that its member airlines carried last year - they paid $30 billion in fares - were on business trips. **********Other expense account conveniences involve the use of an employer's credit card to get discounts on rental cars or hotel rates. In professional baseball and football, large blocks of tickets are often bought by companies and other institutions. The tickets are made available to clients or employees, and the costs deducted from the company's revenues. **********Trips that combine business and entertainment - to the Greenbriar, the conference and resort center in West Virginia, the Masters golf tournament, the Superbowl, to business conferences in Mexico, the Caribbean or Europe -are often considered legitimate business deductions, meaning that the costs of attending the business meetings as well as food and drink and often lavish entertainment are borne at least in part by the nation's taxpayers. **********People in businesses that benefit from its use vigorously defend the expense account. ''The business meal often offers the only means that some elements of the business community have to approach a customer,'' said Robert B. Neville, chief counsel of the National Restaurant Association. A lunch or drink, or a pleasant resort, contribute to an atmosphere of congenialty and trust among businessmen, defenders says. And Mr. Neville suggests that they also often increase productivity. **********''I find business lunches extremely beneficial,'' says James Kennedy, a tax partner with Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., one of the nation's major accounting firms. He says if he has a meal by himself, his company gains nothing, but that if he takes someone to lunch and discusses business, his company benefits. **********''It's not the luxury of the food or the luxury of the drinks,'' according to Mr. Kennedy, who says he also takes clients to dinner and to such events as New York Knickerbocker games. ''It's the luxury of the surroundings. To be uninterrupted for an hour - that can be luxurious, too.'' He adds he does not entertain clients because the expenses are deductable. If his company does not gain, he does not entertain. **********''There's hardly a reason to have a meal in a restaurant that does not involve business,'' said Eric Green, of the restaurant consulting firm of Harris, Kerr, Forster & Company. **********Yet Ralph Nader, the frequent business critic, says, ''Inflationary forces are held in check when people who pay the bills, pay all the bills.'' He suggests that when the prices of the finest steak and wine are subsizied (business resents the word) by expense account purchases, price increases filter down to the lowliest hamburger and soda. Mr. Nader calls the expense account a kind of transfer payment, a term economists use to describe programs such as Aid to Families with Dependent Children, food stamps, or unemployment compensation. **********Tax deductions for business travel and entertainment last came under attack when President Carter complained during the 1976 Presidential campaign that it was unfair for a businessman to deduct a restaurant meal from his taxes, when a hod-carrier cannot deduct a bologna sandwich. As President, he proposed that the price of a business meal and drinks - the so-called ''three-martini lunch'' - be cut to 50 percent. He also would have eliminated deductions for other business entertainment, club dues, tickets to theater and symphony performances and sporting events, yachts and hunting lodges. In addition, he would have disallowed first-class air travel deductions by the amount they exceeded coach travel. **********But the Carter proposals were easily defeated. Al Ullman, former chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said, ''We're not going to pass a bill that puts half of America out of business.'' **********It is the jobs argument - that entertainment and travel deductions would mean reductions in employment - that is most often advanced by business and labor to defend the deductions. **********Fred Sampson, executive director of the New York State Restaurant Association, says that if a proposal like that advanced by the Carter Administration were passed, it would mean a 25 percent reduction in jobs in the New York restaurant industry, which employs 150,000 workers. Those affected, he said, would be women, blacks, Hispanic workers and the disabled, all employed in the restaurant industry. **********He adds, ''Lots of people who work in our industry - and thank God we have them, don't misunderstand me - if they were not working for us and supporting government services with their tax dollars, they would be on the dole.'' **********Robert Juliano, chief lobbyist with the 450,000-member Hotel and Restaurant Employees and Bartenders International Union, says he is not troubled making the jobs argument, although it opens him to charges that he is a collaborationist. ''For us, it's one issue, and one issue alone,'' he said. ''Jobs. Jobs. And jobs.'' **********Mr. Nader, however, strongly opposes the expense account because, he said, it is an example of ''nonmeritorious competition.'' He says: ''You get your sale from your customer not by providing better quality, durability, a warranty, or safety, but by wining and dining.'' **********He adds that the expense account can lead to corruption. ''When people wine and dine politicians, they get them a little tipsy. They take them to the Yucatan or them take them on a hunting trip. They get them drunk and they have a nice, happy time, and then they've got them. Six months later when this sobered-up senator meets with some lobbyist, in the back of his mind is, 'They know something about me I don't want anybody else to know,' '' Mr. Nader says. **********Virtually the entire defense of deductions in Congressional hearings was given by officials of the restaurant or hotel industries, or from labor institutions that benefit from the expense account system, not by businessmen or others with the availability of expense accounts, notes Thomas F. Field, executive director of Taxation With Representation, a tax group. He rejects the argument that the expense account provides employment, and says the real reason food, lodging and travel industries oppose expense account curtailment is that it would reduce profits. **********Daniel Halprin, a Georgetown University law professor, who as a Treasury Department lawyer was charged with helping institute the Carter Administration proposals, says of the meal, drinks, and other entertainment expenses: ''If they are the thing that makes business go, if they are essential to doing business, there is no reason to expect that they wouldn't continue'' even if deductions were disallowed. But he adds, ''If they really aren't efficient, if people are being driven to do this only because of the tax benefits involved, certainly they are not something you would want to continue.'' **********He says the Carter Administration's proposals were defeated for three reasons. First, they became, under the phrase ''the threemartini lunch,'' humorous, even though vast amounts of money were involved. Second, many Government officials and politicans in Washington enjoy the amenities of the expense acount, making it difficult to alter the system. Finally, he says, the combined opposition of industry and labor was difficult to counter. **********And Sheldon Tallen, an owner of the 21 Club in Manhattan, suggests there was no reason for the law to change in the current political climate. ''Business and restaurants and people who work in restaurants cannot do without each other,'' he says.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/23/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Gunmen in West Beirut Fire at the U.S. Embassy
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/23/world.body_text: **********Unidentified gunmen in a speeding car fired automatic weapons at the American Embassy in the western sector of Beirut early today and Lebanese guards returned fire, an embassy spokesman said. No injuries or damage were reported. **********The spokesman said the attackers and curity force, exchanged fire briefly at about 3:15 A.M. local time, when the embassy was not staffed. **********Last August the American Ambassador here, John Gunther Dean, survived an assassination attempt when a rocket and machine guns were fired at his motorcade as he and his family left their home. In September the embassy was attacked with rockets by a pro-Iranian group.unharmed when a gunman fired at his motorcade and struck a tire of an escort car. It was not clear if this was an attempt on the Ambassador's life.   Special to the New York Times **********TEL AVIV, March 22 - Israel's top military commander, Lieut. Gen.  Rafael Eytan, said today that there was a danger that Palestinian guerrillas would step up infiltration into southern Lebanon under the protection of the United Nations peacekeeping troops. The general, in an interview over the state radio, said that such a move might touch off a ''state of border attrition,'' the phrase Israel has used to refer to a long period of artillery exchanges and casualties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/world.main_headline: Greek Cabinet Modified To Prepare for Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Greek Cabinet Modified To Prepare for Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/world.body_text: **********The Greek Cabinet today formally submitted its resignation and was then immediately given a mandate to form a slightly modified Cabinet to conduct next month's elections. **********The only change in the new Cabinet will be the replacement of the Ministers of the Interior, Justice and Public Order and the Under Secretary of Press and Information with people equally acceptable to the Socialist opposition as a means of holding irreproachable elections. **********Prime Minister George Rallis submitted his Cabinet's resignation to President Constantine Caramanlis.  Parliament also held its last session today, and will be formally dissolved on Saturday.  The elections scheduled for Oct. 18, are being contested by the ruling New Democracy Party and the opposition Socialists. The latter is headed by Andreas Papandreou on a platform challenging Greece's traditional ties with the United States and Western Europe and calling for a greater ''socialization'' of the economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/08/world.main_headline: BRITISH OFFICIAL WARNS OTTAWA ON CONSTITUTION ISSUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/08/world.print_headline: BRITISH OFFICIAL WARNS OTTAWA ON CONSTITUTION ISSUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/08/world.body_text: **********The controversy about Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's plans to give Canada a new constitution has increased after a warning from the British High Commissioner that the British and Canadian Parliaments are ''on a collision course'' on the issue. **********Sir John A. Ford, who as High Commissioner is Britain's highest representative in Canada, was accused in the House of Commons here on Thursday of undue interference in Canadian affairs after he warned that ''it would be a mistake for people here to assume that the British Parliament would immediately do exactly what they were asked to do by the Canadian Parliament.'' **********His statement was at odds with the stand taken by Mr. Trudeau and other Canadian officials, who have insisted that Britain had no choice but to accede to the request from Canada for changes in the constitution. **********The present constitution is the British North America Act of 1867, and all changes in it must be approved in London. But in addition to requesting that the constitution be transferred to Canada, along with the exclusive power to change it, Ottawa is asking the British Parliament to approve a few amendments, including a new bill of rights. 6 of 10 Provinces Opposed **********A resolution is before the Canadian Parliament and is due to be approved next month before being sent to London. But six of Canada's 10 provinces are opposed both to the bill of rights and to the federal Parliament's taking action without their consent. This has caused concern in London, and last month the Foreign Affairs Committee of the British House of Commons unanimously recommended rejection of the request. **********Ed Broadbent, leader of the left-wing New Democratic Party, which is backing Mr. Trudeau's proposals, asked in the Canadian Parliament on Thursday whether the Government knew of efforts by the High Commissioner to influence members of Parliament. Mark MacGuigan, Secretary of State for External Affairs, said he was investigating and suggested that the High Commissioner's conduct might be found to be ''unacceptable.'' **********Later Ian Waddell, a New Democrat from British Columbia, said he had been told by Sir John at a dinner party that the Trudeau proposals stood little chance of approval in Britain and that the New Democrats were foolish to back them. Commissioner Defends Action **********The High Commissioner, who will be 59 years old in a few days and will soon retire, held a news conference to deny that he had ever told anyone what position to take. He said he had done what is normal for a diplomat, informing opinion makers as to the situation in his country. This situation, he said, was far more difficult than members of the Canadian Parliament appeared to believe. **********For several days a series of leaked documents, which Sir John said did not come from him, have been cited by the opposition Progressive Conservative Party and by the press to show the deep concern in Britain about a constitutional change that does not have general consent from the provinces. The documents concern private conversations between Canadian and British officials during which the British expressed reluctance to act if the changes were still under review by the Canadian Supreme Court. **********On Tuesday, an appeals court in Manitoba decided in a 3-to-2 ruling that the federal Government did not need provincial consent for constitutional change. Manitoba, backed by five other provinces, is appealing the decision to the Supreme Court, which might not render a decision for a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Japan's steel exports in the six months ended Sept. 30 fell 3.8 percent in tonnage from a year earlier, but the value rose 5.6 percent because of price increases, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today. **********Exports in the latest period totaled 14.8 million metric tons, worth $856 million. **********The average price of steel products was $578 a ton, up from $526 the year before. A metric ton is about 2,204 pounds. **********Steel exports to the United States, mainly pipes, surged 31.1 percent in volume, while those to Canada climbed 26.8 percent. By contrast, steel shipments to the Common Market nations plunged 69.3 percent amid economic stagnation in Europe. **********In the latest six months, Japanese production of crude steel dropped 9.8 percent, to 51 million tons. Federation officials cited sluggish domestic demand as well as the overall decline in export volume.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/10/busin.body_text: **********The Fluor Corporation reported today that earnings in its third fiscal quarter, ended July 31, fell to $20.5 million, or 42 cents a share, from $36.2 million, or 75 cents a share, a year before. Revenues were $1.5 billion, up from $1.3 billion. **********The refinery builder said results were depressed by its acquisition of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation.  Fluor borrowed $1 billion on May 1 to finance the purchase of 45 percent of St. Joe's common stock. The rest of the transaction, an exchange of 1.2 Fluor shares for each St. Joe share, did not take place until Aug. 3, after the quarter had ended. Thus, Fluor said, the report for the quarter includes interest costs on the entire $1 billion but only 45 percent of St. Joe's earnings. **********Apart from this, Fluor said, its operating results were higher than in the prior year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/06/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH HAIG ON MIDEAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/06/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH HAIG ON MIDEAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/06/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from a Stat e Department transcript of an interview with Se cretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in which he discussed t he Middle East: **********Q. Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel will be visiting next week. What kind of a role do you see for the United States over the next several months in negotiations between Israel and Egypt? **********A. Let's answer the question by talking about the visit itself and how the visit will or will not contribute to that. Clearly, we had discussions during the Sadat visit on the Middle East peace process, and it was clear then that President Sadat is anxious to get on with both phases of the Camp David structure. We've had in the meantime an announced meeting to go on with that process on Sept. 23 at the ministerial level - that's the autonomy talks. **********So with respect to Mr. Begin's visit, we are very anxious to hear how he views this process, particularly with respect to the autonomy talks. **********But I think it's important that we view the prospects for the peace process itself under the Camp David framework; that we recognize there have been some fundamental changes since Camp David in the whole Middle East environment and situation. **********One of those changes is now an interrelationship which has developed between the situation in Lebanon and the peace process which, while on totally separate tracks, are increasingly interrelated, and a failure or a collapse of one can have a serious impact on the other; whereas progress in one contributes to an atmosphere of progress in the other. A Strategic Consensus **********Q. When you said that things have changed since Camp David, do you mean to say that you're looking for some widening of the framework of these negotiations? **********A. No. What I'm saying is that the environment has changed. When I went to the Middle East in April-May, you will recall my talking about a strategic consensus. Whether that's the right terminology for the phenomenon is less important than the fact that there is such a consensus. **********I wasn't talking about creating one. I kept hitting that as we went around. I was talking about the fact that one was emerging historically, and it was a product of post-Camp David events. **********What am I speaking of? I'm speaking of the collapse of the Shah of Iran, of the Iran-Iraq conflict, the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, the dynamics of the Horn of Africa and the two Yemens - that all of these things were a fact of life that have impinged upon the perceptions of the nations in the area with respect to the Soviet threat. **********It was really this strategic consensus - and still in embryo but nonetheless existent - which moved in under the Habib mission, the first to deal with the initial crisis itself in Lebanon, and you recall that was restricted. Surviving 2 Jolts **********Q. The Syrian missiles?A. Missiles, Zahle town, the Heights overlooking the Christian heartland and the efforts that Phil Habib launched at the President's direction to try to resolve that issue. **********That involved harnessing leadership and support from the Arab League, and with considerable help from Saudi Arabia not only in leadership and diplomacy but in resources which catalyzed certain progress. **********That progress was not certain. There was evidence of it, but it wasn't complete, when the whole process was jolted severely, first by the Israeli raid on the Iraqi reactor; and, secondly, the subsequent increased violence along the border of Israel, which involved Palestinians, the P.L.O. and the Israeli forces. **********The simp le fact of that, as a value judgment, is that this consensus had to be a very strong element in the new Middle Eastern mix or that p rocess would have collapsed by either of those two shocks. It ma naged to sustain itself in a very shaky way by some veryskillful work by Phil to produce a cessation of hostilities. **********That's not an insignificant new factor in the whole Middle East process, and it must never be overlooked as we talk about the strategic consensus, because that's what we're talking about. Uncertainty Over Meeting **********Q. The Egyptians and Israelis have talked about this ministerial level meeting on the 23d. Obviously, they mean real ministers. You can't attend. You've got business elsewhere on the 23d. **********A. There's still some uncertainty about this meeting in terms of location. We will participate, in any event, at whatever appropriate level we decide upon, and that should not be done until we have a little more information from both parties. Q. Is it possible you might move to New Yor k?  A. It's not impossible, and we would be hap py to do that. Or it's also possible that we would have one meeting at that time in which we would be represented on another level and have it take place in Egypt or any place else, and that it would be followed by another meeting that I could perhaps participate in.  We have some judgments to make before we get definitive on it, and c ertainly the discussionswith Mr. Begin will help in that regard. **********Q. I take it from what you're saying that it is your inclination not to have a special superambassador on this as has been done in the past? **********A. No. It is my inclination that it's too early to know whether or not such an ambassador would make an important contribution, or whether it's better to approach it from another point of view, either high or low level, so we have not prejudged it. **********Q. It's been done both ways, obviously. Kissinger and Vance did it; then they switched.  A. One of the outcomes of the Begin visit we hope for is a sharpening of our thinking on that subject. So while I'm getting back to the Begin visit, there will be two aspects of it. **********We would want to discuss the peace process under the Camp David framework and specifically the autonomy talks. Our strong feeling, which is now clearly shared by the other two partners - and we want to be a partner in this effort - is to get on with it and to get on with it rapidly. Regional Security **********Q. You said the first part of the talks with Begin will be on the autonomy.  A. Yes. And the second part, clearly, will be on the Lebanon process, which is far more fragile, far more prone to disruption and mischief making, and far more complex because of multiplicity of interest in parties involved -internal parties in Lebanon, Syria, with whatever degree of mischief the Soviets might or might not care to apply, and the other Arab states that have been involved. **********Q. Will Mr. Habib be here for those talks?  A. Yes. We want Phil here for precisely that reason, and it's clear that his rule of concern is that thus far that this cessation of hostilities not be an umbrella under which the P.L.O. can be further rearmed and strengthened and the Syrian missiles remain untended. **********So it is fragile and they must be reassured, and we must get progress and we must get cooperation from all the parties to get it, and Israel's cooperation is required as well. **********The third thing that this visit will involve, and probably first and foremost the most important thing is a meeting engagement between two leaders who have never met. I suppose I've become increasingly sensitive to the importance of the chemistry of the meeting of leaders. **********Let me add another final point for the Begin meeting that will also be on the agenda, and that's a discussion of the bilateral relationships in the sense of the period ahead in a changing situation - strategic concerns - and whether or not we are going to reaffirm. There's been a lot of rhetoric in the past and I think both sides are interested in putting some meat on the bone for that rhetoric with respect to our bilateral strategic relationship. **********Q. ''Putting some meat on the bone for the rhetoric.'' There's always the constant talk about some kind of defense, mutual security agreement. You're not talking about --A. No. I'm not talking about a treaty or an agreement, but I'm talking about practical cooperation, practical cooperation that will contribute to regional security. **********Q. Will you give me any hint on that? What you mean?  A. That could involve any number of things.  Awacs Discussion **********Q. Where will the Awacs discussion come in on this?  A. The Awacs discussion, I think, will come on probably early in the meeting and be disposed of rapidly. We understand, and I think the President will understand, Israel's natural concerns about any enhancement of Arab capabilities, especially in a neighboring Arab state. **********There's nobody that I think would approach this meeting with a view toward making this a litmus test of future relationships. It cannot be. We are very confident that the position we have taken on Awacs is the correct one. It is in America's strategic interest. It coincides with our regional objectives, and therefore indirectly - although difficult for Israel to accept -we feel it meets their interests as well. **********Q. How would you, just in a nutshell, explain to an Israeli supporter - you will get a chance at this many times in the next few weeks - how it serves Israel's interests? **********A. First and foremost, it brings America' s presence - we've talked about two Israels for some time. Some people have said, ''You are a strategic asset.'' That bothers Israelis. And why does it bother them? Because they've been the bastion, and a rather lonely bastion historically, toward Soviet inroads in the Mi ddle East. **********Historically, the United States has been somewhat less than that, and so in that context this Awacs, the American presence with respect to it - even though being in a sovereign nation -should be operated and owned with sovereignty in mind. It couldn't expect to be otherwise. **********It is a manifestation of, among a number of other steps that we are considering with the R.D.F. (Rapid Deployment Force) and not bases but facilities. That's a very important argument. **********Another very important argument is that it is in Israel's interest for someone else to provide Saudi Arabia with assistance, and we don't think so. **********Thirdly, we think that the operation of the system itself for the foreseeable future, our support will be inherent -maintenance and operation and supply of the system for the life of the system. All of these things, plus operating conditions, which will be explained when the consultation process starts in Congress, are justified that this is the right decision. **********We understand Israel has concerns about it as it is entitled to and which they have a right to express. I think on the American side we have to confine our approach to convincing the Senate that it should not challenge this important initiative taken by the President which could damage his foreign policy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/24/busin.body_text: **********The Consumer Price Index rose 1.2 percent in September. The rate, projected annually, was more than 14 percent, continuing a reversal of the slowing trend registered last spring. The chief impetus came from rising food, transportation, interest and medical costs. (Page 1.) The index in the New York area rose 1.5 percent. (30.) **********The requirement that 1982 cars be equipped with airbags or other automatic crash protection devices was thrown out by the Administration. It said auto makers were planning to meet the requirement with passive belts that would not have been effective.  (1.) **********New car sales by the Big Three dropped 27.6 percent in the middle 10 days of October, the companies said. It was the lowest rate of sales for the period since 1958. G.M.'s sales fell 33.5 percent, Chrysler's 18.5 percent and Ford's 12.2 percent. (29.) **********A key measure of the nation's money supply fell $1.5 billion in the week ended Oct. 14, the Fed reported. Thus, growth of the M-1B measure remains far below the minimum 6 percent target set by the Fed. Short- and long-term interest rates rose slightly. (29.) **********The Government ranked 114 hazardous chemical waste dumps as the worst in the country. The list, prepared by the E.P.A., will be used to disburse Federal money to clean up sites. (1.) Companies **********Government officials expect Chrysler to request the $300 million in loan guarantees still remaining in the $1.5 billion Federal aid package. Such a move, possibly prompted by a cash shortage, would pose a hard choice for the Administration. Chrysler had vowed it would not seek aid beyond the $1.2 billion already extended. (29.) **********Three Pabst officers resigned in a major restructuring program begun by William F. Smith Jr., the company's new chief executive officer. Pabst, the No. 3 brewery, has been losing sales to both Anhe@user-Busch and Miller in recent years. (30.) **********Four oil companies reported lower profits in the thrid quarter: Phillips Petroleum, Pennzoil, Amerada Hess and Tenneco. Burlington Industries said its net in the latest quarter more than quadrupled.  (38.) **********Bass Brothers and Bass Equity have purchased a 4.5 percent interest in Marathon Oil, the companies reported. (30.) International **********More than half the capital of Paribas's Swiss subsidiary has been acquired by a Swiss financial group. This presents France's Government with possible defeat in its bid to take over the foreign operations of Paribas and other concerns through nationalization.  (29.) **********Two days of closed-door talks at Cancun, Mexico, ended with a detailed analysis of world poverty problems, but with no agreement on a strategy for alleviating them (6.) **********Volkswagen said that its chief financial officer had resigned in what is expected to be a major reshuffling of management. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/01/busin.print_headline: Business Conditions; NEW YORK INCOMES UP
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/01/busin.body_text: **********Helped by lower inflation and a general improvement in economic conditions, personal incomes for New York State residents showed renewed strength last year. **********New Yorkers' total personal income grew 11.8 percent in 1980, compared with an 11.5 percent rise nationwide, Rona B. Stein and Mark A. Willis, economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said in the autumn issue of the bank's Quarterly Review. Between 1969 and 1979, New York's average annual gains were significantly below the national average. **********''The fact that New York's total personal income grew faster than the rest of the country last year is terribly encouraging,'' Mr.  Willis said, ''because employment growth in New York State has not been as rapid as in the rest of the country. That suggests the mix of jobs has improved here.'' **********On a per capita basis, the gains were even more impressive. Incomes of New York State residents grew at an 11.9 percent rate last year, up nearly 5 percentage points from the annual average rate of increase between 1969 and 1979, and 1.7 percentage points higher than the 1980 national average. In 1980, per capita incomes in New York averaged $10,260. Nationwide, the total was $9,521. **********Lower local rates of inflation also helped. After a decade when real per capita income in New York grew eight-tenths of a percent a year - or half as rapidly as the national average - prices in New York State last year rose less swiftly than nationwide, and real incomes increased at a faster rate than the national average. **********Using an average of Consumer Price Indexes for the New York City and Buffalo metropolitan areas, the economists said inflation in New York State rose 11.4 percent in 1980, compared with 13.5 percent nationwide. As a result, real incomes among New York State residents rose five-tenths of a percent last year but fell nationwide by 2.9 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.main_headline: POLISH BEST SELLER: HOW TO OUTWIT THE SECRET POLICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.print_headline: POLISH BEST SELLER: HOW TO OUTWIT THE SECRET POLICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/world.body_text: **********The latest best seller in Poland is a 23-page pamphlet that can fit inside a breast pocket, costs the equivalent of 60 cents and contains the kind of information that has never seen print here before. **********It is called ''The Citizen and the Security Services - A Manual of Social Life in the People's Republic of Poland,'' and it carries practical instructions on how to stand up under harassment and interrogation by the secret police. **********The booklet contains such tips as these for political activists: **********- A summons that is not properly filled out in every space can go legally unanswered. **********- Do not respond to informal requests by security police officials for a ''meeting'' because such encounters might lead to entanglement through blackmail. **********- Demand to know the reasons for detention, do not sign anything and send written complaints to the prosecutor. **********- Above all, do not answer questions or provide even seemingly meaningless information because it might be used to break others or to fabricate a case. Police Want Evidence, Not Truth **********''What is important to remember is that interrogators do not care for the truth,'' it says. ''Evidence for an act of accusation does not have to contain a word of truth. Words are the evidence -no matter what words.'' **********The unsigned pamphlet was produced by an underground publishing house and was evidently compiled by people who had frequent dealings with the secret police. It first appeared in September, amid the rush of hopes for political liberalization brought about by the Gdansk strikes in August. It has already gone through three printings. People familiar with its distribution say that boxes of the pamphlets are being sent to small towns and villages throughout the country, where they are rapidly snapped up. **********The book concentrates on techniques used by the secret police to obtain information. But it also outlines sections of the Criminal Code stipulating certain rights accorded suspects and witnesses. Most are unaware of these rights and the police are hardly disposed to inform them. Answering Questions Not Required **********It is possible to cite Article 166, which permits witnesses not to answer questions. The pamphlet says: ''The witness does not have to explain his refusal. It is extremely important to refuse answers because one who is a witness today can be the accused tomorrow and his answers can be used against him. If you are not strong enough to refuse, you can say 'I do not remember.' But this is not a good solution because it gives an opportunity for conversation, which should not be done under any circumstances.'' **********Under Polish law, the book says, persons who are detained are entitled to know the reason. They should demand to know the reason, the pamphlet says, even though they will probably not be told.  ''Sometimes we are told it is because we look like a dangerous criminal,'' it goes on. ''The militia man simply says he was 'told to' or answers 'Do not be so curious or I'll smash your face in.' '' **********The pamphlet paints a dark picture of the operations of the security police, asserting that they try to obtain information through illegal means, including lies, blackmail, threats, slander, force and imprisonment. It counsels a firm refusal to cooperate because any sign of wavering will be seized upon. **********''They are on the lookout for weak people,'' the readers are warned. ''If during the first talk, we do not give a strong 'no,' they begin the telephone calls, the visits at home and at work and the offer of meetings. **********''After a while, we are tired of it and surrender and 'for the sake of peace' agree to sign some sort of a paper, which most often is a promise to remain silent about these talks. Such a document can be easily changed, by cutting out a few words and and piecing them together, and used as blackmail.'' **********The readers are left with a final cautioning message: ''When we are under interrogation we should remember that one day we will be set free and will have to look our friends in the eye.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/24/world.main_headline: AFGHAN WAR ECONOMY: THIN DIETS, FAST FORTUNE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/24/world.print_headline: AFGHAN WAR ECONOMY: THIN DIETS, FAST FORTUNE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/24/world.body_text: **********Considering that a guerrilla war has been raging in Afghanistan for more than three years, the rural economy of the largely isolated desert and mountain settlements has survived with remarkable self-sufficiency. **********During six weeks of traveling in the countryside, most of it far from major roads or towns, this reporter found people living in stark conditions, but there were no signs of hunger or widescale malnutrition. **********Certainly for most of the hardy and poor people of Afghanistan the war has meant a steady, meager diet of bread and tea, often without sugar. For some, willing and eager to run the new risks of conflict, the war has brought relative riches, mostly from an active trade in guns and hashish. **********Many guerrillas talked openly of their bizarre black market collusion with the Soviet and Afghan troops who are their battlefield adversaries. Corrupt quartermasters are reportedly supplying diesel fuel and ammunition to the guerrillas in exchange for cash or hashish. A Boom in Lumbering **********In Paktia Province, a mountainous area, the war has led to a boom in lumbering. Most of the country's mountain slopes have been stripped of cover by generations who relied on wood for cooking and heating, but Paktia still has forests of cedar. Before the war the Government protected these woods but now the foresters are gone and there is no real administration. As a result the local tribes are felling trees with abandon. **********Along the three foot wide tracks that lace through the mountains, trains of camels plod, with each animal carrying two 400-pound logs.  The price paid for each log just over the border in Pakistan is $200, which is a great deal of money in Afghanistan, where the per capita annual income is about $190. **********As in peacetime, much of the economic activity in the rural areas involves subsistence farming. Men often divide their time between their homes and guerrilla groups, while women and young children tend fields and flocks. **********Some guerrillas explained that families were sometimes divided, with one brother taking some of the women to sanctuary in Pakistan, while others either stayed behind or joined the insurgents. There seemed to be some rotation among the men, who at times rested in Pakistan from the battle. Some Rebels Receive Pay **********Within some of the guerrilla groups food, such as it was, and the spoils of battle were distributed in equal shares. Some of the fighters are reported to receive regular pay, but others have only the barest essentials. One group had been forced to sell a rifle to buy food, and a few weeks later, when the unit's commander ordered a chicken killed in honor of the unexpected visit of a journalist, the 15 men who shared the meal said it was the first time they had tasted meat in two weeks. **********In addition to the food and clothes produced for purely local consumption, there is wider trade and commerce, as in the case of the logging in Paktia. In Kandahar, grapes are harvested and dried into raisins and funnelled into urban markets. Fruit and mutton as well as firewood does make its way to Kabul, the capital. **********In the small village shops, there is produce that has obviously come from the cities; drinking glasses from France, ballpoint pens, Russian cigarettes, cookies, rubber slippers and razor blades. Each of the tiny shops, which also sell dates, eggs and watermelon, had the same stock. The unit of exchange everywhere was the afghani, the country's unit of currency. No one would accept dollars, though Pakistani rupees were willingly taken. **********In addition to the sharing and self-sacrifice of the rebels, there is some evidence that guerrilla groups behave like brigands and demand tribute from civilians. Some Reports of Extortion **********There are reports of extortion and some of the guerrillas visited suggested that this might be the work of Government-sponsored provocateurs seeking to discredit the resistance fighters. Other rebels, though, said they had heard of young, undisciplined tribesmen who may have demanded not only food and shelter but actual taxes from villagers. **********Another recent problem described by the guerrillas involved urban merchants who, presumably out of sympathy, supplied food and equipment to the guerrillas at night. The fighters said that some merchants had been telling them that in some cases local Communist officials were keeping close watch on their stocks, demanding day by day accountings. **********Another aspect of the war economy involves the refugees in Pakistan and the amount of support provided to them by international agencies and Islamic groups. Officially, Pakistan and the United Nations High Commission for Refugees put the number of those who have sought sanctuary at close to 2.5 million, but some of the aid officials privately doubt this number. **********Some of these people say that many of the refugees register more members of their family than have actually come to Pakistan, and draw benefits fraudulently. The refugees receive $5 a month per person, with a maximum of $50 per family each month. Abuses Hard to Gauge **********Some people are said to collect this amount while actually spending most of their time in Afghanistan working their farms and coming across regularly to collect their benefits. It is hard to determine how widespread such abuses are and there is no doubt that most of the refugees are in genuine difficulties, living in tents. Some legitimate refugees have been waiting for five months in camps near Quetta for payment of support funds. **********Still, the commander of a guerrilla force in Paktia Province whose wife and children remain in Afghanistan worried that the refugees across the border were being treated too hospitably and might not return to the villages where, he said, they were needed. **********Like other guerrilla leaders, he speculated that Soviet strategy might center on driving as many people out of Afghanistan as possible. Here in Pakistan, there are officials who believe that the Russians would like to set off an outflow of refugees, realizing that a large, demanding population of outsiders could serve to disrupt the Government in Islamabad.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/world.body_text: **********A man arrested Sunday in the abduction of a nine-year-old black child in Beacon, N.Y., will be questioned by Federal agents about any possible link to the case of Atlanta's slain and missing children, a spokesman for the East Fishkill Police Department said last night. **********The suspect, Frankie Edmunds, 32, of St. Albans, Queens, was charged with unlawful imprisonment and endangering the welfare of a minor. Mr. Edmunds, who is black, allegedly grabbed a nine-year-old black youth outside a neighborhood school in the town about 70 miles north of New York City and forced the child into the back of a rented truck. **********Charles Lamb, a spokesman for the East Fishkill police, said that the truck, which had Georgia license plates, had been rented in New York City. **********A spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York declined comment on the report.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/02/busin.body_text: **********Novo Industri, the world's leading producer of enzymes and the second-largest producer of insulin after Eli Lilly & Company, has reported that net income in the first half of 1981 soared 96.8 percent on an increase in sales of 48.7 percent. **********The Copenhagen-based biotechnology concern, which has two subsidiaries in the United States and is about one-third owned by investors in this country, said that earnings in the first half widened to $18.7 million, or 97 cents a share, from $9.5 million, or 55 cents a share, in the first half of 1980. **********Sales increased to $142 million from $95.5 million. **********The company attributed the sharply higher results to significant rises in its pharmaceuticals and enzymes divisions.  Novo said that sales of pharmaceutical bulk products -mainly insulin - more than doubled from the first half of 1980. The strongest gains relative to 1980 were enzyme sales to the starchconversion, alcohol-conversion and dairy industries, the company added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/20/world.main_headline: ALLEN'S JAPANESE FRIEND: ROLE OF GO-BETWEEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/20/world.print_headline: ALLEN'S JAPANESE FRIEND: ROLE OF GO-BETWEEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/20/world.body_text: **********Tamotsu Takase, a business consultant who is a friend of Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, has played a role behind the scenes in trade negotiations between the United States and Japan for more than a decade, according to Japanese Government officials. **********''Takase has occasionally served as a kind of go-between and informal line of communication between Japan and America,'' said a high official in the Ministry of International Trade and Industry who asked not to be identified. **********Mr. Takase's wife, Chizuko, was one of three Japanese women involved in a $1,000 payment received by Mr. Allen after a Japanese magazine interview with Nancy Reagan on Jan. 21 that the White House adviser helped arrange. **********Just what Mr. Takase's role in negotiations has been in specific instances remains unclear. He has sometimes merely been present at meetings between Americans and Japanese, usually meetings that occur outside official negotiating channels. At other times he has apparently served as a messenger. **********Meeting With Toyota Head **********Mr. Allen met in March with Shoichiro Toyoda, head of the Toyota Motor Sales Company, at a time when the Reagan Administration was debating lower import quotas for Japanese cars. Mr. Takase attended that session. **********During last year's Presidential campaign, Mr. Allen was accused of having leaked trade secrets to Mr. Takase while Mr. Allen worked in the Nixon White House. The charges resulted in Mr. Allen's resignation as a Reagan campaign adviser. After Mr. Reagan's victory, Mr. Allen was reinstated as foreign policy adviser after Mr. Reagan said there was no evidence that Mr. Allen had done anything wrong. **********On at least one occasion, Mr. Takase is said to have been a more active figure in negotiations between Tokyo and Washington. In his book ''The White House Years,'' former Secretary of State Henry A.  Kissinger describes his contacts with an unidentified emissary from Japan, who was not a Government official, during negotiations that began in 1969 on reducing Japanese textile exports. **********''It is widely believed that Takase is that man,'' said another official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry official who also asked that his name not be used. Japanese diplomats confirmed that Mr. Takase was the ''back channel'' used by Prime Minister Eisaku Sato to try to resolve the textile issue at frequent meetings with Mr. Kissinger. Tradition of Go-Betweens **********In Japan, there is a long tradition of men such as Mr. Takase, who are sometimes called kuroko, or ''stagehands,'' a term taken from the Kabuki theater. Such people act as intermediaries so that political leaders and their aides do not become personally involved in difficult negotiations. **********The reason for this is that through the use of go-betweens, the leaders may be able to avoid loss of face if negotiations go badly, a paramount consideration in a formal society. **********Mr. Takase, 52 years old, is a professor at Kyoto Industrial University. But his university position is largely a vehicle for a career in business, Japanese diplomats said; it gives Mr. Takase prestige and an impressive calling card. Diplomats said his salary at the university would be insufficient to cover frequent visits to the United States. **********Mr. Takase is ''not a scholar but a businessman,'' said an executive at an international company here who asked that his name not be used. He teaches twice a week at Kyoto Industrial University, where his colleagues include Kei Wakaizumi, who also served as an intermediary for Prime Minister Sato with the Americans in the late 1960's and early 1970's. Outside Activities **********Among his outside activities, Mr. Takase is a director of a Tokyobased consulting and research company called Technova. ''The firm pays a monthly remuneration to the members of the board, including Takase,'' said Toshikazu Kurokawa, general manager of Technova. Mr. Kurokawa did not disclose the amount of the compensation. **********Earlier this month, it was announced that Technova and the Center for Japanese Studies at the University of Michigan would coordinate research for a two-year study of the auto industries in the United States and Japan designed to provide ''a foundation for understanding and cooperation.'' **********The project is being sponsored by major auto makers in the United States and Japan, according to Mr. Kurokawa, who would not estimate its total cost or the amount that Technova is likely to receive. He said the four sponsors were Toyota, Nissan, General Motors and Ford. **********Technova was set up May 1, 1978, with capital of 10 million yen ($43,000). Its 15-member advisory council includes such figures as Saburo Okita, a former Japanese Foreign Minister, and Kenzo Tange, Japan's leading architect. Several prominent professors also serve on the council, but the newly established research group is run by an eight-m@ember board, with Mr. Takase listed in its brochure as senior director, under the president. A Staff of About 20 **********The headquarters of the company is on the 13th floor of a new life insurance building in central Tokyo, and it has a staff of about 20, including the board. The office is spacious and smart. Technova has a branch in Paris but none in the United States. **********Technova has had a close working relationship with the Potomac International Corporation, a Washington-based consulting company that Mr. Allen owned until just before he joined the Reagan White House staff. **********Peter D. Hannaford, who bought the business from Mr. Allen, said in an interview that Mr. Allen, while he headed Potomac International, worked as a consultant for Technova and that the two companies had common clients. One of those clients, Mr. Hannaford said, was the Industrial Research Institute of Tokyo, an organization supported by Japanese utilities and energy companies. **********Mr. Hannaford was an aide to Mr. Reagan when he was Governor of California. **********''Potomac International has no branch in Tokyo,'' said a leading businessman, who asked to remain anonymous. ''Takase at this end is their man, people here believe,'' he said. Ties to Governing Party **********Mr. Takase attended Harvard's Yenching Institute, which specializes in Asian affairs, and then went to the Hoover Institute at Stanford University in 1955. He met Mr. Allen while working in charge of Japanese materials at Hoover, a research institute closely associated with American conservatives. Mr. Allen also worked at the institute in the late 1960's. **********Mr. Takase has depended on close ties to members of the governing Liberal Democratic Party in his work as a consultant. He was originally introduced to Cabinet ministers in the 1960's by Okinori Kaya, a right-wing member of the party, and was later close to members of the Seirankai, an extremist group in the party formed at a blood oath ceremony after the suicide of the novelist Yukio Mishima in 1970. **********Ithiro Nakagawa, currently Minister of Science and Technology, and once a leader of the now disbanded Seirankai, is said to be one of those closest to him in the party. Another associate is Shintaro Ishihara, a former novelist and friend of Mr. Mishima.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/22/busin.print_headline: American Express to Buy Shearson as Takeovers Transform Wall St.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/22/busin.body_text: **********The American Express Company will acquire Shearson Loeb Rhoades, Wall Street's second-largest brokerage firm, for about $915 million in stock, the two companies announced yesterday. **********The resulting company will be one of the giants within a new industry of financial institutions that is transforming Wall Street by offering consumers and businesses a broad range of banking and financial services as well as traditional brokerage activities. **********Responding to the news that American Express had agreed to exchange its shares for Shearson's, Shearson stock jumped $6.38 a share, to $48.63, with 500,000 shares changing hands. As generally happens to the buying company, American Express stock fell. It was down $2.375, to $40.75, on 1.3 million shares. **********The deal came one month after the surprise purchase by the Prudential Insurance Company of America of the Bache Group Inc., another leading Wall Street firm, for $385 million. Shearson, a larger brokerage house, is second only to Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. **********Both purchases are being heralded as the forerunners of a new competitive environment on Wall Street. Even Merrill Lynch is expected to feel the effect of the Bache and Shearson acquisitions because of the strong financial support and entrepreneurial spirit of their new owners. **********Recognizing that likelihood, Roger E. Birk, chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company, the parent of the brokerage firm, remarked, "The strong companies coming in will probably make the financial services business increasingly competitive." He said that the trend "isn't surprising" because other brokers are already "thinking of filling out their hands." **********The growing competition, moreover, is expected to increase the interest of other major corporations in buying brokers, with some of the candidates widely ex-pected to include E.F. Hutton, Dean Witter, Paine Webber and A.G. Edwards. One of the potential buyers, according to Wall Street speculation, is Sears, Roebuck & Company, owner of the Allstate Insurance Company. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/30/busin.body_text: **********The Republican-dominated Senate voted tonight by 64 to 34 to raise the Government's borrowing authority to more than $1 trillion for the first time in history. **********The vote to raise the debt ceiling, to $1,079 bil lion, will allow the Government to start its new fiscal year T hursday with sufficient funds in its coffers to pay its bills. **********Had the Senate missed its deadline of midnight tomorrow, the Treasury would have been unable to borrow money to honor Social Security and Government paychecks as early as next Monday. **********Since the House of Representatives already approved the new limit, the bill now goes to President Reagan for his signature. Amendments Rejected **********Tonight's vote came after the Senate soundly rejected an amendment to restore Presidential impoundment authority, which Congress revoked in 1974. It culminated three days of debate on whether to raise the ceiling from its current level of $985. **********Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, staged a one-man protest against the move, holding the Senate floor in a 16-hour filibuster from last evening until this morning. But his vigil was futile, with the Senate voting by 63 to 33 to kill his amendment, which would have raised the limit only to $995 billion. **********Robert Dole, Republican from Kansas and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, who shepherded the bill through the Senate for the Administration, argued that Senator Proxmire's suggested ceiling ''wouldn't get us through tomorrow.'' **********Senator Dole successfully managed to defeat any moves to amend the legislation; any variation would have sent the bill back to the House for concurrence, risking further delay and possible defeat. **********The only amendment that G.O.P. leaders felt had any chance of passage was offered by Senator William L. Armstrong, Republican from Colorado. It would have given the President authority to withhold funds from Federal programs already approved by Congress, and was defeated by 84 to 15. Such impoundment authority was revoked by Congress in 1974 after what were viewed as abuses by former President Richard M. Nixon. **********The Senate also killed an amendment by Senator J. James Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, that would have delayed the final installment of the 33-month, 23 percent across-the-board cut in individual income tax rates unless the economy improved. The Senate also tabled an amendment by Senator Thomas Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, to repeal tax benefits for oil interests contained in the recently approved tax-cut bill and turn the money over to the financially troubled Social Security system. **********Although the routine increase in the debt ceiling was essential to meet Government obligations already incurred, the vote is traditionally delayed to the 11th hour, with the minority party accusing the party in power of spendthrift ways.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/busin.main_headline: CHAIN DEVELOPS FILM IN AN HOUR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/busin.print_headline: CHAIN DEVELOPS FILM IN AN HOUR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/busin.body_text: **********A 70-year-old bride showed off pictures of her reception before the wedding cake was brought in.  A mother awoke in a hospital room, eager to examine the photographs of her newborn child, snapped by her husband just hours earlier.  A Los Angeles man who evacuated his hillside home as a brush fire encroached, displayed snapshots of the fire to friends before returning to survey his home. **********These southern California residents are not professional photographers. They are, however, among the clients of One Hour Photo Developing Centers, a new chain of laboratories that can process and deliver color prints in an hour. **********Idea Started in Toronto **********The developing centers are owned by a California couple, Dr. Bruce Frome, 42 years old, an anesthesiologist, and his wife, Diane. The idea began when a cousin visited Toronto in November 1979 and saw a photo-finishing machine there deliver finished prints in less than an hour. He told the Fromes about it. They investigated the technology and last March opened their first store. **********''People were amazed,'' said Mrs. Frome, president of the chain.  ''They'd stop and read the signs mouthing the words 'Film developed in an hour.' They thought we must be kidding.'' **********That first store, in Encino, a Los Angeles suburb, cost almost $300,000 to open, which included $150,000 for equipment, $60,000 for the white-and-blue futuristic interior, $55,000 in advertising, $14,000 in inventory, and $8,000 for salary and other expenses. In 60 days, the Fromes say, the store turned a profit. **********The Fromes now operate four stores in southern California; three more are scheduled to open before the end of the year. Franchising Planned **********The Fromes plan to sell franchises for the labs around the country and perhaps even overseas. (Paris and London are favored as initial sites.) Their plans call for 220 outlets to be in operation by the end of 1981. **********For a $300,000 franchise fee, the Fromes will select the site for the store, furnish it, train up to 10 employees, supply the inventory, provide preliminary advertising and put $20,000 in the cash register for the opening day of business. **********The technology of the development process is not new. Two machines developed in the past year by a Japanese manufacturer, Noritsu Koki, can develop 110, 126 and color film in 32 minutes, although the Fromes have allowed an hour to include the handling time of the film. **********The film is placed on 35-millimeter film canisters and fed into a processor, where it is developed in 17 minutes. Then, each negative is individually analyzed to determine the amount of compensation necessary for each print. The pictures are then printed in 11 1/2 minutes by the printer/developer, packaged and delivered to the customer. The labs can develop as many as 50 rolls of film an hour. Method of Analysis Disputed **********The Fromes say their machines produce high-quality prints, as good as if not better than their leading competitors, including Eastman Kodak and the Fotomat Corporation. They stress, for example, the individual analysis performed on each negative. But according to their competitors, computer analysis of negatives rather than hand analysis produces superior prints. **********''There are two ways to analyze negatives - by hand and by machine,'' said Richard Irwin, president of Fotomat. ''We, like other large photo finishers, use automatic printers controlled by computers. The computer analyzes each negative in at least 100 places and then makes a judgment on how to print the negatives.'' **********The Fromes also say that their service is competitive in price.  Their chain charges 29 cents a print plus $1.99 for processing.  Fotomat charges 35 cents a print plus $1.85 for processing, and an additional $1.50 for overnight service. Eastman Kodak charges 23 cents a print and $1.60 for processing. **********Although the new stores do offer the consumer a shorter waiting time, the one-hour photo developing centers are not yet considered a threat by their established competitors, including the Polaroid Corporation, which has been catering directly to the instant-picture market. **********''We haven't noticed, nor do we expect, any effect at all on us,'' said Donald A. Dery, a Polaroid spokesman.  ''They offer a beneficial service to the consumer and that's beneficial to the industry,'' said Tim Elliott, a spokesman for Eastman Kodak at the company's Rochester headquarters. ''We don't expect any significant adverse effect on our business.'' **********The Fromes, however, are banking on consumers who care about getting their film back almost immediately. ''The industry seems to think that people don't care when they get their film back,'' Mrs.  Frome said. ''Well, they've been in the darkroom too long.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/03/busin.body_text: **********Deere & Company, a large manufacturer of farm equipment, diesel engines, transmissions and other major components for tractors and construction equipment, said it will place 800 more employees on indefinite layoff in the next four months as it reduces production of large farm tractors beginning in February. **********About 120 will be laid off at the foundry in East Moline, and the balance will be laid off at Deere's manufacturing complex in Waterloo, Iowa, a Deere spokesman said. **********In addition, the Waterloo operations will be closed for two weeks beginning in March, the company said. **********Of Deere's total work force of slightly more than 15,000, about 1,275 employees currently are on layoff at the Waterloo factories and about 50 at East Moline.
