https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/22/busin.body_text: **********Scott Lancaster Mills Atha, a Los Angeles agency, has been named to the Tyco Industries toy account and has changed its name by adding Jackman in the middle. **********The story behind the new name -Scott Lancaster Jackman Mills Atha -is an interesting one. **********The agency was begun five years ago by four people out of Gumpertz, Bentley, Fried, Scott, where each had worked on Tyco business. **********Their contact at the client company was Robert A. Jackman, the marketing head. When he left to go to Aurora, the agency gave up Tyco and got the Aurora account. **********Kurtz & Tarlow, New York, got the Tyco business.  Mr. Jackman left Aurora and began consulting on adveritsing and marketing in Westport, Conn. One of his clients was Tyco. Another of his clients was S.L.M.A., which acquired the Jackman operation last December. Last week the Kurtz crowd resigned the Tyco account. **********Tyco, out of a total promotion budget of about $8.7 million, probably spends about $3.5 million in media.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Allegheny International and the Sunbeam Corporation announced a definitive merger agreement yesterday, firing the first volley in a bidding war for Sunbeam between Allegheny and IC Industries for one of the world's leading home appliance makers. **********Both bidders were concentrating initially on getting at least half of Sunbeam. IC, in anticipation of Allegheny's entry yesterday, acted a day earlier, sweetening its earlier offer of $32, to $36 a share.  It was the first phase of IC's two-part merger plan that would involve some $480 million in cash and stock. **********Allegheny abruptly bid $38. It was the first phase of Allegheny's two-part merger plan that would involve approximately $521 million in cash and stock. **********The agreement as announced called for Allegheny to make an immediate public offer to pay $38 a share for up to 7.5 million Sunbeam shares. In a merger to come later, Allegheny would swap 36 one-hundredths of a new convertible preferred share for each Sunbeam share. The preferred stock theoretically is valued at $38, but because it yields only 11 1/4 percent interest, it was valued at roughly $31.50 to compensate for the yield. **********IC already owns 681,500 shares, or about 4.5 percent of Sunbeam, and is offering $36 each for 7.25 million shares, which would give it 53 percent. Its merger plan, which remained unchanged, called for a share-for-share stock swap. Although the stock price changes daily, IC rose $1.63 yesterday, to $32, in a move that some analysts said meant that IC's chances of landing Sunbeam had diminished. **********Allegheny's shares fell $2.88, to $36.63 a share, while Sunbeam's advanced $5.13, to $35.13, with more that a million shares changing hands. **********In a related move, intended to strengthen Allegheny's hand, Sunbeam agreed to sell 2.75 million new Sunbeam shares to Allegheny at $36 a share, giving Allegheny what would be 15 1/2 percent of the company after the shares were issued. The agreement -binding on both Sunbeam and Allegheny unless there are antitrust problems - could be construed as a hurdle for IC. Sunbeam's charter provides that at least 75 percent of its shareholders must approve any merger and 15 1/2 percent in Allegheny hands would mean that IC would have to get practically all the remaining votes to win. **********IC said only that it was studying the new development, but it did not appear yet that IC was conceding anything. In what was becoming a kind of chess game between IC and Allegheny, sources close to IC maintained that the battle would be fought over the first 50 percent of Sunbeam and that the bidder with the best price would win. **********This raised the possibility that should IC further sweeten its offer and Allegheny not outbid it, IC might land a big chunk of Sunbeam and Allegheny might be left with just the 15 1/2 percent it contracted to buy. Even so, according to sources close to Allegheny, since Sunbeam's directors serve staggered terms - with just a few being elected every year - even if IC landed a big block of Sunbeam, it would have to wait at least until 1983 to control Sunbeam. **********A hearing had been scheduled in the Federal District Court in Chicago yesterday on a motion by Sunbeam to delay the IC offer, but IC said Sunbeam had requested a postponement. Both sides will convene in court tomorrow to decide whether to reschedule the hearing. **********Until Allegheny's entry, Sunbeam shareholders had until midnight last night to withdraw shares sent to IC, if they wanted to do so, but the new bidder automatically extend's IC's withdrawal date to midnight Oct. 27. **********Documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed that Allegheny has obtained written committments from 13 banks for $490 million on the basis of 90-day unsecured notes. **********Allegheny's $38 offer for 7.5 million Sunbeam shares involves only $285 million, Its agreement to buy stock from Sunbeam would cost $99 million but only 10 percent would be in cash. Even then, should Allegheny land Sunbeam, all of the funds would flow back to Allegheny. **********On the other hand, should IC win, IC would have to buy the shares from Allegheny, thus making the cost at least $100 million higher to Allegheny than to IC. **********As pieced together from a number of sources, nine days after IC first approached Sunbeam, the First Boston Corporation called Robert J. Buckley, chairman of Allegheny, to propose a merger with Sunbeam. **********By Oct. 5, Mr. Buckley met with Sunbeam's chairman, Robert P.  Gwinn, in the offices of Morgan Stanley & Company, Sunbeam's adviser. A few days later, the two talked by phone to discuss the terms. **********It had been agreed in advance that while the two chief executives would discuss the terms, the final offer -when it came - would be made only at Sunbeam's Columbus Day board meeting. Fredlock F. Babb, Allegheny's treasurer, acting on behalf of Mr. Buckley, who he said was away on business, stated that he made the $38-a-share offer personally to Mr. Gwinn outside the board meeting. **********The stakes are also high for the Wall Street advisers, with Lazard Freres to get a $3 million fee if IC wins and First Boston to get $3 million if Allegheny wins. Morgan Stanley, as adviser to Sunbeam, would get at least $2.5 million, regardless of which bidder wins.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/05/busin.body_text: **********By Reuters **********Two months after being acquired by Societe National Elf Aquitaine, the Frenc h st ate-owned oil concern, Texasgulf Corporation said yesterday tha t it had raised the price of sulfur by $10 a ton, to $150, effecti ve immeidately. **********The rise drew immediate criticism by the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, a major consumer of sulfur for its fertilizer operations. **********The Northbrook, Ill., company said it had sent telegrams to about 200 Congressmen and Cabinet officers protesting the increase. **********Elf paid about $2.8 billion in a tender offer last July for all of Texasgulf's stock except a 37 percent stake held by the Canada Development Corporation. Canada Development's shares are to be given to Elf later this month in exchange for the Canadian assets of Texasgulf, based in Stamford, Conn. **********International Minerals said the phosphate fertilizer industry, which uses about 65 percent of the sulfur sold in the United States, is in ''a stifling cost-price squeeze.'' **********It said that phosphate fertilizer producers, currently operating at 75 to 80 percent of capacity, cannot absorb additional cost increases and will have to pass them along to farmers. **********Higher fertilizer costs are likely to result in higher food prices, which Government economists previously have predicted will climb for the rest of 1981, after moderating during the first half of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/15/world.main_headline: U.S. CHALLENGES VISIT BY TOP MILITARY MEN FROM SOUTH AFRICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/15/world.print_headline: U.S. CHALLENGES VISIT BY TOP MILITARY MEN FROM SOUTH AFRICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/15/world.body_text: **********Five senior South African military officers arrived in Washington this week using visas that Reagan Administration officials said they had obtained without having identified themselves as military men. They were to depart tonight after the State Department raised questions about their status. **********The Administration said the five officers had applied for diplomatic visas through the American Embassy in Pretoria under what one official called ''misleading circumstances.'' The South African Foreign Ministry was said to have asked that they be given visas to consult with the South African Embassy in Washington. **********The whole matter is being treated very cautiously by the Administration. A reason for the extreme sensitivity seems to be that many of President Reagan's supporters have advocated a less hostile relationship with South Africa and Mr. Reagan himself has recently made some conciliatory statements about the South African Government. State Dept. Confirms Account **********The following account has been confirmed by the State Department and independently by other Administration officials: Upon arrival in Washington, the officers were said by Administration officials to have met some members of Congress through the auspices of individuals favorable to an improvement in relations between the United States and South Africa. **********One Administration official said that the American Security Council, a private group that espouses conservative views, played a role. It was not possible to reach any officers of that group by telephone this afternoon. **********An appointment was made for the five military officers to meet with a senior State Department official who was not identified, but shortly before they were to arrive at the State Department yesterday, the African Bureau of the department discovered who they were. When they entered the lobby of the department they were told that the appointment had been canceled. **********Subsequently, the department learned that one of the group paid what was described as ''a courtesy call'' on an official at the Defense Intelligence Agency at the Pentagon and on a staff officer at the National Security Council. When the State Department raised the matter of their status with the South African Embassy this morning and asked when they were leaving, it was told that they were leaving tonight to return to South Africa. The embassy had no comment. Some officials were upset at the developments because the South Africans seemed to be trying to initiate contacts through military channels at a time when future policy toward South Africa is one of the most sensitive questions facing the Reagan Administration, given traditional American opposition to South Africa's apartheid, or racial separation. Concern in Washington **********There was concern at the State Department that the visit not be interpreted as having been initiated by Washington. Officials insisted that it had not occurred with the advance knowledge of the Administration. **********But the trip of the five officers occurred at a time when some African specialists have been led to believe that the Reagan Administration intends to take steps to improve ties with the South African Government. The Carter Administration had very chilly relations with South Africa and imposed a total ban on all military sales to that country because of its apartheid policy. **********The Carter Administration was also very concerned about the possibility of South Africa developing nuclear weapons.  James P. Lucier, an aide to Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, arranged a meeting on Capitol Hill for three members of the group with several staff assistants. Mr. Helms did not meet with the South Africans. **********A participant in the meeting said that the officers had told of what they perceived to be a growing Soviet threat to Africa, particuarly in such places as Angola and Namibia, which are of particular concern to South Africa. One staff assistant said that the South Africans met at least one Cabinet member, but he would not identify him. **********President Reagan, in an interview with Walter Cronkite broadcast by CBS News on March 3, said that there had been ''a failure'' in the United States to ''recognize how many people, black and white in South Africa, are trying to remove apartheid and the steps that they've taken and the gains that they've made.'' **********''As long as there's a sincere and honest effort being made, based on our own experience in our own land, it would seem to me that we should be trying to be helpful,'' the President said. **********Mr. Reagan asked: ''Can we abandon a country that has stood beside us in every war we've ever fought, a country that strategically is essential to the free world? It has production of minerals we all must have and so forth?'' **********''I just feel that, myself, that here, if we're going to sit down at a table and negotiate with the Russians, surely we can keep the door open and continue to negotiate with a friendly nation like South Africa,'' he concluded. Preliminary Policy Conclusions **********State Department officials said that while the Reagan Administration had not concluded an overall policy review for southern Africa, of which policy toward South Africa is part, some preliminary conclusions have been reached. **********In essence, the official said, it is that although the United States cannot accept apartheid as such, it is important to approach South Africa from the point of view of ''constructive engagement'' rather than ''confrontation.'' **********But there has been no change in the regulations barring any military sales, officials said.There have been other signs recently that have been interpreted as indicating that the Administration was considering changes. These include the possibility of asking Congress to revoke the amendment barring aid to opposition groups in Angola. **********A key question that has not been answered yet is what approach the United States will take to the effort to bring independence to Namibia, also known by its colonial name of South-West Africa. The United States had been part of a Western effort, working through the United Nations, to bring about South Africa's disengagement from that territory. **********But no developments are expected until after South Africa's elections next month, officials said.  As to the visit of the five military officers, State Department officials expressed some puzzlement. They said they were not sure of the purpose of the mission or why South Africa resorted to misleading efforts to gain entry to the United States. **********''It's not as if we've been trying to stiff-arm South Africa,'' an official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/10/busin.main_headline: The Textile Industry Shakes Itself Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/10/busin.print_headline: The Textile Industry Shakes Itself Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/10/busin.body_text: **********The yarn whips across the Nissan loom 10 times a second, piling up cloth at the rate of 12 inches a minute. A jet of water propels each strand, driving it across the face of the fabric three times faster than the fastest shuttle loom - and far less noisily. It is quiet enough to hear the robots beep as they wheel down the wide aisles, picking up rolls of finished cloth and carting them off to the trucks. **********Experts say that this is the most advanced textile factory anywhere. Opened one and a half years ago by Burlington Industries, the largest textile manufacturer in the world, this $40 million plant contains the latest technology in the industry. It replaces a turn-of-the-century mill down the road, which produced one-fourth as much fabric with the same 800 employees. **********It is on this factory, and others nearly as modern, that the American textile industry is pinning its hopes for survival and future prosperity. **********Progressiveness and prosperity have not been virtues traditionally associated with textiles, especially in this Piedmont country that is the heart of the industry. What has tended to characterize textile manufacturers, rather, are father-and-son management, unimaginative marketing and an anti-union militance made infamous by J.P. Stevens, the second-largest publicly held textile company. Propagated by ''Norma Rae,'' the movie based on the Stevens labor dispute, the industry's reputation for backwardness has clung as persistently as cotton dust. **********Recently, however, the textile business has been undergoing a technological, managerial and marketing revolution. Instead of merely flailing against imports, it is starting to sell goods abroad. It is bringing in professional management. And it is continuing to invest in new technology, with the result that its productivity is outpacing that of United States manufacturing overall. In the 1980's, analysts say, the textile industry should be more competitive and - a quality that has also long been elusive - profitable. **********''They've been through labor problems, government regulations problems, and they've learned to cope with them,'' said Freddie Wood, a senior vice president of Kurt Salmon Associates, an Atlanta-based textile and apparel management consulting firm. ''I'm more bullish on the textile industry than I've been in many years.'' **********But the technology that is increasing productivity and exports, textile executives say, is also spelling the beginning of the end for a number of small companies, which have traditionally been a main part of the textile industry. And in the short term, the industry's prospects inspire less enthusiasm. **********With cutbacks in consumer spending in the United States and Europe, textile mills used only 72 percent of their factory capacity in February, the third straight monthly decline, according to the Johnson Redbook, a research service specializing in apparel, textiles, retail and chemical industries. For 1980, capacity use averaged 77.2 percent, compared with 85.6 percent in 1979. **********Orders for denim and corduroy have dropped the most precipitously, hurting specialty manufacturers such as Cone Mills and Crompton, which had profited from the worldwide jeans craze. **********Nor is it difficult to see new problems ahead. The weak dollar and controlled oil prices, two advantages that American textile manufacturers have historically held over foreign competition, have recently been lost. Apparel imports continue to rise at an alarming rate, reducing sales of United States apparel manufacturers and thus eroding an important market. **********Furthermore, the industry's profitability and return on investment, which have traditionally been well below the average for United States manufacturing, are becoming more critical to its survival, analysts say. Because of the huge sums that it must invest in technology, ''the big problem facing the industry in the 1980's will be the generation of cash flow necessary to stay in business,'' said Jay Meltzer, a textile analyst for Goldman, Sachs. ''Those that don't, will fall by the way.'' **********At Burlington's state-of-the-art plant here, however, it is easy to be optimistic about the future of American textiles. The mill's main product, an all-polyester fabric that is known in the trade as textured woven, buys man-made fiber from Du Pont that is made more cheaply in this country than anywhere else. The fabric can be manufactured at top speeds, wide widths and in long runs, and it is thus the sort of product for which America's textile mills are uniquely equipped. **********Each week, the Rockingham mill weaves 1.8 million yards of this fabric. The cloth sells to such major United States apparel manufacturers as Levi Strauss and Haggar, as well as to foreign customers. Originally, 1,000 people were to be hired to run the mill, 24 hours a day, seven days a week, ''but the technology is so good that we saved 20 percent of the labor,'' said Dale Ormsby, mill manager. Nor was there any labor trouble when the new technology was introduced; like most of the mills, the Burlington plant is not unionized. **********Ironically, Burlington and other big American textile manufacturers owe their dazzling efficiency largely to foreign technology. West German-made Barmag machines, priced at upward of $500,000, process the polyester fiber at a rate of 700 meters every minute -heating it, stretching it and putting in a twist. The yarn it produces is fed into some 700 Japanese-made Nissan looms, costing roughly $36,000 apiece, which weave it into fabric with the help of Staubli warpcontrol machinery from Switzerland. **********According to the American Textile Manufacturers Institute in Washington, approximately half of the fortune spent by the industry on new machinery - this year alone, the industry is investing an estimated $1.6 billion on new plants and equipment - is going abroad. While manufacturers still buy materials handling equipment, compressors, combers and some less sophisticated machinery in the United States, the pride of the mills in the Carolinas these days comes from West Germany, Switzerland, Italy, France, Japan and even Britain. **********Textile manufacturers are going abroad because, they complain, the best technology is not available here at any price. ''In the 1950's, we bought most of our machinery in the United States,'' recalled Duke Kimbrell, president of Parkdale Mills, a $120 million-a-year yarn spinning company based in Gastonia, N.C. ''Then all the manufacturers were bought by conglomerates, stopped doing research and just sold machines.'' **********For his open-end spinning operation (a form of yarn spinning vastly more efficient than the traditional ring spinning), Mr. Kimbrell bought 30 Toyoda frames from Japan. When the yarn breaks, Schlafhorsts, German-made robots, deftly tie the strands together. In the last 16 months, Parkdale has bought eight Schlafhorsts at $386,000 apiece, and has four more on order. ''In cost per pound, we can match anything they're doing in Japan,'' he said. **********Thanks to such investment, the industry's record on productivity is one of the strongest at home and abroad. Despite occasional slumps in actual production during recessions such as in 1975, productivity has been rising at an annual rate of 4 percent for the last 20 years, an economist at the textile institute said. According to a study conducted last year by Werner Management Consultants, the United States textile industry has the highest average productivity for spinning and weaving, by a substantial margin. **********The American companies also have an edge in labor costs. Of the 864,000 workers currently employed in textile manufacturing - down from the 1973 peak of 1 million - fewer than 15 percent are unionized. And despite the much-publicized battle between Stevens and the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, the work force remains relatively docile - and inexpensive. ''The European textile industry is unbelievably mesmerized by social benefits,'' said William Lord 2d, chief executive of Crompton. **********After years of indifference to, or distrust of, overseas markets, American manufacturers of yarn, fabrics and household textiles have begun actively courting foreign buyers. In 1980, they increased their exports by 14 percent, to a record $3.6 billion. That followed a year of even more dramatic growth, when exports rose by 43 percent - admittedly, from a very low base. **********Cannon and Fieldcrest, two leading household textile manufacturers, are selling their high-fashion sheets and towels abroad.  Americanmade rugs and carpets, which took a beating when the United States housing construction went into a slump last year, near doubled their exports, to 75 million square yards. The stylish, relatively inexpensive carpets were snapped up by Canada, Britain and Saudi Arabia, where construction is booming. **********The biggest beneficiaries of the export boom, of course, have been manufacturers of denim and corduroy, where a made-in-America label carries a cachet even if the jeans themselves are manufactured in Hong Kong. Crompton's exports, for example, are now running at about 25 percent of sales - a falloff from their 33 percent mark in 1979, before the European recession. **********Arguably the industry's strongest proponent of exporting, Mr. Lord said that his goal is to sell as much as half of Crompton's production abroad, and he is setting his sights on the Far East.  From its office in Hong Kong, Crompton is trying to peddle its corduroy and velveteen to the same Asian clothing manufacturers who have been overwhelming the American apparel trade. ''Down the road, the business is going to be re-exporting from the Far East to affluent markets, including America and Europe,'' Mr. Lord said.  ''Exporting to Europe is fun, but exporting to the Pacific Basin will be a matter of economic survival.'' **********Even relatively small companies are starting to hustle. In March, about a dozen yarn spinners embarked on their first trade mission to Hong Kong and China. ''There's an awful lot of folks over there to keep clothed,'' said Jim Conner, executive director of the American Yarn Spinners Association in Charlotte, N.C., who organized the expedition. **********Today, there are still an estimated 6,000 separate textile manufacturers in the United States; even Burlington, the giant with sales last year of $2.9 billion, had only 6 percent of the business.  But consolidation, which has been taking place steadily, has been accelerated by the industry's increasing capital-intensiveness. By one estimate, it will force as many as one-third of the companies out of business by 1990. In fact, Robert Coleman, chairman of Riegel and current president of the textile institute, predicts that there will be mergers even among the top 20 textile makers. **********''It takes a lot of money today to buy equipment,'' said Charles McLendon of Burlington, which invested $215 million on new plants and equipment last year and has budgeted more than $200 million for 1981. ''Small companies can still buy used equipment to start up, but that will happen less and less.'' **********The cost of capital is forcing larger companies to rationalize, too. Increasingly, analysts say, they are narrowing their product lines to a handful of areas where they are assured a large market share. ''If the company can't be a major factor, it's choosing to walk away from the business,'' said Jeffrey Edelman, textile analyst for Dean Witter. Frequently, the business being walked away from is apparel textiles, where imports have had their largest impact. In one of its mills, for example, West Point-Pepperell has converted its shirting line to sheets, where the outlook is brighter. **********Such changes have been facilitated by the entry of professional management into an industry once dominated by fathers and sons. In the last two decades, a number of companies - notably Cannon, Cone, Riegel and Springs - have come under professional management, and many that are still family-controlled are paying more attention to M.B.A. techniques. ''They seem to be running their companies better,'' said Mr. Edelman. **********Shake-out and specialization are just what the industry needs, according to Mr. Wood, the management consultant. ''Historically, the industry's basic problem has been overcapacity,'' he said. ''It is shaking down into a rational industry, with a half-dozen companies making towels, a few making denim.'' For the survivors, ''the 1980's will be a much more profitable decade,'' he added. **********Precisely how profitable, however, is hard to predict. One imponderable is the cost to be borne to clear the air of cotton dust, associated with the respiratory ailment, byssinosis. In recent years, manufacturers say, they have been spending up to 25 percent of their capital outlay to comply with Occupational Safety and Health Administration standards. **********Last month, however, O.S.H.A. announced that it had decided to review its standard for protection of workers to determine whether the costs of the rule justified the benefits. While labor groups have protested the decision, industry executives say that they are hopeful for some relief. **********Textile executives caution that the export bubble could be pricked by the resurgence of the dollar and the decontrol of the price of oil, a prime feedstock for synthetic fibers. At Cannon, where exports are targeted to rise by 20 to 25 percent annually for the next three years, ''a stronger dollar could hurt us,'' cautioned Otto Stolz, the company's chairman and president. One of the newer breed of managers, Mr. Stolz, a New Jersey-born former Washington lawyer, is the first outsider to run the company. **********Apart from the denim and corduroy specialty manufacturers, moreover, few companies view exports as more than a bonus or a comfortable buffer against downturns in the domestic market.  Burlington, whose exports are currently running at a respectable 7 percent of total sales, has stated that exports are unlikely to exceed 10 percent of total sales in the future. And even Mr. Lord of Crompton noted that some Asian countries have virtually closed their markets to American imports. ''You can't get a yard of goods into South Korea with a shoehorn,'' he said. **********Some are even more blunt about the possibilities of markets abroad: ''Exports are the big myth of the time,'' said Mr. Edelman.  ''They're not the big savior of the industry.'' **********Apparel imports, meanwhile, grew by 8 percent last year, to 20 percent of all clothing sold in this country. With the entry of China, the industry fears, imports could reach 40 or 50 percent by the end of this century. That is bad news for United States apparel manufacturers and, of course, for the people who sell them their cloth. ''Every time one of our customers goes out of business, that's a sale we've lost forever,'' said Mr. Conner of the yarn spinners association. ''There's no way we can survive without them.'' **********Accordingly, the textile industry has joined apparel makers in clamoring for a more restrictive policy on imports from the low-wage regions, particularly the so-called ''Big Three'': Taiwan, South Korea and Hong Kong. With the present Multi-Fiber Arrangement, the international agreement signed by both importing and exporting nations, expiring at the end of the year, negotiations on the next M.F.A. opened in Geneva last week. The industry is lobbying for an agreement that would limit annual import growth to the growth of the United States market. **********Ultimately, could the textile industry be more directly threatened by imports? ''The import problem is an apparel problem, not a textile problem,'' Mr. Wood said, noting that importers have concentrated on the labor-intensive garment manufacturing. Most analysts and manufacturers, arguing that low-wage manufacturers won't receive an adequate pay-off for such large investment, believe that the American industry will be able to maintain its technological and cost advantage. **********Mr. Stolz of Cannon is less confident. Asia ''can buy those looms in Germany and Switzerland, just as we can,'' he said. ''And they don't need our air-cleaning equipment.'' **********Against that day, he added, he is doing everything to fortify Cannon -strengthening its brand name, improving productivity, increasing exports. ''You've got to do all those things when imports are insignificant,'' he said. ''If Cannon is successful with its program, we should be able to deal with imports when they make a major push.''  TEXTILESAT A GLANCE **********Last year, there were 6,000 companies around the nation with 7,200 plants employing 864,000 people, producing 24 billion square yards of material and racking up total sales of $44.9 billion, according to the American Textile Manufacturers Institute. **********The mills consumed 8.6 billion pounds of man-made fibers, 3 billion pounds of cotton and 1.2 million pounds of wool. Of the finished product, 42 percent went into apparel, 30 percent into home furnishings, 23 percent into industrial and other consumer uses and 5 percent into exports. **********The Southeast is the home for the majority of textile companies, 47 percent of which are in that area. The Mid-Atlantic states account for another 32 percent, with the rest of the industry scattered about the nation. **********The top 10 textile states, in terms of numbers of people employed by the industry are: North Carolina 254,000 South Carolina 142,000 Georgia 116,000 Pennsylvania 51,000 Alabama 44,000 Virginia 44,000 New York 42,000 Massachusetts 28,000 Tennessee 27,000 New Jersey 23,000 The top 10 companies, in terms of 1980 sales, are: Burlington Industries $2,901 million J.P. Stevens $1,916 million West Point-Pepperell $1,246 million Springs Mills$938 million Cone Mills $730 million Cannon Mills $660 million United Merchants and Mfgrs. $622 million M. Lowenstein$620 million Dan River $6.08 million Collins & Aikman $600 million

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/06/busin.main_headline: TRADE DEFICIT WIDENS ON A 'PAYMENTS' BASIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/06/busin.print_headline: TRADE DEFICIT WIDENS ON A 'PAYMENTS' BASIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/06/busin.body_text: **********Despite a reduced volume of oil imports, the nation's merchandise trade deficit grew to $6.99 billion in the second quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today. **********A lower volume of farm-produce exports - coupled with lower prices -helped push the deficit well beyond the first quarter's $4.6 billion for trade on a ''balance of payments'' basis, one of several ways the Government computes the trade balance. **********Another version of the trade balance, released last week, showed a deficit of a little more than $10 billion for the second quarter.  That version is more widely publicized than today's narrower version, which excludes military trade and some insurance and freight costs for imports. **********The value of oil imports rose about 2 percent, to $21.2 billion, with the increase more than accounted for by higher prices, the new report said. **********''The average number of barrels imported daily declined to 6.53 million from 6.59 million, as importers drew down their large inventories,'' it said. A Comparison of Figures **********In all, the new report showed that the value of imports in the quarter increased 2.5 percent, to $67.4 billion. Exports fell 1.2 percent, to $60.4 billion. **********The results, which the Commerce Department adjusted for normal seasonal variations in trade, also were affected by the rising strength of the dollar in relation to many foreign currencies, a development that generally made American exports more expensive and imports cheaper. **********An exception was agricultural exports, which declined 15 percent, to $10.84 billion, in the quarter. The volume of farm exports was down about 10 percent, but lower prices accounted for about one-third of the overall drop, according to the new report. **********''The decline followed an exceptionally strong first quarter and was concentrated in reduced grain and soybean exports to the Soviet Union and Latin America,'' the report said. **********Nonagricultural exports increased about 2 percent, to $49.54 billion, with significant increases reported for civilian aircraft, machinery and auto parts to Canada. Coal exports, affected by the nationwide strike, were down $400 million. Other Categories Noted **********Imports other than oil rose about 3 percent, to $46.2 billion, with major increases in iron and steel, automotive products from Canada and business machines. Food and natural gas imports were down. **********''The increase in automotive imports from Canada occurred despite a sharp decline in sales of domestic autos,'' the report said.  ''United States auto manufacturers have been building up inventories of new subcompact models, some of which are produced in Canada, in preparation for their introduction in the United States,'' it said. **********On a balance-of-payments basis, the deficit for the first half of 1981 stood at a seasonally adjusted $11.59 billion, a bit less than half the $25.34 billion deficit for all of last year. **********By comparison, the trade figures released by the Commerce Department last week showed a first-half deficit of $19.07 billion, a little more than half of 1980's $36.4 billion deficit according to that method of computation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/15/busin.body_text: **********Six of the 13 cases of the challenged advertising claims being investigated by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureau that were resolved in December, were resolved when advertisers either changed the claim or stopped the advertising. Those companies were: American Home Products, for Momentum Tablets; Associated Mills, for Pollenex Dial Shower Massage; Bandai America, for the Hulk and Spiderman Electronic Marvel games; Criterion Manufacturing, for Dynascope RV-6 telescope; Culligan, U.S.A., for the automatic water conditioner, and Schwan's Sales Enterprises, for Tony's Pizza.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/16/world.body_text: **********The euphoria here that followed Ronald Reagan's Presidential victory a year ago has given way to confusion, disappointment and anger. **********Elated at the defeat of Jimmy Carter, Government supporters celebrated with bursts of automatic weapons, fireworks and a marimba band in front of the United States Embassy. **********They blamed Mr. Carter's human rights policy for the leftist revolution that led to the overthrow of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle in Nicaragua and for serious guerrilla threats to the governments here and in El Salvador. **********''There were those who expected guns, helicopters, ammunition on Jan. 21,'' said a civic leader who devotes much time to trying to improve United States-Guatemalan relations. **********But so strained are those relations now that an influential Congressional aide who visited here recently said that he could more easily get appointments with governmnent officials if he did not request them through the United States Embassy. And embassy officials, aware of the Guatemalan Government's sensitivity to foreign criticism, will not discuss the situation except on ''deepest background,'' refusing even to permit attribution to a ''foreign diplomat.'' U.S. Seeks Better Relations **********The Reagan Administration is struggling to improve relations with Guatemala, which is the most populous Central American country and which has turned up evidence of oil fields that could supply 10 percent of the United States needs. **********This year, as a good-will gesture, the Reagan Administration sent military jeeps and trucks and quietly assured the regime that more military aid would be forthcoming if it improved its human rights record. Lieut. Gen. Vernon A. Walters, a former deputy director of Central Intelligence who is now an Ambassador at Large, has been dispatched here twice in the past six months. State Department officials have said that his plea to the Government to end human rights abuses was curtly rejected. **********Also ignored were urgings by the United States that a military man not run for President in the elections scheduled for next March since it would be easier for the United States to send aid to a civilian government. But a coalition of the army and the ruling parties chose as their candidate Gen. Anibal Guevara, who resigned as Minister of Defense to campaign. **********United States economic and military assistance to tiny El Salvador, Guatemala's neighbor to the south, will be about $250 million next year. Guatemala will receive less than $6 million. **********This confuses and angers Guatemalans, who believe that the guerrillas here are being helped by Cuba and present as great a threat to the stability of their country as do those in El Salvador. 'Contradictions' in U.S. Policies **********''There are contradictions in the policies and declarations of Secretary of State Alexander Haig,'' Hector Napoleon Alfaro, a member of the Guatemalan legislature, said in a speech in October. Mr.  Alfaro charged that Mr. Haig applied different criteria to the situation in El Salvador than to that in Guatemala where ''we have not seen any plan of collaboration.'' **********The Reagan Administration has said that it wants to send military aid to Guatemala, but military sales to countries engaged in ''gross and consistent'' violation of human rights are prohibited. **********Amnesty International, the London-based human rights organization, has said that ''a long-established Government program of murder and torture in Guatemala is run from an annex of the National Palace, under the direct control of President Romeo Lucas Garcia.'' **********According to an Evangelical Church leader here, more than 11,000 civilians have been killed this year. Another religious worker put the number of killings at 35 to 40 a day. Entire Indian villages have been wiped out by soldiers taking revenge after guerrilla ambushes. Scores of People Flee **********Figures on the political killings maintained by the State Department are considerably lower - an average of about 300 a month recently - but still high enough for officials to know that any military aid request would not get through Congress. **********Several religious and political leaders here have said that Government persecution is greater in Guatemala than in El Salvador.  Scores of priests and community workers have fled, usually after being warned that their work with the Indians and peasants is supporting the revolution. **********A businesswoman who helps Indians develop markets for their woven goods says that when the Indians come to the capital now they look at the ground and say they know nothing when asked what is happening in the countryside. Priests and businessmen nervously caution a reporter to make all his calls from a public telephone, which they say is more difficult to tap, and not to identify himself or go to their offices. Foreign correspondents cannot enter the country if their names are on a list kept at the airport. **********''We have no options'' in Guatemala, a senior State Department official said several weeks ago. A solution along the lines of El Salvador where, with encouragement from the United States, moderate military offices deposed a rightist dictator then formed a government with civilians was not possible in Guatemala, he explained, because there are not a sufficient number of junior officers disturbed by the practices of the colonels and generals. **********In addition, more than 130 Christian Democratic leaders and active party members have been killed here in the past several years, most of them since the Christian Democrats joined the Government in El Salvador. A former high Government official here charged recently that the Government and right-wing groups had killed moderate politicians precisely so that what has happened in El Salvador could not occur here.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/busin.body_text: **********The chairman of the Braniff International Corporation, John J. Casey, found himself surrounded by controversy today because the airline decided to raise the pay of 864 management-level employees by an average of 11.4 percent. **********The salary increases for supervisory and staff employees were disclosed last week, barely a month after Braniff's 11,500 workers covered by labor union contracts were asked to accept a 10 percent pay cut to help the financially troubled airline survive. **********Some of the company's union employees have bitterly criticized Mr.  Casey.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/11/busin.body_text: **********Pan American World Airways Inc. said that it had completed the sale of its Intercontinental Hotels Corporation subsidiary to Grand Metropolitan Ltd. **********The financially distressed airline holding company had announced on Aug. 21 an agreement to sell its chain of luxury hotels to Grand Metropolitan for $500 million. With the sale of Intercontinental, Pan Am now operates only a contract services business in addition to its airline. Grand Metropolitan, based in London, is a diversified liquor and hotel concern and one of Britain's largest companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/26/busin.main_headline: Advertising; New Push By Allied Chemical
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/26/busin.print_headline: Advertising; New Push By Allied Chemical
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/26/busin.body_text: **********FOLLOWING the lead of many diversified companies that consider themselves not fully understood in the marketplace, the Allied Chemical Corporation has decided to explain itself through corporate advertising. And it has picked Doyle Dane Bernbach as its agency. **********Allied Chemical, formed in 1920, is made up of four operating divisions: chemicals, Union-Tex Petroleum, fibers and plastics, and the Eltra Corporation. Eltra, acquired in 1979, probably needs the most explaining to the business and financial communities, because it has more consumer products than the other three combined, and they are as varied as Prestolite Batteries and Converse sneakers. **********The decision to go the corporate advertising route after all these years was made by David G. Powell, senior vice president, public affairs, who was hired away from Exxon by Edward L. Hennessy Jr., who arrived two years ago as chairman and chief executive from United Technologies. **********''Our perception was that the Allied Chemical Corporation of today was different from what an important part of the public think us to be,'' he explained. **********Consciously avoiding agencies with specific corporate advertising units, Allied screened ''quite a few,'' working with information gathered from ''people with objective points of view,'' Mr. Powell said. The original group was cut ''to a handful.'' No speculative advertising was required. **********''We were looking for an agency with competence in advertising and competence in corporate advertising and one with good creativity, a solid agency and good chemistry,'' he said. **********Now that D.D.B. has been selected, Mr. Powell said, he plans to sit down with its people to decide what what sort of program to plan. He did not think at this point that Allied would be interested in either advocacy or issue advertising. **********Doyle Dane, 12th-largest American agency worldwide, already does corporate advertising for International Business Machines (for television only), General Telephone and Electronics, Bankers Trust and some for Mobil. **********''Good corporate advertising,'' said Paul Paulson, president of D.D.B., New York, ''is no different from any good advertising, in that it delivers something that is in the public's self interest. It shows how the corporation fits into people's lives.'' **********The new client expects to break $5 billion in sales in 1980. It has 10 other ad agencies, including an in-house unit called Merlin Advertising. **********During the 1970's Allied got some exceedingly bad press that culminated with a $15 million Federal pollution fine. But by January 1980, it had improved its operation enough to be called an ''environmental good guy'' on the editorial page of The New York Times. A good start for anyone's image.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/world.main_headline: Riots Erupt in Belfast; Hunger Striker Buried
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Riots Erupt in Belfast; Hunger Striker Buried
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/world.body_text: **********Rioters in Roman Catholic neighborhoods threw bricks, bottles and gasoline bombs at police and troops today after the funeral of Kieran Doherty, the Irish Republican Army member who died Sunday in a hunger strike. **********Security forces retaliated by firing plastic bullets to disperse crowds. **********No casualties were reported. **********Mr. Doherty, 25 years old, died on the 73d day of his fast. He was the eighth hunger striker to starve himself to death in Maze Prison since the protest demanding special privileges for jailed guerrillas started on March 1. **********Fifty miles west of Belfast, one of the guerrillas' latest victims was buried. Two thousand Protestants attended the funeral in Omagh of John Smyth, one of two police officers killed by a land mine in an ambush on Sunday. **********About 8,000 Roman Catholics attended the funeral of Mr. Doherty, far fewer than the crowds that followed the coffins of the first hunger strikers who died in May. Mr. Doherty was buried in Milltown Cemetery here alongside Robert Sands, the first hunger striker to die, and Joseph McDonnell, the fifth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/23/busin.body_text: **********Renewed concerns over interest rates sent stock prices slightly lower yesterday after two major New York banks raised their prime rates to 20 percent, the prevailing level for the industry. Airline issues, however, posted gains following the Government's tentative agreement with air traffic controllers to avert a nationwide strike. **********The prime rate increases were made by Citibank and Chemical Bank, following similar moves to the 20 percent level last Friday by Bankers Trust and Marine Midland, less than a week after the latter two banks had reduced the rate, their basis for loan charges to blueribbon corporate clients. These gyrations, Wall Street analysts noted, have confused investors on the near-term trend of interest rates. **********The Dow Jones industrial average declined 1.99 points, to 994.20.  Trading volume contracted to 41.8 million shares, from Friday's 46.4 million. **********After a number of leading bank stocks sold last week at their highest prices for a year or more, most issues in the group displayed weakness yesterday. On the New York Stock Exchange's active list, Chase Manhattan Bank dropped 2 3/8, to 54. **********A declining prime rate generally is considered bullish for bank issues, since their interest margins - the spreads between cost of funds and yields on earnings assets - tend to widen as rates move lower. The Airline Sector Gains **********In the airline sector, Delta Air Lines rose 1 1/2, to 76 1/4, as the best gainer in the Dow transportation average. Southwest Airlines climbed 1 1/2, to 54 1/4. Last year, this Texas-based carrier sold as low as 11 3/4. **********Trading in Conoco Inc., the nation's ninth-largest oil company, resumed in the afternoon for the first time since Friday, and the stock closed at 58 7/8, up 2 5/8. Conoco had announced the rejection of a proposal by an unidentified ''major foreign corporation'' to purchase about 25 percent of its stock for as much as $2 billion. At the same time, the company disclosed last Friday that it was engaged in preliminary talks with a major corporation, also not identified, toward a merger of that company with Conoco. **********The day's best gainers included Clark Oil and Gas, up 5 1/8, to 31 3/8, and United Guaranty Corporation, up 3 3/8, to 34. The Emory T.  Clark family indicated it was seriously considering the sale of its 41.8 percent holdings in Clark Oil. United Guaranty moved ahead after the American International Group, which already owns about 25 percent of its stock, proposed to acquire the remaining shares.  United Guaranty's subsidiaries write loan guaranty insurance that protects lenders against loss if borrowers default. **********Corning Glass Works, which reported lower quarterly earnings, fell 2 7/8, to 69 5/8.  SmithKline Corporation fell 1 5/8, to 78 1/2, after dropping 3 1/4 points Friday. The Food and Drug Administration has referred to the Justice Department its investigation of the reporting of adverse effects of SmithKline's anti-hypertension drug, Selacryn. Aquitaine of Canada Up **********On the American Stock Exchange, Aquitaine of Canada jumped 6 3/8, to 58. The company attributed this gain to rumors of a possible acquisition of 25 percent of its stock by Petro-Canada or the Nova Corporation. **********Dome Petroleum, the volume leader, rose 3/4, to 19 3/4, amid conjecture concerning its drilling propects in the Beaufort Sea.  The class A shares of The New York Times also were actively traded. The stock finished at 37 1/8, down 1/4. A block of 254,200 shares changed hands at 37 1/2 with Drexel Burnham Lambert as the selling brokerage firm. Salomon Brothers purchased 53,000 shares of this block and Drexel Burnham, in what amounted to a cross transaction, bought the remaining 201,200 shares. Last December Reliance Group reported that it held 700,300 Times A shares, or 6.25 percent. In answer to a question as to whether Reliance was involved in the transaction, Michael Holland, executive vice president for investments of the Reliance Group, said, ''We never comment on trading activities.'' **********The Amex market value index gained 0.99, to 371.60. In over-thecounter trading, Micom Systems fell 1 1/4, to 34 1/4 bid. Its initial public offering was made Friday at $30 a share. The Nasdaq composite index eased 0.96, to 218.60.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/12/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Technology And High P/E's
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/12/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Technology And High P/E's
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/12/busin.body_text: **********WHEN is a high price/earnings multiple justified? Fans of Frequency Electronics say this New Hyde Park, L.I., atomic clock company justifiably carries a multiple of 50 - a multiple higher than that accorded to all but the most promising of companies. **********Two years ago, that multiple would have been absurd since this high-technology company earned modest profits on sophisticated timing devices produced by the handful for the Apollo moon shots and other space programs of the 1960's and 1970's. **********But about a year and a half ago, the Government began specifying ultra-precision timing and frequency control devices for encoded military communications, for navigation and for guidance systems.  Frequency Electronics, a leader in these fields, began to experience a sales bonanza. **********At $14.2 million, sales in the fiscal year ended April 30 were up more than 50 percent from the $9.3 million reported in the prior fiscal year. Meantime, income nearly tripled, reaching $2.2 million, up from $784,000. Even adjusting for an additional 500,000 shares offered to the public last November (adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in April) that raised capitalization to 2.4 million shares, earnings per share were up 130 percent. **********But the skeptical, viewing the stock at 49 on earnings of 90 cents a share, might think Frequency Electronics to be a short sale. And there is evidence from the floor of the American Stock Exchange that short sellers are becoming active in the stock. **********Frequency Electronics is moving into a larger plant in Mitchell Field, L.I., next December, which will increase the company's shipping capacity to $125 million a year, up from $25 million now.  Presumably, it will be years before Frequency Electronics reaches that sales level. **********Speaking generally with regard to rapidly growing young companies, analysts are quick to point out that problems often develop at some point - usually at around the $100 million sales level. **********Further, Frequency Electronics shares have experienced a two-and-ahalf-fold price increase in four months and could fall prey to profit-taking. **********The shareholders experienced dilution again in June when the company offered 334,000 new shares at 40, raising capitalization to almost 2.9 million shares. **********The skeptics also note that, with a total market capitalizaiton of $145 million - 10 times sales -there is not much room for such disappointments as a lag in earnings. **********In any event, there are two major reports out on the stock that find the shares attractive at current levels. One is by Stanley J.  Goldring, who follows the company for Advest Inc., a New York Stock Exchange member firm. **********Mr. Goldring notes that Frequency Electronics controls the market for military ultra-precision time and frequency control devices since Hewlett-Packard, the company's major competition, has withdrawn from that sector of the market. **********Frequency Electronics products are quartz crystal and cesium beam atomic clocks - timing devices with accuracies up to 10-billionth of a second. The devices allow a navigator to determine position with heretofore unattainable accuracy. In a different form, they allow military cryptographers to divide speech into minute portions for encoded communication. **********The company serves three major military programs. The first is Navstar, which, in Defense Department planning, is called the non-Communist world's military navigation system for the 1980's and 1990's. **********The second is the The Tiger secured digital multiplex communication system, which provides nonvoice data transmission capability for satellite and military uses. The third major military application is quartz crystal oscillators for tail warning radar systems on fighter aircraft. **********Mr. Goldring has written that sales of these three programs could reach $2.5 billion to $3 billion by mid-decade, up from $150 million today. He argues that these are high-priority items that would not be affected by defense cutbacks mandated by Congress or under a different national Administration. **********The analyst adds that the company should not need additional capital since Government prepayments provide 85 percent of its working capital needs. The company is debt-free and has $17 million in cash. **********He is expecting Frequency Electronics earnings to nearly double in the fiscal year that began May 1, 1981, to $1.75 a share on $25 million in sales. He expects the company to maintain a 100 percent earnings growth rate for several years to come and to earn $10 to $15 a share by 1985-86. **********Michael Carstens, who follows the company for A.G. Becker & Company, believes that Frequency Electronics is ''uniquely situated'' to benefit from an expected tenfold to twentyfold expansion of the high precision frequency and time control device market over the next five to six years. **********If the analysts are correct, the current price-earnings ratio will drop dramatically in just a few short years if the share price holds steady.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/10/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan's senior economic advisers have warned him that continuing high interest rates could cut deeply into the economy across a broad front, weakening the economic expansion forecast for 1982 and driving unemployment higher. **********At a White House meeting yesterday with Cabinet-rank officials, Mr. Reagan was told that unless interest rates came down soon, there could be pronounced softening of business investment plans and business inventories. The weakness in auto sales and house buying caused by high interest rates could spread to other consumer durable goods, the advisers said. **********Administration officials reported the essence of the appraisal as part of a White House drive to prepare Congress for more cuts in the budget, including military spending. **********Dismayed and frustrated by the continuous rise of interest rates in recent weeks despite slower inflation and deep budget cuts by Congress, David A. Stockman, the budget director, and other senior aides have concluded that the Government - White House and Congress - must make an even greater show of willingness to tighten spending and hold down the budget deficit. **********As politically risky as this may be for Mr. Reagan and Republican hopes of winning control of the House in 1982, the President's advisers have concluded that there is nothing else to do. 'Time Is Now' **********The new emphasis on interest rates was reflected in remarks by two senior Congressional leaders who conferred with Mr. Reagan at the White House yesterday. Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the Senate majority leader, said, ''The time is now to address the high interest rates and get them down.'' **********Chastising the financial community, Senator Baker said, ''It's time they pulled their oar.'' Consequently, the aides said, the persistence of high interest rates for a few more weeks could hold back the surge in business investment in 1982 that was expected to result from the more generous investment write-offs authorized in the 1981 tax bill. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/27/busin.main_headline: HOW PAMELS MASON IS RATTLING BRITISH WOOL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/27/busin.print_headline: HOW PAMELS MASON IS RATTLING BRITISH WOOL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/27/busin.body_text: **********A STRONG-WILLED heiress, an ailing company, a tradition-bound milltown: It's a setting that is supposed to happen only in the movies. But lately, real-life Hollywood has been intruding on the largest manufacturer of wool textiles in Britain. **********The company, Illingworth, Morris, produces some of the world's best-known names in textiles, such as Huddersfield worsteds and Scottish Crombie wool for overcoats. It also makes the covering for Dunlop tennis balls, lining for Rolls-Royces, and cloth for papal vestments and the uniforms of guards at Buckingham Palace. Its roots run deep in the rich history of one of this country's bedrock industries -the company's headquarters enjoin a 125-year-old mill in this town about 200 miles north of London. **********But Illingworth's most powerful shareholder is Pamela Mason, a 58-year-old television talk show personality, denizen of Beverly Hills and ex-wife of film star James Mason. As executor of her father's estate, she effectively has a controlling interest. Her son, Morgan Mason, 25, who has been active as a fund raiser for the Presidential campaign of fellow Californian Ronald Reagan, is on the board. **********Under the suddenly active direction of Mrs. Mason, Illingworth has recently been acting out of character. At the annual meeting last September, she abruptly dismissed the company's long-time auditors, investment bankers and stockbrokers, and appointed to the board a fellow expatriate, Thomas Yeardye, a former executive of Vidal Sassoon, a maker of cosmetics and owner of a chain of hair dresser salons. **********''I want to get this company off its butt,'' Mrs. Mason said at the time, adding recently that the company ''needed to consolidate manufacturing and look for new markets.'' **********For Illingworth, that has mainly meant moving into the United States. In March, it set up a company under New York designer Leon Block to manufacture women's wear there from top-quality Illingworth textiles. Nancy Reagan, wife of the Presidential candidate, has already bought 10 of the suits, which retail for about $400 each.  Illingworth expects to set up another company by year-end and also has acquisition plans. **********Such sudden moves, after years of quiescence, have surprised Illingworth's rivals as well as financial analysts. Some applaud Mrs. Mason for making the company more aggressive, but some doubt that Mr. Yeardye and Mr. Mason are the right men for the job. Others are even more skeptical. ''Illingworth's management clearly needs a bomb behind them,'' said David Buck, of Laing & Cruickshank, a stock brokerage firm in London. ''But I'm not sure that Mrs. Mason is the right kind of bomb.'' **********Although Mrs. Mason inherited control of the company when her father and uncle died in 1976, what provoked her recent interest was a blot of red ink on the company's balance sheet last fiscal year. In the year ended March 31, Illingworth lost $3.2 million on sales that declined 9 percent, to $238 million, which compared with an aftertax profit of $5.8 million in fiscal 1979 - itself a 13 percent decline from the previous fiscal year. **********Illingworth is not the only British wool textile company in distress. The industry is still Britain's sixth-largest exporter, having sold $912 million worth of goods abroad last year of its total production of $2.8 billion. But it has been in steady decline since World War II, and the downturn has accelerated in the last five years. **********Compounding the problems of the strong pound, soaring inflation and high interest rates, which make British goods less competitive on the world market and are afflicting most industries here, a handful of other factors are bringing Britain's wool textile manufacturers to their knees. The important Iranian market, a particularly large consumer of British wool textiles before the Islamic revolution, has collapsed, and the attractive United States market has been virtually closed to foreign manufacturers through a prohibitive 50 percent tariff on wool and worsted fabrics. **********At home, top-quality British suits have been shouldered aside by Italian imports, generally rated superior in design - although companies here charge that the Italians' major advantage is their evasion of some taxes and their failure to pay certain employee benefits. The lower end of the market is also being flooded with European imports, many of which, British manufacturers charge, are actually made in East Germany, Poland and other Communist-bloc countries. **********As a result, companies in West Yorkshire - the heart of the British wool textile trade - are closing mills and laying off workers at an unprecedented rate. Since the start of this year, employment has plummeted by 6,000, to 64,000, and is expected to continue to fall.  The National Union of Dyers, Bleachers and Textile Workers, which has accepted the job cuts with relative docility, has predicted that the industry may disappear within two years unless it is nationalized.  Employers are scarcely less pessimistic. ''It's a back-to-the-wall situation,'' admitted Peter Richardson, of the Confederation of British Wool Textiles, an industry trade association. **********The recession could not have come at a worse time for Illingworth, which had embarked on a long-overdue reorganization following the deaths of Isidore (Mrs. Mason's father) and Maurice Ostrer. The brothers, who acquired a majority stake in the company during the 1940's, had spent their last years in the south of France. ''Isidore used to meet the board at Claridge's,'' recalled Peter Hardy, the company's joint chief executive for wool and worsted manufacturing. **********Directors remember that he used to instruct them to order the lamb cutlets at the London hotel's restaurant and to avoid white sugar. He also instructed them to buy companies, lots of them, and to finance them with short-term bank loans that now total some $56 million. **********With Mrs. Mason's go-ahead, Mr. Hardy and Donald Hanson, the joint chief executive for raw material-to-yarn production, are now whittling away at Illingworth's empire and its large debt. In the past 15 months, they have shut down five mills, trimmed operations in others and cut employment by 2,000 jobs, to 7,000. ''Our first priority is to get our house in order here,'' said Mr. Hardy. **********In the company's new Los Angeles office, meanwhile, the California branch of the board is laying the groundwork for expansion into the United States. ''Our long-range plans are mainly into America,'' said Mr. Yeardye during a visit to London last month. Although exports to the United States contributed a modest $3.5 million to Illingworth revenue last year, Mr. Yeardye said that ''we'd like it to account ultimately for half of our overseas sales.'' **********Already in the planning stages, according to management, is a United States factory that would weave cloth from Illingworth yarn. A men's wear manufacturer that would use imported Illingworth cloth is also contemplated. **********By setting up its own United States sales network - thus avoiding agents' commissions - and importing lower-duty yarn rather than cloth for use in its own United States factory, Mr. Yeardye maintained, Illingworth would be able to leap the tariff hurdle that has caused problems for its competitors. Nor would Illingworth's huge debt be an obstacle, according to Morgan Mason, who, after an extended absence from the board - ''He came to Shipley for a few days and then disappeared to Malibu for a year,'' grumbled a former Illingworth executive -has plunged full time into the company's United States affairs. **********''I'm up to my ears in banks and insurance companies to refinance Illingworth,'' he said in a telephone interview. He predicted that he could put together a consortium of 10 banks to furnish working capital as well as cash for takeovers. **********The company's other directors are less enthusiastic about United States expansion. ''There's no fundamental disagreement,'' insisted Mr. Hardy. ''It's just a question of timing.'' According to an industry analyst, however, the plans have produced ''a complete divergence on the board. Yeardye's off paddling his own canoe, while the other directors have to cope with the real problems,'' he said. **********Analysts are dubious about the odds for success in the United States. ''How can you sell to the U.S. with a 50 percent tariff anyway?'' asked Donald Anderson, of Vivian Gray, a London stock broker. ''They're concentrating on the U.S. because they live there.'' **********''A lot of U.K. weavers have burned their fingers in downstream activities, such as manufacturing garmets, to use up their cloth,'' observed Mr. Buck, of Laing & Cruickshank. ''If Illingworth textiles are not competitive, a U.S. company won't do them any good.'' **********But Mrs. Mason does not share such doubts. ''There is a market for British wool wherever there is money,'' she said.  Rival manufacturers also question the qualifications of Mr.  Yeardye, who oversaw Sassoon salons in the United States, and the young Mr. Mason, a graduate of Beverly Hills High School who was once the program coordinator of the ''Tonight Show.'' ''You can't suddenly jump into the textile business and make snap decisions,'' declared a top executive of a major British textile company. ''Those guys are acting like two kids in a candy shop.'' **********But Mrs. Mason is quick to back up her selection of Mr. Yeardye, noting that he had been in charge of selling Sassoon salon franchises around the world. ''Selling is selling,'' she said. **********Her son displays a similar confidence, asserting that he is no newcomer to the business. ''My father is from Huddersfield and my grandfather was a textile merchant,'' he said. ''My family is as well steeped in the industry as any in Britain.'' As American residents, he added, ''we probably know the U.S. market better than most British textile manufacturers.'' **********Thanks in part to its large payroll cuts and mill closures last year, Illingworth is expected to edge back into profit in 1981. But few analysts are optimistic about its long-term prospects. ''What Mrs. Mason wants to do could be good for the company, but she hasn't got the right men in Yeardye and Morgan,'' said the former Illingworth executive. ''On the other hand, the company has foundered for so long that it becomes very difficult to know whether they or Illingworth are out of step.''
