https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/23/busin.body_text: **********The General Electric Company said it plans to close its 77-year-old flat iron plant here, putting about 1,000 employees out of work, because it is phasing out its metal irons in favor of plastic bodied irons. **********Plant workers were told that G.E. will halt production in the United States of metal irons and close the plant, about 45 miles east of Los Angeles, by next February. **********No attempts are being made to convert the plant to the production of plastic irons, which company officials said would take 18 months to two years. A G.E. spokesman, Al Kennel, said American consumers prefer plastic irons, and metal ones produced in Mexico and Brazil will be for customers in those and other South American countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/01/busin.body_text: **********In a ruling hailed today by the railroad industry, the Interstate Commerce Commission has decided that the nation's railroads can raise rates, if they wish, so that they can earn a return on their investment equal to the current cost of capital. **********Under the ruling, the railroads this year, if they so desired, could raise rates to earn revenue equal to 11.7 percent of their investment. **********By contrast, the actual average rate of return is less than 3 percent, according to industry figures, and the commission found that only three relatively small railroads now earned a rate of return of 11.7 percent or more on their investment. **********The effect of yesterday's ruling is that almost all railroads, which gained the power last year to raise rates yearly until 1984 within a range established by the Staggers Rail Act, will be able to continue to exercise rate freedom if earnings do not exceed the threshold set by the I.C.C. The I.C.C. ruling yesterday implements the Staggers deregulation act. **********The three railroads that met or exceeded the 11.7 percent return were the Fort Worth & Denver, a subsidiary of the Burlington Northern, and two lines owned by United States Steel, the Bessamer & Lake Erie and the Elgin, Joliet & Eastern. **********''The ruling is very important to the industry,'' said Richard E.  Briggs, executive vice president of the Association of American Railroads. ''Its full effect will not be realized for several years as we get into deregulating somewhat further, but it is a very sound beginning.'' The association is the chief trade group here for the nation's major railroads. Commission's Position **********''Railroads can obtain funds for investment only by offering rates of return comparable to other investment opportunities,'' the commission said in its ruling yesterday. ''Otherwise, investors will elect to invest their funds elsewhere. If railroads earn less than adequate rates of return because of inappropriate regulatory action, rather than because they are not providing a desired service, then the standards of the Rail Act and the clear thrust of Congressional policy will be thwarted.'' **********While praising the move of the commission as a step in the right direction, securities analysts were doubtful that the 11.7 percent return - if it was to be accomplished by railroads - would be adequate to make the companies comparable in financial performance to other industries. The acceptable rate of return, which will be recalculated yearly, may be higher in the future, they agreed. **********''The 11.7 percent does not match the current cost of capital, either debt or equity, but we are glad to see them moving in that direction,'' said Henry Livingston of Kidder, Peabody in New York City. Analyst Lauds Move **********Robert Long of First Boston, also in New York, said that the commission action was a ''positive event,'' but observed that most railroads ''are very far below the threshold that the agency has established.'' **********Mr. Long said that other future actions by the commission, such as decisions on new coal rates or exemptions of certain sectors of the railroad industry entirely from regulation, would be more important.  ''The exemption of piggyback traffic from regulations, done recently, was very important,'' he said. **********By comparison with the 11.7 percent rate of return that the commission found acceptable, some major roads, based on 1979 data, showed results as follows: Union Pacific, 7.4 percent; Southern System, 9.1; Seaboard Coast Line, 7.2; Chesapeake & Ohio, 4.6; Burlington Northern, 4.1, and Conrail, because it makes no profits, 0.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/03/world.main_headline: ALGERIAN ENVOYS RETURN TO TEHERAN WITH NEW U.S. OFFERS ON HOSTAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/03/world.print_headline: ALGERIAN ENVOYS RETURN TO TEHERAN WITH NEW U.S. OFFERS ON HOSTAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/03/world.body_text: **********The Algerian intermediaries returned here today with the latest United States proposals and terms for the release of the 52 American hostages. **********The three intermediaries - the Ambassador to Washington, Redha Malek; the Ambassador to Teheran, Abdelkarim Gheraieb, and the director of the Algerian Central Bank, Mohammed Seghier Mostefai - arrived at Mehrabad Airport by special plane this morning, after four days of talks in Washington. They were met at the airport by Ahmad Azizi, the Government's Director of Hostage Affairs. **********There was no official comment from the Iranians, although they were presumably given the United States position paper. Friday is the Moslem Sabbath and all Government offices were closed. **********The Algerian diplomats, who have maintained a steadfast public silence, retired to their rooms in the old Hilton Hotel in northern Teheran. General Agreement on Terms **********Iran and the United States have apparently reached general agreement on the terms for the release of the hostages but are bogged down in the mechanism for carrying them out. **********The key factors are money and the possession of the hostages - when the Iranians will receive the assets frozen by the United States, how much they can put their hands on immediately and when the hostages will be set free. **********The proposal brought here today is reported to have called for the deposit of $5 billion to $6 billion - the amount of Iranian assets relatively unencumbered by lawsuits in the United States - in the Algerian Central Bank. **********The Iranians are to take possession of the money when the hostages are released. The rest of the assets are to be released as claims against them are processed by an international arbitration panel. The value of the frozen assets has been estimated at up to $14 billion. **********The proposal also serves notice that an agreement must be reached within two weeks if the situation is to be resolved by the Carter Administration. **********Otherwise, the notice seems to imply, the administration of President-elect Ronald Reagan will begin with a clean slate. Although Mr. Reagan has refrained from involvement in the negotiations before he takes office, in recent days he has described the Iranian conditions as ''ransom'' demanded by ''barbarians,'' remarks that have caused considerable stir here. **********On Nov. 2 the Iranian Parliament laid down four conditions for the release of the hostages: a pledge by the United States not to interfere in Iran's internal affairs, the return of the assets that were frozen after the United States Embassy was seized in November 1979, the dropping of court suits by American companies and individuals and the return to Iran of the late Shah's wealth. Agreement on Most Demands **********The initial American response of last month, along with a later clarification, were released by the Iranians and then by the State Deptartment and indicated that the United States had agreed to all or most of the Iranian demands. **********The initial response and the clarification said the United States would formally promise not to interfere in Iranian affairs, to unfreeze the assets and revoke all economic and financial sanctions, to ''cancel and nullify'' legal claims and to freeze, help identify and assist in court cases aimed at recovering portions of the wealth of the late Shah and his family that were still in America. **********The Minister of State for Executive Affairs, Behzad Nabavi, one of the key Iranian officials involved in the negotiations, described the terms of the American response as ''generally acceptable.'' **********However, the Iranians, in their response to the United States on Dec. 21, put a $24 billion price tag on carrying out the conditions.  They demanded that the United States put that sum, which included $10 billion as a security for the recovery of portions of the Pahlevi family fortune, in the Central Bank of Algeria as a ''guarantee'' against the return of what they regarded as Iran's money. Deep Distrust for Great Satan **********The $24 billion plan seemed largely to be an expression of the deep distrust the revolutionaries feel for the United States, which they call the Great Satan. It was suggested, said the Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, ''so you don't swindle us.'' **********American officials immediately said that the new proposal was impossible to carry out.  Then Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai summoned the heads of diplomatic missions to an extraordinary session last Saturday evening at which he made another proposal: the United States should return everything that could be documented as belonging to Iran, and the rest would be decided by binding arbitration. Meanwhile, the hostages would stay in Iran. **********Otherwise, Mr. Rajai said, after lengthy denunciations of the United States, ''the heroic nation is ready for martyrdom.'' Not much more has been heard of the Prime Minister's proposal, which carried no dollar figure but appeared to be an indication that Iran wnated to keep a flexible bargaining position. Latitude in Settling Mechanics **********Iranian officials have emphasized in the last few days that, within the context of the conditions set down by Parliament, Mr. Rajai, Mr.  Nabavi and the others are to have latitude in settling the mechanics of the agreement. **********The adherents of the Islamic Republican Party, who dominate Parliament and have effectively controlled the fate of the hostages all along, now appear eager for a settlement of the issue. **********Among the pressures mitigating for a settlement is the financial crunch caused by the border war with Iraq, the destruction of oilproducing facilities during the fighting, and the cumulative effect of the economic sanctions imposed after the seizure of the embassy. **********But the religious fundamentalists, having used the hostage issue as a weapon to undercut the liberals around President Abolhassan BaniSadr, risk being put in a difficult political position if, after morethan a year of flaming oratory, they are seen to be compromising with the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Despite the Government's partial shutdown, the Securities and Exchange Commission will continue to process registration statements relating to new issues of corporate securities, an S.E.C. spokesman said yesterday. **********A curb on nonessential Government activities while Congress and the President seek an agreement on spending plans aroused fears in the corporate bond market that the commission would be unable to process registration statements of companies that have been rushing to sell notes and bonds. **********Last week more than $4 billion of corporate notes and bonds were sold. **********Andrew Rothman, spokesman for the commission, said it was continuing to process registration statements because orderly handling of corporate issues is necessary to preserve stability in the money and banking markets. But he added, ''It is unclear how long we will continue to process applications received after last Saturday.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/busin.body_text: **********Steelworkers at the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant will vote later this week on whether to accept a pay cut to save about 3,200 jobs, an official of the United Automobile Workers union said today. **********U.A.W. and Ford negotiators reached tentative agreement over the weekend to reduce the incentive pay that about 5,200 steelworkers get for increased productivity, Mike Rinaldi, president of Local 600, said. **********Ford had threatened to lay off 560 workers at the mill on April 1 and a total of 3,200 by June 1 if the union did not accept the cut, Mr. Rinaldi said. He said a ratification vote was expected toward the end of this week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/25/busin.body_text: **********The Auto-Train Corporation, the bankrupt transporter of vacationers and their cars to Florida, has run out of funds and will cease operations next Thursday, the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed today. **********With about $24 million in debts and assets that amount to no more than $4 million, Auto-Train succumbed to its financial problems today in a bankruptcy court after nearly 10 years of operation. **********Auto-Train carries passengers and their automobiles between Lorton, Va., outside Washington, and Sanford, Fla., in the central part of the state. The service had been marketed as a worry-free, energyefficient way to travel, especially for people who planned to spend a month or more in Florida, and in its first years it was a resounding financial success. **********Attractive Discounts a Lure **********In recent years, however, airlines and car rental companies have been providing attractive discounts that lured customers away from Auto-Train. **********Five years ago, when the company first began to operate in the red, its founder, Eugene Kerik Garfield, searched the United States and Europe for financing to stay afloat. Meanwhile, the company became embroiled in a dispute with the I.C.C. over assertions by customers that Auto-Train would not refund advance payments when they canceled trips. **********Then, the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad Company, which provided Auto-Train with rail lines, complained that it was not being paid on a timely basis. Finally, last September, the company filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws, which allowed it to continue operating while it sought to clear up its debts and restore its operations. Mr. Garfield was subsequently dismissed from his post of president. Many Face Loss of Money **********The Auto-Train shutdown next week after the departure of trains on Thursday from both of its terminals is expected to force many of those who expected to return from Florida with Auto-Train to drive their cars north or spend additional funds to have their cars driven home or transported by auto trucking concerns. Many face the loss of the money they paid Auto-Train for the return trip. **********Daniel Linhardt, an I.C.C. official, said that Auto-Train was barred from accepting any advance payments for trips after next Thursday, but it was unclear when refunds would be made to those who had already paid for tickets after the closing date. **********''We tried to get those people pushed ahead as first priority creditors, as an administrative expense, but it is not clear that it will happen,'' Mr. Linhardt said. ''We will try our best to help people recover their funds.'' **********Tom Tucker, a public relations consultant for Auto-Train, disagreed with Mr. Linhardt and said the company regarded customers who were to travel after next Friday to be ''at the head of the line - especially those who paid by credit card.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/25/busin.print_headline: Business People; Management Realigned At Towers, Perrin Firm
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/25/busin.body_text: **********Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby, which was founded as an employee-benefits consulting firm but has since expanded into human resources, insurance and general management consulting, has a new top management lineup. James B. Kielley, 50, has been elected president, succeeding Quentin I. Smith Jr., 53, who was named to the vacant post of chairman while continuing as chief executive officer. **********Bernard D. Berry, 52, was appointed vice chairman. **********''Employee benefits and human resources are particularly strong because they tend to be less affected by business conditions,'' Mr.  Kielley said from his New York office. ''General management consulting, which is more affected by general business conditions and is a bit more cyclical, is not as strong.'' **********Mr. Kielley began at Citibank in 1953 and joined Towers Perrin four years later in its Philadelphia office. He has been an executive vice president since 1974. **********Mr. Smith was associated with Johnson & Higgins and the Prudential Insurance Company of America before coming to Towers Perrin in 1957.  He became executive vice president in 1969, president two years later and chief executive the following year. **********Mr. Berry has worked only for Towers Perrin, starting in 1956 and rising to executive vice president four years ago. In addition to his new post, he will continue as managing director of the concern's reinsurance operations. **********''The consulting business is a competitive business and the areas in which we've picked to operate are some of the more competitive ones,'' Mr. Kielley asserted. ''We try to emphasize that we're spending money on computerization and research and that it's not just the consultants you're dealing with, but the whole backup.'' Leonard Sloane

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/22/world.main_headline: U.S. CANCELS VISA OF ULSTER ACTIVIST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/22/world.print_headline: U.S. CANCELS VISA OF ULSTER ACTIVIST
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/22/world.body_text: **********The State Department said today that it had invalidated a visa held by the Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Protestant political leader from Northern Ireland. **********A department spokesman said the decision had been made because of growing concern in the United States over the ''divisive'' nature of Mr. Paisley's public comments. ''Mr. Paisley's presence in the United States is prejudicial to U.S. public interests,'' Dean Fischer, the spokesman, said. **********Mr. Paisley, leader of Ulster's militant Protestant Democratic Unionist Party and a member of both the British and European Parliaments, was scheduled to make a speaking and fund-raising tour of the United States from Jan. 15 to Jan. 28. **********The plans of the Ulster Protestant leader, who held a four-year multiple-entry visa issued in September 1980, had prompted a letter of protest to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. from 126 members of Congress. **********Decision Welcomed by Biaggi **********Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx and chairman of the Ad Hoc Congressional Committee for Irish Affairs, welcomed the State Department decision. **********''At long last,'' he said, ''we send a signal to the world that we can no longer afford to engage in selective sectarianism in our visa policy in Northern Ireland.'' **********The critics of Mr. Paisley's trip had noted in their letter that Owen Carron, a hard-line republican who was elected to the British Parliament last summer but has refused, as an anti-British protest, to take his seat, had been denied a visa earlier this year because of his support of violence. **********Mr. Paisley, who has been an outspoken critic of any British moves to conciliate the provinces's Roman Catholic minority, was to be joined on the tour by Peter Robinson, deputy leader of Mr. Paisley's party and also a member of the British Parliament, and John Taylor, a member of the European Parliament and a representative of Northern Ireland's older and more moderate Protestant party, the Official Unionists. **********The group originally included the Rev. Robert Bradford, a member of the British Parliament from South Belfast. Last month, however, Mr.  Bradford was killed by Irish Republican Army gunmen. His widow, Nora, has been invited to take his place on the tour. **********Jim Webb, a spokesman for the State Department's consular affairs office, said that the visas for other members of the party had not been revoked. Kerry Buttram. a spokesman for the Jack E. Buttram agency, which is handling the trip in this country, said today that the visit of the rest of the group would go on as planned. **********Mr. Paisley had planned to visit Atlanta, Dallas, Houston and Birmingham, Ala., before joining other members of the group for appearances in Washington and New York. Paisley Denounces Move Special to the New York Times **********BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 21 - The Rev. Ian Paisley said today that the cancellation of his American visa was a ''denial of free speech,'' and he ''utterly repudiated'' the suggestion that he had encouraged violence. **********''This treatment meted out to a member of the British House of Commons and the European Parliament contrasts sharply with the absolute freedom with which Irish-American supporters of the I.R.A.  come and go from this country without hindrance,'' Mr. Paisley declared in a statement. **********But the trip next month, which is designed to arouse American sympathy for the Ulster Unionist cause, countering Irish Republican Army propaganda, will go ahead even without him, he said. Referring to the killing last month of the Rev. Robert Bradford, Mr. Paisley said, ''The murder of one of the delegation did not stop it, so the revocation of another certainly will not.'' **********When Deputy Secretary of State William Clark visited London early this month, the British Government informally suggested to him that Mr. Paisley's visa should not be canceled, according to informed Government sources. **********''We quite honestly thought it would be useful to have the Americans see the kind of thing we are up against,'' a British official explained privately. The Foreign Office had no official reaction tonight to the news from Washington. **********But at a news conference tonight, Mr. Paisley said that the cancellation of his visa was part of ''the conspiracy between the Thatcher Government and the U.S.A. Government to sell out Ulster.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/busin.main_headline: EXPORTS OFF FOR TOYOTA AND NISSAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/busin.print_headline: EXPORTS OFF FOR TOYOTA AND NISSAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/busin.body_text: **********The two largest car makers in Japan, the Toyota Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, said yesterday that their production and their exports to the United Stattes had dropped in May from a year earlier, partly because of export restraints. **********Some Japanese trade specialists took the figures as evidence that, even though the procedures for the export curbs with the United States and some European countries were not yet worked out in detail, the biggest auto makers were taking the lead in restraining shipments. **********''The Japanese Government and the Japanese industry are very sincere about the export-restraint commitment,'' said Takanori Mizuno, senior economist in New York for Tokyo's Fuji Bank Ltd.  ''Japanese auto makers fully intend to hold car shipments to the level agreed.'' **********Japan, under strong pressure from the United States, decided May 1 to cut car shipments to America in the year ending next March 31 to 1.68 million units, down 7 percent from the 1.82 million units shipped last year. **********Toyota and Nissan also reported that domestic sales had dropped in May.  For Toyota, the largest car maker in Japan, the drop in all three categories - exports, domestic sales and production - was the first since January 1974. For Nissan, the second-biggest producer, whose vehicles sell under the Datsun brand, it was the first decline in all three figures since last February. **********Both companies, in separate statements, attributed the decline in part to export curbs worked out with the United States, Canada and West Germany. **********In the domestic market, the companies said sales were depreseed by an increase in Japanese commodity taxes that went into effect May 1.  Moreover, Mr. Mizuno noted, until recently wage increases in Japan had not kept pace with inflation, reducing disposable income and hurting car sales. **********While some recent wage gains have been more favorable, the effect on car sales will not develop until later this year, he predicted.  ''I think car sales in Japan will pick up in the second half,'' Mr.  Mizuno said. Declines of 3.5% and 11% **********Toyota's total vehicle exports to the United States in May came to 63,146 units, down 3.5 percent from May 1980. Exports of Toyota passenger cars fell 5.2 percent, to 50,093. **********At Nissan, shipments to the United States declined 11 percent, to 53,206 units. Passenger car shipments fell 11.1 percent, to 42,040.  Yet despite the decline in United States shipments by Toyota and san, Japan's Kyodo News Service quoted industry sources as saying that exports to the United States by the Japanese auto industry as a whole rose 3.9 percent in May from the year before, to 155,446.  Exports by such companies as the Honda Motor Company and Mitsubishi Motors rose, the Japanese news service said. **********Auto analysts speculated that it may have been more difficult for some of the smaller, fast-growing Japanese producers to restrain their exports than for their larger counterparts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Ashland Oil Inc. said the insurance commissioners of Georgia and Kansas had approved Ashland's plan to acquire the Integon Corporation in a two-phased transaction valued at about $252 million. **********An Ashland subsidiary will buy 2.84 million shares of Integon common at $40 a share in cash, as provided in its tender offer. **********It said the 2.84 million shares, or 45 percent of Integon, would be selected from the roughly 3.14 million shares tendered. **********In the second phase, Ashland will make a one for one exchange of a new series of cumulative convertible preferred stock for the remaining 55 percent of Integon. **********Ashland also announced that it had completed the purchase of an additional 1.7 million shares of the United States Filter Corporation at $33 each, giving it 60 percent of the company's voting stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/01/busin.body_text: **********LOS ANGELES I T is often characterized as enigmatic. It tells what it cares to about itself, and generally that is not much. It seems to discard more prevailing wisdom than it follows. Big as it is, it tends to keep its head low. And it is widely heralded as one of the best-managed companies in the world of business. **********Teledyne Inc. keeps rolling along, getting bigger, drawing more envy, attracting more mystery. It prospered mightily during the golden years for conglomerates in the 1960's, prospered when they subsequently fell from favor, and continues to prosper as they march back into the affections of investors. It is that rare conglomerate that has always worked. ''It's one of the almost unique companies in America,'' says Robert Christensen, a securities analyst at A.G.  Becker. ''It's a company that's a different beast than most.'' **********Broadly diversified, Teledyne is an amalgam of 130 companies (it doesn't like to call them subsidiaries) that make, among other things, engine tools, drones, Water Pik dental hygiene products, shower heads, swimming pool heaters, Acoustic Research stereo speakers, dental cements, the world's largest welding positioners and manipulators (capacities to 227 tons), bakery production lines and seismic systems to monitor earthquakes. It also owns several prominent insurance companies. The horde of properties can essentially be split up into five lines of business: industrial products, aviation and electronics, specialty metals, consumer products, and insurance and finance. **********Through its insurance arms, Teledyne has also poured money into a flock of companies - Litton Industries, Reichhold Chemicals, Walter Kidde -that are not brought into the family. On the whole, they have been propitious investments, the latest evidence being the agreement struck this week between Kennecott and Curtiss-Wright in their scrap for Curtiss-Wright shares. One upshot is that Teledyne's holdings in Curtiss-Wright will swell to a majority 57 percent, from 31.6 percent. **********To a large extent, Teledyne is the creation of one man. The man is Henry Singleton, an unorthodox and remarkable businessman who is high on almost everybody's list of the 10 most effective chief executives in the country. The holder of a doctorate in electrical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (he favors being called Doctor), Teledyne's chairman founded the company in 1960, and, going his own idiosyncratic way, has fashioned it into a $3 billion corporate whale. While many other conglomerates have recently been selling off diseased acquisitions from the 60's, Teledyne eschews such activity and goes its smiling way. **********''It is, in my opinion, one of the best-managed companies in the country,'' says Robert Hanisee, an analyst at Amdec Securities, ''and Dr. Singleton is one of the best managers of assets there is.'' As one example of its stellar performance, Teledyne ranks 11th among the largest companies in its earnings-per-share growth rate between 1969 and 1979. **********Mr. Singleton runs the variegated world of Teledyne out of farfrom-ostentatious quarters high in a sleek Century City tower, symbolic of the lean operations that Teledyne prefers. These days, he rarely strays far afield. Company officers fly in to see him. He shuns presentations before Wall Street analysts. (''I have a job to do here, rather than running around touting the stock.'') The corporate communications staff rarely blows the publicity bugles very loudly, though, every so often, Mr. Singleton will consent to sit still for an interview in his office. **********The office affords a panoramic view of the Los Angeles Country Club. Near the window stands a low table supporting an exquisite chess set. An accomplished player in his own right, Mr. Singleton continues to follow developments in the chess scene, though he says he hasn't played the game much in the past 30 or 40 years. Teledyne has been his profession and avocation. **********Although many corporations readily spew forth long-range strategic plans, designed to fuel stupendous growth, Mr. Singleton professes to have no grand scheme for his empire. ''In the 60's, I was flying around trying to buy companies all the time,'' he says. ''In the 70's, we were trying to build up the companies and work on organization. The 80's? I don't know. I didn't know what I'd be doing in the 60's. Basically, it's the same thing. You just go to work and work the same.'' **********He continues, ''I don't think we can successfully lay out as a long-term strategy what we should be doing right now and for a month from now and for 10 years from now. If we could lay this out, we could just go on vacation for 10 years.'' **********To some extent, Mr. Singleton is being cute. He has now proven, better than anyone else, that the conglomerate concept can be made to work and thrive without having a feel for the future. ''You can't tell me that someone as smart as Henry Singleton doesn't have plans in mind,'' says an analyst who has long followed the company. ''He likes to tweak the nose of the outside world a little bit. The latest game that Henry is on is that he doesn't know what he's going to do.'' **********Though many corporate chieftains are lamenting the uncertainty of the time, Mr. Singleton doesn't view the environment as overly unpredictable. ''It's pretty uncertain all the time,'' he says.  ''People say it's more uncertain. You pick up Dickens's 'A Tale of Two Cities,' and it starts off, 'It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.' These are not the worst of times. I can remember a lot worse. I can remember the beginning of the 40's. I can remember all of the 30's. Those were worse times. Those were more uncertain times.'' **********In many respects, Mr. Singleton is akin to a corporate hoarder - gathering up a mishmash of properties, squirreling them away and never letting go. If one of his ''children'' misbehaves, he merely cracks the whip and brings it into line. With few exceptions, he has kept the companies he has acquired and held on to most of the investments he has orchestrated. **********A SK him why, and he responds, ''We're not in the cigarette business, but let's say we are. Say we just built another plant for cigarettes. Why should we sell it? We're selling a lot of cigarettes from the plant, why sell it? I have the same feeling about everything else, whether it's a cigarette business or oil or shares of Coke.'' **********Teledyne has attracted gales of attention for its large-scale investments, through its insurance companies. Whereas many other insurance companies pour their cash into a broad portfolio, Mr.  Singleton has opted to amass sizable holdings in a more select group. Teledyne holds 25 percent of Litton Industries, 57 percent of Curtiss-Wright (pending the Kennecott deal), 29 percent of Brockway Glass, 21 percent of Reichhold Chemicals, as well as large chunks of Walter Kidde, National Can, H.J. Heinz and International Harvester, among others. **********Though the performance of these investments has varied widely, they have, on the whole, done handsomely.  The Litton experience alone has been spectacular enough to wring emotion from the crustiest of investors. Teledyne bought its 9.6 million Litton shares at an average price of $14. Litton currently sells for about $75, a gain of more than $580 million in roughly five years. What does Mr. Singleton think of that? ''It's turned out just fine.'' One of the ironies of Henry Singleton is that he formerly worked at Litton, learned conglomeration at the feet of what was the concept's master, and learned to run a better conglomerate. When Litton came on hard times, its departed son returned to scoop up large blocks of Litton stock. **********Over the years, there has been conjecture that Mr. Singleton was aiming to add Litton and some of the others to the Teledyne stable, but he has always staunchly insisted that he had no such designs. And he has kept his word. He has also largely shied away from selling investments, even when the sweetest of offers present themselves.  ''All of these are thought of pretty much as permanent investments,'' Mr. Singleton explains. ''The idea of buying and selling investments is not very appealing to us. I'm not sure we'd be good at that.'' **********Also, to heck with meddling in the management of the companies in which he has sunk money, even though the size of his holdings affords him effective control in several of them. ''I don't get involved,'' he says. ''The phone is there, and anybody can call me.'' Do they?  ''It would be the exception if someone did.'' **********Although there have been undeniable disruptions in Teledyne's kingdom -some of them critical - Mr. Singleton does not publicly admit to disappointment in any acquisition. ''No,'' he says, ''the feeling of disappointment or happiness is not a very professional one. If one company needs attention, we just work on it.'' **********The Singleton way of working on a company can assume several forms. A major failing was Packard-Bell, which ran into serious problems in its television and stereo business some years ago. Mr.  Singleton plucked the company from those businesses. Another major crisis befell the Argonaut Insurance subsidiary in the mid-1970's.  The company, like some others, was hit with an avalanche of large malpractice settlements at a time when malpractice premiums were low, resulting in a major write-off in 1975. Teledyne management replaced most of Argonaut's senior officials, and essentially pulled out of the malpractice business. **********Last year, Teledyne's net earnings slipped to $343.8 million, from $371.9 million, on sales that edged up to $2.93 billion, from $2.71 billion. However, Mr. Singleton and company analysts ascribe the earnings drop strictly to the tough economy and not to any inherent problems at any of its sundry companies. **********Indeed, the performance of Teledyne has been daunting enough to almost trigger suspicion from interested observers on Wall Street.  ''I can't tell you for sure that it's not done by mirrors, the numbers are so good,'' says Robert Christensen. ''I can't be sure that something won't come unglued, but these numbers have been high for years. Some have accused Singleton of not spending enough on plant. I don't think that's true, but I can't swear he isn't milking something.'' **********I MMEDIATELY prior to beginning Teledyne, Mr.  Singleton worked for six years at Litton Industries, where he ascended to vice president and general manager. Along with George Kozmetsky, a Litton associate, Mr. Singleton left and with $225,000 each, they founded Teledyne. The enterprise grew by snapping up small and medium-sized companies, the bulk of them private, while leaving the management pretty much intact. Overall, Teledyne boasts an enviable record of management continuity. **********As distinct from the fashion of many conglomerates of merging companies in related businesses together, Teledyne fastidiously believes in keeping things small. What better way, it figures, to motivate company managers and to smoke out ills before they turn cancerous. **********For instance, Teledyne Systems, one of the electronics companies, had a department that made hybrid circuits for in-house consumption.  The department began to sell to outside purchasers and after sales got up to several million dollars a few years ago, Teledyne broke off the department into a separate company called Teledyne Microelectronics. **********As conglomerates go, Teledyne is relatively decentralized, affording its scattered companies considerable autonomy. ''Teledyne'' is a word culled from Greek origins that means ''force applied at a distance.'' **********''We simply function here as personnel directors and reviewers of the activities,'' Mr. Singleton says. When it comes to tracking the financial health of its widespread companies, however, Teledyne is a watchful parent indeed. Voluminous reports flow into the Century City offices, where they get scrutinized by Mr. Singleton and George Roberts, Teledyne's president. **********Day-to-day operations are largely the province of Mr. Roberts, though there is no clear split of duties between him and Mr.  Singleton. ''As far as I'm concerned, he can do anything he wishes, and I always know what that is,'' Mr. Singleton says. ''I'm free to do anything I want, and he's not going to get on me. He's free to do anything he pleases, and I won't get on him.'' **********After buying up companies during the 1960's, Teledyne has become an unusually passive consumer. It has not bought a company since 1969.  In large part, Mr. Singleton has been abashed at the gigantic prices that companies are fetching. ''We have a fine group of companies and our attention is on them,'' he says. ''I believe we can do a better job for our shareholders investing the money rather than buying up companies.'' **********''He'd rather buy 25 percent of a company real cheap than get into a bidding war,'' says Robert Hanisee.  Close followers of Teledyne, however, anticipate that the aggressive conglomerate will be shopping again in not too many years. Teledyne generates a tremendous cash flow, on the order of $150 million to $200 million a year, and it needs to find a home for that money. In the past decade, it has used the cash to buy back large blocks of its stock and to invest money in the insurance subsidiaries. **********For many years, Teledyne has been viewed as a vastly undervalued stock. Like its conglomerate kin, it fell out of fashion. But of late, conglomerates have come part of the way back into vogue, though securities analysts still regard Teledyne stock, which closed Friday at 190 1/4, as a good buy. **********As it happens, the stock is one of the most expensive issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Though it currently hovers around $200 a share, it sold for $60 in late 1976 and about $8 in late 1974. Some analysts are predicting a rise to above $300 within a few years. **********Some corporate chieftains might split the stock when the price gets that high in order to bring it within reach of a broader array of investors, but not Mr. Singleton. ''I don't really think much about that,'' he says. ''The company is traded on the stock exchange, and if people want to buy it they can.'' **********Another quirk of Mr. Singleton's is his adamant refusal to pay a cash dividend. Asked about this, he retorts, ''Well, I feel the shareholders don't want a cash dividend. If they wanted one, they wouldn't buy the stock, because they know we don't pay one.'' Pressed for further elaboration, he adds, ''If you have to borrow the money for a cash dividend, I don't know why you would want to do it. It is the practice of American industry to borrow money to pay the cash dividend.'' They say, 'Oh, no, we're paying it out of profits.' Well, then they're borrowing for something else. Be-cause there is debt. So you're asking the wrong person. You should ask the others why they're paying the cash dividend.'' **********Mr. Singleton does, however, pay a stock dividend. ''Many years ago we started doing that for many of the same reasons that people started paying cash dividends,'' he says. ''It was the fashion, and some of the shareholders like it. I don't think it has much effect one way or the other. It's a noneconomic event.'' **********Though he is now 64, Mr. Singleton claims that retirement is not in his thoughts. Nor does he admit to fears of a Teledyne minus a Singleton. He maintains that George Roberts ''could run this company as well as I can.'' **********Can the company continue its staggering growth? ''I think we can,'' Mr. Singleton says without pause. ''I just don't know how to do it.  That's why you just go to work every day. We can do the best job we can by being diligent every day.'' https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/busin.main_headline: 3 1/4-Year Notes Bring 15.96%; U.S. Issue Sets Record
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; 3 1/4-Year Notes Bring 15.96%; U.S. Issue Sets Record
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/05/busin.body_text: **********The credit markets flirted with a 16 percent yield at yesterday's auction of new 3 1/4-year Treasury notes, but as the time for bidding drew near, demand was great enough to reduce the average yield on the 15 7/8 percent notes to 15.96 percent. It was a record yield for a new Treasury issue of that maturity, exceeding the previous high of 15.81 percent for notes sold May 5. **********Many economists who have been predicting a sustained drop in interest rates since May are dismayed by yields that are at record high levels for maturities longer than a year. So far, investors have not shown much confidence that the slowdown of inflation will continue over the life of their investments and are quite willing to keep their funds invested in the money markets, where yields are well over 17 percent for nearly risk-free securities due in a month. **********''Bullishness toward fixed-income securities has not been squelched by any means,'' commented Alan Lerner, senior vice president at the Bankers Trust Company, ''but there is considerably more indecision today.'' He pointed out that the Treasury expects to raise more than $30 billion of new cash in the fourth quarter, which could put upward pressure on rates. **********Although analysts agreed that investor demand for notes and bonds was weak, many said that the weakness tended to be overstated in the days before large Treasury financings as dealers try to cut prices and raise yields to levels that will make it easier to sell the new securities. More Financing Imminent **********The $4.25 billion note sale was the first of three note and bond auctions this week and will be followed by sales of $2.25 billion of 10-year notes today and $2 billion of 13 7/8 percent bonds tomorrow.  In advance of those auctions, the 14 1/2 percent notes due in 9 3/4 years were offered at 97 30/32, to yield 14.89 percent, up 1/8 on the day, and the 13 7/8 percent bonds due 2011 were offered at 98 6/32, to yield 14.12 percent, up slightly more than 1/2. **********In the tax-exempt market, many state and local governments, like corporations, have been relying on short-term debt while they defer long-term bond financings until interest rates are lower. For some, it has been a costly lesson in the perils of trying to predict interest rates. **********Philadelphia, for example, rejected bond underwriters' proposals last March because the net interest cost of 13.21 percent was unacceptably high. Since then, interest rates have moved sharply higher and yesterday the city sold $60.5 million of bonds at a 13.9 percent net interest cost. **********Underwriters led by Citibank said that all but $2.7 million of the issue was sold from the syndicate account by late in the day, though a significant number of bonds were still in dealer hands. Yields for the serial bonds ranged from 10 percent in 1982 to 12.4 percent in 1991, while 13 percent term bonds due 1996 were offered at par, as were $43 million of 13 1/2 percent term bonds due 2006. **********Despite the Philadelphia experience, many local government borrowers continue to develop sources of credit that would suplement the long-term bond market. Connecticut recently announced plans to sell $150 million of notes due April 15, 1982, with most of the proceeds earmarked for repayment of previously issued temporary notes that fall due on Sept. 1. The offering circular for the notes said that the state plans to begin sales of tax-exempt commercial paper in September, which would make it the first state to make use of that increasingly popular financing device. Cheaper Source of Funds **********Underwriters say that several other states, as well as the Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York are considering issuing tax-exempt commercial paper because it adds financial flexibility and can be a cheaper source of funds. Recently 30-day tax-exempt paper was sold with rates of 7 1/2 and 7 5/8 percent, compared with about 11 percent for high grade state bond issues due in 20 years or more. **********In the negotiated sector, a $100 million issue of A-rated Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company was tentatively priced by a Salomon Brothers group to yield as much as 13.51 percent for bonds due 2017. The company operates a power supply system for publicly owned electric utilities in Massachusetts. **********Elsewhere in the tax-exempt market, $25.1 million of triple A-rated bonds of Minneapolis were reoffered with yields ranging from 8.75 percent in 1982 to 11.25 percent in 2002. Underwriters led by Salomon Brothers said that about $12 million of bonds remained unsold late in the day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/14/world.body_text: **********Private ''community schools,'' regarded by the Zimbabwean Government as a means of continuing whites-only education in an officially desegregated society, will be abolished at the end of the month, Education Minister Dzingai Mutumbuka announced today. **********He said in a statement that from next month the schools would operate on the same basis as state schools, charging the same tuition fees and boarding rates. **********Community schools were set up in 1979 under the Government of Bishop Abel T. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/17/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Margin Debt's New Pressure
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/17/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Margin Debt's New Pressure
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/17/busin.body_text: **********HEAVILY leveraged margin accounts could touch off a good deal of selling in the near future in the event of further weakness in share prices. This was clearly implied by figures released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The figures disclosed that margin debt in accounts with less than 40 percent equity jumped to 38 percent of the total at the end of August, up from 25 percent in July. **********Margin accounts with less than 40 percent equity are regarded as vulnerable because most brokerage firms send out margin calls when accounts fall below 30 percent. Some firms call for more capital when accounts drop to 35 percent. **********Not since March 1980 has so much of the margin debt been concentrated in accounts with less than 40 percent equity. It was perhaps understandable, then, that the market plunged in April 1980 as investors reacted to word that the capital of a few major brokerage firms could be in jeopardy as a result of alliances with the Hunt brothers of Texas, who had experienced heavy losses in the silver market. The market's downswing that April was pushed still lower when shares were ordered sold as thousands of investors failed to meet margin calls. **********Last month, as share prices plummeted, total margin debt dropped by $600 million, reducing the total to $14.3 billion. That decline was the largest since April 1980, in the wake of the silver crisis. **********Since the end of last month, the market as measured by the Dow Jones industrials has dropped another 4 1/2 percent. That includes yesterday's drop by the Dow of 6.75, to 851.60 - a fraction of a point above the 15-month low. **********Margin calls were clearly a factor in the August decline and brokerage houses have taken to monitoring accounts closely so that calls can go out promptly in the event of a drop below the required level of equity in the weeks ahead. **********There are factors at work in margin accounts that can bring an early call. Many brokerage houses in calculating the value of customer portfolios for purposes of determining whether to call for additional funds do not recognize as eligible for margin purchases shares selling for less than $5. Many firms also require maintenance of 50 percent equity in shares selling at between $5 and $10 each.  The extended bear market has caused shares of some companies that once sold in the high teens to drop below the $10 level. **********In any case, margin calls go out sooner than many inexperienced investors expect. Assume a customer's equity is at 40 percent and the total value of the customer's holdings are $10,000. The equity then is $4,000. A decline in the shar es averaging 10 percent (less than that if the v alue of some shares dropped below $10, of course) reduces the c ustomer's equity to $3,000, or just over 30 percent of the new $9,00 0 value of the holding. **********As the customer's equity declined, he would receive a call even at the more liberal brokerage house to increase the percentage of his equity and decrease the amount of his margin - the money borrowed to buy the stock holding. (Stock exchange rules require that a customer have at least 25 percent equity.) **********In an era of unusually high interest rates, the customer might think twice about answering the call with more cash. Brokers are charging most margin customers at least 20 percent interest and some are subject to even higher charges. **********The customer with the $10,000 account on 40 percent margin would have a loan of 60 percent of that sum, or $6,000. Assume that he paid interest on the account at a rate of 20 percent a year. That would amount to $1,200 a year, or $100 a month. **********Once the values in the account dropped by $1,000, the customer would have to produce several hundred dollars to meet the broker's margin call, without a reduction in the monthly interest expense.  Obviously, many hard-pressed investors cannot afford to hold their positions and others are so discouraged that they no longer want to. **********The price of failing to meet a call is considerable. The account in the example is now worth $9,000 and the customer still owes $6,000.  Liquidation would leave him less than the $3,000 selling price because of the deductions for margin interest and brokerage commissions.
