https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/29/world.main_headline: MRS. THATCHER BACK, TO RISING CRITICISM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/29/world.print_headline: MRS. THATCHER BACK, TO RISING CRITICISM
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/29/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has returned to Britain from the conference of rich and poor nations in Mexico to find the dissatisfaction with her economic program stronger than ever. **********Mrs. Thatcher had hoped to calm the dissidents within her party at the Conservatives' annual conference in Blackpool this month, and she won a standing ovation from the grass-roots activists on the conference floor. But she failed completely to calm the anxieties of Tory backbenchers and Cabinet members who see their political futures jeopardized by the rigor of the Prime Minister's doctrine. **********Today, the House of Commons debated a no-confidence motion introduced by Michael Foot, leader of the opposition Labor Party.  ''Many on the Government side are becoming increasingly alarmed at the course on which they have embarked,'' said Mr. Foot. ''They would like to see a change and a very drastic change - they have spoken out against the theoretical basis of monetarism and said they wish to place a greater emphasis on dealing with unemployment. Much of what they said is right.'' To no one's surprise Mrs. Thatcher restated her faith in her monetarist policies, and to no one's surprise she won a vote of confidence, but the victory will still leave vital problems unsolved.'' **********The fears of the dissidents, or ''wets'' - ''wet'' is an undergraduate slang word in Britain meaning weak-willed -were heightened by the Tories' bad showing in the Croydon North West byelection Thursday, when the Liberal-Social Democratic alliance won the seat. Those fears were redoubled this weekend when a publicopinion poll showed that Shirley Williams of the Social Democrats was likely to win the next by-election, at Crosby in the Liverpool area, overturning a Tory margin of nearly 20,000 votes. Change of Course Predicted **********Speaking on television Sunday, Sir Ian Gilmour, a leading ''wet'' who was ousted from the Cabinet some weeks ago, argued that widespread unhappiness among Conservative M.P.'s and Conservative voters, as manifest at Croydon, would soon force the Prime Minister to change course. He said that ''the strategy is falling apart,'' and added that ''Mrs. Thatcher can see the writing on the wall as quickly as anyone else and does not want to go down in disastrous defeat.'' **********''It is quite impossible for Mrs. Thatcher to ignore that very heavy weight of opinion,'' Sir Ian declared. ''It is there. She cannot wish it away. She cannot reshuffle her Cabinet all the time, presumably to get 21 people all of whom agree with her. It is simply not practicable to do so.'' **********The Cabinet is Mrs. Thatcher's most pressing current problem. At an unusually difficult meeting last week, it was unable to reach agreement on the Treasury's proposals for cuts in public spending of almost $10 billion. The Prime Minister strongly supported the proposals, a key element in her anti-inflationary strategy, but she was able to command the backing of only seven other ministers of the 21 present at the session. **********It seems evident that Mrs. Thatcher's most recent Cabinet reorganization, which was designed to reward her friends and punish her critics, has failed to achieve its goals. Sir Ian asserted, and several current Cabinet members privately agreed, that the Prime Minister no longer commands a Cabinet majority for her overall economic plan, which is called the medium-term financial strategy. **********Even John Biffen, one of the most vehement monetarists at the beginning of Mrs. Thatcher's term two and a half years ago, has in the last two weeks begun saying semipublicly that her strategy is impossible to sustain politically, and he opposed the cuts in the Cabinet discussions last week. Cabinet Gets a Warning **********Sir Geoffrey Howe, the embattled Chancellor of the Exchequer, remains a loyal supporter of the Prime Minister. He has warned the Cabinet that he will not increase public borrowing to make up for any failure to cut spending, because that would increase inflation.  His only alternative, he reportedly said, would be to increase levies such as sales and excise taxes. **********In contrast to the previous pattern, Sir Geoffrey's threat appeared to have little impact on the ministers opposed to more cuts. One said over the weekend that higher taxes were ''better political symbols than spending cuts'' at a time of record unemployment. **********The argument will resume tomorrow at another Cabinet meeting. Since last week, Leon Brittan, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, has been attempting to sell its ideas to the rebellious ministers in ''spending'' departments, with a conspicuous lack of success so far. **********Some Conservatives believe that there are already enough dissident backbenchers prepared to vote against another deflationary budget to prevent Mrs. Thatcher from getting it through the House of Commons, even if she could somehow win in the Cabinet. If she becomes convinced that they are right, the Prime Minister might relent from her insistence on a rigid link between revenue and spending; a defeat on a budget bill would be a crippling humiliation, even if it did not precipitate a general election that she would almost certainly lose. **********A clue to the trend in the Government's thinking may have been provided last weekend in a speech by Francis Pym, the leader of the House of Commons. Mr. Pym is considered a likely future party leader by his peers, and he has been reluctant to become publicly identified with the ''wet'' point of view. **********Speaking to a group of Young Conservatives in Suffolk, he said of the nation and the Conservative party: ''We abhor extremes, or anything near them; we prefer compromise and agreement to confrontation and disharmony.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.main_headline: WALESA APPEALS TO THE WEST FOR FOOD AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.print_headline: WALESA APPEALS TO THE WEST FOR FOOD AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/21/world.body_text: **********Lech Walesa, Solidarity's leader, addressed an unusual appeal to ''the working people and trade unions of Western Europe'' today, asking them to pressure their governments to provide food aid to get Poland through a difficult winter. **********The nation's economic situation was so alarming, he said, that it could lead to ''spontaneous outbursts of public discontent'' in the coming months that ''would have disastrous economic and political consequences.'' **********If Western trade unions were to persuade their governments to provide emergency food aid, he said, then the Solidarity union would ''insure public control of the distribution'' and also the fastest possible repayment. The Solidarity leadership also appealed to its members for restraint over strikes and other protests. **********Central Committee to Meet **********It was announced tonight, meanwhile, that the Communist Party would hold a Central Committee meeting next Friday to discuss the country's crisis. **********Mr. Walesa's appeal came a day after the Government announced that it was recalling the troops that it dispatched to the countryside a month ago. When the military units were sent out Oct. 26, at a time of growing labor unrest, some Poles feared that their primary function might be to impose military order to break strikes. That aspect of their mission was emphasized in Government statements at the time. **********But the units appear to have been used mainly to check on local authorities and to search for incidents of inefficiency, hoarding of food and transportation difficulties. **********The use of the troops also bolstered the prestige of the new party leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. It reminded Poles that the army was available in case the situation got too far out of hand, and it made General Jaruzelski, who has not exactly galvanized the nation as Prime Minister over the last six months, appear to be taking action at last to try to get a grasp on things. Strikers Are Ignored **********That the army units directed most of their attention toward the local administration, and not to the strikers, was implicit in remarks today by a Defense Ministry spokesman, Maj. Stanislaw Masztanowicz. He said that local administrators had been made aware of their own ''shortcomings'' and that the military group leaders had collected information for the Supreme Control Chamber, the state body that investigates official corruption. **********A Solidarity bulletin from Katowice noted a few days ago that ''party propaganda'' had originally depicted the army units' role as ''suppressing hotbeds of tension'' and ''neutralizing'' anti-Communist forces. **********''Everyone has been pleasantly surprised that the operational groups are not pulling pigs out of pigsties,'' the Solidarity publication said, ''but are driving the corrupt local government apparatus to work. It has turned out that indeed the army is looking for antisocialist elements and is finding them in local governments, in rural retailing cooperatives and also, which no one had anticipated, in local party committees.'' **********''Carry on, general,'' the bulletin urged, ''but with greater courage.'' Gasoline Prices to Rise **********In an attempt to cut down lengthy gasoline lines, the Government announced an increase of up to 50 percent in the price of high-octane gasoline. It will take effect Sunday. **********In another development, a Deputy Prime Minister, Mieczyslaw Rakowski, told representatives of officially sponsored trade unions that the Government would appoint a group within the next few days to set up a front of national accord, an overall coalition that would presumably include Solidarity, the Communist Party and the Roman Catholic Church. But exactly what its powers and role would be have not been spelled out.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/23/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON THE Federal Financing Bank, which provides money for the Tennessee Valley Authority, Amtrak, student loans, New York City and the Washington subway system, is quietly assuming an important military and foreign policy role. **********The Treasury's ''back door,'' as the bank is sometime called because it borrows from the Treasury to relend chiefly to other Federal agencies, lends also to allies of the United States to help them purchase American military hardware. **********A little-noticed report by the bank, which was set up in 1973 to consolidate agency borrowing, shows it now has $7.7 billion in loans outstanding for foreign military sales, representing nearly 10 percent of its outstanding loan total of $88.4 billion. **********Among the borrowers in January were: El Salvador ($1.4 million); Israel ($8.1 million); Greece ($15 million); South Korea ($18 million); Turkey ($5.3 million), and Spain ($13 million). **********The Reagan budget would trim some of the activities of the bank, but Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. prevailed over David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, who wanted to curb the military financing activities. **********In fact, according to the budget documents just submitted to Congress, the Administration is asking for a $500 million increase in the Department of Defense guarantee fund, which, as its name implies, guarantees that the loans will be repaid. Under a complex 10-1 leveraging formula, the $500 million increase in guarantee authority means Defense is contemplating guaranteeing loans of $5 billion for the next fiscal year. **********The interest cost is far below what the foreign governments would have to pay if they went to the financial markets themselves to borrow. The Federal Financing Bank charges them one quarter of a percentage point above the Treasury's borrowing rate. **********Glenn Willett Clark, a McLean, Va., lawyer who, as a former assistant general counsel at Treasury in the mid-1970's, was close to the Bank's activities, said its operations over the last four years have added $50 billion to the national debt. **********Despite the growth of the military financing activities, most of the bank's money has gone into activities guaranteed by the Federal Home Administration. F.H.A.-guaranteed paper accounts for nearly half the outstanding loans. Mutual Aid Society **********Saul B. Klaman, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, was in town the other day to remind the Administration that mutual savings banks, like their thrift cousins, the savings andloan associations, are also suffering profit-squeeze blues and need some regulatory relief. **********''Depressed, but not yet desperate,'' was the way Mr. Klaman described the earnings position of his members, noting that they have a capital and surplus position strong enough to withstand significant losses well into the future. **********The association's demands include restoration of a differential that would permit thrift institutions to pay a quarter of a percentage point more than commercial banks on six-month certificates; elimination of the 12 percent ''cap'' on 30-month certificates; equalization of the regulatory burden between depository institutions and money market funds, and legislation that would target more savings for retirement. Third World **********The debt of developing countries more than quadrupled in the last decade, reaching $400 billion by the end of 1980. Chandra Hardy, on leave from the World Bank as a visiting fellow at the Overseas Development Council, warns that debt servicing problems are bound to arise and suggests that existing machinery to deal with them needs to be improved. **********She is critical of the present practice whereby a debtor country meets with its creditors to work out the terms of rescheduling. To her, this looks too much like creditors ganging up. She wants the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to play a greater role in the process. Clausen's Coming **********The World Bank preparing for its new president, Bank of America Chairman A. W. Clausen, who takes over in June. Staff members are already speculating about new policy directions. Should he follow some of the principles laid down at the Bank of America, the World Bank over the next few years will probably embark on a decentralization program, with chunks of its operations moving away from Washington, out into the lending fields of Africa, Asia and Latin America. Standby **********United States Trade Representative Bill Brock has a negotiating team ready to move out to Tokyo on short notice should President Reagan decide he wants the Japanese to curb their auto shipments to the United States. Mr. Brock says he has no present plans to go to Tokyo himself, but that could change. **********If talks begin, they will probably include a lot of other things besides autos. The United States still has a rather big complaint list of allegedly restrictive or discriminatory Japanese import practices. Briefcases *********** Van Doorn Ooms, former chief economist at the Senate Budget Committee, has moved over to the House Budget Committee, where he also will be the chief economist. *********** Bernard M. Shapiro, former staff director at the Joint Taxation Committee of Congress, has taken a job at Price Waterhouse.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/busin.body_text: **********Trans World Airlines lowered its weekday New York-to-Florida fare to $69, matching the fare announced last week by Air Florida in the latest round of a fare war on the busy North-South route. **********T.W.A. said its fares applied to weekday coach flights from New York or Newark to Miami or Fort Lauderdale and that children accompanied by adults could fly free under certain conditions.  Previously, T.W.A.'s fare on the route was $79 during the week and $99 on weekends. It did not change the weekend rate. **********In a round of fare cutting announced last week, Eastern Airlines and Pan American World Airways reduced their fares on the route to $75 for weekday flights.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/busin.main_headline: PRESIDENT IS APPOINTED AT DATA ELECTRONICS INC.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; PRESIDENT IS APPOINTED AT DATA ELECTRONICS INC.
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/26/busin.body_text: **********Jack H. King, 47, has joined Data Electronics Inc., a manufacturer of digital drives for tape cartridges and related systems, as president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Hal Georgens, 58, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the San Diego company. **********"I like building businesses and helping people develop," said Mr.  King. "My goal is putting the people and systems in place and allowing them to grow." **********Mr. King started in the data processing business in 1960 with the General Dynamics Corporation. He became president of the banking division of the University Computing Corporation in 1976 and moved two years later to the Memorex Corporation as vice president and general manager of its computer tape division. For the last two years, he has been president of its computer media group. **********Mr. Georgens worked for Honeywell Inc. and Motorola Inc. before becoming a group vice president of Bell & Howell in 1970. Four years later he founded Data Electronics. **********Mr. King, who was recruited for his new post by the executive search frim of Finnegan & White, observed that "the order rates are very strong and the backlog is very good. I don't see anything that gives me major concern on the demand side." .end.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/23/busin.body_text: **********Texas Instruments Inc. said that it would sell a new line of desk computers for small business, becoming the latest of several companies to enter a market estimated to contain 2.2 million individual businesses. **********Computers designed to sell to this market generally cost $5,000 to $10,000, slightly more than the so-called personal computers, although there is a great deal of overlap. **********In the last few months, companies such as International Business Machines, Data General and Hewlett-Packard have all introduced computers aimed at the smallbusiness market. **********Texas Instruments said that it would sell four models of the machine ranging in price from $6,200 to $9,900, depending on the amount of attached disk memory capacity. The internal memory of all models will be 64,000 characters. Programs initially available computer will handle accounting programs and word processing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/25/busin.body_text: **********People Express Airlines, a new regional airline being formed in Newark, said it had taken delivery of its first Boeing 737 aircraft under an agreement with Lufthansa Airlines. **********It said eight additional aircraft are scheduled for delivery between April and September of this year. People Express said that financing of up to $37.4 million for the purchase of its fleet had been arranged between it and the Bank of America and four major New Jersey banks. The New Jersey banks are the Fidelity Union Trust Company, the First Jersey National Bank, the First National State Bank of New Jersey and the Midlantic National Bank.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/15/busin.body_text: **********Uranium drilling activity in Wyoming, the nation's major producing state, declined 57 percent in 1980, the Department of Energy reported today. **********Exploration and development drilling for new deposits in Wyoming fell from 14.8 million feet in 1979 to 6.4 million feet in 1980, the agency said. More than 1,000 uranium workers in Wyoming have been laid off in the past year because of the declining uranium market. Uranium producers cited slowdowns in construction of nuclear power plants and what they termed excessive Government regulation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/world.main_headline: Report on Guyana Election Says It Was Rigged
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Report on Guyana Election Says It Was Rigged
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/world.body_text: **********Guyana's general election in December was ''rigged massively and flagrantly'' in favor of the ruling People's National Congress, a team of international observers reported today. **********The report said the election, which the party won by an overwhelming majority, was an example of President Forbes Burnham's determination ''to cling to power at all costs.'' **********The team, led by Lord Avebury of the British parliamentary human rights group and including representatives from Canada, the United States and Jamaica, was invited to observe the elections by the Guyana Human Rights Association. Its report said that the People's National Congress had vastly superior access to news organizations, that electoral rolls were inaccurate and that people were often wrongly turned away from polling stations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/16/busin.main_headline: DOW ADVANCES 3.50, WITH OILS IN LEAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/16/busin.print_headline: DOW ADVANCES 3.50, WITH OILS IN LEAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/16/busin.body_text: **********Energy-related issues, buoyed by prospects of an early decontrol of domestic oil prices, stood out yesterday as the stock market's strongest group. However, certain high-technology issues displayed weakness as the result of order slowdowns and lowered earnings estimates for 1981 by Wall Street analysts. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, locked in a narrow trading range for the last five sessions, closed with an advance of 3.50 points, to 969.97. This reflected price gains in its energy components.  Volume contracted to 39.6 million shares from the previous session's 41.4 million. **********Oil stocks, which showed signs Wednesday of returning to investor favor after their recent sell-off, moved ahead briskly.  Sanford L. Margoshes of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. said this reflected the expectation that President-elect Ronald Reagan would carry out his campaign pledge to speed up decontrol of domestic oil prices early in his administration. The present timetable calls for phased decontrol to continue through Sept. 30. 'A Salutary Effect' **********''This expectation had a salutary effect on energy stocks, inasmuch as speedy decontrol will mean a one-time earnings increase, particularly for the producing part of the business,'' the analyst said. **********Phillips Petroleum and Union Oil of California each rose more than 3 points among the 10 most-active issues on the New York Stock Exchange. Earlier this week, Phillips reported finding significant hydrocarbons in an appraisal well in the North Sea. Union Oil said a Wyoming well showed a new productive pool. The active roster also included point-plus gains for Mobil, Atlantic Richfield and Standard Oil (Indiana). **********Moving ahead in less active trading were Getty Oil, Conoco Inc., Southland Royalty, Standard Oil Company (Ohio), Exxon and Central Louisiana Energy. **********Superior Oil rose 11 points, to 212. Superior said that directors of Peru's state oil company had approved a contract for an oil and gas prospect in which it holds an 80 percent interest as operator. **********Oil service and drilling issues shared honors with energy stocks, as did railroads with a stake in natural resources. Gainers here ranged from Schlumberger to Union Pacific. **********Sedco Inc., an offshore drilling contractor, ran ahead 10 1/2 points, to 90. In Dallas, a spokesman for the company said that he knew of no specific reason for this advance, but noted that the stock had dropped sharply last week during the market's general sell-off. NCR Down Again **********Among high-technology issues, the NCR Corporation fell 3 points, to 65 1/4, after Wednesday's 5 1/4-point loss. The company has said that, although its latest quarterly profits increased, incoming orders had declined. Computer stocks generally were weak. **********Chrysler, the volume leader, rose 3/4, to 6 1/8. This followed the Wednesday night announcement that the Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board had given the auto maker conditional approval for $400 million in loan guarantees. **********Alcoa moved ahead 1 3/8, to 63 3/4, after directors declared a 2-for-1 stock split and raised the dividend. Amstar rose 2 points, to 25, after reporting sharply higher earnings. Texas Pacific Land Trust, which showed a profit decline, fell 2 3/8, to 52 5/8. **********Strength in energy issues helped to send the American Stock Exchange's market value index to its best gain in nine sessions. It rose 4.91, to 344.29. Among the better performers were Houston Oil & Minerals, Dome Petroleum and Michell Energy & Development.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/26/world.main_headline: U.N. PLANS PARLEY ON ENERGY SOURCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/26/world.print_headline: U.N. PLANS PARLEY ON ENERGY SOURCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/26/world.body_text: **********As the Reagan Administration moves to cut back on Federal efforts to develop renewable energy sources and other alternatives to oil, the rest of the world is starting to move in the opposite direction. **********Next month, the United Nations will hold a conference on new and renewable sources of energy in Nairobi, Kenya. The purpose, according to Enrique V. Iglesias, the secretary general of the conference, is to create a worldwide climate of opinion that will pave the way for accelerated development of alternatives to fossil fuels. **********In a recent interview, Mr. Iglesias, a Uruguayan, said it was important for the world to begin ''to move away from oil to a new energy mix.'' **********The Nairobi conference will examine ways to broaden the use of power from the wind, the oceans and water in other forms, the sun, geothermal sources, draft animals and firewood, which all provide fuels that tend to be environmentally benign. Focus on Developing Nations **********Mr. Iglesias said that the conference would concentrate on the needs of the developing countries. He noted that more than two billion people now depend on rapidly diminishing supplies of firewood as their major source of energy. **********However, a recent gathering of experts known as the North-South Roundtable, meeting to prepare for the Nairobi conference, concluded that the increased use of renewable energy might be more critical in industrialized nations than in the poor countries. **********Maurice F. Strong, the Canadian chairman of the International Energy Development Corporation, a private company concerned with energy resources in developing countries, conducted the roundtable meeting in Rome. He said at a recent news conference that the industrialized nations could certainly afford the investments in research and development of new energy sources, which could then be shared with the poorer nations. **********A State Department paper on the conference said that the goals of the United States for the meeting included accelerating ''the development, acceptance and use of new and renewable sources of energy, taking into account the effects on the global environment and resource base.'' Elimination of Support **********In its domestic program, however, the Reagan Administration is trying to eliminate or cut back Government support of most programs to develop renewable fuel sources and other alternatives to oil and coal consumption. **********This year the Department of Energy prepared legislation to eliminate many of these subsidized programs and the Office of Management and Budget has been seeking to cut the money available for such projects. **********In its recent budget vote, the House of Representatives retained some funds to encourage the commericial development of solar energy and other alternate programs. But the Administration seems determined to leave such efforts largely to the private sector. **********A study conducted for the Carter Administration's Energy Department by the Solar Energy Research Institute, a Federal agency, concluded that heavy investment to promote renewable sources and energy efficiency could virtually eliminate this nation's need to import oil by the end of the century. Director Asked to Resign **********In late June, the director of the institute, Denis A. Hayes, was asked by the Energy Department to resign. He charged that the Administration, specifically Energy Secretary James B. Edwards, was seeking to paralyze solar energy development to concentrate on nuclear power. **********No one could be reached at the Energy Department who would respond to questions about the Administration's position on renewable energy resources. **********However, James Stromayer, the United States coordinator for the Nairobi conference, said, ''The new Administration feels it is sound economics to put all forms of energy on an equal footing in the marketplace.'' **********Mr. Stromayer added that the Reagan Administration had not embarked on ''a total abandonment of research and development in new and renewable sources of energy.'' The Government's role, he said, was to investigate long-term applications of new energy sources while commercial interests developed such sources in response to market conditions. Essential to Remove 'Burdens' **********''This Administration is not saying by its policy that we don't think renewable energy sources are good,'' Mr. Stromayer said. ''What our policy is saying is that it is essential to remove regulatory and bureaucratic burdens from the economy. Lifting that burden should release the creative forces of the private market.'' **********But Mr. Iglesias said ''it would be a pity for the United States not to continue to develop technology'' for new and renewable energy sources. ''It is not only in your interests but the interests of the rest of the world,'' he said. **********Mr. Iglesias said that the attitude of the United States toward renewable energy ''is not the mood you perceive in Western Europe.'' ''All the Western European countries are working hard on this,'' he said. ''So is Japan.'' Mr. Iglesias emphasized that the conference was not an attempt to turn the developing countries to alternative sources of energy so that the remaining oil reserves would be available to the industrialized countries. He said that the poor countries would continue to require oil and coal. **********But he said he was optimistic that alternate fuels could supply some 20 percent of the world's needs by 2000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/world.body_text: **********A drive by Islamic hard-liners to oust former Prime Minister Mehdi Bazargan from Parliament includes a petition drive for the ouster for Mr. Barzargan's parliamentary supporters, a former Bazargan aide said today. **********Ahmad Sadr Haj Seyyed Javadi, who was Interior Minister under Mr.  Bazargan, said in a telephone interview that the petition by supporters of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini appeared to be part of a campaign to have the Parliament, vote to expel Mr. Bazargan and eight others, including himself. Mr. Javadi, a deputy from Teheran and a member of Mr. Bazargan's Liberation Movement, said it was ''not unlikely'' that the group would be ousted. **********Mr. Bazargan, the first Prime Minister to govern Iran after the overthrow of the monarchy in 1979, was shouted down in the Parliament Wednesday when he criticized the current m ass executions of people suspected of belonging to or supporting the P eople's Mujahedeen, a leftist group, arguing that they were ''not t he lackeys of the UnitedStates.''

Reports No Gains On Rights for Chileans **********UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 18 (Reuters) - A United Nations study said today that it was not possible to report any improvement in the human rights situation in Chile and recommended that the international community ''use whatever means it deems appropriate'' to insure the restoration of rights there. **********The report was made by Abdoulaye Dieye, secretary general of the Supreme Court of Senegal, who was made a special representative on Chile by the United Nations Human Rights Commission in 1979. ---- **********SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 18 (AP) -Three plainclothes policemen were slain by gunmen today near the home of Chile's Chief of Staff, Brig.  Gen. Santiago Sinclair, the police said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Future Growth Of McDonald's
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Future Growth Of McDonald's
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/15/busin.body_text: **********ONE of the premier growth companies of the last 20 years, the McDonald's Corporation, has slowed down. Although McDonald's is expected by forecasters to earn $6.60 a share in 1981 - which would be a sparkling 20 percent gain over last year's $5.49 a share - that growth rate looks like a peak to some analysts and is decidedly below historic rates. **********Skeptics argue that a major factor in the company's recent success has been the depressed condition of the beef market over the last two and a half years. Wholesale utility cattle prices, which peaked at 57 cents a pound in the spring of 1979, touched 42 cents a pound earlier this year, just above the low of 39 cents a pound set at the end of 1978. The most recent available figures showed 44 cents a pound. **********While beef prices have fallen, menu prices have remained firm. As a result, McDonald's and other leading fast-food companies have experienced improved margins but with smaller increases in traffic.  Specifically, the sales of McDonald's were up about 14 1/2 percent in the first half of 1981, while earnings were up 22 percent. **********The question is, will McDonald's grow enough in the years ahead to justify investment by those seeking high future growth?  Michael Culp, who follows McDonald's for E.F. Hutton & Company, thinks not. He comments: ''McDonald's growth in recent years has come almost exclusively from the opening of new stores and the raising of menu prices. If you adjust the figures to reflect changing economic environments, you discover that the customer base has been flat for five to 10 years. It stands to reason that growth over the next five years for a company with 6,000 outlets here and abroad should be much closer to 15 percent than 20 percent.'' **********Mr. Culp expects that reduced rate of growth as a result of a 7 percent addition to the store base annually and 8 percent higher menu prices. He explained that, when inflation is high - as it has been - McDonald's ''needs to and can get 10 percent price increases annually.'' But in a period of declining inflation, which he expects will occur well into the decade, he believes that price increases will have to be lower - especially since new competitive factors loom. **********In a recent report by Mr. Culp recommending Denny's Inc., a coffee shop chain, he argued that McDonald's, Burger King and other limitedmenu chains had broadened their menus in recent years, thereby compromising the two areas critical to their success: low prices and fast service. ''In so doing, they have made themselves vulnerable to intense competition from the coffee shops because the price differential has been narrowed but the quality differential has not,'' he said. **********Coincident with a reduced rate of growth is McDonald's rapidly rising dividend. McDonald's formerly paid out 5 to 10 percent of earnings, using most of its cash to finance new stores. Now much of McDonald's excess cash is being used to retire debt since less is needed to finance new stores. **********Mr. Culp couples a 15 percent growth rate with the company's 1 to 2 percent dividend yield for a total return of 16 or 17 percent. This assumes no improvement in the price-earnings multiple, currently 8 1/2 times the $7.75 a share he estimates for 1982. **********By contrast, the 1,000 companies that E.F. Hutton follows show an average earnings growth of 14 percent and a yield of 5 percent for a total average return of 19 percent. On average, these stocks sell at a price-earnings multiple of 7, Mr. Culp said. ''Thus, McDonald's has a below-average total return and an above-average price-earnings multiple,'' he added. **********Needless to say, he is not recommending the shares, though he believes they are worth 70 as compared with the current price of 64.  William Trainer of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith believes McDonald's growth rate over the next five years will be 17 percent.  But he draws a different conclusion: This rate of growth makes the company's shares highly attractive. Mr. Trainer concedes that past tactics of opening more and more units will be tempered by the company's already impressive size. **********But there are favorable implications to slower growth: Internal cash flow will exceed capital expenditures for the first time in 1981 and continue to do so by ever wider margins, he said. In 1980, cash flow was 92 percent of capital expenditures. He noted that balance sheet leverage was declining. In the first six months of 1981, the company retired $87 million in long-term debt, ''mostly prime-related,'' to reduce the total to $883 million on June 30. **********Mr. Trainer said that McDonald's ''has a consistency that is extremely hard to find; it is one of the few companies among the socalled 'nifty fifty' of the late 1960's that hasn't stubbed its toe; I am an aggressive buyer of the shares.'' **********Robert Emerson, who follows McDonald's for Fred Alger & Company and looks for even higher growth than Mr. Trainer, said: ''The problem Wall Street has had with McDonald's is the slowing growth rate. In the mid-1970's, growth was about 30 percent, and it gradually slowed to the 16 percent area in the late 1970's. But this year the growth is accelerating to about 20 percent, and the rate could be 21 to 22 percent next year.'' **********He added that the key to McDonald's success now is that McDonald's is so profitable and is such a cash generator it can open 500 stores and increase market share even as it pays off debt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/14/busin.main_headline: Patents; Avoiding Closed Eyes As Photos Are Taken
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/14/busin.print_headline: Patents; Avoiding Closed Eyes As Photos Are Taken
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/14/busin.body_text: **********An engineer for the Eastman Kodak Company, Rochester, has found a way to avoid poor photographs of people who shut their eyes. Before the exposure begins, a flash of light is released to cause the subject to blink. **********About a quarter-second after the flash, when the subject raises the eyelids again, the picture is made. **********William H. Cushman obtained patent 4,299,464 for the method and apparatus. The equipment can be made to operate both the flash and shutter upon pressure of a single button. In group photographs, as of schoolchildren, one estimate is that the number of closed eyes shown will be less than 1 percent. **********Another of the half-dozen Kodak patents granted this week is aimed at restoring lost data from camera memories. Donald M. Harvey, a design engineer, obtained patent 4,299,466. Such a memory would keep track of exposures made in a roll of film by counting the perforations in the edge. If the battery failed, the total would be lost. The invention will rewind and return the film strip so the count can be made again.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/01/world.body_text: **********AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Sept. 30 -President Jean-Claude Duvalier said tonight that he expected that the United States would provide new economic and social aid soon to this poverty-stricken country. **********Mr. President made his comments in a rare and brief appearance here before reporters who sought to learn details of a joint agreement between the United States and Haiti aimed at stopping the migration of Haitians to the United States. **********The occasion was his appearance for a picture session that followed a meeting with Gov. Bob Graham of Florida, in whose state thousands of Haitians have sought refuge in past months, and Ernest H. Preeg, the new American Ambassador to Haiti, who worked out the agreement with Government officials here. **********President Duvalier, speaking through an interpreter, characterized his one-hour meeting with the American officials as ''extremely positive,'' adding that Governor Graham ''will be bringing in assistance to help us bring a solution to our problems.'' 'We Will Receive a Proposition' **********Mr. Duvalier also said that ''very soon we will receive a proposition'' from President Reagan for further economic and social aid. Neither Mr. Duvalier nor the American officials elaborated. **********American officials denied that the economic aid proposals discussed today were tied to Haitian Government acceptance of a plan to halt migration to the United States. But the tone of comments by the Americans appeared to indicate that there was a connection. **********Governor Graham, who has been pressing Federal officials for tougher enforcement of immigration laws, said he was organizing a trade mission to visit Haiti from Florida in the next 60 days to explore ways that private business could help stimulate Haiti's agriculture business, which is the economic base of this country and which employs 79 percent of the workers here. He said that relief of many of the problems here would ''ease the pressure'' on those who seek to leave to improve their standard of living. But the Governor seemed to imply that the depth of his commitment depended on the seriousness with which Haiti responded to the refugee problem. 'Move With Boldness' **********''I told the President that one way the Haitian Government can revive the confidence of the American investor is to demonstrate that it is a law-abiding nation,'' Governor Graham said of his talks with Mr. Duvalier. ''This is an important time for Haiti to move with boldness to make itself attractive, Mr. Graham said, noting that that many other Caribbean nations seek American business. **********The Governor said Mr. Duvalier ''indicated a commitment'' to make Haiti more attractive by carrying out a program announced in August to improve and build roads and utilities and establish a new development policy. **********The two American officials said in response to a question that no discussion about the human rights of Haitian refugees was made.  Ambassador Preeg said he had been assured by Haitian officials that Haitian migrants returned as innocent victims of ''traffickers'' would not be prosecuted, whereas those who profited would be. He said that that to his knowledge the Government had taken no punitive action against ''traffickers,'' who officials say have been luring Haitians into boats unsuited for the trip to the United States. Details to Be Worked Out Soon **********Mr. Preeg said the details of President Reagan's new policy on Haitian migrants were to be worked out in ear ly October. Mr. Reagan ordered the Coast Guard yesterday to begin in tercepting ships in international waters if the vessels are suspected of carry ing illegalmigrants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/24/busin.main_headline: MARKET DIP: IMPACT ON THE BIG AND SMALL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/24/busin.print_headline: MARKET DIP: IMPACT ON THE BIG AND SMALL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/24/busin.body_text: **********Professional money managers, chastened by plummeting stock prices, are regrouping for what many of them believe will be a modest recovery in stock values sometime next year. **********Rather than spurning stocks, most are scavenging eagerly for bargains in both stocks and bonds. Many are already buying.  ''We think we're near the bottom in both the stock and bond markets,'' said Donald R. Kurtz, executive vice president for securities investments for the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States. Despite having lost money so far in 1981 for Equitable's pension fund accounts, ''we're becoming fairly fully invested,'' he added. **********The profess ionals, as they are known on Wall Street, did not panic during August and the first half of September, when the market suffered its worst drubbing of the year. Few have reduced their stockholdings belo w 50 percent of the total assets under their aegis. Highinterest rate s have enticed major institutions, such as the Bank of America Inves tment Management Corporation an d the Alliance Capital Management Corporation, to put up to 20 percent of their a ssets into the short-term money market. **********Yet keeping a majority of assets of institutional accounts invested in stocks is typical. At the end of last year, for instance, 65 percent of pension fund assets were invested in stocks, with 35 percent in bonds, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission. 'Not Until 1982' **********''Nobody is going to make money in the stock market until 1982,'' Mr. Kurtz said. The market's latest tumble is only another dip along a long road they are traveling, most of the money managers said confindently. **********''We're not short-term players, we're in the market for the long run,'' asserted William Iglehart, vice president for common stocks at the Aetna Life and Casualty Company. **********In interviews, some managers of the larger institutional investors were quick to dismiss the much-vented worry about a deepening Federal deficit, arguing instead that the Administration's economic program was likely to soften the pace of inflation and spur the economy if the Federal Reserve Board did not weaken its steady grip on the nation's money supply. Scope of Their Holdings **********Money managers have notable influence on movements in stock prices. Institutions managed stocks valued at $519.9 billion at the end of 1980, or roughly a third of the total value of common stocks of American companies, according to the S.E.C. (The total value was $1.600 billion.) **********Foreigners held stocks valued at $114.5 billion, with other domestic stock investors, primarily individuals, owning shares worth $938.9 billion. On the New York Stock Exchange, institutions owned $440 billion at the end of last year, or 35.4 percent of the total value of $1,200 billion for all common stocks listed on the exchange, according to the exchange. **********Many of the professionals already have begun to place their bets on specific stocks and industries that they believe are likely to outperform the broader market in the coming months. They point out, however, that bonds appear to be a better buy for making money quickly. Some of the Favorites **********Dave H. Williams, chairman of Alliance Capital, which shepherds more than $10 billion in pension funds, is favoring stocks that will benefit from increased consumer spending. Recent Alliance purchases included Walmart, General Motors, Cox Broadcasting and Delta Air Lines. Stocks in favor are among other fund managers include MCA, Coca-Cola and General Electric, plus utilities like Commonwealth Edison, Consolidated Edison, Houston Natural Gas and Florida Power and Light. **********''We think we're in for a long period of declining interest rates,'' Mr. Williams said. ''We're very light on energy stocks, but are fairly heavily invested in specialty retailers and consumer goods manufacturers.'' Alliance also is accumulating bonds with eight- to 10-year maturities, he said. **********Eliot Williams, president of the Travelers Investment Management Company, a unit of the Travelers Insurance Company, said ten-year bonds, with yields of 15 percent or more, were paying so much that only further, sharp rises in interest rates could render them poor investments. Travelers has extended its retreat from stocks, and is buying bonds. Attractiveness of Bonds **********''Looking out over the next six to twelve months, bonds are at least as attractive as stocks,'' acknowledged Robert G. Wade Jr., president of the Bank of American Investment Management Corporation.  ''But stocks selected now should do extremely well over the next two to three years.'' **********Mr. Iglehart of Aetna says that buying bank, insurance and other financial service companies should be profitable in 1982 if the surprisingly protracted run of high interest rates abates. ''But we would change our strategy in a lot of ways if the Federal Reserve eases its monetary policy,'' he cautioned. ''That would put us back into the inflation kick, making the energy area and other inflation hedges much more attractive.'' **********Many of the managers said, however, that they believed the Fed would continue its tight grip on the growth of the money supply. They acknowledged that the monetary policy was already squeezing the availability of credit within the economy and that a stiff recession might be unfolding. ''That is w hy the market has been scared,'' said Dave Williams of Alliance Capi tal. Mr. Iglehart deflected the notion that the anticipated g rowth of the Federal deficit, causing the Government to borrow more a nd keep interest rates high, would be the main cause of a recession.  ''The issue of the deficit is irrelevant compared to theimportance of monetary policy ,'' Mr. Iglehart said. **********A recession would depress corporate earnings in what a few months ago was expected to be a strong economy in 1982. But ''the potential for earnings gains is really substantial when the recovery comes'' after the Administration's investment and savings incentives have taken hold, said Mr. Kirby of Capital Guardian.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/17/world.body_text: **********A Zimbabawe army ammunition dump caught fire today, setting off six hours of explosions. **********The Defense Ministry, ruling out sabotage, said the cause was the accidental explosion of a gas cylinder. **********There was no official report on casualties. Ambulances were seen leaving the area and racing toward Salisbury, 20 miles away.  The sky over the barracks, northwest of Zimbabwe's capital, was lit up by rockets, mortar shells and grenades. The barracks houses, among other units, the army's First Parachute Battalion and mounted regiments. **********Bullets and shrapnel riccocheted around the camp after each blast.  Buildings were engulfed by fierce fires that officials said might take two days to extinguish.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/14/busin.body_text: **********I have just finished reading ''When Amway Opportunity Knocks'' (May 31) by Matthew L. Wald. I was drawn to read the article because of the word Amway. I am one of the 750,000 Amway distributors that Mr.  Wald wrote about. **********Mr. Wald evidently believes that with his various jibes and journalistic innuendoes, he has belittled these distributors.  Speaking for myself, I found the reverse to be true. Some very positive aspects were evident for the discerning reader: *********** ''The Amway totals are staggering; founded in 1959, the privately held company reported sales of $1.1 billion in the 12 months ending Aug. 31, 1980 ...'' *********** The Federal Trade Commission investigation begun in 1975 found ''the bulk of its operation was judged legal.'' (Actually, Amway won.) *********** ''For those with faith, it seemed, all things are possible.'' *********** Janice Santovasi, of Vernon, Conn., describing dropping out of Amway, is quoted: ''I guess I didn't believe in it enough myself. I couldn't get up there and explain it to them, and get very enthusiastic.'' **********I think the article was slanted to show Mr. Wald's clever turn of phrase, rather than to inform his readers in a straightforward manner of his encounter with one Amway distributor. It is easy to spice up a story. I could do so rather easily by questioning his expectations when he implies that he was lured to a strange woman's apartment. **********I would like to address Mr. Wald's astonishment at the failure of the Amway distributor to disclose her profits. I challenge him to contact 20 or so people in business or otherwise and see how many disclose their income. The corner delicatessen man, his most respected Congressman (who is bound by law to full disclosure), the fellow pounding out a story in another office of The Times, is hard pressed to be completely honest in this regard. Mr. Wald might even try asking his mother-in-law or his best friend, and I will wager he would not be able to separate fact from fiction. **********Mr. Wald contacted the Amway Corporation to ascertain the volume of the average distributor. He was told the average doesn't mean a lot, but he evidently disputed this fact. In order to bring this idea into focus for him, I would suggest that he research the average income of writers. Or actors. Does that discourage the thousands of college students studying journalism today? Does that account for the long waiting lists to enroll in the prestigious drama schools? **********Mr. Wald questioned the ''retention rate'' or survival rate of Amway distributors. I suggest he question the turnover rate of any business or industry he chooses. Start with The New York Times. Then General Motors. How many times do you get waited on by the same clerk in your local ''7-11'' or Waldbaum's? All this research might be enlightening. **********I could continue discussing each and every point of the article.  Instead, I would just like to put on record that Mr. Wald is only one person with one opinion. He saw only one distributor's effort to take a shot at improving her financial status. I applaud anyone who tries to better him or herself, and I deplore the negative media who make their living dredging up the worst in any given situation and relishing every opportunity to do so. **********You, Mr. Wald, take your way! I will stick with Amway.  RITA C. SWEENEY Baldwin, N.Y., June 2, 1981

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/01/world.main_headline: THE CASBAH IS CAVING IN, BUT RESTORATION PROJECTS ARE FACING MANY PROBLEMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/01/world.print_headline: THE CASBAH IS CAVING IN, BUT RESTORATION PROJECTS ARE FACING MANY PROBLEMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/01/world.body_text: **********The Casbah, with its maze of cobblestone stairs and alleys, windowless homes and flat, connecting roofs, is crumbling. **********Buildings in this part of the city, once the central business district, tend to collapse with alarming frequency. Wooden poles prop up shaky walls, patched roofs continue to leak and sewer breaks send rivulets down the steep streets where children play. **********''We'd like to get out, but there's no place to go,'' Mohammed Makhloufi, a cinema operator, told a visitor at his home. ''We got scared when the house next door fell down recently and cracks began to appear in our walls.'' **********One of the fine old mansions of the Casbah, the Makhloufi house, with its tiled, Moorish-style balconies and arches, marble stairs and fountain, was built for one family. Today there are 14 families living in the 14-room house, each family with seven to ten people in a room. There is no kitchen or bathroom to speak of, only three Turkish toilets, but the house is scrupulously clean. Too Many People **********The main problem of the Casbah, in fact of Algiers as a whole, is overcrowding. In precolonial times, prior to 1830, the Casbah was the city of Algiers, with a population of 30,000. Then came the French colonial settlement, the general rush to the cities and a high population growth rate in Algeria of 3.2 percent. Today, between 80,000 and 100,000 people live in the 110-acre Casbah. They represent only a small part of the Algerian capital, which has a population of more than two million. **********An international effort to rehabilitate the Casbah is under way.  ''We must displace one-half of the population of the Casbah,'' said Hiroshmi Daifuku, an American consultant with the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. Mr. Daifuku is one of a small group of international experts working with Algerian architects on a project called The Conservation and the Rehabilitation of the Casbah of Algiers. **********There have been debates for the last decade over what to do about the Casbah, but until now no serious reconstruction plans were drafted. **********Some people argued that the Casbah should be emptied and converted into a museum and tourist area. Others thought that it was more urgent to resolve the housing shortage and that the whole place should be razed to make room for decent housing. A Plan for Restoration **********Two years ago, the Algerian Government turned to Unesco for help.  Tugrul Akcura, a Turkish professor of town planning who has worked on the restoration of the cities of Fez in Morocco and Mecca in Saudi Arabia, is considered the father of the new plan for the Casbah. **********Mr. Akcura and a team of foreign consultants together with young Algerian architects of the Atelier, or Workshop of the Casbah, have carried out detailed studies of the Casbah and drafted a renovation plan. The plan is to be submitted to the Algerian Government next month. **********''Our aim is to restore the urban fabric of the Casbah as a whole, physically, socially, economically,'' Raci Bademli, another Turkish consultant, told visitors in the Atelier offices, located in the ancient governor's palace, which itself is undergoing restoration. **********Mr. Bademli recently completed a study of small workshops in the Casbah, which became a slum area in the 1940's, when the modern, largely French section of the city emerged. There are today about 500 shops -jewelers and clockmakers, tailors and shoemakers, repairers and carpenters, leather-product makers and weavers - scattered hither and yon. Residential and Business Zones **********The upper part of the Casbah is scheduled to be restored as a residential quarter, Mr. Bademli said, with the workshops shifted to the lower Casbah, which will be zoned as a business district. **********''We're trying to reintegrate the Casbah into the life of the city,'' said Scheherazade Nafa, an Algerian architect, who added that under French rule the area had become a ''Moslem ghetto.'' **********The principal need is to establish a mechanism for financing the restoration, according to Mr. Akcura. He said that almost all property in the Casbah was privately owned and that the people did not have the money to pay for restoration. **********''The state will have to subsidize the works in part,'' Mr. Akcura said. He estimated that it would cost $140,000 to restore a house in the Casbah. The Housing Problem **********Algeria, however, already has a huge housing deficit. The people who lack any housing must be helped before the Government will consider the enormous improvements required in the Casbah, according to Algerians working on the Casbah project. **********Algeria's new five-year plan introduced last year emphasizes social needs, particularly housing, and calls for the construction of 100,000 dwelling units a year. Housing units are now going up at a rate of 20,000 a year, a pace that does not keep up with the population increase. **********There is also the problem of El Asnam, the city 100 miles southwest of Algiers that was devastated by an earthquake last October. At least 5,000 people were killed and 200,000 were left homeless. The city has become the Algerian Government's top priority, and most international aid has gone to the regugees of El Asnam. **********Nevertheless, the people of the Atelier said that it was becoming more urgent to to something about the Casbah. Of a total of 1,700 houses, there are 457 houses in ''very bad condition,'' compared with 100 five years ago, according to Ahmed Koumas, an Algerian architect. **********Houses are pronounced dangerous when it is apparent that they could fall down at any time. The familes who are forced to evacuate those houses are lodged in ''dormitories,'' dark cellars under the market. The Glory That Was **********A tour of the Casbah shows little of the glamour of the days of World War II or the Battle of Algiers in 1957, when the French besieged this nationalist fortress. **********Instead, there are children everywhere, playing in the rubble of a fallen house or in the garbage heaps in the few vacant lots. Sturdy donkeys, the only means of conveyance to master the steep cobblestone stairs, bring in goods of all kinds and serve as garbage collectors.  There are scenes of dire poverty - veiled women with plastic bags picking up dung to take home for use as firewood. **********''People with money are no longer interested in the old houses in the Casbah because they can't get to them by car and prefer a villa in the new city,'' Miss Nafa said. ''If we can make this a decent living area, I'm sure it will become fashionable again to come to the Casbah.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/19/busin.body_text: **********Italy's state-owned gas company has signed a preliminary agreement to buy about 300 billion cubic feet of natural gas a year from the Soviet Union starting in 1984, officials said.  The announcement Friday of the Oct. 6 agreement was the first firm commitment by a West European country to purchase Siberian gas. **********The Reagan Administration has urged European nations not to buy the gas on the ground that it would make the countries too dependent on the Soviet Union for fuel supplies. **********The gas would be supplied through a planned 3,100-mile Siberia-Europe pipeline, for which the engineering subsidiary of Italy's state oil company, ENI, recently won a contract to build 19 pumping stations. The pricing structure for the agreement has not been completed. **********Moscow is offering to sell about 1,600 billion cubic feet of gas a year to West European countries and many, especically West Germany, are interested in buying the gas to reduce their dependence on imported oil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/17/world.body_text: **********France's new Socialist Government has approved what may be the most far-reaching of all its proposals, the decentralization of government. **********The measure, called ''the rights and liberties of the communities, departments and regions,'' was described by Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy as ''the most important business of our seven-year term.'' President Francois Mitterrand had made decentralization one of the key planks in his campaign platform. **********''We must rid ourselves of what remains of Napoleon's ancien regime,'' Mr. Mauroy said recently. **********Assembly Approval Certain **********''The men of the chateaus are gone now,'' he said, referring to the defeated Government of Valery Giscard d'Estaing. ''We must acomplish the historic task of creating a republic of citizens.'' **********The decentralization program, which is sure to be approved by the Socialist majority in the National Assembly, calls for a transfer of power from the departmental prefects, appointed by the Government in Paris, to regional and departmental councils. **********The plan, which will take effect over three years, in effect calls for the dismantling of a form of government that has been virtually unchanged for more than four centuries, except for the chaos of the Revolution, after which Napoleon re-established the strong central control that had existed under the monarchy. **********The first step in the new plan, to be carried out almost immediately, is to end the powers of the 21 regional and 96 departmental prefects. Their most important powers are negative. They have the right of veto over all administrative and fiscal actions approved by local governments. **********The second step, to be accomplished within a year, will exactly define the powers of the bodies replacing the prefects - the regional and departmental councils. The final segment of the plan will determine to what extent local authorities will be responsible for their own finances. **********Even some of Mr. Mitterrand's opponents in the campaign endorsed his decentralization proposal. There is almost no French citizen who has not suffered frustration at the hands of the central Government - or suffered neglect from it. Anyone who has read Balzac is familiar with the hatred and suspicion provincial France traditionally has felt for the Government in Paris. ''This is a country of petits fonctionnaires, little clerks,'' is a common and ancient complaint. Everything Through Paris **********Stories of waiting 10 years to get a road approved in Angouleme or four years to get a street name changed in Nimes are routine, for almost everything that is done by a government agency must pass through the appropriate ministry in Paris. **********The prefects, ranking civil servants with good Paris connections, have been transferred like ambassadors from one department to another with no thought to their familiarity with local problems or local politics. **********Under the proposed law, the elected leaders of local governing bodies, along with the elected regional and departmental councils, will have the right to determine their own budgets without advance approval from Paris or from the new ''commissioners of the republic,'' who will be appointed by Paris but who will have mostly consultative roles. **********At least that is what the Mauroy Government is saying. There are some skeptics. ''In France,'' said Charles-Noel Hardy, a Giscardian and prefect of the department of Loire-et-Cher until the Socialist victory, ''when one really doesn't want to change things fundamentally, one changes their name.'' Fiscal Watchdogs Curbed **********Also losing out in the new arrangement are the regional paymasters-general, budgetary watchdogs appointed by the Ministry of Finance in Paris who, like the prefects, have had absolute veto power over local expenditures. Their powers, too, are to be diminished. **********The new law has been dubbed the Defferre law after the Gaston Defferre, Interior Minister in the new Government, a long-time Socialist politician and Mayor of Marseilles for almost 40 years. **********Mr. Defferre has been in charge of preparing the decentralization legislation since Mr. Mitterrand's victory May 10. There is some irony in this since he has governed Marseilles with an iron hand and neither prefects nor fiscal inspectors nor even heads of state crossed him lightly. **********Not everyone approves of the new program. Objectors include those who believe the Constitution demands that such a profound change be put to the voters in referendum and leaders of the conservative political minority who see France's fundamental strength emanating from its strong central government. Prefects' Contribution Cited **********''It would be sad to see the title of prefect disappear,'' said Roger Genebrier, a former prefect, writing in Le Monde. ''Our corps has contributed enormously to the grandeur of the nation. The prefects assumed by delegation from successive governments the permanence and heavy responsibility of the general administration.  And in troubled times, they have been in the provinces the principal maintainance of the state and of the republic.'' **********Then too, many of the mayors of France's tiny villages - 90 percent of the country's 36,000 incorporated communities have fewer than 2,000 inhabitants - have neither the desire nor in some instances the competence to deal with fiscal matters. **********Andre Reny, the Mayor of Girancourt, a town of 516 people in the Vosges, said he had no faith in local democracy. He recalled a questionnaire about increasing local responsibilities that was sent to 520 mayors in his region in 1976. ''Only 121 of them responded,'' he said, ''and all they were interested in was how to get more money from the Government because of a serious drought we were having at the time.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/27/busin.body_text: **********The Brazilian Government has adopted a new gold policy aimed at increasing its reserves of the metal, the Finance Ministry said today. A meeting of the National Monetary Council, a top decision making body, decided to give the central bank wide powers to buy and sell the metal on the domestic market at international prices, a ministry spokesman said. Exports would be prohibited; the central bank would be a buyer offering London bullion market prices or above.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/03/world.print_headline: Seoul Jails 9 Students for Leading A Demonstration Against Regime
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/03/world.body_text: **********Nine students of Seoul National University were given prison sentences of one to three years today for having led an anti-Government demonstration on the university campus last December, court officials said. **********The nine were found guilty of contravening martial law decrees and violating South Korea's stern anti-Communist law. Police charged that their leaflets had attacked the Government, had said that Japan and the United States were not the country's allies so long as they supported a ''fascist regime'' and had contained seditious pro-Communist slogans. **********Student demonstrations demanding the resignation of President Chun Doo Hwan continued on the campus last week. One student plunged to his death from the fifth floor of the university library during a protest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/11/busin.body_text: **********Fresh from a House of Representatives victory for the Reagan Administration last week on its budget, Treasury Donald T. Regan said today that the White House was counting on popular support to ''give us the victory'' for the Kemp-Roth tax cut of 30 percent over three years. **********But two House Democratic leaders expressed doubt today that President Reagan could translate his popularity and momentum from his budget victory into enactment of the tax cut plan. **********Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said that ''unless commitments have changed,'' the Democrats and some Republicans on the panel would prefer a less extensive one-year tax cut that he has proposed, or some compromise. **********Mr. Rostenkowski and Thomas S. Foley, the Democratic majority whip, both called the Reagan-backed Kemp-Roth plan dangerously inflationary. **********Tax Burdens 'Inequitable' **********Mr. Foley also said it was ''inequitable'' because it ''puts most of the tax relief on very high income people rather than on the bulk of the middle class.'' **********All three made their comments on television network news programs.  Mr. Regan was interviewed on ABC's ''Issues and Answers,'' Mr.  Rostenkowski on CBS's ''Face the Nation,'' and Mr. Foley on NBC's ''Meet the Press.'' **********Mr. Rostenkowski, whose committee originates tax measures, acknowledged the President's political strength and declined to predict a victory for his own plan. Dangers of Tax Cut **********He said that many conservative Democrats and Republicans who supported the President in the budget vote shared his own view that a three-year tax cut and the larger deficits that it would entail would be ''dangerous'' in light of ''the unpredictability of the economy.'' **********He said that he would be open to discussions of a possible compromise with Republican leaders including the President.  Mr. Regan, on the other hand, said the Administration was ''standing firm'' on its proposed three-year tax cut as an ''integral part'' of the President's economic recovery program, and predicted an Administration victory. **********''The support is out there for President Reagan's tax cut proposals,'' Mr. Regan said. Popular Support **********''People actually do want a stop in the amount of money that they are paying to the Federal Government.'' he said.  Mr. Regan appeared to keep the door to possible compromise barely open by saying that he would listen to proposals for a tax cut smaller than the $54 billion that the Administration proposes for the first of the three years if they could ''accomplish the same thing.'' **********But he said that alternative proposals made so far, apparently including those made by Mr. Rostenkowski, ''would negate the effects of what the President wants to do,'' and ''would just be adding little baubles on.'' **********He denied that the Administration was in a mood to compromise ''even on dollar figures,'' at this point, although Republican leaders have said privately that the President may have to make some compromise eventually of about $40 billiion to retain about the same $10 billion saving for business that the President's plan calls for in the first year, and would save individuals about $14 billion less.  Incentives For Savings **********The Rostenkowski plan also contains specific incentives for savings and investment and provisions to deal with such problems as the marriage ''penalty'' for working couples. **********Mr. Foley said that ''some of our Southern conservatives and others in the party that voted with the Administration on the overall budget resolution are going to feel very differently about the tax cut,'' and would oppose President Reagan's plan despite his ''great popularity.'' **********He credited the President's success in identifying ''the general consensus in the country to limit federal spending'' as being responsible for the defection of 63 Democrats who supported the President's budget proposals, rather than those of their own party, and conceded that ''perhaps we didn't do a very good job'' at selling the Democratic program to the voters, ''particularly in the districts of members who were concerned about voting against the President.'' **********But Mr. Foley predicted that the Democratic leadership would have greater success selling its tax-cutting plan because of widespread fears that the President's plan would be inflationary as well as weighed in favor of more wealthy taxpayers. **********Mr. Regan, in remarks on other subjects, said that ''high interest rates are not a tool of this Administration'' and tempered his prediction last week that rates would probably stay high for several months by stating that ''I'd like to see them start coursing down, and it's my judgment that in a couple of months they will start coursing down.'' **********He said that last week's 20-point stock market slide was caused by a jump in the money supply and a resulting increase in interest rates and rejected suggestions that it reflected lack of business confidence in the Reagan economic program. **********The Treasury Secretary also said the Administration will have a ''final package'' of proposals for trimming Social Security outlays this week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/21/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates presented a puzzling picture last week. They seemed to be declining as the week started. I.B.M. announced a $250 million issue of two-year debentures. Chemical Bank trimmed its prime lending rate to 19 percent. Then short-term rates unexpectedly rose sharply.  I.B.M canceled its issue. On Friday, Bankers Trust and Marine Midland raised their prime rate to 20 percent from 19.5 percent. But when money supply figures were issued Friday afternoon, they showed only a slight $500 million rise in the week ended June 10, which would normally be an outlook for lower rates. **********The economy is putting in a flat performance this quarter, the Government said in a preliminary report. But inflation is slowing.  First-quarter results were revised, with expansion put at an 8.6 percent annual rate, up from 8.4 percent estimated earlier. **********Housing starts slumped 14 percent in May. Durable goods orders declined by four-tenths of 1 percent in May. Personal income rose a slight six-tenths of 1 percent in the month. Industrial production gained three-tenths of 1 percent. **********Auto sales rose 11.5 percent in the first 10 days of June, compared with depressed sales in the year-earlier period, the Big Three makers said. **********Stocks declined on the week. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 10.09 points to finish at 996.19.  Oil prices continued under pressure. Britain agreed to cut the price of crude from the North Sea by $4.25 a barrel to $35. The move was expected to put pressure on African producers. **********Conoco, the nation's ninth-largest oil company, said it had received a $2 billion bid from an undientified foreign comany to buy a quarter of its stock. It said it rejected the proposal, but was talking merger with another company. **********The Allied Corporation plans to sell two Canadian oil subsidiaries for a combined price of $391.3 million. Husky Oil will buy Uno-Tex, and Drummond Petroleum will acquire Union Texas of Canada. **********The textile industry lost its argument in the Supreme Court that the cost of government regulation must be balanced against benefits.  The industry must now meet expensive standards that limit exposure to cotton dust. **********A.T.& T. net rose 10.8 percent to $1.62 billion in its quarter ended May 30, compared with 1980 results. A.& P. said it lost $10.4 million in that quarter. AM International lost $82.2 million for its third quarter ended April 30. **********Genentech, working with International Minerals and Chemicals, helped develop a vaccine against foot and mouth disease in livestock with the gene-splicing technique. **********U.S. Industries plans to shed 14 of its less profitable divisions, which will mean a write-off of $117 million and a loss for the year.  The Tribune Company, publisher of The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York, bought the National League Chicago Cubs for $20.5 million from William Wrigley. **********Avon Products called on Tiffany last week and installed its chairman and chief executive, David W. Mitchell, 53, in identical posts at the prestigious New York jewelry subsidiary. The loser in the shuffle was Henry B. Platt, (right) who relinquished the posts, but who will become vice chairman. Mr. Platt, 56, is a descendant of Tiffany's founder, Charles L. Tiffany. He had been chairman since January, when he took over from Walter Hoving on the latter's retirement. Avon bought Tiffany in 1979 for $104 million in stock.
