https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; WHILE AWAITING MERGER, INA REALIGNS DUTIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/12/busin.body_text: **********Following Monday's announcement that the INA Corporation and the Connecticut General Corporation plan to merge, forming what would be the nation's sixth-largest insurance company, INA has named a new chief operating officer to handle its day-to-day operations. John R.  Cox, 49, INA's senior executive vice president, will assume the additional title on Nov. 25. **********This action follows the disclosure that Ralph S. Saul, 59, INA's chairman, president and chief executive officer, will also become chairman and co-chief executive officer of the merged company - to be called the North American General Corporation. Analysts indicated that Mr. Saul would probably be busy first with the merger arrangements and then with getting the new corporation under way and that Mr. Cox would probably take over some of Mr. Saul's INA duties. **********''I've got $5 billion worth of revenue to concern myself with,'' Mr. Cox said in a telephone interview from his Philadelphia office.  ''We've got others to take care of the merger.'' **********In describing his new role, Mr. Cox added: ''We previously had two operating groups within the company, but with the sale of Hospital Affiliates International earlier this year, it really came down to one: insurance. The integration of the management strength is what I'm going to have to spend time on. But obviously I'm not going to let the marketing go down either. Otherwise none of us can eat.'' **********Mr. Cox started at the American International Group in 1959, and 13 years later he became president of its American Life subsidiary. He moved to INA in 1975 as executive vice president and chief financial officer, advancing to his present position last year. When Mr. Cox becomes chief operating officer, his other post as president of INA's Insurance Company of North America subsidiary will be assumed by Donald G. Heth, 59. **********''It's the most competitive time I've ever been in, and I don't think it's going to get any easier in the next two years,'' Mr. Cox remarked. ''Frankly, there is too much capital chasing too little business. I talk like a pessimist, but I'm really a bull.'' Leonard Sloane

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/31/busin.body_text: **********misunderstood, much-slandered, whiskered item, is generally known as something Southerners eat, Northerners throw back in the lake and Westerners would not recognize if they fell over it. **********But big profits in the 16-year-old catfish farming industry, plus booming growth last year, are quickly changing the catfish's status from a regional delicacy to a nationally marketed product. United States agribusiness conglomerates are said to be eyeing the industry, as are farmers in a number of foreign countries. **********For Dolores and Charles Rowland, soybean farmers in Humphreys County, Miss., raising catfish began eight years ago as ''just something to play around with, like a hobby,'' Mrs. Rowland said. **********But the couple say they have made more money in the last three years off their 70 acres of fish ponds than from their 1,000 acres of soybeans. ''We were using the fish to pay for our losses on beans,'' Mr. Rowland said, which moved them last year to quadruple their pond acreage and stop farming soybeans altogether. **********Catfish culture started in the mid-1960's as the hobby of a few entrepreneurial Mississippi and Arkansas farmers. It has now spread to some 70,000 acres in 16 states, mostly in the South. Mississippi leads with 63 percent of the pond acreage, followed by Alabama, Arkansas, California, Texas, Georgia and Missouri. The 1980 harvest brought in 76.7 million pounds of channel catfish worth $54 million to growers - double the haul just two years before. And the windfall led to a pond building explosion last year that will double the crop again in 1982. But compared with the 216.9 million pounds of flounder harvested last year, worth $82.5 million, catfish have a way to go. **********With supplies overflowing the traditional Deep South and Middle West markets, catfish processors began to hire salesmen to market the fish to restaurants and supermarket chains in Texas, the upper Middle West and California. The fish are now being shipped to 36 states, including Alaska and Hawaii. **********The toughest markets to crack, it is said, will be the seafood-rich Northeast and Northwest, where catfish is still disdained as a lowly ''trash fish,'' unfit for good eating. **********Mention of this unsavory fish is not without justification. The ''wild'' catfish tend to have flavor problems. They are by nature hardy scavengers that thrive in polluted waters, and as a result, their flesh can have a dank, musty flavor. About half the catfish sold in the United States belong to this wild variety, caught in American rivers and lakes or imported from the Brazilian Amazon. **********Farm-raised fish are more expensive than the wild type, but they have the advantage of being grown in a controlled environment and fed a high-protein grain, soybean and fishmeal diet. The product is not cheap - fillets retail around $3.69 a pound - but the flesh has a mild flavor, no odor, a low cholesterol and a lot of protein. **********Tommy Taylor, agriculture extension agent for Humphreys County in Mississippi, otherwise known as the Catfish Capital of the World, has taken a more optimistic outlook on the new product. ''You don't have to change people's taste to sell catfish,'' he said. ''Once they bite into it, they're hooked.'' One of Mr. Taylor's professional assets is that he can recite catfish recipes in rapid succession. All of them, he says, are ''so good they'll make you slap your Granma.'' **********To the grower, the appeal in catfish is the money. In a good year, catfish bring in three times more per acre than cotton and rice, and five times more than soybeans. **********Catfish are fairly invulnerable to such natural forces as drought and heat, and last year they thrived, despite the dry weather.  ''Farmers were sitting there watching their cotton and soybeans burn up,'' said Charles Estess, assistant agriculture extension agent for Humphreys County. ''That made catfish look all the better.'' **********Indeed, catfish have seemed such a promising investment that even high interest rates have not damped an epidemic of pond-building fever. In the Mississippi Delta, the heart of the industry, the pond acreage jumped by nearly 50 percent in 1980 and is expected to increase by at least 40 percent this year. **********A profitable catfish business first requires heavy clay soil to form a stable pond, a cheap supply of clean water, flat land and a warm climate. In Mississippi, which averages 240 days a year of weather no cooler than 65-degrees, six-inch fingerlings put in the ponds in March will usually be ready to harvest in November at 1 1/4 pounds, the size the processors prefer. **********And startup costs average between $3,500 and $4,000 an acre for land, pond construction and equipment, plus another $1,800 an acre for the first year's operations costs. **********T HERE are risks, however, chiefly oxygen depletion and disease. If oxygen levels in the pond drop too low, the fish will die within minutes. During the active growing months -March to October - farmers become fanatical pond checkers using special aerating equipment at night when oxygen levels are lowest. Sometimes an entire pond will die anyway - an instant loss of as much as $50,000. **********The disease problem is just as troublesome. Even to the experts, many ailments are still mysteries. A whole pond may thicken and the fish die within a few days. ''We're just completely in the dark,'' complained Neal Berryhill, president of Catfish Farmers of Mississippi, who himself lost $100,000 worth of fish last winter to disease. ''The research is years behind us. We're just feeding fish and crossing our fingers.'' **********But the rewards match the risks. With current prices the farmers get at around 70 cents a pound for whole, live fish, a good farmer will average at least $400 an acre per year in pretax profits. If all goes well, he can make twice that much. Part of the profitability is because of the fish's efficient protein-conversion ratio. It needs only 1.6 pounds of food to gain a pound of protein. For chickens, the ratio is 2.4 to 1. **********Promoting the fish seems to be as much as part of the growers as fingerlings and water. Besides Humphreys County calling itself the Catfish Capital, there is a Catfish Queen and a yearly Catfish Festival, complete with a Catfish Eating Contest and a Catfish Cookoff. The festival is held in Belzoni - the seat of the catfish capital - and draws a crowd of 20,000, a sizable number since in all of Humphreys Country there is only one 18-room hotel. **********Investment-hungry corporations, naturally, have started to test the catfish waters. Mark Freeman, executive secretary of Catfish Farmers of America, says he has been inundated with inquiries from major American and foreign companies. Mr. Freeman will not divulge company names, but says agribusiness corporations are showing the most interest. **********And it is not hard to explain all the interest. Even growers who complain most bitterly about the risks of fish farming tend to betray their satisfaction with the profits in subtle ways. What is the accepted ''cure'' for losing $50,000 worth of fish in 30 minutes? Three farmers put it this way recently: ''Sit down on the bank, open a bottle of Jack Daniels, and cry.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/world.main_headline: REAGAN SEEKING MORE 'FLEXIBILITY' TO SET FOREIGN POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/world.print_headline: REAGAN SEEKING MORE 'FLEXIBILITY' TO SET FOREIGN POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration today unveiled a set of legislative proposals designed to provide greater ''flexibility'' in the conduct of foreign policy, including the creation of a $350 million fund to aid foreign buyers of American arms. **********''Circumstances change,'' Under Secretary of State James L.Buckley told the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on international security and scientific affairs, ''and in our view it is vitally important that U.S. foreign policy options not be circumscribed by inflexible statutory provisions.'' **********Some of the measures, however, were immediately criticized by Democrats, who argued that they would weaken Congressional power, accumulated over many years, to affect the tone and direction of American foreign policy. **********''I don't think Congress will abdicate its rightful authority and responsibilities,'' cautioned Representative Clement J. Zablocki, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee.  ''You're asking for a little too much.'' **********In other action, the Administration asked that a Congressional ban on military aid to Argentina be lifted, pointing out that nation's ''strategic location alongside vital lines of communication in the southern Atlantic and its natural resources.'' **********Much of the legislative package announced today has already been reported and has already stirred criticism on Capitol Hill.  For example, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, expressed her concern to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.  that a move at this time to repeal the so-called Clark amendment, which prohibits military assistance to Angola, could adversely affect efforts to negotiate an end to the conflict in South-West Africa and alienate friendly black African countries. **********In his testimony today, Mr. Buckley urged repeal of the Clark amendment, calling it a ''unique and unusually all-e@ncompassing restriction on U.S. policy options toward an individual nation.'' **********But Mr. Buckley also said that ''it is our firm intention to seek viable diplomatic solutions to the problems of the southern African region.'' **********Mr. Buckley went on to urge the repeal of the so-called Symington amendment, which in effect prohibits shipments of nuclear fuel and other forms of assistance to nations that detonate or actively seek to build nuclear weapons. The Adminis@tration wants Congress to adopt language that would make it easier for the President to waive the export ban. **********This request was challenged by Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of New York, who contended that repealing the provision would send Pakistan a signal that it could continue to pursue its efforts to develop nuclear weapons without risking its security relationship with the United States. **********Another proposal that stirred concern today was an Administration request that Congress repeal a law requiring Congressional approval before military aid groups of more than six people may be sent to any country. Mr. Buckley told the panel that the repeal would not lead to proliferation of such groups throughout the world. **********Concern was also voiced about the Administration's previously announced plan to establish a $350 million security assistance contingency fund to address foreign policy crises without specific Congressional approval.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/16/world.print_headline: IN TAIPEI, NO ONE WANTS PEKING TIES; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/16/world.body_text: **********Most of the population of Taiwan listens to the Government's ritual vows to ''recover the mainland'' with a jaded ear and little-disguised derision. **********But the same people - native Taiwanese and those who fled the mainland in 1949 alike -are even less moved by urgings from Peking that this island of 18 million inhabitants place itself under Communist rule. **********The blandishments that accompanied last week's proposal, which amounted to an offer to let Taiwan become China's only province with its own army and capitalist economy and human rights not available to other Chinese, found no more credence among critics of the Government of President Chiang Ching-kuo than they did within the Government. **********Like the opposition to the authoritarian regimes in South Korea, people who oppose the Kuomintang's rigid rule, for reasons of democracy or of Taiwanese nationalist resentment against being governed by mainland refugees, reject submission to the Communist claimants of their country even more strongly. **********Taiwanese Fear a Deal **********Several Taiwanese intellectuals interviewed here expressed the fear that the present Government or a Kuomintang successor - President Chiang is at least 71 years old - might eventually strike a bargain with Peking at the expense of the Taiwanese, who constitute the island's overwhelming majority. **********''The mainlanders have the family ties and the nostalgia,'' a writer said. ''We don't.'' Since the Japanese colonization in 1895, Taiwan has not been ruled by mainland governments. **********Reunification is not an aspiration cherished by many Taiwanese, nor is it considered a realistic hope by the children of those who fled here. ''When you ask me, I will say that I am Sichuanese,'' a woman in her late 30's said. ''But that doesn't mean that I expect to return to where I was born.'' **********Alluding to Taiwanese suspicions that a ''great China'' patriotism that the islanders do not share might prompt a Kuomintang government to accept a Peking offer one day, a senior official rejected a frequently heard contention that the Government was adamant in rejecting all Peking proposals largely because categorical opposition to the Communists was the Kuomintang's main claim to legitimacy for its rule over Taiwan. Flight of Talent Is Feared **********''We reject it for more practical reasons,'' he said. ''We would divide this country if we accepted negotiations with Peking, no matter how hard a stand we adopted.'' **********Government officials, businessmen and foreign business and banking representatives here offered another practical reason for the Government's almost automatic rejection of all offers from Peking.  To raise the possibility that Taiwan might surrender its independence, under whatever guarantees Peking offered, would shake faith in the continuation of the economic policies that have brought about one of the most booming economies in Asia, and lead to a flight not only of capital but also of entrepreneurs and technical and business talent. **********Many highly educated people here hold ''green cards'' that entitle them to permanent residence in the United States.  With surprising unanimity, which is rarely heard among Taiwanese commenting on Government declarations, various versions of the theme ''We have nothing to gain and everything to lose'' were heard in interviews and conversations. No one argued with the view that the Government spokesman, James Soong, expressed in two questions: ''What do we have to give away? What can we get?'' On most other issues, Mr. Soong does not express the views of the other people interviewed. U.S. Called the Audience **********Opponents of the Government also share the official view that Peking's offers are addressed to the United States rather than to Taipei. They are generally regarded as an attempt to depict Peking as conciliatory and Taipei as obdurate and thus to influence the Reagan Administration to weaken further its ties to the nationalists and reduce military sales. **********''If Peking really thought that reunification is a serious subject, they would not make a public ballyhoo but use more discreet channels that are available,'' a foreign professional analyst said. **********Speaking about the Governments on both sides of the Formosa Strait, a Taiwanese writer said: ''There isn't a popular Chinese Government.  We don't want the Communists, and we doubt the sincerity of the K.M.T. We fear one day they will go to the mainland and make a deal without asking us.'' **********Speaking of reunification under either existing regime, he said: ''I am not so ambitious. Maybe in the next generation they will have the wisdom to solve that problem. But the Kuomintang can't drop the idea. If they did consider Taiwan as separate from the mainland, as it is, they would have to change the Government and hold elections, and the President would be a Taiwanese. They would have no excuse to postpone all kinds of reforms.'' **********The state of emergency that has justified restrictions on democratic government since 1949 is based on the claim that the Nationalist Government rules all of China and that Taiwan is only one province in a country still engaged in civil war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/09/world.main_headline: CANADA BLAMES ITSELF FOR HALF OF ITS ACID RAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/09/world.print_headline: CANADA BLAMES ITSELF FOR HALF OF ITS ACID RAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/09/world.body_text: **********A parliamentary subcommittee said today that half of the acid rain falling on Canada ''comes from domestic sources of air pollution.'' It recommended a number of actions within Canada to solve the problem. **********Acid rain, which is precipitation made more acidic than normal by emissions of sulfur and nitrogen oxides into the air, has become a major political irritant between the United States and Canada because of what is regarde d here as a lax attitude by the Federal and state governments a nd private industry in the United States. **********After a study that lasted more than a year, the subcommittee of Parliament's Committee on Fisheries did not absolve the United States of a great part of the blame for the damage done to Canadian lakes, rivers, forests and farm land by acid rain, which it called ''the greatest threat to the North American environment in the recorded history of this continent.'' The report said American sources contributed as much as 70 percent of the acid rain detected in populous southeastern Ontario; it added that three to four times as much sulfur dioxide pollution moved from the United States to Canada as the other way. Auto Standards Weaker **********But noting that most of the nitrogen oxides came from vehicles, the subcommittee said it was ''appalled'' that a motor vehicle in Canada is permitted to emit three times as much nitrogen oxide as a vehicle in the United States. The subcommittee urged that control standards for cars and trucks be made at least as stringent as those that have been in force in the United States since last June. **********The group described the nonferrous smelting industry as the largest source of sulfur dioxide emissions in Canada, and it urged that six major smelters in Manitoba, Ontario and Quebec be forced to reduce their pollution by 80 percent within th e next five years. **********''Canada's nonferrous smelters are owned and operated by very profitable corporations which can afford to implement the necessary technology,'' it said. **********Ontario has begun to apply tighter controls on Canada's biggest single polluter, the smelter operated by International Nickel in Sudbury, which spreads sulfur dioxide over large areas of eastern Canada and the northeastern United States. Worried About Coal Use **********The subcommittee warned that the problem may worsen as the United States converts oil-fueled industries to coal and as Canada makes greater use of coal to generate electricity, notably in the Maritime provinces, which now rely heavily on oil-fired power plants. In Nova Scotia and New Brunswick, the coal has a high sulfur content. Two new stations in Ontario and Saskatchewan, close to the border, will burn low-sulfur coal. **********Canada and the United States signed a memorandum of intent in August l980 to study and control crossborder pollution. Talks on an agreement for controlling air pollution began last June, and the subcommittee urged that an agreement be signed by the end of 1982.  But it said new Canadian legislative, regulatory and enforcement measures, including heavy fines for noncompliance, should not wait for the completion of the agreement or further studies. **********''The time for protracted study of the acid rain problem has ended,'' the subcommittee said. ''The need for immediate action is clear and unequivocal.'' It said the United States ''should similarly act in good faith.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/12/busin.body_text: **********THE first advertising campaign from Young & Rubicam for the Jamaica Tourist Board, seeking to sell the American traveler on the feeling of civility and gentility on the island, will begin to run Monday on television in seven markets. **********The three 60-second TV commercials, prepared under William H.  Appelman, who is creative director and a vice president, are all made up of quick takes and comments from a variety of local people. All are affluent and most of the locations are steeped in affluence - the polo field, the expensive restaurant, the mansion. **********The campaign is one of three that Y.&R.; presented to the Jamaicans in rough form and the one that helped them win the business on April 6 from Intermarco U.S.A., the incumbent, and Benton & Bowles. **********''No reggae,'' Mr. Appelman said. ''No tourists frolicking around.  We're showing the people themselves and, through them, reflecting the island and its treasures. **********The new theme, he said, is: ''Make it Jamaica. Again.'' ''And that's saying, 'Come back, everything's O.K.' '' ''We're not appealing to the head,'' he explained. ''We're trying to talk to them though the heart, showing the pride the people have in their island.'' **********When Doyle Dane Bernbach had the business, three ad agencies ago, it tried some ''back'' theme lines, too: ''Take me back to Jamaica,'' and ''Welcome back to Jamaica.'' **********There may be something in that to appeal to the important travel agent segment. Travel agents, who tend to recomend destinations that customers will want to go back to, have a 68 percent rate of repeat business. Many travel agents, one travel advertising source believes, have not been recommending Jamaica to clients. **********Since 1975, when Caribbean travel suffered, Jamaica travel suffered more.  And now, with the eight-month-old conservative Government of Prime Minister Edward Seaga, the tourist unit has the mandate to turn things around. **********In a full-page ad in The New York Times in December, the Prime Minister was quoted as saying: ''I belive Jamaica's tourism industry is vital to a strong economy. In the coming months we will do everything possible to promote and develop tourism in Jamaica. Our people are committed to this.'' **********The difficulty of changing American perceptions of the island is reflected in the agency's use of the 60-second, more persuasive commercial, and by the fact that the $7 million budget (two-thirds in TV) is twice last year's budget. Some $2 million of the $7 million will come under the Jamaica Vacations program, which promotes charters through ads in newspaper travel sections. **********The advertising that breaks next week will all be in TV and will push summer vacations.  ''The sooner we get people down there the better the word will spread when they get back,'' Mr. Appelman said.  The markets on the schedule are New York, Philadelphia, Atlanta, Miami, Los Angeles, Dallas and Houston.  In the fall, when winter vacations are being planned, Minneapolis, St. Louis and perhaps Memphis and Tulsa, Okla., will be added. In addition, there will be newspaper advertising and a national print umbrella in news weeklies, and travel and trade publications. **********The television, aimed at more affluent adults 22 years old and up, will run during all parts of the TV day using a system borrowed from Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, Young & Rubicam's direct marketing subsidiary: A station is given a budget and asked for the most efficient buy. It comes back with a schedule, which the agency checks out and approves. This replaces the normal agency practice of selecting the time and buying it. **********Jamaica is trying, through stressing wealth in its creative product, what Bermuda is attempting to do through its magazine selection: to attract a higher class of people than it was getting. **********''The people with more money,'' said Thomas Spangenberg, agency vice president, ''will stay longer and spend more money.'' Spoken like a real believer.

Keenan, 47-year-old chairman and president of Keenan & McLaughlin, which is in the process of being disolved, has joined the 26-year-old Chester Gore Company as president. That means that the founder, Chester Gore, will step up to chairman and chief executive of the shop. **********The disolving agency was founded in 1970 as Keenan, Keane & McLaughlin. It still has clients with about $4 million in billings who are making up their minds about who their future agency will be. **********At Creamer Inc./New York, meanwhile, Peter Lubalin, at the tender age of 39, has been named executive vice president and creative director, the same title he held at his last place, Chalek Dryer Comerford Lubalin. He is a son of the late Herb Lubalin, the graphics great. **********And at Conde Nast, J.E. Corr Jr., publisher of the new Vanity Fair magazine, which is still in the planning stages, has named Douglas Johnston, formerly of Gentlemen's Quarterly, ad director; Katherine Mountain, formerly of House & Garden, promotion director, and Jonathan Newhouse (a cousin of S.I. Newhouse Jr.) business manager.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/05/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Macy's Revises Expansion Plans
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/05/busin.body_text: **********R.H. Macy & Company said that it was revising its new-store expansion plans to provide for the opening of two stores in 1982 and the building of between 12 and 15 stores between 1984 and 1986. **********Macy's had previously said it would open seven stores this year and one store in 1982, but had been vague about its later plans. Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive officer, told securities analysts that new Macy stores will open in the next two years in Stamford, Conn., and Santa Rosa, Modesto and Fresno, all in California. Bamberger stores will open in King-of-Prussia, Pa., and two near Baltimore. A Davison's department store will open in Athens, Ga., and in suburban Atlanta.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/busin.main_headline: Pay Cut Set At Republic Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/busin.print_headline: Pay Cut Set At Republic Air
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/28/busin.body_text: **********Republic Airlines, the seventh-largest passenger carrier in the nation, announced that a majority of its union employees would take a 10 percent pay cut for six months as part of the carrier's costcutting program. The employees will also forgo any scheduled pay increases during that period. **********Republic said that the pay cuts were approved in balloting by about 80 percent of its more than 13,000 unionized employees. A spokesman for Republic said that these actions would save Republic $4 million to $5.5 million a month. **********The spokesman said that the International Association of Machinists, which represents about 1,800 Republic employees, had refused to consider the company's request regarding a pay cut.  Management and nonunion employees at Republic earlier accepted a similar pay cut and delay in scheduled raises. **********In the first nine months of the year, Republic's losses have increased to $38.5 million from a deficit of $24.8 million in the same period last year. The airline blamed high interest rates and lowerthan-expected passenger traffic resulting from the air traffic controllers' strike.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/29/world.body_text: **********Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today scoffed at a North Korean statement denying it had fired on a United States fighter jet and warned that the United States would take steps to meet any new acts of ''international piracy'' by North Korea or Libya. He did not specify what steps he had in mind. **********''We believe our pilot,'' Mr. Weinberger said on the NBC News program ''Today.'' He said that there was ''nobody else in the vicinity, that is to say within hundreds of miles, that has the surface-to-air missiles except North Korea.'' **********Mr. Weinberger's warning about countermeasures was the second by the Reagan Administration in two days. Yesterday, the State Department said the United States would take ''whatever steps are necessary'' to protect its pilots and planes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/08/busin.snippet: T HE missing link in all the recently proffered tax reduction programs is the conduit between consumer tax reduction and the reindustrialization of America. Will an open-handed tax cut strewing money on the public like the gentle rain produce a re...
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/08/busin.main_headline:
COMMENT;
A WAY TO CUT TAXES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/08/busin.print_headline:
COMMENT;
A WAY TO CUT TAXES
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/08/busin.body_text: **********T HE missing link in all the recently proffered tax reduction programs is the conduit between consumer tax reduction and the reindustrialization of America. Will an open-handed tax cut strewing money on the public like the gentle rain produce a return to industrialization? **********Come, let us reason together: Suppose we take the average individual taxpayer in 1981 and estimate his tax at, say, $5,000 a year. Now we give him a $500-ayear tax cut; that is $10 a week. Let's see how this individual's $500 might find its way back into the economy. **********In one week, he might buy an extra eight gallons of gasoline to drive the kids to the amusement park. Or in another week, his wife might buy a little better cut of meat. Maybe he saves the whole $500 and uses it to buy a Sony television set, in which case most of the $500 goes winging to Japan. Money trickled through the $2 trillion United States economy in this fashion is not likely to create great pools of new profits with which Bethlehem Steel can rebuild its forges. **********The supporters of the kind of tax cuts advocated by Congressman Jack Kemp would argue that the Kennedy tax cut in the early 1960's created more jobs and more income for the Government. However, the situation was somewhat different then: The United States was operating in a much more closed economy that was far more selfsufficient and paying far less than the $100 billion yearly now spent on imported oil. **********What is more, the Kennedy tax cut was not entirely free of inflationary byproducts. For that matter, the economic spurt in 1963 may have been the result of events other than the tax cut, like the increase in foreign sales and the growth of United States multinational corporations. **********There is no certainty over what effect the current tax-cut proposals would have. The ''X'' factor in the equation appears to be the way the money would be returned to the taxpayers. All of the tax bills that have been offered so far suggest that the money would be returned in a kind of hose-like spray - scattered over the population to fall where it may and to produce what it may. **********It is paradoxical that politicians who are so adept at developing specific taxes and specific methods of taking money out of the private sector are so careless about returning it. Shouldn't there be some kind of direction to the manner in which this money is returned to the private economy? Could@n't the tax reduction be made in such a way as to encourage consumer investment and savings, produce jobs, increase capital investment in plant modernization, and improve the value of the dollar? **********This could be accomplished if the consumer tax reduction was made with a temporary string attached. An individual receiving a $500 tax cut could be given one-third outright and the other two-thirds at the end of each tax year in the form of special Federal investment certificates. **********These certificates could be used to purchase a unique preferred class of stock in companies with capital improvement programs. The certificates could also be used to buy three- to five-year building certificates in savings and loan institutions. They could be applied to any class of investment that was involved with construction, capital-building, or domestic expansion. Smaller companies or nonstock companies might participate in the benefits of this new money through the Small Business Administration. **********Of course, big investors in the stock market and the mutual fund industry would benefit from such a plan, but only to a modest degree. If tax-cut money went into a special preferred class of stock, closed to all except the influx of tax funds, then there would really be no market in that category of stock, at least not for several years. **********O N the other hand, all investors certainly would benefit, since the regular market would boom in the face of this type of investment. And that boom would draw billions of Eurodollars, which would push the market higher still. **********The effect on interest rates should be rewarding, too. The presence of billions of dollars of new funds in the United States market would drive bank rates down to the 6, 7 or 8 percent level. What is more, the presence of this new capital pool would make additional sources of money available. If the General Motors Corporation could easily acquire $1 billion or $2 billion through such a program for a $10 billion rebuilding project, it would certainly have no trouble finding the other $8 billion through normal money markets. **********To qualify for such a program, the activities of recipient companies could be shaped to help the job market. Part of G.M.'s capital building program, for example, would have to involve training marginal workers. **********Of course, doctrinaire conservatives, as well as doctrinaire liberals, may object to the attachment of such Government strings on returning this tax money to the public. But there should be some order to the removal of excess taxation - anarchy is not necessarily a perfect alternative to tyranny. A little transitory logic and direction can do a lot toward making the remedy work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/world.main_headline: BREZHNEV PHONE CALL SAID TO HAVE PROTECTED HARD-LINERS IN POLAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/world.print_headline: BREZHNEV PHONE CALL SAID TO HAVE PROTECTED HARD-LINERS IN POLAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/14/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union interceded at a Central Committee meeting of the Polish Communist Party two weeks ago to insure that hard-liners in the Politburo were not purged, reliable Polish sources said today. **********These sources said that the hard-liners, Tadeusz Grabski and Stefan Olszowski, were retained after a letter was read from the Soviet Central Committee. The letter, sent when Soviet troops were on maneuvers in and around the country, reportedly said that ''Poland is at a critical moment'' and urged against any change in the Politburo or Central Committee for the sake of ''party unity.'' **********The letter reportedly was backed up by a phone call from Leonid I.  Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to Stanislaw Kania, head of the Polish Communist Party, during a crucial two-hour recess of the Central Committee meeting. **********Mr. Brezhnev is presumed to have conferred with Mr. Olszowski when both attended a party congress in Czechoslovakia last week. This has prompted speculation among Western diplomats in Moscow, who believe that the Kremlin is losing confidence in Mr. Kania and may sponsor a move to put Mr. Olszowski in his place. **********Such a move, however, is virtually ruled out here, since Mr.  Olszowski represents a minority view among the leadership on how to deal with the crisis. He would clearly be unacceptable to the Central Committee and the vast majority of rank-and-file party members. The party base is moving rapidly in a liberal direction, and any attempt to impose a hard-liner as leader might set off a party rebellion. **********There is a precedent for ignoring Moscow's wishes. In 1956, the Polish party faced down Nikita S. Khrushchev and the threat of military intervention to elevate Wladyslaw Gomulka, then viewed by the Soviet Union as heretical, to be first secretary. Poles feel even more defiant now. **********The strains in the relationship between Moscow and Warsaw are not always apparent, but they are considerable at times. Two weeks ago, for example, Orbis, the Polish tourist agency, abruptly stopped all excursions to the Soviet Union without providing a reason. Officials have confirmed privately that the move was taken because a busload of Polish tourists was attacked there and some of them were badly injured. **********The Warsaw Pact maneuvers may have exacerbated the strains. Leaders of the independent trade union Solidarity maintain that during the exercises they sent spotters around the country to ascertain the scope of the maneuvers. The spotters reportedly met with Polish troops, including commanders. **********Some union leaders are concerned that the Polish party may be moving too quickly on liberalization and democratization, raising the danger of new strains with the Soviet Union. **********Solidarity is undergoing strain itself, largely from the way in which Lech Walesa, the chairman, and a handful of negotiators reached an agreement with the Government to call off a threatened general strike on March 31. Other leaders on the union's national commission, saying they were presented with a fait accompli, accused Mr. Walesa of acting undemocratically. **********Karol Modzelewski, a historian and political activist who helped transform the union from a regional to a national organization last September, resigned as press spokesman. He complained that Mr.  Walesa was ''like a monarch surrounded by his favorite advisers who treats this national commission like a parliament without any power.'' **********''If not for Walesa and the advisers, there would have been a general strike right away,'' said Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a ranking adviser to Mr. Walesa. ''What if we had called the national commission, and what if they had not called off the strike?  What would have happened then?'' **********''It's easy to talk about being autocratic,'' Mr. Mazowiecki said.  ''But what happens in that final dramatic moment, when one man with the full weight of social responsibility has to make a final decision?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/world.main_headline: BANI-SADR SAYS EFFORT TO OUST HIM IS UNDER WAY, THREATENING HIS LIFE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/world.print_headline: BANI-SADR SAYS EFFORT TO OUST HIM IS UNDER WAY, THREATENING HIS LIFE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/13/world.body_text: **********14 TEHERAN, Iran, Saturday, June 13 (Reuters) - President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr said last night that a coup was under way to deprive him of the Presidency and of his life. **********With pressures for his resignation increasing, the President issued a statement denouncing the policies of the ruling, clergydominated Islamic Republican Party and calling on the Iranian people to resist what he described as a dictatorship. **********''I did what I had to do,'' he said. ''It is up to you to worry about the future of the Islamic revolution and your country and resist.'' **********Mr. Bani-Sadr did not say that he would resign, but his statement was taken by many here as a farewell to the nation. It was given to Reuters by a staff member but was not immediately used by the state radio or television or by Pars, the official press agency. It was not clear how he expected to get it to the Iranian people, who elected him to the Presidency by a landslide in January 1980. His Office Is Surrounded **********Shortly before his statement was issued, revolutionary guards armed with submachine guns and rifles surrounded the President's official quarters, patrolling its perimeter and blocking surrounding streets.  Inside the floodlighted Presidential compound there were policemen, and a spokesman said the revolutionary guards, who are loyal to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, had tried to enter but had been stopped at the gate.  Just after midnight, the revolutionary guards withdrew from the area. **********The statement was Mr. Bani-Sadr's first attempt to speak out since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini dismissed him as Commander in Chief of the armed forces two days ago. The statement said that the last stage of the coup - ''taking the Presidential job from me as well as my life - is being carried out.'' **********A few hours earlier, crowds at a prayer meeting at Teheran University called for the President's death. There were shouts of ''God is great!'' ''Khomeini the leader!'' and ''Death to Bani-Sadr!'' **********Teheran's spiritual leader, Hojatolislam Ali Khameini, challenged earlier appeals by Mr. Bani-Sadr to his supporters to help resist tyranny and said that anyone inviting ''people to resist the great waves of the revolution'' was guilty of treason and of betraying ''the ideals of Moslems.'' **********The 48-year-old President, who has been opposed by Islamic fundamentalists since his election, has been accused by a three-member commission appointed by Ayatollah Khomeini of violating the Constitution and the orders of the Ayatollah. He faces the prospect of a trial. Parliament to Meet **********Iran's Parliament has been called into special session tomorrow, presumably to discuss his case. It has the power to declare him ''politically incompetent'' and recommend that Ayatollah Khomeini remove him from office. **********Mr. Bani-Sadr, referring in his statement to demonstrations this week outside his official quarters by Islamic extremists who called for his trial and death, said: **********''These days, from morning to night and from night to morning, official and unofficial club-wielders are surrounding your President's place. They are exceptions and can do what they want and commit any meanness they want. But what will they do against you tomorrow?'' **********Attacking the ruling Islamic Republican Party, he said the Iranian people could see that two and a half years of rule by it had ''worsened the conditions of the country every day.'' **********''Of the three slogans of the Islamic revolution - independence, freedom and Islamic republic - nothing has been left,'' the President said. **********He said that there was no security in Iran, that its economy had been crippled and that there was a danger that the continuing war with Iraq might expand. **********All this week, the Islamic fundamentalists' showdown with the President prompted widespread clashes between his supporters and Islamic extremists.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/30/busin.main_headline: Con Edison Head Committed to Coal
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/30/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Con Edison Head Committed to Coal
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Arthur Hauspurg, the new president of the Consolidated Edison Company, who will also become chief executive officer when Charles F. Luce steps down on Aug. 1, has an extensive background with coalburning utilities. He is therefore determined to increase Con Edison's use of coal to help produce electricity. **********''Coal conversion is near and dear to our hearts,'' Mr. Hauspurg, a native New Yorker, said yesterday. ''We could reduce our expenses by $400 million if we converted three units that had burned coal at one time and which can be turned back to coal and still meet environmental standards.'' **********Before coming to Con Edison in 1969 as a vice president, Mr.  Hauspurg, who is 55 years old, spent 22 years with the American Electric Power Company, one of the largest users of coal among privately owned American utilities. He started there with its Ohio Power Company and later moved to the American Electric Power Service Company, where he rose to assistant vice president. At Con Ed, he became a senior vice president in 1973, executive vice president and chief operating officer in 1975 and president later that year. **********Asked about the use of nuclear power, Mr. Hauspurg said that the corporation's only nuclear unit, Indian Point 2, was expected to be back in service within a week. ''We have no other nuclear plants in our long-range plans,'' he added. ''Until the regulations and rules of the Government change and Federal policies are cleared up, there isn't going to be anymore nuclear at any utility. It's sort of like swimming upstream.'' **********Mr. Hauspurg asserted that a major problem these days for Con Edison was inflation. ''When we adjust our earnings for inflation, we don't have any earnings,'' he noted. ''This is because of the capital-intensive nature of the electric utility business. Nobody that I know has a great solution for it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/world.main_headline: SOVIET, ACCUSING U.S. OF RECKLESS ARMS PLANS, PRESSES FOR START OF TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/world.print_headline: SOVIET, ACCUSING U.S. OF RECKLESS ARMS PLANS, PRESSES FOR START OF TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/26/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union accused the United States today of plunging ahead with a reckless program of rearmament and intervention in disregard of Leonid I. Brezhnev's proposals for a new round of talks to limit tensions. **********The attack on the Reagan Administration's policies, bringing together many of the charges that have been appearing in the Soviet press in recent weeks, took the form of an article in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda signed ''Igor Aleksandrov,'' a name that is used when an article contains important Kremlin pronouncements. **********The article seemed to be an effort to maintain the momentum of Mr.  Brezhnev's proposals for high-level talks, made in a speech to the Communist Party congress on Feb. 23. **********Desire for Normal Ties Stressed **********''The Soviet Union wants normal relations with the United States,'' the article declared. ''The present stage of these relations and the acuteness of international problems requiring solution dictate the need for an active Soviet-American dialogue at all levels. The quicker this is realized in Washington, the more useful it will be for the American and Soviet peoples, for all the peoples of the world.'' **********With Mr. Brezhnev's proposals for a summit meeting and a moratorium on medium-range missile deployments in Europe being met with skepticism, the Kremlin's object, according to Western diplomats, is to deflect attention from the questionable aspects of these proposals and to portray the United States as the source of all dangers to peace. **********One of the Russians' purposes, in the diplomats' view, is to frustrate plans for what the Atlantic alliance regards as redressing the balance in medium-range missiles by the deployment of American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles by 1983. On this and other issues, the Russians appear intent on dividing the United States from Western Europe, where there has been some opposition to the missile plans. 'Multiplying of Errors' Charged **********Tracing the ''poisoning of the international atmosphere'' to the policies of President Jimmy Carter, the Pravda article said the new American leaders ''appear to be bent not on rectifying but on multiplying the errors of the previous Administration, facilitating not a lessening of international tension but its growth.'' **********The article said that, even though Soviet leaders insist that they have no intention of upsetting the nuclear balance, the United States has embarked on a program of ''unprecedented superarming,'' rationalized as a move to forestall future Soviet superiority but actually meant to achieve American superiority now. **********This goal will not be achieved, but it threatens mankind with ''a new, unprecedented phase of the arms race,'' the article said. In addition, it charged, the new Administration adopted a number of belligerent measures, seeking to ''drown the national liberation movement in El Salvador in blood,'' promising ''continued arming of counterrevolutionary bands'' in Afghanistan, espousing the cause of ''terrorist groups'' in Angola, raising a Rapid Deployment Force for the Persian Gulf area and creating new flashpoints for armed conflict around the world. **********There is a way out of the dangerous situation created by the United States, the article continued, and that is to take up the proposals put forward by Mr. Brezhnev at the party congress.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/world.main_headline: SOVIET PRESS IS CRITICIZING SCHMIDT HARSHLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/world.print_headline: SOVIET PRESS IS CRITICIZING SCHMIDT HARSHLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/world.body_text: **********The Soviet press has recently made an unusually harsh series of attacks on Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, and West German correspondents in Moscow, quoting diplomatic sources, said the criticism was unlike anything seen in the Soviet media in Mr.  Schmidt's seven years in office. **********Some of the diplomatic reports have speculated about the possibility of a serious deterioration in West German-Soviet relations. A more current analysis among officials in Bonn was that Moscow was trying to increase pressure on the Chancellor and encourage those in his party who are seeking to block deployment in West Germany of NATO's new medium-range nuclear missiles. **********The main attack was in an unsigned article in Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, but other, similar commentaries were carried by Tass, the Soviet press agency, and by the weekly Novoye Vremya. **********Writing of Mr. Schmidt's visit to Washington, Pravda said, ''Having confirmed there the American line toward the arms race and primarily that of nuclear armaments in Europe, the Federal Chancellor followed Washington along the path of aggravating the international situation.'' Schmidt's Tone Has Changed **********As if acknowledging how sharply Mr. Schmidt's position toward the Soviet Union had changed, the newspaper continued: ''It was not so long ago that he favored detente, defended the SALT II treaty and declared for good neighborliness with the Soviet Union.'' **********While in Washington, Mr. Schmidt did not use the word detente and referred to his concerns about Soviet expansionism and the Soviet arms buildup. The Chancellor, whose tone on the Soviet Union was cautious for the first year after its intervention in Afghanistan, became more directly critical this spring, saying in a state of the nation address April 12 that Soviet policy was essentially responsible for the ''world's darkened political horizon.'' **********The Soviet attacks on Mr. Schmidt were rejected by a Government spokesman here as ''totally baseless,'' but there was irritation in some areas of the Government coalition about what was seen as an attempt to discredit the Chancellor and to characterize him as a hostage of Mr. Reagan. Invitation Is a Complication **********The situation is complicated by an invitation from Leonid I.  Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to Willy Brandt, the chairman of the Social Democratic Party and a former Chancellor, for talks in Moscow. A party spokesman indicated yesterday that Mr. Brandt would probably visit Moscow in June or July. **********Mr. Brandt has been a very much less avid supporter of the NATO missile plan than the Chancellor and recently described a decision by a party regional conference to call for its reconsideration next year at a national party congress as ''important and weighty.'' **********Newspaper editorials asked what purpose Mr. Brandt's trip to Moscow could serve, particularly since Mr. Brezhnev plans to come to Bonn in the autumn and could communicate directly with Mr. Schmidt any time. **********The Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung commented: ''Now the Moscow leaders will try to influence developments in the Federal Republic over Schmidt's head. A visit to Moscow by Brandt would be especially in line with their interests. This is what they're striving for.'' The Opposition View **********Alois Mertes, the foreign policy spokesman of the opposition Christian Democrats, said Moscow was trying to turn Mr. Brandt into an ''anti-Schmidt'' who might persuade the Chancellor to change his ways. **********Mr. Brandt's attitudes were so carefully masked, Mr. Mertes charged, that the Russians hoped they could soften Bonn's position with his help. **********Mr. Mertes called the former Chancellor ''the secret leader'' of the forces in the Social Democratic Party who want to move closer to Moscow. ''He'll be briefed in Moscow,'' he said, ''and then he'll brief his hosts.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/29/busin.main_headline: IT'S GETTING EASIER TO BUY A HOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/29/busin.print_headline: IT'S GETTING EASIER TO BUY A HOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/29/busin.body_text: **********I N the rubble of the worst year in decades for residential real estate has sprung the hint of a better day: The price of a home mortgage is going down. **********Home lenders have followed cuts in the prime rate of recent months with cuts in mortgage rates. In the last last week or two, many lending institutions across the country have clipped off about a point. This break in rates comes during a period in which the sharp increases in home prices have also abated. In the last year, after a decade in which average prices almost tripled, housing prices dropped by about 10 percent after accounting for inflation and for discounts on financing granted by owners eager to sell. **********This is not, however, a new turn of the old cycle of prices and mortgages. The old cycle has been buried in the immense losses that the lenders have swallowed for letting homeowners reap the benefits of low-rate mortgages in a time of high inflation. From that era, a wholly new housing market is emerging. **********The terms of mortgages have been changed to favor the banks. The forces that allowed house prices to outperform just about all other investments in recent years have been deflated. Yet mortgage rates and prices, most analysts expect, are likely to remain relatively high, putting ownership of a single-family home beyond families that earn less than $30,000 to $40,000 or so.  ''Isn't it amazing, people say they can't wait for rates to get down to 13 percent,'' muses Anthony Downs, a housing expert and a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. ''Right now 12 percent sounds like a red hot item.'' **********Of course, rates are still well above that level. Nevertheless, this season's break in mortgage rates and home prices makes buying a home easier than it has been in months. And because of that, some economists see a turnaround in the market beginning about now, and ending perhaps late next spring when they expect prices to begin creeping up again. **********Housing experts differ on the best way to approach the housing market now. Some advise waiting until rates fall further. Others recommend jumping in as soon as rates fall far enough for a house to be affordable. **********What seems to be developing in the housing market is a new opportunism that dictates playing the business cycle in buying a home and looking for dips in interest The new home-buying rules of thumb. Page 15. rates and housing prices rather than holding out for the much lower rates and prices that were available through the 1950's and 1960's. **********Kenneth J. Thygerson, a vice president at the Western Federal Savings and Loan Association of Denver and chairman of its subsidiary, the WestAmerica Mortgage Company, drew an analogy between the emerging home-buying strategy and the way companies seek financing. ''Corporations look for a window in the bond markets to do financing,'' he said. ''Now the individual has to do the same thing, and the window is just beginning to open now.'' **********While rates are likely to fall further still as the recession deepens through the winter, and perhaps into next spring, most economists predict that rates on fixed-rate, conventional mortgages will not drop much below 14 or 15 percent. Rates on variable-rate mortgages are likely to be somewhat below those of the conventional fixed-rate mortgages.  Robert Dall, a managing director at Salomon Brothers Inc., said, ''Mortgage rates might come down to 14 percent by the end of the first quarter of 1982. But then I'd expect them to go right back up again.'' **********Peter Treadway, chief economist at Cralin Securities, an investment banking firm, and the former chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, is even less optimistic.  ''Long-term mortgage rates may come down a little bit more,'' he predicted. ''But 15 percent is likely to be the bottom for fixed-rate mortgages, and anything below 15 percent will not last too long.'' **********While it is possible to find forecasts that call for somewhat lower mortgage rates, Kenneth L. Rilander, a vice president at Blyth Eastman Paine Webber, said, ''The only people who expect to see a more dramatic drop in mortgage rates are those who expect a very severe recession.'' **********For the home buyer, then, the trick is to find the best combination of mortgage rates and housing prices. Some bankers and real estate agents recommend buying as soon as possible, to take advantage of the depressed housing prices before they turn up. **********''The housing market is probably at rock bottom right now,'' said Mr. Treadway. ''While mortgage rates may still come down a little bit more, a home buyer could take out a mortgage now with an adjustable rate, and still benefit if rates fall further. The key is to try to develop flexibility.'' **********Others recommend waiting a few more months until mortgage rates have dropped a bit further, although there is a greater risk of waiting too long, until the decline in rates has stimulated demand and sent prices rising again. **********''I would advise someone who wanted a fixed-rate loan to wait a while longer, because rates are going to come down some more,'' Mr.  Dall of Salomon Brothers said. He said a few extra months would not necessarily cost the home buyer more on the price of a house, ''because there is still a backlog of homes to be worked off and because there are still financing problems that will keep buying activity slow.'' **********While the experts debate the best time for buying a home, they are united in the belief that the consumer should not try to pick the exact bottom in rates, since when rates do reach their lows they often turn up almost immediately. ''If the experts can't pick the bottom, most consumers probably won't be able to either,'' Mr.  Thygerson said. **********Indeed, one factor that is likely to help push mortgage rates up again is a sudden rush to buy houses or to renegotiate the mortgages on the houses they already own. **********''If rates come down, a lot of people sitting with properties are going to run out and refinance them,'' said James T. dePietro, a sales associate at First Minneapolis Realty. ''The demand for credit could be so great that it would just push those rates right back up again.'' **********W HATEVER the timing strategy, housing experts say there is a good deal of pent-up demand for housing, and that many people are expected to begin buying as rates continue to edge down. But instead of heralding a period of unlimited vigor, it is expected that the lower rates will usher in only a limited resurgence. **********''We are moving down from an impossible level to a slightly less impossible level,'' said Richard G. Marcis, chief economist for the Dallas Federal Savings and Loan Association, and until recently the chief economist for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board. He noted that the current level of rates was still too high for most people to jump back into the market. ''The real key will be to get rates down to 14 or 15 percent, where some segment of potential home buyers will begin to qualify for mortgages,'' he said. **********N. Leo Beller, an assistant vice president for real estate loans at the Bank of America, illustrates the affordability problem with the example of a family that is seeking a $100,000 mortgage for the purchase of a $125,000 house. For a 17 percent mortgage, monthly mortgage payments would run about $1,425, and a typical lender would probably look for yearly income of $62,400, Mr. Beller said. ''That's twice the average household income in California,'' he said. **********If mortgage rates were 15 percent, he said, the income requirement would fall to $55,900 for that same mortgage application. If rates fell another point, to 14 percent, the income requirement would still be $52,750. **********That continuing affordability problem is a grim reminder that while the recession will bring some relief by lowering interest rates, consumers are not likely to find the market they knew 10 or 20 years ago. It was a market that housed and enriched millions of Americans for several decades, but it was also based on a financial structure that helped to drive the thrift industry close to bankruptcy. **********For while mortgage rates will fall during the downturn of each business cycle, other changes have been taking place - especially in the way in which homes are financed - that will not be reversed. **********These more permanent transformations, which are still in the process of evolving, include everything from who makes mortgage loans to the kinds of mortgages that are available. And the home buyer attracted by lower interest rates will still have to be prepared for the other changes in the marketplace. **********The shift in who is willing to make mortgages is expected to continue. Traditionally, savings and loans have been the largest mortgage lenders. Because of low earnings and outflows of deposits, however, many of them have stopped making mortgages. Mergers of troubled associations have also reduced the number of institutions making mortgage loans. Commercial banks have picked up some of that slack. But many of them are willing to make a mortgage only if they know they can resell it to a pension fund or other institutional investor. **********New kinds of mortgages will continue to displace the traditional long-term, fixed-rate mortgage. It is still possible to get a 30-year mortgage with a fixed rate, but fewer of them are available. In their place are mortgages with shorter terms and with interest rates that vary during the life of the mortgage. The forms are still proliferating, as lenders and buyers search for a new formula that will please both. ''There will be a panoply of mortgages available, and the best deal will really be a matter of doing a heck of a lot of shopping around,'' Mr. Thygerson advised. **********''Creative financing'' will remain prevalent. Instead of bank mortgages, many home buyers have been receiving financing from relatives, friends or the people selling the house. This kind of financing now takes place in about 60 percent of all home sales, according to a broad survey just completed by the National Association of Realtors. **********The survey also found that the average interest rate on these loans is 13 percent, well below the rates available on more traditional mortgages. People who cannot afford even the lower bank mortgage rates predicted for next spring are likely to continue to use these new financing methods, so long as they remain less expensive, said Jack W. Carlson, executive vice president of the association. **********House prices should start rising again by mid-1982, but the increases will be much more moderate than in the late 1970's. Any decline in house prices is likely to end when mortgage rates fall to about 14 percent, although it may not happen immediately because there will be inventories of housing to be sold off. When that is finished, economists predict, prices will again begin to rise, although the large price gains that outstripped both the inflation rate and many other forms of investment are not likely to return soon. **********''Owning housing is not going to be the windfall it has been,'' said Mr. Downs of Brookings. ''In the future, people shouldn't be as reluctant to rent, since the advantages of owning are now greatly weakened.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; U.S. and Egypt Discussing Sinai Peacekeeping Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/29/world.body_text: **********The United States and Egypt resumed talks here today on forming a multinational peacekeeping force to patrol the Sinai peninsula when Israel completes its withdrawal from there next year. So far, Israel has handed back to Egypt two-thirds of the peninsula, which it occupied in the 1967 war. **********Only the United States has said that it is ready to contribute troops, and Foreign Minister Kamal Hassan Ali of Egypt is in Scandinavia seeking support for the force. **********Tomorrow, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Michael Sterner will fly to Israel to continue the talks. Then he will return to Cairo to brief Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who is due here next Saturday on his first Middle East visit since taking office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/13/busin.body_text: **********The Hobart Corporation said it had asked the Federal District Court in New York to issue a preliminary injunction against the continuation of the tender offer by Canadian Pacific Enterprises United States Inc. for the acquisition of all of Hobart's outstanding common shares. **********Hobart, a leading maker of electrical food related equipment, said its motion was based on claims that the Canadian Pacific offer misrepresented and omitted material facts concerning the financing of the $32.50-a-share offer, or a total of about $372 million. **********Last week Hobart sued Canadian Pacific in the same court to enjoin Canadian Pacific from proceeding with the offer because of alleged violations of federal securities laws and regulations of the Federal Reserve Board. **********Canadian Pacific Enterprises said it had no comment to make on Hobart's motion for an injunction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Companies involved in takeover situations scored the best gains yesterday as stock prices over all registered a slight setback in the lowest trading volume of the last four sessions. **********With all of its 30 components showing only fractional price changes, the Dow Jones industrial average eased 1.14 points, to 851.79. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange contracted to 45.3 million shares from Friday's 52 million. **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, trading ex-dividend, declined 7/8, to 59. A.T.& T. has paid cash dividends each year for the past 100 years. On Friday, the stock sold at 61 1/2, its highest price since the spring of 1979. **********Telephone issues generally have been good market performers for the past 10 weeks. Lower interest rates, along with rate increases by regulatory bodies, have brightened their prospects, according to analysts. International Host Up 5 1/4 **********On the takeover front, Host International jumped 5 1/4 points, to 27 1/4, the Big Board's best percentage gainer. The Marriott Corporation announced a bid for Host of $29 a share late Friday, topping the offer of $24.25 a share by DFS Group Ltd. of Hong Kong.  Marriott eased 3/4, to 32 7/8. **********The Richardson Company, which rejected a merger bid from MacAndrews & Forbes, rose 1 3/4, to 27 5/8, after Witco Chemical offered $27.50 a share for its stock. Witco fell 5/8, to 23 7/8. **********''The stage may be set for a year-end bounce soon'' in the stock market, Robert J. Farrell, who heads the market analysis department at Merrill Lynch, advised clients. He noted that most cyclical and capital-goods issues were depressed in price, reflecting investor concern over the earnings outlook as well as selling for the establishment of tax losses for 1981. **********However, looking beyond the next few weeks, Mr. Farrell is cautious. He said he anticipated ''a persuasive case for raising cash and getting bearish at lower prices sometime in the first half of 1982.'' **********The Merrill Lynch analyst based his forecast, to a considerable degree, on the behavior of institutional investors that have come to dominate stock market activity. ''The institutional majority has been determined to ride this recession out and not raise cash or get bearish this time,'' he said. ''Most of those deciding not to sell this time were the same group that were so afraid of the 1980 recession that they raised big cash in 1978.'' **********The result of that strategy, he said, was that many institutions missed the most dynamic phase of the market's recovery in 1978 and finally put their cash to work as stock prices approached their highs. Pennzoil Gains 1 7/8 **********In a repeat of Friday's market action, several energy stocks considered as potential takeovers moved ahead yesterday. Pennzoil, rumored as a possible target for Gulf Oil, traded ex-dividend and rose 1 7/8, to 53 3/4. Other gainers were Getty Oil and Union Oil of California. **********Marathon Oil, the volume leader, fell 2 3/4, to 104 1/2. It soared 29 3/4 points last week after United States Steel announced a rescue bid valued at about $6.4 billion. Marathon has opposed an earlier offer by the Mobil Corporation. U.S. Steel eased 1/4, to 27 1/2, while Mobil gained 1/4, to 25 7/8. **********Zenith, which cut its dividend, fell 1 1/4, to 10 1/2.  Texaco Canada rose 2 1/4, to 27 1/2, on the American Stock Exchange after Texaco International Financial made a tender offer for the company's series A first preferred shares. The Amex market value index gained 0.06, to 318.05. **********In over-the-counter trading, Bolar Pharmaceutical rose 2 1/2, to 15 bid, and Technology Inc. advanced 1 1/2, to 8 1/4 bid. The Nasdaq composite index declined 0.59, to 198.01.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/04/busin.body_text: **********I T'S no secret that the stock market likes to anticipate events by a matter of months. Prices have been plummeting since mid-1981. So what is the basic message of the market? **********''It's saying that we are heading into a recession,'' declared A.  Marshall Acuff Jr., investment strategist for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. **********At Goldman, Sachs & Company, the chairman of the investment policy committee concurred. Leon G. Cooperman amplified his recession forecast by stating: ''We believe the economy is likely to be stagnant over the next three quarters.'' **********If this is the case, where does an investor find the best protective cover to survive a business slowdown with a minimum of bumps? **********The accepted wisdom of Wall Street is that certain stock groups weather a recession better than others - although even these ''defensive'' sectors offer no sure-fire guarantee against falling prices. ''It's like combat,'' a money manager said. ''Instead of getting killed, you may escape with some minor wounds.'' **********Merrill Lynch, in a study of group performance during the last seven recessions, found certain sectors did consistently better than the overall market. **********''Among these are drugs, foods, utilities, soaps and banks,'' according to the nation's largest brokerage house. ''Companies that produce day-to-day necessities such as soap, food and drugs tend to be good performers because their businesses are less affected by recessionary forces. **********''Interest-sensitive groups such as utilities and banks tend to do well, because lower interest rates, which usually accompany a recession, help to moderate their operating and financing costs.'' **********But a person does not necessarily make money -or even hold portfolio losses to a minimum - by following past scenarios.  In last year's short but sharp business downturn, for example, soap stocks fared poorly. Three months into the teeth of the 1980 recession, the soaps sank 15.2 percent, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 5.4 percent. Then, six months after the onset of that recession, soap stocks were ahead a mere 1.1 percent, while the broad market index gained 5.8 percent. **********Oil stocks, which often slide during a recession, turned in snappy gains last time. Six months after the recession began, this group had scored an advance of 30.6 percent, reflecting the frantic search for ''inflation-hedge'' issues prevailing at the time. **********''So far, in the face of the oncoming recession, the more defensive stock groups seem to be adhering pretty much to past patterns,'' Mr.  Cooperman said. **********There exists no clearcut consensus among analysts pointing to emerging new groups that could outperform the market in the next recession. **********One possible candidate is the funeral service business. The basic rationale here is that th e death rate is rising - recession or no recession - a nd certain companies stand to benefit. Hillenbrand Industries, t he leading manufacturer of finished burial coffins, is the choice of Prescott, Ball & Turben, a Cleveland-based brokerage firm. Smith B arney's pick is the Service Corporation International, whose activit ies embrace funeral homes, cemeteries, crematories and flower shops. **********Other possibilities: drug store chains, producers of bank checks, telephone companies and service companies that clean and maintain office buildings. Some analysts, meanwhile, detect recession-resistant qualities in hospital-management companies. One caveat for investing in this group, however, could be the matter of price, inasmuch as some companies have scored huge market advances in recent years and now carry fairly lofty price-earnings ratios. **********Group performance in the next recession depends upon certain variables, including the length of the slowdown and the level of interest rates. **********One way to build a ''defensive'' portfolio is to find industries that seem to have something extra going for them this time around.  Using this approach, Smith Barney's Mr. Acuff sees good things ahead for two broad market segments that would benefit from a slowgrowth economy and a declining inflation rate. These are the electric utilities and the insurance stocks, specifically fire-andcasualty and multiline companies. **********''While traditionally regarded a s defensive investments, the utility and insurance stocks could assume a l eadership position in the economic environment we envisage and thus take on offensive - or more dynamic - characteristics,'' he explaine d. **********Specific purchase recommendations by Smith Barney in utilities have included Consolidated Edison, Dayton Power and Light, Delmarva Power, Pacific Power and Light, Southern California Edison, Texas Utilities and Wisconsin Public Service. **********The firm's suggested ''buy'' list of insurance issues - a group that generally has suffered from investor disfavor for several years - includes Aetna Life and Casualty, the INA Corporation and the U.S.  Fidelity and Guaranty Company. Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. also favors the outlook for electric utilities. **********Mr. Cooperman's current strategy takes a different approach. He noted that several groups that are sensitive to perceived changes in interest rates, particularly large money-center banks and electric utilities, have outperformed the overall stock market recently. **********But rather than stick with these groups now, he would choose to ''play'' the actual decline in interest rates elsewhere. His top choice is not some recession-resistant stock group but intermediateterm bonds with a maturity of 10 years or less. **********It's not that Mr. Cooperman is bearish on the stock market at this point, in the face of the sharp decline of recent months. But he feels that bonds, along with cash equivalents, offer a safer haven for a while, at least. **********Some stock groups that have fared poorly on a relative basis during a recession in the past have included home furnishings, textile products, electrical household appliances, automobiles and building materials. **********High technology stocks can suffer in the face of a business slump, according to John R. Groome, who heads investment research for the United States Trust Company. ''A case in point is the price decline in semiconductor stocks, which are reflecting a slowdown in capital spending,'' he said. **********Texas Instruments and the Intel Corporation, leaders in the semiconductor industry, have sustained sharp price drops this year.  Imminent recessions also can be hard on former market stars. Apple Computer traded early last week below $15, in the wake of lowered earnings estimates by some analysts. When this maker of personal computers made its eagerly awaited market debut in December, it sold as high as $29.25. **********What investors must bear in mind, of course, is that groups or individual stocks whose prices falter in the face of a recession often reach a level where they become attractive for potential market gains. Here the secret of success has not changed. It's simply a matter of stock selection and timing.
