Elliott of the United States Bankruptcy Court in San Antonio authorized the Commonwealth Oil Company to solicit creditor and shareholder acceptances of its plan for emergence from bankruptcy. **********Commonwealth, known as Corco, said it expected to begin the solicitation by the first week of May and hopes to emerge from Chapter 11 protection by mid-July. **********It has been operating under Chapter 11 since March 2, 1978. **********The company, a 36.7 percent-owned subsidiary of the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, owns a big refinery and petrochemical complex in Puerto Rico. It ran into severe financial difficulties during the mid-1970's, when some fixed-priced contracts became unprofitable because of rising oil prices. **********In the bankruptcy court hearings, Corco testified that it had arranged for working capital after coming out of Chapter 11 and had also agreed to a settlement of claims of W.R. Grace & Company and Grace Petrochemicals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/24/world.main_headline: FABLED MOROCCAN CITY POLISHES UP FOR ARAB CHIEFS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/24/world.print_headline: FABLED MOROCCAN CITY POLISHES UP FOR ARAB CHIEFS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/24/world.body_text: **********The sons of Fez have dominated the politics, economics and culture of Morocco for so long that, even though many leaders were born elsewhere, their tradition is here. **********''One's family, not one's birthplace, determines one's origins,'' John Waterbury, a writer on Morocco, has observed.  So when Arab heads of state gather at Fez on Wednesday, Nov. 25, they will find themselves in a city whose spirit and power have run well beyond the high crenelated walls that girdle it, past the magnificent vistas that strikingly recall those of Jerusalem, a place that will certainly figure on their agenda. **********King Hassan II, who will be host to the meeting of the Arab League, has seen to it that Fez, whose 570,000 people are mostly crammed into the maze-like old city behind the walls, is being spruced up. Hotels are being refurbished, walls and road signs repainted and roads cleaned; a lot of money is being spent at a time when the Moroccan exchequer is dry. **********Opposition Party Curbed **********The King clearly wants no domestic embarrassments during the Fez meeting, and some link his crackdown on the Socialist opposition - whose leader, Abderrahim Bouabid, has been arrested -to this desire to keep a lid on things. **********The meeting will bring Fez momentary international luster. But in Morocco the mystique of the city is fading as powerful and wealthy natives abandon it for Casablanca, the teeming commercial metropolis, or Rabat, the capital and center of political advancement. **********''Fez is no longer the city of the bourgeoisie,'' said Mohammed Ben Said, a Socialist politician, offering a visitor a plate of sweet cakes and mint tea. ''It is now the city of the proletariat, with a little bit of the lower middle class.'' **********Confirmation of this downward sociological shift came in the 1977 municipal and parliamentary elections. Fez had traditionally been a fief of the Istiqlal, a nationalist party led by wealthy Fassis, as Fez natives are called, but the Socialists took all four of the city's seats in Parliament. The Socialists won 19 of the 39 municipal council positions to the Istiqlal's 16. But after some political maneuvering, in which an independent councilor was said to have been kidnapped, the Istiqlal stapled together a coalition that now runs city hall. King Keeps People Waiting **********King Hassan, who moves his court around from one sumptuous palace to another, has a habit of keeping important people waiting. A year ago, the ruler stirred a serious diplomatic furor by arriving 54 minutes late for a dinner that Queen Elizabeth II of Britain, on a state visit, held for him on the royal yacht Britannia, and by otherwise switching her program. **********''Going to Morocco is rather like being kidnapped,'' Princess Margaret is said to have told the Queen. ''You never know where you are going or when.'' **********It was nothing especially noteworthy, then, that King Hassan twice recently fixed and then at the last minute switched the appointments for Joseph Verner Reed Jr., the new American Ambassador, to present his credentials, and kept Prime Minister Mohammed Maati Bouabid and his new Cabinet waiting around in the Hotel de Fes to be sworn in. **********Hanging around and waiting for the King is almost a Moroccan political art form. An easygoing camaraderie develops among those called upon to wait. **********Sitting in the lobby of the Hotel de Fes, Yevgeny V. Nersesov, the Soviet Ambassador, disclosed that he had been summoned to the palace, presumably to be lectured on allegations that Moscow has been supplying sophisticated SAM-6 missiles to the Polisario guerrillas fighting the Moroccan army in Western Sahara. Ambassador Nersesov attempted with a joke to deflate the accusation: ''A Moroccan minister friend admitted to me that any American gangster can get his hands on a Kalashnikov'' - the Soviet assault rifle. Diplomacy at a Poolside Bar **********Chattiness is not limited to the Soviet camp. One night, at the poolside bar of the Hotel Jamai, Francis J. West Jr., Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, was speaking, loudly, on the phone to a colleague about American plans for strengthening the Moroccan forces against the Libyan-armed Polisario. **********''Are you on a secure telephone?'' called out the red-headed Mr.  West to the American at the other end of the line. Then, in only vaguely elliptical language, he discussed last-minute snags in the negotiations, the involvement of the Central Intelligence Agency station chief and commitments that had been made to ''the top man'' - King Hassan - that could not be broken at the last minute. **********Sitting down in the bar with Col. Maj. Mohammed Kabbaj, the head of the Moroccan air force, Mr. West delivered a forceful argument on the need for the 80,000 Moroccan troops in the Sahara to stage behindthe-lines commando operations against the guerrillas, as Egypt did in its 1977 border war with Libya. Colonel Kabbaj parried with a preference for sweeps by large formations, which he said were easier to control. U.S. Training Aid Offered **********Mr. West told the Moroccan that the United States was willing to train commando units, and even discussed the public relations aspects of American aid to counter the Soviet SAM-6 missiles.  ''Diplomatically, if we say that we are training SAM-killers, obviously that means they can go in after all kinds of other equipment,'' the American explained. **********The two men and Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, an American Air Force officer, then adjourned for dinner, leaving two journalists intently watching an Egyptian soap opera on a soundless television set in the corner of the bar. **********Such matters of state are of little concern in the countryside around Fez. A cruel drought, which some say is the worst to have afflicted Morocco in this century, has driven a new generation of poor off the land and into the miserable slums that encircle Fez. **********Out on the burnt land, farmers plow their fields, wait and pray.  October should have brought rain, but did not. More time has passed, without relief. **********''I usually sow on Oct. 20,'' said Ben Abu Brek, a spindly 65-yearold wheat farmer who works 18 acres near the Roman ruins of Volubilis. ''Last year we lost the whole crop. One more year like that will be a disaster. Only Allah can save us.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/29/busin.print_headline: Business Digest; FRIDAY, MAY 29, 1981; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/29/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan criticized Wall Street, charging that the financial community had focused excessively on credit market conditions and that it had failed to understand his economic program. The remarks were seen as a sign of frustration over the recent disarray in financial markets and the resulting pressure on the Administration to compromise its position on tax cuts. (A1.) Wall Street's reaction was mixed. (D4.) In Washington, the Administration and Congressional Democrats continued negotiations on tax-cut legislation, without notable success. (D4.) **********Chase Manhattan Bank cut its prime lending rate to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent. Other major banks seemed to be waiting for the Federal Reserve's money-supply report today before acting. Bankers and economists declined to interpret the move as the start of a longterm drop, but Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said that rates were near their peak. (D1.) **********The Index of Leading Economic Indicators rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Commerce Department reported, suggesting that the economy would grow this summer, but at a slower rate than the 8.4 percent expansion recorded during the first quarter. The index's rise, the second straight following three months of declines, came largely on the strength of expanding money supplies, which led some experts to predict it would slip in the coming months. (D1.) **********The nation's trade deficit rose to $3.46 billion in April from $451 million in March. Agricultural and manufacturing exports fell while oil imports rose $1.54 billion. The increased oil imports apparently include substantial amounts unloaded late in March but not included in that month's statistics, one analyst said. (D1.) **********Coal-strike negotiators were optimistic that an accord was near, despite a day of bargaining complicated by technicalities. (A12.) Companies **********Dome Petroleum was prepared to cancel its $1.43 billion offer for 20 percent of Conoco at midnight Wednesday, insiders reported. The deal hung in limbo while Dome, a Canadian company, tried to convince Conoco instead to sell its 53 percent stake in Canada's Hudson's Bay Oil for $1.5 billion cash. (D1.) **********UA-Columbia Cablevision's attempt to avoid a takeover by Dow Jones & Company and Knight Ridder Newspapers is focusing on negotiations for a proposed merger with United Artists Theater Circuit, the largest shareholder in UA-Columbia, and Rogers Telecommunications.  (D3.) **********Massey-Ferguson reported an $8 million loss for its second quarter ended April 30. That was a sharp improvement from the $81.4 million loss the ailing Canadian farm equipment manufacturer posted in its first fiscal quarter. (D2.) **********Chrysler has a ''good shot'' at breaking even in the current quarter, according to Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige. (D12.) Markets **********Interest rates dropped sharply yesterday, and the Treasury sold new 13 7/8 percent, five-year, five-month notes at an average rate of 13.95 percent, well below the 14.6 percent yield that was estimated earlier in the week. But analysts continued to describe credit markets as volatile. (D5.) The assets of money market mutual funds fell $104.6 million in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said. The average 30-day fund yield was 15.4 percent, compared with 15.925 percent for six-month certificates of deposit.  (D9.) **********A late rally lifted the Dow Jones industrial average 1.11 points yesterday in heavy trading. Brokerage, airline, precious-metal and bank stocks moved higher, while energy stocks continued under selling pressure. (D6.) The dollar lost ground in light trading on European and New York currency markets, primarily because of Chase Manhattan's cut in its prime rate. Gold rose $12 to $479 a troy ounce in London and $11.50 an ounce to $481.20 on the Comex in New York.  (D10.) Grain and soybean futures closed lower after doubts that interest rates had peaked wiped out an early price rise based on news of scheduled U.S.-Soviet trade talks. (D10.) Today's Columns **********OPEC's decision this week to freeze oil prices creates a situation where a slight easing of the Federal Reserve Board's restraints on monetary supply growth could stimulate economic activity and help bring down interest rates. But monetarist policy makers in the Reagan Administration favor continued restraint to fight inflation.  Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********The depressing effect of high interest rates on home sales is evident in the efforts being made to sell condominiums in Barclay Woods Inc., a new New Jersey townhouse complex. Carteret Savings and Loan Association of Newark, a partner in the project, is offering mortgages at below-market terms. About Real Estate. (B5.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/11/world.main_headline: EGYPT ORDERS U.S. TV REPORTER OUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/11/world.print_headline: EGYPT ORDERS U.S. TV REPORTER OUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/11/world.body_text: **********A reporter for ABC News was given 24 hours to leave Egypt tonight after the Government showed other foreign correspondents television tapes in which the reporter interviewed an outspoken critic of the policies of President Anwar el-Sadat. **********Mr. Sadat, who assured the foreign press yesterday that there would be no censorship of its news coverage, had the chairman of State Information Services, Shafei Abdul Hamid, issue the expulsion order for the reporter, Chris Harper of ABC News. **********The tapes containing the interviews, which were unedited and were seized at Cairo Airport just before shipment to ABC News headquarters in London more than a month ago, came to light yesterday when Mr.  Sadat angrily waved them in the air at a news conference for foreign correspondents. Mr. Sadat has been upset by some foreign press criticism of his recent arrests of 1,600 Egyptians. **********At the time, many reporters assumed that the tapes were of a telecast that had been shown in the United States, but it turned out that they had never been shown and never reached New York. **********Called Distorted Coverage **********Mr. Sadat, who was angry, said at the news conference that the tapes, which he considered to be prime examples of distorted coverage of Egypt, would be shown to the press by the Information Ministry. **********Tonight foreign correspondents were shown the tapes, which consisted of footage in Beirut of an interview Mr. Harper conducted late in July with David Hirst, a British journalist and author who has long been critical of Mr. Sadat. Mr. Harper and his wife, Elizabeth, were present at the screening, which Don Schanche, chairman of the Foreign Press Association here, formally disavowed as ''a show staged by the State Information Services.'' **********Mr. Harper is the first foreign journalist to be expelled from Egypt since 1977, when President Sadat ordered Mr. Hirst to leave.  Mr. Harper is the first American reporter ordered out since Mr. Sadat came to power 11 years ago. **********Asked about the expulsion order, Mr. Abdul Hamid, the information chief, said only that ''everything is self-e@xplanatory.'' Asked how and why the Government had obtained the raw tapes, which were in transit, he said, ''They were given to us through a friendly channel.'' ABC News Crew Films Scene **********Mr. Harper said that after the screening he was given 24 hours to leave. At one point an ABC News crew was filming the scene in which their confiscated material was being shown. **********''I asked for the reason,'' Mr. Harper said tonight, ''and I was told I know the reason. I said I don't know, and I want the order in writing with the reasons. **********''I'm really sorry this has happened,'' Mr. Harper said.  ''Obviously they want to make an example of me.'' Mr. Harper has irritated Mr. Sadat in the past. The Egyptian leader has several times chastised ABC for a telecast Mr. Harper made on July 2 in which he spoke about some of the opposition Mr. Sadat faces at home. Sadat Prods Reporters **********At yesterday's news conference, Mr. Sadat, prodded the foreign correspondents to ''tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing but the truth.'' He dwelt at length on Mr. Hirst's articles castigating his regime, and he renewed his criticism of ABC News. **********In the footage shown tonight, Mr. Hirst characterized Mr. Sadat as ''an actor'' who had lived in the shadow of the late Gamal Abdel Nasser and who overreacted to ''the least sign of opposition.'' **********After the order expelling Mr. Harper, Mr. Schanche sent Mr. Abdul Hamid a telex message formally protesting the action in the name of the Foreign Press Association. The organization's executive committee will meet on the issue tomorrow and is expected to send a letter of protest to Mr. Sadat. **********The order affects only Mr. Harper, not the ABC News operation here.  ---- ABC News Protests Expulsion **********WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (Reuters) -The president of ABC News, Roone Arledge, sent a letter today to Dr. Ashraf Ghorbal, the Egyptian Ambassador to the United States, protesting the expulsion of Chris Harper. **********''ABC News protests in the strongest possible terms the actions taken by the Egyptian Government,'' Mr. Arledge said.''In reviewing Mr. Harper's work from Cairo, we take pride in the fact that in every instance he has more than lived up to most exacting standards of his profession.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/12/world.body_text: **********Alarmed by the suspension of American economic aid last month, Nicaragua's Sandinist Government has begun pressing El Salvador's leftist guerrillas to seek a political settlement rather than an armed victory in their conflict with the United States-backed junta. **********Although Nicaragua has denied United States charges that it allowed its territory to be used for the shipment of arms from Cuba to the guerrillas, officials here recognized that if relations with Washington are to improve the situation in El Salvador must be stabilized. **********The Reagan Administration claims to have ''overwhelming evidence'' of Nicaraguan support for the Salvadoran guerrillas and has suspended economic aid pending ''a very active review'' of relations with the 18-month-old Sandinist regime. **********''Washington's message has been received loud and clear,'' a senior Nicaraguan official said. ''There is recognition of the very high political cost to Nicaragua of involvement in El Salvador.'' **********Sandinists Seek Negotiations **********Since the failure of the Salvadoran left's ''final offensive'' last month, Sandanist leaders have tried to promote political negotiations between the warring factions, apparently convinced that prolongation of the conflict would involve the United States more deeply in the region and eventually threaten the survival of the Nicaraguan revolution. **********The Nicaraguan Government also seems aware that a permanent suspension of United States economic aid could have a disastrous effect on this country's efforts to recover from the civil war that preceded the ouster of the Somoza regime in July 1979. **********Already Nicaragua is facing a period of deep austerity because of a shortage of foreign exchange. But officials argue that failure to patch up relations with Washington could also lead the Reagan Administration to ''strangle'' Nicaragua economically by trying to block assistance from international financing agencies and other Western governments. **********''The American problem is not with El Salvador but with the very existence of our revolution,'' one official said. ''Their idea is not to send in the Marines here, but to make us surrender through hunger.'' Private Businesses Survive **********At the same time, there appears to be a growing consensus among officials, businessmen and opposition politicians that any move by the Reagan Administration to isolate Nicaragua economically would result in a rapid radicalization of the political process here. **********Despite frequent opposition charges that the Sandinists enjoy a ''monopoly'' of power here, the regime has permitted the survival of both a private sector, which still controls about 60 percent of economic activity, and of independent political parties. These parties use the widely read newspaper La Prensa as their mouthpiece. **********''A suppression of U.S. aid would be very negative and counterproductive,'' said Arturo J. Cruz, a non-Sandinist member of the five-man ruling junta. ''Political pluralism and the right to dissent would be affected. The economic crisis would be translated into a real radicalization and Nicaragua would have to look to other blocs for funds.'' **********Alfonso Robelo Callejas, a former junta member who is now the main opposition spokesman, also argued that ''the country and people of Nicaragua need U.S. help and I think that the U.S. has a moral obligation to give it because it is largely responsible for our situation through its long support for the Somozas.'' Sale of Wheat Delayed **********The suspension of United States economic aid last month involved the remaining $15 million of a $75 million credit granted to Nicaragua last year. The United States is also delaying a $9.6 million sale of wheat to Nicaragua. **********Since the Reagan Administration took office three weeks ago, the United States has also adopted a much tougher stance in its diplomatic dealings with Nicaragua. **********In several meetings with junta members, the American Ambassador, Lawrence A. Pezzullo, reportedly warned the Government to silence a Salvadoran leftist radio station, allegedly broadcasting clandestinely from Nicaragua, and to prevent arms from flowing through here to El Salvador.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/26/busin.body_text: **********Motor vehicle production in West Germany was generally steady in May at 16,994 vehicles a day, a trade association said today. This was slightly up from daily production of 16,799 in April, but below average daily production of 17,407 in May 1980. Car output in May was down 2 percent, at 296,300, from 301,340 a year ago, and below the 309,800 in April, when there were more working days, the group added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/world.body_text: **********The official Soviet press agency Tass today described President Reagan's meeting yesterday with the wife of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet dissident, as interference in Moscow's internal affairs. **********A senior commentator said Avital Shcharansky traveled the world specializing in anti-Soviet slander.  Mr. Reagan had a 30-minute meeting with her in the White House and promised to do all he could to obtain the release of her husband. **********In 1978, Mr. Shcharansky was sentenced to three years in jail and 10 years in a labor camp on charges that he had spied for the United States. The White House denied the accusation. **********''Not for the first time,'' Tass said, ''certain circles in the United States try to extricate their paid agent and to justify their activities in the public eye by portraying him as an innocent victim.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/03/world.body_text: **********A former Prime Minister of Portugal, Alfredo Nobre da Costa, is in stable condition after a heart attack during the night, medical sources said today.  They added that Mr. da Costa, who was here on vacation, showed no complications. Mr. da Costa, who is 57 years old, became Portugal's first presidentially appointed Prime Minister in 1978. He served four months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/17/busin.body_text: **********The people at the top of the cable television industry have asked for a hiatus in audience research accumulated by the diary-keeping method because ''the present method of reporting cable viewing is clearly inadequate and discriminatory to the cable industry.'' **********That request comes from the Cable Advertising Bureau/National Cable Television Association Cable Research Standards Committee, which met last week to analyze the major techniques being used to measure audiences. **********There is considerable anxiety about these audience figures because advertisers putting their money into cable, or contemplating doing so, want hard figures on which to base their decisions. **********Bob Alter, president of the bureau, said that, in addition to diary-based research, independent research companies are also getting data from day-after recall surveys, and, on a national scale, from meters on sets in selected households. **********''We're in the formative stage,'' Mr. Alter said. ''Let's not build bad habits.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/16/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration's plans for obtaining a long-term presence in Saudi Arabia through the stationing of Awacs surveillance planes have run into such criticism in Israel and on Capitol Hill that consideration is now being given to postponing the projected multibillion-dollar sale. **********High-ranking Administration officials said today that the political problems are looming so large, not only here, but in Israel and Saudi Arabia as well, that President Reagan will probably have to decide personally whether to go ahead with the Awacs sale this month or to delay it, perhaps until after the Israeli elections on June 30. **********What is particularly frustrating to some Administration officials is that one reason for supplying the advanced military technology to Saudi Arabia is to open the way to a permanent American force in the region, something which Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.contends would accrue to Israel's benefit as well as Saudi Arabia's.  The Awacs dispute has become the first test of Mr. Haig's premise that despite local animosities between Arabs and Jews, a ''strategic consensus'' can be forged against the Soviet Union in which these differences can be put aside. **********So far, however, the Israelis and Saudis have not been persuaded by Mr. Haig's recent trip to the region to show any interest in shelving their antagonisms. The issue has been complicated because the Administration - and, to a large extent, the Carter Administration as well - has not spoken candidly in public about its motivations in wanting to supply the Awacs to Saudi Arabia. Past Requests Refused **********The Saudis, despite their close economic and military ties to the United States, have refused past American requests to allow American forces facilities on Saudi territory. Privately, however, the Saudis have encouraged the United States to strengthen its naval presence in the region and welcomed the dispatch of four Air Force Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia last September at the height of the Iraq-Iran war. **********When those four planes, and the several hundred Air Force support personnel, flew to Saudi Arabia, the Carter Administration said they were on ''temporary deployment'' and would be withdrawn when the crisis eased. Without any further public statements, the Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to keep those four planes in Saudi Arabia through 1985, and to sell the Saudis five Awacs of their own, which will be delivered in 1985. **********Discussions have been under way with the Saudis for many weeks on having the kingdom increase its share of the costs of the four Air Force Awacs, and on possibly ''leasing'' Air Force personnel to run the Saudi-owned Awacs after 1985. Pentagon officials insist that the Saudis will be unable to handle the $400 million, ultrasophisticated Awacs on their own in the foreseeable future. **********In addition to the Awacs, the Administration plans to sell Saudi Arabia fuel tanks and advanced air-to-air missiles for the 62 F-15 fighters now on order. The Air Force also intends to sell the Saudis about seven ground radar stations to receive information from the Awacs. Saudi Apprehension Is Issue **********The Administration asserts that these moves will ease Saudi apprehension about American willingness to bolster regional defenses and will provide advanced equipment in case American forces have to be sent into the region to fight a war. **********The Administration's original intention, before Mr. Haig left on his trip to the Middle East on April 3, was to inform Congress officially of the Saudi package on April 27, the day it returns from its Easter recess. **********Then Mr. Haig was told in Jerusalem by Prime Minister Menachem Begin that Israel regarded the Awacs sale as a major threat to its security, that the high-flying Awacs could detect movements throughout Israel and would neutralize Israel's ability to make a surprise attack. **********While Mr. Haig was in the Middle East, supporters of Israel in Washington also began to flex their muscles. The contemplated Awacs sale led to widespread opposition, even among Republicans, on Capitol Hill. So far, 47 senators and about 100 Congressmen have spoken out against the projected sale. **********Under current law, the sale could be blocked if majorities in both houses of Congress vote against it within 30 days of receiving formal notification. No arms sale has ever been blocked by Congress, but the Administration, aware of Saudi sensitivities, does not want a bruising battle. Gesture to Israel Is Sought **********The sale could be made more acceptable to Congress if the Saudis would undertake commitments not to use the planes against Israel, to offer support for the American-sponsored Camp David peace process, to condemn the Palestine Liberation Organization, or to offer some other gesture to Israel. But the political maneuverings of the Arab world make such gestures out of the question. **********American officials contend that the Awacs pose no threat to Israel and that the Saudis would never use them against Israel for fear that the Israelis would shoot them down. But with Israel in the opening phases of its election campaign, no Israeli politician will do anything but express strong opposition to the projected sales to Saudi Arabia. This, in turn, will only fan criticism on Capitol Hill.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/world.print_headline: POLISH EX-LEADER IS UNDER INQUIRY; GRAFT IS SUGGESTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/10/world.body_text: **********A former Polish Prime Minister is under investigation by the state prosecutor for decisions made while in office, and a similar case may be prepared against the former party leader, Edward Gierek, a newspaper reported today. **********The paper, Zycie Warzawy, did not disclose the details of the investigation against Piotr Jaroszewicz, the former head of Government. However, many rank-and-file members of the Polish Communist Party have demanded that Mr. Jaroszewicz and other top party leaders be tried for mismanaging the country's economy. **********Mr. Jaroszewicz, who was dropped as Prime Minister at a party congress in February 1980 and was expelled from the party several months ago, is widely reported to have enriched himself during his 10 years in office. In addition, his son was given a lucrative job heading an automobile importing agency while Mr. Jaroszewicz was Prime Minister. **********Gierek Still in Party **********Mr. Gierek has been stripped of all his positions but he is still nominally a member of the party. He has not been seen in public since he was ousted in disgrace on Sept 6, a week after the signing of the agreement permitting a free trade union in Poland. **********As the country's economic situation has continued to deteriorate, in part because of the crushing burden of foreign debts run up by Mr. Gierek's Government, public anger against him has grown. So far, the party leadership has fended off demands for action against him, out of respect for the high position he held. But there is a groundswell of sentiment against him, both inside and outside the party, and the leadership may soon have to acknowledge it. **********The anger has been increased by continuing revelations about the privileges afforded high party members during the Gierek years. One newspaper interviewed Mr. Gierek's daughter, who disclosed that she shopped on the third floor of Warsaw's main department store at a special ''yellow curtain'' shop, stocked with goods unobtainable elsewhere and closed to all but dignitaries. **********Mr. Gierek, fond of high-priced imported suits and expeditions to exclusive hunting lodges, lived in a number of luxurious villas. A small but irksome details was added by the country's foremost muckraking newspaper, Gazeta Krakowska, which suggested that a special scientific degree awarded to the party leader by Cracow's Academy of Mining and Metallurgy was fradulent. The former first secretary called the allegation libelous in his only newspaper interview since being dismissed. **********Mr. Gierek, citing ill health, has refused to appear at Central Committee meetings to defend himself. When he was ousted, a heart attack was given as the reason. **********During a recent meeting with party activists, Kazimierz Barcikowski, a Politburo member, was asked why Mr. Gierek was allowed to remain in the party. He replied that the former leader could not be treated in the same way as Mr. Jaroszewicz. He said that Mr.  Gierek was enjoying a pension and was probably playing happily with his grandchildren. **********The news of the investigation into the Prime Minister came in a small item buried in today's issue of Zycie Warszawy. The Warsaw paper reprinted an account from a local newspaper in Bydgoszcz about a press conference in which the first secretary from Wloclawek, Edward Szymanski, revealed the investigation. 2 Hard-Liners May Be Purged **********Mr. Szymanski was the Central Committee member who campaigned at a heated party meeting on March 29 against accepting the resignations of two hard-line members of the Politburo. At the news conference, however, he indicated that the hard-liners would be purged at a party meeting later this month. **********The delegates at the March 29 meeting called on party leaders to go into the factories to listen to the rank and file.  This afternoon, Stanislaw Kania, the party's first secretary, met with thousands of workers in a sports hall inside the Gdansk shipyard, birthplace of the Solidarity free trade union. He ran into an avalanche of criticism. Workers charged that the Politburo was out of touch with the mood of the country and that the game of ''musical chairs'' - switching old leaders around instead of letting new ones rise - was getting the nation nowhere.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/world.main_headline: Iran Says It Destroyed Iraqi Bombers in Raid
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Iran Says It Destroyed Iraqi Bombers in Raid
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/06/world.body_text: **********Iran's Defense Minister, providing details on an announcement yesterday, said today that eight Iranian aircraft had destroyed a number of Soviet-built TU-22 long-range bombers and some long-range fighters at the Iraqi base of Haj Sen near the Jordanian border. He said the raid had been carried out to demonstrate that no part of Iraq was safe from Iran's air force. **********However, the official, Javad Fakuri, made no mention of the three other bases that Iran said yesterday had been bombed. He provided no figures on the number of Iraqi planes destroyed and he did not identify the kind of long-range fighter planes that were hit. **********Iraq reported only one attack on any base, asserting that Iranian aircraft flying from inside Syria had attacked an air base near the Syrian border. **********''From now on, we will strike at any point inside Iraq unless Saddam comes to his senses,'' Colonel Fakouri said. This was an apparent reference to the refusal of Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, to withdraw his army from Iran as a condition for negotiations to end the six-month-old Persian Gulf war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/25/busin.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia has lent the World Bank $10 billion, a Kuwaiti newspaper, Al Qabas, today quoted the Saudi Finance Minister, Mohammed Balkhail, as saying. **********The loan, as previously reported, was part of a ''new strategy to help out the Arab cause and the developing countries,'' he said. **********He was also quoted as saying that the oil-rich kingdom, having become the sixth permanent member of the International Monetary Fund, would be ''able to influence certain decisions in favor of the developing countries and the Arab world.'' **********He added that the Saudi delegates to the fund's executive directors' conference scheduled for mid-July would try again to sponsor the Palestine Liberation Organization for membership in the fund.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/07/busin.body_text: **********The Reichmann family, through its privately owned Olympia and York Company, was confirmed today as the victor in the takeover battle for Abitibi-Price Inc., the Toronto-based company that is the world's largest newsprint producer. They immediately extended the olive branch to the losing Thomson family by asking Thomson's representatives to remain on the Abitibi board. **********Olympia and York Investments Ltd. of Toronto paid $536.7 million (Canadian) to acquire 16.7 million Abitibi shares at $32 each early today in an offer on the floors of the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. **********Olympia and York now holds 88 percent of Abitibi common shares on a fully diluted basis, taking into account the 1.85 million common Abitibi shares the company already owned, and the 2.3 million additional common shares that would be issued if Abitibi's 2 million convertible preferred shares are converted into common and all existing stock options are exercised. **********Thomson Newspapers and Nu-West Group Ltd., a Calgary, Alberta, real estate developer, were the losers in a joint offer for about 46 percent of Abitibi stock at $31 a share. Thomson Newspapers, which owns 130 newspapers in the United States and Canada, gets 63 percent of its newsprint from Abitibi. **********The offer by the Reichmanns, who are also the owners of Olympia and York Developments Ltd. of Toronto, Canada's largest real estate developer, was for 100 percent of Abitibi stock. **********Paul Reichmann, secretary of Olympia and York, said in a statement that he had asked Kenneth R. Thomson and John A. Tory, chairman and deputy chairman, respectively, of Thomson Newspapers Ltd. of Toronto, to remain as Abitibi directors and that both had agreed to do so. He also said that Olympia and York intended that Abitibi continue under existing management. **********The Toronto Stock Exchange said today that it and the Montreal and Vancouver exchanges had agreed to extend the Olympia and York investment offer until March 13 so that more Abitibi shareholders would have the opportunity to offer their shares under the Reichmann bid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/31/world.main_headline: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: PARTY AIDES INVESTIGATED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/31/world.print_headline: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: PARTY AIDES INVESTIGATED
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/31/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency: Food Shortages Reported 10 A.M. Wednesday **********(4 A.M., Wednesday, E.S.T.) By 28 December, socialized and private farms delivered to the procurement points just over 90,000 tons of meat. That is, 75 percent of the month's plan. **********Since the middle of December, the procurement of livestock has improved. An average of over 5,000 tons is procured daily, but 6,000 tons are required. **********In order to supply the population, 1.1 million tons of potatoes have been procured; of this, 134,000 tons have been set aside as winter reserves. This is 300,000 tons short of the amount needed to provide full supplies to the market according to the calculations of the Ministry of Agriculture and Food Economy. **********Abuses to Be Investigated 7:30 P.M. Wednesday **********(1:30 P.M. Wednesday E.S.T.) **********Here is a communique on the results of the investigations of cases of abuse of position for material gain: 1. In 1980-81 numerous reports were submitted to prosecutors from various social circles - work forces, social and union organizations and also private citizens. The reports accused numerous persons performing responsible state and party functions. Common accusations involved the use of social property for constructing villas and vacation houses and for fitting out living quarters above the usual standard, accepting expensive gifts and irregularities in the distribution of tokens entitling the purchase of passenger cars. **********As a rule the reports were not supported by the necessary evidence. Hence they demanded detailed examination. On examination, some appeared to be untrue and to have been tendentious. Most proved to be true, and the persons who exposed the misdeeds were guided by social interest and a desire to eliminate from public life damaging and negative phenomena. **********Numerous inspections had been carried out in order to establish that the accusations are correct. Apart from the investigations to establish the true character of earlier accusation, the Supreme Control Chamber, regional boards of state revenue and financial control and other state control bodies have also made wholesale investigations aimed at disclosing abuses connected with the use of prominent posts in the organs of state and economic administration for personal advantage. **********Based on the results of the investigatons other materials, the prosecutor's offices began penal proceedings. The complicated character of many cases and also the existing legal procedure required comprehensive expert reports which contributed to the drawn-out nature of the proceedings. **********2. The results achieved so far are follows: 263 persons have been charged with offenses. Temporary arrest has been applied to 101 persons. Investigations have been completed on 181 persons.  Indictments have been submitted to the courts against 154 persons.  Preliminary proceedings against 7 persons have been discontinued. The remaining cases are in the final stage of proceedings and it is expected that these will be completed in January or February of next year. The cases which are currently being completed include the investigations against Communist Party Central Committee former first Secretary Edward Gierek and former Deputy Prime Ministers Tadeusz Wrzaszczyk, Jan Szydlak and Franciszek Kaim. **********3. Trials are in progress against 27 persons, as has already been reported by the press. The public will be informed about the completion of proceedings and their results. **********Unionists Punished 7:30 P.M. Tuesday **********(1:30 P.M. Tuesday E.S.T.) The press spokesman of the Prosecutor General reports that more cases of persons charged with violating the regulations of the decree on martial law were tried on Dec. 23 at military district courts and provincial courts, under summary proceedings. **********The court of the Silesian miliary district has sentenced Andrzeu Pawlki, head of the transporation and supples section in the Solidarity chapter in lower Silesia, to 8 years in prison, has taken away his public rights for 5 years and has taken his automobile, after having found him guilty of transporting leaflets in his car containing false information for dissemination which could have aroused public unrest. **********The Jelenia Gora provincial court has sentenced Jan Filipek to 3 years in prison and loss of public rights for 3 years, finding him guilty of preparing of proclaiming strikes in the construction materials factory in Boleslawiec. **********The Bielsko-Biala provincial prosecutor has issued arrest warrants for Partycjusz Kosmovski, chairman of the interfactory founding committee of Solidarity of the sub-Beskids region, and Waclaw Szlegier. It is suspected that even after Dec. 13, as members and activists of the suspended Solidarity, they have not stopped their participation in further union activities and have embarked on the organization of protest actions against the martial law already in force. **********Soviet Aid Delivered 7:30 P.M. Tuesday **********(1:30 P.M. Tuesday E.S.T.) Continuously intensive transloading of large food consignments from the Soviet Union for Poland has been taking place during the past few days at eastern border stations. Deliveries of meat, initiated during the last 10 days of November, reached peak intensity in the second half of December. So far, more than 32,000 tons of meat have been received at Malaszewicze and Zurawica and have been transloaded from broad-guage Soviet cars into Polish state railways vehicles. There has been notification that 8,000 tons more meat from the Soviet Union and 2,000 tons from Mongolia will be arriving in the next few days.  Canned fish, mandarin oranges, raisins, fruit juices and other foodstuffs from the Soviet Union have also been received and transloaded at the border station. Large supplies of rice have begun in the past few days. **********Production Increasing 5:18 P.M. Wednesday **********(11:18 A.M. Wednesday E.S.T.) **********All Warsaw factories and plants worked full steam from early morning on December 30. The city transport functioned smoothly.  Thursday is the traditional celebration of the end of the year and the welcoming of the New Year. This year Warsaw residents will celebrate only at home, amid their relatives and friends But already today business at the hairdresser's is very lively and ladies buy evening dresses as usual for the occasion. **********Railway transport across the country functioned normally. To insure smooth railway services, 22,500 persons were engaged removing snow from tracks and railway stations. Among them were 6,500 workers of various enterprises and several hundred troops. **********Coal extraction is increasing. On Dec. 9 miners supplied 595,400 tons of coal. This is the highest daily extraction reached after the introduction of martial law in Poland. **********The two collieries in Tychy, Ziemowit and Piast, are gradually coming back to their normal production rhythm. However, after a long standstill machinery and installations require detailed survey. That is why the collieries have not reached their full daily capacity yet. On Dec. 29 miners in the Ziemowit colliery extracted 7,100 tons of coal (their daily plan is 23,500 tons) and miners in the Piast colliery supplied about 12,000 tons of coal (daily plan - nearly 17,500 tons). **********Espionage Charged 7 P.M. Wednesday **********(1 P.M. Wednesday E.S.T.) We have learned from the press spokesman at the Ministry of Internal Affairs that the investigation conducted against Bohdan Walecki by the Investigation Bureau of the Ministry of Internal Affairs under the supervision of the supreme military prosecutor is nearing completion. **********Bohdan Walecki, for many years an employee of the Ministry of Foreign Affiars, former Deputy Director of the Polish Institute for International Affairs and former employee at diplomatic missions, including in the United States, and recently head of a department in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, was detained by the security services in March on the charge of espionage. **********In the course of the investigation it was established that Bohdan Walecki was recruited by the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency for intelligence cooperation during his work at a foreign mission.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/world.main_headline: Schedule Is Announced For Pope's Swiss Visit
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Schedule Is Announced For Pope's Swiss Visit
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/11/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II will visit the three different language-speaking regions of Switzerland during a four-day trip that will begin June 1 in Zurich, the country's German-speaking financial and business capital, it was announced today. **********The Conference of Swiss Catholic Bishops said that the Pope's visit will be ''pastoral'' rather than ''official,'' although the seven-man Swiss federal Cabinet plans to receive him in a body. **********On the day of his arrival the Pope will fly by helicopter over the Alps to visit the Italian-speaking region. He will spend his first two nights at the abbey of Einsiedeln, in central Switzerland, and his third night at Fribourg, on the edge of Switzerland's Frenchlanguage region. **********On June 4 the Pope is to come to Geneva, where he is expected to address the annual conference of the International Labor Organization and visit the World Council of Churches and the International Committee of the Red Cross. **********ROME, March 10 (AP) - Pope John Paul II will visit Lourdes, France, for three days in July to take part in an international eucharistic congress, the president of the French bishops announced today.
