It said the plant would manufacture semiconductor devices and voltage supressors for sale in Europe and the Middle East. Construction will take place in two phases over the next three years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.main_headline: MORE SALVADOR AID BACKED IN CONGRESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.print_headline: MORE SALVADOR AID BACKED IN CONGRESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration won strong support from key members of Congress today for future increases in American aid to El Salvador to help the Government there to counter what the Administration says is Soviet-bloc assistance to the insurgents in the country. **********''I think those outside forces should be on notice that this nation will do whatever is necesary to prevent a Communist state takeover in El Salvador,'' said Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. He made the statement after a closed-door briefing from Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on the Administration's assertions that arms supplied by the Soviet Union, Cuba, Ethiopia and Vietnam had been sent to the Salvadoran insurgents. No Decision Is Reached **********Although William J. Dyess, a State Department spokesman, said that the Administration had not decided whether, or how much, additional military and economic assistance would be needed for El Salvador, various Senators and Representatives appeared favorably inclined in advance to requests that might be submitted. **********El Salvador, which is ruled by a military-civilian junta, is receiving $73.5 million for this fiscal year, of which $10 million is in military aid. **********Representative James C. Wright Jr., Democrat of Texas, who is the House majority leader, said after Mr. Haig's briefing that ''Central America is probably more vitally important to us than any other part of the world.'' **********''Our response to what is happening there requires a bipartisan, unified approach and I fully expect that that is what the President and the Secretary of State will receive,'' he said. **********Mr. Percy was asked if his pledge to do ''whatever is necessary'' was meant to include the dispatch of American combat troops to El Salvador. He said that such a move ''would be highly unlikely'' but he declined to ''rule out any options.'' **********''I am simply saying that we will do what is necessary to resist outside intervention,'' he said. ''We will not stand idly by while outside forces - outside our hemisphere or within our hemisphere - are feeding arms to one particular faction attempting to bring down what looks to be a centrist government.'' **********''The Administration is reaching out seeking Congressional support,'' Mr. Percy said. ''They will have that support.'' So far the Administration has not made public what Mr. Dyess described today as ''the very solid, increasing evidence that the leftist guerrillas are being supplied with arms from the outside.'' **********In addition to sharing the material with members of Congress throughout the day, the Administration has sent special envoys to Europe and Latin America to brief other governments on the data in an effort to win their political backing. **********Officials said that a ''white paper'' would be made available later in the week.  They said that the information, which they said was compiled from a number of sources including documents captured from the insurgents, disclosed that the rebels had been supplied with Soviet- and American-made military equipment shipped to El Salvador from as far away as Vietnam. Arms From Vietnam Reported **********The Administration says, for instance, that large amounts of captured American military equipment had been sent from Vietnam to Cuba by the Soviet Union. From Cuba, the equipment was said to have been shipped to Nicaragua, from where, according to these accounts, it was slipped into El Salvador by sea and air and by land through Honduras. **********Mr. Haig has indicated privately that he sees the situation in El Salvador as an early test of relations with both American allies and with the Soviet Union. He seems to want to make El Salvador a demonstration of allied unity and an example of Soviet overseas ''expansionism.'' **********Support for the Salvadoran Government in this country has been weakened, however, by its seeming inability to crack down on rightwing groups that have carried out political assassinations. **********Of particular concern was the murder in December of four American churchwomen. For a while, American aid to El Salvador was suspended as a result of the killings. Aid Resumed in January **********The Carter Administration, which had suspended the aid, resumed it shortly before leaving office because of the increased guerrilla activity. The Reagan Administration said last week that it had ''delinked'' the question of aid to El Salvador from the question of a thorough investigation by Salvadoran authorities into the death of the Americans. **********But Senator Percy said today he had told Secretary Haig that ''it is absolutely crucial'' that the Salvadoran authorities find out who murdered the churchwomen. He said that resolution of the matter was very important to Americans. Mr. Dyess said the Administration was pressing for action on the matter. **********The Senate Majority Leader, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, said the briefing he had received from Mr. Haig was ''alarming.'' He said it was ''pretty clear that there is a major problem there and it is also clear to me at least that Cuba is directly involved in the difficulties of that region.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/11/busin.body_text: **********OPEC's chief spokesman cautioned today against expecting a significant drop in oil prices even though the current worldwide oversupply is forcing producing countries to offer hefty discounts. **********The official, Hamid Zaheri, told reporters after a speech to corporate public relations executives here that oil supply imbalances had occurred frequently and ''I don't think you should be very optimistic'' about prices. **********He attributed the current buyers' market to a mild winter, stockpiling by consumer countries and a worldwide recession that had cut energy demand. **********He disputed the allegation that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was a cartel, saying it did not control supply and price but merely recommended a reference price for one specific type of oil to its members. ''We don't have any control on the market,'' Mr. Zaheri said. Shipping, refining and product marketing were not controlled by OPEC, he said, and the group's ''price decisions always follow the market trend.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/22/busin.body_text: **********On a torrid day in July 1979, with the Super Bowl XV kickoff still a year and a half away, the office of Antoine's Restaurant here was abuzz with activity. **********Staff members planned, conferred and dictated memos. Within days, Antoine's regular customers received letters reminding them that New Orleans had been chosen as the Super Bowl City for 1981, suggesting that they should make reservations without delay if they wished to dine at Antoine's during the weekend of the game. And, days later, almost 500 of the 650 chairs in the restaurant were reserved for dinner -on Jan. 24, 1981. **********Yes, by July 1979 the Super Bowl XV rush was on - for the best restaurants with the biggest names, the best rooms at the most glamorous hotels and the longest, sleekest limousines with the plushest built-in bars and television sets. **********For Super Bowl, in the words of a New Orleans executive, is an event for ''super people'' - ''people in big business who can appreciate the big business of football.'' **********And for New Orleans, a city that increasingly relies on the tourist business, it is yet another means to attract visitors. For hotel executives, French Quarter businessmen, T-shirt sellers and souvenir shop owners, it is a dream of great riches. City's Pregame Frenzy **********But as the pregame activity worked up to a frenzy in recent weeks - with the usual avalanche of phone calls directed to local residents from long-forgotten acquaintances and relatives seeking tickets, hotel rooms or just a corner to park a sleeping bag - there were signs that the glow from the business side may be a little dimmer at this year's game. **********While the city is expecting ''3,000 private aircraft using three airports and probably some cornfields as well'' for the game this coming Sunday, according to Beverly Gianna of the Greater New Orleans Tourist and Convention Commission, she noted that some of the big corporations that usually descend upon a Super Bowl city in their corporate jets had not made their usual requests for airport service. **********One major airport ground service company, the General Aviation Corporation, reported that corporate bookings were ''considerably less'' than for the last Super Bowl here in 1978. Nick Boroni, assistant vice president, said: ''I'd have to say the economy is playing a role. The thrill riding has been cut to a minimum.'' **********And Joseph Bonomolo of Bonomolo Limousines, which rents Lincoln Continentals equipped with televisions and bars for $40 an hour, said: ''Reservations are down from corporate groups, but the game is sold out, and they've got to come in. We have one client coming in from Frankfurt, Germany.'' **********Super Bowl tickets continue to be eagerly sought at prices far above the National Football League price of $40. The scalpers' market is lively here with tickets selling for as much as $500. **********''Money doesn't mean anything to these people,'' said a New Orleans stockbroker who has sat in on discussions at downtown luncheon clubs centered on tickets and hotel rooms. ''The way to get a suite at a good downtown hotel is to tip an employee $100 a room, $300 for a three-room suite.'' Hotels Fully Booked **********The city's 22,000 hotel rooms are fully booked at the usual prices ($90 and $100 a day at the major hotels) and have been ''for some time,'' said Joseph F. Frederick Jr., president of the Greater New Orleans Hotel and Motel Association and general manager of the New Orleans Hilton. Many hotels require a minimum stay of three days. **********There has been brisk corporate demand for blocks of hotel rooms, Mr. Frederick said. ''A company might reserve anywhere from five to 200 rooms. They use Super Bowl as a means to solidify and enhance their customer relationships and to recruit new customers. It's a great tool for that. They invite people to the game, buy their tickets, pay for their transportation and hotel.'' Such an invitation can cost thousands of dollars a customer, he said, but ''in the long run, it may be worth hundreds of thousands of dollars in business.'' **********For the city of New Orleans, the game means anywhere between $40 million and $150 million in business, said John Bender, city public information director. **********''We are ecstatic,'' said Morris H. Auerbach, food and beverage director of the Ogden Foods Service Corporation at the Superdome, who is prepared to supply food and drink to 76,000 fans on Super Bowl Sunday as well as to cater private parties. But he is not sure how many parties there will be. **********''It's like standing-room-only at the opera and they're all hungry, thank God,'' he said. During the 1978 Super Bowl, sales of food and beverages at the Superdome exceeded $500,000. Sales-Incentive Program **********Among companies having parties at the Superdome will be AnheuserBusch Inc., which is planning for a hundred or so people having ''a few beers and some snacks,'' said Robert Berra, the brewer's New Orleans branch manager. Anheuser-Busch traditionally uses the Super Bowl as part of a sales-incentive program for 40 or 50 Anheuser-Busch employees, Mr. Berra said. **********Wembley Industries, the New Orleans-based pie company, is still looking for tickets but has booked hotel rooms in any case for ''24 to 36'' customers from all over the country, said Sam Pulitzer, the company's chairman. **********''A lot of customers say, 'We'll pay you back,' but if they don't we don't worry about it,'' Mr. Pulitzer said. ''We spend hundreds of thousands of dollars each year on advertising, and another $5,000 or $10,000 on the Super Bowl is not significant.'' Wembley has also scheduled a cocktail party and dinner at Antoine's, where not only football but also business is discussed. **********The National Broadcasting Company is throwing a party for 1,000 aboard the steamer President on Saturday on the Mississippi River, with fried catfish and crawfish quiche, among other dishes. **********Barron Hilton, chairman and president of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, who is flying in after the Presidential inauguration in his corporate jet, will be host at a pregame party for 1,200 to 1,400 guests in the grand ballroom at the Hilton. His co-hosts are John W.  Mecom Jr., president of the New Orleans Saints, and Eugene V. Klein, president of the San Diego Chargers. More Than Fun and Games **********Many corporations prefer anonymity. ''Frankly, I guess, like most companies, we are not looking for a lot of publicity about this,'' said an American Cyanamid executive in Wayne, N.J., in a telephone conversation about the company's planned Super Bowl trip. ''It's not just fun and games and shooting off fireworks. We have a business program planned as well.'' **********Ella Brennan, an owner of Commander's Palace Restaurant in the Garden District, said, ''We find we sell our most expensive wines for the Super Bowl - Dom Perignon, the better Bordeaux, Chateau Latour.'' **********Among the first of the Super Bowl parties during bowl season here was one being used to finance the city's new summer festival, La Fete, an attempt to make the city more attractive during its hot, humid July weather. **********The festival backers, designated as contributors of $5,000 and $1,000 each, and an assortment of political figures and celebrities gathered recently in the Hilton Hotel's Napoleon Ballroom. The $5,000 donors receive two free Super Bowl tickets; $1,000 donors receive a chance at a ticket.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The American Motors Corporation today reported a $16.8 million net loss for the third quarter, a sharp reduction of the loss of $84.9 million a year earlier. **********The company, which is controlled by Renault of France, lost $19.9 million in the second quarter of 1981.  A.M.C. is the first domestic auto maker to report third-quarter results. **********Analysts expect the Big Three - the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation - will also report quarterly operating losses later this month because of slumping sales. Industry analysts have attributed the low level of new-car sales through the summer and into the autumn to high interest rates and high sticker prices on cars. **********Gerald C. Meyers, A.M.C.'s chairman and chief executive officer, said in a prepared statement: ''Domestic market conditions remain depressed and continue to hamper automotive sales in the United States and Canada. Our third-quarter results, while improved over those of last year and the previous quarter, are primarily a reflection of stringent cost control measures and contributions by our International and AM General operations.'' **********''In spite of current economic conditions, we are sustaining our product and plant modernization programs to prepare for a return to better times.'' **********At the annual shareholders meeting in April, Mr. Meyers said he did not expect the company to return to profitability until late in 1982. **********Net sales for the quarter were $648 million, up from $563 million for the comparable period in 1980, but down from $722 million in the second quarter of this year. **********For the first nine months of 1981, A.M.C. reported a net loss of $89.4 million on sales of $2 billion. In the first nine months of 1980, the company lost $171.7 million on net sales of $1.9 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/06/world.main_headline: KILLINGS BY GUARD TEST SPANISH REGIME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/06/world.print_headline: KILLINGS BY GUARD TEST SPANISH REGIME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/06/world.body_text: **********An investigation into the deaths of three young men at the hands of the Civil Guard is turning into a major test of the independence of the Spanish judiciary and the credibility of the Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo. **********The Almeria case, as it has become known, has also raised questions about the ability of the Government to control its security forces in the edgy political atmosphere that has taken hold since February's unsuccessful military coup. **********On May 7, Luis Cobos, Luis Montero and Juan Manas arrived in Almeria in southern Spain from Santander, the northern city where they lived, to take a vacation and attend a relative's first communion. **********On the night of May 9 they were arrested by Civil Guardsmen, who took them for Basque terrorists. The next morning they were dead.  Their charred, bullet-ridden bodies were found in a burned rented car on a lonely road. **********Bodies Are Mutilated **********The arms and legs of two of the men were missing and an autopsy found that many of their bones were broken. The Civil Guard agreed to return the body of Mr. Manas to his family on the condition that his coffin not be opened. **********On May 21, Interior Minister Juan Jose Roson gave a parliamentary subcommittee the Government's version of what had happened.  Recalling that on May 7 terrorists belonging to E.T.A., the Basque separatist group, had killed three soldiers in Madrid in an attack on an aide to King Juan Carlos, the Interior Minister blamed the overheated political atmosphere for a ''tragic error.'' After a number of citizens had spotted the youths in Almeria, taking them for terrorists, he said, the Civil Guard detained them. **********They gave evasive answers. Two pistols were found in their car.  Handcuffed, they were being driven to Madrid for questioning when they overpowered the two Civil Guardsmen accompanying them, hurling them from the rented Ford. Legislators Express Disbelief **********Lieut. Col. Carlos Castillo Quero, in another vehicle, ordered his men to fire at the wheels of the Ford. It spilled into a ditch and caught fire, killing the three men. **********Opposition legislators greeted Mr. Roson's version with angry incredulity. How could three handcuffed youths overpower two armed Civil Guardsmen? If the Civil Guardmen fired at the Ford's wheels, why were the bodies riddled with bullets that had been come from various directions? Why had the two pistols not been produced? Why did a plainclothes Civil Guardsman tell a group of people who came upon the burning car that the victims had been removed? **********''Why were these three young men killed if the death penalty does not exist in Spain?'' asked Carlos Sanjuan, a Socialist member of Parliament, challenging the Interior Minister. ''If we don't have a convincing answer I have to think we are before a triple crime, and that the Government is covering up this crime.'' **********Subsequent investigations by lawyers, an investigating magistrate and the press have uncovered more disquieting facts. Colonel Castillo Quero, the Almeria Civil Guard commander, has been hospitalized in the past for ''nervous disequilibrium.'' He was declared ill with a stomach problem the day the three youths died. Other Defects in the Case **********According to informants close to the case, shards of bone were found in the burned car. But there were no signs of smoke inhalation in the dead men's lungs, suggesting that they had been killed before the car caught fire. **********The official version has other defects in it. Mr. Roson said the agency that rented the three men the car had reported them as suspicious to the Civil Guard; the car rental company has denied this. The three men had identity papers and no criminal record, but the Civil Guard maintained that their documentation was faulty. **********The local prosecutor in Almeria has asked that Colonel Castillo Quero and two other Civil Guardsmen be prosecuted for homicide, but the investigating magistrate, Angel Tortosa, has not yet completed what looks like an exhaustive inquiry. A lawyer for the families of the three dead men has praised the judge's meticulous work. **********The available evidence suggests that the three youths were tortured and then murdered - a conclusion that many had reached even when Interior Minister Roson gave his account to Parliament. If Judge Tortosa reaches a similar conclusion, the Government's credibility will have suffered another blow. **********On Feb. 13, Jose Ignacio Arregui, an E.T.A. militant, died in Madrid after being held incommunicado in police custody for 10 days under an antiterrorist statute. His body showed signs of torture, including burns on the soles of his feet. **********Mr. Roson still maintains that Mr. Arregui died of a lung condition. The investigation of the five policemen who questioned the E.T.A. militant is continuing. ---- Land Mine Kills Spanish Officer **********SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, June 5 (AP) - A land mine detonated by remote control exploded under a police bus tonight in Loyola, a suburb of this city in northern Spain. Officials said that one officer was killed and five were seriously wounded. Witnesses said the attackers, believed to be Basque separatists, also raked the bus with bullets before fleeing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/11/world.main_headline: CHINA AND INDIA STARTING TALKS ON BORDER DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/11/world.print_headline: CHINA AND INDIA STARTING TALKS ON BORDER DISPUTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/11/world.body_text: **********Nearly two decades after they fought a short, fierce border war, China and India took a major step today toward improving relations by opening negotiations on their Himalayan frontier dispute. **********The delicate talks, the details of which are being kept secret, were agreed to when the Chinese Foreign Minister, Huang Hua, visited India in June. **********No specific agenda has been announced, and Peking-based diplomats following the talks do not expect any breakthroughs at this initial session, which is to end Monday. An Asian diplomatic analyst said he believed that the two sides would start by seeking a framework for dealing with the complex and emotional border issue. The talks will also cover scientific and cultural contacts and trade. **********Late tonight the New China News Agency reported that in today's talks ''the two sides expressed common aspirations for the settlement of the Chinese-Indian border problem and the development of relations between the two countries and reached identical views on procedural matters.'' 'Sincere and Friendly' **********It did not specify how long the talks lasted but said officials of the two nations had split into discussion groups. The atmosphere was described as ''sincere and friendly.'' **********The Chinese have cordially welcomed the Indian delegation, which arrived Monday night. At a banquet here Tuesday, the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Han Nianlong, said China was ''very pleased'' about the talks and hoped that ''with our common efforts, our discussion will surely proceed smoothly and our friendly relations will grow.'' **********Eric Gonsalves, the head of the Indian delegation, responded by saying, ''We have no way to go other than forward with our friendly relationship.'' Mr. Gonsalves, who is Secretary of the Ministry of External Affairs, had made a preparatory visit here last year. **********In another tentative sign of improving relations, it was announced last week that Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had accepted an invitation from Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang to visit China sometime in the future. The invitation, originally extended when Mr. Huang visited New Delhi in June, was renewed when Mr. Zhao met Mrs. Gandhi at the economic conference in Cancun, Mexico, in October. Two Areas at Issue **********The border dispute led to full-scale fighting in 1962. India has accused the Chinese of seizing nearly 14,500 square miles in the Aksai Chin and Ladakh region of their common western frontier. The Chinese in turn have said that India holds about 56,000 square miles of former Chinese territory on their eastern frontier. **********Last year China declared that it was not asking for the return of territory ''illegally incorporated into India by the old colonialists'' and proposed that both nations make concessions by accepting the realities of the present border. India rejected this as acquiescing to China's seizure of its land. **********The root of the dispute is that India adheres to the so-called McMahon line drawn between India and Tibet by the British in 1915, while China bases its claim on a tributary-based ''traditional and conventional'' frontier. **********Because the positions are so entrenched, the decision to negotiate at all is viewed as something of a breakthrough. The Chinese had previously contended that the border dispute was so formidable that both sides should concentrate on other aspects of their relations.  The Indians maintained that no real improvement was possible until the border question was settled. Thaw Began Five Years Ago **********After Chinese troops overran the disputed border region in the west in October 1962, diplomatic ties were virtually frozen until five years ago, when China and India decided to restore ambassadors.  A slow thaw followed. **********In early 1979 Atal Bihari Vajpayee, then India's Foreign Minister, visited Peking only to return home prematurely because China had attacked Vietnam, which India supported. Prospects for improving relations were further stalled when Mrs. Gandhi recognized the new Vietnamese-backed regime of Heng Samrin in Cambodia in place of the ousted Pol Pot regime backed by China. **********But last year Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, was quoted as telling an Indian visitor to Peking that he saw no reason why the border problem could not be solved by repeated discussions. In June, when Mr. Huang visited India, he told reporters that he thought that ''a fair, comprehensible and reasonable'' solution could be found. **********The Chinese have since allowed small groups of Indian pilgrims to visit holy sites in Tibet. The overland trade route between India and China remains closed, except for what gets smuggled through Nepal.  Nonetheless, Chinese-Indian trade has grown from virtually nothing two years ago to an estimated $100 million annually, running heavily in India's favor.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/28/busin.body_text: **********The stock market's ''OPEC rally'' gained momentum yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average sharply higher in stepped-up trading. Airline, brokerage and bank issues spearheaded the general advance. **********After gaining 12.24 points Tuesday, mostly in late-afternoon trading, the Dow staged another afternoon run-up yesterday to finish at 993.14, up 9.18 points. It declined 14.23 points last week. **********''The market is smelling lower interest rates and less inflation,'' said Newton D. Zinder of E.F. Hutton & Company. Broker Loan Rate Cut **********This view was reinforced after the Chemical Bank reduced its broker loan rate to 19 1/2 percent from 20 1/2 percent, reflecting a recent easing in money market rates. Brokerage firms borrow from banks at the broker loan rate to finance margin accounts of their customers. **********As institutions fed money into the market, turnover on the New York Stock Exchange expanded to 58.7 million shares from 42.8 million shares Tuesday. Market technicians generally regard a combination of rising prices and rising volume as a favorable portent for stocks. **********Meanwhile, Wall Street analysts agreed that the spark igniting this week's rally was the decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, meeting in Geneva, to freeze oil prices at current levels and to cut production. **********This signaled good news for the airlines, since it might mean lower fuel costs, or at least no increases. Eastern Air Lines and American Airlines topped the active list. Eastern climbed a point, to 12, while American rose 1 1/8, to 20 1/4. Elsewhere among the trunk carriers, even stronger gains were registered by Delta Air Lines and UAL. **********In turn, the Dow transportation average climbed 6.40 points, to 435.91. Technical analysts at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company have said that the airline group ''appears to be returning to investor favor after many years of neglect and unpopularity.'' **********It was a market that moved ahead in gear as advances outnumbered declines by almost a 2-to-1 ratio on the Big Board. Amex Index Sets Mark **********For the second consecutive day, basic indicators for the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market set records. The Amex market-value index climbed 4.30 points, to 379.77, while the Nasdaq composite index moved up 1.93, to 222.17. By and large, highs for these barometers reflect buying interest in smaller stocks by individual investors, as well as bank trust departments and other institutions. **********Brokerage issues benefited from two forces: trading activity and continuing conjecture that some publicly owned houses might become takeover targets. E.F. Hutton jumped 3 1/2 points, to 46 1/2, while Shearson Loeb Rhoades climbed 2 5/8, to 58 3/4. Last week, directors approved the acquisition of Shearson, whose stock sold at less than $1 a share in 1975, by the American Express Company. **********Price gains among the large money-center banks included Chase Manhattan, up 1 7/8, to 49 3/8, and Citicorp, up 1 1/8, to 27 3/4.Some industry analysts maintain that recent strength in bank shares could prove to be a harbinger of declining rates, inasmuch as interest margins at major banks widen when short-term rates start to move downward. **********Meanwhile, the prime lending rate at banks was raised by half a point last Friday, to 20 1/2 percent.  Blue-chip issues shared in yesterday's advance as Merck, General Motors, Eastman Kodak and International Business Machines posted good gains. Among technology stocks, Texas Instruments, Control Data and Digital Equipment advanced more than 2 points each. **********Thompson Medical fell 1 3/4, to 18 5/8, while Revlon gained a point, to 41 3/4. The companies said they had ended merger discussions. **********While the OPEC decisions on an oil price freeze and production cut dominated this week's developments on the commodity front, prices have been slumping this year for such other basic commodities as grains, livestock, and precious and base metals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/world.main_headline: JAPAN LOOKS TO MAJOR GAINS IN USE OF ROBOTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/world.print_headline: JAPAN LOOKS TO MAJOR GAINS IN USE OF ROBOTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/27/world.body_text: **********Robots will be widely used later in this decade in Japanese hospitals, in service industries and in agriculture, as well as in manufacturing, where Japan already leads the world in use of robots, according to a report issued here. **********The Japan Industrial Robot Association announced the results of a survey at 444 nonmanufacturing companies and robot-makers, concluding in its report that robots had a great role to play on Japanese farms, in hospitals and in dangerous primary industries such as mining. **********''If robots develop as planned, there will be nurse robots to take care of physically handicapped people and aged patients in bed, to sweep the streets, to guide the blind and to serve on fishing vessels,'' said the report. **********''From 1985 through 1990 robots will come into use on a massive scale in spraying insecticide on farms, spreading fertilizer, inspecting eggs and packing them, milking cows, cutting lumber, in planting and in ocean research,'' it said. **********Kanji Yonemoto, executive director of the robot association, said in another recent report that ''98 percent of robots in Japan are engaged in manufacturing.'' Use in Forestry Foreseen **********''There is an increasing demand for robots which can assume tasks in construction and mining,'' he said. ''In the primary industries robots are needed in forestry, where wood is being studied as a renewable source of energy, and a tree-cutting robot is expected to eliminate Reynaud's disease - a disease caused by vibration affecting chain saw operators.'' **********''Submarine robots, which can construct fish farms and build marine structures in deep water are needed as well,'' said Mr. Yonemoto.  The association forecast in its latest survey that amount spent on robots in nonmanufacturing industry would total $27 million by the mid-1980's and that it ''will rise sharply by more than 10 times in value, reaching $360 million by the end of the decade.'' **********Overall production of robots will multiply, mainly for manufacturing industry, to nearly $5 billion by the end of the decade, according to separate industrial estimates, as compared with 1980 production worth $180 million, counting sophisticated robots only. **********The robot association here estimated that there were 14,000 ''advanced'' robots in Japan at the end of 1979 and 50,000 robots of simpler type. It compared the 14,000 total with 3,255 in the United States, 850 in West Germany, 600 in Sweden and 500 in Italy. It gave no estimate for the Soviet Union. Japan Said to Have Big Lead **********Using these numbers the association estimated that, excluding the Soviet Union, Japan had 69 percent of the world's advanced robots in 1979 and the United States 16 percent. **********Definitions of ''advanced'' robots vary and an American expert, Paul H. Aron of Daiwa Securities America Inc., has estimated that these totaled 11,250 in Japan and 4,370 in the United States at the end of 1980. **********The new development here is that experts predict a jump in the use of robots outside manufacturing industries, putting Japan first in this field in terms of the numbers of robots involved. **********Japanese television recently showed an experimental robot for use in hospitals that responds to ''commands'' blown into tubes by bedridden patients unable to move. The robot tilts the bed upward when the patient blows into one of 15 tubes and offers a glass of water when another tube is used.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/18/busin.body_text: **********The office automation business, William S. Anderson, chairman of the NCR Corporation, says, ''has become so crowded that it's difficult to keep track of all the players without a scorecard.'' **********Yet that did not stop NCR yesterday from announcing its entry into word processing, to be followed next year by other electronic office systems. At virtually the same hour, at a news conference elsewhere in New York, the Data General Corporation, a minicomputer manufacturer, announced that it, too, was entering the office automation market. **********And Data General's announcement follows by less than three weeks nearly simultaneous announcements by two other minicomputer makers, the Digital Equipment Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company, that they, too, would make major thrusts into office automation. **********Indeed, almost all the computer companies, whose products were once kept separately in out-of-the-way rooms, are now trying to get their ''work stations,'' the new name for a computer terminal with a typewriter keyboard and television screen, on every office worker's desk. **********In the products announced by Data General yesterday, such a desktop terminal, when connected to a larger computer, could be used by an office worker for word processing, to send memos to another terminal, to retrieve data from the computer and to quickly plot that data into graphs or charts. The prices range from about $70,000 for a system with eight terminals to as much as $250,000. **********NCR's systems, selling for $7,800 for one desktop station to as much as $100,000 for large systems, are intended for word processing, but the company promised advanced options such as electronic mail in 1982. **********The activity reflects the fact that the business of providing electronic aids to office workers is becoming a big business.  Wordprocessing sales alone, which were about $2 billion in 1980, are expected to reach $5 or $6 billion by 1985. **********It also reflects the fact that the new multi-purpose work stations are starting to combine the functions of a word processor, which have traditionally been thought of as electronic replacements for a typewriter, with some functions of computers, such as storing and processing data. That represents an opportunity for computer makers to expand into word processing. But it also represents a threat that word processing companies will encroach on the turf of the computer companies. **********Some analysts say, in fact, that computer makers are now engaged more in making announcements to prevent their customers from looking to other vendors of word processors than they are in actually selling office automation products. Ahead of Its Time **********''You're seeing technology that's really a year or two ahead of its time,'' said Sanford J. Garrett of Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins.  ''It's important that they announce now.'' **********These analyst suggests that the road to the automated office market is likely to be a rocky one for the computer companies. While large companies like Xerox and Exxon are losing money in office automation and even Digital Equipment has stumbled on its way into the wordprocessing business, the smaller companies, such as the CPT Corporation of Eden Prairie, Minn., and NBI Inc. of Boulder, Colo., that specialize in word processing, are growing at 50 percent a year or more. **********''The industry was supposed to be dominated by a whole different set of companies,'' said Melody Johnson, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company. Seeking Wider Market **********One reason for that, analysts say, is that while integrated word and data processing systems are the wave of the future, right now most companies looking to automate their office functions are content merely to replace typewriters with word processors. That is easier to conceive and much cheaper than rewiring the whole office so that everyone is electronically connected to everyone else. **********Another pitfall is that computer companies that have traditionally sold to data-processing experts have had trouble selling directly to non-technical office managers. **********''The whole reason the word-processing business exists is that the computer people don't understand the office,'' said Dean F. Scheff, chairman of CPT. Mr. Garrett of Paine Webber agreed. ''The products being offered by the computer companies promise all things to all people at all times, but they don't know how to sell it and the customers don't know how to use them,'' he said. Expanding Product Lines **********Meanwhile, other companies with a head start in the market are busily expanding their product lines. **********Yesterday, the Xerox Corporation, which already offers word processors and other products, announced a new series of electronic typewriters, with a base price of $1,430. **********On Monday, the Datapoint Corporation announced new printers, facsimile and graphics systems. Wang Laboratories, one of the leaders in word processing, announced a whole new line of products this month, as did the Exxon Corporation, which has so far been a failure in the business. Anticipating the Market **********Although most companies are cautious about automating their offices beyond word processing, the computer manufacturers insist that the market will develop. '' We don't know when it's going to happen, but we know we have to be there when it happens,'' said Mr. Anderson of NCR. **********The Dayton, Ohio, computer company is, in fact, stressing integrating various office systems and is not even manufacturing some of the products it will sell. The desktop terminal announced yesterday is made by Convergent Technologies, a West Coast company, and the printers by Nippon Electric Company of Japan. And NCR is recruiting a new sales force to sell its office products. **********As the marketing approach shifts to combining word processing and data processing, the computer companies will have an advantage.  Since thousands of companies already have computers in place, adding the extras for office automation would be less expensive than buying a completely separate office automation system. Building a Network **********However, word-processing companies, even if they do not provide complete systems, will be able to connect their systems with communications networks and computers made by others. ''I'm not sure every company that's in the business needs to provide all the pieces,'' said Thomas S. Kavanagh, president of NBI. **********While each company says its products are unique and better than the rest, many of them seem similar in purpose. In addition to word processing, which is designed for secretaries, the companies are trying to entice managers and even top executives to put terminals on their desks by offering these features: **********- Electronic mail, which would allow messages to be sent from one desk to another and perhaps to other locations. **********- Electronic calendars, in which the computer can help find times when a group of people in the office are free for meetings. **********- Electronic filing, which allows documents to be stored in a computer and retrieved. **********- Systems which allow office workers to retrieve data from their company's computers with simple commands. **********- Graphics programs, so the data can quickly be displayed as graphs or charts. **********- Local networks, which use a cable or wires to tie all the equipment together and to connect it to printers or copiers.  In the future, voice messages, which are now handled by a separate telephone system, might be combined with the network, as will be the capability to transmit and store images and video. Some office equipment companies are already moving in that direction. And all companies are emphasizing that their products are easy to use by people with no computer experience.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/busin.body_text: **********The Atlantic Richfield Company said it will spend $27.6 billion on capital projects between 1982 and 1986, mostly for exploration and development of domestic energy sources. **********Under its five-year capital program, Arco said, more than $4 billion will be spent on the development of the Kuparuk and Prudhoe Bay oilfields in Alaska, and another $2 billion will be spent on exploratory work in that state. **********In all, nearly $19 billion will be spent on exploration and development of oil in gas in the United States, the Los Angeles-based company said. **********About $1.3 billion will be put into expan ding the company's worldwide coa l operations, Arco said. The company's coal production is forecast t o reach 14 million tons this year and at least 28 million tons in 1985.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/30/busin.body_text: **********The first installment of about $5 million in back pay was mailed today to several hundred Southern textile workers who lost their jobs in a labor dispute dating to 1956. **********William A. Lubbers, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board here, said that the first checks for back pay were being sent to about 400 people affected by the closing of a Darlington, S.C., textile mill. **********The payments represent settlement of a quarter-century-old dispute that arose when Deering-Milliken Inc. of New York closed its Darlington plant after workers there voted to be represented by the Amalgamated Textile Workers Union. The company is now known as Milliken Inc. **********Mr. Lubbers said that payments also will be sent to heirs of most of the 144 deceased people who lost their jobs because of the plant closing. **********In protracted litigation that reached the Supreme Court, the N.L.R.B. held, and the courts agreed, that the loss of employment stemming from affiliation with the union was a violation of the National Labor Relations Act. **********Mr. Lubbers said that the checks, which range from a few dollars to as much as $30,000, were mailed from the N.L.R.B. regional office in Winston-Salem, N.C.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/15/busin.body_text: **********The Atlantic Richfield Company is giving up its right to 60,000 barrels a day of expensive, high-quality Nigerian crude oil, a move that oil industry sources say is illustrative of the current oil glut. **********Atlantic Richfield said that the termination next month of the two 30,000-barrel-a-day contracts was allowed by provisions in them and was typical of the kind of move that oil companies frequently make when faced with an oversupply. **********''There was no burning of bridges,'' a spokesman said.  But some analysts read considerably more into the decision, noting that oil companies had generally held onto financially draining supply contracts in recent years in key producing nations in the belief that a continued presence would offer insurance against supply shortages in the future. **********These sources suggested that Atlantic Richfield's decision would encourage other companies to stiffen bargaining positions with suppliers of high-priced crude, such as Libya and Algeria, and perhaps to allow supply contracts to lapse as they run out. A Strong Signal **********''I think it is the starting point for a trend,'' said a spokesman for the trading unit of one major oil company. ''I don't know how you could send a stronger signal that prices are too high.'' **********In recent weeks some oil-producing nations have responded to the oil glut by announcing price reductions on certain heavy crudes, and United States refiners have cut the prices they pay for similar United States crude produced in the Rocky Mountains. **********The major force behind the glut, however, is Saudi Arabia's high production level, a ploy to get other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to accept the need for a unified and moderate pricing policy. Thus, most experts say the glut is not creating a true buyers' market. Only an 'Indication' **********''The glut will last only as long as Saudi Arabia wants to discipline the other members of OPEC,'' Robert Stobaugh, an oil expert at the Harvard School of Business Administration, said. **********''It is too simplistic to call it a buyers' market,'' agreed a spokesman for a major oil company. ''Between the low prices on the spot market and Atlantic Richfield's move, you are still only talking about no more than 1.5 million barrels a day of the 50 million barrels a day consumed by the free world. The spot market, in particular, is an indication of the trend, but no more than that.'' **********Will others follow Atlantic Richfield's lead and drop major highcost supply contracts? ''No one is going to take on anyone really big right now in areas that are important to them,'' said Dennis Salzman, a hydrocarbon business manager at the Shell Oil Company.  ''The fear of running short is still predominant. The glut would have to last for another year for a real buyers' market to emerge.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/18/busin.body_text: **********The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Tenneco Corporation said they had decided to delay for an undetermined period development of their joint Cathedral Bluffs oil shale recovery project in Colorado. **********The companies said the delay was necessary to permit a reassessment of the feasibility of the project in view of ''current increased construction costs, oil prices and high interest rates.'' **********Neither company disclosed its investment in the giant project, but a source put the value at close to $200 million. **********The companies also said that they would not file a revised application for financial assistance with the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation in response to its first-round solicitation. They had previously planned to file the application in early January. **********The Cathedral Bluffs Shale Oil Company and the Occidental-Tenneco partnership have been developing an underground mine on a 5,094-acre Federal lease in northwestern Colorado. The companies estimated that the area holds reserves equal to 1.2 billion barrels of oil and that their joint venture could process about 94,000 barrels a day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/world.main_headline: HAIG MEETS WITH FIVE FOREIGN GUESTS IN CAIRO
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/world.print_headline: HAIG MEETS WITH FIVE FOREIGN GUESTS IN CAIRO
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/11/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. conferred today with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and the leaders of the Sudan, Somalia, Oman and Liberia. The State Department said the parties had agreed on the need to defend the Middle East against all forms of intervention. **********Although a State Department spokesman, Dean Fischer, did not refer to Libya by name, it was understood that the statement was issued with the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, in mind. When asked whether Libya was meant, Mr. Fischer said, ''If the shoe fits, wear it.'' **********Mr. Fischer said at a news conference that Mr. Haig and the others had reached a consensus ''on the need to defend the region against external intervention and against internal intervention manipulated by external forces.'' **********In response to a question, Mr. Fischer referred to ''trouble along the border between the Sudan and Chad.'' The Sudanese have been complaining of Libyan incursions along the border. Asked why a statement was being issued now, and in Cairo, he said, ''As a warning.'' **********On Wednesday, Mr. Haig used a Washington news conference to accuse Libya of threatening the security and stability of the Sudan, an ally of Egypt. The perceived Libyan threat to Sudan had been a matter of concern to Anwar el-Sadat, the Egypti an leade r. **********Mr. Haig met separately with Mr. Begin, President Gaafar el-Nimeiry of the Sudan, President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia, Deputy Prime Minister Fahd ibn Mahmud al Bu Said of Oman and the leader of Liberia, Samuel K. Doe. **********Mr. Fischer said Mr. Haig had discussed internal and external threats to the Middle East with each of the leaders, suggesting that he took the initiative in raising the issue. It was not explained what the Liberian's role could be in defending the Middle East. **********Mr. Haig is expected to meet with Vice President Hosni Mubarak and other Egyptian leaders tomorrow, before leaving Cairo in the evening.  Mr. Fischer said Mr. Haig and the others had been encouraged by the smooth transition of power here and by the ''evident competence'' of the new leadership. **********Egypt and the Sudan have had strained relations with Libya for a long time. The Libyan radio gloated over Mr. Sadat's death and said the ''revolutionary masses'' were about to take over Egypt. Today it reported - falsely -that the Cairo-Alexandria rail line had been blown up. Egyptian of ficials have stated that there is no evidence of foreign inter vention in the assassination of Mr. Sadat.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/24/busin.main_headline: G.S.A. Head Is Seeking Private Sector Advisers
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/24/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; G.S.A. Head Is Seeking Private Sector Advisers
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/24/busin.body_text: **********Gerald P. Carmen, head of the General Services Administration, hopes to bring together ''the best minds from the private sector'' to supplement the staff of his $5-billion-a-year agency, which acts as business manager for the Government. **********The wiry, energetic, self-made businessman who was President Reagan's Northeast coordinator and helped mastermind the President's campaign, appears determined to do his part in fulfilling Mr.  Reagan's promise to run the Government like a business. **********''We will borrow ideas from industry and bring outside perspective to our problems,'' the hard-driving Mr. Carmen said yesterday in announcing the planned formation of a 15-man, unsalaried advisory board from industry, business and labor. **********''I am here to make changes to restore credibility to this agency's reputation,'' Mr. Carmen said. The board will advise the G.S.A. on policy issues, new management projects and major organizational changes. The G.S.A. supplies equipment and services, office space and maintenance to other agencies of the Government. **********Mr. Carmen, who took over as head of the agency on May 26, already has named private-sector executives to top jobs with his agency.  Steven L. Hammer, formerly with a subsidiary of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will become associate administrator for operations while Charles S. Davis 2d, formerly with the Ford Motor Company, will be associate administrator for policy and management systems. **********''In the past there has been little private sector influence and generally people have moved around from within in the beuracracy,'' Mr. Carmen said in a telephone interview from Washington. **********''It takes a partnership between the private and the Government sectors,'' Mr. Carmen concluded. For more than 30 years he was active in Republican politics in New Hampshire, where he ran his own auto supply and service center chain. **********Mr. Carmen, 51, said that he hoped the panel would become ''a major problem-solving board'' and establish better cost efficiencies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/04/world.body_text: **********The leader of Cambodia's major non-Communist insurgent group met with State Department officials today in another effort to gain American financial and military help for his group's activities against the Vietnemese-backed Government in Phnom Penh. **********But the State Department reaffirmed that while the Cambodian nationalists led by Son Sann have American ''moral and political support'' there were no plans to provide military aid to any of the insurgent groups. **********Mr. Son Sann, a Prime Minister under Prince Norodom Sihanouk, now heads a group known as the Khmer People's National Liberation Front.  It is one of three organizations opposed to the Phnom Penh Government. The group with the largest military force is led by Pol Pot, who has some 30,000 to 40,000 Communist forces operating out of sanctuaries inside Cambodia with military help from China. The other group is nominally loyal to Prince Sihanouk. **********Coalition Is Overall Aim **********At the urging of Southeast Asian nations backed by the United States, the three groups, despite the animosity of Mr. Son Sann and Prince Sihanouk toward the Pol Pot forces, have been holding talks on forming a coalition against the Phnom Penh regime. **********Mr. Son Sann, who met with John H. Holdridge, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs, told reporters at a breakfast sponsored by Foreign Policy magazine today that he was here to request military and financial support from the United States. **********Referring to the Pol Pot forces as the Khmer Rouge, Mr. Son Sann said, ''We are here to make an appeal to the people and the Government of this great nation, the defender of freedom and of human rights.'' **********''The Khmer Rouge are abundantly aided by a Communist big power,'' he said. ''The Vietnamese are receiving enormous quantities of aid from another Communist big power,'' he went on, alluding to the Soviet Union. Help for 'an Entire People' **********''We, the non-Communists and nationalists, have not received any appreciable aid from the West,'' he said. ''We are here to ask you not to help any individual but to help an entire people who support the Khmer People's National Liberation Front in its struggle to save what is left of this people.'' **********Although his group is ostensibly in a loose grouping with the Pol Pot forces and Prince Sihanouk, he had nothing but scorn for the Pol Pot group, which officially represents Cambodia in the United Nations. **********He said: ''The Cambodian people have been victims of the Khmer Rouge's autogenocide, and of the hunger organized by the Vietnamese who divert the greatest portion of international humanitarian aid, and who continue to decimate the Cambodian population and even their livestock by introducing toxic materials everywhere, including in food products and in the fields.'' **********Mr. Son Sann said he could field 9,000 troops now, some of them equipped with Chinese-supplied weapons and others with weapons once belonging to Mr. Pol Pot. Mr. Son Sann has been denied American military aid since his first appeal during a trip here earlier in the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/22/busin.body_text: **********NOW that the Reagan Administration has decontrolled oil prices, it has begun to consider the more politically troublesome and economically volatile issue of natural gas deregulation. Even though candidate Reagan campaigned on a platform calling for immediate decontrol of natural gas prices, it is becoming more and more likely that President Reagan will not ask Congress to vote on the issue.  Instead, he will probably embark on what some have called ''the backdoor approach'' to decontrol, an approach that requires no legislated change in the current law, the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978. **********Through the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which administers the gas act, the Administration can raise the average price for all gas by allowing dramatic increases in the price for certain categories of gas. It was precisely this path that David Stockman laid out to a gas industry meeting before he became director of the Office of Management and Budget. **********''There's a lot of discretion available to the commission (in) devising additional categories of high-cost or incentive gas that could for all practical purposes be deregulated,'' Mr. Stockman said. Moreover, in the opinion of Danny Boggs, the chief of the transition team for the energy commission who is now a White House aide, the commission can even raise the price of gas flowing under old (pre-1977) contracts. **********Such views make the natural gas industry analysts on Wall Street very, very bullish. ''The Reagan Administration's most realistic option is to provide incentive pricing,'' says one of their reports, ''for categories where it is needed - through the F.E.R.C. as provided in the N.G.P.A. We believe this approach can achieve many of the same results as can accelerated decontrol, and yet avoid many of the (political) risks associated with the latter.'' **********For President Reagan, the advantages of administrative, or backdoor decontrol are straightforward: *********** No bitter battle in Congress to arouse public outrage; *********** The opportunity for Congressional allies to deny responsibility for their constituents' suddenly higher natural gas bills; *********** The transfer of the gas pricing issue from a highly charged arena closely watched by the media to a complex and leaden regulatory process understood by few and ignored by most; *********** The chance to take credit for protecting the economy while actually damaging it; *********** And finally, pacifying the gas industry by providing producers with decontrolled prices for ''new'' gas and pipeline and distribution companies with price controls on ''old'' gas. **********The cost to America's economy, however, will be devastating. The continuation of strict price controls through 1985 would increase average gas prices by at least 20 percent yearly, but the accelerated approach would impose a whopping 50 percent yearly. **********For the average worker, whose earnings have already been eaten up by higher energy bills, decontrol means he would have to work three weeks instead of one week to pay for the gas he uses in his home. **********American industry, which consumes 40 percent of the nation's gas, would be hit for as much as $234 billion between now and 1985. This compares with $34 billion for the period 1976-1980. **********Producers and Administration officials continue to publicize the myth that decontrol will increase drilling and production, and that producers will choose to invest in oil rather than gas, if gas prices are not raised to the artificially high levels imposed by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. **********But the facts - namely, the amount of money actually invested in oil and gas exploration and development - reveal a very different picture. According to Bureau of Census data, between 1974 and 1978, oil and gas producers invested more money in gas exploration and development than in oil exploration and development. **********THIS was so despite the fact that natural regulated gas prices were far lower than oil prices. Why? Mainly, because the actual cost of producing gas is one-third the cost of producing oil - all of which means that profits in every dollar invested have been greater for gas than for oil. **********The energy commission will probably attempt to accelerate decontrol by changing the rules governing the prices for various categories of gas. A number of consuming states, consumer and industry groups are challenging these rulings in commission proceedings and in the courts. If these challenges fail, the commission would be in a position to undermine the entire price control mechanism of the gas act. The commission would be able to create so many ''incentive'' categories of gas that producers would only drill for gas within those categories and leave the low-priced (although easily produced) gas for sometime in the future when gas is decontrolled. **********Even though, in the short run, it is less costly to the economy than immediate decontrol, backdoor, or accelerated decontrol is really more disturbing, because it is an effort by the Reagan Administration to get total decontrol without arousing public indignation and political retribution. It is decontrol by attrition, rather than by all-out war. The end result is the same. OPEC and the international oil companies will set a cartel price for the inexpensive gas produced in America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/world.main_headline: FOOD IS STAKE IN SOMALIA'S REFUGEE NUMBERS GAME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/world.print_headline: FOOD IS STAKE IN SOMALIA'S REFUGEE NUMBERS GAME
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/world.body_text: **********There are 15,000 people here - or 68,000. The higher figure is the official estimate of the Somali Government, the lower was provided by some of those running this refugee camp. **********Those who made the lower assessment requested anonymity since, they said, the Government is deeply sensitive about this sad numbers game, which has become a controversy throughout Somalia. Qoryoley lies about 80 miles southwest of Mogadishu, the Somali capital. It is, possibly, the least harrowing of the 35 refugee camps in Somalia, the world's eighth poorest country. Malnutrition affects only 6 percent of the people, compared with 30 percent elsewhere. It lies hard by the Shebeli River in Somalia's slim green belt; plant tomatoes here, relief workers say, and you'll get a record crop. **********Yet the camp also yields insights into some of the problems besetting the huge relief operation by Western countries, voluntary organizations and international agencies in Somalia. Relief goods are diverted away from refugees and the visitor can see American wheat, stacked for sale in tin-roofed stores. Tuberculosis haunts the beaten-earth pathways and gray, thatched homes of the camp; there are tribal tensions, and the place has become a permanent settlement of outsiders in a country where the indigenous population is fast outstripping the resources of an economy that depends on exporting camels, goats and bananas and on foreign aid. 'The Hottest Issue' **********''The hottest issue at the moment is the numbers,'' said an official of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Mogadishu. The Government estimate for the total number of refugees in Somalia is 1.3 million. Western estimates range between 300,000 and 600,000. The United Nations decided recently on a planning figure of 650,000. **********Word of the estimate incensed the Government of President Mohammed Siad Barre. A United Nations demographer took a sampling earlier this year and reportedly came up with a figure of 450,000 to 600,000.  That, too, left Mogadishu affronted and the demographer's report was not published. **********Two new experts arrived in town recently, one Norwegian and one Frenchman, to take a fresh sample. Ahmed Yassin, the deputy head of Somalia's national refugee commission, said the Government favored a full census of the camps and would abide by its outcome. But that will take too long for Western planners, who favor a statistical sampling, by head-count or by aerial photography. The debate may seem dry and hard on those who have lost their lands and fathers and husbands and who hold out empty hands for food. It does cut, however, to the quick of Somalia's relationship with and dependency on its donors. **********''Fo od is f oreign exchange for the Government,'' a United Nations official said . The higher the refugee count, the more food comes in and the less Somalia's tired resources are strained. As it is, Somalia's foo d exports and production have been falling while its imports have been rising a nd now, Western economists say, the nation of four million people - 80 per cent of them subsistence f armers or nomadic herders -imports half its own food needs, much of it in aid. **********American aid to Somalia last year totalled $90 million. Two thirds of that went to the refugees. For the West, there is a prospect of a costly, open-ended commitment to Somalia and its refugees because the forces driving them here have not been removed, despite Western efforts to promote better relations between Somalia and neighboring Ethiopia. The fugitives came, initially, to escape the war between these two countries over the Ogaden region in 1977 and 1978. **********Formallly, the hostilities have ended. Unofficially, the war simmers, with bombing raids along the disputed border by Ethiopian forces and guerrilla attacks against Ethiopia by the Somali-backed Western Somali Liberation Front. Both the guerrillas and the Somalis seek to end Ethiopian control of the Ogaden, an area populated by ethnic Somalis and claimed by Somalia. **********The heat seems to have gone out of the fighting since the time when refugees were arriving at a rate of 1,200 per day, their camels heaped high with skins and poles to build tented homes away from the fighting. Now, the figure of new arrivals if 50 to 100 per day while others, Western officials say, are returning to their homes because a drought has broken. ''It is still a massive problem,'' a relief worker said, ''but not the dire emergency it once was.'' **********Food is reaching most of the refugees most of the time, United Nations officials say, though worries persist about the protein adequacy of the diet, and Western agencies are seeking tighter regulatory systems to control the flow of aid, beginning with the proposed head-count. The American group, CARE, has set up a Government-supported monitoring unit that is intended to prevent food intended for the refugees from going astray into commercial markets and elsewhere. ''Certainly there is some diversion involving officials in the distribution system,'' one of those monitoring officials said. American Badly Beaten **********He requested, however, that his name be withheld because, he said, an American in one camp came too close to exposing racketeers recently and was beaten so savagely that he was hospitalized in the United States. **********Officially, the Government does not wish these refugee settlements to become permanent places. Somalia's own population is growing at a rate of 2.6 percent a year, yet its food production has not kept pace, and the country is running out of usable land. The corn crop in 1970, for instance, was 122,000 tons. Last year it was 110,000 ton.  Yet refugees are settling, presenting a long-term problem. ''This is here to stay. This is a new city,'' said an American here, gesturing with a sweep of his arm around Qoryoley camp, which looks more like an established village than a place of transition. **********''These people won't go home until there's a settlement in the Ogaden and that doesn't seem likely for some time,'' the relief offical said. ''So now we have to start them on development projects with tractors and cultivation and so forth.'' That smacks of permanency and presents its own problems. **********There are few men here, because most are either dead or out fighting the forgotten war in the Ogaden or, in some camps, out herding cattle and livestock. Of all the refugees in Somalia, the United Nations says, only 10 percent are men. Those that are here, the relief workers say, are sometimes too proud for humble tillage.  Some, the workers assert, are Western Somali Liberation Front guerrillas, resting nearby in a private area reserved for ''warriors'' outside the camp's limits, a reminder of the conflict that brought the refugees here.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/16/busin.body_text: **********The stockpile of gasoline at American refineries is fast approaching a record inventory that may cause slowdowns or shutdowns of the facilities and could eventually restrain gasoline price increases, an oil industry expert said today. **********Consumer conservation of gasoline and continued production of fuel oil for winter heating, which results automatically in production of large amounts of gasoline, were combining to create stocks of 277 million barrels of gasoline at refineries, in pipelines and at large terminals throughout the country, according to the Lundberg Letter, an oil industry publication. **********''What the refineries are going to do with it, I don't know,'' said Dan Lundberg, author of the publication. ''The industry may have to drink it.'' **********The publication said refinery production runs are at ''uneconomic rates,'' dropping in January to 72.7 percent of capacity, from an already low level of 76.6 percent in December. Refiners are faced with ''even greater slowdowns, perhaps shutdowns,'' it added. **********A record surplus of 283.1 million barrels, set in April of last year, brought an average 1.2-cent price drop over an eight-month period, and another overload ''would almost certainly cool the current round of price increases,'' the Lundberg Letter said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/04/world.body_text: **********President Goukouni Oueddei of Chad said today that Libyan troops would leave Chad as he had requested, the French news agency reported. He did not indicate a departure date. **********''The Libyan forces are leaving at the request of the Chadian Government,'' Agence France-Presse quoted Mr. Goukouni as saying at the 31-nation French-African conference here. ''I was not surprised to learn it.'' **********In a dispatch from Ndjamena, capital of Chad, the French news agency quoted the commander of Libyan forces in that country, Col.  Radwan Salah, as saying he had received direct orders from the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to withdraw all troops ''within two or three days.'' **********There was no official confirmation of the withdrawal order from Libyan authorities. A news broadcast by Tripoli Radio monitored here made no reference to it. **********French intelligence sources estimate that 10,000 Libyan troops are deployed across nation in north-central Africa.  The Libyan forces entered Chad almost a year ago at Mr. Goukouni's request to help him win a 16-year-old civil war. Last week, Mr.  Goukouni formally requested that the Libyan forces withdraw across the two countries' desert border, which is more than 1,000 miles north of Ndjamena.
