https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/12/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Industry Week Is Moving Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/12/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Industry Week Is Moving Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/12/busin.body_text: **********''B USINESS WEEK and The Wall Street Journal own the hard news and Fortune does pretty well on the issues; finance is covered by Forbes, The Journal, Dun's Review and the others, but we frequently hear from our readers, 'Industry Week catches me right where I'm living,' '' said Patrick B. Keefe, in from Cleveland and talking about his favorite magazine. **********The publisher at the appropriate time can also unlimber this favorite reader quotation, ''I have a feeling your editors have their noses in my 'in' basket.'' **********The magazine in 11 years has become the flagship of Penton/IPC, the country's third-largest business magazine publisher with 27 titles.  It started making a profit after 30 months and, economy or no, is celebrating November as the hottest month in its history following the best first half in its history. Ad pages for November are up 22.8 percent from a year ago, to 258, while revenues soared 45.3 percent, to more than $2 million. **********For 1981, the publisher expects to gross $17 million, a 20 percent increase in revenues, and hit 1,593 advertising pages, a 7.8 percent improvement over 1980. **********In 1976, Mr. Keefe recalls asking himself what the growth industries were as far as his future advertisers were concerned and decided they were information management, office equipment and office furniture. And that plus some corporate advertising is pretty much what the magazine is getting. **********''We are a classic study of taking a very sophisticated marketing approach to positioning a publication and staying with it,'' Mr.  Keefe said, explaining that when his magazine was started the only magazine around for the general industrial audience was the Manufacturing edition of Fortune. ''We are the magazine for the wealth creators of America,'' he added. **********Industry Week magazine started with 130,000 controlled, or free, circulation sent to top and middle management in manufacturing companies. The company knows who to mail a publication to because starting in 1933 Penton began developing a census of manufacturers, investing an estimated $27 million in it over the years, until today it has data on every plant employing 20 or more people. **********Now the circulation is at 300,000 and copies are going to 96,000 facilities operated by 24,000 companies that employ 100 or more persons and represent 76 percent of the gross national product. (Mr.  Keefe calls it ''a neat, focused market.'') It is fourth among business management magazines after Business Week, Fortune and Forbes, all three of which had first-half ad page declines, but not Industry Week. **********The editorial mix, he said, is 50 percent on management approaches, technique and style; 20 percent on business and finance, 20 percent on social issues, particularly corporate responsibility, and 10 percent on far-reaching technology. Mr. Keefe thinks of the whole package as a ''survival kit for executives.'' **********''By serving the reader first, you serve the advertiser best,'' Mr. Keefe said.  Who are those readers?  Well, they are more than 82 percent male, more than 53 percent managers and professionals, 64 percent of them are between 25 and 49 years of age and almost that many are in households with $25,000 a year income. In all cases, according to Industry Week promotion data, the magazine has higher percentages than the three major competitors. **********But the publisher is pretty pleased with the publication's niche.  ''We've made it with our special-interst position and I don't want to give it up,'' he said, adding, ''I don't have much hope for mass publications.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/24/busin.body_text: **********A S the Government ponders legislation designed to revitalize American industry, it is being hit with demands from a somewhat unexpected quarter - the United States semiconductor industry. **********Although these companies are among the most innovative, fastestgrowing and most prosperous of enterprises, the integrated circuit manufacturers say they are suffering from the same sort of problem that has vexed such weaker industries as steel and autos: intense and unfair competition from Japanese concerns. Chip manufacturers say it is hard even for them to raise the money needed to invest in new equipment to keep up with rapid changes in technology. At the same time, semiconductor prices are falling, biting sharply into earnings. **********The makers of the tiny chips, which form the heart of modern computers, are banding together to seek tax incentives from Washington to encourage capital formation and research and development. They contend most proposals now being considered are geared toward older industries, and are ill-suited for the rapidly changing high-technology companies. **********Last week three executives of leading concerns in California's socalled Silicon Valley talked with reporters and editors of The New York Times about the industry's problems and prospects. The executives were Robert N. Noyce, vice chairman of the Intel Corporation, W.J. Sanders 3d, president and chairman of Advanced Micro Devices Inc., and John L. Nesheim, treasurer of the National Semiconductor Corporation. **********Q. What are you seeking from the Government? **********NOYCE: The problem that we see is that there is relatively little recognition yet of the importance of this new technology and where it's going to take us as a society. And it is the emerging importance of that that we believe needs to get a lot more attention. I just did a conference in London where I found one very, very interesting thing - The Minister of Industry also bears the title of Minister of Information Technology. **********In general, we feel that our Government's policies in this area have been overly weighted to the mature industries and underrepresenting the new growth industries. **********NESHEIM: Our industry looks at capital formation as its fundamental objective. John Kennedy said there are three ways to win an election: money, money and more money. You pump cash flow into brains, and you're eventually going to win. It's the staying power of raising capital that is the key. **********We view research and development just like investments in factories. Both are long-term investments, both depreciate very rapidly because of movements in technology. In the Reagan economic package, the main error is that they have forgotten about incentives for research and development and have assumed that by putting the cash flow incentive into equipment instead of ideas that they have solved the problem. **********Q. Are you also saying that losing the edge in technology has strategic implications? **********NESHEIM: It has an interesting implication. When a foot soldier has a mostly electronics hand-held weapon that costs $6,000 and has a 90 percent probability of destroying a $2.5 million NATO tank, that says we can fight iron technology with electronics very efficiently. **********If we lose the technology, we will have to cover two supply routes to and from Japan in the next war. And then wait until the military men open up the black boxes operating the MX missile system and all the semiconductors say, ''Made in Japan.'' That's the strategic problem we're facing. **********Q. If you got your tax breaks, where would you be putting your investment money? Are there particular problems you view as threshold technological problems that will be neglected unless you get this break? **********NOYCE: If you look at the man years per product in designing software, it's going up exponentially now, and we need to control that expansion of required manpower. The whole software area is one that is grossly inadequate. We have to find better ways to do it.We're moving in another area from higher power devices to lower power devices. **********Most of this is a question of the rate of development. You cannot do one thing and that be enough. You've got to push this front pretty broadly. It's no longer a spearhead sort of thing. **********Q. To what extent does the American industry have the advantage of a superior product over foreign competitors? **********SANDERS: All the Japanese manufacturers of microcomputers use American microprocessors. So at the leading edge of technology, there's no question of American superiority. There is no Japanese originated, conceived and designed microprocessor. They're all American. The fact that they may later become socket stealers and replicate these designs certainly is possible. But there's no doubt that the entire driving force behind the computer explosion has been American technology and still is. **********Q. The Japanese have been producing a product that has a much lower reject rate than the American manufacturers. Are we catching up? **********SANDERS: Quality means conformance to specification. And a lot of people have extrapolated that to mean that somebody's product is better. That is not what quality means. Our products were never worse than the Japanese. The only question was what percentage of the product being shipped was rejected. For the Japanese it might have been, for example, three-tenths of 1 percent, whereas maybe Ameican industry was 1 percent. **********On an absolute basis there's no question that they then had higher quality. That's two years ago, and that's a dead issue. Today, American companies, being the responsive companies we are, meet the market challenge. It's no longer an issue, and any customer that you talk to will tell you there's now no material difference between the best Japanese supplier and the best American supplier. **********Q. Let's talk a little bit about business conditions. We've heard a lot about price weakness. Where do things now stand? **********NOYCE: Right now, there's an excess capacity. I think the industry this time has made very firm decisions not to do what they did in 1975. In other words, we decided to absolutely keep the R.& D. going, to keep the market development going, to keep the process development going and take the lumps on the bottom line. **********SANDERS: This is kind of an interesting recession for our industry because it's basically a price recession, if you will. The units shipped are still up. Now, if the units are up and the prices are down, such that you have flat sales, that will put some temporary discomfort on the profit margins. But the truth is, never have more units been consumed than today. So this proves our historic theory of price elasticity. With these prices, for example on memory, coming down as far as they have, although it may cause us some short-term perturbations, the bigger perturbation is that we need more volume. **********Q. What time frame are you talking about? **********SANDERS: Our estimate is that 1981 will be a rather boring year, that in 1982 business will be much stronger. And we think there's no reason to go out of our historical quadrennial cycle where three years from now we'll be talking about inadequate capacity, long lead times, people in the computer and communications businesses saying that they can't ship systems because they can't get components. **********In reality, all we have going on right now is the unit demand is up but not up enough to offset the price attritions. Memory is, for all intents and purposes, free. If you look at what we're charging for microprocessor chips, for all intents and purposes, they're free. **********Q. You mentioned that you're going to keep spending and keep your people working and take the lumps on the bottom line. How bad are those lumps going to be? Do you think any companies will see losses in the quarter? **********NOYCE: I don't think they will. I have not seen any yet, but we haven't seen all the results yet either.  SANDERS: We don't see any losses. I think we see lots of pressure.  Q. In terms of products, is the industry maturing? Are you now somewhat like the steel industry where the major innovations have been made and now you're just refining things, or are there major new thresholds to cross? **********NOYCE: From the technological point of view, we are far from the fundamental limits. We can probably go to 1,000 times the complexity that we're at today. The question is: Who can use that intelligence? **********In other words, by a decade or two decades from now you'll be able to put into something that costs, let us say $20 or $30, the most complex system that has ever been built today. That is where the technology is going. What will you use it for, that's the question. **********Q. One of the characteristics of your industry is the way companies come and go. Who are the next Advanced Micro Devices and Intels? **********SANDERS: There's no question there are a lot of niche markets which are great opportunies, where entrepreneurially oriented companies will get started and will build a $50 million or maybe even a $100 million business. **********But if you look at how much it costs to be in the business, to be a major factor, just to stay abreast of the technology, there is not likely to be another A.M.D. or another Intel. **********NOYCE: I see the opportunity now for applications of this technology. And I think that there's a good chance that you'll have major new companies. You'll have the Apples of the world. **********We sat around, we had all of the capabilities to do that job (in personal computers) and we said, ''It's not going to be an interesting market, so we'll neglect it.'' It was a gross error on our part, but that's what we did. **********I think it's interesting to note that, in spite of the real damage done by defecting groups, that the electronics association in general has done everything to encourage those defections. **********Q. Then why is Intel suing Seeq Technology Inc., which is a company that broke off from it, while Intel itself broke off from Fairchild Camera and Instrument? **********NOYCE: We think there's a question of ethics involved here as to whether the venture capitalist should go into an existing company with the technology and try to drag that out, or whether they should wait for the people to come to the venture capitalist and say, ''We want to leave. Would you finance us?'' **********Q. Are you saying the venture capitalists are going in and plucking people out of companies? **********SANDERS: Right now there's a mountain of money out there. In 1979 alone, $900 million flooded into venture capital. I know of at least three or four groups now that are taking their little dog and pony show around which will raise another $100 million from various foreign investors to set up new venture capital pools. So now you've got the funds looking for the talent as opposed to the talent looking for the funds, and I think there are going to be some excesses. In 1975, nobody was suing anybody. There was only $10 million of venture capital available. **********Q. There seem to be increasing calls in the industry, first by Control Data and then by National Semiconductor, that competitors like yourselves get together for joint research ventures. What do you think of that idea? **********NESHEIM: You end up with a concept of basically getting more mileage per dollar of R.& D. How do you do that? One way is to avoid duplication. In our industry, with $50 million required just to build one production line for the latest equipment, can those that have dedicated internal manufacturing, such as the medium-sized companies, afford to try to continue to do internal semiconductor work? **********NOYCE: If we are looking at joint research, where I think it should be open and it will be in the most part open, then we have the problem that XYZ Company sits here and says, ''Well, gee, I can get all the benefit of that without putting the money in.'' That is going to be a very difficult problem to get by in cooperative research.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/21/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan reiterated his campaign promises to take bold and immediate actions to remedy the nation's ''economic afflictions.'' The primary targets would be the excessive taxes and government, which he said were responsible for curbing industry, individual achievement and thrift, and which were hobbling the solution to the problem of ''the longest and one of the worst sustained inflations in our national history.'' The President also vowed to reduce Federal spending sharply and shift more government from Washington to the states. (Page A1.) **********Leading business and financial leaders generally applauded the tone of the Inaugural Address, although they noted the lack of a specific agenda and programs aimed at correcting the nation's economic problems. While the business community differed over the approach it would like the President to take, it was unanimous in advocating strong and quick actions. (D1.) **********The Iranian Situation **********Iran got back $2.9 billion of its $12 billion in frozen assets after the hostages were released, former Treasury Secretary G.  William Miller said. The movement of Iran's funds was closely synchronized with the release process and involved bankers in New York, London, Algiers and Teheran. (A9.) **********Iran has already repaid some loans to American banks after the transfer of funds to Iran. One such payment was reported by Morgan Guaranty Trust. (A9.) **********More questions than answers cloud American-Iranian relations, despite the release of the hostages. Among them: Can former imports of Iranian oil, which averaged 545,000 barrels a day in 1978, be resumed? How much, if any, of the $300 million of former monthly export trade to Iran can be recovered? (A9.) **********American companies said they would like to resume business in Iran eventually. But the companies, including those with pending lawsuits against Teheran, added that they would prefer to wait until Iran's internal situation stabilized. (A9.) The Economy **********Albany legislators lean toward allowing out-of-state banks to open branches in New York City, but only on a reciprocal basis.  California, the target of many big New York banks, is having trouble with similar legislation. (D1.) **********New York's highest court ruled in favor of consumers seeking indemnification from makers of faulty products. The Appeals Court said subsequent changes in product design may be more widely used as evidence in such suits. (D1.) **********Pennsylvania's utility regulators propose to slash the rate rise sought by owners of the closed Three Mile Island nuclear power plant to only 18.5 percent of the amount requested. The General Public Utilities Corporation says it needs the whole amount. (D1.) **********Citicorp reported a 37.7 percent plunge in profits for the fourth quarter of 1980, to $96 million, citing ''unprecedented volatility'' of interest rates. Manufacturers Hanover reported a 15.1 percent gain. BankAmerica and Chase Manhattan, two other banking giants, are also expected to show improved earnings. (D1.) Markets **********Dow Jones industrials plunged more than 20 points in moderately active trading. Market analysts attributed the drop in part to the lack of the buying expected after the release of the hostages and the President's Inaugural Address. (D1.) **********Interest rates declined more on speculative dealings than on any appreciable increase in investor buying. The fall in rates was most pronounced in Federal funds, which puzzled dealers. (D7.) **********The dollar declined and gold rose $5.80 an ounce, to $568.30, in quiet trading. Both money and precious metals market traders were preoccupied with the possible impact of the transfer of $5 billion in dollars and gold to Iran. (D11.) Commodity futures markets were mostly higher on balance. (D11.) Today's Columns **********President Reagan's strong hints of bold immediate economic initiatives strengthen the view that he supports the activist element among his advisers. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Syntex's shares have shown a sharp rise in recent months, owing in large part to its new line of drugs. But the stock's long history of volatility must still be overcome. Market Place. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/06/world.print_headline: ISRAEL SAYS IT WILL NOT ASK THE U.S. TO SEND IN G.I.'S FOR DEFENSE ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/06/world.body_text: **********Israel said today that it would not ask for the stationing of American troops on its soil and did not want to depend on any foreign army for its security. **********The statement came at a news conference held by the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Naftalie Lavie, two days after Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said in Washington that the Reagan Administration would examine any such Israeli request ''very sympathetically and very carefully.'' **********Senior Israeli Army officers are understood to be opposed to an American military presence in the country, arguing that it would undermine Israel's morale and determination to take responsibility for its own defense. Some civilians in office have also expressed fears that large numbers of American soldiers would bring social and economic problems to the country. **********Mr. Lavie explained that if Washington asked for military facilities to meet its global strategic requirements, Israel would provide them, but would not make a request. 'A Certain Misunderstanding' **********''There is a certain misunderstanding on the subject,'' Mr. Lavie said in answer to a question. ''As you remember, Israel always said and says now that we never expected foreign troops, American or others, to come here to fight for Israel.'' **********The spokesman drew a distinction between American troops for Israel's defense and an American deployment in the Middle East ''to face some dangers that have more of a global nature than the Israeli-Arab confrontation.'' Israel supports an enhanced American presence in the region to counter Soviet advances. **********''In this connection,'' Mr. Lavie declared, ''it was said on many occasions that Israel would be willing to facilitate American troops if they will need any sort of facilities. That has been said in the past, and that we continue to say. Now I believe if the American authorities are interested in that sort of Israeli assistance, then it's there. But it does not mean that we are interested in having here American or other troops to take care of Israel's security.'' **********A senior Israeli officer said in an interview this week that he would like to see an American military presence in Egypt and Saudi Arabia, neither of which has offered to open its territory to permanent American bases, but not in Israel. **********''I hope Israel will never ask for American troops on its soil,'' said the officer, who asked not to be identified. ''I'd hate to live in a country where I'd have to raise my kids on the knowledge that somebody else has to take care of your defense.'' He said it would harm the Israelis' motivation to do it themselves.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/05/world.print_headline: CITIZENSHIP BILL GAINS IN BRITISH PARLIAMENT OVER MINORITY PROTESTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/05/world.body_text: **********Britain's House of Commons tonight passed a nationality bill attacked by immigrant groups as racially discriminatory. **********The measure would set up three categories for British subjects - British citizenship, citizenship of British dependent territories and British overseas citizenship. **********Only one category, British citizenship, would carry an automatic right to live in Britain. **********John Tilley, a spokesman for the opposition Labor Party, said any future Labor Government would give high priority to repeal of the act. **********''In every case where there are people who lose their rights or opportunities under this bill, the vast majority of these groups are black,'' he said. House of Lords to Take Up Bill **********The legislation, approved by a 287-234 vote, now goes to the House of Lords for consideration.  The Conservative Government denied that the bill was racially inspired. It said the measure was aimed at clarifying confused immigration rules. **********Speaking for the Government, Timothy Raison, the Home Office's Minister of State, said the bill was aimed at creating a citizenship that would ''tie us together and give a focus for our pride and loyalties.'' **********After protests from Hong Kong and other British dependencies, the bill was amended to permit dependency citizens and overseas citizens to qualify for full British citizenship after five years of residence in Britain. **********The dependencies had complained that the original measure would have required their residents to seek naturalization on arrival in Britain in the same way as incoming aliens.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/world.print_headline: Around the World; Leader Wins Six-Year Term In Central African Republic
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/20/world.body_text: **********President David Dacko has been elected for a six-year term as head of state in the Central African Republic, the Supreme Court announced tonight. **********The 50-year-old Mr. Dacko, who came to power in a French-backed coup 18 months ago, won 374,027 votes, or 50.23 percent of the 744,688 votes cast Sunday, the court said. He defeated former Prime Minister Ange Patasse, who was second among the five candidates with 283,739 votes, or 38.11 percent. **********Mr. Dacko was the first President of the Central African Republic after it was granted independence from France in 1960. Five years later he was overthrown by his cousin, Jean-Bedel Bokassa, who in turn was ousted with the aid of French paratroopers in September 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/10/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve Board is considering imposing reserve requirements on money market mutual funds, Frederick H. Schultz, a Fed governor, said yesterday. **********At a conference sponsored by the American Bankers Association in Washington, Mr. Schultz said the Fed was concerned about unequal competition for the public's savings. **********The money funds are able to pay higher interest rates than the legal maximum that banks and savings institutions may pay. Many funds now yield more than 17 percent, compared with 13.99 percent for new six-month savings certificates at banks. **********Mr. Schultz said he would favor, in principle, removing regulations on banks and thrift institutions. But financial problems at many savings and loan associations would make it unworkable at this time, he said. **********Money funds now have nearly $87 billion of assets. Restrictions on them were part of the Government's credit controls last spring, when the Fed imposed a 15 percent reserve requirement on increases in their assets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/20/world.body_text: **********The Polish authorities attempted to publish skeleton editions of a number of newspapers today, but distributors and vendors refused to handle them. **********The Government's move came on the second day of a printer's strike called by Solidarity, the independent trade union, to protest attacks in the official press and to demand access to the media. **********Trybuna Ludu, the Communist Party daily, and Zolnierz Wolnosci, the armed forces newspaper, were printed on emergency military presses on Grzybowska Street, but deliverers boycotted them and the two papers were virtually unavailable at newsstands. **********In Bydgoszcz, where many printers are loyal to the old official trade union, newspapers were published fairly normally. Other regional newspapers were also reportedly produced in Katowice, Szczecin, Radom, Opole and Lublin. But distribution blockages by supporters of the Solidarity union seem to have prevented people from seeing the few newspapers that were printed. **********Lodz Threatens Longer Strike **********Though the union's national leadership scheduled the printers' strike for two days, a union local in Lodz, Poland's second largest city, said it would not allow newspapers to publish until Lech Walesa, the national union leader, was given 20 minutes' television time to answer Government criticisms. It also demanded regional television exposure for the leader of the Lodz local. **********At the office of Trybuna Ludu, the party daily, an editor said 150,000 copies - on better newsprint than usual but with printing defects - had been printed compared with the usual 1.1 million. **********''In spite of the aims of the organizers of this action,'' said a commentary in the trimmed-down, four-page daily, ''these are not days without Trybuna Ludu.'' **********Finding copies of either Trybuna Ludu or Zolnierz Wolnosci, the army daily, was a challenge. At the office of the armed forces daily, guarded by a soldier, a vendor slipped a copy to a foreign customer from under her counter. 'Editors Begging for Copies' **********''Even the editors have been begging for them,'' she said.  A front-page editorial in the army newspaper said: ''Who gave Solidarity the right to cut off the links between millions of readers and their national and local dailies?'' The editorial accused the union of ''striking out blindly,'' and predicted that ''tension in the country will grow again'' because of the printers' action. **********Printers from the official union produced 5,000 copies of Zycie Wars@zawy, a popular daily, at a plant on Smolna Street, but Solidarity militants stopped it from leaving the building. **********''I heard on the radio that Zycie Wars@zawy was printed,'' said a journalist at the newspaper's offices. ''Are they talking about that one copy over there?'' **********Solidarity permitted a copy to be posted on the bulletin board. The newspaper decided tonight to abandon attempts to publish tomorrow's issue. **********According to scattered accounts, there were moments of tension when strikers confronted printers from the official union who wanted to work, but there were no reports of violence. **********In Olsztyn, the local prosecutor announced an investigation of Solidarity militants who prevented official printers from reporting to work. **********''The right to strike,'' the prosecutor's office said, ''cannot be equated with the right to restrict the will to work or with the right to force people to quit work.'' **********In at least seven cities - Olsztyn, Cracow, Lodz, Bialystok, Gdansk, @Wroclaw and Warsaw - printers were reported to have stage sit-ins to prevent strike newspapers from appearing. **********The authorities have avoided a confrontation so far. A commentary on television said the printers' strike showed that Solidarity ''is leading the movement in a political direction.'' It called the action ''an irresponsible act of political adventurism'' and an attack on the Government and the Communist Party.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/world.main_headline: AFGHANISTAN AND PAKISTAN REPORT PROGRESS TOWARD PLANNING TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/world.print_headline: AFGHANISTAN AND PAKISTAN REPORT PROGRESS TOWARD PLANNING TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/07/world.body_text: **********In the last three days, Pakistan has issued a statement proposing the involvement of the United Nations in talks with Afghanistan, and Kabul has issued a statement accepting the idea. **********Western and Asian diplomats here described the two statements as exploratory, and they cautioned that a wide and perhaps unbreachable gulf lies between the Pakistani and Afghan positions on negotiations and on a role for the United Nations. **********Still, as a Western diplomat remarked, the Pakistani suggestion and the Afghan response made public here yesterday seemed to signal slight flexibility in positions that have been frozen since May. **********The first sign of limited movement came when Agha Shahi, Pakistan's Foreign Minister, said in Islamabad that he had urged Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations to appoint a representative to convene discussions on relations between Afghanistan and two neighbors, Pakistan and Iran. Rebel Role Is Demanded **********At first glance, Mr. Shahi's statement appeared to be a retreat from Pakistan's earlier position that it would not talk to representatives of the Soviet-installed Kabul regime since such contact would imply recognition. **********But Mr. Shahi made it clear that what he sought was a meeting in which Pakistani and Iranian delegations would represent their Governments while the group from Kabul would speak only for the ruling party of President Babrak Karmal. Some diplomats from Islamic countries said that Mr. Shahi had insisted that rebel groups involved in the struggle against the Soviet-supported Kabul Government also participate. **********The diplomats acknowledged that it was unlikely that such demands would be accepted by the Afghans or by the Russians, who at the very least are consulting closely on Afghan foreign policy if not framing it. **********But they said that Pakistan's willingness to meet with the Afghans as a political party was new and that it was being projected as a concession and a signal. Minister Accepts Proposal **********The Afghan response to Mr. Shahi was issued here by Dr. Anahita Ratibzad, the Afghan Minister of Education and a confidante of President Karmal. During a meeting with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, Dr. Ratibzad reportedly said that her Government was willing to discuss outstanding problems with Iran and Pakistan under the auspices of the United Nations, or at least with the participation of United Nations observers. **********This announcement, on its face, indicated appreciable movement from earlier Afghan positions. Since the overwhelming General Assembly vote to condemn the Soviet intervention, the Kabul regime has been wary of the United Nations and also of regional and Islamic groups.  It has clung instead to a proposal for direct talks with Pakistan and Iran proposed by Mr. Karmal on May 14. Implicit in this view was the notion that the participants would affirm sovereign legitimacy of their neighbors. **********This earlier Afghan and Soviet position also implied the promise of some sort of phased Russian withdrawal and implied also that Iran would thwart infiltration of guerrillas into Afghanistan and prevent the arming of Islamic rebels. Pakistan Shuns Direct Contacts **********Pakistan has insisted that sealing its long mountainous border with Afghanistan is physically impossible and it has shunned direct contacts, seeking to have discussions carried out within the framework of the 44-nation Islamic Conference. **********Mr. Shahi now seems to be opening the door to having the United Nations play the role he had earlier hoped to secure for the Islamic group, and Afghanistan so far has not slammed it shut.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/15/busin.body_text: **********The International Harvester Corporation announced a 20 percent pay reduction today for each of its 26 corporate officers and said the salaries of 30,000 managerial, professional and other white-collar workers would be frozen for an indefinite period. **********A Harvester spokesman said the company did not know how much the pay reductions and the freeze, which are retroactive to Jan. 1, would save the company. **********Analysts have said that weak markets for Harvester's products - trucks, farm equipment and construction equipment - and high interest rates could force the company into stringent cash conservation measures this year. A few have predicted that Harvester, saddled with high interest rates on large short-term borrowings, may have to sell some assets to meet its financial obligations. **********Harvester last month cut its quarterly dividend to 30 cents, from 62 1/2 cents, and has predicted a loss in the first quarter of the fiscal year 1981, which ends this month. Last year, Harvester posted a loss of $397.3 million, largely because of a six-month strike by the United Automobile Workers. **********Today's action does not affect a controversial $1.8 million bonus that the Harvester board of directors voted last summer for Archie McCardell, chairman. The bonus was paid because of Harvester's highly profitable performance in 1979. However, Mr. McCardell's regular salary will be affected by the 20 percent reduction. Last year he received $460,000 in salary and director's fees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/19/busin.body_text: **********Under pressure from sharp increases in short-term interest rates that have raised their own cost of money, many of the nation's leading banks raised their prime lending rate yesterday to 20 percent, from 19 1/2 percent. **********Yesterday's half-point climb in rates was led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and followed by Citibank, Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, First National Bank of Chicago and a host of other banks. Several institutions, including the Chase Manhattan Bank, said they would lift their prime to 20 percent effective today. **********Nevertheless, in the credit markets both short-and long-term interest rates declined substantially yesterday, a signal to some economists that interest rates may have peaked. **********Prime Usually Lags Behind **********New three-month Treasury bills, for example, were sold at a yield of 16.03 percent, down nearly half a percentage point from last week's auction. The prime rate usually lags behind interest rates in the money markets. **********''Our forecast is that this is about it; we have probably seen all of the increase we are going to see,'' said Edward Boss, vice president and economist at Continental Illinois Bank in Chicago, another bank that raised its prime to 20 percent. **********The prime reached a record 21 1/2 percent last December and then dropped to 17 percent in early April, reflecting declines in other interest rates. But then, just as quickly, the prime bounced back up, hitting 19 1/2 percent a week ago. Linked to Many Other Rates **********The prime is the announced rate that banks charge on short-term loans to their best corporate customers, although many large corporations obtain short-term loans at rates below the prime. The prime is particularly important, nevertheless, because many other interest rates are tied to it. **********Bankers and credit analysts, many of whom had been caught by surprise at the sudden resurgence in interest rates, are split on their future course. Some see underlying economic trends remaining strong, preventing any immediate turnaround in rates. Others, however, look for money supply growth to slow, allowing the Fed to relax its upward pressure on rates. **********''I expect we are close to the peak in this particular phase,'' predicted Leif H. Olsen, chairman of the economic policy committee at Citibank. ''This increase in interest rates has really been the result of monetary policy in the short run overshooting the targets, and the markets reacting. Unfortunately, once the process begins, it takes awhile to corral it.'' **********But Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, one of the banks that raised its prime yesterday, is somewhat more cautious in his predictions. ''As long as loan demand pressure continues strong, we could see further upward movement,'' he said, noting that commercial and industrial loans at major reporting banks had soared by $4.6 billion since mid-March, for an annual growth rate of 22 percent. But, Mr. Robertson added in a telephone interview yesterday, ''when it comes to the prime, a lot depends on short-term money market rates, which are off today.'' **********Mr. Boss of Continental Illinois acknowledged that the Federal Reserve Board had given no indication yet of backing away from its high interest rate strategy. The rate that banks pay for overnight money remained fairly steady around the 18 1/2 percent level yesterday. But, Mr. Boss said, ''We still feel the economy is weakening, and that will result in slower growth in the money supply.'' Bankers Not Alone **********Bankers are not alone in looking for rates to come down. In Washington, the Reagan Administration has said that lower interest rates will be the first signal that the new economic program has begun to take hold, bringing down inflation. There has been some concern, therefore, over the Fed's role in pushing rates upward in recent weeks. **********Yesterday morning, the Fed chairman, Paul A. Volcker, met with President Reagan, on what the White House called topics of general economic policy. Although the Administration declined to elaborate on the talks, the Deputy White House press secretary, Larry Speakes, said afterward that the Administration still looked for its economic program to reduce interest rates, making it unncessary for the Fed to raise short-term rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/busin.main_headline: Stock Prices Retreat; Dow Is Off by 2.50
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/busin.print_headline: Stock Prices Retreat; Dow Is Off by 2.50
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/30/busin.body_text: **********With energy issues still under pressure, stock prices moved lower yesterday to record their only loss of the week. Also, for the first time this week, the market failed to stage a final-hour rally. **********As a result, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 2.50 points, to 991.75, after advancing 22 points in the three previous sessions.  Stock exchanges were closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day.  Over all, the New York Stock Exchange showed slightly more declines than advances yesterday. **********Trading remained active at 51.6 million shares, although this was a drop from Thursday's 59.5 million, which marked the busiest session in five weeks. **********Merck, the best performer in the Dow industrials, climbed 3 1/8 points, to 100 1/2, after equaling its record high of 101 1/2 earlier in the day. This gain was attributed to prospects that the company's new heart medicine, timolol, will receive marketing approval from the Food and Drug Administration. Timolol is intended for use in reducing the risk of death among heart attack patients. Last month, Merck's stock sold as low as 85. **********Analysts attributed yesterday's generally cautious attitude among investors to several factors. First, there was the psychological barrier that often leads to wary profit-taking when the Dow industrials approach 1,000. More importantly, the stock market often strikes a cautionary tone on Fridays in advance of the weekly release of money-supply figures after trading closes on the Big Board. A decline of $2.2 billion in the nation's basic money supply, reported on the previous Friday, was a key factor in providing strength to securities markets earlier this week. Reserve's Money Report **********Yesterday, the Federal Reserve reported that, for the latest reporting week, the nation's basic money supply fell by $1.2 billion, a decline greater than Wall Street had forecast. The latest drop raised expectations that interest rates would continue to decline next week. **********Bank stocks displayed fractional price changes, following strong gains on Thursday, when 16 bank issues on the Big Board traded at their highest prices for at least a year. Analysts explained that interest margins at banks widen when short-term rates start to move downward. **********Texas Instruments fell 5 3/8 points, to 114 1/2. The company said it was laying off permanently 2,800 workers, 3 percent of its work force, because of weakness in the semiconductor business. **********Illustrating the continued decline of energy shares, Standard Oil (Indiana) dropped 2 points, to 51 1/2, in active trading. Last year, when oil stocks were market favorites, it sold at a record price of 99 1/2. **********Although most computer issues moved lower, International Business Machines advanced 3/4, to 58 3/4. The company was the subject of a favorable cover article in the current issue of Business Week. **********Conoco Inc., trading for the first time since Tuesday, fell 2 points, to 51 5/8. Dome Petroleum, which has purchased 20 percent of Conoco from the company's stockholders, also fell 2 points, closing at 94, on the American Stock Exchange. **********The Amex market value index declined 0.87, to 377. One loser on the exchange was Aeroflex Labs, dropping 3 1/4, to 33 1/2, after the company ended merger discussions with Premier Microwave. However, the Whitehall Corporation jumped 4 7/8 points, to 49 7/8, after completing negotiations for a contract with the Navy. Last year, Whitehall sold at 5 1/8. **********The Nasdaq composite index set another record, gaining 0.16, to 223.47.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/09/busin.main_headline: Texaco Seen Preparing Cities Service Takeover
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/09/busin.print_headline: Texaco Seen Preparing Cities Service Takeover
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/09/busin.body_text: **********Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, is preparing to make a bid for another major oil company, banking industry sources said yesterday. **********These sources said flatly that the target was the Cities Service Company, the 20th-largest energy company, although speculation elsewhere centered on Conoco Inc., No.9. **********Moving to dispel the avalanche of rumors contributing to the upward price spiral for its stock, Charles J. Waidelich, president of Cities Service, said at his headquarters in Tulsa, Okla., ''Cities Service is not engaged in any discussions or merger with Texaco Inc. or any other company, and we have no plans to do so.'' **********A Conoco spokesman said the company would have no comment. Financial Activity Reported **********Texaco is understood to be putting the finishing touches on a loan of more than $3 billion that, according to bankers, would be part of the amount needed to make an offer to buy Cities Service. **********Wall Street sources said persistent reports linked Texaco with Conoco.  Only 48 hours earlier, in what would, if completed, be the biggest corporate merger on record, E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company reached agreement to buy Conoco for $7.3 billion in cash and stock, a price calculated at the time the deal was concluded. **********Du Pont's $87.50-a-share bid for 100 percent of Conoco won out over a $73 offer by the Seagram Company for 40 percent and a still-secret offer at $85 a share. Wall Street professionals, nevertheless, said that they felt almost certain that some new bidder would emerge to outbid even Du Pont's offer. **********''History is being made with all these takeovers,'' said Stanley Schiff, senior vice president and risk arbitrager of the Wall Street house of Drexel Burnham Lambert. **********''We've just had two major instances in one day where somebody's raised the bidding - Du Pont and Elf Aquitaine. That's never happened before.'' In addition to Du Pont's outbidding of Seagram, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, France's state-controlled oil concern, sweetened its own bid for Texasgulf Inc., from $2.5 billion to $2.8 billion. Previous Texaco Response **********Despite its traditional reluctance to comment, Texaco announced earlier in the week, ''in response to a request from Conoco,'' that it had held ''informal discussions'' for an ''all-cash merger'' with the company but that Texaco had made ''no merger offer.'' It has since refused further comment. **********Should Texaco be considering a bid for either company, analysts said, there is no reason that either would yet have to know that a takeover was even in prospect. **********''Texaco has the funds for either deal,'' one Wall Street professional remarked. ''If, say, it bid $87.50, all cash, for Conoco,'' he added, ''it would have a good chance of succeeding.'' Du Pont's offer of $87.50 a share calls for part payment in cash and the rest in stock. **********Unless tax considerations are a factor in how the deal would be paid for, most investors prefer cash, even though the transaction is taxable. Exchanges of stock are generally tax-free. **********Cities Service did not begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday until almost 2 P.M. and by the end of the day had slid $3.375, to close at $55.75 a share in heavy trading. Confused by conflicting developments, traders intially thought the stock might plunge by more than $10 a share. The strength, despite a decline of a few points, was attributed to the strong possibility of merger activity that could begin soon. **********Conoco, the most active issue on the Big Board, with more than 900,000 shares changing hands, edged up 50 cents a share, to close at $76.375.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.print_headline: Swedish Journalists Go on Strike In a Dispute Over Working Hours
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/world.body_text: **********Swedish journalists began their first strike at nationwide newspapers today in a dispute over working hours and copyrights. **********Expressen, the paper with the largest circulation in Sweden, and papers in Gothenburg and Malmo were unable to publish, according to a spokesman for the Swedish Journalists Union. Four other papers printed a reduced number of pages, he said, and Aftonbladet, the other nationwide evening paper, published with a blank front page. **********The 350 striking journalists have rejected a compromise proposed by a state mediator, the union spokesman said. The publishers accepted the compromise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/busin.main_headline: Personal Finance; GETTING AN EXECUTIVE TO RELOCATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/busin.print_headline: Personal Finance; GETTING AN EXECUTIVE TO RELOCATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/13/busin.body_text: **********M ORE and more executives are finding that even with corporate sweeteners, they cannot afford to accept promotions if it means they have to move to another city. The real estate and mortgage costs are simply prohibitively high. **********''Relocation should not be the determining factor as to whether a person takes a certain job, but it often is,'' said Edward R. Koller, executive vice president of Howard-Sloan Associates, a New York City executive search firm. Companies are discovering they cannot hire the executive they want to hire, and many are being forced to limit their search to a particular geographical area, Mr. Koller said. **********The most common way that companies try to ease the financial strain of moving is to offer executives a ''mortgage interest differential'' payment that compensates for the the difference between the individual's old low-rate mortgage and the new higher-rate loan. But this is not an unlimited subsidy. **********In the past, the typical mortgage differential was allowed for a maximum of three years and was usually graduated downward, from the full difference the first year to perhaps 50 percent by the third year. Now many employers are being forced to extend the differential for a year or two or face employee resentment. **********Daniel A. Picard, managing director of Lamalie Associates, notes that more companies are now paying the full differential for the first three years and only decreasing the subsidy in the fourth and fifth years. When the subsidy finally ends, however, the employee could face the same high-rate problem he did originally, and then he has to meet the higher mortgage costs alone. **********Stephanie Pinson, the new relocation specialist at Gilbert Tweed Associates, a New York executive recruiter, gives an example of just how large the combination of higher interest rates and higher house costs - despite a generous differential - can be for an $80,000-ayear executive who is transferred from New York to California, where house prices are still well above those most everywhere else. **********Assume the executive has a 9 percent mortgage with $75,000 still outstanding. His bank payments, for principal and interest but not for real estate taxes, come to $603 a month. He sells the house for $200,000. **********To buy an equivalent one in Los Angeles, in a neighborhood roughly similar to the one he left, he would have to pay $350,000, according to Mrs. Pinson. He would put up his $125,000 equity from the sale of the New York house, so he would then have to he take out a $225,000 mortgage. He might get a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage at 16 percent.  The monthly payments, not including taxes and before any differential, would be $3,025, or $2,422 more than he had been paying in New York. **********To ease that burden the executive's company agrees to pay a sevenpoint differential (the difference between the old and the new mortgage rates) on the $75,000 balance that was outstanding on his old mortgage for three years. That works out to a total of $15,750, or $438 a month. So the executive's added cost of housing at the new location is nearly $2,000 a month, or more than $70,000 for the first three years. **********''The real chiller,'' Mrs. Pinson said, is that even with the differential, the executive would probably not even qualify for a mortgage to buy a house like the one he left. Using a rule of thumb that limits payments to no more than 28 percent of monthly gross income, the $80,000 executive could handle monthly payments of only $1,867. **********Of course, the picture would change considerably if the executive were moving from Los Angeles to New York or some other city. In such a case, there probably would not be a need to take out a mortgage. **********Because of the economics of the New York to Los Angeles move, for example, most companies would be almost forced to offer additional financial inducements to persuade the executive to transfer, Mrs.  Pinson said. These might include a substantial raise and a no- or low-interest loan for a big chunk of the new mortgage, or reducing the interest rate on the new mortgage by paying the bank five to 10 ''points'' (a point is equivalent to 1 percent of the face value of the loan and represents prepaid interest). ''How much the company gives depends on how much the guy wants the job, and how much the company wants the guy,'' Mrs. Pinson said. ''There are no rules.'' **********For this reason, Mr. Picard of Lamalie Associates, urges executives to work out the housing costs before accepting a transfer and to bargain hard before packing their bags. ''Your only leverage is before you're there, and that's why it's so critical to have an upfront agreement,'' he said. **********Among other things, the agreement should contain a ''settling-in'' allowance, equivalent to one- to three-months' salary, to cover the one-time costs of moving, such as hooking up utilities and appliances. It might also require the company to pay the duplicate costs of carrying two dwellings for a specified period of time, usually just 30 days but sometimes as long as two or three months. **********B ECAUSE of difficulties in unloading houses in the current sluggish housing market, many large companies turn to firms like Merrill Lynch Relocation Management to handle the deal. But even Merrill Lynch, which guarantees executives the market value of their homes, is having trouble selling residential property these days. **********Patricia Matteson, marketing director for Merrill Lynch Relocation, says it takes the firm five months to sell the average house, up from three and a half months a year ago. And she expects the selling time to stretch out to six months this winter. The firm is now carrying an inventory of 10,000 houses, double the level of a year ago, she added. **********Another approach favored by some companies is to offer a broader cost-of-living adjustment based on overall costs in the new area, according to Runzheimer & Company, a Rochester, Wis., consulting firm. The adjustment typically covers such costs as transportation, real estate taxes, homeowners insurance, utilities, home maintenance and Federal, state and local income taxes. **********The index provides a more accurate gauge of an executive's new living costs than a mortgage differential alone, according to Gaylord Milbrandt, head of Runzheimer's living cost division. He added that the impact of high mortgage interest payments may be overstated because the payments are tax-deductible, while the advantage of living in a state with no income tax may be overrated because money that is not taxed by the state is then taxed by the Federal Government at progressive rates. **********''Chances are the impact of higher housing costs might not be as great as one might expect because of the tax effect,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/03/world.body_text: **********IRANIANS URGED TO BE ALERT FOR SUSPICIOUS ACTIVITY **********TEHERAN, Iran, July 2 (Reuters) - Iran's leaders, seeking to prevent further violent attacks on prominent Iranians, declared today that it was the duty of all people to be alert and inform the authorities immediately of any suspicious activities. **********''From now on,'' Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said in a speech, ''all of you are members of the intelligence organization.'' A similar request for information on what people might be saying in buses, public places and even doctors' offices was made by the newspaper of the ruling Islamic Republican Party, whose headquarters was wrecked last Sunday by a bomb explosion that killed 72 leading members. **********The newspaper, Jomhuri-i-Islami, also called on both the Iranian people and the authorities to ''bring under their severe control the activities of foreign journalists.'' **********Quick Report by BBC Noted **********The paper recalled that it had long warned that ''reporters of the foreign press are spies.'' It stressed that the British Broadcasting Corporation had obtained information on the bomb blast within five minutes after it occurred. **********The Teheran radio said that seven more leftists were put to death - six in Ahwaz, the southwestern oil city near a front of the war with Iraq, and one in the northern town of Babol.These actions were said to raise to about 90 the total number of executions on charges of ''counterrevolutionary'' activities since Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the leader of secular, leftist and liberal groups, was removed from the presidency 10 days ago. **********The newspaper of the ruling party said that the authorities had uncovered20 ''safe houses'' of anti-Government groups in Teheran and arrested a number of people, including two high members of the Islamic Marxist guerrilla organization, Mujahedeen-i-Khalq. Fifty others were reportedly arrested Tuesday and accused of plotting to destroy the Parliament building. Khomeini Accuses Guerrillas **********Shortly before the arrests, the guerrillas' organization was denounced by Ayatollah Khomeini as responsible for the bombing of the Islamic Republican Party's headquarters on Sunday. **********Speaking today to the families of the 72 Islamic clerics and political figures killed in that attack, the Ayatollah said: ''It is the duty of all our people to watch every suspicious action and to find the saboteurs who have hidden and are planning further sabotage.'' **********He said, however, that citizens should not take the law into their own hands but should, ''at most, arrest these saboteurs and hand them over to the security forces.'' **********The Ayatollah warned all anti-Government groups in his speech to ''repent before it is too late,'' and he recalled that he had repeatedly warned Mr. Bani-Sadr ''to separate himself'' from the leftist guerrillas who supported his presidency because they ''would destroy him.'' Charges Against the U.S. **********Repeating his charge that the United States was involved in the bomb attack last Sunday, Ayatollah Khomeini described the action as an ''American movement against Islam.'' **********In other developments, the Interior Ministry said that all those wishing to run in the presidential elections on July 24 to replace the fugitive former leader, who was last seen in public three weeks ago today, should announce their candidacies beginning tomorrow.  Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai has been rumored as most likely to represent the ruling party and to win. **********Parliamentary by-elections for 46 seats, including those made vacant by the deaths of 27 in the bomb explosion, are to be held the same day, the Interior Ministry declared. Iran Rebuffs Cease-Fire Offer **********A Foreign Ministry spokesman said, according to the state radio, that Iran could not agree to a recent offer by Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, of a cease-fire in the war during the Moslem holy month of Ramadan, which begins tomorrow. **********It was also announced that Ayatollah Khomeini would hold no meetings during the Islamic month of Ramadan, a time of fast from dawn to dusk. **********Diplomats here said during the day that continued preoccupation with security matters - a result of the destruction of the party headquarters and other violent attacks - appeared certain to delay plans by Iranian leaders to revive the battered economy. **********They said that there had been brief optimism that, with the removal of Mr. Bani-Sadr on June 22, the clergy-dominated Government had neutralized its internal critics and could get down to the task of repairing the damage of the upheavals brought by the revolution of February 1979 and the nine-month-old war with Iraq. **********But, the diplomats added, the bomb blast on Sunday showed that the revolution was still under way and that stability could be a distant goal. ---- Iranians Seize Paris Office **********PARIS, July 2 (AP) - About 30 Iranians said to be leftists occupied the Iranian Consulate here for three hours today to protest executions in their homeland.  French security forces surrounded the consulate but allowed the Iranians to leave after they voluntarily ended their protest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/09/world.main_headline: NAMIBIA CONFEREES CLASH, THEN GET DOWN TO BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/09/world.print_headline: NAMIBIA CONFEREES CLASH, THEN GET DOWN TO BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/09/world.body_text: **********The two sides at the conference on South-West Africa exchanged bitter barbs today at a brief public session that was called to enable the political parties from inside the territory to assert their claim to equal status with the insurgent movement known as the South-West Africa People's Organization. **********At issue was South Africa's insistence that the so-called ''internal parties'' are the real negotiators with whom the insurgents must reach an understanding if the territory is to become independent under the name Namibia, in accord with a plan sponsored by five Western nations. **********Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations, the only speaker at yesterday's session, made no reference at all to the eight political groups that were seated as members of the South African delegation. The United Nations, along with the Western and African nations who are here as observers, recognize the insurgents as a party to the talks on an equal footing with South Africa. **********Moreover, a 1973 General Assembly resolution - never endorsed by the Western nations - declares the insurgent movement to be ''the sole and authentic representative of the Namibian people.'' **********Nevertheless, no objection was raised by the South-West Africa People's Organization or anyone else yesterday when South Africa seated the political parties from the territory in the front ranks of its delegation. But then those parties said they would not go on with the talks unless they were given more explicit recognition. **********After excruciating negotiations over precisely what was supposed to be said at today's public session, the two sides filed back into the old League of Nations Council Chamber late this afternoon as the light started to fade over Lake Geneva. It was then that the carefully planned set piece turned into a tense moment of diplomatic theater. **********Mr. Waldheim opened the session with an artfully ambiguous statement in which he insisted that the United Nations was not changing in any way the framework of the talks and then invited the Administrator General of the disputed territory, a South African official named Danie Hough, to introduce the members of his delegation. As Mr. Hough read out the names of the various parties and their leaders, they rose to their feet like ballplayers being introduced at the start of a game. **********The ritual may have been a symbolic victory for the parties from the territory, but they were immediately upstaged by Sam Nujoma, the leader of the insurgent movement. Called on to introduce the members of his delegation, Mr. Nujoma did not bother to read off names but simply declared, ''My delegation is one, united, representing the oppressed people of Namibia.'' With that, three rows of delegates rose smartly to their feet with their fists in the air in the familiar revolutionary salute. **********Mr. Nujoma then observed that some members of the delegation were not present because they were in prison on Robben Island off Cape Town and in Namibia. He ended by declaring his readiness to sign a cease-fire agreement with South Africa now, ''so that peace can come to Namibia.'' **********As soon as Mr. Nujoma was in his seat, with a broad smile breaking through his silver beard, Mr. Hough was calling for the floor to deliver an impromptu response that was evidently not part of the script. **********''There are many other people whom we would like to have in this delegation with us,'' the South African said heatedly, ''many who are killed, many who are in graves.'' Minutes later the Secretary General's gavel ended the round and the conference went, at last, into its first session behind closed doors.

''This is a question of human dignity which is preserved by all nations in the world.'' **********The rally was held ''to try and curb the activities'' of what a Neturei Karta spokesman called ''accelerated digging activity'' by archeologists at the disputed site near the Old City walls. https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/18/busin.body_text: **********The beleaguered Consolidated Rail Corporation, plagued last year by equipment malfunctions, overcrowding and poor on-time performance, reported yesterday that it had narrowed its loss to $12 million in the the fourth quarter of 1980 from a deficit of $59.7 million in the fourth quarter of 1979. Revenues edged up eight-tenths of 1 percent, the company said. **********''The loss was the smallest in the any fourth quarter in the corporation's five-year history,'' L. Stanley Crane, Conrail's chairman and chief executive officer, said. ''This improvement came despite the worst fourth quarter in terms of carloadings handled by Conrail.'' **********Conrail, established by Congress to reorganize and consolidate six bankrupt Northeast railroads, said that in the latest three months revenues advanced to $1.044 billion from $1.036 billion in the fourth quarter of 1979. **********Conrail said that for the year it reported a loss of $243.7 million on consolidated revenues of $3.99 billion, compared with a restated loss of $220.5 million, in 1979, on consolidated revenues of $3.96 billion. The 1980 and 1979 results, the company said, include expenses of $37.5 million and $37.8 million, respectively, attributable to the settlement of the Penn Central Corporation valuation case. **********''The higher loss for 1980 stems mainly from recessionary forces in the economy which brought about precipitous traffic declines in carloadings of approximately 20 percent in the second and third quarters of 1980 versus the prior year's same quarters,'' Mr. Crane said. **********Conrail has been buoyed by $3.15 billion in Federal funding since its establishment on April 1, 1976. Mr. Crane said that $2.77 billion of that amount was designated for physical improvement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/23/busin.body_text: **********Two years after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher dropped foreign-exchange controls, a flood of money out of the country has provoked a spate of calls for renewed strictures. **********In just the past few weeks, demands for controls have come from politicians and agencies representing a variety of persuasions, including Edward Heath, the former Conservative Prime Minister, and the Trades Union Congress, the workers group closely allied to the Labor Party. **********For her part, Mrs. Thatcher has remained adamantly opposed to any such action. Her Cabinet ministers do not share the ''siege economic view that if money flows overseas, it will deprive people of jobs,'' a Treasury official said. ''It makes economic sense in Government policy to build up this level of overseas dividend flow.'' **********Exporter of Investment Capital **********To be sure, having matured economically earlier than most countries, Britain has long been a key exporter of investment capital, despite exchange controls that date to 1939. **********As they ultimately developed, the controls prevented most direct conversions of sterling to foreign currencies by businesses, institutions and individuals. But these groups worked around the regulations by borrowing foreign currencies or by buying foreign currencies at a premium from a Government-regulated investment currency pool. **********But the extent of the outflow of money since October 1979, when the controls were abolished, is striking. Last week, the Treasury reported that in the first half of this year, the equivalent of $7.8 billion was invested outside Britain, compared with $4.9 billion in the similar period of 1980 and $3.3 billion in the first half of 1979, when restrictions were still in place. How the Money Leaves **********The money generally leaves in two ways. Individuals and financial institutions, including pension funds, engage principally in portfolio investment, purchasing financial assets like stocks and bonds. This category in particular has surged. However companies will often make direct investments, which means buying real assets, such as another company. **********The Treasury report said that investment institutions and unit trusts, which are similar to mutual funds, increased their proportion of overseas assets in the course of 1980 to 31 percent of total holdings from 24 percent. **********As for companies, hardly a day goes by without another overseas acquisition by a British company. Among the most publicized lately were Grand Metropolitan's acquisition of Intercontinental Hotels from Pan American World Airways and Midland Bank's purchase of the Crocker Bank in California. British pension funds have also been pouring money into American real estate. U.S. and Asia Attractive **********Thus far, the United States and the high-growth economies of Asia have proved most attractive. In its latest quarterly bulletin, the Bank of England said about half of Britain's overseas investments were now in North America. Last week, for example, Unigate Ltd., a major dairy here, agreed to purchase Casa Bonita, a West Coast fastfood chain. **********''We believe very strongly in the United States economy,'' said Daniel Hodson, Unigate's finance director, in an interview. ''Any multinational company should have a substantial portion of its earnings in the U.S.'' **********The example of Unigate also illustrates why many British executives agree with Mr. Hodson. With Britain in the midst of a recession, the company, in the year ended March 31, earned just $55 million in operating profit on sales of $2.2 billion, a return of 2.5 percent.  By comparison, its foreign subsidiaries - including two cheese companies in the United States - earned $17.5 million on sales of $296 million, a return of 5.8 percent. Impact on Total Earnings **********A recent study by Phillips & Drew, a stockbrokerage firm, concluded that, over all, 40 percent of British corporate profits last year came from overseas subsidiaries and another 15 percent resulted from export earnings. **********Supporters of exchange controls argue that, in view of the nation's troubles, Britain would be justified in taking what are essentially protectionist actions to develop jobs for the three million people out of work. Even many normally unsympathetic economists accept this view. **********But other economists note that if Britain's investors are forced to keep their money at home, interest rates would tend to be lower. That in turn would discourage non-British investors from bringing money here, even temporarily. The exchange rate would also probably be higher, which would exacerbate the problems British companies already have in competing in the export market. A Debate Over Goals **********''In the back of the Government's mind may be the thinking that they want to get some of the oil money invested overseas,'' said Gavyn Davies, chief economist at Simon & Coates, an investment firm, referring to the long debate over what to do with the fruits of the oil and gas finds in the British sector of the North Sea. **********Others believe that, even with controls, there is substantial leakage that negates much of their effect. During the last round of strictures, a variety of devices, including foreign holding companies, sprang up.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.print_headline: Hirohito Marks Anniversary Of War's End at Tokyo Rites
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/16/world.body_text: **********Emperor Hirohito marked the 36th anniversary today of the end of World War II with a ''prayer for world peace'' in ceremonies before 6,600 people at Tokyo's Martial Arts Hall. **********''Even now, when I think of those who fell in the ranks of the last great war, or the many who perished in the ravages of that war, and their survivors, my heart is filled with pain,'' the 80-year-old Emperor said. **********Elderly people were predominant in the audience, many of them somberly dressed women who lost husbands or sons in the war. The silver-haired Emperor bowed before an altar at the stroke of noon for a minute of silent prayer for the three million Japanese who died in the war. Sirens and bells were sounded throughout the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/25/busin.body_text: **********The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to examine alleged accounting irregularities involving the Rockwell International Corporation's space shuttle contract, the company confirmed today. **********A former Rockwell employee, Ray Sena of Fullerton, Calif., charges that some working hours spent on an Air Force satellite contract were improperly charged to the shuttle. The allegations were first made public last year. **********Earl Blount, a Rockwell spokesman, confirmed that some hours were mischarged, but contended the problem had been confined to a single facility at Seal Beach. He said Rockwell management had nothing to do with the incident. **********''We investigated and NASA investigated,'' Mr. Blount said. ''We said there's something like $60,000 involved and NASA said it was $120,000. NASA has asked the Department of Justice to come in and look at the situation.'' F.B.I. Confirms Investigation **********John Hoos of the F.B.I., said, ''We do have a preliminary investigation into that.'' He would not elaborate. **********On the $9.6 billion shuttle project, for which Rockwell is the main contractor, NASA pays all costs plus a guaranteed profit. On the other program, a navigation satellite system called Navstar, the contractor's initial bid must cover both costs and profit. **********The allegation implies that, to keep Navstar costs down, the timecards of some satellite workers were charged to the shuttle.  Mr. Blount said the company had disciplined several employees, but that all were back at work.  Mr. Sena, subsequently dismissed after 24 years with Rockwell, is suing the company for reinstatement and punititive damages. He contends he lost his job because he made the allegations against his employer, a charge Rockwell that denies. **********Other former employees' allegations concerning the shuttle project include charges of excessive travel vouchers, decorating at the homes or businesses of Rockwell executives and charged to the shuttle and awards of subcontracts to companies in which Rockwell officials had financial interests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/15/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Rudolph G. Penner in ''Why Indexing Was a Big Mistake'' (Feb. 1) has adopted a browbeating attitude toward the beneficiaries of the indexing of social programs, particularly Social Security recipients. He repeatedly refers to such beneficiaries as ''special interest'' groups and implies that they are gorging themselves at the trough of ''ordinary tax-paying workers.'' **********Professor Penner forgets that Social Security recipients were, up until the time of their retirement, ''ordinary tax-paying workers'' who are now trying to live out their remaining years at a little above the poverty level. **********He might also remember that someday he too may be one of those ''special interest'' Social Security recipients. Or perhaps Mr.  Penner is a member of that ''privileged special interest'' group which is able to take advantage of private pension plans, tax shelters and tax avoidance schemes. If so, let him set an example for others of his class and let him offer to forgo any Social Security benefits which will accrue to him at retirement so that these monies can be used to help less privileged recipients keep up with inflated living costs. ANNE DAGOSTO Elmont, N.Y., Feb. 3, 1981
