https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/25/busin.body_text: **********The BankAmerica Corporation announced yesterday that it intended to acquire Charles Schwab & Company Inc., America's largest discount brokerage firm, for about $53 million in common stock. The transaction could develop into a historic test case for Federal banking laws. **********The proposed merger would appear to conflict with the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which drew a line between investment banking and commercial banking. The act forbids commercial banks to own, underwrite or deal in corporate stocks and bonds. **********If the merger does proceed, it would give BankAmerica, owner of the nation's largest commercial bank, Bank of America, a decided advantage over its competitors. The merger would allow BankAmerica to offer a full range of ''one-stop'' financial services, from checking accounts to the sale of stocks. It would mark the first time that an American bank has acquired a brokerage house. **********Stephen T. McLin, senior vice president for strategic planning at BankAmerica, said that his company proposed the deal to Schwab last September and was confident that it could convince regulators that it would not violate the Glass-Steagall provisions. Confidence in Merger **********''Our attorneys feel that the merger will be permitted within the confines of the Glass-Steagall Act,'' Mr. McLin said. ''Charles Schwab does not underwrite securities, take positions for its own account or inventory securities, like a typical broker-dealer for whom the act was originally designed.'' **********The Glass-Steagall Act, argued Charles R. Schwab, chairman of the the brokerage house, was written after the stock market crash to prevent banks from selling or buying for their trust accounts securities that they had underwritten and to forbid them to lend money to concerns whose stocks they were offering. None of these issues, he said, would apply to a Schwab-BankAmerica marriage. **********''We are completely different from most brokers,'' Mr. Schwab said. ''Our business is exclusively executing stock orders for customers; we do not underwrite or trade ourselves, so there should be no conflict with the intent of Glass-Steagall.'' **********''Merrill Lynch and the other broker-dealers have been competing at the heart of the banking industry with their cash management accounts,'' Mr. McLin added, ''and now we will be able to compete at the heart of their industry. While Schwab will remain a separate subsidiary, we eventually hope to offer brokerage services at our branches and to offer banking services at Schwab's offices around the country to the extent which the various state banking regulations permit.'' Regulatory Approval Needed **********Mr. McLin said the proposed acquisition would require the approval of the BankAmerica board; the shareholders of the Charles Schwab Corporation, the parent company of the brokerage firm, and the Federal agencies with regulatory jurisdiction. He said his company had informed the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Reserve Board that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Charles Schwab for 2.2 million shares of BankAmerica common stock, which would be worth about $53 million. **********Sources close to the BankAmerica management said the company was still debating whether to go through the Federal Reserve or the Comptroller's office for regulatory approval. **********Schwab is a 10-year-old privately held company with 38 offices around the country, but based only three blocks from the main office of BankAmerica in San Francisco. It is considered by analysts as one of the best-managed companies in the so-called bargain basement of the securities industry and a leading innovator. **********The firm expanded earlier this year with the acquisition of Kingsley, Boye & Southwood, a New York-based discount brokerage concern. Lower Fees Offered **********Schwab buys and sells stocks and bonds for fees that often are 50 percent below those of the major brokerage houses. In recent years, it has introduced services such as extended business hours, automatic transfers of cash into a money market fund and 60-second stock transactions. **********Mr. Schwab said there was no question that all the limited shareholders in his company would approve the sale, which would give ''it the capital resources to continue our rapid expansion.'' He said the only major stockholder outside of his family and the employees and senior officers of the company was the United Financial Corporation, a subsidiary of the National Steel Corporation. United Financial owns a 20.1 percent stake in the firm.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/busin.main_headline: Commodities; Platinum's Link to Gold Price
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/busin.print_headline: Commodities; Platinum's Link to Gold Price
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/30/busin.body_text: **********ONE of the mysteries confronting futures traders in precious metals in recent months has been the closing of the gulf between the prices of gold and platinum. **********For many years the premium on platinum had been about $100 an ounce, largely because the trade estimated the above-ground gold stock at about 50 years of current demand and that for the gray metal at five years. **********This may be so, but at last Friday's close of New York's Commodity Exchange, the active near December gold futures found the price at $621 an ounce, up $14 on the week. The active January platinum contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose $14.30, to close the week at $632.90 an ounce. **********Some futures analysts attributed this to the fact that gold is mostly a ''monetary metal,'' whose price reflects the value of paper money and currently must compete for the favor of investors at a time when they can obtain relatively high returns on safe Treasury bills. Platinum, they note, is under even greater pressure because 95 percent of it is used by the depressed auto industry in antipollution devices and by petroleum and chemical makers as a catalyst. **********However, most commodity analysts do not expect the prices of gold and platinum to stay wedded forever. Most expect platinum to again sell at a premium. So does Rudolf Wolff Commodity Brokers Inc., the American affiliate of the London-based trading house, which is considered one of the leading dealers and brokers in physical metals. It is also 51 percent owned by Noranda Mines (Canada) Ltd., the large international copper mining concern. **********Last Friday, the American brokerage branch offered its opinion in its first published research report to its clients. Because the Soviet Union is the leading supplier of platinum and related metals, followed by South Africa, Rudolf Wolff expects the defense-oriented Reagan administration to increase substantially the United States' currently low stockpile of these strategic metals. **********''This factor could have, of course, effect on the market and could carry the price of platinum well over the premium of $100 an ounce above the gold price that existed during 1979 and early 1980.'' the Rudolf Wolff report said. **********It added : ''Such potential, therefore, represents a unique opportunity for sensible spreading by selling short gold futures and simultaneously purchasing platinum futures in this manner: Sell one 100-ounce Comex April 1981 gold contract and buy two 50-ounce New York Mercantile April platinum futures.'' **********Paul Sarnoff, research chief of Rudolf Wolff's American operations, said in an interview last Friday: ''Ideally, the spread should be effected at equal prices for both metals, but this is almost unlikely. Chances are the spread would come at a slight premium for platinum over gold, or conceivably a slight discount from gold's price. That is why orders for these spreads should contain a leeway of at least $10 an ounce either way.'' **********The initial goal is a $30 platinum premium over gold, for a gross profit of $3,000 on the spread, Mr. Sarnoff continued. ''We also recommend placing stop-loss orders limiting potential losses to $1,000 per spread, which should involve a cash outlay of about $5,000 plus commission.'' **********To limit loss to $1,000, the broker would have to cancel the spread when the loss on one leg exceeded the gain on the other by more than $10. Normally, there will be a loss on one leg because the spreader has simultaneously bought and sold short commodities that tend to move up or down together. The object of the spread is to have one leg of the spread produce more profit than the other's loss. **********If it does not work out that way, prudent futures traders cancel their spread as quickly as possible. But if it works well, the traders can drop the losing leg and run with the profitable one until the goal of the spread is acheived. **********What if one owns gold bullion, which is a ''sterile investment'' in that it produces no dividends or other income, and is enviously looking at the currently rising yields on Treasury bills. One way to ''own'' gold and receive the current 13.5 percent discount rate on 90-day Treasury bills was offered by Mr. Sarnoff. **********''Suppose one had 100 ounces of gold or, say, Krugerrands in the vault,'' he said. ''At today's price the 100 ounces would be worth $62,000. One could take the proceeds and buy a 100-ounce Comex gold futures contract with a maturity as far ahead as 20 months or so for a cash outlay of about $3,000 and put the rest of the money in Tbills, which would be held by the broker.'' **********There would be no margin calls because the broker could cover any price decline with the Treasury bills. Not only would the bills produce income and be rolled over at maturity, but so could the maturing futures. If the futures produce a gain, he said, the investor can tell his broker to apply the profit toward the purchase of more bills or other short-term money market instruments. **********If gold prices should appear headed on a long downward trend, the investor can usually get out of the futures with a phone call, instead of paying storage costs for an income-less metal that is declining in value, Mr. Sarnoff added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/17/world.main_headline: SAUDIS WILL PAY FOR REPAIRS ON IRAQ'S REACTOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/17/world.print_headline: SAUDIS WILL PAY FOR REPAIRS ON IRAQ'S REACTOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/17/world.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia said today that it would pay the entire cost of rebuilding the Iraqi nuclear reactor that Israeli planes wrecked on June 7. **********The announcement, the Saudi press agency said, was made by Information Minister Mohammed Abdo Yamani after talks between King Khalid and Iraq's Oil Minister, Tayeh Abdel Kerim, who was on a visit to Saudi Arabia. **********One purpose of the decision is to confront Israel ''and its supporters who create obstacles in the way of Arabs seeking modern technology,'' the Saudi radio said. **********No figure was mentioned in the Saudi statement of what it would cost to reconstruct the Osirak reactor. When built by the French, it was said to have cost $250 million. The Saudi offer would be in addition to the money Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf Arab countries are said to be providing Iraq toward the costs of its war with Iran. **********The statement quoted Crown Prince Fahd, the operating head of the Saudi Government, as having said that King Khalid advised President Francois Mitterrand of France of his intentions when they met in Paris last month. The statement did not say whether France had agreed to rebuild the reactor. **********However, an interview with President Mitterrand published in mid-June quoted him as having said that France would agree to reconstruct the reactor only if Iraq would first agree to the same strict safeguards against any possible military use that would apply to all future French sales of nuclear technology. ---- Decision Due on F-16's By HOWELL RAINES Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, July 16 - The Reagan Administration is expected to announce tomorrow that it will release to Israel the four F-16 fighterbombers whose delivery was held up after the Israeli air strike on the Iraqi reactor. **********White House sources said the announcement would be made at the State Department.  The four F-16's, whose delivery was scheduled for last month, were withheld pending a determination whether Israel had used Americansupplied planes in the raid in violation of United States statutes limiting such weapons to defensive purposes. **********American officials also made it clear that delaying the planes was a way of reprimanding Israel and calming Arabs who demanded that the United States condemn Israel for the attack on Iraq. Assurances on Other F-16's **********After it delayed the June deliveries, however, the Administration announced that it would go ahead with delivery of six other F-16's to be released to Israel tomorrow. White House spokesmen said at the time that the matter of the four planes would be resolved by the time the six were due to be delivered. **********Since the policy was announced July 1, it has been regarded as a foregone conclusion that the United States would eventually deliver all the planes. But the Administration faced the problem of working out a diplomatic explanation for its action that did not appear either to endorse Israel's attack or to call into question the United States' role as an ally of Israel. **********Participants in a White House meeting on the issue last night included Edwin Meese 3d, Counselor to the President; Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.; Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger; Richard V. Allen, Mr. Reagan's national security adviser, and the State Department counselor, Robert C. McFarlane. **********Mr. McFarlane briefed members of the House and Senate foreign affairs committees today on talks he had had in Israel with Prime Minster Menachem Begin on Monday about the F-16's. . But an Administration official said Mr. McFarlane had not informed the legislators of President Reagan's decision. **********The official said the announcement tomorrow would be accompanied by a ''fairly brief statement'' that was still being drafted.  He said the statement would not go much beyond the joint declaration issued by Mr. Begin and Mr. McFarlane at the end of their discussions. This said without elaboration that ''misunderstandings'' stemming from the Israeli raid had been ''clarified to the satisfaction of both sides.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/24/world.main_headline: Bushmen in Namibia Are Fighting for South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/24/world.print_headline: Bushmen in Namibia Are Fighting for South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/24/world.body_text: **********West Africa (Reuters) - Thousands of Bushmen who supported the Portuguese colonialists during Angola's long independence war are now fighting on the side of South Africa against guerrillas of the South-West Africa People's Organization. **********There are 29,000 of the San people, commonly known as Bushmen, in sparsely populated South-West Africa, or Namibia, about a quarter of them refugees who fled neighboring Angola after Portuguese rule ended in 1975. It was from these refugees that Battalion 202 was formed five years ago, one of two San battalions in South Africa's military forces in South-West Africa. **********The San, who are famed for their tracking abilities, fought fiercely against encroachment by white settlers in the 18th and 19th centuries but were defeated. Culturally rich but technologically primitive and declining in numbers, they are estimated to total 50,000. **********''If they weren't in the army, there'd be nothing else for them to do,'' a South African lieutenant, Ben Wolff, said. Six-Week Tours in War Zone **********Some 850 San troops, 2,700 dependents and 250 whites are at this base, one of an undisclosed number along the Caprivi Strip, a fertile area rich in game in the northeastern corner of the territory. The troops are flown to the main war area in Ovamboland for six-week tours. **********Lieutenant Wolff, who is the main training officer because he speaks a dialect of the complex clicking San language, said, ''SWAPO usually clears out when they know there are Bushmen around.'' He was referring to the insurgent group by its initials. **********The San are fighting not only because of the absence of employment in this virtually undeveloped area but also because they fear that if the guerrillas are victorious they will be massacred for having supported the Portuguese in Angola. **********Apart from two San corporals, the officers, both commissioned and noncommissioned, are white. Black and white privates are paid equally. **********San boys get a junior high school education in Afrikaans, the predominant language among South African whites, with boxing and soccer lessons, and once a month they are taken into the bush by a San elder to learn tracking and hunting with bow and arrow. Traditions Being Preserved **********Although the San here are no longer nomads, the army authorities want to preserve as many of their traditions as possible. They have kept their religion although there is a Christian church on the base. ''Our aim is not to Westernize them but to make them a better Bushman,'' Lieutenant Wolff told visiting foreign correspondents. **********The base has a hospital with a well-equipped operating room, but San women still bear their children in the bush, though they bring them in to see the doctor the following day. The doctor, a white, is assisted by four San nursing aides and three interpreters. **********The guerrilla war has little effect on the tranquillity of the Caprivi, mainly because there are no guerrilla forces in the area of Angola that lies immediately to the north. The guerrillas cannot operate there as it is a stronghold of Unita, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, a South African-supported organization that unsuccessfully fought in a three-sided civil war after the end of Portuguese rule and is still harassing the forces of the Marxist Angolan Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.main_headline: IN POLAND, PRAYERS FOR A NATIONAL HERO
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.print_headline: IN POLAND, PRAYERS FOR A NATIONAL HERO
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/14/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of thousands of Poles attended special masses or prayed on street corners tonight for the recovery of Pope John Paul II. **********The Government announced that all theaters, movies and entertainment centers would be closed tomorrow and the Roman Catholic Church announced that a special mass would be held for both Pope John Paul II and Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the 79-year-old Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, who has been seriously ill for a month. **********As word of the shooting spread through Warsaw, the city seemed to fall strangely quiet. People gathered around television sets, stood in clusters on street corners and went to church to pray. Some wept openly during the services. **********''Now what will poor Poland do,'' said a 65-year-old grandmother in the Pyry section, talking to a neighbor over a wire fence in a lawn flooded with daffodils. ''The Pope is a father to the nation, to all Poles. He protects us. When we are afraid or worried or suffering, we just think of him.'' 'What Will Happen to Us?' **********''Now what will happen to us?'' she said, lifting a white handkerchief to her cheek.  A 28-year-old economics professor said he heard the news when a friend called him from Switzerland. He said he put down the receiver and cried. **********''I am stunned,'' he said. ''I am numb. I simply cannot believe this has happened.'' The news came over Polish television in a special bulletin at 5:30 P.M. The entire half-hour evening news program was devoted to the event. To expand its coverage, the Polish network picked up Italian television and provided a voice-over translation. Programs were interrupted to provide later information. Unusual Pickup From Italian TV **********The television coverage, with its direct, live pickup of Italian programming, was unprecedented in a Soviet-bloc country. The Polish announcer's voice quivered as he said: ''The Pope was struck by three bullets that entered his body. His white robes were stained with blood.'' **********The reaction from the Communist Party and the Government was swift.  ''The news of the criminal attempt on the life of Your Holiness comes as a great shock to the Polish nation and the authorities of the Polish People's Republic,'' said a message signed by Stanislaw Kania, the party leader, and by President Henryk Jablonski and Gen.  Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Prime Minister. **********''In this grievous moment we send to Your Holiness from your fatherland our wishes for a speedy recovery of your strength so indispensable to fulfilling your mission in the service of humanistic ideals of peace and the welfare of mankind.'' **********The church and the labor movement, the two other major Polish institutions, responded in a similar vein.  ''We cannot find the words to sufficiently condemn this criminal act,'' said a statement from the episcopate read over television by a spokesman, the Rev. Alojzy Orszulik, standing in front of the Pope's portrait. ''The whole church of Poland prays for the Holy Father's quick return to health and active services to the church on the Throne of St. Peter.'' **********A message from the union leadership spoke of the shock it felt and added: ''Let your suffering be a symbol of love for man. We have hope in Poland that you will quickly recover.'' **********By nightfall, hundreds of thousands had attended special masses.  Thousands crowded into the church at Wadowice in southern Poland, where the Pope was born and baptized. **********In Warsaw, people gravitated to the Old Town, walking up and down the cobbled streets and stopping to pray in any one of dozens of churches. **********In the Jesuit church, the Sanctuary of the Gracious Madonna, the first church in which the Pope prayed in 1979, the presiding priest told a congregation that flowed down the steps and into the street that the shooting ''is proof of the existence of the forces of hate.'' **********''We must pray to the Madonna that she protect us so that the forces of hate disappear from the world,'' he said. Then he led a procession down the center aisle, to a marble and gold tablet commemorating the Pope's visit, and laid a bouquet of flowers as a ''sign of our love.'' **********''Madonna, Queen of Poland, we pray to you,'' he began, and many sank to their knees, weeping.  Afterward, outside the church, a man dressed in a blue suit was interviewed by television. The man said he was frightened by the attack on the Pope. ''This bullet struck all of us,'' he said. The interviewer could not think of another question and both he and the man stood in silence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/09/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Lewis W. Lehr and John M. Pitblado of 3M; New Approach For the 80's
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/09/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Lewis W. Lehr and John M. Pitblado of 3M; New Approach For the 80's
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/09/busin.body_text: **********It is hard to define 3M. Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company produces more than 45,000 different products, from suntan lotion to sandpaper, from skin staples to Scotch tape. ''3M's business is not producing any one product,'' says Ty Govatos, who follows the company for Bache Halsey Stuart Shields. ''Its business is inventing new products. For years the whole structure of the company has been designed for that purpose.'' **********Lewis W. Lehr, 60 years old, 3M's chairman, recently completed a major revamping of the company's management and marketing approach in an effort to insure that 3M will continue to churn out new ideas during the next two decades. Mr. Lehr, and John M. Pitblado, 63, the president of 3M's United States operations, were in New York last week to explain the company's new look to the area sales staff. In an interview, they talked about some of the key issues affecting the future of 3M and other American manufacturers. **********Q. In your speech to the sales staff you referred to the breakdown of monolithic structures in our society in the 1980's and 1990's.  What does that mean for 3M? LEHR: ''If you look at the entrepreneurship of American industry it's wonderful. On the other hand, if you look at the paternalism and discipline of Japanese companies, it's wonderful too. There are certain companies that have evolved into a blend of those industries and 3M is one of them. The explanation of why this is happening is indicative of this monolithic breakdown. **********Companies like 3M have become sort of a community center for employees, as opposed to just a place to work. We have employee clubs, intramural sports, travel clubs and a choral group. This has happened because the community in which people live has become so mobile it is no longer an outlet for the individual. The schools are no longer a social center for the family. The churches have lost their drawing power as social-family centers. **********With the breakdown of these traditional structures, certain companies have filled the void. They have become sort of mother institutions, but have maintained their spirit of entrepreneurship at the same time. **********Q. American companies have been continually yielding ground to the Japanese. We have lost the lead in automobiles, steel and some hightechnology fields. What is behind this? LEHR: The Japanese have selected certain industries in which to become leaders and have done so. This country is not as disciplined as Japan. I think that's very good because if we were so disciplined we probably wouldn't be leaders in computers and the bio fields. But lack of discipline has created part of our problem. We have compounded that with a lack of incentives for research and the additional regulations and costs we have imposed on industry. This is what has created the problem. **********Q. Growth in productivity in the United States has declined steadily in the past decade, save for a few companies like 3M which continually managed to cut its per-unit manufacturing costs. How have you escaped this national malaise? PITBLADO: Productivity is not accomplished by getting a man to dig a hole faster. Productivity is accomplished by giving him a power shovel, and power shovels cost money. 3M has continued its capital investment in the areas of productivity improvement. But look at the steel and auto industries, where we see little productivity growth. I think the newest plant Chrysler had was 16 years old. That is where our productivity problem on a national scale is not being addressed. **********It takes new tools, new plants and new systems to make a man dig, instead of one shovelful, 10 yards of dirt with the same pull of the hand. **********Q. What do you see as 3M's biggest area for potential growth?  PITBLADO: We see a tremendous need worldwide for the increased production of food, nonpolluting herbicides and other ways of controlling the problems related to growing food and fiber without fertilizers. We think we can increase the amount of protein in sugar and grass. Who cares? Grass is the largest crop in the world and most of the world depends on it for animal food. It's a tremendous opportunity and a tremendous opportunity to do good. Thomas L. Friedman

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/21/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; LONG-TERM BOND PRICES FALL
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/21/busin.body_text: **********Long-term bond prices dropped sharply late yesterday and yields rose in thin trading that dealers said was typical of a nervous market. **********In advance of today's auction of $4.75 billion of new Treasury notes due in two years, dealers said the issue might have a 14 1/2 percent coupon but stressed that prices were very volatile. Late in the day, the outstanding 16 percent notes due in September 1983 were offered at 100 26/32 to yield 15.48 percent. **********Bond prices dropped sharply late in the day and were heavily influenced by trading in the futures markets, where bond contracts fell three-quarters of a point. Analysts stressed that many investors were on the sidelines and that the declines were caused by professional traders, many of them reacting automatically to technical sell signals. **********By late in the day, the actively traded 13 7/8 percent Treasury bond due in 2011 was offered at 94 14/32 to yield 14.60 percent, down from 95 7/8 a day earlier. High Financing Costs **********Many analysts said that weak investor demand might encourage dealers to cut prices so that yields were higher and more attractive by early November, when the Treasury is expected to sell $9 billion of notes and bonds. **********High financing costs also helped increase yields for short-term and long-term issues yesterday. The rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market was around 15 3/4 percent most of the day, despite the Fed's move to buy securities temporarily and provide reserves to the banking system for two days. The high funds rate dampened hopes for a drop in overnight financing costs, dealers said. **********The bias toward lower prices was enhanced when the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced plans to sell tomorrow $250 million each of five-year and 10-year bonds. **********Besides the additional supply of securities, some dealers said the World Bank move was bad news for the market because it was a sign that financial planners at the World Bank expected interest rates to move higher. The World Bank, whose financial expertise is highly respected, is not infallible, however. Last July, it deferred a similar financing even though yields were lower then. **********In the tax-exempt market, investors bought about half of a $100 million issue of triple-A-rated Illinois bonds at yields ranging from 8.75 percent for bonds due in 1982 to 10 1/2 percent for bonds due in 1991 and 12.4 percent for bonds due in 2005-06. Underwriters led by Continental Illinois said bonds due in 1997-2001 were not publicly reoffered. Problems at Washington Power **********While the Washington Public Power Supply System is trying to resolve problems in financing five nuclear power plants, prices of its outstanding bonds have suffered. Dealers said the secondary market for the $2.25 billion of outstanding Baa-1-rated bonds of Projects 4 and 5 was especially thin, and warned that prices would fall further if investors tried to sell more than a handful of bonds. The the 12 1/2 percent issue due in 2012 was bid at about 79 yesterday with a yield to maturity well in excess of 15 1/2 percent. **********The triple-A-rated power system bonds of Projects 1, 2 and 3, which have backing from the Bonneville power administrator, have also suffered and are trading with yields higher than the 14 percent return typical for other long-term double-A-rated electric revenue issues. Yesterday, the 15 percent Aaa-rated bonds due in 2017 were offered at 104 1/2 to yield 14.3 percent to maturity, down from 108 1/4 early Friday. **********At the other end of the maturity spectrum, the Municipal Assistance Corporation's new commercial paper issuing program included an agreement with Citibank providing M.A.C. with ''worst case'' financial insurance. The bank agreement was a necessary part of the commercial paper program, which M.A.C. can use to save interest expenses and give more flexibility in timing its long-term bond sales. **********Besides the tactical uses of short-term paper, M.A.C.'s executive director, Heather Ruth, explained that the Citibank facility provided insurance against the day when, for some reason, M.A.C. could not repay maturing commercial paper. Steep Price Acknowledged **********As she pointed out, that situation could conceivably arise from adverse rulings by the Internal Revenue Service or other events unrelated to the quality of M.A.C. securities. In that case, the bank's irrevocable letter of credit guarantees that M.A.C. could borrow from Citibank, repay the commercial paper holders, and then take more than five years to repay the bank. **********''The price is steep,'' Mrs. Ruth acknowledged, ''but it is not too much for the kind of absolute guarantee we are given.'' If M.A.C.  borrowed under a revolving credit agreement, it would be charged an interest rate equal to prime plus a half a percentage point, rising to prime plus a point for the first two years of the term loan and prime plus one and a half points for the next three years. **********For its efforts, Citibank is paid a 3/4-point facility fee, plus 3/4 point of an activity fee based on the amount of paper outstanding, plus a management fee of 1/8 point. **********In the corporate market, underwriters led by Salomon Brothers are offering a $100 million issue of 16 percent Province of Ontario notes due in 1991 at 99 to yield 16.205 percent and $150 million of 17 percent debentures due in 2011 at 99.535 to yield 17.08 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/world.main_headline: ASSAD ASSERTS SYRIA IS SEEKING 'PEACE WITH JUSTICE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/world.print_headline: ASSAD ASSERTS SYRIA IS SEEKING 'PEACE WITH JUSTICE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/17/world.body_text: **********President Hafaz al-Assad of Syria said today that his Government wanted peace based on justice in the Middle East and not on what he described as Israeli terms backed by the United States. **********In a 45-minute address before the new Parliament in Damascus, he said, according to the Syrian radio, that Israel was not interested in peace but wanted to continue to occupy Arab lands. He denounced the United States for its ''total support of Israel against the Arabs.'' **********The Syrian leader made no mention of Saudi Arabia's proposals for a settlement, which include a call for the creation of an independent Palestinian state in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and recognition of the right of all nations in the area to live in peace. This is being interpreted as alluding also to Israel. **********Arab diplomats said his silence on the Saudi proposals could be a positive sign. They noted that Libya, an ally of Syria, had been pressing Arabs to stand firm against the Saudi proposals, made last summer by Crown Prince Fahd, the operating head of the Government. Syria to Offer Own Ideas **********Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam has said that the Syrian Government will offer its own ideas about the Middle East at a conference of leaders of Arab League nations scheduled to convene in Fez, Morocco, on Nov. 25. **********Mr. Khaddam visited Riyadh yesterday to deliver a message from President Assad to King Khalid of Saudi Arabia. Arab diplomats said the letter pertained to consultations on the Saudi plan. The Saudis and five other Persian Gulf states have decided to bring the plan before the Fez meeting. **********President Assad, in attacking the United States, said it continued to support the Israeli-Egyptian accords that Syria and its allies had rejected. **********The United States, he went on, is trying to ''fill the Middle East with its fleets and troops in order to subjugate the Arabs to its will.'' This was an allusion to the maneuvers under way in Egypt, the Sudan, Oman and Somalia. **********Mr. Assad described as ''hell'' the conditions in Israeli-occupied Arab territory, and hailed the ''strong resistance'' displayed by the residents. **********''We stand by you until you return to us,'' the Syrian leader said.  He declared that Syria was striving to enhance its strength ''but strength is not military might alone.'' ''We are the ones who are striving for peace,'' he said, adding that ''it is a peace based on justice.'' He said such a peace must provide for the establishment of an independent Palestinian state on Palestinian soil.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.main_headline: Citicorp Sharply Cuts Power of Its Treasurer
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Citicorp Sharply Cuts Power of Its Treasurer
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/15/busin.body_text: **********Donald S. Howard, executive vice president, chief financial officer and treasurer of Citicorp, has been stripped of much of his power, a spokesman for the nation's largest bank holding company confirmed yesterday. Within the banking industry, Mr. Howard is known as one of the most innovative and aggressive treasurers. **********Rumors were circulating in banking circles that Mr. Howard, who has been with Citibank for 23 years, had been dismissed because of recent poor investment decisions. But Edward C. Palmer, chairman of the executive committee, said that Mr. Howard would retain responsibility for raising long- and medium-term funds for Citicorp, and for investor relations. **********''I can tell you categorically,'' Mr. Palmer said, that the changes had nothing to do with the recent drain on earnings caused by the bank's short-term investment policies. Late last year Citibank concluded that interest rates would decline, and it made heavy shortterm investments on that basis. Instead, rates rose, and the bank's earnings were hard hit. **********A bank spokesman confirmed, however, that the 52-year-old Mr.  Howard had been relieved of responsibility for Citicorp's foreign exchange operations and for its activities in the highly volatile sho rt-term money markets. He also no longer w ill be responsible for the private placement of debt obligations of other companies. Only earlier this year, Mr. Howard's responsibilit ies had been considerably expanded when he took over the m oney market activities of Citicorp's merchant banking group. **********Michael A. Callen, a 41-year-old senior vice president, has been called back from Saudi Arabia, where he had been managing director of the Saudi American Bank, a Citicorp affiliate, to take over the responsibilities that had been Mr. Howard's. **********In a call to his home last evening, Mr. Howard's wife said that he would not have time for comment.

Seagram & Sons Inc. and the Mobil Corporation. **********Although Seagram was defeated in its bid to obtain Conoco, it acquired a 20 percent share of Du Pont. It is unknown whether Seagram will gain seats on Du Pont's board. **********Under terms of the merger agreement, the energy concern will operate as a wholly owned subsidiary of Du Pont.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/06/world.main_headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: AT CUBA CLUB, PARTY'S OVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/06/world.print_headline: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: AT CUBA CLUB, PARTY'S OVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/06/world.body_text: **********The Rovers Athletic Club, a luxurious remnant of the British Empire, managed unobtrusively to survive the first 20 years after the Cuban Revolution but now seems about to die, the victim of its own allure. **********The club, established 70 years ago for Britons and other citizens of the empire living in Cuba, lies not far from the Havana airport and offers tennis courts, a swimming pool and Havana's only golf course. The British and Cuban flags fly side by side, and portraits of Queen Elizabeth II and President Fidel Castro hang in the clubhouse. **********On a warm, languid afternoon, the shrieking of children fills the pool area, and the Ambassador from Sierra Leone may be found sipping a drink in the bar before a tennis game. All members of the foreign diplomatic community may join the club. Membership for others is handled pretty much the way it is at country clubs anywhere. **********After the revolution, Cubans were eligible for membership.  President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile liked to play golf there when he visited Cuba and Mr. Castro was even made honorary president. **********Otherwise, the golf tournaments and the dances continued, surviving along with other anachronisms such as the extremely popular and festive 15th-year birthday parties for girls -the equivalent of a debut - and the Cubans' disconcerting insistence that women wear long gowns to formal parties and receptions. Many Members Leave Country **********Then, in April 1980, the Peruvian Embassy crisis brought a huge exodus by boat from the port of Mariel and the beginning of the end for the Rovers Athletic Club. Among those who left were many of its Cuban members. **********''They weren't very revolutionary people,'' a Canadian officer of the club conceded regretfully. ''They liked our way of life.'' The Cuban authorities placed the club in trusteeship in July, explaining that it had failed to comply with some legal technicalities in its registration and, worse, had been infiltrated by ''antisocial elements.'' The Cuban membership of the club dropped from 200 to about 20, and the club's treasury of more than $100,000 was confiscated. **********The 80 foreign members, who lost all their legal appeals, have been told they can continue to use the facilities and that these will be even better than before. In the meantime, members of the Cuban secret police keep an eye on the place. **********One showed up at a Havana hotel where a visitor had arranged to meet one of the remaining Cuban club members, who has a visa to leave for Venezuela but has not been able to get an exit permit from the Cuban Government. **********When he saw the policeman, who is also his neighbor, the Cuban was so terrified he was barely able to speak.  ''It was an island of freedom,'' he managed to say of the club. **********Another society is being built at the Grandes Alamedas infant center in Havana, where 229 children aged from 45 days to six years can spend from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M. if their mothers are working. **********The children are fed, given medical attention and even provided with the clothing or diapers they wear. A child's development, from its first efforts to sit up to its expression of patriotic sentiments, is closely monitored. **********Cristina Ribalta, a psychologist with the Ministry of Education, who is at the center studying the links between the emotional and intellectual development of children, said attempts are being made to motivate children better, to help them understand early in life that efforts bring rewards. **********''If children do a task and get a result,'' she said, ''they can see the fruit of their labors.'' There is not a great deal of individual attention - the school has just seven teachers - but this did not seem to bother the toddlers and pre-schoolers playing happily and relatively peacefully with each other in the sun-drenched play yard. **********The infants, on the other hand, looked apathetic and lay quietly in their rows of plain wooden cribs without toys, staring into the air. **********There are still many people in Cuba who want to leave. They range from the genteel Rovers Club member to the former mental patient who, armed with two grenades, hijacked a bus in the province of Matanzas the other day and demanded to be taken to Varadero to catch a boat, an episode that ended with one death and 13 injuries when the hijacker threw the grenades. **********With an American visitor, older Cubans will talk about their desire for freedom, but the younger ones speak of their yearning for money and for jobs. **********Salaries in Cuba are low, ranging from the equivalent of $96 a month for a janitor or street sweeper to $384 a month for a psychiatrist or other medical specialist A taxi driver earns $151 a month; a high school teacher earns $177. **********Medical care is free, as are schools, and rents are low, 10 percent of one's salary. Appliances are expensive: $833 for a television set, $1,538 for a standard refrigerator or an air conditioner, $6,4l0 for a Soviet car. Air conditioners and cars are available only to party officials and to special workers. **********But the big problem seems to be food, which is still rationed. For one month, one person may buy only 12 ounces of meat, two pounds of chicken, five pounds of rice, 10 ounces of beans, 10 ounces of peas and one four-ounce can of tomato concentrate. Milk can be bought for children under the age of 12. The monthly allotment of coffee for adults is four ounces. **********Oil, salt, bread, sugar and cigarettes are also rationed. Dinner Guests Eat Hungrily **********In an effort to provide more food, the Cuban Government has encouraged farmers' markets, where peasants may sell food at freemarket prices, but these prices are high, and although the markets seem to have helped, there are still many people who are hungry. **********It is not the shocking hunger that assaults a visitor to a country such as Haiti. It is far less severe, but it is also difficult for visitors to ignore. **********A Western diplomat who had invited a group of Cuban intellectuals to his home for a buffet dinner realized to his dismay that he was going to run out of food because his guests were taking five and six helpings. The men in the group were so hungry they did not volunteer to bring plates for their wives or even to wait for them before starting to eat. **********And on an outing to Santa Maria beach one recent Sunday it was clear that very few of the hundreds of Cubans enjoying the water had brought picnic lunches or were able to buy anything to eat. When foreign visitors brought out a cooler filled with beer and rather uncomfortably started eating the hot dogs they had brought along, Cubans, by themselves or in groups, came and stood from four to five feet away and stared. **********Finally, a tough-looking man strode up and demanded food, saying rather belligerently, ''I'm hungry.'' When the visitors offered him two hot dogs, he proudly refused, indicating that he would make do with one.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/02/busin.body_text: **********The 47 producer members of the 72-nation International Coffee Organization plan to meet in London tomorrow to negotiate their shares in a world market undermined by tumbling prices and demand. **********In the United States, the world's largest importer of coffee, international experts have estimated that consumption has fallen to about 18 million bags of green coffee in the crop year 1980-8l from a high of 24 million bags in 1962. A bag holds 132.2 pounds of unroasted coffee beans. **********Coffee prices were about 32 cents a pound in 1962. In real terms, prices have slumped to a 1962-equivalent of 30 cents a pound.  According to the International Coffee Organization, the daily average price of all coffees was 96.79 cents a pound yesterday, compared with $1.50 a pound two years ago, and the 20-day running average stood at $1.07 a pound. The 20-day average has not risen above $1.25 this year. **********Against that economic background, the coffee organization's annual council session is scheduled to open next Monday, when producers and consumers will negotiate the export quote for the 1981-82 crop year and the shares that the producers will be entitled to export. **********But before the talks begin, the producers decided that they would meet tomorrow to discuss possible quotas.  Last year, the overall 1980-81 export quota was set at 57.7 million bags. But because prices continued to fall, the coffee group cut this total four times during the crop year, reducing the overall export quota to 51.1 million bags. Experts, however, said exports were actually much lower and when figures are finally published it could turn out that only about 48 million bags found their way to world markets. **********Traders here said that prices have been falling because no roaster will pay the high interest rates on the financing needed to warehouse coffee. Now is the season when stockpiling for the coming year usually begins, but there has been little or no buying. **********The traders also said that there is plenty of coffee worldwide.  United States Department of Agriculture estimates put the current crop at 96 million bags. **********Taking into account that about 12 million to l5 million bags could be consumed in producing countries, some 26 million bags of the current crop will remain unsold, if 55 million are exported. If less is exported, the total of unsold bags will be higher.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/12/busin.print_headline: COMMODITY HOUSE IN BRITAIN PRESSING FOR SUGAR TAKEOVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/12/busin.body_text: **********It was not too long ago that S.& W. Berisford Ltd. was a sleepy company making a nice profit importing food and handling the distribution of sugar in Britain. Then, under new management with new ideas, the company threw itself into the highstakes business of commodity trading. **********The result was a spectacular period of growth. In the last 10 years, earnings before taxes increased from just $6 million to $79 million last year, while revenues shot up from $334 million to almost $5.4 billion. In 1980, almost 70 percent of the company's profits came from commodity trading and distribution, with the rest spread mostly across food processing and scrap metal recovery. **********But now S.& W. Berisford is once again seeking to return to a more stable business. Last month, the company offered the equivalent of about $340 million for the 91 percent of the British Sugar Corporation that it does not already own. **********''Since we have been selling sugar in the United Kingdom for 100 years, we know a fair bit about the business,'' Gordon Percival, a director of the London-based Berisford, said in an interview.  ''British Sugar fits like a glove.'' **********That, however, is not the opinion of the board of directors of British Sugar, which refines more than half the sugar sold in Britain each year. The board rejected the bid unanimously and has begun a campaign to convince shareholders to do the same. Bid Called 'Derisory' **********At this point, British Sugar's main defense is the low price of the offer, which values each British sugar share at $6.23. John Beckett, chief executive of British Sugar, called the bid ''deriso@ry.'' British Sugar has put the asset value of its shares at almost $11 each. ''We are fighting off the bid and want to remain as we are,'' a spokesman for British Sugar said. **********British Sugar, which refines all the sugar beet production in Britain (adding up to almost one-half the sugar consumed), is subject to the European Economic Community's agricultural policy fixing the amount of sugar beets refined in Britain. Under a new quota and price agreement that takes effect in July, analysts estimate that British Sugar could make nearly $100 million this year in pretax profits, compared with $75 million in the last financial year. **********Berisford, according to financial analysts, will do well to equal last year's earnings performance of $79 million pretax. ''The company has hit a bit of a plateau, which is a reflection of dull commoditytrading conditions,'' one analyst said. ''Berisford hopes that British Sugar's earnings will be more stable.'' **********The hunt for acquisitions began about three years ago, according to John Elston, a food analyst at the London firm of James Capel & Company. ''The idea was that one-half of the company profits would come from commodity trading, and the other half would come from tangible assets,'' he said. **********Although the past decade of wildly fluctating commodity prices has given traders ample opportunity to make profits, the risk, increasingly complicated by the politics of the producing nations, is considerable. ''In our acquisitions we are not anxious to take on the same political risks as we do in our other businesses,'' Mr.  Percival said. **********For its part, Berisford has proved to be a patient suitor. Last May, the company made its first offer for British Sugar. The Government, disturbed by Berisford's role as distributor for Tate & Lyle, Britain's only other sugar manufacturer, referred the offer to the Mergers and Monopolies Commission. **********After nine months, the commission concluded at the beginning of last month that it would not block the bid if two conditions were met. First, Berisford must sever its link with Tate & Lyle. Second, and more ambiguously, Berisford must maintain British Sugar as a separate entitity. Government Stake Is Issue **********Berisford has no problems with these conditions. ''The statement may read as if it is the commission's thought, but we had freely offered those conditions ourselves,'' Mr. Percival said. **********The transaction is further complicated by the Government's ownership of almost 25 percent of British Sugar's shares. Although the Government has announced its intention of selling its shares as part of a larger policy of returning Government investments back to the private sector, it cannot very well sell its shares at what is being seen as a discount.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/04/busin.body_text: **********The stock market finished moderately higher yesterday with some of the energy, technology and gold issues posting the biggest gains.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up by only about 2 points at 3:30 P.M., closed ahead 9.13 points, to 941.38. Analysts said that bargain hunters and short-covering were responsible for much of the late rally. **********Yesterday was only the third time in the last 11 trading sessions since President Reagan took office on Jan. 20 that the Dow finished higher. On Monday, the blue chip barometer tumbled 15.02 points because of investors' concern over tax and spending cuts promised by the new Administration. **********In the overall market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declining stocks by 914 to 606. In midafternoon, losers were ahead of winners by a small margin. **********Turnover on the Big Board continued moderate, with 46 million shares changing hands, as many institutional investors remained on the sidelines awaiting the announcement of President Reagan's economic plans tomorrow night. On Monday, 44.1 million shares were traded. Inflation Fears Cited **********Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst of MKI Securities Inc., commented that the strongest issues yesterday, mainly the energy, technolgy and gold stocks, generally do well in an inflationary environment. **********Mr. Jensen noted that the upswing in these issues, which recently had been depressed, ''may reflect some second thoughts by investors regarding the probability of President Reagan being successful in combating inflation.'' **********In the energy group, Phillips Petroleum gained 2 1/8, to 50 7/8; Getty 2, to 80; Standard of Ohio 2, to 60 3/8; Standard of California 1 5/8, to 89 5/8; Mobil 1 1/2, to 71 3/4, and Exxon 1, to 75 3/8. **********The oil service issues also did well, with Halliburton up 3 5/8, to 74, while Schlumberger added 1 3/8, to 104 1/8 and Dresser Industries rose 1 1/2, to 45 1/4. **********Among the gainers in the technology category, Texas Instruments climbed 3 3/8, to 111 3/8; Teledyne 1 3/4, to 187 1/4; Honeywell 1 1/4, to 98 3/4, and Computervision 1 3/4, to 65 3/4. **********The gold mining issues ended higher as bullion prices declined abroad while rising in United States markets. Among the stronger gold issues, Homestake Mining added 2 3/8, to 53 1/4; Dome Mining was up 1 3/4, to 77 3/4; ASA Ltd. 1 3/4, to 53, and Campbell Red Lake 1 1/2, to 49 1/2. Big Loss for Cannon Mills **********The big loser on the exchange was Cannon Mills, which lost 7 1/2, to 25 3/4, in active trading. The textile company on Monday ended negotiations with a group of investors who had wanted to make a $40-a-share tender offer, amounting to $376 million, to buy the company. The termination of the talks came as a suprise since Cannon's previous reaction had been favorable. **********Golden Nugget, a recent entry to the gaming market in Atlantic City, rose 2 1/8, to 26 1/2. On Monday, the company said it planned to build a second casino in Las Vegas and added that its new casino in Atlantic City had done well in January. **********Some of the blue chips also made impressive gains. Aluminum Company of America rose 1 1/2, to 64 1/4; American Brands 1 1/4, to 73; Minnesota Mining 1 1/8, to 58 3/4, and United Technologies 1 1/4, to 55 1/4. **********Prices on the American Stock Exchange advanced, with the market value index up 1.84, to 335.87. Mitchell Energy tacked on 2 1/2, to 48 3/4, after directors voted a 4-for-3 stock split and raised the quarterly dividend.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/12/busin.main_headline: A Reader Writes; ON BOYS AND BASEBALL CARDS, AND BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/12/busin.print_headline: A Reader Writes; ON BOYS AND BASEBALL CARDS, AND BUSINESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/12/busin.body_text: **********M Y eight-year-old son began collecting baseball cards this season, and it is none too soon. The activity not only provides him with a link to the sport during the players' strike, but is an initiation into the world of American business. For the lessons a boy learns from managing a shoebox full of baseball cards are as hard and sobering as any gotten over the bargaining table in a complex labor dispute. **********Baseball card collecting is still a very sexist thing. There are no women on the cards, and the hobby is practiced almost exclusively among a network of good young boys, who will grow up to join the good-old-boy network. After their team and position, the hirsute heroes on the cards are described by the vital statistics of height and weight - 6 feet 3 inches, 190 pounds - which all the boys want to attain. There are no models here for young girls. **********What baseball card collecting does teach its participants are all the elements of successful business practice. While it is of course not the only introduction to the realities of the business world, it is a traditional one for boys. To collect and trade cards requires a youngster to become comfortable, or at least proficient, in buying, selling, trading, risking and generally managing his most important and valuable possessions. There must be an awareness of worth and a deliberateness of purpose in trying to decide whether to specialize in getting the entire home team or diversifying by filling out an all-star team of interleague dimensions. **********Assembling the capital of a baseball card collection is as instructive as any other stage of the activity. The boy must make what are usually among his first regular purchases that cannot be wholly eaten or drunk. Although the wrapper may be ripped and discarded like that of a candy bar, the baseball cards and not the token bubble gum are the treasure inside. Buying a package of cards is as important to the young boy as purchasing a stock is to his father. But the element of mystery, the joy of the blind gamble of the purchase, is unique to baseball card collectors and venture capitalists. Unwrapping the package is a holiday, and scanning the contents is an adventure. **********On the backs of his baseball cards a boy's fascination with numbers begins, preparing him for the Dow Jones industrial average, the Consumer Price Index and Moody's credit ratings. Besides the heights and weights and birthdates, there are the columns of performance figures that contain as much mathematics and as many subtleties of interpretation as an adult will encounter in reading the market reports. **********The young card collector soon learns to scan a new card for his touchstone statistics as naturally as the commuter scans the newspaper to follow his investments. The boy with a baseball card collection knows averages, records and statistics the way a market analyst knows prices, dividends and betas. **********The seemingly idle hours spent reading the fine print behind the picture of a baseball player are rewarded in eye muscles attuned to the format of the business pages, if not in mental skills favorably inclined to mathematical achievement tests. **********A boy's trading cards also give him the chronology of a baseball player's record through obscure minor league teams to success in the majors. The repeated reminder that success and celebrity come of humble beginnings is precisely the lesson one needs later to put his foot firmly on the bottom rung of the corporate ladder and climb with deliberation. **********Perhaps the greatest lessons of baseball cards are learned on the trading floors of boys' bedrooms. Here hard decisions and value judgments must be made by children alone in a world of cardboard adults. The worth of a card wanted must be weighed against that of a card or cards willing to be traded. Order must be maintained among piles of cards numbering in the hundreds to the thousands, none of whose provenance or ownership is documented or documentable beyond the agreements of little gentlemen. **********My son is now investing virtually all of his modest allowance in baseball cards, and he is bullish on new issues. His present portfolio consists of about 100 Fleer, 100 Don Russ, 200 Topps common and an odd lot of autographed Topps preferred. He holds his own trading with the older boys, and soon I expect him to be willing to trade more than just the Yankees for a share of Telephone. **********Not all traders are gentlemen, of course, and stories are told among the eight- and nine-year-olds of 11- and 12-year-olds to be watched. And the younger traders learn quickly that it is against their interests to give in to unreasonable demands for a card they want, no matter how badly. Even a Fernando Valenzuela is not worth the whole Yankee team.   ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Henry Petroski is an associate professor of civil engineering at Duke University and regrets that he no longer has his own baseball cards.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/03/busin.body_text: **********TO hear executives talk, the ''cutting edge'' of technology in most industries must be very crowded. One reason so many companies can claim this position may be that their audiences are generally too polite to laugh. Another explanation could be that the executives doing the talking do not know any better. **********''The average upper-level corporate executive is deluged with information on finance, sales and production performance, but receives virtually no objective information on the firm's technological health,'' said Richard S. Campbell, a researcher at the Battelle Institute's Pacific Northwest Laboratories in Richland, Wash., who has been studying technology indicators with the aid of a National Science Foundation grant. **********That technology information gap contributes to the widely noted bias of many businesses toward maximizing short-term performance, he added. Referring to the ''tug-of-war for managerial attention and resources,'' he said, ''The tabulators with numbers almost always triumph over the technologists.'' **********Help may lie in the United States Patent Office. Results of the early phases of the Battelle study of patent data as a technology indicator have been intriguing. While many companies routinely track the patent activity of their competitors, the Battelle study suggests that more systematic research into particular technologies, or ''problem domains,'' can reveal rich profiles. **********In some cases, technological shifts show up in patents well in advance of their appearance in other indicators, such as the volume of papers published in technical journals. The data in patents can also be used to determine whether a technology is growing, maturing or dying, the rate of change, and the relative patent position of various competitors, according to Mr. Campbell. **********The first technology examined by Battelle was that used in the catalytic converter, the pollution control device widely used on automobiles. Simply looking at the number of patents filed each year indicated that converters might become an important technology 15 years before a large number of technical articles on the subject began to appear. **********Battelle went on to identify 10 technological indicators that might be derived from patents. For example, the number of patents in a given period, the number of new firms receiving patents in the area, the number of active firms and the number of dropouts might all be combined to measure how active a technology has been in that period. **********If many new firms are entering an area, one might conclude that there is a widespread belief that the technology addresses a significant need in an economical manner. Conversely, if many firms have apparently ceased efforts to patent in an area, it could mean that the technology has been superseded or that one company has a position so strong that it can dominate competitors. **********Another indicator - Battelle calls it ''immediacy'' - draws on the requirement that patent applicants cite related articles and inventions. If the ''closest prior art,'' as such citations are known, is very recent, one might conclude that the technology is growing rapidly. **********To examine ''dominance,'' Batelle looks at the pattern of closest prior art citations among firms. A great deal of self-citation may indicate that a firm believes that it has a key patent or simply that it follows a defensive patenting policy. If a company frequently cites another's patents, it may indicate a technological dependency or offensive patenting. **********There is plenty of skepticism about the value of such extensive patent analysis. ''There are a lot of companies who have decided that patent activity is more a function of the number of lawyers you have than of innovativeness,'' said John M. Ketteringham, a health care industry and corporate strategy specialist at the consulting firm of Arthur D. Little in Cambridge, Mass. **********Mr. Campbell's response is that in-depth analysis reveals whether the lawyers are building up the company's position in a key, fastdeveloping area or wasting its resources by piling up patents in an area that everyone else has abandoned. However, he conceded that the concept of patent analysis may not be equally helpful in every industry. **********The semiconductor industry, for instance, is famous for freely trading product patents and sometimes not even bothering to seek patents. The rapid pace of new-product introductions limits the value of the 17-year patent protection period and large semiconductor consumers are sometimes reluctant to commit themselves to a new design unless more than one company is offering it. However, Mr.  Campbell said, one could still learn something about technological strength in the industry by focusing on patents for manufacturing processes, rather than for the products themselves. **********Mr. Ketteringham, who has been working on ways to apply Arthur D.  Little's general strategic planning theories to technology investment strategies, expressed reservations about the usefulness of patent analysis but said that he agreed wholeheartedly with Mr.  Campbell's observations about the need for objective information.  ''We have had numerous big companies come to us in the past year expressing just that need,'' he said. ''They know they are involved with risk but they don't know how to characterize or express it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/18/world.print_headline: MEXICAN FAVORS CUBA'S PRESENCE AT TALKS REAGAN PLANS TO ATTEND
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/18/world.body_text: **********The decision not to invite Cuba to the North-South conference scheduled to be held in Cancun, Mexico, in October was made in spite of the recommendation of Mexico at a conference in Vienna last fall, the Mexican Ambassador here said today. **********Announcements made in Washington during the visit last week of President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico and by Senator Charles H.  Percy, Republican of Illinois, during a visit to Mexico, indicated that President Reagan had accepted an invitation to attend the conference after President Lopez Portillo assured him he would not invite President Fidel Castro of Cuba. **********Actually, according to Gonzalo Martinez Corbala, the Mexican Ambassador in Havana, the list of countries to be invited was drawn up in November by a group of 11 countries, in which Mexico had only one vote and in which the United States was not included. **********At that time, the Mexican Government recommended that Cuba be asked to attend and when this suggestion was not accepted it was explained that other countries had thought the presence of Cuba would discourage the United States from attending. Soviet Declines to Attend **********Originally, 23 countries were on the invitation list, but the Soviet Union said it would not attend.  ''Cuba still wants to attend,'' Ambassador Martinez said in an interview today, ''and Mexico considers these aspirations just, as it considers that it would be beneficial for the President of the United States to attend.'' **********''It would be a good chance for Reagan to meet Castro,'' he added, ''a chance for them to begin to talk about their bilateral problems, problems that we all - especially Mexico - wish could find a peaceful solution.'' **********The 11 countries that drew up the guest list at a meeting in Vienna last Nov. 7 and 8 were Algeria, Austria, Canada, France, India, Nigeria, Sweden, Tanzania, Yugoslavia, West Germany, and Mexico. **********In addition to these countries, invitations to attend the conference have also been sent to Saudi Arabia, Bangladesh, Brazil, Ivory Coast, China, the Philippines, Guyana, Japan, Britain, the United States and Venezuela. **********Up to now, Ambassador Martinez said, there has been no indication that the list of countries invited will be expanded, although a number of other nations have said they would like to attend.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/28/busin.main_headline: U.S. FILES FOR DELAY OF COURT CASES ABOUT IRAN PENDING REAGAN STUDY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/28/busin.print_headline: U.S. FILES FOR DELAY OF COURT CASES ABOUT IRAN PENDING REAGAN STUDY
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/28/busin.body_text: **********The Justice Department today began filing papers in at least 388 court cases asking judges to delay proceedings over Iranian assets and private claims against Iran for 30 days to allow the Reagan Administration time to complete its review of President Carter's hostage agreement, a spokesman said today. **********The Justice Department announcement today followed a Treasury Department statement late yesterday that legal review of regulations implementing President Carter's agreement to transfer the remaining $3 billion to $4 billion in frozen Iranian assets out of the country ''will take some time.'' **********Regulations had been drafted and were expected to be issued last week. But they were held up after a committee of lawyers who represent more than 100 nonbank companies with claims against Iran asked President Reagan and other top officials to delay implementation of the agreement until they have had a chance to discuss legal and constitutional question with Administration officials. **********Officials have said that the Administration intends to honor the complex agreements with Iran insofar as they are legal, but that the legality of some provisions is in question. Some Violations Suggested **********''There may be some portions of the agreement or extensions of it that would be in violation of United States or international law or that would unfairly cut out the rights of someone,'' the White House counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, said last night on public television's ''MacNeil-Lehrer Report.'' **********Separately, a State Department spokesman warned Americans against traveling to Iran, saying that though such travel had become legal with the release of the hostages, it was still ''extremely hazardous'' because of anti-Americanism in Iran and the war between Iran and Iraq. **********Several companies and individuals with claims against Iran have gone to Federal courts in Washington, Boston, Dallas and San Francisco seeking to block the Government from removing Iranian assets that are tied up by court orders from the country as President Carter agreed to do. Lawyers for many other companies have said they are waiting to see what steps the Reagan Administration takes under the agreements before they decide whether to attack them in court. **********A series of executive orders signed by President Carter before he left office, and before the hostages were released, appeared to require banks and others holding Iranian assets in the United States to transfer them immediately - some to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, some to Iran itself. Meeting With Lawyers **********But Reagan Administration officials have announced that those holding Iranian assets can keep them where they are, pending further notice. In the meantime, State Department officials are planning to meet with lawyers representing nonbank claimants to discuss some of the ''serious constitutional and other legal questions'' that the committee of lawyers representing about 100 of these claimants in New York cases raised in a letter and telex message to President Reagan and other top officials last week. **********President Carter promised to transfer the $3 billion to $4 billion worth of Iranian assets that remain in the United States to Iran, most of them within seven months, except for $1 billion that would be put in a special Algerian-controlled security fund to cover arbitration awards against Iran.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/08/29/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON A DIAGNOSTIC instrument using ordinary light for breast examination to detect cancer or other abnormalities will be patented next week by a French engineer and manufacturer of medical equipment. The instrument, called Diagnoscope, is to be marketed in this country. **********Patent 4,286,602 will be granted Robert Guy of Lyons, France, for what is called a transillumination diagnostic system. The Food and Drug Administration has approved the instrument embodying it. **********The pistol-shaped device has a trigger switch to turn on a light beam. It also contains a camera whose shutter can be operated by hand or foot. A physician can directly see and record any abnormality without exposing the patient to radiation, which many women are reluctant to undergo. **********An earlier form called the Diaphanoscope, manufactured by the company of which Mr. Guy is president, is used clinically abroad but not in the United States. Arrangements for American production of the Diagnoscope are being made by Robert Deslauriers of New York. ---------------------------------------------------------------------  To get a copy of a patent, send the number and 50 cents to the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C., 20231.
