Burnett, which earlier this week acquired the $75 million dollar McDonald's account, has been the agency for Steak & Ale since 1977, the year it lost Kentucky Fried Chicken. **********Steak & Ale, a chain of limited-menu dinner houses with headquarters in Dallas, is a subsidiary of the Pillsbury Company, which, by the way, has been a client of Burnett since 1944.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/24/busin.body_text: **********United Grain Growers, a farmerowned grain company, forecast today that prairie farmers in Canada's western provinces will produce a bumper 1981 crop of 41.8 million tons of grain, significantly above the 34.1 million tons in 1980. **********The cooperative credited timely rains and ideal growing temperatures for the excellent crop prospects. Output of red spring wheat on the prairies was expected to total 748 million bushels, up 25 percent from last year. Durum wheat production was forecast at 97 million bushels, a 38 percent increase.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/world.main_headline: Major Battle Reported In the Western Sahara
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/world.print_headline: Major Battle Reported In the Western Sahara
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/10/17/world.body_text: **********Fierce fighting was going on today between guerrillas and Moroccan forces in the Western Sahara some 650 miles southeast of Rabat, according to reports reaching here. **********Moroccan military sources said it was one of the biggest battles in the conflict for control of the former Spanish colony. **********The Algerianbacked Polisario Front has been fighting since 1976 for the independence of the territory. **********Western diplomats said some 2,000 guerrillas, backed by armored vehicles and antiaircraft missiles, were battling a Moroccan motorized infantry regiment as well as local garrison troops. **********Moroccan officials said the guerrillas launched a major assault Tuesday on Guelta Zemmur, an area outside the 290-mile Moroccan defense perimeter that protects the main towns and phosphate mines in the territory. **********On the first day of the battle the guerrillas shot down a Moroccan C-130 troop transport plane and a Mirage F-1 fighter-bomber with Soviet-made surface-to-air missiles, King Hassan II said in a message to world leaders. **********Neither side has issued details on casualties. Reports from Algiers said the Polisario guerrillas reported capturing the area, which is in difficult mountainous terrain. **********The Western Sahara was ceded to Morocco and Mauritania by Spain in 1976. Mauritania withdrew after an accord with the guerrillas in 1979. Morocco claims sovereignty over the territory.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/08/busin.main_headline: Economic Affairs; THE ELEGANCE OF DOING NOTHING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/08/busin.print_headline: Economic Affairs; THE ELEGANCE OF DOING NOTHING
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/11/08/busin.body_text: **********W HEN confronted with a complex public policy problem, it has always been difficult to sell what is often the most elegant and sophisticated policy option. That is, to do absolutely nothing. **********Even when doing nothing has considerable intellectual appeal, politicians seem unable to make a positive case for it. No one wants to be a member of a do-nothing Congress or Administration. Generally, we have to do nothing very quietly. **********I certainly do not wish to claim that doing nothing is the solution to all of our problems. I would only argue that it is always an option and that it always deserves careful consideration. **********The appeal of doing nothing stems from a few simple rules.  First, free markets and the natural dymanics of the business cycle often solve problems long before the bureaucracy can limber itself up to devise a solution. Thus, it is always important to consider the possibility that the solution may be enacted after the problem has vanished. Then, the possibility arises that the solution will do more harm than good. **********Second, solutions must generally be enacted by politicians who have very short-time horizons. Consequently, short-run solutions become appealing even for long-run problems. They are seldom appropriate. A corollary stems from the fact that the politician's time horizon shrinks as an election approaches, and the probability of doing the wrong thing varies inversely with the distance from the next election. **********Third, powerful special-interest groups often stand to gain or lose significant amounts of income as a result of any solution to a problem. Therefore, they work hard to play a role in designing the relevant policy. The end result may be a solution that is not in the best interest of the ordinary voter. Because different interest groups favor different solutions, the chosen policy often represents a compromise. That leads to Rule No. 4, compromises often turn out to be worse than any of the extreme positions, perhaps because they are inherently very complicated. **********Does doing nothing have any appeal when confronted by our current problems of recession, high interest rates and soaring budget deficits? One problem with the do-nothing approach is that it is not easy to define given our complex policy-making processes. **********In one sense the Congress has been doing plenty of nothing recently. The appropriations bills, which in theory should have been enacted for fiscal year 1982 before Labor Day, are still far from completed. The second budget resolution which is supposed to be in place by Sept. 15 is unlikely to be completed before Thanksgiving. **********All that is not what I mean by doing nothing. It is instead the result of a paralysis caused by an overabundance of policy options being placed on the table. If we are to do nothing, it is preferable to do it aggressively and not by default. **********What does that mean in the present context? To me it implies sticking with the 1982 policies inherent in the first budget resolution. It also implies readily admitting that given the recession, the deficit implied by those policies may be more than twice as large as the $37.7 billion originally estimated. The Administration and the Congress must stop gradually dribbling out higher and higher deficit estimates like Chinese water torture. **********Of course, a major long-run deficit problem remains. The tax cut was far too large even if the Administration were to obtain all of its proposed specified and unspecified spending cuts, and they will not. Taxes will have to be increased eventually. But because of my corollary to Rule 2, the period just preceding an election is a terrible time to debate tax policy. **********I DO not mind violating the do-nothing rule by making further cuts on the spending side. But the sort of cuts now being contemplated, even in the President's September budget proposal, are trivial relative to future deficits. Long-run spending control is essentially impossible without Social Security control and sensible reforms of that program are not possible in an election year. **********The time for major spending and tax changes is in that brief period of rationality following elections. A new economic strategy should be designed in the Administration and Congressional budgets that will be offered in early 1983. By that time, the recession should be behind us and we shall have a much clearer picture of the sort of tax increases and spending reform required for reduced deficits and healthy economic growth in the mid-1980's. **********In suggesting this nonaction course for 1982, I am relying heavily on Rule 1, that many of our current problems will cure themselves.  More specifically, I believe that because of the current recession, interest rates will continue to fall despite a large deficit. **********Falling interest rates and steady money growth will create a recovery by early 1982, before any new policies could possibly have any impact. If this is wrong and if we, like the British, are faced with continued high interest rates combined with a much more severe recession than anyone now contemplates, it may be necessary to rethink our policies before early 1983. **********But, even with such a dire situation, it may be that we, like Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, should decide to stick with the current policy course. Doing nothing to change things is particularly appealing when it is hard to think of anything better to do.   ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Rudolph G. Penner, Resident Scholar at the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research in Washington, was assistant director of economic policy in President Ford's Office of Management and Budget.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/busin.main_headline: U.S. TO SEEK BIDS FOR PHONE SERVICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; U.S. TO SEEK BIDS FOR PHONE SERVICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/10/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Government, in a shift away from its customary reliance on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said today that it would put up for competitive bidding a substantial part of its long-distance telephone service. **********In an action expected to trim Government operating costs, the General Services Administration, the agency that handles Federal housekeeping needs, said it would seek competitive bids to lease 8,000 long-distance circuits linking major cities in the continental United States - a package for which it now pays the Bell System about $50 million a year. **********Bell has been providing the service on a bulk-rate basis as part of Telpak, a form of service it plans to discontinue.  G.S.A. has previously put up for bid smaller packages of service, but not more than 200 or 300 circuits, officials said. The offering announced today amounts to about 75 percent of all Government leased phone service that can be handled on a competitive bid basis. **********About a dozen companies appear to be candidates for bidding on the contract. Among them are the American Satellite Corporation, the United States Transmission Systems division of I.T.T., MCI Telecommunications, Satellite Business Systems, RCA Americom and Western Union. **********Bell would not be precluded from competing for the contract.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/03/busin.body_text: **********A color calculator invented by Thomas E. Norton of Cambridge, Mass., is regarded as useful for photo laboratories, commercial art departments and printers. **********He has been awarded patent 4,241,520 for what is trademarked the Norton Auto-Chromic Wheel. **********The lightweight wheel, which is about 15 inches in diameter, has a cardboard base and three transparent color films that can be completely moved around. The primary colors they carry can be used to produce thousands of mixed colors. **********When the wheel is laid on a table, the user can manipulate the films with both hands to select desired color combinations. It is said that more than 64,000 are possible. The calculator is sold by Tom Norton Designs in Cambridge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/16/world.main_headline: KENYA ASKS AFRICANS FOR MORE AID TO NAMIBIA REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/16/world.print_headline: KENYA ASKS AFRICANS FOR MORE AID TO NAMIBIA REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/16/world.body_text: **********President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya issued a call today to African nations to step up their political, financial and military assistance to the guerrillas who are fighting to free South-West Africa from the control of South Africa. **********Addressing delegates at the formal opening of the foreign ministers' meeting of the Organization of African Unity, President Moi also urged African countries to step up efforts to insure the establishment of black majority rule in South Africa itself. **********Stating that the white minority regime ''still indulges in slavery,'' Mr. Moi accused ''some countries'' of being motivated by ''hypocrisy or greed'' in continuing their relations with South Africa. **********''Let me emphasize that Africa does not seek the wastage and bitterness of military conflict,'' he said, receiving resounding applause. ''But as the record has shown in my own and other countries, armed struggle with all its costs and sacrifices may be the only ultimate way of achieving independence.'' Effort to Bolster Kenya's Image **********The President's remarks were seen by Africans and Westerners here as an effort by Kenya to buttress its image with the left-wing governments of black Africa that form the overwhelming majority in the 50-nation organization. Kenya has generally been regarded as pro-Western and a moderate on the issue of South-West Africa, also known as Namibia. **********President Moi said that the ''sole and legitimate representative of the aspirations of Namibia's people in their struggle for selfdetermination'' would continue to be the South-West Africa People's Organization. **********While the Kenyan leader only implicitly criticized the United States, other speakers were far more direct and far more bitter in their attacks on the Reagan Administration. Foreign Minister Witness Mangwende of Zimbabwe said the recent visit by Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark to Namibia was intended ''to throw the cat among the pigeons.'' **********''The West must be told to its face that we have no intention of playing games in Namibia - too many lives have been sacrificed for too long,'' said Mr. Mangwende, the outgoing chairman of the African organization's council of ministers. ''Enough is enough. Namibia must be free.'' 'Cold War Politics' **********Further criticism of the West, particularly the United States, came from Henry Isaacs, the New York-based foreign affairs director of the Pan Africanist Congress, a South African nationalist movement. **********Accusing the Reagan Administration of offering ''overt support'' to South Africa in exchange for strategically important minerals, Mr.  Isaacs said, ''The danger in this introduction of cold war politics is that it will obfuscate the issues of liberation.'' **********An effort by Mozambique to put the question of Western Sahara on the formal agenda for a meeting of African heads of state next week was turned down tonight after a spirited discussion. **********Morocco, which is fighting the Polisario Front for control of the former Spanish colony, has vigorously opposed moves to admit the guerrilla group as a member of the African organization. **********Polisario officials accused Edam Kodjo of Togo, Secretary General of the African organization, of acting to deny membership to the guerrilla group. Mr. Kodjo denied the accusation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1981/12/29/busin.body_text: **********Domestic production, consumption and exports of coal will reach record levels in 1982, the coal industry's trade organization predicted today. **********The National Coal Association said coal production should set a record of 886 million tons, up from 805 million in 1981 and 824 million the year before. **********Domestic use next year is expected to reach 772 million short tons, compared with a revised estimate for 1981 of 738 million tons and 699 million tons in 1980. **********Exports should total 105 million tons, with 18 million going to Canada and 87 million to overseas customers. The trade association placed United States coal exports this year at a revised 95 million tons and 90 million in 1980. **********The average price of coal is less than one-third the price of oil and about half the price of natural gas burned at electric generating plants, according to Government data.
